headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Auburn, N.Y.; Cambridge, Md.; Seattle
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the world curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Harriet Tubman Centennial, New York and Maryland A woman leads a military expedition against a brutal regime, helping hundreds of people to escape. Sounds like the plot of a Quentin Tarantino film, but it is the story of Harriet Tubman, above, who died 100 years ago next week. New York State, where she settled, and Maryland, where she led many to freedom, are full of events in her honor, including a wreath-laying at her grave in Fort Hill Cemetery in Auburn, N.Y., on March 9, and a party that same day at the Harriet Tubman Museum in Cambridge, Md. (harriettubmanbyway.org)

headline: Vain Glorious | Terveer Perfume Oils
abstract: From the sisters behind the home fragrance brand Alora Ambianc comes a new collection of personal fragrance oils.
lead_paragraph: Sisters Annie and Therese Gibbons, creators of the blockbuster home fragrance brand Alora Ambiance, have channeled their past and present travels into a new collection of personal perfume oils named after their mother. “I fell in love with the ritual of applying oil to your skin, and fragrance oils are more concentrated and therefore last longer as well,” Annie says. Green, which contains notes of fig leaves and wet oakmoss, aims to capture their childhood memories of growing up on a southern Minnesota farm; Incense, a blend of peppery-sweet bergamot and burnt firewood, evokes the spicy-smoky aroma of the Romanesque cathedrals they would frequently pass while living in Lake Como, Italy; and Gardenia celebrates the exotic flora of Hawaii, where Annie resides. “I actually sent several gardenia flowers, tuberoses and pikake leis to our perfumers, and we ended up with an authentic gardenia scent that smells like my backyard,” she says. Thanks to the supersleek refillable perfume holder, you can securely stash the fragrance oil in your bag and always have it within reach, regardless of where life may take you.

headline: Detroit's Fiscal Woes
abstract: The governor of Michigan says a state-appointed manager could help the city avert disaster.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Michigan says a state-appointed manager could help the city avert disaster.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Wobble Solved!
abstract: For the first time, a Well reader with no medical training (or a doctor in the house) was the first to solve the “Think Like a Doctor” mystery.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 56-year-old man who suddenly became too dizzy to walk. More than 400 readers wrote in with their take on this patient’s problem. I was amazed by how many of you were on the right track. At least 30 readers figured it out – with the first right answer coming in just a half hour after the case was posted.

headline: God’s Word, the Greatly Abridged Version
abstract: The History channel mini-series “The Bible,” a 10-hour dramatization that begins on Sunday, puts the emphasis on moments of suffering rather than messages of joy.
lead_paragraph: Mark Burnett, an impresario of reality television, has surely encountered the question before: How do you make viewers believe what they’re seeing? Did those “Survivor” contestants really eat that stuff? Would any of these seemingly intelligent “Apprentice” candidates actually want to work for Donald Trump?

headline: Kerry Comes to Turkey With Rebuke of Its Leader Over Zionism Remark
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'International Relations', 'Zionism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan had made “objectionable” remarks when he cast Zionism as a crime against humanity in comments at a United Nations meeting.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Secretary of State John Kerry chastised Turkey’s prime minister on Friday for recently calling Zionism a “crime against humanity,” a comment that could frustrate Mr. Kerry’s desire to see an improvement in estranged Turkish-Israeli relations.

lead_paragraph: Jeff Z. Klein and Stu Hackel, who cover hockey for The Times, answer questions from readers.

lead_paragraph: In its ongoing campaign to win over opponents of hydraulic fracturing, the natural gas industry has succeeded in persuading the owner of a historic Pennsylvania farm to allow gas to be extracted from beneath her property.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Months after Hurricane Sandy devastated the region, a number of businesses in Brooklyn’s Red Hook neighborhood will finally open. Fairway Market, 480-500 Van Brunt Street, re-opens today, and there will be free food samples and raffle prizes. Red Hook Winery, 175-204 Van Dyke Street, and Red Hook Lobster Pound, 284 Van Brunt Street, will also be back in business.

headline: Photo Replay: March 1
abstract: The day in sports features highs and lows in the European indoor track and field championships, golfer Rory McIlroy hitting a new low, and top-ranked Novak Djokovic soaring to the finals in Dubai.
lead_paragraph: The day in sports features highs and lows in the European indoor track and field championships, golfer Rory McIlroy hitting a new low, and top-ranked Novak Djokovic soaring to the finals in Dubai.

headline: Already a Cinema Veteran at 19
abstract: Julia Garner, who has her first starring role in “Electrick Children,” discusses her journey.
lead_paragraph: “Here, touch it,” Julia Garner instructed, offering up her wild mane of springy blond curls. “It’s not a big deal. We’re girls.”

headline: Finding Fulfillment in a Smaller Spotlight
abstract: Jean Butler rose to fame in “Riverdance,” but in her 40s she is unassumedly reinventing herself as a choreographer and performer of contemporary dance.
lead_paragraph: Jean Butler, the choreographer and dancer, remembers the moment she taught herself how to jump higher. She was around 13 and had been, she said, “jumping for hours” with no success. And then she realized the trick.

headline: A Virtuoso, at Least in His Spare Time
abstract: The pianist Stephen Hough, who’s playing at Carnegie Hall on Monday, finds time for writing, painting, poetry and composing, and he says they all contribute to his performing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pianists can be bells-and-whistles showmen (Lang Lang, Liberace, Liszt) or soberly remote (Sviatoslav Richter, Rachmaninoff). But by tradition they are the mavericks of the music world, who spend long hours in small rooms poring over solo repertory that turns them into either thinkers or eccentrics. Maybe both. And an example of the thinking pianist (make up your own mind about the eccentricity) is Stephen Hough, whose thoughts take center stage Monday evening in a recital at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Sacrifice at the Altar of Intolerance
abstract: Cristian Mungiu’s new film, “Beyond the Hills,” based on an actual incident in Romania, dissects authoritarianism and intolerance.
lead_paragraph: Two girls grow up together, friends and allies, in a decrepit Dickensian orphanage. When they turn 18 and have to leave, one goes abroad in search of work, while the other, after drifting for a while and out of other options, enters a monastery led by a charismatic monk and becomes a nun. After a few years the émigré returns to visit her friend and finds her changed, a bit distant.

headline: Automakers Work to Achieve Zero-Waste Goals
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Ford announced that it would increase its environmental strategy with a five-year plan to cut the waste it sent to landfills globally by 40 percent per vehicle.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Ford announced that it would increase its environmental strategy with a five-year plan to cut the waste it sent to landfills globally by 40 percent per vehicle from 2011 levels. In 2016, the company said, Ford would be producing just 13.4 pounds of waste a vehicle at its operations around the world, down from 38 pounds in 2007, 22.7 pounds in 2011 and 20.3 pounds this year.

headline: Obama Jokes of ‘Jedi Mind Meld’
abstract: Speaking to reporters after meeting with Congressional leaders, President Obama playfully talks about negotiating with Republicans on the automatic spending cuts.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to reporters after meeting with Congressional leaders, President Obama playfully talks about negotiating with Republicans on the automatic spending cuts.

headline: Hollywood’s Priceless Sounding Board
abstract: Steven Spielberg’s creative input for filmmakers not necessarily under his authority is as close to a benediction as one can hope for in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: When the action hit “Cloverfield” thrilled audiences in 2008, few in theaters could have guessed that they were, at least in part, under the creative stewardship of Steven Spielberg. That’s because Mr. Spielberg has no credit on the production. But that didn’t stop him from giving the movie’s director, Matt Reeves, and its producer, J. J. Abrams, advice on how to improve the film.

headline: Royal Pedigree Infuses Collective Beats
abstract: The debut album of the brothers Raul and Mexia Hernández, sons of the bassist for Los Tigres del Norte, is definitely not Los Tigres 2.0.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In 2010 Raul and Mexia Hernández set up a camera and a keyboard in their living room in San Jose, Calif., to sing a song about immigrant rights. Mexia rapped about cooks and domestic workers and Latinos being “on the rise like blood pressure.” Raul crooned the Spanish-language hook (“I just want to succeed/And now they want to deport me”). Their brother, Giovanni, played a beat on a trash can. They called the song “Todos Somos Arizona” (“We Are All Arizona”) and uploaded the video to YouTube as a direct response to the state’s passage of a strict anti-immigrant law. The song quickly racked up thousands of views and earned the siblings a publicist.

headline: A Symbol of Liberty, Strength and Budget Fights
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: When budget cuts have loomed, politicians have long warned that the Washington Monument might have to be closed. That tactic is of limited value now, as it is closed for repairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In April 2011, just before a midnight deadline to avert a government shutdown, President Obama celebrated a budget agreement between Congressional Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Kimchi Radish Pickle
keywords: ['Pickles and Relishes', 'Canning and Preserving', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: Have you run out of ideas for root vegetables? Melissa Clark adds one more possibility with kimchi radish pickles.
lead_paragraph: Have you run out of ideas for root vegetables? Melissa Clark adds one more possibility with kimchi radish pickles.

headline: The Limits of Executive Power
abstract: The president can’t force a deal on Republican lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is obviously sick and tired of the widely peddled notion that the sequester and all other budget failures are ultimately his fault because he’s the president. His frustration made for a surprisingly lively news conference this morning, and gave the public a brief reminder that there are real limits to the power of the White House.

headline: Before a Tourist’s Body Was Found, Rebuffed Efforts to Report Her Missing
abstract: After Li Junyun, a Korean citizen, disappeared in Queens last week, her friends tried several times to report her missing. Ms. Li’s death is now being investigated.
lead_paragraph: Li Junyun, 46, arrived in New York last month with a tourist visa and a single suitcase, “hoping to see what America was like,” a friend said.

headline: New Orleans Snowball Wars Come to an End
abstract: Lawsuits in New Orleans over snowball patents and trademarks involving equipment and flavors are finally settled.
lead_paragraph: Snowballs are as integral to New Orleans life as beignets. But hard-core loyalties have cleaved the community of shaved-ice enthusiasts and vendors, as seen by the three decades of lawsuits that have just come to an end. Channel 4 in New Orleans has the story. The lawsuits involved disputes over trademarks and patents for the equipment used to make the snowballs, and also which companies could use which names for flavors like “King Cake,” “Cajun Red Hot,” “Orchid Cream Vanilla” and “Hurricane.”

headline: German Copyright Law Targets Google Links
abstract: A bill broadening protections for news publishers was approved by German lawmakers, but critics said the measure did not go far enough.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German lawmakers approved legislation on Friday that grants publishers the right to charge search engines and other online aggregators for reproducing their content but continues to allow the free use of text in links and brief summaries.

headline: A Rainbow of Root Vegetables
abstract: Root vegetables make a colorful and satisfying winter meal, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Recipes for Health is as much a treat for the eyes as the palate. Colorful root vegetables from bright orange carrots and red scallions to purple and yellow potatoes and pale green leeks will add color and flavor to your table.

headline: With ‘The Bible,’ the Mini-Series Goes Back to the Beginning
abstract: A 10-hour mini-series, “The Bible,” begins on Sunday on History and will rerun on Monday nights on Lifetime.
lead_paragraph: For as long as there has been filmed entertainment there have been producers and directors retelling the dramatic stories from the 66 books of the Old and New Testaments. But the cable channel History’s coming 10-hour mini-series, “The Bible,” might be the first to include an angel skilled in Chinese martial arts.

headline: A Day of Watching TV at Sundance
abstract: Jane Campion’s TV mini-series “Top of the Lake,” the first TV show to be screened at Sundance, was well-received — not surprising, given how TV watching is changing.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Jane Campion has spent decades traveling the festival circuit, listening to countless audiences react to her films, like “The Piano” or “Bright Star.” Still, nothing prepared her for the response during a showing in the Egyptian Theater during the Sundance Film Festival in January.

headline: Spain’s Paradors Face an Uncertain Future
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Financial woes are forcing cutbacks and closings in government-owned hotels known as paradors, many of which occupy striking historic buildings.
lead_paragraph: We crisscrossed Europe in the family car when I was a child. My father, a sports columnist based in Paris in the 1960s, was always testing tips he had gotten from Grand Prix racecar drivers. My mother, no surprise, was constantly telling him to slow down. In the back seat, my sisters and I were usually hungry, tired or fighting. But we saw amazing things: castles, cathedrals, villages slapped up against cliffs to protect them from Roman invaders, beaches still scarred with the wreckage of World War II battles.

headline: A Crunchy End to Winter
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Pickles and Relishes', 'Radishes', 'Kimchi (South Korean Food)']
abstract: A spicy, zingy pickle alleviates the root vegetable doldrums of winter.
lead_paragraph: By March I’ve had my fill of root vegetables. All winter long, I gratinéed them, puréed them, roasted and sautéed them. I savored them in soups, blanketed them with cheese and cream and shaved them sensibly into lean, crisp salads.

headline: Model Diary | Daria Strokous
abstract: The 22-year-old Russian model and face of Christian Dior talks to T about music, beauty and more.
lead_paragraph: It was no surprise that Daria Strokous, a face in Christian Dior’s current advertising campaign, was on the runway today in a Raf Simons-designed frock. The 22-year-old Russian model lives in New York and is currently bopping around Paris to hip-hop music on her iPod.

headline: Getting Comfortable With the New Vail
abstract: From a Wi-Fi-equipped gondola to smart lift tickets, the Vail experience has been transformed. A veteran skier returns to the resort to see if new also means improved.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1950s, Pete Seibert, who dreamed of building a major ski resort in Colorado, spent seven hours hiking to the top of what is now Vail Mountain. At the crest of the obscure, unpopulated hill, he glimpsed a rare landscape of largely treeless bowls, a vast panorama of seemingly boundless, perfect skiing terrain.

headline: Vail at 50
abstract: As the resort celebrates a milestone anniversary, see how skiing there has evolved.
lead_paragraph: As the resort celebrates a milestone anniversary, see how skiing there has evolved.

headline: 9 Spring Breaks, From Budget to Beyond
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Travel Agencies and Agents', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: We gave a few travel agents an assignment: come up with three weeklong vacations for a family of four. The result is nine trips, from thrifty Florida to in-your-dreams French Alps.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to my children’s school vacations, the only one that has always produced an overwhelming need to get away as a family is spring break. Falling in March or April, depending on the school, the week punctuates the endless stretch between January and school’s end, providing a chance for rest and adventure after a long period of burrowing.

headline: Safekeeping a Relic of the Punk Era
abstract: Richard Hell, the proto-punk rocker and writer, has kept a handmade book for 40-some years, since it was created and given to him by its author.
lead_paragraph: Every day, we upload and unload, migrating more and more of our hard stuff to the digital realm. Films, music, photos, magazines, even tools like levels, flashlights and thermometers are now mushed into megabytes. Yet there is one object we remain ambivalent about letting go of, and that is that much-loved portable media-holder known as the book.

headline: Shooting Vacation Video Like a Pro
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: You don’t need to be a filmmaker to create high-quality travel videos. Daniel Klein, who co-produces an online video series, offers tips on everything from gear to technique.
lead_paragraph: No longer is travel programming the sole territory of television and big budgets. A younger generation of filmmakers like Daniel Klein is producing Web travel series pretty much on their own, thanks largely to new digital cameras that are (relatively) small in size and price.

headline: Bonnie Franklin, Steadfast Mom on ‘One Day at a Time,’ Dies at 69
abstract: Ms. Franklin, an accomplished stage and film actress, was best known for playing Ann Romano, a divorced mother of two daughters, on television.
lead_paragraph: Bonnie Franklin, whose portrayal of a pert but determined Ann Romano on the television show “One Day at a Time” in the 1970s and ’80s spun laughter out of the tribulations of a divorced woman juggling parenting, career, love life and feminist convictions, died on Friday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 69.

headline: Now Hear This: Works by Chinese Sound Artists
abstract: Colgate University is presenting the exhibition, scheduled for March 26-April 26.
lead_paragraph: Colgate University is mounting an exhibition of sound-art installations by Chinese artists whose work has never been displayed in the United States.

headline: Tip Bankers Like Waiters
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Waiters and Waitresses']
abstract: Forget about Europe’s proposed bonus rules. Instead, why not put a ceiling on banker salaries and let clients reward good service, just as they do in restaurants?
lead_paragraph: Forget Europe’s bonus caps for bankers. It might make for good publicity for the politicians, but wags in the City, London’s financial district, are already joking about ways to get around it.

headline: Global Event Succeeds Where It Needs To
abstract: Many players are sending mixed signals about the World Baseball Classic, an event that has featured several foreign players who have gone on to the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

headline: Statistics Guru Settles In With the Grizzlies
abstract: John Hollinger, the creator of the Player Efficiency Rating metric, is only a few months into his role as Memphis’s vice president of player personnel.
lead_paragraph: It was a coup for basketball’s stats geeks when one of their own, John Hollinger, was hired away from ESPN to be the vice president of player personnel for the Memphis Grizzlies in December. Hollinger, who created the Player Efficiency Rating metric, a single number to measure a player’s overall value, is enjoying himself as the Grizzlies are riding high for the moment. So he will presumably be feeling pretty good on Friday as he heads to the Sports Analytics Conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the highlight of the sports geeks’ calendar.

headline: 10 Questions for the Red Bulls
abstract: The Red Bulls open their 2013 season at Portland on Sunday evening. Here are some questions to ponder.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls, the ever-underachieving Red Bulls, open their 2013 season at Portland on Sunday evening. And the schedule makers in Major League Soccer must have a perverse sense of humor because Game 2 will also be on the West Coast, at San Jose. That makes it coast to coast to coast to coast to coast in the space of a couple of weeks. Here are some questions to ponder before the opener, and beyond:

headline: March 3 — March 9
abstract: A selection of culture events.
lead_paragraph: Creativity on the Road

headline: Ireland Seeks Easing of Its Debt Terms
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The country’s proposal for paying back its bailout is likely to be discussed at a meeting of European finance ministers on next week in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland has been widely praised as the good pupil of the euro zone’s austerity school of thought. Now it wants to be rewarded.

headline: Italian Lender Sues Deutsche Bank and Nomura
abstract: In a first attempt to retrieve some of its losses, Monte dei Paschi di Siena sued Deutsche Bank and Nomura over certain financial transactions that went bad.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a first attempt to retrieve some of its losses, the Tuscan lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena sued Deutsche Bank and Nomura on Friday over certain financial transactions that went bad.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Batman Battles the Owls
abstract: “Batman: Night of Owls” is No. 1 on the hardcover list.
lead_paragraph: New on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, at No. 1, is “Batman: Night of Owls,” written by Scott Snyder and illustrated by Greg Capullo.

headline: Sharp Memory Yields Perils and Payday
abstract: Everybody is on the make in “The Mnemonist of Dutchess County,” by Josh Koenigsberg, in which a synesthete with perfect memory is also out to get the girl.
lead_paragraph: What are the elements that make us human, that make us ourselves? Our memories, our ability to feel and to empathize? Or perhaps our capacity for cruelty?

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: It Helps to Lift the Bride Off Her Feet
abstract: After becoming sweethearts in high school, Claire Lieberman and Nicholas Keefe made a pact to remain a couple though they were attending different colleges.
lead_paragraph: After a decade-long courtship, Nicholas Keefe was as ready as one could be to wed Claire Lieberman, his high school sweetheart. Yet as their wedding day approached, there was one detail about it that sparked nervousness in Mr. Keefe, a former high school football, basketball and baseball player: the first dance.

headline: ‘Smash’ Getting Only a Little Help From DVR Numbers
abstract: “Smash,” which was buoyed by DVR ratings in its first season, isn’t getting as many eyeballs through delayed viewing this time around.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the ratings for the second season of NBC’s “Smash” have been low. The most recent episode fell to 3.3 million total viewers and it barely cleared the 1 million threshold in viewers between the ages of 18 and 49, the demographic most important to advertisers. But DVR viewing was crucial to buoying “Smash” in its first season. Will that be a help this time around?Probably not.

headline: A Snapshot of Drilling on a Park’s Margins
keywords: ['Glaciers', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Wells']
abstract: A photographer seeks to drive home the proximity of fracking to Glacier National Park.
lead_paragraph: More on the fracking front:

headline: Dior: A Comfortable Embrace
abstract: This collection shows Raf Simons challenging himself more and, at the same time, thinking harder about the modernist qualities that attracted Dior himself.
lead_paragraph: People left the Dior show today on a high, or I had the feeling they did. What is it about the sight of those huge Mylar bubbles hovering near the ceiling that made people feel giddy? The self-reflecting possibilities of the silvery surfaces were intriguing, as was the background music: a neurotic recording by Laurie Anderson of a visit to her Greenwich Village vet to see why her dog was so fat. Or was it that Raf Simons had once again changed people’s expectations about Dior and, by association, fashion?

headline: Countdown to Sequester Links
abstract: Some reading while we prepare for the budget cuts.
lead_paragraph: Some potential consequences of the sequester:

headline: Vanessa Bruno: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Cleveland TV Station Celebrates Andy Griffith After Oscars Snub
abstract: Andy Griffith, who died last year, was not included in the obituary reel at the Oscars, but a Cleveland TV station celebrated him on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Andy Griffith received little love from the Oscars last Sunday, as the producers decided to leave him off the list of actors honored in the yearly obituary reel.

headline: Blogging Her Life With Cancer
abstract: Introducing Lisa B. Adams, a mother living with Stage 4 breast cancer, to the Motherlode blogroll.
lead_paragraph: When I called on readers to submit the blogs they loved for the Motherlode blogroll, one name came up more than any other: Lisa B. Adams. And I can understand why. The best personal blogs come from people on a journey through something that is as intense as anything they’ve ever experienced, and Lisa is on a journey none of us want to be on. She has breast cancer, and last fall she learned that the cancer had metastasized to her bones, becoming Stage 4 breast cancer.

headline: Breaking Free of Fashion’s Hamster Wheel
abstract: Raf Simons at Dior and Jun Takahashi at Undercover offered the unexpected.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As I said in a previous post, Alber Elbaz saw the problem of all these fashion shows, running like a hamster wheel, each format virtually the same, and in his own way did something about it. But now I’ve seen Raf Simons’s Dior show, and also Undercover (by the amazing Jun Takahashi), and they all express a similar attitude — which is freedom. It sounds silly to say that of talented and well-paid designers, but there’s a reason you leave their shows feeling good.

headline: The Donut District
abstract: Three artist-run spaces in Brooklyn have named their micro-neighborhood after its commercial center, an off-ramp Dunkin Donuts.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 1
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gun rally in Albany; a demolished home in Roxbury, Queens; and a flash mob in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gun rally in Albany; a demolished home in Roxbury, Queens; and a flash mob in Times Square.

headline: Church, State and Bible Class in Texas
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Bible', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Evangelical Movement']
abstract: Despite efforts to integrate other religions at Texas public schools, teachers are not doing enough to make their classes welcoming to all beliefs, a study has shown.
lead_paragraph: It may be a little late for the holiday of Purim, but on Tuesday, in Eastland, Tex., Gay Hart will be baking hamantaschen — the traditional doughy, triangle-shaped pastries accented with dollops of prune, Nutella or some other delectable paste — for the mostly Protestant students in her class on the Bible at Eastland High School. Her curriculum also includes latke recipes for Hanukkah, “challah-days” and the Hebrew melody “Hava Nagila.”

headline: Q and A: The Angry Economist
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming', 'Kyoto Protocol', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Because of its natural gas boom, the United States is ahead of Europe in fixing climate change, the Oxford economist Dieter Helm argues.
lead_paragraph: Dieter Helm has long been frustrated that, despite more than two decades of international negotiations, the world has failed to tackle climate change. So he got angry, he said, and decided to write a book about it: “The Carbon Crunch: How We’re Getting Climate Change Wrong — and How to Fix It.”

headline: An Exuberance Is Bustin’ Out All Over, Under the Loving Gaze of a Father
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s presentation of “Carousel” was given a spirited kick by Tiler Peck and Robert Fairchild in the second-act ballet.
lead_paragraph: Tiler Peck, wearing a pale pink dress with her brown hair streaming around her shoulders, dashes across the stage at Avery Fisher Hall with her arms open wide and her heart exposed. As Louise, Billy Bigelow’s daughter in “Carousel,” Ms. Peck is a vulnerable spitfire — and just about as transcendent as the music.

headline: Two Composers’ Jaunts to Latin America
abstract: The Collegiate Chorale paired works by Philip Glass and Osvaldo Golijov at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: The Collegiate Chorale had logical reasons to pair the pieces it performed in its concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, Philip Glass’s  Symphony No. 7 (“Toltec”) and Osvaldo Golijov’s  “Oceana.” Both are substantial statements by well-known, popular living composers. Both deal with Latin American culture, though in disparate ways. And, on the evidence offered here by the chorale with the conductor James Bagwell, the American Symphony Orchestra and other guests, both works recall stronger efforts by these important, distinctive composers.

headline: Week in Review: Sizable Pay for the Wall St. Survivors

headline: Mom Always Said to Share
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Roommates', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Real estate agents report an increase in sibling roommates.
lead_paragraph: From the time they were middle-school students in Manhattan, Arielle Patrick and her brother, Andrew, had an agreement: come college graduation, if they weren’t married they would share a “bachelor/bachelorette pad” in the city. They were serious enough about the matter to put the pact in writing on a piece of loose-leaf paper and, with great earnestness, to sign their names at the bottom.

headline: Teams Begin Using Franchise Tag
abstract: Buffalo, Cincinnati and Indianapolis were the first three teams to use the franchise tag on players.
lead_paragraph: With the N.F.L. salary cap finally set at $123 million, teams began Friday to make some of their most critical off-season decisions. Three teams used the franchise tag – Buffalo on safety Jairus Byrd, Cincinnati on defensive end Michael Johnson and Indianapolis on punter Pat McAfee – essentially halting the players’ opportunities to test the free-agent market when it opens March 12.

headline: Noodles With No Need to Dress Up
abstract: Make fresh homemade egg pasta, then forget the cheese and ignore the sauce.
lead_paragraph: The first time I tasted fresh egg pasta, back in the 20th century, it was cooked by a bunch of Italian hippies in a dilapidated Victorian house in San Francisco, and it was an event. These expatriates may have been sharing a house on the cheap with their counterculture pals, but they were not about to eat bland brown rice and steamed vegetables if they could help it. Having been raised to appreciate a tastier form of communal eating, they invited a bevy of friends to a Sunday meal. The only thing on the menu was handmade pasta, and part of the experience was observing the process.

headline: In Like a Lion: Knicks Face Tough Road in March
abstract: A tough schedule greets the Knicks in March, which may make or break their season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – It is probably an oversimplification to say that a single month can make or break a team’s season. But the month of March just might make or break the Knicks.

headline: Report May Ease Path for New Pipeline
abstract: A revised federal statement on the Keystone XL pipeline offers no environmental reasons that it should not be built, giving President Obama political cover to approve it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department issued a revised environmental impact statement for the 1,700-mile Keystone XL pipeline on Friday that makes no recommendation about whether the project should be built but presents no conclusive environmental reason it should not be.

headline: Wilson to Obama: March Forth!
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: With the budget impasse, perhaps President Obama could learn a few lessons in enacting transformative legislation from the nation’s first scholar-president.
lead_paragraph: “THERE has been a change of government,” declared Woodrow Wilson in his first sentence as president of the United States, one hundred years ago this Monday. Until 1937, when the 20th Amendment moved Inauguration Day to late January, chief executives took their oaths of office on March Fourth, a date that sounds like a command.

abstract: Revisiting John Tierney’s 2002 article on trains in America.

headline: Poll Finds Record Support for Same-Sex Marriage in California
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A new Field Poll shows that support for same-sex marriage in California has increased drastically since Proposition 8 was passed there a little more than four years ago.
lead_paragraph: The same week the Obama administration filed a brief urging the Supreme Court to strike down California’s ban on same-sex marriage, a new Field Poll was released showing that support for same-sex marriage in the state has increased drastically since the ban was passed there a little more than four years ago.

headline: The Holocaust Just Got More Shocking
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Forced Labor', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The Germans had vastly more work camps and ghettos than anyone knew.
lead_paragraph: THIRTEEN years ago, researchers at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum began the grim task of documenting all the ghettos, slave labor sites, concentration camps and killing factories that the Nazis set up throughout Europe.

headline: A Pickle With Different Roots
abstract: Pickle any root vegetables you have on hand.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I found a bag of watermelon radishes in my Community Supported Agriculture box. So I took them home and pickled them for this week’s column, flavoring the roots with traditional kimchi seasonings. But the same recipe would work well with other juicy root vegetables, too, including carrots, kohlrabi, celery root and turnips. Feel free to experiment with whatever you happen to have on hand – or whatever your C.S.A. box gives you.

headline: Teams Trailing Late in Games Play More Efficiently, Paper Suggests
abstract: Teams that were behind were shown to exhibit more efficiency while teams that were ahead tended to shoot less efficiently and shun 3-pointers more than they should.
lead_paragraph: This year marks the seventh installment of the M.I.T. Sloan Sports Analytics Conference. Held in Boston, the conference – which is expected to draw in excess of 2,500 attendees – represents the cutting edge of statistical, economic and technological information in the world of sports, with dozens of papers, panels and presentations giving attendees a first-hand look at the future of our most cherished pastimes.

headline: A Blog’s Adieu
abstract: The New York Times is discontinuing the Green blog but plans to press on with aggressive energy and environment coverage.
lead_paragraph: The Times is discontinuing the Green blog, which was created  to track environmental and energy news and to foster lively discussion of developments in both areas. This change will allow us to direct production resources to other online projects. But we’ll forge ahead with our aggressive reporting on environmental and energy topics, including climate change, land use, threatened ecosystems, government policy, the fossil fuel industries, the growing renewables sector and consumer choices.

lead_paragraph: A sun-glazed floor-through penthouse with a modernist mind-set in a Costas Kondylis-designed condominium tower at 279 Central Park West sold for $8.15 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

lead_paragraph: The new ABC series stars Radha Mitchell as the titular widow.

headline: Traditions Change, Even Here
abstract: A high-priced Westchester village with a top-rated school system has acquired a slightly more diverse population.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, when Irina Sher, a native of Yerevan, Armenia, first set foot in the southern Westchester suburb of Bronxville and saw its wooded hillsides inset with substantial Tudor, Shingle-style and Victorian homes, she was captivated. When she learned about its top-rated public school, her decision was made: “I knew right away I had to raise my children here, whatever the cost.”

headline: Fairway Market Comes Back After Sandy
abstract: Several businesses in Red Hook have reopened.
lead_paragraph: In another sign that the region is recovering from Sandy’s devastation, the Fairway Market and other businesses in Red Hook on Brooklyn’s waterfront reopened today. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Senator Charles E. Schumer were some of the first customers to order from the Fairway deli counter.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Chalayan
abstract: The goal: a pure look. the makeup artist Aaron de Mey achieved this by giving the models a dewy, shimmery complexion.
lead_paragraph: “Hussein is doing something very elevated with his collection, so I wanted the girls to appear very pure,” said the makeup artist Aaron de Mey backstage at Chalayan. To accomplish this, he first worked M.A.C. Mineralize Charged Water Moisture Gel onto the skin to lay the groundwork for a dewy complexion. He then mixed together two shimmery hues of M.A.C. Cream Color Base, Pearl and Luna, and applied them “where the sun hits your face” — cheekbones, bridge of nose, cupid bow, chin — “to give the face dimension.” The look was stark and clean but not severe thanks to the iridescence in the product.

headline: Adam Selman Dresses Rihanna for the Stage
abstract: Rihanna’s costume designer, who worked with her on the Rihanna for River Island collection, is sharing the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna’s costume designer, who worked with her on the Rihanna for River Island collection, is sharing the spotlight.

headline: Insurgent St. Patrick’s Day Parade Comes Into Its Own
abstract: A parade that was established in Queens in 2000 to include gay groups excluded from other St. Patrick’s Day parades has become ever more popular, including with elected officials and candidates.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Fay pointed to an e-mail on his computer screen from the New York Fire Department’s Emerald Society Pipes and Drums corps confirming that it would be marching in the St. Patrick’s Day parade in Queens, on Sunday.

headline: A Well-Done Do-Over Raises the Final Grade
abstract: Honda, responding to the near universal disdain of the 2012 Civic, went back to the drawing board and produced a car that is much better than the lackluster previous model.
lead_paragraph: The 2012 Honda Civic was a goof: a dull all-new car that wasn’t better, in any significant way, than the one it replaced. Goofs are fixable, however — just ask NASA.

lead_paragraph: The trial against BP over the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico began in New Orleans, Marissa Mayer ordered Yahoo workers back to the office, and Jacob J. Lew was confirmed as Treasury secretary.

headline: The Secret Weapon Behind Rihanna’s Look
abstract: Get to know Adam Selman, the designer behind Rihanna’s CFDA dress, in this profile from the archives.
lead_paragraph: After the Rihanna for River Island presentation during London Fashion Week, its namesake designer, the biggest pop star on the planet, came out for a bow. Accompanying her was a boyish, mustachioed fellow. Most of the audience had no clue who he was. Beaming, he turned to Rihanna and applauded.

headline: With Rodman Stunt, American Reality TV and North Korean Propaganda Fuse
abstract: Elements of American show business and North Korean propaganda came together when the former basketball star Dennis Rodman said in Pyongyang that North Koreans “love” their new leader, Kim Jong-un.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Sunday, 11:21 p.m. Elements of American show business and North Korean propaganda briefly fused on Friday, when the former basketball star Dennis Rodman told reporters in Pyongyang that North Koreans “love” their new leader, Kim Jong-un. “And guess what?” the athlete turned reality TV star added, “I love him — the guy’s awesome.”

headline: 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational
abstract: Twenty pairs played a round robin of eight-board matches.
lead_paragraph: The 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational took place last weekend. Twenty pairs played a round robin of eight-board matches. The scoring method was Butler. Each pair’s results were scored by international match points against the average on a board, with the extreme results being eliminated from the calculation of the average.

headline: How to Overcome a Gaffe: Two Contemporary Case Studies
abstract: President Obama and Senator Marco Rubio have shown recently how to turn distractions into political gifts, even in the age of Twitter.
lead_paragraph: There is a formula emerging for solving that most contemporary of political problems: when a silly gaffe – propelled and amplified by Twitter – distracts from the substantive message.

headline: Plumbing the Deep

lead_paragraph: Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor talk about their new film “Leviathan,” a documentary about commercial fishing without interviews, voice-over, narrative or a traditional point of view.

headline: Not Enough Inflation
abstract: The inflation numbers for January underscores that the Federal Reserve underestimated the stimulus required to prevent inflation from sagging below the level it considers most healthy.
lead_paragraph: Yes, we have low inflation: The Commerce Department reported Friday that prices rose just 1.2 percent over the 12 months ending in January.

abstract: Is John Mulaney the next Jerry Seinfeld? Maybe his new NBC sitcom pilot will tell.
lead_paragraph: John Mulaney seems like the kind of stand-up comic you could take home and introduce to your parents.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: You Plunder, I’ll Pillage, Maybe We’ll Find England
abstract: “Vikings,” on History, explores what might have happened when cultures from the Dark Ages collided.
lead_paragraph: “Vikings” is a mini-series about a band of professional pillagers with a disregard for human life and a relentless focus on gratifying material desires. So it is somewhat surprising that it is also a refreshing study in restraint.

headline: England Develops a Voracious Appetite for a New Diet
abstract: The British are embracing a weight-loss plan that involves five days of eating and drinking whatever you want, and fasting for two days a week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Visitors to England right now, be warned. The big topic on people’s minds — from cabdrivers to corporate executives — is not Kate Middleton’s increasingly visible baby bump (though the craze does involve the size of one’s waistline), but rather a best-selling diet book that has sent the British into a fasting frenzy.

headline: The No-Limits Job
keywords: ['Internships', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Youth', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: For 20-somethings in creative fields, the work — often unpaid — never seems to end. Nor do the days.
lead_paragraph: Every generation has its own anthem of making the journey from youthful naïveté to adult reality, whether it’s Neil Young’s “Old Man,” Nirvana’s “Smells Like Teen Spirit” or most recently, perhaps, the Taylor Swift song “22.”

headline: Let Your Body Sing
abstract: Presented with a boombox playing a dance remix, passers-by showed their moves and were filmed for a music video. It’ll take less than four minutes to check it out.
lead_paragraph: As video concepts go, it was pretty simple: hit the streets and parks of New York with a boombox playing a dance remix of your band’s song and ask passers-by of all ages, races, shapes and sizes to move to it. Film the results.

headline: Manuela Frey Transforms Backstage at Maison Martin Margiela
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Hannah Murray and hair by Tomohiro Ohashi.

headline: A Brazilian Menu Inspired by Mom
abstract: The kitchen at Samba Montclair is small, and the cooking that comes out of it is guileless, in the best sense: straightforward, hearty, built for comfort.
lead_paragraph: A blast of warmth hits you as soon as you enter Samba Montclair, a tiny Brazilian restaurant in the heart of Montclair, though it’s not a matter of temperature, even if the place does offer a blessed respite from a frigid winter evening. It’s a subtler, enveloping glow: the soothing Latin music, the weathered rustic décor, the low lighting, the young, easygoing staff. That, and the large chalkboard toward the back that offers up bits of homespun wisdom, like “The torch of love is lit in the kitchen.”

headline: Drawn Into Crime, Trying to Get Out
abstract: In “Red Widow,” a new drama on ABC, Radha Mitchell plays the daughter of a Russian gangster forced into a drug-smuggling deal to protect her children.
lead_paragraph: In the “Twilight” series Bella Swan holds out until the fourth movie before being forced to transform from young human bride into vampire. In “Red Widow” Marta Walraven makes a parallel jump — from Marin County suburban homemaker to Russian mobster — before the end of Sunday night’s two-hour premiere. That’s television, always in a hurry.

headline: Open Exploring, With Skill for a Net
abstract: Ravi Coltrane is playing with three different sets of musicians in his run at the Jazz Standard, celebrating his new release, “Spirit Fiction.”
lead_paragraph: In the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane’s new album, “Spirit Fiction” (Blue Note), he works with two different groups, destabilizing the idea that he has a current group sound, or maybe enlarging it. In his Jazz Standard run he’s pushing the idea further, playing with three different bands over the course of a six-day week. The third one, playing this weekend, is as close as it gets to his latest going concern.

headline: A Strong First Impression
abstract: David Michael Leedy says his 1975 Rolls-Royce helps him stand out in a crowded real estate market.
lead_paragraph: David Michael Leedy says his 1975 Rolls-Royce helps him stand out in a crowded real estate market.

headline: The Devil Wants a Sequel
abstract: In “The Last Exorcism: Part II,” the victim of the first film in this series is in a house for recovering trauma patients in New Orleans when her demon again comes a-courting.
lead_paragraph: Poor Nell can’t catch a break. In “The Last Exorcism” (2010) this Louisiana teenager was possessed by the demon Abalam and ultimately bore his progeny, only to have their unholy offspring disposed of by solemn hooded attendants. In “The Last Exorcism: Part II” she has survived that ordeal, unlike her father (or so it appears), the documentary crew filming her and the minister of lapsed faith who attempted to coax out her tormentor.

headline: Selections From the Sea on a Refreshed Menu
abstract: One the Waterfront, in New Rochelle, underwent a renovation last year and returned with a refreshed menu of mainly seafood, with a smattering of traditional pub fare.
lead_paragraph: One cold, windy evening, I found myself yearning, somewhat perversely, for a seafood dinner served on a deck overlooking the water. Though that’s really a summertime treat, I went in search of the closest thing I could find in these waning weeks of winter.

headline: With Friends Like These . . .
abstract: “21 & Over,” the directorial debut of the “Hangover” screenwriting team, Jon Lucas and Scott Moore, follows an odd couple through a night of juvenile debauchery.
lead_paragraph: There’s a line early on in “21 & Over” about your “oldest friends always being your strangest ones.” That may be true, but there is a bigger theme here: After four years of college lifelong friendships can become forced, resulting in awkward attempts to reconnect and relive the good old days.

headline: In Nigeria’s Largest City, Homeless Are Paying the Price of Progress
abstract: As Lagos tries to raise its business profile, the city’s poor feel they have become the government’s enemy, a feeling deepened by the dismantling of a slum last week.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The young man with the crowbar stood on a heap of rubble — planks, pallets, remains of pots, bits of cardboard, wisps of clothing, chunks of concrete — indistinguishable from every other pile in a field of debris stretching far into the distance.

headline: A High-Dollar Debutante Ball
abstract: A bumper crop of new million-dollar cars will be shown at the 83rd International Motor Show in Geneva, where press previews begin on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A glittering bumper crop of million-dollar babies will be shown at the 83rd International Motor Show in Geneva, where press previews begin on Tuesday.

headline: Compressing Gas for a Cheaper, Simpler Hybrid
abstract: The Hybrid Air, which combines hydraulic drive with a conventional gasoline engine, is an experimental vehicle that PSA Peugeot Citroën says is an exemplar of energy efficiency.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — What’s that car that just breezed past?

headline: Expressionism’s Sooty Anomaly
abstract: The exhibition “Franz Kline: Coal and Steel” is at the Sidney Mishkin Gallery at Baruch College.
lead_paragraph: Franz Kline established himself as a major Abstract Expressionist painter almost overnight. In 1950, the year he turned 40, he had the first solo show of his career, at the Charles Egan Gallery on 57th Street in Manhattan. There he unveiled the dynamic abstractions, with their jutting, intersecting beams of black embedded in dense fields of white that would earn him a place in the Abstract Expressionist pantheon and rank among the style’s most emblematic motifs.

headline: Gunfight at the Universal-International Corral
abstract: TCM’s “Western Horizons” set gathers five Universal westerns, while “The Philo Vance Murder Case Collection” gathers six takes on S. S. Van Dine’s detective.
lead_paragraph: Western Horizons

headline: Rich Tastes on Small Plates
abstract: The cornucopia of classical French cuisine at Vinted, in West Hartford, courts the carnivore and the oenophile.
lead_paragraph: I’m going to be harshly critical of Vinted: in my expert opinion, no restaurant should have a past participle for a name.

headline: The Daily Do | Maison Martin Margiela
abstract: Several jackets sent down the brand’s Paris runway came complete with a barrette-like flap that kept the hair in place.
lead_paragraph: There are certain tools necessary to keep one’s mane from becoming too unruly — the ponytail holder, Aqua Net, bobby pins. Several of the jackets sent down the Margiela Fall/Winter 2013 runway came complete with a built-in, barrette-like flap where the hair was tucked in, securing the hair so it was never out of place.

headline: A Time of Transition in the Church
abstract: Readers respond to Op-Ed articles by Hans Küng and Paul Elie, and a column by Frank Bruni.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Homeless Veterans
abstract: An official with the Doe Fund calls for more assistance for women who suffered trauma in the military.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: From Sure Hands, a Smooth Riesling
abstract: Roman Roth’s 2010 Virgin Berry Riesling is smooth, balanced, concentrated and zippy, and it has a low alcohol content.
lead_paragraph: Roman Roth, Wölffer Estate Vineyard’s winemaker since 1992 (he was recently named a partner), has released an unusual riesling under his personal label, the Grapes of Roth.

headline: Bright Lights, Big City (Redux)
abstract: Gavin Doyle went from fresh-faced kid to night-life fixture in the time it took the doorman to lift the velvet rope.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Doyle went from fresh-faced kid to night-life fixture in the time it took the doorman to lift the velvet rope.

headline: Bright Lights, Big City (Redux)
abstract: Gavin Doyle went from fresh-faced kid to night-life fixture in the time it took the doorman to lift the velvet rope.
lead_paragraph: When Gavin Doyle moved to New York from Miami in 2006, he knew only one person, Abby Hofeldt, a classmate from Miami Country Day who’d come here to study fashion. On Halloween night they presented themselves outside the Beatrice Inn in the West Village, a speakeasy-turned-restaurant-turned-low-key bar with a tough door policy.

headline: Using Walls to Talk Back to Unwelcome ‘Compliments’
abstract: A Brooklyn artist has plastered her borough with posters carrying messages like “My name is not baby” and “Stop telling women to smile” because, she said, “These things make you feel like your body isn’t yours.”
lead_paragraph: Shorty. Sweetie. Sweetheart. Baby. Boo. If you’re a woman, you’ve probably heard it.

headline: Fighting the Insurer Over Hurricane Sandy Damage
abstract: A Brooklyn couple say their insurance company will pay $49,000 for home repairs, while an adjuster they hired put the figure needed at $200,000.
lead_paragraph: With Hurricane Sandy moving in, Andrea and Stephen Kondaks gathered candles, water and flashlights, and then put on their fishing waders. There was nothing left to do but wait, and watch, as the oily water slowly seeped into the hallway of their house, two and a half blocks from the bay in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

headline: Too Fat to Enlist
abstract: A retired Air Force general responds to a news article, “Children in U.S. Are Eating Fewer Calories, Study Finds.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Where Does Your Hurricane Sandy Claim Stand?
abstract: Bucks readers tell of their own experiences in dealing with their insurance companies for damage to their homes from Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column tells the tale of Andrea and Stephen Kondaks, a couple whose Brooklyn home took in nearly eight feet of water during Hurricane Sandy. Dealing with the trauma and physical clean-up after the storm was hard enough. But Mrs. Kondaks has spent the last four months trying to convince the couple’s flood insurer that its estimate for the cost of repair was woefully inadequate.

headline: Cruise Ship Safety
abstract: The president of the Cruise Lines International Association responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Voyage to Thailand, by Land or Sea
abstract: Thai Taste in Massapequa Park fires the imagination with dishes like crying tiger (marinated sirloin) and drunken sea (seafood in a chili-fueled sauce) served among hanging fabric and carved wood.
lead_paragraph: Long before Pan-Asian palaces were the rage, Thai food had already won many fans on Long Island. Some of the best Thai food around is served at an attractive storefront in Massapequa Park, Thai Taste, which opened eight years ago.

headline: Run Airlines as a Monopoly
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A writer suggests running airlines as a regulated monopoly.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: French and Chad Forces Strike Militants in the Mountains of Mali
abstract: Chad’s president confirmed the death of the toughest and most ruthless of the Al Qaeda commanders in the region.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The French military struck at Islamist militants dug in along the remote, rocky mountain ranges of northern Mali over the last week, killing scores, a French military spokesman said Friday.

headline: State Department Again Sees No Environmental Barriers to Keystone Pipeline
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Pipelines']
abstract: The State Department finds no significant environmental barriers to approval of the Keystone XL pipeline.
lead_paragraph: The State Department’s revised supplemental environmental impact statement on the proposed 1,700-mile Keystone XL pipeline is out, and offers very little that Secretary of State John Kerry or President Obama might use as a reason to reject the plan.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Sonia Rykiel
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a chic, color combination of violet and cherry red.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Under Fire, the Mayor of Pittsburgh Quits Race
abstract: Luke Ravenstahl abruptly dropped his bid for re-election amid a federal investigation of the city’s Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Luke Ravenstahl, who at 26 became Pittsburgh’s youngest mayor ever, abruptly dropped his bid for re-election Friday amid a federal investigation of the city’s Police Department and the forced resignation last month of the police chief.

headline: Joe Johnson Back for Nets
abstract: Nets guard Joe Johnson returned to the lineup Friday against the Dallas Mavericks after a three-game absence due to a left heel injury.
lead_paragraph: Nets guard Joe Johnson returned to the lineup Friday against the Dallas Mavericks after a three-game absence caused by a left heel injury.

headline: Tasting Freedom at Dior and Lanvin
abstract: Raf Simons of Dior and Alber Elbaz of Lanvin experiment with the freedom in diversity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 1
abstract: View a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gun rally in Albany; a demolished home in Roxbury, Queens; and a flash mob in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a gun rally in Albany; a demolished home in Roxbury, Queens; and a flash mob in Times Square.

headline: Lawyers Go to Cambodia Over Statue
abstract: Two United States attorneys traveled to Cambodia this week to see firsthand a temple tied to a 10th-century statue, whose ownership is under contention.
lead_paragraph: Two lawyers from the United States Attorney’s Office in Manhattan traveled into the Cambodian jungle this week to inspect an ancient, crumbling temple as part of their office’s effort to seize a 10th-century Khmer statue that Sotheby’s hopes to sell at auction.

headline: Old Tricks Up New Sleeves
abstract: When the novelty of their flashy fashion wears off, young designers realize it helps to sell some clothes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS
