abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Florida Man Lost in Sinkhole
abstract: A 36-year-old from Seffner, Fla., was buried and presumed dead after being sucked into a hole that was still expanding.
lead_paragraph: An enormous sinkhole opened beneath a central Florida house on Thursday night, sucking down and burying a man who was in his bedroom.

headline: Argentina’s About-Face on Terror
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Why is Iran being let off the hook for a deadly 1994 attack on Jews?
lead_paragraph: ON July 18, 1994, a van filled with explosives blew up outside the Jewish community center in Buenos Aires, killing 85 people and injuring hundreds. It was the worst terrorist attack ever in Argentina, which has Latin America’s largest Jewish population, and one of the deadliest anti-Semitic attacks since the Holocaust.

headline: In His Annual Letter, Buffett Plays Up Newspapers
abstract: Warren Buffett also struck a patriotic tone, telling his fellow chief executives “that opportunities abound in America.”
lead_paragraph: Over the last half-century, Warren E. Buffett has built a reputation as a contrarian investor, betting against the crowd to amass a fortune estimated at $54 billion.

headline: ‘Equality First, Guns Afterward’
abstract: Why many Boston blacks refused to join the famed 54th Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: When recruiting began in February 1863 for the 54th Massachusetts – one of the first regiments in the Union Army composed of Northern free blacks–many Bostonians expected Robert Morris to be among its strongest boosters. A key figure in the city’s black leadership, Morris had spent much of the previous decade demanding a place for his black military company in the Massachusetts Volunteer Militia. He passionately believed that the spectacle of black men arrayed in the state’s uniforms, marching in disciplined ranks, would force a change in how most whites perceived them, replacing inchoate fears of slave rebellion with admiration for the newest members of the citizen-soldiery.

headline: Touring the Source of a Writer’s Vaunted Words
abstract: Newark plans bus tours, parties and conferences to honor Philip Roth, who turns 80 on March 19.
lead_paragraph: Philip Roth turns 80 on March 19, and in his hometown, Newark, bus tours and an exhibition of photographs are among the events planned for the occasion.

headline: Homeless in an Instant
abstract: As Lagos aims to become a premier business center, the city’s poor and homeless are becoming the government’s enemy.
lead_paragraph: As Lagos aims to become a premier business center, the city’s poor and homeless are becoming the government’s enemy.

headline: Frisky Comedy and Hotel-Room Farce
abstract: “Lend Me a Tenor,” written in 1986 by Ken Ludwig, is a 1930s-style comedy that uses traditional elements from farces of centuries past.
lead_paragraph: One of the nicest features of the Broadway revival of Ken Ludwig’s “Lend Me a Tenor” back in 2010 was John Lee Beatty’s creamy rococo hotel suite where the operatic characters dashed about.

headline: Questions Emerge About the Mold That Hurricane Sandy Left Behind
abstract: How to best tackle the problem of mold in homes flooded by the storm is a subject of debate in New York.
lead_paragraph: At a mayoral debate in January, candidates vied to outdo one another in their dire warnings of a growing threat to public health that they said was hurting families all over New York City. Soon afterward, public and private groups pledged that millions of dollars would be spent to fight the scourge. And last month, Congressional representatives from New York called upon the federal government to help resolve what they called “this emerging crisis.”

headline: Wet Conditions Raise Issue of Lift-Clean-and-Place Rule
abstract: Ernie Els said he was unhappy that tour officials decided not to use the lift-clean-and-place rule that was in effect for the first round of the Honda Classic.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Like Rory McIlroy, Camilo Villegas is a former Honda Classic champion. Like McIlroy, Villegas began his second round Friday on the back nine at PGA National Resort and Spa and was seven over par for the day when he finished.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Capitalists for Preschool
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: The connections from preschool to reading proficiency to high school completion — a bare-minimum requirement in today’s economy — could not be clearer.
lead_paragraph: IN his State of the Union address, President Obama called for making preschool available to every 4-year-old in America, opening a welcome discussion on whether and how to make the investments needed to realize this vision.

headline: At Planetarium, It’s Not the Same Old Sky
abstract: The Planetarium at the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum in Centerport is reopening after a renovation, including a new projection system.
lead_paragraph: CENTERPORT, N.Y. — Standing behind the complex instrument panel that controls the gleaming Konica Minolta GeminiStar III projection system, Lorraine Vernola looks as though she could easily launch a spaceship, what with all the buttons, switches, computer screens and flashing lights in front of her. And in a sense, she can, at least virtually, for audiences inside the newly refurbished planetarium at the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum, the 43-acre former estate of William K. Vanderbilt II.

headline: And the Oscar Doesn’t Go to the Oscars
abstract: Some of the most frightening words in the English language are “I’d like to thank…”
lead_paragraph: Well, here we are again. Oscar has come and gone.

headline: Obama Pardons 17 Felons, First in His Second Term
abstract: President Obama issued pardons on Friday to 17 convicted felons, most of whose offenses were small-scale crimes committed many years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama issued pardons on Friday to 17 convicted felons, making the first use of his clemency powers in his second term. Their offenses were largely small-scale crimes many years ago, and 12 of the people had not been sentenced to serve time in prison.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Publisher Pulls a 2nd Book by Lehrer, ‘How We Decide’
abstract: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, which published all three of Jonah Lehrer’s books, confirmed after fact-checking the book that it would no longer offer it for sale.
lead_paragraph: Troubles for Jonah Lehrer, journalist wunderkind turned plagiarist and disgraced author, will not abate.

headline: Singing the Sequester Soap Opera
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)']
abstract: The sequester isn’t as bad as it looks — and Republicans aren’t as dumb as they look.
lead_paragraph: THERE are cracks in time when history bends and for an instant it seems as if the world itself stops turning, from that Sunday afternoon when our parents learned Pearl Harbor had been bombed to the football drill I was in the middle of coaching in Pensacola, Fla., when I first got the news that the Challenger had exploded. We may not agree on many things in this era of reflexive polarization, but here is one: nobody will remember where they were and what they were doing when the Great Sequester of 2013 kicked in.

headline: As the Cuts Hit Home
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Unemployment', 'Welfare (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Editorials']
abstract: Republicans who applaud the budget cuts are cheering for misery.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans were elated this week when their leader, John Boehner, made it clear that deep, automatic spending cuts would begin as scheduled on Friday. Incredibly, some consider the decision a victory.

headline: Ex-College Quarterback Is Acquitted of Rape in Montana
abstract: A former quarterback for the University of Montana was acquitted Friday of rape in a trial that riveted the city of Missoula.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — A former quarterback for the University of Montana was acquitted Friday of rape in a trial that riveted the city of Missoula.

headline: Another Try at Nuclear Talks
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: With Iran, agreeing to meet again keeps alive the slim chance of a diplomatic solution.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations this week between the major powers and Iran on its nuclear program achieved only an agreement to hold technical talks in March and then another meeting in April. The outcome was frustratingly incremental, but it keeps alive the slim possibility of a diplomatic solution.

headline: Way to Reach Kim Jong-un? Follow the Ball
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Basketball', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Dennis Rodman and his traveling companions are now the only Americans known to have met the North Korean leader since he took power more than a year ago.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Landing an audience with Kim Jong-un, the leader of one of the world’s most reclusive countries, is not easy.

headline: Longing to Escape From the Debt and the Dirt
abstract: The early Sam Shepard play, known for its violently dark humor, is at Long Wharf Theater Stage I until March 10.
lead_paragraph: The lamb gets laughs.

headline: Soldier to Face More Serious Charges in Leak
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Despite a guilty plea, military prosecutors decided to proceed with a court-martial that could result in a sentence of life without parole for Pfc. Bradley Manning.
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — Military prosecutors announced on Friday that they had decided to try Pfc. Bradley Manning on the most serious charges they have brought against him and seek a sentence that could be life without parole, despite his voluntary guilty plea to 10 lesser charges that carry a maximum total sentence of 20 years.

headline: Penney’s and Macy’s Battle Over Martha Stewart Products
abstract: A trial between J.C. Penney and Macy’s shows how competitive the middle-market home goods category is and how much a brand like Martha Stewart can matter.
lead_paragraph: Two of the biggest names in retail are fighting over Martha Stewart.

headline: Better Care for Young Offenders
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Youth', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials']
abstract: The new juvenile justice administrator should push more states to lock up fewer young people.
lead_paragraph: It took four years. But the Obama administration has finally filled an important post at the Justice Department’s Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention, which oversees juvenile justice policy and distributes federal grants to encourage reform at the state and local levels.

headline: Surrendering His Front-Row Seat
abstract: After waiting, and waiting, for his turn, the American goalkeeper Brad Guzan is finally the starter for Aston Villa in England’s Premier League.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — From the moment last Saturday’s Premier League game between Arsenal and Aston Villa began, goalkeeper Brad Guzan was in constant motion.

headline: More Cameras for New York City Streets
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'State Legislatures', 'Cameras', 'Editorials', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The State Legislature should permit New York City to enforce its speed limits and traffic rules.
lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration has been working to combat a deadly problem in New York City: drivers who speed or run through red lights.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 2, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Mar. 2, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “The Chinese hold the key to the elephants’ future. If things continue the way they are, many countries could lose their elephants altogether.”

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Changing Minds After Newtown
abstract: A budding campaign aims to encourage a cultural shift on guns after Newtown.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS

headline: Concern and Canceled Flights as Airlines Wait for 787
abstract: The grounding of Boeing’s 787 jetliner because of battery trouble has meant delayed new services and scheduling headaches for airlines.
lead_paragraph: Facing continued uncertainty over the fate of the Boeing 787 and its batteries, airlines are canceling more flights and adjusting their routes out of concern that it could be several more months before they can fly passengers on the planes again.

headline: Space Station Astronauts Will Get Their Fruit, After a Bit of a Scare
abstract: The cargo ship’s rendezvous with the International Space Station will now occur on Sunday at the earliest.
lead_paragraph: At lunchtime on Friday, things were not looking good: a rocket carrying cargo to the International Space Station was having problems with its thrusters, imperiling its ability to get where it was going.

headline: From Elephants’ Mouths, an Illicit Trail to China
abstract: Trade in elephant tusks continues to thrive in China, even as conservation groups call on Beijing to do more to crack down on the slaughter of African elephants.
lead_paragraph: PUZHAI, China — Chinese investors have anointed it “white gold.” Carvers and collectors prefer the term “organic gemstone.” Smugglers, however, use a gruesomely straightforward name for the recently harvested African elephant tusks that find their way to this remote trading outpost on the Vietnamese border.

headline: Skin and Earth, Suddenly Unrecognizable
abstract: “Terra Incognita,” an art exhibition at the College of New Rochelle, displays familiar surfaces in unfamiliar ways.
lead_paragraph: Despite the name, “Terra Incognita,” a new exhibition at Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle, is not a show that limits itself to depicting unknown lands.

headline: On Revis, the Jets Can Best Afford to Wait and See
abstract: Cornerback Darrelle Revis, recovering from a torn knee ligament, wants a new contract, but his trade value will not increase until he proves himself on the field.
lead_paragraph: Either Darrelle Revis will play for the Jets in 2013, or he won’t. The simplicity of that statement obscures a complicated problem, one that will lord over the team until it is resolved, be it in six days, six weeks or six months.

headline: France: Le Monde Picks First Woman for a Top Post
abstract: Natalie Nougayrède, 46, was chosen Friday as the first woman to serve as both director and editor of Le Monde, France’s most prominent newspaper, and its Web site.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Nougayrède, 46, was chosen Friday as the first woman to serve as both director and editor of Le Monde, France’s most prominent newspaper, and its Web site. Ms. Nougayrède, the diplomatic correspondent and former Moscow bureau chief for the newspaper, was elected by the staff after being nominated by the principal owners. She succeeds Érik Izraelewicz, who died suddenly in November and who had first combined the jobs of director and editor. Sylvie Kauffmann was the first woman to serve as editor of Le Monde, under the director Éric Fottorino.

headline: Soccer in the Blood, Pork on the Platter
abstract: At the Strand Smokehouse in Astoria, Queens, four soccer teammates and a friend gathered to eat off platters covered in butcher paper.
lead_paragraph: With its smoky aromas, rough-hewed picnic tables and numerous bourbons poured straight from the barrel, the Strand Smokehouse, at 25-27 Broadway, brings a hint of down-home flavor to the traditionally Greek precincts of Astoria, Queens. Half barbecue joint, half beer garden, the Strand, which opened two months ago, serves a pan-regional mash-up of ribs, smoked chicken and pulled pork accompanied by local craft beers and a whiskey selection that could easily make a transplanted good old boy nostalgic for home. While the large backyard was still closed for the season last week, the cavernous main room was filled with an assortment of sticky-fingered families, curious local residents and at least one heterogeneous party of first-time visitors.

headline: Corrections: March 2, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 2, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Things Worth Waiting For
abstract: Bowled over by Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Holy moly, this one by Barry C. Silk took my breath away. I feel energized and beaten up at the same time, and as the “Top Gear” host Jeremy Clarkson once said, “the last time I had this much fun, furniture got broken.” This one got me RARIN’ TO GO.

headline: More Reasons to Enter Arena
abstract: A Barclays Center mobile app lets basketball fans watch close up, make their own replays and buy food without waiting in the usual lines.
lead_paragraph: Bigger and clearer televisions keep bringing couch-bound sports fans closer to the action, while tickets to live events are hardly getting any cheaper. This prompts the question: When will it make sense just to stay home?

headline: Classic Toys Redesigned to Traverse Generations
abstract: To Hasbro, there is no one too young or too old to play with a Transformers robot, watch a Transformers television show or play a Transformers video game.
lead_paragraph: To Hasbro, no one is too young or too old to play with a Transformers robot, watch a Transformers television show or play a Transformers video game.

headline: Poison Pill Politics
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Our political system is broken beyond anything even remotely resembling a functional government.
lead_paragraph: The deadline has passed. The sequester is in effect. And Congress is not in session.

headline: A Divide on Voting Rights in a Town Where Blood Spilled
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: McComb, Miss., was a battleground in the war for voting rights in the South. Residents disagree over whether their state and eight others need federal approval for changes.
lead_paragraph: McCOMB, Miss. — In the refined air of the United States Supreme Court, the questions posed by justices on Wednesday seemed so big as to be unanswerable: Are parts of the Voting Rights Act an unfair infringement on state sovereignty? How different is the South these days from other regions, and from itself in bloody years past?

headline: A Good Night for Fishnets
abstract: Ron Maxwell has done over 1,000 performances as Brad in “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Ron Maxwell has done over 1,000 performances as Brad in “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” in Chelsea.

headline: World Baseball Classic Explained
abstract: The three-round tournament starts with 16 teams divided into four pools.
lead_paragraph: The three-round tournament starts with 16 teams divided into four pools.

headline: Gaza: Gunfire Erupts Along Border With Israel
abstract: Palestinians fired at an Israeli military jeep, hitting the vehicle but causing no injuries, and three Palestinian protesters were wounded by Israeli fire, the Israeli military said.
lead_paragraph: Palestinians fired at an Israeli military jeep along the Gaza border on Friday, hitting the vehicle but causing no injuries, and three Palestinian protesters were wounded by Israeli fire during disturbances along the border fence, the Israeli military said. The confrontations erupted three days after Gaza militants fired a rocket into Israel for the first time since a cease-fire agreement took hold in November. In addition, hundreds of Palestinians held rallies in several locations across the West Bank to protest the death of a Palestinian prisoner in an Israeli jail last weekend. The prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Salam Fayyad, was hustled away from a protest in Bilin after he inhaled tear gas fired by Israeli soldiers, and two Palestinians were injured elsewhere, according to Palestinian reports. The military said that it had used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse rioters and that one soldier had been injured by a rock.

headline: Doing the Time Warp, Again
abstract: Ron Maxwell, an auxiliary New York City police officer by day, has a nocturnal identity that involves dressing in drag for “The Rocky Horror Picture Show.”
lead_paragraph: Dammit, Janet’s getting tough to lift.

headline: A Recruiter at Heart Is Able to Build a Winner at Any Level
abstract: Northwest Florida State was impressed by the former Tennessee assistant Steve Forbes’s track record of recruiting impact players. He has built them into a title contender.
lead_paragraph: When the Tennessee men’s basketball team arrived in Atlanta for the Southeastern Conference tournament in 2011, its season was spiraling out of control. The Volunteers had limped to an 8-8 record in league play, and the N.C.A.A.’s Committee on Infractions had recently released a 26-page notice of allegations regarding the basketball program.

headline: Death of Russian Adoptee Was Accidental, Texas Says
abstract: Officials investigating the death of a 3-year-old boy adopted from Russia said that they had found no evidence to support the filing of criminal charges against the boy’s parents.
lead_paragraph: Texas officials investigating the death of a 3-year-old boy who had been adopted from Russia said Friday that they had found no evidence to support the filing of criminal charges against the boy’s parents. The death of the boy, Max Alan Shatto, prompted outrage in Russia, which late last year banned adoptions by American citizens. Russian leaders had accused the boy’s adoptive mother of fatally beating him. Two Ector County officials — Sheriff Mark Donaldson and District Attorney Bobby Bland — said that after an autopsy, the medical examiner had ruled that Max’s death was accidental. They said that he had been treated for a behavioral disorder that caused him to injure himself and that the bruising that had been found on his body was consistent with the kind of self-injury associated with the disorder. The boy’s adoptive mother, Laura Shatto, told investigators that she had left Max and his brother playing outside unattended and returned to find Max lying on the ground, unresponsive. He died later that day at a hospital. The United States Embassy in Moscow called the boy’s death a tragedy, but added that Texas officials “worked diligently and professionally to examine the evidence concerning Max’s death.”

headline: Testimony Outlines Workday of Officer Accused of Grisly Plot
abstract: Gilberto Valle’s supervisor was asked on the witness stand about his job description, his access to equipment, his routine and even his meal preferences.
lead_paragraph: It would be an innocuous enough question in most criminal trials:

headline: Argentina: U.S. Court Orders Debt Repayment Plan
abstract: A United States court of appeals gave Argentina until March 29 to submit a plan for the repayment of $1.33 billion in debt that the country defaulted on 11 years ago.
lead_paragraph: A United States court of appeals gave Argentina until March 29 to submit a plan for the repayment of $1.33 billion in debt that the country defaulted on 11 years ago. N.M.L. Capital, a subsidiary of the New York-based hedge fund Elliott Management, is leading a lawsuit among bondholders who refused Argentina’s 2005 and 2010 debt swaps. Ninety-three percent of creditors agreed to the restructuring in which debt stemming from Argentina’s $100 billion default was exchanged for new issues at 35 cents on the dollar. A judge ruled last fall in favor of creditors, saying that Argentina could not service only some of its debt, and that it had the “financial wherewithal” to pay in full. Speaking to Congress on Friday, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner said Argentina would pay “these vulture funds” but only according to the same terms and conditions agreed upon for the other creditors. A spokesman for Elliott Management declined to comment.

headline: When Fans Flood Floor, Ritual Trumps Peril
abstract: Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski was critical of the risk to his team after Virginia fans stormed the court on Thursday, but the phenomenon is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: There is no known provenance for the phrase “storming the court,” but for as long as there have been basketball courts, there have been faithful fans itching to celebrate significant wins on them with one another and their conquering heroes.

headline: Ruses Used by F.B.I. Are Recounted in Cannibal Case
abstract: The authorities lied to Officer Gilberto Valle to get him to step out into the hallway of his apartment complex, and at least once while they were interrogating him, a federal agent testified.
lead_paragraph: Last October, as agents with the Federal Bureau of Investigation prepared to arrest Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, they decided to use a ruse — a standard and legal law enforcement technique. He was, after all, a trained officer and had a gun. Agents arrived at his apartment complex in Queens, and one called him on the phone, saying that his car had been hit on the street.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for March 1, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 1, 2013

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about a short-lived monorail in the city, and the birthplace of Batman.
lead_paragraph: Q. I heard there used to be a monorail running out to City Island. Whatever happened to it?

headline: License for Operator of Chinatown Buses Is Pulled
abstract: The action by the Department of Transportation may signal an end to the Fung Wah bus service between Manhattan and Boston.
lead_paragraph: The shutdown of the Fung Wah bus service between the Chinatown neighborhoods of Manhattan and Boston may have become permanent on Friday when federal officials revoked the company’s license to operate.

headline: ‘White Gold’ in China
abstract: High Chinese market demands leads some to wonder if the only way to curb ivory poaching in Africa is to ban ivory.
lead_paragraph: High Chinese market demands leads some to wonder if the only way to curb ivory poaching in Africa is to ban ivory.

headline: Knicks Start Busy Stretch by Handling the Wizards
abstract: To outlast the Wizards, the Knicks leaned on Carmelo Anthony for scoring and their defense to contain John Wall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a night of change and midseason tinkering, the Knicks leaned on their one constant and avenged one of their most humiliating defeats of the season.

headline: Flacco and Baltimore Agree on a Long-Term Contract
abstract: Baltimore quarterback Joe Flacco, the most valuable player of the Super Bowl, reached a deal with the team that was expected to be worth about $20 million a year.
lead_paragraph: Joe Flacco, who turned down a contract offer last summer because he believed he was worth more than the Baltimore Ravens were offering — and then led them to a Super Bowl championship — cashed in Friday when he agreed to terms on a new long-term deal, the team said.

headline: Officer Stabbed in Head in ’12 Gets Praise and a Promotion
abstract: The police commissioner said Detective Eder Loor’s courage “reflects proudly on every member of this department.”
lead_paragraph: Eder Loor approached the podium slowly on Friday, his gait tentative. Moments later, he raised a white-gloved hand as he was sworn in as a New York City police detective. Behind him, a crowd of officers, in freshly pressed blue uniforms, erupted in applause and rose to their feet. His wife wiped tears from her eyes.

headline: Taking Cookies (and Hugs) to the Theater
abstract: For the Tony Award-winning producer Daryl Roth, Sunday is a day to sit on a bench in the park, see a morning movie or visit the cast and crew of her shows.
lead_paragraph: Even on Sundays, the theater takes center stage for the Tony Award-winning producer Daryl Roth. With her newest production, the musical “Kinky Boots,” starting previews at the Al Hirschfeld Theater this Sunday, a visit with its cast and crew is a priority. But Ms. Roth, 68, who has produced seven Pulitzer Prize-winning plays and serves as artistic director of her two Off Broadway theaters, also makes time for the other joys in her life, which include her grandchildren and her dog. She lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Steven, 71, the chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, and their 14-year-old Lowchen, Lucy.

headline: Safety Board Calls Copter in East River Crash Overloaded
abstract: Investigators reported that the pilot was expecting fewer passengers.
lead_paragraph: The pilot of a helicopter that crashed into the East River in 2011 failed to properly account for the weight of his passengers, three of whom died after being trapped underwater, federal safety officials concluded in a report released on Friday.

headline: Down by 20, Nets Can’t Quite Close the Gap
abstract: Deron Williams tried mightily against the team that courted him in the off-season, but the Nets had dug themselves into too deep a hole.
lead_paragraph: Deron Williams opened and closed Friday’s game against Dallas playing like a motivated superstar, one the Mavericks openly coveted and the Nets paid handsomely to keep this past off-season.

headline: The Lower East Side, in 1980 and 2010
abstract: Toward the end of 1979, Brian Rose and Edward Fausty began roaming the neighborhood, carrying a Japanese view camera attached to a tripod. Mr. Rose revisited the area 30 years later.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of 1979, Brian Rose and Edward Fausty began roaming the neighborhood, carrying a Japanese view camera attached to a tripod. Mr. Rose revisited the area 30 years later.

headline: Former Dot-com Millionaire Guilty of Selling Drugs
abstract: Thirteen years ago, Jennifer Sultan and her colleagues sold a technology company for $70 million; on Friday, she got a four-year sentence for selling oxycodone and conspiring to sell a gun.
lead_paragraph: At the height of dot-com mania 13 years ago, Jennifer Sultan and a few colleagues sold their small technology company for $70 million in stock and cash. She and her boyfriend rented a large house in the Hamptons for the summer and bought a spacious loft near Union Square.

headline: A 30-Year Time Lapse of the Lower East Side
abstract: Brian Rose and Edward Fausty documented the neighborhood, concentrating not so much on the people, but on the structures and shapes that made up the local landscape.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of 1979, Brian Rose and Edward Fausty began roaming the Lower East Side of Manhattan with a Japanese view camera attached to a tripod. New York City’s fiscal crisis was a fresh memory, and gentrification had not yet arrived. Tenements seemed to burn daily. But the frontierlike nature of the neighborhood and the availability of cheap rent encouraged an explosion of creativity.

headline: Guard Said She Was at Post Before Truck Killed Boy, 6
abstract: Flavia Roman is unlikely to face criminal charges but may face administrative charges for not being at her post when Amar Diarrassouba was hit.
lead_paragraph: A school crossing guard who was not at an intersection in East Harlem when a truck hit and killed a 6-year-old boy had called into the police station just before the accident to report being on the job, the police said on Friday.

headline: Something New for Yankees: Few Victories, Little Panic
abstract: There was a time when a sloppy 1-7 start, such as this Yankee team is off to, would have led to an outraged owner.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — There may be nothing as meaningless as the results of spring training games, especially only one week into the exhibition schedule. And there is no proven correlation between wins and losses at this time of year and what happens in October, so Yankee fans do not need to panic. At least not yet.

headline: Outside Box, Federal Judges Offer Addicts a Free Path
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: In federal courts in eight states including New York, “drug courts” for some defendants in nonviolent crimes have been embraced by a judiciary bristling at rigid sentencing guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Federal judges around the country are teaming up with prosecutors to create special treatment programs for drug-addicted defendants who would otherwise face significant prison time, an effort intended to sidestep drug laws widely seen as inflexible and overly punitive.

headline: Venezuelan Official Confirms Chávez Receiving Cancer Treatments
abstract: President Hugo Chávez is receiving chemotherapy or radiation treatments, a government official said Friday. Mr. Chávez has not been seen in public since his Dec. 11 surgery in Havana.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez is receiving chemotherapy or radiation treatments in the aftermath of his most recent cancer surgery, a government official said for the first time on Friday.

headline: Remember Misogyny?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Kidnapping', 'Sex Crimes', 'Cannibalism', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The trial of Gilberto Valle, accused of plotting to kidnap, cook and eat female victims, should serve as a summons to broaden our discussions about the corners of the Internet where violent notions about women flourish.
lead_paragraph: If you spent any time in Manhattan during the 1980s, particularly on the Upper West Side, you are likely to recall a recurrent vignette of dissent — the presence of a thin, wiry woman with hair that made emphatic her seriousness, who colonized the sidewalks in what appeared to be a full-time avocation as a crusader against pornography and other forms of sexual degradation. To make her point, she would often have with her a blowup of a notorious Hustler cover that featured an image of a woman who had been plunged headfirst into a meat grinder. Her approach was hardly solicitous; she demanded of those who passed by, “Sign the petition!”

headline: Battle for the Soul of a Park
abstract: Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick’s opposition to a luxury housing plan has her seen as both an obstructionist and a protector of Hudson River Park.
lead_paragraph: In the grand dream of Hudson River Park, the five-mile greensward stretching down Manhattan’s West Side from 59th Street to Battery Place, Pier 40, a hulking structure at the foot of West Houston Street, was supposed to be a cash cow, providing millions of dollars annually in revenue from parking and commercial development.

headline: Mets Publicist Embraces Social Media With Fervor and Occasional Typo
abstract: Jay Horwitz’s posts on Twitter are a mixture of untold stories and recurring jokes about the Mets.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Think of the stories Jay Horwitz could tell if he ever decided to write a memoir.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 2
abstract: Concern about ivory trade; joblessness rises in Europe; challenge for Syrian rebel leader; and Swiss consider compensation laws.
lead_paragraph: NEWS To the growing outrage of international conservation groups and the embarrassment of Chinese law enforcement agencies, the international ivory trade is booming, with much of the smuggled ivory ending up as statuary and jewelry in Chinese showrooms and private collections. Critics say the Chinese government is not doing enough to stem the illicit ivory trade, which has exploded in the five years since conservationists and governments agreed to a program of limited ivory sales intended to stifle poaching and revive a centuries-old handicraft. In the past year, more than 32,000 elephants have been illegally killed, according to the Born Free Foundation, a wildlife organization, and conservationists say the vast majority of ivory sold in China is of questionable origin. Dan Levin reports from Puzhai, China.

headline: Rising Star in Nascar Is Calm After Wild Crash
abstract: A rookie driver on Nascar’s Nationwide Series, Kyle Larson is eager to race again after being involved in last week’s crash at Daytona International Speedway.
lead_paragraph: Mike and Janet Larson were sitting in the upper deck of the front-stretch grandstand at Daytona International Speedway last Saturday afternoon when they saw a 12-car crash in the final lap of a Nascar Nationwide Series race. The crash began almost right in front of them.

headline: Right to Play Is a Victory for a Texas School
abstract: Basketball players from the Robert M. Beren Academy in Houston won the right to compete in a state tournament without having to play on the Jewish Sabbath. Then they had to win their games on the court.
lead_paragraph: When he woke up Friday, Zachary Yoshor, 17, a senior at the Robert M. Beren Academy in Houston and a star player on the school’s basketball team, said he was not nervous about the state semifinal game looming for his team that afternoon in Fort Worth.

headline: Late Night With Ben Bernanke
abstract: Mr. Bernanke, speaking at a conference in San Francisco, said the Federal Reserve’s stimulus was working and he warned of the risk of raising interest rates too soon.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, picked an unusual time to offer his most recent defense of the Fed’s campaign to stimulate the economy: 7 p.m. on a Friday night in San Francisco, 10 p.m. back home on the East Coast.

headline: Division III Postseason Changes Create Long Wait Until Championship Game
abstract: A 41-day road from bracket pairings to a championship has drawn criticism from coaches.
lead_paragraph: David Hixon, the coach of second-ranked Amherst, had mixed emotions when he saw the draw for the Division III men’s basketball tournament, which begins Saturday.

headline: The Crime of His Childhood
abstract: In 1973, a man committed an unthinkable act against a Brooklyn boy named Josh Miele. Still haunted decades later, a neighbor searched for answers.
lead_paragraph: On an October afternoon 40 years ago, on a beautiful block in Park Slope, Brooklyn, a crime occurred in a split second that was as permanent as it was cruel. Grown-ups tried to make sense of it, even use it as a cautionary tale for their children, but in the end, many just put it out of their minds. How could they not? It was just too awful, its lessons too hard to fathom.

headline: N.H.L.’s Request for Video Rights Creates Quandary for Olympics
abstract: As talks continue over whether N.H.L. players will go to the Sochi Games, there is concern that other leagues may ask the I.O.C. for the same concessions.
lead_paragraph: Talks between the N.H.L. and the International Olympic Committee over whether the league will send its players next year to Sochi, Russia, hinge on one overarching issue: if the I.O.C. grants the N.H.L. concessions for shutting down its business at midseason, other leagues that send players to the Olympics may ask for the same.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE AMAZING SPIDER-MAN (2012) Five years after “Spider-Man 3,” the director Marc Webb rebooted the franchise with new stars — Andrew Garfield, above, as Peter Parker; Emma Stone as his girlfriend, Gwen Stacy; and Martin Sheen and Sally Field as Uncle Ben and Aunt May — and an updated origin story centered on a bioengineering company, Oscorp. And along comes a spider. “The latest post-atomic-age Spider-Man has been updated with a skateboard and a hoodie, but it’s unclear whom he speaks to (beyond Sony’s shareholders), and for what reason,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Garfield and Ms. Stone are by far the movie’s greatest assets and when they’re together on screen, they add warmth and a believable closeness to the industrial mix.” Still, “this ‘Spider-Man’ feels like one of those unnecessary software versions, more Spider-Man 1.5 than Spider-Man reborn,” she said. “Spider-Man’s ethos remains — with great power comes great responsibility — but these days you can’t see his superhero heart and soul for his branding.”

headline: Philippine Leader Calls for Surrender of Group in Malaysia
abstract: President Benigno S. Aquino III made the plea a day after the group lost several members in a violent clash with Malaysian police officers.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Philippine president, Benigno S. Aquino III, called on Saturday for the surrender of an armed Muslim clan that took over a Malaysian village, making the plea a day after the group lost several members in a violent clash with Malaysian police officers.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: Demands for a discussion over the recent execution of Muhammad Afzal, who was convicted in a deadly attack on India’s Parliament, rocked the state legislature on Friday, according to an IANS report on the NDTV Web site. The call for debate was initiated by the opposition People’s Democratic Party, and it found support from the governing National Conference party in the state.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Environmental Warning Fatigue Sets in
abstract: Global concern for major environmental issues is at an all-time low, according to a poll of more than 22,000 people in 22 countries.
lead_paragraph: Record levels of industrial smog? A dwindling number of fish in the world’s oceans? A 4° Celsius warming in global temperatures by the end of the century?

headline: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Piece Goods and Misty Irreverence
abstract: Junya Watanabe gave his customers a nice bunch of clothes along a familiar story line. Haider Ackerman’s show began in a fog.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Junya Watanabe’s shows are always held on Saturday morning, prompting the usual sullen greeting, “Hello, and where’s the coffee?” Mr. Watanabe provides. He also gave his customers a nice bunch of clothes along familiar Watanabe story lines. These included couture-shaped dresses and loose-back jackets that combined leather and tweed, motorcycle jackets mixed with knitting, and cute, low-riding patchwork jeans. Among the fresher looks were skimmy dresses made from oblong scraps of plaid wool and silk, and worn over black tights.

headline: The Gun Report: March 2, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: March 1 marked the 19th anniversary of the shooting death of Ari Halberstam, a 16-year-old Brooklyn Yeshiva student, who was traveling by van on the Brooklyn Bridge with his fellow students when an anti-Semite who’d been following them fired 18 bullets into the van, using a Cobray submachine gun and a Glock. Halberstam was killed. The gunman, Rashid Baz, admitted last year that he targeted the boys because they were Jews. The FBI classified the act as terrorism.

headline: Viktor & Rolf: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Across-the-Board Cuts Take Effect, but Their Impact Is Not Immediately Felt
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: President Obama formally triggered the across-the-board reductions late Friday night after failing to persuade Congressional Republicans to replace them with a mix of cuts and tax increases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — University officials, city managers, day care providers and others spent Saturday assessing how they would absorb their part of the across-the-board cuts in federal spending that began taking effect over the weekend.

headline: A Farewell to Green
abstract: Can green news be covered without a Green blog?
lead_paragraph: 12:08 p.m. | Updated |With the posting Friday evening of “A Blog’s Adieu,” The New York Times shut down the Green blog, which, through 5,364 posts, had been an excellent aggregator of environmental news and analysis that didn’t fit in the flow of conventional articles.

headline: Self-destructive Europe
abstract: Two grim readings.
lead_paragraph: I just wanted to flag two important articles on Europe. First, Simon Wren-Lewis reminds us that while extreme austerity is being imposed on Europe’s periphery, the core has also pursued contractionary fiscal policies. Here’s the IMF’s estimate of the cyclically adjusted primary balance — a measure of what the non-interest budget balance would have been at full employment:

headline: Israeli Premier Gets Extension to Form a Coalition but Faces Turmoil
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel received a two-week extension to form a governing coalition, a situation complicated by an unexpected alliance of two rising political stars.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s president on Saturday granted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu a two-week extension to form a governing coalition, a task complicated by mathematics and chemistry.

headline: Viktor & Rolf in Black and White
abstract: Viktor & Rolf presented a fall show on Saturday that was minimal on tricks, and also minimal on lengths.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Continuing in the restrained direction of their last collection, the designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf presented a fall show on Saturday that was minimal on tricks, and also minimal on lengths. The only thing that caused a ruckus was the arrival of the actress Jessica Chastain in the front row.

headline: Welfare for the Medical-Industrial Complex
abstract: Wasting taxpayer money is OK, as long as it’s on corporations.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Brill’s long piece about medical costs has brought forth a mixture of praise and annoyance from health-care economics experts, including Aaron Carroll and Uwe Reinhardt; they’ve been screaming for years that our medical system charges too much, and so they’re both gratified and annoyed to see a major-media piece confirming what they’ve been saying all along.

headline: Sequestration’s Impact
abstract: Virginia’s economy will be among the hardest hit by the federal government’s $85 billion in spending cuts to military and domestic programs.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s economy will be among the hardest hit by the federal government’s $85 billion in spending cuts to military and domestic programs.

headline: Mets Outfield Prospect Builds a Highlight Reel
abstract: Matt den Dekker, a 25-year-old center field prospect, has lit up television screens and computer monitors through a growing highlight reel of leaping grabs and diving catches.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Though he has yet to play an inning of major league baseball for the Mets, Matt den Dekker has already begun to make a name for himself among the team’s fans.

headline: For Yankees’ Suzuki, Spring Challenges Include Alligators
abstract: For the first time in his career, Ichiro Suzuki is training in a new environment, no small matter for a master technician who takes a scientific approach to virtually everything he does.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — For each of his previous 12 years in major league baseball, Ichiro Suzuki made his spring training home in Peoria, Ariz., where the dry desert air allowed balls to carry, and his family’s house made it a most comfortable experience.

headline: Experts Want More Studies of Diet’s Role for the Heart
abstract: A study has infused the field of cardiovascular medicine with optimism, as scientists are calling for similarly rigorous studies of other popular diets.
lead_paragraph: This is a watershed moment in the field of nutrition, medical experts say. For the first time, researchers have shown that a diet can have an effect as powerful as drugs in preventing what really matters to patients — heart attacks, and strokes and deaths from cardiovascular disease.

headline: With Bernard Lagat
abstract: Bernard Lagat, the holder of several American track records, discusses his preparations for his first long-distance road race, the 13.1-mile NYC Half, on March 17.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Lagat has been so successful on the track for so long that he has been able to delay running road races, a transition that Mo Farah of Britain and other middle-distance specialists have been making. In February, Lagat, 38, set an American indoor two-mile record at the Millrose Games, adding to his many national records. But days later, Lagat announced that he would run his first long-distance road race, the 13.1-mile NYC Half, on March 17. He spoke recently by telephone from his home in Tucson, where he trains with the distance runner Abdi Abdirahman. KEN BELSON

headline: Pitcher’s Stare Is Menacing, but Fastball Is Feared More
abstract: The Braves’ Craig Kimbrel is a hitter’s nightmare: his fastball, reaching into the upper 90s, has an extra gear. Last season, he struck out more than half the batters he faced.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — It cannot be detected by a radar gun, and it would not make sense to a physicist. But to the sharpened eyes of a major league hitter, one pitcher’s 98-mile-per-hour fastball can behave much differently from another’s. And when that pitcher is Craig Kimbrel of the Atlanta Braves, it does not seem fair.

headline: Variety: Takeaway Crossword
abstract: A different sort of crossword by Matt Ginsberg.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Note Pad Alert! One letter of the alphabet has been removed from each clue every time it appears in the clue. If you remove this letter from the clue’s answer, the remaining letters will themselves spell a word, which is to be entered in the grid. For example, the clue “Be a sni*ch” would suggest “Be a snitch” with a missing T, leading to the answer TATTLE, which, with the T’s removed, would be entered in the grid as ALE. Every answer in the grid is a regular word or name except as indicated.

headline: Francis Lieber and the Law of War
abstract: The German immigrant who defined the modern rules of fighting.
lead_paragraph: The philosopher and legal scholar Francis Lieber was born in 1798 in Germany, and as a young man was wounded in the final skirmishes of the Napoleonic wars. He emigrated to the United States in 1827, after twice being imprisoned by Prussian authorities for his pro-reform political activities. A respected jurist in his home country, he eventually became a professor at Columbia, a few years before the outbreak of the Civil War.

headline: Two Afghan Boys Accidentally Killed by NATO Helicopter
abstract: Two boys out collecting firewood with their donkeys were killed by weapons fired from a NATO helicopter, Afghan and American military officials announced on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two boys out collecting firewood with their donkeys were killed by weapons fired from a NATO helicopter, Afghan and American military officials announced Saturday.

headline: Nothing ‘Mid’ About Gonzaga
abstract: Gonzaga Coach Mark Few has stayed to construct a program that year after year is the equal of the best in the major conferences.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Trophies cover most of Mark Few’s office. They rest behind the desk, on bookshelves, near the black leather couches and the photographs of Few with fishing rod in hand. When available space shrank, he simply lined them on the floor.

headline: Coaches Who Have Been There Before
abstract: Mike Petke, the Red Bulls’ new leader, is, like many of his peers, an American who played in the league.
lead_paragraph: Thierry Henry flashed his Cheshire cat grin when asked about playing for a rookie coach.

headline: Kerry Is Hoping to Nudge Egypt Toward Reforms

abstract: John Kerry made his first trip to an Arab capital as secretary of state on Saturday, hoping to prod Egyptian politicians to show a measure of political peace and a commitment to economic change.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry told Egypt’s political and business leaders on Saturday that it was urgent their country institute economic reforms and satisfy the conditions the International Monetary Fund has set for a $4.8 billion loan.

lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Players May Again Reject N.H.L. Realignment Plan
abstract: For the second time in 14 months, the N.H.L. is out with plan to better balance its conferences. But some of the issues that scuttled the initial proposal remain.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in 14 months, the N.H.L. has drawn up a plan to realign its clubs and devise a new playoff format. It is quite possible that, for a second time, questions raised by the Players’ Association will prevent its implementation.

headline: Hungary Tries a Dash of Taxes to Promote Healthier Eating Habits
abstract: In a trend seen across Europe, Hungary has imposed taxes on salt, sugar and the ingredients in energy drinks, hoping to raise revenues and spur healthier eating habits.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Gizella Beres Devenyi, who works behind the cash register at the delicatessen Zena in a working-class neighborhood here, says it is easy to see Hungary’s new salt tax at work.

headline: For the Sabres, Vanek Is Behind the Wheel While Hodgson Navigates
abstract: The Buffalo Sabres have a knack for winning when Thomas Vanek and Cody Hodgson are on the score sheet.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Vanek drives the Buffalo bus.

headline: Spill in China Underlines Environmental Concerns
keywords: ['Water', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Environment', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Chemicals', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: A conflict over a recent chemical spill at a factory has drawn attention to growing problems with environmental degradation and officials’ reluctance to take on polluters.
lead_paragraph: HANDAN, China — The first warning came in the form of dead fish floating in a river.

headline: Walking the Country as a Spiritual Quest
abstract: A growing number of pilgrims are lacing up boots and sneakers to walk across America.
lead_paragraph: KEN ILGUNAS, who is 29 years old, arrived at the Gulf Coast town of Port Arthur, Tex., last month after hiking 1,700 miles from Alberta, Canada, crossing through the American heartland. On his arrival, he met a big-hearted Texan who knew of him from reading his blog and generously offered him dinner at his home and a place to stay for the night. “To walk across this country is to fall in love with mankind,” Mr. Ilgunas said.

headline: We Are What We Quote
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Quotations and Proverbs', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A good quotation can serve as a model for a writer’s own work.
lead_paragraph: Quotes are the mental furniture of my life. From certain angles my inner landscape resembles a gallery hung with half-recalled citations, the rags and tag-ends of a lifetime of reading and listening. They can be anything at all, the exquisitely chiseled perceptions of poets and philosophers or the blurts of unscheduled truth-telling by public figures caught in the spotlight (the former Jersey City mayor Frank Hague’s “I am the law” or Richard Nixon’s “I’m not a crook”); the punch lines of 1930s comedians or the curtain lines of Jacobean dramatists; or words of wisdom or anguish or ridiculous humor, or simply, for instance, M.F.K. Fisher’s recollection of “the potato chips I ate slowly one November afternoon in 1936, in the bar of the Lausanne Palace.” They are the dangling threads that memory can latch onto when everything else goes blank.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: A Cure for ‘Senioritis’?
abstract: Readers discuss options for the last year of high school.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss options for the last year of high school.

headline: The Scary Hidden Stressor
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'Wheat', 'Weather']
abstract: The brutal winter drought in China is connected to a global wheat shortage is connected to the Arab Spring is connected to ...
lead_paragraph: IN her introduction to a compelling new study, “The Arab Spring and Climate Change,” released Thursday, the Princeton scholar Anne-Marie Slaughter notes that crime shows often rely on the concept of a “stressor.” A stressor, she explains, is a “sudden change in circumstances or environment that interacts with a complicated psychological profile in a way that leads a previously quiescent person to become violent.” The stressor is never the only explanation for the crime, but it is inevitably an important factor in a complex set of variables that lead to a disaster. “The Arab Spring and Climate Change” doesn’t claim that climate change caused the recent wave of Arab revolutions, but, taken together, the essays make a strong case that the interplay between climate change, food prices (particularly wheat) and politics is a hidden stressor that helped to fuel the revolutions and will continue to make consolidating them into stable democracies much more difficult.

headline: Tony Kirkham
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: The Royal Botanic Gardens’ arborist on bluegrass, fly-fishing and polar bears.
lead_paragraph: Tony Kirkham is the chief arborist at the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew outside London. He is responsible for the more than 14,000 trees growing there. A sort of Indiana Jones of plants, Mr. Kirkham also travels the world to hunt down exceptional specimens.

headline: Promises, Promises at the New York Fed
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: A secret agreement shows that in exchange for $43 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York agreed to testify on Bank of America’s behalf in a battle over fraud claims.
lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago, I wrote a column about a secret agreement struck in July 2012 by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Bank of America. The existence of the confidential deal was disclosed recently in court filings, which showed the New York Fed releasing Bank of America from all fraud claims on mortgage securities the Fed had bought as part of the government’s rescue of the American International Group in 2008.

headline: In Benedict’s Resignation, the Potential to Place Limits on Future Popes
abstract: Vatican experts and some church leaders said Pope Benedict XVI’s decision to quit could set limits for future popes and make them more subject to pressure from critics.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The resignation of Pope Benedict XVI, who last week renounced what for nearly 600 years has been a lifelong office, will reverberate for years to come and could change the nature of the modern papacy, starting with the election of his successor.

headline: A Class Action in the Public Interest
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Editorials']
abstract: By letting a securities fraud case proceed, the Supreme Court embraced an important principle.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Connecticut’s public employee retirement plans brought a class-action lawsuit against Amgen, one of the world’s largest biotechnology companies, accusing it of securities fraud. Last week, in a 6-to-3 decision affirming a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, the Supreme Court allowed the suit to proceed, giving the retirement plans the chance to prove their case.

headline: Location, Location, Location
abstract: Companies will need to finesse their policies on telecommuting by employees.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Mayer, chief executive at Yahoo, may not have set out to start a national conversation about working from home when she decided that employees at that Internet company must come into the office. But she has done just that. In a memo, Ms. Mayer’s top human resources executive wrote: “Speed and quality are often sacrificed when we work from home. We need to be one Yahoo!, and that starts with physically being together.”

headline: The White House Joins the Cash Grab
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: A new advocacy group debases the presidency by trolling for unlimited corporate money.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to applaud the nonprofit group now spending nearly $100,000 on ads to pressure Republican lawmakers to accept gun-control measures. The group is fighting a well-financed and powerful corporate gun lobby that has never hesitated to spend millions to get its way in Congress.

headline: Russians Renew Fury After Death of Adopted Boy in Texas Is Ruled Accidental
abstract: Texas officials said that so far they had found no reason to file criminal charges against the adoptive mother of a Russian boy.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Supporters of a Russian law banning adoptions by Americans reacted with renewed fury and derision on Saturday after Texas officials said that so far they had found no reason to file criminal charges against the adoptive mother of a 3-year-old boy from Russia who died under mysterious circumstances in January.

lead_paragraph: When ESPN recently asked Michael Jordan which current players would have been able to excel in his era, he came up with only four: LeBron James, Kobe Bryant, Tim Duncan and Dirk Nowitzki.

headline: A Word Gone Wrong
keywords: ['Minorities', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'English Language', 'Editorials']
abstract: A national campaign is raising awareness that the R-word is a slur.
lead_paragraph: This Wednesday is the fifth annual “day of awareness” in a national campaign to stop the use of the word “retarded” and its variants. As a medical label for people with intellectual and developmental disabilities, the R-word used to be neutral, clinical, incapable of giving offense. But words are mere vessels for meaning, and this one has long since been put to other uses.

abstract: Readers react to recent articles in the Sports section of The New York Times.

headline: This Story Stinks
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Online reader comments have a bigger effect on our understanding than many of us realize.
lead_paragraph: IN the beginning, the technology gods created the Internet and saw that it was good. Here, at last, was a public sphere with unlimited potential for reasoned debate and the thoughtful exchange of ideas, an enlightening conversational bridge across the many geographic, social, cultural, ideological and economic boundaries that ordinarily separate us in life, a way to pay bills without a stamp.

headline: Land of Plenty (of Government)
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Researchers have uncovered evidence that points to a bigger governmental presence in the United States than previously thought, in some cases surpassing what we find in Western Europe.
lead_paragraph: Why do European countries have lower levels of poverty and inequality than the United States? We used to think this was a result of American anti-government sentiment, which produced a government too small to redistribute income or to attend to the needs of the poor. But over the past three decades scholars have discovered that our government wasn’t as small as we thought. Historians, sociologists and political scientists have all uncovered evidence that points to a surprisingly large governmental presence in the United States throughout the 20th century and even earlier, in some cases surpassing what we find in Western Europe.

headline: Bloody Sunday, Revisited
abstract: Marching in Selma, in 1965 and again this week, in the struggle for voting rights.
lead_paragraph: March 7, 1965, became known as Bloody Sunday in the annals of the civil rights struggle in America. That day, around 500 people set out to march the 54 miles from Selma, Ala., to the state capital in Montgomery in support of what would become the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Seized Chinese Weapons Raise Concerns on Iran
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: The presence of 10 Chinese heat-seeking missiles in an arms cache seized by American and Yemeni officials sets off concerns about further regional instability.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian dhow seized off the Yemeni coast was carrying sophisticated Chinese antiaircraft missiles, a development that could signal an escalation of Iran’s support to its Middle Eastern proxies, alarming other countries in the region and renewing a diplomatic challenge to the United States.

abstract: The church is still here, despite the doubts, scandals and divisions.

headline: The Perils of Perfection
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Wearable Computing', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The dominant ideology of Silicon Valley today is: what could be disrupted should be disrupted — even death.
lead_paragraph: “WHEN your heart stops beating, you’ll keep tweeting” is the reassuring slogan greeting visitors at the Web site for LivesOn, a soon-to-launch service that promises to tweet on your behalf even after you die. By analyzing your earlier tweets, the service would learn “about your likes, tastes, syntax” and add a personal touch to all those automatically composed scribblings from the world beyond.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Viktor & Rolf
abstract: Luigi Murenu used wispy double braids to create a windblown, schoolgirl hairstyle.
lead_paragraph: Luigi Murenu, the global creative director for John Frieda, evoked the “age of innocence” with the windblown, schoolgirl hairstyle he created for Viktor & Rolf on Saturday. John Frieda Luxurious Volume Volume Building Mousse (for a slight oomph), a messy middle part, and double braids (crossed and pinned along the bottom of the hairline) were the foundation. Murenu then put his palm right at the top of the model’s head and made a turntable motion to purposefully free a few strands and create extra wispiness. He likened this look to evoking meadows of wheat, and indeed it felt fresh from the fields.

headline: The Happy Warrior Meets the Obsessive Competitor
abstract: An obsessive drive to win is often cited as a trait of those who reach the pinnacle. But perhaps LeBron James has a better model: the happy athlete.
lead_paragraph: Is anyone having more fun these days than LeBron James? As he demolishes his opposition nightly, the N.B.A.'s resident megastar has bearhugged a fan who drained a halfcourt shot, elevated the pregame dunk line into an art form and joined his Miami Heat teammates in putting together their own version of a Harlem Shake video. (James is the shirtless one wearing the crown.)

headline: A Grudge Match for Global Finance
keywords: ['Bretton Woods Agreement', 'Gold Standard (Monetary)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Economy', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: In a new book, Benn Steil describes in detail the intellectual back-and-forth that played out in 1944 at the Bretton Woods monetary conference.
lead_paragraph: “DOWNTON ABBEY” has tapped our inner Anglophile on a wide front. But Americans were not so besotted with Britain in the first half of the 20th century, when it was a powerhouse of international trade. Until World War II, Britain ran international finance to its liking, and Americans were thirsting to chop it down to size. We need to understand that to grasp the importance of the Bretton Woods monetary conference.

headline: Two Rebels, One on Pause
abstract: Rei Kawakubo wanted guests for Comme des Garçons to see the clothes in detail, so she moved the front rows closer.
lead_paragraph: Rei Kawakubo wanted guests for Comme des Garçons to see the clothes in detail, so before her show on Saturday afternoon she moved the front rows closer, narrowing the long runway in a metal-craft warehouse. You could have touched the clothes. That might have been the idea, but it was not necessary. Ms. Kawakubo’s extreme tailoring was easy to parse.

headline: Hello, I Must Be Going
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: In the tech world, where failure is seen as an opportunity for spiritual growth, some dismissed chief executives are delivering a new kind of corporate goodbye: the honest one.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Mason, founder of the daily deals site Groupon, is a big goof. He was booted last week as chief executive, but didn’t let it cramp his style. Mr. Mason’s resignation letter, which he tweeted under the entirely reasonable notion that it would leak anyway, said he was leaving to spend more time with his family, the age-old alibi of dismissed chiefs everywhere. Then he came clean: “Just kidding — I was fired today.”

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Top 10 First Basemen
abstract: As usual, the first base position is the deepest of them all. Here’s a look at Justin Sablich’s Top 10 fantasy first basemen.
lead_paragraph: As usual, the first base position is the deepest of them all. Here’s a look at Justin Sablich’s Top 10 fantasy first basemen.

headline: Bringing Music Back to School
abstract: The executive director of VH1 Save the Music Foundation, which helps schools that are facing cuts in music education budgets, says fund-raising is a creative career.
lead_paragraph: MY family lived in a working-class neighborhood of West Philadelphia. My mother sent my older sister and me to Catholic school to escape the gangs in the local public schools. My father was a mechanic at the local Ford dealer, and he, my two older brothers and I would always talk about car magazines and the latest cars. Every Christmas I’d get a radio-controlled toy car. The year the Mustang came out, I got one with working lights.

headline: Why Five Days in the Office Is Too Many
abstract: Yahoo has banned employees from working from home. But an executive at Smule Inc., an app company, disagrees with the idea that workers are always most productive when in the office.
lead_paragraph: FOR most of my professional life, I have worked from home. The freedom to work outside a traditional office was one of the main reasons I left the corporate world eight years ago, at age 23, to start a software company.

headline: Alaska Airlines, Flying Above an Industry’s Troubles
abstract: Born in rugged terrain, Alaska Airlines fortified itself — and has resisted the cycle of bankruptcy and mergers buffeting its industry.
lead_paragraph: FLYING over Alaska in the wintertime is a spectacular experience. At 35,000 feet, the state’s rugged beauty unfolds, a succession of white mountain peaks against steel-blue skies, icy lakes and frozen rivers that snake as far as the eye can see. It’s an awesome sight, wild and pristine, that glows in a thousand hues of red, orange and pink when the sun sets against the horizon.

headline: Adapting to Extreme Conditions
abstract: Alaska Airlines had the industry’s best on-time performance for the third consecutive year in 2012, despite Alaska’s harsh weather and terrain.
lead_paragraph: Alaska Airlines had the industry’s best on-time performance for the third consecutive year in 2012, despite Alaska’s harsh weather and terrain.

headline: Selling the Home Brand: A Look Inside an Elite JPMorgan Unit
abstract: While financial advisers at other firms are typically free to offer a variety of investments, JPMorgan pressures brokers to sell the bank’s own products, current and former employees say.
lead_paragraph: Everything is scripted for the brokers in an elite group at JPMorgan Chase: the sales pitches; the personal voice mail message; even the preferred desk candy, Glitterati Fruit & Berry.

headline: Seven Blurbs for Seven Biographies
abstract: Blurbing books with Samuel A. Donaldson.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the more interesting parts of the writing process is trying to find people who are willing to write what is called a blurb for your book. Blurbs are those quotes you see on the back cover that rave about what readers will find inside, and one trick to publishing a successful book — other than being J.K. Rowling — is to find people in the literary world who are impressive enough to help you move merchandise and are willing to say nice things about what you wrote. It’s not as easy as it looks.
