headline: Logan Sidelined by Elbow Pain
abstract: A magnetic resonance imaging test revealed no structural damage on Boone Logan’s left elbow, but the Yankees will rest him until his pain subsides.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Boone Logan had a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left elbow, which revealed no structural damage, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Saturday. But Logan, the Yankees left-handed relief pitcher, is still feeling pain in one spot in his elbow so he will be shut down until the pain is gone. Girardi described the elbow as tender.

headline: As Marines Exit Afghan Province, a Feeling That a Campaign Was Worth It
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: In Helmand Province, the number of violent events, from gunshots to roadside bombs, has dropped in almost every district since 2010, Marine commanders say.
lead_paragraph: CAMP LEATHERNECK, Afghanistan — On a whirlwind Christmas tour of Helmand Province in 2010, Gen. James F. Amos, the commandant of the Marine Corps, visited 11 bases in a single day. At one, thousands of Marines showed up for prime rib, dust-covered and grim-faced after weeks of dodging and delivering gunfire, seeing comrades killed, and sleeping on dirt. Helmand had become Marineistan.

headline: Sinkholes, Which Swallow Homes, Cars and People, Are Not So Rare
abstract: News reports, and videos posted on YouTube, reveal that while falling ground is uncommon, it does happen in the United States and around the world.
lead_paragraph: A sinkhole that opened under a bedroom in Florida, swallowing a man who was not recovered, has prompted new interest in the phenomenon. News reports, and videos posted on YouTube, reveal that while such disappearances are rare, the falling of ground that takes homes, cars and other items does happen in the United States and around the world.

headline: Hardy Survivor of a Vanishing Print Era Is Still Delivering the Newspaper at 93
abstract: Newt Wallace, one of eight carriers for The Winters Express, has been walking the same blocks of downtown Winters, Calif. (population about 6,600) since 1947.
lead_paragraph: In the troubled newspaper industry, where steady layoffs mean that gray-haired reporters have disappeared from newsrooms as quickly as the typewriters that preceded them, Newt Wallace, a broad-shouldered 93-year-old, has held on.

headline: An Outfield Prospect Catches Attention of the Fans
abstract: Ronnier Mustelier, with the build of Kirby Puckett, has given fans reason the cheer, especially at the plate where he’s off to a hot start.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — A new cult hero is emerging at Yankees camp in the rotund shape of Cuban defector Ronnier Mustelier, who is hitting .500 (3 for 6) in his first big league spring training.

headline: Sylvia Smith, Memoirist of the Life Banal, Dies at 67
abstract: Ms. Smith was a British secretary whose memoir “Misadventures” was seen by some as an existential masterpiece of tedium.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Smith — who dropped out of high school at 15, never married, lived most of her life in London rooming houses, never had a great adventure or suffered a great misfortune, and never read books by most accounts — began writing her memoirs in her late 40s, when illness and a government disability pension had allowed her to quit the last of a long series of secretarial jobs, most of them as a temp.

headline: Evidence of Hope and Loss During a Parade in Queens
abstract: The devastation from Hurricane Sandy, and the promise to rebuild, were inescapable during the Queens County St. Patrick’s Day Parade in the Rockaways on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: There were the usual caps dotted with shamrocks; bunting in the green, white and orange of the Irish flag; and the nasal hum of bagpipes. While some of the bands marching in the Rockaways on Saturday were from schools that had been flooded out by Hurricane Sandy and some of the spectators watching from the sidewalks were still living in temporary quarters because their homes were either badly damaged or destroyed, the Queens County St. Patrick’s Day Parade seemed to make a special effort to hew to its nearly four decades of tradition.

headline: Stanley Snadowsky, Nightclub Founder, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Snadowsky was a lawyer and music promoter who with his partner opened the Bottom Line nightclub in Greenwich Village that showcased Bruce Springsteen and Miles Davis  among others.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Snadowsky, a founder of the Bottom Line, a landmark Greenwich Village nightclub that for 30 years presented artists like Bruce Springsteen, Miles Davis and Billy Joel in a setting often described as one of New York City’s great living rooms, died on Monday in Las Vegas. He was 70.

headline: In Filing, Casino Operator Admits Likely Violation of an Antibribery Law
keywords: ['Casinos', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The violation is believed to involve former executives with Las Vegas Sands, which is controlled by Sheldon Adelson, and their efforts to expand in China.
lead_paragraph: The Las Vegas Sands Corporation, an international gambling empire controlled by the billionaire Sheldon G. Adelson, has informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that it likely violated a federal law against bribing foreign officials.

headline: Jane Wright, Oncology Pioneer, Dies at 93
abstract: Dr. Wright defied racial barriers in a profession long dominated by white men and helped found the American Society of Clinical Oncology.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jane C. Wright, a pioneering oncologist who helped elevate chemotherapy from a last resort for cancer patients to an often viable treatment option, died on Feb. 19 at her home in Guttenberg, N.J. She was 93.

headline: Recent Reductions to the Deficit
abstract: Spending cuts and new revenue from a handful of bills since 2011 are projected to reduce deficits by $3.9 trillion over the next 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Spending cuts and new revenue from a handful of bills since 2011 are projected to reduce deficits by $3.9 trillion over the next 10 years.

headline: A Star Returns as Duke Shows It’s Back
abstract: Ryan Kelly, who missed the previous 13 games with a foot injury, led third-ranked Duke to a victory at home over No. 5 Miami in a game that had a March tournament feel to it.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski did not have to worry about fans storming the court when the Blue Devils faced Miami on Saturday night in an Atlantic Coast Conference showdown. The game was at Cameron Indoor Stadium and the Crazies were not likely to do anything crazy to the Blue Devils or Krzyzewski, who was livid after Virginia fans stormed the court following a game in Charlottesville on Thursday.

headline: On Eve of Vote, Fragile Valley in Kenya Faces New Divisions
abstract: Kenya is about to hold another major election on Monday, the first since the tumult of 2007 and 2008, but the Rift Valley is still polarized.
lead_paragraph: KIAMBAA, Kenya — After another long day, Joseph Kairuri Mwangi walked back to his farmhouse shack, the late afternoon sun slanting behind him, his strides slow, his shoes muddy with rich, freshly turned earth.

headline: Kenya’s Rift Valley, Five Years After Election Violence
abstract: In 2007, the Rift Valley exploded when a disputed election set off ethnic clashes that killed hundreds of people. Thousands are still living in shacks and tents, driven off their land with nowhere to go.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, the Rift Valley exploded when a disputed election set off ethnic clashes that killed hundreds of people. Thousands are still living in shacks and tents, driven off their land with nowhere to go.

headline: Hope and Fear in Kenya's Election
abstract: Five years after ethnic violence swept through Kenya’s Rift Valley, Jeffrey Gettleman returns to see how a new election could affect the still-scarred region.
lead_paragraph: Five years after ethnic violence swept through Kenya’s Rift Valley, Jeffrey Gettleman returns to see how a new election could affect the still-scarred region.

headline: For Deaf and Hard of Hearing, the Joy of Live Music
keywords: ['Music', 'Deafness', 'Sign Language', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Lollapalooza (Music Festival)']
abstract: Barbie Parker and other emotive sign language interpreters from LotuSIGN in Austin help communicate the entire musical experience.
lead_paragraph: On the last night of the 2012 Lollapalooza music festival in Chicago, the sun set over a crowd of thousands who had stood for hours waiting to see Jack White, the headliner. A figure strode onto the stage, setting off a cascade of cheers.

headline: After Slump, Ogilvy Climbs Into Contention
abstract: When Geoff Ogilvy’s drop in the rankings kept him out of tournaments, he saw it as a “wake-up call.” At the Honda Classic, he is tied for third after three rounds.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — For the last year, Geoff Ogilvy has been telling anybody who would listen that there was nothing wrong with his game that a few more dropped putts could not cure. As 2012 turned to 2013, he insisted he was playing pretty well.

headline: Different Recipient, but Same Beneficiary
abstract: There is nothing wrong with state officeholders raising money for their favorite charities during legislative sessions or with prominent people contributing, but it is difficult to believe everyone’s motives are pure.
lead_paragraph: It is legal during legislative sessions for state officeholders to raise money for their favorite charities from the same people who are prohibited from donating to their political campaigns in that same time period.

headline: The Twin in the Background Takes Center Stage
abstract: Joaquin Castro is no longer just the mayor of San Antonio’s twin brother; he is building quite a reputation in Washington in his first year in the House of Representatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking last week at a conference on dropout prevention a few miles from his new Congressional office here, Representative Joaquin Castro, Democrat of San Antonio, cracked a self-deprecating joke. “In case you’re wondering,” he said, “you’re not talking to the mayor of San Antonio.”

headline: Beating the Heat Does Not Mean Equaling the Heat
abstract: As the Knicks prepare to face the Heat again, they’re relying on finding the form that led them to two early-season wins over Miami.
lead_paragraph: When the season was young and legs were spry and 3-pointers rained from the sky like parade confetti, the Knicks dared to reimagine themselves, to stretch their aspirations to logical extremes.

headline: Drought Revives Interest in Reservoirs
abstract: Texas’ water planners envision 26 new reservoirs over the next half-century, at a cost of $13.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in northeast Texas, Lake Gilmer was the last major reservoir built in the state, more than a decade ago. Local officials said they had intended to share construction costs and water with a new power plant, but the power company backed out, leaving the City of Gilmer with the bill.

headline: Same Southern Border, Varied Views
abstract: In some spots along the Mexican-American border, a well-fortified fence extends as far as the eye can see, while in others a wall ends abruptly in the ocean.
lead_paragraph: In some spots along the Mexican-American border, a well-fortified fence extends as far as the eye can see, while in others a wall ends abruptly in the ocean.

headline: Increased Border Enforcement, With Varying Results
abstract: There are now more agents along the 1,954-mile-long border than ever before, but even in the most secure areas, people still cross illegally.
lead_paragraph: There are now more agents along the 1,954-mile-long border than ever before, but even in the most secure areas, people still cross illegally.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Winning numbers for March 2, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 2, 2013

headline: A Border Evolves as Washington Pursues Immigration Reform
abstract: Lawmakers have agreed in principle to provide a pathway to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants – provided the border is strengthened first. But what does a “secure border” mean exactly?
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers have agreed in principle to provide a pathway to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants – provided the border is strengthened first. But what does a “secure border” mean exactly?

headline: Long Border, Endless Struggle
abstract: Is the United States-Mexico border better secured than it used to be? Answering this question is complex, and it largely depends on which stretch of the border you consider.
lead_paragraph: PENITAS, Tex. — The border fence behind Manuel Zamora’s home suggests strength and protection, its steel poles perfectly aligned just beyond the winding Rio Grande. But every night, the crossers come. After dark and at sunup, too, dozens of immigrants scale the wall or walk around it, their arrival announced by the angry yelps of backyard dogs.

headline: Virginia’s Feast on U.S. Funds Nears an End
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Government Employees', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Washington metropolitan area is in line to experience the largest economic hit of any region from the $85 billion in spending cuts that President Obama made official on Friday.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — To listen to the human side of sequestration, wait in line here for the 595 bus to Reston, Va., a journey across a suburbia grown fat and happy on a federal spending boom in the past decade, primarily military.

headline: Nets’ Energy Fades, Taking Lead With It
abstract: The Nets, who may have been tired after their home loss to Dallas on Friday, grabbed an early 15-4 lead but fizzled out and lost, 96-85, at Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — There was intensity and passion on the court right from the start of the Nets’ matchup with the Chicago Bulls on Saturday — although it was not exactly coming from the Nets’ side.

headline: Ex-Inmate Sneaked Into Jail by Impersonating Official, Authorities Say
abstract: Matthew Matagrano, a registered sex offender who had been caught posing as an Education Department official in 2004, spent over seven hours conversing and smoking with inmates, according to a criminal complaint.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Matagrano should be well known to the authorities. In addition to being a registered sex offender, he was once jailed for disguising himself as an Education Department official and sneaking into a Queens school.

headline: Corrections: March 3, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 3, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 3
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 3.
lead_paragraph: “No more movies, no more out-to-dinners, no more fun.”

headline: Amanda Lum and Gavin Tsang
abstract: The bride works for a clothing company; the groom, a bank.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Lum and Gavin Tsang were married Saturday at the Alger House, an event space in Manhattan. Allen Lum, the bride’s brother who was ordained through First Nation Ministry for the event, officiated.

headline: Leslie Swiedler, Ryan McDonald
abstract: The couple met while attending Clark University.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Anne Swiedler and Ryan Daniel McDonald were married Friday in New York. Matthew V. Greco, a family friend who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the State Supreme Court’s Appellate Division.

headline: Kelly Yonon, Matthew Bijur
abstract: The bride is a clinical psychologist; the groom is the chief executive of a online video platform used by publishers.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Nicole Yonon and Matthew Montgomery Bijur were married Saturday at the Sundance Resort in Utah. David Bijur, the brother of the groom, who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Erin Flannery, Brent Keith
abstract: The bride is an environmental lawyer; the groom is a forestry policy director.
lead_paragraph: Erin Aileen Flannery and Brent Lee Keith were married Saturday at Immaculate Conception Church in New Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Iain Highet, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Elizabeth Bryan and Andrew Caswell
abstract: Learning to share their passions, his for college football and hers for the performing arts.
lead_paragraph: The Gators Meet the Opera

headline: Beth Kowitt, Karsten Moran
abstract: The bride writes for Fortune magazine; the groom is a photographer and photo editor.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Scott Kowitt and John Karsten Moran were married Saturday evening at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Dr. Anne Klaeysen, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Bridget Carroll and Timothy Brennan
abstract: The bride is a manager at a design, animation and production company; the groom is an owner of a company that develops smartphone applications.
lead_paragraph: No First-Date Jitters? Audition Passed

headline: Amanda Jabour and Nicholas Kowalski
abstract: The bride is a lawyer; the groom is a director of outreach for an advocacy group in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Marie Jabour and Nicholas Foreman Kowalski were married Saturday at Historic St. Mary’s Church in Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. Leo M. Goodman III, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jacquelyn Copeland and Livingston Miller II
abstract: The bride is a second-year radiology resident at Maimonides Medical Center; the groom is an associate at Davis Polk & Wardwell.
lead_paragraph: Jacquelyn Nicole Copeland and Livingston Anthony Miller II were married Thursday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Gerald Shaw, a minister of the Christian Cultural Center, performed a ceremony with only the couple and their witnesses in attendance, in the center’s chapel.

headline: Karen Kandel and Jason Conn
abstract: The bride is a first-year resident in orthodontics and dentofacial orthopedics; the groom is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Karen Helena Kandel, a daughter of Dr. Barbara Wajsbrot Kandel and Joseph Kandel of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., was married Saturday evening in Philadelphia to Jason Belmont Conn, the son of Janet Belmont Conn and Richard J. Conn of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Rabbi Alan LaPayover officiated at the children’s museum in Memorial Hall.

headline: David Knopf, Edwin Marrero
abstract: The couple placed first in a same-sex ballroom-dancing competition last year.
lead_paragraph: David Alfred Knopf and Edwin Monserrate Marrero were married Thursday at Buenos Aires City Hall.

headline: Searching for a New Way to Measure Defensive Production
abstract: A research paper presented at the M.I.T. Sloan and Sports Analytics Conference showcases a method for assessing basket protection.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For many basketball traditionalists, defense has been the go-to factor when denouncing the importance of basketball’s advanced statistics revolution. Hard to concretely quantify as an individual skill, defense and the metrics that would define it have lagged as numerous new-age offensive statistics have become more and more a part of day-to-day player evaluation. Kirk Goldsberry and Eric Weiss acknowledged as much in a research paper presented here at the annual M.I.T. Sloan and Sports Analytics Conference.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: In Down to Earth, Alok Gupta analyzes the damaging effect violence has had on Bihar’s efforts to empower women and advance self-governance. The article argues that although the Bihar government announced a 50 percent quota for women in the panchayat (village council) in 2006, it has not helped in bringing about true empowerment for women. Instead, men force their homemaker wives to contest elections as the husbands continue to make all the decisions.

headline: Couple Expecting Baby Are Killed in Car Crash; Doctors Deliver a Boy
abstract: A man and his pregnant wife were on the way to a doctor when they were fatally injured in a Brooklyn collision, but their son was delivered.
lead_paragraph: They were newlyweds barely into their 20s, looking forward to the joy of having their first child, when the unthinkable happened.

headline: Kenzo: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: India in Race to Catch Up
abstract: Rosy predictions on India’s growth inspire skepticism.
lead_paragraph: Rosy predictions on India’s growth inspire skepticism.

headline: Smoother Access to Europe for the Trusted Few
abstract: A proposed new border regime has been billed as offering an open and secure Europe. Critics say it is just a way to make life harder for the kind of visitors the Continent does not really want.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A European plan to introduce high-tech “smart borders” that would give trusted travelers speedy entry to the Continent has been attacked by critics who say its main goal is to keep out immigrants and would-be refugees.

headline: Suvi Koponen Riggs Transforms Backstage at Givenchy
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: F.B.I. to Help Investigate American’s Death in Singapore, Reports Say
abstract: The parents of Todd Shane, an American engineer found dead in Singapore last year, believe he may have been murdered, amid warnings of “Chinese spying.” Now Singaporean investigators have asked the F.B.I. to help investigate.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Amid growing global tensions over alleged extensive spying operations originating in China, often aimed at U.S. companies and organizations, Shane Todd’s death in Singapore last June is striking a nerve.

headline: Cacharel: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Céline: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A High-Functioning Bereaved Parent
abstract: So where am I now, 13 years after my 2½-year-old son, Jacob, died because of a brain tumor? One thing I can say is that my junk mail has no idea where I am.
lead_paragraph: So where am I now, 13 years after my 2½-year-old son, Jacob, died because of a brain tumor? One thing I can say is that my junk mail has no idea where I am. The other day I threw out yet another letter offering to give us advice on Jacob’s college career, as well as a solicitation to re-subscribe to Highlights magazine. Obviously, Jacob is not going to college. And my surviving children are 11 and 13, a bit out of the Highlights demographic.

headline: Government and Medical Costs, Continued
abstract: Here, the private sector does it worse.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent some more time going through Steven Brill’s magnum opus on medical prices, and am even more amazed at (a) the quality of the reporting (b) his weird refusal to draw the obvious conclusion.

headline: Shirley MacLaine to Return to ‘Downton Abbey,’ but Others Are Leaving the Series
abstract: Shirley MacLaine will reprise her role as the outspoken Martha Levinson in Season 4 of “Downton Abbey,” and several new characters will join the series. But one more star of the PBS/”Masterpiece” period drama has announced her exit.
lead_paragraph: The revolving door of casting continues to spin at “Downton Abbey” as the popular PBS/”Masterpiece” period drama prepares for its fourth season. After a year in which the series lost the actors Dan Stevens, who played Matthew Crawley, and Jessica Brown Findlay, who played Lady Sybil (for reasons that the “Downton Abbey” creator Julian Fellowes explained here), PBS announced over the weekend that some new faces would join the series and that a familiar one was returning. But another well-known co-star has also announced her exit.

headline: Today in Well, Duh
abstract: Politicians aren’t sincere. Who knew?
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein mans up and admits he was wrong. He had written a piece suggesting that if only Republicans knew how much Obama has been willing to offer, they might be willing to make a deal. Jonathan Chait set him straight, informing him that no matter what Obama put on the table, Republicans would find a way to say that it’s not enough. And sure enough, a Twitter exchange lets Klein watch that process in real time, as a top Republican consultant, confronted with evidence that Obama has already conceded what he said was all that was needed, keeps adding more demands.

headline: Anais Pouliot Transforms Backstage at Jean Paul Gaultier
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Lloyd Simmonds and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Speaker Says Broad Budget Deal Is Possible, but Not With More Revenue
abstract: House Speaker John A. Boehner reiterated his opposition to new revenue as part of any deal to reverse automatic budget cuts that took effect over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: With federal budget cuts beginning to take effect, House Speaker John A. Boehner reinforced his opposition Sunday to any deal to reverse the cuts that includes raising new revenue. But he and senior White House officials left open a narrow path to a comprehensive budget agreement that could restore at least some of the money at some point.

headline: Disruptions: As User Interaction on Facebook Drops, Sharing Comes at a Cost
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: It seems as if Facebook is not only promoting paid links on news feeds, but also possibly suppressing the ones that aren’t paid for.
lead_paragraph: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Rocking the Streets With a Band and a Gang
abstract: The rerelease of an album shines a spotlight on a band from the Bronx, the Ghetto Brothers, that played an important role in the evolution of hip-hop in New York.
lead_paragraph: Between sips of coffee and occasional tears, Benjy Melendez recalled a band from the 1960s with British accents that had young girls from his South Bronx neighborhood swooning over songs like “I Want to Hold Your Hand,” and “A Hard Day’s Night.”

abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Little Second-Guessing From Romney
abstract: As Mitt Romney begins his return to public life, he said he does not expect to lead his party, but sharply criticized President Obama’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: Easing his way back into public life, Mitt Romney, the former Republican presidential candidate, in a TV interview Sunday mostly declined to reflect on his campaign’s shortcomings in his first interview since his defeat in November. But he did have a performance evaluation of the man who defeated him.

headline: New Chinese Leader Shores Up Military Support
abstract: On the eve of the opening of the National People’s Congress, Xi Jinping is using the armed forces to cement his political authority and present a tough stance by China in growing territorial disputes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — On the eve of the National People’s Congress, the chief of China’s Communist Party, Xi Jinping, is emphasizing his role as a champion of the military, using the armed forces to cement his political authority and present a tough stance in growing territorial disputes in the Pacific region.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Who Should We Listen To?
abstract: A political appointment does not an expert make.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker is feeling dyspeptic — not for the first time — over a WaPo piece suggesting that slow growth is the new normal. Dean wonders why we should listen to people who have been wrong about everything so far. But it’s actually worse than he says.

headline: Blast Kills at Least 45 Pakistanis in Shiite District of Karachi
abstract: The attack suggests Sunni militant groups are widening their brutal campaign against the country’s Shiite minority.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A powerful explosion ripped through a crowd of Shiites as they left a mosque in Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city, on Sunday, killing at least 45 people. It was the latest atrocity in an escalating campaign of countrywide sectarian violence.

headline: Life’s Very Fine Lines
abstract: A song about the very fine lines in life.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a brief musical interlude. I spent a couple of hours yesterday building a little video around a fresh recording (still a work in progress) of one of my older songs, “Very Fine Line,” which explores life’s close calls (“winning and losing, living and dying, loving and leaving…“). As I’ve explained many times, without music, journalism would be utterly unsustainable (for me, at least).

headline: Swiss Voters Approve a Plan to Severely Limit Executive Compensation
abstract: Ignoring a warning from the business lobby, Swiss citizens voted to give shareholders a binding say on the overall pay packages for executives and directors.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Swiss citizens voted Sunday to impose some of the world’s most severe restrictions on executive compensation, ignoring a warning from the business lobby that such curbs would undermine the country’s investor-friendly image.

headline: Kerry Announces $250 Million in U.S. Aid for Egypt
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said the United States would provide $250 million in aid after Egypt’s president promised to move ahead with talks over economic reforms.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Secretary of State John Kerry announced Sunday that the United States would provide $250 million in assistance to Egypt after Egypt’s president promised to move ahead with negotiations with the International Monetary Fund over economic reforms.

headline: Web Privacy Becomes a Business Imperative
abstract: Increasingly, Internet companies like Microsoft, Facebook and Mozilla are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Privacy is no longer just a regulatory headache. Increasingly, Internet companies are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.

headline: Mets Are Wearing Smiles This Spring, at Least on Their Caps
abstract: The Mets’ new spring training caps, part of a line of lighter headwear introduced for all 30 teams, features the cheery mascot Mr. Met.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mr. Met, a perpetually cheery mascot, is everywhere at Citi Field: on top of the dugouts, shooting T-shirts into the stands and hugging children. He is also on all manner of merchandise, like bobblehead dolls and sweatshirts.

headline: Poetry, Love and Letters: A Romance Imagined
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: “Frances and Bernard” by Carlene Bauer is a novel told in letters between characters based, both in temperament and biographical detail, on the writers Flannery O’Connor and Robert Lowell.
lead_paragraph: “Flannery, I love you very much,” the poet Robert Lowell wrote to his friend Flannery O’Connor in 1954. He hastened to add parenthetically, “This isn’t a proposal, I have other eggs to fry.” In her own letter to “A.,” in 1956, O’Connor said of the troubled Lowell, “I feel almost too much about him to get to be able to get to the heart of it. He is a kind of grief to me.”

headline: Opening Day Howler in M.L.S.
abstract: On opening day in M.L.S., Dallas took advantage of a goalkeeping miscue by Steward Ceus of Dallas in a 1-0 victory.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was opening day in Major League Soccer’s 2013 season, but it will take some doing to match a howler of epic proportions in Colorado’s 1-0 loss to Dallas in Frisco, Tex.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (History) THE BIBLE Mark Burnett, the reality television impresario, and his wife, the actress Roma Downey, tackle great biblical moments in this 10-hour mini-series, which Neil Genzlinger, writing in The New York Times, called “a rickety, often cheesy spectacle that is calculated to play well to a certain segment of the already enlisted choir but risks being ignored or scorned in other quarters.” Ms. Downey leads the cast, which also includes Diogo Morgaldo as Jesus, above center, being baptized by John (Daniel Percival). Alas, “Abraham, Moses, David, Daniel and the other great biblical figures aren’t really developed in a way that illuminates them or makes them linger in our minds,” Mr. Genzlinger said. “And those thinking that the ancient miracles might be better served by the special effects available in 2013 than they have been in previous versions should prepare for disappointment. The Red Sea parts no more convincingly here than it did for Charlton Heston in 1956.” (“All-Star Celebrity Apprentice,” of which Mr. Burnett is an executive producer, has its season premiere on NBC at 9.) “Vikings,” making its premiere at 10, fares somewhat better in Mr. Genzlinger’s opinion. It is “a mini-series about a band of professional pillagers with a disregard for human life and a relentless focus on gratifying material desires,” he wrote. “So it is somewhat surprising that it is also a refreshing study in restraint.” Created by Michael Hirst, whose previous projects include “Camelot,” on Starz, and “The Tudors,” on Showtime, “it has the same relatively high production values,” and “sometimes the cinematography is downright arresting,” he said. “But what really drives the series are the performances”; he cited in particular Travis Fimmel, Gabriel Byrne and Gustaf Skarsgard.

headline: Amazon’s Labor Relations Under Scrutiny in Germany
abstract: The online retailer has become a symbol for everything that many Germans resent about American-style management and so-called Anglo-Saxon capitalism.
lead_paragraph: BAD HERSFELD, GERMANY — Manuel Sauer, a union activist, stood in front of Amazon’s colossal gray distribution center here last Thursday, masquerading as the company’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, by holding up a cardboard cutout of a scowling Mr. Bezos. Television crews crowded in for the money shot.

headline: A Museum’s Games Are Not on Pedestals
abstract: The 14 video games the Museum of Modern Art acquired in November are on display in a new installation.
lead_paragraph: Video games, as their name suggests, combine the ancient human practice of formal play with moving pictures, a younger form. But the unsatisfying name we are saddled with for this medium — itself approaching middle age, if you date its history to the first home console in 1972 and apply the rule that middle age begins when you are older than every current Major League Baseball player — doesn’t capture the essence of video games.

headline: ‘Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella’
abstract: Scenes from the new Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the new Broadway musical.

headline: Heat Rally Past Knicks for 14th Straight Win
abstract: Led by LeBron James, who brushed off a knee injury and scored 29 points, Miami overcame a double-digit deficit to beat the Knicks for the first time this season.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James wobbled, but only for a moment. He winced, flexed his left knee a few times, reset himself and returned to his unshakable agenda: soaring over a league of helpless challengers.

headline: Saying Mass at Vatican, Dolan Urges Catholics to Look Beyond the Papal Conclave
abstract: As he celebrated a Mass in St. Peter’s Basilica’s grottoes, New York’s archbishop, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, said the daily life of the church was more important than choosing a new pope.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The cavernous nave of St. Peter’s Basilica was nearly empty when Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan arrived Sunday morning, shortly after dawn, a fading moon still hanging in the sky, and red streaks of sunlight illuminating the facade.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Givenchy
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){ data = response;}NYTD.options = { source: data, cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow', showHeadLine: 'false' , renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Fee, Fi, Fo, Fizzle: ‘Jack’ Disappoints at the Box Office
abstract: Warner Brothers and a financing partner spent about $190 million, and $80 million in marketing costs, for a film that made $28 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Jack the Giant Slayer” bombed at the North American box office over the weekend, teaching Warner Brothers a harsh lesson about derivative subject matter, flawed release dates and imperfect marketing.

headline: G.O.P. Clings to One Thing It Agrees On: Spending Cuts
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As many Republicans soften their stance on social issues, including same-sex marriage and immigration, the only issue truly uniting the party is a commitment to shrinking government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Conservative governors are signing on to provisions of what they once derisively dismissed as Obamacare. Prominent Senate Republicans are taking positions on immigration that would have gotten the party’s presidential candidates hooted off the debate stage during last year’s primaries.

headline: Akris: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: In Medical First, a Baby With H.I.V. Is Deemed Cured
abstract: The baby, born in rural Mississippi, was treated aggressively with antiretroviral drugs starting around 30 hours after birth; if further study shows this treatment works, it will almost certainly be recommended globally.
lead_paragraph: Doctors announced on Sunday that a baby had been cured of an H.I.V. infection for the first time, a startling development that could change how infected newborns are treated and sharply reduce the number of children living with the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: The Other Delights in a Trumpeter’s Life
abstract: Herb Alpert, the 77-year-old jazz-pop trumpeter and co-founder of A&M Records, is working on his 34th studio album and has an art exhibition opening soon.
lead_paragraph: Few people can claim to be a Renaissance man in this complex age, but Herb Alpert, the jazz-pop trumpeter and co-founder of A&M Records, might be one of them.

headline: Britten’s Softly Mad Last Quartet
abstract: Benjamin Britten’s Third String Quartet, performed by the Escher String Quartet at the Rose Studio, was one of the most profound expressions of his final years.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Britten completed his final opera, “Death in Venice,” early in 1973 and went into the hospital for heart surgery. A minor stroke affected his hand, the convalescence was rocky and he found himself — “perhaps for the first time,” according to the Britten scholar Philip Brett — unable to compose.

headline: Hopelessly Devoted to Himself
abstract: In “I, Me aur Main,” a Bollywood romance directed by Rakesh Sharma, a vain hunk has a lot to learn from the women in his life.
lead_paragraph: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: Blood Spills Over Black Gold
abstract: In Jean-Jacques Annaud’s “Day of the Falcon” warring Arab leaders in the early 20th century agree to a peace sealed with a buffer zone, but their pact is threatened by oil discovered there.
lead_paragraph: Opened on Friday in New York; Los Angeles; Chicago; Detroit; Cincinnati; Orlando, Jacksonville and Tallahassee, Fla.; Kansas City, Mo.; and Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Life’s Minor Milestones, Served in Lush Detail
abstract: Boy made a belated New York City debut on Friday; its album, “Mutual Friends,” is newly released here but has been available in Europe since 2011.
lead_paragraph: Of course, in 2013, a group called Boy is a duo of women: Valeska Steiner, from Zurich, and Sonja Glass, from Hamburg, Germany. But any subterfuge ends there. Boy writes and sings tuneful, friendly, forthright pop-folk songs about life and relationships. The songs detail small milestones: moving into a new apartment, working as a waitress, partying, flirting, fending off unwanted advances, savoring friendship and love. The lyrics are in idiomatic American English, cradled by melodies with a comfortable lilt and by Ms. Steiner’s sweet, unfailingly precise lead vocals. Boy’s songs make sleek craftsmanship sound guileless.

headline: Unresolved Feelings Long After a Murder Trial’s End
abstract: “The Staircase 2: Last Chance” is Jean-Xavier de Lestrade’s sequel to his eight-part documentary “The Staircase,” an examination of a sensational murder trial in Durham, N.C.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago the French filmmaker Jean-Xavier de Lestrade spent a reported 650 hours filming his eight-part documentary “The Staircase,” an examination of a sensational murder trial in Durham, N.C. It was a highly accomplished true-crime thriller that also functioned as an evisceration of the American legal system and a “what can you do?” evocation of Southern cronyism and small-mindedness for a European audience.

headline: Love, Cleareyed and Resolute
abstract: The indie singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson offered her take on love during an evening at Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: “No one’s gonna wait for you/so do it now.” That statement may sound like a slogan spouted by a motivational speaker, but as sung at the Allen Room on Saturday evening by the gifted indie singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson it conveyed the warmth and encouragement of a close friend sitting beside you in the back of a bus when you’re feeling discouraged. “Do It Now” was one of 16 originals she performed at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.

headline: Bangkok’s Governor Re-elected, Signaling Thailand’s Political Split
abstract: Defying predictions by pollsters, Gov. Sukhumbhand Paribatra retained his post, winning a hard-fought election against a candidate from the party of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Defying predictions by pollsters, the incumbent governor of Bangkok retained his post on Sunday, winning a hard-fought election against a candidate from the party of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational
abstract: Before the main event at the 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational over the weekend, there was a pro-am event for 52 pairs.
lead_paragraph: Before the main event at the 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational over the weekend, there was a pro-am event for 52 pairs. The winners could not really be termed pro-am, because the “am” was Helle Rasmussen, who has played four times on the Danish women’s team. Her partner was Michael Barel from Israel, who also won the invitational pair event with Yaniv Zack from Israel.

headline: Unfolding a Prophet, With Song
abstract: Kent Tritle conducted a student presentation of Mendelssohn’s “Elijah” at the Manhattan School of Music.
lead_paragraph: Happily, there are more ways than one to enjoy Mendelssohn’s “Elijah.” The most satisfying, perhaps, is to be swept along by a powerful bass or baritone in the title role of the combative prophet, as he roars through the work like the “mighty wind” of the text that “rent the mountains around.” Characterizations by the likes of Benjamin Luxon, Thomas Quasthoff and Bryn Terfel blaze in the memory.

headline: Pushing, Prodding and Exploring the Potentials of Men
abstract: San Francisco Ballet presents its commissions by Mark Morris, Ashley Page and Yuri Possokhov.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When San Francisco Ballet celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2008, it had achieved the unusual feat of making its third quarter-century its most prestigious, the one that established it as a world-class company, with seasons on the East Coast and in Europe. This it owed to Helgi Tomasson, who became its artistic director in 1985.

headline: When the Sun Is Out
abstract: Oh, look: Ian Livengood is back!
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh, look: Ian Livengood is back, and he’s offering us a “RHO” sound puzzle to start our week. Nice and smooth, this one is, with different spellings of that RHO sound inside a word: ROW, RO, RAOH, ROUGH and REAU.

headline: The U.S. Health Care Rip-Off
abstract: The United States spends much more than other countries on health care, yet many studies show the outcomes are less beneficial.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. health care system is the most expensive in the developed world and the gap with other countries isn’t narrowing. As I write in my latest Letter From Washington, a cover story in Time magazine, the American weekly, shows that many parties are to blame, though none admits responsibility. Nonetheless, in 2010, the last year for which data is available, the United States spent 17.6 percent of its gross domestic product on health care, according to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development. That’s at least 50 percent more than Canada, Great Britain or Germany, all of which spend less than 12 percent of G.D.P. on health care.

headline: National Attention and Cash in Los Angeles School Vote
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Charter Schools', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: After years of trying to curb the power of school boards, some advocates of overhaul are backing board candidates in the hope that they will support their causes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Tuesday, voters in Los Angeles will go to the polls for a mayoral primary. But much of the attention will also be on the three races for the school board, a battle that involves the mayor, the teachers’ union and a host of advocates from across the country — including New York City’s billionaire mayor — who have poured millions of dollars into the races.

headline: Biden May Take On Expanded Role in Foreign Policy in Second Term
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s stature is likely to rise with the departure of other foreign-policy heavyweights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Secretary of State John Kerry was scrambling last week to prevent the leader of the Syrian opposition from boycotting a meeting with him in Rome — a snub that could have spoiled his maiden voyage as the nation’s chief diplomat — he leaned on an old Senate colleague to help him out: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II Hospitalized
abstract: The queen, who is 86, was admitted to a London hospital after experiencing symptoms of gastroenteritis, according to Buckingham Palace.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II, who is 86, was admitted to a London hospital on Sunday after experiencing symptoms of gastroenteritis, according to a statement issued by Buckingham Palace.

headline: At Least 19 Killed as Unrest Persists in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Angry skirmishes over convictions by a war crimes tribunal entered another day, with several deaths.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladesh had yet another day of bloodshed on Sunday, as at least 19 people died in angry skirmishes between the police and supporters of the country’s biggest Islamist political party. The supporters were protesting the recent convictions of their leaders by a special tribunal prosecuting accused war criminals from the country’s 1971 struggle for liberation.

headline: Footnote
abstract: Madonna is to present the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper an award at the 24th annual Glaad Media Awards on March 16 in New York.
lead_paragraph: Madonna is to present the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper,  below, with the Vito Russo Award, which honors openly gay media professionals who have made a significant difference in promoting equality, at the 24th annual Glaad Media Awards on March 16 in New York, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation has announced. Mr. Cooper has previously won three Glaad Media Awards for his coverage.

headline: Suzuki Unhurt in Car Accident in Florida
abstract: Ichiro Suzuki said his vehicle was totaled when another driver ran a red light Saturday, but he expected to play in a spring training game Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Ichiro Suzuki’s first spring training in Florida continues to be eventful. First he had a close encounter with an alligator on a golf course, and on Saturday afternoon he was involved in a car accident. In both instances, he was uninjured.

headline: Assad and British Official Trade Verbal Blows Over Syrian Conflict
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad criticized British aid for rebels in Syria, but Britain’s foreign secretary, William Hague, called Mr. Assad’s view of the conflict “delusional.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Almost two years after the start of an uprising that has become a bloody civil war, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday accused Britain of seeking to “militarize” the conflict, prompting a taunt from a senior official here that Mr. Assad’s remarks ranked among “the most delusional” of modern times.

headline: Venezuela Says It’s Tracking Opposition Leader in U.S.
abstract: Vice President Nicolás Maduro said on national television that the government was monitoring Henrique Capriles Radonski while he was on a trip to New York and Miami.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The bruising and often bizarre world of Venezuelan politics would seem to be a long way from New York City, but a top official here said this weekend that the government of President Hugo Chávez was tracking the movements of a prominent opposition politician while he was on a trip to Manhattan.

headline: Mary Ellen Moore-Richard, American Indian Memoirist, Dies at 58
abstract: Ms. Moore-Richard was a member of the American Indian Movement during its militant actions of the 1970s and, under the name Mary Crow Dog, later wrote a well-received memoir, “Lakota Woman.”
lead_paragraph: Mary Ellen Moore-Richard, who was a member of the American Indian Movement during its militant actions of the 1970s and who, under the name Mary Crow Dog, later wrote a well-received memoir, “Lakota Woman,” died on Feb. 14 in Crystal Lake, Nev. She was 58.

headline: Givenchy: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: At AMC, Zombies Topple Network TV
abstract: Being a cable network is less of a disadvantage than it used to be, as broadcast networks become just one more click on a seemingly infinite dial.
lead_paragraph: When a show about the walking dead on basic cable beats every network show in the ratings demographic that advertisers care most about, you have to wonder who the real zombies are.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Company Reports']
abstract: Data to be released will include employment figures for February and the trade deficit for January, and Staples and Kroger are among the companies scheduled to report earnings.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for February (Tuesday); A.D.P. employment for February, factory orders for January and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the trade deficit for January, fourth-quarter productivity (revised) and consumer credit for January (Thursday); and unemployment for February and wholesale trade inventories for January (Friday).

headline: Austrian Protest Party Wins in Two States
abstract: Team Stronach, a pro-business and anti-euro party, won seats in Carinthia and Lower Austria on Sunday, building momentum for national elections in the fall.
lead_paragraph: ST. PÖLTEN, Austria — Europe has its next surging protest party, this time in Austria, courtesy of a free-spending billionaire emigrant who is looking to make a splash in his home country.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: U.S. and Russia Team Up in Bid to Aid Polar Bears
abstract: The countries are the main allies pushing for greater protection for the bears under a global treaty on endangered species, which is being reviewed at a conference in Bangkok.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — With relations between Russia and the United States increasingly frosty because of entrenched disagreements over Syria, child adoptions, missile systems and other issues, the two countries have quietly joined forces to help polar bears.

headline: Céline Keeps Paris on a Roll
abstract: Phoebe Philo keeps the momentum up for a strong Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: Prime Minister Promises to End Thailand’s Ivory Trade
abstract: The announcement adds pressure on China to halt its legal ivory trade, which experts say has helped fuel the highest rate of African elephant poaching in decades.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The prime minister of Thailand pledged Sunday to end the nation’s ivory trade, responding to growing calls from international wildlife groups desperate to stop the slaughter of African elephants.

headline: N.H.L. Bargains for Rights in Exchange for Suspending Play for Olympics
abstract: Though the N.H.L. is expected to send players to the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, next year, the league is still trying to get extra concessions from Olympic officials.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. is expected to send its players to Sochi, Russia, next February, marking the fifth time the world’s best players take part in the Olympic men’s hockey tournament, but it is hardly a done deal.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Kenzo
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a glam-rock red slingback with a chunky heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: One More Trip to Land of Oz
abstract: Disney’s movie studio, which has stumbled recently, takes a bold risk with a prequel to the beloved 1939 musical, “The Wizard of Oz.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Near the middle of “Oz the Great and Powerful,” James Franco, who plays the title character, surveys his bewildering surroundings and mutters “Are you kidding me?”

headline: Obama Asks Health Plans to Report Rising Rates
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: New rules being issued by the Obama administration will extend a previous requirement to report all rate increases for health plans sold to individuals, families and small businesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration says it will require health insurance companies to report all price increases, no matter how small, to the federal government so officials can monitor the impact of the new health care law and insurers’ compliance with it.

headline: Marie-Claire Alain, Master of the Organ, Dies at 86
abstract: Ms. Alain’s 300 recordings include, on organs of different periods, J. S. Bach’s complete organ works and collaborations with the trumpeter Maurice André.
lead_paragraph: Marie-Claire Alain, a master French organist and teacher with admirers and distinguished former students around the world, died on Tuesday in a retirement home in Le Pecq, outside Paris. She was 86.

headline: Was Wittgenstein Right?
abstract: The man who insisted that Western philosophy was based in confusion and wishful thinking is not popular among philosophers. But he should not be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: The singular achievement of the controversial early 20th century philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein was to have discerned the true nature of Western philosophy — what is special about its problems, where they come from, how they should and should not be addressed, and what can and cannot be accomplished by grappling with them. The uniquely insightful answers provided to these meta-questions are what give his treatments of specific issues within the subject — concerning language, experience, knowledge, mathematics, art and religion among them — a power of illumination that cannot be found in the work of others.

headline: Olbermann Angling for Return to ESPN
abstract: Sixteen years after leaving ESPN, Keith Olbermann and his representatives have expressed an interest in his return to the employer that made him famous.
lead_paragraph: Keith Olbermann was in Los Angeles on Friday being deposed for a reported $70 million lawsuit he filed against his most recent employer, Current TV, with the trial expected to begin in May. Whether the court rules in favor of Olbermann or the network, the verdict will put an official end to a one-year stint at Current that was supposed to last at least five.

headline: Joseph Frank, Biographer of Dostoevsky, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Frank’s five-volume biography of Fyodor Dostoevsky is considered one of the finest 20th-century literary biographies on any subject.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Frank, whose magisterial, five-volume life of Fyodor Dostoevsky was frequently cited among the greatest of 20th-century literary biographies, alongside Richard Ellmann’s of James Joyce, Walter Jackson Bate’s of John Keats and Leon Edel’s of Henry James, died on Wednesday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 94 and lived in Palo Alto.

headline: General Says Killing of Militant in Mali Is Not Confirmed
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The commander of Chad’s troops in an operation with the French says that the fate of the Islamist leader Mokhtar Belmokhtar was still unknown.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The general commanding troops from Chad in a French-Chadian antiterrorist operation in northern Mali said Sunday that he could not yet confirm the death of a principal Islamist leader, Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a day after his government announced it on Chad’s national television.

headline: PBS Near a Decision on Adding a Weekend Edition of ‘NewsHour’
abstract: A decision on adding half-hour Saturday and Sunday editions of the popular news program is not expected before the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: PBS is close to a decision on adding weekend broadcasts of the “PBS NewsHour” for the first time since the program began in 1975, and producing them in New York, instead of the program’s longtime studios in Arlington, Va., according to public television employees.

headline: As Automatic Budget Cuts Go Into Effect, Poor May Be Hit Particularly Hard
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicaid', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'United States Politics and Government', "State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Poverty', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: Unless a deal is reached, the $85 billion in cuts will affect programs that help low-income Americans, including those that provide housing vouchers and fortified baby formula.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $85 billion in automatic cuts working their way through the federal budget spare many programs that aid the poorest and most vulnerable Americans, including the Children’s Health Insurance Program and food stamps.

headline: Puzzle News!
abstract: How excited are we about the upcoming American Crossword Puzzle Tournament? Turns out that the Internet is abuzz with anticipation. Also, some news about the “American Red Crosswords” puzzle project to benefit survivors of Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — At the time of this writing, there are approximately 120 hours left until the start of the 36th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. Can you tell I’m excited?

headline: Following Resignation, Top British Cardinal Acknowledges Sexual Misconduct
abstract: Cardinal Keith O’Brien, Britain’s top Roman Catholic cleric and the head of the Scottish church, is the highest-ranking priest in recent history to make such an admission.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s most senior Roman Catholic cleric, Cardinal Keith O’Brien, acknowledged Sunday that he had been guilty of sexual misconduct, a week after he announced his resignation and said he would not attend the conclave to choose the next pope. The moves followed revelations that three current and one former priest had accused him of inappropriate sexual contact dating back decades.

headline: In Oakland, Photojournalists Covering Crimes Become the Victims
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Cameras', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Television', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Newspapers']
abstract: In less than a year, journalists at every major television news station in the Bay Area have been robbed of expensive cameras, sometimes at gunpoint, and it is changing the way they report.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In recent months, journalists covering crime and other stories here have themselves become victims of crime, robbed of expensive cameras, sometimes at gunpoint.

headline: Creaking Sounds From Pettitte, Rivera and Jeter Are Growing Fainter
abstract: The Yankees’ 40-and-over pitchers, Andy Pettitte and Mariano Rivera, faced hitters in a simulated game. Shortstop Derek Jeter, recovering from a broken ankle, was progressing as planned.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Old-timers day went smoothly at the Yankees’ training camp Sunday. Two 40-and-over stars ascended the mound to face hitters in a simulated game, while the 38-year-old Derek Jeter went through his workouts and reported that he was on track to be with the team on opening day.

headline: Seeking Compromise, President Reaches Out to the Rank and File
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In conversations last week with Republican senators and rank-and-file members of Congress, President Obama hopes to build a broad consensus on deficit reduction that includes new revenue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With few avenues left for winning a comprehensive budget deal that can reverse the across-the-board spending cuts that took effect over the weekend, President Obama has begun reaching out to senators in a bid to isolate Republican leaders in Congress and force a compromise.

headline: Former Adviser Criticizes Obama on Afghan War
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In his new book, “The Dispensable Nation,” Vali Nasr, a former senior State Department policy expert, describes the Obama administration’s handling of foreign policy as overly cautious.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new book by a former senior State Department policy expert paints a sharply critical picture of the Obama administration’s handling of foreign policy, detailing destructive turf battles and policy debates that challenge the White House’s claim that its management of the Afghan war is a vital accomplishment.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Tottenham Fans Serenade Their Hero While They Still Can
abstract: Gareth Bale, 23, is in his sixth season at Tottenham, but richer clubs in Europe are circling as he scores one stunning goal after another.
lead_paragraph: LONDON

headline: The Feminization of Farming
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Food', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Women are producing ever more food, but not reaping enough gains.
lead_paragraph: LOUVAIN, Belgium

headline: Stubbing Out Cigarettes for Good
abstract: We’ve done a good job of reducing smoking rates. Now it’s time to finish the job.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON

headline: Main Street Gets the Gun News From Washington
abstract: Hope is fading fast for a ban on the type of bullet-spraying assault rifle that took the lives of 20 children at the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn.

headline: Guardian Aims to Turn American Readers’ Heads
abstract: The venerable British newspaper is hoping to increase American readership with an ad campaign exploring controversial topics through graphics.
lead_paragraph: NEWSHOUNDS have no shortage of resources, particularly on the Web. And whether you define news as the latest updates on the Kardashians or the conflict in Syria, enough digital sources abound to satisfy every taste and to feed the incessant demands of social media. So how does a 192-year-old news organization get people to pay attention to its online edition?

headline: A Sneaky Way to Deregulate
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups']
abstract: It’s called a jobs act, but it’s really a con job for small investors.
lead_paragraph: SLAPPING a catchy acronym like the JOBS Act on a piece of legislation makes it more difficult for politicians to oppose it — and indeed that’s what happened with the Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act.

headline: Obama Picks Foundation President for Budget Chief
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President Obama plans to nominate Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the president of the Walmart Foundation, as his budget chief, the White House said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the president of the Walmart Foundation, as his budget chief, a White House official said on Sunday.

headline: Frequent Fliers, Prepare to Pay More
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new standard could make it easier for airlines to raise fares on some customers.
lead_paragraph: Airlines could soon start offering customized fares to travelers based on how regularly they fly, where they live and the kind of trip they are taking.

headline: James and the Heat Are Always in the Knicks’ Way
abstract: As long as LeBron James plays for the Miami Heat, the Knicks and their fans face an ultimately grim future.
lead_paragraph: There are times — and Sunday had to be one of them — when the chilling realization must run through the Knicks, and all those emotionally tethered to them, that their Eastern Conference fate for another cluster of years was cruelly settled during the summer of 2010, when they thought they were in the game for LeBron James.

headline: In Trafficking of Wildlife, Out of Reach of the Law
abstract: Interviews with officials in five countries and a review of hundreds of pages of government and court documents provide strong evidence that a Laotian man is a linchpin of wildlife smuggling operations.
lead_paragraph: HONG TONG, Laos — On an obscure and bumpy dirt road not far from the banks of the Mekong River, the compound of Vixay Keosavang stands out for its iron gates and cinder-block walls topped with barbed wire, a contrast to the rickety wooden stilt houses nearby in the shade of rubber trees.

headline: Too Few Fish in the Sea
abstract: Is there a way to meet consumer demand for quality seafood and protect threatened marine life at the same time?
