headline: A Screenplay Contest From Beijing
abstract: Screenwriters who live in the United States may submit feature film proposals or completed short film scripts in a Beijing-based contest that aims to turn some of them into movies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What can be built for almost nothing, usually can’t find a buyer and may soon put a dent — a small one, anyway — in the United States trade deficit with China?

headline: As Hacking Against U.S. Rises, Experts Try to Pin Down Motive
abstract: Motives for a cyberattack, which could range from industrial spying to disabling the power grid, remain obscure.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Telvent, a company that monitors more than half the oil and gas pipelines in North America, discovered last September that the Chinese had hacked into its computer systems, it immediately shut down remote access to its clients’ systems.

headline: Where Apps Meet Work, Secret Data Is at Risk
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Data Storage', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cloud Computing', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Smartphones', 'Computer Malware']
abstract: Employees who put company information online with their smartphones create a tricky problem for I.T. departments: how to protect corporate data without hindering employees’ work.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As is the case with many busy people, Delyn Simons’s life has become an open phone app of commingled corporate and personal information.

headline: Mooching Off Medicaid
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Is it O.K. if corporations do it?
lead_paragraph: Conservatives like to say that their position is all about economic freedom, and hence making government’s role in general, and government spending in particular, as small as possible. And no doubt there are individual conservatives who really have such idealistic motives.

headline: Obama’s Fault
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Taxation']
abstract: The bad timing and missed opportunities that brought us to the sequester zone.
lead_paragraph: Our feckless leaders may be incapable of passing a budget, but, boy, can they pass the buck. The White House spent last week in full campaign hysteria, blitzing online followers with the message that heartless Republicans are prepared to transform America into “Les Misérables” in order to protect “millionaires and billionaires, oil companies, vacation homes, and private jet owners.” Republicans retort that the budget-cutting Doomsday device called sequester was actually invented by the White House.

headline: First Lady’s Dance Moves Catch Fire on the Web
abstract: Mrs. Obama may have been criticized for handing out the Best Picture award at the Oscars, but her appearance on NBC’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” has been immensely popular.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama may have drawn some criticism, especially in conservative circles, for showing up a week ago to hand out the Best Picture award at the Oscars. But interest in the first lady is surely intense, as proved by the continuing phenomenon of her guest appearance on NBC’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon.”

headline: Shots and Goals from the Premier League’s Top Scorers This Season
abstract: Where the top scorers were successful on the field.
lead_paragraph: Where the top scorers were successful on the field.

headline: Bleeding the Borrower Dry
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Payday Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: Regulators need to crack down on payday lenders’ raiding checking accounts.
lead_paragraph: New York is one of 15 states that have banned the predatory, high-interest loans that payday lenders commonly use to pillage low-income borrowers. But offshore lenders increasingly get around state laws by issuing predatory loans over the Internet. Worse still, as the Times’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg reported recently, banks in the state are profiting from the loans by allowing the Internet lenders to automatically withdraw payments from the borrower’s account, in some cases without his or her permission. When the borrowers — or their lenders — overdraw on the accounts, the banks get to collect fat overdraft fees.

headline: A Jester No More, Italy’s Gadfly of Politics Reflects a Movement
abstract: After a successful showing in last week’s election, Beppe Grillo, a comedian turned activist, is being courted by Italy’s traditional political players, with whom he has refused to play ball.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A populist with wild hair, a booming voice and untucked shirts, Beppe Grillo now holds the fate of Italy — and to some extent Europe — in his hands.

headline: A Knick Misses 3-Pointers but Keeps Shooting Them
abstract: Guard J. R. Smith continued his poor shooting against the Heat, hitting only three of a game-high 14 3-point attempts, and made critical turnovers in the loss.
lead_paragraph: J. R. Smith hung his head the moment he realized his mistake. He did not run after LeBron James. It was already too late. Smith knew the end result of James’s critical steal, and the outcome of Sunday’s game, even before James soared through the air for a one-handed dunk with less than 30 seconds on the clock.

headline: More Than One N.Y.U. Star Got Lavish Parting Gift
abstract: At least two high executives at New York University got big bonuses on leaving, and prominent faculty members have received big housing loans.
lead_paragraph: New York University attracts figures of international stature with the promise that the university is a rewarding place to work. Less well known is how rewarding it can be to leave.

headline: Double Crisis: A Pregnant Woman Is Dying
keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Early Sunday, doctors at Bellevue Hospital Center delivered a boy by Caesarean section after Raizy Glauber of Brooklyn was killed in a car crash.
lead_paragraph: It is a situation as harrowing as it is rare: a pregnant woman suffering severe trauma arrives in an emergency room on the edge of death, and the life of her unborn baby hangs in the balance.

headline: Daredevil Media Outlet Behind Rodman’s Trip
abstract: Vice Media, known for stunt journalism, approached HBO with the idea of arranging a North Korea trip centering on basketball, a sport the nation’s leader loves.
lead_paragraph: Imagine being the HBO executive who hears this from one of the channel’s producing partners: “We think there’s an opportunity for us to get into North Korea.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: After 10 Uneventful Days, Martin Hopes to Stay a Few More With Knicks
abstract: Kenyon Martin has said and done the right things since joining the Knicks on a 10-day contract. The Knicks must decide Monday whether to keep him around for a bit longer.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Kenyon Martin, a former No. 1 pick in the N.B.A. draft, was at home in Dallas waiting for an invisible fence to be installed around his yard for his dog.

headline: To Stem Juvenile Robberies, Police Trail Youths Before the Crime
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Juvenile Delinquency']
abstract: The New York City Police Department has embarked on a novel approach to deter juvenile robbers, staging interventions in an effort to dissuade those youths most likely to commit crime.
lead_paragraph: Three police officers knocked on the apartment door of a 15-year-old boy. He had already been on both sides of a police blotter: shot and stabbed, but also arrested on robbery charges. He ran in an East Harlem gang and lived with his grandmother on the seventh floor of a public housing building, where the stairwells reeked of marijuana.

headline: Tracking Troubled Youths
abstract: The New York City Police Department is taking a novel approach to help teenagers with criminal backgrounds to stay out of trouble.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Police Department is taking a novel approach to help teenagers with criminal backgrounds to stay out of trouble.

headline: Gowns From the House of Sincere & Snark
abstract: “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” wants to be reassuringly old-fashioned and refreshingly irreverent, sentimental and snarky, sincere and ironic, all at once.
lead_paragraph: OMG, everybody, they’re doing instant makeovers at the Broadway Theater. First, this scruffy fox and raccoon suddenly turn into total studmuffins in satin suits. And then — this is the best part — this girl’s lame, retro peasant-chic outfit is transformed, right before our eyes (and while she’s singing), into a red-carpet ball gown. Make that two ball gowns: one white and one gold.

headline: Everything’s Fine, Until It Isn’t
abstract: A marriage unravels in “Belleville,” Amy Herzog’s new drama set in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Tragedy slips into the room quickly and quietly in “Belleville,” the extraordinarily fine new play by Amy Herzog that opened on Sunday night at New York Theater Workshop. A portrait of a marriage sliding ineluctably into crisis, Ms. Herzog’s delicately constructed drama simmers along coolly until, almost unnoticeably, the small secrets and larger lies that have become woven into the fabric of a young couple’s life begin to tear them apart.

headline: Amid the Empty Lots, Loneliness Creeps In
abstract: On Kissam Avenue on Staten Island, most property owners have held off on rebuilding after Hurricane Sandy and instead are betting that the state will buy them out.
lead_paragraph: Marisa Finco sat in her kitchen, or what had once been her kitchen, her bearlike dog, a Labrador retriever/Newfoundland mix, dozing at her feet. The road outside on that evening in late February was quiet and dark, save for two police floodlights and the low rumble of their generators.

headline: Recovery in U.S. Is Lifting Profits, but Not Adding Jobs
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Experts estimate so-called budget sequestration could cost the country about 700,000 jobs, but Wall Street doesn’t expect the cuts to substantially alter corporate profits or threaten stock markets.
lead_paragraph: With the Dow Jones industrial average flirting with a record high, the split between American workers and the companies that employ them is widening and could worsen in the next few months as federal budget cuts take hold.

headline: Banks Find More Wrongful Foreclosures Among Military Members
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Banks uncovered the foreclosures, which eclipse earlier estimates, in an analysis done as part of a multibillion-dollar settlement deal with federal authorities.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest banks wrongfully foreclosed on more than 700 military members during the housing crisis and seized homes from roughly two dozen other borrowers who were current on their mortgage payments, findings that eclipse earlier estimates of the improper evictions.

headline: Illegal Blow to Richards Spurs Rangers’ Goals
abstract: The Rangers won in a shootout, but the image most will carry from the game is that of Brad Richards writhing on the ice after being shoved hard into the boards from behind.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers beat the Buffalo Sabres, 3-2, in a shootout at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night. But the image most will carry from this game is that of Brad Richards writhing on the ice after being shoved hard into the boards from behind.

headline: From Last to First, Winner of Honda Classic Offers Lesson in Staying Around
abstract: Michael Thompson finished at minus-9 to win the Honda Classic, a startling improvement over his 16-over-par performance two weeks ago at the Northern Trust Open.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — The cold wind that buffeted the Honda Classic left a trail of debris. It creased the shiny image of the world No. 1, Rory McIlroy, who abruptly gave up the defense of his title in the middle of the second round. It whipped Tiger Woods, the world No. 2, like a pin flag. By Sunday’s conclusion, the leader board was so topsy-turvy that it produced a winner who had finished dead last in the field in his previous start.

headline: Scoring Woes Leave Nets Desperate For Solutions
abstract: After losing four of five games, Coach P. J. Carlesimo is struggling to come up with productive rotations as the season winds down.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Nets Coach P. J. Carlesimo spent a majority of Saturday’s 96-85 loss to the Chicago Bulls seated on the bench, head in his hand, looking on helplessly as his team fell to its fourth defeat in five games.

headline: Nominee for Japan’s Central Bank Vows Aggressive Action
abstract: The candidate, Haruhiko Kuroda of the Asian Development Bank, told a confirmation hearing he would do “whatever it takes” to counter the country’s deflation.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The nominee to become the next Bank of Japan governor said Monday that he would do “whatever is needed” to finally end deflation in the world’s third-largest economy.

headline: For Her Encore, Diggins Hopes to Lead Notre Dame to Championship
abstract: Skylar Diggins, a star point guard who has the second-ranked Fighting Irish in position to win it all, is the center of attention on the court and onstage.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — The beat dropped, a local legend grabbed the microphone, and the crowd went wild. Chris Brown’s “Look at Me Now” thumped through the room, and the D.J. shouted, “Do y’all want to hear some serious flow?”

lead_paragraph: “We are coming to find you and monitor every step you take. And we are going to learn about every bad friend you have. And you’re going to get alienated from those friends because we are going to be all over you.”

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) JOHN GUARE: A YOUNGARTS MASTERCLASS For more than 30 years the organization now known as National YoungArts Foundation has offered scholarships and mentors to emerging high school artists. This latest installment of the Emmy-nominated “Masterclass” series, directed by the Oscar-winning filmmakers Karen Goodman and Kirk Simon and featuring sessions between acclaimed artists and students, focuses on Mr. Guare (above) — the author of plays including “A Free Man of Color,” “The House of Blue Leaves” and “Six Degrees of Separation” — as he advises writers at a workshop in Rome. Their assignment is to wander the city for inspiration and then compose a monologue drawing on their experiences in the voice of an imagined character, all while being encouraged by Mr. Guare to pursue “weird vibes” and “go into the darkness.”

headline: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ in the Black Church
abstract: A young churchgoer watches a Pentecostal minister slowly become more accepting of gays.
lead_paragraph: I’d been assigned to write a story for Loop21.com, an online African-American publication, about how pastors at black churches were handling homosexuality with their congregations. I’d picked one of my friend’s father to interview, a Pentecostal minister in Chicago.

headline: Red Bulls: Is Glass Half Full, or Half Empty?
abstract: The Red Bulls’ season-opening game at Portland might have been the best game of a busy opening weekend for Major League Soccer. In some ways, though, it was also the worst.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls’ season-opening game at Portland on Sunday night might have been the best game of a busy opening weekend for Major League Soccer. In some ways, though, the 3-3 tie was also the worst.

headline: Something Motivates Santana to Throw
abstract: Johan Santana, who disappointed his general manager by showing up in camp not ready to pitch, is still likely to miss the start of the season.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The theatrics surrounding the Mets ace Johan Santana continued on Sunday. Santana threw off a pitching mound at the Mets’ spring training site in Port St. Lucie a day after General Manager Sandy Alderson appeared to upbraid him for not being in shape.

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: India’s Only Electric Car Revamped to Woo Drivers
abstract: A brand new factory in Bangalore is expected to assemble 30,000 units of Mahindra Reva’s E2O annually.
lead_paragraph: Long before the Nissan Leaf and the Chevy Volt were born, India had its own electric car, the tiny REVAi. The car ended more than a decade of production last year after selling less than 5,000 units worldwide. But underwhelming sales haven’t prevented its maker from raising the stakes: This year, Mahindra Reva is betting everything on its new electric four-seater hatchback, the E2O.

headline: Harmony on the Subway Platform
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A moment when borders cross and timetables are forgotten while waiting for an uptown train.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Strong Calls for Change on Eve of China’s National Congress
abstract: As China’s Parliament, the National People’s Congress, opens Tuesday, some are calling for changes to the re-education-through-labor system, which one delegate said causes citizens to “live in fear.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Amid lots of Communist red in the Great Hall of the People on Beijing’s Tiananmen Square, China’s Parliament, the National People’s Congress, opens Tuesday with some delegates issuing strong calls to end the country’s re-education-through-labor camps.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 4
abstract: Doctors say a baby with H.I.V. has been cured; a man suspected of wildlife smuggling operations seems beyond reach in Laos; an escalating battle between union workers and Amazon in Germany; more Indian students are taking the International Baccalaureate; and the Premier League continues to flaunt its international soccer talent.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Doctors announced on Sunday that a baby had been cured of an H.I.V. infection for the first time, a startling development that could change how infected newborns are treated and sharply reduce the number of children living with the virus that causes AIDS. Andrew Pollack and Donald G. McNeil Jr. report.

headline: Kenyans Flood Polls for Presidential Vote
keywords: ['Elections', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: As the voting proceeded relatively smoothly in the presidential election, a real chance emerged that a candidate accused of crimes against humanity could win the race.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Millions of Kenyans poured into polling stations on Monday to cast their ballots in a crucial, anxiously awaited presidential election, and as the voting proceeded relatively smoothly a real chance emerged that a candidate charged with crimes against humanity could win the race.

headline: A Conversation With: Sotheby’s Lord Poltimore
abstract: On Sotheby’s expansion plans in India and the growing art market.
lead_paragraph: As a regular visitor to India, Lord Poltimore, deputy chairman of Sotheby’s Europe and chairman of Sotheby’s Russia, has had a ringside view of the changes that have taken place in the Indian art scene over the past two decades. Lord Poltimore has had a storied auction house career, including 23 years at Christie’s, where he rose to deputy chairman. He left Christie’s in 2000 to join an online auction startup called eAuctionRoom. At Sotheby’s, where he has spent a decade, Lord Poltimore led the company’s foray into Russia and is responsible for cultivating new markets like India.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 4, 2013
abstract: Can you calculate the amount of money that would be donated if five percent of the people who play Half the Sky Movement: The Game each give an average of $15?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “A Game Aims to Draw Attention to Women’s Issues.”

headline: Crossing the Country, One Step at a Time
abstract: Why do some people choose to walk thousands of miles?
lead_paragraph: In “Walking the Country as a Spiritual Quest,” Kate Murphy writes about people who have taken this journey.

headline: Seeing Contrasts Along Two Sides of Cyprus
abstract: Though Cyprus is smaller than Connecticut, Alexandros Demetriades has covered 22,000 miles in his trips there. He is hoping to capture a complex place that has been divided for 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Alexandros Demetriades spent his childhood summers in Kyrenia, a picturesque resort town in Cyprus nestled between the rugged Besparmak Mountains and the sparkling blue waters of the Mediterranean. He would awaken to the smell of warm bread from the bakery next door and, if he was lucky, go for a ride with his father in the family’s small motorboat.

headline: How Good is Your Grammar?
abstract: In honor of National Grammar Day, tell us how good your grammar is, and to what extent you think it matters.
lead_paragraph: It’s National Grammar Day, a perfect day to reflect on how well you speak and write, and whether or not it matters.

headline: Chinese Stocks Plunge on Plan to Tax Home Sales
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Capital Gains Tax']
abstract: China’s cabinet, or State Council, said home sellers would soon pay a 20 percent capital gains tax.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Faced with a difficult combination of an economy addicted to cheap credit, exorbitant real estate prices fueled by that credit and mounting public concern that housing is no longer affordable, China’s government is laying plans for steep new taxes on home sellers.

headline: HSBC’s Profit Fell 17% in 2012 on Money Laundering Fine
abstract: HSBC, Britain’s biggest bank, said net profit fell 17 percent, to $13.5 billion, last year because of a record fine to settle money laundering charges in the United States and changes to the value of its own debt.
lead_paragraph: 1:49 p.m. | Updated

headline: March College Checklist for Seniors
abstract: A college counselor advises high school seniors to decide how they plan to learn and share their admission decisions, and how to evaluate their offers of acceptance.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Precautionary Tales
abstract: Kenyans’ preparations for Monday’s election vary according to class, ethnicity and skin color: Some panic-shop and send their kids away; others hit the nightclubs.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI — “Sorry I’ve been out of touch. I went to my farm in Trans Nzoia to sell my maize,” a Kenyan journalist friend explained. “With the Kenyan police busy guarding the polling stations, someone might grab the opportunity to do a bit of looting. So I thought it best to sell.”

headline: Minimal Wages, Minimal Families
abstract: The proposed increase in the federal minimum wage to $9 an hour will raise incomes for families with children and help young adults start families of their own, even though it won’t lift them all out of poverty, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.“

headline: U.N. Nuclear Official Seeks Access to Iranian Site
abstract: The head of the United Nations nuclear regulatory body urged Iran on Monday to permit access to a site near Tehran to ascertain whether nuclear bomb trigger tests have been carried out there.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The head of the United Nations nuclear regulatory body urged Iran on Monday to permit access by international inspectors to a military site near Tehran to ascertain whether tests have been carried out there on nuclear bomb triggers.

headline: Mystery Shrouds the Deaths of 3 Sisters
abstract: “I dressed them for school. That was the last time I saw them alive,” the mother of the three said.
lead_paragraph: BHANDARA, Maharashtra —As the police investigate the deaths of three young sisters in a small village in central India, they are certain of one thing: someone killed the girls, ages 6, 9 and 11, sometime after they were last seen on Feb. 14 in Murmadi, in the Bhandara district of Maharashtra, and then dumped their bodies into a well in a rice field, where they were found on Feb. 16.

headline: Givenchy’s Layers of Emotion
abstract: Riccardo Tisci’s Givenchy show on Sunday was very affecting, with a firm grasp of the Givenchy woman: a layered personality and plenty of grit.
lead_paragraph: The Paris collections are giving women — and anyone who monitors fashion as closely as the Vatican and the N.F.L. draft — a lot to obsess over. That’s quite a change from Milan, where many of us were wishing the Italians could get their shows done in fewer days. (When people are discussing the schedule, and not the clothes, you know there’s a problem.)

headline: The Last All-Nighter
abstract: I thought it would fast-track me to adulthood, but what Adderall gave me was nothing compared to what it took away.
lead_paragraph: The first time I took Adderall I didn’t think twice. It was 2007. I was in my last year at U.C.L.A., where I had come down with a bad case of senioritis, and found myself cramming for finals. I bought it from a gangly kid with yellow skin and bags under his eyes who lived in the dorms. His hair was stringy. There were papers on the floor and piles of clothes on all the furniture in the room. Above his desk was a poster of John Belushi from “Animal House,” chugging a bottle of Jack Daniels and wearing a sweatshirt that read COLLEGE.

headline: Behind the Story: Nathaniel Rich on Kooky Train Travelers and Why He Always Shaves Before Reporting
abstract: The author of one of the magazine’s features this week talks about his voyages on Amtrak.
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel Rich wrote a feature article in this past weekend’s Voyages issue about long-distance train travel. Rich is the author of the novel “The Mayor’s Tongue”; his second novel will be published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux this spring. Last year he wrote cover stories for the magazine about a Japanese scientist who studies jellyfish and the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans.

headline: This Week in Small Business: It’s On
abstract: The budget cutting begins. New home sales are up, manufacturing is up, even music sales are growing. How to get the most from YouTube. And do you let employees work from home?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the Syrian opposition is capable of properly handling the military support it receives.

headline: A Pale Reflection of Reality
abstract: Political theater became life when the Russian immigration police interrupted a performance on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The press materials called it “political theater.” Last Friday through Sunday, three of the most important Russian political trials of the last decade were to be re-enacted in compressed form by people who had either taken part in them or might have taken part in them. Staged by the Swiss director Milo Rau, the “Moscow Trials” series was being performed at the Andrei Sakharov Museum and Public Center, itself a contested space. It would be filmed, for airing on television, presumably anywhere but in Russia, where a Western view of these trials could hardly be broadcast to a wide audience.

headline: Temasek Increases Stake in Spanish Energy Concern
abstract: Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings said on Monday that it had increased its stake in the Spanish energy company Repsol in a deal worth around $1.3 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings said on Monday that it had increased its stake in the Spanish energy company Repsol in a deal worth around 1 billion euros, or $1.3 billion.

headline: Big Data Done Cheap
abstract: Violin Memory, a maker of advanced data storage systems for big computer centers, heads down-market with powerful flash memory cards in servers. The company hopes to spur a market in inexpensive machines that perform fast predictions, genetic modeling and complicated logistics.
lead_paragraph: Some new products impress for what they say about the future. Win or lose, they show where the world is going with near certainty.

headline: What Betting Markets Are Saying About the Next Pope
abstract: According to the bookmakers’ odds, four of the top six contenders are Italian, and the average age of the top 10 is 68.
lead_paragraph: In Vatican City on Monday, the College of Cardinals will gather to decide on when to hold the papal conclave to select the next pope. There are no polls of the 115 cardinals who will vote in the conclave, and FiveThirtyEight is not making any predictions. But plenty of others are — notably, bookies and bettors.

headline: Obama Announces 3 Cabinet Nominations
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Clean Air Act', 'Global Warming']
abstract: President Obama on Monday revealed his choices to take top posts on the budget, energy and the environment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday made three cabinet nominations — for budget, energy and environmental policy — hours before his first cabinet meeting of his second term.

headline: Banks Find More Foreclosure Problems
abstract: Big banks wrongfully foreclosed on more than 700 military members during the housing crisis. | Brokers in an elite group at JPMorgan Chase are said to face pressure to sell JPMorgan financial products. | Profit fell 17 percent at HSBC in 2012. | Swiss citizens vote to impose severe curbs on executive compensation.
lead_paragraph: Big banks discovered they wrongfully foreclosed on more than 700 military members during the housing crisis and seized homes from about two dozen other borrowers who were current on their mortgage payments, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in The New York Times. The banks — Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo — found the foreclosures after regulators ordered them to examine mortgages as part of a multibillion-dollar federal settlement, according to people with direct knowledge of the findings.

headline: Green Groups Decry Sequester’s Effects
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: From environmental programs to renewable energy support to all kinds of inspections, the more than $80 billion in automatic budget cuts will have an impact.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after President Obama promised to develop sustainable energy and green jobs and to fight climate change — first in his second Inaugural Address, and then in his State of the Union Message — the realities of American politics have set in.

headline: Monday Reading: Spring Breaks, From Budget-Oriented to Beyond
abstract: Spring breaks that range from budget-oriented to beyond, when siblings are roommates, how to beat some Facebook scammers and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Hess to Sell Gas Stations as Part of a Shift in Strategy
abstract: The oil company, in a proxy fight with the hedge fund Elliott Management, said it would shed its retail and refining arms so that it could focus on exploration and production.
lead_paragraph: 8:55 p.m. | Updated  The Hess truck may be going in a yard sale.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: How Rodman Wound Up in North Korea, and AMC Lurches Ahead in Ratings
abstract: Vice magazine was behind Dennis Rodman’s high-profile trip to North Korea; “The Walking Dead” is killing networks in the ratings; and a photojournalists in Oakland, Calif., have become victims of a rash of robberies.
lead_paragraph: Vice, a print magazine that is producing a TV newsmagazine that will debut on HBO in April, made international news by arranging a basketball game featuring flamboyant former N.B.A. player Dennis Rodman and three Harlem Globetrotters players before Kim Jong-un, in North Korea, Brian Stelter writes. Mr. Rodman and Vice’s film crew are the first Americans to meet the North Korean ruler since he inherited power from his father in 2011. Pundits debated on television and online over who gained more from the interaction, Vice or the North Korean government, and reporters at the State Department wanted to know why Mr. Rodman, who has returned to the United States, was not debriefed about his visit with Mr. Kim, whom he called a “friend.” Vice had no assurance that Mr. Kim would watch the game, but were familiar with his love of basketball, especially the Chicago Bulls.

headline: Massacre of Syrian Soldiers in Iraq Raises Risk of Widening Conflict
abstract: More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq were killed on Monday in an ambush, in the most serious spillover of violence into Iraq since the Syrian conflict began.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — More than 40 Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety in Iraq from rebel fighters along the border were killed on Monday in an attack by unidentified gunmen as the Iraqi military was transporting the soldiers back to Syria in a bus convoy, the Iraqi government said.

headline: Sitting Pretty | The Poltrona Frau Museum
abstract: To coincide with its 100th anniversary, the manufacturer of luxurious leather furniture has officially inaugurated its museum in central Italy.
lead_paragraph: To coincide with its 100th anniversary, Poltrona Frau, the manufacturer known for its luxurious leather furniture, has officially inaugurated its museum in the central Italian town of Tolentino, its headquarters since the early 1960s. Designed by Michele De Lucchi, the Milan architect who was a key figure in radical design movements like Memphis, the Poltrona Frau Museum presents both the company’s history and the processes involved in making its products.

headline: Brits Off Broadway Adds ‘Bull’ to Slate
abstract: “Bull,” a drama about office politics by the British playwright Mike Bartlett (“The Cockfight Play”), will have its New York premiere in the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: “Bull,” a drama about office politics by the British playwright Mike Bartlett (“The Cockfight Play”), will have its New York premiere in the Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters, the theater is to announce on Monday. The play, which is to begin performances on April 25, recently completed a run at the Crucible Studio in Sheffield, England, where it received good reviews.

headline: Calls to Charge Driver Grow After Couple’s Newborn Dies
abstract: The infant had been delivered prematurely after his mother and father were killed in a car crash in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before the crash, they were strangers inhabiting vastly different Brooklyns.

headline: Heeeeere’s Napoleon: Spielberg Developing Kubrick Script as TV Miniseries
abstract: Steven Spielberg says he plans to develop Stanley Kubrick’s unproduced screenplay about the life of Napoleon as a television miniseries.
lead_paragraph: While another collaboration between Stanley Kubrick and Steven Spielberg would seem to require a time machine, a Ouija board or some sort of interdimensional extraterrestrial monolith, plans are nonetheless underway for these two celebrated filmmakers to work together again.

headline: The Gun Report: March 4, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: As these things go, the incident was pretty benign. In Des Moines, Iowa, a 13-year-old boy, Jesse Guevara, along with his friend Alec Osborn, were visiting a third friend at the friend’ s godfather’s house. They found several guns that were loaded, and Guevara accidentally shot Osborn in the shoulder. The shooting was recounted in our February 25 Gun Report, linked to a lengthier account in the Des Moines Register. Our brief encapsulation ended by reporting that Osborn had been released from the hospital. And that appeared to be that.

headline: American Won’t Join South Korea Cabinet
abstract: A South Korean-born American entrepreneur, nominated to be minister of education, science and technology, withdrew on Monday, blaming political gridlock.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean-born American business executive who was nominated by President Park Geun-hye to be the minister of future creation and science withdrew on Monday, blaming political gridlock that has delayed his confirmation hearing in the National Assembly.

headline: Winners of Hefty New Literary Prizes Announced
abstract: James Salter, Jonny Steinberg and Naomi Wallace are among the winners of the Windham Campbell Prizes.
lead_paragraph: Yale University announced on Monday the inaugural winners of the Windham Campbell Prizes, which are given to writers for outstanding achievement in fiction, nonfiction and drama.

lead_paragraph: Paris

abstract: As usual, the first base position is the deepest of them all, with plenty of 25-plus home run power throughout the top 25.
lead_paragraph: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich Brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: A Growing Divide
abstract: As federal budget cuts begin, high productivity and low interest rates help corporations but not job seekers.
lead_paragraph: As federal budget cuts begin, high productivity and low interest rates help corporations but not job seekers.

headline: PMS Symptoms Linked to Diet
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Iron (Nutrient)', 'Potassium Iodide', 'Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A decade-long study of more than 3,000 women found that dietary iron may reduce the risk for premenstrual syndrome, while potassium intake may increase it.
lead_paragraph: A 10-year study of more than 3,000 women has found that dietary iron may reduce the risk for premenstrual syndrome, while potassium intake may increase it.

headline: CVC Hires Ex-C.E.O. of Lloyds Banking
abstract: CVC Capital Partners, a European private equity firm, has tapped a former chief executive of the Lloyds Banking Group, Eric Daniels, to be a senior adviser for its banking team.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – CVC Capital Partners, a European private equity firm, has tapped a former chief executive of the Lloyds Banking Group, Eric Daniels, to be a senior adviser for its banking team.

headline: Wild Buzzer-Beater Leaves 2 Teams Celebrating
abstract: LeBron James and Patrick Kane delivered late-game heroics but a high school player made the most impressive shot of all.
lead_paragraph: If you spent the weekend looking for a sports highlight fix, you did not have to search hard. On Sunday alone the highlights came fast and furious and from many of the usual suspects. You could have chosen LeBron James breaking the Knicks’ hearts — although yes, that has happened enough times to qualify as a dramatic series — or the Blackhawks pulling another victory out of thin air. You had Danica Patrick slamming into a wall. You could have gone back and replayed Rory McIlroy hitting a proverbial wall as he melted down at the Honda Classic and walked off the course.

headline: New Programmer at Film Society Steps Down; Replacement Named
abstract: Robert Koehler, who last fall was named year-round director of programming at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, is resigning that position, to be replaced by Dennis Lim.
lead_paragraph: Robert Koehler, who last fall was named the year-round director of programming at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, is resigning that position, the organization said Monday. Taking over for him will be the critic and journalist Dennis Lim.

headline: When Software Vendors Take Their Time
abstract: A group considered what, if anything, a fellow business owner could do to address a dissatisfying experience with a software supplier at a late stage.
lead_paragraph: At the last meeting of the She Owns It business group, Susan Parker talked about the frustrating process of switching to new software to run her company, Bari Jay. After more than a year, the project, which was supposed to take three months, is still unfinished — although she hopes the new software will be live within a month. Although she likes the software, with hindsight she says that she would never work with this particular software development company again. But where does that leave her now?

headline: Daily Report: Web Privacy Becomes a Business Imperative
abstract: Companies are increasingly responding to privacy concerns, not just because of regulatory requirements but because of customers’ desires.
lead_paragraph: Privacy is no longer just a regulatory headache, reports Somini Sengupta in Monday’s New York Times. Increasingly, Internet companies are pushing each other to prove to consumers that their data is safe and in their control.

headline: Pregnant Without a Policy in Graduate School
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Families and Family Life', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Do graduate schools, in medicine or anything else, support pregnant students, or leave them at the mercy of individual instructors?
lead_paragraph: Is a pregnant medical student — or a pregnant law or other graduate student — “not a bad idea”?

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Akris
abstract: A minimalist beauty look ruled the day, with light foundation, powder blush and nude lips.
lead_paragraph: “I definitely think that the ‘no makeup’ makeup look is around,” said Diane Kendal of the trend on fall runways. Backstage at Akris, Kendal’s minimalist beauty look featured light foundation, M.A.C. Powder Blush in Tenderling on the apples of the cheeks, and nude lips. The one bit of glamour? The eyes, which were painted with grease shadows in a mix of brown and gray to “give a dewy feel on the lids,” lined with M.A.C. Pro Sculpting Cream in Coffee Walnut on the lash line, and finally veiled with finely netted bandeau, like a chic (and discreet) Zorro.

headline: President Announces Choice for Budget Chief
abstract: In selecting Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obama enlisted another Clinton-era veteran for his economic team.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In picking Sylvia Mathews Burwell to be his budget director, President Obama on Monday again enlisted a Clinton-era veteran for his economic team as it deals with fiscal and partisan challenges that make the earlier time seem like the good old days.

headline: Miners in Australia Fired Over ‘Harlem Shake’ Video
abstract: Workers at the Agnew gold mine were fired after posting their video to YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Several miners in Australia were fired from their jobs after filming a “Harlem Shake” video underground, a performance that the owners of the Agnew gold mine apparently considered unsafe, The Associated Press and Reuters reported.

headline: A Boy Saved by Oskar Schindler: Memoir Will Tell the Story
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Leon Leyson was 10 when the Germans invaded Poland, but was saved, along with some members of his family, by Oskar Schindler, who employed them in his factories.
lead_paragraph: Leon Leyson, one of youngest of the Jews saved by Oskar Schindler from the Holocaust, completed a memoir just before he died in January, and the book will be released in August, his publisher said on Monday.

headline: Racist Incidents Stun Campus and Halt Classes at Oberlin
abstract: In the last month, Oberlin College has been jolted by slurs, swastikas and a late-night sighting of someone in a robe and hood.
lead_paragraph: OBERLIN, Ohio — Oberlin College, known as much for ardent liberalism as for academic excellence, canceled classes on Monday and convened a “day of solidarity” after the latest in a monthlong string of what it called hate-related incidents and vandalism.

headline: Image of the Day: March 4
abstract: Delhi court frames charges against Irom Chanu Sharmila, an activist from Manipur, for attempting suicide.

headline: Video of Cardinals Arriving to Choose Benedict’s Successor
abstract: With all of the world’s cardinals not yet in Rome, a date is not expected to immediately be set on Monday for the start of the conclave to choose a new pope.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 cardinals from throughout the world arrived at Paul VI Hall in Rome on Monday to prepare for the conclave, the process used to select the successor to Pope Benedict XVI, who stepped down last week. Not all of the cardinals have yet arrived in Rome, officials said, so the date for the start of the conclave is not expected to immediately be set.

headline: Buffett Picks His ‘Bear’ for Annual Meeting
abstract: Warren E. Buffett announced on Monday that Douglas Kass, a hedge fund manager, would be added to the panel of analysts who question him and Berkshire’s vice chairman, Charles T. Munger, on stage during Berkshire Hathaway’s annual gathering in Omaha on May 4.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett has found his bear.

headline: China’s Wen Warns of Inequality and Vows to Continue Military Buildup
abstract: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao delivered a sometimes gloomy assessment of the state of Chinese society in his final annual work report to the national legislature.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China entered his final days in power on Tuesday with a warning that the nation remained troubled by divisions between the urban rich and rural poor and unbalanced economic growth, and he vowed that the government would continue building up its military, which received a 10.7 percent increase in spending for 2013.

headline: Former Greek Defense Minister Convicted in Corruption Case
abstract: The former minister, Akis Tsochatzopoulos, was sentenced to eight years in prison in the second high-profile corruption conviction in a week in Greece.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A former Greek defense minister, Akis Tsochatzopoulos, was convicted and sentenced on Monday to eight years in prison for concealing assets from the authorities. It was the second high-profile corruption conviction in a week in Greece, a country where prosecutions of senior political figures are very rare.

headline: The Gambling Machine Puzzle
abstract: An entrepreneur has devised a gambling machine. Would you play?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by mathematician Nelson Blachman, who began his research and teaching career at the Underwater Sound Laboratory at Harvard University 70 years ago. Dr. Blachman continues to produce original mathematical research today, a feat of endurance made even more remarkable because of a quality rare among mathematicians: Dr. Blachman is blind.

headline: For Flavor and Versatility, Add Bulgur
abstract: The cracked wheat product can lend a nutty flavor to a variety of dishes.
lead_paragraph: Ana Sortun, a Cambridge-based chef who loves the cuisines of the Eastern Mediterranean and Turkey in particular, was doing a cooking demonstration recently at the Worlds of Healthy Flavors retreat at the Culinary Institute of America in Napa, Calif., a collaborative effort between the institute, the Harvard School of Public Health and the foodservice industry. As she filled chard leaves with a mix of bulgur, sautéed onions, hazelnuts, red pepper paste and dried mint she said: “I think bulgur should be the next quinoa.”

headline: A Stealth Tax Subsidy for Business Faces New Scrutiny
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Government Bonds', 'Corporations', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Many companies are borrowing money for projects using tax-exempt bonds called qualified private activity bonds, costing federal taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: The last time the nation’s tax code was overhauled, in 1986, Congress tried to end a big corporate giveaway.

headline: In Doctor’s Account of Scene, Boy’s Blood Pooled in Street
abstract: A family doctor who lives and works in East Harlem happened upon the scene Thursday moments after Amar Diarrassouba, 6, was struck by a truck. She sent us this account.
lead_paragraph: Melanie M. Canon, a family doctor who lives and works in East Harlem, happened upon the scene last Thursday moments after a 6-year-old boy, Amar Diarrassouba, was struck by a turning truck and tried to save his life. She sent us this account.

headline: China’s Push to Cool Down Housing Raises Questions
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Are there bubbles in the Chinese real estate market? And can some of them burst without bringing down the entire economy?
lead_paragraph: Chinese shares fell the most in two years on Monday as the Shanghai stock exchange’s property index tumbled 9.25 percent. Late on Friday, China’s State Council had announced a new set of policies designed to cool down the housing market.

abstract: The Phys Ed columnist Gretchen Reynolds answers a reader’s question about shoulder pain and rotator cuff injuries.

abstract: After getting accepted to college, I realized I didn’t want to slow down. I wanted to explore my passions and interests.
lead_paragraph: After getting accepted to college, I realized I didn’t want to slow down. I wanted to explore my passions and interests.

headline: Student Advocate Finds an Antidote to Senioritis
abstract: After getting accepted to college, I realized I didn’t want to slow down. I wanted to explore my passions and interests.
lead_paragraph: Getting accepted to Vanderbilt felt like crossing the finish line of a four-year marathon.

headline: Whole Wheat Irish Soda Bread With Bulgur
abstract: A quick and easy bread with a rich and nutty taste.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever been to Ireland you have tasted soda bread, a moist, easy to make bread that is rich and nutty tasting when made with whole wheat flour. It is a very quick and easy bread to make as long as you are willing to get your hands sticky. When you pull the bread from the oven wrap it loosely in a kitchen towel and allow to cool. This softens the crust and makes it easier to cut.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Skirts and Sweaters
abstract: Seen at Paris Fashion Week: ladylike hemlines were coupled with bulky knits at Celine, Dries Van Noten and Jil Sander.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, designers modernized their approach to ladylike hemlines with skirts hitting just at the calf. Pairing them with bulky knits appeared fresh instead of frumpy.

headline: Bulgur Bowl With Spinach, Mushrooms and Middle Eastern Nut and Spice Seasoning
abstract: A simple skillet supper with a savory mixture of mushrooms and spinach.
lead_paragraph: This is a simple skillet supper, a bowl of bulgur topped with a savory mixture of mushrooms and spinach. It gets a final flourish of dukkah, a Middle Eastern seasoning made with toasted nuts (or in some places chickpea flour), seeds and spices that is as much a snack as it is a seasoning; a favorite way to eat dukkah is to dip vegetables or bread into olive oil and then into the dukkah. There are many versions of the mix. Ana Sortun, a chef at Oleana in Cambridge, Mass., and the author of “Spices: Flavors of the Eastern Mediterranean,” adds coconut to hers. The recipe for the dukkah makes more than you will need for this meal, but it keeps well (I keep mine in the freezer) and it is great to have on hand.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: A selection of events for this week.
lead_paragraph: Bento Boxes

headline: Tips for Disputing Credit Report Errors
abstract: If you lose a dispute over negative information in your credit report, you can still include a short statement on the report explaining the circumstances.
lead_paragraph: Checking the accuracy of your credit report is important, given recent reports that 5 percent of consumers may have errors in their reports that can result in higher interest rates on a loan.

headline: Northern Exposure
abstract: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s beautiful, meditative essay in this past weekend’s issue suggests nothing of the controversy that surrounded the publication of his novel in Norway.
lead_paragraph: The essay that accompanies Simon Norfolk’s photographs of the northern lights in this past weekend’s Voyages issue was written by the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard. A beautiful, meditative piece, it suggests nothing of the controversy that surrounded the publication of Knausgaard’s six-volume autobiographical novel in Norway. Lauded by critics as a literary feat (the first volume appeared in English last summer), the book played less well among Knausgaard’s own family members. Part fiction, part memoir, “Min Kamp,” or “My Struggle” as it is known in English, included not just unflinching descriptions of his father’s alcoholism and grandmother’s incontinence but also revealing details about his ex- and his current wife. Some took revenge (the ex made a radio documentary); others sued (the uncle succeeded in getting his family members’ names changed before publication). As The Guardian noted last March, the question of whether Knausgaard had crossed a line became a national obsession:

headline: Viewing World War II Through a Soldier’s Camera Lens
abstract: Tony Vaccaro, who took as many as 8,000 photographs during World War II, was one of about 50 veterans honored along with Holocaust survivors on Sunday. “I felt the world had to see it,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Tony Vaccaro wanted to become a foreign correspondent, but after being raised in Italy, he returned to the United States less than proficient in English. One of his teachers at Isaac E. Young High School in New Rochelle, N.Y., suggested he become a photographer instead. (He joined a camera club begun by his science teacher, Bertram L. Lewis.) He worked as a caddy to afford a $47.50 American-made Argus C2 camera, intent on taking it with him when he went to war.

headline: Are You a Member of the Military Who Illegally Lost Your Home to Foreclosure?
abstract: Wrongfully foreclosed on? We want to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess have a shocking story in the Times today about how, in the course of their foreclosure review, the big bank servicing departments discovered they had foreclosed on at least 700 members of the military, in clear violation of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act. The story also reported that some two dozen homeowners lost their homes in foreclosure proceedings despite being current on their mortgages. (The story also describes, in damning detail, the pathetically weak settlement recently negotiated – if you can call it that – by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the nation’s top bank regulator. But let’s leave that for another day.)

headline: Cardinals Start to Ponder Subtleties of a Big Task
abstract: The general congregation offers a chance for the cardinals to make a case for what kind of pope they want, and to size one another up at coffee breaks and later over dinner.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Like first-year seminarians, they walked through the glass doors on Monday carrying briefcases. Some arrived in chauffeured cars and taxis. Wearing long black coats and red caps, they took their assigned places in maroon lecture-halls seats, flipped through the assigned reading, recited prayers and swore on the Bible to “maintain rigorous secrecy” about their task.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Edwards Wins Phoenix Sprint Cup Race
abstract: Danica Patrick escaped injury when her Chevrolet blew a right front tire, slammed into the wall, then was smashed by David Ragan’s car.
lead_paragraph: Carl Edwards held off strong challenges by Jimmie Johnson and Denny Hamlin to win the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Phoenix International Raceway on Sunday.

headline: Bond Giveaway
abstract: The Times’s Louise Story on corporations that enjoy billions of dollars in tax-free financing.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Louise Story on corporations that enjoy billions of dollars in tax-free financing.

headline: Report Blames Climate Change for Extremes in Australia
abstract: A government report argues that the frequency and ferocity of recent extreme weather events demands action to prevent further changes to the environment.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Climate change was a major driving force behind a string of extreme weather events that alternately scorched and soaked large sections of Australia in recent months, according to a report issued Monday by the government’s Climate Commission.

headline: ‘Fortress of Solitude’ Musical to Open in Dallas
abstract: Adapted from the novel by Jonathan Lethem, the show will play at the Dallas Theater Center before coming to the Public Theater in New York.
lead_paragraph: “The Fortress of Solitude” — a new musical which its composer, Michael Friedman, once described as “a history of soul music on a particular block in Brooklyn” — will have its world premiere in Dallas before landing closer to home, at the Public Theater in Manhattan.

headline: Pro Lacrosse Team Hopes It Can Gain a Foothold
abstract: The rebranded New York Lizards of Major League Lacrosse will play two home games on Randalls Island in 2013; the other five will still be at Hofstra.
lead_paragraph: The owners of the New York Lizards, who had the second-lowest attendance in Major League Lacrosse last year, are hoping that playing games at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island will attract new fans.

headline: New Estimates Question Savings from Farm Bills
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Farm bills passed by the full Senate and the House Agriculture Committee in 2012 would cost billions more this year if they were enacted without changes, according to a new estimate from the Congressional Budget Office.
lead_paragraph: Farm bills passed by the full Senate and the House Agriculture Committee in 2012 would cost billions more this year if they were enacted without changes, according to a new estimate from the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: For a Hospice Pioneer, Still a Tough Call
abstract: For more than 25 years, Paul Brenner led nonprofit hospice organizations. Yet when his health faltered, choosing to become a hospice patient himself proved unexpectedly difficult.
lead_paragraph: Family, friends, colleagues and parishioners said goodbye to Paul Brenner on Monday. He served as the associate pastor of St. Mark’s Lutheran Church in San Francisco, where his funeral service was held.

headline: False Modesty in Decline in European Bank Bonuses
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: One might have expected European bank bosses to show more contrition in the year that the Libor scandal erupted, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: European banks were asking for a slap when new rules on pay were unveiled last week. Just consider this year’s bonus round. Lower payouts had been predicted, reflecting the relative weakness of the business environment. In fact, pay for the average investment bank employee at Europe’s top four firms fell just 2 percent last year, to $313,000. Deferred awards cloud the picture, but there’s little sign of pay restraint.

headline: Ex-Governor Hopes a Lively House Race Is His Comeback Trail
abstract: Mark Sanford, who turned the phrase “hiking the Appalachian Trail” into a euphemism for an affair, is one of 18 candidates vying for a Congressional seat in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Mark Sanford, the former Republican governor of South Carolina, who turned the phrase “hiking the Appalachian Trail” into a euphemism for having an affair, sat in a coffee shop here on a recent morning and wept.

headline: Restless Shareholders May Force Buffett’s Hand on Dividends
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway’s performance over the last four years has been disappointing. That’s likely to increase the chances of a cash payout, whether from Mr. Buffett or his successor, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett’s stance against paying Berkshire Hathaway shareholders a dividend looks to be wearing thin.

headline: Sundance Plans a Mini-Festival in Los Angeles
abstract: The festival, called Next Weekend, will take place Aug. 8-11.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The film festival arms race continues: Robert Redford’s Sundance Institute, having established an offshoot of its signature Utah event in London, now plans to expand into the movie capital.

headline: Return of the Romneys
abstract: In an interview with Chris Wallace, Mitt and Ann Romney explain why their side lost.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney, and his wife, Ann, have had four months to reflect on the 2012 presidential campaign and what it all meant. But time doesn’t always breed wisdom. In an interview with Chris Wallace of Fox News on Sunday, the couple seemed detached from reality.

headline: The New Beltway Icebreaker: “What Episode of ‘House of Cards’ Are You On?”
abstract: “House of Cards” has become the new D.C. social crutch, a pick-up line of sorts that guarantees ready-made conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to the “House of Cards” recap where Ashley Parker and David Carr chat about the media and political dimensions of the show. This week, episode four is under the microscope. You can catch up on recaps of episode one, two or three, as well, but please know spoilers are everywhere, so watch first, then read.

headline: N.C.A.A. Advises on Sexual Orientation Issues
abstract: The N.C.A.A. released an 82-page guide Monday intended to help its constituents — administrators, coaches and students — navigate the broadening world of gay, lesbian and transgender athletes amid its myriad sports.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. released an 82-page guide Monday intended to help its constituents — administrators, coaches and students — navigate the broadening world of gay, lesbian and transgender athletes amid its myriad sports.

headline: Developing Education Initiatives for City’s Young Mexican Immigrants
abstract: A foundation’s efforts are progressing, with 17 proposals for preliminary grants now under review.
lead_paragraph: The numbers alone were stark and worrisome: About 41 percent of all Mexican immigrants 16 to 19 years old in New York City have dropped out of school, according to census statistics — more than double the rate of any other major immigrant group and more than four times the city’s overall rate.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Kim Corrigan joined the New York office of Rosetta, part of the Publicis Groupe, in a new post, partner in the health care vertical.
lead_paragraph: Kim Corrigan joined the New York office of Rosetta, part of the Publicis Groupe, in a new post, partner in the health care vertical. She had been executive vice president and group management director at the New York office of DraftFCB, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Once again, readers contribute “Tom Swifty” jokes about marketing and advertising.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: The Higgs, From Theory to Reality
abstract: The long road to find the Higgs boson is littered with subatomic particle discoveries and canceled colliders, but it ends with a discovery and a theory validated nearly 50 years after the idea was born. (Related Article)
lead_paragraph: The long road to find the Higgs boson is littered with subatomic particle discoveries and canceled colliders, but it ends with a discovery and a theory validated nearly 50 years after the idea was born. (Related Article)

headline: Samsung’s New Smartphone Will Track Eyes to Scroll Pages
abstract: Samsung’s next big phone, the Galaxy S IV, will have many new software features, including eye scrolling. As a user looks at the screen, a sophisticated eye tracking system will anticipate what the user wants to see next.
lead_paragraph: Samsung’s next big smartphone, to be introduced this month, will have a strong focus on software. A person who has tried the phone, called the Galaxy S IV, described one feature as particularly new and exciting: Eye scrolling.

headline: Being Human (Personal and Trivial)
abstract: But not for long.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about silence this morning, but I was actually trying to have a life, briefly. As some readers of my last Friday Night Music post might have guessed, I went to see Elephant Revival at Joe’s Pub Sunday. I uploaded a snippet (it’s an mp4) that I recorded on my smartphone; sorry, I don’t have a YouTube channel, but if someone else wants to post it, feel free.

headline: Craft Beer’s Larger Aspirations Cause a Stir
abstract: The move toward large bottles is part of what is being called the “wine-ification” of beer.
lead_paragraph: Time was, beer came in one size: whether bottle or can, the stuff inside measured a reliable 12 ounces. But walk into a craft-beer store these days and you’ll see shelf after shelf taken over by giants: 22-ounce “bombers,” 750-milliliter wine bottles, even three-liter jeroboams.

headline: A Boston Building for People, Not Cars
abstract: Plans include bicycle racks on the lowest level and six spaces for car-sharing vehicles. Residents would also get their own private garden plots on the car-free grounds.
lead_paragraph: The 44-unit apartment building with ground-floor storefronts, proposed for Boston’s Allston neighborhood, is a fairly bold and modern design under development by the studio of Sebastian Mariscal, the architect. But the most radical thing about it is what is missing — parking.

headline: Cockroaches at the European Commission
abstract: Keynes and debt, again.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written several times about cockroach ideas in economics — ideas that you try to flush away, but keep coming back. (Are cockroach ideas the same as zombie ideas? Not quite, I would say; I think of cockroach ideas as misconceptions held because the people holding them are just unaware of basic facts, while zombie ideas are held by people who refuse to acknowledge contrary evidence).

headline: Biden and Netanyahu Stress Points of Unity in Speeches to Pro-Israel Group
abstract: In contrast to past friction over settlements or the peace process, the focus was on threats from Iran and Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The thundering ovations, slickly produced videos and legions of lawmakers were the same as ever. But something was missing as the American Israel Public Affairs Committee convened here this week for its annual conference: tension.

headline: With Nieuwenhuis on Crutches, Mets’ Outfield Prospects Grow Dimmer
abstract: The Mets’ already weak outfield took another hit Sunday when Kirk Nieuwenhuis left the game against the Marlins after banging his knee while sliding on the basepaths.
lead_paragraph: 2:33 p.m. | Updated A magnetic resonance imaging exam confirmed Kirk Nieuwenhuis has a bone bruise. He said he would be out about a week.

headline: Houston, We Have an Opportunity (to Attract More Tourists)
abstract: A tourism campaign shifts from celebrities to people who are celebrated for achievement in the arts and food.
lead_paragraph: A campaign to attract visitors to Houston has undergone a makeover, shifting from celebrities to people who are celebrated locally for achievement in the arts and cuisine.

headline: Fill-In | It’s a Worldwide Dance Craze, but It’s Not the Real Harlem Shake
abstract: Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article “It’s a Worldwide Dance Craze, but It’s Not the Real Harlem Shake” by Kia Gregory.
lead_paragraph: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first 10 paragraphs of the article “It’s a Worldwide Dance Craze, but It’s Not the Real Harlem Shake” by Kia Gregory.

headline: Ask Ben Brantley About London Theater
abstract: Mr. Brantley will answer questions from readers this week.
lead_paragraph: This week Ben Brantley, chief theater critic for The New York Times, will be reporting on the London theater scene. Among the shows he’ll be writing about are Ian Rickson’s West End production of Harold Pinter’s “Old Times,” starring Rufus Sewell and Kristin Scott Thomas, and a revival of the Stephen Sondheim and George Furth musical “Merrily We Roll Along” at the Menier Chocolate Factory.

headline: Rapping About Saving Money
abstract: The America Saves campaign aims to encourage better savings habits.
lead_paragraph: Reagan Elkins, 19, of Chickasaw, Okla., has this advice for other young Americans: Save  your clams.

headline: Spurned Apartment Buyers Still Long for ‘the One’
abstract: Even if they are settled elsewhere, some cannot help walking by the first place they fell in love with, or wistfully viewing pictures online.
lead_paragraph: Do you ever think about the ones that got away? Has time worn away their good looks? Are they being cared for and treated well?
