headline: Dealing With the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Information disclosed last week about two prominent investigations are more evidence of how mindful companies need to be about the antibribery law.
lead_paragraph: The pressure is only increasing on companies that get caught up in bribery cases, making it unlikely that efforts to soften United States laws will occur anytime soon.

headline: A New Italian Spot? You’ve Been There Before
abstract: Carbone in Greenwich Village looks to summon up a spirit of 1950s, big-meatball abundance.
lead_paragraph: For Italian-Americans, it was the moment when the meatballs got big.

headline: ‘We Are Definitely Continuing,’ Says Living Theater Executive
abstract: The famed experimental theater troupe is losing its current home, but hopes to keep producing work elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: 2:09 p.m. | Updated The Living Theater closed its production of “Here We Are,” a spirited audience-participation piece by its founder, Judith Malina, on Saturday evening. But though the performance was the company’s last at the Clinton Street theater that had been its home since 2007, Brad Burgess, the executive producer, said that recent reports that the esteemed experimental company was shutting down for good are incorrect.

headline: Conjuring a Lively Night Downtown, Circa 1958
abstract: An early look at Carbone, the Italian-American restaurant that pays tribute to the abundance of a bygone era.
lead_paragraph: An early look at Carbone, the Italian-American restaurant that pays tribute to the abundance of a bygone era.

headline: Why Carried Interest Is a Capital Gain
abstract: Little discussion has focused on how carried interest actually functions and why it was treated as a long-term capital gain in the first place, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Steve Judge is the president and chief executive of the Private Equity Growth Capital Council.

headline: Halloween on Coney Island
abstract: Oleg Boksner, also known as Alec Fly, shares a story of celebrating Halloween in the Russian neighborhoods on Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: Oleg Boksner, also known as Alec Fly, shares a story of celebrating Halloween in the Russian neighborhoods on Coney Island.

headline: Walkabout – 3/4: Alaska Airlines Leads the Way, and BBC Sells Lonely Planet
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the Curve Alaska Airlines’ satellite guidance, a navigation technique that allows the carrier to reach towns like Petersburg, above, is now at the heart of the Federal Aviation Administration’s plan to modernize the nation’s air-traffic system. (The New York Times)

headline: Peplum People | A Fendi Film
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld's exclusive new video for Fendi, which features the brand's spring collection, stars Kati Nescher, Saskia De Braw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld's exclusive new video for Fendi, which features the brand's spring collection, stars Kati Nescher, Saskia De Braw, Joseph Dolce and Willy Cartier.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Giambattista Valli
abstract: The makeup artist Val Garland created a subtly futuristic eye for today’s Giambattista Valli show.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist Val Garland created a subtly futuristic eye for today’s Giambattista Valli show. Using a M.A.C. No. 212 brush, she applied M.A.C. Pro Eye Gloss from the outer corner of the eye outward toward the temples, in a thick stripe that tapered toward the hairline, for “a high-gloss finish.” To add a bit of unexpected sparkle, Garland dabbed the same gloss lightly upon the cupid’s bow, following the M of the upper lip. “You don’t really see it, but it’s making the mouth feel fuller,” she said.

headline: Obama’s ‘All of the Above’ Energy and Environment Nominees
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Radiation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: President Obama’s cabinet choices on environment and energy reflect his middle-path approach to governing.
lead_paragraph: 7:06 p.m. | See addendum for sample of Twitter commentary |

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Hit the Wall’
abstract: Frank Fraver talks about his poster design for the “Hit the Wall,” a play about the Stonewall rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Frank Fraver was 19 when he heard about an outbreak of violence between patrons of the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar on Christopher Street in the West Village, and New York City police over the course of several June and July nights in 1969.

headline: What Economists Think About Raising the Minimum Wage
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Minimum Wage', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A recent survey of elite economists found significant disagreement over the effects of raising the minimum wage on low-skilled job seekers.
lead_paragraph: 5:29 p.m. | Updated  As Christina D. Romer wrote in a column on Sunday, there is some disagreement among economists about the prudence of raising the minimum wage. The Initiative on Global Markets at the University of Chicago’s Booth School of Business recently queried a panel of 38 economic experts on the subject, and the responses were mixed, particularly about the effect on low-skilled job seekers. (Nancy Folbre mentioned this survey in passing in her weekly post; here are the fuller findings.)

headline: Geneva Notebook: The Ruined Surprise Edition
abstract: The unveiling of the 220-m.p.h. Veneno, the most powerful Lamborghini ever, is scheduled for Tuesday but photos were leaked earlier.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Despite stern warnings to the media against premature release of information about Lamborghini’s Veneno supercar before its official unveiling on Tuesday at the Geneva motor show, the surprise was ruined anyway.

headline: Another Testing Ground for a Resurgent Nadal and His Injured Knee
abstract: Rafael Nadal, who won on clay last week, will make his first appearance on a hardcourt since his injury, when he plays an exhibition Monday at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: Until only a week ago, Rafael Nadal still did not feel free to run to every ball. His left knee injury, which forced him to take a seven-month hiatus from competition, was still causing enough trouble that three tournaments into his return, he termed his status day to day.

headline: Britain Takes On Brussels in Fight Over Bank Pay
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Bonuses', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: The British finance minister, George Osborne, is expected Tuesday to urge his European Union counterparts to water down proposed rules restricting the size of bankers' bonuses.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The British finance minister, George Osborne, is expected Tuesday to urge his European Union counterparts to water down proposed rules restricting the size of bankers’ bonuses.

headline: Miami Imam Sent Money to Terrorists, Jury Finds
abstract: Hafiz Khan, the imam of a mosque in Miami, was found guilty of two counts of conspiracy and two counts of providing material support to terrorists.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The imam of a small mosque in a working-class neighborhood here was found guilty in federal court on Monday of providing thousands of dollars of support to the Pakistani Taliban.

headline: Support for Israel
abstract: The Times’s Mark Landler reports from the Aipac conference, where attendees offer thoughts on President Obama’s scheduled visit to Israel.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Mark Landler reports from the Aipac conference, where attendees offer thoughts on President Obama’s scheduled visit to Israel.

headline: Caesarean Deliveries Vary Widely, Study Finds
abstract: The rate of the most common operating-room procedure performed in the United States ranges from 7 percent of all births at one hospital to 70 percent at another, a study has found.
lead_paragraph: The rate of Caesarean deliveries, the most common operating-room procedure performed in the United States, varies drastically among hospitals across the country, a new study has found, ranging from 7 percent of all births at the hospital with the lowest share of Caesarean deliveries to 70 percent at the hospital with the highest rate.

headline: Theaters Add Dates for ‘Vandal,’ ‘Belleville,’ ‘Passion,’ ‘Really Really’
abstract: The Flea Theater will give two of its actors a break for other commitments before bringing back “The Vandal” by Hamish Linklater
lead_paragraph: Three Off Broadway theaters announced on Monday that their current productions would add performances because of audience demand after positive reviews from critics, while a fourth theater, the Flea, said that its recent and highly praised production of “The Vandal” would return for an encore run later this month.

headline: The Deficit Reduction We Deserve
abstract: How a dysfunctional Washington delivered the kind of deficit cutting that voters claim to want.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, my colleague Jackie Calmes noted the peculiar reality that Washington has come close to achieving its short-term deficit reduction goals, but the real drivers of our long-term debt haven’t been touched:

headline: Jeb Bush’s Change of Heart
abstract: He was for a path to citizenship before he was against it.
lead_paragraph: In late January, Jeb Bush wrote an op-ed for the Wall Street Journal in which he seemed to endorse a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants and criticized members of his own party who think “illegal immigrants should return to their native countries and wait in line like everyone else.” He argued that, for most illegal immigrants — those without a relative in the country and without access to the limited number of work-based visas — “no line exists.”

headline: Wrinkles of the City: Cuba
abstract: Two artists, José Parlá and JR, interviewed 25 of Havana’s oldest residents for their 26-minute documentary.
lead_paragraph: Two artists, José Parlá and JR, interviewed 25 of Havana’s oldest residents for their 26-minute documentary.

headline: In Berlin, a Protest to Keep What Remains of the Wall
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Berlin Wall', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The dismantling of a 70-foot section of the Berlin Wall has now been delayed, the developer says, after thousands of people massed to protect the wall from being relocated.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In November 1989, the Berlin Wall opened, and soon after was being torn to pieces by jubilant crowds from both sides. Almost a quarter of a century later, Berliners again took to the streets over the wall — only this time to protect what is left of it.

headline: Herding a Photo Crew, and Swimsuit Models, on 7 Continents
abstract: Nothing much bothers M. J. Day, a helpful trait because flying with a crew and models can be an adventure, even before the harrowing helicopter rides.
lead_paragraph: I NEVER stepped foot on a plane until I was a freshman in college. But once I took a trip to Chicago on a plane, I never wanted to stop flying. I’ve worked on the last 14 issues of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, and I’ve been very fortunate to see most of the world. I generally fly in business class, but occasionally coach. In my life outside of work, I seem to always fly coach. Nothing much bothers me, and that’s really helpful because flying with a crew and models can be an adventure.

headline: Canseco, a Former Steroid User, Backs Ban on Stimulant in Diet Pills
abstract: Jose Canseco visited Albany to endorse a legislative measure and to warn about the dangers of supplements and performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY – He was a head taller than any of the elected officials in the room. He wore a bedazzling pinstripe sport coat and sunglasses. And he absolutely did not want to talk about the Baseball Hall of Fame.

headline: Saint Laurent Show Produces Conflict, Both the Usual and Bizarre
abstract: The collection shown tonight by Hedi Slimane, his second women’s ready-to-wear since taking over the house of Yves Saint Laurent label (which he renamed Saint Laurent), will be as divisive as his first.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the things overheard on my way out of the Saint Laurent show Monday night at the Grand Palais, while being trampled by photographers who were trying to get a shot of Catherine Deneuve.

headline: Bumpy Start for a Court Cloaked in Grandeur
abstract: In a new book, Justice Sandra Day O’Connor recounts the Supreme Court’s evolution from what seemed like a jerry-built enterprise.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Day O’Connor or, as she likes to call herself, the Fwotsc — the First Woman on the Supreme Court — is the author of one wonderful book: “Lazy B,”  an evocative memoir about growing up among “old-time, long-suffering, good-natured cowboys” on a cattle ranch on the Arizona-New Mexico border. Written with her brother, H. Alan Day, that book not only did a magical job of conjuring an isolated and now vanishing world of big skies and wide-open plains, but it also underscored how the frontier values of her childhood — self-reliance, competence and dependability — shaped her pragmatic judicial philosophy.

headline: Omega-3s May Lead to Healthier Babies
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Omega-3 Fatty Acids', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Pregnant women who took daily supplements of DHA, a type of omega-3 fatty acid, had longer gestations, bigger babies and fewer early preterm births, according to a new clinical trial.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who took daily supplements of DHA, a type of omega-3 fatty acid, had longer gestations, bigger babies and fewer early preterm births, according to a new clinical trial.

headline: Malhotra and Canucks Remain at Odds
abstract: The Vancouver Canucks insist Manny Malhotra’s compromised vision makes it unsafe for him to play, but Malhotra said their decision was premature.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after his season was ended when Vancouver management placed him on injured reserve and seemed to declare his career over, Manny Malhotra and Canucks General Manager Mike Gillis seemed to be on entirely different wavelengths.

headline: A Poet at the French Laundry
abstract: Marie Howe, the state poet for New York and the author of such books as “What the Living Do,” speaks about the lyrical and occasionally comic role food has played in her life.
lead_paragraph: Marie Howe, the state poet for New York and the author of such books as “What the Living Do,” specializes in vibrant, bracing, haunting work that stops you in your tracks. Ms. Howe, 62, lives in Manhattan; she spoke about the lyrical and occasionally comic role food has played in her life.

lead_paragraph: Joe Wong, a Chinese-American comedian, spoke about the common mispronunciations and misinterpretations of his family's last name of "Xi."

headline: Elliott Calls Hess Plan ‘Incomplete’ and Lacking ‘Accountability’
abstract: Elliott Management, the hedge fund leading a proxy fight against Hess, said in a statement that the oil company’s recently unveiled plan to shake itself up did not go far enough to address management problems.
lead_paragraph: Despite the multitude of proposals that the Hess Corporation unveiled on Monday to unlock its shareholder value, it appears that the oil company’s most outspoken investor isn’t satisfied.

lead_paragraph: A scene from "Stoker," directed by Park Chan-wook.

headline: A Fast Start for ‘Lucky Guy’ on Broadway
abstract: The Nora Ephron play, starring Tom Hanks, drew well at the box office in its first weekend of performances.
lead_paragraph: The new Tom Hanks play “Lucky Guy” posted some big box office numbers by Broadway standards in its first weekend, as did the long-running musical “Mary Poppins” during its final week of performances, according to ticket sales data released on Monday by the Broadway League of theater owners and producers.

headline: The 911 at 50: More Power, Performance and a Higher Price
abstract: The newest Porsche 911, the über GT3 variation that has its premiere this week at the Geneva motor show, produces 475 horsepower.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The first Porsche 911, introduced in 1963, boasted 128 horsepower.

headline: The Right to (Look for) Work
abstract: Arizona’s crudely drafted day-labor law violates the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s crudely drafted and unconstitutional immigration law, already battered in its journey through the federal courts, had yet another setback today. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled that its provisions forbidding day laborers to look for work violate the First Amendment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Kenya, Syria, Pakistan and Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Kenya, Syria, Pakistan and Kashmir.

headline: Eight Teams Use Franchise Tag
abstract: The number of players tagged was down sharply from 21 last season.
lead_paragraph: Just eight N.F.L. teams used their franchise tags by the Monday afternoon deadline, a steep drop from the 21 players who were tagged last season. The decline is likely an indication that even with a modest rise in the salary cap this year, most teams – many of which have gone on a wave of restructuring contracts in recent days to create cap space — found it too expensive to use the tag on any but the most critical players. This came a year after tag numbers that were reduced from the pre-lockout years were considered more palatable.

headline: For Daring Yankees G.M., Sky Diving Proves Undoing
abstract: Brian Cashman sustained his first injury from one of his adventurous extracurricular activities when he broke his right fibula jumping out of a plane for charity.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Brian Cashman has often said that being the general manager of the Yankees is much harder than any of the high-altitude, thrill-seeking challenges he has undertaken in recent years.

headline: Independent Women Celebrate Genres That Never Went Away
abstract: The Indie Pop Prom, at 285 Kent, featured the bands the Pains of Being Pure at Heart, Swearin’, Waxahatchee, Potty Mouth and the Weed Hounds.
lead_paragraph: From a distance they looked polite, the attendees of the Indie Pop Prom, which took over 285 Kent on Thursday night. Most of the young women wore shimmery dresses, most of the young men had on suits that could have used a little tailoring. You couldn’t turn your head in any one direction without spying a tiara clinging to a head of hair.

headline: Improving Security Checks to Help the Disabled
abstract: The T.S.A. is promoting its program for disabled travelers after a clumsy security check involving a 3-year-old girl last month at the St. Louis airport.
lead_paragraph: THERE is clearly no good security purpose served in traumatizing a 3-year-old girl in a wheelchair and upsetting her parents at an airport security checkpoint. Having a security agent take away the crying child’s beloved stuffed doll while the mother records it all on her smartphone can lead to what the Transportation Security Administration, in an apology to the family, gingerly referred to as an unfortunate “incident.”

headline: Singing as if Prizes Depended on It
abstract: The George London Foundation’s annual competition gave six prizes and six “encouragement” awards at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: A singing competition is no ideal biosphere for music to flourish.

abstract: The human story behind the search for the hidden fabric of the universe and the Mediterranean diet — an old standby, back in the the news.
lead_paragraph: The human story behind the search for the hidden fabric of the universe and the Mediterranean diet — an old standby, back in the the news.

headline: The Roving Runner: There’s the Steeple
abstract: The Roving Runner column returns to explore routes in unfamiliar places, or in familiar places but from a new perspective.
lead_paragraph: Pleasing scenery can punch up a routine run, and one recent Sunday I was treated to a majestic view of the Calvary-St. George’s Episcopal Church at Park Avenue and East 21st Street.

headline: Last Dances, Celebrating Last Tour
abstract: Swedish House Mafia — the disc jockeys and producers Axwell, Sebastian Ingrosso and Steve Angello, of Stockholm — came to the Barclays Center on their “One Last Tour.”
lead_paragraph: The joy of self-congratulation filled the Barclays Center on Sunday night, where Swedish House Mafia was playing the penultimate New York City show of its “One Last Tour.” For Swedish House Mafia — the disc jockeys and producers Axwell, Sebastian Ingrosso and Steve Angello, of Stockholm — it was one of four arena-size valedictory shows in New York City, on the way to a final farewell on March 15 at the Ultra Music Festival in Miami.

headline: (Real) Cats on Broadway
abstract: Meet the felines that could play the part of Holly Golightly’s cat in the coming production of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.”
lead_paragraph: Meet the felines that could play the part of Holly Golightly’s cat in the coming production of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.”

headline: For Manchester United and Real Madrid, a Cordial Clash
abstract: The emotion around this city ahead of Tuesday’s Champions League match between Manchester United and Real Madrid is every bit as intense as the feeling outside White Hart Lane on Sunday, when Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur faced off in the North London derby. That doesn’t mean, however, that there is a similar amount of nastiness.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England – The emotion around this city ahead of Tuesday’s Champions League match between Manchester United and Real Madrid is every bit as intense as the feeling outside White Hart Lane on Sunday, when Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur faced off in the North London derby. That doesn’t mean, however, that there is a similar amount of nastiness.

headline: Maybe Stuffy, Certainly Sumptuous
abstract: The Vienna Philharmonic presented three programs over the weekend at Carnegie Hall, conducted by Franz Welser-Möst, the Austrian maestro best known as the music director of the Cleveland Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Orchestras everywhere these days are feeling pressure to find new ways of reaching audiences, to loosen up stuffy concert protocols and, especially, to enliven programming.

headline: Urk, Charlie Rose Edition
abstract: Not my finest hour.
lead_paragraph: Well, we’ll see how it comes out after editing, but I feel that I just had my Denver debate moment: I was tired, cranky, and unready for the blizzard of misleading factoids and diversionary stuff (In 1997 you said that the aging population was a big problem! When Social Security was founded life expectancy was only 62!) Oh, and I wasn’t prepared for Joe Scarborough’s slipperiness about what he actually advocates (he’s for more spending in the near term? Who knew?)

headline: Back and Forth Along an Ancient Trade Route
abstract: China Gansu Dance Theater, from northwest China, brings a Silk Road tale to the Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: The Mogao caves near the oasis of Dunhuang, in the deserts of the northwestern Chinese province of Gansu, are one of the world’s great sites of Buddhist art. By a junction of the ancient Silk Road, they are testament to China’s engagement with cultures to its west. “Silk Road,” the dance drama presented by the China Gansu Dance Theater at the David H. Koch Theater last week, is an example of the specific way that some Chinese artists can turn their great culture into kitsch.

headline: Photos of Oberlin College Students Rallying Against Hate Incidents
abstract: Twitter photos from rallies at Oberlin College after a series of racist, antigay and anti-Semitic incidents on campus.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Richard Pérez-Peña reports, Oberlin College in Ohio canceled classes Monday for a “day of solidarity” after a person wearing what appeared to be a Ku Klux Klan-style white hood and robe was spotted on campus early Monday near the college’s Afrikan Heritage House.

headline: The Daily Do | Stella McCartney
abstract: The Stella McCartney woman is unleashing her inner tomboy for fall.
lead_paragraph: Armed in a voluminous overcoat with pinstripes and baseball cap, the Stella McCartney woman is unleashing her inner tomboy for fall. The borrowed from the boy look is complete with hair that requires zero effort — a simple low ponytail. The message in hair this week is: the less maintenance, the better.

headline: Like Herding Cats? Well, Try It on Broadway
abstract: Will act for herring: The director of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” coming to Broadway, is facing predictable challenges in casting — and rehearsing — the onstage cat.
lead_paragraph: Four days before previews, the cast and crew of the new Broadway version of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” were putting the finishing touches on the show’s blocking, lighting and costumes. But on this final day of February, there remained one gaping hole: the director still hadn’t cast the role of Holly Golightly’s cat.

headline: Scaling Everest and Conquering More Peaks
abstract: In this installment of Jennifer Koh’s Bach and Beyond series — in which she assesses Bach’s impact on other artists — she played a Bach sonata and partita, as well as work by Phil Kline and Bartok.
lead_paragraph: The six unaccompanied Sonatas and Partitas for violin that Bach composed during the first two decades of the 18th century have long represented an Everest that every serious violinist feels compelled to climb. The challenges are considerable, not least because Bach provides few explicit interpretive directions. And for some players, Bach’s monumental set is less a peak to be surmounted than a journey that warrants return excursions and encourages consideration of manifold paths.

headline: Photo Replay: March 4
abstract: A day of races — dogs in Alaska, bikes in France — and Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman before his painful landing in Florida.
lead_paragraph: A day of races — dogs in Alaska, bikes in France — and Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman before his painful landing in Florida.

keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Consumer Protection', 'Liability for Products']
abstract: Karen Bartlett was grievously injured by a mild painkiller, and the Supreme Court will hear arguments this month on whether the maker can be held responsible.
lead_paragraph: The injuries that Karen Bartlett suffered after taking a mild pain pill are enough to make anyone squeamish.

abstract: Just for the record.
lead_paragraph: Joe Scarborough’s accuracy deficit.

keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote Thursday on a bipartisan gun safety measure designed to curb illegal gun trafficking and purchasing.

headline: Elite Status on Airlines Loses Some of Its Appeal
abstract: Carriers have begun selling services once reserved for those who reached elite status in an airline’s frequent-flier program to anyone willing to pay a fee.
lead_paragraph: Travelers with elite status in an airline’s frequent-flier program used to be rewarded with perks unavailable to the masses, like access to better seats, priority boarding and faster security lines.

headline: ‘The Bible’ on History Reaches 13.1 Million Viewers
abstract: The opening night of “The Bible,” a series on the History network, attracted the biggest audience for an entertainment show on cable television this year.
lead_paragraph: The record pace being set by cable programming continued Sunday night as “The Bible,” a series on the History network, reached 13.1 million viewers, the biggest audience for an entertainment show on cable television this year.

headline: Honoring a Force of Nature, in Computers and Networks
abstract: Danny Cohen, a distinguished scientist whose work has been essential to computers and networks, was honored by his colleagues on his retirement from the former Sun Microsystems Laboratories.
lead_paragraph: As a brilliant Israeli-born math student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the 1960s, Danny Cohen was known as a force of nature. And when he learned that Ivan Sutherland, the inventor of the seminal Sketchpad computer interface system, was teaching a small graduate seminar on computer graphics at Harvard, he was determined to take the course.

headline: Czech Senate Accuses Outgoing President of High Treason
abstract: The decision was prompted by the outgoing Czech president’s decision to grant amnesty to more than 6,000 prison inmates and to halt prosecution of executives charged with fraud.
lead_paragraph: The Czech Senate voted on Monday to accuse the outgoing president, Vaclav Klaus, of high treason. The vote was a largely symbolic rebuke of Mr. Klaus, a vociferous euroskeptic who has often polarized Czech society.

headline: Jeb Bush Appears to Support Middle Ground on Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former governor of Florida, a prominent Republican voice on immigration, advocates giving illegal immigrants a permanent legal status, but not a special path to citizenship.
lead_paragraph: As Congressional Republicans stake out an approach to overhauling the nation’s immigration system, a high-profile voice has emerged in support of a middle-ground option for the 11 million immigrants already in the country illegally.

headline: ABC Networks Will Offer Guarantees to Advertisers Across Platforms
abstract: A deal with Nielsen will allow ABC to measure viewing whether on television or online.
lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company will take a significant step toward equalizing the business of advertising on television and online this spring when three of the networks owned by the company, ABC, ABC Family and ESPN, offer advertisers guarantees for video programming distributed both on television and online.

abstract: It was the longest, most costly manhunt in science for an elusive particle that was said to be key to the workings of the universe. For a generation of physicists, it was an appointment with history.
lead_paragraph: It was the longest, most costly manhunt in science for an elusive particle that was said to be key to the workings of the universe. For a generation of physicists, it was an appointment with history.

lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: Israelis Divided Over Separate Bus Lines for Arabs and Jews in Occupied West Bank
abstract: In response to Israeli settlers’ complaints, Palestinians who live under Israeli military occupation in the West Bank and commute to work in Israel are being encouraged to use buses that keep the groups apart.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s transportation ministry introduced Monday what it billed as improved service for nearly 30,000 Palestinians who live under Israeli military occupation in the West Bank and commute to work daily in Israel: two new bus lines “designated” for their use.

headline: Eight Seek to Be Los Angeles Mayor
abstract: None of the candidates to succeed Antonio R. Villaraigosa is expected to win a majority of votes, making a runoff at the end of May all but certain.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With the mayor’s office up for grabs for the first time in nearly a decade, voters here will go to the polls Tuesday in the first step to choose a successor to Antonio R. Villaraigosa. But the mayoral primary is drawing far less enthusiasm than the election eight years ago, when Mr. Villaraigosa rode a wave of enthusiasm and became the city’s first Latino mayor in more than a century.

headline: Fearing Deluge of Litigation, Supreme Court Works the Floodgates
abstract: Lawyers sometimes warn that a certain ruling could mean a “flood” of cases. But if a legal theory is sound, is it a problem if it produces too much justice?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — February was flood season at the Supreme Court.

headline: Bondholders and Mexico Glass Maker Reach Deal
abstract: The Mexican tycoon David Martinez helped Vitro, a big Mexican glass maker, reach a deal with American bondholders after a dispute over repayment.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The giant Monterrey glass maker Vitro said Monday that it had reached an agreement with bondholders, ending a dispute among powerful financiers that had ricocheted between Mexican and American courts.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Microsoft Backs Off, and YouTube’s TV Dollars
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include selling software to companies by persuading its employees to use it, a look at the man who invented emoji, and a walk-on by a mobile app in HBO’s “Girls.”
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: China’s Premier Admits Failings, but Defends Image
abstract: Wen Jiabao is expressing regrets in his final days as China’s prime minister for falling short of achieving genuine political and economic reforms, but he is also defending his integrity.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China, well known for baring his emotions in public, has displayed a blend of defeatism and defensiveness as he winds down his decade in office. During a visit last month to a Muslim neighborhood here, Mr. Wen lamented that he “fell short in some tasks” to improve people’s livelihoods. “In my heart I feel guilty and constantly blame myself,” he said.

headline: Virginia Pastor Sentenced for Aiding Parental Kidnapping
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Child Custody and Support']
abstract: Kenneth L. Miller helped a woman leave the country with her daughter to avoid sharing custody with a former same-sex partner.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia pastor who said that his actions “flow out of my faith in Jesus,” was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison for abetting the international parental kidnapping of a girl in a high-profile case involving a same-sex union and the condemnation of homosexuality by conservative Christians.

headline: Glossary: A Guide for the Perplexed
abstract: Definitions of some important physics terms, from atoms to Z bosons.
lead_paragraph: ATOMS The basic units of ordinary matter consist of one or more electrons circling a tiny, dense nucleus of protons and neutrons.

headline: Read On: Books About the Higgs
abstract: Some recommended reading to learn more about the search for the Higgs boson.
lead_paragraph: Some recommended reading, with comments from Dennis Overbye.

headline: Particle Physicists in U.S. Worry About Being Left Behind
abstract: American scientists are wondering what role, if any, they will play in the future in high-energy physics — the search for the fundamental particles and forces of nature — a field they once dominated.
lead_paragraph: Are the glory days of American physics over?

headline: All Signs Point to Higgs, but Scientific Certainty Is a Waiting Game
abstract: It will take more work and analysis before physicists have the cold numbers that clinch the case that the new particle announced last July is in fact the long-lost Higgs boson.
lead_paragraph: In their bones, physicists feel it is the long-lost Higgs boson, but in science, feelings take second place to data. So these same physicists admit that it will take more work and analysis before they will have the cold numbers that clinch the case that the new particle announced on July 4 last year is in fact the exact boson first predicted by Peter Higgs and others in 1964 to be the arbiter of mass and cosmic diversity. “Personally, I have no problems calling this a Higgs boson,” said Joe Incandela, a professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and spokesman, or leader, of one of the teams, known as CMS, that reported the new particle last July. “If it’s not, I won’t mind eating my words, because it would be so much more interesting.”

headline: Chasing the Higgs
abstract: At the Large Hadron Collider near Geneva, two armies of physicists struggled to close in on the Higgs boson, the Great White Whale of modern science.
lead_paragraph: Meyrin, Switzerland — Vivek Sharma missed his daughter.

headline: Texans Rebut Gov. Rick Perry on Expansion of Medicaid
abstract: Supporters said the expansion would provide coverage to more than one million low-income residents and ease the burden on local taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Hundreds of activists and uninsured Texans plan to rally at the steps of the Capitol here Tuesday, increasing the pressure on Gov. Rick Perry and other Republican leaders to switch their stance on expanding Medicaid, a major provision of President Obama’s health care overhaul.

headline: Mississippi: Candidate Beaten and Burned, Family Says
abstract: A mayoral candidate in Clarksdale was beaten and burned before his body was found by a river levee last week, his family said Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A mayoral candidate in Clarksdale was beaten and burned before his body was found by a river levee last week, his family said Sunday. The authorities have charged Lawrence Reed, 22, with murder in the death of Marco McMillian, 34, but they have not released the cause of death pending toxicology tests. “We feel that this was not a random act of violence based on the condition of the body when it was found,” Mr. McMillian’s family said in a statement.

headline: Obama Faces Political Risks in Emphasizing Effects of Spending Cuts
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama is trying to strike a balance between ratcheting up pressure on Republicans to undo the cuts and minimizing the damage for Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the nation’s top Democrat, President Obama has a clear imperative: to ratchet up pressure on Republicans for across-the-board spending cuts by using the power of his office to dramatize the impact on families, businesses and the military.

headline: Fire in Senegal Kills Child Beggars Trapped in House
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Beggars', 'Children and Childhood', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: At least nine children died in a fire in Dakar, including seven boys who beg and study the Koran under the guidance of a holy man.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A child’s sandal, a charred begging bowl, some fire-singed tin plates. Little else but cinders remained Monday of the house here where 60 children were crammed in by a Muslim holy man to study the Koran — and beg.

headline: Heinz Sale Could Yield a Big Payday for Chief
abstract: Heinz disclosed late on Monday that William R. Johnson, its chief executive of 15 years, could stand to make nearly $213 million if Heinz’s new owners decide to show him the door.
lead_paragraph: How will William R. Johnson console himself if he’s dismissed as H.J. Heinz‘s chief executive following the ketchup titan’s sale to Warren E. Buffett and a Brazilian investment firm?

headline: Come Home, America
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: Our allies must pick up more of the cost of policing the world.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO

headline: Geneva Notebook: Heavy Hauler Edition
abstract: Volkswagen reveals its e-Co-Motion concept at the Geneva auto show.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — One of the faster-growing segments in today’s transportation industry is commercial vans, like the handy new Transit and Transit Connect vehicles made by Ford. At this year’s Geneva auto show Volkswagen reveals it is a “hand-raiser” in the segment also, with its e-Co-Motion concept.

headline: African Trial of H.I.V. Drugs Fails
abstract: The failure was not due to the methods — two different pills and a vaginal gel — but to the fact that the women did not use them consistently.
lead_paragraph: Scientists on Monday reported failure in a large African trial of three different ways to protect women against H.I.V.

lead_paragraph: A takeover. Private equity. Politics. And guns.

keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: For some foreign-born comedians in New York, stand-up can be a milestone to assimilation, whether appealing to niche audiences or seeking to build a mainstream following.
lead_paragraph: In the Bronx you hear that old side-splitter from Zambia about the reluctant debtor trying his best to hide from the neighborhood loan shark behind the short curtain that divides traditional one-room homes, his toes poking out.

keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Head Start Program']

headline: F.C.C. Backs Consumers in Unlocking of Cellphones
abstract: The White House and the Federal Communications Commission said consumers should be free to unlock their phones once contracts are satisfied.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a decade consumers have been able to keep their cellphone numbers even if they switched their wireless carriers. On Monday, the Obama administration and the Federal Communications Commission said consumers should also be able to switch carriers and keep their actual phones.

headline: High Hopes for Cuban Baseball, but Challenges Ahead
abstract: Cuban baseball fans are in a tizzy about their team’s chances in the World Baseball Classic, but that excitement is tempered by concerns about the future of the national team.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — On Sunday, the morning after Cuba’s 5-2 triumph against Brazil in Fukuoka, Japan, its opening game in this year’s World Baseball Classic, Sigfredo Barros ventured to the tree-lined Central Park here to partake in the musings of La Peña del Parque Central, a group of men who gather each day to debate baseball.

headline: A Liberal Party Faces Inquiries Without End
abstract: Federal prosecutors looked into the activities of the Working Families Party and found no whiff of wrongdoing, but the organization cannot seem to get out from under the microscope.
lead_paragraph: It is a backhanded tribute to the power of the left-leaning Working Families Party that it keeps being subjected to the legal equivalent of a full-body scan.

headline: Prosecution Rests in Cannibalism Case; Defense Asks for Officer’s Acquittal
abstract: After the prosecution offered grisly images into evidence, the defense lawyer for Officer Gilberto Valle argued to the judge that the government had failed to prove the officer’s guilt.
lead_paragraph: After offering grisly images and revealing Internet searches into evidence, federal prosecutors in Manhattan rested their case on Monday in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York City police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women.

headline: Inquiry on C.I.A. Detentions to Be Unveiled
abstract: A United Nations investigator, whose report on the C.I.A.’s use of secret detentions and interrogation techniques is to be released, called on the United States to publicly account for the policy.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations investigator whose report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s use of secret detentions and interrogation techniques is to be released on Tuesday called on the United States to publicly account for the policy and said that failure to prosecute those responsible would breach international law. The investigator, Ben Emmerson, whose report was to be presented to the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva, added that although President Obama had clearly repudiated “the unlawful actions carried out by the Bush-era C.I.A., many of the facts remain classified and no public official has been brought to justice.” Mr. Emmerson, a British human rights lawyer working for the United Nations, also called for the publication of a report by the Senate Intelligence Committee on rendition and interrogation programs “to the fullest extent possible.” The C.I.A. declined to comment.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Advises Against Two Medicines to Treat Hot Flashes
abstract: The F.D.A.’s committee members said both medicines offered only marginal benefit, reducing the number of hot flashes by only about one a day compared to a placebo.
lead_paragraph: Menopausal women looking for an approved alternative to hormones to treat hot flashes will probably not be getting immediate relief.

headline: Mali: More Weight to Reports of Militant’s Death
abstract: On Monday, there were further indications that Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, a leader of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, had been killed last week in northern Mali.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, there were further indications that Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, a leader of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, had been killed last week in northern Mali, in the Adrar des Ifoghas mountains, where French and Chadian troops were hunting down Islamist fighters. A Mauritanian news Web site, Sahara Media, which has close contacts with Abu Zeid’s group, cited an Islamist source as confirming that he had been killed in a French airstrike. But the same unnamed Islamist source denied reports of the death of Mokhtar Belmokhtar, another militant leader, who Chad’s military said had been killed by its soldiers in Mali last week. The source claimed that Mr. Belmokhtar was alive and operating to the southwest, close to the Malian town of Gao. France’s chief of the defense staff, Adm. Édouard Guillaud, told Europe 1 radio Monday morning that it was probable that Abu Zeid had been killed. “It is likely, but only likely,” he said. “We don’t have any certainty for the moment. It would be good news.” Abu Zeid is said to have abducted more than 20 Western hostages since 2008 for ransom, some of which went to Al Qaeda. He is believed to have killed a British hostage, Edwin Dyer, in 2009, and a 78-year-old Frenchman, Michel Germaneau, in 2010.

headline: Speaking Fees Bring Booker $1 Million; He Says He ‘Kept Very Little of It, if Any’
abstract: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, who is running for Senate, pledged to put forth a full accounting of his outside earnings.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Mayor Cory A. Booker has earned about $1 million from public speaking engagements during his seven years in office, as he has built his position at City Hall into a national brand.

headline: Senate Report Said to Fault JPMorgan
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A Congressional investigation could revive questions about the role of senior executives in a $6 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: While a trader known as the “London whale” has come to represent a multibillion-dollar blowup at JPMorgan Chase, Congressional investigators have discovered that the problems involved more senior levels of the nation’s largest bank.

headline: Residents Sue FreshDirect Over Move to the Bronx
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A coalition of residents and community groups accused city officials of understating the traffic problems and other impacts the company’s move would have on their neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: After months of protesting FreshDirect’s move to the Bronx, a coalition of residents and community groups took their fight to a Bronx courtroom on Monday to accuse New York City officials of systematically understating the traffic problems and other impacts on their neighborhoods.

headline: Don’t Touch That Remote: TV Pilots Turn to Net, Not Networks
abstract: More television shows are being produced only for the Internet, circumventing existing distribution channels.
lead_paragraph: In the television pilot that Cheyenne Jackson taped recently, he played an aggressive young news anchor whose ascendancy threatened an older colleague. It was a fitting metaphor for the industry itself, because while Mr. Jackson had taped pilots for ABC, NBC and USA before, this was his first time doing one for a new challenger to those alphabet networks: Amazon.com.

headline: Egypt Needs to Act
abstract: America’s $250 million in aid should inspire Mohamed Morsi and his opponents to stop the infighting and turn around their failing state.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s decision to provide $250 million in aid to Egypt is a vote of confidence in a country that is critical to stability in the region but is also teetering on the edge of economic disaster. It is now up to Egypt’s government — and its opponents — to create the political and economic consensus that can leverage the American money to turn around their failing state.

headline: Father Gets 5 to 15 Years in the Death of a Baby Girl
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Shaken Baby Syndrome', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Li Hangbin was convicted of manslaughter last month in the death of his 2-month-old daughter, Annie.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese immigrant convicted last month of manslaughter in the death of his 2-month-old daughter was sentenced on Monday to 5 to 15 years in prison.

headline: A First Amendment Storm
keywords: ['First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The First Amendment does not allow a Hurricane Sandy exception to pay for the rebuilding of damaged houses of worship with federal money.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans and Democrats do not agree on much these days, but they managed to join together last month to breach the proper separation between church and state. By a 354-to-72 vote, the House approved a measure sponsored by Representatives Christopher Smith, a New Jersey Republican, and Grace Meng, a New York Democrat, that would authorize the Federal Emergency Management Agency to make direct grants to churches, mosques, synagogues and other houses of worship “without regard to the religious character of the facility or the primary religious use of the facility.”

headline: Caught in North Korea, Sold in China, Crabs Knit Two Economies
keywords: ['Crabs', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Seafood']
abstract: In a border town in China’s cold and poor northeast, a bridge serves as the gateway for a lively commerce in North Korean shellfish.
lead_paragraph: YANJI, China — At the Red Sun restaurant, a short-order joint on Crab and Beer Streets, live crabs with plump legs wriggle in a cooled tank, fresh from the North Korean coast just two and a half hours away by road.

headline: Long Stuck in Obscurity, Bay Bridge Will Go From Drab Gray to Glowing
abstract: An art installation, billed as the world’s largest L.E.D. sculpture, is set to illuminate the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, the Golden Gate’s long-overshadowed rival.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For decades the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge has been considered, when it is considered at all, as a headache for commuters and a place not to be in an earthquake.

headline: The Intriguing Case of a Baby Cured of H.I.V.
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Medicine and Health', 'Editorials']
abstract: If confirmed, this would be the first time a person has been cured with simple drug treatments, making a lifetime of antiviral therapy unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: Doctors have apparently cured a baby infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, with an aggressive treatment of drugs starting a day after the baby was born. If confirmed by further analysis, this would be the first time a person has been cured with simple drug treatments, making a lifetime of antiviral therapy unnecessary.

headline: Timid Use of the Pardon Power
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Editorials']
abstract: Seventeen new pardons are a step in the right direction but are still disappointing for a president whose clemency record is woeful.
lead_paragraph: Last week, President Obama pardoned 17 people who had been convicted of felonies. An Na Peng, a Chinese citizen living in Hawaii, is the first person convicted of an immigration crime to be pardoned in many years. With the pardon, she can now become an American citizen. Lynn Marie Stanek, convicted in a minor drug deal, told her Oregon newspaper that the pardon would allow her to “move beyond my past in a tangible, legal and personally meaningful way.”

headline: Cabinet Picks Could Take On Climate Policy
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Global Warming', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: In nominating Gina McCarthy to head the E.P.A. and Ernest J. Moniz for the Energy Department, President Obama showed his intent to use all the tools at his disposal to tackle climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday named two people to his cabinet who will be charged with making good on his threat to use the powers of the executive branch to tackle climate change and energy policy if Congress does not act quickly.

headline: Big Shot on Campus, and Everywhere, After Buzzer-Beater
abstract: Khalil Edney became a basketball star of the moment on YouTube and national television after he heaved a winning 55-foot shot at the buzzer for New Rochelle High School.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — In the 24 hours that followed the buzzer-beater turned international Internet sensation, Khalil Edney rode in a limousine, stayed overnight at a Manhattan hotel, conducted national television interviews, held a makeshift news conference and resumed the end of his usual routine — an anticlimactic high school basketball practice.

headline: Lottery Numbers

I’m also impressed that Dr. Bain has taken the time to learn the art of constructing American-style crossword puzzles (he lives and works in South Africa), and because he talks to the animals, so to speak, I would not be surprised if three of the theme entries in today’s puzzle were inspired by his chosen profession.

headline: Venezuela: Chávez’s Condition Worsens, Official Says
abstract: President Hugo Chávez has taken a sharp turn for the worse, nearly 12 weeks after undergoing cancer surgery, a government official said Monday.
lead_paragraph: President Hugo Chávez has taken a sharp turn for the worse, nearly 12 weeks after undergoing cancer surgery, a government official said Monday. “There is a worsening of the respiratory function related to the state of immunodepression corresponding to his clinical situation,” said Information Minister Ernesto Villegas in a 10 p.m. broadcast. He added that Mr. Chávez was suffering from “a new and severe infection.” Officials previously said the president had overcome a lung infection, and it was not clear from the statement whether the new infection was also in the lungs. Mr. Villegas said Mr. Chávez had been receiving “chemotherapy of strong impact” and characterized his condition as “very delicate.” Monday’s health update was one of the bleakest since Mr. Chávez’s surgery.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)']

lead_paragraph: John Wilpers, the last known surviving member of a team of Army intelligence officers who captured the former Japanese prime minister Hideki Tojo after World War II, foiling his attempted suicide so he could be brought to trial for his role in the attack on Pearl Harbor and other war crimes, died on Thursday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 93.

Latecomers looking for lodging, though, were out of luck; there was nary a room to be had in the city. And out near Old Trafford, a pair of drivers idling at a red light on Sir Matt Busby Way waved over two ticket scalpers before sending them back almost immediately after hearing the asking prices for tickets to the game everyone is talking about.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2010) Michael Nyqvist stars as a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Sven-Bertil Taube) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier. Noomi Rapace, above with Mr. Nyqvist, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery in this original Swedish film adaptation of the Stieg Larsson novel, directed by Niels Arden Oplev. “Though Ms. Rapace is a fine professional scowler, with cheekbones that thrust like knives and a pout that’s mostly pucker, she tends to register as an intriguing idea instead of a thoroughly realized character,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “She more or less looks the part that the filmmakers don’t let her fully play.” Ms. Dargis added: “ ‘The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo’ was originally published as ‘Men Who Hate Women,’ which apparently wasn’t sexy enough for English-language bookshelves. The title change certainly spices things up, no matter how commonplace body art is, at least outside of Stockholm, and it plays down its overarching theme, which the movie only does further. Just as significant is the substitution in the title of ‘girl’ for ‘women,’ a categorical displacement (and diminution) that also shifts the emphasis from the crime (and criminals) and places it on Salander’s slender back. It’s an attractive back in the movie, as is the tattoo adorning it, even if, like all the prettily photographed winter landscapes, the dragon covers up something the filmmakers seem loath to reveal and simultaneously eager to exploit.”

headline: Brahmaputra Dams Promise Prosperity But at a Big Cost
abstract: In the Brahmaputra River system, planners face a Hobson’s choice between the twin goals of climate change adaptation and mitigation.
lead_paragraph: ROTTUNG, Arunachal Pradesh—I’m standing, weak-kneed, midway across the gorge of the Siang River, one of the three tributaries that converge to form the Brahmaputra River. Treading slowly over a bamboo suspension footbridge 300-odd meters long and just a meter wide, I marvel at this premodern engineering by the Adi Minyong tribe that dominates this section of Arunachal Pradesh.

headline: U.N. Resolution to Aim at North Korean Banks and Diplomats

lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council moved closer on Tuesday to expanding sanctions on North Korea for its nuclear and ballistic missile activities. The United States and China introduced a resolution that would target North Korean bankers and overseas cash couriers, tighten inspections of suspect ship and air cargo, and subject the country’s diplomats to invasive scrutiny and increased risk of expulsion.

Jeffrey Gettleman reports from Nairobi.

In the southern Spanish state of Andalusia, a network of urban squatters operating under the umbrella name of Corrala Utopia has started occupying some of the more than 130,000 homes and spaces made vacant by the country’s housing crisis.

headline: How Economics Can Help You Lose Weight
abstract: Your personal austerity program.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I visited the southern New Jersey plant of the Robard Corporation, a company that makes meal-replacement products for dieters. Robard’s president, Robert Schwartz, took me to the factory floor, where huge vats of powders — proteins, flavoring ingredients, vitamins — are poured into a 450-gallon V-shaped industrial mixer. The ingredients are then spun together and turned into protein shakes that sell for around $3.50 a serving. As I watched this process, it seemed as if Robard were in the world’s easiest business: take dirt-cheap raw materials, mix them together and sell them at a huge markup to America’s tens of millions of desperate dieters, like me.

headline: What Makes This Radio D.J. Roll?
abstract: Carol Miller, 62, began her radio D.J. career in 1973 and is continuing over the years to solidly promote classic rock.
lead_paragraph: Carol Miller, who is 62, began her New York radio career as a disc jockey at WNEW-FM in 1973. These days she can be heard weeknights on Q104.3 FM and on Sirius/XM’s Classic Rewind channel. Get the Led Out, her widely syndicated show chronicling the history of Led Zeppelin, began in 1984. (That’s not a misprint; it’s Ms. Miller’s commitment to rock ’n’ roll forever) In her recently published memoir titled "Up All Night: My Life and Times in Rock Radio" (Ecco/Harper Collins), she describes her relationships with some of the greatest rock stars of the time. Paul McCartney and Robert Plant dropped by the studio to chat; she dated Aerosmith’s Steven Tyler and Paul Stanley of Kiss. And through it all, she has battled cancer — for 40 years now. This interview has been condensed and edited.

headline: How Users Rate Their Phones

headline: You Have Identified the Candidates. How Do You Pick the Right One?
abstract: When we started H.Bloom, we would hire a candidate based exclusively on e-mail interactions, a phone screen and in-person interviews. After a couple of early mistakes, we realized that we needed to make a change.
lead_paragraph: In my last two posts, I talked about the process we use at H.Bloom to run a recruiting campaign: defining the role, targeting the right profile of candidates, building a list of potential candidates and presenting them with a persuasive pitch. This process is meant to yield viable candidates for a position.
