headline: Cardinals Signal Careful Pace Toward Vote on Pope
abstract: The cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church moved deliberately on Tuesday toward the selection of a new pope following the resignation of Benedict XVI.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Despite intense anticipation, the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church marched toward the papal election at a deliberate pace on Tuesday, making clear they would not be rushed as they formulate their views on who should be the next man to lead the world’s more than one billion Catholics.

headline: In Performance: Maggie Siff and Jonathan Cake in ‘Much Ado About Nothing’
abstract: The actors in a scene from Theater for a New Audience’s production of Shakespeare’s romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Siff and Jonathan Cake play Beatrice and Benedick, the bickering romantic leads, in the Theater for a New Audience production of Shakespeare’s comedy “Much Ado About Nothing.” In this scene from Act I, Beatrice and Benedick, old verbal sparring partners, continue their tart war. The show, directed by Arin Arbus, continues through April 6 at the Duke on 42nd Street.

headline: Warming Up for South by Southwest Interactive 2013
abstract: At the end of this week, thousands of techies will descend on the sunny, sprawling town of Austin, Tex., to mingle and talk about the hottest topics in the technology world. A look at what to expect on the ground and from The New York Times, which will be filing dispatches from the scene.
lead_paragraph: Friday will be the start of the annual South by Southwest festival, a week of presentations, meet-ups, parties, barbecues and hallway talks about the ever-evolving start-up industry and the technology world.

headline: Now Streaming | Valentino Spring 2013 Women’s Collection
abstract: The Fall 2013 women’s collection from Valentino at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Fall 2013 women’s collection from Valentino at Paris Fashion Week, scheduled to go live at 2:30 p.m. local time; 8:30 a.m. Eastern Standard Time. Please be patient; delays may occur.

headline: F.C.C. Backs Consumers in Unlocking of Cellphones
abstract: The White House and the Federal Communications Commission say consumers should be free to unlock their phones once contracts are satisfied.
lead_paragraph: The White House and the Federal Communications Commission say consumers should be free to unlock their phones once contracts are satisfied, Edward Wyatt writes in The New York Times.

headline: Favorite Grammar Gaffes: Danglers
abstract: In our list of recurring grammatical woes, dangling modifiers rank right alongside subject-verb problems and who-whom missteps.
lead_paragraph: On our list of recurring grammatical woes, dangling modifiers rank right alongside subject-verb problems and who-whom missteps.

headline: Opinion Report: Clemency
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: In Performance: ‘Much Ado About Nothing’
abstract: A scene from Theater for a New Audience’s production of Shakespeare’s romantic comedy, with Jonathan Cake as Benedick and Maggie Siff as Beatrice.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Theater for a New Audience’s production of Shakespeare’s romantic comedy, with Jonathan Cake as Benedick and Maggie Siff as Beatrice.

headline: Daily Report: TV Pilots Turn to Internet, Not Networks
abstract: An increasing number of TV shows are being produced only for viewing on the Internet, circumventing existing distribution channels in favor of services like Netflix and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Internet-delivered TV, which until recently was unready for prime time, is the new front in the war for Americans’ attention spans, Brian Stelter reports in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: Houses of Worship
keywords: ['Hinduism', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Mosques', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'Synagogues']
abstract: Places of worship abound in Mumbai and New York.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to get a moment of solitude in a city like Mumbai or New York, where the workplace is often competitive and chaotic, the commute is overcrowded, homes are cramped and the streets are teeming with a bustling populace. In both cities, places of worship often serve as a serene respite.

headline: Still-Unhappy Southeastern Seeks Dell Shareholder List
abstract: Southeastern Asset Management is seeking a list of shareholders and other books and records from Dell, according to a letter to the computer maker’s board sent on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: It appears that despite Dell Inc.’s efforts to the contrary, Southeastern Asset Management remains unconvinced that the computer maker’s $24.4 billion sale to its founder is the last best hope for shareholders.

headline: China’s Balancing Act
abstract: In his final report to China’s national legislature on March 5, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao highlighted the country’s “unbalanced” economic and social development.
lead_paragraph: In his final report to China’s national legislature on March 5, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao highlighted the country’s “unbalanced” economic and social development.

headline: Bad Signs (New York Trivia)
abstract: Think of the visitors.
lead_paragraph: Not a policy post, just a tiny public service intervention from a concerned citizen. So, a plea to Penn Station management: fix your signs! Not for my sake, since I know my way around, but for visitors.

headline: LaFerrari: The New Supercar From Maranello
abstract: Seating positions are molded, padded forms that are incorporated right in the carbon-fiber tub. The steering wheel and pedals adjust to the driver.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Ferrari finally took the wraps off its secrecy-shrouded new supercar, to be called LaFerrari, on Tuesday at the 83rd International Motor Show here.

headline: Bad Breath on Broadway
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: During intermission, two women lament the lack of personal hygiene in the audience.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Tuesday Reading: Exercises for Shoulder Pain
abstract: Exercises for shoulder pain, how to prevent falls and manage the fear of falling, users rate their phones and other consumer focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Chanel: As the World Turns
abstract: With Chanel’s big shows, what we’re missing is the clothes.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld called the latest Chanel collection, simply, “Globalization.” That’s thinking big. And he planted a giant wooden replica of the planet in the middle of the Grand Palais on Tuesday, with pin lights denoting cities and little red flags for the 300 Chanel boutiques around the world. So Chanel rules.

headline: Microsoft Faces Fine in Europe After Breaking a Deal
abstract: The fine for failing to give Windows users the choice of competing Web browsers would be the first levied by the European Union for neglecting to comply with a settlement.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Europe’s antitrust regulators are preparing to deliver a strong message: a deal is a deal, and if a company fails to live up to a settlement agreement, there will be consequences.

headline: Chanel: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Some Things You May Not Have Known About Adam Davidson
abstract: Most important: He is running the magazine’s Twitter account this week.
lead_paragraph: If you read Adam Davidson’s “It’s the Economy” column, you might think that he is a pretty smart guy who knows a lot about how the exchange of money and ideas shapes our thinking. What you wouldn’t know, however, is that Adam isn’t interested in only beer mergers or finding a nanny for his 1-year-old. He also likes to sing Kelly Clarkson songs at the top of his lungs, make henna designs and watch endless loops of “Full House” reruns. He also wore only green clothing for an entire year when he was 38.

headline: Why Don’t We Have Deflation?
abstract: Sticky question, sticky answer.
lead_paragraph: Whenever you see a piece suggesting that the US economy has entered a “new normal” of slow growth, you’re likely to see someone making the argument that if the economy actually had lots of excess capacity, we should be seeing deflation. And the question of why we don’t have deflation is a good one. It is, however, a question that people like me have answered repeatedly; unfortunately, it seems that this analysis hasn’t been making it to, say, a number of current and former Fed officials.

headline: A Promising Debut at Ungaro
abstract: Ungaro’s new designer hits some high notes.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Emanuel Ungaro retired, in 2005, and the Avenue Montaigne house was sold to Asim Abdullah, an affable Silicon Valley entrepreneur with no experience in fashion, the company has floundered. Five or six designers have come and gone (I’m not sure whether to count Lindsay Lohan, who laughably served as artistic adviser). The most recent was Giles Deacon, a London designer, who initially seemed a good choice but couldn’t make anything happen.

headline: British Regulators Slow to Respond to Libor Scandal, Audit Says
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: British officials were too focused on containing the financial crisis to analyze information connected to potential interest-rate manipulation, an audit by the Financial Services Authority said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British authorities failed to spot interest-rate manipulation by big banks because they were narrowly focused on responding to the financial crisis, according to an internal review by the country’s financial watchdog released on Tuesday.

headline: Anadarko and Videocon to Sell Mozambique Gas Stakes
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Natural Gas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: A 20 percent stake in an offshore field being sold by Anadarko and Videocon could lead to a breakthrough for development of the country’s considerable energy resources.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anadarko Petroleum of the United States and Videocon of India have put 20 percent of an important natural gas field off the coast of Mozambique up for sale, according to Videocon’s chairman and others with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Town & Country: The urbane maître d’hôtel of Daniel, John Winterman, bemoans the unsightly legions of “baggy trench coats, oversized shopping bags and damp umbrellas” cluttering his dining room, as more customers refuse to check their belongings. — Pete Wells

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: TV Pilots Move to the Web and Fox Prepares to Take On ESPN
abstract: Television pilots are moving from networks to streaming services online, Fox plans to take on ESPN with Fox Sports 1 and San Francisco becomes a center for innovative advertisers.
lead_paragraph: TV shows like “House of Cards,” “Hemlock Grove” and the latest iteration of “Arrested Development” are debuting regularly on streaming services like Netflix, signaling a departure from traditional networks and a sea change in the way television is viewed, Brian Stelter writes. Amazon.com and Microsoft are also commissioning original shows for their millions of subscribers. The shows’ production values now rival those of network television, and their proliferation is seen as a good thing for viewers that may inflame cable companies’ concerns about cutting the cord.

headline: As Fears Recede, Dow Industrials Hit a Milestone
abstract: There are concerns about whether the forces that have driven the market rally — government spending and banner corporate profits — will be sufficient to push it higher.
lead_paragraph: The economy may be struggling to recover, but by one closely watched measure the fear that not long ago paralyzed the markets has lifted.

headline: The Life Expectancy Zombie
abstract: Definitely a wow moment.
lead_paragraph: So, one of the moments in my debate with JoScar — which wasn’t as bad as I felt, but should have gone much better — was my “wow” when JS raised the old line that life expectancy was 62 when Social Security started, so the program was no big deal.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Saint Laurent
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a four-buckle studded motorcycle boot.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Yes, Even Young College Graduates Have Low Unemployment
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The unemployment rate for people in their 20s with college degrees was 5.7 percent in late 2011. For those with only a high school education, it was 16.2 percent.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written recently about the job prospects for college graduates versus those without bachelor’s degrees, noting that the unemployment rate for college graduates is about half that for workers with no more than a high school diploma (3.7 percent versus 8.1 percent as of January). Several readers wrote me to take issue with the fact that I was looking at the whole universe of workers with these credentials, rather than just the recently graduated. Perhaps college graduates from generations past are more protected than those just entering the work force, they wrote, and it is misleading to say that young graduates are equally secure.

headline: In Women’s Basketball, a Season of the Powerhouses
abstract: Men’s basketball has another No. 1, but the women’s game is all about Baylor, Notre Dame, Connecticut — and Brittney Griner.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever a year when men’s and women’s college basketball were more different, well, it’s hard to remember it, and Monday summed it up in one nice little package. The women’s game is all about powerhouses, about Baylor’s Brittney Griner’s being one in and of herself, scoring 50 points and dunking on Kansas State; about Notre Dame elbowing Connecticut out of its usual spot atop the Big East hill; about UConn hyperventilating because it hasn’t won a national title in three whole years. Gasp.

headline: Hakaan: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: More People Commute to Manhattan Than Any Other County
abstract: Seven in 10 people employed in Manhattan commute from another county, according to the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:47 p.m. | No wonder so many people in New York seem to be coming or going. Manhattan draws more commuters than any other county in the country, while more people leave Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx to work than any other counties.

headline: What Parental Leave Does Your Employer Offer?
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Family Leaves', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: We’re tracking America’s corporate family leave policies.
lead_paragraph: Between Marissa Mayer’s new full-time face-time policy at Yahoo, new numbers showing America’s support for breast-feeding — as long as we don’t have to pay for it — yet more news regarding the dismal state of family leave in the United States, and now, a discussion of whether even graduate schools support new mothers (let alone new parents), family leave has been a big topic here in the past few weeks. With no national paid leave policy (and only 40 percent of employees eligible for unpaid leave under the Family Medical Leave Act), whether workers have access to leave depends largely on where and for whom they work.

headline: Net Over Network
abstract: The Times's Brian Stelter discusses the new, high-quality programming that shuns traditional broadcast TV for the Web.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Brian Stelter discusses the new, high-quality programming that shuns traditional broadcast TV for the Web.

headline: HSBC Sells U.S. Loan Portfolio for $3.2 Billion
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The British banking giant is making progress in shrinking its consumer loan portfolio in the United States, which has been a drag on its earnings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British bank HSBC made some progress on Tuesday in shrinking its consumer loan portfolio in the United States, which has been a drag on its earnings.

headline: The Costs of Underconfidence
abstract: There is a cost to being underconfident as much as there is to being overconfident. Finding the line between the two can be fuzzy.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: The Gun Report: March 5, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: One of the problems with guns is that there are too many people who simply don’t take seriously their killing potential. Either that or they don’t care. Last Friday, for instance, a woman named Mary Frances Alday, 61, went into a Walmart in Crawfordville, Fla., and when she got to the checkout line, demanded that the store redeem a “dollar off” coupon she procured online. She became furious when told the store would not honor Internet coupons, and after lashing out at the store clerk and other Walmart employees – and hurling a shopping cart at them – she went to her car, where she pulled out a loaded Smith & Wesson .38 Special and waved it in the direction of the Walmart staff. After she fled the parking lot, Alday was pulled over by the sheriff’s department and charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.

headline: Don’t Tear Down This Wall
keywords: ['Berlin Wall', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Cold War Era', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'International Relations']
abstract: Germans with little or no direct memory of the Berlin Wall are demanding the preservation of what’s left of it, even if it’s fake.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — One quarter of a century after Ronald Reagan called on Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall, a new generation of Berliners is taking to the streets to preserve it.

headline: Colonel Shaw’s Drummer Boy
abstract: The story of Alex Johnson, one of the youngest soldiers in the famed 54th Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: African-American volunteers poured into the ranks of the 54th Massachusetts Infantry from across the Bay State during the early months of 1863; conspicuous among the patriotic towns that sent their black sons off to war was New Bedford. The seafaring city, with its large population of escaped slaves, had been targeted early on as a prime spot for recruits, and among those who enrolled in the new regiment was Alex Johnson, a 16-year-old sailor with a passion for percussion.

headline: Occupy Rice Paddy
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'Irrigation', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Despite reforms in Myanmar, many grievances remain and the downtrodden are less and less afraid to express them.
lead_paragraph: ALWAN SOK, Myanmar — “Nostalgia” is one way to translate the name of this small farming village 25 kilometers south of Yangon. Nostalgia is also one way to describe the way the farmers who live here feel about their land and the time, many years ago, when they were sure it was theirs.

headline: Lamb of God Singer Acquitted in Fan’s Death
abstract: A court in Prague rules that Randy Blythe is not guilty of causing the death of a 19-year-old fan at a concert in 2010.
lead_paragraph: A municipal court in Prague on Tuesday acquitted the lead singer of the heavy metal band Lamb of God of causing a teenage fan’s death at a concert in the Czech Republic, The Associated Press reported. A court spokeswoman, Marketa Puci, said that the court had ruled that what Mr. Blythe did was not a crime and that the concert organizers were to blame for the incident.

headline: Liz Magic Laser’s Armory Show Souvenirs
abstract: Laser’s concept for the namesake art fair, now in its 100th year, will turn the show on its head by focusing on the visitors as the subject.
lead_paragraph: The European avant-garde crashed onto American shores with the 1913 Armory Show, introducing New York’s art-going public to many of today’s most revered modern painters, among them Cézanne, Kandinsky, Matisse and Picasso. With radical works like Marcel Duchamp’s “Nude Descending a Staircase,” the exhibition both fascinated and disturbed; many visitors regarded the paintings, with their brash colors, warped perspectives and semi-abstract figures, as assaults on the virtues of classical beauty.

headline: When James Becomes Janice: What Not to Ask a Transgender Friend
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Homosexuality', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Supporting a transgender friend  is not only good manners but also about being an ally to those who too often face bias.
lead_paragraph: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners,” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Kennedy Center Season Will Include ‘Swan Lake’ and Hip-Hop
abstract: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington announces its 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: With the Mariinsky Ballet’s “Swan Lake,” Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” and a weeklong hip-hop festival, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington is offering a mix of classics and contemporary pop culture in its 2013-2014 season.

headline: In Video Series, Wall St. Leaders Reflect on Their Careers
abstract: Hamilton E. James, president and chief operating officer of the Blackstone Group, discusses his life and career in a video series created by OneWire, a financial services recruitment firm.
lead_paragraph: Hamilton E. James, the president and chief operating officer of the Blackstone Group, is one of the most powerful figures on Wall Street, overseeing an alternative investment empire from offices on Park Avenue on Manhattan. But it was not always so.

headline: The Lightness of Being Above the Arctic Circle
abstract: Simon Norfolk’s photographs of the aurora borealis and other spectacles.
lead_paragraph: For this past weekend’s Voyages issue, the photographer Simon Norfolk traveled to the Lofoten Islands in Norway in search of the aurora borealis. He first learned about the Lofotens while researching an earlier project he shot for the magazine on rocket launches. He then encountered the northern lights on a separate assignment to photograph radio equipment in Norway:

headline: North Korea Threatens to Attack U.S. With ‘Lighter and Smaller Nukes’
keywords: ['Nuclear Tests', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: North Korea said on Tuesday that it would cut off a hot line with the United States military in South Korea, calling the truce that stopped the Korean War in 1953 null and void.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Tuesday that it would cut off a hot line with the United States military in South Korea, calling the truce that stopped the Korean War in 1953 null and void and threatening to strike the United States with “lighter and smaller nukes.”

headline: London Theater Journal: Memory Plays
abstract: Ben Brantley on Harold Pinter’s “Old Times” and an intimate revival of “Merrily We Roll Along.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One thing, at least, is certain in both the fascinating new versions of Harold Pinter’s “Old Times” that are keeping audiences in a rapt state of perplexity here: The man loses.

headline: With Isolation Looming, Mets Look for Company on Florida’s East Coast
abstract: The Mets seek a second team to share their spring training facility in Port St. Lucie, Florida, because it would generate more revenue and ensure another team does not depart the region.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When the Mets set up training camp here in 1988, Keith Hernandez and some of his teammates took to calling the city Port St. Lonesome because it was so sleepy.

headline: Image of the Day: March 5
abstract: Pigeons being cremated in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

headline: Back Pain Unrelieved by Steroid Shots
abstract: Epidural steroid injections for spinal stenosis may do more harm than good, a small study suggests.
lead_paragraph: A pinched nerve in the back, or lumbar spinal stenosis, is often treated with epidural injections of steroids when exercise and physical therapy are ineffective. Now a small study suggests that the injections may do more harm than good.

headline: A Truck Strikes a Child, and a Doctor Can’t Help
abstract: A doctor’s account of her attempt to save a life of a child struck by a truck on the city streets.
lead_paragraph: Melanie M. Canon, a family doctor who lives and works in East Harlem, happened upon the scene last Thursday moments after a 6-year-old boy, Amar Diarrassouba, was struck by a turning truck and tried to save his life. She sent City Room this account.

headline: Baseball Statues Aplenty, Many of Them in Unexpected Places
abstract: The University of Sheffield in Britain has cataloged baseball statues in the United States in Canada and found that they are a relatively recent trend for the sport.
lead_paragraph: If you are looking for a statue of Babe Ruth, you will not find one at Yankee Stadium. The Sultan of Swat may have been the most dominant player in the game’s history, but the Yankees seem to consider that more worthy of a monument than a sculpture.

headline: Deconstructing ‘World’s Friendliest People’
abstract: Breaking down that perennial question and breaking it down, with the help of Twitter and some travel experts.
lead_paragraph: Which country has the world’s friendliest people?

headline: Nominee to Lead C.I.A. Clears Hurdle After Release of Drone Data
abstract: Senators of both parties have used John O. Brennan’s nomination to try to pressure the White House into disclosing information it has previously withheld.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday voted 12 to 3 to confirm John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency after the White House agreed to provide more information on the legal basis for targeted killings of Americans abroad who are believed to pose a terrorist threat.

headline: Pilot Says Drone Flew Past Jet Nearing J.F.K.
abstract: An Alitalia pilot arriving from Rome on Monday afternoon told air traffic controllers that he had spotted a small unmanned craft as he approached John F. Kennedy International Airport, officials said. The sighting is being investigated.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:00 p.m. |Flocks of geese are not the only airborne hazards pilots will be watching for around New York City’s airports, after one captain reported passing a drone on Monday afternoon.

headline: Living in His Van, Trying to Rebuild a Life Upended by a Bullet
abstract: “Of all the people who got shot, the shooter has the best life,”said Andrzej Leonik, a victim of a serial shooting spree in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Update, March 14 | Many readers have written wondering how to donate to Mr. Leonik. You may send a check made out to him to:Andrzej LeonikP.O. Box 863697Ridgewood, N.Y. 11386

headline: For Times Environmental Reporting, Intentions May Be Good but the Signs Are Not
abstract: The Times has dismantled its environmental pod and discontinued the Green blog.
lead_paragraph: Judging by appearances, things are not looking good for environmental reporting at The Times.

headline: Sweetheart Rates for Corporations
abstract: While the sequester threatens real suffering, Republicans won’t even talk about ending special tax breaks and bond subsidies.
lead_paragraph: At any other time, the news that Chevron Corporation received a federal tax subsidy to expand a refinery in Mississippi would register as just another example of corporate welfare.

headline: Oooohs Turn to Boos as Bieber Shows Up Late for Concert
abstract: “It’s one thing if your demographic is 50-year-olds, but his demographic is lots of little girls who need to go home and go to bed,” one frustrated mother said.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber, who usually enjoys an adulation bordering on worship among his fans, was forced to apologize on Tuesday to concertgoers and their angry parents after he took the stage almost two hours late for a show at the 02 Arena in London, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Revisiting the Story of ‘A Harlem Family’
abstract: For the 100th anniversary of Gordon Parks’s birth, the Studio Museum in Harlem is exhibiting the photos that made up “A Harlem Family.” The Lens blog has the story.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, the Life magazine photographer Gordon Parks riveted the nation with a photo essay on the grinding daily struggles of the Fontenelles, a desperately poor family in Harlem.

headline: Blame It on Bad Data
abstract: Amazon.com is getting bad press again, this time for something it was selling. When you offer millions of items from millions of vendors, you have no idea if a few of them are T-shirts promoting violence against women.
lead_paragraph: Amazon.com can’t seem to stay out of trouble these days. First it hired a shadowy group accused of having neo-Nazi sympathies — not exactly the sort of people you want to be called out for using in Germany, no matter how much trouble you have keeping your warehouse workers in line. Now the giant retailer is under fire in Britain for selling T-shirts that say things like, “Keep Calm and Rape Me” and “Keep Calm and Hit Her a Lot.”

headline: Sonos Does Television
abstract: Sonos’s new Playbar fills what has been a major gap in the Internet-connected stereo service that the company offers.
lead_paragraph: Sonos is no longer ignoring the TV. The company’s new Playbar begins shipping Tuesday, allowing customers to improve the sound of their televisions while also connecting them to Sonos speakers throughout the house.

headline: Ask Well: Can Weather Affect Mail Order Drugs?
abstract: Heat, moisture and cold are just some of the conditions that can make a medicine less potent.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Rich and Proud of It, Saudi Billionaire Prefers Bloomberg’s To Forbes
abstract: Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal has had long disputes with the Forbes Billionaires List, which he says understates his wealth.
lead_paragraph: It’s report card time for the world’s billionaires and one contender is balking about his grades. But as journalism about the world’s wealthy grows, this billionaire now can take his complaints to a competitor.

headline: ‘Downton’ Destinations
abstract: The drama has sent travel outfitters and tourism boards scrambling to come up with ways to explore the lives of the noble classes and their servants, on both sides of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “Downton Abbey” feeling wistful after the season finale won’t have to wait until new episodes air next year to get their fix. The drama — and its success — has sent travel outfitters and tourism boards scrambling to come up with ways to explore the lives of the noble classes and their servants, on both sides of the Atlantic. Below are a few options, ranging from high end to low.

headline: Trading Hits a High
abstract: The Times's Peter Lattman on what's behind a record moment for the Dow Jones industrial average.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Peter Lattman on what's behind a record moment for the Dow Jones industrial average.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Fringe
abstract: A flapper-style fringe melded with modern Parisian silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: A flapper-style fringe melded with modern Parisian silhouettes: Akris created a smoking suit; Dries Van Noten transformed a champagne confection into a daytime staple; and Ann Demeulemeester kept things light with an ombre effect.

headline: Study: Facebook Users More Protective Even as They Reveal More About Themselves
abstract: Facebook users in one university network have become more wary of revealing sensitive personal information to the public even as they seem to be revealing much more about themselves to Facebook and its third-party business partners, an academic paper concludes.
lead_paragraph: Facebook users became much more protective about who sees sensitive information about them, even as they were urged to share more about themselves on the social network, according to an unusual seven-year study by researchers at Carnegie Mellon University.

headline: Relational Urges Hess to Talk With Elliott
abstract: Relational Investors wrote in a letter to Hess’s board on Tuesday that, like Elliott Management, it has found the company’s response lacking.
lead_paragraph: 3:56 p.m. | Updated with Hess’ letter to Relational

headline: Incoming, From the North, a Blizzard of Fresh Dance
abstract: Ice Hot, a festival of Nordic dance opening on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, will expose New York audiences to contemporary dance from Denmark, Norway and Finland.
lead_paragraph: The Nordic nations’ cultural scene hasn’t wanted for attention lately. Stieg Larsson’s crime novels and “Nordic noir” television series like “The Killing” have inspired almost cultlike followings, to say nothing of all that oh-so-sleek, oh-so-expensive furniture.

headline: Vivienne Westwood: At 71, Still Not Done Provoking
abstract: Punk is back in the fall collections, which is not surprising given that the impact of the punk movement in fashion is the subject of an upcoming Costume Institute exhibition. Here are excerpts from a conversation with Vivienne Westwood about punk, and continuing to push buttons:
lead_paragraph: Punk is back in the fall collections — spikes at Donatella Versace and Anthony Vaccarello, garbage bag dresses at Gareth Pugh — which is not surprising given that the impact of the punk movement in fashion is the subject of an upcoming Costume Institute exhibition. It all goes back to Vivienne Westwood, who designed for the Sex Pistols and whose collaborations with Malcolm McLaren in the 1970s will feature prominently at the Met. At 71, she remains as provocative as ever while continuing to design collections shown in London and Paris.

headline: Jimmie Johnson: From Track to Surf to Track
abstract: There’s no slowing down for Jimmie Johnson as he tackles different sports.
lead_paragraph: FONTANA, Calif. — Jimmie Johnson, the five-time Nascar Sprint Cup champion, tossed and turned last Sunday night. His wakefulness didn’t derive from frustration about finishing second earlier that day in the Subway Fresh Fit 500 at Phoenix International Raceway.

headline: Facebook News Feed Draws More Criticism
abstract: While Facebook responded to criticism that it was suppressing content in its news feed in order to highlight advertising posts, small businesses started voicing concerns about the company’s actions too.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week, I wrote about how content I shared on Facebook saw a paltry amount of interaction unless I paid Facebook to highlight it on the company’s signature news feed. Other reporters and bloggers said they had seen a similar drop in connection.

headline: A Well-Heeled Candidate Runs Political Season’s First Radio Ad
abstract: John A. Catsimatidis, the supermarket magnate turned political upstart, is said to have paid to run the 30-second ad for two months.
lead_paragraph: It is a scrappy, somewhat corny political ad (click to listen) featuring a stilted exchange about a New York City mayoral candidate that ends with a woman asking, “How do you pronounce his name again?”

headline: The Bullying Pulpit
abstract: Social media can bring out the bully in all of us.
lead_paragraph: Next Monday I’m scheduled to be on a panel at the South by Southwest mediafest in Austin, discussing the ways in which our digital culture is changing how our children grow up. My role is apparently to make the more expert members of the panel – Emily Bazelon of Slate, Danah Boyd of Microsoft Research and Jason Rzepka of MTV – look brilliant by comparison. Given Bazelon’s timely new book on bullying, I expect that much of the conversation will explore whether the Internet contributes to a rising tide of meanness.

headline: Jazz Hall of Fame Opens Voting to Fans Online
abstract: Jazz at Lincoln Center is asking fans to vote for their favorite artists from a list of 10 nominees chosen by a panel of experts.
lead_paragraph: As part of a broader effort to harness the Internet to engage more jazz fans, Jazz at Lincoln Center is inviting the general public to vote online for the 2013 inductees to the Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame.

headline: Consumer Groups Urge Scrutiny of Car Title Loans
abstract: About 17 percent of car title loans incur repossession fees of about $400.
lead_paragraph: As payday loans come under more scrutiny, consumer advocates are also urging a closer look at a similar type of short-term loan often marketed to the poor: car title loans.

headline: Private Equity and Venture Capital Investments Rise in Latin America
abstract: Private equity and venture capital firms last year committed $7.9 billion to invest in Latin America, although fund-raising was down significantly as smaller firms raised more than big firms.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Private equity and venture capital firms committed $7.9 billion last year to invest in Latin America, a substantial jump of 21 percent over the previous year, the Latin American Private Equity and Venture Capital Association said Tuesday.

headline: From Lot 2 in Brooklyn, Pecorino Fried Bread With Broccoli
abstract: Introducing Restaurant Takeaway, a new online feature devoted to restaurant food you can actually make at home.
lead_paragraph: Is there a restaurant dish that haunts you? Something that makes your mouth water and your stomach growl whenever you start to describe its manifold charms? A dish you’d love to have the recipe for if it were readily available?

headline: First Round of Programming Announced for Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: New features from Rachel Boynton (“Our Brand Is Crisis”), Laurie Collyer (“Sherrybaby”) and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason (TV’s “Designing Women”) are among the 46 works announced on Tuesday for the 2013 Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: New features from Rachel Boynton, Laurie Collyer and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason are among the 46 works announced on Tuesday for the 2013 Tribeca Film Festival, which unveiled its selections for the competitive world narrative and documentary categories, as well as its noncompetitive Viewpoints series.

headline: Pakistan Rejects U.S. Disavowal of Drone Strikes
abstract: The Pakistani military issued a statement criticizing claims by American officials that Pakistan had used the C.I.A. drone program as cover for its own operations in the tribal belt.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military on Tuesday denied suggestions by American officials quoted in an article in The New York Times that Pakistan had used the C.I.A. drone program as cover for its own military operations in the tribal belt.

headline: Telling Secrets
abstract: The White House agreed to send the Senate and House intelligence committees all 11 legal memos on targeted killing.
lead_paragraph: After a long delay, the White House has agreed to send the Senate and House intelligence committees all 11 secret legal memos that it has relied on to kill suspected terrorists, including American citizens, in other countries without judicial oversight.

headline: Victory Gardens Theater to Shrink Its 2013-14 Season
abstract: In his second year as artistic director, Chay Yew has decided to put on three productions, instead of the usual five, as part of a strategic plan to shore up the theater’s shaky finances.
lead_paragraph: Facing years of budget deficits, uneven ticket sales and other financial challenges, the leaders of Victory Gardens Theater of Chicago announced on Monday that they will produce only three shows during the 2013-14 season – instead of the usual five – while trying to generate more revenue by renting out the space to several of the city’s renowned storefront theaters.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Talley’s Folly’
abstract: Danny Burstein and Sarah Paulson in the Roundabout Theater’s revival of the Lanford Wilson play.
lead_paragraph: Danny Burstein and Sarah Paulson in the Roundabout Theater’s revival of the Lanford Wilson play.

headline: Planes, Trains and Automobiles: 8 Tips for Keeping Adult Children Close
abstract: As the novelist Christopher Morley said, “We’ve had bad luck with our kids … they’ve all grown up.”
lead_paragraph: After each of our children was born, the “other biological clock” we faced as new parents was that there are only 940 Saturdays between a child’s birth and her leaving for college. Although many days raising our young children  felt like they would never end, the years flew by fast, and suddenly our precious newborn was saying goodbye to us in her new dorm room. Now what? What happens after kids graduate from high school and leave home for young adulthood? How can a close family stay close?

headline: Gaza Marathon Canceled After Women Are Barred From Participating
abstract: The decision came after Hamas leaders informed the race’s organizer, a United Nations agency, that women would not be allowed to take part under any circumstances.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Gaza’s third marathon run, an annual fund-raising event planned for April 10, was canceled after the Palestinian territory’s Islamic leaders barred women from participating, the organizer, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency said on Tuesday.

headline: Jon Stewart to Direct Serious Film, Will Take Hiatus From ‘Daily Show’
abstract: The television host will direct a drama called “Rosewater” from a screenplay that he wrote, about a Canadian-Iranian journalist who was jailed in Iran in 2009.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jon Stewart, serious film director?

headline: Edita Vilkeviciute Transforms Backstage at Hakaan
abstract: The model transforms with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Paul Hanlon.
lead_paragraph: (function($) {var data = chameleonData[0];var beforeAfterContainer = $('#nytmm_beforeAfter_wrapper653 .nytmm_beforeAfter_container');var options = {leftImage: data.images.left.leftImage,rightImage: data.images.right.rightImage,showFooter: data.footer.showFooter,leftCredit: data.images.left.leftCredit,rightCredit: data.images.right.rightCredit,caption: data.footer.caption,startPoint: data.images.startPoint,showButton: data.footer.button.showButton,leftButtonText: data.footer.button.leftButtonText,rightButtonText: data.footer.button.rightButtonText}beforeAfterContainer.BeforeAfter(options);})(jQuery||NYTD.jQuery);

headline: Southern Cal Interviews Floyd
abstract: While Tim Floyd’s tenure at Southern Cal was successful — he was 85-55 with three N.C.A.A. tournament appearances — bringing him back would seem like a strange decision by athletic director Pat Haden.
lead_paragraph: When Pat Haden was hired as Southern California’s athletic director in 2010, the emphasis was on cleaning up the place. His ousted predecessor, Mike Garrett, had presided over N.C.A.A. scandals in both the football and basketball programs that brought stiff sanctions to the school.

headline: Mark Cuban May Face S.E.C. Insider Trading Trial
abstract: A Federal District Court judge in Dallas denied a request by Mark Cuban to dismiss a nearly five-year-old insider-trading lawsuit brought against him by federal securities regulators. A June trial is scheduled.
lead_paragraph: With the Dallas Mavericks having a subpar season, it is unlikely that the basketball team’s charismatic owner, Mark Cuban, will find himself courtside during the N.B.A. finals in June.

headline: Living Along Central Park West
abstract: Tony residential buildings look out onto an oasis of green along one of New York City’s grandest stretches.
lead_paragraph: Tony residential buildings look out onto an oasis of green along one of New York City’s grandest stretches.

headline: Eye Candy, Structural and Natural
abstract: A necklace of fine architecture, strung between clasps — Columbus Circle to the south, Frederick Douglass Circle to the north — with barely any storefronts, unless you count doctors’ offices.
lead_paragraph: Architectural grandeur lines one side, 1.32 square miles of natural splendor the other; in these you have the virtues that validate Central Park West’s pride of place among city attractions. It certainly isn’t the shopping — there is no sidewalk-level retail on the entire 51-block stretch, beyond a dry cleaner, a tax preparer and a deli (unless you count doctors’ offices).

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Dismissing Science
abstract: A doctor laments that science is increasingly ignored in devising public policy. Readers are invited to reply.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sports Illustrated Lands New Armstrong Interview
abstract: The magazine billed it as Lance Armstrong’s first since talking with Oprah Winfrey six weeks ago. It came about serendipitously after the writer, Michael McCann, noticed that Mr. Armstrong had started following him on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: 4:17 p.m. | Updated Lance Armstrong thought about bypassing the media and making a confessional video for the Web that would have detailed his substance abuse and included an apology to his fans. But instead he sat down with Oprah Winfrey, and he doesn’t regret the choice, Mr. Armstrong told a writer for Sports Illustrated in a column that was published online on Tuesday.

headline: Guest Lesson | Espionage Everywhere: Spying in the News and Popular Culture
abstract: In this lesson plan, we provide five ways you can pair the intrigue of espionage with Times reporting to get students to think critically, ask questions, and see a different side of history and current events.
lead_paragraph: When the International Spy Museum approached us about doing a guest lesson, we were immediately intrigued, especially when they pointed out how much of the news The Times reports every day is based on intelligence gathering.

headline: Former Wells Fargo Broker Is Sentenced to 2 Years
abstract: A former Wells Fargo broker who pleaded guilty to defrauding more than a dozen clients was sentenced to two years in jail.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in California has sentenced Philip Horn, a former Wells Fargo broker who pleaded guilty to defrauding more than a dozen clients, to two years in jail.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Backs Mideast Efforts to Arm Syrian Rebels
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said that the Obama administration had gained new confidence that the Syrian opposition can minimize the risk of weapons falling into extremists’ hands.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Secretary of State John Kerry said Tuesday that the Obama administration supported efforts by Middle Eastern nations to send arms to the opposition in Syria, and had had discussions with foreign officials to emphasize that those arms should go to moderate forces rather than to extremists.

headline: Moldova’s Pro-Western Government Falls
abstract: Prime Minister Vlad Filat’s governing coalition failed a no-confidence motion on Tuesday, shattering an alliance that had put the former Soviet republic on a path toward integration with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The pro-Western government of Moldova fell on Tuesday when Parliament passed a no-confidence motion, shattering a fragile political alliance that had put the former Soviet republic on a path toward integration with the European Union.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Saint Laurent
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Manhattan Theater Club to Stage Play by Amanda Peet
abstract: Amanda Peet, a television and theater actress, has written “The Commons of Pensacola,” about a family grappling with the fallout from the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: The actress Amanda Peet will get her first professional credit as a playwright next season when Manhattan Theater Club stages “The Commons of Pensacola,” her work about a family grappling with the fallout from the financial crisis.

headline: Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque
abstract: Inside the East Village barbecue restaurant that serves Flintstonian beef ribs.
lead_paragraph: Inside the East Village barbecue restaurant that serves Flintstonian beef ribs.

headline: BrisketTown and Fletcher’s Brooklyn Barbecue
abstract: Inside two of Brooklyn’s new barbecue restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Inside two of Brooklyn’s new barbecue restaurants.

headline: Concerns About Politics Overshadow an Auto Show
keywords: ['Geneva International Motor Show', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Amid the new models at the auto show, fresh reasons to fear for the health of the long-suffering European market.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Such is the state of the European car industry that one of the main topics at the Geneva auto show on Tuesday was the political situation in Italy. While automakers continued to show new models with extravagant events, almost everything is overshadowed by the economic crisis in Europe and the risk that political turmoil in Italy will undermine any recovery.

headline: Officer Won’t Testify, Ending Defense Side in Cannibal Case
abstract: The officer, Gilberto Valle, charged with plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women, told a judge it was in his best interest not to take the stand.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women, rested their case on Tuesday, shortly after the officer said he would not take the witness stand in his own defense.

headline: Big League BBQ Arrives
abstract: True barbecue in New York? Mighty Quinn’s Barbeque in the East Village is leading the charge.
lead_paragraph: Chase the scent of great barbecue in New York City, and you are rooting for a team that will, sooner or later, let you down. You are a Red Sox fan in any season from 1919 to 2003. There will be enough victories to keep the dream flickering, and there will be nights when you watch the ball hop between the first baseman’s legs.

headline: Charges Against Florida A&M Band Members Are Changed to Manslaughter
abstract: Robert Champion was found beaten to death by fellow Florida A & M band members in 2011, and 12 men have been charged with manslaughter in the crime.
lead_paragraph: The charges against 12 former band members at Florida A&M have been upgraded to manslaughter in the beating death of drum major Robert Champion in 2011, Florida prosecutors informed the accused on Monday.

headline: Chávez Dies, Leaving Sharp Divisions in Venezuela
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: President Hugo Chávez left behind a nation in the grip of political turmoil that grew more acute as he languished for weeks.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela died Tuesday afternoon after a struggle with cancer, the government announced, leaving behind a bitterly divided nation in the grip of a political crisis that grew more acute as he languished for weeks, silent and out of sight, in hospitals in Havana and Caracas.

headline: Lip-Smackin’ Sips to Wash the Barbecue Down
abstract: Any discussion of barbecue is likely to become an argument. Why should a discussion of what to drink with it be different?
lead_paragraph: Any discussion of barbecue is likely to become an argument. Why should a discussion of what to drink with it be different?

headline: The Tsunami Killed Her Family. She Tells of What Came Next.
abstract: Sonali Deraniyagala chronicles the agonized aftermath of the 2004 tsunami that drowned her parents, husband and two children.
lead_paragraph: “This is the saddest story I have ever heard.” So goes the first sentence of Ford Madox Ford’s 1915 masterpiece, “The Good Soldier.”

headline: Photo Replay: March 5
abstract: A look at the day in sports from the Paris-Nice cycling race to baseball spring training camp games.
lead_paragraph: A look at the day in sports from the Paris-Nice cycling race to baseball spring training camp games.

headline: Hermès: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Video Games May Aid Children With Dyslexia
abstract: A small study finds that certain action video games may help improve reading skills in children with dyslexia.
lead_paragraph: Playing action video games may improve reading in children with dyslexia, Italian researchers have found.

headline: Teen Angst Leavened by Goofiness
abstract: Music, wrestling, pratfalls: an “As You Like It” at the New Victory Theater that aims to charm adolescents.
lead_paragraph: First, let’s change the title to “B.F.F.’s in the Forest of Arden.”

headline: Take Part in Our Recipe Lab Video Chat
abstract: You’re invited to a live cooking conversation with Julia Moskin of The New York Times and the cookbook author Nigella Lawson.
lead_paragraph: Today we posted our first installment of Recipe Lab, a monthly feature by Julia Moskin in which you, our readers, will play a central role. On March 14 at 3:30 p.m. Eastern, the cookbook author Nigella Lawson will join Ms. Moskin for a live video conversation, via Google+ Hangout, about cooking, her new book, “Nigellissima,” and her recipe for whole wheat pasta with brussels sprouts, cheese and potato.

headline: Making Pasta With Nigella Lawson
abstract: Recipe Lab, a new feature, invites you to join cookbook authors to discuss their recipes in a live video chat.
lead_paragraph: It takes just two good recipes for a new cookbook to earn a place on my shelf. But which recipes to try first? In Recipe Lab, a new monthly online feature, I make the book’s author choose its essential recipes for us. I’ll select one for you, our readers, to make at home. As you cook — or even if you don’t — you’ll be able to post comments and questions for the author here on Diner’s Journal. The author will then join me, and three of you, in a live video chat that everyone can watch.

headline: Composer Can’t Complain About the Piano Player
abstract: The British pianist Stephen Hough played the New York premiere of his own Piano Sonata No. 2 on Monday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: It is hard for concertgoers today to imagine what it must have been like in the early decades of the 20th century, when towering composers who were also extraordinary pianists, like Rachmaninoff, Prokofiev and Bartok, performed their own works. We have some invaluable recordings, of course. But hearing these composers playing their music when it was new must have been overwhelming.

headline: Martha Stewart Back in Court in Contract Dispute
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Testifying in a lawsuit by Macy’s over where her branded products can be sold, Ms. Stewart talked about her designs, her past ventures and her prison time.
lead_paragraph: It was a familiar scene for Martha Stewart’s day in court: photographers camped at the back and front entrances of a Manhattan courthouse, members of the news media lining up for seats, spectators buzzing about what she might say.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: This May, plenty of new restaurants opening in Kennedy Airport; Texas barbecue will find its way to Brooklyn; and more.
lead_paragraph: Headliner Terminal 4, Kennedy Airport

headline: Head Over Heels
abstract: Valerie Steele and Colleen Hill of the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology meticulously chronicle the world of fancy footwear in their new book.

headline: White House Tours Halted Over Cuts; Congress Says, ‘We’re Open’
abstract: As the spring tourism season nears, the White House said it would cease offering tours starting on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration told members of Congress on Tuesday that it was canceling all White House tours beginning on Saturday because of the $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts that went into effect last week.

headline: Kissinger Briefly Hospitalized After Fall
abstract: Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, was admitted to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital on Tuesday and released later in the day.
lead_paragraph: Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, was admitted to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital on Tuesday after a fall at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. Mr. Kissinger, 89, was released Tuesday afternoon, the hospital said. No details were released about his injuries.

headline: Surveys Quantify Loss of Elephants in Africa
abstract: A new report, based on 80 surveys, suggests that 60 percent of the forest elephants in Africa were killed between 2002 to 2011.
lead_paragraph: Sixty percent of the forest elephants in Africa were killed from 2002 to 2011, scientists reported on Monday, putting a number to the rampant slaughter of both forest and savannah elephants for their ivory.

headline: A Two-Man Team’s Songs, Too Big for Just Those Two
abstract: The songs of Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey were performed on Friday at Lincoln Center as part of its American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: In his Broadway score for “Next to Normal” the composer Tom Kitt did more than anyone since Jonathan Larson in “Rent” to advance the inevitable integration of rock sound, rhythm and attitude into the Broadway musical. That’s a tricky challenge, since the louder music becomes, and the more obtrusive its beats, the more that intelligibility and melodic subtlety tend to fall by the wayside.

headline: Who Really Hates Anne Hathaway?
abstract: The Twitterverse, the media, and the wider world beyond.
lead_paragraph: To the surprise of absolutely no one with a Twitter feed, a new Pew study finds that tweeted reaction “to major political events and policy decisions often differs a great deal from public opinion as measured by surveys,” and reports that more than partisanship, it’s “the overall negativity” of Twitter reactions that really stand out. I could write a thumbsucking post about how this phenomenon probably influences our politics for the worse, by encouraging journalists — most of whom (myself included) now watch crucial moments of political theater with their fellow scribes’ snark scrolling in the background — to let their natural solipsism and their natural cynicism intertwine, and pretend that what they see on Twitter is the political world entire. But I think I can get at the same idea by talking about Anne Hathaway instead.

headline: Hugo Chávez, 1954-2013
abstract: Simon Romero, The Times’s former Caracas bureau chief, reflects on the presidency of Hugo Chávez.
lead_paragraph: Simon Romero, The Times’s former Caracas bureau chief, reflects on the presidency of Hugo Chávez.

headline: It’s Still Winter, Unless You’re a Fall TV Pilot
abstract: The major networks have ordered scores of pilots for the 2013 fall season, including some linked with big names and intriguing premises.
lead_paragraph: The terror gripping broadcast television as viewers continue to run away — 8.6 million to “Duck Dynasty,” 13.1 million to “The Bible,” who knows how many to “House of Cards” — has meant boom times for TV’s most ephemeral product: the network pilot.

headline: Flash of Red Leaves United Speechless
abstract: Cristiano Ronaldo’s goal with about 20 minutes left gave Real Madrid a 3-2 aggregate lead over Manchester United, securing Real’s passage to the Champions League quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Cristiano Ronaldo nudged the ball over the goal line from a sharp angle, then slid past the post and behind the net. As the small Real Madrid section of fans at Old Trafford roared, Ronaldo, who twirled his magic for Manchester United for six seasons before departing for Spain, held up his hands and asked for restraint.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, West Bank, Kenya and Italy.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, West Bank, Kenya and Italy.

headline: U.S. Relaxes Air Travel Carry-On Prohibitions
abstract: Starting April 25, the T.S.A. will allow pocketknives, golf clubs and other sports items aboard planes, permitting agents to focus on “higher-threat items.”
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration said on Tuesday that it would allow airplane passengers to bring pocketknives, golf clubs and other sports items aboard in carry-on bags, loosening some of the restrictions created after the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Kickstarter Undressed and Evernote’s Ambition
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include an analysis of Facebook’s attempts to make money from advertising, some interesting buildings that are going to rise in Silicon Valley and a discouraging anecdote from a freelance journalist about his dealings with an online news site.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 5
abstract: Video highlights of Tuesday’s games in the Round of 16 in the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: The Payoff in Delaying Retirement
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Retirement', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: One way of dealing with the federal deadlock is to have older, healthy Americans work a little longer.
lead_paragraph: It’s remarkably difficult to find an economist who thinks the spending cuts ripping through the budget since last Friday amount to a good idea.

headline: A Polarizing Figure Who Led a Movement
abstract: Mr. Chávez led a nationalist movement that lashed out at the United States and wealthy Venezuelans, tapping into the resentments of his country’s poor.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Hugo Chávez, who died on Tuesday at 58, rose from poverty in a dirt-floor adobe house to unrivaled influence in Venezuela as its president, consolidating power and wielding the country’s oil reserves as a tool for his Socialist-inspired change.

headline: Former SAC Trader Gets More Time to Prepare Defense
abstract: A federal judge has granted a former employee of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors additional time to review the government’s evidence in an insider trading case brought against him.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday granted a former employee of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors additional time to review the government’s evidence in an insider trading case brought against him.

headline: Jeb Bush Enters Debate, and Possibly 2016 Race
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Books and Literature', 'Illegal Immigrants']
abstract: Mr. Bush could be setting up a G.O.P. showdown with a protégé, Marco Rubio, and another Bush vs. Clinton presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As political re-entries go, Jeb Bush’s has been rocky.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, a French book on cooking vegetables; a doughnut that’s not shy; sauces that taste of the Caribbean and more.
lead_paragraph: To Read: Vegetables the French Way

headline: 10 Memorable Hugo Chávez Moments
abstract: Mr. Chávez was known for his grand overtures and bold attacks. An exceptionally gifted orator who relished media attention, he continually came up with show-stealing lines.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Chávez was known for his grand overtures and bold attacks. An exceptionally gifted orator who relished media attention, he continually came up with show-stealing lines.

headline: Obama Recruits Republicans for Budget Talks With Personal Calls
abstract: Amid onset of across-the-board spending cuts and an impasse with Republican leaders, President Obama is looking to rank-and-file Republican senators.
lead_paragraph: For most of his presidency, Barack Obama has viewed outreach to Congress as a chore rarely to be touched, and rank-and-file Republicans largely a contact point of last resort.

headline: The Daily Do | Valentino
abstract: The look evoked school-girl charm with a woman’s sophistication.
lead_paragraph: The Valentino girl, sweet and feminine this season in lace baby doll dresses and T-strap shoes, flaunted hair parted down the middle, braided to the side and topped with a satin ribbon. The look evoked schoolgirl charm with a woman’s sophistication.

headline: Where You Go to Get Away
abstract: A gallery of readers’ local escapes.

headline: Paris Lands in Brooklyn, for a Day
abstract: The St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble presented a Paris-themed concert, “Spin Paris,” at the Brooklyn Museum, featuring the premiere of a piece by Sean Shepherd.
lead_paragraph: Just outside the Cantor Auditorium at the Brooklyn Museum, curators have hung Henri Fantin-Latour’s “Portrait of Madame Léon Maître.” The painting’s subject seems both quietly pleased and a little disengaged.

headline: Venezuela Without Chávez
abstract: A senior fellow for the Council on Foreign Relations discusses a country left in flux after the death of President Hugo Chávez.
lead_paragraph: A senior fellow for the Council on Foreign Relations discusses a country left in flux after the death of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: A Sports Complex Shows Its Brains and Brawn
abstract: Columbia University’s new sports complex, by Steven Holl Architects, fills a difficult site at the northern tip of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University, busily expanding into Harlem, has meanwhile opened the Campbell Sports Center, a $30 million athletic building in Inwood, the neighborhood at the northern tip of Manhattan.

headline: Model Diary | Esther Heesch
abstract: The 16-year-old German model loves “Gossip Girl,” Paris and Jake Bugg.
lead_paragraph: Esther Heesch, 16 years old and from the city of Lübeck in northern Germany, was scouted just over a year ago on the streets of Hamburg. The young newbie rocked the runway today in sophisticated Valentino, edgy Chanel and showstopping Alexander McQueen.

headline: D’Angelo and Ahmir Questlove Thompson at Brooklyn Bowl
abstract: D’Angelo and Ahmir Questlove Thompson played to a sold-out crowd on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: D’Angelo and Ahmir Questlove Thompson played to a sold-out crowd on Monday night.

headline: Resonant Oldies With a Tongue-in-Cheek Subtext
abstract: Performing with Questlove, D’Angelo segued from others’ songs to his own.
lead_paragraph: The long tease continues.

headline: Missing German Reporter Released by Syrian Government
abstract: Syria released a German journalist who went missing more then two months ago, saying he had entered the country illegally but would be turned over to the Russian ambassador and sent home.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian government released a German journalist who went missing more than two months ago on Tuesday, saying the man had entered the country illegally but would be turned over to the Russian ambassador and sent home.

headline: A Lyrical Tour Through Europe Starts on the West Coast
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s “From Foreign Lands,” which had its premiere at the San Francisco Ballet, spins through European national dances.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is living a jet-setter’s life: On two consecutive Fridays two of his works had their world premieres on prestigious stages more than 5,000 miles apart. On Feb. 24 at the Royal Opera House in London, he joined eight Royal Ballet dancers onstage after the first performance of his “24 Preludes.” On Friday, at the War Memorial Opera House here, he similarly joined the 12 San Francisco Ballet dancers who had just delivered the premiere of his “From Foreign Lands.”

headline: A Work in Progress, From the Inside Out
abstract: “Gut Renovation” is Su Friedrich’s cranky, sarcastic documentary about the real-estate boom that changed, and drove her out of, what had been an artists’ enclave in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: An alternate title for “Gut Renovation,” Su Friedrich’s cranky, sarcastic documentary polemic about the gentrification of a Brooklyn neighborhood, might be “The Rape of Williamsburg.” Ms. Friedrich, an independent filmmaker, moved there in 1989 when it was an artists’ haven and a multiethnic, working-class neighborhood with a vibrant street life. After the City Council passed a rezoning ordinance in 2005, an area 6 blocks wide and 17 blocks long became the site of a frantic real estate boom.

headline: Americans on Terror Threats

headline: U.S. Catholics in Poll See a Church Out of Touch

lead_paragraph: Roman Catholics in the United States say that their church and bishops are out of touch, and that the next pope should lead the church in a more modern direction on issues like birth control and ordaining women and married men as priests, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

lead_paragraph: A star-studded battle among hedge fund titans over the nutritional supplements company Herbalife became the talk of Wall Street when it erupted. But when the barbs eventually fall silent and the klieg lights dim, how will the Herbalife war end? And what truth will emerge?

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, is all but certain to take his case directly to a jury on June 10 and skip a highly anticipated pretrial self-defense hearing, his lawyer said Tuesday.

headline: Geneva Notebook: The Revenge of the Customizers
abstract: When Geneva rolls around on the international auto salon calendar each March, consider the styling envelope about to be folded, spindled and mutilated.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — If the Hollywood director Tim Burton designed cars, he would save his most twisted creations for the Geneva motor show. When Geneva rolls around on the international auto salon calendar each March, consider the styling envelope about to be folded, spindled and mutilated. To tell a designer with something on display here that his work is wildly impractical would be to bestow the highest sort of compliment.

abstract: Though his ill-fated design became a synonym for bad ideas, Mr. Brown was proud of it and drove one into his 90s.
lead_paragraph: Roy Brown Jr., a car designer for Ford Motor whose signature creation, the supposedly futuristic but ultimately ill-fated Edsel, became a synonym for bold, bad ideas not long after it was introduced in 1957, died on Feb. 24 in Michigan. He was 96.

headline: Turkey Renews Focus on Ending Its Long Conflict With Kurds
abstract: One of the region’s most intractable conflicts may be nearing a close, thanks to the determination of the prime minister, yet ending violence will not end tension.
lead_paragraph: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — When three prominent Kurdish women activists were murdered in Paris in January, analysts worried that the killings would derail the fledgling peace talks, begun late last year. Just the opposite appears to have happened, as both sides have moved forward with more determination to end one of the region’s most intractable conflicts, which has claimed almost 40,000 lives over nearly three decades.

lead_paragraph: EARLIER this week, I spotted, among the job listings in the newspaper Reforma, an ad from a restaurant in Mexico City looking to hire dishwashers. The requirement: a secondary school diploma.

lead_paragraph: CLARKSDALE, Miss. — A Mississippi mayoral candidate who was found dead last week was not killed by being beaten, burned or dragged, the coroner said on Tuesday, challenging a statement from the victim’s family that the official said was misleading.

A ledger inside the case was opened to a page where an accountant once entered players’ salaries.

headline: Condemnation but Some Praise for Chávez From Washington

lead_paragraph: Not long after the death of Hugo Chávez was announced in Venezuela, a variety of major figures in American politics in Washington and beyond released statements offering their reactions. While his death was welcomed by some, others praised the Venezuelan leader for his efforts to help the poor.

headline: Ford Foundation Head Steps Down
abstract: The president of the Ford Foundation, Luis A. Ubiñas, will leave in September after six years at the nation’s second-largest philanthropic organization.
lead_paragraph: The president of the Ford Foundation, Luis A. Ubiñas, will leave in September after six years at the nation’s second-largest philanthropic organization. Mr. Ubiñas engineered an overhaul intended to streamline Ford’s operations and led Ford through the worst of the recession. “One of the hardest things for a leader is to know when to step down,” he wrote to the staff.

headline: Confirm Caitlin Halligan for the Federal Bench

This will show whether there are Republicans who care enough about the proper functioning of the federal courts to help defeat their party’s filibuster attempt.

headline: Another Round of Sanctions on North Korea
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Editorials']
abstract: Creative thinking is needed to break the endless cycle of punishments and threats in order to disrupt the North’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: China’s decision to join the United States in proposing tougher sanctions on North Korea is a welcome step. The new resolution, introduced at the United Nations on Tuesday, would seek to curtail North Korea’s nuclear and missile programs by making it more difficult for that country to move money around the world and explicitly banning the sale of items coveted by its elite, like yachts. It would also increase scrutiny of North Korea’s diplomats.

headline: Missouri: Jail After Years of Hiding
abstract: A British man who spent nearly two decades hiding in the United States after driving off with an armored van with $1.5 million in England was sentenced Tuesday in London to five years in jail.
lead_paragraph: A British man who spent nearly two decades hiding in the United States after driving off with an armored van with $1.5 million in England was sentenced Tuesday in London to five years in jail. Edward J. Maher was a guard for a security company in 1993 when he took off with the van as a colleague was making a delivery. He was arrested in Ozark, Mo., in 2012 on a tip from his estranged daughter-in-law. In the United States, Mr. Maher often used a brother’s name or the alias Stephen King.

headline: Free Speech on the Street Corner
abstract: It is heartening to see an appellate court block the anti-solicitation provision of Arizona’s immigration law, calling it unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: They trim trees, mow lawns, care for the elderly, clean up and rebuild after hurricanes and floods — and they defend the Constitution, too. Immigrant day laborers, who are so often the targets of local laws meant to sweep them off street corners, keep battling in court to defend their right to seek work, and they keep winning.

headline: Obama Visits Wounded as Afghanistan Casualties Continue

lead_paragraph: President Obama is winding down the war in Afghanistan, but the casualties continue. So on Tuesday afternoon, he made the first trip of his second term, and the 12th of his presidency, to visit wounded service men and women at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

headline: ‘Shoot One, Please’
abstract: This short documentary follows a 15-year-old from Stamford, N.Y., in the Catskills, as he hunts his first deer in the state’s first Youth Firearms Deer Hunt.
lead_paragraph: Last October, New York State for the first time held a three-day season for 14- and 15-year-olds to use guns to hunt deer. The State Department of Environmental Conservation had proposed the Youth Firearms Deer Hunt as a way to engage more young people in nature and outdoor recreation and to protect against deer overpopulation. The number of hunting licenses sold in New York has fallen by about one-quarter since peaking in the 1980s, the department said.

keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Air Pollution', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Arkansas: Abortion Law Survives Veto
abstract: The State Senate voted 20 to 14 Tuesday to override Gov. Mike Beebe’s veto of a bill that would establish the country’s most stringent limits on abortion, banning the procedure after 12 weeks of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: The State Senate voted 20 to 14 Tuesday to override Gov. Mike Beebe’s veto of a bill that would establish the country’s most stringent limits on abortion, banning the procedure after 12 weeks of pregnancy. The governor and most legal experts said the measure would quickly be struck down by federal courts as unconstitutional. The Supreme Court has ruled that women have a right to an abortion up to when the fetus is viable outside the womb, generally around 24 weeks into pregnancy. The motion to override now passes to the House, where a vote is expected to be close.

headline: Of Flies and Philosophers: Wittgenstein and Philosophy
abstract: The idea that philosophy is purely descriptive, and should “leave the world as it is” falls short. It can play a more radical role.
lead_paragraph: “To show the fly the way out of the fly bottle ”— that, Wittgenstein once said, was the aim of his philosophy. While it is perhaps unclear whether anyone — philosopher or fly — should be flattered by this comparison, his overall point is clear enough, as Paul Horwich notes in his recent piece, “Was Wittgenstein Right?” When we get curious about philosophical problems we are drawn into puzzles by the promise of sweet enlightenment, only to find ourselves caught in frustration (and banging our heads against the same wall over and over again). What we need, Wittgenstein thinks, is liberation — liberation from the prison of pseudo-problems we have brought upon ourselves; liberation from traditional philosophy.

headline: As Tourist, Hughes Got an Earful of England
