headline: Fending Off an Antic Suitor Who Came Late to Hope
abstract: Danny Burstein and Sarah Paulson star in the Roundabout’s revival of “Talley’s Folly,” Lanford Wilson’s romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: That most seductive of notions, the dream that one enchanted evening can change the course of two lives, takes beguiling dramatic form in “Talley’s Folly,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Lanford Wilson that has been lovingly revived by the Roundabout Theater Company at the Laura Pels Theater. Portraying a pair of mismatched mates trying to find a mutual rhythm for a waltz that at least one is hoping will last forever, Danny Burstein and Sarah Paulson infuse this gossamer two-character play with a warm, slightly spiky humanity that breathes vital life into material that might in lesser hands feel creaky or sentimental.

headline: Long Isolated Behind a Freeway, Santa Monica’s Civic Center Rejoins Its City
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A residential development and a new park with playgrounds are helping to integrate a forgotten part of Santa Monica, Calif., with the city’s downtown.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — In contrast to many other places in the Los Angeles area, this small city along the Pacific Ocean has long been easy for pedestrians to navigate — except when it comes to its Civic Center. City Hall, the courthouse and the Civic Auditorium are isolated from the city’s vibrant and walkable downtown, separated by the Santa Monica Freeway, overly wide streets and a dreary expanse of parking lots.

headline: A City Reunites
abstract: The Civic Center in Santa Monica, Calif., long separated from the city’s vibrant and walkable downtown by the Santa Monica Freeway, is about to be reunited with the city’s heart through a residential development and parkland.
lead_paragraph: The Civic Center in Santa Monica, Calif., long separated from the city’s vibrant and walkable downtown by the Santa Monica Freeway, is about to be reunited with the city’s heart through a residential development and parkland.

headline: Fingers Are Pointed After Truck Kills Boy
abstract: The death of Amar Diarrassouba, 6, has provided a window into how elected officials and pedestrian safety advocates in New York City navigate the complex politics of a tragedy.
lead_paragraph: For years, the debate over the safety of New York City’s streets has roiled without pause, from the highest corridors of elected office to the zealous corners of social media, inflamed whenever a pedestrian is fatally struck by a vehicle.

headline: Spokesmanship Over, Ex-Obama Aide Now Feels Free ... to Speak
abstract: 48 hours after leaving the White House, Tommy Vietor, the former spokesman for the National Security Council, began making waves on Twitter with a range of pointed opinions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last Thursday, the night before he left the White House, Tommy Vietor issued the last of countless carefully worded statements about a foreign-policy flare-up, this one deploring an inflammatory remark about Zionism made by Turkey’s prime minister.

headline: South Africans Seek Meaning in a Shooting
abstract: Reeva Steenkamp, who was shot by the sprinter Oscar Pistorius, had big plans for her newfound fame, including speaking about violence against women in South Africa, friends and family said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The day before Reeva Steenkamp died, she was getting ready to give a speech on a subject that she had known first hand and that is endemic in South Africa: violence against women.

headline: Investors’ Quandary: Get In Now?
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As the Dow set a record, investors were weighing whether the market has spent its momentum or is about to reach new heights.
lead_paragraph: So is it too late for investors to join the party?

headline: Canada’s North, Home to Bears, and Once, Camels
abstract: A paper published in Nature Communications details the 2006 discovery of the fossilized remains of a giant camel in Canada.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Though camels are usually associated with the searing heat of the desert, a group of scientists reported on Tuesday that they had found fossilized remains of a giant camel, with a shoulder height of perhaps nine feet, in Canada’s frigid high Arctic.

headline: On Social Networks, Mourning and Division After Chávez’s Death
abstract: Reactions from Venezuelans and people around the world after the death of President Hugo Chávez.
lead_paragraph: With expressions of mourning and calls for peace and stability, Venezuelans took to the streets and social networks on Tuesday after the announcement of the death of President Hugo Chávez. Messages came from all over the country and around the world, as supporters and critics of Mr. Chávez grappled with the news and tried to figure out what was next for the deeply divided country.

headline: You May Now Kiss the Computer Screen
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Some international couples are marrying by proxy over the Internet, a practice so new that immigration authorities say they do not typically watch for it in their efforts to detect fraud.
lead_paragraph: With a red embroidered veil draped over her dark hair, Punam Chowdhury held her breath last month as her fiancé said the words that would make them husband and wife. After she echoed them, they were married. Guests erupted in applause; the bride and groom traded bashful smiles.

headline: North Carolina to Give Some Immigrants Driver’s Licenses, With a Pink Stripe
keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: This month the state will begin giving some young immigrants driver’s licenses marked with a bold pink stripe and the words “no lawful status” printed in red.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — In a move some are calling a modern-day scarlet letter and others say is the best way to manage changing federal immigration policy, North Carolina this month will begin giving some young immigrants driver’s licenses marked with a bold pink stripe and the words “no lawful status” printed in red.

headline: Venezuelan Expatriates See a Reason to Celebrate
abstract: In Miami-Dade County, news of Hugo Chávez’s death elicited outpourings of raucous celebration and, to many, cautious optimism for the future.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — First the car horns blasted the news on street corners here, a town so packed with Venezuelans that it is nicknamed “Doralzuela.” Then came dozens of yellow, blue and red flags, floating in celebration, followed by bursts of singing.

headline: Anger and Kudos as Florida Governor Tacks Left
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott, who recently endorsed a Medicaid expansion, said he had not changed so much as Florida’s economy and deficit changed, freeing him to spend money.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A few days after Gov. Rick Scott of Florida endorsed a Medicaid expansion, a U-turn so sharply executed that it flabbergasted his supporters, the head of a local Tea Party group typed up a “breakup note.”

headline: How The New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The methodology of the latest New York Times/CBS News poll of United States Catholics is explained.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 23 to 27 with 1,585 adults throughout the United States. Interviews were conducted in English and Spanish.

headline: Chinese Premier’s Parting Words Include Warning
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Wen Jiabao, in a break from the past, sent signals reaffirming the party’s heavy-handed approach to the nation’s political and economic affairs.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Wen Jiabao, in his final address as China’s prime minister, warned on Tuesday of the growing divisions between rich and poor, the hazards of unchecked environmental degradation and the risks posed by unbalanced economic growth.

headline: Nash and His 2 Goals Power Rangers Over Flyers
abstract: Rick Nash broke a late tie by scoring two goals to lead the Rangers, who played with center Brad Richards and lost defenseman Marc Staal early in the third period.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers were tied at 2-2 entering the third period; time for Rick Nash to electrify the Madison Square Garden crowd again with his speed, stickhandling skills and will to score.

headline: Around the World in 80 Days for Cuba’s Most Famous Dissident Blogger
abstract: As Yoani Sanchez started her worldwide book tour, questions swirled — about both her future and her country’s.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Yoani Sanchez, Cuba’s most famous dissident blogger, arrived in Brazil looking like a ’60s hippie, her hair falling below her waist, her dark ankle-length skirt floating under a summery flower-child top. It was the first stop on Ms. Sanchez’s 80-day tour of South America, Europe and the United States.

headline: Barefoot Running Can Cause Injuries, Too
abstract: Does going barefoot solve running injuries? Or does it just create new ones?
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Douglas Brown, a radiologist in Orem, Utah, noticed an uptick recently in the number of barefoot runners he was seeing with heel and foot problems, he wondered if there might be a connection between their unshod training and their sore feet. But he couldn’t find any scientific studies that had examined the issue.

headline: Report Details Mistakes Made by U.S. in Improvement Projects for Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The United States, officials from both countries say, took on too many projects and often did not consult with the Iraqis about which projects were needed and how best to go about them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before he left his Pentagon post, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta concluded that the inability of the Obama administration to complete an agreement providing for an American military presence in Iraq after 2011 had deprived the United States of important political leverage in Iraq.

headline: News Corp. Has a Tablet for Schools
abstract: The Amplify, a 10-inch Android tablet for kindergartners through 12th graders, will come with the company’s education curriculum, which can also be used on other devices.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, Joel I. Klein helped Rupert Murdoch and News Corporation weather a phone-hacking scandal at the company’s British tabloids with the promise that he would eventually be able to return to the role the company hired him for: to spearhead News Corporation’s new venture into the public school market. That day has finally come.

headline: Financing for Colleges Declines as Costs Rise
abstract: Experts say there is a long-term trend of shifting the cost of higher education from the public onto students and their families.
lead_paragraph: State and local financing for higher education declined 7 percent in fiscal 2012, to $81.2 billion, according to the annual report of the State Higher Education Executive Officers Association, and per-student support dropped 9 percent from the previous year, to $5,896, in constant dollars, the lowest level in at least 25 years.

headline: Report on Iraq Reconstruction
abstract: A report by Stuart W. Bowen Jr., the special inspector general for Iraq reconstruction, covers the more than $60 billion in American aid that was used to carry out projects in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: A report by Stuart W. Bowen Jr., the special inspector general for Iraq reconstruction, covers the more than $60 billion in American aid that was used to carry out projects in Iraq.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE RACHEL ZOE PROJECT Ms. Zoe has expanded her empire in Los Angeles and New York to include a line of women’s clothing and accessories, a celebrity-styling department, a digital media team and a blow-dry salon, all on top of mothering her toddler son, Skyler. In this Season 5 premiere, Ms. Zoe (above right, with the actress Jaime King) prepares to unveil her spring collection at New York Fashion Week but is thrown off balance when a gossip columnist writes that her clothing line isn’t selling. In the Season 2 opener of “It’s a Brad, Brad World,” at 10, Brad Goreski, a former assistant to Ms. Zoe, styles looks for Kate Spade’s runway presentation while juggling clients like the actress Minka Kelly. And “Dukes of Melrose,” a new series at 10:30, follows Christos Garkinos and Cameron Silver, the owners of the Decades boutique in Los Angeles, as they raid closets and scour auctions for vintage couture.

headline: Chávez’s Death May Challenge China, a Friend
abstract: Hugo Chavez, the former Venezuelan leader, was a friend of China and oversaw large oil deals. A day after his death official media and the blogosphere discussed him.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Domestic politics trumps international politics, in China as everywhere. So even though China lost a friend in President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who died in Caracas on Tuesday, the homepage of the Xinhua News Agency online today is mostly filled with news of the National People’s Congress meeting in Beijing, where important appointments will be made, such as naming a new president (certain to be Xi Jinping, barring an extraordinary and unforeseen event.)

headline: News Quiz | March 6, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Russian Police Say Dancer and Two Others Confess to Bolshoi Attack
abstract: Pavel Dmitrichenko and two other men said they had carried out the January acid attack on the ballet company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet and two other men have confessed to carrying out an acid attack in January on the company’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, a crime that gripped Moscow and left one of Russia’s most revered institutions in turmoil, the police announced on Wednesday.

headline: Vietnam Allows Visit by Amnesty International
abstract: The government allowed the human rights group to meet with key dissidents and officials in the first such contacts since the end of the Vietnam War, Amnesty said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Vietnamese government has opened a dialogue with Amnesty International, allowing the human rights group to meet with crucial dissidents and government officials in the first such contacts since the end of the Vietnam War, Amnesty said Wednesday.

headline: India’s Record on Terror Attacks Holds Lessons for Hyderabad
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Police', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Lack of political consensus on terror laws and poor conviction rates have resulted in fewer breakthroughs in terror-related crimes.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI —A special court in Delhi on Tuesday issued arrest warrants for 10 members of the Indian Mujahideen, a banned terrorist organization, including its founder, Riyaz Bhatkal, in connection with the Feb. 21 Hyderabad blasts.

headline: Number of Syrian Refugees Hits 1 Million, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations Refugee agency warned that resources for helping the refugees fleeing nearly two years of conflict in Syria are stretched dangerously thin.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The relentless exodus of Syrians fleeing two years of increasingly violent conflict pushed the number of refugees in neighboring countries past the million mark on Wednesday, the United Nations Refugee Agency said, warning that resources for helping them are dangerously thin.

headline: Seeing Red Over Nani: Was the Referee Right?

headline: Runoff Set in Race for Los Angeles Mayor
abstract: Eric Garcetti and Wendy Greuel, both Democrats, will face each other in a May runoff after neither candidate received the majority of the vote in a nonpartisan mayoral primary.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After finishing first and second in Tuesday’s nonpartisan mayoral primary, City Councilman Eric Garcetti and City Controller Wendy Greuel will face each other in a May 21 runoff to take over a city that faces a $216 million budget gap and rising pension costs that could cripple municipal finances.

headline: Dead But Alive
abstract: Chávez is gone, but the aggressive rhetoric of the Venezuelan government is here to stay.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Hugo Chávez’s death, following a battle with cancer, has left Venezuela teetering on the edge. The relentlessly divisive leader left power in the hand of a dauphin, Nicolás Maduro, who is also wedded to the kind of aggressive rhetoric that was the cornerstone of his mentor’s government.

headline: South Korea Pushes Back on North’s Threats
abstract: The South Korean military’s warning marked a sharp escalation in a war of words with North Korea and came amid consideration of new United Nations sanctions against Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean military warned on Wednesday that if it was provoked by North Korea, it would strike the North’s “command leadership,” escalating a war of words and hinting at an attack on a North Korean headquarters.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 6
abstract: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela dies; a dancer and two other men have confessed to an acid attack on the Bolshoi’s artistic director; Italian politics dominate the discussion at the Geneva auto show; Michael Haneke’s opera; and a World Cup problem that won’t go away.
lead_paragraph: NEWS President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela died Tuesday afternoon after a struggle with cancer, the government announced, leaving behind a bitterly divided nation in the grip of a political crisis that grew more acute as he languished for weeks, silent and out of sight, in hospitals in Havana and Caracas. William Neuman reports from Caracas.

headline: Oh, Canada?
abstract: Naomi Harris, a Toronto native who hadn’t truly explored her vast homeland, set out on what she calls “the Maple Highway” to find what it means to be Canadian.
lead_paragraph: After a summer on the road, Naomi Harris pulled into her parents’ driveway in Toronto in September 2011 and photographed her odometer. She had driven just over 22,000 miles — more than four times the distance across Canada. Ms. Harris, a self-described “professional hobo,” had traveled the country in a car she bought on eBay, taking portraits of people she met along the way. Having lived in the United States for many years, she was seeking to capture her beloved homeland, asking herself an all-too-common question:

headline: What’s the Most Impressive Sports Moment You’ve Seen?
abstract: If you could have any achievement, in sports or elsewhere, caught on camera for the world to see, what would it be?
lead_paragraph: A leaping catch in the back of the end zone. A bottom-of-the-ninth, come-from-behind grand slam. A perfect landing off the balance beam.

headline: Taliban Kill 17 Afghan Soldiers in Once-Quiet Area
abstract: Northern Badakshan Province is far from insurgent strongholds and had been generally peaceful until recent months.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents killed as many as 17 Afghan National Army soldiers in a single episode in northern Badakhshan Province, an area that has been generally quiet and far from insurgent strongholds until recent months, according to accounts from Afghan officials on Wednesday.

headline: European Regulators Fine Microsoft, Then Promise to Do Better
abstract: In announcing a $732 million penalty, regulators said they had been “naïve” to let the company monitor its own adherence to an antitrust settlement.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union fined Microsoft $732 million on Wednesday for failing to respect an antitrust settlement with regulators. But in a highly unusual mea culpa, the European Union’s top antitrust regulator said that his department bore some of the responsibility for Microsoft’s failure to respect a settlement that caused the fine.

Because my days at AbesMarket.com are filled with e-commerce decisions, I appreciate the value of baseline data, and knowing how visitors act on other sites helps me gauge our performance. I hope you, too, can benefit from these ideas and statistics.

headline: Nora Ephron’s Final Act
abstract: The play “Lucky Guy,” Nora Ephron’s last completed work, is about a journalist who kept striving to do his best work even as he was dying of cancer. He was her inspiration to do the same.
lead_paragraph: At 10 p.m. on a Friday night in a private room on the 14th Floor of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital on 68th and York Avenue, my mother was lying in her bed hallucinating, in that dream space people go on their way to being gone.

headline: Cautious Mood as Stocks Rise
abstract: The Dow’s nominal high prompted few cheers on Wall Street. | Will the rally lead to more deals? | As Wall Street titans battle over Herbalife, there can be a tendency to forget the fundamentals. | Gary Gensler of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission says he plans to stay in the Obama administration through at least December.
lead_paragraph: The nominal high that the Dow Jones industrial average reached on Tuesday prompted few cheers on Wall Street, in contrast to the recoveries of years past. Even as the gain capped nearly five and a half years of progress since the depths of the financial crisis, there were questions about whether the forces that fueled the rally — in large part, the Federal Reserve’s stimulus and strong corporate profits — would be enough to keep it going, Peter Eavis writes in The New York Times. James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, cautioned that “prudent investors would be well served to tread carefully and look for improving economic evidence to support any moves to higher levels.”

headline: London Theater Journal: Follow the Money
abstract: Ben Brantley on “Money: The Game Show” and a revival of “Privates on Parade,” starring Simon Russell Beale.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It felt like a good day to go to a funeral for the financial system that rules the Western world. My reading on the subway had been the Evening Standard (now a giveaway), which featured a lead story with blaring headlines about bankers’ bonuses and money laundering. (The next day I would awaken to a grim front-page essay in the Guardian on the same subject with the no-win headline “Too big to fail – and too big to manage.”)

headline: The Singer Who Fell to Earth
abstract: David Bowie’s new album, “The Next Day,” to be released on Columbia on Tuesday, is receiving acclaim as the artist’s strongest effort in decades.
lead_paragraph: On “The Stars (Are Out Tonight),” the new single from David Bowie’s comeback album, “The Next Day,” one line jumps out: “We will never be rid of these stars.” In the video Mr. Bowie and the actress Tilda Swinton play an elderly couple persecuted by a pair of vampiric stars, who stalk them, invade their house and manipulate them like marionettes. But the song itself is less literal. It portrays celebrities as members of an overlord class who “burn you with their radiant smiles” but also as faintly pitiable creatures, jealous of the quiet, grounded lives of ordinary folk. “But I hope they live forever,” Mr. Bowie sings, a nod to the notion of fame as immortality, a compensation for all the damage and delusion that comes with the territory.

headline: Secrecy Vow and Leaks Complicate Interaction of Cardinals and News Media
abstract: Under pressure from their fellow cardinals, the Americans canceled their news briefing and shut down all communication with the news media.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Journalists from around the world packed the daily briefings, relishing the rare opportunity to pose questions to the cardinals who will vote in the conclave to elect the next pope. The sessions, led by American cardinals, were a far cry from the elliptical approach favored by the Vatican.

headline: Bangalore Drivers Plead Cases in ‘Court of Instant Traffic Justice’
abstract: Citizens turn arbitrators in minor road accidents, thanks to their dwindling faith in the system.
lead_paragraph: When a motorcycle rider rammed his car from behind in peak Bangalore traffic some weeks ago, Nagaraju Mariankiah, a 37-year-old cab driver, responded as he usually did when he got into an accident. He immediately stopped the car on the busy street and got out to inspect the damage.

abstract: Visiting destinations seen in “Downton Abbey,” deadly drug-resistant bacteria are spreading, making the most of a college visit and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Dell Board Committee Insists Sale Was Best Outcome
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The special committee of Dell’s board that supervised the company’s $24.4 billion sale to its founder reiterated on Wednesday that the deal was the best option for shareholders.
lead_paragraph: The special committee of Dell’s board that supervised the company’s $24.4 billion sale to its founder reiterated on Wednesday that the deal was the best option for shareholders.

headline: What the Mullahs Are Mulling
abstract: The struggle in Afghanistan is a straightforward tussle for power, not a holy war — according to senior Afghan clerics and some of the world’s leading Islamic theologians.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Midday in Istanbul’s historical Beyazit district and the air suddenly fills with the call to prayer from the many royal mosques nearby. It is a reminder that a part of the city that now bustles with shoppers, university students and tourists was once the heart of a great Islamic empire.

headline: Mama Whales on the Run
abstract: The expedition sets off from Maui in search of competitive groups, large groups of male whales that form frequently at this time of year.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Cartwright teaches biology at California State University Channel Islands and is studying trends in habitat use in humpback whale mother-calf pairs in Hawaiian waters.

headline: If You Like the Animals, Try the Rubens
abstract: The Rubens, a young quartet  from Sydney, Australia, whose frontman is reminiscent of Eric Burdon, are likely to soon be the big  headlining act.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Crowdfunding Clean Energy
abstract: There are plenty of recent signs that we may be witnessing the coming of age of solar power.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to get large numbers of people actively engaged in helping to solve global warming, how might you go about it? For years, the main approach in the environmental movement has been to sound the alarm bell and implore people to consume less, switch to green products, recycle, and speak up to companies and politicians. It hasn’t always been an easy sell. However, if the approach of a promising Oakland-based start-up takes hold, there may be another line of action that could become available to ordinary people: directly financing renewable energy.

headline: Paris Street Style | Birds of a Feather
abstract: Girls and boys alike teamed up in similar colors, patterns and styles to make people-watching an event of its own.

headline: Americans on the Catholic Church
abstract: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Catholics in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Catholics in the United States.

headline: Moncler: Fall 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: News Corp. Wants a Place in School, and Upfronts Are Not Just for Spring Anymore
abstract: Joel I. Klein announces Amplify, the curriculum-cum-tablet from News Corporation; the upfronts season spreads throughout the year; and former White House staffers find new identities on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Joel I. Klein, the former chancellor of New York City’s schools, will introduce News Corporation’s Amplify, the company’s fledgling education division coupled with a new tablet of the same name, at the SXSWedu conference in Austin, Tex., on Wednesday, Amy Chozick reports. The tablet, a 10-inch Android made by Asus, will run Amplify’s curriculum and provide storage for students’ data. It couples a touch screen with education-specific features, like an “eyes on teacher” warning when attention wanders and quizzes that use sad and smiley emoticons so teachers can ascertain whether students grasp new material. It will also have education-based games for students when they’re not in class, including one in which Tom Sawyer battles the Brontë sisters.

headline: Chávez Transformed the Way Venezuelans View Themselves
abstract: The legacy of Hugo Chávez, who died Tuesday, is not made of concrete and steel, highways and houses, but something less tangible: he has changed the way Venezuelans think.
lead_paragraph: LA GUAIRA, Venezuela — Ever since her home was washed away in the devastating mudslides that killed thousands along Venezuela’s coast in 1999, during President Hugo Chávez’s first year in office, Graciela Pineda waited for him to carry out his vow to rebuild.

headline: Paul Capital Takes Stake in Brazilian Venture Fund
abstract: Paul Capital, a private equity firm focused on secondary market transactions, has acquired 18.2 percent of a fund managed by the Brazilian technology venture capital firm Ideiasnet for 79 million reais ($40 million).
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO – Paul Capital, a private equity firm focused on secondary market transactions, has acquired 18.2 percent of a fund managed by the Brazilian technology venture capital firm Ideiasnet, paying 79 million reais ($40 million).

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Fast Food Forward: Two new waves of food activism are rising in New York: one, a movement to raise wages for fast-food workers … — Julia Moskin

headline: Bye-Bye, Bumbo and Boppy (With Reservations)
abstract: The hard truth is, my indecision and sentimentality have all just been an excuse: what I really can’t reconcile is that once I pack up the baby gear, I’m packing it in. No more babies for us.
lead_paragraph: It seems like an instant ago, that sweltering summer I spent scouring Craigslist and tag sales, possessed by a frenzied, pre-baby urge to nest. I scooped up gently used Ergos and Bjorns — words that were foreign to a first-time mother’s tongue but promised parental salvation. Eventually, all the essential gear was acquired, along with a few items that in hindsight (yes, that would be you, wipes warmer) were anything but.

headline: David Bowie Through the Years
abstract: After a career of five decades, Mr. Bowie has a new album.
lead_paragraph: After a career of five decades, Mr. Bowie has a new album.

headline: Endangered or Not, but at Least No Longer Waiting
abstract: Under the terms of a 2011 settlement, the Interior Department has promised to rule on the endangered status of dozens of species by 2018.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it does not seem cause for celebration that the Oregon spotted frog, a four-inch-long amphibian that prefers the Pacific Northwest’s dwindling marshy spots, is to be considered this year for federal protection as an endangered species.

headline: Sporting Goods
abstract: Athletic gear, from bright cross-trainers to sleek canvas backpacks, is edging in on fashion’s turf.
lead_paragraph: Athletic gear, from bright cross-trainers to sleek canvas backpacks, is edging in on fashion’s turf. See our interactive feature ->

headline: Crowds Throng Caracas Streets to Salute Chávez
abstract: Mourners filled the streets to say goodbye to President Hugo Chávez. But there was uncertainty in Venezuela about how the nation would be run and when an election would be scheduled.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In a modest brown wood coffin covered in a Venezuelan flag, President Hugo Chávez was carried through the capital, Caracas, on Wednesday morning as crowds thronged the streets, cabinet ministers and top military officials walked alongside his black hearse, while hundreds of soldiers in green fatigues and other supporters followed in the yellow, blue and red caps of the national colors.

headline: Toyota Brings a GT-86 Convertible Concept to Geneva
abstract: The Open Concept envisions what the Toyota GT-86 or Scion FR-S might look like as a convertible.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA – Almost lost in the hype around the introduction of the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray convertible at the Geneva motor show here on Tuesday was the unveiling of another, nearly as significant convertible.

headline: Brave Girls
abstract: Two new picture books, both with origins in Israel, tell stories about young girls whose bravery and endurance reap great rewards.
lead_paragraph: Books about girl power are easy to find in March, National Women’s History Month, though not all of them feel timeless or universal. Two new picture books, both with origins in Israel, tell stories about young girls whose bravery and endurance reap great rewards, in ways that transcend the specific circumstance of a people and place.

headline: Threatened Species Have a Chance for Protection
abstract: As many species facing extinction have waited for years to be protected by the United States, the Fish and Wildlife Service has pledged to decide the fates of all the backlogged candidates by 2018.
lead_paragraph: As many species facing extinction have waited for years to be protected by the United States, the Fish and Wildlife Service has pledged to decide the fates of all the backlogged candidates by 2018.

headline: The Gun Report: March 6, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last night, Jon and Rebecca Bond, the founders of Evolve, which I wrote about in Saturday’s column, were on Piers Morgan’s CNN interview show. Their emphasis was about how they hope their new organization will become a bridge that links gun owners and non-gun owners, and how they hope it can help bring about the same kind of cultural change with guns that we have already made with two other dangerous behaviors: smoking and drunk driving. Here is the link to their appearance.

headline: Report From Venezuela
abstract: After President Hugo Chávez’s death, The Times’s William Neuman surveys the scene in Caracas and the president of the Inter-American Dialogue examines American relations going forward.
lead_paragraph: After President Hugo Chávez’s death, The Times’s William Neuman surveys the scene in Caracas and the president of the Inter-American Dialogue examines American relations going forward.

headline: The First Strike in the Roger Ailes Book Wars
abstract: In an excerpt from “Roger Ailes: Off Camera,” Mr. Ailes, the head of the Fox News Channel, takes aim at Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Newt Gingrich, among others.
lead_paragraph: The Roger Ailes book wars have begun.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Top 10 Second Basemen
abstract: Question marks abound among the top 10 second basemen. Justin Sablich makes his picks.
lead_paragraph: Question marks abound among the top 10 second basemen. Justin Sablich makes his picks.

headline: Elliott Criticizes Hess Chief as Unaccountable
abstract: Elliott Management criticized a letter sent by Hess’s chief executive, John B. Hess, to another dissident investor, arguing the letter showed the company and its management lacked accountability.
lead_paragraph: The battle over the board of the Hess Corporation has become a tiny war of words.

headline: Clothing Companies Trying to Find More Direct Paths to Customers
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Small Business']
abstract: Many new apparel brands have decided to forgo the traditional wholesale route of selling through multibrand boutiques and department stores, but it is not for everyone.
lead_paragraph: When Joanne and Tim Medvitz founded an outdoor clothing company, Pop Outerwear, in San Francisco in 2009, they were sure of one thing. They were going to sell their clothing directly to consumers, whether online, through their own store or through consumer ski and snowboard shows.

headline: New Card Offers Cash Back for Paying on Time
abstract: A new card rewards users with cash back for paying on time.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America this week introduced a new credit card aimed at rewarding customers who paid on time and who paid more than the minimum amount due each month.

headline: High Speed, Lower Price
abstract: The French national rail company SNCF is starting an economy high-speed rail service called Ouigo.
lead_paragraph: The French national rail company SNCF is starting an economy high-speed rail service called Ouigo on April 2. It will operate between the Paris suburb Marne-la-Vallée (home to Disneyland Paris) to points south, including Lyon, Marseille and Montpellier. Fares for the single-class, no-frills service (with no food or drink) range from 10 to 85 euros (about $12.50 to $107).

headline: Sam Mendes Says He Won’t Direct Next James Bond Movie
abstract: Under the direction of Mr. Mendes, “Skyfall” — which featured an Academy Award-winning title song performed by Adele and a regrettable title — sold more than $1.1 billion in tickets worldwide.
lead_paragraph: With any luck, the next James Bond movie will have a better title than “Skyfall” — yes, “Skyfall” — the 23rd official entry in that long running spy-thriller franchise, which featured an Academy Award-winning title song performed by Adele, the detachable jaw of Javier Bardem and Albert Finney in a supporting role that seemed almost surely designed for Sean Connery.

headline: Former Defense Officials Urge Using Budget Cuts to Shape Military Strategy
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a letter to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, five former deputy defense secretaries suggest using the budget cuts as an opportunity to re-examine military strategy, personnel numbers and weapons purchases.
lead_paragraph: With the across-the-board spending cuts now a reality, a group of five former deputy defense secretaries has written to the new Pentagon chief, Chuck Hagel, urging that he make the best of a bad situation by using the budget cuts as an opportunity to re-examine military strategy, personnel numbers and weapons purchases.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Beaver Fur
abstract: If there’s one type of fur you need next season, it’s beaver.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one type of fur you need next season, it’s beaver: Chloe kept its Parisian girl cool in a vest; Givenchy had its girls slink around in a bomber; and Haider Ackermann added subdued glamour to his monochromatic look.

headline: Venezuelans Recall Leader’s Love of Game
abstract: Members of the Venezuelan national team getting ready for the World Baseball Classic in Puerto Rico refrained from discussing Hugo Chávez’s politics.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Luis Sojo, manager of Venezuela’s national team, likes to sleep in. But on mornings after games he expected a call from Hugo Chávez, the country’s president, who died on Tuesday.

headline: 2 Burned Bodies Found After Fire in Queens Marshland
abstract: The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said it was quite likely that the brush fire had been set deliberately not long after the bodies were dumped.
lead_paragraph: There is little to lure visitors into the weeds and moldering woods that stretch for miles along Jamaica Bay’s northern edges, near where Brooklyn dissolves into Queens. It is a place well out of sight for most New Yorkers, and therefore out of mind.

headline: That’s Quite a Guest List at Buckingham Palace
abstract: “The Audience” is a sort of starched-bosomed nanny of a play, offering the artistic equivalent of nursery food and equally digestible history lessons.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A faint but palpable discomfort rippled through the audience at the Gielgud Theater on Tuesday night when a uniformed Equerry announced that Her Majesty had taken ill.

headline: Campbell Sports Center
abstract: The center is Columbia University’s new $30 million athletic building in Inwood.
lead_paragraph: The center is Columbia University’s new $30 million athletic building in Inwood.

headline: Image of the Day: March 6
abstract: Kathakali dancers from Kerala perform during a roadshow in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Harpers Ferry, Redux
abstract: How John Brown’s 1859 raid inspired a minister-turned-colonel to carry out a similar attack on Jacksonville, Fla. in 1863.
lead_paragraph: A raid into the South was afoot. So reported The New-York Tribune, which sketched out a few details of a plot to surprise Southerners “not with the phantom, but the reality of servile insurrection.” At the behest of a radical white abolitionist, a group of free African-Americans had laid the groundwork for the clandestine incursion by preparing enslaved populations, who waited, ready “to rise in thousands.” After capturing a Southern town, the abolitionist and his colleagues, black and white, planned to establish a base from which to organize and arm a force of escaped slaves. The raid would be the opening salvo in a war on slavery.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: With Legal Reserves Low, Bank of America Faces a Big Lawsuit
abstract: A lawsuit over Bank of America’s mortgage portfolio could cost the bank tens of billions more than it had planned, prompting critics to say the bank had not set aside enough for a settlement.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America has been underestimating its legal risks for years, and brazenly so, according to its critics. Is that strategy about to pay off with the Federal Reserve?

headline: Ahmadinejad Says Chávez Will Rise Again
abstract: In a letter of condolence to the people of Venezuela, Iran’s president struck a note of interfaith harmony, expressing confidence that Hugo Chávez would be resurrected, along with Jesus and the Hidden Imam.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 3:44 p.m. In a letter of condolence to the people of Venezuela, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, struck a note of interfaith harmony on Wednesday, expressing confidence that the late Hugo Chávez would eventually be resurrected, along with Jesus and the Hidden Imam, a messianic figure in Shiite Islam.

headline: For Obama and Senate Republicans, an Opportunity to Dine and Deal
abstract: President Obama will host a group of Senate Republicans on Wednesday for a dinner to discuss the federal debt.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama ratchets up his outreach effort to Congressional Republicans on Wednesday with a dinner date at the Jefferson Hotel, his guests will include some of his fiercest critics in the Senate, some conciliators and some lawmakers who hardly have made a ripple in the public debate over how to tackle the federal debt.

headline: Schools, and Syllabuses, Designed With the Environment in Mind
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Education (K-12)', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Museums', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Satellites', 'Science and Technology', 'Solar Energy', 'Space', 'Television', 'Wind Power']
abstract: A look at schools where design and teaching focus on energy and the environment.
lead_paragraph: Schools can play an important role in fostering environmental and energy awareness not only through how they teach, but also their physical structures and grounds. I’ve been getting familiar with the remarkable, and growing, range of “green school” designs and initiatives around the country. Here’s an initial survey, spurred in part by invaluable input from Veronique Choa Pittman of the Green Schools Alliance and from my visit last week to the engaging new Green Schools exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington.

headline: City Life Takes a Toll on China’s Children
abstract: Widespread anecdotal evidence suggests that children are suffering as parents live the hard life in China’s cities.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Life in China isn’t cheap any more, despite its reputation as a low-cost center. While many families have prospered from economic liberalization, others struggle to get by. And that includes many considered to be doing fairly well.

headline: Targeted Killing in the U.S.A.
abstract: Is it legal for the president to authorize lethal force against a citizen on American soil?
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration finally answered a simple question today: Does the president think he has the power to authorize lethal force, such as a drone strike, against an American citizen, in the United States, without trial.

headline: WGBH to Partner on Children’s Pilot for Amazon
abstract: Amazon’s production arm said Wednesday that it had ordered a children’s pilot called “Sara Solves It,” which was co-developed by WGBH in Boston and Out of the Blue Enterprises.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest suppliers of programming for PBS, WGBH, is the latest to climb aboard Amazon’s television pilot process.

headline: Dyson’s Bladeless Fan: A Little Cooler
abstract: The new Dyson AM05 bladeless fan and heater has an unusual redesigned impeller that moves more air.
lead_paragraph: The Dyson AM05 bladeless fan and heater is much cooler than its predecessor. Its new motor spins 33 percent faster, moving more air, hence: cooler.

headline: As You Travel, Making Money Work for You
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Credit Cards', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The travel blogger known as Nomadic Matt offers tips on setting a daily travel budget, choosing the right credit cards and avoiding transaction fees abroad.
lead_paragraph: When the travel blogger Matt Kepnes, a k a Nomadic Matt, set off on a six-and-a-half-year backpacking trip that would take him to a staggering 70 countries, the relative merits of his bank account and credit card were an afterthought, he said. Two years into his journey, he realized he was needlessly racking up bank fees and missing out on free flights, so he sat down and figured out how to manage his personal finances abroad. These tips and others he shares in his new book, “How to Travel the World on $50 a Day: Travel Cheaper, Longer, Smarter.” Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Kepnes on which bank accounts and credit cards help you stick to your budget.

abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
