headline: Hotel Review: Gradiva in Istanbul
abstract: This new boutique property packages arresting views, live music and easy access to both history and hedonism.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Brindillas in Vistalba, Argentina
abstract: At this small, highly touted spot near Mendoza, modern meals are paired with gentle prices.
lead_paragraph: In Argentina, the peso is written with a dollar sign. So when we were presented with the menus at Brindillas, an unassuming but highly touted little restaurant about 20 minutes from downtown Mendoza, and saw a five-course tasting menu for what looked like $135, or seven courses for $175, we felt ambushed but undaunted. But after our meal — which cost about $100 (that’s U.S. dollars) for two, wine included — we were pleasantly surprised, a feeling enhanced by food that had a sophisticated, modernist outlook that went well beyond the borders of Argentina.

headline: Unreported Side Effects of Drugs Are Found Using Internet Search Data, Study Finds
abstract: Scientists have detected evidence of unreported prescription drug side effects before they were found by the Food and Drug Administration’s warning system.
lead_paragraph: Using data drawn from queries entered into Google, Microsoft and Yahoo search engines, scientists at Microsoft, Stanford and Columbia University have for the first time been able to detect evidence of unreported prescription drug side effects before they were found by the Food and Drug Administration’s warning system.

headline: Musical Version of ‘Beaches’ Finds a Home
abstract: Virginia’s Signature Theater will stage an adaptation of the 1985 novel that also spawned the 1988 film, but at this point “Wind Beneath My Wings” won’t be part of the score.
lead_paragraph: The wind beneath the wings of the musical adaptation of the film “Beaches” has landed the show a home. This week the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., announced that it would produce the show as part of its 2013-14 season. Eric Schaeffer, Signature’s artistic director, will direct the production, which has been talked about for a Broadway run. Casting is still to be announced.

headline: Talking N.C. State and the M.A.A.C. Tournament
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)', 'Television']
abstract: Dereck Whittenburg, an analyst for ESPN, discusses North Carolina State’s national championship in 1983 and what to look for in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament, among other things in a question-and-answer session.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, Dereck Whittenburg won a national basketball championship as a player at North Carolina State. More recently he coached at Wagner and Fordham, where he was fired midseason in December 2009.  Whittenburg still lives in the New York area and works for ESPN as a television analyst. Among the games he covers are those played in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.

headline: Warner Music Owner Bets on Competing Digital Services
abstract: Access Industries, a holding company owned by Len Blavatnik, the Russian-born billionaire investor, is one of several parties investing $60 million in Daisy, a planned service by Beats Electronics, Beats announced late Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Len Blavatnik, the Russian-born billionaire investor who bought the Warner Music Group two years ago, has placed big bets on multiple digital music services as the streaming model grows around the world.

headline: McIlroy Says of Midround Withdrawal, ‘I Should Have Stayed Out There’
abstract: Rory McIlroy, who withdrew during a poor round in the Honda Classic last week, citing a sore wisdom tooth, said “it wasn’t the right thing to do.”
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — The public apology thinly veiled as a news conference opened Wednesday as the moderator turned to Rory McIlroy and said, “Just go straight into the heart of the matter here.” Pause. “How disappointed were you with Manchester United’s score yesterday?”

headline: German Riesling’s Turn in the Spotlight
abstract: Perhaps the most intriguing wine event in a month full of them was Rieslingfeier.
lead_paragraph: La Paulée de New York, Daniel Johnnes’s adaptation of the Meursault harvest festival, begins this week, signifying the apogee of a remarkable month of wine in the city. La Paulée, a mélange of seminars, discussions and tastings culminating in a grand dinner in which producers and collectors share precious bottles, has been so successful that it has inspired similar events celebrating other wines.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Second Base Preview
abstract: Other than Robinson Cano, question marks abound among the top 10 second basemen and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Recalling a ‘Writer’s Paper’ as a Name Fades
abstract: When The International Herald Tribune is rebranded as The International New York Times this fall, one of the great names in American journalism will fade away.
lead_paragraph: Ghostly vestiges of the gothic Herald Tribune logo still survive on the eastern facade of 230 West 41st Street in Midtown Manhattan, camouflaged by a faded Group Health Insurance emblem, and, more recently, dwarfed by the towering headquarters of The New York Times next door.

headline: Rangers Claim Hamrlik Off Waivers
abstract: The Rangers picked up a veteran defenseman, Roman Hamrlik, off waivers on Wednesday, with the status of the injured Marc Staal still unknown.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers claimed the veteran defenseman Roman Hamrlik off waivers from Washington, the team confirmed Wednesday. It was unclear whether the acquisition indicated a long-term injury to defenseman Marc Staal, who was struck in the right eye by a shot in a game Tuesday.

headline: A Government LGBT Site
abstract: The State Department created a Web portal for LGBT travelers last month that includes advice and links for gay people traveling abroad.
lead_paragraph: The State Department created a Web portal for LGBT travelers last month that includes advice and links for gay people traveling abroad. In addition to steering travelers to country-specific pages that outline which governments give gay travelers legal protections, and which criminalize same-sex relations, the portal also suggests precautions, like carrying documents verifying custody of any children.

headline: The Small Picture: Grab a Shovel
abstract: There is no one else to clear the path ahead.
lead_paragraph: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: Time Warner Ends Talks With Meredith and Will Spin Off Time Inc. Into Separate Company
abstract: The primary sticking point between the two companies was the fate of several titles, including Time and Sports Illustrated, which Time Warner wanted to shed but which Meredith was not eager to acquire.
lead_paragraph: 9:14 p.m. | Updated What do you do with a group of celebrated magazines that no one seems to want?

headline: The Sequester App
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: Brooks and Collins try to balance the budget since Washington can’t be bothered.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, I’ve been pretty calm about all the fiscal-cliff crises, but now I’m really getting ticked off. I hate this sequester thing.

headline: Back in Brooklyn | Karkula
abstract: The design shop has returned to its roots, with a new home in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: The design store Karkula has returned to its Brooklyn roots: its new home in Williamsburg officially opens tomorrow, at 98 South 4th Street, with an exhibition of chandeliers by Michelle James and jewelry by Monica Castiglioni. The store’s owner, the designer John Erik Karkula, co-founded the Brooklyn design object shop Breukelen in 1996 before moving to Manhattan and opening Karkula, where he was an early supporter of emerging talent like Jim Zivic and Lindsey Adelman, first in the meatpacking district, and later in TriBeCa. The new shop, which was designed by Karkula and the Brooklyn-based architect Philipp Mohr, now represents European brands like e15, Bocci and Nanimarquina, as well as its owner’s designs. Karkula maintains that he has always kept a low profile on New York’s design scene. “I thought it was cool to be under the radar,” he said. But that might not be so easy now.

headline: Senators Press Holder on Use of Military Force
abstract: Senators of both parties criticized Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for the secrecy surrounding legal memorandums justifying drone strikes aimed at American citizens.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators of both parties on Wednesday criticized Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. for the secrecy surrounding the Justice Department legal memorandums justifying drone strikes aimed at American citizens, while pushing him to say more about when the Obama administration believes it can use military force on United States soil.

headline: Syrian Rebels in Golan Region Hold U.N. Peacekeeping Team
abstract: Syria’s civil war entangled the peacekeeping operation in the disputed Golan Heights area Wednesday, when 30 armed fighters for the insurgency detained a group of peacekeepers.
lead_paragraph: Insurgent fighters from Syria seized a group of United Nations troops on patrol in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel on Wednesday and threatened to treat them as prisoners of war, an abrupt escalation in the Syrian conflict that entangled international peacekeepers for the first time.

headline: Rodriguez, Set to Face Mets, Hopes for Return
abstract: Pitcher Francisco Rodriguez was a flop in his last stint with the Mets, but he’d like an opportunity to redeem himself.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -– When Francisco Rodriguez was traded to Milwaukee midway through the 2011 season, he left the Mets with the label of overpriced failure on his back. He notched 83 saves in 165 appearances over two and a half years, but also suffered through injuries and an ignoble tantrum in which he punched his father-in-law after a blown save.

headline: Software and Side Effects
abstract: Scientists find that analyzing online queries provides valuable insight into drug interactions.
lead_paragraph: Scientists find that analyzing online queries provides valuable insight into drug interactions.

headline: A Young Woman’s Choice, and Its Consequences
abstract: The Mint Theater Company performs “Katie Roche,” the third play by Teresa Deevy it has revived in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Not since that incident at Boston Harbor in 1773 has tea been as central to a dispute as it is in “Katie Roche,” the third Teresa Deevy play to be examined in recent years by the Mint Theater Company, whose mission is to shine new light on neglected works.

headline: With Worries for Its Economic Future, Cuba Bids a Sad Goodbye to a Generous Ally
abstract: The death of Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan leader, sent a ripple of sadness and uncertainty across Cuba, which has long relied on Venezuela’s hefty oil subsidies.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The death of Hugo Chávez sent a ripple of sadness and uncertainty across this island on Wednesday as Cubans mourned the loss of an ideological son and generous ally, and worried about the economic pain that could lie ahead if the new Venezuelan leadership cut off hefty oil subsidies.

headline: ‘Smash’ Ratings Hit a New Low on NBC
abstract: The enormously publicized drama crashed to a new ratings low Tuesday night, hitting a level that only a few weeks ago caused another NBC drama, “Do No Harm,” to be yanked off the air.
lead_paragraph: Can “Smash” stay on the air? The enormously publicized — and enormously expensive — NBC drama crashed to a new ratings low Tuesday night, hitting a level that only a few weeks ago caused another NBC drama, “Do No Harm,” to be yanked off the air.

headline: Stranger Than We Can Imagine: David Toomey Talks About ‘Weird Life’
abstract: Mr. Toomey’s book concerns the search for life unlike any we have discovered to this point.
lead_paragraph: In “Weird Life,” David Toomey writes about the search for life that is not just strange, but in fact, like nothing we’ve discovered. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Toomey discussed the origins of life on Earth, the porous line between science and philosophy, his favorite science fiction and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Anthony Questionable for Game Against Pistons
abstract: Coach Mike Woodson said that the Knicks’ star forward had some fluid buildup on his injured knee.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. – The Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony remains questionable for tonight’s game against the Detroit Pistons, because of stiffness and soreness in his right knee.

headline: Sallie Mae Lowers Top Loan Rates for Graduate Students
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Interest Rates', 'Student Loans']
abstract: Sallie Mae said the lower maximum interest rates reflected the educational achievement and greater earnings potential of graduate students.
lead_paragraph: Graduate students may now be able to qualify for private student loans at lower interest rates from Sallie Mae, the education finance company announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Nets' Ongoing Identity Crisis
abstract: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks' shadow. It hasn't exactly worked out that way.
lead_paragraph: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks' shadow. It hasn't exactly worked out that way.

headline: Video: The Nets’ Continuing Identity Crisis
abstract: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks’ shadow. It hasn’t exactly worked out that way.
lead_paragraph: The move to Brooklyn, with the stars Deron Williams and Joe Johnson, was supposed to help the Nets escape the Knicks’ shadow. It hasn’t exactly worked out that way.

headline: Content Lives On, Even if Web Site Doesn’t
abstract: The Web site Budget Travel is in bankruptcy court and the trustee handling the case says no staff member “will be paid a penny.” But that hasn’t stopped the staff from producing new content.
lead_paragraph: 11:01 a.m. | Updated Some journalists just can’t stop working.

headline: Familiar Names Join the List for the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: The newly announced features include movies from Richard Linklater, Neil Jordan, David Gordon Green, Mira Nair, Neil LaBute and Clark Gregg; documentaries about Elaine Stritch, Richard Pryor and Gore Vidal; and a nonfiction feature about Moms Mabley directed by Whoopi Goldberg.
lead_paragraph: New movies from Richard Linklater, Neil Jordan, David Gordon Green, Mira Nair, Neil LaBute and Clark Gregg; and documentaries about Elaine Stritch, Richard Pryor, Gore Vidal and —  from Whoopi Goldberg — Moms Mabley  were among the latest announced for the Tribeca Film Festival by its organizers on Wednesday.

headline: Last Stop Before the Outlet Center
abstract: H. W. Carter and Sons tells you what you need to know about modern Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: Everything you love will eventually become a mall. It will be unearthed, polished, commodified and disseminated. It will be silver-platter-delivered to the next generation in a way that will make your earnest passion and curiosity seem infantile. “Remember when?” you will say, and nobody will.

headline: Subscribing to Office, Now and Forever
abstract: This year with Microsoft Office, it’s not what the features are, but how you pay for them. There are two ways to subscribe.
lead_paragraph: It must be tough to be on the Microsoft Office team. Year after year, you’re given the same assignment: add new features to Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Outlook. New features that people will pay for, but that won’t turn Microsoft’s cash cow into a bloated, sloshing mess.

headline: Rand Paul Leads Filibuster of Brennan Nomination
abstract: Senators from both parties joined the Republican from Kentucky, who opposes John O. Brennan to lead the C.I.A. and said he would “speak until I can no longer speak.”
lead_paragraph: 4:59 p.m. | Updated Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, began an old-school, speak-until-you-can-speak-no-more filibuster on Wednesday just before noon, and was still going strong hours later.

headline: With Positions to Fill, Employers Wait for Perfection
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Many companies remain reluctant to hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.
lead_paragraph: American employers have a variety of job vacancies, piles of cash and countless well-qualified candidates. But despite a slowly improving economy, many companies remain reluctant to actually hire, stringing job applicants along for weeks or months before they make a decision.

headline: The Roots of Dennis Hopper’s Style
abstract: The rollercoaster life of the actor, filmmaker and artist points like a weather vane to a half-century of pop culture.
lead_paragraph: It’s a peculiar brand of American voodoo, a mix of Pabst Blue Ribbon and white Stetson hats and weather-beaten Levis. And a gas mask. It has a lot to do with being dirty.

headline: Skiing Kashmir’s Snow-Swept Peaks
abstract: The risks of a ski trip to Kashmir? Security, avalanches and the altitude. The rewards? Perfect powder, an absence of crowds and staggering Himalayan beauty.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid night in Gulmarg, a Himalayan outpost deep in Kashmir, a friend and I sipped sweet tea and warmed ourselves next to a wood stove while a local ski guide named Javed stood in front of us, roaring like a bear. “Baah! Baah!” he shouted, his hands outstretched like claws. “I thought it was going to kill us,” Javed said of the Asiatic black bear he had encountered a few days before while skiing in the backcountry.

headline: Where Skiing Is Only Part of the Adventure
abstract: A journey to rugged Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: A journey to rugged Kashmir.

headline: Honey, We Barely Shrunk the Financial System
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: After an unsustainable boom, some shrinkage in the global financial sector was inevitable, and desirable, the author writes. Besides, excluding the euro zone, cross-border capital flows are still reasonably healthy.
lead_paragraph: The global financial system isn’t dead. But it might be shrinking.

headline: A Weather Report That’s Colorful, With a Chance of Fun
abstract: A new kind of weather reporting app provides forecasts that are easy to understand and filled with usable information.
lead_paragraph: I’ll bet that one of the first apps you downloaded onto a smartphone or tablet was for weather. These apps are more appealing than weather forecasts on television, because they provide interactive weather reports you can hold in your hand.

headline: Suspect in Crash That Killed 3 Turns Himself In
abstract: Julio Acevedo, who was wanted in a hit-and-run accident in Brooklyn that killed a young couple and their child, surrendered to New York police detectives in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: The manhunt ended at a roadside minimart.

headline: A Call for a National Strategy on Veterans
abstract: A National Veterans Strategy would include a national dialogue to define our societal obligations to those who volunteer for military service and establishing policies to carry out those obligations, engaging government, the private sector, veterans service organizations and local communities to combine resources in support of veterans and their families.
lead_paragraph: Stand on the corner of H Street and Vermont Avenue in Washington, D.C., and in every direction you’ll see the ways and means of American government — the White House in front, the Treasury to the left and the huge Office of Management and Budget building down the street and to the right. This vista is both symbolic of — and essential to running — our system of governance “by the people, for the people.”

headline: German Museum Returns Painting to Jewish Estate
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: A German museum has returned a painting to the estate of a Jewish art dealer who was forced to sell it under duress during the time of Nazi rule.
lead_paragraph: A German museum has returned a 15th-century Renaissance painting to the estate of a Jewish art dealer who was forced to sell it under duress in 1935.

headline: Scouting Report
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'T-Shirts (Apparel)']
abstract: Diesel + Edun collaborate on a new collection made from Conservation Cotton Initiative fibers; a Surface to Air sale; and other shopping-related news.
lead_paragraph: Hitting the Racks

headline: Groom’s Letter to Parents, Remembered After Fatal Hit and Run
abstract: The letter, written by Nathan Glauber on his wedding day last year, has been circulating electronically since he and Raizy Glauber, pregnant with their first child, were killed Sunday by a hit-and-run driver.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Monday, March 11 | The young groom took some moments on his wedding day to write a letter thanking his parents for never sparing time or money if he needed, say, a tutor or an eye doctor, and for sending him to yeshiva “to learn your values, religious and worldly, until I reached to this current lucky moment.”

headline: Artist Quits Superman Project After Outcry Over Writer’s Marriage Views
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The writer, Orson Scott Card, is on the board of an organization opposed to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: “Adventures of Superman,” a digital anthology from DC Comics, is scheduled to begin on April 29. But it will not feature the work of Chris Sprouse, an artist who has decided to drop out of the project because of a controversy surrounding the opposition to gay marriage by the novelist Orson Scott Card, one of the writers.

headline: Ask Well: Keeping Knee Arthritis in Check
abstract: Unfortunately, knee arthritis is incurable, but there are ways to slow the progression, explains the Phys Ed columnist Gretchen Reynolds.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Young Poets Society
abstract: Each year, the Lilly fellowships offer five young poets prestige, publicity and — most elusive of all — money. The latest crop of winners represents how important, and how controversial, these awards have become.
lead_paragraph: Each year, the Lilly fellowships offer five young poets prestige, publicity and — most elusive of all — money. The latest crop of winners represents how important, and how controversial, these awards have become.

headline: Bruno Mars, Discounted Online, Tops Album Chart
abstract: A discount at Amazon.com helped push Bruno Mars’s “Unorthodox Jukebox” to No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Never doubt the selling power of a deep, well-publicized sale.

headline: Arkansas Adopts a Ban on Abortions After 12 Weeks
abstract: A law enacted Wednesday contradicts the 24-week limit established by the Supreme Court, and abortion rights groups have promised a suit to block the ban before it goes into effect.
lead_paragraph: Arkansas adopted what is by far the country’s most restrictive ban on abortion on Wednesday — at 12 weeks of pregnancy, when a fetal heartbeat can typically be detected by abdominal ultrasound.

headline: New Bruce Norris Play Will Be Part of Steppenwolf Season
abstract: “The Qualms” by Mr. Norris is part of a season that also includes the return of actress Joan Allen.
lead_paragraph: New plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Bruce Norris (“Clybourne Park”) and Mona Mansour (“Urge for Going”) are among the productions in the 2013-14 season at Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theater, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: March 7
abstract: Carson Street Clothiers, a new men’s store in SoHo; Chloé celebrates 60 years; and the casual wear of 194t makes being comfy look good.
lead_paragraph: Carson Street Clothiers, a new men’s store in SoHo; Chloé celebrates 60 years; and the casual wear of 194t makes being comfy look good.

headline: Free Throws and High-Fives: A Routine Within a Routine
abstract: Quirks of the game: N.B.A. players didn’t always celebrate free throws, but now it’s done on nearly every free throw.
lead_paragraph: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times sports blogs.

headline: The Benefits of Working in the Office
keywords: ['Fringe Benefits', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Research shows that in some industries, casual interaction among employees enhances creativity and innovation. Plus, some benefits, like free meals, might actually give workers a tax break.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, inspired much debate and rebuke when she recently abolished Yahoo’s work-at-home policy. In academia, “working from home” is a treasured euphemism for heading home after your morning class to have lunch, read the newspaper and take a nap. I hate to see anything that would endanger this hallowed tradition.

headline: Northwestern’s Road to Success Getting Tougher
abstract: Northwestern has been the women’s Division I college lacrosse champion in seven of the past eight years, but other programs are quickly catching up.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill.–It can be lonely at the top.

headline: They’re Not Quite ’N Sync
abstract: They’re buff, gay and play both classical and pop hits on chamber instruments. They’re called Well-Strung, and they sing too.
lead_paragraph: Muscles, Mozart and marketing: following the strippers’ dictum from “Gypsy,” “You Gotta Have a Gimmick,” the four stars of “Well-Strung: The Singing String Quartet” present themselves as a buff, gay, pop-classical hybrid of juicy boy band and staid chamber group with a vocal component.

headline: Obstruct and Delay
abstract: Senator Rand Paul is speaking on the Senate floor to extend debate on John Brennan’s nomination. When he gets tired, the real filibuster will start.
lead_paragraph: As of 3:30 p.m. Wednesday, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been speaking on the Senate floor for about three-and-a-half hours, self-indulging in an old-school filibuster against John Brennan, President Obama’s choice to run the C.I.A. At 3 p.m., Senator Mike Lee of Utah jumped in to help him, asking Mr. Paul questions so he could keep the floor. Then Ted Cruz of Texas and Jerry Moran of Kansas joined in the tirade. It’s a C-Span spectacle, but make no mistake: this isn’t the real filibuster of Mr. Brennan.

headline: A Marble-Floored Contemporary With a Garden
abstract: A minimalist house in a suburb of Athens is on the market for $4.4 million.
lead_paragraph: A minimalist house in a suburb of Athens is on the market for $4.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Greece
abstract: Greece’s severe recession has had a profound impact on the real estate market.
lead_paragraph: A MARBLE-FLOORED HOUSE NORTH OF ATHENS

headline: Europe’s Carmakers Look Forward to U.S. Trade Pact
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Geneva International Motor Show', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Prospects for a trade pact have brightened the spirits of automakers who want to not only sell in the American market, but also to export their American-made cars back to Europe.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As the industry convenes here for the Geneva auto show amid the worst European car market slump in decades, there is at least one ray of hope: the green light President Barack Obama recently gave to negotiations for a U.S.-E.U. free-trade pact.

headline: Sequencing the Stages: Understanding H.I.V. Infection at the Molecular Level
abstract: In this lesson, students watch animations of the H.I.V. life cycle, sequence infection stages, and illustrate those stages. Then, students use their illustrations to demonstrate how the drug AZT counteracts the virus and relate H.I.V. mechanics back to fundamental virus and cell biology.
lead_paragraph: The Complicated AIDS Battle: There is some (qualified) good news in the fight against H.I.V. infections around the world. Go to related article »

headline: Why Vodafone Should Head for a Verizon Exit
abstract: Vodafone’s stake in Verizon Wireless may be worth $120 billion. If a deal can be reached with Verizon, the big question is what strategic options the British telecommunications would pursue with such a windfall.
lead_paragraph: Vodafone should dash for a United States exit if it’s open. Shares of the British telecommunications company soared on Wednesday on hopes that Verizon Communications could buy it out of their $250 billion-plus joint venture. Ending a long standoff while American assets are at high valuations makes sense — as long as Vodafone doesn’t squander the proceeds on a costly makeover.

headline: A Traveling Violation?
abstract: Call it basketball diplomacy or stunt journalism. But the bromance between Dennis Rodman and Kim Jong-un was simply bizarre.
lead_paragraph: Call it basketball diplomacy or stunt journalism. But the bromance between former National Basketball Association star Dennis Rodman and Kim Jong-un, the repressive leader of North Korea, was simply bizarre. Mr. Rodman’s less-than-eloquent appearance on ABC’s “This Week” did little to shed light on the North Korean trip. Twitter users, luckily, had more to say.

headline: If a Rabbit Wore a Mini
abstract: The mini-trend of the fur skirt was one signature of fall fashion weeks in New York, Milan and Paris.
lead_paragraph: THIS HAS BEEN the season of the fur skirt.

headline: Is Poetry Good For Pigs?
abstract: In this week’s briefs: the lives of other animals, the real roots of republicanism, and more.
lead_paragraph: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Vionnet
abstract: The fresh-faced models at Vionnet got a hint of sheen on the eyes and lips.
lead_paragraph: It was all about M.A.C. Silver Dusk Iridescent Powder for extra sheen on the fresh-faced models at Vionnet. The makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury dusted some over the T-zone, “taking one brush and literally going straight down” from the bridge of the nose to the cupid’s bow, and then lightly over the lips. The iridescent powder was also used as a highlighter in the corner of the eyes.

headline: On ABC Family, an Episode in Sign Language
abstract: On Monday night, the channel broadcast an episode of “Switched at Birth” in sign language, with closed captioning turned on by default.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, ABC Family did something that no commercial television outlet in the United States had ever done: it broadcast an entire episode of a show in sign language, with closed captioning turned on by default.

headline: The (Historical) Clothes Make the Reality Show
abstract: The new Smithsonian Channel series “L.A. Frock Stars” chronicles the goings-on at a vintage clothing store in Los Angeles that sells carefully selected women’s fashions.
lead_paragraph: Other fashion-related reality shows tart themselves up with the histrionics of designer competitions or workplace friction, formats that now seem tired. So purists might find “L.A. Frock Stars” to be a refreshing change. In this engaging series, which begins Thursday on the Smithsonian Channel, the clothes really are the main attraction.

headline: Open Houses on Sunday Afternoons Long Ago
abstract: Tafelmusik led a house tour in mirror image on Sunday, from London to Venice to Paris.
lead_paragraph: After the members of the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra strolled onstage at the American Academy of Arts and Letters on Sunday afternoon, they arranged themselves into a formation that mirrored the image projected overhead — an early-18th-century painting by Marco Ricci called “Rehearsal of an Opera.”

headline: Lessons From the Stratosphere, and How to Get There
abstract: Sheryl Sandberg’s new book, “Lean In,” has reignited the debate about women climbing the workplace ladder.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after “The Feminine Mystique” identified the depression and stir-craziness of suburban housewives, another rallying cry for women has come along. It was written by Sheryl Sandberg, a mother of two who works outside the home. Ms. Sandberg addresses 21st-century issues that never entered Betty Friedan’s wildest dreams, and she is a walking advertisement for women’s empowerment. As a former vice president of Google who is now chief operating officer of Facebook, she writes about how women can best rise to the top of the corporate world.

headline: At Shooting Site, Giffords Urges Lawmakers to Act on Gun Safety
abstract: Gabrielle Giffords, a former congresswoman for Arizona, held a news conference in Tucson to urge Senators John McCain and Jeff Flake to support legislation requiring background checks for every gun purchase.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON – “Fight, fight, fight” were the first words by Gabrielle Giffords during a news conference on Wednesday from the same supermarket parking lot where a gunman opened fire on Jan. 8, 2011, wounding her and 12 others and taking six lives.

headline: Bolshoi Intrigue
abstract: The Times’s Ellen Barry offers the latest updates from Moscow regarding the acid attack on a ballet company’s artistic director.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Ellen Barry offers the latest updates from Moscow regarding the acid attack on a ballet company’s artistic director.

headline: Sandberg Takes Her Message to Wall St.
abstract: Kicking off her East Coast book tour, Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, will attend events this week at Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, is heading to Wall Street with her message about women in the workplace.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
abstract: A Gothic Revival in upstate New York, a house in North Carolina and a midcentury ranch house in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: GERMANTOWN, N.Y.

abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Disney Shareholders Endorse Pay of Chief Executive
abstract: Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chairman and chief executive, had been reported to be under fire despite Disney’s excellent results, but more than 57 percent of the company’s shareholders supported his $40.2 million compensation plan for 2012.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – As expected, two shareholder resolutions challenging how the Walt Disney Company is managed were defeated on Wednesday at the entertainment conglomerate’s annual meeting in Phoenix.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google and the F.B.I., and HTC Falters
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include efforts in Congress to make unlocking cellphones legal, a review of Ray Kurzweil’s latest book and Google talking about secret requests by the F.B.I. for information.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: French Ministry Posts Online Full File on ‘Dreyfus Affair’
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Freedom of the Press', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: The entire secret military file that was used to wrongly convict Capt. Alfred Dreyfus of spying for Germany in 1894 has been posted by the French Ministry of Defense.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The entire secret military file that was used to wrongly convict Capt. Alfred Dreyfus of spying for Germany in 1894 has been posted online by the historical department of the French Ministry of Defense.

headline: Homes for $1.1 Million
abstract: A three-bedroom house built in 1841, in Germantown, N.Y.,; a house on a golf course in Durham, N.C.; and a midcentury ranch house in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom house built in 1841, in Germantown, N.Y.,; a house on a golf course in Durham, N.C.; and a midcentury ranch house in Oklahoma.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Have a Growing Stake in Dell, and No Taste for Buyout
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the veteran activist investor, is poised to announce his opposition to Dell’s proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: 11:17 p.m. | Updated

headline: Stalking the Light
abstract: It’s tricky to create a striking highlight in a food photograph without being so bright as to overpower the food.
lead_paragraph: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

headline: Follow Our Environmental Coverage
abstract: Where to find continuing coverage of the environment at The Times.
lead_paragraph: As we wind down this blog, readers have asked how best to follow The Times’s ongoing coverage of the environment.

headline: The Republican Party’s “Donorism” Problem
abstract: Why elite self-interest may be a bigger obstacle to Republican reform than grassroots ideology.
lead_paragraph: Politico’s Jonathan Martin has a good piece today about the divide between conservative policy writers and Republican politicians, and the absence (which I’ve touched on recently) of any actual G.O.P. elected officials willing to champion the various reformist ideas that have been floating around right-of-center journals and magazines and blogs recently (and really for years now). I agree with most of the people quoted in the piece — and particularly Bill Kristol and Ramesh Ponnuru, who both bemoan the absence of domestic policy entrepreneurism among the party’s backbenchers. But Martin’s conversation the American Enterprise Institute’s Jim Pethokoukis seemed particularly worth highlighting:

headline: Scene City: A Parisian Ball with Fashion Week MVP’s
abstract: Carine Roitfeld and Stephen Gan hosted a black-tie ball for CR Fashion Book.
lead_paragraph: Carine Roitfeld and Stephen Gan hosted a black-tie ball for CR Fashion Book.

headline: After the Shows, It’s Shangri-La
abstract: From the runway to the dance floor in Paris, as models and designers party down.
lead_paragraph: It was half past midnight when Kate Moss landed with a thud right next to my feet.

headline: Republicans Block Judicial Nominee’s Confirmation for a Second Time
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: For the second time in two years, Senate Republicans filibustered the confirmation of Caitlin J. Halligan to become a federal appeals court judge in the District of Columbia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked the confirmation of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to become a federal appeals court judge in the District of Columbia, the second time in two years Republicans have filibustered her nomination.

headline: Rehearsals for the Revolution
abstract: The Chilean playwright Guillermo Calderón discusses his play “Neva,” which opens at the Public Theater in its English-language debut.
lead_paragraph: “Neva” may be set in a Russia on the verge of explosion, but the Chilean playwright Guillermo Calderón still calls it “my American play” because “it was born here.” As a graduate student in film at the City University of New York a decade ago he prowled Manhattan’s bookstores, where he found Janet Malcolm’s “Reading Chekhov,” which stimulated an interest in Russian culture and politics that led him to “A People’s Tragedy: The Russian Revolution 1891-1924” by Orlando Figes.

headline: House Tells Postal Service to Keep Six-Day Delivery
abstract: Lawmakers on Wednesday rejected a plan by the Postal Service, faced with billions in losses, to stop delivering mail on Saturdays.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - A spending measure passed by the House on Wednesday to keep the government operating through September requires that the Postal Service maintain a six-day mail delivery schedule, a potential setback for the agency, which announced last month that it planned go to five-day deliveries to cut costs.

headline: Ford Recalling 196,500 Minivans for Corrosion Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Minvans', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Only vehicles sold or registered in 20 salt-belt states and the District of Columbia are affected.
lead_paragraph: 4:44 p.m., March 7 | Updated Ford is recalling about 196,500 of its 2004-7 Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans to fix a corrosion problem that prevents the fold-down third-row seats from locking safely into place, Kelli Felker, a spokeswoman for the automaker, said today.

headline: Going Once, Going Twice
abstract: This week, Doyle New York will auction off more than 400 objects belonging to the Southern decorator Charlotte Moss.
lead_paragraph: If you are one of the many individuals who has been mourning the loss of Charlotte Moss’s treasure trove of design gems ever since she shuttered her Upper East Side town house store in 2008, you can now rejoice a bit. On Thursday at 10 a.m., Doyle New York will auction off “The Charlotte Moss Collection,” which includes over 400 objects belonging to the Southern decorator, including leftover inventory from the retail space as well as other design items she’s collected along the way. Pieces range from signed 18th-century art to a set of De Gournay hand-painted Indian tea paper wallpaper panels with an estimated price tag somewhere between $2,000 and $4,000, and the comprehensive catalog is available at doylenewyork.com leading up to the auction.

headline: We’re Through. Check the App.
abstract: Using a smartphone or your computer to get rid of gifts and block any traces of past loves.
lead_paragraph: Breaking up has always been excruciating, but at least in the old days lovers could split, move on and retain their dignity. Now, in the age of social media, extrication is nearly impossible. The pain of a breakup is nourished by an endless real-time stream of Facebook status updates, Instagram photos and tweets about one’s ex.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 6
abstract: Video highlights of Wednesday’s games in the Round of 16 of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Exhuming the Last of Hendrix’s Studio Sessions
abstract: Jimi Hendrix’s “People, Hell and Angels,” which was released on Tuesday, is likely to be the last album of unreleased studio tracks from the tapes in his estate’s possession.
lead_paragraph: When Jimi Hendrix died in September 1970, he left hundreds of session tapes behind. Over the last three decades producers have mined that trove of recordings, putting out a dozen posthumous studio albums, selling millions of copies.

headline: Witches Lose the Warts
abstract: They darken the plots of young-adult novels, and witches are having an effect on runway fashion, too.
lead_paragraph: Lena Duchannes is new in town, exotic and seductive to a handful of bored locals in the Southern community where she lives. But if that weren’t enough to turn her into man bait, her pallid good looks would do the trick.

headline: Reactions to the Death of Hugo Chávez
abstract: After the death of Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan president whose views and policies were controversial both inside and outside his country, readers discussed his legacy as an economic populist and diplomatic provocateur. Below is a selection of their comments.
lead_paragraph: After the death of Hugo Chávez, the Venezuelan president whose views and policies were controversial both inside and outside his country, readers discussed his legacy as an economic populist and diplomatic provocateur. Below is a selection of their comments.

headline: Witches Have a Fashion Moment
abstract: Witchcraft and its moody expressions — long weedy hair, peaked hats and pointy boots — have attained a strange cachet of late.
lead_paragraph: Witchcraft and its moody expressions — long weedy hair, peaked hats and pointy boots — have attained a strange cachet of late.

headline: Gadgets You Need, Even if You Have a Smartphone
abstract: Smartphone apps have made many electronic devices, like the point-and-shoot camera, superfluous. But some stand-alone devices are still useful.
lead_paragraph: After I bought my first iPhone, something changed. When I bought a new electronic device, I was often filled with regret rather than joy.

headline: Copenhagen Bridge Invitational
abstract: At the 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational, the most famous “am” in the preliminary pro-am event was the husband of Queen Margrethe II of Denmark, Henrik, the prince consort.
lead_paragraph: At the 2nd Copenhagen Bridge Invitational, played two weeks ago, the most famous “am” in the preliminary pro-am event was the husband of Queen Margrethe II of Denmark, Henrik, the prince consort.

headline: Mannequins, Then and Now
abstract: A new exhibition in Paris examines historical representations of the garment vis-à-vis the female shape.
