headline: Order and Disorder, as Dawn Casts a Glow Over a Funereal March
abstract: The opening night gala for the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s three-week season at Lincoln Center included a work from 1956 and one world premiere.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor has often seemed the greatest of today’s choreographers, the most imaginative and disconcerting in any genre. Tuesday’s opening night gala of his dance company’s three-week season at Lincoln Center didn’t demonstrate enoughof that top quality, but its four works — spanning from 1956 to a world premiere — represented an intelligent retrospective. They showed his diversity, from offbeat idiosyncrasy to poetic orthodoxy and from comic pratfalls to dark, wild force. They also included costumes and designs by Alex Katz and Robert Rauschenberg, and scores from jazz to Offenbach. The season that follows contains 17 other works, many of which are among Mr. Taylor’s most singular masterpieces.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company at Lincoln Center
abstract: The company presented its opening night gala of its three-week season on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The company presented its opening night gala of its three-week season on Tuesday.

headline: A Paris Quartier Surges
abstract: New cafes, bars and boutiques are enlivening a stretch of the 10th Arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: New cafes, bars and boutiques are enlivening a stretch of the 10th Arrondissement.

headline: Yanks Lose Another Big Bat to Injury
abstract: A strained right wrist tendon will sideline Mark Teixeira for 8 to 10 weeks and leave the Yankees with a hole in the middle of their lineup for the first month of the season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Sitting in a wheelchair parked in the middle of the Yankees’ clubhouse, with his broken right leg in a cast, General Manager Brian Cashman delivered the details about the latest injury to befall the Yankees, and it was not his own.

headline: A New Look at What Used to Be Chic
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Dresses', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'ART DECO']
abstract: William Banks-Blaney is increasingly becoming a bulwark in the field of vintage couture, drawing celebrity fashion mavens to his elegant London store.
lead_paragraph: Extraordinary dresses have a way of finding William Banks-Blaney. Dresses like the mint condition 1970s Ossie Clark he discovered, along with a floor-length, silk velvet Art Deco cape, in “a random little store on Waiheke Island, off the coast of Auckland, New Zealand, when I was there for Christmas last year,” he said recently, sipping a cappuccino in the lobby of the Maritime hotel in Manhattan. “You just never know where a dress will travel to.”

headline: Boxers HK
abstract: A sports bar in Chelsea creates an outpost to the north in Hell’s Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the center of LGBT night life has shifted from Downtown to Midtown, with 13 gay bars now clustered in Hell’s Kitchen. The newest one is Boxers HK, the northern branch of the popular Chelsea sports bar, that opened its frosted glass doors in January.

headline: Art-Shopping for Stars, So They Don’t Have To
abstract: For Maria Brito, a luxury lifestyle consultant, checking out the Armory art show is just a part of the job.
lead_paragraph: For Maria Brito, the Armory Show, the contemporary art fair that starts Thursday at Piers 92 and 94 on the Hudson River in Manhattan, is kind of like a Stop & Shop. Acting as purchasing proxy for clients like Sean Combs, (“His friends call him Puffy, but I call him Sean,” she said) and Gwyneth Paltrow, Ms. Brito will be looking for works by “established, midcareer and emerging artists,” she said, though her voice ticked up a notch when mentioning younger ones: “Christa Joo-Hyun D’Angelo, Andrea Mary Marshall, Caragh Thuring and Angel Otero.”

headline: Painting Music, and Listening to Art
abstract: “Inventing Abstraction: 1910-1925,” at MoMA, speaks to how musicians and others influenced this art form.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Jan. 2, 1911, at half past 7 in the evening, Wassily Kandinsky attended a concert at a hotel ballroom in Munich. The next day he painted it.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Alexander McQueen
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a reflective gold heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Creative Class Is in Session
abstract: The Luck You Collective is a crew of 19- to 21-year-olds who organize art shows, run zine workshops and bring together the bright young things of the downtown art world.
lead_paragraph: It was a hot Saturday night last summer, and a pack of scruffy kids, many toting skateboards and backpacks, spilled out onto Canal Street from a shoe-box-size storefront Buddhist temple.

headline: In the Bronx, Where Art Is Still Free
abstract: Shelley and Donald Rubin’s $500,000 gift to the Bronx Museum of the Arts will allow its free admission to continue through 2015.
lead_paragraph: How did the Bronx Museum of the Arts, an institution on the Grand Concourse that is far removed from the tourist precincts of Manhattan’s Museum Mile, boost its attendance by 50 percent last year?

headline: Suit Says Sherlock Belongs to the Ages
keywords: ['Holmes, Sherlock (Fictional Character)', 'Books and Literature', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: Whose property is Sherlock Holmes? Opinions and a lawsuit roil the Baker Street crowd.
lead_paragraph: Devotees of Sherlock Holmes are a famously obsessive bunch, and in the 126 years since Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his coolheaded detective they have certainly had plenty of real-world intrigues to ponder alongside fictional ones like “The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle.”

headline: Parsing Motives in Bolshoi Attack
abstract: The motive for an acid attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director may partly turn on a ballerina, Anzhelina Vorontsova, who is romantically involved with another company dancer who has confessed to involvement in the attack.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prosecutors have yet to lay out a possible motive in the January attack on the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, but the revelations of the past few days suggest that it may boil down to a ballerina.

headline: Accessories From Paris Fashion Week
keywords: ['Handbags and Purses', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: A selection of accessories from the Parisian runways.
lead_paragraph: A selection of accessories from the Parisian runways.

headline: Pursuing the Men Who Destroy Majestic Lives
abstract: “Battleground: Rhino Wars,” Thursday night on Animal Planet, is a reality show about the fight against poachers in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes even a dumb show can contain something important. That’s the case with “Battleground: Rhino Wars,” a three-part mini-series that starts Thursday night on Animal Planet.

headline: Past Forward: Hugo Chávez as a ‘Shock Therapist’
abstract: Revisiting Deborah Sontag’s 2002 article for the magazine about Hugo Chávez.

headline: Sacrament, With Birds
abstract: Jon Gillock, organist and student of Messiaen, played his teacher’s work on Tuesday at the Church of the Ascension.
lead_paragraph: Two estimable figures have hovered over the Manton Memorial Organ at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village since that tremendous instrument was inaugurated in May 2011. One is Olivier Messiaen, the visionary 20th-century Frenchman who made the organ a staple of his life’s work as a composer and performer. The other is Jon Gillock, a superb organist born in Oklahoma and based in France who played Messiaen and more to christen the Ascension organ in 2011.

headline: Photo Replay: March 6
abstract: A look at the day in sports from spring training camp and World Baseball Classic games to the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race.
lead_paragraph: A look at the day in sports from spring training camp and World Baseball Classic games to the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race.

headline: The New Seats of Power
abstract: New York’s elite are increasingly networking over a trim, a shave or a coloring treatment.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday, Gary Ginsberg, a senior executive at Time Warner, walked into an unremarkable office building on the corner of 57th Street and Sixth Avenue and took the elevator to the eighth floor, entering a windowless door for a 2 p.m. appointment. A couple of hours later, Kenneth Lerer, a founder of The Huffington Post, followed.

headline: Looking for the Right Solution to Hearing Problems
abstract: Dr. Neil J. DiSarno of the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, answers questions about hearing aids, cochlear implants, genetic causes of hearing loss and more.
lead_paragraph: This is the second set of answers to reader questions from Neil J. DiSarno, chief staff officer for audiology at the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, and a former chairman of the department of communication sciences and disorders at Missouri State University. Dr. DiSarno’s first set of answers can be found here. Because more than 200 people wrote in, not all questions can be answered individually; Dr. DiSarno selected representative questions on similar topics. This feature is closed to new questions.

headline: Say, You’re Not the Brother I Thought I Was Marrying
abstract: Marcello Giordani, Eva-Maria Westbroek and Mark Delavan star in the Met’s revival of Zandonai’s “Francesca da Rimini.”
lead_paragraph: There is no missing the sheer effort involved in the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Riccardo Zandonai’s “Francesca da Rimini,” which opened on Monday evening for its first Met run in close to 27 years. From the moment the curtain rises you are awed by Ezio Frigerio’s towering, grandly detailed sets, designed for a 1984 resurrection of a work neglected since 1918. Franca Squarciapino’s costumes delight your eyes. Zandonai’s luxuriously orchestrated music caresses your ears.

headline: Beauty Spots
abstract: New colors from Estée Lauder, stickers from Essie and metallic nail sheets from Ciaté.
lead_paragraph: Spring Awakening

headline: Boeing Plan to Test Fixes on 787 Nears Approval
abstract: Battery tests on the 787 Dreamliner could begin next week, officials said, but federal regulators could still demand changes in the proposed design changes if problems develop.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration is close to approving tests of Boeing’s approach to fixing the batteries on its 787 jets, and the tests could begin next week, federal and industry officials said Wednesday.

headline: Lean, Unfold, Affix or Fold: A Desk for Tight Spaces
abstract: A desk that can act as a writing or computing surface, a storage ledge or a hat rack.
lead_paragraph: With Appunto, the Belgian-born designer Laurent Corio has created a versatile piece of furniture for small spaces. His modern escritoire for the French company Eno works as a writing or computing desk: the surface measures 19 by 24 inches to support a laptop. It can also do duty as a ledge for storing items in a kitchen, bathroom, children’s room or foyer. When Appunto is closed, its solid beech legs serve as a place to hang shopping bags, scarves or backpacks, and its reverse side, which is washable, also functions as a message board.

headline: In Brooklyn, Tripping the Plastic Fantastic
abstract: Souda, a Brooklyn design group, transforms recycled plastic bottles into chandeliers.
lead_paragraph: The latest evidence that Brooklyn is a hotbed of progressive design comes from Souda (pronounced SOH-duh), a Japanese word that translates to “oh, yeah” or “aha!” That’s the name of a design group started by three 2012 graduates of Parsons the New School for Design: Isaac Friedman-Helman, Shaun Kasperbauer and Luft Tanaka.

headline: Basic Zebra Commands: Sit, Stay, Roll Over, Sleep
abstract: For four-legged friends, a dog bed, and for the two-legged types, a bed skirt and pillow shams.
lead_paragraph: Since 1945, when Flora Scalamandré designed a red zebra wallpaper for the New York restaurant Gino of Capri, the pattern has migrated to umbrellas, china and tote bags. Now it can be found on bedding for people and pets alike. In December Scalamandré introduced a dog bed in the perky stripes, and next month it will follow with a zebra bed skirt and pillow shams for humans.

headline: A Bird in the Hand Is...a Knob
abstract: Cabinet knobs shaped like the heads of four birds: a finch, grosbeak, cardinal and woodpecker.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco-based designer Ted Boerner has teamed up with Rocky Mountain Hardware to create four drawer pulls in the shape of bird heads: a finch, grosbeak, cardinal (shown) and woodpecker. Each one is cast in bronze at the Rocky Mountain foundry in Blackfoot, Idaho, using the centuries-old lost-wax method. (Wax molds are dipped into a liquid ceramic slurry multiple times and hardened. Then the wax is melted out of the shell, liquid bronze is poured in to replace it, and the ceramic shell is cracked off after the metal cools.)

headline: The Daily Do | Louis Vuitton
abstract: In short brown wigs that looked slept-in, models appeared to play the role of a woman in love, or lust.
lead_paragraph: At Louis Vuitton today, Marc Jacobs sent his boudoir-clad ladies out from hotel room doors at the start of the runway. In short, brown Clara Bow-inspired wigs that looked slept-in, the models all appeared to play the same role of a woman in love, or lust.

headline: Sales at Property and Kartell
abstract: Sales on furniture and accessories at Property Furniture and Kartell. Discounts on chairs, sofas, storage systems and more.
lead_paragraph: During Property’s sale from Friday through March 23, some furniture and accessories will be up to 60 percent off, and most new orders will be 20 percent off (the Cubica leather lounge chair by Lievore Altherr Molina, which was originally $4,560, will be $1,800; the Booknest pullout sofa by Carlo Colombo, originally $11,070, will be $5,500); 14 Wooster Street (Grand Street), (917) 237-0123, propertyfurniture.com.

headline: A League of One
abstract: David Beckham’s move to Paris St.-Germain in January created a buzz, but it was hardly a footnote in the larger narrative about the club: It suddenly has a credit card with no limit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One day last week, David Beckham clogged foot traffic on the Champs-Élysées when he made a promotional appearance at the Adidas store. Wearing bright yellow sneakers and his seemingly indefatigable smile, Beckham was like catnip for tourists and locals alike as they walked past the majesty of the nearby Arc de Triomphe and crowded a cramped storefront instead, hoping to snap a camera-phone picture of soccer’s perpetually coifed superstar.

headline: In Defense of Collisions in the Office
abstract: A conversation with Bart Higgins, the director of ?What If!, a self-described “innovation” company with the latest progressive office playground.
lead_paragraph: The latest progressive office playground can be found in the old Stuyvesant Polyclinic, a stately red brick building on Second Avenue near Ninth Street that was once a medical clinic. Inside, its three stories and basement have been reimagined by ?What If!, a self-described “innovation” company that works to expand the markets of businesses like PepsiCo, Pfizer and Virgin.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Venezuela and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Venezuela, Kenya, Myanmar and the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Venezuela, Kenya, Myanmar and the Vatican.

headline: Carter Murray Named as Chief of DraftFCB
abstract: Mr. Murray, 38, will succeed Laurence Boschetto, 58, who has been chief executive at DraftFCB since 2009.
lead_paragraph: The search for a new leader for the global advertising agency DraftFCB Worldwide, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, ended on Wednesday afternoon with the selection of an outsider from a rival agency owned by WPP.

headline: A House Built for a Family of Individuals
abstract: A honeycomb of rooms in bold colors in Kansas City, Mo.
lead_paragraph: A honeycomb of rooms in bold colors in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: It Has Its Points
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: An octagonal house with everything a man and his poodle could want, even a ring of fire.
lead_paragraph: As you approach the Nicol House, you might not realize those are Italian glass ashtrays embedded in the front door or tiny hobby-store mirrors glinting among the shingles. But you would know you were in for something out of the ordinary.

headline: Japan’s New Leader Takes On Old Order to Jolt Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is showing a willingness to challenge some of the pillars of Japan’s establishment and sail “the rough seas of global competition.”
lead_paragraph: TAHARA, Japan — Just two months into office, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is showing an increasing willingness to take on some pillars of Japan’s establishment — the central bank and the country’s politically influential farmers — in an aggressive attempt to finally breathe some new life into Japan’s listless economy.

headline: Market Ready
abstract: We have an enclosed, uninsulated porch that we use for storage. Should we renovate to turn it into a usable living space before selling our house?
lead_paragraph: Q. We have an enclosed, uninsulated porch that we use for storage. Should we renovate to turn it into a usable living space before selling our house?

headline: Casting a Wide Net
abstract: A new show at MoMA looks at all that design can be.
lead_paragraph: A new show at MoMA looks at all that design can be.

headline: And to Think I Saw It @ MoMA!
abstract: In a new show, the Museum of Modern Art taps its own collection to offer a revised definition of design.
lead_paragraph: Posted above the doorway of an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is a question raised in 1911 by the painter Wassily Kandinsky: “Must we not then renounce the object altogether, throw it to the winds and instead lay bare the purely abstract?”

headline: Clues Sought in Burning of Bag Holding 5 Dogs
abstract: Authorities are looking for the people who set fire to the bag behind a Brooklyn warehouse on Saturday. It is unclear whether the dogs were dead before the fire began.
lead_paragraph: Animal protection authorities are looking for the people who set fire to a bag containing five pit bulls behind a beverage distribution warehouse in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

headline: Engineering Serendipity
abstract: Maybe ending work from home isn’t about making sure everyone is doing the job but about making sure there are chance encounters in dense work environments. Tony Hsieh, who built Zappos.com, says such encounters are crucial to his company’s success and his plan to revitalize downtown Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Why do some parties, companies and cities work, while others don’t? It takes some social engineering to foster serendipity and creativity.

headline: Housewares Through an 8-Year-Old’s Eyes
abstract: New products from the International Home and Housewares Show.
lead_paragraph: New products from the International Home and Housewares Show.

headline: Robots, Ducks and Awesome Swag
keywords: ['Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Cookware', 'Design', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: What’s new in housewares? An 8-year-old offers his perspective on the recent show in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — There are few phrases in the English language that bore an 8-year-old more than “trade show.” “Agricultural field trip” might qualify, or maybe “indoor summer camp.” But to draw a truly blank stare, tell a second grader that the two of you are headed to an expo on kitchen, bath and living-room accessories.

headline: The DNA of Cool
abstract: Michelle Harper has made herself so ubiquitous a subject of the street fashion photographers that she was finally forced to reverse herself and declare “street style so over.”
lead_paragraph: Michelle Harper has made herself so ubiquitous a subject of the street fashion photographers that she was finally forced to reverse herself and declare “street style so over.”

headline: Michelle Harper, a Woman of Mystery
abstract: Is the ubiquitous, flamboyantly dressed Michelle Harper this generation’s Holly Golightly? Or is she its Sylvia Miles?
lead_paragraph: It’s definitively established that in the Age of Instagram and Twitter metrics, it is possible to become pretty darn famous for omnipresence. Case in point: Michelle Harper, an eccentric and modish figure whose image over the last several years has seemed to be everywhere, in both real life and, possibly more important, in the parallel universe that is the Web.

headline: Model Diary | Edie Campbell
abstract: The 22-year-old British model loves “24” and horses.
lead_paragraph: Edie Campbell wraps up this season’s Model Diary series for T. If you missed her in today’s Louis Vuitton show, you may find the 22-year-old British model and equestrian hanging out around the Marché des Enfants Rouges market before she catches a plane back home to London.

headline: Two Men Scale New York Times Building
abstract: Alain Robert, a stunt man famous for scaling monuments, hung a bright green banner: “Global warming kills more people than 9/11 every week.” Hours later a copycat also made the climb.
lead_paragraph: Alain Robert, a stunt man famous for scaling monuments, hung a bright green banner: “Global warming kills more people than 9/11 every week.” Hours later a copycat also made the climb.

headline: Trend Report: Fur Skirts
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Fur', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Fur skirts offer a way for designers to explore wider, and wilder, proportions in their fall 2013 collections.
lead_paragraph: Fur skirts offer a way for designers to explore wider, and wilder, proportions in their fall 2013 collections.

headline: Alberto R. Gonzales’s Tenure
abstract: President Bush had repeatedly stood by Mr. Gonzales, even as he faced increasing scrutiny for his leadership of the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: President Bush had repeatedly stood by Mr. Gonzales, even as he faced increasing scrutiny for his leadership of the Justice Department.

headline: Helping Immigrants Warm to Winter
keywords: ['Weather', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: A class in Portland, Me., is helping asylum seekers and people from places like Central Africa and Iraq adjust to frigid temperatures and icy streets.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — Charlene Masengu left the Democratic Republic of Congo late last year, hoping to get asylum status in the United States after a wave of political violence made life at home unbearably dangerous. She made it to this coastal city last month, just before it was covered in more than 30 inches of snow, and she wondered, briefly, whether she had made a mistake.

headline: A Poetry Reading by Alfred Brendel
abstract: Mr. Brendel, a pianist, read two selections from his poetry collection, 'Cursing Bagels.' Recorded by James Barron of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Brendel, a pianist, read two selections from his poetry collection, 'Cursing Bagels.' Recorded by James Barron of The New York Times.

headline: Sears and Penney Respond to ‘SNL’ Sketch Complaint
abstract: The companies have made arrangements to avoid placing any ads adjacent to online replays of the sketch in question, but that will not affect any commercials in the television version of “SNL.”
lead_paragraph: So did a comedy sketch on the Feb. 16 edition of “Saturday Night Live” called “Djesus Uncrossed” really lead two companies to ask NBC not to place their ads in future editions of the show?

headline: Where Everything Smells Bad
abstract: Why do we need three new perfumes a day when we can just get one giant bottle of Everything?
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: Stage Scenes: Alice Ripley
abstract: A look at some of the actress’s stage performances.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the actress’s stage performances.

headline: Posters on Teenage Pregnancy Draw Fire
abstract: The city’s public education effort speaks frankly about the increased chances that teenage mothers will become impoverished, but critics say it reinforces stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: The curly-haired baby looks out from the poster with sad eyes and tears dripping down his tawny cheeks.

headline: When Arkansas Travels, Success Doesn’t Follow
abstract: Arkansas’s 84.4-percentage-point disparity between its winning percentages at home (94.4 percent) and on the road (10 percent) is the highest in Division I.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Anderson left Missouri to become the men’s basketball coach at Arkansas in March 2011, he said he was going home.

headline: Clothes Worthy of Their Label
abstract: While some high-end labels lazily rest on status, Hermès appeared to put some effort into its new collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — You sometimes think, at the bleary end of a runway season, that fashion would be better off if companies didn’t have labels to sell.

headline: Television’s ‘C.S.I.’ Gets New Financial Partner to Replace Goldman
abstract: Content Partners has agreed to buy half of the franchise from a unit of Goldman Sachs in a deal that makes it a co-owner with CBS.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Crime continues to pay, at least where the “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation” television franchise is concerned.

headline: Egypt Court Cancels Parliamentary Elections
abstract: The court referred the election law to the Supreme Constitutional Court, adding to the uncertainty about a vote that had been scheduled to begin as early as April 22.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A top court on Wednesday canceled pending parliamentary elections and referred the election law to the Supreme Constitutional Court, adding to the mounting uncertainty about a vote that had been scheduled to begin as early as April 22.

headline: Video of Syrians With Seized U.N. Vehicles in Golan Heights
abstract: A rebel group calling itself the Martyrs of Yarmouk Brigade claimed to have abducted 20 United Nations peacekeepers in the Golan Heights.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Thursday, 9:07 a.m. As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Alan Cowell report, 30 armed rebel fighters kidnapped a group of 20 United Nations peacekeepers in the Golan Heights on Wednesday and gave a 24-hour deadline before they would treat the peacekeepers “as prisoners of war.”

headline: The Struggle for Jihad
abstract: Two opposing groups battle to define the word jihad on public buses and subways.
lead_paragraph: Two opposing groups battle to define the word jihad on public buses and subways.

headline: In Upgrade, Google Adds to Model for Mobile Marketing
abstract: Google is bringing three new brands to its digital advertising initiative, an attempt to get marketers to think of technology as their best asset.
lead_paragraph: GOOGLE executives, declaring themselves pleased with the results of an unusual advertising initiative last year, are bringing out a Version 2.0, again teaming with agencies and marketers to try demonstrating that technology is not incompatible with traditional Madison Avenue sales strategies like emotional storytelling.

headline: A Nascar Driver’s Deeds Fail to Match Her Words
abstract: Tia Norfleet has long portrayed herself as an accomplished driver, but the discrepancy between her true record and her public comments has drawn objections from racing officials.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Nascar, which has long struggled to develop minority and female participants, seemed to have a barrier-breaking athlete in its ranks in recent years: Tia Norfleet, a 20-something driver from Georgia. With a savvy marketing campaign, Norfleet garnered attention in several national publications while promoting her accomplishments as the first African-American woman to race in Nascar.

headline: Using Billboards to Stake Claim Over ‘Jihad’
abstract: Two advocacy groups in Chicago are running dueling ads over the meaning of jihad: one campaign is focused on a nonviolent interpretation of the word, the other on its association with terrorism.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — There is an advertising war being fought here — not over soda or car brands but over the true meaning of the word “jihad.”

headline: A Locust Plague, Shy of Biblical Proportions, in Israel
abstract: It seemed, to many Israelis, a vivid enactment of the eighth plague visited upon the obdurate Pharaoh: Three weeks before Passover, locusts swarmed across the border from Egypt.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For many Israelis, the biblical comparisons were irresistible: locusts were swarming across the border from Egypt three weeks before Passover, like a vivid enactment of the eighth plague visited upon the obdurate Pharaoh. Others with a more modern sensibility said it felt more like Hitchcock.

headline: Killer of Girlfriend and Her Son Is Sentenced to 50 Years to Life
abstract: The killer, Jimmy Humphrey, did not want to start a family with the victim, Linda Anderson, who was pregnant, the district attorney said.
lead_paragraph: A man convicted of strangling his pregnant girlfriend and killing her 2-year-old son in a fire he set at her Queens apartment was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison on Wednesday, the Queens district attorney said.

headline: A Shift Toward Higher Job Vacancy Rates
abstract: There has been a fundamental shift over the last several years toward more unfilled jobs, even as the unemployment rate has fallen.
lead_paragraph: There has been a fundamental shift over the last several years toward more unfilled jobs, even as the unemployment rate has fallen.

headline: Officer’s Trial Has a Jury That Appears Tech-Savvy
abstract: Closing arguments are expected on Thursday in the trial of Gilberto Valle, who is accused of plotting online to torture, kill and eat women.
lead_paragraph: One day last month, as Judge Paul G. Gardephe was overseeing jury selection for the trial of a New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, he asked prospective jurors about issues that could call their impartiality into question.

headline: Security Council Loosens Somalian Arms Embargo
abstract: The easing was portrayed as part of an effort to strengthen the fragile government’s authority by permitting it to purchase light weapons.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Wednesday to temporarily rescind part of a 21-year-old arms embargo on Somalia, the East African country once considered synonymous with warlordism, piracy and anarchy, portraying the easing as part of an effort to strengthen the fragile Somalian government’s authority by permitting it to purchase light weapons.

headline: Global Slavery, by the Numbers
abstract: A Big Data start-up analyzed reports from governments and human rights organizations, then presented its findings in a pretty graphic full of ugly truths. Among the findings: Slaves may cost as little as $60, and children are often used for fishing and harvesting stones.
lead_paragraph: Here are some chilling statistics: The lifetime profit on a brickmaking slave in Brazil is $8,700, and $2,000 in India. Sexual slavery brings the slave’s owner $18,000 over the slave’s working life in Thailand, and $49,000 in Los Angeles.

headline: Guns and Congress
abstract: The Times's Mike McIntire on the close relationship between members of Congress and a sportsmen's charity pushing gun rights.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Mike McIntire on the close relationship between members of Congress and a sportsmen's charity pushing gun rights.

headline: Despite Ranger’s Eye Injury, Union Rejects Calls for Mandatory Visors
abstract: Marc Staal’s eye injury refueled the argument for mandatory use of visors in the N.H.L., but the players union insists that wearing them should be a matter of personal choice.
lead_paragraph: The puck may have been flying about 75 miles per hour when it exploded off the stick of Flyers defenseman Kimmo Timonen and deflected into the face of Marc Staal near his right eye Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. Staal, a 26-year-old Rangers defenseman, went down as if shot, hands covering his face as he squirmed on the ice and bled profusely.

headline: Microsoft Is Talking About the Future, a Lot
abstract: Microsoft held an event inside a home of the future on its campus. One technology Microsoft is betting on is jumbo-size touch-screen displays that can be used for presentations and meetings.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — There are technology companies that won’t say anything about the futuristic inventions they’re tinkering with in their labs — Apple, for instance.

headline: Latin America After Chávez
abstract: No matter his flaws, Hugo Chávez’s passion for lifting up the poor is a lasting legacy.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil

headline: Pakistan, Under Cultural Siege, Is Buoyed by Book Festivals
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Man Booker Prize', 'Writing and Writers', 'Culture (Arts)']
abstract: The festivals tapped into a well of pent-up enthusiasm for cultural and political debate among young Pakistanis, and offered a counterpoint to extremism.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Assailed by jihadist attacks and the moral cudgels of religious conservatives, Lahore’s celebrated cultural vitality has waned somewhat in recent years. A famous kite-flying festival is no more; a performing arts festival vanished after being attacked; and music concerts take place in restricted circumstances.

headline: Latest Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
abstract: The massacre in Newtown, Conn., that killed 27 people, including 20 children, has reignited a conversation about our country’s relationship with guns.
lead_paragraph: President Obama travels to Connecticut Monday, where lawmakers last week approved stricter gun laws nearly four months after 20 children and six educators were shot and killed in Newtown, Conn.

headline: What Young Republicans Want
abstract: Why are fewer young people -- the millennial generation -- identifying themselves as conservatives?

headline: How to Start a Good School Day
abstract: New York City schools are among the least effective in the country in providing free breakfast to low-income children.
lead_paragraph: Breakfast is served every weekday morning to 12 million students across the country, courtesy of the Department of Agriculture. Free breakfast reduces hunger and can improve academic performance, but in New York City, too many students do not get the meals they need.

headline: Proposed Dam Presents Economic and Environmental Challenges in Alaska
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Salmon', 'Hydroelectric Power']
abstract: At a time when large dams are being taken down, the state is planning to construct one of the tallest and most expensive hydroelectric dams ever built in North America.
lead_paragraph: At a time when large dams are being taken down, not put up, the state of Alaska is proposing to construct one of the tallest and most expensive hydroelectric dams ever built in North America.

headline: Face-Lift at Facebook, to Keep Its Users Engaged
abstract: Facebook plans to announce a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed both at keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook plans to announce on Thursday a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed at both keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.

headline: Charity Takes Gun Lobby Closer to Its Quarry
keywords: ['Firearms', 'Philanthropy', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Series']
abstract: The Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation allows its donors to mix with lawmakers and press issues important mainly to the firearms industry.
lead_paragraph: On a Monday evening in early February, two months into a national debate over gun violence after the massacre at a Connecticut elementary school, representatives of the firearms industry were wining and dining lawmakers in Washington.

headline: Hugo Chávez
abstract: His policies improved conditions for poor Venezuelans, but he left a stained legacy, and his main theme seemed to be taunting the United States.
lead_paragraph: Hugo Chávez dominated Venezuelan politics for 14 years with his charismatic personality, populist policies and authoritarian methods before his death this week. His redistributionist policies brought better living conditions to millions of poor Venezuelans. But his legacy is stained by the undermining of democratic institutions and the embrace of malevolent foreign leaders like Bashar al-Assad of Syria and Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

headline: Death in the Forests
abstract: China’s voracious appetite for ivory continues to devastate Africa’s elephants.
lead_paragraph: Day after day, the slaughter of the elephants continues at a record pace — 25,000 killed in 2011, conservationists say, and more than 30,000 last year. A study from the Wildlife Conservation Society shows that 60 percent of all African forest elephants (a slightly smaller subspecies of the African savanna elephant) have been killed in the last decade for their ivory, leaving about 80,000 in their primary habitats in Western and Central Africa.

headline: From One Budget Fight to the Next
abstract: At a time when Republicans are divided on many social issues, the budget wars are one of the few things that unite them.
lead_paragraph: Unable to stop the sequester’s job-killing spending cuts, President Obama now says he wants to move past the endless wars of budget attrition. Though he still wants a long-term deficit deal, he said last week, it is time to turn to immigration, gun control, universal preschool, a higher minimum wage and voting reform.

headline: Newly Discovered, Nearly Extinct
abstract: The Gunnison sage grouse, only recently known to science, is going extinct, right before our eyes.
lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N.Y.

headline: ‘A Big New Power’
abstract: The Supreme Court appears ready to eviscerate the Voting Rights Act — and seriously harm itself in the process.
lead_paragraph: Years from now, when the Supreme Court has come to its senses, justices then sitting will look back on the spring of 2013 in bewilderment. On what basis, they will wonder, did five conservative justices, professed believers in judicial restraint, reach out to grab the authority that the framers of the post-Civil War 14th and 15th Amendments had vested in Congress nearly a century and a half earlier “to enforce, by appropriate legislation” the right to equal protection and the right to vote. How on earth did it come to pass that the Supreme Court ruled a major provision of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 unconstitutional?

headline: Cry About the Real Wolf
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Alarmism erodes credibility, but real danger can still lurk.
lead_paragraph: The White House horribly botched its messaging on the sequester.

headline: Talk of the Town
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Rand Paul just goes on and on and on.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul has his faults. Who among us can forget the time he ranted at a representative of the Department of Energy about the inadequacy of his bathroom plumbing? (“You busybodies always want to do something to tell us how we can live our lives better. ... I’ve been waiting for 20 years to talk about how bad these toilets are.”)

headline: The Good, Racist People
abstract: What does it mean when Forest Whitaker is frisked at a deli?
lead_paragraph: Last month the actor Forest Whitaker was stopped in a Manhattan delicatessen by an employee. Whitaker is one of the pre-eminent actors of his generation, with a diverse and celebrated catalog ranging from “The Great Debaters” to “The Crying Game” to “Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai.” By now it is likely that he has adjusted to random strangers who can’t get his turn as Idi Amin out of their heads. But the man who approached the Oscar winner at the deli last month was in no mood for autographs. The employee stopped Whitaker, accused him of shoplifting and then promptly frisked him. The act of self-deputization was futile. Whitaker had stolen nothing. On the contrary, he’d been robbed.

headline: On Campus, Costly Target of Brazen Thefts: Nutella
abstract: Columbia University students may be hoarding jars of the chocolate hazelnut spread, to the tune of thousands of dollars a week.
lead_paragraph: This has all the makings of a tempest in a Nutella jar, which may not be as appealing as a Nutella milkshake, Nutella fudge or Nutella-stuffed French toast. Or stolen Nutella, which, apparently, has mouthwatering appeal at Columbia University.

headline: Wall Street Ties in a Prospect for Deputy at the S.E.C.
abstract: As Mary Jo White confronts scrutiny over her ties to big Wall Street firms, a leading candidate to be her enforcement chief — Andrew J. Ceresney — has trod a similar path.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White, who appears set to become a top Wall Street regulator, is seeking to allay skepticism about her spins through the revolving door between government service and private practice.

lead_paragraph: Call it the coffee conundrum: What to do when new sugary drink rules come between a harried, half-awake New Yorker and a morning cup?

headline: New to the Neighborhood
abstract: Jennifer Dady and Samantha Kubler, who are sisters, are moving into a renovated apartment in Ocean Village, Queens, which, after decades of neglect, is being repaired under new management.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Dady and Samantha Kubler, who are sisters, are moving into a renovated apartment in Ocean Village, Queens, which, after decades of neglect, is being repaired under new management.

headline: New Life Takes Hold After Hurricane and Blight
abstract: An apartment complex on the Rockaway Peninsula is under renovation, and people displaced by Hurricane Sandy are given priority for renting there.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Dady was not there when Hurricane Sandy sent ocean water into the courtyards of Ocean Village, an apartment complex on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens. She had never visited the place, though it is just a short distance from her own home in Broad Channel, where she spent the storm on her second floor, watching as seawater lapped across her living room.

headline: A Leader Cries, ‘I Am Chávez,’ as U.S. Seeks Policy Clues
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'International Relations']
abstract: As President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela neared death, Vice President Nicolás Maduro’s imitations of him became apparent. Less clear are Mr. Maduro’s intentions toward the United States.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the weeks leading up to his mentor’s death, Vice President Nicolás Maduro’s imitations of President Hugo Chávez became ever more apparent.

abstract: Some residents and local leaders recalled that Hugo Chávez’s visit to the South Bronx in 2005 led to donations in oil and money from the Venezuelan leader.
lead_paragraph: Lucia Solano became something of a stalker when Hugo Chávez visited the South Bronx in 2005.

headline: Means of Divination
abstract: Jim Page rounds third base.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Leaving For the A.C.P.T. Alert! I’m off to cover the gathering of the word nerd tribe at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. If you aren’t planning on joining us, you can still register to solve online or by mail. Not only that, but you can follow along as I post about the tournament here in between puzzle posts, and if you’d like to ask a question or give a shout out to anyone at the tournament, Tweet to me at @nytimeswordplay. Enjoy your weekend, and keep on solving!

headline: A Respite in Efforts by Wal-Mart in New York

lead_paragraph: After losing a battle in September to open its first store in New York City, Wal-Mart Stores appears to have scaled back its efforts to gain a foothold in the nation’s largest city.

lead_paragraph: March 6, 2013

headline: France: Sarkozy Dips a Toe Back In
abstract: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy has sent a signal, through friends quoted in an article to be published on Thursday, of his supposedly reluctant willingness to return to politics.
lead_paragraph: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy has sent a strong signal, through friends quoted in an article to be published on Thursday, of his supposedly reluctant willingness to return to politics out “of duty, and only because it is for France.” His remarks will be published in a center-right magazine, Valeurs Actuelles, whose editors said they had not spoken directly with Mr. Sarkozy but with close associates, who presumably did so with his encouragement. Mr. Sarkozy, 58, who narrowly lost his attempt at re-election in May, said that politics “bores him to death,” but that “sadly, there may come a moment when the question is no longer, ‘Do you want to?’ but, ‘Do you have a choice?’ ” He predicted a “social crisis” and a “financial crisis of an uncommon violence.” Mr. Sarkozy’s comments were greeted with pleasure by his supporters and derision by his critics.

lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: High School Detention Was Never This Creepy
abstract: A vice principal relentlessly grills an Arab-American student in Rajiv Joseph’s drama “The North Pool.” But why?
lead_paragraph: The bewildered high school student made to cool his heels in the vice principal’s office may not be the only one feeling he’s been given a raw deal in “The North Pool,” the disappointing play by Rajiv Joseph that opened on Wednesday night at the Vineyard Theater. The audience too may come to feel it has been unjustly condemned to an afternoon of detention as this contrived drama moves through its sluggish paces.

headline: Republicans, Led by Rand Paul, Finally End Filibuster
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The senator from Kentucky staged a filibuster over the government’s use of lethal drone strikes, forcing the Senate to delay the expected confirmation of John O. Brennan to lead the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: 1:27 a.m. | Updated WASHINGTON — A small group of Republicans, led by Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, stalled the Senate on Wednesday by waging a nearly 13-hour old-school, speak-until-you-can-speak-no-more filibuster over the government’s use of lethal drone strikes — forcing the Senate to delay the expected confirmation of John O. Brennan to lead the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Amid Cuts, Does a President Dare Tee Off?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Government Employees']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fair or not, the extracurricular lives of American presidents are often measured by how they compare with the everyday pursuits of the people they lead.

headline: Knicks Beat Lowly Foe, but Without Anthony, It’s a Struggle
abstract: The mystery over Carmelo Anthony’s ailing knee continued as he sat out a victory over the Pistons in which the Knicks fell behind by 10 points in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Carmelo Anthony stepped off the team bus, made the 30-yard walk to the visitors’ locker room and disappeared into the trainer’s area, out of sight, out of the cross-fire and out of the lineup.

headline: Against the Bobcats, the Nets Receive Another Chance to Start Over
abstract: Charlotte has the worst record in the N.B.A., but it took the Nets a while to put the game away against their less talented opponent.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Charlotte Bobcats have appeared on the schedule at fortuitous times for the Nets.

headline: Michigan: Detroit Council Resists State Plan for Emergency Manager
abstract: Detroit’s City Council voted on Wednesday to challenge state plans to assign an outside emergency manager to shore up the city’s troubled finances.
lead_paragraph: Detroit’s City Council voted on Wednesday to challenge state plans to assign an outside emergency manager to shore up the city’s troubled finances, even as Mayor Dave Bing announced that he would take no part in a challenge. “We need to end the drama and infighting and understand that whether we like it or not, an emergency financial manager is coming to Detroit,” Mr. Bing said. In a hearing planned for Tuesday, the City Council, which would lose authority with state intervention, is expected to argue that although Detroit’s financial circumstances are indeed dire, the city has a plan for repairing them. Gov. Rick Snyder, who last week deemed an outside manager a necessity for the city, would be asked to reconsider, a possibility Mr. Bing and others view as remote.

headline: Amid Suffering, Animal Welfare Legislation Still Far Off in China
abstract: Animals suffer. So what excuse is there for treating them badly? Is “culture” a reason?
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — About animals, “The question is not, ‘Can they reason?’ nor, ‘Can they talk?’ but, ‘Can they suffer?’” So wrote Jeremy Bentham, the English philosopher, more than 200 years ago.

headline: G.O.P. Senators Give Obama Dinner Thumbs Up
abstract: Washington will be digging for days for reports about what – if anything – President Obama’s unusual dinner with Republican senators might mean for progress on the budget, immigration, gun safety or any other issue central to his second-term agenda.
lead_paragraph: For Washington-watchers looking for positive signs from President Obama’s unusual dinner with Republican senators on Wednesday night, there was this: Senators John McCain of Arizona and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma each gave waiting reporters a thumbs up as lawmakers exited the private dining room.

headline: C.I.A.’s History Poses Hurdles for an Obama Nominee
abstract: John O. Brennan’s first challenge at the agency where he worked for 25 years may be confronting a sweeping indictment of its former interrogation program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John O. Brennan’s first difficult challenge at the C.I.A. may not be confronting the agency’s future, but its past.

headline: Allan Calhamer Dies at 81; Invented Diplomacy Game
abstract: The objective of Mr. Calhamer’s game, reportedly a favorite of Henry Kissinger, is simple: to achieve world domination in as many hours (or days, or even years) as it takes.
lead_paragraph: Allan Calhamer, a Harvard-educated postman who invented Diplomacy, which for more than half a century has been a favorite board game of calculating, caffeinated intellectuals, died on Feb. 25 in La Grange, Ill. He was 81.

headline: Alvin Lee, British Blues-Rock Guitarist, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Lee and Ten Years After played at the Woodstock festival in 1969 and were in the movie “Woodstock” and on its soundtrack with “I’m Going Home.”
lead_paragraph: Alvin Lee, whose fire-fingered guitar playing drove the British blues-rock band Ten Years After to stardom in the 1960s and early ’70s, died on Wednesday in Spain. He was 68.

headline: The War On Entitlements
abstract: Why aren’t we talking about what the public wants when it comes to Social Security and Medicare?
lead_paragraph: The debate over reform of Social Security and Medicare is taking place in a vacuum, without adequate consideration of fundamental facts.

headline: Ex-Premier’s Ally Expelled From Ukraine Parliament
abstract: The lawmaker, Sergey Vlasenko, is a close associate of former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who has been jailed.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The lead defender of Ukraine’s jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, was stripped of his seat in the Ukrainian Parliament on Wednesday by the country’s top administrative court, despite stern warnings by Western officials who said the case was a matter of political retribution.

headline: Straight to the Point
abstract: Neatly tailored and to the knee, all manner of coats this season offer a sharp measure of austerity.
lead_paragraph: Neatly tailored and to the knee, all manner of coats this season offer a sharp measure of austerity.

headline: Eat Your Heart Out
abstract: Do we need to change the rules about healthful eating?
lead_paragraph: Over the last several decades, it has become accepted wisdom that consuming saturated fat, the type found in meat and butter, is bad for you. Starting in the 1960s, studies showed convincingly that saturated fat raises cholesterol levels and that these elevated levels, especially of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, or LDL (the so-called bad cholesterol), increase heart disease. Studies also showed that consuming polyunsaturated fats — safflower, corn and soybean oils — reduced people’s levels of overall cholesterol and LDL and should be encouraged.

abstract: This word has appeared in 257 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: U.N. Starts Talks to Free Peacekeepers Held by Syria Rebels
abstract: It was not clear when 21 Filipino captives, seized on Wednesday in the Golan Heights, might be set free, but the authorities in Manila said they had not been harmed.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials negotiated on Thursday with Syrian rebels who had seized a group of United Nations peacekeepers in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel, as the rebels offered assurances of the peacekeepers’ well-being and appeared to back away from threats to hold them as hostages.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Sundance) MARATHON MAN (1976) Dustin Hoffman (above, with Marthe Keller) portrays Babe, a Columbia graduate student who unwittingly finds himself in a mysterious plot involving diamonds and a Nazi war criminal named Szell (Laurence Olivier, in an Oscar-nominated role) with a penchant for dentistry in this thriller from John Schlesinger, adapted by William Goldman from his novel. “Is it safe?” Szell asks. “Is what safe?” Babe replies. “Is it safe?” Szell asks again before fiddling with a live nerve in one of Babe’s teeth. “High-level conspiracies really aren’t that interesting unless we can get a fix on who is doing what to whom, which is never clear here,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “Yet the individual details of ‘Marathon Man,’ the performances, and the attention given to its physical settings — in New York, Paris and South America — keep one’s belief willingly suspended by a wickedly thin thread.” The film “hasn’t a real idea in its head,” he added. “It just wants to scare the hell out of you — and it does.”

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

abstract: Not sure how to meet people at the A.C.P.T.? Come hang out with the Cru.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — One of the statements I hear most from people who would like to dip a toe into the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is “I wouldn’t feel comfortable. I don’t know anyone.” The other is “How exactly does Dan Feyer do that?”

headline: A Conversation With: Video Artist Nalini Malani
abstract: On melding political and social themes in art and more.
lead_paragraph: Nalini Malani is a pioneering video and installation artist who lives and works in Mumbai. Born in Karachi in 1946, she came to India as a refugee of the partition of India, an experience that deeply informs her art practice. Her piece at the Kochi-Muziris Biennale, “In Search of Vanished Blood (2012)”, is a “video play” that melds Greek and Indian myths with the revolutionary poetry of Faiz Ahmed Faiz through projection, sound and hand-drawn animation. The effect is a multilayered commentary on social fracturing, gender violence and the echoes of American hegemony.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 7, 2013
abstract: Can you identify the literary device found in the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Chasing the Higgs Boson.”

headline: Cardinals Hold 4th Day of Talks on New Pope
abstract: A week after Pope Benedict XVI formally retired, cardinals gathered in Rome to choose his successor went into a fourth day of soundings and deliberations on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A week after Pope Benedict XVI formally retired, cardinals assembled in here to choose his successor went into a fourth day of soundings and deliberations on Thursday without reaching a decision so far on a date to begin the secret papal balloting known as a conclave, a Vatican spokesman said.

headline: LED Light Sculpture Makes Bay Bridge a Glowing Attraction
abstract: How many LED white lights are included in the public art sculpture?
lead_paragraph: In “Long Stuck in Obscurity, Bay Bridge Will Go From Drab Gray to Glowing,” Malia Wollan writes about the Bay Bridge’s transformation into a 1.8-mile light sculpture.

headline: Proposal to Ban Trade in Polar Bear Parts Is Rejected
abstract: The rejection at a major international conference  highlighted the difficulties of reaching a global consensus on protecting many kinds of endangered wildlife.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A proposal to ban international trade in polar bear parts was rejected on Thursday at a major conference on wildlife trade, highlighting the difficulties of reaching a global consensus on protecting many kinds of endangered wildlife.

headline: Filling a Fed Vacuum in Bank Supervision
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Federal Reserve must stop its internal wrangling and impose more effective control over the biggest banks, and Sheila Bair is the kind of strong regulator to lead the effort, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Way Down and Out in Ulan Bator
abstract: Mikel Aristregi went to Mongolia to document street children. Instead, he found homeless alcoholics living underground among the pipes that run beneath the streets of Ulan Bator.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, Mikel Aristregi documented street children in Cambodia, fascinated by the bonds they forged among themselves, a coping mechanism against an onslaught of threats along the harsh landscape of Phnom Penh’s boulevards. So when he learned of children living in the sewers of Ulan Bator, Mongolia, he went there in pursuit of a similar project.

headline: The Last Time Inter Saw Gareth Bale
abstract: You may not remember the last time Gareth Bale and Tottenham faced Inter Milan, but fans of both clubs will never forget.
lead_paragraph: The Champions League has a pretty sexy first four for its quarterfinals — Real Madrid, Dortmund, Paris Saint-Germain and Juventus — but Thursday is the Europa League’s day, and it has at least one matchup no one will want to miss: Inter Milan against Tottenham at White Hart Lane (Fox Soccer, 3 p.m. ET).

headline: Should Students Be Allowed to Skip Senior Year of High School?
abstract: Are many seniors so “underscheduled” that the year is a waste and might be better spent in an internship, or going to college early? Or, does senior year play an important emotional role in college readiness?
lead_paragraph: Is senior year just about partying? If so, should prepared students be allowed to skip it and spend a year volunteering, or go on to college early? Or, does senior year play an key role in helping students transition emotionally to being on their own?

headline: New Sanctions on North Korea Pass in Unified U.N. Vote
abstract: A resolution in response to North Korea’s nuclear test last month, negotiated between the United States and China, won unanimous approval from the United Nations Security Council.
lead_paragraph: Ignoring threats of retaliation, the United Nations Security Council ordered new economic sanctions against North Korea on Thursday for its third nuclear test last month, unanimously approving a resolution that the United States negotiated with China, the North’s greatest protector.

headline: In France, They Call It ‘Happiness Therapy’
abstract: In an age when movies go global, what’s to be done with a confoundingly American title like “Silver Linings Playbook”?
lead_paragraph: PARIS—Friends will sometimes ask if you’ve seen a movie. You will say no. They will tell you what the plot is, and you will immediately realize that you have in fact seen the movie, just with a different title.

headline: The Early Word: Pressing
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:In a series examining how the gun industry lobbies Congress, Mike McIntire writes about how the Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation and a Congressional caucus provide the firearms industry with direct access to lawmakers to press industry concerns.

headline: Kenyan Party Says Vote Count Should Stop
abstract: Tensions rose after the party of Raila Odinga, the prime minister, who has been trailing in the polls, said that preliminary results had been “doctored.”
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Election-related tensions rose steadily on Thursday after the party of Raila Odinga, the prime minister, who has been trailing in the polls, said that preliminary election results had been “doctored” and the counting process needed to be stopped.

headline: Malaysian Troops Kill 31 Filipinos; Calls for Cease-Fire Are Rejected
abstract: Malaysian security forces killed 31 Filipino gunmen on Borneo Island, officials said, and the government rejected calls by the United Nations for an end to the fighting.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Malaysian security forces killed 31 Filipino gunmen on the island of Borneo, officials said Thursday, and the government rejected calls by the United Nations for an end to the fighting.

headline: 10 Years After the Invasion of Iraq, a World of Hurt
abstract: Across the world, countries as disparate as the United States, Britain and Uganda grapple with the gruesome legacies of a war.
lead_paragraph: This month marks the 10th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq. You could certainly be forgiven for thinking it might be a time for reflection, remembrance and, ultimately, moving on.

headline: Tip of the Week: Free Microsoft Office Quick-Start Guides
abstract: Microsoft has free colorful guides to the new features in its Office 2013 suite, available to download from its site.
lead_paragraph: Software updates often bring changes like new menus, commands and keyboard shortcuts to Microsoft Office programs — and these new elements can temporarily slow down even the most experienced users of Word, Excel and PowerPoint. To help its customers get up to speed with the latest release, Microsoft has colorful “quick start” guides for all the programs in the Office suite available at its site.

headline: The Allergy Buster
abstract: An experimental new treatment seeks to release children from the terror of severe food allergies.
lead_paragraph: For nine years, the greatest challenge Kim Yates Grosso faced each day was keeping her daughter Tessa safe. Tessa was so severely allergic to milk, wheat, eggs, nuts, shellfish and assorted other foods that as a toddler she went into anaphylactic shock when milk fell on her skin. Kim never left her with a baby sitter. She slept with her each night. And when she needed to work, she found a job she could do primarily from home in the evenings. She successfully lobbied the Menlo Park, Calif., school district to provide Tessa with a full-time aide (in accordance with the Americans With Disabilities Act) to shadow her at all times. She made all of Tessa’s food from scratch, including safe treats to bring to birthday parties, when she could persuade her daughter to attend them at all. Tessa never spent the night at a friend’s house — she didn’t feel comfortable sleeping in an unsafe environment.

headline: Do You Listen to Your Employees?
abstract: It’s amazing what you can find out when you ask questions instead of making assumptions.
lead_paragraph: When I had my vending business, one of the things we constantly told employees was the following statement: “You are the expert at your job.” It took several years for some of our people to actually believe it.

headline: Daily Report: Face-Lift at Facebook, to Keep Its Users Engaged
abstract: Facebook plans to announce a substantial redesign of its News Feed, a makeover aimed both at keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars.
lead_paragraph: Facebook plans to announce on Thursday a substantial redesign of its News Feed — a makeover aimed both at keeping users glued to the social network and luring more advertising dollars, Somini Sengupta reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Chávez at the Pearly Gates
abstract: Here’s a complicated case.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a complicated case.

headline: In Tamil Nadu, Domestic Violence Cases Rise, and Women’s Activists Cheer
abstract: The southern state leads India in reported domestic violence, as increasingly employed women go to the cops.
lead_paragraph: Tamil Nadu boasts some of the best indicators in India when it comes to women.

headline: The S.E.C. and Wall Street
abstract: Mary Jo White, who faces questions about her Wall Street work, may end up tapping a deputy who has taken a similar path. | Carl C. Icahn has joined the fight over Dell. | Time Warner is spinning off its Time Inc. unit. | Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. says some firms are so big that bringing criminal charges against them could threaten the economy.
lead_paragraph: Even as Mary Jo White, President Obama’s choice to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, faces concerns about her work in private practice, she may end up finding a deputy in a lawyer who has taken a similar path. Andrew J. Ceresney, who was Ms. White’s lieutenant as both a defense lawyer and as a federal prosecutor in Manhattan, is a top contender to become her head of enforcement at the S.E.C., DealBook’s Peter Lattman and Ben Protess report. “A Washington outsider and relative unknown beyond legal circles, Mr. Ceresney would help set the tone for policing financial fraud, effectively making him a top cop on Wall Street. He could join as soon as spring, potentially serving as co-chief with the agency’s acting head of enforcement, the people briefed on the matter said.”

headline: Opinion Report: School Breakfast
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: The Heavy Mantle of Holly Golightly
abstract: Emilia Clarke of “Game of Thrones” wears the mantle of Holly Golightly in the new stage production of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.”
lead_paragraph: Hovering about Richard Greenberg’s new stage adaptation of Truman Capote’s “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” like a beloved, chatty relative who doesn’t know when it’s time to go home is the memory of Audrey Hepburn as Holly Golightly in the 1961 movie. When the lights go down at the Cort Theater, where the show began previews on Monday, you expect her to sweep in any second, tall and swanlike, wearing her sunglasses and little black Givenchy dress and waving that ridiculous, yardlong cigarette holder.

headline: Sanjay Gupta to Join Health Web Site
abstract: EverydayHealth.com will announce on Thursday that Dr. Sanjay Gupta, the chief medical correspondent for CNN and a contributor to “60 Minutes,” will join the site.
lead_paragraph: EverydayHealth.com is adding a familiar face to its roster of medical contributors. On Thursday, the company will announce that Dr. Sanjay Gupta, the chief medical correspondent for CNN and a contributor to “60 Minutes,” will join the site.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Have a Growing Stake in Dell, and No Appetite for a Buyout
abstract: Carl C. Icahn is poised to announce his opposition to Dell’s proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, is poised to announce his opposition to Dell’s proposed $24.4 billion sale to its founder, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, Michael J. de la Merced writes in The New York Times. Read more »

headline: European Central Bank Leaves Key Rate Unchanged
abstract: In leaving the benchmark interest rate at 0.75 percent, the central bank chose not to react to political instability in Italy and rising inflation.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The president of the European Central Bank on Thursday played down risks reverberating from his native Italy, evading questions about what policy makers might do if the country’s chaotic politics become a threat to euro zone stability.

headline: Deep Thoughts on the Bus
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: What is it about riding the bus that makes some of us wax philosophical?
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In Letter, Icahn Pledges to Fight Dell Over Sale
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: A special committee of Dell’s board disclosed on Thursday that it had received a letter from Carl C. Icahn, who hinted at “years of litigation” if the company did not back away from its $24.4 billion sale to its founder.
lead_paragraph: A special committee of Dell’s board disclosed on Thursday that it had received a letter from Carl C. Icahn, who hinted at “years of litigation” if Dell did not back away from its $24.4 billion deal to sell the company to its founder.

headline: Thursday Reading: Apps That Help With a Breakup
abstract: Apps that help with a breakup, the benefits of working in the office, a new Web portal for gays traveling abroad and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Solar Eclipse
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources']
abstract: There is no issue more sensitive for the average Egyptian than the availability and price of diesel fuel.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian pound is weakening at an alarming rate. Hard currency reserves are dwindling. Unemployment is up; investment is down. Imports are being restricted, and banks are no longer giving out loans. The list of worrisome indicators goes on, but there is no word that better encapsulates the severity of Egypt’s economic situation than “solar.”

headline: Citywide Festival to Celebrate García Lorca’s Years in New York
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The events will celebrate the Spanish poet Federico García Lorca, who lived in New York City in 1929 and 1930.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish writer Federico García Lorca, who lived in New York in 1929 and 1930, and wrote about the experience in a book of verse, “Poet in New York,” will be the subject of a citywide festival anchored by an exhibition this spring.

headline: The Multi-Tasker
abstract: The new FEED function bag, a messenger-like iteration on the brand’s familiar burlap theme, is being promoted with photos taken by Lauren Bush Lauren herself.
lead_paragraph: In her brief tenure on earth, 28-year-old Lauren Bush Lauren has already occupied many roles in the public sphere: presidential niece, model, wife of David Lauren, fashion designer, social entrepreneur, philanthropist — and now, photographer. Her latest venture with FEED Projects — her six-year-old company that sells utilitarian-chic, grain-sack-inspired bags and donates school meals to the world’s hungry children with each sale — is the FEED function bag, available now on the company’s Web site. It’s a messenger-like iteration of FEED’s familiar burlap theme, with a detachable shoulder strap, a faux suede bottom and an interior outfitted with pockets for today’s many gadgets. To promote it, Bush Lauren, who minored in photography in college, has shot portraits of a smattering of her many creative (and busy) friends, among them the photographer Henry Hargreaves (above), the Town and Country editor Amanda Hearst and Lehmann Maupin’s Carla Camacho, all pictured carrying the bag. “We wanted to show real people that I am inspired by, and how they function,” Bush Lauren says of the project, which can be viewed on FEED’s Web site. “Instead of hiring a photographer, I thought: I would love to do this.”

headline: European Regulators Fine Microsoft, and Then Promise to Do Better
abstract: The European Union fined Microsoft $732 million on Wednesday for failing to respect an antitrust settlement with regulators, but in a highly unusual admission, the union’s top antitrust regulator said his department bore some responsibility for situation that led to the fine.
lead_paragraph: The European Union fined Microsoft $732 million on Wednesday for failing to respect an antitrust settlement with regulators. But in a highly unusual mea culpa, the European Union’s top antitrust regulator said his department bore some responsibility for Microsoft’s failure to respect a settlement that caused the fine, James Kanter writes in The New York Times. Read more. »

headline: Obama Continues Congressional Outreach With White House Lunch
abstract: President Obama will have a bipartisan lunch on Thursday with Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, and the panel’s senior Democrat, Representative Chris Van Hollen.
lead_paragraph: Following on his unusual dinner on Wednesday with a dozen Republican senators, President Obama will have a bipartisan lunch on Thursday with Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, and the panel’s senior Democrat, Representative Chris Van Hollen.

headline: In Supreme Court Debate on Voting Rights Act, a Dubious Use of Statistics
abstract: In oral arguments before the Supreme Court last week, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. introduced a statistical claim that he took to imply that an important provision of the Voting Rights Act has become outmoded.
lead_paragraph: In oral arguments before the Supreme Court last week, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. introduced a statistical claim that he took to imply that an important provision of the Voting Rights Act has become outmoded.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Time Warner to Spin Off Time Inc., and Facebook’s New Look
abstract: Time Warner will spin off its magazine titles, Facebook will revamp its News Feed and Google executives try to bring advertisers into social media.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner announced Wednesday that it would spin off its Time Inc. magazine unit into a separate, publicly traded company, Amy Chozick writes. The announcement came hours after negotiations on a possible merger between Meredith Corporation and many Time Inc. titles fell through. The deal did not work out in part because of Time Inc.’s concern about flagship titles Time, Sports Illustrated, Fortune and Money, which Meredith had decided not to pursue. Time Warner found it made more economic sense to spin off all its titles rather than retain a few of them, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said. Time Inc. is the nation’s largest magazine publisher, and the breakdown in talks threw into sharp relief how once-glamorous magazines have become troubled assets.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘One Girl of Many’
abstract: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “One Girl of Many,” a poem by Charlotte Anna Perkins Gilman, with “Taking the High Road” by Abby Goodnough.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Women’s History Month, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “One Girl of Many,” a poem by Charlotte Anna Perkins Gilman, with “Taking the High Road” by Abby Goodnough.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Magazine: How to cope with the explosion in food allergies among children, many of whom react to several different foods? Some flummoxed families set out to bankroll the research themselves. – Patrick Farrell

headline: Hidden Talent
abstract: With his unconventional layouts and sensual use of materials, Ward Bennett attracted a clientele as rarefied as his designs. Meet the unsung hero of 1970s modernism.
lead_paragraph: The 1970s have always been a nebulous time for style, particularly interior design. An era — or was it a moment between two eras? — full of brazen promise at the beginning, but to which the harsh light of passing years has not always been kind. Especially when it comes to modernism. Picture conversation pits, exposed reel-to-reel stereo equipment or George Hamilton in a leather vest, shirtless. Of course, there are also the highlights, like Babe Paley in a caftan, or the town house rebuilt for Halston on 63rd Street by Paul Rudolph, snapshots of a moment whose fabulousness is undimmed.

headline: More Vehicles Earn Insurance Institute’s Top Safety Award
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Honda Civic is the first small car to earn the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s new Top Safety Pick+ award based on their performance in the new small overlap frontal crash test.
lead_paragraph: The Honda Civic two-door and four-door models are the first small cars to earn the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s new Top Safety Pick+ award based on their performance in the new small overlap frontal crash test.

headline: Subscribing to Office, Now and Forever
abstract: This year with Microsoft Office, it is not what the features are, but how you pay for them. There are two ways to subscribe.
lead_paragraph: This year with Microsoft Office, it is not what the features are, but how you pay for them. There are two ways to subscribe, David Pogue writes in The New York Times. Read more. »

headline: Sycamore Partners to Buy Hot Topic for $600 Million
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']
