lead_paragraph: The clothing retailer Hot Topic, a mainstay of teenage mall shoppers, has rung up a big sale – to a private equity firm.

headline: After the Caregiving Ends
abstract: Is there life after caregiving, and if so what it is like?
lead_paragraph: In January, the 93-year-old mother of my oldest friend died in a Chicago suburb. Suzy was exceptionally close to her mother, and had long dreaded saying a final goodbye. But when it came time to do so — after a year in which her mother struggled with illness and increasing disability — my friend was surprisingly at peace.

headline: Challenges for Brennan
abstract: The Times's Scott Shane says a classified report poses risks for John O. Brennan, the nominee to lead the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Scott Shane says a classified report poses risks for John O. Brennan, the nominee to lead the C.I.A.

headline: Last Stop, Adulthood, the Bronx
abstract: Michel Gondry’s film “The We and the I” captures the chaos, glee and heartache of the last day of school for a group of boisterous South Bronx high school students.
lead_paragraph: Any adult who has ridden public transportation in New York around 3 o’clock on a weekday afternoon will find the opening scenes of “The We and the I” familiar, perhaps dismayingly so. At certain stops the bus or subway car will suddenly be flooded with adolescents releasing their pent-up energies in a confined space. Their loudness, their rudeness, the lack of consideration they display as they flirt, fight, tease and shout can be overwhelming, and can cause even tolerant old-timers to think grouchy thoughts. What’s the matter with kids these days?

headline: The Bilious Robert Bork
abstract: His new, posthumous memoir sheds light on the Saturday Night Massacre.
lead_paragraph: The late Robert Bork became infamous long before the Senate rejected his nomination for the Supreme Court in 1987. Fourteen years before, to be exact, when President Richard Nixon ordered Mr. Bork to fire the Watergate Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox, and Mr. Bork complied—the so-called Saturday Night Massacre.

headline: IFC Orders New Comedy Shows from Will Ferrell, Ben Stiller and Bob Odenkirk
abstract: The two new comedy shows, “The Spoils of Babylon,” a comedy serial produced by Will Ferrell and Adam McKay, and “The Birthday Boys,” a variety show produced by Ben Stiller and Bob Odenkirk, would make their debuts on IFC this year.
lead_paragraph: Will Ferrell, Adam McKay, Ben Stiller and Bob Odenkirk aren’t just the stars and producers of comedy films and television series that will live in perpetuity on DVD players, DVRs and cable-TV programming lineups. They’re also among the creative talent responsible for two new comedy series that IFC said Thursday it had picked up.

headline: Goldman Hires a Top Executive in Asia
abstract: Goldman Sachs has lured away Kate Richdale, Morgan Stanley’s chief of investment banking in Asia, to be Goldman’s head of investment banking services for Asia, excluding Japan.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has lured away Morgan Stanley’s chief of investment banking in Asia.

headline: The Gun Report: March 7, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: You read the items in today’s gun report, and you know what your first thought is? Thank goodness no children died. But rare is the day when no children are shot. Today we have two examples – a 16-year-old shot near a high school in Northern California and a 5-year-old boy shot in the knee while leaving a daycare center. In both cases, you wonder about the lingering aftereffects, both physically and emotionally.

headline: ’Hawks, Heat and Streaks
abstract: There is a lot of talk about a lot of victories in the N.H.L. and N.B.A. (and a lot of points by the Lakers).
lead_paragraph: Midway through the N.H.L. season and roughly midway through the N.B.A. slog, we have been greeted with a full blast of streak mania, conveniently being played out on a hype machine near you. Having the Chicago Blackhawks on a 24-game points streak and the Miami Heat on a 16-game winning streak at the same time is wonderfully easy fodder for the screaming TV types who can mindlessly compare the two, ad nauseam. It is also cause for the conga line that has formed in the N.H.L. offices, which cannot believe its good fortune to be mentioned in the same sentence as the N.B.A. Lockout? What lockout? What concussion epidemic? How ‘bout them ‘Hawks!!

headline: A Communications Scholar Analyzes Bill McKibben’s Path on Climate
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Endowments', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A long, deep look at the strategy and tactics of Bill McKibben, the ultramarathoner of climate campaigners.
lead_paragraph: Bill McKibben and I have been on parallel but very different journeys related to human-driven global warming since the greenhouse effect first became front-page news back in the late 1980s (examples here and here). (Our video chat above was done in December for my Pace University blogging class.)

headline: School Socket Syndrome
abstract: Kenya’s election was supposed to be the most modern in Africa. But almost everything that could go wrong did.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI — I’m thinking of calling it School Socket Syndrome. That’s my term for the screech heard when modern technology is suddenly grafted onto a developing state’s crumbling infrastructure.

headline: A Night at the Bates Motel
abstract: The Times reporter Neil Genzlinger spends a night on the set of A&E’s “Bates Motel,” a TV series that is a prequel to Hitchcock’s “Psycho.” He even takes a shower.
lead_paragraph: The Times reporter Neil Genzlinger spends a night on the set of A&E’s “Bates Motel,” a TV series that is a prequel to Hitchcock’s “Psycho.” He even takes a shower.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Lewis Lapham and Harmony Korine
abstract: The founder of Lapham’s Quarterly and the rapscallion filmmaker sound off on Norman Foster’s controversial redesign for the New York Public Library, Jimmy Choo leather sandals and artisanal bacon mayonnaise.
lead_paragraph: A dual review of what’s new: the legendary editor and founder of Lapham’s Quarterly, left, and the rapscallion filmmaker sound off on Norman Foster’s controversial $300-million-plus redesign for the New York Public Library’s main branch, Jimmy Choo leather sandals and artisanal bacon mayonnaise.

headline: Marilynne Robinson: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Gilead” says that after “Housekeeping,” her greatest fear was writing “a fraudulent book simply to escape the embarrassments of having written only one novel.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Gilead” and “When I Was a Child I Read Books” says that after “Housekeeping,” her greatest fear was writing “a fraudulent book simply to escape the embarrassments of having written only one novel.”

headline: Top Rebounder Nears End of College Career
abstract: O.D. Anosike, last season’s national rebounding leader, discusses his career at Siena and what the future might hold for him in a question-and-answer session.
lead_paragraph: Last season, Siena’s O. D. Anosike won the national rebounding crown, and this season, as his team limps into the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament with a 7-23 record, he is locked in a tight battle with Colorado’s Andre Roberson to defend that title.

headline: Peacock Alley, a Bar that Lives Up to  Its Name and Setting
abstract: Two bars at the Waldorf-Astoria:  Peacock Alley, which is  festive, and the Bull and Bear, a little less so.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, a cocktail bar in a landmark hotel really can be as impressive as its setting, and Peacock Alley at the Waldorf-Astoria is, happily, one of them.

headline: High Stakes for 2 Royal Ballet Premieres
abstract: Expectations were soaring for two new pieces from the choreographers Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon at the Royal Ballet. But after the premiere, the reviews were, for the most part, far from sky high.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon are, with reason, frequently referred to as the most important ballet choreographers working today. A new ballet by either is reason for excitement, so it was quite a coup for the Royal Ballet — and a shot in the arm for the company’s new director, Kevin O’Hare — when the company announced last year that two commissions were in the bag, on a single program.

headline: Workers’ Share of Health Costs Is Likely to Continue Rising
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Employers are shifting more of the cost of health care to workers.
lead_paragraph: Workers are paying a greater share of their health care costs, and that trend is likely to continue over the next several years, a new report on employer-based health plans finds.

headline: This Is My Brain on Kickstarter
abstract: Kickstarter is successful and popular. You know that. I want to talk about what it has done to my brain, and may soon do to yours: Kickstarter is turning me into an investor.
lead_paragraph: These days, Kickstarter is close to a household name, raising nearly $500 million for books, movies, podcasts, design objects, food items and anything else someone might come up with. I just helped a coffee shop in Oakland buy a roaster. I helped Ze Frank bring back his transcendent video show. I backed my favorite menswear video series and blog. I backed an animation made of engraved wooden tiles. And yes, I backed the Pebble.

headline: Creighton Star Seeking a Bigger Stage
abstract: Doug McDermott, a two-time Missouri Valley Conference player of the year, could be a dynamic player in the N.C.A.A. tournament, but first Creighton has to get there.
lead_paragraph: The moves. The smoothness. The deadeye release. Even on television, almost everything that Doug McDermott of Creighton used to score 41 points against Wichita State on Saturday appeared so familiar to Ed Schilling that he had to smile.

headline: The Terror Loophole
abstract: Why are people on the F.B.I.’s terrorist watch list legally entitled to buy guns?
lead_paragraph: The law that requires background checks on gun buyers is full of loopholes, some big and some small, but the most egregious loophole of all may be the fact that people on the F.B.I.’s terrorist watch list are legally entitled to buy firearms and explosives. And they have been doing so at an alarming rate. Between February 2004 and December 2010, individuals whose names turned up on the list were cleared to purchase firearms or explosives a total of 1,321 times, according to the General Accounting Office. Felons, illegal immigrants and mentally ill applicants are barred on the obvious grounds that they could present a heightened risk of violence. Not so, terrorist suspects — an anomaly that congress has occasionally tsk-tsked over since the 9/11 atrocities, but done nothing substantial to repair.Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, has reintroduced a worthy measure to close this “terror gap”— eight years after his initial attempt failed. It would give the Attorney General authority to stop a firearm or explosive sale when a background check reveals the buyer is a known or suspected terrorist who the Attorney General reasonably believes may be planning mayhem. The National Rifle Association opposed the measure in the past because the terrorist watch list has been shown to contain errors. That’s hardly a justification for extending carte blanche to terrorist suspects. Besides, the Lautenberg bill includes written guidelines and due process safeguards that would permit individuals to challenge denials. There’s really no good reason for inaction, unless of course fear of the gun lobby counts as an excuse.

headline: Living With Cancer: For the Birds
abstract: At times, I have to admit, there is absolutely no response to my cancer that seems acceptable to me, probably because the cancer isn’t.
lead_paragraph: “There’s nothing makes us feel so much alive as to see others die,” exclaims a dying Ralph Touchett in Henry James’s “Portrait of a Lady.” At my most snarky, it seems to me that there’s nothing makes some people so invigorated as to see others debilitated by cancer or by medical responses to it. To my beloved friends, I hiss what must be tedious recriminations against off-the-wall reactions to my continuing treatments. But here I’ll simply wing it.

headline: Video of Captive U.N. Peacekeepers in Syria
abstract: Syrian rebels released video on Thursday showing six of the 21 Filipino United Nations peacekeepers they abducted the day before in the Golan Heights.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 8:19 p.m. One day after Syrian rebels seized 21 United Nations peacekeepers from the Philippines in the Golan Heights, a part of Syria held by Israel since the 1967 war, all of the captives appeared in a series of video clips released by an opposition group.

headline: I.B.M.’s Rometty on the Data Challenge to the Culture of Management
abstract: Virginia Rometty, the chief executive of I.B.M., is delivering a speech on Thursday evening at the Council on Foreign Relations that addresses the management challenges posed by the spread of Big Data technologies. Her speech comes five years after her predecessor, Samuel Palmisano, used the same setting to sketch out the benefits to business and society of exploiting advances in computer intelligence. That concept became I.B.M.’s successful Smarter Planet campaign.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Samuel J. Palmisano, then chief executive of I.B.M., gave a speech at the Council on Foreign Relations on the big opportunity ahead for modern computing technology to help businesses, government agencies and other institutions operate more intelligently. His remarks captured an emerging trend that opened the way to a large, lucrative business for I.B.M.

headline: Staying Sane in Small Spaces
abstract: The only way to survive in the confines of New York: compromise.
lead_paragraph: I was born and grew up in the late ’80s in a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side. In New York, apartments can be appealing for three reasons: size, location and cost. You hope to score in one of these categories. Sometimes you’re lucky enough to find a place with two. Three is unimaginable.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Louis Vuitton
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: To Place Graduates, Law Schools Are Opening Firms
abstract: Efforts like creating school-run law firms are trying to address the glut of heavily indebted graduates with no clients and a vast number of Americans unable to afford a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — When Douglas J. Sylvester, dean of the law school at Arizona State University, was visiting the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota a couple of years ago he mentioned the shifting job market for his students — far fewer offers and a new demand for graduates already able to draft documents and interact with clients.

headline: Comparing Hybrid and Electric Vehicles
Thousands Line Up for Last Glimpse of Chávez
abstract: People waited for hours to pay their respects to the late president of Venezuela, Hugo Chávez, as conflicting accounts of his final days began to emerge.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Thousands of people waited for hours on Thursday to pay a moment of respect to the body of the late president of Venezuela, Hugo Chávez, dressed in his iconic red beret and green military uniform, visible to his people one last time.

headline: Tennis Strengthens Testing for Drugs
abstract: The International Tennis Federation said that it would use the biological passport program and increase testing on both the men’s and women’s tours.
lead_paragraph: The International Tennis Federation announced Thursday that it would stiffen the sport’s drug testing this year by adopting the biological passport program, which tracks an athlete’s blood profile over time, and increasing the number of blood tests and out-of-competition tests.

headline: American Ballet Theater
abstract: Images from the company's opening night at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: Images from the company's opening night at New York City Center.

headline: Opening Night at American Ballet Theater
abstract: American Ballet Theater opened its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater opened its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Merck Replaces Its Research Chief
abstract: Dr. Roger M. Perlmutter, the former research head of Amgen, will replace Peter S. Kim, who is retiring after a number of successes and some recent disappointments.
lead_paragraph: Merck announced on Thursday that it was replacing its head of research with the retired research chief at Amgen, a leadership shake-up that follows several major setbacks in Merck’s drug development pipeline.

headline: Elizabeth Olsen to Star in ‘Romeo and Juliet’ at Classic Stage Company
abstract: The actress will star in a production set to open the theater’s 2013-14 seasion.
lead_paragraph: The twins Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen have found success after transitioning from TV sitcom tots on “Full House” to major design darlings with their own fashion house. Now it’s time for their sister Elizabeth Olsen to make a high-profile career switcheroo: the Classic Stage Company announced on Thursday that the actress will star in a production of “Romeo and Juliet” that will open the company’s 2013-14 season this fall. Additional casting, a creative team and run dates are to be announced.

headline: ‘Straw Purchases’ Gun Law Is Approved by Senate Panel
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee passed a bill that would make it a felony to illegally buy a gun for someone else.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved a measure that would make the practice of illegally buying a gun for someone else a felony, and increase penalties for the crime.

headline: The Civil War’s War on Fraud
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Defense Contracts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Government Procurement', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Confederacy wasn’t the only enemy of the Union Army. Rampant fraud was a threat, too.
lead_paragraph: Popular memory holds that among the many differences between Billy Yank and Johnny Reb were the clothes on their back. Union soldiers, we are told, had more and better everything, while rebels had to scrounge for uniforms, weapons and even shoes. But especially in the early years of the Civil War, this was more an impression than reality. Union supplies were poor and in short supply, thanks to unimaginable levels of fraud.

headline: Safety Board Gives New Details on Boeing Battery Fire, but Not Cause
abstract: In a safety board report, witnesses tell of intense smoke, acrid smells and a white glow from a battery that caught fire on a Boeing airliner parked at Boston’s airport two months ago.
lead_paragraph: The first hint of trouble came just minutes after passengers and crew left the Boeing 787 jet that had just landed at Logan International Airport in Boston. A cleaning worker noticed “an electrical burning smell and smoke” in the back of the cabin. Other managers reported smoke that was “intense” and “caustic smelling.”

headline: Daylight Time Does Begin on Sunday, Despite the Local Law
abstract: New Yorkers who know the city’s administrative code may be under the impression that daylight saving time begins in April.
lead_paragraph: When the rest of America springs forward Sunday morning, there might be some New Yorkers under the impression that they can doze for an extra hour and presumably still legally comply with court deadlines or other official proceedings.

headline: Journalism in 8-Minute Chunks: A Back-and-Forth on ‘House of Cards’
abstract: Recapping the fifth episode of “House of Cards”: Zoe Barnes joins Slugline, Frank Underwood joins Ms. Barnes, while his spouse considers the upside.
lead_paragraph: Every couple of days, Ashley Parker and David Carr kick around an episode of “House of Cards.” We are now deep in the story and deconstruct, but if you want to catch up with past chats, you can find episode one, two,three or four in the archives. But be warned that there is a thicket of spoilers there, and in the discussion that follows.

headline: Fine Dining Gets the Dim-Sum Treatment (Finally)
abstract: Putting the cart before the main course at State Bird Provisions.
lead_paragraph: I first ate dim sum in 1968 at Nom Wah, on Doyers Street in New York’s Chinatown. (The place is still there.) The appeal of the service style was immediate and tremendous — why couldn’t every meal be an uninterrupted stream of small, exotic dishes brought to you on a gleaming (or at least functional) cart? I’m quite sure that I said, either on that visit or one of the frequent ones that followed, “Someone needs to do this with non-Chinese food.”

headline: For Gulbis, a Fast Climb After a Steep Fall
abstract: Ernests Gulbis discusses his fall from the top 130 men’s tennis players last year and his climb to No. 67 this year.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Ernests Gulbis has often seemed pretty far gone, but now he seems to be on his way back.

headline: That Man, Before the Curtain, and Before Dorothy, Too
abstract: “Oz the Great and Powerful,” starring James Franco and Michelle Williams, is Disney’s prequel to the original story.
lead_paragraph: Can the major studios still make magic? From the looks of “Oz the Great and Powerful,” a dispiriting, infuriating jumble of big money, small ideas and ugly visuals, the answer seems to be no — unless, perhaps, the man behind the curtain is Martin Scorsese or James Cameron. The Walt Disney Company is the studio lurking behind “Oz,” and, as usual, it is banking that it can leverage this 3-D prehistory of the Wizard of Oz (James Franco) for its wonderful world of cross-promotional marketing and ancillary revenue streams. With so much riding on this “Oz” it’s a surprise that the results are so uninspired — or given Disney’s recent run with the likes of “Alice in Wonderland,” maybe not.

headline: A New Season in Chinese Super League
abstract: The new season in the Chinese Super League begins on Friday highlighted by the departure and arrival of new players from abroad.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — With the arrival of Nicolas Anelka and Didier Drogba at Shanghai Shenhua last season, the international news media hailed the Chinese Super League as one to watch and talked of a shift in the global goalposts. It is not surprising then that the departure of the two players has led to the lifting of that particular label.

headline: For Icahn, a Game of Chicken With Dell’s Board
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: With his two alternatives to the proposed buyout of Dell, Carl C. Icahn is hoping to make the computer maker’s board blink first.
lead_paragraph: Let’s face it, our lives would be much less interesting without Carl C. Icahn, whom I have previously referred to as a genius version of Wile E. Coyote.

headline: Apple’s Internet Radio Service Said to Be Delayed
abstract: The company’s efforts to create an Internet radio service to compete with Pandora has been delayed by licensing negotiations with music companies, according to a number of people briefed on the talks.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s efforts to create an Internet radio service to compete with Pandora has been delayed by licensing negotiations with music companies, according to a number of people briefed on the talks.

headline: John Brennan and the Classified C.I.A. Torture Report
abstract: How will the likely next C.I.A. chief handle what is “by far the most thorough examination of how the United States came to use nudity, cold, sleep deprivation, stress positions, wall-slamming and waterboarding, methods it had long condemned as abuse or torture”?
lead_paragraph: A 6,000-page Congressional report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s use of so-called enhanced interrogation techniques is “by far the most thorough examination of how the United States came to use nudity, cold, sleep deprivation, stress positions, wall-slamming and waterboarding, methods it had long condemned as abuse or torture,” reports Scott Shane, a national security correspondent.

headline: Bold Threats From North Korea
abstract: The Times’s David E. Sanger on North Korea’s nuclear strike warnings as it faces a new round of sanctions.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David E. Sanger on North Korea’s nuclear strike warnings as it faces a new round of sanctions.

headline: The Artist as Curator
abstract: Danh Vo cleverly assembles the personal effects of Robert McNamara, the former secretary of defense, for his new show at Marian Goodman Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Born in Vietnam and raised in Denmark, the conceptualist Danh Vo’s rapid rise in the art world can be attributed to his incisive and enigmatic style. His most famous work to date involved “building” a to-scale model of the Statue of Liberty: the hundreds of discrete chunks were never actually assembled into a whole; instead they were scattered around the globe to represent the reach of democracy and American imperialism. Last year, Vo won the Guggenheim’s prestigious Hugo Boss Prize, a biennial award that comes with a solo show at the museum. Continuing his exploration of identity and heritage, Vo has filled his show, which opens on March 15, with artwork, kitschy Americana (above right) and Oriental knickknacks that belonged to the late painter Martin Wong. “I consider it a kind of collaboration,” he says. “And I don’t have any problems collaborating with dead people.”

headline: On the Ground on Time
abstract: Alaska Airlines, AirTran Airways and US Airways were the most punctual North American carriers last year, says a company that tracks air travel.
lead_paragraph: FlightStats, a company that tracks air travel, released its annual On-time Performance Service awards for 2012. Alaska Airlines, AirTran Airways and US Airways were the top North American carriers last year; Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways and Scandinavian Airlines were the top three international ones. The rankings were based on the percentage of the carriers’ flights that arrived within 15 minutes of their scheduled time.

headline: Myanmar Reforms Could Falter, U.N. Investigator Says
abstract: Shortcomings continue particularly in discrimination against the Muslim Rohingya minority and abuses in northern Kachin State, the investigator said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Political reforms that are delivering greater freedom in Myanmar could falter if the authorities do not tackle some conspicuous failings, including continuing torture in prisons and discrimination against ethnic minorities, a United Nations investigator said in a report released on Thursday.

headline: Bushifying the Berlaymont
abstract: The officials are not the continent.
lead_paragraph: Busy day today, so no blogging until late. But a quick thought in passing: reading what the three tweeters of Brussels had to say, it struck me that they have a habit of mind that, to my mind, is more disturbing than a bit of incivility here and there. In fact, they sound remarkably like George W. Bush.

headline: Excerpt: 'Katie Roche'
abstract: Jon Fletcher and Wrenn Schmidt in the Mint Theater’s revival of Teresa Deevy’s 1936 play.
lead_paragraph: Jon Fletcher and Wrenn Schmidt in the Mint Theater’s revival of Teresa Deevy’s 1936 play.

headline: Sculpture, Transformed
abstract: Anish Kapoor’s pieces dispense multiple visual thrills and mysteries, as seen at a well-chosen survey at the Institute of Contemporary Art and at the Gladstone Gallery. Roberta Smith reviews.
lead_paragraph: Anish Kapoor’s pieces dispense multiple visual thrills and mysteries, as seen at a well-chosen survey at the Institute of Contemporary Art and at the Gladstone Gallery. Roberta Smith reviews.

headline: An Original’s Original
abstract: A look at the work of the artist Neil Jenney.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of the artist Neil Jenney.

headline: Mayfield
abstract: Inside the Crown Heights restaurant whose name is a hat tip to Curtis Mayfield, the soul singer and civil rights advocate.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Crown Heights restaurant whose name is a hat tip to Curtis Mayfield, the soul singer and civil rights advocate.

headline: An Artist Reluctant to Sell Himself
abstract: The artist Neil Jenney, long under the art world’s radar, is the subject of a new show, “Works of the Jenney Archive,” at Gagosian’s Madison Avenue gallery.
lead_paragraph: The art world has always laid claim to its share of oddballs and mavericks, including those who pose as such. True-blue originals, however — people who follow their own lights, make their own rules and essentially create their own frame of reference — are as rare in this context as any other. One of the few contemporary artists in this latter category, for better and worse, is Neil Jenney.

headline: An Odd Shift in an Unemployment Curve
abstract: Why is the job vacancy rate relatively high, when there are so many jobless workers out there?
lead_paragraph: In an article on Thursday’s front page, I wrote about how long job vacancies are taking to fill, especially when you consider the abundance of unemployed workers.

headline: Government Takes Legal Action Over Phone Spam
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Smartphones', 'Spam (Electronic)']
abstract: In eight federal civil cases, the Federal Trade Commission named 29 individuals, most of whom worked for companies that were hired to send the unsolicited text messages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had recently filed eight lawsuits in federal courts around the country against companies it accused of ordering or engineering the sending of hundreds of millions of spam text messages to mobile phone users.

headline: A Senator’s Stand on Drones Scrambles Partisan Lines
abstract: Senator Rand Paul’s filibuster won praise from the Tea Party movement and civil-liberties-minded liberals, but two prominent fellow Republicans accused him of scaremongering.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul’s intention was to highlight his misgivings about how drones are used. He ended up enmeshing his fellow Republicans in a broader debate over national security that scrambled the politics of left and right.

headline: A Hit in Seattle, ‘First Date’ Coming to Broadway
abstract: The musical tale of a mismatched couple on a blind date will open at the Longacre Theater in late summer.
lead_paragraph: It was probably only a matter of time before the high-tech side of dating – Google background checks and fake emergency cellphone calls – would find its way onto the Broadway stage. The technological aspects of romance will be part of the fabric of “First Date,” a new musical that will open at the Longacre Theater on Aug. 4, with previews starting on July 9.

headline: Interior Dept. Nominee Is Questioned on Public Land Use
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Federal Lands', 'Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Natural Gas', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Sally Jewell, the chief executive of R.E.I., told senators that she believes that climate change is real but was noncommittal on other subjects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sally Jewell, President Obama’s nominee for interior secretary, deflected many of the questions she faced at her confirmation hearing Thursday but made clear she supports expanded oil and gas development on public lands and waters, including exploratory drilling off the North Slope of Alaska and seismic testing in the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Do You Really Have to Go to College?
abstract: Dale J. Stephens, an author and vocal proponent of self-directed learning, challenges the notion that college is the only way to become successful.
lead_paragraph: As high school seniors await thick envelopes and weigh their options, one young man is making the case for another college choice: None of the above.

headline: Grassroots, Big Money
abstract: A pro-Obama advocacy group won’t accept corporate contributions, but will accept unlimited donations from individuals.
lead_paragraph: Organizing for Action, the pro-Obama advocacy group spun off from the president’s campaign machine, announced an important change today: It will not accept corporate contributions.

headline: Seeking the Soul of a Namesake
abstract: Mayfield, which opened in October in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, is broadly American in mission, with an occasional Southern twang.
lead_paragraph: It is a dish that unfolds in panorama: on one end, a bowl of smoky collards, the leaves sweated until just soft, with hunks of bacon waiting to be flushed out of the undergrowth; then spoonbread, made with white cornmeal and given breath by whipped egg whites so it has the body of a soufflé and the heart of a pudding; and, last, quail, brined, soaked in buttermilk and dredged in flour and Old Bay seasoning, its dainty legs under ruffles of crisp skin.

headline: Facebook Shows Off New Home Page Design, Including Bigger Pictures
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg described the social network’s new look for its News Feed as a “personalized newspaper” that allows users to choose the topics they’re most interested in.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Hoping to tame the blizzard of information that has turned off many users and discouraged some advertisers, Facebook on Thursday unveiled a major makeover of the home page that greets users when they log into the site.

headline: Wines of The Times: Malbecs From Argentina
abstract: In a tasting of 25 malbecs that cost $25 or less, the panel found wines that showed liveliness and structure — and as the American dollar weakens abroad, wines that are good values.

abstract: New research has found that caffeine-laced nectar enhances the learning process for bees, so that they are more likely to return to those flowers.
lead_paragraph: Nothing kicks the brain into gear like a jolt of caffeine. For bees, that is.

headline: Scientists Find an Abrupt Warm Jog After a Very Long Cooling
abstract: An exploration of new work putting abrupt recent warming in long-term context.
lead_paragraph: March 31, 11:55 p.m. | Fresh updates below |There’s long been a general picture of the climate of the Holocene, the period of Earth history since the last ice age ended around 12,000 years ago. It goes like this: After a sharp stuttery warm-up following that big chill — to temperatures warmer than today — the climate cools, with the decline reaching bottom around 200 years ago in the period widely called the “little ice age.” (A graph produced by Robert Rohde for his Global Warming Art Web site years ago nicely captures the general picture.)

lead_paragraph: A recent speech by Daniel Libeskind has reanimated a debate among architects over the ethics of working in countries with repressive leaders or shaky records on human rights.

headline: Two Looks at Danny Lyon’s ‘Bikeriders’ Photos
abstract: Two gallery exhibitions — one in Ohio and one in New York — showcase the photographs from Danny Lyon’s book “The Bikeriders.”
lead_paragraph: Half a century ago a young student who grew up in Queens, began photographing a motorcycle gang in Chicago. The student, Danny Lyon, assembled the black-and-white images he took from 1963 to 1967 into a book, “The Bikeriders,” that became a touchstone of the 1960s. It helped inspire the vision of biker as outlaw hero in the 1969 film “Easy Rider.”

headline: Latinos Gain Political Muscle, and Fund-Raisers Show How
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: A new generation of Latino leaders — highly educated, sophisticated and rich — is tapping into Hispanics as a fund-raising pool to influence elections and policy.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — On a wall in his sun-drenched, art-filled Tudor home, Henry R. Muñoz III displays a memento of his childhood: a framed protest sign proclaiming, “Texas needs $1.25 an hour minimum wage.” He carried it when he was 6 years old while riding a burro during a farm workers’ march alongside his father, a labor organizer, and the Mexican-American activist Cesar Chavez.

lead_paragraph: While disappointed that none of the candidates have served in the military, Patrick Murray, a disabled veteran and student from Arlington, Va., says that his vote will come down to the economy.

headline: Your Rights in Dealing With Telemarketers
abstract: Even if your number isn’t on the Do Not Call Registry, you can tell a telemarketer to stop calling.
lead_paragraph: We have all had the urge to hurl the phone across the room when a telemarketer calls in the middle of dinner.

headline: Technology Turns to Tracking People Offline
abstract: New companies are coming up with ways to make smartphones into devices to monitor the foot traffic in stores or keep track of Alzheimer’s patients with the kind of technology used in house arrests. With the right incentives, people might even choose to be watched.
lead_paragraph: Following people online, with cookies, tagged pixels and even voluntarily given information, has been a big business. Now much of the same technology is moving into the physical world.

headline: This ‘Granny’ Can Dish It Out
abstract: Rock hunting goes awry in this debut thriller from Becky Masterman about a 59-year-old former undercover F.B.I. agent.
lead_paragraph: Becky Masterman’s pulse-quickening debut thriller, “Rage Against the Dying,” starts with the genre’s standard-issue opening scene — almost. That’s the prologue in which somebody is violently killed so that the rest of the book can revolve around making sense of the crime. The scene’s two characters seem pretty familiar too. There is the oily-haired Gerald Peasil, the kind of guy who once smacked his mother across the chest with a skillet. And there’s the little old white-haired lady spied by Gerald as she pokes along the Arizona desert with a walking stick, looking for interesting rocks.

headline: Predicting Avalanches
abstract: Mark Moore of the Northwest Weather and Avalanche Center in Washington discusses how to predict an unpredictable natural phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: Mark Moore of the Northwest Weather and Avalanche Center in Washington discusses how to predict an unpredictable natural phenomenon.

headline: Into Search Mode
abstract: Survivors of an avalanche recount the rescue.
lead_paragraph: Survivors of an avalanche recount the rescue.

headline: Wi-Fi for Every Room in the Home
abstract: When a Wi-Fi signal is weak, there is still hope. You can try a Wi-Fi range extender.
lead_paragraph: Wi-Fi is awesome. But when the Wi-Fi signal is weak, it’s almost worse than having no signal at all. You see signal-strength bars, but you can’t connect. Or videos play, but with a lot of pauses. Or your e-mail program tries to download messages, but just hangs there.

headline: Bin Laden Relative With Qaeda Past to Have New York Trial
abstract: A son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda will appear in court Friday to face terrorism charges that could bring a life sentence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Weeks after he was first arrested in Turkey, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda will appear in a New York courtroom on Friday to face terrorism charges that could result in life imprisonment.

headline: Richards to Miss Another Game, but Feels Better

lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. – Rangers center Brad Richards, hit from behind by Buffalo’s Patrick Kaleta four nights ago, said on Thursday that he is feeling better.

lead_paragraph: A Fiscal Cliff

headline: Film Festival Explores an Ugly Medical Chapter
abstract: A new film about researchers injecting active hepatitis virus into healthy children with mental disabilities explores a dark chapter of medical history.
lead_paragraph: A film festival dedicated to stories about people with disabilities kicks off this week in New York City. The event, called “ReelAbilities,” is mostly a celebration of people with different abilities, but one troubling new film explores a particularly dark chapter of medical history.

headline: Born-Again Virgins
abstract: The Virgins’ newest album will be released on Cult Records, which is run by Julian Casablancas of the Strokes.
lead_paragraph: It’s pretty neat to be the first act with an album out on a brand-new record label, but even more momentous when that label — in this case, Cult Records — is run by Julian Casablancas, of the Strokes. While lead singer Donald Cumming isn’t shying away from whatever halo effect that may cast on the Virgins‘ “Strike Gently,” which will be released March 12, mostly he’s excited to have the blessing of a fellow musician who understands both sides of the mixing board. “We all played the songs in the studio together,” Cumming said of the band. “You can really hear our instruments bleeding over each other.” The organic quality here lies in considerable contrast to the Virgins’ self-titled 2008 debut, whose rock ‘n’ roll was produced to within inches of bubble-gum pop on tracks like “Rich Girls” and “One Week of Danger.” Their new material is stripped down, a harmonic rumble of moonlight swagger and blue-rose tattoos. “I never aspired to hear someone sing my lyrics on ‘American Idol,'” Cumming explained. “I just wanted to make music that felt authentic to me.” Indeed, a lot has changed in the intervening five years: Cumming is the only original member left in the group; he’s married now, to the artist Aurel Schmidt; and he even taught himself to play the piano (think Schroeder from Peanuts, but with a Brechtian twist). “I don’t like to practice too much,” he admitted. “I like the discoveries I make to sound fresh.”

headline: City’s Jobless Rate in January Hit 4-Month High
abstract: The State Labor Department, in a new report, said the rate was 9.1 percent, up from 8.8 percent in December.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate rose back above 9 percent at the start of 2013, even though the city started the year with more jobs than it had ever had, according to reports released on Thursday.

Her dancers apply its principles to the daredevil antics — like running up walls and falling off trusses — for which they are renowned. (Last summer they bungee- jumped off the London Millennium Bridge to celebrate the Olympics.)

lead_paragraph: Edgar Allan Poe spent a few of his difficult final years in a modest white cottage in the Bronx, where he conjured haunting poems like “The Bells” and “Annabel Lee.”

lead_paragraph: Detractors of Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln” took the view that the film was a brief battle scene followed by more than two hours of erudite yet wearying political talk. Shakespeare’s “Henry IV, Part 1” might be seen as the reversal of that formula, a marathon of debate among royals, rebels and reprobates, culminating in a clash of swords and daggers. With fat jokes.

abstract: Shinique Smith, whose solo exhibition is at the James Cohan Gallery in Chelsea, is a collector of discarded things that find their way into her art.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Shinique Smith’s studio in Hudson, N.Y., learn not to leave stray articles of clothing lying around the clutter when Ms. Smith is working. Items might get swept up into multipatterned sculptures of castoff clothing bound with rope in monumental bales or cloudlike bundles dangling from the ceiling, or else collaged into exuberant paintings with calligraphic graffiti and colorful fields of pigment and fabric.

lead_paragraph: One of the best things about automated teller machines is that they accept cards from many different banks, a convenience not available to electric car owners plugging in at some fee-based public chargers. Public charging companies tend to develop their own billing networks, smart card access and other features, so an E.V. driver who is running on empty can be out of luck if the only available station is operated by an “out of network” provider.

Mr. Holder suggested, as a Financial Times headline put it this morning, that some banks are “too big to jail.”

headline: A Grand History of Mergers, Told in Magazines
abstract: From a single magazine, Time, a giant media conglomerate was built. With the planned spinoff, the dismantling of the empire is now nearly complete.
lead_paragraph: The brief history of Time Inc. is a truly epic M.&A. tale. The gold standard of American magazine publishing proved the foundation for a giant media conglomerate. Time Warner’s decision on Wednesday to spin off the legacy of Henry Luce’s 1920s vision represents the last step in dismantling the empire.

lead_paragraph: As a battle builds over the $24.4 billion buyout of the computer maker Dell Inc., an important date is drawing near.

headline: A Bolshoi Dancer Says He Condoned a Beating but Not an Acid Attack
abstract: The Bolshoi dancer Pavel Dmitrichenko says he condoned a beating but not an acid attack on the company’s artistic director.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Bolshoi Ballet soloist Pavel Dmitrichenko on Thursday tried to deflect blame for the January attack on Sergei Filin, the company’s artistic director. Mr. Dmitrichenko said he had agreed that an ex-convict acquaintance would “knock him around,” but that he was unaware that the man planned to douse Mr. Filin’s face with sulfuric acid, jeopardizing his eyesight.

headline: The Famous Mountain City of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico
abstract: Explore this lovely, lively town overflowing with shops, restaurants and churches.
lead_paragraph: Explore this lovely, lively town overflowing with shops, restaurants and churches.

headline: 36 Hours in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico
abstract: This beloved town north of Mexico City feels fresh again, with local restaurants and shops that cater to a younger generation.
lead_paragraph: San Miguel de Allende is almost 500 years old, and for more than 50 it’s been a beloved tourist destination. Nevertheless, it’s still possible for newness to wash over this famous Mexican mountain city of snaking cobblestone streets and colonial buildings in delectable fruit-bowl-meets-spice-rack colors (think mango and avocado next to paprika and turmeric). After a spell when some Americans hesitated to travel to their southern neighbor, San Miguel — a Unesco World Heritage site — feels fresh again, with rebooted energy from an influx of sophisticates far younger than the expatriate retirees traditionally associated with the town. Stores focus on regional designers and artists, and restaurants specialize in the locally grown — organic produce and livestock from surrounding farms that thrive year-round in the eternal spring climate at roughly 6,100 feet. Lovely as always and livelier than ever, it’s a new old San Miguel.

headline: Twenty Years Later
abstract: Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the notorious physical and symbolic barrier between East and West Germany, and Eastern and Western Europe, the photographer Anthony Suau returned to Berlin to again photograph history.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the notorious physical and symbolic barrier between East and West Germany, and Eastern and Western Europe, the photographer Anthony Suau returned to Berlin to again photograph history.

headline: Inquiry Into Officers After They Visit Man Who Accused Police of Assault

headline: Bar Shuffleboard: Beer, Yes; Sticks, No
abstract: Some bars around New York offer shuffleboard as an alternative to pool or darts.
lead_paragraph: IF you find yourself walking into the Whiskey Brooklyn in Williamsburg, ignore (for the moment) the 99 varieties of whiskey in the window that are sold by the adjoining liquor shop. Head down the stairs, past the three-sided bar and the raised D.J. booth. Disregard the sounds of robotic destruction emanating from the Terminator: Salvation video game and go to the back of the room. There you’ll find two 12-foot-long wooden shuffleboard tables, your ticket to a night of rousing social interaction and entertainment.

lead_paragraph: As Alan Gilbert explains it, the New York Philharmonic’s Bach Variations festival is a kind of reclamation effort. On a video introducing the project, Mr. Gilbert says that all performers have learned from the early-music and period-instrument movements. But one “weird phenomenon” has resulted: It is “pretty rare,” Mr. Gilbert says, for big orchestras using modern instruments to perform the major works of the Baroque repertory.

lead_paragraph: Some people are inherently more deserving of sympathy than others.

headline: Writhing in a Sea of Change
abstract: Its expressionist aesthetic intact, the Tero Saarinen Company returns to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Of the three troupes from Nordic lands visiting the Joyce Theater this week and next for the Ice Hot festival, the Tero Saarinen Company is the most familiar to New Yorkers. In recent years this Finnish choreographer’s group has graced the stages of the Joyce, Bard College and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Yet the aesthetic still feels arrestingly strange.

headline: A British Power Couple’s Long, Seamy Slide
abstract: Vicky Pryce, a top government economist, was found guilty Thursday of perverting justice, capping the collapse of the ambitions she and a leading Liberal Democrat,  Chris Huhne, shared.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For years, they were one of London’s most glittering couples: he a fast-rising politician with fashionably left-of-center views on social issues and a background in high finance that had yielded a multimillion-dollar fortune; she a top government economist, who once hinted to an interviewer that she had ambitions to be Britain’s first female chancellor of the Exchequer.

lead_paragraph: Banning smoking at charity bingo games may have health benefits, but it is proving harmful to earnings.

abstract: By allowing 101.7 points per 100 possession, second best in the Eastern Conference, the Bulls are contending for a top-four seed in the N.B.A. playoffs despite being without Derrick Rose.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Bulls were the model franchise of the 1990s, winning six N.B.A. championships in an eight-year span. But after Michael Jordan’s second retirement, following the 1997-98 season, the franchise sputtered.

headline: Imagining a Swap Meet for E-Books and Music
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Music']
abstract: The prospect of online stores that sell used e-books and digital music has heartened consumer advocates, but publishers and artists are worried.
lead_paragraph: The paperback of “Fifty Shades of Grey” is exactly like the digital version except for this: If you hate the paperback, you can give it away or resell it. If you hate the e-book, you’re stuck with it.

lead_paragraph: ROME — Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister and dominant political figure in Italy, was convicted and sentenced on Thursday to one year in prison for his role in the publication of a wiretapped conversation in a newspaper his family owns.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden and a former spokesman for Al Qaeda, was taken into American custody in Jordan and is facing numerous charges, including material support for terrorism.

headline: Yes, You Can
abstract: In “Lean In,” Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer of Facebook, encourages women to make their voices heard at the workplace.
lead_paragraph: When I was an assistant professor at the University of Chicago Law School in the early ’90s, I tried to explain to a prominent senior colleague why I had not yet managed to write one of the 10 or so articles required to get tenure in three years. He listened to me, then said, “Journals don’t publish excuses.”

lead_paragraph: Images from a new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.
