lead_paragraph: ALKMAAR, the Netherlands — Highs and lows come around all the time on the field of play. But man, what a roller coaster it has been over the past few games for me, my teammates and coaches at Alkmaar.

headline: Bob Knight:  A Look Back
abstract: Knight resigned as coach of Texas Tech. There was no hint that such a change was coming. He will be replaced by his son, Pat, a Red Raiders assistant.
lead_paragraph: Knight resigned as coach of Texas Tech. There was no hint that such a change was coming. He will be replaced by his son, Pat, a Red Raiders assistant.

headline: The American General Who Ruled Japan
abstract: In “Emperor,” Tommy Lee Jones plays Gen. Douglas MacArthur during the American occupation of Japan that followed World War II.
lead_paragraph: Aggrieved and exasperated: that is the signature expression of Tommy Lee Jones, a star who often conveys an attitude of terminal impatience, as if coping with the fools around him were almost more than he could bear. That gruff demeanor suits his character, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in “Emperor,” the British director Peter Webber’s stolid, simplified history lesson about the delicate relationship between the United States and Japan just after World War II.

headline: The Romanov Legacy Finds New Life
abstract: Commemorations of the Romanov dynasty’s 400th anniversary this year include exhibitions of imperial treasures and sales of family memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: The Soviets, as brutally and thoroughly as any foreign invader, looted the Romanov collections of art, jewelry, furniture and books. In the 1920s and ’30s aged Russian scholars and curators were forced to catalog treasures, so that foreigners could browse and buy them from the Communist government.

headline: Up Front
abstract: When The Atlantic published an article by Anne-Marie Slaughter with the title “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” the online response broke records for the magazine.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2012, when The Atlantic published an article by Anne-Marie Slaughter with the title “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” the online response broke records for the magazine. Slaughter had written about trying to juggle a senior position at the State Department while raising two sons; her frank admission of “how unexpectedly hard it was to do the kind of job I wanted to do as a high government official and be the kind of parent I wanted to be” made her both a figure and a flash point in a long-running conversation about working mothers.

headline: The Power of Faith, for Good and Ill
abstract: In “Beyond the Hills,” by the Romanian director Cristian Mungiu, a girl who visits her friend at an isolated rural convent is suspected of being possessed.
lead_paragraph: Cristian Mungiu’s “Beyond the Hills” is a tough and engrossing work of realism, set in rural Romania in the dead of winter, but it also has some of the shadowy magic of an ancient folk tale. At its heart are two orphan girls — one dark, one fair — whose destinies are entwined even as their paths in life have diverged. One of them has fallen under a malign and powerful spell, or maybe both of them have.

headline: The Spark Is Still There
abstract: As theme parties go, it was a spirited hoedown, guests miming the moves and the scintillant garb of their favorite performers, Prince and Michael Jackson.
lead_paragraph: As theme parties go, it was a spirited hoedown, guests miming the moves and the scintillant garb of their favorite performers, Prince, that living avatar of ’80s glam, and the pop legend Michael Jackson.

headline: A Camera Ravenous for Emotional Depth
abstract: The British photographer Bill Brandt, whose work is on view at MoMA, took pictures whose balance of art and humanity is frequently called strange, mysterious and irresistible.
lead_paragraph: The pre-eminent British photographer of the 20th century, Bill Brandt, took pictures whose balance of art and humanity is frequently called strange, mysterious and irresistible. The best induce us to pore over them, exploring their psychology as much as their form, their implied narratives as much as their brooding blacks or parsimonious whites, their connections to the history of art as much as their documentary realism. Brandt himself wrote in 1948 that he admired photography’s power to make people see the world anew, to experience it with “a sense of wonder.”

headline: Dehumanized Souls Packing Noir Weapons
abstract: In “Dead Man Down,” a thug with a secret past squares off with a disfigured woman seeking revenge for an attack.
lead_paragraph: One of the pleasures of movie watching is the suspension of disbelief. Yet while you can be fully absorbed in a movie, unless you’re a child or certifiable, you never actually put aside your belief in the real world — you just happily agree to go along with the fictional flow. Some directors never spin their lies successfully enough for this to happen, while others blow it with anachronisms, miscasting, shoddy filmmaking, dumb choices or merely a solitary false note. Other movies lose you, only to reel you back in tentatively with a jolt of intelligence or an image that sticks.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cartoon Math and Tablet Traffic
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include Web sites now drawing more traffic from tablets than from smartphones, a commercial for the Path social networking app that seems to have gone astray and how Pixar scientists translate mathematical principles into software for making animated films.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Spirits of The Times: Bourbons
abstract: The Dining section’s tasting panel recently evaluated 25 bourbons strictly to answer the question: How good are these whiskeys, anyway? The short answer is, very good.
lead_paragraph: The Dining section’s tasting panel recently evaluated 25 bourbons strictly to answer the question: How good are these whiskeys, anyway? The short answer is, very good.

headline: Treasures of the Alps
abstract: The smallest Italian viticultural region brims with little-known wines offering great pleasure.
lead_paragraph: Of the many wrinkles in the Italian wine tapestry, one of the wrinkliest is about as far northwest as you can go in Italy. There, tucked away in the Alps beneath looming Mont Blanc, the tallest peak in the chain, is the smallest Italian viticultural region, brimming with little-known wines capable of offering great pleasure.

headline: Holy Man or Hypocrite? A Low-Risk Devil’s Wager
abstract: Based on a Gothic thriller, “The Monk” traces the downfall of a sternly pious monk.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in “The Monk,” an adaptation of a notorious 1796 Gothic novel, when the shadows all but swallow the actor Vincent Cassel’s face. It’s an appropriately foreboding image for a heavily plotted tale of demons and men, God and the Devil that, in his influential review of the novel, Coleridge excoriated for combining “all that is most awfully true in religion with all that is most ridiculously absurd in superstition.” He conceded that the book had “much real merit” but also “impiety,” “abominations” and “libidinous minuteness.”

headline: Fish Bolstered With Herbs and Smoky Bacon
abstract: Trout plucked from an icy mountain stream seems just right with wines from the Alps.
lead_paragraph: There you are in the Alps. You take off your skis and you’re ready for a cool glass of local red alongside some fresh trout just plucked from an icy mountain stream. The wine promises lean, herbaceous, earthy, even flinty notes to accompany the meaty fish. No plans for skiing or fishing in Italy, or even the Gallatin River near Big Sky, Mont., or the in the Esopus Creek in the Catskills? Simply find a reliable fish market for the trout and bolster the whole fish with herbs and smoky bacon (or speck, the regional Italian version). You will not need black-diamond kitchen skills to put it on the table or to open that bottle of Valle d’Aosta.

headline: Homages, Giddy Humor and Less Clutter
keywords: ['Art', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: “Give them what they want” could be the motto of this year’s Armory Show, which has seen changes after a focus group and others weighed in.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a focus group convened to discuss the 2013 Armory Show. Organized and videotaped by the fair’s official artist, Liz Magic Laser, it engaged art writers, curators, collectors and others in a lively discussion of the flagging Armory brand. It was a clever way of acknowledging things that art-worlders have been complaining about for years: That the Armory had become too big and too corporate under its owners, Merchandise Mart; that it took New York for granted; and, most recently, that it had been dealt a possible death blow by the upstart Frieze art fair.

headline: Going Solo Has Its Day, in a Hodgepodge of Styles
abstract: More than half of the booths at the Art Show, the annual exhibition of the Art Dealers Association of America, are dedicated to single artists, a rarity in past years.
lead_paragraph: It would be hyperbolic to call it a revolution, but it is a significant development: Of the 72 vendors taking part in this year’s Art Dealers Association of America Art Show at the Park Avenue Armory, 40 have dedicated their booths to single artists. Last year’s featured 30 solo shows.

headline: A Light Hand at an Art Fair
abstract: The Independent art fair in Chelsea has no booths, no shadows and plenty of light — a state of affairs that extends to much of the art itself.
lead_paragraph: Of the art fairs large and small that have set up shop in Manhattan this week the Independent must be the most fun to work. It sure is the most fun to visit. The size is right; the atmosphere is light and bright, especially now that the show is back in its original digs in Chelsea, with some 40 galleries spread over three floors of the former Dia building.

headline: Fire Destroys a Pioneering Plug-In Prius Conversion
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Fuel Efficiency']
abstract: The destroyed vehicle played a crucial part in the history of plug-in electric vehicles. The cause of the fire was unknown.
lead_paragraph: A 2004 Toyota Prius that had been converted to run on grid-supplied electricity caught fire at 6:30 p.m. Tuesday night in Corte Madera, Calif., according to The Marin Independent Journal and other Bay Area news outlets. Nobody was hurt, but the fire killed a cat and caused about $250,000 worth of damage to the owner’s condominium.

headline: Comedy Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up and improv in New York.
lead_paragraph: Comedy

headline: Movie Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Movies

headline: Even a Birthday Cake Is Hardly a Distraction
abstract: Jason Marsalis and his band played a set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola that was slow and fast, and fanciful and serious, yet kind of severe in form and affect.
lead_paragraph: For most of Jason Marsalis’s playing life he’s been a drummer, and a rare one. His playing is eccentric within graceful boundaries, concerned with polyrhythm as science, history and gamesmanship, full of technique used to nonslick ends. It also often feels as if his work has an objective detachment. It’s about music as much as of it.

headline: Pop Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to indie rock,  pop, rock, hip-hop and R&B performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Pop

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Kenya, Chile, Afghanistan and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Kenya, Chile, Afghanistan and Pennsylvania.

headline: Jazz Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances and series in New York.
lead_paragraph: Jazz

headline: Lady in Red, Upbeat and Proud of It
abstract: Marilyn Maye performed anthems by Jerry Herman and standards by Cole Porter with gusto in her show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: “Life’s a banquet, and most poor suckers are starving to death.” I thought of that famous declaration by Auntie Mame while listening to the unstoppable Marilyn Maye at 54 Below on Wednesday evening. After playing almost everywhere in New York over the last several years Ms. Maye has finally landed at a club she approvingly dubbed a nightclub, rather than a cabaret.

headline: Finding Painterly Drama in Life’s Delicate Perch
abstract: The galleries of the New-York Historical Society are given over to an extraordinary assemblage of more than 200 watercolors of beautiful (if not happy) birds.
lead_paragraph: If John James Audubon had been less avian in his ambitions, he might have made a career as a portrait painter, which is how, on occasion, he supported himself while longing to paint birds and “go in pursuit of those beautiful and happy creatures.” Had he taken the human route, the galleries of the New-York Historical Society, which are now given over to an extraordinary assemblage of more than 200 watercolors of beautiful (if not happy) herons, owls, woodpeckers, ravens, rails, falcons, blue jays and their fellows, might instead be presenting portraits of early-19th-century Americans.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to classical music performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Classical

headline: Dance Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dance

headline: Unwanted Reunion
abstract: Dealing with a reunion with a former bully, wedding invitations on a budget, dawdling diners and an unwanted nickname.
lead_paragraph: I’ve befriended a co-worker at my new job. Turns out, her husband bullied me in high school and caused me great anguish at the time. That was 25 years ago, and I haven’t seen him since. My colleague is now asking my wife and me to join them for dinner at their house. I don’t want to see him, but she is being persistent. I also don’t want to cause problems between my colleague and her husband by bringing this up. What should I do?

headline: A Room for Joseph Cornell
abstract: A look at Charles L. Mee's "Hotel Cassiopeia" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: A look at Charles L. Mee's "Hotel Cassiopeia" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Stage Fright
abstract: Photos of Ivo van Hove’s stage adaptation of the 1977 film “Opening Night.”
lead_paragraph: Photos of Ivo van Hove’s stage adaptation of the 1977 film “Opening Night.”

headline: Young, Pregnant, Gone to Vegas
abstract: “Electrick Children,” written and directed by Rebecca Thomas, is a coming-of-age fable about two teenagers from a fundamentalist Mormon family in southern Utah.
lead_paragraph: The fanciful “Electrick Children” plumbs the feverish imagination of Rachel (Julia Garner), a 15-year-old brought up in a fundamentalist Mormon enclave in southern Utah, who is convinced that she is the conduit for a miraculous virgin birth. Believing she was impregnated by a voice she heard on a cassette singing Blondie’s “Hanging on the Telephone,” she assumes this country-rock drone somehow reached inside her to create a being who might be the son of God.

headline: Test Run: Facebook’s New News Feed
abstract: Facebook borrowed some lessons from traditional media empires, finally learning that for people who consume content, less is often more.
lead_paragraph: 3:57 p.m. | Updated Added context about the two types of ads in the feed.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Art

headline: Though Now Apart, We Faced a Common Enemy
abstract: After our divorce, we didn’t want to lose the friendship. We still helped each other through the hard times.
lead_paragraph: Last April I was eating my salad in front of the TV when the beautifully coifed anchor on “Entertainment Tonight” announced, “After the commercial break we go to a story you won’t believe: a man killed by a swan in Des Plaines, Illinois.”

headline: Theater Listings for March 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to plays running in New York, with special note of productions in previews or opening.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: Spare Times for Children for March 8-14
abstract: A listing of noteworthy cultural events for children, teenagers and families
lead_paragraph: ‘GRUG’

headline: Democrat Says He Won’t Run for Re-election to the Senate
abstract: Senator Carl Levin of Michigan is one of a growing list of senior Democrats who will not seek re-election in 2014, leaving Republicans more opportunities in their attempt to take back the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Carl Levin, a liberal fixture in the Senate and in Michigan, which he has served since 1979, said Thursday that he planned to retire, saying he would spend the next two years focusing on legislative business and not campaigning.

headline: Leader of Vote Count in Kenya Faces U.S. With Tough Choices
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations', 'Kikuyu Tribe', 'Elections']
abstract: The Obama administration has signaled its disfavor for Uhuru Kenyatta, accused of war crimes, who was ahead in presidential balloting. But rejecting him could harm ties to a vital ally.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — He has been charged with heinous crimes, accused of using a vast fortune to bankroll death squads that slaughtered women and children. His running mate also faces charges of crimes against humanity, and as Kenya’s election drew closer, the Obama administration’s top official for Africa issued a thinly veiled warning during a conference call about the vote, saying that Kenyans are, of course, free to pick their own leaders but that “choices have consequences.”

headline: Photo Replay: March 7
abstract: A look at the day in sports, from a cycling race in France to high school wrestling in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: A look at the day in sports, from a cycling race in France to high school wrestling in Pennsylvania.

headline: Necropsy of Burned Dogs Yields Surprises
abstract: Doctors found that the dogs were a pregnant mother who died of an intestinal blockage and four puppies who died inside her. Someone had cut the mother open after her death to try to deliver the puppies.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, thankfully, the most horrible seeming things are not what they appear to be.

headline: Spare Times for March 8-14
abstract: A listing of noteworthy events and activities in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: For White-Collar Defense Bar, It’s Happening in Vegas
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Legal Profession', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: “What happens in Vegas is the same thing that happens here in Washington: the blurring of lines between the regulator and the regulated,” contends a consumer advocate.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In 1986, Raymond Banoun, a Washington lawyer, organized an annual meeting for the white-collar criminal defense bar. He picked a warm-weather locale for the event, reserving conference facilities at the Boca Raton Resort and Club in Florida.

headline: Egyptian Activist Subjected to ‘Virginity Test’ Dropped From U.S. Honors List for Tweets
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The State Department dropped an activist from a list of women to be honored in Washington after comments celebrating attacks on Israelis and the American Embassy were discovered, along with a quotation from Hitler.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Friday, 10:43 a.m. The State Department dropped an Egyptian activist from a list of women to be honored in Washington on Friday after comments celebrating attacks on Israelis in Bulgaria and the American Embassy in Cairo were discovered in her Twitter feed, along with an anti-Semitic quotation from Adolf Hitler.

headline: Wines of The Times: California Sauvignon Blancs
abstract: The panel tasted sauvignon blancs from California and overall found them to be a delight, easy to drink and easy to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: The panel tasted sauvignon blancs from California and overall found them to be a delight, easy to drink and easy to enjoy.

headline: Wines of The Times: Paso Robles Zinfandels From California
abstract: The panel tasted 20 bottles of zinfandel from Paso Robles, Calif.
lead_paragraph: The panel tasted 20 bottles of zinfandel from Paso Robles, Calif.

headline: Wines of The Times: Pinot Noirs From the Russian River Valley
abstract: California pinot noirs that are approachable and well made — but not inspiring.
lead_paragraph: California pinot noirs that are approachable and well made — but not inspiring.

headline: Rape and Murder, Precisely Like a Crime Years Ago
abstract: “The Silence” begins with the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl; 23 years later, it happens again in an eerily precise duplicate.
lead_paragraph: “The Silence,” Baran bo Odar’s first feature, begins in 1986, with the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl, who is attacked as she rides her bicycle near a field of summer wheat. The identity of her killer — and of his panicked accomplice, a younger man named Timo (Wotan Wilke Möhring) — is known to the audience, but the case is never solved. Then, 23 years later, it happens again: not just a copycat crime but an eerily precise duplicate.

headline: Missing Nutella, Part 2: Columbia Puts Consumption Far Below Report
abstract: Columbia University says a well-repeated student’s statements about the popularity and cost of a new offering in the dining halls were not very accurate.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University on Thursday issued what a spokesman called “a tongue-in-cheek university statement” about the cost of Nutella that students have been eating in — or stealing from — campus dining halls.

headline: A Blunt Instrument in the Climate War
abstract: In “Greedy Lying Bastards,” Craig Scott Rosebraugh sets out to kick global-warming-denying corporate keisters.
lead_paragraph: As the title suggests “Greedy Lying Bastards” sees more value in urgency than in subtlety. For that reason alone this propulsively single-minded attack on climate-change deniers by Craig Scott Rosebraugh may just be the feel-good documentary of the year.

headline: Pratt Students Talk About Fire’s Cost to Them
abstract: The Local blog spoke to some students who picked up donated art supplies.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after a fire at Pratt Institute ravaged the Brooklyn art school’s historic Main Building and destroyed thousands of student artworks, The Local blog checked in with a handful of students who came by a makeshift dispensary to pick up donated art supplies.

headline: He Just Wants a Woman to Settle Down With
abstract: In “Language of a Broken Heart,” written by and starring Juddy Talt, a young man flees New York after being dumped.
lead_paragraph: Although “Language of a Broken Heart,” a romantic comedy written by and starring Juddy Talt, eventually drowns in clichés and predictability, it has a few decent moments of humor and some appealing performances that make it marginally better than most vanity projects.

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for March
abstract: College counselors in the United States offer monthly advice for juniors and seniors who want to stay on track during the admissions process.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 8, 2013
abstract: The New York Times critics on “Oz the Great and Powerful,” “Beyond the Hills” and “The We and the I.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on “Oz the Great and Powerful,” “Beyond the Hills” and “The We and the I.”

headline: Syrian Rebels Interview Captured Government Officials
abstract: Syrian rebels who seized the capital of the northern province of Raqqa on Wednesday also appeared in a video posted online that showed some high-profile captives.
lead_paragraph: As our colleagues Duraid Adnan and Rick Gladstone reported, Syrian rebels seized the capital of the northern province of Raqqa on Wednesday, driving government forces from the town and capturing two high-ranking prisoners, the governor of Raqqa Province and the local chief of the ruling Baath Party.

headline: The Dog Stays. We’ll See About the Stuff.
abstract: Matt Kroll and Catherine Kellogg went looking for a large one-bedroom on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: When Matt Kroll moved to the city after graduating from Colgate University, he lived with roommates in a three-bedroom duplex in the East 70s, paying $1,250 a month for a large bedroom with an en-suite bathroom and four closets. The situation, as well as the vast amount of space, “worked out seamlessly,” Mr. Kroll said.

headline: Bailout Official at the Treasury to Leave Post
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Matt Pendo, the chief investment officer of the bailout program, is stepping down on Friday. He will be succeeded by Charmian Uy, who joined the department last summer.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years of long train rides and selling off more than $120 billion in assets, the chief investment officer of the Treasury Department’s bailout program is stepping down.

headline: Justice Orders Mediation in Martha Stewart Case
abstract: If the companies do not reach an agreement before April 8, Justice Jeffrey K. Oing of New York State Supreme Court will continue hearing the case.
lead_paragraph: After almost three weeks of testimony, the judge overseeing the lawsuits that Macy’s brought against J. C. Penney and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has sent the parties into mediation.

headline: The Power of an Educated Woman
abstract: Young women from around the world tell their stories of triumph over adversity in “Girl Rising,” a twist on the social issue documentary.
lead_paragraph: If “Girl Rising” is wholly a vehicle furthering the cause of girls’ education across the globe, it’s more of a multicolored bus to worthy destinations than a pace car. In this twist on the social-issue documentary, girls act out stories adapted from their own lives by writers from their own countries, including Edwidge Danticat, Aminatta Forna and Manjushree Thapa. The hybrid results feature occasional bold strokes alongside ad-pitch eye candy and sleeve-tugging.

headline: Anthony to Miss Game Against Thunder
abstract: Carmelo Anthony still has not played since sustaining a knee injury on Monday in a game against the Cleveland Cavaliers.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks will play without Carmelo Anthony on Thursday in their nationally televised game against the Oklahoma City Thunder. Coach Mike Woodson said he was told earlier in the day that Anthony would not be available.

headline: The Time, and Place, to Buy
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Home mortgage rates aren’t expected to rise much this year, but the same cannot be said for housing prices, especially in some areas of the country.
lead_paragraph: As both mortgage rates and housing prices head higher, home buyers may be wondering whether they ought to settle for whatever property they can get now, rather than risk paying more later.

headline: 26 Ways to Die Gruesomely
abstract: Everybody’s got to go sometime in “The A B Cs of Death,” a collection of horror shorts in many languages.

headline: A Brick-Watcher’s Favorites
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Brick and Tile', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: No matter how old, brick speaks of the mason who laid it. And it comes in many styles.
lead_paragraph: Stone leaves me cold. Yes, Connemara green marble can be luscious, and the fossils in Indiana limestone may be mesmerizing, but the setting of stone — massive hunks of rock, which must be derricked into place — removes all sense of handwork. A stone wall is the creation of machines.

headline: Report Suggests a Digital Divide Among Latinos
abstract: The report, by the Pew Hispanic Center, said that while a digital divide between Latino Americans and white Americans may be closing, a divide still exists between native- and foreign-born Latinos.
lead_paragraph: A digital divide between Latino Americans and white Americans may be closing, but a divide still exists between native- and foreign-born Latinos, according to a report issued Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: Chief Executive at Pandora Media to Step Down
abstract: Joseph J. Kennedy, the company’s chief since 2004, suggested he needed a rest after 10 years on the job, though he said he would stay till a successor was found.
lead_paragraph: The chairman and chief executive of Pandora Media, the company behind the popular Internet radio service, announced on Thursday that he would be leaving the company after nine years, on a day when Pandora reported growth and better-than-expected earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter and full year.

headline: Net May Sit Despite His Strong Suit
abstract: Nets forward Reggie Evans has accounted for nearly half of the team’s rebounds nightly when he has been on the floor. But his scoring numbers have not been so impressive.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — With his shiny bald head, scraggly beard and Bunyanesque build, Reggie Evans is a physical oddity in the N.B.A., a 6-foot-8 power forward with shoulders rounded like bowling balls and wrists as thick as fire hoses.

headline: Billionaires’ Club Is Set to Grow
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Around the world, a growing number of billionaires are purchasing homes at record prices, and reportssuggest that the luxury-buying ballet is likely poised for a sustained performance.
lead_paragraph: Watching a ballet, you cannot help but marvel at the power of the movement, and the ability of the dancers to soar through the air, time and again, as if there were no limits to their stamina.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: The Bay-Gull Store
abstract: The Bay-Gull Store, known for its cheese bagels, became a meeting place, kitchen and supply distribution center for the community in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: The Bay-Gull Store, known for its cheese bagels, became a meeting place, kitchen and supply distribution center for the community in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Hopes, Maybe Misguided, That Food Will Breed Productivity in Capital
abstract: People who study presidents’ relationships with Congress say efforts to win hearts don’t often change minds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all they fail to agree on, Republicans in Congress and President Obama have come to see eye to eye on at least one thing: four years of relatively little contact is no way to run the country.

headline: Cal’s Win Over Stanford in Pac-12 Swimming Is Not Last Word
abstract: The University of California men’s swimming team ended Stanford’s 31-year conference title streak, but both programs await nationals as the final word.
lead_paragraph: When California’s men’s swimming and diving team won the Pac-12 championship on Wednesday night, ending rival Stanford’s 31-year conference-title streak, the Bears received their trophy, and their banner, in a somewhat sour mood.

headline: Regulator Expresses Doubts About an Auditor’s Procedures
abstract: The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said that it found problems with procedures at PricewaterhouseCoopers in 2008 and 2009 and that they had not been remedied.
lead_paragraph: The regulator for American auditing firms said on Thursday that it had found serious problems with procedures at PricewaterhouseCoopers and that the firm had failed to remedy them.

headline: Plucked From Obscurity, and Now a Star!
abstract: A young Filipino gets to live his Steve Perry dream in “Don’t Stop Believin’: Everyman’s Journey.”

headline: A Cannery Row in Maine
abstract: Workers for a closed sardine plant in Maine get their hopes up in “Downeast.”
lead_paragraph: All those daunting economic numbers that tabulate how many Americans are unemployed and how many factory jobs have been lost in the last 30 years can seem abstract until you run into a documentary like “Downeast.” This modest film by David Redmon and Ashley Sabin looks at one small effort to save a handful of jobs in Gouldsboro, Me. It’s a tale of hope, frustration and disappointment that reminds us that behind all those big numbers are real human beings.

headline: Obama Signs Expanded Anti-Violence Law
abstract: The new law expands the federal protections and resources of the original 1994 Violence Against Women Act.
lead_paragraph: Standing with survivors of domestic abuse and sex trafficking, President Obama on Thursday signed into law a renewal and expansion of the 19-year-old Violence Against Woman Act, a long-sought victory made possible last month when House Republicans quit blocking the measure’s passage.

headline: Cooped Up in a Trawler With Dad
abstract: In “The Other Side of the Ice” a family picks its way among the floes of the Northwest Passage.
lead_paragraph: Sometime during “The Other Side of the Ice,” Sprague Theobald’s documentary log of his voyage through the Northwest Passage with his adult children, one family member impatiently describes his companions as a bunch of spoiled sourpusses. That’s not far off the mark. This tedious chronicle has the interest level of a home movie of a vacation with bickering and yammering left intact.

headline: Hicks Nix Climate Fix
abstract: Who better to convince farmers of the perils of climate change than a farmer?
lead_paragraph: Everybody loves a farmer, judging by the popularity of this year’s hit Super Bowl ad about the virtues of those who coax food from dirt. And yet nobody wants to be one, with less than 1 percent of the population claiming it as an occupation.

headline: Clinton Urges Court to Overturn Marriage Law He Signed
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton said he had come to believe the 1996 law is unconstitutional and contravenes the quintessential American values of “freedom, equality and justice above all.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, who signed the Defense of Marriage Act in 1996 barring federal recognition of same-sex weddings, called on the Supreme Court on Thursday to overturn the law.

headline: Serving Solace, One Bagel at a Time
abstract: The Bay-Gull Store in Broad Channel, Queens, had to rebuild after Hurricane Sandy, but with its cheese bagels, it became a source of comfort to residents surviving on canned soup.
lead_paragraph: Broad Channel is a marshy sliver of land nestled between mainland Queens and the Rockaways, a roughly 20-block string of one- and two-story houses often circled by white picket fences. People here drop their Rs when they speak about their mothas, their brothas, their neighbas. They are police officers and firefighters, often of Irish descent.

headline: Justin Bieber Collapses During Show
abstract: The teenage pop idol became short of breath, but finished his performance after being given oxygen backstage.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber collapsed after becoming short of breath during a performance at London’s O2 arena on Thursday night, but finished his performance after being given oxygen backstage, Reuters reported.

headline: China and the U.S. Join Forces on North Korea
abstract: David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, and Marcus Mabry, Rendezvous’ editor, discuss North Korea’s nuclear strike warnings and whether a new round of sanctions, written by China and the United States, can work.
lead_paragraph: David E. Sanger, chief Washington correspondent, and Marcus Mabry, editor of Rendezvous, discuss North Korea’s nuclear strike warnings and whether a new round of sanctions, written by China and the United States, can work.

headline: After Chávez, a Chance to Rethink Relations With Cuba
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: An end to the Cuba embargo would send a signal to Latin America that the United States wants a new relationship with democratic forces seeking social change throughout the Americas.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va.

headline: A Longtime Comedian, Still Without a Break
abstract: A ranter with jokes onstage, Eddie Pepitone shows a mellower side at home in “The Bitter Buddha.”
lead_paragraph: A rough-hewed and admiring portrait of the 54-year-old comedian Eddie Pepitone, “The Bitter Buddha” will, like its subject, struggle to appeal to a wider audience than comedy geeks and professional dyspeptics.

headline: A Budget Delayed, to Little G.O.P. Sympathy
abstract: Though serial fiscal crises have helped push President Obama’s budget plan well past a deadline, Republicans are demanding quick action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a year-end fiscal crisis and protracted deficit-cutting negotiations between the White House and Congress scrambled the government’s accounting, the president was more than a month late in meeting a deadline set by law for getting his annual budget to Capitol Hill in the new year.

headline: Chávez Lives On
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Throngs of supporters of the deceased Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez gathered in Caracas to see his embalmed body, which will be on permanent display.
lead_paragraph: Throngs of supporters of the deceased Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez gathered in Caracas to see his embalmed body, which will be on permanent display.

headline: Debating Chávez’s Legacy
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: While poverty went down significantly during Hugo Chávez’s years as president, Venezuela ranked 13th of 18 countries in per capita economic growth from 1999 to 2011.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Heads of state from around Latin America flocked to Venezuela for the funeral on Friday of Hugo Chávez, a tribute to the undiminished drawing power of the charismatic leftist leader, although perhaps not to the lasting influence of his socialist-inspired policies.

headline: Now a Little Spray Will Quickly Moisturize You
abstract: Vaseline is introducing a line of moisturizing body lotion sprays that it claims go on easily and do not mark clothing.
lead_paragraph: BODY lotion is used by 96 percent of women, according to the market research firm Mintel, and for moisturizer marketers hoping to increase sales, that, fittingly, is the rub. There are, after all, so few nonusers to sign on as new customers.

headline: Our Wait-and-See Culture
abstract: The new “follow-up culture” in medicine: wait six months and see.
lead_paragraph: JUST as the captain of the Rachel in “Moby-Dick” searched for his lost son and instead found Ishmael, doctors routinely reveal the unexpected while scanning for something else. What to do with this acquired information and how to follow up is becoming an increasingly vexing problem for physicians and their patients.

headline: It’s About the Work, Not the Office
abstract: Corralling workers in one place doesn’t necessarily lead to productivity or innovation.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: The Orthodox Surge
abstract: A thriving Jewish counterculture prompts reflections on collective commitments in the modern age.
lead_paragraph: In Midwood, Brooklyn, there’s a luxury kosher grocery store called Pomegranate serving the modern Orthodox and Hasidic communities. It looks like a really nice Whole Foods. There’s a wide selection of kosher cheeses from Italy and France, wasabi herring, gluten-free ritual foods and nicely toned wood flooring.

headline: The Market Speaks
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Dow Jones Stock Average']
abstract: Yes, the Dow Jones industrial average has been setting new records this week, but the message from the markets is actually not a happy one.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, as a newly elected president began his efforts to rescue the economy and strengthen the social safety net, conservative economic pundits — people who claimed to understand markets and know how to satisfy them — warned of imminent financial disaster. Stocks, they declared, would plunge, while interest rates would soar.

headline: Arkansas’s Attack on Abortion
abstract: A new law, which violates 40 years of Supreme Court precedent, bans abortions at 12 weeks of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Republican-controlled legislatures have been working for many years to limit women’s access to legal abortion care, but the Republican-led Legislature in Arkansas took the campaign to a new extreme on Wednesday when it overrode the veto of Gov. Mike Beebe, a Democrat, and ignored the Supreme Court to adopt the most restrictive abortion ban in the country.

headline: Shareholders in Europe Demand Control
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Editorials']
abstract: Swiss measures are the newest and most far-reaching of the say-on-pay policies now in place or under consideration in many European nations.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Switzerland this week overwhelmingly approved a referendum to give shareholders a binding say on executive pay. The Swiss measures are the latest and most far-reaching of various say-on-pay policies now in place or under consideration in many European nations. Denmark, Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands all have some form of voting on binding pay.

headline: Next Step for Rivera: Closing a Career
abstract: The Yankees’ Mariano Rivera, revered as one of baseball’s gentlemen and perhaps its greatest closer, is expected to announce that this season will be his last.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX

headline: Angry at Public and Officials, Security Forces Strike in Egypt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Strikes']
abstract: Officers said they were protesting official pressure to crack down on demonstrators and public demands for restraint.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Thousands of Egyptian security officers went on strike on Thursday in cities around the country to protest conflicting pressures from the government to crack down on street demonstrations and from the public to exercise restraint.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Mar. 8, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Mar. 8, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Politics really understands a couple of things — votes and dollars. My father always used to tell me, ‘No peso, no say-so.’”

headline: Polar Bears Go to Court
keywords: ['Polar Bears', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Editorials']
abstract: The bears are threatened by the melting of Arctic ice, and although a global conference failed to protect them, they did get some judicial help in an American court.
lead_paragraph: The polar bear, whose long-term survival is threatened by the loss of Arctic sea ice because of global warming, got a welcome judicial assist this month, but a broader effort to protect it suffered defeat at an international conference on trade in endangered wildlife on Thursday.

headline: Kenyan Election May Offer U.S. Tough Choice
abstract: The presidential candidate Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenya’s first president, is accused of using a vast fortune to bankroll death squads that slaughtered women and children.
lead_paragraph: The presidential candidate Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenya’s first president, is accused of using a vast fortune to bankroll death squads that slaughtered women and children.

headline: Mr. Brennan’s Excuse
abstract: The newly confirmed C.I.A. chief should commit to making a Senate report on torture public.
lead_paragraph: John Brennan, the newly confirmed chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, has been at the agency for most of 25 years. He had two counterterrorism jobs during the administration of George W. Bush. In one, he compiled intelligence reports from 20 agencies (including the C.I.A.) for Mr. Bush’s morning briefing. He was President Obama’s counterterrorism adviser in his first term and an architect of the Obama administration’s targeted killings policy.

headline: Conservatives Revive Proposals for Term Limits
abstract: In Texas, a state dominated by Republicans, conservatives are pushing two constitutional amendments that would limit most statewide officeholders.
lead_paragraph: Texas conservatives were pushing for term limits 20 years ago, in an effort easy to dismiss as an attempt to flush Democrats out of the Legislature, the Congressional delegation and even some executive offices.

headline: The Cellphone Records, Officer? You May Soon Need a Warrant
abstract: House Bill 1608 would require Texas law enforcement agencies to obtain warrants and prove probable cause of illegal activity before obtaining cellphone records in their investigations.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to regulate the use of cellphone records in investigations by law enforcement, Texas lawmakers are considering a bill that would require police officers and prosecutors to have a warrant before obtaining such records.

headline: McIlroy Struggles, but Woods Soars at Doral
abstract: In a grouping of the top three players in the world, only Tiger Woods posted a luminous score in the first round of the World Golf Championship event. Rory McIlroy and Luke Donald struggled.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — The featured group at the Cadillac Championship on Thursday was like a marquee with one light burned out and another flickering. In a grouping of the top three players in the world, only one posted a luminous score.

headline: Bronx Offers Case Study Over Future of Voting Act
abstract: As the Supreme Court reviews a section of the landmark Voting Rights Act, arguments for and against election monitoring are again being batted about in New York.
lead_paragraph: Emerging from the bloody protests in Selma, Ala., the Voting Rights Act was initially heralded as a declaration that the federal government would no longer tolerate the open racism of the segregated South. But this narrow mandate to monitor elections in six Southern states grew quietly over the years, extending to unexpected corners of the country, including the Bronx.

headline: Corrections: March 8, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 8, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Global Temperatures Highest in 4,000 Years
abstract: The modern warming period is unique over a longer period than previously thought, according to research published in the journal Science.
lead_paragraph: Global temperatures are warmer than at any time in at least 4,000 years, scientists reported Thursday, and over the coming decades are likely to surpass levels not seen on the planet since before the last ice age.

headline: Shot After a Break
abstract: Admiring the clever cluing of Paula Gamache.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a fun one, with a tantalizing mix of “just easy enough to get it” entries and Bald Mountain ranges like UINTA that most of us, and by that I mean me, needed to look up. Also, BEER GOGGLES. You can look it up.

headline: In a Spinoff of Time Inc., Evolution Is Complete
abstract: With the spinoff of Time Inc., Time Warner has become an example of the media industry’s shift away from rapid acquisition and growth.
lead_paragraph: The sprawling media conglomerate that Steven J. Ross joined together, Jeffrey L. Bewkes has put asunder.

headline: Fiery, Salty and Brash, This Rose of Texas
abstract: The life and career of Ann Richards, the onetime governor of Texas, are being given a ticker tape parade on the stage of the Vivian Beaumont Theater.
lead_paragraph: She was a memorable figure even before she opened her mouth — that sculptured meringue of hair seemed to enter the room before she did — and an unforgettable one when she opened it, as salty wisecracks poured forth like popcorn from a machine. She was politically as blue as they come, but managed to win the leadership of a state as red-trending as any in the land. She acquired a national political profile without holding national office, and openly discussed her alcoholism before this became a rite of passage for famous figures from across the political spectrum.

headline: As Fracking Increases, So Do Fears About Water Supply
abstract: The amount of water used in hydraulic fracturing is stirring concerns around drought-stricken Texas as the drilling boom continues.
lead_paragraph: CARRIZO SPRINGS, Tex. — In this South Texas stretch of mesquite trees and cactus, where the land is sometimes too dry to grow crops, the local aquifer is being strained in the search for oil. The reason is hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, a drilling process that requires massive amounts of water.

headline: Is That a Movie or Video Game?
abstract: Are digital effects ruining the magic of cinema or enhancing it?

headline: On Egypt, Focus on Rights
abstract: Human Rights First responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Combating Cyberattacks
abstract: A research scientist at the Georgia Tech Research Institute responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Police Program to Keep Tabs on At-Risk Teenagers
abstract: Two readers raise concerns about police intervention in teenage lives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Next Pope and the Future Church
abstract: Readers’ reflections at a time of transition in the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hit-Run Suspect Charged With Felonies
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The suspect in a hit and run that killed a young pregnant woman, her husband and, later, their newborn son was charged with three felony counts of criminally negligent homicide.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in a hit and run that killed a young pregnant woman, her husband and, later, their newborn son was returned to New York on Thursday and charged with three felony counts of criminally negligent homicide.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: The troubadour Ryan Bingham in Fort Worth, niche music in Houston and a paella contest in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH

headline: Stompin’ Tom Connors, Canadian Singer, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Connors sang often about his hardscrabble life and shunned American music as he built a wide following in his native country.
lead_paragraph: Stompin’ Tom Connors, a Canadian country-folk singer whose odes to the vast country he had roamed as a hitchhiking troubadour made him a beloved figure from the Maritime Provinces to British Columbia, died on Wednesday at his home in Halton Hills, Ontario. He was 77.

headline: Diplomat Calls for End to Drunkenness During U.N. Negotiations
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: A culture of heavy drinking among delegates at the world council likely will not change despite the “modest proposal” by Joseph M. Torsella, a diplomat from the United States.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — When the United Nations began renovating its Manhattan headquarters in 2009, one of the first casualties of the construction was the storied Delegate’s Lounge, where for decades the delicate work of diplomacy was aided by a good stiff drink.

headline: Pope Wanted. Must Possess Magnetic Charm. And Grit.
abstract: Cardinals who will select the next pope would like to find one with the charisma of Pope John Paul II, and the toughness to tackle Vatican disarray.
lead_paragraph: ROME — No candidate for pope can have it all. But the cardinals who will elect the next pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church seem to be looking for someone who combines the charisma of Pope John Paul II with the grit of what one Vatican analyst called, only slightly tongue in cheek, “Pope Rambo I.”

headline: Opposition Emerges to Cuomo’s Plan to Cut $120 Million for the Disabled
abstract: The Assembly’s Democratic majority will propose restoring the full $120 million that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is seeking to cut; the State Senate’s majority coalition is also objecting to the reduction.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A plan by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to cut $120 million in financing for nonprofit organizations that serve people with developmental disabilities is emerging as a flash point in this year’s budget negotiations.

headline: For a Baseball Traveling Man, an Unexpected Stop
abstract: In 23 seasons, Pedro Valdes, 39, has played for 18 teams, in 13 leagues and in five countries. Now with Puerto Rico, Valdes plans to retire after the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Pedro Valdes stepped inside the batting cage at Hiram Bithorn Stadium on Thursday morning and took cut after cut, each swing a perfect reproduction of the last. His mechanics were distinctive: the high leg kick and the way he whipped the bat across the plate, his left hand releasing after impact.

headline: Cooper Union Board Delays Tuition Decision
abstract: The board of trustees met with the expectation of making a decision on whether to end the college’s policy on free tuition for undergraduates, but left saying they are still reviewing options.
lead_paragraph: Students, faculty and alumni of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art eager to learn the fate of the college’s distinctive no-tuition policy have been told to wait, again.

headline: Lillian Cahn, Creator of the Coach Handbag, Dies at 89
abstract: Mrs. Cahn suggested the design for what became the first successful bag for Coach, the company she helped found: a tote modeled on a type of paper shopping bag she had used as a girl.
lead_paragraph: Lillian Cahn, who founded the Coach Leatherware Company in a Manhattan loft in 1961 with her husband, Miles, and went on to help produce the “shopping bag” tote and other handbags that have become ubiquitous accessories in the wardrobes of well-heeled American women, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Nash and Gaborik Fuel a Late Surge for the Rangers
abstract: Marian Gaborik scored a power-play goal against the Islanders in overtime to extend the Rangers’ winning streak to four games.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Rangers left wing Rick Nash does not quite look all of his 6 feet 4 inches and 200-plus pounds without his equipment. On the ice, he looms much larger — as the Islanders found out Thursday night.

headline: Joseph Kelner, 98, Dies; Led Kent State Lawsuit
abstract: Besides Kent State, other high-profile cases included those of Bernhard Goetz, the subway vigilante, and a pair of fired baseball umpires.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Kelner, a lawyer who took on the sitting governor of Ohio, a former university president and the National Guard in a suit on behalf of the student victims of the Kent State shootings in 1970, died on Monday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 98.

headline: New York City Says It Erred by Not Telling Parents of School PCB Leak
abstract: A mother of a child at an Upper West Side elementary school learned of the December episode while perusing a Department of Education report about PCBs posted online.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Department of Education has apologized to parents of an Upper West Side elementary school for failing to inform parents that a faulty light fixture in a classroom leaked a toxic chemical in December.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 7, 2013

headline: Closing Arguments Made, Jurors at Cannibal Trial Get Case
abstract: The central question posed by both sides was whether the sadistic acts that Officer Gilberto Valle had fantasized about involved real crimes.
lead_paragraph: For much of his two-week trial, it had become clear that Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kill and cannibalize women, had become immersed in a bizarre fantasy world that revolved around a fetish Web site and his electronic communications with others.

headline: Judge Temporarily Blocks Cab-Hailing by Smartphones
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Mobile Applications', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Owners of for-hire vehicles sued the city, saying use of the apps would violate a ban on prearranged rides in yellow taxis and upend their business model.
lead_paragraph: A State Supreme Court justice on Thursday blocked New York City’s plans to allow taxi riders to hail yellow cabs using smartphone apps, preventing the Bloomberg administration from beginning the program on Friday as scheduled.

headline: Injuries Like Teixeira’s Can Linger
abstract: Jose Bautista injured his wrist on July 16 and was forced to have season-ending surgery. The Yankees can only hope that is not the path that Mark Teixeira will follow.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — When Jose Bautista took the fateful swing that injured his left wrist on July 16, the Yankees’ hitting instructor, Kevin Long, winced along with Bautista from inside the dugout and told Yankees Manager Joe Girardi that Bautista would require surgery.

headline: Philadelphia Officials Vote to Close 23 Schools
abstract: The closings are part of a plan by the school district to erase a huge budget deficit and reduce the number of underused schools.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Officials on Thursday night approved closing 23 public schools, about 10 percent of the city’s total, largely backing a plan by the school district to erase a huge budget deficit and reduce the number of underused schools.

headline: Trial of Courier Tied to Terror Plots Ends, Putting Pressure on Hezbollah
abstract: Hossam Taleb Yaacoub’s trial, on charges he participated in a Hezbollah plot to strike at Israeli tourists in Cyprus, ended Thursday.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — For days after his arrest by the Cypriot police, Hossam Taleb Yaacoub kept to the cover story he had spent years building: He was a Lebanese businessman looking for import opportunities, not an operative for the Shiite militant group Hezbollah scouting potential targets for terrorism.

headline: Grounding a Romance in Memories
abstract: The animator Goro Miyazaki, son of Hayao Miyazaki, talks about drawing on his memories to create an idealized Yokohama for “From Up on Poppy Hill.”
lead_paragraph: Audiences familiar with the films of the Japanese animation house Studio Ghibli may be surprised to find no witches, forest spirits, wolf-goddesses or dragons in its latest production. “From Up on Poppy Hill” follows a more reality-based narrative — a budding romance between high school students, Umi (voiced by Sarah Bolger in the English-language version) and Shun (Anton Yelchin) — reflecting a place and time in Japanese history: the port city of Yokohama in 1963, as preparations for the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo are under way.

headline: In Myanmar, Pro-Democracy Party Meets in Bid to Revitalize
abstract: Members of the long-repressed pro-democracy party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi gathered in Yangon for their first party congress, in an attempt to revitalize the group.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Nearly a quarter century after it was founded, members of the long-repressed pro-democracy party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi gathered here for their first party congress, an attempt to revitalize a political organization that some of its own members say lacks competence, efficiency and effective midlevel leadership.

headline: N.H.L. Realignment Plan Gains Union’s Approval
abstract: The plan, which is pending a vote by the Board of Governors, would replace the two-conference, six-division setup with a two-conference, four-division setup and ease travel burdens.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. Players’ Association announced Thursday its approval of the league’s realignment proposal, which would begin next season pending a vote next week by the Board of Governors.

headline: Syria Opposition Leaders Delay Trip to Washington
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Moaz al-Khatib, the leader of the Syrian Opposition Council, may be building up his moderate coalition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the Syrian opposition have put off a visit to Washington for a series of high-profile meetings, including an expected stop at the White House, administration officials said Thursday, underscoring the challenge the United States faces in cultivating a still-evolving political movement.

headline: A Letter to the University of North Carolina
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: The education department responds to a discrimination complaint filed with the D.C. Office for Civil Rights.
lead_paragraph: The education department responds to a discrimination complaint filed with the D.C. Office for Civil Rights.

headline: Students Initiate Inquiry Into Harassment Reports
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: An investigation into whether the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill routinely botched sexual assault and harassment complaints is the latest in a series of such allegations against other schools.
lead_paragraph: The federal government has begun an investigation into claims that the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill routinely botched sexual assault and harassment complaints and mistreated victims — the latest in a series of similar allegations against high-profile colleges and universities.

headline: Depth Puts the Blackhawks on Top
abstract: A look at the players who are behind the Chicago Blackhawks’ 21-0-3 record.
lead_paragraph: At 21-0-3, the Chicago Blackhawks have roared through half of their schedule without a regulation loss. Their 24-game run has shattered the previous N.H.L. record for longest season-opening point streak (16 games, by Anaheim in 2006-7) and is second to the overall single-season mark (35 games, by Philadelphia in 1979-80).

headline: Knicks’ Spark Vanishes in a Flash
abstract: With Carmelo Anthony sitting out, J. R. Smith had 36 points to keep the Knicks competitive. He came up short, though, and the Thunder won.
lead_paragraph: J. R. Smith is not Carmelo Anthony. He is a little shorter, a little lighter, slightly younger. He does not have the All-Star credentials or the gold medals or the fame. Where Anthony celebrates his dominance with a megawatt smile, Smith prefers a well-timed snarl.

headline: Visualizing ‘Poppy Hill’
abstract: Images from the latest Studio Ghibli feature, “From Up on Poppy Hill.”
lead_paragraph: Images from the latest Studio Ghibli feature, “From Up on Poppy Hill.”

headline: New Proposal to Merge Art Museums in Los Angeles
abstract: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art has proposed combining with the Museum of Contemporary Art, which has struggled with precarious finances.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which has been battered in recent months with defections of board members, criticism of its direction and precarious finances, would merge with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art under a proposal by the latter museum.

headline: Half of New York City Marathon Entrants Opt for a Refund
abstract: New York Road Runners will have to limit the number of new entrants to accommodate runners who had the right to compete after they missed last year’s canceled race.
lead_paragraph: About half of the runners registered for last year’s New York City Marathon, which was canceled after Hurricane Sandy, chose to have their entry fee refunded, and the other half chose to run in a coming marathon or half marathon, New York Road Runners said in a letter to runners.

headline: Looming Budget Cuts Add to Problems at Nuclear Site
abstract: The Hanford nuclear cleanup project in Richland, Wash., has been hit by leaking waste, layoffs and delays; now more trouble is ahead.
lead_paragraph: RICHLAND, Wash. — Here in the place where plutonium production for the nation’s bomb arsenal was elevated to industrial scale, in the rolling scrub country of south-central Washington, dangerous industrial pollutants are still getting into the soil only a few miles from the Columbia River.

headline: N.F.C. Free Agency Preview
abstract: The 49ers should maintain their dominance, with the Falcons at their heels if Tony Gonzalez returns, while the Eagles are rebooting with a new coach, and the Saints with a familiar one.
lead_paragraph: In the N.F.C., the 49ers’ returning weapons and 15 draft picks should help them maintain their dominance, with the Falcons at their heels if Tony Gonzalez returns. On the other side of the 2012 standings, the Eagles are looking to reboot with a new coach, and the Saints with a familiar one in Sean Payton, following his bounty-induced suspension.

headline: Postal Service Looks to Sell Historic Buildings
abstract: Preservation groups say some of the buildings, which are for sale or being considered for sale, are architecturally significant and that their design elements and historic features should be protected.
lead_paragraph: Preservation groups say some of the buildings, which are for sale or being considered for sale, are architecturally significant and that their design elements and historic features should be protected.

headline: Post Office Buildings With Character, and Maybe a Sale Price
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: Preservationists are fighting what they consider shortsighted decisions to sell architecturally distinctive post office buildings.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — The lines are often long inside the Art Deco post office here under the palm trees. But few people complain these days when they visit that New Deal-era building.

headline: On the Set With Matthias Schoenaerts
abstract: Behind the scenes at the shoot for the cover story of the Men’s Fashion issue.
lead_paragraph: As the rain poured down on the drive from downtown Miami to the Ocean Queen Motel in Hollywood, the actor Matthias Schoenaerts, marking his first visit to Florida, said this isn’t how he imagined the Sunshine State. Schoenaerts was right on time for a 7:30 a.m. pickup from the Eden Roc Hotel, despite having arrived from Brussels only hours before. Once everyone got to the motel, to shoot the Men’s issue cover, the photo crew worked tirelessly to keep the breakfast catering out of the rain, while Schoenaerts stood on the motel balcony smoking hand-rolled cigarettes and taking iPhone photos of the Atlantic.

headline: In From the Cold
abstract: The life of Evgeny Lebedev, a London Russian who owns the Evening Standard and The Independent, is Balzac-meets-Bulgakov.
lead_paragraph: The British establishment is a notoriously tough guard to crack —particularly for the wave of oligarchs who have been making London their home. So how come Evgeny Lebedev makes it look so easy?

headline: The Dark Side
abstract: Lightweight summer suits — traditionally in pale neutrals — get a sophisticated remake in deep navy and charcoal hues. The rising actor Max Irons steps into the picture.
lead_paragraph: Lightweight summer suits — traditionally in pale neutrals — get a sophisticated remake in deep navy and charcoal hues. The rising actor Max Irons steps into the picture.

headline: The Gardener’s House
abstract: For the peripatetic Madison Cox, home is a simple Moorish refuge in a city that has captivated like-minded wanderers for centuries: beloved books and plants share his view of the deep blue Strait of Gibraltar.
lead_paragraph: For the peripatetic Madison Cox, home is a simple Moorish refuge in a city that has captivated like-minded wanderers for centuries: beloved books and plants share his view of the deep blue Strait of Gibraltar.

headline: Good Morning, Matthias Schoenaerts
abstract: With a string of movies on the docket, one of Hollywood’s men of the moment kicks back with T.
lead_paragraph: After a breakout performance in ‘Rust and Bone,’ Hollywood is waking up to the raw magnetism of this Belgian import.

headline: Breaking the Silence on Sexual Abuse
abstract: Nilanjana Roy shares a personal tale of abuse to make a point “about the importance of consent” in the present debate over women’s rights in India.
lead_paragraph: “The man who was my abuser was a fine host, a good husband, a caring father, a respected elder whose generosity and kindness were as genuine as the fact of the abuse,” Nilanjana S. Roy wrote in The Opinion Pages. “These qualities were important, because they helped him conceal the abuse he carried out over a period of four years.”

headline: Advocacy Group to Monitor Reform Efforts in Public Schools
abstract: The Network for Public Education will call for curriculums that include arts and foreign languages, as well as better financing for schools and more respect for teachers.
lead_paragraph: Diane Ravitch, the historian and former assistant education secretary who has become an outspoken critic of those who favor high-stakes testing, tenure reforms and other controversial measures aimed at the public schools, has joined with other education advocates to form a group that will grade and endorse political candidates.

headline: Word of the Day | frond
abstract: This word has appeared in 191 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: frond •\ˈfränd\• noun

headline: A.F.C. Free Agency Preview
abstract: In the A.F.C., active teams in free agency could be the Dolphins, who need receivers; the Colts, who need offensive linemen; and the Jets, who need, well, almost everything.
lead_paragraph: In the A.F.C., active teams in free agency could be the Dolphins, who need receivers; the Colts, who need offensive linemen; and the Jets, who need, well, almost everything.

headline: The Hunt for N.F.L. Players Is About to Begin
abstract: When free agency opens, the market will be flush with quality veterans, albeit no boldface names. Here’s a look at what each team needs, which players they should keep and who might be better off in a new city.
lead_paragraph: Twelve months ago, the N.F.L. universe was waiting for Peyton Manning to pick his landing spot and for Andrew Luck and Robert Griffin III to find their first professional homes. It was one of the most transformative off-seasons in recent years. Those, though, happen rarely.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) FASHION STAR Thirteen aspiring fashion designers, including a team of two, display their wares for buyers from Macy’s, Saks Fifth Avenue and, new in this second season, Express. The buyers will bid — or not — on the right to carry the creations exclusively. After each episode viewers can buy the winning clothing as well. At the end of the season one designer (or designer pair) will receive $3 million in orders from the three retailers. Jessica Simpson, Nicole Richie and John Varvatos return as celebrity mentors; Louise Roe, replacing Elle Macpherson, who is an executive producer, joins the show as the host.

headline: App Smart Extra: Unusual Weather Apps
abstract: Reviewing some weather apps designed to be attractive and interesting.
lead_paragraph: This week in App Smart, I wrote about a rather unusual class: Weather prediction apps designed to be simple or beautiful, and almost the antithesis of a brash TV weather report. Unlike watching a weather report on TV or reading one in a paper, an app of this type places interactive weather data in your hands, and can even make learning about coming rain or windstorms a very interesting experience.

headline: News Quiz | March 8, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Nightmare Noir and Giddy Farce
abstract: “On Approval,” Clive Brook’s sole directorial effort, offers a rare screen glimpse of Beatrice Lillie; Fritz Lang’s “Ministry of Fear” recalls his earlier movies.
lead_paragraph: Ministry of Fear

headline: Long Island Landmark: Scary Since 1974
abstract: “My Amityville Horror,” a new documentary, adds to the library of books and films about a paranormal classic.
lead_paragraph: AMITYVILLE, N.Y. — It’s a splendid day for a stroll past a haunted house: dark, damp, forbidding. A thin mist rises like a mourner’s veil above the gambrel roof, and low-slung clouds bathe the grounds in perpetual gloom.

headline: After U.N. Vote on Sanctions, 2 Koreas Ratchet Up Threats
abstract: North Korea responded angrily to a decision to impose tightened sanctions, saying it was nullifying all nonaggression agreements with South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The governments of North and South Korea escalated their hostile warnings to the highest level in years on Friday, with each threatening to annihilate the other a day after the United Nations Security Council unanimously imposed tightened sanctions on the North for its nuclear test last month.

headline: Meet the Captain of India’s Women’s Cricket Team
abstract: Mithali Raj was encouraged by her father to drop classical dance for cricket.
lead_paragraph: When she was a child, Mithali Raj, the Indian women’s cricket team captain, trained in the art of Bharatanatyam, a genteel pastime for a proper young Indian girl. She loved performing and considered a career in dance.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 8
abstract: New sanctions for North Korea; Berlusconi convicted and sentenced to prison; Malaysian troops in Borneo kill 31 Filipino gunmen; and in rugby, the struggles of Les Bleus.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Ignoring threats of retaliation, the United Nations Security Council ordered new economic sanctions against North Korea on Thursday for its third nuclear test last month, unanimously approving a resolution that the United States negotiated with China, the North’s greatest protector. Rick Gladstone reports from New York, and David E. Sanger from Washington.

headline: Syrian Rebels Agree on Deal to Release Peacekeepers
abstract: Syrian rebels holding a group of peacekeepers from the Philippines in the Golan Heights region were pressing for a redeployment of Syrian government forces nearby, the Filipino authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations said Friday that an agreement had been reached to secure the release of the 21 Filipino peacekeepers seized two days earlier by Syrian insurgents in the disputed Golan Heights region between Syria and Israel. But it was unclear when the captives, the first international troops to become entangled in Syria’s civil war, would be freed.

headline: Cardinals’ Balloting for a New Pope Will Start on Tuesday
abstract: The princes of the Roman Catholic Church chose March 12 to begin secret voting for a successor to Benedict XVI, who set the transition in motion by resigning the papacy.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The identity of the new pope fuels enormous anticipation, but the next most breathlessly discussed topic here has been when the cardinals will actually get down to choosing him.

headline: With New Round of U.N. Sanctions, North Korea Threatens Pre-emptive Nuclear Strike
abstract: How are these sanctions stronger than previous sanctions?
lead_paragraph: In “U.N. Security Council Passes New Sanctions on North Korea,” Rick Gladstone and Choe Sang-Hun write about the new sanctions imposed on North Korea this week and the increasingly harsh words coming from that country’s leaders.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, March 8, 2013

headline: Kenya Race Is Said to Have Winner, but Rival Won’t Concede
abstract: Uhuru Kenyatta appeared to have secured enough votes to win the race for Kenya’s presidency by a narrow margin, but his opponent’s rejection of the result raised fears of chaos.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenya’s first president and a divisive political figure who has been accused of bankrolling death squads, appeared to have secured enough votes to win the race for Kenya’s presidency early Saturday. But no official announcement was made, and the other top contender indicated that he would not concede defeat, raising worries of violence and chaos.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A civilian contractor was killed on an American base Friday afternoon when three men wearing Afghan National Army uniforms stormed the gate and began firing, military officials said, in what appeared to be the second insider attack on Western troops this year.

headline: Is Europe Trying to Ban Pornography?
abstract: European legislation meant to protect women from degradation is being attacked by opponents as an encroachment on freedom of speech and expression.
lead_paragraph: Europeans don’t mind sunbathing topless or in the nude, in fact they rather enjoy it, and have for as long as anyone cares to remember. But if the European Parliament follows a recommendation soon to come before them, nudity of the sort you might see on a beach in Cannes could soon be illegal if it’s found on the Internet, construed as porn.

headline: Killings Stir Fears of Ethnic Tensions in Chinese Region

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At least four people were killed and eight injured in what appeared to be a knife fight in the city of Korla, a center of oil production in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, regional officials said on Friday.

headline: Daily Report: Government Takes Legal Action Over Phone Spam
