lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had recently filed eight lawsuits in federal courts around the country against companies it accused of ordering or engineering the sending of hundreds of millions of spam text messages to mobile phone users, Edward Wyatt reports on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: The Professor, the Bikini Model and the Suitcase Full of Trouble
abstract: A world-renowned physicist meets a gorgeous model online. They plan their perfect life together. But first, she asks, would he be so kind as to deliver a special package to her?
lead_paragraph: In November 2011, Paul Frampton, a theoretical particle physicist, met Denise Milani, a Czech bikini model, on the online dating site Mate1.com. She was gorgeous — dark-haired and dark-eyed, with a supposedly natural DDD breast size. In some photos, she looked tauntingly steamy; in others, she offered a warm smile. Soon, Frampton and Milani were chatting online nearly every day. Frampton would return home from campus — he’d been a professor in the physics and astronomy department at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for 30 years — and his computer would buzz. “Are you there, honey?” They’d chat on Yahoo Messenger for a while, and then he’d go into the other room to take care of something. A half-hour later, there was the familiar buzz. It was always Milani. “What are you doing now?”

headline: Q&A: Dumping the Windows Jump List
abstract: Microsoft’s Jump Lists feature in recent versions of Windows is intended to make life easier, but it can be turned off if you would rather not leave a trail of files you have recently used.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: After Caregiving, Comfort in Having Helped
abstract: After her brother and mother died, Karen Gurney felt as if a truck had been lifted off of her. Then she realized her purpose in life was gone.
lead_paragraph: Caregiving is so all-consuming, it can seem impossible to imagine life after, when all of those responsibilities are suddenly gone.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British insurance firm Esure set the price range for its pending initial public offering on Friday that could value the company at up to $2 billion.

headline: Easy ‘A’ on Bank Stress Tests?
abstract: The big question raised by some analysts was whether the Fed was too lenient in the so-called stress tests of banks. | Dell’s directors face an increasing challenge as they prepare to defend the proposed buyout of the computer maker. | The chief executive of Pandora Media said on Thursday that he would be leaving the Internet radio company. | Lawyers gathered in Las Vegas for the American Bar Association’s three-day White Collar Crime National Institute.
lead_paragraph: EASY ‘A’ ON BANK STRESS TESTS?  |  Federal regulators found that banks, four years after the financial crisis, are better prepared to weather future financial shocks, according to the results of the so-called stress tests that the Federal Reserve released on Thursday. But the big question raised by some analysts was whether the Fed was too lenient in the tests, which now pave the way for the healthiest institutions to return money to shareholders, DealBook’s Peter Eavis and Ben Protess write.

headline: Friday Reading: Subaru Recalls Cars That Could Start Themselves
abstract: Subaru recalls cars that could start themselves, keeping knee arthritis in check, a test run of Facebook’s new News Feed and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Seats of Power
abstract: Sebastian Brajkovic deconstructs the historical elements of his tables, chairs and lamps while giving them a surreal, extruded quality that is only possible with high-tech machinery.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch designer Sebastian Brajkovic deconstructs the historical elements of his tables, chairs and lamps while giving them a surreal, extruded quality that is only possible with high-tech machinery. He was barely out of school when pieces from his Lathe furniture series began to appear at design fairs and in the collections of major museums. The furniture, inspired by Brajkovic’s childhood interest in things that turned, like reel-to-reel tape decks, is the subject of an exhibition that opens on March 18 on the European campus of the Savannah College of Art and Design in Lacoste, France. Several of his pieces are available for purchase through the Carpenters Workshop Gallery in London and Paris.

headline: Where is India’s Feminist Movement Headed?
abstract: Feminism in India is grappling with new problems as vast economic and social changes sweep the country, while old mindsets steeped in patriarchy still prevail
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 28, 2012, the sarpanch, or the elected head of the village council, of Singar village in rural Haryana, his nephew and two other men allegedly abducted a 15-year-old girl. According to the official complaint, The Hindu reported, the four men beat her up and then took turns repeatedly raping her.

headline: Unemployment at 4-Year Low as U.S. Hiring Gains Steam
abstract: The joblessness rate sank to 7.7 percent as 236,000 positions were added across a broad range of sectors, but analysts warned that federal budget cuts could slow the recovery.
lead_paragraph: The economy picked up speed in February, creating jobs at a pace that would substantially lower the unemployment rate. But Washington could put a stop to that.

headline: Istanbul Museum Stroll: At the Pera

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL—Many of the artists whose works are being shown at the Pera Museum these days might say they owed a debt of gratitude to the 75-year-old cubist painter Muhanna Durra of Jordan.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: New Ways to Swap E-Content and Time Warner’s Spinoff Trend
abstract: Apple and Amazon are trying to make it possible for Web consumers to swap content on a grand scale, Time Warner’s spinoff of Time Inc. is the latest evidence of a strategy of divestment, and Facebook’s redesign strategy is already popular with advertisers.
lead_paragraph: Apple and Amazon, the two largest purveyors of digital media, are working to create a kind of online swap meet where consumers can exchange music, movies or e-books, David Streitfeld writes. Buyers basically rent iTunes songs or Kindle books under the current system, with no way to transfer the content. The exchanges would allow users to trade content without reproducing it — when a song is traded, it disappears from its original owner’s library. Publishers and music companies are against this kind of trading, as they believe it could devalue their products, while libraries, which have not been able to dispense e-books very openly, are generally in favor.

headline: Wunderman, Big WPP Agency, Gets a Major Makeover
abstract: Wunderman, one of the largest agencies inside the WPP agency holding company empire, is being overhauled to better respond to the significant shifts in how marketers are seeking to reach consumers.
lead_paragraph: Wunderman, one of the largest agencies inside the WPP agency holding company empire, is being overhauled to better respond, executives say, to the significant shifts in how marketers are seeking to reach consumers.

headline: The Gun Report: March 8, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Senate Judiciary Committee passed a bill that would make it a felony for someone to illegally buy a gun on someone else’s behalf. Stunningly—at least to me—only one Republican senator supported the bill, Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa. Here’s what I don’t understand: how can this bill be even remotely controversial? “Straw purchasing,” as it is called, is usually needed by people whose history—a criminal record, perhaps?—would make it impossible for them to pass a background check. Are Republicans really taking the position that convicted felons should be able to buy guns through intermediaries? What am I missing here?

headline: From the Department of Things That Are Just Too Perfect
abstract: Dowist destinies.
lead_paragraph: Limited time this morning, so light blogging. But I can’t resist posting this. Jonathan Chait finds James K. Glassman, co-author of “Dow 36,000″ — a 1999 book that argued, based on some creative double-counting and other innovations, that 36,000 was the right value of the Dow at the time of publication — claiming that this week’s Dow high vindicates his ideas. But that’s not what’s so perfect.

abstract: It’s not enough to retire. Now players like Mariano Rivera are announcing that they will announce that they will retire.
lead_paragraph: It seems we have entered a new era in athlete retirements. It has suddenly become boring to have a news conference to say your career is finished. No, now the in thing is to have a news conference to announce the impending retirement. Or even more humorously, “leak” to the news media that you are having a news conference on Saturday to announce your retirement after the season, as the Yankees’ Mariano Rivera has.

headline: At the S.E.C., a Revolving Door That Helps the Public
abstract: The so-called revolving door between private sector and government posts has several positive implications, and it means that law enforcement officials have some first-hand knowledge of how the industry they regulate works, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.Both Mary Jo White, President Obama’s nominee for chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and her likely enforcement deputy, Andrew J. Ceresney, had lucrative careers as white-collar criminal defense lawyers after leaving their jobs as federal prosecutors in Manhattan. Now that it appears that they are likely to rejoin the government, people have wondered, here and elsewhere, whether we should worry about picking law enforcement officials from the ranks of those whose résumés include stints prosecuting and defending the same sorts of people.

headline: The Unequal Time Rule
abstract: Some sectarian attacks in Pakistan get media attention, others don’t, and the difference means getting a political reaction, or not.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Sunday a bombing in Abbas Town, a predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Karachi, killed 48 people and injured almost 200. Although it was just the latest incident in a sinister trend of sectarian violence in Pakistan, the attack prompted a swifter political response.

headline: Solar Cells May Supplement Smartphone Batteries
abstract: Solar cells under development by a Silicon Valley start-up, Alta Devices, could give smartphone batteries a boost of as much as 80 percent of a battery’s power. The company uses hybrid gallium arsenide solar cells, which are better at capturing energy than silicon solar cells.
lead_paragraph: Why don’t power-thirsty smartphones incorporate solar cells, to reduce the reliance on batteries? Because in general, the kind of solar cell that can be fabricated in a lightweight, flexible and durable form does not capture enough energy per square inch to make it worthwhile.

lead_paragraph: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment on Friday morning in federal court in Manhattan, where he was charged with conspiring to kill Americans.

headline: Focus on the Family Works to Change Its Message
abstract: Under the leadership of Jim Daly, the evangelical group has tried to be less divisive and invite civil dialogue with its religious and ideological foes.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — One Wednesday afternoon last month, Jim Daly drove a couple of miles from his office at Focus on the Family to a classroom building on the University of Colorado’s local campus. Short as the trip was, it carried Mr. Daly beyond his theological and political comfort zone. Such disorientation was the whole point.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — As Wernher von Braun, the rocket scientist, used to say, the most overwhelming obstacle to exploring the cosmos isn’t gravity. It’s the paperwork.

headline: Dignitaries Pay Chávez Tribute, as Venezuelans Express Grief and Misgivings
abstract: The funeral was a stunning display of the political alliances that President Hugo Chávez assembled while in power, including some of those with a history of difficult relations with Washington.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — While dignitaries from around the world attended the funeral of Hugo Chávez on Friday, Angélica Rodríguez stood in a line that stretched close to a mile in hopes of getting a glimpse of him lying in state. But her older brother, Gustavo, was much farther away, geographically and politically, having moved to Panama over a year ago because he believed there was no future in a Venezuela run by Mr. Chávez.

headline: Storm Damage Prompts Return of Old Subway Stop
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, in an unusual move, has decided to reopen the former South Ferry subway station because repairs to the new station there will take years.
lead_paragraph: Over its nearly 109 years, the New York subway system has inspired many questions. Why do pigeons ride the A train in Queens? What becomes of a failed MetroCard swipe, curdling at the turnstiles?

headline: Open Arms for Daring Dance
abstract: Yasuko Yokoshi, as the first artist to participate in the New York Live Arts resident commissioned artist program, will present her new piece, “Bell.”
lead_paragraph: What is New York Live Arts? That’s been a question in the dance world since an announcement in late 2010 that Dance Theater Workshop, a cherished institution that had been presenting and supporting experimental artists for 45 years, was merging with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. New York Live Arts became the name of the hybrid.

headline: Common Core Practice | Environmental Issues in the Humanities Classroom
abstract: This week: wildlife smuggling, the North Korean crab business, and the fossilized remains of a giant camel — along with an invitation to find environmental stories that compel you.
lead_paragraph: As regular readers know, our partner for this series is a ninth-grade humanities class at a high school in New Jersey recognized as one of the top S.T.E.M. schools in the nation.

headline: A Senate of Prostitutes? Now That’s Opera!
abstract: Gotham Chamber Opera’s production of Francesco Cavalli’s 1667 opera “Eliogabalo,” about the most flamboyant of Roman emperors, is being staged inside the most flamboyant of New York nightspots.
lead_paragraph: Heliogabalus was a third-century teenage Roman emperor who dressed in women’s clothes and prostituted himself in the imperial palace, appointed an all-female senate and put a dancer in charge of the praetorian guard. According to the historian Lampridius, he traveled with 600 chariots “full of his male prostitutes, bawds, harlots and lusty partners in depravity” and referred to one blond charioteer, Hierocles, as his husband. He also married and divorced five women. When he was 18 and had ruled for nearly four years, he was murdered by his own guard.

abstract: Why are tens of millions of people gathering by the Ganges?
lead_paragraph: Why are tens of millions of people gathering by the Ganges?

headline: A Public Apology for My Sofa
abstract: Allow me to explain why we left that couch outside our door for two weeks in 1995.
lead_paragraph: Dear Residents of 208 East 7th Street: Sorry for leaving that couch outside our door on the fourth-floor stairwell for two weeks.

headline: Should I Pay for a Gas-Station Attendant’s Mistake?
abstract: The difference between what is reasonable and what is “right.”
lead_paragraph: When I go to the local gas station, I always give the attendant $20 and request that he provide me with that specific value of fuel (which always changes because of fluctuating gas prices). I repeat my request three times and show the attendant the $20 in my hand. During a recent visit, I glanced over to the pump to see that the attendant had made a mistake and exceeded our $20 agreement. I beeped my horn and waved my arms. Once I got out of my car, he came forward and realized his error. Because the amount of $20 was stated before the gas being pumped, should I stand my ground and agree to pay only $20? Or should I pay the difference (because I will obviously use the extra gas at some point in the future)? VINCENT MAZZOLLA, NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J.

headline: The 2.24.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE EXTRAORDINARY SCIENCE OF ADDICTIVE JUNK FOOD

headline: Harmony Korine’s Spring-Break Intentions Are Pure
abstract: The director on naked cavorting in Florida and why he wants to be Clint Eastwood.
lead_paragraph: You actually used real spring breakers in your new film, “Spring Breakers,” about a group of young women who commit armed robbery, do drugs and get into trouble. Did you feel like it was wrong to be filming these people half your age, cavorting naked?  I never really feel wrong while making movies. I know myself and I know that my intentions are pure and I’m on the side of righteousness.

headline: Who Made That Fishing Lure?
abstract: Plus: The bumblebee in the tackle box and the best way to attract a fish.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, word spread of a fishing lure with seemingly mystical powers. In the lake country of Finland, an artisan named Lauri Rapala had handcrafted artificial minnows out of balsa wood that zipped around with realistic movements. Life magazine described the product as “a lure fish can’t pass up.” Desperate to obtain the lures, anglers in America hunted for a way to buy them, usually with no luck. Imports were few, and bait shops often required a $20 deposit (about $160 in today’s dollars) to rent a Rapala lure for the day.

headline: Sons of Opera Moms Go Far Afield
abstract: The jazz musicians Ben Wendel and Dan Tepfer are releasing their first album as a duo, “Small Constructions,” which includes original compositions along with a songbook standard, a Handel variation and choice material by Thelonious Monk and Lennie Tristano.
lead_paragraph: On the closing track of their new album, “Small Constructions,” Ben Wendel and Dan Tepfer switch instruments, improvising a dialogue from scratch. That exercise in uncertainty revealed something essential about the personalities of Mr. Tepfer, a pianist by training, and Mr. Wendel, usually a saxophonist.

headline: Tenor From the Dark Side of the Moon
abstract: Saimir Pirgu, an Albanian who made his Metropolitan Opera debut in 2009 in Puccini’s “Gianni Schicchi,” returns this week in Verdi’s “Traviata.”
lead_paragraph: “This is the house of God. You can’t turn me away.”

headline: The Rise of Part-Time Work
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Working Hours']
abstract: The economy is nowhere near recovering the jobs lost in the recession, and the record looks even worse because so many jobs lost were full time, while so many of those gained have been part time.
lead_paragraph: One of the more unsettling trends in this recovery has been the rise of part-time work.

headline: One Hundred Seconds of Solitude
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: At writers colonies like MacDowell and Yaddo, e-connections threaten to defeat the purpose of artistic retreat.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I found myself in a cabin in the snow-­dusted New Hampshire woods of the MacDowell Colony working on a book that’s due in few enough months to cause concern. It was a four-week residency, and wildly productive: without social distractions, the Internet or even decent cellphone reception, I churned out pages in record time, hitting and then exceeding my regular word count on a daily basis.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Fifty years ago, the Book Review was shuttered during a four-month newspaper strike — but the best-seller list rolled on.
lead_paragraph: STRIKE I: Fifty years ago this week, there was no New York Times Book Review — there was, indeed, no proper New York Times at all, as the 1963 newspaper strike was limping to the end of its four-month run. When the Book Review returned on April 7 of that year, its front cover featured a cartoon of a despondent bearded man slumped in an armchair, his concerned wife soothing him: “Cheer up, Harry. You’re not the only author who came out during the strike.” And he wasn’t: the first quarter of 1963 saw the arrival of big books from Günter Grass (“The Tin Drum”), Betty Friedan (“The Feminine Mystique”), Anthony Burgess (“A Clockwork Orange”) and Alexander Solzhenitsyn (“One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich”), among many others. The Book Review did what it could to catch up — all four of those books received respectful reviews in the April 7 issue, and both “The Tin Drum” and “The Feminine Mystique” went on to become hardcover best sellers. But Burgess and Solzhenitsyn had to defer their gratification. “A Clockwork Orange” finally turned up on the paperback fiction list in 1972, after Stanley Kubrick had turned it into a hit movie. And Solzhenitsyn (like Grass) eventually won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: STICKS AND STONES: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy,  by Emily Bazelon. (Random House, $27.) This intelligent study presents profiles of affected children and synthesizes current scholarship.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE MAN WITHIN MY HEAD,  by Pico Iyer. (Vintage, $15.) This is a deeply felt meditation on the dual influences Iyer’s father and Graham Greene exerted upon him. Iyer, a novelist, essayist and travel writer, follows Greene’s trail from his first novel, “The Man Within,” to classics like “The Quiet American,” exploring ideas of love, faith and divided identity.

headline: In Praise of Rivera, What’s the Limit?
abstract: If baseball fans can agree that Mariano Rivera is the best closer in baseball history and therefore the best reliever in baseball history, can one make the case that he is the best pitcher in history?
lead_paragraph: As Tyler Kepner writes of Yankees closer Mariano Rivera, who is expected to announce his retirement on Saturday, it is the postseason that has distinguished him from every other reliever, before or since: “His regular-season earned run average is 2.21. His postseason E.R.A. — in 96 games against the best competition, under the most pressure — is 0.70.”

headline: Rising Stars
abstract: In two middle-grade novels, boys pursue a passion for show business.
lead_paragraph: At first glance the protagonists of these two middle-grade novels, “Better Nate Than Ever” and “I Represent Sean Rosen,” have a lot in common: they’re both 13-year-old boys; they both have blue-collar parents and white-collar aspirations; they both have intelligent and original voices; and they’re both in the process of doggedly pursing their life’s passion to be in show business. And yet. . . .

headline: Two Against the World
abstract: This novel’s title characters are an unlikely couple.
lead_paragraph: When I began reading contemporary fiction in high school, I remember feeling that each book was an absolute revelation. Whether I was reading Michael Crichton or Amy Tan or Tom Robbins, there had never been anything like it before in my life. The novel’s novelty passes, of course. I’m 35 now. I’ve read a dozen “we brought back the dinosaurs and they are mad” books. I’ve seen the conventions, and I’ve seen them interrogated.

headline: South Side Story
abstract: A man vanishes in Chicago, and his family struggles to survive.
lead_paragraph: Langston Hughes’s poem “Dreams” inspired the title of Blue Balliett’s “Hold Fast,” which opens with clear signals of the distress to come — and of the effort people require to stay hopeful through hardship. Before the novel even begins, Balliett offers dictionary definitions of the words “home,” “lost” and “time,” as well as a brief, sobering statement about the thousands of homeless children in Chicago. She also describes a 2003 diamond heist, at the time the biggest in history, in which the thieves were caught but the gems never found. All these elements play a part in the story that lies ahead.

headline: That’s Life?
abstract: A search for hidden organisms finds some that thrive in extreme conditions, and some that may live only in the imagination.
lead_paragraph: It's life, Jim, but not as we know it. The familiar phrase, apocryphally attributed to “Star Trek,” encapsulates David Toomey’s study of the search for species flourishing in places where life was thought to be insupportable. “Weird Life” is a breakneck tour through natural history, encounters of an impossible kind, researchers as weird as the organisms they pursue that leads the reader to wonder where science ends and fantasy begins.

headline: You’re Special
abstract: Three picture books explore the theme of individuality.
lead_paragraph: How odd, I sometimes think, that so many picture books aimed at our youngest readers emphasize the same theme. “You are special,” they inform us in voices loud and soft. “Celebrate your individuality, your uniqueness, your youness!” The message is a fine one, I suppose, but I can’t help wondering if the constant refrain contains a wee bit of adult projection. After all, the problem among young children is rarely that of mindless conformity. As all parents know, toddlers and early readers do not conform nearly enough, certainly not at mealtime. Or bath time. Or, really, any time.

headline: Prayers for the Dying
abstract: Kent Haruf continues his cycle of novels set in the high plains of Colorado, where a close-knit community is pushed to the brink.
lead_paragraph: A novelist once told me that he had given up writing journalism on the side because “in journalism they only let you tell one story: Something Has Changed.”

headline: Brides Revisited
abstract: It’s difficult to make marriage in the movies interesting, Jeanine Basinger’s survey argues.
lead_paragraph: One morning recently, for 37 minutes, my husband talked to me about light bulbs: how their life expectancy is woefully overcalculated, why they have become so expensive, how the new “efficient” models are a cunning plot by manufacturers to make us spend still more. Knowing this would not even be the most boring conversation I’d face that day, I nodded and tried to look interested. At some point it occurred to me that if I were to make a movie about marriage, its title might well be: “Nodding and Trying to Look Interested.”

headline: Home and Exile
abstract: Taiye Selasi’s first novel follows a splintered Ghanaian-Nigerian family across continents and generations.
lead_paragraph: “Ambitious” is one of those words that shift shape as they cross the Atlantic, as Taiye Selasi is certainly aware. Born in London of Nigerian and Ghanaian parents, and raised in Massachusetts, Selasi has written an ambitious first novel — and I mean that in the best, American sense of the word.

headline: Bodies for Hire
abstract: “The Boyfriend,” by Thomas Perry, is a thriller about a retired homicide detective investigating a series of unsolved murders of high-priced prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: Thriller fans are not to be trifled with. We know what we want — clever protagonists, cunning killers, white-knuckle action and endlessly inventive variations on the fundamental strategies of a deadly cat-and-mouse game.

headline: First Dibs on Warhol’s Photographs
abstract: American pop art history without the million-dollar commitment: Andy Warhol photographs go to auction online next Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Love Knots
abstract: On a trans-Atlantic cruise, a former psychic examines the tricky deceptions of magic, relationships and language itself.
lead_paragraph: We don’t, in America, have any writers quite like the Scottish novelist A. L. Kennedy. Her nearest local relative, perhaps, is Richard Ford in his Bascombe novels, with that funny, dark, vituperative voice that serves equally well for tragic and comic moments. Ford, though, possesses an underlying conviction about continuity — of character, of place, of history — while in Kennedy’s world everything is up for grabs, all the time. One might view her work as surreal, if that didn’t imply a divorce from our own felt reality; one might call her sensibility ironic, except she’s profoundly attached to what she describes. Kennedy’s novels repeatedly take on dark subjects (alcoholism, familial despair, sexual betrayal, loneliness), but they do so in a chatty, engaging manner that can sometimes make you laugh out loud. I wasn’t surprised to learn that she has a sideline as a stand-up comic — though, again, this isn’t something a serious American novelist would do. And A. L. Kennedy is as serious as they get.

headline: Image of the Day: March 8
abstract: A female gymnast performs a stunt in Mumbai on International Women’s Day.

headline: Well, Cheerio, Old Bean
abstract: The collected letters — many previously unpublished — of the great comic writer P. G. Wodehouse.
lead_paragraph: By most measures, P. G. Wodehouse, arguably the greatest writer of comic prose ever, hardly had a life. That was what enabled him to be so productive. In the course of his very long career, he published close to 100 books, worked on more than 30 Broadway shows, put in a couple of highly paid stints as a Hollywood screenwriter and corresponded with practically anyone who sent him mail. Writing and doting over his beloved Pekingese lapdogs was pretty much all he did.

headline: Shaky Foundations
abstract: In Ann Leary’s novel, an alcoholic real estate agent pretends to be sober, with disastrous consequences.
lead_paragraph: In Wendover, Mass., a “regular” is a coffee with cream and two sugars. “Wicked” generally means “very.” And the word “townie” is not an insult, but a badge of honor.

headline: Nasty Bits
abstract: In Herman Koch’s novel, two Dutch couples struggle with the hardest decision of their lives — over the course of one meal.
lead_paragraph: North American readers care inordinately that fictional characters be likable. This preference is strange, given that few real people are thoroughly nice and that those few aren’t interesting. Surely what actually matters is that characters clear this vital hurdle: that they be interesting.

headline: That Old-Time Irreligion
abstract: The 19th-century freethinker Robert Ingersoll drew crowds with his brilliant oratory.
lead_paragraph: Susan Jacoby, whose previous books include “Freethinkers” and “The Age of American Unreason,” begins “The Great Agnostic” by asking why some people famous in their own time become part of our national memory and others fade into oblivion. A case in point is the orator Robert Green Ingersoll: a celebrity in his heyday at the end of the 19th century, he is almost utterly unknown today, even by those who would admire him if they knew more.

headline: Brooklyn’s New Gentrification Frontiers
abstract: Buyers and renters in search of affordability and ambience are moving into parts of Brooklyn that were once considered out of the way.
lead_paragraph: The subway commute to Manhattan is longer, and organic markets and stylish boutiques are fewer. But those are the trade-offs as the search for more affordable real estate in Brooklyn pushes deeper into neighborhoods that for some New Yorkers still evoke images of burned-out buildings, riots and poverty.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Young and the Restless
abstract: In tour-de-force performances, James McAvoy is a war-traumatized Macbeth and Kate O’Flynn is a girl aching to flee her bleak hometown in “Port.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A cruel virus is gnawing at the entrails of James McAvoy, who is delivering a star turn that sears in the title role of Jamie Lloyd’s production of “Macbeth” at Trafalgar Studios. Among the symptoms: coughing, vomiting, gagging, falling down while hallucinating and smiling in the midst of dire situations, as if at some torturous private joke.

headline: The Shrinking Government
abstract: The job market is expanding, and now even construction jobs are growing. But the dark spot remains government employment. Its continued decline set a post-World War II record in February.
lead_paragraph: For the 31st consecutive month, the number of government jobs in February was less than it had been a year earlier. There is an employment recovery, but it is confined to the private sector.

headline: Mar. 10 — 16
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: The Foxy Lady Packs a Wallop

headline: Adding Absurdity to Tragedy
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Sixty thousand dead from drug-related violence in Mexico. One memorial. No visitors.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — It’s one of the trendiest, most expensive and nicest pieces of land around. It’s in Polanco, the city’s most expensive neighborhood, and on a corner of Paseo de la Reforma, the capital’s most important avenue. Less than two kilometers away from the president’s residence and just five blocks from Masaryk Street, our own Park Avenue. It occupies 1,500 square meters of Chapultepec, the park in the middle of Mexico City.

headline: Ras al-Khaimah, the Quiet Emirate
abstract: Ras al-Khaimah, the northernmost of the United Arab Emirates, stands out for its traditionalism and history.
lead_paragraph: On a blistering day in Ras al-Khaimah, I hiked a small, winding staircase to reach an ancient fort, sun hat no match for the rays that beat down, mercilessly. At the top, I rested my legs and took in the valley below where green date palm farms stretched to meet jagged brown and black mountain crags.

headline: Coughlin Makes ‘Daily Show’ Appearance
abstract: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin appeared on Jon Stewart’s “The Daily Show” to promote his new book.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Show with Jon StewartGet More: Daily Show Full Episodes,Political Humor & Satire Blog,The Daily Show on Facebook

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Jeanine Basinger discusses marriage in the movies; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Charles McGrath talks about the letters of P. G. Wodehouse; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jeanine Basinger discusses marriage in the movies; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Charles McGrath talks about the letters of P. G. Wodehouse; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Off the Charts: A Dow Record, if You Ignore Inflation
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks rose to a new record this week, but is still below its 2000 and 2007 highs when adjusted for inflation.
lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks rose to a new record this week, but is still below its 2000 and 2007 highs when adjusted for inflation.

headline: Do You Pay the Baby Sitter if You Cancel?
abstract: This scheduled baby sitter turns down other work to be there for this family, and she counts on the income. So what happens when the parents cancel?
lead_paragraph: Once in a while, everyone cancels on the sitter (and once in a while, the sitter cancels on us). This week’s quandary: If you cancel on the sitter, should you pay her for her time, and how and when? “I baby-sit this wonderful 2-year-old once a week,” the questioner wrote. “There have been issues in the past where they’ve canceled on short notice (12 hours, and there was an emergency) and I’ve been really accommodating.”

headline: On Set | Matthias Schoenaerts
abstract: With a string of movies on the docket, one of Hollywood’s men of the moment kicks back with T.
lead_paragraph: With a string of movies on the docket, one of Hollywood’s men of the moment kicks back with T.

headline: A Long Road Back for the Dow Industrials
abstract: When adjusted for changes in consumer prices, the Dow Jones industrial average remains nearly 10 percent below the nominal record set in 2007, but the real peak was in 2000.
lead_paragraph: MORE than five years after the stock market began to slide in the fall of 2007, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered all of the ground lost in the recession and rose to new highs this week.

headline: A State Backs Guns in Class for Teachers
abstract: South Dakota became the first state to enact a law explicitly authorizing school employees to carry guns on the job, under a measure signed Friday by Gov. Dennis Daugaard.
lead_paragraph: South Dakota became the first state in the nation to enact a law explicitly authorizing school employees to carry guns on the job, under a measure signed into law on Friday by Gov. Dennis Daugaard.

headline: The Case of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith
abstract: The Times’s Mark Mazzetti discusses the details behind the capture and arraignment of Osama bin Laden’s son-in-law.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Mark Mazzetti discusses the details behind the capture and arraignment of Osama bin Laden’s son-in-law.

headline: Disney Stars Throw Off Their Past in ‘Spring Breakers’
abstract: Selena Gomez and Vanessa Hudgens are trying to transition out of children’s entertainment, perhaps Hollywood’s trickiest professional maneuver.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Selena Gomez got her start in “Barney & Friends” and became a cherub-cheeked teen idol on “Wizards of Waverly Place,” a Disney Channel series that has its final hurrah on Friday. But Ms. Gomez was not at a trendy hotel here to discuss Disney. (Eye roll: As if.) On her mind was her new movie — a druggy, violent, hypersexualized tale of innocence squashed called"Spring Breakers.”

headline: Environmental Expo Coming to MoMA PS1
abstract: The festival’s centerpiece is “Dark Optimism,” a show by about 35 contemporary artists based on the notion that we are on the brink of both the apocalypse and a technological transformation that promises a brighter future.
lead_paragraph: Klaus Biesenbach, the chief curator at large at the Museum of Modern Art, and the director of MoMA PS1, the museum’s outpost in Long Island City, will devote the next six months to EXPO 1: New York, a sprawling exploration of the current state of the environment  and social and political change.

headline: The Male Bond
abstract: A woman may represent a man’s better half, but his friends are his other self. Whether they involve arguing, competing or doing nothing much at all, male friendships are elemental — and a salve to the soul.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Gosh, We’re Bad Now!
abstract: There was once a long arc from newfound fame to scandal and disgrace, but now the fallen teen idol embodies potential and letdown all at once.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering night in Florida four bikini-clad girls sit outside a restaurant, drinking and smoking and singing“... Baby One More Time,” Britney Spears’s salacious 1998 debut single and theme song for aspiring femmes fatales everywhere.

headline: How to Stop a Home Invasion When the Intruder Has Four Legs
abstract: Wildlife experts say that how you address the problem depends on the extent of the invasion. And once the animal is gone, you need to figure out how it got into your house.
lead_paragraph: A FEW weeks ago, around 3 a.m., we heard some glass knocked over downstairs. In a daze — and not wanting to get out of bed — I thought it was our cats fooling around. But my older son, who was closer to the action, raced upstairs shouting that a raccoon was sitting on the mantle.

headline: Money Advice for People in Boom-or-Bust Fields
abstract: Some professions have tendencies as a group that can benefit from being managed, for example, oil and gas and professional sports.
lead_paragraph: MORE financial advisers are focusing on a single clientele, say, doctors or athletes. That would seem to make sense, since concentrating on a single group of people gives advisers greater insight into the needs of those people. And if the advisers do a good job, they will get that client’s colleagues as clients.

headline: A Freaky Fund-Raiser for a Storm-Ravaged Freak Show
abstract: Insectavora the fire-eater and Serpentina the 6-foot-tall snake charmer will perform Saturday at Webster Hall for Sideshows by the Seashore in Coney Island, which sustained nearly $400,000 in damage from Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Sideshows by the Seashore in Coney Island — home to some of New York City’s finest sword swallowers and contortionists — was battered last fall by Hurricane Sandy, as water from the ocean and from Coney Island Creek inundated its gift shop, its theater and its on-site watering hole, the Freak Bar, causing nearly $400,000 in damage.

headline: New Defense Chief Visits ‘Reality of Combat’ in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In his first overseas trip as defense secretary, Chuck Hagel landed Friday in Afghanistan, where 66,000 American troops continue to experience what he described as “the heat of battle.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In his first overseas trip as defense secretary, Chuck Hagel landed on Friday in Afghanistan, a country fast fading from political debate and public interest at home, but where 66,000 American troops continue to experience what he described as “the ugly reality of combat and the heat of battle.”

headline: Ready to Share a Life of Front-Page News
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Vows (Times Column)']
abstract: Cynthia May Chessman and Michael Morton met after a church meeting, but she had been praying for his release from prison for years.
lead_paragraph: KILGORE, Tex. — Michael Morton and Cynthia May Chessman politely told the approximately 200 guests invited to their wedding on Saturday to resist giving them gifts. Instead, they asked relatives and friends to donate to the Innocence Project, the nonprofit group founded at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University that uses DNA evidence to free the wrongfully convicted from prison.

headline: London’s Odd and Empty Corners
abstract: A wanderer in the city comes upon museums, houses and bookstores, and has many of them to himself.
lead_paragraph: “You know, guv, that really gets on my goat,” Billy Allardyce said from the front of the taxi, his amplified voice a warble of Abbey Road reverb.

headline: New Mexico Confronts Drunken Driving
abstract: A proposal would bar New Mexicans convicted of drunken driving, who already have to breathe into a device to start their ignitions, from buying alcohol.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — For years, New Mexico has had one of the highest rates of alcohol-related traffic deaths in the nation. And during each legislative session, it seems, lawmakers wrestle with how to make the state’s highways and rural roads safer, usually spurred by the latest horrific accident.

headline: She Set the Job Requirements; He Got Hired
abstract: “I thought I should look at it like a job interview,” she said. “I should have that kind of quality control for a man I invited into my life.”
lead_paragraph: The ad that appeared in the Personals section of Craigslist in February 2008 contained a list of its own, a long one: requirements for anyone wishing to go out with Jessica Delfino, a comedian and singer in New York.

headline: The Obamas Hosted the Clintons at the White House
abstract: President Obama and Michelle Obama, the first lady, had their first double date with Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, over dinner at the White House last Friday.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has been quite the social butterfly lately, dining with Senate Republicans and hosting bipartisan lunches. Now comes word that the president and the first lady had their first double date with Bill Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, over dinner at the White House last Friday.

headline: The Headache in Housewares for J.C. Penney
abstract: A marketing deal between J. C. Penney and Martha Stewart, the subject of a court battle this week, offers a window into the management skills of the company’s chief executive, Ron Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Ron Johnson, the former head of retail at Apple and now the chief executive of J. C. Penney, testified this week that he’d never ask anyone to breach a contract. He said he believed in “perfect integrity” as “a matter of principle,” and he readily agreed with the premise that “it’s important to honor contracts even if the terms are unlikable at the time.”

headline: Gridlock Plagues the New Online-Only SimCity
abstract: Electronic Arts’s new SimCity requires an online connection, even for the private single-player mode, and so far this week its servers haven’t been up to the task.
lead_paragraph: Releasing a video game that paying customers can’t play is about as consumer-friendly as selling the next Jonathan Franzen novel exclusively on the moon. But that’s what Electronic Arts accidentally did this week with SimCity, an attempted revitalization of its 24-year-old franchise of city-building strategy games.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Matrimony in the Movies
abstract: Jeanine Basinger discusses her book “I Do and I Don’t,” a history of Hollywood’s portrayal of marriage.
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Judith Newman reviews “I Do and I Don’t,” Jeanine Basinger’s new book about the history of marriage in the movies. Ms. Newman writes:

headline: Singled Out (for the Single Supplement)
abstract: Solo travelers, long resigned to paying more because they’re traveling alone, are starting to find some relief.
lead_paragraph: Single supplement.

headline: Fatal Fiscal Attractions
abstract: Deficit scoldery makes for careless economics.
lead_paragraph: Oh, my. David Greenlaw, James Hamilton, Peter Hooper, and Rick Mishkin have published an op-ed in the WSJ (where else?) based on their recent paper on debt, deficits, and interest rate spreads. They really shouldn’t have — the argument in that paper collapsed under scrutiny almost the moment it was released.

headline: A Journey Into Films, Beginning at a Bronx Community Center
abstract: Side Street: Alex Barrios, featured in “The We and the I,” a movie by Michel Gondry, is taking life step by step. “I got my foot in the door,” he said. “Now it’s about how you walk through.”
lead_paragraph: After three weeks in upstate New York, Alex Barrios was excited about coming back to the city. The sight of the Empire State Building, its shiny spire peeking over the jagged suburban landscape, set his heart racing.

headline: In the End, No Substitute for Anthony
abstract: The Knicks had a chance to steal a game from the Thunder, but ended up a point short without their injured leading scorer.
lead_paragraph: With Carmelo Anthony injured, out of the lineup and unable to carry them through crunch time, the Knicks had an opportunity to explore a few alternatives on offense in the final minutes of their 1-point loss to the Oklahoma City Thunder on Thursday night.

headline: The Small Picture: Working Nights
abstract: Inside the trailer might be warmer, but outside, Steven Lawrence of Fried & Fabulous can approach people to offer free samples, a sales pitch and maybe a joke.
lead_paragraph: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: Noise Clash in Gowanus Pits New Hotel Against Arts Building’s Drummers
abstract: A Marriott hotel that opened in 2011 complains that the Gowanus Arts Building, which opened in 1985, is responsible for sounds that disturb its guests.
lead_paragraph: The Gowanus Arts Building and the Fairfield Inn & Suites, neighbors in a fast-changing industrial corner of Brooklyn, are separated by only the hotel’s parking lot.

headline: ‘Harlem Shake’ and the New Meaning of No. 1
abstract: For the third week running, Baauer’s trap novelty “Harlem Shake” takes the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, largely because of the magazine’s new tabulating system that takes into account Youtube views. Jon Caramanica talks with host Ben Ratliff about trap, listening, appropriation, memory, impotent rage and disembodied dance crazes.
lead_paragraph: For the third week running, Baauer’s trap novelty “Harlem Shake” takes the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, largely because of the magazine’s new tabulating system that takes into account Youtube views. Jon Caramanica talks with host Ben Ratliff about trap, listening, appropriation, memory, impotent rage and disembodied dance crazes.

headline: Will He Retire? Rivera Won’t Say, Yet
abstract: The Yankees’ star closer spoke briefly with reporters as he walked to his car, but wouldn’t reveal what he would say at a news conference scheduled for Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. – Mariano Rivera went through a normal workout Friday and said he was ready to pitch Saturday, but didn’t give any indication about his other planned activity for that day: announcing his retirement.

headline: Does This Ad Make Me Fat?
abstract: We could reduce obesity by finding its causes, but that isn’t so easy.
lead_paragraph: OBESITY is a problem everywhere, with significant consequences for personal health and public spending. People weigh more than ever — but why? If we can find the causes of obesity, we can try to eliminate or counter them.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Austin, Tex.; London; Eisenach, Germany
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Moontower Comedy and Oddity Festival, Austin, Tex. Not too long after recovering from the hangover left by the commercial debauchery of South by Southwest, Austin will play host to a smaller, funnier festival. The Moontower Comedy and Oddity Festival, April 24 to April 27, will feature more than 90 comedians, from Bill Hader to Reggie Watts (above) to Maggie Maye. The event not to miss: an air sex competition. Remember when air guitar was cool?

headline: Champions League’s German Accent
abstract: There is a strong possibility that there will be three teams from Germany’s Bundesliga in the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: By the middle of next week, there is a good chance that for the first time since 1998 there will be three German teams, of the eight remaining, in the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League.

headline: Big Social Costs Tallied in Regions With Scant Energy Access
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Energy and Power', 'Poverty', 'Solar Energy', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A study charts the impact of energy poverty on public health and education.
lead_paragraph: After reading this Guardian article — “Energy poverty deprives 1 billion of adequate health care, says report” — I dug into the underlying analysis this morning. The report, by the British nonprofit group Practical Action, is a valuable effort to assess the full costs of inadequate energy access through indirect impacts on hospitals, schools and the like. Click here for the executive summary.

headline: Federal Austerity’s Bite on Job Growth
abstract: The combined effect of payroll tax increases and automatic budget cuts could suppress monthly hiring by more than last year’s average monthly gain, economists say.
lead_paragraph: The latest jobs report could have been even better. Employers added 236,000 jobs in February, evidence that the economy is gaining strength, but analysts generally agree that the number would have been higher if the federal government had not increased payroll tax rates in January.

headline: J.&J. Loses First Case Over Faulty Hip Implant
abstract: A jury ordered $8.3 million in damages in the first of some 10,000 lawsuits tied to a now-recalled implant.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Los Angeles on Friday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay more than $8.3 million in damages to a Montana man in the first of more than 10,000 lawsuits pending against the medical products maker in connection with a now-recalled artificial hip.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Drawing on Jewish traditions and ingredients from the farm, Joan Nathan, the acclaimed cookbook author who is also a regular contributor to The Times, will lead a Passover Seder cooking class on Saturday from 1 to 2:30 p.m. at the Stone Barns Center for Food & Agriculture, 630 Bedford Road, in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. Tickets are $40 per person and include a tasting of the holiday meal.

headline: Pennsylvania and Virginia, Where the Nation Was Shaped
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Road Trips']
abstract: When visiting Civil War battlefields and presidential estates, a rich past comes alive.
lead_paragraph: You can almost see them, spectral figures moving through thick forest, ragged, rugged men who endured astonishing hardship just to get here, creeping with their muskets in the sticky haze of a July morning in central Pennsylvania’s Appalachian Mountains. They wouldn’t even know the name of this place, Gettysburg. Yet their blood would become the ink that sets down the town’s name for history.

headline: Service Problems
abstract: How the military draft worked – and didn’t – for each side in the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: What if you threw a war and no one came?

headline: North Koreans Fond of Leader, State TV Suggests
abstract: North Korean state television producers appeared to outdo themselves with a report on the frenzied reaction from the populace Thursday as the nation’s young leader, Kim Jong-un, inspected military units.
lead_paragraph: As The Lede has reported previously, displays of official joy are quite common in North Korea, even before Rodmania swept the nation. On Thursday, though, the producers of state television’s news bulletins appeared to outdo themselves with a long report on the frenzied reaction from the populace as the nation’s young leader, Kim Jong-un, inspected military units deployed near the country’s disputed maritime border with South Korea.

headline: Video of Preparations Inside the Sistine Chapel for Conclave
abstract: Inside the Sistine Chapel, the final preparations for the meetings to decide the next Pope are underway.
lead_paragraph: Vatican officials announced Friday that the 115 cardinals from around the world will officially begin their conclave, the official process used to elect the successor of Pope Benedict XVI, on Tuesday.

headline: Nanny Charged With Murder Appears in Court
abstract: Yoselyn Ortega, who is accused of fatally stabbing two children on the Upper West Side last October, is still undergoing a psychological evaluation to determine whether she is fit to stand trial.
lead_paragraph: Yoselyn Ortega, a nanny charged with fatally stabbing two children she cared for on the Upper West Side last October, appeared in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Friday for the first time since her arrest. Ms. Ortega, 50, who had been unable to attend several prior court dates, was taken to court from the prison ward for psychiatric patients at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens. A psychiatric exam to evaluate her fitness to stand trial has not been completed. A large scar on her throat could be seen above the gray jumpsuit she wore. The authorities have said she turned a knife on herself after attacking Lucia Krim, 6, and Leo Krim, 2, in the bathtub of their apartment.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Can Crime Get More Dull?’ Edition
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Automobiles', 'Gun Control', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']

headline: Fitch Downgrades Italian Debt, Citing Political Turmoil
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: The agency cut its rating on Italy's credit by a notch, saying political gridlock could deepen the slump in a pivotal euro zone economy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Fitch ratings agency cut its assessment of Italy’s sovereign credit by a notch on Friday, citing the abrupt emergence of fresh political turmoil that could push one of the euro zone’s most pivotal economies, already in a deep slump, into a further slowdown.

headline: Bulgur: A Wheat to Remember
abstract: In bowls or bread, bulgur is a versatile and flavorful grain that should become a staple in your pantry.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a new staple for your pantry? Try bulgur, suggests Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Umami Burger to Open in Williamsburg
abstract: This is the third outlet the popular Los Angeles chain plans for New York City.
lead_paragraph: Umami Burger, the Los Angeles burger chain that has drawn a cult following, has already stirred some excitement in New York by announcing it will open in Greenwich Village this spring, and in the World Financial Center early next year. Now it has revealed plans for a third location, in Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: Two panoramic views of Citi Field, the Metsâ€™ new ballpark in Queens, with audio from Metsâ€™ executive Dave Howard.

headline: Popcast: ‘Harlem Shake’ and the New Meaning of No. 1
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss “Harlem Shake” what its chart success means for popular music.
lead_paragraph: For the third week running, Baauer’s trap-music novelty “Harlem Shake” takes the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, largely because of the magazine’s new tabulating system, which takes into account YouTube views. (Baauer is also the cover story in the magazine’s current issue, which tells you something about how a publication can make itself a large part of its own story.)

lead_paragraph: New picture books include a look at baseball in Japan and biographies of Willie Mays and Babe Ruth.

lead_paragraph: Subjects include the reopening of Fairway in Brooklyn, a brightly painted school in the Bronx and the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in the Rockaways.

headline: A Bin Laden Son-in-Law’s Video Messages
abstract: Weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, praised the attacks in a video message broadcast on Al Jazeera.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Marc Santora and William Rashbaum report, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda, was charged with conspiracy to kill Americans in federal court in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Timberwolves Still Hoping to See What They Can Do
abstract: A series of injuries has kept Minnesota from establishing a consistent starting lineup this season.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t the season the Minnesota Timberwolves thought they were going to have. With nearly three-quarters of their games played, they should have been on the road to the playoffs. The new additions Andrei Kirilenko, Chase Budinger and — they hoped — Brandon Roy were supposed to shore up the wing rotation and keep things on track until the return of Ricky Rubio from last season’s anterior cruciate ligament injury.

headline: Beef, Pepper and Parmesan: It’s Italian
abstract: On a bed of arugula and garnished with Parmesan, a dish of grilled sliced steak is impressive to behold.
lead_paragraph: Italians enjoy going out for a good steak, but a steak in Italy isn’t necessarily an individual slab. Yes, there is the famous Florentine bistecca, a large T-bone steak served blood rare. But just as often, restaurants offer a sliced steak, called tagliata, essentially a nice thick piece of beef that is grilled, then carved. It’s simple and delicious but impressive nonetheless, and you really don’t have to go to a restaurant to enjoy it. In fact, it is quite easily prepared at home, year round. Tagliata is what I make for dinner whenever a fuss-free meal is required.

headline: A Magazine, a Plan, a Contest — Symmys!
abstract: The first annual awards will be handed out Sunday in Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: Awards season isn’t over quite yet. On Sunday the winners of the first annual Symmys awards, for outstanding palindrome achievement, will be announced in Portland, Ore. The name of the awards is a palindrome, of course, and so is the date on which they’re being handed out: March 10, or 3/10/2013.

headline: Meet Memoto, the Lifelogging Camera
abstract: Facebook and Instagram have conditioned people into sharing photos of their most memorable moments — vacations, parties, weddings, meals and outings with friends. A Swedish start-up called Memoto wants to be responsible for capturing everything in between.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, TEX., — Facebook and Instagram have conditioned people into sharing photos of their most memorable moments — vacations, parties, weddings, meals and outings with friends.

headline: The Porch Is Gone, the Memories Remain
abstract: David Tanis, a former chef at Chez Panisse, on what was lost when fire destroyed part of the restaurant early this morning.
lead_paragraph: To encounter the remains of a destructive fire, like the one that ravaged a portion of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., early Friday morning, is a traumatic experience, even if no one was injured. As a longtime member of the Chez Panisse family — I was the chef there on and off from the mid-1980s through 2011 — my heart goes out to Alice Waters and the staff. It is especially traumatic for those who know the history of the place. In the wake of such an accident, memories are everywhere.

headline: Dressing for Travel to Any Hemisphere
abstract: The Grammy-winning singer Miguel says, “Most days, I wake up an artist; other days, I wake up a businessman.”
lead_paragraph: Miguel Jontel Pimentel, 27, a recording artist known professionally as Miguel, won the Grammy this year for best R&B song with his single “Adorn.” A native of Los Angeles, he currently lives in the city’s Playa Vista section.

headline: Mejia Is Back in Mets Camp
abstract: The 23-year-old pitcher went to New York for tests on a thyroid gland issue that was first detected during his preseason physical.
lead_paragraph: Jenrry Mejia returned to the Mets’ facility in Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Friday morning ready to resume what has been a troublesome spring training camp for him thus far.

headline: In New Euro Boss, a Hard-Line Future
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The doctrine of Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the head of the Eurogroup, could mean that bondholders end up absorbing steep losses if euro zone members are called upon to prop up failing banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When George Zannakis, a Greek sound engineer, heeded his investment adviser’s guidance in January by plowing half of his life savings into a high-yield bond issued by the Dutch bank SNS Reaal, he did not consider it a high-risk proposition.

headline: More Units Going Up in a Snap
abstract: Though modular building has been around for a while, more developers and architects are embracing it.
lead_paragraph: A vacant lot on Broadway between Academy and 204th Streets in Inwood is littered with rubble and concrete pilings. But in a matter of weeks, this 50-foot-wide sand pit will be transformed into a seven-story apartment building, with finished bathrooms, maple cabinetry and 10 terraces. It is not a magic trick, but rather the result of modular, or prefabricated, construction.

lead_paragraph: Paris is the center of high style during its Fashion Week, when buyers, journalists, design students and designer friends gather.

headline: A Deadly Blizzard, and Then Some Lullabies
abstract: The Oratorio Society of New York performed Paul Moravec’s “Blizzard Voices,” set to texts by the poet laureate Ted Kooser.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening the Oratorio Society of New York presented a concert of American choral music at Carnegie Hall, built around a new work by Paul Moravec, “The Blizzard Voices.” This oratorio about the “Children’s Blizzard” of 1888 had originally been scheduled to receive its New York premiere last November, but in a case of nature dislodging art imitating nature, that concert was canceled because of Hurricane Sandy.

lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — When the Chinese government announced new curbs on property prices this month, homeowners bombarded social networking sites with complaints. They formed long lines at property bureaus to register to sell their homes before the restrictions went into effect.

keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Legal Profession', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Last year, 92 percent of all transactions with a value greater than $100 million experienced litigation. But some argue that the boom in lawsuits can have real value.
lead_paragraph: Shareholder merger litigation is everywhere these days. And recent developments, including a decision in Delaware over the now completed acquisition of Transatlantic Holdings, show not only that merger litigation is here to stay, but also that courts still don’t know what to do about the proliferation of suits.

headline: For Kentucky, a Painful Fall From the Peak
abstract: Poor play by the Wildcats could keep the team from making the N.C.A.A. tournament, a year after they won it all. Kentucky Coach John Calipari blamed himself.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — The dismantling, for the time being, of Kentucky Coach John Calipari’s mystique came in a well-lighted hallway inside Georgia’s Stegeman Coliseum on Thursday night. The scene resembled a politician offering a mea culpa at a news conference, except this was a basketball coach acknowledging he had squandered talent.

headline: Russians Bring Dashcam War Reporting to Syria
abstract: A Russian news crew appears to have brought that nation’s fondness for dashboard-mounted cameras to reporting on the war in Syria.
lead_paragraph: As much of the world first learned last month, when so much extraordinary footage appeared of a meteor screaming across the sky above the Urals, Russians are unusually fond of mounting cameras on the dashboards of their cars to record the many bizarre things that happen on their roads.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Tony Stark’s Struggles
abstract: “Iron Man Omnibus” is at No. 3 on the hardcover list.
lead_paragraph: With “Iron Man 3,” starring Robert Downey Jr., out on May 3, the arrival of the “Iron Man Omnibus” to our hardcover graphic books best-seller list couldn’t be better timed. The book, at No. 3 on the list, offers 944 pages of intrigue following the hero and the man under the armor, Tony Stark. These stories include Stark’s fight against alcoholism as well as a time-travel clash with Doctor Doom, a throwdown with the Incredible Hulk and a cadre of supervillains (Madame Masque, Whiplash, the Titanium Man and more).

headline: Looking to Others for Investing Lessons
abstract: Bucks readers discuss whether investment advice for athletes and others whose income can rise to high levels on year and dry up the next was helpful to them.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan this week begins a short series of Wealth Matters columns about financial advisers who focus on a single clientele, like doctors or lawyers, and what they have learned about the behavioral tendencies of that group.

headline: When the Pope Is Chosen, His Tailors Will Be Ready
abstract: No matter who the next pope is, the papal tailors will be prepared: They’ve made three sets of vestments in sizes small, medium and large.
lead_paragraph: For a select group of Catholics, the news most eagerly awaited from the conclave of cardinals gathering in Rome to elect a new pope is less about who that man is than how big. They are the craftsmen of Ditta Annibale Gammarelli, papal tailors since the 18th century.

headline: 92nd Street Y Announces New Concert Season
abstract: The organization will open its 2013-14 concert series in the Kaufmann Concert Hall with a program chosen through online voting.
lead_paragraph: The 92nd Street Y will open its 2013-14 concert series in the Kaufmann Concert Hall on Oct. 19 with a program of late-19th- and 20th-century piano sonatas by Russian composers. Or with a program of Liszt compositions and arrangements. Or with a program of Bach, Beethoven, Chopin and Shostakovich. As part of the Masters of the Keyboard series, Valentina Lisitsa, a Ukrainian pianist who has recently gained a big following on YouTube, will make her New York recital debut playing one of three programs to be chosen by the general public and the audience through online voting. Three other programs in the Masters of the Keyboard series each feature single programs, to be played by Olga Kern, Yefim Bronfman and Peter Serkin.

lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association’s noxious dictum about guns – that the answer to too many gun deaths is more guns, always more guns, whether for soldiers, police officers, wilderness hikers, mall shoppers, moviegoers or schoolteachers – should be dead and discredited by now.

headline: Echoes of the ’30s, Inflation-Adjusted
abstract: The 83rd International Motor Show in Geneva is featuring cars for the masses, but the show also includes an unprecedented number of models with seven-figure prices.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The 83rd International Motor Show, which opened here last week, features the world premieres of 130 vehicles. These include an unprecedented number of models with seven-figure prices, including the $1.3 million LaFerrari supercar, the $1.15 million McLaren P1, the $1.6 million Koenigsegg Hundra and a trust-fund-busting Lamborghini, the $4 million Veneno.

headline: For Demi Lovato, No Airbrushing Required
abstract: From Disney star to rehab to reality-show judge and fashion idol, the singer is not following the usual Hollywood playbook.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a recent sunny afternoon, Demi Lovato emerged from a black tractor-size SUV and made her way onto a stage set up at the Grove, an upscale outdoor mall here, where she was to perform at the opening of a new Topshop. As screaming Lovatics (as Ms. Lovato’s fans proclaim themselves) flashed iPhones and waved Magic Marker signs at the pop star, she looked a little sheepish. This was understandable: her right foot was encased in a black silver-studded cast that resembled a giant ski boot.

headline: It’s Valentino’s Name, but Their Vision

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The setting was a white-paneled reception hall in the stately Salomon de Rothschild mansion, where a long dining table had been set with blue-and-white Delftware candelabras and vases filled with irises and hydrangea blossoms. Among them, silver platters were piled, obscenely high, with unblemished raspberries, blackberries, strawberries and red grapes.

lead_paragraph: I’ve had real Irish soda bread, and I’ve had ersatz Irish soda bread. Despite my usual preference for foodstuffs rooted in authenticity, in this case I like the fake version better.

headline: Suicide, With No Warning
abstract: Studies show that lax gun laws contribute to the suicide rate.
lead_paragraph: TO his large, loving family and many friends, Kerry Lewiecki was an optimist and problem-solver, with a big laugh and impressive hugs. Early in the summer of 2010, he graduated from the University of Oregon with dual degrees in law and conflict resolution; invitations went out for his August wedding to his longtime girlfriend.

headline: Greek Yogurt Touts Appeal of the ‘Real’ Thing
abstract: Chobani, the Greek yogurt brand, is expanding a marketing campaign called “Go real” into realms that include print and digital advertisements; the brand’s Web site, chobani.com; and social media like Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Chobani, the Greek yogurt brand that has enjoyed explosive growth, is opening wide its corporate wallet to rapidly expand a marketing initiative that began last month during the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards.

headline: The Prince of Ballet, Leaping Onto a New World Stage
abstract: David Hallberg, a principal dancer at the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow and the American Ballet Theater in New York, spans the worlds of ballet and pop culture, one step at a time.
lead_paragraph: David Hallberg, the statuesque ballet star who is a principal dancer at both the storied Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow and American Ballet Theater in New York, is theoretically the type of front-row coup that warrants a fit of camera flashes.

headline: In Florence, Food Gets Its Fashion Week
abstract: Pitti Taste opens on Saturday for three days and has become something of a gastronomic fashion show, where more than 250 of Italy’s standout producers show what they are made of.
lead_paragraph: Much of what makes Florence’s annual artisanal Italian food fair, Pitti Taste, more enjoyable than say, its sibling, the men’s fashion week, Pitti Uomo, is the simple fact that participants are encouraged to eat. In its eighth year, Pitti Taste opens on Saturday for three days and has become something of a gastronomic fashion show, where more than 250 of Italy’s standout producers show what they are made of with craft beer and grappa, ballooning panettone, enormous wheels of unctuous cheese and peppery and delicate olive oils. Over the last several years, the event has catapulted small beer brewers like 32 Via dei Birrai into stardom. Buyers and foodies alike descend to see where the culinary barometer is tilting. The fair includes on-site chats and presentations, like this year’s colloquium about grandiose cake design led by the expert pastry chef Roberto Rinaldini of the famed Pasticceria Rinaldini di Rimini, and discussions about how to encourage your child’s inner foodie presented by Vogue Bambini. The event is held in Florence’s impressive Leopolda train station, but there are more than 100 supplementary food events all over the city at hotels, restaurants and cultural sites like the Gucci museum, where the house chef will be teaching the secrets of cookie-making.

headline: Not Just a Fashion Statement
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Ties (Apparel)']
abstract: Jesse Tyler Ferguson, an actor on ABC’s “Modern Family,” and his fiancé, Justin Mikita, started Tie the Knot to fight the Defense of Marriage Act.
lead_paragraph: What kind of man wears a bow tie?

headline: I Guess It’s a Form of Flattery
abstract: I must have some secret power.
lead_paragraph: OK, I guess I have to say something about this Sachs and Scarborough piece. Let’s do it by numbers.

headline: The Falcons Will Get a New Stadium
abstract: The Atlanta Falcons have a deal with the city for a $1 billion stadium with a retractable roof, with the team picking up 80 percent of the cost.
lead_paragraph: After years of negotiations, the Falcons will get what they wanted: a new stadium to replace the Georgia Dome, which is barely two decades old.

headline: Toyota’s Bottom Feeder Finally Makes Some Waves
abstract: Toyota has not done well with entry-price cars, but with the redesigned Yaris, most of the company’s subcompact sins are forgiven.
lead_paragraph: Considering Toyota’s expertise in democratic, affordable transportation — Corolla, Camry, Prius — you’d think it would rule the realm of entry-price cars.

abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "The We and the I."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "The We and the I."

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Beyond the Hills."

abstract: With the improved Yaris, Toyota seems to recognize that an ultra-affordable car can play a small but important supporting role in its lineup.
lead_paragraph: With the improved Yaris, Toyota seems to recognize that an ultra-affordable car can play a small but important supporting role in its lineup.

headline: Packing 123 Horsepower Into 3 Cylinders
abstract: With the help of turbos, automakers are producing powerful but fuel efficient 3-cylinder engines. A Ford triple, as the engines are called, is small enough to fit into a suitcase.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Craig Daitch needed to fly to Los Angeles on short notice, and he had more than the usual amount of baggage.

headline: Calling Off Those False Alarms
abstract: The latest  technical service bulletins include problems with some Chrysler steering wheels and Subaru transmission sensors.
lead_paragraph: Out-of-line Chrysler steering wheels and misbehaving Subaru transmission sensors are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

abstract: A home in a converted Carroll Gardens church, a Soho co-op with an expansive living/dining area and a West Village Condo with floating staircases and exposed iron beams
