headline: Gentle Viola, Breathless Violins
abstract: An Ensemble Matheus concert at Zankel Hall on Wednesday was full of joy in a program of Handel, Vivaldi and Porpora.
lead_paragraph: It is always inspiring to see a group of musicians enjoying themselves, and the Ensemble Matheus was clearly having a good time at its concert on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall. The members of this early-music group, based in Brittany, France, and led by the conductor and violinist Jean-Christophe Spinosi, smiled and laughed at one another throughout the show.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Fighting Facebook Ads, and Chinese Surveillance
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include a Kickstarter campaign seeking $30,000 to make men’s socks, a guide for talking about Sheryl Sandberg’s book without reading it and Grumpy Cat live at the SXSW conference.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Big East Agrees to Sell Name to Breakaway Group of 7
abstract: The Big East announced an agreement to sell its name to the seven Catholic universities that are breaking away this summer to form a basketball-only conference.
lead_paragraph: The wrenching realignment that has turned the Big East Conference inside-out has meant not only the loss of members but now a divorce from its name. On Friday, the Big East announced an agreement to sell its name to the seven Catholic universities that are breaking away this summer to form a basketball-only conference.

headline: For Love Bugs or Sundered Couples, Choreography That Lasts
abstract: The dancer Michael Trusnovec shines in the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s residency at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: It’s no fluke that one of Paul Taylor’s most profound gifts is his ability to create choreographic structures enduring enough to withstand generations of dancers. But at the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which is in residence at the David H. Koch Theater this month, there are performers so embedded in the fabric of his work that it’s becoming impossible to imagine the stage without them.

headline: Butler Heading Into Home Finale
abstract: Should the Bulldogs beat Xavier it would tighten their hold on the fourth seed in the Atlantic 10 tournament.
lead_paragraph: Butler holds a 23-7 record heading into the last weekend of the regular season, including a 73-62 win over Massachusetts on Thursday night. The team is 10-5 in Atlantic 10 play and is currently in fourth place in the league, which would earn Butler a first-round bye in next week’s Atlantic 10 Tournament at Brooklyn’s Barclays Center.

headline: Pace to Recognize the Legacy of Jule Styne
abstract: Pace University will recognize the musical contributions of composer Jule Styne with a night of performances based on his music.
lead_paragraph: They will be playing a lot of composer Jule Styne’s best known songs at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University on Saturday night — selections from Broadway shows like “Funny Girl” and and “Gypsy” and “Peter Pan.”

headline: For Purists, a Classic Version of Irish Soda Bread
abstract: For a more traditional St. Patrick’s Day, a recipe that makes a fine accompaniment to corned beef and cabbage.
lead_paragraph: Despite the red hair, I haven’t a drop of Irish blood in my veins. But every March I look forward to St. Patrick’s Day, because it’s an occasion to bake soda bread.

headline: Tunisia Includes Independents in New Cabinet
abstract: The ruling Islamist Renaissance Party said that it had yielded control of the ministries of justice, interior and foreign affairs, bowing to a central demand of several opposition parties.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Tunisia’s prime minister announced a new cabinet on Friday, handing over key ministries previously headed by members of the ruling Islamist party to independent figures in an effort to calm the worst political crisis since the country’s revolt more than two years ago.

headline: Remembering the 320th
abstract: The 320th Anti-Aircraft Barrage Balloon Battalion, the only all-black unit in the D-Day landings, were among those being remembered on invasion’s anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The 320th Anti-Aircraft Barrage Balloon Battalion, the only all-black unit in the D-Day landings, were among those being remembered on invasion’s anniversary.

headline: Honoring the Soldiers Who Fought at Normandy
abstract: President Obama led a solemn tribute to the valiant Allied soldiers who stormed the beaches at Normandy 65 years ago.
lead_paragraph: President Obama led a solemn tribute to the valiant Allied soldiers who stormed the beaches at Normandy 65 years ago.

headline: The Week in Pictures from Culture for March 8
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: Book Tries for Balanced View on Roosevelt and Jews
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Richard Breitman and Allan J. Lichtman say their new book is a neutral assessment of Franklin D. Roosevelt’s record on Jewish issues.
lead_paragraph: For decades, it has been one of the most politically charged questions in American history: What did Franklin D. Roosevelt do — or, more to the point, not do — in response to the Holocaust?

headline: Students in Hazing Case Make Court Appearance
abstract: The members of the Bronx High School of Science track team, accused of holding another boy down and striking his genitals, sat quietly as the judge addressed them.
lead_paragraph: The three teenage boys sat up straight, eyes ahead, in a criminal courtroom in the Bronx on Friday morning. They wore dress shirts and ties. On a wooden bench behind them sat their supporters: More young men, in khakis, corduroys and other preppy attire; one wore brown leather boat shoes with no socks, even though it was snowing outside.

headline: Norman, Show Our Guest His Room
abstract: The Bates Motel, the setting for Alfred Hitchcock’s “Psycho” and a new A&E series, doesn’t see a lot of customers these days.
lead_paragraph: ALDERGROVE, BRITISH COLUMBIA — Say what you will about Norma Bates’s notorious motel and her unusually vigilant child-rearing practices. The woman makes a darn good breakfast.

headline: Freak Folk Courts the Plain Folk
abstract: Devendra Banhart shows maturity on his new album, “Mala,” following in the footsteps of other freak-folk acts like Joanna Newsom and Grizzly Bear.
lead_paragraph: On his latest release, “Mala,” the hippie-redux singer-songwriter Devendra Banhart can still be as loopy as he was on his first albums a decade ago. He calls himself a “low-bottom bottle-fed baby” and sings about a nun who quits an abbey to work as a V.J. (For those who don’t recall when MTV played videos, that abbreviation stands for “videodisc jockey.”) Reflecting his mother’s Venezuelan background and his time spent there as a child, Mr. Banhart croons two songs in Spanish.

headline: In the Company of Men
abstract: This month we feature a wonderfully diverse array of men, all admirable in distinct and varied ways.
lead_paragraph: It is a particular pleasure, as a woman, to get to edit a men’s issue. In fact, it is the great pleasure of journalism — and by extension of being a reader — to be able to step outside one’s own world and dive into another as an interested outsider. This month we feature a wonderfully diverse array of men, all admirable in distinct and varied ways.

headline: George Shultz Presses Congress to Act on Climate Change
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy and Power', 'Hydraulic Fracturing']
abstract: Mr. Shultz, who was the secretary of state, labor and the Treasury, urged lawmakers to support the development of hydraulic fracturing, also known as fracking, and alternative energy.
lead_paragraph: George P. Shultz, a former Republican cabinet secretary, seems an unlikely figure to fight for climate change, which is largely the political turf of Democrats.

keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced on Friday that its general counsel, Dan M. Berkovitz, would soon depart. His exit comes after the agency’s recent legal crackdown on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced on Friday that its top lawyer would soon retire, a departure that comes after the agency’s recent legal crackdown on Wall Street.

headline: Bicyclist Riding Against Traffic Dies After Being Hit by 2 Cars
abstract: The man was on New Utrecht Avenue in Borough Park, Brooklyn, on Friday morning when he collided with the first of the two vehicles, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A bicyclist traveling the wrong way in a lane on New Utrecht Avenue in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was killed early Friday morning after two cars struck him near the intersection at 58th Street, the police said.

headline: A Rapper, His DJ and the Sounds of Bompton
abstract: The rapper YG performed at the Knitting Factory on Thursday, backed by DJ Mustard, the force behind ratchet music.
lead_paragraph: It’s consistently thrilling how much DJ Mustard makes from so little.

headline: Detroit Metal Largely Absent at Swiss Show
abstract: To Chrysler, Ford and General Motors, Europe no longer presents a great opportunity to sell American cars in foreign markets.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The evolution of the American automakers in Europe, and their presence at the motor show here, is a study in contrasts. To Chrysler, Ford and General Motors, Europe no longer presents a great opportunity to sell American cars in foreign markets. Not so long ago, those attending the Geneva show could see, touch and kick the tires of a much wider array of American iron than they can today.

headline: Cuomo Voices Mixed Optimism for Chances of Campaign Finance Proposals
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he was “cautiously optimistic” of winning an overhaul, but he sounded uncertain about legislative support for establishing a financing system for state candidates.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday that he was “cautiously optimistic” that he could push through the Legislature this spring an overhaul of the state’s campaign finance laws, one of the top priorities in Albany for government reformers and progressive groups.

headline: T Men’s Fashion Spring 2013
abstract: Our latest issue highlights the rise of the well-dressed man and the importance of male friendships.
lead_paragraph: The actor Matthias Schoenaerts, photographed by Bruce Weber, is the cover subject of the spring men’s fashion issue of T. Learn how the Belgian import is dealing with becoming an American sensation. Inside: read Guy Trebay’s essay about how the average male is shedding schlumpiness for style, meet five exceptionally talented young poets (and read their work) and visit the Stockholm studio of the perfumer Ben Gorham. Additional highlights from the magazine include “Sporting Goods,” a round-up of athletic gear, “The Male Bond,” in which Andrew O’Hagan ruminates on male friendships, and “The Modern Man,” a primer on the frank irony to dressing stylishly today. See all from the issue >>

headline: A Restaurant Built on Chickpeas
abstract: At Hummus Elite, in Englewood, one owner supplies the enthusiasm, and one is the source of the knowledge and technical skills that elevate hummus and other dishes beyond the ordinary.
lead_paragraph: Even though Hummus Elite is mostly about hummus and has only 10 tables, a friend urged me to try it. I did, and was enchanted by almost every dish I ate. In the hummus category, these dishes included hummus with beef, hummus with eggplant, plain hummus and hummus with mushrooms and truffle oil. In the nonhummus category, they consisted of silky, roasted eggplant; ground beef-and-lamb kebabs fragrant with coriander; and, most surprising of all, an eight-ounce hamburger that, like the best backyard burgers, tasted as if it had been cooked over charcoal instead of just gas.

headline: Pango Says Its App Can Cut Waiting Time at Parking Garages
abstract: The Pango system, developed by entrepreneurs in Israel in 2007, is essentially focused on a smartphone app.
lead_paragraph: For drivers who regularly face the challenges of parking in Manhattan, the age of technology has provided precious few options. The automated, robot-operated garage holds promise down the road and may ease the pain. For now, though, there’s a smidgen of help. It’s called Pango.

headline: The Week in Pictures From Business for March 8
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average topped its nominal record high, Martha Stewart took the stand in a trial over sales of her products, and employment data for February suggested the recovery was gaining speed.
lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones industrial average topped its nominal record high, Martha Stewart took the stand in a trial over sales of her products, and employment data for February suggested the recovery was gaining speed.

headline: A Spot to Sample the Mediterranean Diet
abstract: Opa Grille, a Greek restaurant, has plenty of choices to please the health-conscious.
lead_paragraph: In light of recent research showing that a Mediterranean diet — one rich in vegetables, fish and olive oil — lowers the risk of heart disease, Greek restaurants look more appealing than ever these days. Opa Grille, which opened in October in Williston Park, has its share of meat and cheese on the menu, but diners seeking healthful fare can find plenty to enjoy here.

headline: Aiming for the Red Planet
abstract: Several private companies have plans in the works for missions to Mars.
lead_paragraph: Several private companies have plans in the works for missions to Mars.

headline: Florida: Guilty Plea Expected in Hazing Death of Drum Major
abstract: One of a dozen Florida A&M University students now charged with manslaughter in the hazing death of a drum major plans to plead guilty in the hope of receiving a more lenient sentence.
lead_paragraph: One of a dozen Florida A&M University students now charged with manslaughter in the hazing death of a drum major plans to plead guilty in the hope of receiving a more lenient sentence, his lawyer said Friday. The student, Caleb Jackson, 24, who is in the Leon County Jail on a probation violation, was on the bus where the drum major, Robert Champion, was beaten in 2011. Mr. Jackson is expected to plead guilty next month in an Orlando court. Chuck Hobbs, his lawyer, said Mr. Jackson was not one of the students who beat Mr. Champion, 26. The guilty plea comes in response to a decision by Jeff Ashton, the newly elected state attorney for Orange and Osceola Counties, to add manslaughter charges to existing felony hazing charges.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 8
abstract: Subjects include the opening of Fairway in Brooklyn, a brightly painted school and a St. Patrick’s Day parade in the Rockaways.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of Fairway in Brooklyn, a brightly painted school and a St. Patrick’s Day parade in the Rockaways.

headline: Old World Décor, and a Cosmopolitan Menu
abstract: Many of the accouterments of the White Horse Country Pub and Restaurant pay homage to England, but its offerings extend far beyond shepherd’s pie and Yorkshire pudding.
lead_paragraph: Its position along the Aspetuck River on a remote stretch of Route 202 in Marbledale, Conn., a few miles north of New Milford, makes the White Horse very much a country pub.

headline: Ohio: F.B.I. Enters Inquiry at Oberlin
abstract: The F.B.I. is investigating racist and antigay messages left around Oberlin College in the past month and the possible sighting of someone wearing a Ku Klux Klan-type outfit.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is investigating racist and antigay messages left around Oberlin College in the past month and the possible sighting of someone wearing a Ku Klux Klan-type outfit, a college spokesman said on Friday. A student newspaper, The Oberlin Review, reported that the college removed two students last week in connection with the vandalism; Oberlin would not comment on that report. The newspaper also reported that the recent incidents were probably linked to online racist messages dating back almost a year.

headline: Indian Flavors, Cool, Minimalist and Modern
abstract: The dishes at Coriander, compared with those at most Indian restaurants, seem lighter, but each dish’s flavors and complexities remain in full force.
lead_paragraph: In these days of trendy fusion this and fusion that, diners often have to guess what lies ahead when a restaurant claims modernity. In the case of Coriander, in Larchmont, several factors combine to create a modern feel. The décor is low key: a contemporary beige and charcoal color scheme, brightened by a row of charming white lanterns in the aisle that leads to the dining room. A small handful of cross-legged mustachioed Rajasthani figurines and a dramatic Shiva as Nataraja the cosmic dancer set the Indian theme.

headline: Honoring Prince at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Performers from Questlove to Elvis Costello celebrated the music of Prince.
lead_paragraph: Performers from Questlove to Elvis Costello celebrated the music of Prince.

headline: Howard Has Broken Bones in Back; Likely Out for Qualifiers
abstract: Tim Howard’s English club, Everton, announced that he had two broken bones in his back, and he is unlikely to play in two important World Cup qualifiers later this month.
lead_paragraph: Goalkeeper Tim Howard has two broken bones in his back, his English club, Everton, announced Friday, an injury that will almost certainly rule him out of two important World Cup qualifiers for the United States national team later this month.

headline: When Each Stylized Flourish Proclaims Itself
abstract: Ballet Flamenco de Andalusia opened a short season at City Center on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night Ballet Flamenco de Andalusia opened a short season at City Center. When the music was live, it was wretchedly overamplified; often the dancers and singers performed to a taped orchestral accompaniment that sounded less like Andalusia than like a Hollywood idea of Spanish sounds. Two star dancers, Pastora Galván and Rubén Olmo, exuded absurd mannerism far more than they did flamenco rhythms. And the third, Rocío Molina, though a marvelous dancer, performed in an idiom that came across as pretentious.

headline: For a Night, at Least, Nothing Compares to Prince
abstract: “The Music of Prince” brought a wide range of performers, including Elvis Costello, Bilal and the Blind Boys of Alabama, to Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: One concert could hardly contain the multiplicity of Prince’s enormous songwriting catalog over the 35 years since he released his debut album, “For You,” in 1978. “The Music of Prince,” a tribute concert on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, tried hard. The program strove to capture a broad swath of Prince’s work, through funk and rock and pop, from lust to spirituality to apocalypse to partying. It included hits, rarities and even some of Prince’s dance moves (but alas, no leaping splits). It was the ninth annual “Music of” concert produced by Michael Dorf, the owner of City Winery, to benefit music programs for underprivileged children.

headline: The Drone Question Obama Hasn’t Answered
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The attorney general’s statement about drone strikes on American soil should not reassure anyone concerned about human rights and the limits of executive power.
lead_paragraph: THE Senate confirmed John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency on Thursday after a nearly 13-hour filibuster by the libertarian senator Rand Paul, who before the vote received a somewhat odd letter from the attorney general.

headline: Rules of Order Dictate Pitching at World Classic
abstract: Strict limits on pitching and major league teams’ interests weigh heavily on the team managers who take to the mound often in the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Tony Pena likes to be involved in the flow of games. He was involved during his major league career as a catcher, and he remains involved as the manager of the Dominican Republic team at the World Baseball Classic. He refuses to be confined to the dugout; that much is clear.

headline: Teaching Viewers to Hear the TV With Eyes Only
abstract: This week ABC Family broadcast an entire episode of a show, “Switched at Birth,” in American Sign Language.
lead_paragraph: This week ABC Family did something that no commercial television channel in the United States had ever done: It broadcast an entire episode of a show, “Switched at Birth,” in American Sign Language, with next to no oral dialogue.

headline: Night of the Stars
abstract: The Night of the Stars tournament was held on Feb. 28 at the Richmond Bridge Club in London.
lead_paragraph: The Night of the Stars tournament was held on Feb. 28 at the Richmond Bridge Club in London.

headline: Almost Certainly, the Thief Didn’t Know What Was in the Box
abstract: Every day officers in New York City confront all manner of hazardous material and dangerous items, but a robbery in Brooklyn was something else.
lead_paragraph: Ring! Ring! Ring! The man pushed buzzer after buzzer outside the building on Prospect Park West on a February afternoon. Either he knew someone in every apartment and had picked the wrong day to visit, or he was doing some homework for his Burglary 101 class.

headline: The Darkness of an Irish Morning
abstract: My eccentric, boisterous relatives told me everything — almost.
lead_paragraph: MY father came from Ireland and he had the gift of the gab. Part of the reason the Irish developed the gift of the gab was simple. They lived on an island. They had to get along. Not that they did get along. But they had to try. So a style of speaking developed that allowed them to say awful things. With charm.

headline: A Small Stable’s Bridge to the Derby
abstract: The 3-year-old colt Verrazano, a Kentucky Derby contender, has shown early brilliance in two wins for the small Let’s Go Stable.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The bloodlines that are part of the Kentucky Derby contender Verrazano’s story run deep, and not just with the horses.

headline: Visions of Drones Swarming U.S. Skies Hit Bipartisan Nerve
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Big Brother imagery conjured up by Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky during a filibuster this week has animated a diverse swath of political interests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The debate goes to the heart of a deeply rooted American suspicion about the government, the military and the surveillance state: the specter of drones streaking through the skies above American cities and towns, controlled by faceless bureaucrats and equipped to spy or kill.

headline: A Former Hostage Worries for Those Left Behind in the Desert
abstract: Françoise Larribe, who was taken captive in Niger by members of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, clings to hope that her husband, Daniel, is still alive, safe and unharmed.
lead_paragraph: NÎMES, France

headline: An Entry Reserved for Those With Guns
abstract: At the Texas State Capitol, legally armed lawmakers and constituents can enter freely through their own entrance.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — At the State Capitol here, a legal concealed gun is the equivalent of an E-ZPass.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Italy Uneasy as Government and Vatican Drift, Rudderless
abstract: Leadership vacuums in government and the Vatican have further shaken Italians troubled by recession, political instability and church scandals.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The leader has resigned. There are scandals over sex and corruption. Finances are in disarray. And no one knows who will step in to try to clean up the mess.

headline: Blocked Bids to Fill Judgeships Stir New Fight on Filibuster
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republican senators have so far kept President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most important appeals court, reviving talk of a change in Senate rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A fresh feud over federal judgeships has again begun to agitate the Senate, with Republicans so far blocking President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most prestigious and important appeals court.

headline: A Lifetime of Portraits and Shots of Graffiti
abstract: In “Jon Naar: Signature Photography,” at the New Jersey State Museum, black-and-white and color photographs capture the artist’s wide range of subjects through decades.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Preparing to lead a reporter through the exhibition “Jon Naar: Signature Photography” at the New Jersey State Museum here, Mr. Naar paused before starting into what he called “a fast-forward” through his life.

headline: Off the Path to Recovery
abstract: The February jobs report may have seemed to be welcome good news for the economy, but there is much to be worried about.
lead_paragraph: The February employment report shows some notable improvements that, if sustained, would herald a real recovery. Partly boosted by increased employment in the construction industry, the number of new jobs jumped to 236,000 last month, continuing a gradual upward trend.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: As Police Strike, Egypt Tensely Awaits Verdicts in Soccer Riot
abstract: Saturday’s verdicts will determine the culpability of police officers and officials in Port Said’s soccer club who were on duty at the time of the riot in February 2012.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague in Cairo David Kirkpatrick reported, a quickly spreading strike among the police force has added to a growing sense of chaos and lawlessness in Egypt, where opposition to President Mohamed Morsi has been newly energized in recent days by anticipation of a second round of verdicts over the deaths of more than 70 soccer fans in a stadium riot in Port Said last year.

headline: Congress Gets in the Way
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lawmakers need to work with President Obama on a diplomatic solution to the nuclear dispute in Iran.
lead_paragraph: If there is any hope for a peaceful resolution of the nuclear dispute with Iran, President Obama needs Congress to support negotiations. But negotiations and compromise are largely anathema in Washington, with many lawmakers insisting that any deal with Iran would be unacceptable — a stance that would make military action by Israel and the United States far more likely.

headline: Doubling Back for the Roadkill
abstract: Turning roadkill into dinner is common in parts of rural America, and state lawmakers are starting to take notice.
lead_paragraph: Squirrel gravy is such a delicacy in Appalachia that there is a RoadKill Cook-off each year in the hollows of West Virginia. Lawmakers in Montana get the drift. The lower house of the Montana Legislature recently approved a measure that would allow citizens to salvage fresh roadkill and take it home for dinner.

headline: One Way to Cheer Up: Cheer Harder
abstract: Research suggests that sports fans, even zealous ones, are less prone to depression and alienation than nonfans.
lead_paragraph: You probably think rabid sports fans are a bunch of lonely, disoriented souls who try to fill the holes in their lives by attaching themselves to a team. And you’re probably wrong.

headline: Curtains, and Hope for Renewal, Going Up
abstract: After more than 25 years, the Suffolk Theater is open again for business, transformed into a performing arts center that some hope will be the anchor for a downtown revival.
lead_paragraph: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. — When the Suffolk Theater opened as a movie house in 1933, it was heralded by one local newspaper as “a splendidly designed structure, beautifully and modernly equipped and furnished.”

headline: Miles to Go Before He Sings
abstract: On Sundays, David Steinberger, who oversees a library of comics as chief executive of ComiXology, runs in Central Park, exercises his vocals in church and has brunch with friends.
lead_paragraph: David Steinberger, 41, is the chief executive of ComiXology, sometimes called the iTunes of comics, which has about 33,000 comics in its library and adds about 300 a week. A classically trained singer, he has a master’s degree in performance from the Manhattan School of Music and an Advanced Certificate in performance from Juilliard, as well as an M.B.A. from New York University. Mr. Steinberger, who moved to New York from Kentucky in 1994, lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Kittson, a graphic designer, and their two cats, Buddy and Sweetheart. On Sundays, he often sings in church and runs with his wife in Central Park; they plan to run the NYC Half on March 17.

headline: Setback to Boeing’s Hopes for Longer Range for 787
abstract: Because of recent incidents with the jet’s battery, an advanced feature allowing for new flight paths may not receive approval for months, which could dilute the jet’s appeal.
lead_paragraph: With the technologically advanced 787, Boeing offered airlines big fuel savings and better comfort for passengers. It also promised something else: the ability to reach just about any airport on the globe without having to stop.

headline: Cautious Approval for a Plan to Merge a City’s Museums
abstract: A plan to combine the two biggest museums in Los Angeles has both wide support and a powerful potential foe: a philanthropist who bailed one of them out five years ago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For many people in the philanthropic and cultural swirl of Los Angeles, the proposal seems a welcome response to a conflict that has riveted this city’s art world for five years: A merger of its two biggest museums, ending a long-simmering feud, combining two arts collections, and rescuing one of them, the Museum of Contemporary Art, from a spasm of personnel turmoil and fiscal decline.

headline: Saving the Day
abstract: One way to appreciate the conceptual oddness of daylight saving time is to imagine it as a new idea.
lead_paragraph: One way to appreciate the conceptual oddness of daylight saving time is to imagine it as a new idea just cooked up by the Obama administration. An individual mandate to change your clocks twice a year, every year, to enable a government redistribution of sunshine. Or, put another way, the feds’ confiscation of more than 300 million privately held American sleep hours, taken for eight months without interest payments or a penalty. All to make the nation healthier, wealthier and wiser, and for somewhat dubious energy savings. House Republicans would not be pleased — would you? Would you reset the clock radio, or would you demand that the government stay out of your bedroom and leave your dream life alone?

headline: A Dangerous ‘New Normal’ in College Debt
abstract: Many students can’t earn their way out of this trap.
lead_paragraph: We are reaching a crisis point in this country’s higher education system.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Man Who Helped Image of Wal-Mart Steps Down
abstract: Leslie Dach, who is credited with polishing the company’s image through energy conservation, environmentally friendly packaging and philanthropy, is resigning after almost seven years.
lead_paragraph: The chief burnisher of Wal-Mart Stores’ reputation is leaving the company as its image is under new strains.

headline: In Cannibal Case, Deliberations Go On
abstract: Jurors in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap and eat women, ended their first full day of deliberation without reaching a verdict.
lead_paragraph: The jury in the trial of Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, rape and cannibalize women, was sent home on Friday after competing its first full day of deliberations without reaching a verdict.

headline: Exercise May Help Protect Children From Stress
abstract: Children who get less exercise show greater hormonal responses to stress, a Finnish study finds.
lead_paragraph: Physically active children generally report happier moods and fewer symptoms of depression than children who are less active. Now researchers may have found a reason: by one measure, exercise seems to help children cope with stress.

headline: McIlroy Finds His Comfort Zone, but Woods Is Long Gone by Then
abstract: Rory McIlroy, the world’s No. 1 player, kept pace with Tiger Woods on the back nine in the second round of the Cadillac Championship, but Woods had built too big a lead for anyone to catch him.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Making 17 birdies in the opening 36 holes is a first for Tiger Woods in his PGA Tour career, but it is not the neatest trick he has pulled off at the Cadillac Championship this week. On Friday on the ninth hole of Doral’s Blue Monster, Woods made the thousands of fans following him essentially disappear.

headline: An Installation of Dirty Politics and Illusion
abstract: “Matrix 166: Some Concerns About the Candidate,” by Deb Sokolow, is a fictional narrative involving Jim Jones, the cult leader, and David Copperfield, the magician.
lead_paragraph: In the simplest sense, Deb Sokolow’s “Some Concerns About the Candidate” at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford is a clever installation driven by a single conceit: a fictional narrative in which a Congressional candidate hires a campaign consultant to help him get elected. The protagonist, referred to throughout the exhibition as “you,” is a campaign worker who falls under the candidate’s spell — but ends up documenting an unfolding tale of intrigue and deceit.

headline: Queens Congressman Attends Chávez Funeral
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Gregory W. Meeks, who had a little-known but significant relationship with Hugo Chávez, was part of a small United States delegation to Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Gregory W. Meeks, a New York Democrat who developed a little-known but significant relationship with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela over the last decade, attended Mr. Chávez’s funeral on Friday as part of a small United States delegation.

headline: In Parts of Syria, Lack of Assistance ‘Is a Catastrophe’
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The vast majority of foreign aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad while the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.
lead_paragraph: SAWRAN, Syria — The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 8, 2013
