lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow at Tiny Desk
abstract: Less is more.
lead_paragraph: Wow — almost forgot to post tonight. Anyway, this is the best performance I’ve seen yet by this group; no frills, just the three of them, and almost Civil Wars levels of perfection.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 9, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Mar. 9, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "There’s no government, there’s no pope. And now it is snowing in Rome.”

headline: Little Relief in North Syria, Where Need Is Acute
abstract: International donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on aid for Syrians, but the money has brought anger and resentment in some areas.
lead_paragraph: International donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on aid for Syrians, but the money has brought anger and resentment in some areas.

headline: Senators Bearing Arms
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: People, do you think Congress is actually going to do anything about gun violence in the wake of the Newtown shootings?
lead_paragraph: Whenever talk turns to gun control in Congress, lawmakers feel compelled to mention their love of weaponry.

headline: Mets’ Gee Encouraged Despite an Uneven Outing
abstract: Dillon Gee, who missed the second half of last season, said he felt that he was close to ready for the start of the season.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — Despite looking uneven during his second game facing major league hitters since being shut down last summer, Dillon Gee said he felt that he was near his optimal form for the start of the season.

headline: Pope Material or Not, a Charming, Cheerful Cardinal Gains Notice in Rome
abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, head of the United States’ most prominent Catholic diocese, is juggling his leadership roles, Vatican tasks and numerous interviews on Italian television.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — He keeps a set of vestments here, at the American seminary, so he does not have to lug the red robes back and forth to New York. He is a practiced frequent flier; last fall, he flew a round trip in a day, borrowing a billionaire’s jet so he could preside at a dinner in Manhattan without missing a meeting in Rome.

headline: Corrections: March 9, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 9, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Gets in a Lather
abstract: Barry C. Silk collaborates with David Steinberg, who achieves a special milestone today.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a very interesting puzzle on quite a few levels: for one thing, with today’s puzzle, co-written by David Steinberg and Barry C. Silk, Mr. Steinberg has hit for the cycle after only his ninth puzzle published in The New York Times. Mr. Steinberg, who is in his mid-teens, has had at least one puzzle published in The Times on each day of the week.

headline: Finding Lovable Humanity in a Bitter Artist
abstract: The Schoolhouse Theater’s production of Jon Robin Baitz’s “Ten Unknowns” opened on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Most people don’t like Malcolm Raphelson. Even in his 70s, he is a menacing, arrogant, womanizing, narcissistic artist who has never forgiven Jackson Pollock and the other Abstract Expressionists for stealing his thunder in the 1940s and ’50s. Raphelson has an appetite for destruction, including his own.

headline: Paintings From Garage Find Appreciation in Gallery
abstract: Fourteen years after his death, there’s a possibility for something that Arthur Pinajian never enjoyed in life: serious money for his paintings.
lead_paragraph: For years, they languished in a Long Island garage, old canvasses piled in a stack. Then they came close to being thrown into a garbage truck.

headline: As Brodeur Sits, Devils Try to Get Back on Their Feet
abstract: The Devils have struggled without the injured 40-year-old goalie Martin Brodeur, whom an analyst described as their “life source.”
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A back injury to the 40-year-old goaltender Martin Brodeur, a mainstay during the Devils’ three Stanley Cup triumphs, is providing the franchise a glimpse of what life could be like without him. It may not be pretty.

headline: Dwindling Production Has Led to Lesser Role for Venezuela as Major Oil Power
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The death of President Hugo Chávez seems to have had surprisingly little impact so far on global oil markets.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — President Hugo Chávez relished using Venezuela’s oil wealth to project power internationally, nudging OPEC to raise oil prices when he could, showering allies like Cuba and Nicaragua with subsidized oil shipments, and mocking the United States while selling it his crude.

headline: A Restaurant Was Popular; Its Closing Was Celebrated
abstract: Saigon Grill was known for tasty spring rolls and soups, but its owners still owed $1 million for labor violations.
lead_paragraph: For years, Saigon Grill on Amsterdam Avenue at 90th Street was an Upper West Side fixture. Its spring rolls and Vietnamese soups were staples of quick dinners, celebratory lunches and takeout meals. Its deliveries were prompt, its waiters happy to take care of small children.

headline: Are Bicycles Allowed in the Subways?
abstract: Questions about bicycles on subway cars and New York’s rotary-phone friendly area code.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are bicycles allowed in the subways?

headline: Mosby’s Sneak Attack
abstract: A daring Southern cavalryman’s audacious mission to capture a Union officer.
lead_paragraph: “On the bed we saw the general sleeping,” recalled the memoirist. “There was no time for ceremony, so I drew up the bedclothes, pulled up the general’s shirt, and gave him a spank on his bare back, and told him to get up.” This brief description captured the apex of one military career, and the nadir of another.

headline: Swedes on Both Ends of Ice End Rangers’ Streak
abstract: The Rangers’ Brad Richards returned from a two-game absence, but the Senators’ Jacob Silfverberg broke a 2-2 tie, helping end the Rangers’ four-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: Brad Richards made a successful return from injury and Rick Nash scored again, but it was Swedes Night at Madison Square Garden as the Ottawa Senators defeated the Rangers, 3-2, on Friday.

headline: Treasure in the Air Up There
abstract: The architect Robert A. King treks through the streets of New York to find the stone faces and animals that decorate buildings all over the city, capturing them with his camera.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. King, 67, architect, checked in on one of his renovation jobs, a town house on Garfield Place in Brooklyn, and then spent the rest of Wednesday afternoon walking the neighborhood looking up.

headline: Rational Decisions and Heartbreak on School Closings
abstract: Officials in cities like Philadelphia, Chicago and Washington are being met with anger and criticism as they close schools citing budgets.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to school closings, the arguments may make sense on paper, but the reality is much messier.

headline: Filling the D.C. Appeals Court
abstract: Republicans in the Senate have so far blocked President Obama from filling vacant judgeships in the District of Columbia Circuit of the Unites States Court of Appeals.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in the Senate have so far blocked President Obama from filling vacant judgeships in the District of Columbia Circuit of the Unites States Court of Appeals.

headline: Argentina: Ex-President Is Convicted
abstract: An appeals court in Argentina convicted former President Carlos Saúl Menem on Friday of smuggling contraband weapons in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court in Argentina convicted former President Carlos Saúl Menem on Friday of smuggling contraband weapons in the 1990s. Weapons and munitions officially destined to Panama and Venezuela ended up in Ecuador during its brief war with Peru, violating a bilateral peace agreement, and in Croatia during the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia amid an international weapons embargo. The ruling overturned a lower court’s 2011 acquittal of Mr. Menem, left, whose 1989-1999 presidency was marred by accusations of corruption and graft. Mr. Menem, who denies being part of the arms conspiracy, served six months on house arrest on the same charges in 2001, but was freed following a Supreme Court ruling. As a senator, Mr. Menem, 82, is shielded from further imprisonment and may appeal the conviction before the Supreme Court.

headline: Williams Electrifies From Long Distance
abstract: Deron Williams hit 11 of 16 3-point attempts, including an N.B.A.-record nine in the first half, as the Nets cruised past the Wizards.
lead_paragraph: Deron Williams’s night began quietly, with a 3-pointer from the left wing that whipped through the net about 90 seconds after the opening tip. Fans were still settling in their seats, and the Nets’ main concern was stopping Washington’s John Wall, a pesky guard who could cause them headaches.

headline: Germany: Airport Project Reorganized
abstract: A manager who turned around Germany’s national railway and second largest airline took over the company behind the construction of Berlin’s new international airport on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A tough manager who turned around Germany’s national railway and second largest airline took over the company behind the construction of Berlin’s new international airport on Friday. “We will do everything to speed up the completion of the airport,” said the new leader, Hartmut Mehdorn, 70. Embarrassing budgetary and technical problems have repeatedly pushed the opening of the Berlin-Brandenburg Willy Brandt Airport further from its original target of last June, pushed costs to $5.2 billion, turned the project into a national joke, and cost the last manager, Rainer Schwarz, his job. Mr. Mehdorn brought the national railway, Deutsche Bahn, into profitability as its head from 1999 to 2009 and then helped return Air Berlin to competitiveness before leaving as its chief executive in January.

headline: Three Men at Work, Quietly, While Yankees Are Elsewhere
abstract: While their Yankee teammates were on the other side of Florida, the aging stars Derek Jeter, Mariano Rivera and Andy Pettitte moved closer to playing together again.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — A team of aspiring Yankees played in a spring training game on the other side of Florida on Friday. Meanwhile, three of the most revered Yankees in team history had their run of the team’s quiet complex, preparing for what is likely to be their last season together after two immensely successful decades.

headline: Britain: 4 Plead Guilty in Selling Information to Tabloids
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Four former public officials pleaded guilty Friday to illegally selling information to the Rupert Murdoch-owned tabloid, The Sun.
lead_paragraph: In the latest of dozens of criminal cases stemming from the phone-hacking scandal that led to the closure in 2011 of Rupert Murdoch’s News of the World tabloid, four former public officials pleaded guilty Friday to illegally selling information to another Murdoch-owned tabloid, The Sun. One, Alan Tierney, a former police constable, admitted to selling information in 2009 about the shoplifting arrests of the mother and mother-in-law of the soccer star John Terry. He also admitted selling another story that year about how the Rolling Stones guitarist Ron Wood had been arrested on suspicion of beating up a girlfriend. Mr. Tierney, who prosecutors said was paid $2,600, will be sentenced on March 27. Another defendant, Richard Trunkfield, a former prison officer at a high-security facility, admitted to receiving $5,000 for information about a “high-profile prisoner” in 2010. The two other defendants cannot be named because their alleged co-conspirators have yet to face trial.

headline: After Over a Century at Sea, 2 Sailors Are Laid to Rest
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Forensic Science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The dead were two unidentified sailors from the ironclad warship Monitor, buried with full military honors 150 years after their ship sank during a storm off the coast of Cape Hatteras, N.C.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Older women in hoop skirts and petticoats came together with youthful sailors in their dress blues for a rare public double interment at Arlington National Cemetery on Friday.

headline: In a Private School, Seeds of Dissent
abstract: Books on three prominent graduates of the Little Red School House in Greenwich Village and the competition to host the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: No wonder they called it the Little Red School House.

headline: Sailors From the Ironclad Warship Monitor Interred
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The unidentified remains of two of the 16 men who went down with the ship on Dec. 31, 1862, during the Civil War were interred in Arlington National Cemetery on Mar. 8.
lead_paragraph: The unidentified remains of two of the 16 men who went down with the ship on Dec. 31, 1862, during the Civil War were interred in Arlington National Cemetery on Mar. 8.

headline: Iraq: Security Forces Open Fire on Sunni Demonstrators in North
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: Security forces fired on stone-throwing Sunni demonstrators in the northern city of Mosul on Friday, killing one and wounding five, according to Iraqi officials.
lead_paragraph: Security forces fired on stone-throwing Sunni demonstrators in the northern city of Mosul on Friday, killing one and wounding five, according to Iraqi officials. The demonstrators were demanding the release of Sheikh Hussain al-Jubori, a local leader of antigovernment protests that have been going on in Iraq for two months. He was arrested early in the day on suspicion of links to Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the homegrown terrorist group. After the shootings, members of the mainly Sunni Iraqiya bloc held a news conference to denounce the government as “reckless,” and the minister of agriculture, Izzeddin al-Dolah, resigned, the second high-profile Sunni to do so this month.

headline: Colorado Takes Up Gun Limits in Senate
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: The Colorado Senate began a marathon session on a range of new firearms restrictions in a state haunted by two mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — After months of emotional debate, an effort to tighten gun laws in a state haunted by two mass shootings moved toward an uncertain climax on Friday as Colorado’s State Senate began a marathon session on a range of new firearms restrictions.

headline: Capitol Redux
abstract: A visual tour of the New York State Capitol in Albany. Its renovation was completed in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A visual tour of the New York State Capitol in Albany. Its renovation was completed in 2012.

headline: Local Stop: 68th and Lexington
abstract: At Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, Hunter College represents the architectural history of the area as well as the addition of modern amenities.
lead_paragraph: At Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, Hunter College represents the architectural history of the area as well as the addition of modern amenities.

headline: Modernity Among Classics
abstract: The area around Hunter College on Lexington Avenue and 68th Street is filled with contrasting architectural styles.
lead_paragraph: The corner of Lexington Avenue and 68th Street is beyond busy: the subway and the crosstown bus shuttle students to school, deliver staff to hospitals nearby and take locals home from Lincoln Center. A few blocks east, residents of apartments, town houses and tenements suffer equally from the Second Avenue subway project. Closer to Central Park, the atmosphere quiets, and the streets are rich with cultural and architectural history.

headline: Down the Rabbit Hole in a Rental War
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: After a surprise eviction notice, a tenant in Harlem found that the landlord she had been paying rent to might not be the rightful owner of the building after all.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday night not long ago, my roommate and I were sitting in our apartment in Harlem when we were interrupted by frantic knocking. We opened the door to find our upstairs neighbor standing there, a pink notice in her hand.

headline: Vows: Marguerite and Sean
abstract: When Sean Anderson heard Marguerite Daniels was a good cook, he invited himself over for Singaporean chili crab. He got more than he bargained for when her cat was sick on their very first date.
lead_paragraph: When Sean Anderson heard Marguerite Daniels was a good cook, he invited himself over for Singaporean chili crab. He got more than he bargained for when her cat was sick on their very first date.

headline: U.S. Cancels Transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghans
abstract: The military had planned to hand over control of the prison on Saturday, but remarks President Hamid Karzai made about releases may have caused a reversal.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A ceremony in which the American military had planned to hand over full control of the Bagram Prison to Afghanistan was canceled Saturday, throwing into doubt an agreement between the two countries on custody of the remaining Afghan prisoners still being held by American forces.

headline: The Orthodox Fringe
abstract: The band Moshiach Oi!, part of an emerging strand of Jews defined by religion and rebellion, is in a documentary, “Punk Jews.”
lead_paragraph: At age 6, he was a budding yeshiva student, in white shirt and black hat, with little contact outside the Orthodox Jewish world. At 16, he discovered some things he liked better, punk rock and drugs: marijuana, LSD, eventually crack and heroin. At 26, on the Thursday before the holiday of Purim last month, he was back among the faithful, sort of: side curls flailing, knees jackknifing up around his torso, leaping, crouching, shouting a Scriptural message from the Book of Ramones: “Avraham was a punk rocker.”

headline: Is It Safe to Cross?
abstract: Fears are high because of a recent spate of traffic deaths, but you are still more likely to be murdered in New York City than be killed by a car while on foot.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday afternoon last month, Martha Atwater went to buy cookies at a bagel shop on Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street in Brooklyn and was struck by a Honda sport utility vehicle that careered onto the sidewalk as she was leaving. According to the Police Department, the driver, John McKinney, lost control when he experienced a blackout related to diabetes. By the time Ms. Atwater was taken to Long Island College Hospital around the block, she was dead, leaving behind a husband, two young daughters and a closely bound community of mourners in Brooklyn Heights, where she had been a vibrant presence.

headline: Thousands Say Farewell to Chávez
abstract: The death of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela prompted a mass outpouring of grief at his funeral, which also attracted dignitaries from around the world.
lead_paragraph: The death of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela prompted a mass outpouring of grief at his funeral, which also attracted dignitaries from around the world.

headline: A Jewel in Albany Regains Its Luster
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'State Legislatures', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, an architecture buff, gives a tour of the newly renovated Capitol Building.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The Capitol Building here has always been as much a symbol as a building. Soaring, ornate and hand-built over a 32-year span during the industrial heyday of the late 19th century, the Capitol was a testament to the state’s architectural might and the moxie of New Yorkers and their government. It also, of course, spoke to the tendency, sometimes still in evidence, to overspend and procrastinate on big projects. The Capitol’s $25 million price tag, a figure that translates to more than half a billion dollars today, made it one of the most expensive public-works projects in the nation’s history.

headline: Blasts Hit Afghanistan After Arrival of Hagel
abstract: A suicide bombing at the Afghan defense ministry killed nine people just hours after Chuck Hagel, the new United States defense secretary, arrived in the city.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A bomber wearing a vest packed with explosives struck outside the Afghan Defense Ministry on Saturday, killing at least 10 people in a blast just hours after Chuck Hagel, the new United States defense secretary, arrived here.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: LONG WEEKENDS Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore explain why Edmund Goulding’s “Grand Hotel” (1932), about guests linked by varying forms of desperation at a luxurious Berlin hotel — where, a resident complains, life is “always the same. People come, people go. Nothing ever happens” — is required viewing. Among the reasons: The pioneering use of ensemble star power (Greta Garbo, John and Lionel Barrymore, Wallace Beery and Joan Crawford), promoted by the MGM studio as “the greatest cast ever assembled.” And the words “I want to be alone,” the signature line of the fading, suicidal ballerina played by Garbo, which became synonymous with the mysterious image of the actress throughout her life. “Week-End at the Waldorf,” the 1945 “Grand Hotel” remake starring Ginger Rogers and Walter Pidgeon, above, follows at 10.

headline: United States Can’t Recover After Dickey Struggles Early
abstract: R. A. Dickey was hit hard over four innings against Mexico, dooming the United States to a loss and an uncomfortable urgency in the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — R. A. Dickey pitched for the United States at the 1996 Olympics, winning both his starts. Yet he left with a bronze medal and a lingering sense of what could have been.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 9
abstract: Concerns over Syria aid; Europe’s new financial sheriff; Italy’s double challenge; U.S. jobless rate drops; and plans for Mars trip.
lead_paragraph: NEWS The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible. David Kirkpatrick reports from Sawran, Syria.

headline: Video of Police Beating in Fiji Prompts Ire
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: Cellphone footage showing two men being beaten by police officers, according to Fiji officials, has spurred international condemnation.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The nine minutes of shaky cellphone footage are hard to watch, not because of the quality but because of the content. A young man lies handcuffed on the bed of a pickup truck, wailing as he is beaten repeatedly with a thick baton. Later, his assailant switches to a metal rod. A snarling dog drags another victim past his laughing attackers, who punch the man relentlessly.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Punjab:  Ram Singh, a national level boxer, has told the police that he and Vijender Singh, a 2008 Olympics bronze medal-winning boxer, bought heroin from a drug dealer who was arrested near Chandigarh, Punjab, last week, NDTV reported. The interrogation was part of the drug bust that led to the seizure of 26-kilograms of drugs worth 1.3 billion rupees, or $23 million.

headline: The Weekend Word: School Supplies
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, the president’s weekly address and a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: As Crisis Deepens in Egypt After Ruling on Riot, Calls for a Military Coup
abstract: Twenty-one people had been sentenced to death for their roles in the deadly 2012 soccer riot that killed more than 70 people in the city of Port Said.
lead_paragraph: PORT SAID, Egypt — Just months ago, demonstrators here and around Egypt were chanting for the end of military rule. But on Saturday, as a court ruling about a soccer riot set off angry mobs, many in the crowd here declared they now believed that a military coup might be the best hope to restore order.

headline: Never Too Many ‘I Love You’s’ for This Couple
abstract: Skip and Karen Finley attribute their 41 years of marriage to always ending conversations with, “I love you.”
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Kenyatta Is Declared the Victor in Kenya, but Opponent Plans to Appeal
keywords: ['Elections', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The election commission said Saturday that Uhuru Kenyatta had received 50.07 percent of the vote, but the other top contender, Raila Odinga, indicated that he would not concede defeat.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s election commission on Saturday declared Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of Kenya’s first president and one of the prime suspects in a case involving crimes against humanity, to be the winner of the country’s presidential race amid growing allegations of vote fraud and a refusal by the other leading contender to concede.

headline: Gone Deficit Gone
abstract: It’s over.
lead_paragraph: So says the CBO, although not directly.

headline: The English Prisoner
abstract: Cameron is stuck, and so is Britain.
lead_paragraph: “If this plan is working, what would a failing one look like?” So asks Martin Wolf in response to David Cameron’s speech insisting that his austerity policy was right, is right, and is succeeding. Simon Wren-Lewis goes through Cameron’s assertions in some detail, among other things catching him more or less lying about what the Office of Budget Responsibility — roughly speaking the counterpart of the CBO here — ha actually said about the impact of austerity on growth.

headline: Attack on Christians Follows Claim of Blasphemy in Pakistan
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: More than 150 houses and 2 churches were set on fire in a new display of religious intolerance as Pakistan is reeling from violent persecution against other minorities.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An enraged Muslim crowd attacked a Christian neighborhood in Lahore on Saturday, setting fire to more than 150 houses and 2 churches, in a new display of religious intolerance as Pakistan reels from violent persecution against other minorities.

headline: For Some, Owning Guns Doesn’t Necessarily Mean Liking Them
abstract: It is these voices of ambivalence that policy makers say are likely to be drowned out by the passion at the extreme ends.
lead_paragraph: The national debate over firearms regulation is often presented as a battle of extremes: those who view any effort to tighten gun laws as an infringement of rights versus those who see guns as a menace to society.

headline: Unforced Error Is Unloved Statistic Among Tennis Players
abstract: Terms coined to help quantify what led to a match’s outcome are more of a hit with the fans and the news media than with the competitors.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The term unforced error has become a staple of the popular vernacular since its introduction in tennis three decades ago. And though the phrase is still largely identified with the sport, players and coaches have little regard for the statistic. Nor do they care much for the statistical identification of shots as winners or unforced errors, considering them misleading reflections of the flow of a match.

headline: High Tension on the Mountain
abstract: A chairlift deropement on Mount Snow in Vermont was a first-time adventure for a skier with 30 years’ experience, but the resort was prepared.
lead_paragraph: I was suspended 40 feet in the air on a broken chairlift for 80 bitterly cold minutes last month. My brother-in-law and I had been riding up Mount Snow in Vermont, looking forward to a morning on the slopes without our children, when the lift’s steel cable slipped off its track.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: Getting Started
abstract: Will Shortz welcomes the tribe to the 36th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The buzz of excitement begins as you stroll down the hallway outside the ballroom. On Saturday at the A.C.P.T., the Market is home to vendors of all sorts of puzzle-related products, including The New York Times, which is giving away pencils, pens and stickers, as well as a raffle to win one of the New York Times puzzle cookie jars. Those who have filled their arms with puzzle swag mill into the ballroom and find a strategic seat behind one of the many yellow barriers placed around contestants to guard their answers.

headline: Rowdiness Becomes a Business Strategy for the Tour
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s plans for Doral Resort demonstrate the way golf tournaments are trying to attract a broader audience by inviting noisier galleries.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — A color depiction of how the Doral Resort’s Blue Monster will look, post-op, was spread before Donald J. Trump, who could not contain his excitement as he outlined all the spots where the countess of courses will go under the architect’s bulldozer shortly after Sunday’s conclusion of the Cadillac Championship.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: As Big East Basketball Tournament Fades, a Block Remains Fresh
abstract: For a tournament that defined a conference and became synonymous with the Garden, the 1986 final provided the Big East with a blueprint.
lead_paragraph: The game ended 27 years ago, half a lifetime ago, a few pounds ago, yet Dwayne Washington, known to all as Pearl, cannot forget. He will not forget. It still hurts, still stings, the way his Big East career ended, at the 1986 conference tournament finale, in the final seconds.

headline: Rebels in Syria Release U.N. Peacekeepers to Jordan, Easing Crisis in Border Zone
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The release ended a standoff that raised new questions about the fighters just as the United States and other Western nations were grappling over whether to arm them.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Syrian rebels released 21 detained United Nations peacekeepers to Jordanian forces on Saturday, ending a three-day standoff that raised new tensions in the region and new questions about the fighters just as the United States and other nations were grappling over whether to allow more arms to flow to the rebel movement.

headline: Variety: A Timely Acrostic
abstract: A timely acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The author of today’s quote is someone to admire, in my opinion. Nina Berberova was a published writer who chronicled the lives of Russian émigrés in Europe, and while this alone was an accomplishment for a woman of her time, she also made some very brave life choices. Ms. Berberova had a spirit and level of self-awareness that I find intriguing. Here is another quote from the same book that sparked today’s puzzle:

headline: U.S. Again Delays Transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghan Forces
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Detainees', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)']
abstract: A ceremony was called off at the last minute after President Hamid Karzai rejected some measures of the deal, including an American veto over any release.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The promised American transfer of Bagram Prison to Afghan control collapsed once again on Saturday amid misunderstandings and recriminations between the two allies, punctuated by a deadly bombing outside the Afghan Defense Ministry.

headline: Snow in Colorado. Really?
abstract: Saturday’s M.L.S. match between the Rapids and Philadelphia Union in Colorado was postponed one day because of a blizzard in the area.
lead_paragraph: If you happen to be a member of Costa Rica’s national team preparing for the World Cup qualifying match against the United States that will be played outside Denver in less than two weeks, a glance at Saturday’s weather forecast for the area might fill you with dread.

headline: At 43, Yankees’ Rivera Confirms That He’ll Retire in Fall
abstract: Mariano Rivera announced on Saturday that the 2013 season will be his last, bringing an end to one of the most successful careers in Yankees’ history.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past 18 years, the Yankees have relied on Mariano Rivera to pitch in the late innings with games on the line.

headline: Yahoo’s Next Big Play: South by Southwest
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Yahoo has increased its presence at the annual South by Southwest festival in Texas in hopes of burnishing its image among the tech elite gathering there.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A quick spin through the South by Southwest lineup reveals the usual suspects: young start-ups vying to become the next big thing, up-and-coming musical acts, talks by Internet luminaries, and technology meet-ups on topics as varied as learning how to be an angel investor and workshops in 3-D printing.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Science and Politics
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Medicine and Health', 'Gun Control', 'Research']
abstract: Is anti-science sentiment threatening public health policy?
lead_paragraph: Is anti-science sentiment threatening public health policy?

headline: China Says It Won’t Forsake North Korea, Despite Support for U.N. Sanctions
abstract: Careful remarks by the foreign minister masked the plain-spoken discussions among China’s officials and analysts about the value of supporting North Korea even as it continues to develop nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s foreign minister said Saturday that Beijing would not abandon North Korea, reiterating China’s longstanding position that dialogue, not sanctions, is the best way to persuade the North to abandon its nuclear weapons.

headline: Dutch Seek to Extend Their Record of Upsets
abstract: The Netherlands, not known as a baseball powerhouse, toppled Cuba and prepared to take on Japan in pool play in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Netherlands quietly took batting practice at Tokyo Dome on Saturday. Its sluggers, in orange jerseys and caps, casually peppered balls into the blue seats in left, seemingly unaware that their team was once again sending shock waves through the baseball world.

headline: What Hath Rand Paul Wrought?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: He’s coaxing the Republican Party to move past the Bush-era foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: THE Republican Party built an advantage on foreign policy across generations, and then began demolishing it 10 years ago this month. What the cold war made, the invasion of Iraq largely unmade: beginning in 2003, a party that had long promised — and mostly delivered — peace through strength became identified with an intelligence fiasco, a botched occupation and the squandering of American resources, credibility and lives.

headline: Nets Make Full Effort to Fit Into Brooklyn
abstract: The Nets have been able to keep the momentum going for their move to Brooklyn by being involved in all aspects of the community.
lead_paragraph: When a team is about to play its first game of the season, and the owner publicly states that anything less than a trip to the Eastern Conference finals would be a disappointment, pressure is created that is hard to live up to. For the Brooklyn Nets, who invested heavily in putting together a winning team in their first season since their move from New Jersey, the pressure created by the team’s owner Mikhail Prokhorov has seemingly distracted from what has otherwise been a successful move for both the Nets and Brooklyn.

headline: After Rancorous Debate, Colorado Senate Advances Strict New Measures on Gun Control
abstract: The proposals, which await a final Senate vote, call for new ammunition magazine limits and universal background checks.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Colorado took a major step late Friday toward enacting some of the toughest new gun measures that have been introduced since the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut touched off a national debate about gun control.

headline: No to Keystone. Yes to Crazy.
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: If the oil pipeline is approved, President Obama will need to make it up to his green base.
lead_paragraph: I HOPE the president turns down the Keystone XL oil pipeline. (Who wants the U.S. to facilitate the dirtiest extraction of the dirtiest crude from tar sands in Canada’s far north?) But I don’t think he will. So I hope that Bill McKibben and his 350.org coalition go crazy. I’m talking chain-themselves-to-the-White-House-fence-stop-traffic-at-the-Capitol kind of crazy, because I think if we all make enough noise about this, we might be able to trade a lousy Keystone pipeline for some really good systemic responses to climate change. We don’t get such an opportunity often — namely, a second-term Democratic president who is under heavy pressure to approve a pipeline to create some jobs but who also has a green base that he can’t ignore. So cue up the protests, and pay no attention to people counseling rational and mature behavior. We need the president to be able to say to the G.O.P. oil lobby, “I’m going to approve this, but it will kill me with my base. Sasha and Malia won’t even be talking to me, so I’ve got to get something really big in return.”

headline: As Time Goes Bye
abstract: A reverie about the newsmagazine’s days of roast beef, Scotch and snazzy adjectives.
lead_paragraph: AUSPICIOUS my debut at Time was not.

headline: Calmness of Seattle Inspires Second Chances
abstract: Oliver Perez and Jason Bay, who both struggled with the Mets, have shown the benefits of escaping to a faraway setting like Seattle.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz.

headline: Geraldine Knatz
abstract: The executive director of the nation’s busiest port on her pink ’57 Thunderbird and her inner Martha Stewart.
lead_paragraph: Geraldine Knatz is executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, the nation’s busiest. Encompassing 7,500 acres on 43 miles of waterfront, the port handled more than $273 billion in cargo last year and is responsible for 3 million jobs.

headline: The Dow Jones Emotional Average
abstract: Following the market’s mood swings.
lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones closed at a record high last week, leaving investors both richer and further perplexed by a market that continues to exhibit textbook signs of bipolar personality disorder. Herewith, a psycho-diary chronicling the many moods of the Dow Jones.

headline: A Presto, Change-O Opening Night at SXSW
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone” opened the South by Southwest film festival in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Magic was on the streets and on the screen here in Austin on Friday at the opening night of the South by Southwest film festival. This year’s selection, “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone,” featured a starry cast in telling its story about a Vegas-performing magic duo (Steve Carell and Steve Buscemi) and a new kind of magician (Jim Carrey) who threatens to steal their thunder. Olivia Wilde also stars as a magician’s assistant aspiring to be a bigger part of the act.

headline: Yankees Counting Injuries and Pennies
abstract: Faced with injuries to several important players, the Yankees have apparently decided not to shop for high-profile and expensive replacements.
lead_paragraph: These are not George Steinbrenner’s Yankees. Several injuries in spring training, and the team’s response to them, have served to drive home that point.

headline: At Global Showcase, a Blowout and a Brawl
abstract: The World Baseball Classic’s unusual tiebreaker rules, which value run differential, played a role in a bench-clearing brawl late in Canada’s victory over Mexico.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When players stand on the baselines before games in the World Baseball Classic, they hold caps from their countries to exchange with members of the other team. That spirit of good will crumbled Saturday under a tangled pile of players from Canada and Mexico.

headline: Of Fraud and Filet
abstract: Food surprises on both sides of the Atlantic are reminders that almost every bite we take is a leap of faith.
lead_paragraph: THERE are many lessons a person might rightly or wrongly divine from the horse meat scare in Europe, including this: You should perhaps think twice before buying meatballs from a furniture purveyor, unless those meatballs are humongous and nonperishable, and double as ottomans.

headline: Fan Sees Rivera’s Retirement as the Start of His Own Goodbye to Baseball
abstract: After watching Mariano Rivera announce his plan to retire at the end of the season, a lifelong Yankees fan said he, too, would quit baseball.
lead_paragraph: Watching Mariano Rivera on Saturday announce his plan to retire at the end of the season, after nearly two decades with the New York Yankees, David Quinones said that an era was drawing to a close — not just for Rivera or the sport he so thoroughly dominated, but also for Mr. Quinones’s life as a fan.

headline: The Liberals Against Affirmative Action
abstract: With most cases before the Supreme Court, liberals would contemplate a 5-to-4 decision with dread. But the affirmative action case comes with a fascinating wrinkle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: The Gun Report: March 9, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: After Roger Hartley lost his friend Mark Hummels to gun violence in January, he realized Hummels was the ninth person he knew who’d been killed or injured by a gun. So he posed a question to his Facebook friends: “How many people have you known who’ve been the victims of gun violence? Suicide, accidental, murder. No politics. No judgment. Just a number.”

headline: Los Angeles Frets After Low Turnout to Elect Mayor
abstract: Only 21 percent of registered voters turned out for the Los Angeles mayoral election last week, and some residents are both embarrassed and concerned.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The roughly $19 million spent in the 2013 mayoral primary here made it the most expensive on record. But that is not the number that has people agog. Just 21 percent of registered voters turned out for last week’s election — the lowest rate for a primary without an incumbent since at least 1978.

headline: Don’t Be Afraid of Genetic Modification
abstract: We shouldn’t let political calculations or unfounded fears keep safe genetically modified animals off the market.
lead_paragraph: IF patience is a virtue, then AquaBounty, a Massachusetts biotech company, might be the most virtuous entity on the planet.

headline: Chicago’s Blistering Pace Punctuates Whirlwind First Half
abstract: Assessing the best and worst of the 48-game N.H.L. schedule so far, and what to look for in the second half.
lead_paragraph: How short is this lockout-abbreviated N.H.L. season? After seven weeks, it is half over, and the homestretch is about to begin. Here is a look at the best and worst of the 48-game schedule so far, and what to look for in the second half.

headline: eToys vs. Goldman Sachs: The Documents
abstract: The following are a selection of documents that are part of the litigation between eToys creditors and Goldman Sachs over the 1999 eToys IPO.
lead_paragraph: The following are a selection of documents that are part of the litigation between eToys creditors and Goldman Sachs over the 1999 eToys IPO.

headline:
How a U.S.
    Citizen Came to
    Be in America’s
    Cross Hairs
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: An account of how the United States came to use a drone strike to kill the American-born terrorist leader Anwar al-Awlaki highlights the perils of a war conducted behind a classified veil.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One morning in late September 2011, a group of American drones took off from an airstrip the C.I.A. had built in the remote southern expanse of Saudi Arabia. The drones crossed the border into Yemen, and were soon hovering over a group of trucks clustered in a desert patch of Jawf Province, a region of the impoverished country once renowned for breeding Arabian horses.

headline: Rigging the I.P.O. Game
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: What a decade-old dot-com I.P.O. case says about Wall Street today.
lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time, in a very different age, an Internet start-up called eToys went public. The date was May 20, 1999. The offering price had been set at $20, but investors in that frenzied era were so eager for eToys shares that the stock immediately shot up to $78. It ended its first day of trading at $77 a share.

headline: Student Debt and the Economy
abstract: Borrowers with private loans need help before they are ruined by default.
lead_paragraph: The student loan debt crisis has become a drag on the economy. Younger Americans who are saddled with bankrupting payments — or credit ratings damaged by delinquency — are in no position to buy homes, save for retirement or start businesses.

headline: Putting Corporate Cash to Work
abstract: What should profitable companies like Apple do with their growing piles of money?
lead_paragraph: What should successful companies do with their growing piles of cash? Apple, which has $140 billion on hand, is being forced to address this question by one of its prominent shareholders.

headline: Malaysia Detains 79 in Fight Against Filipinos
abstract: Followers of a sultan seeking to re-establish a historic claim over part of Borneo Island have been under attack by Malaysian forces.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Malaysian authorities announced Saturday that they had detained 79 people they suspected of being sympathizers of Filipino fighters who recently landed on Borneo in an attempt to re-establish a historic claim to part of the island.

headline: The Right to Counsel: Badly Battered at 50
abstract: The Supreme Court said the poor must be provided with lawyers, but that promise has been mocked more often than fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: A half-century ago, the Supreme Court ruled that anyone too poor to hire a lawyer must be provided one free in any criminal case involving a felony charge. The holding in Gideon v. Wainwright enlarged the Constitution’s safeguards of liberty and equality, finding the right to counsel “fundamental.” The goal was “fair trials before impartial tribunals in which every defendant stands equal before the law.”

headline: Birth Culture
abstract: Cultural expectations and practices of birth vary around the world.
lead_paragraph: Cultural expectations and practices of birth vary around the world.

headline: Living With Less. A Lot Less.
abstract: The many things I consumed ended up consuming me.
lead_paragraph: I LIVE in a 420-square-foot studio. I sleep in a bed that folds down from the wall. I have six dress shirts. I have 10 shallow bowls that I use for salads and main dishes. When people come over for dinner, I pull out my extendable dining room table. I don’t have a single CD or DVD and I have 10 percent of the books I once did.

headline: The Danger of Suppressing the Leaks
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Those who reveal classified material are being punished like never before.
lead_paragraph: IMAGINE if American citizens never learned about the abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib. Imagine not knowing about the brutal treatment of terror suspects at United States government “black sites.” Or about the drone program that is expanding under President Obama, or the Bush administration’s warrantless wiretapping of Americans.

headline: Life’s Unequal Beginnings
abstract: A photographer looks at the struggle to provide women with safe, respectful care during child birth.
lead_paragraph: FOR the past six years I have been photographing birth, looking at its universal as well as cultural aspects, and the struggle to provide women with safe, respectful care. An estimated quarter of a million women die each year from pregnancy-related causes like pre-eclampsia. Though the number of women who die in pregnancy or childbirth is half what it was 20 years ago, most of these deaths could have been prevented.

headline: Big East Memories: When the Huskies Were Pups
abstract: For one loyal UConn fan, Big East tournaments became memorable after Jim Calhoun was hired at Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Writers who covered the Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories.

headline: Repeal the Military Force Law
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Targeted Killings', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The 2001 resolution, enacted after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, has outlived its purpose and become the basis for perpetual war.
lead_paragraph: Three days after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, Congress approved the Authorization for Use of Military Force. It was enacted with good intentions — to give President George W. Bush the authority to invade Afghanistan and go after Al Qaeda and the Taliban rulers who sheltered and aided the terrorists who had attacked the United States.

headline: The Revolution Will Be Tweeted!
abstract: Hugo Chávez was the world’s leading Socialist on social media, with over four million followers on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: IN the pantheon of world leaders who have embraced 140-character communication, Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s late president, neared the top. Since he first logged on to Twitter three years ago, President Chávez out-tweeted many of his peers with an average of 12 messages each week, nearly all from a BlackBerry. He had more than four million followers and was the second most followed leader on Twitter, after President Obama, whom Mr. Chávez once called a “clown.” In a tweet, Mr. Chávez decried both Mr. Obama and his “gringo imperialist government.”

abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani has signed his name to a fund-raising letter for Joseph J. Lhota, saying the Republican candidate for mayor would “stand up to the destructive policies of tax-and-spend politicians.”
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, has signed his name to a fund-raising letter for Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican candidate for mayor, highlighting how closely the campaign will work with a figure who has, at times, polarized the city’s political world.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: In the Beginning
abstract: The A.C.P.T. standings start pouring in.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Puzzle 4 has just started, and the big news at the end of puzzle 3 is that computer solver Dr. Fill finished with a mistake. That surely will not help him in his quest to beat reigning champion Dan Feyer.

headline: Keep Calm and Carry On... Buying
abstract: Will Google and Amazon turn us into anxious information machines?
lead_paragraph: OUR fully automated, meme-conscious information economy might seem a paradise of reason and rationality. But it also has a seamier, surreal side. Just consider how the phrase “Keep Calm and Rape a Lot” came to appear on T-shirts sold on Amazon.co.uk.

headline: Insomnia and the Poet
abstract: A dark night of the soul, heartache, remorse, guilt, desire, God-hunger — surely this, and not obstructed airways, is the stuff of poetry.
lead_paragraph: Insomnia is never far from my thoughts, especially when I am writing. A poor sleeper even as a girl, I spent many nights scribbling diary entries in a notebook on the bathroom floor after our crowded household had gone to bed. As an adult, with three spirited children and a full-time job, I often sought the desk in the wee hours by necessity. Those liminal hours between dark and dawn continue to haunt my praxis even now that my nest is empty. At night the smallest noises, including the surprising veracity of my own breathing, are more apparent and seem to command an acute attention. For me, there is nothing as inimitably private and attuned as nocturnal writing. As I type away at this piece, for example, I find myself grateful that a lifelong habit of insomnia churned me awake at 5 a.m. from my usual choppy spell of semiconsciousness, affording at least a couple of deliciously quiet hours to think and work before even the dog will rouse and the winter windows lighten.

headline: When Customer Service Isn’t Even Half-Baked
abstract: After trying repeatedly to get a new microwave oven in working order — and then asking the company for a refund — a Whirlpool customer turned to the Haggler to intervene.
lead_paragraph: SOME companies resolve consumer complaints in ways that are both efficient and empathetic, demonstrating not just a grasp of what defines good service but also the ways that brand loyalty is nurtured. Then there is Whirlpool.

abstract: William C. Rhoden remembers Georgetown’s John Thompson as one of the greatest and most influential forces in Big East history.
lead_paragraph: Writers who covered the Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories.

headline: Corralling Mobsters, if Not Many Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Mary Jo White, nominated to head the S.E.C., has a long résumé as a prosecutor, though it includes few cases against large financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows about the mobsters and terrorists that Mary Jo White successfully put behind bars during her nine years as United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Less well-known is Ms. White’s record bringing cases against large financial institutions during her stint as the top criminal prosecutor in New York.

headline: Big East Memories: 6 Overtimes, 1 Memorable Night
abstract: Mike Ogle remembers six-overtime Big East tournament quarterfinal between Syracuse and Connecticut from 2009.
lead_paragraph: When I think of the six-overtime Big East tournament quarterfinal between Syracuse and Connecticut that began on March 12, 2009, and ended March 13, I think of Jonny Flynn.

headline: To Relocate or Not? It’s More Than Math
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Before deciding to accept a job in a new city, consider your long-term prospects for advancement — and how you’ll adjust to a changed way of life.
lead_paragraph: Q. You have been offered a job in another part of the country. How do you determine whether it makes sense to embark on such a major life change?

headline: Trained by a Life of Change
abstract: The leader of the Paley Center for Media says that “an industry undergoing major change is the perfect place for me.”
lead_paragraph: DURING my earliest years, my father was in the Army and I often spent time with my grandparents, who farmed cotton and raised tobacco in rural Georgia. Later, my father and mother settled in Swainsboro, Ga., where my brother, seven years younger than me, was born.

headline: Yes, We’re Confident, but Who Knows Why
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", "Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index", 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)']
abstract: History shows that public confidence is fickle and little understood, but it can have great influence on the markets and the economy.
lead_paragraph: THE recovery in housing, the stock market and the overall economy has finally gained sustainable momentum — or so it is said.

headline: 30 Seconds With Stephane Matteau
abstract: An interview with Stephane Matteau, whose goal in double overtime in Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals against the Devils is a sweet memory for Rangers fans.
lead_paragraph: For Rangers fans, Stephane Matteau’s goal in double overtime in Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals against the Devils is a sweet memory. The Rangers went on to defeat the Vancouver Canucks for the Stanley Cup.

headline: A Billion Years of Time and Toil Are Etched in These Old Hills
abstract: A musical history of the Hudson Highlands.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a musical post honoring a classic March transition in the Hudson Valley from a blast of snow on Friday to a blaze of sunshine and hint of spring today. The sap is running strong in the sugar maples, guaranteeing good times at the “sap to syrup” festivals tomorrow at the Taconic Outdoor Education Center in Fahnestock State Park and on March 24 at Little Stony Point Park, where visitors will likely hear Pete Seeger sing about “maple syrup time.”

headline: N.Y.U.’s Global Leader Is Tested by Faculty at Home
abstract: The faculty of New York University is conducting a no-confidence vote on John Sexton, the university’s president, whom some consider a hero and others an autocrat.
lead_paragraph: Embarking on an ambitious expansion at home, constructing a network of new campuses around the globe, wooing intellectual superstars and raising vast amounts of money, John Sexton of New York University is the very model of a modern university president — the leader of a large corporation, pushing for growth on every front.

headline: Joining the Bandwagon? Don’t Lose Your Balance
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A stock market at a lofty peak can be high-risk for new investors. But if you still want to jump in, strategists advise keeping a diverse portfolio.
lead_paragraph: STOCKS are back. And that could be dangerous.

headline: Online Emotions, in Hundreds of New Flavors
abstract: Emoji and now online “stickers” have not been as popular in the United States as in other parts of the world. But some new American companies are trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: TO say that I like to send text messages is like saying Garfield likes lasagna. It is my expressive medium. On Wednesday alone, I sent at least 100 — but I like to send more than just words. I’m a big fan of using emoji, the colorful symbol alphabet that contains nearly a thousand images of cute animals, food items and expressive smiley faces to convey what words cannot.

headline: The Minimum Wage  and the Economy
abstract: Readers respond to “The Business of the Minimum Wage” (Economic View, March 5).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gauging Veterinarians’ Future
abstract: Leaders of the Association of American Veterinary Medical Colleges respond to “The Vet Debt Trap” (Feb. 24).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Fee-for-Health Model
abstract: A reader responds to “Overcoming Obstacles to Better Health Care” (Economic View, Feb. 24).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Price of Marriage in China
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Single Persons', 'Dating and Courtship', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: China’s economic rise has bred a new type of matchmaker — the love hunter — for those wishing to outsource their romantic search.
lead_paragraph: FROM her stakeout near the entrance of an H & M store in Joy City, a Beijing shopping mall, Yang Jing seemed lost in thought, twirling a strand of her auburn-tinted hair, tapping her nails on an aquamarine iPhone 4S. But her eyes kept moving. They tracked the clusters of young women zigzagging from Zara to Calvin Klein Jeans. They lingered on a face, a gesture, and then moved on, darting across the atrium, searching.

headline: The Two Venezuelas
abstract: Claudia Astor and her mother, Norma Astor, were on opposite sides of Venezuela’s political divide as they watched Hugo Chávez’s funeral on their television in Caracas.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Astor and her mother, Norma Astor, were on opposite sides of Venezuela’s political divide as they watched Hugo Chávez’s funeral on their television in Caracas.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: Puzzle 3 Shake Out
abstract: The re-emergence of Dan Feyer.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Six puzzles are part of A.C.P.T. lore now, and with three judged and scanned, there are new standings to report.

headline: Condensation
abstract: Wring out Finn Vigeland’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I hope you all brought towels, or at least a raincoat. We’re going to get wet today, but depending on how you feel about rebus puzzles, that will either make you feel happy or extremely frustrated. Let’s just say that there is no danger that anyone will CATCH FIRE around this grid.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 10
abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush is doing damage control, and will be featured on almost all of this week’s Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida made headlines in the past week after acknowledging he would be open to a run for the White House in 2016. But the renewed attention on Mr. Bush has been mixed. His book on immigration reform is dividing a Republican Party that is trying to connect with Latino voters. Mr. Bush is doing damage control, and will be featured on almost all of this week’s Sunday shows.

headline: The Leading Liberal Against Affirmative Action
abstract: Perhaps the most prominent self-described progressive with doubts about the current version of affirmative action is Richard D. Kahlenberg. He argues that the current race-focused version of affirmative action can be unfair, is inconsistent with many of the program’s original goals and has lost the support of the public.
lead_paragraph: My Capital Ideas column this week looks at liberals who would see some upsides if the Supreme Court made substantial changes to affirmative-action programs. The justices heard arguments in such a case in October — Fisher v. the University of Texas — and are expected to issue their decision between March 18 and late June.

headline: Buying High and Selling Low
abstract: Over the long term, investors in equity mutual funds have underperformed the S.&.P. 500.
lead_paragraph: Over the long term, investors in equity mutual funds have underperformed the S.&.P. 500.

headline: Venezuelan Election Set for April
abstract: Venezuela will hold a special election on April 14 to choose a new president to complete the term of Hugo Chávez. Nicolás Maduro will face Henrique Capriles Radonski.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela will hold a special election on April 14 to choose a new president to complete the term of Hugo Chávez, the charismatic socialist who died last week after a battle with cancer.

headline: Homegrown Talent at This Year’s SXSW
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Music']
abstract: This year’s South by Southwest has its big national stars, but almost 400 Texas-based acts are on the bill, too, and not all of them are from Austin.
lead_paragraph: After last year’s South by Southwest, talk focused largely on a pair of superstars. It’s not every day that Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band and Jay-Z drop into Texas to play relatively intimate venues. Meanwhile, nearly 2,000 other acts were showcased, including Fun., Ed Sheeran and the Lumineers, who all went from being virtual unknowns to Grammy performers just 10 months later.

headline: Step on Toes in Austin, and You Might Get a Slap
abstract: Giovanni Capriglione, a freshman Republican state representative, got a hazing from fellow legislators when he proposed a new ethics bill.
lead_paragraph: Only the brave and the foolish go against the legislative pack — even when they are on the side of the angels.

headline: Declared Innocent in a Killing, but Still in a Cell
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Witnesses', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: In 2008, Ben Spencer was found “factually innocent” of the killing of Jeffrey Young, yet he is still behind bars.
lead_paragraph: TENNESSEE COLONY, Tex. — In 2008, Ben Spencer’s family bought him clothes in preparation for a day they had prayed for since 1987. A Dallas County judge had declared Mr. Spencer innocent of the robbery and killing that sent him to prison for life.

headline: Recipe for Divided Europe: Add Horse, Then Stir
keywords: ['Horses', 'Meat', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: At a time of immense strains brought on by the euro crisis and austerity, the horse meat scandal has brought into the open the deep divisions that bedevil Europe.
lead_paragraph: OLOMOUC, Czech Republic — For Zuzana Navelkova, it was just another day at the office. She showed up for work last month and found a two-pound bag of frozen Swedish meatballs awaiting her attention.

headline: U.T.-El Paso President Still Making Waves
abstract: Diana Natalicio has been president of the University of El Paso since 1988, and she is still battling for the needs of underserved, often low-income and minority, student populations.
lead_paragraph: Days after Diana Natalicio became president of the University of Texas at El Paso in 1988, the first woman to hold that job, a local newspaper ran an illustration of her as Wonder Woman. As she begins her 26th year at the helm — the longest tenure at the head of a Texas public university among current presidents — that depiction remains apt.

headline: Power Struggle on Reforming Vatican Bank
abstract: The Vatican is under mounting pressure to clean up its bank — long the subject of dark intrigue — in a push by the European Union to apply common rules for the use of the euro.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Negotiations over the Vatican’s adherence to international banking standards were reaching a delicate point. During a lunch, a European official later recalled, discussion turned to the need for more openness from an institution steeped in centuries of secrecy.

headline: Grandmaster Draws Persist, but So Do Fights to the End
abstract: Intentional draws to maintain a share of the prize are a scourge of tournaments, but others must compete for first.
lead_paragraph: Grandmaster draws, the scourge of competition, are unfortunately alive and well.

headline: In Public Eye, Shining Star of Myanmar Loses Luster
abstract: For Myanmar’s opposition leader in Parliament, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace laureate, the transition from dissident to politician has not been easy.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — She endured years of house arrest and was steadfast as her political movement was decimated and her colleagues were tortured. But now, as the leader of Myanmar’s opposition in Parliament, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace laureate, is courting her former jailers.

headline: On Questioning the Jewish State
abstract: It is not anti-Semitic to argue that a nation that favors one “people” over another can never be fully just.
lead_paragraph: I was raised in a religious Jewish environment, and though we were not strongly Zionist, I always took it to be self-evident that “Israel has a right to exist.” Now anyone who has debated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will have encountered this phrase often. Defenders of Israeli policies routinely accuse Israel’s critics of denying her right to exist, while the critics (outside of a small group on the left, where I now find myself) bend over backward to insist that, despite their criticisms, of course they affirm it. The general mainstream consensus seems to be that to deny Israel’s right to exist is a clear indication of anti-Semitism (a charge Jews like myself are not immune to), and therefore not an option for people of conscience.

headline: Neighborhoods Seek to Banish Sex Offenders by Building Parks
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Probation and Parole', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Because of limits on where such offenders can live, the measure is effective for a community, but may be counterproductive to public safety over all.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Parents who pick up their children at the bus stop in this city’s Harbor Gateway neighborhood say they often see men wearing GPS ankle bracelets and tell their children to stay away. Just up the street, 30 paroled sex offenders live in a single apartment building, including rapists and child molesters. More than 100 registered sex offenders live within a few miles.

headline: Moshiach Oi! Performs
abstract: The city’s top and perhaps only Hasidic hardcore band, Moshiach Oi!, plays to a group at a Brooklyn community center.
lead_paragraph: The city’s top and perhaps only Hasidic hardcore band, Moshiach Oi!, plays to a group at a Brooklyn community center.

headline: Jeter Makes His Debut
abstract: Derek Jeter returned to game action Saturday for the first time since he broke his ankle in the 12th inning of Game 1 of the American League Championship Series, and it went well.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA — Derek Jeter returned to game action Saturday for the first time since he broke his ankle in the 12th inning of Game 1 of the American League Championship Series, and it went well.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: The Competition Heats Up
abstract: Reactions to Patrick Blindauer’s puzzle 5.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — After a particularly devilish puzzle 5 by Patrick Blindauer and a somewhat easier puzzle 6, the top three contenders for the finals are still Dan Feyer, Tyler Hinman, and Anne Erdmann. Francis Heaney is in 4th place and Stella Zawistowski and Kiran Kedlaya are tied for 5th place. The puzzle by Mr. Blindauer is the one that everyone seems to be talking about, and with good cause: puzzle 5 at the A.C.P.T. is notoriously the most difficult solve of the entire tournament. I apologize for not being able to share more about the puzzles, but all details are secret until those solving by mail and online are finished.

headline: Stoudemire Is Out Six Weeks for Knee Operation
abstract: Knicks forward Amar’e Stoudemire had been playing well since returning from a left knee injury. Now he is expected to miss the rest of the regular season to recover from surgery on his right knee.
lead_paragraph: Knicks forward Amar’e Stoudemire will have surgery on his right knee and is expected to miss six weeks, the team announced Saturday.

headline: With No Tears, Rivera Confirms That This Season Will Be His Last
abstract: Although the focus was on Mariano Rivera’s departure from the game, Saturday also marked the celebration of his return to the mound for the first time since last April 30.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Throughout what could have been a highly emotional day, from the morning news conference to the first strains of “Enter Sandman” and the two standing ovations he received from the crowd at a sold-out stadium, Mariano Rivera never shed a tear, at least not publicly.

headline: Newspaper Adds New Obstacle to Tribunal Investigating Lebanese Official’s Death
keywords: ['Witnesses', 'Newspapers', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media', 'International Relations']
abstract: A newspaper has published the names of likely witnesses in the murder trial of Rafik Hariri, the former prime minister who was assassinated in 2005.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The first shock came when a leading Lebanese newspaper published a confidential list of 17 witnesses who may testify in the murder trial of a former prime minister — showing their names, passport pictures, dates of birth and where they work.

headline: Savoring Parting Shots of a Rivalry, the Hoyas Overpower the Orange
abstract: Georgetown coasted in its final regular-season meeting with Syracuse. The Orange leave the Big East for the A.C.C. next season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The curtain came down with a thud on one of college basketball’s most storied rivalries Saturday as No. 5 Georgetown trounced No. 17 Syracuse, 61-39, in the final regular-season meeting between the teams before the Orange leave the Big East.

headline: Before a Falklands Vote, Bad Blood Surges Anew
abstract: The Falkland Islands are likely to maintain ties to Britain in a vote that has provoked an aggressive stand by Argentina, which also claims the territory.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Sunday and Monday, the inhabitants of the Falkland Islands, a wind-swept, sparsely populated archipelago that was a final way station for early 20th-century explorers like Ernest Shackleton en route to the icy wastes of Antarctica, will go to the polls in a referendum on the islands’ future.

headline: Menachem Froman, Rabbi Seeking Peace, Dies at 68
abstract: Rabbi Froman’s grand, unrealized vision was that the enmity between Jewish settlers and their Palestinian neighbors could be erased by appeals to religious ideals.
lead_paragraph: Menachem Froman, a maverick Orthodox rabbi who helped lead settlers into the territory seized by Israel in its 1967 war with Arab nations, then became a fervent, startlingly unconventional voice for conciliation with the Palestinians, died on Monday in Tekoa in the Israeli-administrated West Bank. He was 68.

headline: Unrelenting Woods Stands Apart, With Field Struggling to Stay in Touch
abstract: With a 67, Tiger Woods moved to a blistering 18 under par at the World Golf Championships event, expanding his lead over Graeme McDowell.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — It would have been easier on Saturday for Graeme McDowell to reel in a marlin off the coast of Florida than Tiger Woods at the Blue Monster. McDowell began the day two strokes behind Woods in the Cadillac Championship, and after playing the front nine in 32 strokes, equaling the low start of the day, he was still one shot behind.

headline: Dirk Coetzee, South African Official Who Led Apartheid-Era Killings, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Coetzee was a divisive figure who led killings of antiapartheid activists in South Africa and later detailed accounts of a corrupt police force.
lead_paragraph: Dirk Coetzee, who led a South African police hit squad that killed antiapartheid activists, and who eventually confessed to his crimes as his country began shifting away from official racial segregation, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Pretoria. He was 67.

headline: Police Shoot Man During a Traffic Stop on Staten Island
abstract: An officer opened fire on the driver after he tried to flee and appeared to reach for a weapon, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A police officer shot a man in the torso as he tried to flee during a traffic stop on Staten Island on Saturday, the police said. The man, who was not immediately identified, appeared to have reached for a weapon, the authorities said.

headline: Santana Misses Workout, but Mets Play It Down
abstract: The team’s highest-paid player has yet to appear in a spring training game this year.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Johan Santana did not work out with his teammates Saturday morning. Instead, he remained indoors to stretch his arm and receive extra treatment on it.

headline: Den Dekker Comes Up With Another Highlight in Center
abstract: A Mets prospect already known for his defensive prowess takes an extra-base hit away with a sliding catch on the warning track.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Matt den Dekker, a Mets minor league center fielder who has already compiled a substantial highlight reel of athletic and improbable catches, made another spectacular catch Saturday.

headline: Threats Sow Concerns Over Korean Armistice
keywords: ['Korean War', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: North Koreans have said many times over the years that they were disregarding the armistice ending the Korean War. What is unclear this time is whether they mean it.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s latest threats to annihilate its enemies have included a vow to scrap the 1953 armistice, the main legal document that theoretically stands in the way of a resumption of the Korean War, a conflict that by some estimates left nearly five million people dead, including more than 33,700 American soldiers.

headline: Corrections: March 10, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 10, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Kings Point, a Magic Kingdom for the Retirement Set
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Retirement', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: An HBO documentary captures the good and the bad of life in a Florida community — a life my mother saw up close.
lead_paragraph: I loved my mom very much, but never looked forward to visiting her at Kings Point, a huge, gated retirement community in Delray Beach, Fla.

headline: Too Young to Retire, but These Deals Can’t Wait
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Condominiums', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Baby boomers are finding themselves drawn to condos at retirement communities where prices have plunged since the recession.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Susan Shapira, who is 58, recently moved into a condominium in Century Village, a gated retirement community here where most residents are almost as old as the name.

headline: Share of Homes With Guns Shows 4-Decade Decline
abstract: The rate has fallen from an average of 50 percent in the 1970s to 35 percent in the 2000s, suggesting a shift in demographics even as the debate over gun control remains contentious.
lead_paragraph: The share of American households with guns has declined over the past four decades, a national survey shows, with some of the most surprising drops in the South and the Western mountain states, where guns are deeply embedded in the culture.
