headline: Stoudemire Needs Operation on What Was His Good Knee
abstract: The Knicks did not let the news of Amar’e Stoudemire’s coming six-week absence affect them as they rolled to victory against Utah.
lead_paragraph: Amar’e Stoudemire made his season debut for the Knicks on New Year’s Day, and the team embraced his return as a way to breathe fresh life into the roster just as their sensational start began looking more serious.

headline: No Barrage by Williams, but Success Is the Same
abstract: A night after his 3-point bonanza, Deron Williams was a modest 5 of 13 from the field, but he calmly and efficiently led the Nets to a win over the Hawks.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — One night after his 3-point bonanza, Deron Williams gave the nets a break. He did not try to replicate his record night from beyond the arc, but instead controlled the pace offensively and defensively against one of the fastest teams in the Eastern Conference. Williams was the point guard, not the shooting guard, and his floor game helped make for an impressive 93-80 win over the Atlanta Hawks on Saturday night at Philips Arena.

headline: Harvard Searched E-Mails for Source of Media Leaks
abstract: The administration searched staff e-mails to try to root out the source of leaks to the news media in a cheating scandal, and the staff members were not told until months later.
lead_paragraph: Harvard secretly searched the e-mail accounts of several of its staff members last fall, looking for the source of news media leaks about its recent cheating scandal, but did not tell them about the searches for several months, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 10
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 10.
lead_paragraph: “I would still eat these meatballs. No problem.”

headline: With Loss, Isner Takes a Big Step Down
abstract: John Isner’s loss in the second round at Indian Wells means that no American man will be ranked in the top 20.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — On the court where he had stepped up a year earlier, John Isner stepped down.

headline: Against Puerto Rico, Venezuela Comes Up Short Again
abstract: Coach Luis Sojo had hoped this would be Venezuela’s year at the World Baseball Classic, after two relatively unremarkable appearances in 2006 and 2009. But Puerto Rico eliminated Venezuela in the first round.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Luis Sojo arrived in Puerto Rico weeks removed from another championship in a career full of them. Navegantes del Magallanes, the team that Sojo manages in the Venezuelan winter league, took the title over Cardenales de Lara, and Sojo was a central figure. After all, he spent 21 seasons with the Cardenales as a second baseman, collecting five batting titles. In his baseball life, Sojo is intimately familiar with excellence.

headline: Anna Resnick, Ilan Caplan
abstract: Both the bride and groom are graduates of Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Anna Michelle Resnick, a daughter of Wendy Miller Resnick and Marc A. Resnick of Millersville, Md., is to be married Sunday to Ilan Joseph Caplan, a son of Nancy G. Caplan and Cantor Joel E. Caplan of Caldwell, N.J. The father of the groom, who is the cantor at Congregation Agudath Israel in Caldwell, will officiate at the Grand Lodge of A.F. & A.M. of Maryland, a Masonic lodge in Cockeysville, Md.

headline: Shaina Schallop, Garrett Kamen
abstract: The couple, lawyers in New York, are married in Palm Beach, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Shaina Joy Schallop and Garrett Scott Kamen were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Michael P. Singer at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla. Cantor Danielle Bensimhon took part in the ceremony.

headline: Alfred Boll and Joost van Hout
abstract: A foreign service officer and a business development officer, both of whom work in Brazil, marry in New York.
lead_paragraph: A Truly International Relationship

headline: Korin Katzen, Neal Cohen
abstract: The bride is a director of events and promotions for Gucci; the groom owns a business that designs store displays.
lead_paragraph: Korin Jill Katzen and Neal Jay Cohen were married Saturday evening at the New Synagogue of Fort Lee in Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Meir M. Berger, the synagogue’s spiritual leader, performed the ceremony. On April 20, Dee Shamo, a justice of the peace for Providenciales, in Turks and Caicos, will lead a second ceremony that will also feature Jewish wedding traditions, at the Somerset Resort there.

headline: Alice Wylie and Alexander Schmemann
abstract: The bride teaches ballet and yoga; the groom is the managing editor of an international policy program.
lead_paragraph: Alice Belle Wylie and Alexander Schmemann were to be married Sunday at St. Nicholas Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Valery Shemchuk, a Russian Orthodox priest, is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Virginia Lam and Marc Abrams
abstract: The bride and groom met through an online dating service and continued to build on their relationship.
lead_paragraph: Meeting Online (Don’t Tell Her Parents)

headline: Meryl Rosen, Roderick Bernstein
abstract: The bride is an assistant general counsel at Gilt Groupe; the groom is a director in the legal group at Accenture in New York.
lead_paragraph: Meryl Gail Rosen and Roderick Samuel Bernstein were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Cantor Neil Benisvy officiated.

headline: Molly Moran and Mark Synnes
abstract: The bride is a lawyer with the Justice Department; the groom is a senior counsel in the Office of the Legislative Counsel of the House of Representatives.
lead_paragraph: Molly June Moran and Mark Andrew Synnes were married Saturday evening at Old St. Patrick’s Church in Chicago. The Rev. Donald J. Fenske, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Anna Glanfield, Michael Hennessy
abstract: The couple met at Lehigh University.
lead_paragraph: Anna Elizabeth Glanfield, the daughter of Sheila E. Glanfield and Thomas H. Glanfield of Delray Beach, Fla., was married Saturday to Michael Fitzgerald Hennessy, a son of Patricia F. Hennessy and Michael J. Hennessy, both of Vineland, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Amy Rublin, Justin Mayer
abstract: The bride and the groom are lawyers in New York.
lead_paragraph: Amy Deborah Rublin, the daughter of Harriet K. Rublin and Burt M. Rublin of Wynnewood, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Justin David Mayer, a son of Debra Mayer of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Stephen Mayer. Rabbi Joshua Z. Gruenberg officiated at the Four Seasons hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: Talia Davis, Daniel Haykin
abstract: The couple marries in Denver, where they work, she as a marketing manager and he as an investment adviser.
lead_paragraph: Small Garden, Big Yield: A Marriage

headline: Rachel Rovner, Adam Rozen
abstract: The bride graduated from the University of Michigan and the groom from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Hilary Rovner and Adam Mark Rozen were married Saturday in Chicago. Rabbi Sidney M. Helbraun officiated at the InterContinental Chicago Magnificent Mile Hotel, assisted by Justice Judith J. Gische of State Supreme Court in New York.

headline: Ann Ricks and Kevin Duffy
abstract: The bride is an obstetrician and gynecologist; the groom is an M.B.A. student at Yale.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ann Marie Ricks and Kevin John Duffy were married Saturday in Houston. The Rev. Edward Seton Fittin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Michael Catholic Church.

headline: Christia Blomquist, Samuel Freedman
abstract: The bride is a freelance writer; the groom, a professor and writer.
lead_paragraph: Christia Chana Blomquist and Samuel G. Freedman are to be married Sunday evening at Columbia University Faculty House in New York. Rabbi Jeremy Kalmanofsky is to officiate with Rabbi Morris Allen taking part.

headline: Toba Goldfein and Yossi Goldstein
abstract: The bride is studying for a bachelor’s degree in biological sciences; the groom is a freelance sports reporter.
lead_paragraph: Toba Gittel Goldfein, the daughter of Dr. Bea H. Goldfein and Rabbi Ephraim Goldfein of Philadelphia, is to be married Sunday to Yossi Goldstein, a son of Seema E. Goldstein and Jacob Z. Goldstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Edelman, the groom’s maternal grandfather, is to officiate at the Springfield Country Club in Springfield, Pa.

headline: Marguerite Daniels, Sean Anderson
abstract: The bride is a Web designer; the groom, an engineer.
lead_paragraph: Marguerite Danita Daniels and Sean Philip Anderson were married Saturday at the Zoellner Arts Center in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Wilson Kratz of the Journeys of the Heart ministries officiated.

headline: Wright’s Slam Gives U.S Life in World Baseball Classic
abstract: David Wright hit a two-out grand slam in the fifth inning, and the Americans rebounded from a loss to Mexico at the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — For an understated star like David Wright, it was a telling display of emotion. Wright had crushed a ball toward the left-field seats at Chase Field, and he skipped — just for a moment — on his first steps out of the batter’s box. He had earned the right to let loose, in his own way.

headline: For Chinese, Maldives Boycott Goes Beyond Instant Noodles
abstract: Allegations that a Maldives hotel had removed kettles to prevent Chinese tourists from cooking instant noodles is stoking anger in China, amid a broader debate of how to behave while overseas.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Call it, perhaps, a storm in a kettle: A report that an upscale hotel in the Maldives removed kettles from the rooms of travelers from China to stop Chinese guests from cooking instant noodles in their rooms and not dining in hotel restaurant facilities has incited an online uproar here amid allegations of discrimination.

headline: Retirement Central
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Retirement', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Lured by the affordable price, Susan Shapira, 58, recently moved into a condominium in the Century Village retirement complex in Boca Raton, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Lured by the affordable price, Susan Shapira, 58, recently moved into a condominium in the Century Village retirement complex in Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: 2 Cabinet Agencies Are Cut in Restructuring by China
abstract: The Ministry of Railways, long criticized as being a haven of corruption, will be split, and the Ministry of Health will merge with the commission that manages China’s one-child policy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese officials announced Sunday that the government would consolidate some cabinet-level ministries in an attempt to streamline the bureaucracy. The move is the seventh restructuring in three decades, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
abstract: Head, talking again.
lead_paragraph: On this morning. I think we’re talking about horsemeat, or something.

headline: The IMF on the Austerity Trap
abstract: Tales of Osbornia.
lead_paragraph: The IMF has just released a new paper on austerity that is kind of heavy going (unnecessarily, I think), but ends up making a simple but important point.

headline: Attack, Said to Be Drone Strike by U.S., Kills 2 in Pakistan
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: If confirmed, the attack could be the first U.S. strike in Waziristan in two months — one of the longest operational pauses since the drone campaign started in earnest in mid-2008.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Two people suspected of being militants were killed Sunday morning in the volatile North Waziristan tribal region by what Pakistani and Taliban officials said was a drone strike.

headline: Intensive Care
abstract: If my family history taught me anything, it was that hospitals meant death. So when my newborn son contracted a dangerous disease, I braced for the worst.
lead_paragraph: Our son was born healthy, large and pink-skinned, with a newborn assessment score of a perfect 10, but an hour after his birth, a nurse told us that something was wrong. He was jaundiced. It was not a typical case of jaundice; his bilirubin levels kept increasing at an alarming rate. I’d only seen him for a few moments — he’d been delivered by C-section, then whisked away for the usual tests and procedures — but now, as I was moved to a recovery room, the doctors couldn’t tell me when I might see my baby again.

headline: With a Tour of the City, Quinn Declares Her Candidacy for Mayor
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker, visited all five boroughs on Sunday as she officially began her mayoral campaign.
lead_paragraph: When the bus driver in the Bronx called out her name, Christine C. Quinn did not hesitate. The City Council speaker — and, as of Sunday, official candidate for mayor — bounded up the vehicle’s steps and gave him a warm handshake as passengers, unbothered by the delay, began to applaud.

headline: North Korea and the U.N. Sanctions
abstract: Kim Jong-un and Uncle Sam face off.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un and Uncle Sam face off.

headline: Inside the Conclave
abstract: The last few conclaves have been brief, selecting a pope in just a few days. In 2005, Pope Benedict XVI was elected a day after the conclave began.
lead_paragraph: The last few conclaves have been brief, selecting a pope in just a few days. In 2005, Pope Benedict XVI was elected a day after the conclave began.

headline: Myanmar Opposition Leader Vows Party Reform
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi called for a “good relationship” with the military and vowed to infuse new blood into the party, which is recovering from more than two decades of persecution under military rule.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s main opposition party ended a congress over the weekend with the party’s leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, calling for a “good relationship” with the powerful military. She vowed to infuse new blood into the party, which is still recovering from more than two decades of persecution under military rule.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: The Last Waltz
abstract: Sleep-deprived solvers head into Patrick Berry’s puzzle 7.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — As if a whirlwind weekend of puzzling and late night socializing wasn’t enough, Daylight Savings Time has robbed the solvers of an hour’s sleep. There are more coffee cups on the tables of the ballroom than I remember in recent years.

headline: A Military Mom Goes Back to School
abstract: When a classmate mocked a character in our reading as “uneducated,” I told the class I’d never graduated high school. Then I wished I’d kept my mouth shut.
lead_paragraph: On my first day of school I cried, “Mommy, what if they’re all smarter than me?” I wasn’t a first grader. I was a 40-year-old Army wife, a mother of four and a new student.

headline: North Korea Faces Pressure From U.N. on Human Rights
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The United Nations Human Rights Council will meet Monday to consider calls for an international inquiry into possible crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Already angry over tougher sanctions imposed last week to punish its nuclear tests, North Korea faces renewed pressure over its human rights record as the United Nations Human Rights Council meets Monday to consider calls for an international inquiry into possible crimes against humanity.

headline: The (Very) Grand Tour
abstract: London’s Royal Opera House and the Ultimate Travel Company offer privileged access to some of the world’s best operas, ballets and symphonies.
lead_paragraph: Culturati who’ve had enough of art-fair globe-trotting can now move on to music and dance. London’s Royal Opera House and the Ultimate Travel Company offer privileged access to some of the world’s best operas, ballets and symphonies. Each journey begins in London with a performance and private dinner at the Royal Opera House. Then maybe it’s off to St. Petersburg for a show at the Mariinsky Ballet followed by a backstage tour led by the company’s director. Past trips have included V.I.P. treatment at the Salzburg Easter Festival in Austria, a visit to ballet schools, lectures, private concerts and a chance to meet virtuosos like the South African tenor Johan Botha. From $4,640 per person; theultimatetravelcompany.co.uk/roh.

headline: Attack of the Trust Fund Zombie
abstract: Still shambling.
lead_paragraph: So, I’ve Stephanopoulized, along with Senator Ron Johnson, who began by declaring that we need to agree about the facts — then promptly rolled out the old trust fund zombie. I’ve explained this one over and over again, for example here. And I have to say, it’s extremely telling that conservative Republicans don’t seem able to make their case without resorting, right from the beginning, to obviously dumb fallacies.

headline: Police Kill 16-Year-Old They Say Pointed a Handgun
abstract: Police say two officers shot and killed the teenage boy in Brooklyn after he pointed a handgun at them.
lead_paragraph: Two plainclothes police officers shot and killed a teenage boy late Saturday night on a Brooklyn street, after he pointed a handgun at the officers, the police said.

headline: At a Neighborhood Church in Rome, Dolan Delivers a Star Turn
abstract: Two days before the cardinals hold a conclave to select the next pope, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan was treated like a celebrity during a visit on Sunday to a neighborhood church in Rome.
lead_paragraph: ROME — There was no mistaking the fact that a dignitary was coming to Mass in Monte Mario on Sunday.

headline: Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'E-Mail', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: Think of how long it takes to access your voice mail and listen to one of those long-winded messages. In text messages, you don’t have to declare who you are, or even say hello.
lead_paragraph: Some people are so rude. Really, who sends an e-mail or text message that just says “Thank you”? Who leaves a voice mail message when you don’t answer, rather than texting you? Who asks for a fact easily found on Google?

headline: Icon of Harlem’s Gay Night Life Gives Way to Wreckers
abstract: A block of Harlem that is undergoing a makeover was once the home of a century-old entertainment complex where in the 1920s and 1930s a popular lesbian singer performed with a back-up chorus line of black gay men.
lead_paragraph: A block in Harlem that once resonated to the sounds of some of America’s top musicians has, in recent weeks, heard nothing more than the mournful rasp of hydraulic shears and a hydraulic excavator clawing away the remains of a century-old entertainment complex.

headline: Afghan Leader Says U.S. Abets Taliban’s Goal
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Hamid Karzai charged that the American government and the Taliban had in effect colluded to keep Afghanistan unstable in order to justify a continued American military presence.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai leveled particularly harsh accusations against the United States on Sunday, suggesting that the Americans and the Taliban had a common goal in destabilizing his country. The comments cast a shadow on the first visit by Chuck Hagel as defense secretary.

headline: ‘Oz the Great and Powerful’ Has Big Opening
abstract: The Disney movie sold $80.3 million worth of tickets at North American theaters over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was gridlock on the yellow brick road over the weekend as “Oz the Great and Powerful,” backed by a megawatt marketing campaign, took in about $80.3 million in North America and $69.9 million overseas.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) ARMY WIVES Brooke Shields, playing Air Force Col. Katherine Young; Torrey DeVitto as Maggie Hall, a former airborne soldier with three deployments in Iraq turned housewife; and Ashanti (above right, with Catherine Bell, left, and Sally Pressman), portraying Latasha Montclair, a mother of three with a deployed husband, are among those joining the cast in this Season 7 opener, which finds Fort Marshall mourning the loss of one of its own. In the Season 2 premiere of “The Client List,” at 10, trust becomes an issue for Riley (Jennifer Love Hewitt), who finds that even those she believes she can count on harbor their own secrets.

headline: How Grindr Is Changing the Way We Connect
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Grindr may be a mobile application that helps men find other men for casual connections, but a lot can be learned from the success of the application, says Jaime Woo, an author who has studied the service and its users.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — It is easy to write off Grindr — a location-based dating application for gay men — as a hookup application because, well, that is what it is.

headline: For One Night, Sequester Becomes a Punch Line
abstract: Perhaps only at the Gridiron Club dinner could President Obama warm up a crowd by starting with jokes about the across-the-board spending cuts that took effect this month.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has indeed brought change to Washington: in exchange for his white-tied presence on Saturday night, he successfully pressured the journalistic elite at the 128-year-old Gridiron Club to shorten its often interminably long annual dinner roast.

headline: Overrun by Crime, Oakland Looks to Make Allies in Community
abstract: The captains of each of the five police districts in the city will soon focus on community outreach, an area in which law enforcement officials and residents have had a long, troubled history.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Over the next several months, this city just across the bay from San Francisco will be partitioned into five police districts from its current two. The smaller districts, according to a new plan, will each be led by a powerful captain who will be held accountable for crime reduction in regular meetings with the police chief.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2013: The Finals
abstract: This is the one for all the marbles.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The final round of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is actually made up of three rounds: The C Division competitors, the B Division, and, of course, the elite A Division. The puzzle the finalists solve is the same, but the clues that each division receives are different, and if you are lucky enough — and good enough — to make it to the A Division, the clues are not for the faint of heart.

headline: After Cashing In on Job Cuts, Wall St. Looks to Worker Upturn
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: With jobs slowly coming back, hopes are that ordinary Americans will finally feel the recovery that the nation’s corporations have seen for some time.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is hopeful that American companies, after years of gaining ground at the expense of their employees, will start to succeed because of the rising fortune of those workers.

headline: In Wake of Cyberattacks, China Seeks New Rules
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Remarks by Yang Jiechi, the foreign minister, were China’s highest level response yet to intensifying accusations that the Chinese military may be engaging in cyberespionage.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China has issued a new call for international “rules and cooperation” on Internet espionage issues, while insisting that accusations of Chinese government involvement in recent hacking attacks were part of an international smear campaign.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager Found and Jailed in Fraud
abstract: Florian Homm, who spent five years in hiding, was arrested in Italy and faces extradition to America, where authorities have accused him of defrauding investors of at least $200 million.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Florian Homm, a flamboyant former hedge fund manager who spent the last five years in hiding, was arrested in Italy and faces extradition to the United States on securities fraud charges which could expose him to a lengthy prison sentence, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

headline: No Sets? No Costumes? No Music? No Problem
abstract: Contemporary Israeli Dance Week returned to the La MaMa Ellen Stewart Theater in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary Israeli Dance Week returned on Thursday to the La MaMa Ellen Stewart Theater in the East Village, and the opening-night program of three short dances by Noa Zuk exemplified what New York audiences have come to associate with the words “contemporary Israeli dance.”

headline: Batting Slumber Over, Japan Moves to Semifinals
abstract: The defending champion pounded out 17 hits, including six home runs, scored in every inning and advanced to the semifinals after the mercy rule was invoked.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As the jubilant Tokyo Dome crowd roared, Japan’s manager, Koji Yamamoto, stood on the field and raised his arms in triumph amid camera flashes.

headline: Click for Career Enhancement
abstract: CreativeLive and other online companies have tapped into an audience of customers who are motivated to hone skills that might enhance their careers, and investors are noticing the profit potential.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Anyone who wants to learn calculus, statistics or ancient Greek history can take free online courses in those subjects at a variety of sites from instructors with distinguished academic pedigrees. For more mundane pursuits, like learning how to paddleboard or build a planter box for the garden, there is an inexhaustible supply of free how-to videos on YouTube, eHow and other sites.

headline: Boyle Ends Scoring Drought as Rangers Solve Ovechkin and Capitals
abstract: Brian Boyle scored his first goal of the season as the Rangers capitalized on mistakes by Alex Ovechkin and secured their fifth victory in six games.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brian Boyle shot the puck as he glided backward to the top of the face-off circle, and when it went in at 10 minutes 53 seconds of the second period, he dropped to one knee and joyously windmilled one arm.

headline: Crude
abstract: Call me that again and I’ll slug you.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thoma on Jeff Sachs. Also Ryan Cooper. And here’s what happens if you actually read the links from Scarborough-Sachs: you find that what I actually said bears no resemblance to their, ahem, crude caricature of my views.

headline: Progress for Francisco as He Throws Off Mound
abstract: Frank Francisco, who is battling inflammation in his right elbow, threw off a mound Sunday morning for the first time this spring training.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The right-hander Frank Francisco threw off a mound Sunday morning for the first time this spring training.

headline: Vulgarity’s Abrasive Master, but Not at Home
abstract: To the world, Gilbert Gottfried is known for his deliberately abrasive stage presence and bottomless vulgarity, but to his wife, he is a “gentle genius.”
lead_paragraph: When Gilbert Gottfried finds something really funny — like one of his self-deprecating and willfully tasteless jokes — his narrow eyes grow even narrower, he lets out a gruff cackle and buries his face in the palm of his hand.

headline: Voices of a Deadly Blizzard, and Then Some Lullabies
abstract: The Oratorio Society of New York performed Paul Moravec’s “ Blizzard Voices,” set to texts by the former poet laureate Ted Kooser and inspired by the deadly “Children’s Blizzard” of 1888.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening the Oratorio Society of New York presented a concert of American choral music at Carnegie Hall, built around a new work by Paul Moravec, “The Blizzard Voices.” This oratorio about the “Children’s Blizzard” of 1888 had originally been scheduled to receive its New York premiere last November, but in a case of nature dislodging art imitating nature, that concert was canceled because of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: In Search of Debt Deal, Obama Walks a Narrow Path
abstract: As President Obama seeks a solution that will satisfy the ideological and political tests of both parties, he faces complaints from Democrats who say he mishandled his last attempt at a “grand bargain.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will go to Capitol Hill this week to try to salvage a big deficit-reduction deal, battling not only Republican resistance but also complaints from Democrats that he mishandled his last attempt.

headline: Where Everybody Knows Your Bad Jokes and Puns
abstract: In the saloon at the center of Adam Szymkowicz’s “Clown Bar” the regulars wear clown makeup and costumes, and speak in the hard-boiled slang of 1930s gangsters.
lead_paragraph: You’ll roll your eyes constantly during “Clown Bar” — at its groan-worthy puns, its lewd double-entendres and its intentionally bad jokes. But you’ll also laugh quite often. This is a show made for those who enjoy a few winces along with their grins.

headline: Prankish Activity
abstract: The return of Robert Fisher.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — You can practically smell the testosterone in this puzzle, can’t you? This is a manly puzzle for manly men, although anyone can solve it. You just have to know the names of your male animals.

headline: Conversations With Sondheim and His Melodies
abstract: The second installment of “Liaisons: Reimagining Sondheim From the Piano” included selections by 18 composers, all receiving their New York, American or world premieres.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Christopher O’Riley’s fascination with the contrapuntal textures of Radiohead songs inspired him to arrange many for keyboard. Art Tatum and Earl Wild were among the pianists to transcribe the works of George Gershwin.

headline: Q. and A. With Ken Griffey Jr.: Star Turn Over, Slugger Is Still Beloved
abstract: Ken Griffey Jr. batted .524 with three home runs in the first World Baseball Classic in 2006. On Sunday, he and Ferguson Jenkins threw out ceremonial first pitches before the United States played Canada.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Ken Griffey Jr. batted .524 with 3 home runs in the first World Baseball Classic in 2006. On Sunday, he and Ferguson Jenkins threw out ceremonial first pitches before the United States played Canada.

headline: From Head to Toe, Quiet Drama Unfolds
abstract: Jean Butler’s use of space is a hallmark of “hurry,” her 35-minute solo dance in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In “hurry,” the solo that Jean Butler performed at Danspace Project over the weekend, this dancer turned choreographer takes her time. Her feet bare, her long red hair tied up in a ponytail, she bends one knee, then the other. She rotates her shoulders, her hips, her ankles. Many of her precise movements retain the look of a warm-up, of someone working things out.

headline: In Talk Show Tour, Jeb Bush Promotes Book on Immigration and Replies to Critics
abstract: The former Florida governor stoked speculation about his presidential ambitions by appearing on all of the Sunday morning talk shows to sell his new book on immigration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stoking speculation about his presidential ambitions, Jeb Bush, the Republican former governor of Florida, performed a rare Washington feat on Sunday, appearing on all the morning talk shows as part of a blitz that has become equal parts book promotion and damage control.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Draws On an Original
abstract: The show about admen in the ’60s asked a top illustrator of that era, Brian Sanders, to create a poster to promote its new season.
lead_paragraph: In the five seasons that “Mad Men” has been on television that celebrated series set in the art-directed world of 1960s advertising has never marketed itself the way a ’60s ad man most certainly would have: by calling in a hotshot illustrator to do the job.

headline: Surprise Hit Was a Shock for Artists Heard on It
abstract: Two artists belatedly learned that they play integral roles on “Harlem Shake,” a Web sensation that became a No. 1 hit on the pop chart, and both are seeking compensation.
lead_paragraph: Hector Delgado gave up being a reggaetón artist five years ago to become an evangelical preacher in Puerto Rico. So it was something of a surprise when his former manager, Javier Gómez, called him three weeks ago and said his voice could be clearly heard on “Harlem Shake,” a song that had gone viral on the Internet and then climbed to the top of the pop chart.

headline: An Everywoman? In So Many Ways, No
abstract: “Jackie,” starring Tina Benko, is the writer Elfriede Jelinek’s theatrical take on Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Prize-winning Austrian writer Elfriede Jelinek, in an interview in the Yale School of Drama journal Theater with her translator Gitta Honegger, describes how her male colleagues are allowed “to have this subjectivity, this precise, absolutely unmistakable gaze.”

headline: Speaking Rap’s Universal Language in the Ferment of the Arab Spring
abstract: “Mic Check: Hip-Hop From North Africa and the Middle East,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, included a lineup of Tunisian, Egyptian, Malian and (London-born) Palestinian rappers.
lead_paragraph: The international language of hip-hop definitely includes “What’s up, Brooklyn!,” the recurring salutation from the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music during “Mic Check: Hip-Hop From North Africa and the Middle East” on Saturday night. A lineup of Tunisian, Egyptian, Malian and (London-born) Palestinian rappers, including activists from the Arab Spring, brought songs of protest and self-determination. The concert, which including the United States debuts of El Général from Tunisia and Deeb from Egypt, celebrated a courageous new forthrightness from Middle Eastern rappers. It also showed the pervasiveness of hip-hop, and how it works differently as a catalyst wherever it arrives.

headline: ‘Mic Check’
abstract: Photos from a concert featuring Tunisian, Egyptian, Malian and (London-born) Palestinian rappers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Photos from a concert featuring Tunisian, Egyptian, Malian and (London-born) Palestinian rappers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Words That Hurt and Kill: Lessons for Society From Bullying and Its Psychic Toll
abstract: In “Sticks and Stones” Emily Bazelon wants nothing less than for her readers, and her nation, utterly to rethink bullying.
lead_paragraph: When Emily Bazelon was in eighth grade, her friends “fired” her. She had loved them; now they rejected her — an act, she recalls, that left her “crawling with insecurity and self-doubt.”

headline: Drilling Earth Seems to Get It Annoyed
abstract: Big oil plays the bad guy in “Ring of Fire,” on Reelz, and its drilling in an unsafe manner seems to annoy the Earth itself.
lead_paragraph: The cast of “Ring of Fire,” a two-part disaster movie served up by Reelz on Monday and Tuesday, deserves credit for putting some effort into the film rather than sleepwalking through it, as actors often do in these collect-a-paycheck jobs. The script is decent enough too, for the first half. But the closer the world gets to ending, the more wearyingly formulaic “Ring of Fire” becomes.

headline: Dissecting the Dance Even Before It Begins
abstract: As part of the Stripped/Dressed series at the Harkness Dance Festival, a discussion of Liz Gerring’s “she dreams in code” precedes a performance.
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual to see small-scale modern-dance performances in which the choreographer and dancers return to the stage for a question-and-answer session. But the Stripped/Dressed series of this year’s Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y has the choreographer and dancers explain things first.

headline: 2 Awards Given to Promote Multicultural Children’s Books
abstract: First Book, a nonprofit that promotes literacy among children in low-income communities, will give two awards through its Stories for All project to publishers offering multicultural books.
lead_paragraph: A month ago a nonprofit called First Book, which promotes literacy among children in low-income communities, announced the Stories for All project, a program intended to prod publishers to print more multicultural books. Kyle Zimmer, First Book’s chief executive, says that part of the motivation was the “chasm” between the number of people who want such books and what is available.

headline: Night of the Stars at the Richmond Bridge Club
abstract: After the Night of the Stars charity pro-am event at the Richmond Bridge Club in London on Feb. 28 the players received a booklet.
lead_paragraph: After the Night of the Stars charity pro-am event at the Richmond Bridge Club in London on Feb. 28 the players received a booklet. This contained copies of the deals with bidding and play predictions by various experts from around the world. And to give Jason Hackett from England credit, he did mention the unusual contract reached when Shivam Shah sat South, partnering Azad Mahomed.

headline: Cory Booker, Twitter Visionary
keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The Newark mayor took the stage at the South by Southwest conference to extol the virtues of using Twitter to help improve government.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Cory Booker — the mayor of Newark and a virtual Twitter superhero for his chronicle of the city — made the trip to the annual South by Southwest conference here on Sunday to impart his tips and perspective on why Twitter is a valuable tool for governing and civic engagement.

headline: Looking Divine at South by Southwest
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Homosexuality', 'Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Jeffrey Schwarz, the director of “I Am Divine,” discusses his documentary about the drag star Divine.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Playing on screens throughout the South by Southwest festival this weekend were a variety of documentaries focusing on key figures in gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender communities. “Continental” shines its eye on Steve Ostrow, the owner of the Continental Baths, a bathhouse that became a cultural beacon. “Big Joy” focuses on the gay poet and filmmaker James Broughton, whose work in the 1960s and ’70s made him a voice of the sexual revolution. “Mr. Angel” spends time with the porn star and activist Buck Angel, whose work has changed perspectives on transgender performers in adult film.

headline: John Doyle to Direct a London Revival of ‘The Color Purple’
abstract: The Menier Chocolate Factory, a 150-seat performance space in a former factory, will host the engagement from July 5 to Sept. 14.
lead_paragraph: John Doyle, who received a Tony Award for best direction in the 2005 Broadway production of “Sweeney Todd,” will bring his talents to London for his next project, a revival of the musical version of “The Color Purple.” The Menier Chocolate Factory, a 150-seat performance space in a former factory, will host the engagement from July 5 to Sept. 14.

headline: Pearl Theater Company Delays McNally Play
abstract: The Pearl Theater Company has pushed back the spring premiere of Terrence McNally’s “And Away We Go” to the fall season.
lead_paragraph: The Pearl Theater Company has pushed back the spring premiere of Terrence McNally’s “And Away We Go” to the fall season. The play was previously scheduled to run from April 19 to May 19. “This Side of Neverland,” which features a pair of one-acts by J. M. Barrie, will now fill that period and close the Pearl’s 2012-13 season. The delay follows a February letter to subscribers stating that the company was experiencing a cash-flow shortfall and needed to raise an additional $250,000 to continue the current season as scheduled.

headline: Footnote
abstract: Kelly Osbourne said on her Twitter account on Friday that a seizure caused her collapse on the set of E!’s “Fashion Police” last week.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Osbourne  said on her Twitter account on Friday that a seizure caused her collapse on the set of E!’s “Fashion Police” last week. Ms. Osbourne was rushed to the hospital on Thursday and, according to her post on Twitter, which was accompanied by a photo of an I.V. line in her left arm, doctors are still trying to determine why the seizure occurred.

headline: For Wheeler, Demotion Is Probably Temporary
abstract: Zack Wheeler, one of the game’s top pitching prospects, was one of the 10 players demoted to the Mets’ minor league camp.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On Sunday, for perhaps the last time before what is expected to be a promising major league career, Zack Wheeler was cut from a baseball team.

headline: Top Contenders to Lead the Roman Catholic Church
abstract: Cardinals selecting the next pope are looking for someone with the charisma of Pope John Paul II and the grit to tackle the church’s scandals.
lead_paragraph: Cardinals selecting the next pope are looking for someone with the charisma of Pope John Paul II and the grit to tackle the church’s scandals.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Information to be released includes retail sales and industrial production for February, and Costco is expected to report its quarterly results.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Information to be released includes retail sales for February, import prices for February and business inventories for January (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Producer Price Index for February and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for February, industrial production for February and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'States (US)']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: New ‘Arrested Development’ Episodes Aren’t Enough for Some Fans
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Television']
abstract: Mitch Hurwitz, the show’s creator, and two of its stars, Will Arnett and Jeffrey Tambor, talked about fans’ demand for a film at the South by Southwest festival.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For years after the cult series “Arrested Development” went off the air, the question was whether a movie about the demented Bluth family would follow. Now that the show, which ended in 2006, is getting new life with 14 more episodes on Netflix this spring, that was still the question of the hour at a South by Southwest festival Q&A session with Mitch Hurwitz, the show’s creator, and two of its stars, Will Arnett and Jeffrey Tambor.

headline: For Marvel Comics, a Renewed Digital Mission
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Comic books went digital long ago, but Marvel Comics upped the ante significantly by unveiling a superhero-size slate of mobile and online initiatives.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Like the rest of the publishing industry, comic books went digital long ago. You can catch up on Batman via mobile app and unfurl Wolverine’s claws from your laptop. But Marvel Comics upped the ante significantly on Sunday, unveiling a superhero-size slate of new and expanded mobile and online initiatives.

headline: Saudis Consider Firing Squads for Executions
abstract: A committee in Saudi Arabia has recommended that “because of the scarcity of swordsmen and their unavailability in a number of regions” the princes who govern provinces should be free to use firing squads.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After centuries of public beheadings, the kingdom of Saudi Arabia is considering firing squads as an alternative means of execution.

headline: G.O.P. in Arizona Is Pushed to Expand Medicaid
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer and her advisers are working to win over state lawmakers on a measure that is more popular with Democrats.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In the battle to get the Medicaid expansion being championed by Gov. Jan Brewer approved by the state’s legislators, her closest advisers are hanging their hopes on the number eight. That is how many of the 17 Republicans in the State Senate they believe they can get on their side.

headline: Two Sides to a Deodorant Campaign
abstract: Eight years after dividing into Degree Men and Degree Women, the Degree brand of deodorant is advertising its products under one creative umbrella.
lead_paragraph: THE deodorant aisle was once more like the toothpaste aisle, with products mostly unisex rather than marketed strictly to men or women. But today, unisex deodorants account for only 12 percent of the market, according to the research firm Mintel, down from about 35 percent in 1990.

headline: Arthur Storch, Stage Director, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Storch, an Actors Studio alumnus, directed on and off Broadway and created Syracuse Stage, a regional theater he brought to national prominence.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Storch, an exacting and successful director on Broadway and in regional theater, who once asked Eugène Ionesco to rewrite a play and goaded a young Aaron Sorkin to work harder, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Police Scatter Demonstrators in Capital of Azerbaijan
abstract: Police used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannons to disperse protesters demanding an end to the hazing and abuse of military conscripts.
lead_paragraph: BAKU, Azerbaijan — The police in the capital of Azerbaijan on Sunday used tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannons to disperse protesters demanding an end to the hazing and abuse of military conscripts, which activists say the government has concealed.

headline: Islamists Kill 7 Captives in Nigeria
abstract: The deaths signal a shift in tactics by the radical Islamists who have been battling the Nigerian government for nearly four years in the country’s impoverished north.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Radical Islamists in northern Nigeria have killed seven foreign construction workers who were kidnapped in February, a significant escalation of extremist violence in Nigeria’s continuing jihadist insurgency.

headline: From YouTube to the Cineplex
abstract: “Mindless Behavior: All Around the World,” a concert film about the boy band Mindless Behavior, will run in about 120 AMC theaters.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — How fast is YouTube building new media companies? Consider the case of AwesomenessTV, a YouTube-based channel for teenagers.

headline: Quinn Tour Opens Mayoral Campaign
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, officially began her campaign to become mayor of New York. Even before Sunday’s formal announcement, she was the perceived Democratic front-runner.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, officially began her campaign to become mayor of New York. Even before Sunday’s formal announcement, she was the perceived Democratic front-runner.

headline: Real Madrid on a Rampage; United Wilts
abstract: Real Madrid ran its streak to nine games unbeaten in Spain’s La Liga with Sunday’s 2-1 win over Celta Vigo.
lead_paragraph: Real Madrid put an exclamation mark on an impressive run that began with a Copa del Rey win over arch rival Barcelona on Feb. 26 and continued to Sunday (at least) with a 2-1 win at Celta Vigo, the team’s ninth game without a loss in Spain’s La Liga. Those wins sandwiched a second triumph over Barcelona, in the league, and then last Tuesday’s classic demolition of Manchester United to advance to the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League.

headline: United States Avoids Elimination With Victory Over Canada
abstract: The United States came from behind twice to beat Canada and advance to the second round of the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Humiliation was just five outs away. Trailing by a run late in Sunday’s game at the World Baseball Classic, the United States faced the prospect of first-round elimination — and that was not the worst of it.

headline: B-Plus for City’s Parks, but Problems Remain
abstract: An advocacy group gave the 43 large parks in the system, which has seen a decrease in its budget in recent years, a B-plus on maintenance.
lead_paragraph: The conditions of more than 40 large parks in New York City have improved in the last two years, though problems — including a lack of resources and consistency — remain, according to a survey by an independent advocacy group.

headline: British Proposal to Rein In Banks Is Faulted
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: British lawmakers warned on Monday that proposed legislation to protect Britain’s financial services sector from future crises did not go far enough and might fail to stop banks from engaging in risky trading.
lead_paragraph: 8:07 a.m. | Updated

headline: Martha’s Brand Struggling for Right Fit
abstract: As Martha Stewart shifts away from media and toward merchandising, a lawsuit between Macy’s and J. C. Penney has highlighted retailers’ continued hunger for strong brands like hers.
lead_paragraph: Media companies are often closely associated with their founders — Rupert Murdoch at News Corporation and Sumner Redstone at Viacom come to mind — but none are linked with their products in quite the way Martha Stewart is.

headline: Uprooted by Tsunami, Church’s Flock Regroups
abstract: The Fukushima First Baptist Church, whose members fled after the March 2011 disaster, has had a long road back.
lead_paragraph: IWAKI, Japan — After the rumbling and the devastating waves had ceased, the members of a little church a stone’s throw away from the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant discovered that a new set of troubles was just beginning.

headline: Indiana Player Knows How to Wow a Crowd
abstract: Victor Oladipo, an efficient and electrifying 6-foot-5 junior at Indiana, has blossomed from an undervalued recruit into a finalist for the Wooden Award, given to the nation’s top player.
lead_paragraph: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. — Victor Oladipo believes there is a song for every occasion, and to the resignation of his Indiana teammates, those occasions include blinking, breathing and walking.

headline: South Korea Flirts With Nuclear Ideas as North Blusters
abstract: North Korea’s threats of war have led to a new sense of vulnerability among South Koreans that is causing some to push for a nuclear arsenal in their country.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As their country prospered, South Koreans have largely shrugged off the constant threat of a North Korean attack. But breakthroughs in the North’s missile and nuclear programs and fiery threats of war have heightened fears in the South that even small miscalculations by the new and untested leaders of each country could have disastrous consequences.

headline: Mildred Manning, ‘Angel’ of Corregidor, Dies at 98
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Prisoners of War', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mrs. Manning was the last survivor of 77 nurses who served in the Philippines and were known as the Angels of Bataan and Corregidor.
lead_paragraph: Mildred Dalton Manning grew up poor on a Georgia farm. Her mother made all the family clothes on an old sewing machine. Hoping to escape a life of poverty, she attended nursing school during the Depression and became a nurse at a hospital in Atlanta.

headline: CT Scans Find Vascular Disease in Ancient Mummies
abstract: Atherosclerosis — considered an illness of a modern, inactive lifestyle — was discovered in the remains of people from various ancient cultures.
lead_paragraph: Atherosclerosis — the buildup of fats and cholesterol on the artery walls that can lead to stroke and heart disease — is generally considered a problem of modern times, a result of fatty diets and inactive lifestyles. But a new examination of mummies from ancient cultures suggests that the disease appeared long before the arrival of junk food and flat-screen televisions.

headline: Afghan Says Force Backed by the C.I.A. Beat Him
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: A 29-year-old student says he was abducted from Kandahar University in an episode cited by President Hamid Karzai as he rebuked American forces and banned them from Afghan schools.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The 29-year-old engineering student was standing outside his classroom here on Saturday morning when he said two pickup trucks full of armed men pulled up. The men, said to be members of a C.I.A.-backed Afghan strike force, grabbed him, tied his hands behind his back, draped a black hood over his head and drove him to an undisclosed location where, the student says, he was beaten and whipped.

headline: The Caretaker of Boston University Athletics
abstract: Elliot Driben, who suffers from cerebral palsy, has attended more than 5,000 B.U. sporting events and has earned honors and reciprocal loyalty from the university community.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In Section 111, Row Q, Seat 1, above a corner of the Agganis Arena ice, a gray-haired man observed the action. Wearing a scarlet team jacket and a white Friends of Boston University Hockey cap pulled over enormous eyeglasses with brown frames, he was easy to miss. A trumpeter’s brief toot from the opposite end of the rink projected greater sound than the man’s enthusiastic clapping after each Terriers goal in a victory against Merrimack.

headline: Preparation and Vows of Defiance as Big Sugary Drink Ban Is Set to Start
abstract: Businesses are preparing revamped menus but with a pending legal challenge to the new ban, some owners are taking a wait-and-see approach in the hope that the beverage industry will win out.
lead_paragraph: With one day to go before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s ban on large sugary drinks goes into effect across the city, some big-drink lovers, and the places that serve them, vowed defiance. Others accepted it with a shrug. Then there were people like Leonardo Scarpone, the owner of Sanpanino, an Italian sandwich shop in Greenwich Village, who wondered if the small amount of sugar he added to his fresh-squeezed lemonade would push it into forbidden territory.

headline: To at Least One Earthling, Siberia Meteor Proved That Science Is Vital
keywords: ['Astronomy and Astrophysics', 'Meteors and Meteorites', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Neil deGrasse Tyson, an astrophysicist and the director of the Hayden Planetarium, warns that recent cosmic activity should be seen as “a shot across our bow.”
lead_paragraph: Twice on a recent Friday, the cosmos intruded rudely on us earthlings. A meteor exploded over western Siberia, shattering windows, injuring hundreds and scaring pretty much everyone else. That same day, an asteroid passed within 18,000 miles of us, close enough to arch many an eyebrow among astronomers.

headline: No Stumping for Papacy, but Babies Do Get Kisses
abstract: Two days before the papal conclave begins, the cardinals adhered to what might be called the art of running for pope, which means never, ever appearing to be running.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The American contender kissed babies and joked about bad food inside the papal conclave. The Brazilian blessed a couple on their 70th anniversary. The Italian blessed a pack of journalists, and a baby, too. The reserved Hungarian did not kiss anybody.

headline: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering Web
abstract: Computer algorithms are capable of trading stocks, arranging dates and winning “Jeopardy.” But increasingly, behind the curtain, there is a human helper.
lead_paragraph: Trading stocks, targeting ads, steering political campaigns, arranging dates, besting people on “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes: computer algorithms are doing all this work and more.

headline: Chávez Heir Faces Challenge in Ties With Armed Forces
abstract: If elected, Nicolás Maduro, the designated successor to Hugo Chávez, must contend with an array of factions, the most important of which is the scandal-plagued military.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The multitudes in red shirts, clenched fists thrusting in the air — a dominant image of the political movement that President Hugo Chávez left behind — convey a sense of followers united and loyal to the father of their revolution and his designated heir, Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
abstract: The border fence with Mexico is harming communities on both sides of the frontier.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif.

headline: Before Smoke Rises at Vatican, It’s Romans vs. the Reformers
abstract: Beneath an orderly display, the cardinals at the papal conclave are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine who among them emerges as pope.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The cardinals who enter the papal conclave on Tuesday will walk into the Sistine Chapel in a single file, but beneath the orderly display, they are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine which man among them emerges as pope.

headline: No Catching or Doubting a Healthy, Happy Woods
abstract: Tiger Woods moved closer to getting back on top of his sport by claiming his 76th PGA Tour title and first World Golf Championships event since 2009.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — On the second hole Sunday at the Blue Monster, Tiger Woods drained a 19-foot putt for birdie. When at last the applause died down, Graeme McDowell stood over a 7-footer for birdie that suddenly looked twice as long. He rolled it in to remain three strokes behind Woods, and as he walked off the green, he made eye contact with a friend and said, “We’re not playing for second place here.”

headline: Dwindling Deficit Disorder
abstract: There is no need for America’s long-run fiscal concerns to drive its budget policy today.
lead_paragraph: For three years and more, policy debate in Washington has been dominated by warnings about the dangers of budget deficits. A few lonely economists have tried from the beginning to point out that this fixation is all wrong, that deficit spending is actually appropriate in a depressed economy. But even though the deficit scolds have been wrong about everything so far — where are the soaring interest rates we were promised? — protests that we are having the wrong conversation have consistently fallen on deaf ears.

headline: Hold Generic Drug Makers Accountable
abstract: Lawsuits are important as deterrents to negligence or wrongdoing by manufacturers when they fail to make their drugs safe and effective.
lead_paragraph: A New Hampshire woman who was severely injured by a generic drug in 2004 is still struggling to hold the manufacturer liable. Her case will be argued this month before the Supreme Court, which has already severely limited the ability of consumers to sue generic manufacturers and may well limit it further. If so, some way must be found to compensate this plaintiff, Karen Bartlett, and others who have been hurt by generic drugs, which account for 80 percent of all prescriptions in this country.

headline: How to Shop for College
abstract: The government’s new online scorecard can help families cut through some of the cost confusion.
lead_paragraph: Colleges often make themselves appear less expensive — and more attractive to cash-poor families — through promotional materials and financial aid letters that hide the true costs. Last month the federal government unveiled an online college scorecard that can help families cut through some of the confusion. It gives students a reasonable idea of what they could owe once they graduate and allows clear cost comparisons among schools.

headline: Critics Wait for City to Rein In Bus Lines
abstract: Despite complaints about loosely regulated intercity bus companies, New York City has not issued rules it was empowered last summer to impose.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, after a federal crackdown on discount bus lines running through Chinatown in Manhattan, city and state officials celebrated as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a law aimed at bringing some order to the curbside bus business in New York.

headline: Confirmation Questions for Mary Jo White
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: The nominee for S.E.C. chairwoman must address concerns about her Wall Street ties to determine her allegiances.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s nominee for chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is expected to win Senate approval after her confirmation hearing on Tuesday. But unless Ms. White is aggressively questioned, neither the senators nor the public will have a clear idea of the kind of chairwoman she will be.

headline: When to Say No
abstract: The revised plan for the proposed oil pipeline is still a threat to the environment.
lead_paragraph: The State Department’s latest environmental assessment of the controversial Keystone XL oil pipeline makes no recommendation about whether President Obama should approve it. Here is ours. He should say no, and for one overriding reason: A president who has repeatedly identified climate change as one of humanity’s most pressing dangers cannot in good conscience approve a project that — even by the State Department’s most cautious calculations — can only add to the problem.

headline: Private Manning’s Confidant
abstract: What if WikiLeaks’s source had given his secrets to The New York Times?
lead_paragraph: In early 2010, Pfc. Bradley Manning methodically uploaded a digital mother lode of classified United States military and diplomatic documents to the Internet insurgents of WikiLeaks. As everyone knows, WikiLeaks made these secret archives available to a few major news outlets, including this one. Many illuminating and troubling stories were published, and Washington has been gnashing its teeth ever since.

headline: Megadeals: Something to Cheer, or Fear?
abstract: Are recent mergers and acquisitions a sign of economic resurgence or could they actually sap the recovery?

headline: Downside of Drug Courts
abstract: The Drug Policy Alliance responds to a front-page article, “Outside Box, U.S. Judges Offer Addicts New Path.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: JOBS Act Successes
abstract: A senior fellow at the Competitive Enterprise Institute praises the law.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Working at Home: Pros and Cons
abstract: In response to an editorial, readers discuss their own work experiences and tax issues.

headline: Shopping While Black: Racism in Everyday Life
abstract: Sampling the responses to a column by Ta-Nehisi Coates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Criticism, Police Change Policy and Begin Investigating More Traffic Crashes
abstract: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the department would begin using the term “collision” instead of “accident.”
lead_paragraph: In a marked shift of protocol, the New York Police Department has begun conducting robust investigations of traffic crashes that result in critical injuries but not certain or likely death.

headline: ‘The Man Who Sells the Moon’
abstract: For three decades, Dennis M. Hope, a Nevada man, has built a thriving business by “selling” land plots in space.
lead_paragraph: The notion that one man can lay claim to all the extraterrestrial bodies in our little corner of the galaxy sounds preposterous. Yet Dennis M. Hope, 65, of Gardnerville, Nev., the subject of this Op-Doc video, believes just that. For three decades, he has built a thriving business by “selling” land plots in space, on places like the moon, Mars and Venus. Of course, he has no legal authority to do so. How does he get away with this? He told me that, back when he was a ventriloquist in the days before he “owned” the moon, his dummy taught him a valuable lesson: you can say anything you want to anybody as long as you smile.

headline: The Man Who Sells the Moon
abstract: This short documentary looks at Dennis Hope, a Nevada man who has made a living “selling” plots of land on the moon.
lead_paragraph: This short documentary looks at Dennis Hope, a Nevada man who has made a living “selling” plots of land on the moon.

headline: After Rough Patch, ‘The Bachelor’ Wins Back Viewers
abstract: After several seasons in decline, ABC’s “The Bachelor” has had a resurgence rare among network reality shows thanks to social media, casting and a push to attract younger viewers.
lead_paragraph: No matter which contestant Sean Lowe, the chiseled, strawberry blond, chooses as his fantasy fiancée on the three-hour season finale of ABC’s “The Bachelor” on Monday — will it be Catherine Giudici, 26, a quirky graphic designer from Seattle, or Lindsay Yenter, 25, a petite substitute teacher from Fort Bragg, N.C.? — the network has rekindled the romance between the reality series and its viewers.

headline: The Small-State Advantage in the United States Senate
abstract: The Constitution has always given states with small populations a lift, but the scale of the gap has grown in recent decades.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution has always given states with small populations a lift, but the scale of the gap has grown in recent decades.

headline: Stoudemire’s Woes Make Deal Look Worse All the Time
abstract: When the Knicks signed Amar’e Stoudemire in 2010, they ignored his notoriously fragile knees. Now the team faces the scary consequences of that decision.
lead_paragraph: When the tangled history of the Amar’e Stoudemire-Carmelo Anthony era is eventually written, it should be framed as a study in high-stakes gambling, in the fickle nature of the risk-reward scale and the consequences of unchecked desperation.

headline: Opposition Leader Will Seek Venezuelan Presidency
abstract: Henrique Capriles Radonski, 42, will run against Nicolás Maduro, Mr. Chávez’s handpicked successor, in an election scheduled for April 14.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The opposition leader Henrique Capriles Radonski said Sunday that he would run for president in a special election to replace Hugo Chávez, who died last week after 14 years in office.

headline: Yankees Are Said to Pursue Derrek Lee as Replacement for Mark Teixeira
abstract: After Mark Teixeira’s wrist injury, the Yankees were in talks with the retired first baseman Derrek Lee, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — With few obvious options available to replace the injured Mark Teixeira at first base, the Yankees are becoming creative in their search. They have asked the retired first baseman Derrek Lee whether he would come out of retirement, according to a person with knowledge of the talks who asked to remain anonymous.

headline: Cuts Give Obama Path to Create Leaner Military
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Officials see an opening to argue for cuts in bases and health and weapons programs that have long been in President Obama’s sights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a time when $46 billion in mandatory budget cuts are causing anxiety at the Pentagon, administration officials see one potential benefit: there may be an opening to argue for deep reductions in programs long in President Obama’s sights, and long resisted by Congress.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 10, 2013

headline: Harvard Search of E-Mail Stuns Its Faculty Members
abstract: Faculty members expressed dismay that Harvard administrators secretly search e-mail accounts to see who had leaked a memo about cheating.
lead_paragraph: Bewildered, and at times angry, faculty members at Harvard criticized the university on Sunday after revelations that administrators secretly searched the e-mail accounts of 16 resident deans in an effort to learn who leaked information about a student cheating scandal to the news media. Some predicted a confrontation between the faculty and the administration.

headline: Landlord Kills a Tenant in Brooklyn
abstract: The shooting occurred in the East New York area of Brooklyn, the police said, in what investigators believe was a dispute over money.
lead_paragraph: An argument between a landlord and a tenant in Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon ended with a gunshot that left the tenant dead, according to the police.

headline: Third Attempt at Trial in Killing of a Therapist
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Jurors have been selected to hear murder charges against David Tarloff, who says he was legally insane when he killed Kathryn Faughey, a Manhattan psychologist, in 2008.
lead_paragraph: The two brothers stood for hours on end at the back of the courtroom last week, vigilantly watching for any sign that their sister’s killer might crumble yet again — robbing them once more of resolution in a criminal case that has dragged on for five years.

headline: Debates Renewed on Visors and Staged Fights
abstract: A freakish eye injury and a concussion sustained in an orchestrated exchange of fisticuffs raise questions anew about changing the game’s rules.
lead_paragraph: Visors and fighting in hockey are in the headlines again after two prominent injuries.

headline: Time on Mound Can’t Compare With Experiences Watching From Seat
abstract: Mike Harkey pitched in the majors and won a World Series while coaching with the Yankees, but some of his proudest moments involve watching his son Cory play football.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — Mike Harkey, the Yankees’ bullpen coach for the past five seasons, had his best off-season since the Yankees won the World Series in 2009. The highlight came Nov. 18.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Admires Mariano Rivera’s Send-Off
abstract: Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia hopes that he, too, will have a career that someday warrants a news conference to announce his retirement.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA — While watching Mariano Rivera announce Saturday that this would be his final season, C. C. Sabathia wondered whether he, too, would one day have that privilege.

headline: Success in the Classic Could Help Revive Baseball in Puerto Rico
abstract: The surprising performance of the Puerto Rican team in the World Baseball Classic could provide a much-needed lift for the sport in the commonwealth.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Puerto Rico fielded a team for the World Baseball Classic that included players from the likes of the Savannah Sand Gnats, the Akron Aeros and the Brevard County Manatees. Such is the state of baseball in Puerto Rico, where the supply of major league talent has sharply declined.

headline: Bringing Back Detroit
abstract: A resident discusses the city’s opportunity to transform itself.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fish Returns With Win and Guarded Optimism
abstract: Mardy Fish played his first official singles match since September in the second round of the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells — and won.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Six months after Mardy Fish pulled himself off one of the biggest stages in tennis, he was finally able to push himself back on Sunday.

headline: India Rape Suspect Found Dead in Jail
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Ram Singh, one of five men accused in the fatal Delhi attack, appeared to have hanged himself.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — One of the men accused in a Delhi gang rape case was found dead in his jail cell on Monday morning, a jail official said.

headline: Suspect in India Gang Rape Found Dead in Jail
abstract: Ram Singh, one of five men accused in the fatal Delhi attack, appeared to have hanged himself, a jail spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — One of the men accused in the Delhi gang rape case was found dead in his jail cell on Monday morning, a jail official said.

headline: Myths About the Flu Vaccine
abstract: Despite recommendations a majority of Americans do not get the flu shot, putting themselves and others at risk.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 20, 1968, I got the flu. I remember it still: Christmas was a washout — I couldn’t leave the bed unassisted or keep anything down, not even a taste of the goose that someone else had to cook.

headline: Corrections: March 11, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 11, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

abstract: This word has appeared in 614 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: quail •\ˈkwal\• noun and verb

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 11
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 11.
lead_paragraph: “From highway bills to homeland security, small states make out like bandits.”

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Encore) HINDENBURG: THE LAST FLIGHT Maximilian Simonischek portrays an engineer leading the design of the LZ 129 Hindenburg; Stacy Keach is an unscrupulous American industrialist; Greta Scacchi is his wife; and Lauren Lee Smith (above with Mr. Simonischek) is their daughter in this two-part fictionalized account of the May 1937 aviation disaster in which 35 people on board and 1 on the ground were killed when the German airship burst into flames and crashed as it tried to dock at Lakehurst Naval Air Station in Manchester, N.J. Part 2 will be shown on Tuesday at 8.

headline: Photo Replay: March 10
abstract: A view of the day in sports, from college basketball to speedskating.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, from college basketball to speedskating.

headline: Roy Miller and the Red Bulls’ Late Show
abstract: Defender Roy Miller made three big mistakes in the final minutes as the Red Bulls lost, 2-1, to the San Jose Earthquakes on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: A week after a thrilling season-opening tie against the Timbers in Portland, the Red Bulls returned to the West Coast on Sunday night and produced something decidedly less memorable.

headline: Love in the Time of Durjoy Datta
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Youth']
abstract: A fresh-faced, best-selling author who pens raunchy tales of young professionals in India.
lead_paragraph: A lot of young women you have never met are crazy about Durjoy Datta.

headline: News Quiz | March 11, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Push to Investigate North Korea’s Human Rights Abuses
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: As ties between China and North Korea wobble and perhaps cool, Pyongyang may be facing a United Nations inquiry into possible crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Could North Korea be headed toward an international inquiry into possible crimes against humanity?

headline: Smaller States Find Outsize Clout Growing in Senate
abstract: The disproportionate power enjoyed in the Senate by small states is playing a growing role in the political dynamic on issues as varied as gun control, immigration and campaign finance.
lead_paragraph: RUTLAND, Vt. — In the four years after the financial crisis struck, a great wave of federal stimulus money washed over Rutland County. It helped pay for bridges, roads, preschool programs, a community health center, buses and fire trucks, water mains and tanks, even a project to make sure fish could still swim down the river while a bridge was being rebuilt.

headline: The Geneva Auto Show’s Green Lining
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Geneva International Motor Show']
abstract: As the beautiful models standing next to gas-guzzling muscle cars attest, the 83rd International Motor Show in Geneva is firmly rooted in its macho tradition, but there is a definite eco-friendly trend.
lead_paragraph: With growing consumer interest in green vehicles and a pledge to build a European Union-wide network of electric charging stations, many Europeans are looking forward to the next generation of cars.

headline: Cabdriver’s Book Club
keywords: ['Book Clubs', 'Books and Literature', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Testing the theory that one can start a book club with anybody, a woman asked her cabby what he was reading and found a literary sophisticate.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 11
abstract: Harsh words for the U.S. from Afghanistan; politics and the vote for pope; Ph.D. plagiarism in Germany; love hunters in China; and the legacy of the ladderback chair maker.
lead_paragraph: NEWS President Hamid Karzai leveled particularly harsh accusations against the United States on Sunday, suggesting that the Americans and the Taliban had a common goal in destabilizing his country. The comments cast a shadow on the first visit by Chuck Hagel as defense secretary. Alissa J. Rubin and Thom Shanker report from Kabul.

headline: Apps for Philips’s Hue Light Bulbs
abstract: Philips, the lighting giant, is announcing that it will create an official developer’s kit to attract companies to make products that work with its Web-enabled Hue, an LED bulb customers can control from a smartphone. It’s another step on the road to the so-called connected home.
lead_paragraph: How many apps does it take to screw in a light bulb? For Philips, apparently, there can never be too many.

headline: CVC-Led Group to Sell $1.4 Billion Stake in Indonesian Retailer

headline: How Many Text Messages Are Too Many?
abstract: Do you ever worry about annoying someone with too many messages–or using a form of communication that they don’t like?
lead_paragraph: Consider a text message–or voice mail or email–just to say “thank you” to the recipient for something he or she has done.

headline: Gujarat Is Yours, Modi Tells Indian Americans

headline: From the Safety of Switzerland

headline: Early Warnings About Ram Singh’s Safety; Suicide ‘Not Possible,’ Family Says
keywords: ['Police', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
