lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The family of Ram Singh, one of the accused in the Delhi gang rape case who was found hanged in his jail cell on Monday morning, was warned on Friday that his life might be in danger, one of his brothers said on Monday.

headline: Framing — and Reflecting — Beauty
abstract: A photo in Deborah WIllis’s new exhibit shows a woman holding a mirror inside a beauty parlor. It underscores how African-Americans have constructed their image to empower themselves.
lead_paragraph: Inside a beauty parlor in a small Florida town, Carrie is having her hair done. She is oblivious to the commotion around her. Peering intently into a mirror, she is at that quintessential moment of beautification when she must decide if the image she sees pleases her and she is ready to face the world.

headline: Thousands of Dead Pigs Found in River Flowing Into Shanghai
abstract: More than 3,300 pigs have been dumped into a major river in Shanghai, igniting fears among city residents of contaminated tap water.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — More than 3,300 dead pigs have been found in a major river that flows through Shanghai, igniting fears among city residents of contaminated tap water, according to official reports on Tuesday.

headline: This Week in Small Business: The Next Big Battle

headline: Chavismo and Human Development in Venezuela
abstract: Hugo Chavez may not have been much liked in the United States, but the public spending he invested in improving Venezuelan lives may stand the test of time, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.”

headline: Daily Report: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering the Web
abstract: Computer algorithms are capable of trading stocks, arranging dates, winning “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes. But increasingly, behind the curtain, there is a human helper.
lead_paragraph: Computer algorithms are trading stocks, targeting ads, steering political campaigns, arranging dates, besting people on “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes.

headline: NELL Is a Computer That Reads the Web – With a Little Human Help
abstract: The Never-Ending Language Learner is a computer that reads the Web and seeks to understand the meaning of words and phrases in context. The project at Carnegie Mellon University, funded by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and Google, began as a purely automated endeavor, computer algorithms roaming the Web. But it now relies on human helpers as well as algorithms.
lead_paragraph: The clever code of computing – the algorithmic empire – is on the march across business and society, but human help still has a role to play. And that role is increasingly apparent as algorithms try to do more work that was once the realm of human intelligence.

headline: Decision Looms on Trade Status of 5 Shark Species
keywords: ['Sharks', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Delegates at an international meeting on wildlife trade voted on Monday to add several shark species to a list of plants and animals whose international trade is regulated.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Delegates at a major international meeting on wildlife trade voted on Monday to add several shark species to a list of plants and animals whose international trade is regulated. The vote was welcomed by conservationists, though it is still subject to final approval by the conference later this week.

headline: Indictee for President!
abstract: How the International Criminal Court may have won Uhuru Kenyatta the presidency of Kenya.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI — When the International Criminal Court was established in 2002 it had many lofty ambitions. Ending impunity for crimes against humanity, genocide and war crimes. Delivering justice to those abandoned by their national courts.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 11, 2013

headline: India Rape Suspect’s Family Says His Death Wasn’t Suicide
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Ram Singh, the driver of a bus in which a 23-year-old woman was fatally gang raped, was found hanging from a ceiling grill on Monday, jail officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The case of a fatal gang rape aboard a bus here in December, which set off an uproar across India, took a surprising turn on Monday when the body of a suspect in the attack was found hanging from a bedsheet noose in his jail cell. Officials called the death a suicide, but the suspect’s family insisted that he had been killed.

headline: Competing Interests in an I.P.O.
abstract: Joe Nocera examines how Goldman Sachs handled the eToys I.P.O. | Erin Callan, former C.F.O. of Lehman Brothers, expresses regret over how career choices affected her personal life. | British lawmakers raise concerns over proposed legislation intended to protect the financial services sector.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to hot initial public offerings, there is a long-running debate over the obligations of the underwriter. In one classic case, the 1999 I.P.O. of eToys, a cache of documents newly unearthed by Joe Nocera of The New York Times offers insight into the way one Wall Street firm, Goldman Sachs, has approached these deals. In a lawsuit that is still going on, lawyers for an eToys creditors’ committee claimed that Goldman purposely set a low price to create a first-day pop in the stock for institutional investors, at the expense of the company itself.

headline: Monday Reading: Avoiding ‘Single’ Surcharge While Traveling
abstract: Avoiding “single supplements” while traveling, myths about the flu vaccine, Wi-Fi in every room and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Melanie Thernstrom on Untangling the Mystery of Food Allergies
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article answers questions about how her son’s illness informed her reporting, and where the field of food allergy research is heading.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Thernstrom wrote this week’s cover article about a doctor who is trying to cure children of their dangerous food allergies. Thernstrom is the author, most recently, of “The Pain Chronicles.” She last wrote for the magazine about twiblings.

headline: Divining What’s Next for Video Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)', 'Wii (Video Game System)']
abstract: Nintendo’s Shigeru Miyamoto discusses sales of the company’s Wii U, violence and video games, and the games at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Since helping to invent the modern video-game industry in 1981 with his design of Donkey Kong, Nintendo’s Shigeru Miyamoto has repeatedly reinvented it, most notably with the Nintendo Entertainment System in the 1980s — it introduced Super Mario Bros. and the Legend of Zelda to American households — and in the 2000s with the Wii, whose arm-waving motion controls started yet another widely imitated video-game craze.

headline: Those Who Love South Africa Ask If It’s Existentially Violent
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: After the death of a Mozambican immigrant at the hands of police, Graça Machel, Nelson Mandela’s wife, says the country is “bleeding.” Despite falling crime rates, it may be.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a recent spate of high-profile incidents of violence, Nelson Mandela’s wife, Graça Machel last week broke the usual silence of the former first couple and said that South Africa was “an angry nation.”

headline: Q&A: Importing Camera Photos to an iPad Mini
abstract: The iPad Camera Connection Kit and many other accessories designed for older iPads will not work with the iPad Mini without the right adapters.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: A More Opaque British Government
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: On two fronts, the British government has been pressing to restrict public access to and knowledge of judicial proceedings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British governments sometimes seem inclined to offer unrequested advice to countries in the so-called developing world about their commitment to Western democracy. But in recent weeks, the question could be inverted: how open is British society itself?

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 Soldiers in Pakistan Tribal District
abstract: The blast struck a military convoy 20 miles east of Parachinar, the capital of the Kurram tribal district, said a military official who declined to be named.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan – A roadside bomb attack killed three soldiers and wounded at least three others in Pakistan’s tribal belt on Monday, Pakistani security officials said.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘The Bachelor’ Draws Viewers, and Martha Stewart’s Need for Privacy
abstract: “The Bachelor” regains high ratings, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia might be better off private and copyright issues have arisen for “Harlem Shake.”
lead_paragraph: ABC’s romance reality show “The Bachelor” has experienced a rare resurgence after a downswing that lasted several seasons , Amy Chozick and Bill Carter report. The show, which pairs a hunky man with dozens of heavily made-up women until he picks one as his fiancée, has become the unlikely exception in a television season when almost every other show on ABC and its competitors has declined. The audience has increased to 8.8 million viewers, 3.3 million of whom are 18 to 49 years old, the most attractive group for advertisers. The show is especially popular among women, particularly those in households that make more than $100,000 a year.

headline: The Gun Report: March 11, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On February 27, we included in our gun report the murder of two officers in Santa Cruz, Calif., who were shot while following up on a sexual assault claim. The gunman, Jeremy Goulet, who was killed by police, was an Army veteran who had been accused of raping two military officers in 2006. Instead of jail time, a plea bargain allowed him to walk away with a less than honorable discharge. Former Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who once represented Santa Cruz in Congress, spoke at the slain officers’ memorial service and suggested that this slap on the wrist paved the way for Goulet’s final, horrific crime.

headline: Dell Agrees to Open Its Books to Icahn
abstract: Carl C. Icahn said on Monday that he had signed a confidentiality agreement with Dell Inc., potentially heading off a confrontation over its $24.4 billion sale.
lead_paragraph: Dell Inc. has agreed to open its books to the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, signaling a possible truce on one front in the battle over the computer maker’s proposed $24.4 billion buyout.

headline: Breitbarted

lead_paragraph: Iran should be left alone with its nuclear ambitions. Sanctions do nothing more than hurt those who have nothing to say about anything in their own country. Just tell the Iranians this: If you detonate one of the weapons outside of your country, your country will cease to exist.

headline: Ukraine Gets Its Own Vogue

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Masha Tsukanova is the new face on the front lines of fashion. As the editor in chief of Vogue Ukraine, which made its debut this month as Vogue’s 21st international edition, she attended shows in Milan and made a brief appearance in Paris. She seemed to be fitting right in.

headline: Market Milestones Can Lead to False Assumptions
abstract: When the stock market hits new highs or lows, investors often question whether they should be making changes to their original investment plan.
lead_paragraph: Any time the stock market hits a new milestone, whether it’s going up or down, we start to hear a lot of noise. And the chatter seems to be focused on this idea of what it all means.

headline: For the Tech Crowd, a Taste of Newspaper Talk
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Participants at SXSW may not read print newspapers much, but they love quality information
lead_paragraph: Here in Austin, Tex., where I’m attending the digital media extravaganza known as South by Southwest, or SXSW, the arrival of the local newspaper at the hotel room door each morning seems almost otherworldly. Amid this gathering of techie (not to say geeky, because that would be a bit unfair), mostly young, mostly male participants, where plaid flannel is the de rigueur fashion note and Google glasses are the accessory of choice, The Austin American-Statesman feels like an unfamiliar visitor from the distant past. (It’s a good paper, by the way, with Pulitzer Prizes in its history and a lively local report each day.) To put it mildly, this is not a print newspaper kind of crowd.

headline: Reasonable Representation
abstract: The Times's Adam Liptak on the growing advantage less populated states enjoy in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Adam Liptak on the growing advantage less populated states enjoy in the Senate.

headline: Talking Talent | Serena Williams
abstract: The tennis player talks to T about her collaboration with the first lady, Michelle Obama, and the Let’s Move! Active Schools program.
lead_paragraph: At 31 years old, Serena Williams is ranked the No. 1 female tennis player in the world, for the sixth time. Williams is arguably one of the most exciting athletes to ever grace tennis — with her lightning speed serve, her festive fashion and her fierce determination, Williams defines power. Although her life is virtually a hamster wheel of 24/7 tennis, Williams joined the Nike president and C.E.O., Mark Parker, and the first lady, Michelle Obama, on Feb. 28 in Chicago to announce Nike’s investment of $50 million in the United States to increase the physical activity of children in schools and communities, a portion of which will benefit the Let’s Move! Active Schools program. En route to the airport following the event, Williams discussed the first lady, the Miami Dolphins and her Chris Evert fantasy.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea declared the 1953 Korean War armistice nullified on Monday, following through on a longstanding threat that it renewed last week amid rising tensions with South Korea.

headline: Former Mayor of Detroit Guilty in Corruption Case
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'Extortion and Blackmail']

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Kwame M. Kilpatrick, a former mayor of Detroit, was found guilty on Monday of a raft of charges, including racketeering, fraud and extortion, capping a five-month public corruption trial against him and two co-defendants.

headline: The Heights of Hype
abstract: Before the Masters golf tournament and the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, an onslaught of talk about both.
lead_paragraph: Now that we are well into March, it’s time to brace for the coming onslaught. No, we’re not talking about college basketball tournament madness. That is actually the enjoyable part, so fun we manage to block out reality and overlook the whole N.C.A.A. morass for a few minutes. No, the onslaught comes courtesy of CBS, which broadcasts both the N.C.A.A. tournament and the Masters golf tournament, a fact drilled into our heads so often by Jim Nantz every year that mental health counselors should consider setting up a hot line. Mute buttons everywhere quiver in anticipation of angry thumbs.

headline: Your Guide to New York’s Soda Ban
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s ban on the sale of large sugary drinks will go into effect on Tuesday. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Update, 3:30 p.m. | A state Supreme Court judge in Manhattan invalidated the city’s sugary-drink ban on Monday afternoon. Read the article.

headline: Abraham Lincoln, War President
abstract: The Supreme Court’s Prize Cases decision and the apogee of Lincoln’s executive powers.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the Civil War, the federal courts made little attempt to curb the wide executive war powers claimed by President Abraham Lincoln. Judges issued few pronouncements on the legality of the president’s most controversial measures, one way or the other. This included the Supreme Court – with one critical exception: the ruling in the so-called Prize Cases in early 1863, involving the blockade of Southern ports. The justices, along narrow lines, validated Lincoln’s broad claim, under the war powers, to confiscate goods found aboard blockade runners, in perhaps the court’s most important decision during the entire war.

headline: S.B.A. Proposes Rule Changes to Lure Borrowers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Small Business']
abstract: The moves are the latest in a series of steps by taken by both Congress and the administration to expand the S.B.A.’s reach by making more businesses eligible for the agency’s programs.
lead_paragraph: Concerned, apparently, that not enough businesses are taking advantage of government-guaranteed loans, the Small Business Administration recently proposed changing some of its lending rules. If adopted, the new rules could make the agency’s loan programs accessible and popular enough that they could reach their legal limits on lending — something the programs have seldom ever done. Oddly enough, this is happening at the same time the prospective “sequester” budget cuts may force the agency to make fewer loans.

lead_paragraph: The Times's Michael M. Grynbaum on Christine C. Quinn's bid to be New York City's first female and openly gay mayor.

headline: Tenants Worried by Plans to Build Near City Projects
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: New York City wants to raise revenue by leasing open land on the grounds of its housing projects, stirring deep concerns among residents wary of gentrification.
lead_paragraph: When Hassan Adam was growing up in public housing on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, his playground was a nearby recreational yard in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, where residents have long played basketball and neighbors hold an annual “family day.” Mr. Adam still lives in the project, and he taught his daughter to ride a bike in the play area.

headline: The Legitimizing of Rand Paul
abstract: Why the right’s reaction to his filibuster matters to the Republican foreign policy debate.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column argues that the great Rand Paul filibuster represented an important step in the Kentucky Senator’s quest to widen the Republican conversation on national security beyond the “strength good, appeasement bad” rhetoric that the party had fallen back on (though not as completely as some Republicans would like) in the aftermath of the Bush presidency. The most persuasive counterpoint to my interpretation is that the right’s rally around Paul’s drones-on-American-soil stand is sui generis, with no wider implications for the G.O.P. foreign policy debates: Many of the Republican Party’s hawks have always been skeptical of drone warfare (preferring boots on the ground, more prisoner-taking, etc.), and the fact that Paul was making a reductio ad hellfirum argument about drones taking down latter-day Jane Fondas made it that much easier for them to leap on the partisan bandwagon and #standwithRand.

headline: Cutting Down on the Meat, but Not the Taste
abstract: Five healthy dishes that include just enough meat.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to cut down your meat intake and increase your vegetable consumption without becoming a vegetarian. Culinary traditions around the world are filled with dishes in which meat is used sparingly, for flavor and substance, but is not at the center of the plate. Think stir-fries, and some of your favorite pastas that have a little bit of pancetta but are really all about the tomatoes.

headline: A Barclays Banker Bets on a ‘Fat Cat’
abstract: This week, Rich Ricci, the head of Barclays investment banking unit, is entering several horses in the Cheltenham Festival, including “Fat Cat in the Hat.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama irked Wall Street bankers a few years ago by calling them “fat cats.” But one banker has embraced the name.

headline: Painterly Fashion
abstract: How Theodora Allen, an MFA candidate in California, played a part in Saint Laurent’s Paris show.
lead_paragraph: For his second women’s collection at Saint Laurent in Paris last week, Hedi Slimane sent out invitations in the form of an artist book called “49 Paintings” by Theodora Allen. Fashion houses teaming up with contemporary artists is nothing particularly new — there were actual Yayoi Kusama mannequins in Louis Vuitton’s windows when those two paired off — but to tap someone still in graduate school feels the riskier proposition. Allen is currently in her second year at U.C.L.A.’s M.F.A. program and has no gallery representation. “I’m looking at various 19th- and 20th-century bohemian countercultures — from the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, to the early California Arts and Crafts movement, to singer-songwriters living in Laurel Canyon in the late 1960s,” she said of her inspiration.

headline: London Theater Journal: Well-Seated Performers
abstract: Rupert Everett stars as Oscar Wilde in “The Judas Kiss” and Rowan Atkinson plays a teacher of English in “Quartermaine’s Terms.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rupert Everett and Rowan Atkinson are very good at sitting. This is more challenging and less boring than it sounds. I, for example, sat for nearly five hours watching these actors sitting in different West End revivals one day recently. But I seriously doubt that anyone focusing on me, or on any of my fellow audience members, during those hours would have been held in thrall.

headline: Really? Acupuncture Can Reduce Symptoms of Hay Fever
abstract: Studies suggest that acupuncture can help with symptoms of hay fever, but the effects may be short-lived.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Image of the Day: March 11
abstract: Schools reopen in the Kashmir valley after a long winter break.

headline: Conclave Smoke’s Recipe Is a Mystery
abstract: Progress during the papal conclave will be measured in the colors of the smoke that will emerge after the voting, but just how those colors are made remains a mystery.
lead_paragraph: During the papal conclave in the Sistine Chapel, progress will be measured in black and white — the colors of the smoke that will emerge after the voting, coming from a copper flue jutting from the chapel roof. But just how those colors are created remains a bit of a mystery.

headline: Nieuwenhuis on Schedule to Return to Mets
abstract: Outfielder Kirk Nieuwenhuis, who has a left knee bone bruise, is expected to return to outdoor baseball activities for the Mets on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Outfielder Kirk Nieuwenhuis and the Mets are still targeting Wednesday for his return to outdoor baseball activities.

headline: Ritual and Secrecy Surround Conclave
abstract: The conclave to elect a pope, which starts Tuesday, begins with prayers chanted in an ancient language and ends with the unveiling of the supreme pontiff.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — It begins with prayers chanted in an ancient language and ends with a tiny figure on the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica unveiled as the supreme pontiff of more than a billion Catholics. The conclave to elect a pope, which starts Tuesday, unfolds with elaborate ritual, deep secrecy and politicking that would warm the heart of a machine politician.

headline: An Elaborate Ritual to Elect a Pope
abstract: The Times’s Daniel J. Wakin reports on planning behind the conclave beginning on Tuesday. It’s a process that goes back centuries.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Daniel J. Wakin reports on planning behind the conclave beginning on Tuesday. It’s a process that goes back centuries.

headline: Bieber and Rihanna Cancel Shows
abstract: Justin Bieber canceled a performance in Portugal and Rihanna dropped a show in Boston.
lead_paragraph: It may be that the promoters of Justin Bieber’s two scheduled concerts in Portugal this week were overly ambitious: the Web page for the Pavilhao Atlantico in Lisbon, where Mr. Bieber was scheduled to perform tonight and Tuesday, limits ticket purchases to six a customer.

headline: Airport Screening Concerns Civil Liberties Groups
abstract: Civil liberties groups and some European regulators are questioning a plan that would determine which passengers pose a threat based on data collected by governments and airlines.
lead_paragraph: Aviation security leaders are moving forward with plans to shift toward a risk-based system of passenger screening — an idea supported by the travel industry and government officials who want screeners to focus on travelers who may present a security threat.

lead_paragraph: More photos from the Broadway play "August: Osage County."

headline: Tournament Watch: Which Teams Need a Strong Showing
abstract: What teams need a strong showing in the conference tournaments to make the N.C.A.A. field?
lead_paragraph: As every regular season ends and conference tournaments begin, a batch of college basketball teams can breathe easily, knowing that they will soon be one of 68 teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament. This has become a steady truth for usual juggernauts like Duke, Michigan State and Kansas, which will soon seal its 24th consecutive appearance in the tourney, the third-longest streak in tournament history behind North Carolina’s 27 straight from 1975-2001 and Arizona’s 25 from 1985-2009.

headline: Obama to Address Gathering of Donors and Activists
abstract: President Obama will speak Wednesday night at a dinner for donors and activists at the first gathering of Organizing for Action, the nonprofit group created by former campaign officials to help advance the president’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will speak Wednesday night at a dinner for donors and activists at the first gathering of Organizing for Action, the nonprofit group created by former campaign officials to help advance the president’s agenda, according to officials with the new organization.

headline: Chronic Insomnia Affects Heart
abstract: A long-term sleep problem may lead to higher blood pressure and higher heart rate, known risk factors for heart failure.
lead_paragraph: Insomnia may be linked to an increased risk of heart failure, according to a large new study, and the more insomnia symptoms, the greater the risk.

headline: Q. and A. With Thea Goodman, Author of ‘The Sunshine When She’s Gone’
abstract: The author Thea Goodman inhabits the strange, slightly demented world of the too self-conscious new parent.
lead_paragraph: It’s unusual for me to interview the author of a novel, rather than a nonfiction book on parenting. But then, “The Sunshine When She’s Gone,” by Thea Goodman, is an unusual book. Ms. Goodman’s main characters, the new parents Veronica and John, find themselves in that strange, sleep-deprived dream state of new parenthood, and then act on escape fantasies that will seem familiar to anyone who has been there.

headline: Van Jumps Curb in Queens, Killing Boy
abstract: A 16-year-old was fatally struck and four other pedestrians were injured outside LaGuardia Community College in Long Island City.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old boy was killed and four other pedestrians were injured on Monday morning when a van jumped a curb outside LaGuardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Koch Willed Secretary $100,000 From $10 Million Estate
abstract: As an unpretentious politician, Edward I. Koch never flaunted his wealth and lived a relatively modest lifestyle in a rent-controlled apartment on lower Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: She was his fiercely loyal and unwaveringly discreet personal secretary for nearly 40 years, and he credited her for helping him achieve professional acclaim. And so former Mayor Edward I. Koch rewarded his secretary, Mary Garrigan, with a $100,000 bequest, according to his will.

lead_paragraph: Read the full will of Former Mayor Edward M. Koch.

headline: The Curse of EconoSisyphus
abstract: Making the points again and again and again.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Frankel participates in a discussion of Chinese currency policy — and finds many of the participants subscribing to the doctrine of immaculate transfer. As he says, I thought I had definitively disposed of that doctrine 25 years ago. But it keeps coming back.

headline: ’Ino Helped Usher In Simpler, Freer Fare
abstract: Oliver Strand recalls that ’ino, which closed Sunday, was “a casual joint with integrity.”
lead_paragraph: In a Facebook post on Sunday, ’ino announced that it had closed. When the shoebox-shaped and nearly shoebox-size panini shop opened on Bedford Street 15 years ago, there was nothing quite like it in New York, a restaurant that kept things simple and kept prices low, serving flavorful food in a room that was just adorable enough that you could decide, midmeal, that maybe the two of you squeezed into the counter were there on a date, and not just grabbing a bite.

headline: The Junk-Food Pile
abstract: A breakdown of the junk foods that readers said they have a love-hate relationship with.
lead_paragraph: What emerged from the 1,300-plus comments posted by readers in response to Michael Moss’s article, “The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food,” was not only a debate over the tactics of food-industry giants (sentiments expressed on this past weekend’s letters page) but also a series of confessions about the processed foods that readers find most tempting.

headline: Illinois Is Accused of Fraud by S.E.C.
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: In announcing a settlement, the agency said the state had misled investors about the health of its pension system.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in history, federal regulators have accused an American state of securities fraud, finding that Illinois misled investors about the condition of its public pension system from 2005 to 2009.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Director Contends Acid Attack’s Mastermind Yet to Be Found
abstract: Anatoly Iksanov, the theater’s general director, told Russian television that he doesn’t believe that the mastermind behind the January acid attack on Sergei Filin, the ballet company’s artistic director, has been found.
lead_paragraph: The web of intrigue around Russia’s Bolshoi Theater continued to grow over the weekend after Anatoly Iksanov, the theater’s general director, told Russian television that he doesn’t believe that the mastermind behind the January acid attack on Sergei Filin, the ballet company’s artistic director, has been found.

headline: Left Behind, UConn Ponders Starting Over Again
abstract: As the current Big East dissolves, Connecticut is contemplating an immediate future in an unheralded league and the likelihood of no traditional or natural geographic rivals.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut is not eligible to play in the Big East men’s basketball tournament, which begins Tuesday, nor can it qualify for next week’s bigger national show. It would still be fitting for the Huskies to be at Madison Square Garden for the conference finale Saturday night, if only for the purpose of turning out the lights.

abstract: While scientists race to develop a technology, probably nuclear-based, that can slake our energy thirst without a huge environmental cost, it would be folly to wait that long to tackle carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: At a legendary but secretive laboratory in California, Lockheed Martin is working on a plan that some employees hope might transform the world’s energy system: a practicable type of nuclear fusion.

lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Watching genre films and comedies with a South by Southwest audience makes a strong case for the power of the theatrical experience and the value of its preservation. The crowds in Austin dive into festival films with enthusiasm and vigor, which makes them ideal for filmmakers eager to see how their films play to genre-loving fans, giving some indication of how the films might be met by audiences around the country.

headline: Seeing, and Thinking, Like Sherlock
abstract: Two new books aim to offer insights into the fictional detective’s faculties of deduction and logical synthesis.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Conan Doyle’s novels and short stories about the incomparable detective Sherlock Holmes have never been out of print since their first publication in 1887. Holmes collections abound, as do movies, TV series, video games, hats, pipes, T-shirts and calendars, not to mention nonfiction books dissecting the Holmesian method.

headline: For Vince Carter, Happiness as a Sixth Man
abstract: Vince Carter doesn’t fly as high as he did earlier in his N.B.A. career, but being a role-filling veteran for the Mavericks suits him well.
lead_paragraph: “Back in the day, I didn’t really care,” said Dallas’s Vince Carter, in the visitors’ locker room after a game at Minnesota. “I’m suffering now.”

headline: Lumière | They Eat Horses, Don’t They?
abstract: The French and the Anglo-Saxons have found themselves caught in a clash of culinary cultures with the widening food scandal that is “horsegate.”
lead_paragraph: Last October, the super-starred French chef Alain Ducasse invited Dan Barber, of the Blue Hill restaurants in New York, to the Plaza Athenée to cook for some special guests. American Ambassador Charles H. Rivkin and his wife, Susan Tolson, showed up, as did dozens of Paris luminaries. The Americans were wowed by Barber’s inventiveness, including his use of charcoal made from pig bones to roast a whole pig. The French, by contrast, were horrified.

headline: Even Without Intrade, Billions Will Be Bet on 2016 Race
abstract: Yes, money will flow to other betting markets and bookmakers who offer odds on the election. But the billions I am referring to will be wagered somewhere else: Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: The popular prediction market Intrade, which in November shut down its markets to United States residents after a complaint from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, announced on Sunday that it was closing down entirely.

headline: New Optimism on Resveratrol
abstract: A new study found that resveratrol, a minor ingredient of red wine, directly influenced sirtuins, proteins that promote longer life in laboratory worms, flies and mice.
lead_paragraph: A cloud has long hung over the intriguing thesis that resveratrol, a minor ingredient of red wine, activates cellular proteins known as sirtuins that promote longer life in laboratory worms, flies and mice.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mary Jo White plans to strike a hard line against Wall Street wrongdoing at a Senate confirmation hearing on Tuesday, as she deflects concerns over her ability to regulate the same banks she recently defended.

headline: With Few Details, Lucasfilm Signals ‘Star Wars’ Plans for TV
abstract: The company, owned by Disney, says it will pursue a “new direction” in animated programming based on the Star Wars narrative.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Now that Lucasfilm is moving full steam ahead on a new “Star Wars” trilogy, the company — now owned by Disney — is starting to get its TV universe in order. On Monday came word that Lucasfilm has “decided to pursue a new direction in animated programming.”

headline: Ai Weiwei Is Making a Rock Album
abstract: The dissident Chinese artist is working with the rock musician Zuoxiao Zuzhou.
lead_paragraph: When Chinese authorities jailed the dissident sculptor Ai Weiwei for 81 days in 2011, they may have created a monster, of sorts: now Mr. Ai has announced that he is recording a heavy metal album, and he has traced the roots of his interest in music to his incarceration, when his guards asked him to sing, and he realized that he knew only Chinese revolutionary songs.

headline: Mixing Scripture Into the Batter
keywords: ['Monasteries and Monks', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Cheesecake', 'Nuns']
abstract: For the Nuns of New Skete, a simple, pious life; for their customers, rich, tempting cheesecakes.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, N.Y. — At first, the prep work for 200 four-pound cheesecakes in the sunny, commercial kitchen seemed familiar, unremarkable. An elderly woman in a bandanna wielded a cheese cutter, slicing through fat bricks of cream cheese. Another woman with silvery bangs poured heavy cream into the mixer, dipped a tasting pinkie into the batter and grinned. Rich vanilla perfumed the air. As containers from Florida were opened, bright bursts of Key lime scent escaped.

headline: Disruptions: Thank You for Your ‘Thank You’ Comments
abstract: Readers respond to Nick Bilton’s column, which discussed a new kind of digital etiquette in society where asking for directions, leaving a voice mail message and saying “Thank You” in an e-mail can be considered rude.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week I argued that there is a new type of digital etiquette where asking for directions, leaving a voice mail message and saying “thank you” in an e-mail can be considered rude.

headline: In a Break for Senate Democrats, Durbin to Run for Re-election in Illinois
abstract: Senator Richard Durbin, the Senate’s second-ranking Democrat, has decided to to try to stick around for another six years, according to Senate officials familiar with his decision.
lead_paragraph: After a half-dozen senior senators have announced their retirements, it now passes as news when a Senate veteran up for re-election in 2014 decides to try to stick around for another six years. Senator Richard Durbin of Illinois, the Senate’s second-ranking Democrat, has decided to do just that, according to Senate officials familiar with his decision.

headline: Delusions, Anger and Violence
abstract: Patients with mental illness who are also violent are more likely to experience delusions accompanied by anger, a study finds.

headline: Historians Issue Report on Vienna Philharmonic
abstract: The three historians commissioned by the Vienna Philharmonic to carry out an independent study of its Nazi past announced their findings on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The three historians commissioned by the Vienna Philharmonic to carry out an independent study of its Nazi past announced their findings on Sunday. In preliminary materials furnished to The New York Times last month, Oliver Rathkolb, the lead historian, said he had learned, from a “highly trustworthy and well-informed witness,” the identity of a shadowy presence and promised to reveal it with the entire study. That has now been posted on the orchestra’s Web site, in German, with a promise of an English translation to follow. The person served as an emissary, official or not, of the orchestra in delivering a replacement of the orchestra’s ring of honor that had been bestowed on Baldur von Schirach in 1942. Schirach, the Nazi governor of Vienna who lost the ring after World War II, spent 20 years in prison for his part in deporting tens of thousands of Viennese Jews to extermination camps in Nazi-occupied Poland. In late 1966 or early 1967, after he was freed, the replacement ring was tendered by — it is now revealed — Helmut Wobisch, a trumpeter in the orchestra. Wobisch joined the Nazi party and the SS early on, spied on and denounced fellow musicians, was fired by the orchestra after the war, rejoined it in 1947, became its executive director in 1953 and played in it until 1968.

headline: Reaping Connections Paul Taylor Has Sown
abstract: Paul Taylor recombines and juxtapose dances, like the new “To Make Crops Grow” alongside the very different “Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rehearsal).”
lead_paragraph: The foyer at the David H. Koch Theater, happily stripped of recent clutter, is one of this city’s great interiors. Large, calm and elegant, with its vast window space filtered by pearl-rope curtains, it opens onto a balcony that faces over Lincoln Center’s plaza. Now, during the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s annual three-week season at the Koch, this space proves the perfect place in which to let the dances add up after the curtain falls, and to mull over the connections between one work and another.

headline: A Rousing ‘Pasión,’ This Time Spanning Generations as Well as Cultures
abstract: Osvaldo Golijov’s “Pasión Según San Marcos” brought high school choirs from the New York region and performers from Venezuela together at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: For all of its popularity since its triumphant premiere in Stuttgart, Germany, in 2000, Osvaldo Golijov’s “Pasión Según San Marcos” (“The St. Mark Passion”) is not likely to become a standard repertory work. Reimagining the Bach Passions, Mr. Golijov tells the story of the Crucifixion as it has been lived and felt every day in Latin America. This heady, polystylistic, genre-blurring work blends Brazilian, Afro-Cuban and other styles of Latin American folk and pop music into a 90-minute theatrical score that includes elements of ritual and dance. Any presentation requires performers steeped in the musical traditions from which Mr. Golijov draws.
