headline: Arizona: Most of Law on Ethnic Studies Is Upheld
abstract: A federal judge has upheld all but one aspect of an Arizona law prohibiting school districts from offering courses taught from a specific racial or ethnic perspective.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has upheld all but one aspect of an Arizona law prohibiting school districts from offering courses taught from a specific racial or ethnic perspective, which targeted the Mexican-American studies program at some Tucson public schools. The ruling Friday, by Judge A. Wallace Tashima of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, came in a lawsuit brought by teachers and students at the Tucson Unified School District against Arizona’s school superintendent, John Huppenthal, and other state officials. The plaintiffs say the law is too broad to be constitutional. The law, signed in 2010, prohibits public schools from offering courses that promote the overthrow of the United States government, advocate ethnic solidarity and foster resentment toward a race or class of people. In Tucson, students studied history and literature from a Mexican-American perspective. Opponents said the curriculum encouraged students to resent white people. Judge Tashima ruled, however, that banning classes tailored specifically to students of a particular ethnicity is unconstitutional.

headline: For U.S. Seminarians, a ‘Ringside Seat’
abstract: Students at the Pontifical North American College in Rome have the rare opportunity to watch a papal transition up close.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Morning prayers, chanted in Latin, had just ended at the Benedictine monastery in France, where a few American seminarians were on retreat. A monk quietly approached one of them, James Platania, who was walking through the cloister to the refectory, and asked if he had heard the news.

headline: Hagel to Open Review of Sexual Assault Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s decision to review an overturned sexual assault conviction comes amid mounting criticism of the Pentagon’s handling of such cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is beginning an internal review of a decision by a senior Air Force commander to overturn the sexual assault conviction of an Air Force fighter pilot, he said in a letter to top lawmakers made public Monday.

headline: U.N. Ties Gaza Baby’s Death to Palestinians
abstract: A Palestinian rocket, not an Israeli airstrike, most likely killed the baby of a BBC journalist during fighting in Gaza last November, a United Nations report indicates.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A United Nations report has suggested that a Palestinian infant who died in the fighting in Gaza last November may have been killed by an errant Palestinian rocket rather than by an Israeli airstrike as was widely believed at the time. The infant’s death quickly became a powerful symbol of the conflict.

headline: Home of the Lion That Hercules Slew
abstract: The contrasting styles of Bruce Sutphin and Neville Fogarty.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m blogging this from the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, and one of the nice things about solving puzzles in the midst of all this intelligence is that there is always help around when you need it. For example, there I was, sitting in the Marriott lounge, regretting the fact that I wept through most of my college calculus class because of the clue at 14 Down, when the constructor Byron Walden walked by. Mr. Walden is a math professor with a Ph.D. in some mathy subject, so it was a serendipitous moment to stick out my arm, grab him by the lapel, and scream “What is a four-letter word for calculus calculation?” Now that’s what I call using your resources.

headline: Defining Bullying Down
abstract: The word “bullying” is overused — expanding, accordionlike, to encompass both appalling violence or harassment and a few mean words.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN

headline: Notre Dame and UConn Roll to Final
abstract: Connecticut, which has reeled off five consecutive Big East tournament titles in women’s basketball, will face a Notre Dame team eyeing its first such crown on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Connecticut, which has reeled off five consecutive Big East tournament titles in women’s basketball, will face a Notre Dame team eyeing its first such crown in Tuesday night’s championship game at XL Center.

headline: As Rats Persist, Transit Agency Hopes to Curb Their Births
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority detailed plans for a pilot program aimed at sterilization, using a product that would be placed in bait boxes inside the authority’s trash rooms.
lead_paragraph: They have thwarted the poisons. They have evaded the traps.

headline: The Conclave’s Fixed Ways
abstract: The process for choosing the next pope is a recipe and metaphor for the Roman Catholic hierarchy’s aloofness.
lead_paragraph: And now the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church retreat into the Sistine Chapel, hordes of journalists flitting breathlessly around St. Peter’s Square, one question above many others hanging in the air. Will the next pope chart a course of truly significant change for the church, which could certainly use some changing?

headline: Lowe’s Campaign Keeps Eye on the Weather
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: The big retailer’s new ads for the spring, a critical shopping season for home improvement stores, try to capitalize on the rising housing market.
lead_paragraph: LOWE’S is introducing a new round of advertising to promote home improvement projects in the spring, its prime revenue-generating period. The ads, which began appearing on Sunday, reflect an effort by Lowe’s to take advantage of the rebounding housing market and catch up to Home Depot, the country’s most profitable national home improvement company.

headline: The Grim Backlog at Veterans Affairs
abstract: A new report paints a distressing portrait of an agency buried helplessly in paperwork.
lead_paragraph: A new report based on previously unreleased data from the Department of Veterans Affairs paints a distressing portrait of an agency buried helplessly in paperwork — with a claims backlog that has gotten far worse in the past four years. The average wait to begin receiving disability compensation and other benefits is 273 days, and up to 327 days for veterans making claims for the first time. Those in big cities wait far longer — up to 642 days in New York. The total number of veterans with backlogged claims is about 600,000.

headline: Toxic Threats to Grassland Birds
abstract: A Canadian study found that pesticides were four times more likely to be linked with bird losses than any other cause.
lead_paragraph: Ornithologists agree that in the United States no group of birds is declining faster than the grassland species that live in or migrate through agricultural areas. These include, among others, various sparrows, eastern and western meadowlarks, bobolinks, horned larks and at least two kinds of owl. Scientists have generally agreed that the major cause is the fragmentation and loss of prairie habitat, the conversion of grassland to farmland as well as alterations in established farmland.

headline: Unholy Alliance
abstract: At a United Nations conference, Iran, Russia and the Vatican are working to block global standards protecting women against violence.
lead_paragraph: Some horrific events over the past few months, including the shooting of a Pakistani schoolgirl and the rape and murder of a young Indian physiotherapy student, should have been an alert for the world to unite in preventing violence against women.

headline: The Axis of Ennui
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Energy and Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Effective energy innovation is not happening where you think it is, Dear Reader.
lead_paragraph: Because I have to generate two columns a week for you, Dear Reader, I spend some time hunting for new ideas on the conference circuit. When you are on that circuit, you are perpetually under the illusion that you are hearing from the exciting, fresh people who are about to change history.

headline: Politics by Intimidation
abstract: In Oregon, extremists fight gun laws with harassment. It’s the post-Newtown world.
lead_paragraph: Three days before the December massacre in Newtown, Conn., a 22-year-old gunman named Jacob Tyler Roberts opened fire at the Clackamas Town Center, a suburban shopping mall in Portland, Ore. He killed two people before killing himself, though it could have been much worse. His stolen semiautomatic AR-15 rifle jammed early in his shooting spree.

headline: In China, Cinematic Flops Suggest Fading of an Icon
abstract: Celebrations of “Learn from Lei Feng Day” turned into something of a public relations debacle after three films about the propaganda hero bombed at the box office.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It has been five decades since Mao Zedong decreed that the altruistic, loyal soldier Lei Feng should be a shining star in the Communist Party’s constellation of propaganda heroes. But last week, on the 50th anniversary of that proclamation, came unmistakable signs that despite the Chinese government’s best efforts, Lei Feng’s glow is fading.

headline: Trapped Next to a Chatty 8-Year-Old, All the Way to Beijing
abstract: Alex Moazed, the chief of Applico, a mobile strategy firm, learned he limits of technology on a flight next to “the most curious juvenile on the planet.”
lead_paragraph: I’M a 24-year-old entrepreneur in mobile technologies. I haven’t been flying for business all that long, but it’s really important to my company’s growth. I almost always leave home without doing much in terms of checking on my flight, having ground transportation or a hotel reserved. That may sound irresponsible, but I’ve found that mobile apps can do almost everything for me when I’m on the road.

headline: Realities Behind Prosecuting Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Recent comments by the attorney general seem to contradict the administration’s view that too-big-to-fail was fixed by the Dodd-Frank financial regulation law.
lead_paragraph: Are banks too big to jail?

headline: When the U.S. Kills an American Citizen
abstract: Readers debate the legal and moral issues raised by the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Universal Right to Vote
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Elections']
abstract: New legal protections are needed to expand the guarantee of ballot access in every state.
lead_paragraph: Last month’s Supreme Court arguments over the constitutionality of the Voting Rights Act served as a reminder of the long history of racial voting suppression in this country. Many of the states covered by Section 5 of the act, particularly in the South, spent decades trying every method they could think of to keep blacks and other minorities from the polls, or to reduce their voting strength.

headline: Anthony Returns to Lineup in Time for Pivotal Road Trip
abstract: Carmelo Anthony returned to the Knicks on Monday after missing three games because of a knee injury. On Wednesday he faces his former team, the Nuggets, in Denver.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Carmelo Anthony has been primed for his return: to the city he shunned, to the lineup that needs him, to a Knicks season that is teetering uncomfortably beneath his feet as it enters the home stretch.

headline: Nuclear Neighbors for North Korea?
abstract: Will North Korea’s threats and continued testing cause more proliferation in the region?

headline: The Nominee for the S.E.C. Faces a Senate Hearing
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Readers discuss the nomination of Mary Jo White to be chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: E-Mail Scandal at Harvard
abstract: A response to a news article from the novelist Anne Bernays, who teaches at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Suits, Not Settling Them
abstract: The head of the Lawsuit Reform Alliance of New York praises a new city policy to fight weak cases.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shopping for Airfares
abstract: The International Air Transport Association responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: House and Senate Work Simultaneously to Create Budgets, a Rarity
abstract: Despite the fact that the spending plans will be miles apart ideologically, there are signs that some sort of compromise might be possible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress this week will begin taking the first steps toward a more structured and orderly budget process, beginning what both parties hope is a move away from the vicious cycle of deadline-driven quick fixes.

headline: Qaeda Group in Iraq Says It Killed Syrian Soldiers
keywords: ['Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The group’s claim of responsibility of the massacre coincided with news of a religious decree from Syria’s grand mufti suggesting Syria needs more recruits and that it was a call to jihad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Sunni militant jihadist group in Iraq claimed responsibility on Monday for killing dozens of Syrian soldiers who had sought temporary safety on the Iraqi side of the border last week, boasting about the massacre in an Internet posting that used demeaning references to Shiites and President Bashar al-Assad’s Alawite sect.

headline: Penny-Pinching in Pinstripes? Yes, the Yanks Are Reining In Pay
abstract: Long known for lavish payrolls, the Yankees are showing an unfamiliar restraint to get under a $189 million threshold set by the league.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees, the sports franchise known almost as much for lavish spending as winning 27 World Series titles, are turning fiscally conservative.

headline: To Prevent Overpass Hits, New Rules for Truckers
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Global Positioning System', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer and other officials announced the new standards at a parkway bridge on Long Island that has been struck at least 27 times by trucks that should not have been on that road.
lead_paragraph: Tractor-trailers and other commercial vehicles are prohibited from using parkways in New York, like the Jackie Robinson Parkway in Brooklyn and Queens and the Saw Mill River Parkway in Westchester County.

headline: In President’s Outreach to G.O.P., Past Failures Loom
abstract: As President Obama prepares to visit Capitol Hill this week, Democrats said his overtures to Republicans were often resisted because of a sense of political danger in appearing too close.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the attention to President Obama’s new campaign of outreach to Republicans, it was four months ago — on the eve of bipartisan budget talks — that he secretly invited five of them to the White House for a movie screening with the stars of “Lincoln,” the film about that president’s courtship of Congress to pass a significant measure.

headline: In Bullpen Competition, a Track Record Matters
abstract: The Mets have many reliever candidates, but there may only be one spot realistically available to be won.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets’ bullpen represents one of the team’s weakest areas, and at first glance, visions of how it might be constructed for opening day can appear muddled.

headline: Kenyan Reaction to Disputed Election Is Far Calmer Than Last Time
abstract: The loser again claims Kenya’s presidential election was rigged, but major violence, which erupted after the 2007 vote, has so far been absent.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In the Kibera slum, where the sun beats down mercilessly on the metal shacks and ribbons of raw sewage snake across the dirt, people are about as angry as they have ever been.

headline: The Reaction in Kenya
abstract: Jeffrey Gettleman reports from Kibera, a part of Nairobi that was a flashpoint of violence during Kenya’s last presidential election. This time, things are tense but there has been no violence so far.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Gettleman reports from Kibera, a part of Nairobi that was a flashpoint of violence during Kenya’s last presidential election. This time, things are tense but there has been no violence so far.

headline: Barcelona Facing an Early Ouster and Much Analysis
abstract: Four soccer writers weigh in on why Barcelona — the pre-eminent club team in soccer — might not even make the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: Barcelona has become the pre-eminent club team in soccer in recent years but now stands on the brink of being ousted from Europe’s annual Champions League without even making it to the quarterfinals. It trails A.C. Milan by two goals as it prepares for the second leg of their matchup, on Tuesday, before a stadium full of Barcelona fans who cannot quite believe their mighty team is in such a hole. Can they escape? Are they not as good as they used to be? Four of The New York Times’s soccer writers weigh in with their thoughts.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Mar. 12, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, Mar. 12, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve got to defend my children, and yours, and do what’s right to save lives. Obesity kills. There’s no question it kills.”

headline: Corrections: March 12, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 12, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Self-Absorbed, With Chekhov as a Backdrop
abstract: “Neva” is a Guillermo Calderón play set in 1905 Russia and centering on Chekhov’s widow, Olga Knipper.
lead_paragraph: I am beginning to think that all an aspiring (or established) dramatist needs to do to draw notice is to billboard some connection to Chekhov in his or her work, so august has the Russian author’s name become. “Neva,” a new play written and directed by the Chilean writer Guillermo Calderón that is having its English-language premiere at the Public Theater, is a turgid and repetitive meditation on love, theater and politics, but it has already been widely seen on international stages, possibly because Olga Knipper, Chekhov’s widow, has a central role.

headline: Intersection: L Train Inspiration
abstract: Yani Aviles, a Brooklyn native, explains the ebbs and flows of the Williamsburg neighborhood, as well as how she mixes patterns and textures to create her own style.
lead_paragraph: Yani Aviles, a Brooklyn native, explains the ebbs and flows of the Williamsburg neighborhood, as well as how she mixes patterns and textures to create her own style.

headline: Judge in Soda Ruling Is Wary of Government’s Power
abstract: Justice Milton A. Tingling of State Supreme Court in Manhattan has displayed a keen sensitivity to the clout of government, and a willingness to push back when it may be going too far.
lead_paragraph: He ended a state policy of routinely shackling even nonviolent offenders on their way to and from the courthouse. He stopped, at least temporarily, a new city rule limiting the number of art vendors in the parks.

headline: A Hobbled Cashman Goes Fishing for Infielders
abstract: General Manager Brian Cashman sent out feelers to veterans from Derrek Lee to Scott Rolen to Chipper Jones in hopes of saving the Yankees from their numerous injuries.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — General Manager Brian Cashman sat in the team’s dugout Monday morning with his broken leg perched on the bench, discussing his desire to entice first baseman Derrek Lee out of retirement to help save the Yankees from their numerous injuries.

headline: Cheering a Setback to the City’s Drink Limits
abstract: Even with obesity rising, and despite its toll on medical costs, access to bucket-size sodas was widely seen as a personal choice.
lead_paragraph: It would have amounted to a tax on the poor, said some. It would have had little effect anyway, noted others, because people would still have been allowed free refills. It was un-American, said others still, for was this not the country of freedom, more or less, of choice?

headline: Lax Nets Allow the 76ers’ Offense to Come to Life
abstract: Deron Williams did what he could, scoring 27 points with 13 assists, but it wasn’t enough to fend off the 76ers, who shot 53 percent from the field and hit 8 of 15 3-pointers.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Nets have effectively flexed their muscles against the weaker teams in the Eastern Conference all season long, but on Monday, they were outhustled and outplayed by the flailing Philadelphia 76ers for almost a full 48 minutes.

headline: Trial of a Therapist’s Killer Will Hinge on Frame of Mind
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A prosecutor said David Tarloff’s preparations and his escape showed that “he knew what he was doing” when he killed a psychologist, Kathryn Faughey.
lead_paragraph: One evening five years ago, David Tarloff lurked in the stairwell of an Upper East Side building, waiting to rob his former psychiatrist after the last patient left his office.

headline: Russian Judge Delays Trial of Dead Lawyer
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The defense was granted a one-week delay in the trial of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a whistle-blowing lawyer who died in prison in a case that has roiled Russian-American relations.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Justice delayed is justice denied, of course, but for a corpse?

headline: U.S. Expels 2 Venezuela Envoys
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The State Department ordered the expulsion of two Venezuelan diplomats a week after Caracas ordered two American military attachés to leave.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The United States said Monday that it had expelled two Venezuelan diplomats in response to the ouster last week of two American military attachés by Venezuela.

headline: Iran Blocks Way to Bypass Internet Filtering System
abstract: A collection of illegal virtual private networks, or VPNs, was successfully closed by Iran, making visits to Web sites deemed immoral or politically dangerous nearly impossible.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s powerful Ministry of Information and Communications Technology has blocked the most popular software used by millions of Iranians to bypass an elaborate official Internet filtering system, stepping up a campaign to gain more control over the way Iranians use the Internet.

headline: Yankees Embrace Frugality as New Business Model
abstract: Since 2003, the Yankees have paid dearly for routinely exceeding the guideline for payroll set by Major League Baseball.
lead_paragraph: Since 2003, the Yankees have paid dearly for routinely exceeding the guideline for payroll set by Major League Baseball.

headline: Google Shows Off Sample Apps for Glasses
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: At the South by Southwest Conference, Google gave a demonstration of its Project Glass and showed how some apps would work with the eyewear.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Google glasses are everywhere here at South by Southwest. But ask a wearer to try them on or take a photo and you’re quickly rebuffed.

headline: Jury Still at Work in Cannibal Case
abstract: Jurors have so far been unable to agree on the charges against Officer Gilberto Valle, who is accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women.
lead_paragraph: The jury in the trial of the New York police officer accused of plotting to kidnap, kill and cannibalize women was sent home on Monday after deliberating for a second full day without reaching a verdict.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 11, 2013

headline: 2 Afghan Sisters, Swept Up in a Suicide Wave
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: In affluent Mazar-i-Sharif, a family’s bitter grief reflects a town’s growing toll, as the suicide rate among young women skyrockets.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — On the surface, the Gul sisters seemed to have it all: they were young, beautiful, educated and well off, testing the bounds of conservative Afghan traditions with fitted jeans, makeup and cellphones.

headline: In Fighting Teenage Pregnancy, the Folly of Shame and Blame
keywords: ['Teenage Pregnancy', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: The city has begun a judgmental ad campaign that aims to embarrass teenage girls who are not yet mothers by warning of the terrible consequences that can result from getting pregnant.
lead_paragraph: “It is well past time when anyone can afford to be value-neutral when it comes to teen pregnancy.”

headline: Lilian Craig, Beloved of Prince Who Could Be King, Dies at 97
abstract: Ms. Craig and Sweden’s Prince Bertil were unable to marry for decades because she was a commoner. But when the rules changed, wed they did.
lead_paragraph: “If I were to sum up my life, everything has been about love,” Princess Lilian of Sweden once said.

headline: For Detroit, a Crisis of Bad Decisions and Crossed Fingers
abstract: Mandatory financial oversight has come as a result of millions in uncollected fees, a flight of the city’s affluent tax base and hopes that downturns might melt away.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — This city was already sinking under hundreds of millions of dollars in bills that it could not pay when a municipal auditor brought in a veteran financial consultant to dig through the books. A seasoned turnaround man and former actuary with Ford Motor Co., he was stunned by what he found: an additional $7.2 billion in retiree health costs that had never been reported, or even tallied up.

headline: William Moody, 58, Pro Wrestling’s Paul Bearer, Dies
abstract: Mr. Moody gained fame as the urn-carrying manager Paul Bearer for the pro wrestlers the Undertaker and Kane in World Wrestling Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: William Moody, better known as the professional wrestling manager Paul Bearer, who could summon supernatural powers from an urn of cremated ashes whenever his 6-foot-10, 299-pound client, the Undertaker, was in trouble, died on March 5 in Mobile, Ala. He was 58.

headline: My Mother’s Mink
abstract: The passing of a fur coat from mother to daughter evokes memories, then creates a problem.
lead_paragraph: One day my mom simply put the mink coat in a plastic bag, stuffed the bag into a box and shipped it to me. She lives in Scottsdale, Ariz., where she has no needof a calf-length fur in the eight weeks that pretend to be winter, and the mink had become something of a reprimand: Why did she no longer live the kind of life that required a fur coat?

headline: Whither Barcelona?
abstract: Barcelona needs goals to overcome a 2-0 first-leg deficit against Milan and advance to the Champions League quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: With Barcelona needing to overcome a 2-0 deficit against visiting Milan on Tuesday to remain in the Champions League, four Times soccer writers took brief looks at the state of the team as it stands on the brink of elimination.

headline: Sybil Christopher, Nightclub Founder, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Christopher was a former actress, famous ex-wife and founder of Arthur, one of Manhattan’s most popular celebrity nightclubs in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Sybil Christopher, a theater producer, former actress, famous ex-wife and founder of Arthur, one of Manhattan’s most popular celebrity nightclubs in the 1960s, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Falkland Islanders Vote to Remain Part of Britain
abstract: All but three voters in the south Atlantic archipelago, which Argentina claims, cast ballots in favor of remaining an overseas territory of Britain.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — All but three voters in the Falkland Islands, the south Atlantic archipelago, cast ballots Sunday and Monday in favor of remaining an overseas territory of Britain.

headline: Vigil for Brooklyn Teenager Fatally Shot by the Police Turns Violent
abstract: About 130 people had gathered in East Flatbush and were marching toward the 67th Police Precinct station house when about two dozen protesters splintered off and grew rowdy.
lead_paragraph: A vigil for an armed Brooklyn teenager who was fatally shot by police officers turned violent Monday night when a small group broke off from the gathering and began throwing bottles at a local police precinct station house and knocking food off a bodega stand, the authorities said.

headline: Word of the Day | unimpeachable
abstract: This word has appeared in 25 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: unimpeachable •\ˌən-im-ˈpe-chə-bəl\• adjective

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:15 P.M. (MoreMax) LOLA VERSUS (2012) After Lola (Greta Gerwig, above), a graduate student in New York, is dumped by her fiancé, Luke (Joel Kinnaman), as her 30th birthday approaches, she tries to pull her life together with the help of her best friends, the wacky Alice (Zoe Lister-Jones) and the sensitive Henry (Hamish Linklater). But somehow Luke can’t let go of Lola entirely, and she can’t help longing to get back together with him. Debra Winger and Bill Pullman play Lola’s mostly supportive parents. The film, directed by Daryl Wein from a script he wrote with Ms. Lister-Jones, who are a couple in real life, “very much wants to be a funny, affectionate portrait of a young woman in crisis,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Lola Versus,’ unfortunately, is a dismayingly conventional exploration of the vicissitudes of romance. In spite of its scruffy look and slack pacing, it often rings as false as any of the big, shiny and soft studio rom-coms (starring Kate Hudson or Katherine Heigl, say) of the last decade.” Lola, he added, “deserves better.”

headline: Mao’s Anti-Pollution Face Mask
abstract: As anger bubbles up about pollution in China, online posters are altering a sacrosanct image of Chairman Mao to channel their frustration into humor.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With air readings of “hazardous” or “very unhealthy” seemingly the new normal, antipollution face masks are becoming a common sight on the streets of China. Even Mao Zedong has donned one. At least his image has, in doctored photos circulating online to widespread amusement (Mao, of course, died in 1976.)

headline: Panel Rejects Proposal to Stop School Closings
abstract: The vote at a tense and often raucous meeting meant  current plans to close, co-locate or phase out struggling public schools would move forward.
lead_paragraph: A city panel on Monday night rejected a proposal to stop city-mandated school closings in a tense, often raucous meeting, effectively putting any hopes of reversing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s education policy into the next mayor’s hands.

headline: In India, Heated Debate Over Teens and Sex
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Marriages', 'Sex', 'Sex Crimes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Weighing a push to protect women and children against the realities of human sexuality and India’s patriarchal marriage culture.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI —Should it be illegal for 16-year-olds to have sex? What if they’re married?

headline: News Quiz | March 12, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Afghanistan: 5 Coalition Soldiers Killed in Crash
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Helicopters', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The victims, whose nationality was not released, were in a helicopter that crashed on Monday with “no enemy activity in the area,” a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Five coalition soldiers were killed in a helicopter crash in southern Afghanistan on Monday, the coalition announced on Tuesday. The nationality of the victims was not immediately released, in line with official policy to notify next of kin first. A statement from the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force said the crash was under investigation, but “there was no enemy activity in the area at the time.” Javed Faisal, a spokesman for the governor of Kandahar Province, said the crash occurred about 11 p.m. in Daman district.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 12
abstract: North Korea declares an armistice invalid; a suicide wave in Afghanistan; small businesses suffer in Italy; ovarian cancer care is faulted; a stay at the Bates Motel; and baseball tries to become more international.
lead_paragraph: NEWS North Korea declared the 1953 Korean War armistice nullified on Monday, following through on a longstanding threat that it renewed last week amid rising tensions with South Korea. Choe Sang-Hun reports from Seoul.

headline: Anthony’s Return to Lineup Is of Little Help to Knicks
abstract: Carmelo Anthony started Monday night after missing three games with a sore knee, but Golden State held the Knicks to a season low in scoring in a 29-point rout.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The knee was sturdy enough, perhaps not for basketball but certainly for the long, lonely walk to the team bus late Monday night. Carmelo Anthony’s discomfort by that point was purely spiritual.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 12, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the word pair that correctly completes the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the On the Runway blog post “Trendspotting: Taffeta and Tulle at the Golden Globes.”

headline: Black Smoke From Conclave Signals No Pope on First Day
abstract: The cardinals’ first round of balloting, which in other modern conclaves has served as a primary, produced no two-thirds majority.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — It billowed, and it was black.

headline: Selection of New Pope Cloaked in Secrecy and Tradition
abstract: What is the papal conclave? Where does voting take place?
lead_paragraph: In “A Strict Adherence to Ritual and Secrecy in Election of Pope,” Daniel J. Wakin writes about the intricate traditions involved in selecting a new pope.

headline: TV’s New Wave of Women: Smart, Strong, Borderline Insane
abstract: Why do so many shows with central female characters equate “headstrong” with “head case”?
lead_paragraph: At first glance, this looks like a great moment for women on television. Many smart and confident female characters have paraded onto the small screen over the past few years. But I’m bothered by one persistent caveat: that the more astute and capable many of these women are, the more likely it is that they’re also completely nuts.

headline: Good Luck and Good Light
abstract: Broke and without work, Daniel Rodrigues had to sell his photo gear to pay the bills. Then one good frame gave him another shot at photojournalism.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Rodrigues is a 26-year-old freelance photographer based in Porto, Portugal. After graduating from the Portuguese Institute of Photography in 2010, he was an intern for the newspaper Correio da Manhã and worked for the photo agency Global Imagens. Two years later, Rodrigues was broke. That was when a stroke of good luck — and good light — changed his fortunes.

headline: Does Buying and Accumulating More and More Stuff Make Us Happier?
abstract: How much stuff have you accumulated over the years? Are there things you own that you don’t need?
lead_paragraph: Americans love to buy things: tech gadgets, clothing, sneakers, jewelry, you name it. We love to accumulate what we buy too, so it overflows our rooms, closets, garages, basements and yards. And then we throw some of it away and buy more.

headline: Bottle Bing
abstract: To increase its wine business, New Jersey needs to channel its inner Tony Soprano.
lead_paragraph: The Outer Coastal Plain might be the perfect place to make fine wine in America. The region, which has nearly the same sandy soil composition as Bordeaux, experiences a warm growing season; spring frosts are rare; and the breezes from the Atlantic Ocean and a local bay are ideal for winemaking. The O.C.P. has only one real challenge: it’s in southern New Jersey, a state associated with many things — Springsteen, Snooki, industrial pollution, the mob — but not great wine. Much of what is bottled there, in fact, isn’t even grape-based.

headline: Embracing Tradition at Indian Fashion Weeks
abstract: As Western labels land on India’s shores, local designers return to the sari and the churidar.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI —Fashion week fever may have died down in Paris, Milan, New York and London, but in India it’s just getting going.

headline: A Conversation With: Prof. Aseem R. Shukla, University of Pennsylvania
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Hinduism', 'Indian-Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Wharton made a mistake in rescinding an invitation to Narendra Modi, professor argues.
lead_paragraph: The University of Pennsylvania recently withdrew an invitation to Gujarat’s chief minister, Narendra Modi, who was to deliver a keynote address at the Wharton School’s India Economic Forum via video link later this month. The withdrawal, based on questions raised about Mr. Modi’s human rights record, has spurred an animated debate about freedom of speech and Mr. Modi’s leadership credentials in India and among the Indian diaspora.

headline: Eye-Tracking Tech Will Be Open to iPhones and Other Devices
abstract: A start-up company called uMoove says it will offer eye and head tracking to anyone, including device makers like Apple and developers who make mobile apps.
lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics won’t be the only company that gets a fancy eye-tracking feature. A start-up company called uMoove, which has been developing this type of technology for three years, says it will offer eye- and head-tracking to anyone, including device makers like Apple and software developers who make mobile apps.

headline: The Early Word: Called Out
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Wealth, Spending and the Economy
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Personal Finances', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As the nation’s overall wealth has recovered, a vast majority of the gains have been in equities, benefiting mostly the wealthy, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Too Many Colonoscopies in the Elderly
abstract: Nearly a quarter of colonoscopies in patients over age 70 were “potentially inappropriate,” a new analysis finds.
lead_paragraph: Bill Fullington doesn’t remember exactly where he read that all adults over age 50 should be screened for colon cancer. A magazine? Maybe the local paper?

headline: South Korea Disputes North’s Dismissal of Armistice
abstract: South Korea said on Tuesday that North Korea cannot unilaterally nullify the 1953 Korean War cease-fire, calling the North’s threats a ploy to strengthen Kim Jong-un’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has begun evacuating some citizens into tunnels with emergency provisions and putting military camouflage on buses and trucks, the South Korean Defense Ministry said Tuesday.

headline: Is There a Trick to Getting Everything Done?
abstract: The members of the She Owns It business group talk time management. Have you discovered any secrets?
lead_paragraph: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners shared the frustrations of never being able to get to everything. The big things — those critical to the business — get done, said Susan Parker, who owns the dressmaker Bari Jay. But she added that everything else tended to get pushed to the bottom of the pile.

headline: Alphabet Soup Kitchen
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Soup Kitchens']
abstract: The road between chichi café and food bank is short in London these days.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This city sometimes seems to defy financial gravity. The national economy is teetering on the brink of a third recession in five years, real wages are at their lowest in a decade, and austerity is shredding the social safety net. Yet a café 100 meters from my house in Hackney, East London, that sells cupcakes for $4.20 and coffee for more than that is always full. Housing prices rose by almost 10 percent last year, lifting rents along with them. Can this really be the capital of a country whose debt just lost its coveted AAA rating?

headline: Quest for a Little-Known Suburban Lizard
abstract: An expedition to study the variable-scaled anole in the Andean uplands of Colombia begins with a less than scientific challenge: dealing with traffic.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: British Oversight Unit Says Police Failed to Pursue Sex Accusations Against Savile
abstract: A report released Tuesday found a catalog of police failures that allowed Jimmy Savile, a television personality, to avoid investigation for a lifetime of sex offenses.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Police failures over five decades allowed Jimmy Savile, one of Britain’s best-known television personalities, to escape investigation for a lifetime of sex offenses dating back to the early 1960s, according to a report published on Tuesday by a police oversight agency.

headline: Opinion Report: Access to the Polls
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: To Indict, or Not to Indict
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s statement that prosecuting big banks could harm the financial system raises a lot of questions. | Mary Jo White, the nominee to head the S.E.C., goes before the Senate Banking Committee. | Michael S. Dell gave a rare interview about his effort to buy Dell Inc. | Federal regulators accused Illinois of misleading investors about the condition of its public pension system.
lead_paragraph: Some banks may have become too big to prosecute, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said last week in testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. That comment — an acknowledgment, for the first time, that Mr. Holder has not pursued big bank prosecutions out of fear of possibly harming the financial system — raises a variety of questions, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. “Does this mean that our banks are still too big to fail? Should we prosecute corporations? Should the size of an institution or its systemic importance influence the decision of prosecutors? What’s the right policy?”

headline: In a Word
abstract: This week’s grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and readers
lead_paragraph: The file is overflowing, so we’ll go straight to this week’s grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps from recent editions of The Times, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

headline: In Performance: Jenn Harris and Carson Elrod of ‘All in the Timing’
abstract: The actors perform a scene from David Ives’s collection of offbeat sketches.
lead_paragraph: “All in the Timing,” a collection of offbeat one-act plays, established David Ives as a playwright when it was first produced by Primary Stages 20 years ago. In this scene from the comedy “The Universal Language,” Dawn, a stuttering woman played by Jenn Harris, is eager to learn an Esperanto-like language called Unamunda from its creator, Don, played by Carson Elrod. The Primary Stages revival continues through April 14 at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Tweeting the Conclave
abstract: And so begins the conclave at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: And so begins the conclave at the Vatican.

headline: Baz Luhrmann’s ‘Great Gatsby’ Will Open Cannes Film Festival
abstract: Mr. Luhrmann’s adaptation of “The Great Gatsby” stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Jay Gatsby, Tobey Maguire as Nick Carraway and Carey Mulligan as Daisy Buchanan.
lead_paragraph: Who said there are no second acts in American lives? Oh, right: It was F. Scott Fitzgerald, whose seminal novel, “The Great Gatsby,” is getting a lavish reinterpretation from the director Baz Luhrmann that will open the Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced Tuesday.

headline: Tuesday Reading: What to Do With a Hand-Me-Down Mink Coat
abstract: What to do with a hand-me-down mink coat, chronic insomnia affects the heart, more on digital etiquette and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Rome Tourism Rooting for an American Pope
abstract: The papal conclave has provided a welcome off-season boost to visitor numbers in Rome. The tourism trade hopes the effect will last, with some favoring the election of a foreigner.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The tourism industry here is mulling the possible ramifications of the Vatican conclave and some are crossing their fingers for the election of an American pope.

headline: Engendering Law
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Transgender and Transsexual']
abstract: Could the treatment of transgenders become the brightest spot in Vietnam’s bleak record on human rights?
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY — In the video, a transgender Vietnamese in a stringy, low-cut top entertains a crowd by balancing three fiery batons in her hands and on her head. A while later, other transgenders talk about the daily challenges of being at odds with your sex of birth, ranging from which restroom to use to bickering with the police over the gender stipulated on your official I.D.

headline: Sleeping Beauty
abstract: A recent renovation has transformed the Cliveden House, a sprawling Italianate manse overlooking the Thames, into an aristo fantasy camp.
lead_paragraph: Cliveden House, a sprawling Italianate manse overlooking the Thames, was once the home of the Waldorf Astors, who entertained a varied lot, including their pro-fascist aristocratic friends — known as “the Cliveden Set” — before World War II. It was also the backdrop of the Profumo Affair, the political sex scandal that brought down Prime Minister Harold Macmillan’s government 50 years ago. A recent renovation has transformed the manor, located an hour outside of London, into an aristo fantasy camp, complete with 38 Edwardian rooms and a storybook riverside cottage that comes with its own butler, on request. Owned by the National Trust, the luxury hotel and spa overlooks 376 acres of forests and meadows. There’s a garden maze, a 19th-century parterre and a full range of anachronistic amusements — from snooker to archery to a lazy river cruise on an electric canoe that Lady Astor had built for herself in the 1920s.

headline: Matteo Garrone on Reality Television and Italian Culture
abstract: The director Matteo Garrone discusses “Reality,” his film about a fishmonger who becomes obsessed with reality television stardom.
lead_paragraph: In the Italian comedy-drama “Reality,” a Neapolitan fishmonger named Luciano (Aniello Arena) seeks fame by trying to land a spot on “Big Brother,” the reality TV show.  Along the way he loses his grip on his sense of self and his relationships with those around him. The film plays as a satire of Italian society, but also as a commentary on  how such instant fame can affect a culture.

headline: Strong Sales for ‘Lucky Guy’ With Tom Hanks
abstract: Several new Broadway shows are off to good starts at the box office, none more so than the Tom Hanks vehicle “Lucky Guy,” which last week became the rare play to take in more than $1 million for a week of performances.
lead_paragraph: Several new Broadway shows are off to good starts at the box office, none more so than the Tom Hanks vehicle “Lucky Guy,” which last week became the rare play to make more than $1 million for a week of performances.

headline: Is Skype a Telephone Operator? France Will Investigate
abstract: A French regulatory agency said Microsoft’s Skype unit had failed to register as a telecommunications operator as required by law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French regulators said Tuesday that they had asked prosecutors to investigate Microsoft’s Skype unit over its failure to register as a telecommunications operator in accordance with local law, raising the question of what constitutes a telephone company in the age of Internet-based communications.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Regulating Mexico’s Telecom Industry and Fox’s Push for College Sports
abstract: Mexican politicians introduced legislation to regulate telecom giants, Fox Sports 1 has accumulated the broadcast rights for many college conferences and Lisa Pulitzer has cornered the literary marketplace for memoirs of escaped cultists.

headline: An Energy Coup for Japan: ‘Flammable Ice’
keywords: ['Methane', 'Energy and Power', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Japan said it had extracted gas from undersea hydrate, a breakthrough that could provide a promising but still little-understood energy source.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan said Tuesday that it had extracted gas from offshore deposits of methane hydrate — sometimes called “flammable ice” — a breakthrough that officials and experts said could be a step toward tapping a promising but still little-understood energy source.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Two Gun Control Bills
abstract: The Judiciary Committee approved bills to expand background checks to private gun sales and to renew a grant program that focuses on school security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday passed two measures intended to curb gun violence, and the bills are now likely to go to the Senate floor for a full vote. But the committee postponed a vote on the most contentious measure — a proposal to reinstate an assault weapons ban — because its sponsor, Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, was not at the committee’s meeting.

headline: The Eurobeatings Will Continue
abstract: Nothing learned, nothing changed.
lead_paragraph: Until morale improves. So says José Manuel Barroso, in a letter to the European Council saying that what Europe needs is — surprise — more austerity.

headline: Live Blog: Hearing for S.E.C. Nominee
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Mary Jo White is poised to become a top Wall Street regulator. But as President Obama’s pick to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, she first had to clear a crucial hurdle: her Senate confirmation hearing.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s pick to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, testified this morning at her confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking Committee, whose members have lingering concerns about her ties to Wall Street and lack of regulatory experience.

headline: MetroPCS Urges Shareholders to Back Merger With T-Mobile
abstract: MetroPCS urged shareholders on Tuesday to approve its merger with T-Mobile USA, in the face of opposition from two major hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: The cellphone service provider MetroPCS urged shareholders on Tuesday to approve its merger with T-Mobile USA, in the face of strong opposition from two major hedge funds.

abstract: More about Hungary.

headline: 2 Parties’ Budgets Show Big Rift as G.O.P. Renews 2012 Proposals
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s plan to cut spending was unveiled on Tuesday as Democrats circulated the outlines of their budget, repudiating many aspects of the Republican effort.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats and House Republicans on Tuesday outlined vastly divergent approaches to shoring up the government’s finances, a reminder of how far apart they remain on fiscal policy even as both sides insist publicly that a bipartisan compromise is possible.

headline: The Latest Republican Budget Plan
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan unveiled the House Republicans’ budget for 2014, which includes many of the same proposals as previous budgets and promises to erase deficits and balance the budget in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan unveiled the House Republicans’ budget for 2014, which includes many of the same proposals as previous budgets and promises to erase deficits and balance the budget in 10 years.

abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Epicurious: Stocking up on matzo? You’ll need this later: recipes for using it up after Passover. — Julia Moskin

headline: The More He Talks About Immigration…
abstract: Jeb Bush is trying to have it both ways on the “path to citizenship.”
lead_paragraph: … the less we know, and the less I care. I’m talking about Jeb Bush, who’s been trying desperately to explain what he really thinks should happen to the millions of people currently living in the United States illegally.

headline: ‘Dating’ Other Mothers
abstract: My two closest mom friends are moving out of state. I have to start dating again.
lead_paragraph: “I have to start dating again!” I wailed to my husband. It’s probably closer to the truth to say that my 3-year-old and I were going to have to start dating again.

headline: Putting Something Aside for a Future Beyond the Kitchen
abstract: A play from 1921, “The Detour” brings some feminist notes to the tiny Metropolitan Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: Things seem so peaceful as “The Detour” begins. In the quaint kitchen of a Long Island farmhouse in the 1920s, when there were actual farms surrounding these dwellings, a mother and daughter count the money they are saving (and hiding in a vase) for the young woman’s education as an artist. But by Act II, businesses and marriages are falling apart, and suspense is high. And all because of some roadwork, land greed and the revelation of a family secret.

headline: Showbiz Chimp on the Edge of Despair
abstract: Nick Jones’s play “Trevor” was inspired by the story of a Connecticut woman assaulted by a pet chimpanzee.
lead_paragraph: When animals attack, we’re horrified, scared and also, let’s face it, fascinated. “Trevor,” Nick Jones’s witty, sly play inspired by the story of a Connecticut woman assaulted by a pet chimpanzee, invites us to feel something else: empathy for the violent animal.

headline: German Central Bank Doubles Reserves
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The move is an expression of uneasiness with measures by the European Central Bank to combat the euro crisis.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In a profound signal of uneasiness about the health of the euro zone, the German central bank said Tuesday that it had nearly doubled the reserves it held to cover possible losses.

headline: Security Leader Says U.S. Would Retaliate Against Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Testimony by Gen. Keith Alexander was the first time the Obama administration publicly admitted to developing the capacity for offensive cyberattacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief of the military’s newly created Cyber Command told Congress on Tuesday that he is establishing 13 teams of programmers and computer experts who could carry out offensive cyberattacks on foreign nations if the United States were hit with a major attack on its own networks, the first time the Obama administration has publicly admitted to developing such weapons for use in wartime.

headline: Prosecutors Face Test Proving Serious Crime in a Fatal Crash
abstract: Proving the crime of leaving the scene of an accident is often easy; proving “moral blameworthiness” to support a more-serious crime is harder.
lead_paragraph: The crash left a young couple and their baby dead. The driver of the speeding BMW who struck them was charged with criminally negligent homicide. But making those charges stick will be a nettlesome challenge for prosecutors.

headline: 5 U.S. Soldiers Are Killed in Air Crash in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Helicopters']
abstract: The crash brought the American death toll on Monday to seven, making it the deadliest day this year for United States forces.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Five American soldiers were killed in a helicopter crash in southern Afghanistan on Monday, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Win a Super Bowl, Hit the Road
abstract: Anquan Boldin, who helped the Ravens beat the 49ers in the Super Bowl, was traded to San Francisco, which is in an arms race with Seattle.
lead_paragraph: As the N.F.L. kicks off its annual personnel swap meet, better known as the free-agency signing period, it has gotten an early jump on baring its business side to the masses. That happened in a flurry of pre-free-agency moves, most notably the one in which the Super Bowl champion shipped one of its key players (receiver Anquan Boldin) to another team (its Super Bowl opponent, no less: the San Francisco 49ers) for the football equivalent of a case of shoe polish (a sixth-round draft pick). All this was done before Ravens fans could say, “Wha. ...?”

headline: The Gun Report: March 12, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since Newtown, I had been repeatedly told that anti-gun rallies were being cancelled because of threatened gun violence, and that individual gun control advocates, especially state legislators, were being intimidated and harassed. No place is this more evident than in Oregon, where Ginny Burdick, a long-time supporter of sensible gun regulation, has been the victim of a series of small but menacing dirty tricks. The latest one is the subject of my column today. Here is today’s sampling of gun violence.

headline: Scripture and Cheesecake
abstract: Monks are known to make beer to support their order. The nuns of New Skete, in upstate New York, bake cheesecake.
lead_paragraph: Monks are known to make beer to support their order. The nuns of New Skete, in upstate New York, bake cheesecake.

headline: In Schools, a Water-Saving Program Begins With a Flush
abstract: Within five years, the city will replace 40,000 toilets at public schools with new low-flow versions that should save four million gallons of water each day.
lead_paragraph: The toilets in the boys’ room on the third floor of Bayside High School in Queens flush with a quick but powerful surge and then water gurgles back up into the bowl.

abstract: Dell has agreed to open its books to the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn, signaling a possible truce on one front in the battle over the computer maker’s proposed $24.4 billion buyout.
lead_paragraph: Dell has agreed to open its books to the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn, signaling a possible truce on one front in the battle over the computer maker’s proposed $24.4 billion buyout, Michael J. de la Merced reports in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: Costa Rica Picks Miller
abstract: Defender Roy Miller of the Red Bulls is among the players named to the Costa Rica team that will play the U.S. in a World Cup qualifier in Commerce City, Colo., on March 22.
lead_paragraph: An unmitigated disaster for Roy Miller and the Red Bulls did not dissuade Costa Rica from naming the defender to its roster for next week’s World Cup qualifying match.

headline: Prepaid Cards May Lack Protections of Checking Accounts
abstract: Reloadable cards are becoming more widely used but they don’t have to carry federal deposit insurance.
lead_paragraph: Although they are becoming more popular as an alternative to traditional checking accounts, reloadable prepaid cards don’t have to carry federal deposit insurance, as checking accounts do, says a new report from a project of the Pew Charitable Trusts.

headline: ‘Ugly Thoughts’ Defense Fails as Officer Is Convicted in Cannibal Plot
abstract: Gilberto Valle, 28, could receive life in prison for one count of kidnapping conspiracy when he is sentenced on June 19; he was fired from the Police Department upon conviction.
lead_paragraph: A New York police officer was convicted on Tuesday in a bizarre plot to kidnap, torture, kill and eat women, ending a trial whose outcome hinged on a delicate distinction between fantasy and reality.

headline: Skullcandy Crushers Vibrate to Boost Bass
abstract: The Skullcandy Crushers vibrate, using a phenomenon known as bone conduction to increase the perception of bass.
lead_paragraph: How many headphones count a threat to “make your eyeballs bleed” as a virtue? At least one, the Skullcandy Crusher, which uses an unusual speaker technology to generate vibrations that are perceived as powerful bass notes.

headline: Fighting to Follow Chávez
abstract: Simon Romero, a correspondent for The New York Times, looks at the challenges Venezuela’s interim president, Nicolás Maduro, faces in his bid to win the special election to replace Hugo Chávez.
lead_paragraph: Simon Romero, a correspondent for The New York Times, looks at the challenges Venezuela’s interim president, Nicolás Maduro, faces in his bid to win the special election to replace Hugo Chávez.

headline: Introducing a New Article Experience
abstract: The New York Times is redesigning its Web site — starting with the article experience. See what’s different.
lead_paragraph: In the past several months, a cross-functional team of journalists, designers and technologists — as well as project and product managers and sales staff — has taken on the ambitious task of redesigning NYTimes.com. The first phase of the redesign reflects the focus of our readers: articles.

headline: The Other Berlin
abstract: With new hotels and restorations of landmarks on the horizon, West Berlin is experiencing a revival.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, as East Berlin has risen to become Europe’s most fertile breeding ground of cool, West Berlin has languished. By the mid-2000s, once-bustling squares and boulevards were shadows of their glamorous former selves. But the winds of change have shifted. Construction cranes now swing over Breitscheidplatz, and the streets buzz with shoppers and diners. “The city is reorienting itself to the west,” says Stefanie Hering, who will open a flagship store for her porcelain design company, Hering Berlin, in the new Waldorf-Astoria hotel building this spring. The Waldorf, occupying a new high-rise steps from the Zoo station, is only the beginning. Recently opened on the main boulevard Kurfürstendamm, Haus Cumberland is a restored hotel from the early 1900s that houses several welcome arrivals, among them Grosz — a coffeehouse and restaurant evoking 1920s Berlin.

headline: Queen Latifah and Richard Stoltzman to Perform at New York City Ballet Gala
abstract: Queen Latifah will perform George Gershwin’s “The Man I Love” and Mr. Stoltzman is set to perform the “Interlude” from André Previn’s “Sonata for Clarinet and Piano” and Leonard Bernstein’s “Sonata for Clarinet and Piano.”
lead_paragraph: Queen Latifah and Richard Stoltzman, the clarinetist, will be the guest artists at New York City Ballet’s 2013 spring gala, to be held May 8 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

headline: Testing the Limits of ‘We’ll Take Anything in Trade’
abstract: New GSN reality show “Family Trade” takes viewers inside Gardner Stone’s car dealership in Middlebury, Vt.
lead_paragraph: Gardner Stone employs an unorthodox business strategy at his GMC and Ford dealership in Middlebury, Vt. Mr. Stone, a gregarious fellow who likes to follow his sometimes unconventional instincts, brags that he will take anything in trade — not just any type of car or truck, but anything, period. To quote the Web site for G. Stone Motors, “When we say anything, we mean anything!”

headline: Baking and Praying
abstract: For the Nuns of New Skete, monastic gourmet still pays the bills.
lead_paragraph: For the Nuns of New Skete, monastic gourmet still pays the bills.

headline: London Theater Journal: That Born-in-a-Trunk Tribe
abstract: “Trelawny of the Wells” is a portrait of the Victorian era in theater; Betty Buckley brings her distinctive gifts to “Dear World,” a revival of a notorious ’60s flop.
lead_paragraph: The topic was work and its instability – chasing jobs, landing jobs, losing jobs. It’s a common enough subject, especially these days. But the patois of the people sitting behind me at the Charing Cross Theater the other afternoon instantly identified them as members of an ancient and eternal tribe.

headline: College Interview Survivor Awaits Scholarship Decisions
abstract: “In my opinion,” writes Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., “the individual interview was scarier than the group interview.”
lead_paragraph: I spent many nights in February staying up late, applying for more scholarships. It’s exhausting, but it’s better than staying up all night worrying about how I’m going to pay for college.

headline: An Outsize Intellect, Tilting at Obstacles
abstract: Megan Marshall’s “Margaret Fuller,” a biography of the 19th-century scholar, editor and feminist, has the texture of a serious novel.
lead_paragraph: When Margaret Fuller died in a shipwreck off Fire Island in 1850, her friend Ralph Waldo Emerson was devastated. He sent a mutual friend, Henry David Thoreau, to the scene of the disaster.
