headline: Francisco Hopes to Find a Home with the Yankees
abstract: Ben Francisco played for three different teams in two leagues last season. Now he has an opportunity with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA – After a disorienting season playing for three different teams in two leagues last year, Ben Francisco was hoping for more stability this year. Perhaps he might even get to stay with one team.

headline: All About the Billikens
abstract: The St. Louis men’s basketball team won its first outright regular-season conference title since the 1956-57 season.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis men’s basketball team won its first outright regular-season conference title since the 1956-57 season.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Top 10 Third Basemen
abstract: There are not many third basemen who can do it all, but the position is deep in four-category production. Justin Sablich picks his Top 10.
lead_paragraph: There are not many third basemen who can do it all, but the position is deep in four-category production. Justin Sablich picks his Top 10.

headline: If You Like the Chieftains, Try Lindsey Stirling
abstract: If you like the Chieftains, who helped popularize  Irish music, then try Lindsey Stirling, a rock violinist who mixes classical, hip-hop and dubstep.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
abstract: Chandler Buckingham, a senior at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is awaiting scholarship news from John Brown University, one of her top college choices.
lead_paragraph: Chandler Buckingham, a senior at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is awaiting scholarship news from John Brown University, one of her top college choices.

headline: Charlie Pierce Gives a Journalism Lesson to Ezra Klein
abstract: In praise of a delicious take-down.
lead_paragraph: If I tweeted—which I don’t, and never, ever will—I would have sent out a tweet in praise of this delicious take-down of Ezra Klein by Charlie Pierce at Esquire. It takes all of 10 minutes to read, and it is so full of wisdom and common sense about reporting, then and now, that I hope it gets a wide readership.

headline: Germany’s Plague of Plagiarism
abstract: Since the former defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, was found to have plagiarized parts of his dissertation, German politics have been rocked by a series of plagiarism allegations. Why have so many taken that risk to bear the title “Doktor”?
lead_paragraph: Helmut Schmidt, who as Germany’s chancellor from 1974 to 1982 enjoyed his share of societal recognition and admiration, held that there are only two titles that a person should carry with a modicum of pride.

headline: Hurricane Gustav’s Path
abstract: Gustav unleashed powerful winds and heavy rains on Monday, after hundreds of thousands of people had evacuated their homes.
lead_paragraph: Gustav unleashed powerful winds and heavy rains on Monday, after hundreds of thousands of people had evacuated their homes.

headline: Billikens’ Title Is Tribute to What Majerus Taught Them
abstract: St. Louis (24-6) won the Atlantic 10 regular-season title while dealing with the death of its former coach Rick Majerus.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The chant came from the student section as Chaifetz Arena shook, as fans with blue paint streaks in their hair and “All About the Billikens” T-shirts on their backs stood and roared. The final seconds of a season unlike any other ticked away, history in reach.

headline: In Ike’s Wake
abstract: Video and photo reports from around the region that was hit by Hurricane Ike.
lead_paragraph: Video and photo reports from around the region that was hit by Hurricane Ike.

headline: The Ryan Budget’s Step Backward
abstract: The latest Ryan roadmap offers too much implausibility, not enough creativity.
lead_paragraph: The first long term budget proposed by Paul Ryan, shortly after the Republicans retook the House of Representatives, was a major step forward for conservative policy thinking: It cashed in the Tea Party wave with a serious commitment to entitlement reform, and put every House Republican on record supporting the kind of Medicare changes that will be necessary if small-government conservatism takes its own premises seriously, and doesn’t just want to be the partisan arm of the AARP.

headline: Even in Afghanistan, a Focus on Budget Battles of Washington
abstract: At a recent town-hall-style meeting in Afghanistan with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, soldiers mostly wanted to hear about the budget battle back in Washington, and how spending cuts for the Pentagon would affect them.
lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE FENTY, Afghanistan – The new defense secretary, Chuck Hagel, arrived at this rugged security outpost situated along a ratline of insurgent infiltration from Pakistan to talk to American troops about the war.

headline: Made to Measure
abstract: A look at the stage roles of Ian McKellen.
lead_paragraph: A look at the stage roles of Ian McKellen.

headline: Investigator From U.N. Gives Iran Harsh Review
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: With presidential elections approaching in June, the country has cracked down on journalists, rights activists and lawyers in a bid to stifle dissent, the investigator said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — With presidential elections approaching in June, Iran has cracked down on journalists, rights activists and lawyers apparently in a bid to stifle dissent, a United Nations investigator said on Tuesday. He also said that the judicial authorities in Iran had tortured some Iranians for contacting him.

headline: A Red Carpet Stop for Willie Nelson, Then on the Road Again
keywords: ['Country Music', 'Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Willie Nelson discusses his music and his role in the South by Southwest film “When Angels Sing.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The country music legend and occasional film actor Willie Nelson took time out from touring Sunday for a visit to the South by Southwest film festival and the premiere of “When Angels Sing,” an Austin-made holiday film directed by Tim McCanlies. Harry Connick Jr. stars as Michael Walker, a family man who is Christmas-averse. He meets Nick (Mr. Nelson), who sells him his mansion for a steal, but Michael only later discovers that the house is on one of the most Christmas-obsessed blocks in town. The movie, which also features performances by Lyle Lovett, the Trishas, Dale Watson and others, plays as kind of a country-western version of “A Christmas Carol.”

headline: The Last Video Rental Start-Up?
abstract: In this age of streaming videos and movie downloads, can an energetic entrepreneur breathe life into what most people assume is a dying business?
lead_paragraph: As noted in Monday’s Dashboard summary of the week’s small-business news, Miguel Gomez introduced a very unlikely start-up late last year in Ardmore, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. Ready? It’s a retail shop called Viva Video! The Last Picture Store. That’s right, it’s a video rental store. In this age of streaming videos and movie downloads, can an energetic entrepreneur breathe life into what most people assume is a dying business?

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Third Base Preview
abstract: You’re not going to find many third basemen who can do it all, but the position is deep in four-category production.
lead_paragraph: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Judge Said to Be Frustrated Over Lack of Settlement in ‘Spider-Man’ Battle
abstract: The parties have been saying they are close to a deal, but the legal wrangling continues.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge had tough words on Monday for the parties struggling to reach a settlement over copyright control and profits for the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” as the legal wrangling entered a seventh month and a trial date of May 27 loomed.

headline: Not Guilty Plea Is Entered in Colorado Mass Shooting
abstract: The judge in the case of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a mass shooting in Colorado, denied requests by defense lawyers for more time.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — A judge here entered a not guilty plea on Tuesday for James E. Holmes, a former neuroscience student charged with killing 12 people and wounding scores more in a mass shooting in a suburban Denver movie theater.

headline: Historical Society Exhibition to Explore the Early Days of AIDS
abstract: The early years of the AIDS epidemic will be the subject of an exhibition that will open this summer at the New York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: The New York Historical Society will revisit the early years of the AIDS epidemic in a new exhibition scheduled to open this summer.

headline: Tesla Model X Production Won’t Start Until Late 2014
abstract: When Tesla first revealed the electric crossover in February 2012, the company said production would begin at the end of 2013, with deliveries in 2014
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors has confirmed that production of its all-wheel-drive Model X electric crossover will begin in late 2014, a year later than the company had originally announced. The revised timing was described in the company’s Form 10-K filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last Thursday.

headline: New Book Tackles China and its Environmental Exports
abstract: Craig Simons, the former Asia correspondent for Cox Newspapers, discusses his new book, “The Devouring Dragon: How China’s Rise Threatens Our Natural World.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The rapid degradation of the environment in China has become a central topic of discussion this year. Air pollution in Beijing and other parts of northern China hit record levels in January. Water pollution was thrust into the spotlight this week when official news reports said that nearly 6,000 dead pigs had been found floating in a river that slices through the heart of Shanghai. Meanwhile, environmental advocates are pressing the government to release data on soil pollution, which officials have categorized as a state secret.

headline: Can Wind, Water and Sunlight Power New York by 2050?
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Hydroelectric Power', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind']
abstract: A group of researchers proposes a way to power New York State entirely with wind, water and sunlight by 2050.
lead_paragraph: March 13, 12:43 p.m. | Relevant tweets appended |A group of scientists and energy analysts has laid out a path under which New York State could, in theory, eliminate its use of fossil fuels and nuclear power — including for transportation — by 2050. The graph above charts the contributions played by improved efficiency and adoption of renewable electricity sources as well as hydrogen fuel cells (with the hydrogen generated with renewable energy).

headline: The Forgotten Malala
abstract: Guest blogger Seema Jilani writes about a Pakistani girl who, after being shot alongside Malala Yousafzai last year, is struggling under threats from the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the most ruthless attacks of our time: three Pakistani schoolgirls were on their way home when the Taliban shot them. Their crime? Pursuit of an education. Malala Yousafzai was shot in the head and two other young women sustained injuries to their arms. “We are all Malala,” roared the world.  Protestors marched and lit candlelight vigils. Malala was nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize and became an iconic symbol for young women’s educational struggles.

headline: Image of the Day: March 12
abstract: Tibetan exiles in Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh, commemorate Tibetan Women’s Uprising Day.

headline: Two Years After Trade, Nuggets Have No Regrets
abstract: Carmelo Anthony will return to Denver on Wednesday night for the first time since his February 2011 trade, which significantly altered the Nuggets and the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Ty Lawson did not take the bait to talk his way into a trap. He is the Denver Nuggets’ quick-thinking point guard — not far removed from the conversation that includes the N.B.A.’s best — who can turn the direction of the delicate Carmelo question as deftly as he crosses over on the dribble.

headline: Faithful and Patient
abstract: The Times’s Rachel Donadio talks to Catholics waiting in St. Peter’s Square for news about a new pope.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Rachel Donadio talks to Catholics waiting in St. Peter’s Square for news about a new pope.

headline: Spicy Whiskey From a Usual Source
abstract: Aged a minimum of 12 years, Powers John’s Lane Irish whiskey is full-bodied, earthy and spicy, and a worthwhile investment.
lead_paragraph: Powers John’s Lane Irish whiskey, which arrived in the United States this month, is named after the John’s Lane Distillery, established in Dublin in 1791. The new quaff is very much an attempt to evoke the origins of Powers Whiskey as a single-pot-still whiskey. (Powers Gold Label, the distillery’s benchmark whiskey — and, until recently, the best-selling whiskey in Ireland — is today a blend.)

headline: Looking Past the Alter Egos to the Novelist
abstract: It’s fitting that Mr. Roth dominates the screen in the new documentary “Philip Roth: Unmasked,” given that his great subject has always been himself.
lead_paragraph: Philip Roth, having recently announced his retirement from writing — news that not everyone takes entirely at face value — turns 80 next week. Celebration, and maybe valediction, are certainly the order of the day. Visitors to Newark can take a bus tour past his old high school and pause at the intersection of Summit and Keer Avenues, now designated Philip Roth Plaza, an honor that will have to suffice until the Swedish Academy gets its act together.

headline: Are Conference Tournaments the Best Way to Award N.C.A.A. Bids?
abstract: Conference tournaments are fun and exciting, but do they select the best N.C.A.A. tournament contestants?
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. tournament hasn’t started, but the upsets have. The Liberty Flames, who were 11-20 in the regular season, won four games in six days to take the Big South tournament and earned the conference’s automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Voters in Falklands Back British Rule Nearly Unanimously
abstract: All but three voters in the Falkland Islands cast ballots in favor of maintaining British rule, but Argentina, which claims the islands, dismissed the referendum as a meaningless stunt.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the news reached London on Tuesday that 99.7 percent of Falkland islanders who had participated in a referendum had voted “yes” on retaining their ties with Britain, Prime Minister David Cameron was delighted. The result, he said, proved that the islands were “British through and through.”

headline: One Possible Hitch to an Autonomy Investigation
abstract: The Serious Fraud Office of Britain cautioned that it first needed to make sure that its use of an Autonomy product did not pose a conflict of interest for an investigation into its sale to Hewlett-Packard.
lead_paragraph: Presumably, the antitrust investigators who looked at Microsoft back in the day had Windows software on their own computers. One could imagine that the prosecutors who brought accounting fraud cases against WorldCom executives might have used its MCI long-distance service. And any number of regulators around the world are likely to have used Google for personal and professional reasons.

headline: Living in Oyster Bay Cove
abstract: President Theodore Roosevelt and his family are prominent in the area’s history. He is buried in the Long Island village.
lead_paragraph: President Theodore Roosevelt and his family are prominent in the area’s history. He is buried in the Long Island village.

headline: More Country, Less Congestion
abstract: A village retains a country feel, with large expanses of greenery interrupted by homes ranging from historic colonials to modern mansions.
lead_paragraph: Roseanne O’Farrell can watch hawks through her windows. “A red-tailed hawk just flew into a tree in my backyard,” she said. “He’s very still, and then he will swoop down. We have a pair that nest in the hollow behind us. It’s so great.”

headline: A Bumpy Road to a Soda Ban
abstract: Many public health experts support efforts to ban the sale of large sugary drinks but note that, as with efforts to curb tobacco or require seat belt use, the process will take some time.
lead_paragraph: Some of the country’s leading public health experts called Monday’s judicial ruling against New York’s limits on the sale of large sugary drinks a predictable setback in what has become a national campaign against obesity, the country’s newest health epidemic.

headline: Necessary Baggage
abstract: How to turn the touristy fanny pack into a cool travel accessory.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to the Japanese to turn the touristy fanny pack into a cool travel accessory by slinging it over the shoulder. This version by Coach, already huge in Tokyo, is now on sale stateside. $328; coach.com.

headline: Greenberg Forges Ahead With Lawsuit Over A.I.G. Bailout
keywords: ['Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The American International Group’s former chief executive is moving ahead with a lawsuit against the federal government over its $182 billion rescue of the insurer — even without the backing of the company itself.
