headline: Catholics Speak: Modernization
abstract: As Catholics await a new pope, some ask for more transparency, while others hope for a strong, traditional leader.
lead_paragraph: As Catholics await a new pope, some ask for more transparency, while others hope for a strong, traditional leader.

headline: Red Bulls’ Petke Takes High Road on Roy Miller
abstract: Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke said during a conference call on Tuesday that Roy Miller is not solely to blame for the team’s loss Sunday night at San Jose.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls’ Mike Petke, who is still seeking his first victory as a coach in Major League Soccer, did not criticize defender Roy Miller during a conference call Tuesday morning, but he likewise did not issue a soaring endorsement:

headline: Google Concedes That Drive-By Prying Violated Privacy
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wearable Computing', 'States (US)']
abstract: In agreeing to settle a case brought by 38 states over the Street View mapping project, the company for the first time is required to aggressively police its own workers on privacy issues.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google on Tuesday acknowledged to state officials that it had violated people’s privacy during its Street View mapping project when it casually scooped up passwords, e-mail and other personal information from unsuspecting computer users.

headline: Tennis’s Top 5: How Well Do They Know Each Other?
abstract: The Top 5 men’s tennis players answer trivia questions about each other.
lead_paragraph: The folks at the BNP Paribas Open decided to brighten up their spot on the tennis calendar by getting the Top 5 men’s players to participate in a trivia contest about each other.

headline: Intrade Sheds Light on How Gray Markets Can Go Dark
abstract: While Intrade’s predictive record was good, it didn’t foresee the rising controversy over under-regulated speculation.
lead_paragraph: Intrade sheds light on how quickly gray markets can go dark. The site, which took bets on everything, including elections, oil prices and even its own demise, was abruptly shuttered on Sunday. While Intrade’s predictive record was good, it didn’t foresee the rising controversy over under-regulated speculation. It’s a cautionary tale for others operating in a somewhat shadowed zone.

headline: The People Versus the Party
abstract: Republicans are out of sync with public opinion.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans have hit a sour spot in politics — they are 180 degrees opposed to what most Americans want on just about any issue you care to name.

headline: Colorado Legalizes Civil Unions for Same-Sex Couples
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The move came after several years of bitter debate, signaling the latest shift in a state that was once seen as hostile toward gays and lesbians.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Colorado lawmakers passed legislation on Tuesday to legalize civil unions for same-sex couples, following several years of bitter debate over the issue.

headline: War and Healing Depicted in Silicon Valley Art Gallery
abstract: The “War and Healing” exhibit at the Euphrat Museum of Art in Cupertino, Calif., aims to reach the uninitiated, to explain and educate.
lead_paragraph: The bombs that hang from the ceiling in the small art gallery in suburban Silicon Valley are filled with bizarre visions of aquatic pre-dinosaur invertebrates from another age.

headline: Woodland Performance
abstract: A look at a performance of "Invisible Wings" at the Jacob's Pillow festival in Becket, Mass.
lead_paragraph: A look at a performance of "Invisible Wings" at the Jacob's Pillow festival in Becket, Mass.

headline: Mars Could Have Supported Life Long Ago, NASA Says
abstract: Findings from NASA’s Mars rover show that the planet may have once been warm and wet and a pleasant place where microbes could have thrived.
lead_paragraph: Several billion years ago, Mars may well have been a pleasant place for tiny microbes to live, with plenty of water as well as minerals that could have served as food, NASA scientists said Tuesday at a news conference on the latest findings from their Mars rover. But they have yet to find signs that actual microbes did live in that oasis.

headline: Reining In a Restless Lion
abstract: Elijah Moshinsky’s production of “Otello” returns to the Met with a new cast, including an impulsive José Cura in the lead role.
lead_paragraph: Elijah Moshinsky’s striking 1994 production of Verdi’s “Otello” played at the Met last October with the tenor Johan Botha in the title role and Renée Fleming as Desdemona. Illness gave Mr. Botha a shaky opening night and forced him to miss most of the run, although he rallied for the final performance, a live HD broadcast.

headline: Excerpt: 'Hit the Wall'
abstract: A scene from the show about the Stonewall rebellion, at the Barrow Street Theater.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the show about the Stonewall rebellion, at the Barrow Street Theater.

headline: Sourdough Rye Revisited: Don’t Forget the Water
abstract: More details on how to make sourdough.
lead_paragraph: My column on whole-grain bread drew a number of e-mails from readers who were justifiably confused about the Sourdough Rye recipe. Unfortunately, a significant quantity of water was left out of the recipe which resulted in a dough that would never come together; so some who tried the recipe wound up with a dry, crumbly mess. If you want to try the recipe again (or for the first time), the correct version of the recipe is online.

headline: Live Video: A Pope Is Elected
abstract: Video from Saint Peter’s Square as a new pope is elected.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:02 p.m.White smoke poured from the chimney of the Sistine Chapel on Wednesday indicating there is a new pope. The Lede is following the latest developments in the election of a new pope here.

headline: Lawmakers Release Carbon Emissions Tax Plan
abstract: The proposal imposes a fee on greenhouse gas emissions from power plants, factories, refineries and other major sources.
lead_paragraph: Almost exactly four years after unveiling his doomed cap-and-trade proposal to deal with global warming, Representative Henry Waxman, Democrat of California, released a new plan on Tuesday to address climate change and federal budget woes: a tax on carbon emissions.

headline: Bloomberg Again Blasts Court Ruling on Large Sugary Drinks
abstract: A day after a judge derailed his planned restrictions, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forcefully defended them in an appearance at a restaurant whose owner said he was adopting the limits on his own.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:41 p.m. | A day after a judge struck down his administration’s impending limits on large sugary drinks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared at a Manhattan cafe on Tuesday that was nevertheless adopting the limits, and he delivered a forceful defense of his policy and a rebuke of the judge’s decision.

headline: Telemarketer That Aimed at  the Elderly Is Shut Down
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Elderly', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Telemarketing', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: The firm tried to trick elderly people into paying for medical alert services they didn’t order.
lead_paragraph: The federal government recently acted to halt a telemarketing ploy that tried to trick frail elderly people across the country into paying for medical alert services they didn’t order.

headline: Notre Dame to Join A.C.C. This Fall
abstract: The Fighting Irish reached an agreement with the Big East to defect to the Atlantic Coast Conference in all sports except football and hockey.
lead_paragraph: Notre Dame announced Tuesday morning that it had reached an agreement with the Big East to quicken its defection to the Atlantic Coast Conference in all sports except football and hockey beginning this fall.

headline: Change Agent: Examining How and Why the Pope Can Make a Global Difference
abstract: In this lesson we’ll help students raise questions and seek answers on the role of the church and the pope around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 19

headline: Music Man
abstract: Photos of shows written by the composer Jason Robert Brown.
lead_paragraph: Photos of shows written by the composer Jason Robert Brown.

headline: Flimflam Forever
abstract: Paul Ryan, same as he ever was.
lead_paragraph: I took Paul Ryan’s measure two and a half years ago. All the Very Serious People were very angry with me — Ryan was the Serious, Honest Conservative, the guy centrists demonstrated their centrism by praising. But he was an obvious phony. His “plan” was all smoke (I couldn’t even find any mirrors), with all the alleged deficit reduction coming from closing tax loopholes he refused to specify plus projected reductions in discretionary spending that he also refused to specify. Meanwhile, he was pursuing radical redistribution away from the needy to the wealthy.

headline: Illustrating an Online Romance Gone Wrong
abstract: Looking behind the scenes at Wesley Allsbrook’s illustrations for our article on a physicist who was duped by a “model” he met online.
lead_paragraph: In the magazine’s most recent issue, Maxine Swann recounts how an online romance led to incarceration in an Argentine jail for the physicist Paul Frampton. But because her article, “The Professor, the Bikini Model and the Suitcase Full of Trouble,” includes crucial elements that could not be photographed — from Frampton’s life at the University of North Carolina to his online encounters with someone he believed to be the model Denise Milani to his trip to South America to meet her to his eventual arrest on drug charges — we commissioned Wesley Allsbrook to supply the article’s graphic elements. Allsbrook is a Brooklyn-based illustrator whose work accompanied another hard-to-photograph article in the magazine, Jeffrey Gettleman’s 2011 article about pirate kidnappings off the coast of Somalia.

headline: Extending His Sway, Putin Names Loyalist to Head Russian Central Bank
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin’s nomination of Elvira Nabiullina signaled that the bank’s independence may now be subject to more direct Kremlin control.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Asserting further personal control over the Russian economy, President Vladimir V. Putin nominated on Tuesday a close political ally, who is now serving as his chief economic adviser, to become the new chief of the Russian central bank.

headline: Balut
abstract: If you order the balut at Jeepney, be prepared for quite the fanfare when the hard-boiled duck egg is brought to the table.
lead_paragraph: If you order the balut at Jeepney, be prepared for quite the fanfare when the hard-boiled duck egg is brought to the table.

headline: France Proposes New Rules for Internet Equal Access
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Net Neutrality']
abstract: The government called for a law requiring Internet service providers to give all traffic on their networks equal priority, saying existing rules were insufficient.
lead_paragraph: SERRAVAL, France — The French government on Tuesday called for a law requiring Internet service providers to give all the traffic on their networks equal priority, saying existing rules were insufficient for protecting free speech online and ensuring fair competition among Web publishers.

headline: Detroit Asks for More Time to Avoid Takeover
abstract: City leaders asked for more time to put in place changes needed to avoid being replaced by an emergency financial manager as their city inched closer toward bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Under threat of being replaced by an emergency financial manager appointed by Michigan’s governor, Detroit officials made an 11th-hour plea for patience Tuesday, asking for more time to put in place the changes needed to avoid a state takeover as their beleaguered city inched closer toward bankruptcy.

headline: A Tribute to a Troubled Bus Operator
abstract: Channeling Bob Dylan, an assistant cartoon editor at The New Yorker says farewell to the Fung Wah bus service.
lead_paragraph: The engines of the Fung Wah bus have fallen silent, but into the sonic vacuum rushes Marc Philippe Eskenazi, an assistant cartoon editor at The New Yorker, with this touching musical tribute, which his employer posted today. Extra points for fitting “like the clown on the peel of a banana” into half a line.

headline: Jeremy Tyler’s New World
abstract: The transition from high school basketball to a professional league in Israel has not been easy for Jeremy Tyler, an 18-year-old American.
lead_paragraph: The transition from high school basketball to a professional league in Israel has not been easy for Jeremy Tyler, an 18-year-old American.

headline: On Tiptoe to Reach Elevator Buttons
abstract: The JW Marriott Marquis Dubai’s 1,164 feet make it the world’s tallest dedicated hotel.
lead_paragraph: Hotels like to throw around superlatives. And when they do, it is often in categories — customer service, hypoallergenic bedding, size of indoor gym — that matter to guests. But lately, a few hotels have fixated on a factor that isn’t usually mentioned in TripAdvisor reviews: height.

headline: For Boy Scouts’ Parents, a Chance to Weigh In on Ban on Gays
abstract: When the Scouts survey current members regarding their policies on gays and lesbians, will they get a useful result, or an “amen” from the choir?
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts, who are considering lifting the ban on openly gay scout leaders and scouts, have taken the next step toward making a decision: they are surveying volunteers and member parents on how they feel about the ban. Surveys arrived in e-mail in-boxes over the weekend (and can be viewed in full on the Dallas Voice Web site).

headline: Jeepney, and Pig and Khao
abstract: Inside two Asian restaurants that have many things in common.
lead_paragraph: Inside two Asian restaurants that have many things in common.

headline: Butler Prepares for Its First Atlantic 10 Tournament
abstract: The view from Butler: After defeating Xavier to end the regular season, 24-7 Butler is seeded fifth in the Atlantic 10 tournament.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The Butler men’s basketball team concluded a 24-7 regular season with a 67-62 victory over Xavier on Saturday night at Hinkle Fieldhouse. The game was the last home game for the Butler seniors Andrew Smith, Rotnei Clarke, Chase Stigall and Emerson Kampen.

headline: G.O.P. to Put Digital Strategy at Center of New Structure
abstract: As the Republican National Committee rolls out course corrections from 2012, it announced plans to hire a chief technology officer who will “change the way we think.”
lead_paragraph: As part of a rebuilding effort after its 2012 electoral losses, the Republican National Committee on Tuesday announced plans to put an enhanced digital strategy at the center of its operation, led by a new chief technology officer.

headline: Winter TV Schedule Brings Shift in Ratings Race
abstract: Cable shows continue to dominate over most network offerings on Sunday nights, and Fox overtakes a flagging NBC for the season.
lead_paragraph: 7:07 p.m. | Updated The television season continues to generate big shifts in the ratings, with cable shows still dominating over most network offerings on Sunday nights and Fox overtaking a flagging NBC for the season.

headline: New York Theater Workshop’s New Season to Feature Caryl Churchill Play
abstract: The 2013-14 season will feature Ms. Churchill’s “Love and Information,” Will Power’s “Fetch Clay, Make Man,” “What’s It All About? Bacharach Reimagined” and a fourth play to be announced.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed British writer Caryl Churchill will return to New York Theater Workshop during the 2013-14 season with a new drama, “Love and Information,” her first play there since the 2009 staged reading of her controversial work “Seven Jewish Children: A Play for Gaza,” the theater announced on Tuesday. It will be the seventh American debut of a Churchill play at New York Theater Workshop, where her previous plays included “A Number” and “Far Away” as well as “Seven Jewish Children,” which drew complaints in both London and New York for its portrayal of some Israelis, who speak savagely about Palestinians. James MacDonald will direct “Love and Information,” as he did last year in a London production. The play, which features dozens of short scenes about characters overwhelmed by the nonstop pace of modern information, is expected to begin performances in early 2014.

headline: Soda Supporters
abstract: The Times’s Nicholas Confessore on the ties between beverage companies and the groups that oppose limits on large drinks.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Nicholas Confessore on the ties between beverage companies and the groups that oppose limits on large drinks.

headline: Two Roads to the Philippines
abstract: Eating at Pig and Khao felt like poring over postcards from Southeast Asia. Dinner at Jeepney, however, was like parachuting into Manila.
lead_paragraph: The cry goes up around the restaurant.

headline: Hostess Sells Twinkies Brand to Investment Firms
abstract: Hostess said on Tuesday that it had picked a partnership of two investment firms, Apollo Global Management and Metropoulos & Company, as the new owner of its snack cake business, officially concluding the sale of the bankrupt baker’s most prized assets.
lead_paragraph: 8:53 p.m. | Updated

headline: Garrard Has a Chance to Start for the Jets
abstract: Always regarded as an accurate passer, David Garrard will learn the Jets’ new offensive system, which is predicated on timing and precision.
lead_paragraph: After missing the past two seasons because of injury, David Garrard wanted only to return to the N.F.L. Being a backup, he said, was fine with him. And then the Jets came along, with a fluid quarterback situation and an opportunity to unseat Mark Sanchez and fend off any other potential contenders. They conveyed that message to Garrard, who signed with the Jets on Monday.

headline: A View of the 2013 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
abstract: A glimpse of the goings-on at the 36th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The big boards have been packed up, the pencils are worn down to nubs, and once again, Dan Feyer is the fastest crossword puzzle solver on the planet.

headline: U.N. Report Reframes Debate Over Image of a Father’s Agony in Gaza
abstract: Four months after the latest Gaza conflict, an argument has erupted over who is to blame for the suffering shown in a photograph of a Palestinian journalist cradling the dead body of his infant son.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Wednesday, 11:52 p.m. As The Lede reported in November, within hours of the start of Israel’s Gaza offensive that month, images of the dead and wounded, particularly those of children, were shared widely on social networks by Israelis and Palestinians, as both communities sought to alert the world to their grief.

headline: He Won’t Upstage His Food
abstract: Unlike many star chefs, Andrew Carmellini, who is about to open another restaurant, lets his cooking talk for him.
lead_paragraph: When Andrew Carmellini was growing up outside Cleveland, he had a tendency to get a little wild.

headline: Los Angeles MOCA Mulls Pact With National Gallery
abstract: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles is close to working out a five-year agreement with the National Gallery of Art in Washington to collaborate on programming, research and exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Struggling to maintain its independence in the face of dwindling resources, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles is close to working out a five-year agreement with the National Gallery of Art in Washington to collaborate on programming, research and exhibitions, according to the chairman of the Gallery’s board of trustees.

headline: Statistics Challenge Cuomo’s Claim of Record Job Growth
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration has pointed to the increase in New York’s private-sector jobs, yet the state lagged behind the nation during Mr. Cuomo’s time in office.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration has boasted of New York’s private-sector job growth “setting records.” But the state actually slightly trailed the nation in private-sector job growth during the governor’s first two years in office.

headline: Ohio’s Resurgent Natural Gas Industry Spends Millions to Set Up Shop
abstract: As gas starts to flow from wells drilled into the Utica Shale deep beneath the state, a network of infrastructure is being built to process, market and transport it.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ohio — The countryside in eastern Ohio is marked by rusting tanks that stand in open fields and along the edges of family timber patches, like graveyard headstones for an era of energy riches that most people here thought had passed.

headline: Man Admits Stealing Fixtures From a Bronx Cemetery
abstract: Louis Peduto, who pleaded guilty to fourth-degree grand larceny, will enter a one- to two-year residential drug-treatment program.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of stealing brass fixtures from a Bronx cemetery pleaded guilty on Monday. The man, Louis Peduto, 56, admitted to taking items — a few doorknobs and at least one vent cover – found in a bag when he was caught by security guards at St. Raymond Cemetery on Feb. 18, the Bronx district attorney’s office said.

headline: High Horse
abstract: Eleven hundred glass beads and 290 hours of hand embroidery went into transforming a design by the French artist Pierre Péron into a giant silk chiffon scarf for Hermès.
lead_paragraph: Eleven hundred glass beads and 290 hours of hand embroidery went into transforming a design by the French artist Pierre Péron into this giant silk chiffon scarf for Hermès. This piece and seven other couture “carrés” are now on view at the Madison Avenue boutique. While more art than accessory, these works are available by special order. Hermès, 691 Madison Avenue; (212) 751-3181.

headline: Bolling Declines Independent Bid for Virginia Governor
abstract: Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling, who seemed to be positioning himself as a moderate alternative to the Republican nominee, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, said he would not run as an independent.
lead_paragraph: Bill Bolling, in announcing that he will not leave the Republican Party and run as an independent for governor of Virginia this year, did so with one of the classic political dropout lines: It’s not me, it’s the system.

headline: U.S. Backs Boeing Plan for Testing 787 Battery
abstract: The decision is a major step in Boeing’s efforts to get the innovative 787 jets back in the air, but could sharpen a debate over how effective the changes will be.
lead_paragraph: Boeing achieved a major milestone on Tuesday as the Federal Aviation Administration approved its plan to test fixes for the battery problems that have grounded its 787 jets since mid-January.

headline: Call It PoHo, Stirring but Still Sleepy
abstract: The PoHo neighborhood in Hong Kong, once sleepy and residential, has taken on galleries and cafes without losing its low-key atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: The PoHo neighborhood in Hong Kong, once sleepy and residential, has taken on galleries and cafes without losing its low-key atmosphere.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Vatican, Mali, North Korea and Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Vatican, Mali, North Korea and Kenya.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: Barn Joo, a sprawling 8,100-square-foot bar and restaurant in the Flatiron district, is opening, as well as Clos New York and the Ellington.
lead_paragraph: Opening

headline: Oysters Offer a Reason to Pull Out the Sherry
abstract: Sherry’s role has expanded from aperitif to a wine to be enjoyed throughout a meal like baked oysters with seaweed butter.
lead_paragraph: Oysters, seaweed, lemon and a touch of radish bitterness: for me, this recipe by the chef Andrew Carmellini (the subject of a new profile by Jeff Gordinier) calls out for manzanilla, the fino sherry that comes from the seaside town of Sanlúcar de Barrameda. One of the joys of the sherry renaissance is seeing its role expanded from aperitif to a wine to be enjoyed throughout a meal. Longtime sherry enthusiasts know how beautifully manzanilla goes with raw oysters. Its silken strength and saline flavors will pair just as well with the other elements of this baked dish.

headline: Videos Show Store Rampage by Protesters From Vigil
abstract: The group set upon a Rite Aid store in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, after breaking away from a vigil for a teenager who had been killed by the police.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | The police released two videos on Tuesday showing a disorderly group that descended on a Rite Aid store in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Monday night and wrought havoc inside after breaking away from a vigil for a teenager who had been killed by the police.

headline: Ordinary Guys Shifting Around, Surveying New Muscular Territory
abstract: BalletBoyz, the dance company, is presenting new works by Liam Scarlett and Russell Maliphant at Sadler’s Wells in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twelve years ago, flying in the face of all reason, two former Royal Ballet principal dancers, Michael Nunn and William Trevitt, formed their own small company. They quickly became known as the BalletBoyz, appealing to a youthful public that appreciated their irreverent, ordinary-guy humor; their flair for combining risk-taking commissions with entertainment; and — credit where due — their idea, later copied by many companies, of prefacing performances with short films that gave choreographers and dancers a chance to speak of the creative process, often amusingly.

headline: Where Are the Yankees I Loved to Hate?
abstract: The Yankees’ sudden frugality is disorienting to fans, who were used to their win-at-any-cost mentality, and to opponents, who would like consistency from their tormentors.
lead_paragraph: In their current disorienting austerity drive, the Sons of Boss have it backward.

headline: Obama Discusses Entitlement Changes With Senate Democrats
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Social Security (US)', 'Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On the first of three days of meetings with members of Congress, the president expressed hope for a “grand bargain” on the budget with Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama met for more than an hour on Capitol Hill with Senate Democrats on Tuesday, engaging in a lengthy, detailed discussion about potential changes to entitlements and other ways to balance the budget.

headline: India’s Jewish Food
abstract: Joan Nathan travels to India to look for Jewish food and discovers a rich cultural history in the process.
lead_paragraph: Joan Nathan travels to India to look for Jewish food and discovers a rich cultural history in the process.

headline: SXSW Music: A Chance at Serendipity Amid the Glut
abstract: By Sunday, there may be enough live-at-SXSW material online to last until SXSW 2014.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for the annual swarm: the South By Southwest Music festival that runs for five nights in Austin, gathering musicians who want to be heard along with the businesspeople who hope to profit from them. Each year, it sprawls wider, with unofficial events, day and night, surrounding the official showcases that already offer more than 2,000 acts this year. It also moves higher up the pop food chain — gathering not just baby bands hoping for their chance and international visitors dreaming of American exposure — but also big names rolling out their latest efforts — and, inevitably, stealing attention from the underdogs.

headline: A Seder Spiced With Indian Flavors
abstract: Chicken dishes from different parts of the country make liberal use of a variety of spices.
lead_paragraph: KOCHI, India — Dreaming of spices described in the Book of Kings, I came to this southern port city built in the 14th century to learn about its longstanding but tiny Jewish presence and its food, which some believe dates back to the time of the Bible.

headline: In Spinoffs, a Chance to Jettison Liabilities
abstract: Spinning off its magazine unit may be a good move for Time Warner, but spinoffs have a dark side, serving as a convenient dumping ground for unwanted businesses.
lead_paragraph: A spinoff is a product of Wall Street math that says one plus one can equal three. Yet as shareholders of Time Warner may be about to find out, it can also be all about subtraction, as a company ditches an unwanted business, in this case, magazines.

headline: This Week’s Links
abstract: This is the first in a new series of posts, in which NYT developers pass along their recommendations from around the web.
lead_paragraph: This is the first in a new series of posts, in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Metal Gear Rising, Half the Sky Movement, Real Racing 3, MLB 13 and Aliens
abstract: The latest releases include Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance, Half the Sky Movement: The Game, Real Racing 3, MLB 13 and Aliens: Colonial Marines
lead_paragraph: METAL GEAR RISING

headline: A Mother-Son Dance With Many Awkward Steps
abstract: The plot of “I Killed My Mother” centers on the difficult relationship between a teenager and his parent.
lead_paragraph: The bluntly audacious title of the writer-director Xavier Dolan’s debut feature, “I Killed My Mother,” is both a twist on a Freudian joke and a complicated assessment of the hero’s over-cathected relationship with his parent in chief. “Deep down I love her,” the 16-year-old Hubert Minel (Mr. Dolan) says in one of the movie’s confessional black-and-white interludes, “but it’s not the love of a son.”

headline: $10 Million Gift Goes to Juilliard Drama School
abstract: The gift will endow the school’s new four-year masters-level graduate program in drama.
lead_paragraph: The Juilliard School on Monday announced that it had received a $10 million gift that will endow the school’s new four-year masters-level graduate program in drama. According to a news release the money “supports increased instructional costs and new faculty, and provides full scholarships plus stipends for actors in their final and fourth year of the master of fine arts program in drama.” A Juilliard spokeswoman said it is the largest one-time gift that Juilliard has received for its drama department.

headline: Recess Appointments Ruling to Be Appealed
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The Obama administration will appeal to the Supreme Court a ruling that President Obama violated the Constitution when he made appointments to the National Labor Relations Board.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided that it will appeal to the Supreme Court a sweeping ruling by an appeals court in January that President Obama violated the Constitution when he bypassed the Senate in making three recess appointments to the National Labor Relations Board last year.

headline: J.R. Ewing Funeral Brings Season-High Ratings to ‘Dallas’
abstract: With the funeral of the famous character a centerpiece of the episode, “Dallas” attracted 3.6 million viewers, well above this season’s average of 2.6 million.
lead_paragraph: The farewell to J.R. Ewing pulled back some lost fans to “Dallas” on TNT on Monday night, lifting the drama to its best overall audience of its second season.

headline: Web Site Investigated for Posting Private Data
abstract: After a site lists personal information of well-known people, officials seek to learn more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials said on Tuesday that they had opened an investigation into a Web site that posted the home addresses, Social Security numbers and other personal information for more than a dozen celebrities and politicians, including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Michelle Obama and Jay-Z.

headline: What the Tide Brought In
abstract: Ruth Ozeki’s new novel, “A Tale for the Time Being,” is about an American woman who finds the diary of a teenage Japanese girl that has washed ashore after the 2011 tsunami.
lead_paragraph: Nao was easy. The voice of the quirky, troubled 16-year-old Japanese schoolgirl whose words begin “A Tale for the Time Being,” Ruth Ozeki’s new novel, came to the author as she was immersed in a Buddhist teaching. But it took five frustrating years for Ms. Ozeki to round out the story.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, Lobel’s new shop, a vegetable knife with a special blade and more.
lead_paragraph: To Shop: Five Generations, One New Shop

headline: All Me, All The Time
abstract: Purchasing power parody?
lead_paragraph: The Krugman Times. Funny stuff — but I can’t afford to subscribe, having bankrupted myself buying Portuguese wine and antique British cloth and all that.

headline: Arizona Governor Introduces Bill to Expand Medicaid
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gov. Jan Brewer stepped to the lectern under blazing sunshine and before a mostly friendly audience to introduce a Medicaid expansion bill she has championed.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX – Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona stepped to the lectern on Tuesday under blazing sunshine and before a mostly friendly audience to introduce a Medicaid expansion bill she has championed.

headline: Bloomberg Defends Sugary Drink Limits
abstract: The day after a judge struck down Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s impending limits on large sugary sodas, Mr. Bloomberg promised to appeal the decision, and to continue his anti-obesity campaign.
lead_paragraph: The day after a judge struck down Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s impending limits on large sugary sodas, Mr. Bloomberg promised to appeal the decision, and to continue his anti-obesity campaign.

headline: NPR Wants to Click With Those Who Tweet
keywords: ['Radio', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Youth']
abstract: With Generation Listen, NPR, like other old-media companies, is working to build connections to a younger audience.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — NPR might not seem like the most obvious host of a party at the sprawling South by Southwest Interactive conference. But it, like so many other old-line media companies, wants and needs what the conference, part of the South by Southwest festivals, has: youthful energy.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 7
abstract: Highlights of Tuesday’s matches in the Round of 16 of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: F.D.A. Raises Heart Alert on Antibiotic in Wide Use
abstract: Azithromycin, a popular drug, can cause changes in the electrical activity of the heart that may lead to a fatal irregular heart rhythm in some patients.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday toughened a warning it made last year about the potential risks of azithromycin, a commonly used antibiotic that can cause changes in the electrical activity of the heart that may lead to a fatal irregular heart rhythm in some patients.

headline: Wary of Attack With Smallpox, U.S. Buys Up a Costly Drug
abstract: Some experts say a contract for two million doses of a treatment for a disease eradicated in 1980 has the government paying too high a price for too much of a new medicine.
lead_paragraph: The United States government is buying enough of a new smallpox medicine to treat two million people in the event of a bioterrorism attack, and took delivery of the first shipment of it last week. But the purchase has set off a debate about the lucrative contract, with some experts saying the government is buying too much of the drug at too high a price.

headline: Music and Drama
abstract: A look at the stage performances of Kate Burton.
lead_paragraph: A look at the stage performances of Kate Burton.

headline: With Isles in Contention, Grabner Is Out With Injury
abstract: Islanders right wing Michael Grabner will be sidelined for at least a week with a shoulder injury; Devils goalie Martin Brodeur skated for the first time since being sidelined with a back injury Feb. 24
lead_paragraph: Islanders right wing Michael Grabner will be sidelined for at least a week with a shoulder injury. There is no timetable for his return, the team said, adding that Grabner will be re-evaluated in 7 to 10 days. It is unclear how Grabner was hurt. He is third on the Islanders in goals with 10, and has 3 assists in 26 games.

headline: Instruments That Sing, With Singers as Instruments
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke performed love songs inspired by poetry during the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening.
lead_paragraph: Solo singers who focus on opera and symphonic repertory have few opportunities to perform chamber music, the superb mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke wrote in her introduction to the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening.

headline: Vatican Reveals Recipes for Conclave Smoke
abstract: Fairly standard pyrotechnical formulas are behind the white and black smoke used to signal the results of the balloting.
lead_paragraph: The papal conclave’s recipes for white and black smoke are a mystery no more.

headline: Blessings of Low Taxes Remain Unproved
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Paul Ryan of Wisconsin recycled an argument for lower taxes that surfaced in the ’80s and ’90s, but recent history suggests that higher taxes might help the economy.
lead_paragraph: The proposition that low tax rates produce higher economic growth has been a central plank of the Republican platform since I was a teenager.

headline: Views Mixed After Limits on Sweet Drinks Are Blocked
abstract: A New York Times article on a judge’s ruling on Monday striking down the city’s impending limits on large sugary drinks drew more than 1,300 comments; here are some of them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times article on a judge’s ruling on Monday striking down the city’s impending limits on large sugary drinks drew more than 1,300 comments from readers representing a wide range of regulatory philosophies. Here are some of them. A few have been condensed slightly.

headline: Syria Military Shows Strain in a War It Wasn’t Built to Fight
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The conflict has pushed a military built for repelling an Israeli invasion, not carrying out sustained asymmetrical combat, to scale back its goals and rethink its tactics.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian military’s ability to fight rebels and hold territory has steadily eroded, forcing it to cede the job of running many checkpoints to paramilitary groups, give up a provincial city last week without much of a fight and even enlist the top state-appointed Muslim cleric as a recruiter.

headline: Pushing Back Retirement, and Not Always for Money
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Longevity', 'Personal Finances', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Baby Boomers', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: In sharp contrast to earlier generations, many people retire and then unretire, or continue working well after they were supposed to have retired.
lead_paragraph: IT’S not your grandfather’s retirement, not nearly as cut and dried. It’s not the simple picture of stopping work at 60 or 65, moving to Florida and devoting oneself to golf and bridge — not that it was ever totally that.

headline: Choice for Tight Times: Save More or More Risk
abstract: Low interest rates mean retirees must save more money to produce the same income or invest in assets with higher yields but possibly higher risk.
lead_paragraph: BUILDING an investment portfolio that produces enough income to live on is one of the main goals of retirement planning, but lately the goal posts have shifted. With interest rates stuck near record lows, retirees must have more saved up to produce the same income through the usual high-quality investments, like Treasury bonds, or else they must venture into assets with higher yields but potentially higher risk

headline: What Do You Want to Be, Now That You’re Grown?
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Retirement', 'Working Hours', 'Elderly']
abstract: Some older adults are taking jobs that they never trained for as young people, like recording audiobooks, refereeing sports and bartending.
lead_paragraph: FOR most of my working life, I have never had to commute or see the inside of a cubicle. As a television critic, I was “forced” to watch the tube, and as a sportswriter, I inhabited stadiums and press boxes rather than dingy offices.

headline: Hey, at Least You Can Be Virtually Immortal
keywords: ['Biographical Information', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Archives and Records', 'Retirement']
abstract: Digital devices and online services can provide the material to leave a document for younger generations, once you sort through it all.
lead_paragraph: NO one will confuse typical retirees today with the Emperor Augustus, who constructed a huge mausoleum to celebrate his life for eternity. And yet they belong to the first generation of elders within easy grasp of something once so rare and valuable that relatively few historic figures could enjoy it until now: virtual immortality.

headline: Going to College at 65, and Going Greek as Well
abstract: Jerry Reid, who enrolled in college at 65 and joined a fraternity, tells of his experiences as an older student on campus.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, going to college for Jerry Reid meant not enrolling, but tagging along with his pal William Lloyd Sturman and crashing at his fraternity, Chi Phi, at the University of Virginia. “He brought me to U.Va and introduced me to a life I didn’t even know existed,” Mr. Reid said in a recent telephone interview. Despite coaxing from Mr. Sturman, who died in 1984, Mr. Reid assumed that a university education was unattainable for a boy from Dogtown, the working-class neighborhood in Richmond, Va., where he grew up. “I did not see higher education as a possibility,” Mr. Reid said.

headline: A Little of This, a Little of That for Older Exercisers
abstract: Activities that mix strength-building and cardiovascular, or aerobic, exercise, can help older people meet physical activity guidelines.
lead_paragraph: BY 9:30 a.m., the early crowd at Metro Fitness in Montgomery, Ala., has thinned. Those who must be at work are gone. Those who remain are generally retirees. At that time, every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, 15 to 20 of them gather in the club’s first-floor studio for a class called Fitness Fusion.

headline: In Auditing Classes, Older Students Find Welcome on Campus
abstract: Many institutions, including Ivy League universities and unheralded community colleges, offer older students free or discounted tuition.
lead_paragraph: OLDER students audit courses at colleges and universities for many reasons. Some retirees prefer lecture halls to bingo parlors. Travelers might take history or geography classes to learn about future vacation destinations. A philosophy class might help a widow cope with grief.

headline: For Modern Retirees, There’s No Place Like Home
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Elderly', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Housing plans for active retirees take into account the desire to be near urban centers and the wish to live at home as long as possible.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: In Retiree Housing, Talking About Multigenerations
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Cohousing Communities', 'Retirement', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: More older Americans are planning to retire in planned communities that organize group meals and activities and welcome residents of all ages.
lead_paragraph: THERE seems to be a rule that if retirees move to a communal environment, it must consist only of other retirees. But some older adults are challenging that notion by choosing intergenerational cohousing, living side by side with people of all other ages, including singles, childless couples and families with children.

headline: Predicting Commutes More Accurately for Would-Be Home Buyers
abstract: On its Web site, Windermere, a real estate firm, has begun using an online tool from Inrix, a company that does crowdsourced traffic estimates. It gives those looking for a home an hour-by-hour prediction of the drive times to their workplaces.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things people shopping for a house want to know is how agonizing the commute will be. It’s not that hard to get an idea of how bad the pain will be in this era of smartphones and apps. You can punch your work address into Google Maps while you’re standing in front of your dream house to get a ballpark estimate of how long you will spend in a car, on a bus or riding a bike to your office. A start-up called Walk Score even has a search engine that lets you find apartment listings within a selected commuting range — say, a half-hour by bus or 15 minutes by car.

headline: Venture Capitalists Face Another Sexual Harassment Suit
abstract: Another lawsuit is raising the issue of sexual discrimination at Silicon Valley venture capital firms.
lead_paragraph: Another lawsuit is raising the issue of sexual discrimination in Silicon Valley. Three female employees have sued CMEA Capital, a venture capital firm based in San Francisco, claiming sexual harassment and retaliation.

headline: Revolution and Its Aftermath Play Out on an Avenue That Defines a City
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Names, Geographical', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Immolation']
abstract: The changes along Avenue Habib Bourguiba reflect the tumult in Tunisia two years after a revolution deposed a president and ushered in an era of uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — An elderly veteran of Tunisia’s struggle for independence has watched his country’s transformations — through colonialism, a coup and an uprising — from his regular spot at a cafe on the avenue that bears the name of his hero.

headline: Barcelona Sends Emphatic Message to the Doubters
abstract: Lionel Messi scored twice on Tuesday as Barcelona climbed back from an earlier 2-0 loss to eliminate visiting A.C. Milan in the Champions League Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: Ninety minutes of mediocrity led to three weeks of hysterics for Barcelona, all of which was promptly dispatched in less than an hour Tuesday.

headline: Case Already Tried in Social Media Heads to Court
abstract: Two high school football players in Steubenville, Ohio, face charges of raping a 16-year-old girl last summer in a case that has already played out online for months.
lead_paragraph: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — No cellphones, iPads or laptops will be allowed inside Juvenile Court here on Wednesday when two high school football players go on trial on charges of raping a 16-year-old girl last summer. Anyone who wants to post on Twitter or a blog will have to leave the building to do so.

headline: Non-Communist Parties Lend China an Air of Pluralism, Without the Mess
keywords: ['Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Every March at the National People’s Congress in China’s capital is an elaborate display of multiparty cooperation that critics call a sham.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For those accustomed to the partisan jousting that frequently paralyzes Washington, the feel-good unity displayed last week by the leaders of China’s eight so-called democratic parties was eye-opening.

headline: Minority Groups and Bottlers Team Up in Battles Over Soda
abstract: Despite high rates of obesity in the populations they work for, groups with a long history of funding by the beverage industry are now fighting measures like New York City’s stalled soda ban.
lead_paragraph: The decision by a New York State judge striking down the Bloomberg administration’s ban on large, sugary drinks this week was not just a high-profile victory for the soda companies in their pitched battle against anti-obesity policies that are aimed at their products. It was also a victory for the industry’s steadfast, if surprising, allies: advocacy groups representing the very communities hit hardest by the obesity epidemic.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bitcoin Problem and Tracking the Papacy
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include Pinterest’s new tool for helping businesses track the number of visitors it sends them, more ideas about how to use voice mail and a prediction that Android tablets will overtake iPads this year.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Google Elbows Into the Cloud
abstract: Google is expanding its office space and hiring engineers in the Seattle area to compete with rivals in the lucrative cloud computing business.
lead_paragraph: In a battle for dominance in cloud computing, Google is taking on Microsoft and Amazon in their own back yard.

headline: The Scouts’s Survey on Banning Gays
abstract: The Boy Scouts of America is surveying about 1.1 million families about the role of gays in scouting.
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America is surveying about 1.1 million families about the role of gays in scouting.

headline: Boy Scouts Sends Survey to Members About Ban on Gays
abstract: The group is reaching out to parents and scouts around the nation as it decides whether to continue or rescind its ban on gay members and leaders.
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America is reaching out to parents and scouts as it decides whether to continue or rescind the group’s ban on gay members and leaders. Surveys went out in recent days to 1.1 million scouts and their families around the nation.

headline: With Ancient Rites, Cardinals Make First Attempt to Choose a Pope
abstract: The first ballot came up with no new pope, signaled by the black smoke from a Sistine Chapel chimney. But clearly the modern world was pushing against the walls of Vatican City.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — They filed into the Sistine Chapel on Tuesday reciting a Latin hymn, and then swore an oath on the Bible, pledging secrecy. And then the 115 cardinals were sealed inside to choose from among them the next leader of the Roman Catholic Church. It was a ritual, solemn and ancient, that underscored the continuity of a 2,000-year-old institution.

headline: Psychiatrist, Also Victimized, Tells of Attack by Defendant
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A doctor’s appraisal of David Tarloff came to him as he was lying not far from a dead or dying colleague, looking up at his former patient, who was wielding a bloody meat cleaver.
lead_paragraph: At the murder trial of a man accused of killing an Upper East Side psychologist, several mental health experts are expected to testify about the defendant’s state of mind on the night of the slaying. But one of those experts, Dr. Kent D. Shinbach, did not come to his conclusions from the comfort of his desk.

headline: White Says Her S.E.C. Would Be Tough on Wall St.
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee is expected to approve Mary Jo White, who provided few details of her plans for the S.E.C.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mary Jo White moved closer to becoming a top Wall Street regulator on Tuesday as she sailed through a Congressional confirmation hearing. But even her supporters on Capitol Hill pointed to significant challenges awaiting the next leader of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Departures Leave Holes On Jets’ Line
abstract: Cornerback Nnamdi Asomugha was released by the Philadelphia Eagles after two disappointing seasons.
lead_paragraph: The interior of the Jets’ defensive line disappeared Tuesday, when Sione Po’uha was released and the free agent Mike DeVito left for the Kansas City Chiefs. Their departures leave the team with little experience inside besides Kenrick Ellis, a third-round pick in 2011 who has yet to prove he merits a starting job.

headline: Hectic Times Square Is Keeping the Developers Busy
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: As pedestrian traffic and consumer spending have increased in New York City’s theater district, more major development projects are being undertaken.
lead_paragraph: Some two decades ago, New York City began a huge cleanup of its downtrodden theater district, vastly improving the fortunes of the pedestrian-clogged Times Square neighborhood. In recent months, that progress has gone into high gear, with rents reaching new highs and several redevelopment projects proceeding.

headline: Storms Swiftly Claim Trees, but Stumps Stay for Years
abstract: The storms of recent years have toppled thousands of trees, leaving as many stumps behind, as money for removing them has dried up.
lead_paragraph: When a New York City tree crew removed a shade tree whose roots had damaged the sewer line in front of Gwen Grapes’s home, the workers promised they would be back soon to grind down the stump.

headline: Head of U.S. Nuclear Watchdog Emphasizes Preparing for Unknown
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Wastes', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)']
abstract: Allison M. Macfarlane, the chairwoman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said in a speech that nuclear safety was a moving target.
lead_paragraph: Appealing for a shift in emphasis on nuclear safety, the new head of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission warned a gathering of more than 3,000 industry executives, experts and government regulators on Tuesday against relying too heavily on their ability to predict the future, and suggested that when it comes to commercial reactors, the industry and the government should be ready to deal with the unknown.

headline: A Food Market for New York
abstract: The city has a chance to do something on Fulton Street that would benefit us all.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing like a grand urban food market, which can anchor a neighborhood and even a city. Think of the 120-year-old Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia; the Ferry Building in San Francisco, which 10 years ago helped revitalize the Embarcadero; and the ever-popular Pike Place Market in Seattle. Even much-maligned Los Angeles has a permanent mid-city market, in business since 1934.

headline: Is Any Hope Left for Mideast Peace?
abstract: The Israeli-Palestinian “peace process” has actually helped make peace less attainable than ever.
lead_paragraph: WHAT should Barack Obama, who is to visit Israel next Wednesday for the first time in his presidency, do about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict?

headline: Preventing an Arctic Cold War
keywords: ['Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Relations']
abstract: Melting ice raises the potential for conflict.
lead_paragraph: JUST a quarter-century ago, and for millenniums before that, the Arctic Ocean was covered year-round by ice, creating an impregnable wilderness that humans rarely negotiated. Today, as the effects of global warming are amplified in the high north, most of the ocean is open water during the summer and covered by ice only in the winter.

headline: Fund That Subsidizes Internet for Schools Should Expand, a Senator Says
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV proposed an overhaul and update of the E-Rate fund, which uses money collected on consumers’ phone bills to subsidize Internet connections for schools.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $2.3 billion federal E-Rate program, which subsidizes basic Internet connections for schools and libraries, should be overhauled and expanded to provide those community institutions with new, lightning-fast connections to the Web, the chairman of a Senate committee that oversees the F.C.C. said Tuesday.

headline: Cheers for Reyes in His Return, and Even More After a Rally
abstract: In his return to Miami, Jose Reyes homered to help the Dominican Republic overcome a 4-0 deficit and defeat Italy in the first game of the World Baseball Classic’s second round.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Robinson Cano touched home plate, and the party started. His Dominican Republic teammates rushed out of the dugout. They mobbed him, patted his head and danced, as if their three-run seventh inning had won the game, as if this were the Little League World Series, not the second round of the World Baseball Classic.

headline: Too Close for Profit
abstract: There is winning and then there is covering the point spread, an important distinction for sports gamblers, who are forecast to wager billions this month during the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: Chris Lawless knows about bad beats. He has had plenty of particularly painful gambling losses, but he sure did not see it coming Monday night in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference men’s basketball tournament championship game between Iona and Manhattan.

headline: Good News on the Shark Front
abstract: Delegates in a world wildlife convention united to protect five shark species from powerful commercial interests.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting on the world wildlife trade in Bangkok this week, delegates voted to impose strict rules to keep five species of sharks and two types of manta rays from being fished to extinction. This is excellent news.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg’s Anti-Obesity Campaign
abstract: There are better ways for the mayor to use his time and resources to combat obesity in New York City than to ban giant sugary drinks.
lead_paragraph: A state judge ruled Monday that Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s ban on servings of sugary drinks larger than 16 ounces was “arbitrary and capricious,” blocking the limits one day before they were to take effect.

headline: Sexual Assaults and Military Justice
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls', 'Editorials']
abstract: Finding solutions to the epidemic of sexual violence in the armed forces is urgently needed.
lead_paragraph: A Senate Armed Services subcommittee is scheduled to hold a hearing on sexual assaults in the military on Wednesday, the first Senate hearing on the issue in nearly a decade. There will certainly be a lot to talk about.

headline: The Worst of the Ryan Budgets
abstract: President Obama is trying to charm a party that clings to calcified ideas on spending and taxes. Just look at the latest from Representative Paul Ryan.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing wrong with President Obama speed-dating members of Congress. Meeting face to face over food and wine, as Mr. Obama has recently done with several groups of lawmakers from both parties, may ease the demonizing politics of the last four years — along with the president’s well-earned reputation for aloofness. And given how little some Republicans know about his budget proposals — one senator confessed he had no idea what Mr. Obama wanted to cut before last week’s dinner — the shared meals were probably overdue.

headline: The Old Peace Is Dead, but a New Peace Is Possible
abstract: As Arabs and Israelis book look inward, the chance for a New Peace emerges — not lofty declarations, but a pragmatic, gradual process that advances mutual needs and interests.
lead_paragraph: KFAR SHMARYAHU, Israel

headline: Mr. Obama Goes to Israel
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'United States International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Israeli Settlements']
abstract: Here are a few questions the president might ask on his visit to Israel next week.
lead_paragraph: In case you haven’t heard, President Obama leaves for Israel next week. It is possible, though, that you haven’t heard because it is hard for me to recall a less-anticipated trip to Israel by an American president. But there is a message in that empty bottle: Little is expected from this trip — not only because little is possible, but because, from a narrow U.S. point of view, little is necessary. Quietly, with nobody announcing it, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has shifted from a necessity to a hobby for American diplomats. Like any hobby — building model airplanes or knitting sweaters — some days you work on it, some days you don’t. It depends on your mood, but it doesn’t usually matter when that sweater gets finished. Obama worked on this hobby early in his first term. He got stuck as both parties rebuffed him, and, therefore, he adopted, quite rationally in my view, an attitude of benign neglect. It was barely noticed.

headline: Legal Battle Over Limits on Sugary Drinks May Outlast Mayor’s Tenure
abstract: A fight seems headed to New York State’s highest court, and a final ruling may not come until next year.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge’s ruling on Monday striking down New York City’s limits on large sugary drinks set the stage for a test in the state’s highest court of one of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s signature policies.

headline:
Karzai Bets on
Vilifying U.S. to
Shed His Image
as a Lackey
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In what is expected to be his final year in office, President Hamid Karzai is intensifying his criticism of his American allies at a critical moment in their Afghan endgame.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The longest shadow in Afghan politics is cast by a traffic post that used to stand in Ariana Square outside the presidential palace: the Taliban hanged Najibullah, the last president of the Communist government, from it shortly after they marched into Kabul in 1996.

headline: Courts Rein In Bloomberg’s Power to Make Policy
abstract: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s third term draws to a close, his assertion of mayoral power has suffered a series of high-profile setbacks.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has long relished his reputation as a fearless urban innovator, treating New York City as his laboratory for groundbreaking experiments in public health and social engineering.

headline: Mary and the Zombies: Can Science Explain Consciousness?
abstract: Is a purely physical, scientific account of subjective experience possible?
lead_paragraph: We trust science because its claims are based on experience. But experience itself is a subjective reality that seems to elude the objectivity of scientific understanding. We know that our experiences—of seeing red, feeling pain, falling in love and so forth—depend on physical systems like the brain that science can, in principle, exhaustively explain. But it’s hard to make sense of the idea that experiences themselves could be physical. No doubt experiences correlate with objective physical facts, but, as subjective phenomena, how could they be such facts? When I feel intense pain, scientists may be able to observe brain-events that cause my pain, but they cannot observe the very pain that I feel. What science can observe is public and objective; what I feel is private and subjective.

headline: Honest Tea Creates a Business Guide as a Comic Book
abstract: The beverage maker Honest Tea has aimed to help start-ups by telling its tale of missteps and successes in an accessible format.

Now the company’s founders are taking an alternate route to telling a button-down corporate history and are instead laying out their story, warts and all, in the pictorial form of a comic book.

headline: Rains or Not, India Is Falling Short on Drinkable Water
abstract: That people in one of the rainiest places on the planet struggle to get potable water is emblematic of the profound water challenges that India faces.
lead_paragraph: CHERRAPUNJI, India — Almost no place on Earth gets more rain than this small hill town. Nearly 40 feet falls every year — more than 12 times what Seattle gets. Storms often drop more than a foot a day. The monsoon is epic.

headline: Down in the Basement, Family Tensions Stir
abstract: Dominique Morisseau’s “Detroit ’67,” at the Public Theater, sets its story of a fraying relationship between an adult brother and sister in a vividly specific place.
lead_paragraph: The streets are aflame with conflict in Dominique Morisseau’s play “Detroit ’67,” but the temperature in the basement recreation room where the action takes place never rises much above a mild simmer. An overly tidy drama that uses the riots that roiled the title city as the background to formulaic stories about a brother and sister at odds and an interracial romance, Ms. Morisseau’s play blends sentiment and social history in roughly equal parts, with results that feel studied and disappointingly bland.

headline: Written Promises
abstract: A punny Wednesday puzzle by Joe DiPietro.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I am by no means an expert on opera, but I know what I like. I like most of the theme in Joe DiPietro’s punny take on operas.

headline: At This Movie House, the Drama Is Off Screen
abstract: “The Flick,” Annie Baker’s new work at Playwrights Horizons, focuses on the lives of three workers at a film theater.
lead_paragraph: Love, friendship and the daily grind all take on a distinctly sticky quality in “The Flick,” the moving, beautifully acted and challengingly long new play by Annie Baker that opened on Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan. Ms. Baker, one of the freshest and most talented dramatists to emerge Off Broadway in the past decade, writes with tenderness and keen insight about the way people make messes of their lives — and the lives of people they care about — and then sink into benumbed impotence, hard pressed to see any way of cleaning things up.

headline: Conflict in Northern Borneo Seems Poised to Escalate
abstract: A Filipino group seeks to recapture Malaysian territory once belonging to the Sultanate of Sulu.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The leader of a band of armed Filipinos seeking to revive a historical territorial claim on the eastern Malaysian island of Borneo said on Tuesday that his group was evading that country’s forces and was trying to observe a unilateral cease-fire, but would not surrender.

headline: Election of a Pope Tests Betting Markets
abstract: If the papal odds are less reliable than the odds on, say, sporting events – which have a very good overall record – they still may be the most useful publicly available predictions.
lead_paragraph: Intrade may have shut down, but the election of a pope still offers a good chance to study the predictive value of betting odds. Eight years ago, when Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger ascended to St. Peter’s throne, the oddsmakers looked prescient: he was the favorite, or a co-favorite, in several places. Thirty-five years ago, the bookies – and, by extension, the wisdom of crowds – did much less well: Cardinal Karol Jozef Wojtyla, soon to become Pope John Paul II, was nowhere among the favorites.

headline: Venezuela: Panel Will Investigate Roots of Cancer That Killed Chávez
abstract: Venezuela will create a scientific panel to investigate the illness of Hugo Chávez, after an accusation by the interim president that the former president’s cancer was caused by his enemies.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela will create a scientific panel to investigate the illness of Hugo Chávez, after an accusation by the interim president last week that the former president’s cancer was mysteriously caused by his enemies. “We have this intuition that our Commander Chávez was poisoned by dark forces that wanted to get rid of him to destroy the Bolivarian revolution and strike at Latin America and the Caribbean,” Nicolás Maduro, the interim president, said Monday night. Mr. Chávez, a charismatic leftist, died last week after 14 years in office. The government has refused to say what type of cancer Mr. Chávez had, but Mr. Maduro said that it had behaved in a very unusual way. Mr. Maduro said that the United States and other countries had developed programs in the 1940s and 1950s to experiment with intentionally causing cancer, but he added, “I’m not accusing the United States at this moment.” He did not say when the scientific panel would be created or who would be on it.

headline: Mali: France Will Seek U.N. Force to Replace French-Led Coalition
abstract: France has told fellow United Nations Security Council members it intends to introduce a resolution this month that would authorize a replacement peacekeeping force in Mali.
lead_paragraph: France has told fellow United Nations Security Council members it intends to introduce a resolution this month that would authorize a peacekeeping force in Mali to replace the current contingents of African and French soldiers deployed in that country, diplomats said Tuesday. France, which has said publicly it wants to scale down its forces in Mali, plans to schedule a vote on such a resolution in April, with the goal of transferring peacekeeping responsibilities by July, the diplomats said. French forces intervened two months ago in Mali, a former French colony, to stop Islamist militants occupying the northern part of the country from expanding into the south. Since then, a combination of soldiers from France, Mali and neighboring African countries has helped drive the militants out of northern Malian cities deep into the hinterlands, but they remain a threat. The exact size of a United Nations peacekeeping force for Mali has yet to be determined, but France’s foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, was quoted by Agence France-Presse as telling lawmakers in Paris it could be as many as 10,000 soldiers.

headline: When Exercise Stresses You Out
abstract: Does the stress of being, in effect, forced to exercise, perhaps because your doctor or worried spouse has ordered it, cancel out the otherwise sturdy emotional benefits of physical activity?
lead_paragraph: For most people, exercise elevates mood. Repeated studies with humans and animals have shown that regular workouts can increase stress resistance, decrease anxiety, lessen symptoms of depression and generally leave people cheerful.

headline: Virginia: Bolling Decides Not to Run for Governor
abstract: Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling announced Tuesday that he would not leave the Republican Party and run as an independent for governor this year.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Bill Bolling announced Tuesday that he would not leave the Republican Party and run as an independent for governor this year. “I was not confident I could raise enough money to run a winning campaign,” Mr. Bolling said in a message posted online and sent to supporters. In November, Mr. Bolling said he would not run for the Republican nomination, clearing the way for Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, the state attorney general. He cited the state party’s nominating process, which would favor the more conservative Mr. Cuccinelli. Mr. Bolling has withheld an endorsement for either Mr. Cuccinelli or Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic Party’s leading candidate.

headline: Florida: Exhumations Sought at Reform School
abstract: State Attorney General Pam Bondi sought a court order on Tuesday to allow the exhumation of bodies thought to be buried at the Dozier School for Boys in Marianna, which closed in 2011.
lead_paragraph: State Attorney General Pam Bondi sought a court order on Tuesday to allow the exhumation of bodies thought to be buried at the Dozier School for Boys in Marianna, which closed in 2011. The reform school was dogged by reports that the staff beat, neglected and mistreated boys for decades. Forensic anthropologists have spent the past year using radar in the Boot Hill cemetery and have found 50 possible graves. Families of some of the dead boys have asked for exhumations so they can bring their bodies home and resolve questions about their deaths. The boys died between 1900 and 1952.

headline: Dominican Republic Wins Again but Remains Wary of U.S.
abstract: The United States capped a six-run victory over Puerto Rico on Tuesday in the World Baseball Classic to set up a meeting with the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As the Dominican Republic continues to buzzsaw its way through the World Baseball Classic, Manager Tony Pena talks of his team in reverent tones. They are on a mission, he says. There is a reason they are here. Maybe it would sound disingenuous if the Dominicans were not undefeated, if they were not so good.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Discovery) UNDER SIEGE: AMERICA’S NORTHERN BORDER Reporters go under cover with the Homeland Security Department to patrol the border with Canada, focusing on an 863-mile stretch on either side of the Ambassador Bridge linking Detroit to Windsor, Ontario. The area has narrow crossings, heavy boat traffic and many landing spots, which make it especially difficult to stem the flow of illegal money, guns and drugs. The show also looks inside the Operational Integration Center, where live data of the entire border streams from an enormous wall of monitors.

headline: The Man Behind the ‘47 Percent’ Video Comes Forward

lead_paragraph: 10:48 a.m. | Updated  It was one of the enduring mysteries of the 2012 campaign: who was the source of the video that captured Mitt Romney saying at a private fundraiser that 47 percent of Americans are too dependent on government, a remark that haunted him through the remainder of the presidential race?

headline: With 6,000 Dead Pigs in River, Troubling Questions on Food Safety
abstract: The disposal of thousands of pigs in a major source of drinking water raises troubling questions about food safety in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Pork buns and tap water may be off the menu in Shanghai, China’s biggest city with more than 23 million people, after thousands of dead pigs were found floating in the Huangpu River, which flows through the city, and in upstream tributaries. About 6,000 animals have been fished out so far in an operation that began last Friday, according to the Shanghai authorities, with more still surfacing, though at a slower pace. (By early Sunday, four days after this was written, about 12,600 pigs had been fished out of rivers in Shanghai and upstream in Jiaxing, the South China Morning Post reported.)

headline: Mohammad Aamir Khan’s 14 Lost Years
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Police', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Acquitted after 14 years in jail on terrorism charges, Mr. Khan is struggling to rebuild his life.
lead_paragraph: On a February night in 1998, Mohammad Aamir Khan, a resident of the Old Delhi area of India’s capital made his way to a chemist to buy medicine for a kidney stone problem. The deserted streets did not bother Mr. Khan, then 18, since he had lived in the neighborhood all his life and knew that there were likely to be very few people around at that time of the day.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Almost a year after the Chinese human rights advocate Chen Guangcheng made an audacious escape from detention in his home village, his family there remains under surveillance and his jailed nephew has said he was beaten and warned by officials not to challenge his conviction, Mr. Chen and his older brother say.

headline: Ted Kennedy Jr. Is (Finally) Ready for the Family Business
abstract: He has finally received the calling. But does the name still matter?
lead_paragraph: In early December, Washington’s political class was in one of its episodic ventilations over who would fill the latest round of job openings. The intrigue of the moment involved Hillary Clinton’s replacement as secretary of state. Susan Rice, the U. S. ambassador to the United Nations and onetime front-runner, was taking a public battering, and the fallback candidate, Senator John Kerry, was looking more likely to get the job. This would in turn mean that another Massachusetts Senate seat would be up for grabs — the third election since the death of Ted Kennedy in 2009.

headline: North Korea Hurls Barb at President of the South

lead_paragraph: Lynsey Addario entered Syria this year on assignment for The New York Times to show a broader, more human aspect of the conflict there. Her work took her to Aleppo Province, home to Syria’s largest city and site of some of the fiercest fighting. In a phone conversation with James Estrin from London, Ms. Addario, 39, discussed her recent work. Their conversation has been edited.

headline: Some New Songs for a Side Career
abstract: There’s an appetite for Justin Timberlake’s new album, although he has spent most of the time since his last one pursuing other work.
lead_paragraph: The last time Justin Timberlake released an album, Barack Obama was the junior senator from Illinois, Jay-Z and Beyoncé were not married, and iPhones did not exist. It was 2006, just a few weeks before Taylor Swift’s debut album arrived, setting her on the path to become perhaps the last old-fashioned pop superstar. But since then rapid industry decline and atomization have all but eliminated the need for Justin Timberlakes, or Taylor Swifts, or certainly the opportunities to make new ones.

headline: Night of the Living Alesina
abstract: They can’t let the confidence fairy go.
lead_paragraph: Ah, remember the good old days of expansionary austerity? On both sides of the Atlantic, austerians seized on academic work by Alberto Alesina and Silvia Ardagna claiming that fiscal consolidation, if focused on spending cuts, would if anything lead to economic expansion. It wasn’t because the paper was especially compelling — even a quick look suggested that the methodology for identifying austerity was seriously flawed. But A-A told people what they wanted to hear, and they went with it.

lead_paragraph: Condé Nast plans to announce Wednesday that Anna Wintour, editor of Vogue for nearly a quarter-century, will take on the additional role of artistic director for the company, Eric Wilson reports. The move into Condé Nast’s executive ranks ends speculation that Ms. Wintour might leave the company, and it makes her one of the most powerful women in magazine publishing. Ms. Wintour’s new role will assume some of the responsibility from S.I. Newhouse Jr., who has controlled editorial management as Condé Nast’s chairman for more than three decades. Ms. Wintour described the position as “almost like being a one-person consulting firm” for other editors on directing their brands.

headline: The Benefits of Mobile Health, on Hold
