lead_paragraph: The world now has 5 billion mobile phones – one for every person over 15.  Africa has a billion people and 750 million phones, and mobile is growing so fast there that in a few years there will be more phones than people.   In some countries this is already true — South Africa has 47 million people, but 52 million SIM cards.

headline: The Gun Report: March 13, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Take a close look at the first item here. It shows exactly how perverse the gun show loophole is—which, of course, has been staunchly defended over the years by the National Rifle Association. The killer, a felon who had just been released from prison, actually researched gun shows either just before or just after he killed his grandparents so that he could buy a gun without a background check. It boggles the mind. But no state can prevent someone from buying a gun elsewhere and bringing it across state lines. And the beat goes on.

headline: Boutique Wines Aloft

The Japanese airline All Nippon Airways has taken the indulgence one step further; it has brought on Ned Goodwin, a holder of the Master of Wine title and former sommelier at the restaurant Veritas in New York City, to produce wines exclusively for its passengers. The wines, made from grapes from the Languedoc and Roussillon wine regions in France and blended and matured by the boutique winery Hecht & Bannier, will be served through August.

headline: SXSW Music: Korean Pop With Its Own Special f(x)
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: A five-woman group from South Korea, f(x) brought a glossy performance to what is mostly a gritty festival.
lead_paragraph: Mystique does not thrive at South by Southwest. It is very rarely a festival where the polished pop star bestows a slick, remote performance on distant fans and then disappears back behind the veil of celebrity. The clubs where most gigs take place are too small and the stages are too low for that; audience members are close enough to see musicians eye to eye. They can probably run into them backstage, too, loading their own equipment into the van. Even at larger places, the stars don’t get to bring their custom-built stages, lights and sound systems; they play in the existing setups, like the big, bumpy backyard of a barbecue place or a generic temporary stage in a warehouse or a vacant lot. Performers also experience the same Texas weather — summery even in March — that audiences do. It’s a kind of leveler; who are you without your gimmicks, and how do your songs really hold up?

headline: The War Comes Home to Indiana
abstract: Rampant desertion in 1863 leads to a standoff between Army officials and antiwar locals.
lead_paragraph: In early March 1863, an officer in Terre Haute, Ind., ordered two veteran Army sergeants to cross into Clark County in nearby eastern Illinois to carry out a peculiar, though increasingly common, order: arrest a group of Union Army deserters. It wasn’t an easy assignment: the men found swarms of deserters, but also met armed resistance from local residents who were fostering the runaway soldiers, and were even shot at a few times.

headline: Seeking Funds for Movie, Creator of ‘Veronica Mars’ Turns to Kickstarter
abstract: Rob Thomas, the creator and producer of “Veronica Mars,” said a movie adaptation could happen if donors pledge $2 million to the project in the next 30 days.
lead_paragraph: If a “Veronica Mars” movie doesn’t happen now, there will be no mystery about who did it in — its loyal fans will be the culprits. Rob Thomas, the television producer and creator of “Veronica Mars,” the cult hit series that starred Kristen Bell as a crime-solving teenager, has thrown down a challenge to viewers who have long clamored for this show to be turned into a film, telling them that they had 30 days to help raise $2 million for the project and calling it “our one shot” to see it happen.

headline: Man Sought in Upstate Shootings Is Killed
abstract: A man shot six people across two communities and, according to officials, barricaded himself in a building after firing at police officers.
lead_paragraph: HERKIMER, N.Y. — A man suspected of shooting six people, killing four of them, in upstate New York before firing at the police and barricading himself in a building was killed early Thursday when the police stormed the place where he was hiding.

headline: The Case for Shaking Up Hewlett’s Board
abstract: Replacing several directors responsible for H.P.’s past missteps would bring some accountability to the board and ensure an uncomfortable breakup of the company is not pushed aside, the writer contends.
lead_paragraph: A breakup of Hewlett-Packard is both desirable and inevitable. But it requires new blood on the board.

headline: Boom-and-Bust Diamondbacks Try for a Steady Approach
abstract: Arizona entered the major leagues in 1998, and the franchise’s history has been one of peaks and valleys. Kevin Towers, the general manager, is now looking for durable success.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

headline: Obama Continues Evolving
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The president now seems to think that state bans on same-sex marriage are unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has “evolved” yet again on gay rights and now seems to think that state bans on same-sex marriage are inherently unconstitutional.

headline: London Theater Journal: Alan Bennett, a Cozy Everywhere Man
abstract: You can find Alan Bennett two ways on London stages: He’s a character in a double bill starring Alex Jennings (“Hymn” and “Cocktail Sticks”) and the author of “People,” starring Frances de la Tour.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dead-celebrity theater has long been a staple of the English-speaking stage. In New York these days, you can’t turn a corner off Times Square without coming across some esteemed performer pretending to to be Ann Richards or Sue Mengers or even the tabloid columnist Mike McAlary. But this city, at the moment, likes ’em live.

headline: Signature Theater Season to Include Premiere of New Albee Work
abstract: “Edward Albee’s Laying an Egg,” a new play by the Tony Award-winning writer, will have its world premiere this summer at Signature Theater – one of several productions that the company announced on Wednesday for its 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: “Edward Albee’s Laying an Egg,” a new play by the Tony Award-winning writer of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,” will have its world premiere this summer at Signature Theater, one of several productions that the company announced on Wednesday for its 2013-14 season.

But for those still seeking a visit, a bloody action thriller opening next week called “Olympus Has Fallen” may be at least as exciting.

headline: Secularism, the Arab Ways
keywords: ['Arabs', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The Islamists might have scored major electoral victories since the Arab Spring, but a new openness about debating religion has come to the region.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Free Arabs, a new Web site run by a group of Arabs — some in the Middle East, others in the West — is causing a stir. Gathered under the slogan “Democracy, Secularism, Fun,” it laments the fact that “millions of Arabs have internalized the notion that secularism is tantamount to faithlessness, and is all about demonizing Islam and promoting a dissolute way of life.

headline: Budget, Back and Forth

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jonathan Weisman on whether House and Senate plans on government spending can find convergence.

headline: Lhota Makes a Strong Start in Fund-Raising
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican, has begun to dispel worries that he could not mount a candidacy capable of keeping pace with his better-established rivals.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota, a former deputy in the Giuliani administration who made a late entry into the race for New York City mayor, collected $730,000 in campaign contributions over the past two months, a robust show of financial muscle for a first-time candidate.

headline: A New Art Direction
abstract: The Popular Workshop, situated in former cable car factory in San Francisco, serves as both an art studio and gallery for international and emerging artists.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago Nate Hooper and Andy Hawgood decided to open a hybrid space in San Francisco’s Tenderloin district. Part design agency and part gallery, the Popular Workshop is named after the 1960s French Situationist movement “l’atelier populaire.” The airy sprawling space, once a cable car factory, does double duty as a studio space for the partners (who specialize in creative direction for a variety of brands) and as a gallery for the eclectic events and edgy exhibitions that have put the Popular Workshop on the art scene map.

headline: Having None of Having It All
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Brooks and Collins argue about Sheryl Sandberg, “The Bachelor” and the papal election.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks:  As opinionators, this is the late winter of our discontent. The world just hasn’t thrown up that many topics to generate passionate debate. I’m not counting the new episodes of “The Bachelor.”

headline: Detained, Deported and Determined
keywords: ['Arizona Immigration Law (SB 1070)', 'Deportation', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Photography']
abstract: Deportations reached a record 1.5 million people during President Obama’s first term. John Moore sought to put a face on this story, photographing deported — or soon-to-be-deported — immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Almost every day of the week in places like Mesa, Ariz., federal authorities send planes filled with deportees back to Central America. Originally arrested for anything from traffic offenses to murder, they end up patted down and shackled with 100 others who had been in this country illegally. Even more are deported by land across the Mexican border.

headline: U.S. Budget Deal in Doubt; Obama’s Trip to Hill Reveals Split
abstract: The president’s meeting with House Republicans served only to reinforce the divisions that have created a cycle of deadline-driven short-term fiscal policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s meeting with a restive and resistant House Republican majority on Wednesday underscored their deep divisions over fiscal policy as both sides acknowledged that an overarching budget compromise was in doubt despite a new push by the White House.

lead_paragraph: In the 1984 film “The Flamingo Kid,” newly hired cabana boys at a beach club were made to jump off the end of a pier into the ocean below, as an initiation rite.

headline: A Couple at Sea: A. L. Kennedy Talks About ‘The Blue Book’
abstract: A. L. Kennedy’s new novel, “The Blue Book,” involves a relationship between a man and a woman who used to work together as spiritual mediums.
lead_paragraph: A. L. Kennedy’s new novel, “The Blue Book,” is set on an ocean liner and involves a relationship between a man and a woman who used to work together as spiritual mediums. In The New York Times Book Review, Wendy Lesser wrote that the book’s mysterious strands come together in the end: “There are no sleight-of-hand tricks practiced on us here: we are promised a certain kind of novelistic satisfaction, and Kennedy fully delivers.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Kennedy discussed what (if anything) she’s learned from critics, the keys to writing about sex and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Congressional Committees Make Some Gun-Rights Provisions Permanent
abstract: With gun safety measures headed to the Senate, members of the House and Senate appropriations committees made permanent four gun-rights provisions largely favored by Republicans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With gun safety measures headed to the Senate floor, members of the House and Senate appropriations committees have quietly made permanent four formerly temporary gun-rights provisions largely favored by Republicans. Those provisions are part of a spending bill that would keep the government running through Sept. 30.

headline: Even a Sock Can’t Derail Penn State Wrestling
abstract: Penn State dominated the Big Ten wrestling tournament.
lead_paragraph: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.–Matt Brown didn’t know it was a penalty in wrestling to grab an opponent’s sock.

abstract: Netflix said that it would begin offering United States customers the ability to share their video watching habits with their friends on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: You no longer have to ask your friends what they are watching on Netflix. Instead, you can now simply peer over their digital shoulder.

headline: Not So Sweet: Investigating Science and Health Questions About Sugar and Our Bodies
abstract: In this lesson, we’ll help students investigate the science and myths about added sugars. How unhealthy are they? What happens to sugar when ingested? And how much sugar do we actually consume?
lead_paragraph: Sugar and corn syrup have become a large part of the American diet. On average, teenagers get 17 percent of their daily calories from added sugar. Meanwhile, public health officials have taken note that more and more studies suggest a link between sugar consumption and health issues like obesity and diabetes. Some go so far as to say that sugar is toxic to our bodies, and as dangerous to our health as cigarettes.

lead_paragraph: A former executive at the Pacific Investment Management Company, the money management giant known as Pimco, has said that he was fired last year after reporting an array of misconduct at the firm to federal law enforcement officials.

lead_paragraph: “Henri Labrouste: Structure Brought to Light,” at the Museum of Modern Art, is elegant and astringent, like Labrouste’s work. The name may not ring a bell, but don’t let that stop you from seeing the show. It is gorgeous.

headline: Tortorella’s (Latest) Greatest Rant
abstract: Rangers Coach John Tortorella blasted his team after Tuesday night’s loss to Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: Rangers Coach John Tortorella has made a career of the unpredictable news conference and Tuesday night became the latest installment in that long-running series. After the Rangers lost, 3-1, to the Sabres in Buffalo, Tortorella unleashed his thoughts about a loss he found particularly disturbing. It was not the garden-variety blame-the-media rant. It was directed toward his own team.

headline: New Hendrix Album Hits No. 2
abstract: Four decades after his death, a collection of unreleased Hendrix recordings, “People, Hell and Angels,” hit No. 2 on the album chart. Luke Bryan was No. 1.
lead_paragraph: Jimi Hendrix is dead but not forgotten. His posthumous album “People, Hell and Angels,” opened at No. 2 on the Billboard album chart this week, selling 72,000 copies more than four decades after he died. The last time one of Hendrix’s albums charted so high was back in 1968, when “Electric Ladyland” spent two weeks at No. 1.

headline: A Guide for Those Lost in the Aisles
abstract: Personal shoppers sell tailored advice on what makeup to use for the kind of woman who finds the process disorienting.
lead_paragraph: My makeup routine has existed longer than many marriages. For the last 10 years, I’ve swiped my cheeks and lids with a two-in-one blush and eye shadow from Nars, lined my eyes with Laura Mercier’s black liner and used DiorShow mascara on my lashes.

headline: An Automotive Love Story: Reuniting a Car With Its Engine
abstract: Paula Champa’s new novel, “The Afterlife of Emerson Tang,” may be the first whose theme is the reunification of a vintage car with its original engine.
lead_paragraph: Cars play major roles in many important novels, like F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby” and Stephen King’s “Christine.” In a novel published this week, a car and an engine take center stage.

headline: Speeding Through China
abstract: Express train service from Beijing cuts hours off of travel time to some of China’s most popular tourist sites.
lead_paragraph: China recently began express train service from Beijing to Guangzhou, Xi’an and Luoyang, making it easier to visit the terra-cotta warriors, the Buddhist carvings at the Longmen Grottoes, and Hong Kong. The new rail service takes five and a half hours to Xi’an and four hours to Luoyang, which cuts travel time to each city from Beijing by more than six hours. A journey from Beijing to Hong Kong that previously took about 22 hours now takes half that on the new Beijing-Guangzhou express line.

One thing it offered me was a chance to hear performers that Austin can hear regularly, but the rest of us can’t.

lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — While the interactive leg of the South by Southwest festival touted the latest technological tools, select festival films were more comfortable basking in the nostalgic glow of tech history. These films either look back on, or involve, old video formats in their storytelling, in effect using the retro to usher in the new.

headline: Manhattan School of Music Names New President
abstract: James Gandre will assume the post in May, succeeding Robert Sirota.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan School of Music has appointed James Gandre as president, effective May 6. He succeeds the composer Robert Sirota, who stepped down last fall. Mr. Gandre is currently the provost and executive vice president of Roosevelt University, in Chicago, but he has worked at the Manhattan School before, as dean of enrollment and alumni from 1995 to 2000. He joined Roosevelt University in 2000, and held positions there as interim dean of the College of Education, and dean of the Chicago College of Performing Arts.

headline: Two’s Company, Three’s a Tale
abstract: “The Drawer Boy” by Michael Healey looks in on the lives of two aging friends who share a farmhouse in the Canadian countryside, and a stranger who comes to live with them.
lead_paragraph: Actors must be thrilled when handed Michael Healey’s play “The Drawer Boy,” no matter which of the three characters they’ll be tackling. It’s such a beautifully written piece, humorous and heart-wrenching but never overwrought, that all you have to do is ride the vehicle the author has provided. You can concentrate on your performance, not on dredging humor out of unfunny jokes or tears out of unconvincing moments.

headline: Out of Time: The Sins of Immediacy
abstract: In “Present Shock,” Douglas Rushkoff analyzes the breathless impact of today’s technologies, including their consequences for information processing.
lead_paragraph: “Present Shock” is one of those invaluable books that make sense of what we already half-know. Playing on the title of Alvin Toffler’s influential 1970 “Future Shock,” which sounded an alarm about what Mr. Toffler called “a personal perception of too much change in too short a period of time,” Douglas Rushkoff analyzes a very different phenomenon. The future arrived a little while ago, he posits — maybe with Y2K, maybe with Sept. 11. Now it’s here. And we are stuck with “a diminishment of everything that isn’t happening right now — and the onslaught of everything that supposedly is.” Mr. Toffler warned that we would be unready for this onslaught. Mr. Rushkoff is more analytical than alarmist. He divides his thoughts into five sections addressing five kinds of profound change, and his biggest illustration of present shock has to do with the actual book itself. Because the present is more full of interruptions than the past was, it took him extra time to write. Because its ideas aren’t glib, he says, “here I am writing opera when the people are listening to singles.” And he realizes that data-swamped readers may take longer to finish books now. Coming from him the phrase “thanks for your time” has new meaning.

headline: Scenes From South by Southwest Music
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Images from the festival in Austin, Texas.
lead_paragraph: Images from the festival in Austin, Texas.

headline: Subway Reads
abstract: Life on the tube, as written by London’s literati and cultural tastemakers, now in a box set.
lead_paragraph: The sight of subway commuters with their noses buried in books is one that transcends iPods, Angry Birds and any number of technological and cultural advances. It’s only appropriate, then, that Penguin has teamed with Transport for London to create a series of 12 books, each inspired by a different tube line, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the London Underground. The publisher tasked a select group of straphangers — pulling from the city’s literati and cultural tastemakers — with sharing their experiences of the English capital in 15,000 words or less.

headline: U.S. Learns Gold Cup Opponents
abstract: The United States will face Costa Rica, Cuba and Belize in the first round of the 2013 Concacaf Gold Cup in July.
lead_paragraph: The United States was placed in Group C, with Costa Rica, Belize and Cuba, in the draw for the 2013 Concacaf Gold Cup conducted Wednesday in Chicago, which will also host the final — at Soldier Field on Sunday, July 28.

headline: Mother Leaps With an Infant and Dies
abstract: The child was critically injured in the fall from an eighth-floor window on Bradhurst Avenue shortly before 3:30 p.m., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A woman leapt out an eighth-floor window with her infant son in Harlem on Wednesday, killing herself and critically injuring him, the police said.

headline: Portland, Ore., Approves Earned Sick Leave Policy
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: The City Council in Portland, Ore., has passed a law that will enable many employees there to earn up to five paid sick days a year.
lead_paragraph: In Sheryl Sandberg’s “Lean In,” she declares the problem of women’s advancement in the workplace to be a “classic chicken-and-egg problem.” The chicken — her concern — is the impact of the choices women make that make career advancement harder. The egg is the impact of policies and society that push back, on women and all parents, as we work to both raise our families and financially support them. Without progress on both fronts, Ms. Sandberg argues, we’ll never see workplace equality.

headline: Bob Dylan to Be Honored by American Academy of Arts and Letters
abstract: Bob Dylan will become an honorary member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Arts and Letters will go electric (sort of ) in May when it welcomes Bob Dylan as an honorary member at a ceremony at its Upper Manhattan headquarters. If he shows up, Mr. Dylan — the first rock musician honored by the group — will also be serenaded in words by the novelist Michael Chabon, who was elected as a regular member last year and is scheduled to give an address titled “Rock ‘n’ Roll.”

headline: Pop Glitter on Broadway
abstract: A look at the career of the singer Cyndi Lauper.
lead_paragraph: A look at the career of the singer Cyndi Lauper.

headline: That Car in the Rear-View Mirror May End Up in Your Garage
abstract: A buyer’s car choice could be influenced by the type of vehicle seen most often on the road, a study says.
lead_paragraph: A study suggests that a person’s choice of what car to buy could be influenced by the type of vehicle a buyer sees most often.

headline: Families May Gain From Observing CPR
abstract: Family members who observed resuscitation efforts were significantly less likely to experience symptoms of post-traumatic stress, anxiety and depression than family members who did not.
lead_paragraph: It seems counterintuitive: allowing family members of deathly ill patients to watch while doctors try to restart the patients’ hearts. Wouldn’t it be traumatic for the family to see? Couldn’t it be distracting for the doctors?

headline: Allergies Aren’t Just For Kids
abstract: Food allergies don’t only develop during childhood. In my mid-20s I suddenly found myself covered in hives after eating carrots.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend’s cover story hit home for me, not because I was an allergic child, but because I am an allergic adult. In my mid-20s I suddenly found myself toting an EpiPen and looking more closely at menus.

headline: Dolphin Seen on an Apparently Healthy Swim in the East River
abstract: The dolphin was seen off the East 90s of Manhattan and gave no sign of being in any danger, but a marine animal expert intended to assess its health.
lead_paragraph: A dolphin was spotted swimming in the East River off the East 90s of Manhattan on Wednesday morning and was still there Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Unnerved, Like All of Us, by Life’s Strangeness
abstract: “The Curious Case of the Dog in the Night-Time,” a play adapted from the novel about a boy who appears to have Asperger’s syndrome, has opened at the Apollo Theater in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — You need blinkers to navigate a big city, something to screen out the teeming surplus of ambient sights and sounds. Christopher Boone — the 15-year-old hero of the thrillingly staged adaptation of “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” at the Apollo Theater — has no such apparatus at all. And on his first day in London, it’s a lack that threatens to pulverize him.

headline: SandRidge Settles Fight With Hedge Fund
abstract: SandRidge Energy said it would expand its board by four seats, giving the new positions to TPG-Axon Capital Management. The company also said it would decide by June 30 whether to remove its chief executive, Tom L. Ward.
lead_paragraph: SandRidge Energy announced on Wednesday that it had settled with a hedge fund that had been calling for the removal of the oil company’s chairman and chief executive, Tom L. Ward.

headline: Cellphones as a Modern Irritant
abstract: Students overhearing a one-sided conversation had more trouble solving puzzles than those within earshot of two people talking in the same room.
lead_paragraph: If you have just read the same paragraph 12 times because the person sitting next to you on the bus is chatting on her cellphone, feel free to show her this: scientists have found another piece of evidence that overheard cellphone conversations are far more distracting and annoying than a dialogue between two people nearby.

headline: Continuing Resolution, Continuing Dysfunction
abstract: Members of Congress are struggling to agree on a new stopgap measure to fund the government.
lead_paragraph: The “continuing resolution,” now a seemingly permanent method of paying for the United States government, is also a continuing symbol of Congressional dysfunction. Lawmakers resort to C.R.’s (as they are known) when they are unable to agree on a year’s worth of new spending priorities, and so simply keep what is already in effect, along with a few tweaks.

headline: Radiation Raises Women’s Risk of Heart Disease Only Slightly, Study Finds
abstract: Researchers have found that the benefits to women of treating breast cancer with radiation outweigh the risks of heart disease.
lead_paragraph: Radiation treatment for breast cancer can increase a woman’s risk of heart disease, doctors have long known. But the size of the added risk has not been clear.

headline: A Treasure Trove for Japanophiles
abstract: An eclectic array of objects and ephemera plucked from the Land of the Rising Sun, now on sale at the Bureau of Trade web site.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: After the Mile
abstract: Tim Danielson was among an exclusive group of runners who broke the elusive four-minute barrier. Now he is a runner shackled, charged with killing his ex-wife.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — It was to be a reunion of Southern California’s top high school runners, more than a hundred of them across six decades. National record-setters, state champions, a sprinkling of Olympians. Among them, a private man was going to make a rare public appearance. If Tim Danielson was not the guest of honor, exactly, he was the one everybody wanted to see.

headline: The First Latin American and the First Francis
abstract: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina is known as a humble man who spoke out for the poor and led an austere life in Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina is known as a humble man who spoke out for the poor and led an austere life in Buenos Aires.

headline: Racing Leap Into Rhythms and Romance
abstract: “Love Songs,” performed by Tim Rushton’s Danish Dance Theater as part of the Joyce Theater’s Ice Hot: A Nordic Dance Festival, has a problem: It’s lukewarm.
lead_paragraph: During “Love Songs,” a work by the British choreographer Tim Rushton, dancers dressed in everyday clothes swoop onto the stage like beams of light and swivel into deep lunges. Off-kilter steps send bodies gliding from one side of the stage to the other. The chief partnering motif involves a woman — often, the diminutive Maxim-Jo Beck McGosh — running at full speed into the arms of a man. It’s athletic to the point of being clinical. Never once does your heart get caught in your throat.

headline: Obama Appoints Church-State Law Expert to Head Faith-Based Office
abstract: President Obama named Melissa Rogers to replace a clergyman in an office that has long grappled with First Amendment issues.
lead_paragraph: As the world watched the Vatican for an announcement of a new leader for the Roman Catholic faithful, the White House quietly made a leadership appointment of its own on Wednesday, to the office responsible for outreach to religious organizations: Melissa Rogers will be the new director of the Office of Faith-Based and Neighborhood Partnerships.

headline: The Day the World Met Pope Francis
abstract: Readers respond to the announcement that Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, the archbishop of Buenos Aires, is the new pope.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Emotions Drawn Out and Magnified
abstract: A contained Vladimir Jurowski led the London Philharmonic Orchestra in two concerts at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: In England, Vladimir Jurowski, the 40-year-old principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, is revered in equal measure for the fierce elegance of his conducting and the meticulously thought-out programs he puts together. At Royal Festival Hall in London last December he paired Mahler’s Fifth Symphony with “Quatre Chants Pour Franchir le Seuil,” an apocalyptic song cycle by Gérard Grisey; in November he contextualized Beethoven’s emancipatory Fifth with Holocaust-darkened works by Schoenberg and Nono.

headline: A Look at Pope Francis
abstract: The Times’s Rachel Donadio, reporting from Rome, and Ian Fisher on the new pontiff’s selection.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Rachel Donadio, reporting from Rome, and Ian Fisher on the new pontiff’s selection.

headline: Restaurant Report: Violet Oon’s Kitchen in Singapore
abstract: A food writer and leading authority on Singaporean cooking teams up with her children to open her new restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Before Joel Robuchon, Guy Savoy and Daniel Boulud came to Singapore, the country had its own homegrown celebrity chef — Violet Oon, sometimes referred to as the Julia Child of Singapore.

headline: What You Get for ... $2.7 Million
abstract: A beach house in Oregon, a contemporary in Utah and a 2004 house in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: CANNON BEACH, ORE.

headline: Seating Schumann Cozily at the Center of His Universe
abstract: “Schumann: Under the Influence” a series by the pianist Jonathan Biss, found thematic similarities in the works of Mozart and Janacek on Tuesday at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Jonathan Biss’s excellent recital on Tuesday evening at Zankel Hall was part of his series Schumann: Under the Influence, a pop-album name for a thoughtful season-long immersion.

headline: Kurdish Rebels Free 8 Turks, Fueling Peace Talks
abstract: Kurdish militants released eight Turks they had been holding hostage in the latest sign that peace talks between Turkey and Kurdish rebels were gaining momentum.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — A group of Turkish soldiers and civil servants who had been kidnapped and held in the mountains of northern Iraq by Kurdish militants was released to their families at a border crossing Wednesday in the latest sign that peace talks between Turkey and Kurdish rebels were gaining momentum.

headline: Properties for $2.7 Million
abstract: A beach house in Oregon, a contemporary in Utah and a 2004 house in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: A beach house in Oregon, a contemporary in Utah and a 2004 house in Vermont.

headline: Columbia Acquires Dawn Powell Archives
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Books and Literature', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: The archives include diaries that Powell’s biographer had tried and failed to sell at auction last year.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University has negotiated to permanently retain the archives of the author Dawn Powell, the novelist who cast a gimlet eye on life in Manhattan, died in 1965 and has enjoyed an unlikely resurgence among readers in recent years.

headline: ‘Bunheads’ Fans Hope for More
abstract: “Bunheads,” which may or may not be back for a second season, features Amy Sherman-Palladino’s hyperverbal, screwball style and amusingly neurotic characters.
lead_paragraph: As the end of the television season approaches, and odds are laid on the survival of prominent shows like “Smash” and “The Good Wife,” a handful of us are asking: What about “Bunheads”?

headline: After a Divorce, Creeping Around Happiness
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Emotions', 'Families and Family Life', 'Happiness', 'Marriages', 'Parenting']
abstract: After a divorce, a mother looks for an honest conversation about what really makes us happy — and it’s hard to find.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve become a “creeper.” I didn’t even know what this word meant until about a month ago, when my ninth-grade students enlightened me. We had just started reading “Lord of the Flies,” and on our first day of discussion, one student raised her hand. “What are all these creepers all over the place?” she asked. Other students chimed in with echoes of confusion. She continued: “I mean, like, I thought there weren’t any other people on this island? I don’t get it.”

headline: Twombly Foundation Complaint
abstract: The lawsuit filed on Wednesday in Delaware state court.
lead_paragraph: The lawsuit filed on Wednesday in Delaware state court.

headline: Video Shows Syrian Suicide Bomber’s Last Day
abstract: A rebel group accused of ties to Al Qaeda posted a video online that documents the last day of a man who killed himself in an attack on a government checkpoint.
lead_paragraph: Jabhat al-Nusra, a Syrian rebel group accused of ties to Al Qaeda, posted a video online this week that documents the last day in the life of a suicide bomber who killed himself in an attack on a government checkpoint in January.

headline: Turmoil at Cy Twombly Foundation
abstract: The foundation has been roiled by accusations in a lawsuit that one of the four people who run it took more than $300,000 in unauthorized fees for investment services.
lead_paragraph: When Cy Twombly died in 2011 he left behind not only a legacy as one of the 20th century’s most important painters but also a vast estate, plump with paintings and other works and cash in the millions.

headline: Germany Arrests 4 and Bans Groups Linked to Salafism
abstract: Four men associated with a growing ultraconservative Islamic movement were accused of plotting to kill the leader of a far-right political party.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German police announced Wednesday that they had arrested four men associated with the ultraconservative Islamic movement known as Salafism on suspicion of plotting to murder the leader of a far-right political party that has repeatedly taunted Muslims with caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Daylight Saving Links
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Bisphenol A (BPA)', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Some reading for your extra hour of sunlight.
lead_paragraph: Junk Food and Diet News:

headline: A Democracy of Style
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: In Minneapolis, letting the children have their way with decorating.
lead_paragraph: In Minneapolis, letting the children have their way with decorating.

headline: Champions League: Round of 16/Matchday 8
abstract: Video highlights from Wednesday’s games in the Round of 16 of the UEFA Champions League.
lead_paragraph: We continue a feature in which we bring Goal readers video of the goals (and some key plays) of the day in the UEFA Champions League, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: Red Bulls’ Miller: ‘I Did It on Purpose’
abstract: Red Bulls defender Roy Miller said he intentionally strolled into the penalty area as Chris Wondolowski was taking a penalty kick last Sunday in San Jose, Calif., in an effort to distract him and to force a retake.
lead_paragraph: You have got to give Roy Miller credit for his honesty. After training on Wednesday at Montclair State University in Little Falls, N.J., Miller said that his act of encroachment during a penalty kick last Sunday at San Jose was intentional.

headline: Sorting Out the Family Home, Laden With Possessions
abstract: The process would be easier with an inventory of items in a home. Some apps to help.
lead_paragraph: I am not a hoarder. In fact, I’m exactly the opposite: I would love to live in a minimalist house, and have strong opinions about disposing of or recycling old things.

headline: Go to Your Room (and Decorate)
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: One way to get your children to put down the remote is to have them design their own rooms.
lead_paragraph: When Elizabeth Foy Larsen was growing up in the 1970s, she spent an enormous amount of time watching television. But now that she has three children of her own and a four-bedroom Mediterranean-style house filled with computers, TVs and iPads, Ms. Larsen finds herself waging an ongoing battle against screens.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Musicians Go on Strike
abstract: Using a kind of brinkmanship that has become commonplace in contract negotiations of symphony orchestras, the musicians of the San Francisco Symphony went on strike on Wednesday, a week before a scheduled appearance at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Using a kind of brinkmanship that has become commonplace in contract negotiations of symphony orchestras, the musicians of the San Francisco Symphony went on strike on Wednesday, a week before a scheduled appearance at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra announced the cancellation of a concert at its home auditorium, Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall, that was scheduled for Thursday afternoon. The musicians’ contract expired in November but was extended to February when, by mutual agreement, the musicians continued talking and playing. On Wednesday the union rejected the administration’s latest proposal for a three-year contract that, according to the administration, “would have kept the musicians among the three highest-paid orchestras in the country” (the others being the Chicago Symphony and the Los Angeles Philharmonic). The current average salary of the musicians is $165,000, the administration said. In addition to higher salaries, the musicians are seeking increases in benefits and pension contributions. A spokesman for the players could not immediately be reached. The administration said it had already notified the players that it would present a revised proposal on Thursday. It plans to go ahead with the presentation, it said, in hopes that San Francisco concerts can resume on Friday and an East Coast tour can proceed.

headline: Rivera Is Taking Robinson’s 42 to Its Last Stop
abstract: When baseball retired Jackie Robinson’s No. 42 in 1997, the 13 major leaguers with No. 42 were allowed to keep wearing it. Mariano Rivera will be the last.
lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera’s decision to retire after the 2013 season represents the end of an era for several reasons. The major leagues’ career leader in saves, he has been a cornerstone of the Yankees since winning his first championship ring with them, in 1996, and given his remarkable consistency and distinct lack of histrionics, he will be difficult, if not impossible, to replace.

headline: Pope Francis I
abstract: Notes on an unexpected pontiff.
lead_paragraph: So the oddsmakers were wrong, and we have an Argentine Jesuit as pope. This is one of those moments when humility is the better part of punditry: Despite having been the runner-up to Joseph Ratzinger in the last papal conclave, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio was no more on my radar screen over the last two weeks than he was on (almost) anyone else’s, and it would be folly for me to pretend to know what his elevation portends. His age would suggest a kind of caretaker pope, but his name (evoking not only Francis of Assisi but the great Jesuit Francis Xavier as well) suggests a mix of humility and purifying zeal; his rich biography, meanwhile, offers enough material for multiple narratives, multiple hopes, and (of course) multiple lines of attack from the church’s many critics.

headline: A Creative Turn for Watering
abstract: A Brooklyn designer’s latest creation is a twist on an old watering can.
lead_paragraph: Paul Loebach, a Brooklyn-based industrial designer, has produced furniture, accessories, lighting and even wallpaper, but says that his latest creation, the X3 watering can for Kontextür, beats them all. Like much of Mr. Loebach’s work, the can, which won the award for product-design excellence at the Accent on Design show in January, celebrates a vintage industrial aesthetic while looking new. It gets its name from a trick in its construction: a single metal tube is bent three times to create the handle and spout, then soldered onto the body. The X3 will be available in late April in solid copper ($99.95) and in white-, green-, blue- or red-painted steel ($49.95). Information: (614) 818-1446 or wabnitzeditions.com.

headline: House Hunting in ... Uruguay
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Uruguay’s market has slowed, primarily because of concerns about the economy in neighboring Argentina.
lead_paragraph: A CONTEMPORARY WITH FOUR BEDROOMS AND OCEAN VIEWS IN EL CHORRO, URUGUAY

headline: Familiar Material, Postmodern Form
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: “Against the Grain: Wood in Contemporary Art, Craft and Design” opens at the Museum of Arts and Design.
lead_paragraph: “Against the Grain: Wood in Contemporary Art, Craft and Design,” which opens Tuesday at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, is an exhibition of 80 contemporary wood pieces, some decorative, some functional and some in between.

headline: Ocean Views on Uruguay’s Atlantic Coast
abstract: This four-bedroom home in El Chorro comes with an infinity-edge pool lined with royal blue tile.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom home in El Chorro comes with an infinity-edge pool lined with royal blue tile.

headline: A New Coast for the Future Perfect
abstract: An outpost of a Williamsburg design shop comes to the Pacific Heights neighborhood of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a decade since the Future Perfect was founded in Williamsburg as an early champion of the Brooklyn design scene; six years later, a second outpost opened in NoHo. But David Alhadeff, the owner, had always eyed the West Coast. Last week he opened his third shop, in the Pacific Heights neighborhood of San Francisco. “I’ve split my time between New York and San Francisco since 2011, and became very aware of the market here,” Mr. Alhadeff said of the Bay Area. “It’s very progressive and smart.” Among his items are the Future Perfect’s own line of furniture, as well as pieces by Piet Hein Eek and Russell Pinch; lighting by Lindsey Adelman and Charles de Lisle; and accessories from Lobmeyr, Artel, Michele Quan and Fort Standard. The Future Perfect is at 3085 Sacramento Street (Baker Street), (415) 932-6508, thefutureperfect.com.

headline: Kick-Starting a Collection
abstract: Patrick Robinson got a business education in fashion the hard way. Now he’s back; An interview with Matthew Terry, the abs of the Calvin Klein underwear campaigns; and a study on social media impact during Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Since he was fired from Gap in May 2011, and with still-fresh wounds from his days at Perry Ellis and Paco Rabanne, Patrick Robinson checked out of fashion for a while.

headline: Taking a Cue From the Moulin Rouge
abstract: Italian rug maker works with French designer who plays on the can-can.
lead_paragraph: Nodus, the Italian rug manufacturer known for its collaborations with leading artists and designers, will introduce a collection next month in Milan, during the annual international furniture fair. Jupon, one standout, was designed by Sam Baron, the French artistic director of Fabrica, which is the creative studio of the fashion company Benetton. Jupon is French for a garment used to create volume under a dress or skirt, and Mr. Baron had in mind the rippling costumes of can-can dancers. The palette is Parisian: a soft gray like the city’s mansard roofs and a pink like the legs of a Degas ballerina. The eight-foot-round wool rug is hand-tufted in India and is about $3,400. Information: 011-39-02-866-838 or nodusrug.it.

headline: Sales at DwellStudio, Arhaus and Others
abstract: Discounts on decorative accessories, furniture, lighting and more.
lead_paragraph: All upholstered furniture is 20 percent off Thursday through April 7 at DwellStudio (the Martine settee, shown, originally from $3,045, starts at $2,436); 77 Wooster Street (Spring Street), (646) 442-6000, dwellstudio.com.

headline: Speak, Memory, Kvetch
abstract: Barbara Bloom on “As It Were ... So to Speak” at the Jewish Museum.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, “As It Were ... So to Speak,” an exhibition of 276 works of Judaica, art and decorative objects, opens in New York. The pieces were selected by the artist Barbara Bloom from among 25,000 in the collection of the Jewish Museum and are arranged in a suite of ornate rooms in the early-20th-century Upper East Side house the museum occupies.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Sonic Resurgent and Inside a Pebble Watch
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include an app for moving to better seats at a baseball park during the game, Apple criticizing Android smartphones and a look at the growth of Internet technology in emerging nations.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Squeezing Out Cash Long After the I.P.O.
abstract: An obscure tax strategy is the latest technique that private equity firms are using to extract money from their companies well after completing an initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: When the Berry Plastics Group, a container and packaging company, went public last October, it generated up to $350 million in tax savings. But the company won’t collect the bulk of the benefits. Rather, Berry Plastics will hand over 85 percent of the savings, in cash, to its former private equity owners.

headline: Call Your Mother and Tell Her He’s Back in Town
abstract: Las Supper, which blends hip-hop and soul, tried out some songs from its first album, “Back to the Future,” at the Blue Note.
lead_paragraph: Last September, at the inaugural concert at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, Jay-Z brought out just one guest, Big Daddy Kane. It was the student offering the spotlight to the teacher: a show of respect, of civic pride (like Jay-Z, Big Daddy Kane is from Brooklyn) and a compliment. It was also an opportunity, one that Big Daddy Kane took advantage of, showing in just a few minutes why he was worthy of the gesture, and the stage.

headline: Wrongfully Convicted and Seeking Restitution
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Forensic Science', 'States (US)']
abstract: States are grappling with how to compensate the growing number of ex-prisoners for the years they spent locked up after being exonerated by DNA tests.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Robert Dewey spent almost 18 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. Now he spends his time waiting. Waiting for food stamps, or his monthly $698 disability check. Swallowing painkillers and waiting for his wrenched back to stop aching. Waiting for the state to repay him for lost time.

headline: Building Blocks
abstract: Colorful building blocks can find a home anyplace from a child’s playroom to an architect’s desk.
lead_paragraph: Since the completion of the National September 11 Memorial in 2011, its designer, Michael Arad, has turned his attention back to buildings.

headline: Shopping for Building Blocks
abstract: Michael Arad, designer of the National September 11 Memorial, looks for simple colorful blocks.
lead_paragraph: Michael Arad, designer of the National September 11 Memorial, looks for simple colorful blocks.

headline: Diva Digs in to Cole Porter; Wagner Gets the Night Off
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe performed songs by Cole Porter, Irving Berlin and Ray Henderson in her solo debut at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the evening on Monday at Carnegie Hall the galloping strains of Wagner’s “Ride of the Valkyries” suddenly sounded. “Give me a couple of weeks,” the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe said in mock exhaustion.

headline: Mountain or Molehill: A Measure of Anthony’s Words
abstract: Back in Denver, where he started his career, Carmelo Anthony said he had reached the “pinnacle” with the Nuggets, who have never reached the finals.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Carmelo Anthony does many interviews, says many things. To his credit, seldom is he terse with reporters, and never confrontational. Genial would probably be the best way to describe most of his dealings with the news media.

headline: Market Ready
abstract: What should you do to make a nonfunctional fireplace look like an asset?
lead_paragraph: Q. What can I do with a nonfunctional fireplace to make it look like an asset?

headline: Networking Battles to Run the World
abstract: Cisco and VMware talked about ambitious strategies to create powerful data centers and networks, tied to millions of sensors and devices, with an eye on everything we do.
lead_paragraph: Cisco has a simple message: the world has bought so much of its equipment, why stop now?

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: Diesel + Edun collaborate on a new collection made from Conservation Cotton Initiative fibers; a Surface to Air sale and other shopping related news.
lead_paragraph: Shop for a Cause

headline: Spring North American Championships
abstract: The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships began Wednesday in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships began Wednesday in St. Louis.

headline: In Your Pocket, a Lost-and-Found
abstract: There are plenty of gadgets to help you find what you have misplaced. But none do the job perfectly.
lead_paragraph: On a trip from my home in California to New York a few months ago, I experienced one of those big-city moments that always seem so charming in Woody Allen movies: I forgot my bag in the back of a yellow cab. The bag contained my laptop, iPad, phone charger, reporter’s notebook and house and car keys. I realized my error just as the cab pulled out of view, while I stood dumbly on the street, watching my property and data disappear into the night.

headline: A Trainer to the Stars Who’s a Star-to-Be
abstract: Harley Pasternak has made himself into the fitness go-to man to the stars, and gained celebrity himself.
lead_paragraph: If there’s a celebrity body you admire (Rihanna? Halle Berry? Ryan Gosling?), there’s a good chance it’s the trainer and nutritionist Harley Pasternak’s work, and it is equally likely that he has appeared in a magazine (ranging from People to Seventeen to Men’s Health) or on television to describe how he does it.

headline: Romance (and S&M) in the Shtetl
abstract: “The (*) Inn” is a century-old tempestuous Yiddish drama that the adventurous Target Margin Theater has revived at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: “Give me a good thrashing because I’m such a bad girl,” says a young woman to her seductive male cousin. He later woos her with this sweet nothing: “Here is my heart. Take it and gulp down my blood.”

headline: Art? Oh, Yeah. But We’re Here to Party.
abstract: Entangling threads of art, night life, music and fashion, the Hole, a contemporary art gallery in Lower Manhattan, has emerged as a successor to the departed Deitch Projects on the downtown social circuit.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem hip-hop wunderkind ASAP Rocky was holding a party for his debut album, “Long.Live.ASAP,” in January, and as expected, a fashionable mob of his young disciples spilled onto the Bowery, a sea of black leather varsity jackets and Carhartt stocking hats.

headline: Disney Delays Release of Video Game and Toy Initiative
abstract: The company is delaying the introduction of Infinity from June until August, moving it closer to the all-important holiday sales season but possibly disappointing some investors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The introduction of Disney Infinity, an ambitious video game and toy initiative, has been pushed from June to late August, a retail window that Disney said on Wednesday was more favorable.

headline: Bedside Manner
abstract: What goes on beside the bed.
lead_paragraph: What goes on beside the bed.

headline: Obama Discusses Computer Security With Corporate Chiefs
abstract: President Obama is looking for support as he presses for legislation that would give the administration new technological tools and broader authority in the battle against computer attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – President Obama met with an invited group of 13 chief executives at the White House on Wednesday to discuss growing concerns about cybersecurity and enlist them to get behind his proposed legislation to combat the threat of computer warfare and corporate espionage.

headline: The Bedside Battleground
abstract: The increasing popularity of electronics and unmentionables is challenging the modern night stand.
lead_paragraph: Consider the bedside table, a modest domestic surface that nonetheless offers as concise a portrait of human aspirations, anxieties and appetites as one could hope for in 2013. It’s a mess.

headline: Pine Box Rock Shop
abstract: Hold the Baileys: the owners of this taproom in Bushwick, Brooklyn, vow to serve nothing but plant-based ingredients.
lead_paragraph: There are vegan restaurants, vegan cafes, even vegan boutiques. So why not a vegan bar? That’s the conceit behind the Pine Box Rock Shop, a scrappy taproom and music site in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: The Naked Man Doesn’t Dance
abstract: The man at some new bachelorette parties is a model, not a stripper, and guests take to easels to sketch his likeness.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, Amy Albright was celebrating her bachelorette party on West 14th Street. A table was filled with miniature cupcakes and glasses of pink Champagne. Nancy Sinatra’s “These Boots Are Made for Walkin’ ” played on the stereo. A shirtless waiter took coats. The guests, mostly in their 30s, sat down, waiting for the main attraction: a nude male model.

headline: From Loser to Hunk? The Clothes Help

Mahony, gathered with cardinals in Rome to choose the new pope, the Archdiocese of Los Angeles reached a $10 million settlement with four men who say they were abused by a former priest who has been criminally convicted in a separate case.

headline: In Papal Elections, Are Long Shots the Rule?

headline: One Last Block Party for ‘Broken Angel’ House in Brooklyn

Known for his outreach to the country’s poor, he gave up a palace for a small apartment, rode public transportation instead of a chauffeur-driven car and cooked his own meals.

Cano sat courtside, underneath the basket near the Heat bench, and watched LeBron James generate 15 points, 7 rebounds and 7 assists on what was considered an off night.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American commander in Afghanistan quietly told his forces to intensify security measures on Wednesday, issuing a strongly worded warning that a string of anti-American statements by President Hamid Karzai had put Western troops at greater risk of attack both from rogue Afghan security forces and from militants.

Bradley Manning pleaded guilty to several offenses related to leaking hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks in 2010, a plea that could land him in jail for 20 years. But Private Manning still faces trial on the most serious charges, including the potential capital offense of “aiding the enemy” — though the prosecution is not seeking the death penalty in this case, “only” a life sentence.

headline: A Pro-Gun Charity’s Capitol Influence
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials']
abstract: The influence of the Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation, a private charity that receives support from the firearms industry, helps explain why passing sensible gun-control measures is so difficult.
lead_paragraph: Americans puzzled by the growing gap between popular support for gun controls and Washington lawmakers’ obeisance to the gun lobby should know about the Congressional Sportsmen’s Foundation. It is a private charity that enjoys considerable tax-deductible support from the firearms industry and has very close ties to more than 250 members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, those who make up the separate Congressional Sportsmen’s Caucus. A good part of its clout comes from Washington dinners, gala “shootouts” and junkets with lawmakers.

headline: Madison Square Garden’s Overreach
abstract: In order to replace the dismal and inadequate Pennsylvania Station, the massive sports arena should not be given a new lease. It should move.
lead_paragraph: For decades now, New Yorkers have yearned for a grand entranceway to New York City to replace the dismal and inadequate Pennsylvania Station. One major obstacle has always been Madison Square Garden, the massive sports arena that is perched on top of the station and whose presence makes almost any rational redesign of the waiting rooms and tracks below virtually impossible. Architects, designers and a few visionary politicians have been trying to persuade the Garden’s owners to move so that reconstruction can begin.

headline: Awkward Choice in Kenya
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Elections', 'Editorials']
abstract: Kenya’s decision to elect a president charged with crimes against humanity poses a challenge for the West.
lead_paragraph: Kenya’s apparent decision to elect a president charged by the International Criminal Court at The Hague for crimes against humanity is deeply unsettling. But if Uhuru Kenyatta withstands an expected legal challenge by his opponent Raila Odinga, the United States and Europe are going to have to find a way to work with the new government, given Kenya’s standing as a vital security ally and a regional economic power.

headline: Last Pope and Next Budget
abstract: You know, that conclave process works so well in selecting new popes, I wonder if it could help out our fearless lawmakers on Capitol Hill.

headline: For Cardinals, Advantages in Choosing an Older Pope
abstract: At 76, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio is one of the oldest popes in history at the time of his election. But there are reasons his fellow cardinals may see this as a good thing.
lead_paragraph: The selection of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio of Argentina as the new pope, Francis, was largely unexpected by betting markets and Vatican experts, in part because of his advanced age. Cardinal Bergoglio, 76, is probably the ninth oldest of the 266 popes at the time of his election, accounting for some uncertainty because the age of many early popes remains unknown.

He will speak at Jerusalem’s convention center, but not before the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament. headline: It’s a Bumpy Ride, What With Bette Davis in the Driver’s Seat
abstract: In “The Lying Lesson,” a new play by Craig Lucas, Bette Davis goes into semi-hiding in a Maine town in 1981 and meets a young woman who may not be as innocent as she seems.
lead_paragraph: Lightning flickers, rain pelts against the windows, and an ominous thunderclap is heard shortly after Bette Davis — portrayed by Carol Kane — enters the slightly seedy house where “The Lying Lesson,” the new play by Craig Lucas, takes place. The year is 1981, and Davis has long since descended into, and not quite recovered from, her period of low camping as a gorgon in Grand Guignol B movies.

headline: Initial Tests of Battery by Boeing Fell Short
abstract: Evaluations that Boeing conducted while the the 787 jet was in development proved to be far off the mark in predicting what would happen when the plane was in use.

lead_paragraph: Partly driven by an oversupply of cheaper panels from China, the domestic solar market had its best year in 2012, with the growth in installations outpacing that of the global market, according to an annual report to be released Thursday.

lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — By choosing the first pope from the New World, the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church sent a strong message of change: that the future of the church lies in the global south, and that a scholar with a common touch may be its best choice to inspire the faithful.

headline: For Enclave of Rebel Artists, Much in Life Was Free, but Not Real Estate
abstract: The artist squat, in an old factory, became a cultural hub, but now the property owners are trying to shut it down.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Illegal squats in Paris usually have a short life. After one year, perhaps two, they are either shut down or transformed into legal art centers with the support of the city’s Socialist government. But not La Miroiterie, which has been a renowned artists’ squat for the past 14 years.

headline: U.S. Citizens Join Illegal Immigrants in Pressing Lawmakers for Change
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']

headline: Pope Francis, Bowing to Crowds, Wins Hearts
abstract: People in the crowds filling St. Peter’s Square gave their first impressions of Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: They filled St. Peter’s Square on Wednesday night, thousands of people who endured steady rain and cold temperatures, awaiting the naming of the new pope of the Roman Catholic Church. When Pope Francis was introduced, the people responded to history in the making: the first pope from Latin America and the first non-European pope in centuries. Out in the crowds, people sang, shouted the name of the new pope and spoke about the significance of the moment. GAIA PIANIGIANI

headline: Who Is Poor?
abstract: Three ways of defining poverty suggest three different approaches to relief.
lead_paragraph: There are three ways of defining poverty in America: the official Census Bureau method, which uses a set of income thresholds that vary by family size and composition; an experimental income-based method called the Supplemental Poverty Measure that factors in government programs designed to help people with low incomes; and a consumption-based method that measures what households actually spend.By defining poverty according to different criteria, these three methods capture surprisingly different populations of men, women and children. In a perfect world, these three methods would all tell us to do the same thing to alleviate poverty, but it’s not like that. Each method suggests a different approach toward how our government should direct its poverty-fighting resources.

headline: Lessons for Detroit in a City’s Takeover
abstract: Pontiac, Mich., once a healthy blue-collar city, has been guided by emergency managers for the last four years.
lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — The mayor here has no decision-making power. The City Council still holds meetings every Thursday night, though no official business can be conducted. Afterward, the council members are locked out of City Hall until morning, escorted from the building by a janitor.

headline: Egypt: Last Place on Tourism List
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A report on the international travel industry has ranked Egypt the least safe of 140 tourist destinations, evidence of the toll that unrest has taken on the country’s tourist industry.
lead_paragraph: A report on the international travel industry has ranked Egypt the least safe and secure of 140 tourist destinations, putting it behind Pakistan, Yemen and Chad, evidence of the toll that two years of near-constant unrest has taken on the country’s once-lucrative tourist industry. Tourism — which has accounted for 11 percent of Egypt’s gross domestic product, economists say — has suffered more than any other industry from the street protests and political turmoil that have prevailed since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak two years ago. The report, released by the nonprofit World Economic Forum and publicized around the world, is unlikely to help. A Tourism Ministry official said the results were not a surprise, given the turmoil and the survey’s methodology, which relied heavily on a survey of executives as well as statistics like traffic accidents. Both government and industry officials say, however, that there are signs of recovery, although mainly because of bargain-hunting Red Sea beachgoers, rather than the more profitable Sphinx-and-Pyramids circuit.

headline: Iran: Oil Exports Rose, Report Says
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Iranian oil shipments to foreign customers increased in February, a report said Wednesday, despite a new regimen of American sanctions over Iran’s disputed nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Iranian oil shipments to foreign customers increased in February, a widely followed monthly report said Wednesday, despite a new regimen of American sanctions over Iran’s disputed nuclear program intended to further limit the country’s ability to sell petroleum, its most important export. The monthly report, by the International Energy Agency, a 28-nation group of oil-importing nations, said Iran’s exports rose to 1.28 million barrels a day, from 1.13 million barrels a day in January, suggesting that the impact of the new sanctions was either negligible or had not yet begun to be felt. Under an American sanctions law provision that took effect on Feb. 6, any country that buys Iranian oil must put the purchase money into a local bank account. Iran cannot repatriate the money and can only use it to buy goods within that country. Violators of the provision risk severe penalties in doing business with the United States.

headline: Monarch Migration Plunges to Lowest Level in Decades
abstract: The monarch population has declined with extreme weather and a lack of the milkweed that the butterflies feed on, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The number of monarch butterflies that completed an annual migration to their winter home in a Mexican forest sank this year to its lowest level in at least two decades, due mostly to extreme weather and changed farming practices in North America, the Mexican government and a conservation alliance reported on Wednesday.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Flix) THE DOOR IN THE FLOOR (2004) In this adaptation of John Irving’s novel “A Widow for One Year” Jeff Bridges and Kim Basinger, above, portray Ted and Marion Cole, a long-married couple still reeling from the deaths of their two teenage sons in a car accident some years earlier. Elle Fanning is Ruth, their 4-year-old daughter, whose arrival was meant to help alleviate their grief. And Jon Foster is Eddie O’Hare, a boarding school student who has traveled to the family’s home in the Hamptons to spend a summer working as an assistant to Ted, an author and illustrator of children’s books, but ends up sleeping with Marion. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this drama from Tod Williams was “surely the best movie yet made from Mr. Irving’s fiction.” He added: “It may even belong in the rarefied company of movies that are better than the books on which they are based. And above all, Jeff Bridges offers perhaps the wittiest and richest piece of screen acting by an American man so far this year.”

headline: So Unusual for a Theater Tunesmith

lead_paragraph: “I look like what’s-her-butt, from ‘Sunset Boulevard,’ ” Cyndi Lauper announced in her pipsqueak voice. She checked herself out in the mirror in her foyer, surrounded by framed platinum records. Though she talks with the panache of a 1940s movie moll crossed with a character from “Goodfellas” — all dames and broads and outer-borough curse words — she didn’t resemble even a profane Norma Desmond. In head-to-toe black, save for a leopard-print sweater and a tight cap over her hot pink hair, Ms. Lauper, the singer of enduring hits like “Girls Just Want to Have Fun” and “True Colors,” mostly looked like what she is, a pioneering rocker.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The ‘Today’ Show’s Popularity Woes, and Anxiety at Time Inc.
abstract: NBC’s “Today” show faces dwindling popularity, perhaps because of Matt Lauer; Time Inc. employees are worried about the company’s prospects after it is spun off; and some new Spanish media outlets are trying to look on the bright side.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s “Today” has continued to lag behind ABC’s “Good Morning America” for 10 months now, a ratings slump that started just one week after its co-host, Matt Lauer, signed a contract with NBC said to be worth $25 million a year, the highest compensation ever on a morning show, Brian Stelter reports. Some “Today” staffers cite a lack of audience connection to Mr. Lauer as the root of the problem. Mr. Lauer’s popularity plummeted when his co-host, Ann Curry, was forced out last summer. Mr. Lauer, 55, started a belated image campaign this week, publicly stating that he thought his bosses had botched Ms. Curry’s departure, but it may be too late.  Alex Wallace, the NBC News executive in charge of “Today,” said NBC wants Mr. Lauer to be host for “years to come.”  The network has denied suggestions that it may replace him with a younger host like Willie Geist, 37, or David Gregory, 42.
