On Wednesday night fans and supporters of that show about a wisecracking young sleuth (played by Kristen Bell) pledged more than $2 million to produce a “Veronica Mars” movie, less than 12 hours after the fund-raising drive was announced on Kickstarter.

headline: When Your Partner Writes the Book on ‘Happy Families’
abstract: Quizzing Bruce Feiler, the author of “The Secrets of Happy Families,” and his wife, Linda Rottenberg, on their year as “happy family” guinea pigs.
lead_paragraph: It takes a lot to tolerate having a spouse (or a parent) who writes about family life, and it takes even more when that partner pulls a stunt like monthly “This Life” Styles columnist Bruce Feiler’s latest.

headline: Recipe Lab Video Chat With Nigella Lawson
abstract: Join the cookbook author Nigella Lawson, Julia Moskin of The Times and three home cooks for a live video chat about a recipe from Ms. Lawson’s new cookbook, “Nigellissima.”
lead_paragraph: Attention home cooks: It’s time to take your dish out of the oven and join us for a chat with Dining’s own Julia Moskin and the cookbook author Nigella Lawson. We selected three Times readers to join the chat via Google+ Hangout after making the first Recipe Lab dish, Ms. Lawson’s whole wheat pasta with brussels sprouts, cheese and potato. Ms. Moskin and Ms. Lawson, speaking from their kitchens in New York and London, respectively, discussed the recipe, Ms. Lawson’s new cookbook, “Nigellissima,” and food in general with our three home cooks.

headline: At the Corner of Broadway and Phish
abstract: Trey Anastasio of the band Phish prepares for the opening of his Broadway musical, “Hands on a Hardbody.”
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s superfluous kick lines or applause for the set or obligatory standing ovations, even the most die-hard Broadway zealot has a pet peeve.

headline: U.S. Drops to No. 33 in FIFA Rankings
abstract: The U.S. dropped to No. 33 in the latest edition of the FIFA men’s world rankings released Thursday.
lead_paragraph: They are mostly for amusement purposes only, but the United States’ soccer brain trust cannot be amused by the release of the latest monthly FIFA men’s rankings.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Kickstarter: The oldest active fishing vessel in the United States, the Laurel, needs a new deck … and a few other things in order to become a floating oyster bar that plies local seafood at stops around Long Island Sound. — Julia Moskin

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Irish Poetry’
abstract: In honor of St. Patrick’s Day on Sunday, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Irish Poetry,” a poem by Billy Collins, with “Lost in Ireland” by Matt Gross.
lead_paragraph: In honor of St. Patrick’s Day on Sunday, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Irish Poetry,” a poem by Billy Collins, with “Lost in Ireland” by Matt Gross.

headline: Full Frontal: Send Us Photos of Front-Yard Finery
abstract: We want to put together a crowd-sourced gallery of the world’s most striking front yards, and we need your help.
lead_paragraph: Tattered couches. Elegant porch swings. Manicured lawns. Overgrown jungles. We want to put together a crowd-sourced gallery of the world’s most striking front yards, and we need your help. Submit a photo of the most interesting one you’ve seen. It could be yours. It could be your neighbor’s. (We won’t scold you for coveting.) If you send us the picture by March 22, your work could be featured in the magazine. (The last time around, we asked to see your rooftops. We will also run a larger selection of images online.

headline: Leading Off: The Patriot Highway
abstract: Wes Welker’s departure comes as little surprise to anyone who has watched the Patriots treat players like disposable napkins through the Bill Belichick era.
lead_paragraph: You do have to hand it to the Patriots. Because if there is going to be trend of heartlessly cutting the players your fans have grown attached to, well, the Patriots are going to be out in front of that. The most productive receiver in football wanted to come back for a reasonable salary? Gone. What, Tom Brady isn’t happy either? The all-world quarterback who just restructured his contract, essentially returning armored trucks full of money to his team so it could sign guys like Welker, his football soul mate? Pffffttt.

headline: A Diarist at War
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World Trade Center (NYC)']
abstract: The wartime writings of a Marine who invaded Iraq make up part of an exhibit at the Bronx Documentary Center.
lead_paragraph: With the invasion of Iraq just weeks away, Lt. Tim McLaughlin began a military ritual that dates back to Homer. He started a war diary. It was not a blog or e-mails sent from his waiting-to-invade base in the Kuwaiti desert, it was a plain notebook and pen with which he kept track of what was on his mind and what was in the cross hairs of his Abrams tank.

headline: Night of the Living Alesina, Continued
abstract: Flimflamming away.
lead_paragraph: So, while I was dealing with real life yesterday — sorry about the blog silence, but sometimes other things are more important — Paul Ryan weighed in. Now, Ryan’s status among the Very Serious People has taken a Very Steep Plunge; at this point Dana Milbank sounds a lot like, well, me back in 2010. (But that won’t stop the VSPs from considering me unsound; I was prematurely anti-flimflam, you know.) Still, it’s worth spending a few seconds parsing his current position.

headline: Papal Expectations
abstract: Representatives from the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops and DignityUSA, a Catholic group supporting G.L.B.T. rights, talk about what they want from Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: Representatives from the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops and DignityUSA, a Catholic group supporting G.L.B.T. rights, talk about what they want from Pope Francis.

headline: The Gun Report: March 14, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Gun advocates call it DGU. The initials stand for Defensive Gun Use. Gun proponents claim that such incidents – homeowners using guns to protect themselves against intruders – are extremely common, and that we don’t work hard enough to include them in the Gun Report. (A reminder: we compile this daily report by typing “shooting” into Google News and looking at gun injuries and deaths from the past 24 hours. We don’t “favor” any form of gun violence over any other form.) In any case, today we have three examples of DGU, along with one example of a 3-year-old shooting himself by accident. It is unclear whether the gun the child used was owned by someone in his home, but we have our suspicions.

headline: Next in Mobile Banking: Photo Bill Payments
abstract: Banks are now adding “photo bill payment” features to their mobile banking apps.
lead_paragraph: Now that many banking customers are used to depositing paper checks by snapping a photo with their cellphones, some banks are adding another feature: photo bill pay.

headline: The Inscrutable Brilliance of Anne Carson
abstract: Is she a poet? No one quite knows for sure.
lead_paragraph: Anne Carson was uncomfortable with the idea of a traditional profile: a journalist following her around for a few days, like a private detective, noting her outfits and mannerisms, shadowing her on errands, making lists of furniture and wall decorations and pets, quizzing her students, standing behind her holding his breath while she tried to write in her journal. Carson is a private person. She prefers to be alone. (When her husband is traveling, Carson will call and tell him, “I miss you, but I’m having a great time.”) Her book jackets have no author photo. Her back-flap biography — “Anne Carson was born in Canada and teaches ancient Greek for a living” — is so minimalist that it sounds like a parody of a back-flap biography. Carson told me that, years ago, she had a bad experience with the private-detective model of journalism and would prefer never to do it again. It took her publisher a couple of weeks to wear her down to the point that she would agree, even in a limited way, to participate in a profile. Carson later described those weeks as akin to water torture.

headline: Lost in Transition: Nuggets Pass the Knicks
abstract: Wednesday’s rout of the Knicks should leave little doubt that the Nuggets have become the superior team just two years after Carmelo Anthony forced a trade to New York.
lead_paragraph: DENVER

headline: Diskerud Stays in Norway but Still Has U.S. on His Mind
abstract: U.S. national team midfielder Mix Diskerud is hoping to get off to a strong start with Rosenborg when Norway’s Tippeligaen season opens this weekend.
lead_paragraph: When the 2013 Tippeligaen season opens this weekend in Norway, midfielder Mix Diskerud will be looking to help bring Rosenborg BK back to the elite level of European soccer. But he will also be looking to attract the attention of the United States national team coaching staff.

headline: The Wander Years
abstract: In her memoir, the daughter of the irascible New York City cook Kenny Shopsin chronicles a year filled with drama yet also strange moments of grace.
lead_paragraph: The irascible New York City cook Kenny Shopsin never met a curse word he didn’t love, and the tirades from his cramped restaurants are the stuff of legend. His daughter Tamara, a graphic designer and sometime chef in the family kitchens, has inherited his fondness for the profane but she’s also a romantic, and she shows these twin sides in her memoir, “Mumbai New York Scranton.” Through terse prose and charming illustrations, Tamara chronicles a year filled with drama yet also strange moments of grace, taking her from the rickshaw-clogged Indian city of Kochi to a hospital bed in New York to her unlikely second home in the Rust Belt: “I’m not sure what the people of Scranton do for a living. I know there is a ring-pop factory.” Scribner, $25.

headline: I Want My Music Videos: The Art Form Gets Its Own Museum Exhibition
abstract: “Spectacle: the Music Video,” celebrating the short films made for the music of artists like Devo, Madonna, Peter Gabriel, Beastie Boys and Bjork, will come to the Museum of the Moving Image on April 3.
lead_paragraph: Long before party-goers at New Jersey beaches and dudes who shock themselves with Taser guns were deemed worthy of their own television series, there was the music video: an art form so prolific and diverse that there were whole television channels that ran almost nothing but these short musical films, nearly 24 hours a day.

headline: The Distance Between the Parties’ Budgets
abstract: Budgets proposed by House Republicans and Senate Democrats for the 2014 fiscal year.
lead_paragraph: Budgets proposed by House Republicans and Senate Democrats for the 2014 fiscal year.

headline: Party-Line Vote in Senate Panel for Ban on Assault Weapons
abstract: A bill passed by the Senate Judiciary Committee, which would also limit the size of magazines, had tenuous prospects before the entire Senate and House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved a measure to reinstate a ban on assault weapons in the first major Congressional test of the issue since the law expired in 2004. But the ban remains unlikely to clear the full Senate.

headline: How Creative Is Your Doctor?
abstract: Medicine is a field with a strong history of creativity, but its daily practice feels less and less creative.
lead_paragraph: What are you doing creatively these days?

headline: India and Italy Share Blame in Marines Case, Analysts Claim
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Both countries made mistakes, political experts say.
lead_paragraph: India’s Supreme Court on Thursday ordered the Italian ambassador Daniele Mancini to remain in the country while India and Italy settle the dispute over the latter’s refusal to send back two Italian marines who face murder charges in India.

headline: Image of the Day: March 14
abstract: A watermelon being carved by a chef in New Delhi.

headline: Undercover Inquiry Leads Gun Shows to Tighten Checks
abstract: New York State’s attorney general brokered a deal on new rules after an operation in which agents were able to buy weapons without any screening.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — An overwhelming majority of gun show operators in New York State have agreed to new procedures to ensure that criminal and mental health background checks are conducted on buyers.

headline: Life of a Lizard Wrangler
abstract: When you’re on a scientific lizard hunt, it’s good luck to find the first specimen within minutes — unless that’s the last one you see for hours.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: Petition by Owner Prompts Recall of 183,000 Honda Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Brakes', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Carrie Carvalho of Arlington, Mass., filed a formal defect petition with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration requiring the agency to review her concern.
lead_paragraph: Honda’s recall of about 183,000 vehicles that might apply the brakes on their own was prompted by a woman who was frightened by having that problem in her own Honda and angry that there wasn’t a recall.

headline: Touring Holly Golightly’s New York
abstract: It’s not hard to follow in the footsteps of the “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” heroine.
lead_paragraph: It’s not hard to follow in the footsteps of the “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” heroine.

headline: Forever a Gamine at Tiffany’s
abstract: With the play “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” opening on Broadway, a new generation is being drawn to the allure and mysteries of Holly Golightly.
lead_paragraph: FIFTY-FIVE years after stepping off the pages of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” Holly Golightly is starring in a Broadway play. So does that make her an ingénue or a trouper?

headline: Stop Stealing From Our Kids
abstract: Forget the sequester. Washington’s focus should be a short-term growth strategy, coupled with long-term reform of entitlement programs that threaten the nation’s fiscal solvency.
lead_paragraph: The sequester’s arrival on March 1 has set off a raging debate over not only whether those immediate forced budget cuts are the right fiscal medicine, but also whether we should be trying to accomplish longer-term deficit reduction while the economy remains weak.

headline: Sheryl Sandberg: By the Book
abstract: The chief operating officer of Facebook and author of “Lean In” doesn’t like to use the iPad Kindle app on the elliptical. “When you get sweaty, you can’t turn the pages.”
lead_paragraph: The chief operating officer of Facebook and author of “Lean In” doesn’t like to use the iPad Kindle app on the elliptical. “When you get sweaty, you can’t turn the pages.”

headline: Sexual Harassment Lawsuit Filed Against Prominent Plaintiffs’ Lawyer
abstract: A former junior lawyer at the firm filed a lawsuit against Faruqi & Faruqi on Wednesday, accusing one of its most prominent partners of sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the law firm Faruqi & Faruqi has given corporate America big headaches, filing a steady stream of shareholder lawsuits against companies related to executive pay as well as mergers and acquisitions.

headline: The Case of My Missing Confidence
abstract: In the jewelry store where I worked, a robbery at knife-point left me feeling ashamed.
lead_paragraph: When I was 23, and living in San Francisco, I worked at a high-end design and jewelry store that not many people went into. One afternoon, as I was sitting at a desk with a phone that never seemed to ring, a man came in. He had a brown beard, a gas station cap and aviator sunglasses. A knapsack. He tripped over a stool, walked up to the desk, and pulled a nine-inch chef’s knife from the waistband of his pants. Later I would wonder about this. How had he been carrying it around, comfortably?

headline: At Least 18 Killed in Baghdad Attacks
abstract: The attacks in the Iraqi capital, apparently coordinated, involved car bombs outside three government ministries, a raid by gunmen and a suicide bombing.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Eighteen people were killed and 67 were wounded on Thursday when a suicide bomber blew himself up inside the Ministry of Justice compound, which he and other armed attackers had managed to infiltrate after a series of car bomb blasts nearby, the police said.

headline: Deprecating the New York State Legislature API
abstract: On April 15, 2013, we will deprecate our New York State Legislature API. We encourage you to switch to the Open States API.
lead_paragraph: On April 15, 2013, we will deprecate our New York State Legislature API. We’re doing this for several reasons, but what influenced our decision most is that there is a better source for this information: the Open States Project, run by the Sunlight Foundation. The Open States Project has an excellent API and also offers bulk downloads of legislative data for many states, including New York. If you’re interested in state legislative data, you can contribute.

headline: The Codes of War
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Both sides in the Civil War used ciphers and other forms of cryptography to send messages.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when I was working on my master’s degree in history at Louisiana Tech University, an acquaintance allowed me to use the Civil War diary of Joseph W. Ely as the basis for my thesis. Ely, a corporal in the 19th Michigan Infantry, was captured at Thompson’s Station, Tenn., and spent time in the infamous Libby Prison before being exchanged. He had his left ring finger shot off in the Atlanta Campaign and survived the March to the Sea and the Carolinas Campaign to return home and live well into the 20th century.

headline: Look of the Moment | Karolina Kurkova
abstract: The model steps out in a mod striped turtleneck and skirt.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Opposites Attract. A mod striped turtleneck balances out a flouncy mini. Booties with contrasting colored heels add a subdued edge.

headline: Jets Deconstruct as Ryan Looks On
abstract: With only four returning starters under contract, the Jets’ needs on offense and defense are plentiful, leaving Coach Rex Ryan in an unenviable position.
lead_paragraph: Pretend, for a second, that you’re Rex Ryan.

headline: A Catholic Comeback for Latin America?
abstract: Now under the first pope from Latin America, what can the Catholic Church do to compete with the appeal of evangelicalism there?

headline: SXSW Music: Punk’s Not Dead
keywords: ['Rock Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Punk lives at South by Southwest: across generations, genders, wardrobes and skill sets.
lead_paragraph: Punk lives at South by Southwest: across generations, genders, wardrobes and skill sets. As Dr. Seuss never wrote, you can do it in a suit, you can do it in a dress, you can play it quite precisely, you can play it like a mess. Much of my Wednesday at SXSW was a blast of punk old and new, a testament both to indie-rock’s archival pride and to the enduring alchemy of frustration and loud guitars.

headline: The Censors’ Salon
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A legendary literary café reopens in Lahore as ever more Pakistanis are silenced by restrictions on free speech.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pak Tea House, a café that was home to Pakistan’s intelligentsia for decades and an icon of resistance to authoritarian rule, reopened last week in Lahore after being closed for 13 years.

headline: Bugs
abstract: In the East Village, a tiny Japanese restaurant with a kooky spirit.
lead_paragraph: In the East Village, a tiny Japanese restaurant with a kooky spirit.

abstract: The Times’s Thomas Kaplan on gun show operators in New York State who have agreed to broader rules restricting firearms sales.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Thomas Kaplan on gun show operators in New York State who have agreed to broader rules restricting firearms sales.

headline: Keeping Score: Winning Is Just Another Constant for the Spurs
abstract: Tim Duncan’s statistics per 36 minutes underscore his remarkable consistency over the years, and win shares highlight Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili’s value to the Spurs.
lead_paragraph: The San Antonio Spurs will enter Thursday night’s matchup against the Dallas Mavericks one win short of 50 victories for the season. This is nothing new for the Spurs, who have won 50 or more games for the past 13 seasons, the longest such streak in N.B.A. history.

headline: Are You Sticking With Expensive Financing Too Long?
abstract: Lots of small-business owners are maintaining more expensive financing arrangements then they need.
lead_paragraph: I am currently involved in two loan transactions where the small-business owner stands to save substantial money by changing lenders. In both instances, these are relatively young companies that have been working with expensive private money lenders and factors, and their companies have grown to the point where they can now work with the asset-based lending departments at Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation-insured banks.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
abstract: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: 5:04 p.m. | Updated Anquan Boldin to the 49ers? Wes Welker to the Broncos? Darrelle Revis to…where, exactly? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers. Put your questions in the comments field and answers will appear on The Fifth Down next week.

headline: ‘Vocal Electrofolk’ in SoHo
abstract: Performers will bring a range of styles from two continents to the “Vocal Electrofolk: Africa to New York” concert.
lead_paragraph: We live increasingly, so the Miser is assured, in a remix culture, an age when new digital media and the Internet have conspired to collapse time and space. But doesn’t it seem as if most of this mashing up were done by machines, issued as recordings, and consumed in private? It’s a rare privilege to encounter performers musically skilled and culturally sympathetic enough to synthesize a global range of styles and periods before a live audience in real time and in an intimate space. “Vocal Electrofolk: Africa to New York,” a concert on Saturday night at the radio station WQXR’s Jerome L. Greene Space in the South Village, could be such an occasion.

headline: A Clash of Aesthetic Styles
abstract: Explore the updated campus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Explore the updated campus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: A Night That Veers to Eccentric
abstract: No entomological specimens appear on this Japanese restaurant’s menu. Dishes are homey, and the place is a little kooky.
lead_paragraph: THE MASHED POTATOES are cold, intentionally so, which doesn’t make them any less baffling. Beneath warm hunks of pork belly, tender from a long soak in soy, sake and dashi, you do not expect to find a spongy glacier.

headline: Security Forces Injure Citizens in Srinagar Attacks
abstract: Young men recuperating from bullet wounds blame paramilitary group for indiscriminate firing.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir— Four Kashmiri youths said they were brutally attacked by government security forces on Wednesday after militants started firing at a Central Reserve Police Force base.

headline: ‘Six Things: Sagmeister & Walsh’
abstract: Can we make ourselves happier? A New York-based designer explores the question in his show at the Jewish Museum.
lead_paragraph: For the past 10 years, the Austrian-born, New York-based designer Stefan Sagmeister has explored an appealing subject: happiness. Is it possible, he asks, to train our minds the same way we train our bodies? Can we make ourselves happier? His latest findings, the product of a collaboration with his recently acquired partner, Jessica Walsh, are presented in “Six Things: Sagmeister & Walsh,” an exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Jewish Museum and runs through Aug. 4.

headline: A New Big East Is a Better Big East
abstract: Instead of mourning the Big East, consider that it might be a better conference without the football schools.
lead_paragraph: After this week, the Big East will never be the same.

headline: House of Nerds: What If You Crossed a Political Convention and SxSW?
abstract: As soon as someone at SxSW found out I was from Washington D.C., the first question they invariably asked was, “Do you watch ‘House of Cards?’ ”
lead_paragraph: If someone melts down on CNN, is that just one small gaffe or the natural order of things? Ashley Parker and David Carr recap episode six of “House of Cards” through the prism of politics and media. In this step back, we end up detouring through the South-by-Southwest festival in Austin Tex., where yes, people were talking about Frank Underwood and Zoe Barnes in addition to Dennis Crowley and Elon Musk.

headline: Focusing on Violence Before It Happens
abstract: Mental health professionals, law enforcement agencies and schools collaborate in one of the nation’s most intensive efforts to identify potential perpetrators of violent crimes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the days after the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn., Tony Beliz and his staff at the county’s mental health department here made a series of calls.

headline: N.H.L. Realignment Receives Final Vote of Approval
abstract: The Red Wings and the Blue Jackets will move to the Eastern Conference next season, while the Jets will move to the Western Conference.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Governors on Thursday approved the N.H.L.’s long-awaited realignment plan, including its first new playoff format since 1994.

headline: Not Your Parents’ Mary Poppins at Art Fair in Maastricht
abstract: A work by the Portuguese artist Joana Vasconcelos is eye-catching and sets tongues wagging.
lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — As a flood of collectors began pouring into the cavernous convention center here for the invitation-only opening of the European Fine Art Fair on Thursday afternoon, the first artwork they encountered was a bit confounding. Called “Mary Poppins,’’ it is a monumental and wildly colorful hanging creature with elongated arms and a strangely organic body that hangs, chandelier-like, at the fair’s entrance.

headline: A Life in Music
abstract: A look at the career of Luciano Pavarotti.
lead_paragraph: A look at the career of Luciano Pavarotti.

headline: Is It Too Early for 2016 Polls?
abstract: Recent elections suggest that early presidential primary polls sometimes tell you more than you might expect.
lead_paragraph: There are more than 1,000 days before the 2016 Iowa caucuses, but several polls have already been released testing national support for prospective candidates for the Republican and Democratic nominations for president.

headline: Boehner Says Losses in Election Won’t Affect Budget Stance
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner suggested on Thursday that candidates and personalities – not Republican proposals on Medicare and spending cuts – contributed to party losses in November.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner said Thursday that election losses last November would not deter his party from pressing its vision of reducing the size of government and turning government health care programs largely over to the private sector — with no more tax increases.

headline: Red Carpet at the 2009 Grammy Awards
abstract: Celebrities arriving at the annual music awards ceremony in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities arriving at the annual music awards ceremony in Los Angeles.

headline: Some Primitive Birds Flew With 4 Wings, Study Says
abstract: Some bird species had a four-wing body plan before they lost hind-limb feathers and started to use those limbs to walk, scientists reported Thursday.
lead_paragraph: First, paleontologists spread the word that modern birds are actually living dinosaurs. Then came the news from China that some dinosaurs and related reptiles long ago seemed to be marvelous four-winged creatures, seemingly on standby at some runway for takeoff in flight as early birds.

headline: White House Tour Outrage
abstract: Not since Benghazi has the G.O.P. seemed this intent on second-guessing the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: Not since Benghazi — no, not since Fast and Furious has the G.O.P. seemed this intent on second-guessing the Obama administration. I refer, of course, to the matter of White House public tours.

headline: Critic of Japan’s Central Bank Is Now Its Leader
abstract: Haruhiko Kuroda, a Finance Ministry veteran and lover of Greek philosophy, has been charged with turning around an institution reviled for its monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the late 1990s, in the thick of the Asian financial crisis, a top Japanese Finance Ministry official turned to his protégé and found him engrossed not in policy documents, but in a chunky volume of the works of Aristotle.

headline: Disney to Overhaul to Its Retail Complex in Orlando — Again.
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: Disney quiety scrapped plans it announced in 2010 to redo a retail shopping area on Disney property. Now it has announced new plans, for a themed mall called Disney Springs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney blew its trumpets on Thursday and announced a splashy overhaul of its Downtown Disney retail complex in Orlando, Fla. The mall will double in size to 150 shops, restaurants and theaters and become Disney Springs.

headline: Attorney General Urges N.F.L. to Battle Discrimination
abstract: Eric Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, called for the N.F.L. to adopt a written policy prohibiting discrimination in any form.
lead_paragraph: After multiple reports by players interviewed at the N.F.L. combine indicated teams were trying to find out if prospective draft picks are gay, New York State attorney general Eric T. Schneiderman sent a letter to N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell urging the league to take a stronger stand against discrimination based on sexual orientation.

headline: Anschutz Calls Off Sale of Entertainment Arm
abstract: The investment company owned by the billionaire Philip Anschutz has decided to call off efforts to sell the Anschutz Entertainment Group, a sports and live entertainment juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: 5:47 p.m. | Updated The billionaire Philip F. Anschutz said on Thursday that he has called off efforts to sell the Anschutz Entertainment Group, a sports and live entertainment juggernaut that owns stakes in the Los Angeles Lakers and the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: In Modern Singapore, Vintage Clothing Stores
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: In a city that prizes the new, a small crop of stores has sprung up, filled with old dresses and accessories from Asia and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Past the coffee-shop uncles having a good smoke with their afternoon beers, past the giant table of pungent durians, past the provision shop shelves crammed with sponges, incense and other household necessities, my friend Jeanette and I strolled, keeping our eyes peeled for signs of fashion.

headline: Gagosian Gallery Settles Suit Filed Over Lichtenstein Painting
abstract: The Gagosian Gallery has settled a suit filed by a collector who said it sold her Roy Lichtenstein painting without permission.
lead_paragraph: A bitter lawsuit in which the gallery owner Larry Gagosian was accused of selling a prominent collector’s Roy Lichtenstein painting without her permission and making a huge commission on the deal has been settled.

headline: Dolphin’s Still in East River. What’s Up With That?
abstract: The dolphin, believed to be an offshore bottlenose, was first spotted in the river on Wednesday, and while marine mammal experts said they were concerned, they said it did not exhibit any health issues.
lead_paragraph: The dolphin that turned up Wednesday morning in the East River has yet to return to sea, and while rescue experts are growing more concerned, they say that the animal, while “on the thin side,” does not appear to have any obvious health issues and is still swimming well.

headline: Bankruptcy Lawyer Is Named to Manage an Ailing Detroit
abstract: Michigan’s governor recommended Kevyn D. Orr, a lawyer who worked on Chrysler’s bankruptcy, to be Detroit’s first emergency manager.
lead_paragraph: A veteran lawyer who once worked on Chrysler’s bankruptcy has been handed what may prove to be his toughest case yet: to bring Detroit back from the edge of financial collapse.

headline: ‘War Is for the Living’

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — France, joining Britain, is urging its European Union partners to meet this month and end an arms embargo on Syria, to allow weapons to be sent to the opposition there.

headline: Market Sweep | The Transition Tote
abstract: Handbags that are sure to last from spring to fall.
lead_paragraph: With spring bloom approaching, sling on one of these color-block totes in a mix of rose, black and cream that will last until the first signs of fall foliage.

headline: Access to the Yaeyamas
abstract: A new airport in Ishigaki Island in Japan widens the gateway for tourism to the Yaeyama Islands.
lead_paragraph: In March, an airport opened on Ishigaki Island in Japan, creating a bigger gateway for tourism to the tropical Yaeyama Islands in the southern Okinawa prefecture. The new airport, unlike the old one, can accommodate long-haul jets coming from more than 1,200 miles away in Tokyo. Now both Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways offer direct flights from Tokyo and other cities in Japan. From Ishigaki, travelers can snorkel among rare blue coral or catch a ferry to some of the nine other neighboring Yaeyamas, including Taketomi Island, home to traditional wooden houses.

headline: Billie Joe Armstrong to Write Songs for Yale Repertory Theater Show
abstract: “These Paper Bullets” is a rock ‘n’ roll updating of “Much Ado About Nothing.”
lead_paragraph: The Green Day frontman Billie Joe Armstrong will write new songs for Yale Repertory Theater’s production of “These Paper Bullets,” a rock ‘n’ roll updating of “Much Ado About Nothing” that will have its world premiere next March, the theater announced on Thursday.

abstract: Among other questions raised by proposals from Apple and Amazon for e-book resales is this one: When a resold digital book is just as good as a new one, what happens to prices?
lead_paragraph: There’s so much to love about e-books. They weigh nothing, they remember your place, you can make the type larger.

headline: Capturing Communities:  An Invitation to Photograph Your Hometown for the Lens Blog
abstract: The Lens blog invites people age 14 to 18 to submit photos for their “My Hometown” project by May 1. Learn more, and find related ideas for making this invitation a starting point for rich project-based learning.
lead_paragraph: Son, take a good look around. This is your hometown.

headline: Boston Schools Drop Last Remnant of Forced Busing
abstract: The Boston School Committee approved a plan designed to allow students to attend schools closer to home.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Boston School Committee, once synonymous with fierce resistance to racial integration, took a historic step Wednesday night and threw off the last remnants of a busing system first imposed in 1974 under a federal court desegregation order.

abstract: Amid the city’s chaos, visitors find charm and character.
lead_paragraph: Amid the city’s chaos, visitors find charm and character.

lead_paragraph: A slide show of images from the music festival, from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs to the Coo Coo Birds.

headline: A Dozen Recipes for Slawless Cabbage
abstract: This St. Patrick’s Day, cabbage deserves better than to be boiled within a clover’s width of its life.
lead_paragraph: This St. Patrick’s Day, cabbage deserves better than to be boiled within a clover’s width of its life.

headline: Why Do My Knees Hurt?
abstract: The first generation to exercise is getting an unwanted message from its knees: slow down. The problem may be your genes.
lead_paragraph: “Bend the knee,” a triumphant Queen Cersei tells Eddard Stark after outfoxing the nettlesome Northerner in “Game of Thrones.”

headline: The End of Google Reader Sends Internet Into an Uproar
abstract: After Google announced that it will be shutting down Google Reader on July 1, unhappy customers turned to the Internet to protest the closing.
lead_paragraph: 4:43 p.m. | Updated  to provide Google comment on why it shut down the service.

headline: Denver in Overdrive
abstract: The Denver Nuggets are really fast. How far will that take them?
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night in Denver the Knicks resembled the Eddy Curry era and the Nuggets won their 10th consecutive game in a typically swift fashion. Even when the Knicks scored, Ty Lawson and his athletic teammates repeatedly sprinted the other way for easy 2s. While Carmelo Anthony’s unsatisfying return to Denver made headlines, the game also served as another snapshot of ideal play under Coach George Karl.

headline: Keep Your Cabbage Vibrant
abstract: A dozen ways to make cabbage, and not a coleslaw in the bunch.
lead_paragraph: On St. Patrick’s Day you have a better shot at finding green beer than green cabbage, because most cabbage is served boiled to within a clover’s-width of its life, turning from lovely green to what you’d have to call gray. It’s easy to overlook mushy and soggy cabbage when it’s served next to a giant hunk of corned beef and on the tail end of a couple (or five) of those beers, but cabbage deserves better. Here are a dozen ways to cook the vegetable so that it retains its vibrancy, flavor, all-important texture and appealing color.

headline: Movie Review Aggregator to Shut Down
abstract: Movie Review Intelligence, which culled reviews from dozens of publications, did not have the support of large companies to help sustain the site, its editor said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Movie critics are about to lose one of their more avid online advocates.

headline: The Pay Quandary for Banks
abstract: As long as there is always one bank out there willing to bid high, existing pay structures will be hard to change, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Orcel’s signing-on package shows the scale of the pay pickle facing banks.

headline: Boston Phoenix to Cease Publication
abstract: The weekly newspaper failed to attract sufficient advertising to continue publishing.
lead_paragraph: 4:30 p.m. | Updated The Boston Phoenix, an alternative weekly newspaper known for its sharp political coverage and smart insight into culture and music, announced Thursday that it would fold.

headline: At a Cocktail Classic, High-Tech Drinks, Sherry and a ‘Tiki Safari’
abstract: Tickets go on sale Friday for the Manhattan Cocktail Classic.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the highlight of the Manhattan Cocktail Classic in May is a Friday night gala on four floors of the elegant New York Public Library. But for the true fan of cocktails and of how they’re made, the five-day event will feature a seminar on the techniques and technologies that produce the high-tech cocktails at Booker and Dax in the East Village. And there will be not one, but two panels on sherry-based cocktails. One will delve into sherry’s history as a mixer, and the other will look at the wine’s future in the mixology world.

headline: Aaron Swartz to Be Honored by Library Association
abstract: The Internet activist, who died in January, will be given the American Library Association’s James Madison Award on Friday as part of the group’s Freedom of Information Day event.
lead_paragraph: The Internet activist Aaron Swartz will be awarded the American Library Association’s James Madison Award on Friday as part of the group’s Freedom of Information Day event at the Newseum in Washington, D.C.

headline: Art and Architecture in Seoul, South Korea
abstract: Doryun Chong, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, on how to see art in Seoul and understand the history behind it.
lead_paragraph: The Seoul of today, said Doryun Chong, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, is far different from the one he left in 1992, the year South Korea elected its first civilian leader after three decades of military rule. Instead of student protesters and riot police, the city center now brims with museums, galleries and restaurants. And its transformation is still under way, said Mr. Chong, particularly where art and architecture are concerned: “All of those ‘what do you preserve, and what do you not?’ questions,” as he put it.

headline: A New G.O.P. Tack
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The Times’s Richard W. Stevenson on some party-evolving ideas being posed early at the Conservative Political Action Conference.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Richard W. Stevenson on some party-evolving ideas being posed early at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

headline: 36 Hours in Bangkok
abstract: This vibrant, sprawling city of contrasts is becoming easier to navigate, but the main reason visitors return is the people.
lead_paragraph: Bangkok has hit the sweet spot. It’s modern but far from antiseptic, filled with luxuries, pampering and great food — but still affordable. In the glare of the tropical sun it can be an ugly sprawl of tangled wires and broken pavement. Yet amid the chaos, visitors find charm and, above all, character. Somehow extremes coexist: skyscrapers and moldy tenements; high-end, cloth-napkin dining and tasty street food stalls; five-star hotels and fleabag guesthouses overflowing with backpackers; libidinous hedonism and Buddhist meditation. To travel across Bangkok is to see several worlds at once. Increasingly it is also convenient. The city of paralyzing traffic now has ample public transportation options ranging from boats to an expanding subway system. But if there is one reason visitors return again and again to Bangkok, it is the people. The anonymity and daily grind of urban life is slowly wearing away at the legendary Thai smile. Yet Bangkok remains one of the friendliest cities on the planet, still infused with the Thai village traditions of hospitality and graciousness.

headline: Sailing in the Mergui Archipelago off Myanmar’s Coast
abstract: A charter boat, “Sea Gipsy,” ferries travelers among the islands of the Mergui Archipelago or Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: A charter boat, “Sea Gipsy,” ferries travelers among the islands of the Mergui Archipelago or Myanmar.

headline: A Few Stray SXSW Thoughts
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Highlights from Darwin Deez, Emicida and the English singer and songwriter Charli XCX.
lead_paragraph: The best lost-love song with advanced-physics puns has to be “Redshift” by Darwin Deez, whose mission as a songwriter seems to involve merging the guitar-scrubbing light funk of the 1970’s with the musicianly twists–gnarled harmonies, leaping and twisting melodies–of Frank Zappa. “You loved all of my little quarks, so what went wrong?/Don’t superstring me along,” he lamented in a semblance of an R&B ballad. “Wave or particle, I can’t be both.”

headline: Sailing Among  Myanmar’s Islands of Mystery
abstract: Living aboard a 100-foot boat, exploring a mostly uninhabited region spread out over 250 miles in the Andaman Sea.
lead_paragraph: I arrived on a chaotic pier in the border town of Ranong, Thailand, feeling as if I was about to throw up as I watched three-story fishing boats chug by. I had persuaded my two younger brothers and eight girlfriends to fly across the world and pool a large chunk of money so we could charter a live-aboard boat. The plan was to sail for six days through the Mergui Archipelago, a chain of 800 islands off Myanmar’s coast that’s become the holy grail of sublime, empty beaches.

headline: Once Again, Lenders Ask Greece for Additional Cuts
abstract: International creditors  suspended their latest review of Greece’s economic overhaul program, demanding firmer details on cost cuts.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — It has been so elaborately repeated that it almost borders on ritual: Greece’s troika of lenders leaves Athens with disagreement over whether the country should receive billions of euros in fresh financial aid.

headline: Danish Imports
abstract: Han Kjobenhavn’s signature eyewear and work-wear-inspired clothing can now be found at their new flagship boutique in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: Not too far from fellow Danish designer Henrik Vibskov’s store, the team behind Han Kjobenhavn has opened their own flagship boutique in SoHo. The designers Tim Faith Hancock and Jannik Wikkelso Davidsen are the latest Copenhagen exports to find a foothold in New York, settling into a 850-square-foot space at 27 Prince Street.

headline: European Leaders Stick to Austerity Course
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Leaders from the European Union nations gathered in Brussels, jeered by protesters and shaken by rejection of their economic strategy by Italian voters.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Jeered by angry protesters demanding an end to austerity and shaken by a resounding rejection of their economic strategy from Italian voters, European leaders gathered for an economic summit meeting Thursday amid few signs that the bloc’s policies were healing the twin blights of rising unemployment and recession.

keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Credit and Debt', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: MADRID — The regional government of Galicia said Thursday that it stood ready to provide economic help to Pescanova, an insolvent fishing company that has become the latest big corporate casualty of the Spanish debt crisis.

abstract: Crown Books said Timothy Geithner, the former Treasury secretary under President Obama, will publish a book recounting the administration’s response to the global financial crisis of 2008 and the recession that followed.
lead_paragraph: Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary who managed the Obama administration’s response to the global financial crisis of 2008 and the recession that followed, will publish a book recounting that harrowing time, his publisher said Thursday.

headline: In the Men’s Game, a New Level of Noise
abstract: Men’s tennis players are turning up the volume in their matches, much to the chagrin of those who dislike the grunting that has become common in the women’s game.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Excessive grunting is often considered a problem only in women’s tennis, but high-volume ball-striking has become increasingly voluminous on the men’s side as well.

headline: Hoping to Save Bees, Europe to Vote on Pesticide Ban
abstract: European officials plan to vote on a proposal to sharply restrict the use of chemicals that have been implicated in the decline of global bee populations.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Will Brussels try to give bees a break?

headline: Breast-Feeding May Not Lead to Leaner Children
abstract: Breast-feeding confers benefits, but a lower risk for obesity may not be one of them.
lead_paragraph: Breast-feeding is widely encouraged for its many positive health effects, but the claim that it reduces the risk for childhood obesity may be going too far. A randomized trial has found that even long-term exclusive breast feeding has no effect on obesity or stature in childhood.

headline: Keeping a Closer Eye on Student Loan Servicing Firms
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Student Loans']
abstract: A proposed rule would give the federal government authority to oversee student loan servicing companies.
lead_paragraph: Companies that service student loans will get more scrutiny from the federal government under a new rule proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Hidden Numbers Make Banks Even Bigger
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: New accounting rules will force better disclosure of assets and liabilities of American banks that trade heavily in derivatives.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like a simple question. How big is that bank?

headline: At Vatican, the New Boss Is a Soccer Fan
abstract: The new pope, Francis, is a soccer fan and a supporter of the Argentine club San Lorenzo.
lead_paragraph: The election of Cardinal Jorge Maria Bergoglio as the new pope on Wednesday sparked immediate — and quite serious — analysis about the future of the Roman Catholic Church, and about what it would mean for the church’s profile in the Americas. But in other corners of the Internet, there were also some less serious discussions, too.

headline: Debauchery and the American Experience (Woo-Hoo!)
abstract: “Spring Breakers” delves into a deeply American topic: the pursuit of happiness taken to nihilistic extremes.
lead_paragraph: Just before the candy-colored apocalypse comes to Harmony Korine’s “Spring Breakers” you hear the peaceable murmurings of a beach, of lapping water, calling gulls and playing children. They’re nice, these sounds of summer, promises of carefree, youthful pursuits like building sand castles and shrieking at waves. The first image of what looks like a beach party keeps the happy vibe going. Dozens, hundreds of gyrating, dancing young women and men are basking in the honeyed light — as the beat goes on and the smiles sour into sneers — though it becomes evident that they’re also marinating in a tsunami of beer.

headline: Celebrating Voices as Instruments
abstract: The New York Philharmonic presented Bach’s Mass in B minor with New York Choral Artists on Wednesday, part of the Bach Variations festival.
lead_paragraph: On a video introducing the New York Philharmonic’s monthlong Bach Variations festival, Alan Gilbert, the orchestra’s music director, describes himself as not at all a Bach specialist. That is exactly why it was a fresh idea for Mr. Gilbert to oversee this initiative. The major offering came on Wednesday night, when he conducted the first of four performances of Bach’s Mass in B minor at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Fed Rebukes Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase Over Capital Plans
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Federal Reserve said Goldman and JPMorgan would need to resubmit their proposals to pay out billions of dollars to shareholders, citing weaknesses in their capital plans.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, the Wall Street giants that emerged from the financial crisis in a position of strength, are now facing questions about their ability to withstand future market shocks.

headline: Don’t Lean In: Do We Want Mothers to Work Part-Time?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours']
abstract: When Pew researchers ask if survey respondents think it’s best for children if mothers work full-time, part-time, or not at all, they’re not asking the right question.

headline: Serenity of a War Strategist
abstract: In “The World According to Dick Cheney,” on Showtime, the former vice president defends his ardent push to go to war against Iraq but faces few tough follow-up questions.
lead_paragraph: Dick Cheney was often referred to as the Darth Vader of the Bush administration.

headline: Bride of Hades
abstract: In Joyce Carol Oates’s new novel, a curse infects Princeton, N.J., beginning in 1905 when a new bride is abducted by a demon in front of a church congregation.
lead_paragraph: Some novels are almost impossible to review, either because they’re deeply ambiguous or because they contain big surprises the reviewer doesn’t wish to give away. In the case of “The Accursed,” both strictures apply. What I wish I could say is simply this: “Joyce Carol Oates has written what may be the world’s first postmodern Gothic novel: E. L. Doctorow’s ‘Ragtime’ set in Dracula’s castle. It’s dense, challenging, problematic, horrifying, funny, prolix and full of crazy people. You should read it. I wish I could tell you more.”

headline: 92nd Street Y to Leave Its Downtown Space
abstract: 92YTribeca opened in October 2008 but is no longer seen as “critical to our mission.”
lead_paragraph: The 92nd Street Y will leave its space at 200 Hudson Street, known as 92YTribeca, because “a second, physical location is not critical to our mission,” according to a letter sent Thursday afternoon to the workers at both sites. The decision was made by the 92nd Street Y board Wednesday night. The 92nd Street Y expects to be out of the Hudson Street space sometime this summer, according to the letter signed by Sol Adler, the Y’s executive director.

headline: Asked & Answered | Allison Williams
abstract: We caught up with one of the stars from HBO’s hit series “Girls” for an exclusive peek at her own beauty look book.
lead_paragraph: Allison Williams, from HBO’s hit series “Girls,” has got that whole enviable Brooke Shields beauty thing going on. As the polished but somewhat angst-ridden Marnie on the show, her character is a little more disheveled. We caught up with Williams in New York for an exclusive peek at her own beauty look book. The season finale of “Girls” is this Sunday.

headline: JPMorgan Faulted on Controls and Disclosure in Trading Loss
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase ignored internal controls and manipulated documents, as the nation’s biggest bank racked up trading losses last year, Senate investigators say.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s biggest bank, ignored internal controls and manipulated documents as it racked up trading losses last year, while its influential chief executive, Jamie Dimon, briefly withheld some information from regulators, a new Senate report says.

headline: One Start Gee Would Like to Forget
abstract: Dillon Gee’s third start of spring training was one he would like to erase from his memory.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Dillon Gee was asked after his start Thursday about whether he could learn anything from it.

headline: An Argentine Pope
abstract: The Times's Laurie Goodstein reports from Vatican City, where Latin American Catholics in the square were elated to see a new church leader from the Americas.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Laurie Goodstein reports from Vatican City, where Latin American Catholics in the square were elated to see a new church leader from the Americas.

headline: Studies in Human Frustration
abstract: Photos from "Beckett Shorts," starring Mikhail Baryshnikov.
lead_paragraph: Photos from "Beckett Shorts," starring Mikhail Baryshnikov.

headline: Taking Up Paintbrushes, Not Arms
abstract: To demonstrate loyalty in the face of the Ming defeat, some 17th-century Chinese artists chose to signal their resistance through paintings, which are now on display in “The Artful Recluse” at Asia Society.
lead_paragraph: The early spring of 1644 must have felt like the end of the world in China. People were already rattled by portents and signs. Hellishly hot summers, winters too cold to bear; drought, followed by floods, followed by drought. As peasants starved, the Ming government gouged them for taxes. Rumor had it that foreigners, Manchus from the northern steppes, were poised for a kill.

headline: Theater Talkback: How to Offend a White Person
abstract: Greg Kalleres, whose play “Honky” opened at Urban Stages on March 14, wonders what word best pushes white people’s buttons.
lead_paragraph: For years people have tried to find a slur for white Americans as evocative and offensive as the N-word is for African-Americans. And, frankly, there aren’t many classics to choose from. Honky, whitey, cracker, hillbilly: they all fall flat.

headline: She Cheats, He Knows, Life Goes On
abstract: The characters in Jamie Quatro’s collection of short stories, “I Want to Show You More,” are preoccupied with five things: sex, running, God, illness and infidelity.
lead_paragraph: The woman on the (terrible) dust jacket of Jamie Quatro’s first book, a collection of stories called “I Want to Show You More,” is wearing a dress made out of tin foil, as if she wanted to be baked like a sweet potato — or wants to protect her heart from electromagnetic fields or meddling influence of any sort.

headline: Walking the Walk, in a Rhapsodic New York Ballet
abstract: “Street,” a hypnotic video by the artist James Nares, is accompanied by artworks on the theme of urban theater in an exhibition at the Met.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that you find a gallery filled with people transfixed by a contemporary video at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But that’s what I discovered at “Street,” an exhibition of works from the museum’s collection centered on a ravishing video projection of that title by the artist James Nares, who also organized the show as a guest curator.

headline: Percussive Steps From Streets and Mines
abstract: The Via Katlehong dance troupe from South Africa performs “Katlehong Cabaret” at Montclair State University.
lead_paragraph: Striking miners killed by the police. High-profile murder and rape. South Africa has been much in the news in the last few weeks, for particularly distressing reasons. So it’s perhaps useful to have a counterbalance in the shape of Via Katlehong, the vibrant South African dance troupe that returns Friday night, with “Katlehong Cabaret,” to the Peak Performances series at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University in New Jersey, where it was first seen in 2009.

headline: The Things Bankers Say, the London Whale Edition
abstract: Buried with the 300-plus report by the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations are choice e-mails, instant messages and phone recordings that demonstrate how JPMorgan Chase traders hid “substantial losses for months at a time.”
lead_paragraph: Another Wall Street investigation. Another trove of e-mails, instant messages and telephone conversations capturing executives, bankers and traders discussing their compromising positions.

headline: N.F.L. Ponders Changing the Tuck Rule
abstract: The controversial rule that helped launch the New England Patriots’ dynasty and has haunted the Oakland Raiders for nearly a dozen years may finally be struck down.
lead_paragraph: The controversial rule that helped launch the New England Patriots’ dynasty and has haunted the Oakland Raiders for nearly a dozen years may finally be struck down.

headline: U.C.L.A. Needs Rally to Get Past Arizona State
abstract: Travis Wear’s late jumpers shunted Arizona State’s upset bid, and top-seeded and 21st-ranked U.C.L.A. escaped with a victory in a Pac-12 tournament quarterfinal in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS – U.C.L.A., virtually unrecognizable in new tournament uniforms with gray-camouflage shorts and shirt sleeves, barely looked itself for most of the Bruins’ Pac-12 quarterfinal game with ninth-seeded Arizona State.

headline: CERN Physicists See Higgs Boson in New Particle
keywords: ['Higgs Boson', 'Physics', 'Large Hadron Collider', 'Particle Accelerators', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Scientists at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, say they need more data to understand how the particle works and what it means for the universe.
lead_paragraph: Physicists at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, said Thursday that the new particle discovered with enormous fanfare last summer definitely looks like a Higgs boson, the particle famously predicted by Peter Higgs and others to imbue elementary particles with mass. But they said they still needed more data to understand how it works and what it means for the universe.

headline: Koch’s Touch of the Irish
abstract: The sweater Edward I. Koch traditionally wore in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade on Fifth Avenue wasn’t green, but it was direct from County Clare.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, since he was a city councilman, Edward I. Koch proudly marched in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade, typically in his Aran Islands fisherman’s sweater. Now, the story can be told of how that tradition began.

headline: Rooted in Ancient Cultures
abstract: A look at exhibitions across the city during Asia Week New York.
lead_paragraph: A look at exhibitions across the city during Asia Week New York.

headline: Awash in a Cultural Deluge
abstract: “The Hugo Boss Prize 2012: Danh Vo I M U U R 2” at the Guggenheim Museum is a homage to an artist’s ambiguous cultural explorations.
lead_paragraph: The exhibition as cornucopia — as an overwhelming array of found objects selected and arranged by an artist — has become something of a trend. You could call it the return of the repressed: a way for stringent conceptually motivated sensibilities to re-engage with materials and objects.

headline: Everyday Life, Washed in the Colors of Memory
abstract: “From Up on Poppy Hill” was written by Hayao Miyazaki, the renowned Japanese animator, and directed by his son Goro.
lead_paragraph: “From Up on Poppy Hill” takes a gentle, nostalgic look at Japan in 1963, from the perspective of a schoolgirl who lives in the Yokohama neighborhood evoked in the title. Though it was written and “planned” by Hayao Miyazaki, perhaps the greatest living fantasist in world cinema (and directed by his son Goro), this movie, based on a manga by Chizuru Takahashi and Tetsuro Sayama, is a lovely example of the strong realist tendency in Japanese animation. Its visual magic lies in painterly compositions of foliage, clouds, architecture and water, and its emotional impact comes from the way everyday life is washed in the colors of memory.

headline: Across a Sprawling Continent, Across the Centuries
abstract: More than 40 art shows presented in tandem with Asia Week New York capture the sweep of that continent’s many cultures and their histories.
lead_paragraph: The annual Asia Week New York has the festive hum of a big art fair, but is somewhat more challenging to navigate: its 40-plus shows take place at galleries all over the Upper East Side, and there’s often enough in a single exhibition to hold your attention for hours. Home in on a particular region or bring a stopwatch and make it a cross-continent marathon; the choice is yours.

headline: Let’s Be Friends and Showstoppers
abstract: A legend and her charming squire: that would describe Liza Minnelli and Alan Cumming on Wednesday evening at Town Hall.
lead_paragraph: A legend and her charming squire: that would describe Liza Minnelli and Alan Cumming on Wednesday evening at Town Hall in the first part of a two-evening celebration of Ms. Minnelli’s 67th birthday (last Tuesday).

headline: Life-Altering Plea for Help
abstract: In “The Call,” a 911 operator takes a life-altering call from a teenage girl who has just been abducted.
lead_paragraph: An effectively creepy thriller about a 911 operator and a young miss in peril, “The Call” is a model of low-budget filmmaking. Well, as low as anything starring Halle Berry goes. It’s probable that Ms. Berry was the priciest item in the budget, followed by the movie’s one other conspicuous expenditure, a sprawling 911 dispatch center called the hive. Buzzing with the trills of incoming calls and the hum of reassuring voices, the hive is where every rote greeting — “911, what is your emergency?” — becomes the opening line in a never-ending procession of melodramas, comedies, dramas, tragedies and horror stories like the one that puts the chill in this no-frills diversion.

headline: A Success in HD, but at What Cost?
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s chief, Peter Gelb, is softening his assessment of the house’s HD broadcasts as cannibalizing ticket sales. But there are reasons to think he was right.
lead_paragraph: Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, now says that it was not the most fortunate choice of words when he recently attributed a decline in attendance at the house to the “cannibalization” of the audience by the company’s high-definition broadcasts.

headline: Ticking Bomb in Their Friendship
abstract: In “Ginger & Rosa,” a coming-of-age story directed by Sally Potter, the close friendship of two teenagers comes undone with an act of treachery.
lead_paragraph: Ginger and Rosa are best friends. Vanguard baby boomers born in adjacent London hospital beds in 1945, they are teenagers in 1962, when most of Sally Potter’s ardent and intelligent film about the girls takes place. The air around them is charged with anxiety — about the threat of nuclear war, mostly — intellectual restlessness and sexual curiosity. Perhaps it always is that way for 17-year-olds, but every generation acts out its own particular pageant of rage, revolt and disillusionment.

headline: Thomson Reuters Editor Is Charged in Hacking of News Site
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Matthew Keys, a 26-year-old social media editor, was charged with assisting the hacking collective Anonymous in an attack on The Los Angeles Times Web site.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m. | Updated Matthew Keys, a 26-year-old deputy social media editor at Thomson Reuters, has been charged with assisting the hacking collective Anonymous in an attack on the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, the Justice Department said Thursday.

headline: SXSW Music: Dave Grohl Urges Musicians to Discover ‘Your Voice’
keywords: ['Rock Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The Foo Fighters frontman made an impassioned plea in his 45-minute keynote address.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Recounting his rise from obscure punk rocker to mainstream rock star, Dave Grohl gave a impassioned defense of the importance of artistic freedom and a do-it-yourself ethic in keeping popular music vibrant, as he delivered the keynote address at the South by Southwest Music Festival on Thursday.

headline: Live Nation Names Gregory B. Maffei Chairman
abstract: Mr. Maffei replaces Irving Azoff, the longtime music executive who helped see Live Nation through its merger with Ticketmaster in 2010, and who left at the end of last year.
lead_paragraph: Live Nation Entertainment, the concert and ticketing giant, named Gregory B. Maffei its new chairman on Thursday, the latest in a series of shifts in corporate allegiances for the company.

abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Movies

headline: Sleepwalking Magician Pulls a New Self Out of a Hat
abstract: In “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone,” Steve Carell is a successful Las Vegas magician who faces a challenge from a take-no-prisoners newcomer played by Jim Carrey.
lead_paragraph: Is that Steve Carell or Will Ferrell? While watching “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone” you may be forgiven for confusing the two, since Mr. Carell’s title character, a vainglorious Las Vegas magician, is drawn straight from the Will Ferrell playbook.

headline: Fast Friends, With Man in Middle
abstract: “If I Were You” is the story of a boozy middle-aged marketing executive who impulsively bonds with her husband’s girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: Buried in the bloat of Joan Carr-Wiggin’s interminable “If I Were You” are the seeds of what might have been a lean, snappy farce about duplicitous, adulterous games. The story of Madelyn (Marcia Gay Harden), a boozy middle-aged marketing executive who impulsively bonds with her husband’s girlfriend, has its goofy moments but lacks focus, precision and structure. The pace is sluggish and the humor spotty. Just when you think it might settle into a comfortable rhythm, it throws in unnecessary characters and takes a mystifying tangent.

abstract: Picking up on the signs of a relationship after being oblivious for so long.
lead_paragraph: If you had asked me several months ago what I thought about marriage, I would have said, “I don’t think about marriage.”

lead_paragraph: GAZA — “Hey, collaborator! Stop and think! Isn’t it time to get out of the swamp?”

abstract: Some of basketball’s top prospects give their take on the players they’ve competed with and against.
lead_paragraph: Some of basketball’s top prospects give their take on the players they’ve competed with and against.
