abstract: With the realignment of the Big East Conference, the annual tournament at Madison Square Garden will never be the same, or as good, says William C. Rhoden.
lead_paragraph: With the realignment of the Big East Conference, the annual tournament at Madison Square Garden will never be the same, or as good, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: The End of the Big East as We Know It
abstract: With the realignment of the Big East Conference, the annual tournament at Madison Square Garden will never be the same, or as good.
lead_paragraph: With the realignment of the Big East Conference, the annual tournament at Madison Square Garden will never be the same, or as good.

headline: British Comedian Confronts Russian Lawmaker on ‘Gay Propaganda’ Ban
abstract: The British comedian Stephen Fry brought a sharp tongue and a Twitter following of millions when he confronted a Russian lawmaker who drafted the ban on “homosexual propaganda” in St. Petersburg.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The British comedian and author Stephen Fry brought a sharp tongue and a Twitter following of millions on Thursday when he confronted a Russian lawmaker who drafted the ban on “homosexual propaganda,” in the city of St. Petersburg.

headline: Hearst Executive Tied to Improper Texting Is Said to Resign
abstract: Scott Sassa, who was tied this week to a scandal involving improper text messages, informed executives at several of the entertainment divisions affiliated with Hearst that he had resigned.
lead_paragraph: Executives who worked with Scott Sassa, the president of Hearst Entertainment, confirmed on Thursday that he had left the company.

headline: On Location, Location, Location
abstract: Paul Kostick spends his days hunting for real estate that’s just right for film and video productions. View a gallery of advertisements for which he scouted locations and stories from the sets.
lead_paragraph: Paul Kostick spends his days hunting for real estate that’s just right for film and video productions. View a gallery of advertisements for which he scouted locations and stories from the sets.

headline: When This Stranger Knocks, It’s Thrilling
abstract: Paul Kostick, a location scout for film and advertising shoots, has seen the inside of more of the city’s homes than most New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Paul Kostick, a New Yorker by way of Colorado (where he studied acting and directing) and Seattle (where he began his career in 1992 working for Tom Hanks) has seen the inside of more of the city’s homes than most New Yorkers.

headline: Running Government Like A Business or Family
abstract: People borrow? Who knew?
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent a lot of time trying to knock down the bad analogy between governments and individuals, and the line that the government should act like an individual family or business, and cut back when times are tough. The key point is realizing interdependence: your spending is my income, my spending is your income, and if we all try to slash spending at the same time the result is a depression. Somebody needs to step up and spend when others won’t — and the government can and should be that somebody.

headline: Use Your Words
abstract: Addressing teachable moments, smelly feet, parents in the dark and a roommate who shops at secondhand stores.
lead_paragraph: While I was driving a group of elementary school students on a field trip, one of my child’s classmates commented on a homeless person we saw (“I hate homeless people”) and a wheelchair-bound person (“He’s icky”). Other students responded by telling her “That’s not nice,” which led me to a teachable moment about compassion. But should I share this girl’s comments with her parents, whom I do not know? If our roles were reversed, I would want to know.

headline: Top of Their Game
abstract: The Negro leagues made a lasting mark on baseball in the New York region.
lead_paragraph: The Negro leagues made a lasting mark on baseball in the New York region.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Swarming Robots and Competing Taxis
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include an essay on the way we sign e-mails, an experiment using robots made from toothbrushes and an advice story from the chief of an online real estate company.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Fortunately for Yankees, This One Didn’t Count
abstract: The Yankees, who brought their C team, were drubbed by the Blue Jays, the off-season champions in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — The off-season champions in the American League East flexed their new-found muscles Thursday, hammering the Yankees, 17-5. Although the victory was earned by one of the Toronto Blue Jays’ key winter acquisitions, the starting pitcher Josh Johnson, it was still far too early to regard the game as a harbinger of change in what has traditionally been baseball’s toughest division.

headline: Champions League Power Rankings
abstract: Power rankings of the teams left in the Champions League before Friday’s draw in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: The draw for the quarterfinals of the Champions League will be held Friday in Switzerland (7 a.m. Eastern, Fox Soccer), but why not pause first and see where we stand.

headline: Readers Consider the Selection of a New Pope
abstract: After Pope Francis was introduced in Vatican City, The Times asked readers to describe how they thought his papacy would affect the future of the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: After Pope Francis was introduced in Vatican City, The Times asked readers to describe how they thought his papacy would affect the future of the Catholic Church.

headline: A Lifeline for Children of the Street
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The 1892 Sullivan Street Industrial School awaits a new mission.
lead_paragraph: In the 1880s and 1890s the Children’s Aid Society built a dozen distinctive Victorian Gothic lodging houses and vocational schools, advancing its mission of rescuing young people from the evils of 19th-century New York. All were on the same model, red-brick Victorians with towers and gables, and six remain.

headline: A Few Signs of Spring Downtown
abstract: Two new condos report robust sales, just months after a storm left the area in tatters.
lead_paragraph: Late last year brokers fretted that Hurricane Sandy would stigmatize downtown Manhattan. Flood zones and generators were the talk of the town after the superstorm knocked out power to most of the island below Midtown, leaving many residents to stumble in the dark looking for water and a place to charge their cellphones.

headline: NBC Uses Comedy to Address Its ‘Today’ Problem
abstract: At NBCUniversal’s annual presentation to advertisers, Matt Lauer and Savannah Guthrie made a few jokes about the show’s weakened ratings.
lead_paragraph: NBC NEWS has been without a president for more than a month. And the future of “Today,” its most highly visible — and profitable — show, has been the subject of conjecture after a ratings decline put it second to its longtime competitor, “Good Morning America.”

headline: Saudi Human Rights Record Comes Under New Scrutiny
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s human rights record came under scrutiny again this week after seven men were publicly executed and a court sentenced two prominent civil rights activists to jail.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s human rights record came under scrutiny again this week after seven men were publicly executed and a court sentenced two prominent civil rights activists to jail.

headline: Music Meets the Egg
abstract: A look at the New York Philharmonic’s debut at the Egg, otherwise known as the National Center for the Performing Arts, in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: A look at the New York Philharmonic’s debut at the Egg, otherwise known as the National Center for the Performing Arts, in Beijing.

headline: Inside North Korea
abstract: Chang W. Lee, a photographer for The Times, got a rare outsider’s glimpse of North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Chang W. Lee, a photographer for The Times, got a rare outsider’s glimpse of North Korea.

headline: The Philharmonic in Pyongyang
abstract: Images from the New York Philharmonic’s arrival and scenes from the streets of Pyongyang and the performance at the Mansudae Art Theater.
lead_paragraph: Images from the New York Philharmonic’s arrival and scenes from the streets of Pyongyang and the performance at the Mansudae Art Theater.

headline: Onstage All of His Life, but Aching to Be Seen
abstract: “Reality,” a film by Matteo Garrone, follows a fishmonger as he attempts to land a place on Italy’s version of “Big Brother.”
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to pinpoint when Luciano, the gregarious, generous-hearted fishmonger at the center of the Italian movie “Reality,” decides he wants to be a star. Specifically, what Luciano wants — what his wife (at first), children, his hectoring aunt, yammering cousins, many neighbors and seemingly most of his small town want — is that he be chosen to appear on a new season of the reality television show “Grande Fratello,” the Italian version of “Big Brother.” And why not? When everyone gathers to watch the show, they glow in its reflected light.

headline: A New Sound
abstract: Photos from Elevator Repair Service’s stage adaptation of “The Sound and the Fury.”
lead_paragraph: Photos from Elevator Repair Service’s stage adaptation of “The Sound and the Fury.”

headline: Theater’s Everyman
abstract: A look at performances by actor Bill Camp.
lead_paragraph: A look at performances by actor Bill Camp.

headline: Saving on Title Insurance
abstract: A debate about whether title insurance premiums are too high and competition too constrained.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers don’t often pay much attention to the title insurance required by their mortgage lender — until they see the sizable charge for it on their list of closing costs.

headline: Samsung Introduces New Galaxy Phone
abstract: Increasing the stakes in the smartphone battle, the South Korean manufacturer showed off the Galaxy S IV, the latest version of its flagship device.
lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics is the world leader in smartphone sales, besting Apple in many countries. Now Samsung of South Korea is stepping up its challenge to Apple, bringing the battle to its rival’s home turf.

headline: Seeking Your Questions on Paying for College
abstract: Laura Perna, a researcher in college finance and affordability, answers select reader questions about paying for college.
lead_paragraph: If you are a college-bound senior who has started receiving financial aid award letters, or a high school junior who is beginning to consider your college options more seriously, you have no doubt tried to answer two essential questions: How much will college cost, and what is the best way to pay for it?

headline: Suspending More Than Disbelief
abstract: Kirsten Dunst and Jim Sturgess are lovers kept apart by physics, among other forces, in a new release with a science-fiction twist.
lead_paragraph: Eden (Kirsten Dunst) and Adam (Jim Sturgess), the star-crossed lovers in the murky science-fiction romance “Upside Down,” occupy different worlds. Eden lives Up Top on a planet of cold corporate affluence. Adam’s planet, Down Below, is a grungy wasteland that suggests Union Square after an earthquake. The planets are practically within spitting distance, yet despite that proximity, it is almost impossible to get from one to the other.

headline: F.B.I. Dog Is Killed in Raid on Hideaway
abstract: Ape, a Czech German Shepherd equipped with a camera, was shot in the chest just as he breached the doorway of an abandoned bar where Kurt R. Myers was hiding.
lead_paragraph: The gunman, who was suspected of already killing four people and shooting at police officers, was holed up inside an abandoned bar in upstate New York.

headline: A Tide of Death, but This Time Food Supply Is Safe
keywords: ['Pigs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Rivers', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Livestock Diseases', 'Water', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: Hard as it may be to believe, the recent discovery of thousands of pig carcasses floating in a Shanghai river may represent a step forward in Chinese public health.
lead_paragraph: JIAXING, China — Hard as it may be to believe, the recent discovery of thousands of pig carcasses floating in a river that supplies drinking water to Shanghai may represent an encouraging step forward in Chinese public health.

headline: A Home With a Little Less Waiting
abstract: Patricia Roman and William Soto wanted to buy an apartment in Brooklyn, but that’s not where they wound up.
lead_paragraph: At first, Patricia Roman and William Soto expected to buy a home in southern Brooklyn. That’s where, for $1,500 a month, they rented a two-bedroom apartment across from Coney Island Hospital, where both work.

headline: Cyberattacks a Topic in Obama Call With New Chinese President
abstract: President Obama used a congratulatory call with China’s new president to discuss the loss of American intellectual property from cyberattacks.
lead_paragraph: Cyberthreats featured prominently in President Obama’s congratulatory call to the new Chinese president, Xi Jinping, on Thursday.

headline: Revisiting Stonewall, 1969, Onstage
abstract: “Hit the Wall,” Ike Holter’s latest play, relives the Stonewall riots in the Lower Manhattan of 1969.
lead_paragraph: The words “I was there,” intoned repeatedly by the characters in “Hit the Wall,” give Ike Holter’s play about the 1969 Stonewall riots the self-consecrated holiness of solemn testimony. But the crucial refrain is: “The reports of what happened next are not exactly clear.”

headline: Finding a Partner for Children’s Health in Centralized Care
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Children and Childhood', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Founders of a pilot program to aid medically needy children in Austin, Tex., hope that data will show that centralized coordination improves the quality of health care while cutting costs.
lead_paragraph: It takes a team of medical specialists to care for Anna Barkhuizen, a 9-year-old with epilepsy, cerebral palsy and significant developmental delays. Her mother, Rebecca, recalls waiting for hours in exam rooms and leaving before seeing the doctor, because Anna had grown too impatient.

headline: Democrats Aim to Turn Texas Shade of Blue
abstract: Sick of Republican dominance, Democrats are trying to get off the ground, with efforts like Battleground Texas, started by operatives from the Obama campaign.
lead_paragraph: Here is a quick measure of the political climate in Texas, from one of the leaders of a group that wants to make this a competitive state: Texas Democrats don’t let friends run for statewide office.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: A G.O.P. Senator Who Is Unafraid to Suggest Raising Taxes
abstract: State Senator Kevin Eltife says what he thinks, even if his fellow Texas Republicans don’t agree, and that includes his proposals to raise some taxes to help reduce bond debt.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Eltife did not plan to make news last month while speaking at a transportation conference in Austin. Participating in a legislative panel, Mr. Eltife, a Republican state senator from Tyler, tried to explain how he would revamp the way Texas financed road construction. Taking on more state debt is not the answer, he said.

headline: Burmese Laureate Heckled Over Backing Copper Mine
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The hostile reception by farmers for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi underscores the rockiness of her transition from international symbol to elected official.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Hundreds of angry farmers heckled and walked out on Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese politician and Nobel laureate, during a visit on Thursday to villages in central Myanmar that might be displaced by a copper mine.

headline: Alabama: Governor Signs Law Granting Private School Tax Credits
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Gov. Robert Bentley signed a law on Thursday granting tax credits to families who want to send their children to private schools or better-performing public schools.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Robert Bentley signed a law on Thursday granting tax credits to families who want to send their children to private schools or better-performing public schools. The act was passed amid heated controversy, not only about its substance, but about the way it was passed: A conference committee that was to reconcile versions of a school-related bill already passed by the House and Senate added the tax credit, and more than tripled the original bill’s length. The new version was then voted on quickly by both houses. Republican leaders said the maneuver was necessary for passage, but Democrats were left fuming. A circuit court initially blocked the bill from going forward out of the House, but the State Supreme Court lifted that hold on Wednesday. The legal fight is far from over, however, and even now at least one Republican legislator has raised questions about the bill’s passage.

headline: Dueling Court Filings by ‘Rebecca’ Combatants Reveal Backstage Drama
abstract: After the former publicist for the troubled musical seeks dismissal of a lawsuit against him, the producers respond with details of phony emails sent to warn a potential investor.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway publicist who used to represent the troubled musical “Rebecca” has asked a State Supreme Court judge to dismiss a lawsuit that accuses him of torpedoing the show last fall, arguing that he simply warned a potential investor that its producers had fallen prey to a fraud scheme.

headline: Virginia: Report by Professors Faults University in Firing of President
abstract: Ousting the University of Virginia president last year was “a failure of judgment and, alas, of common sense,” the American Association of University Professors said in a scathing report.
lead_paragraph: Ousting the University of Virginia president last year was “a failure of judgment and, alas, of common sense,” the American Association of University Professors said in a scathing report released Thursday, adding that the episode looked like “a crude exercise of naked power.” Amid a storm of protest, the Board of Visitors reinstated President Teresa A. Sullivan last June, 16 days after forcing her out. The rector, or board chief, Helen E. Dragas, orchestrated the removal, offering what the professors’ group called vague, unfounded reasons. Neither woman would comment.

headline: Jack Curran, a Mentor in Two Sports, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Curran coached generations of baseball and basketball players for 55 years at Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens, N.Y., winning more than 2,600 games.
lead_paragraph: Jack Curran, who coached generations of baseball and basketball players for 55 years at Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens, winning more than 2,600 games, certainly among the most victories that any scholastic coach anywhere has compiled, died late Wednesday or early Thursday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: Lustful Pursuit of Sensory Overload
abstract: “Vanishing Waves,” a psychedelic science-fiction tale, is a discomfiting blend of visual ecstasy and narrative sterility.
lead_paragraph: Whatever else is going on in the psychedelic science-fiction tale “Vanishing Waves,” an unflattering portrait of the male psyche is front and center. Focusing on Lukas (Marius Jampolskis), an unlikable, emotionally withdrawn scientist who discards all professional ethics the instant an attractive woman sheds her clothing, this Lithuanian love story from Kristina Buozyte offers a discomfiting blend of visual ecstasy and narrative sterility.

headline: Senate Mulls a Showdown on Saturday Mail Delivery
abstract: The Postal Service says it will continue with its plan to stop mail service on Saturday despite the Senate’s threat to stop the agency from doing so.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A power struggle over the post office is growing, with the Senate considering a move to block a plan to end Saturday deliveries, even as the agency presses ahead.

headline: Interior Dept. Warns Shell on Arctic Drilling
abstract: The government wants a detailed plan on how the company plans to address safety issues before allowing it to resume exploration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Shell Oil Company must provide a detailed plan addressing numerous safety and operational issues that plagued its efforts to extract oil beneath the Arctic Ocean last year if it wants to resume drilling off the coast of Alaska, the Interior Department said Thursday.

headline: City Sidewalks, Little Siblings and Tiny Adventures
abstract: “Crazy and Thief,” named for its two young characters, is a catch-as-catch-can feature that basically watches these children tool about New York and New Jersey on wispy quests.
lead_paragraph: Sweet in conception but a lost cause, “Crazy and Thief” is a fitful sidewalk daydream starring the 7-year-old daughter and 2-year-old son of the director, Cory McAbee. Barely holding together at 52 minutes, this catch-as-catch-can feature basically watches the kids tooling about New York and New Jersey on wispy quests and saying cute nonsense.

abstract: Representatives Ed Royce and Eliot L. Engel of the Foreign Affairs Committee respond to an editorial.

abstract: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks about his visit to an upscale kosher grocery in Brooklyn.

headline: Wright Dropped From U.S. Lineup Because of a Sore Back
abstract: David Wright’s sizzling run in the World Baseball Classic was halted Thursday night because of an injury in his rib area. He will be examined at the Mets’ training complex on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — David Wright had his cleats tied, his uniform on and tucked in, and the big three letters, “USA,” across his chest. He was ready to go, to play his figurative Captain America role at the World Baseball Classic, and continue some of what he had called the best times of his baseball life.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: South Brooklyn Weightlifting Club
abstract: The club, in Gowanus, draws both experienced athletes and curious beginners, and over half of its members are women.
lead_paragraph: The club, in Gowanus, draws both experienced athletes and curious beginners, and over half of its members are women.

headline: Pataki Endorses Catsimatidis in Race for Mayor
abstract: Former Gov. George E. Pataki announced his support of the billionaire supermarket owner John A. Catsimatidis for the Republican mayoral nomination and said he “isn’t a career politician.”
lead_paragraph: Two Republican titans of Empire State politics now find themselves on opposite sides in this year’s race for New York City mayor.

headline: Republicans Are Divided on Proper Role for U.S. Abroad
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: A new generation of Republican leaders is questioning the approach of an aggressive use of American power abroad as a policy imperative and a political advantage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than three decades, the Republican Party brand has been deeply tied to a worldview in which the aggressive use of American power abroad is both a policy imperative and a political advantage.

headline: Ranked Sixth but Seeded Fifth? In Competitive Big Ten, Nothing Is Easy
abstract: Michigan struggled before defeating Penn State in the first round of the Big Ten tournament, and Illinois edged Minnesota at the buzzer.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The question should not have stumped Michigan Coach John Beilein, but it did.

headline: Prison Jumpsuits Are So Passé
abstract: In “K-11” a stoned record producer is dumped into a jail’s holding pen for gay and transgendered inmates, and the lacy underwear and hooker heels do not make him a happy man.
lead_paragraph: The lunatics are running the asylum in “K-11,” a sordid prison drama that struts an unsteady line between full-on camp and “Oz”-style Darwinism.

headline: Wolf Whisperer in the Vatican
abstract: Taking the name of a saint who slept on dirt floors and dined with lepers is the most radical first move by a pontiff in some time.
lead_paragraph: The world is full of Roman Catholics who long ago stopped following the dogma, doctrine and medieval sexual dictates of the church. But they never lost faith in Francesco, the merchant’s son who spoke to wolves, slept on dirt floors and dined with lepers.

headline: Heavy Lifting, With Paulie T-Shirts
abstract: Paul Steinman runs the South Brooklyn Weightlifting Club, a bare-bones gym in Gowanus where workouts focus on powerlifting and Olympic weight lifting.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Wednesday morning, Elizabeth Picardi was discussing her diet with her trainer as she warmed up.

headline: In Syrian Clash Over ‘Death Highway,’ a Bitterly Personal War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A battle for a stretch of northern road that government forces still risk using pits a conventional arsenal against fighters armed with faith as much as weapons.
lead_paragraph: HEESH, Syria — The Islamic fighters peered through rifle scopes and machine-gun sights at the remains of a Syrian military convoy disabled on the highway several hundred yards away. They were peppering President Bashar al-Assad’s soldiers with gunfire, trying to prevent their escape.

headline: Mother Called Her Final Act ‘Evil’
abstract: Cynthia Wachenheim jumped to her death from her eighth-floor Harlem apartment on Wednesday, holding her 10-month-old son, who survived.
lead_paragraph: Sometime before 3:25 p.m. Wednesday, Cynthia Wachenheim, a lawyer who was on child-care leave from her job, wrote out a note. On lined notebook paper, it ran for 13 pages.

headline: Why Label Genetically Engineered Food?
abstract: There is no reliable evidence that genetically modified foods now on the market pose any risk to consumers.
lead_paragraph: Whole Foods Market caused a stir last week when it announced that it would require all products sold in its stores in the United States and Canada to carry labels indicating whether they contain genetically modified ingredients by 2018. Food advocacy groups hailed its action as a possible “game changer” that would push the entire food industry to adopt similar labels.

headline: God Is an Argentine
abstract: The election of Pope Francis confirms what we always suspected.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES

headline: A Troubled Veteran Meets a New Enemy
abstract: In “The Kill Hole” a brooding veteran who was involved in an atrocity while fighting overseas gets no respite back home.
lead_paragraph: Public concern for veterans who have come home physically or psychologically scarred is rightfully widespread, but that good will has bred laziness in film and television. Put a troubled veteran or two into your script, and you tap everything the public already knows and feels, relieving you of the responsibility of having any fresh insights into veterans’ issues or creating an involving story.

headline: A Dictator’s Last Laugh
abstract: How an ex-president swayed Kenya’s election.
lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif.

headline: Younger Generations Lag Parents in Wealth-Building
abstract: A study finds that younger working adults are not doing better financially than the previous generation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pearl Brady has a stable job with good benefits and holds two degrees, a bachelor’s and a master’s. But despite her best efforts, she has no savings, and worries that it will be years before she manages to start putting away money for a house, children and eventually retirement.

headline: New York’s Education Deficit
abstract: School aid is skewed to help districts of politically powerful legislators. It should be changed to spread more money to impoverished areas.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and state legislative leaders are hammering out the $142 billion state budget for the 2013-14 fiscal year, which must be approved by April 1. It is crucial that more financing be allocated to public schools, both in upstate areas and in New York City.

headline: Italy, in Search of a Government
abstract: With no definitive results from a messy election, Italy can’t push through the kind of radical changes it needs to grow its economy.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s newly elected Parliament convenes on Friday with no clear governing majority. Only a government with a strong popular mandate can push through the kind of radical changes Italy really needs: sweeping labor market and tax reforms, tough anticorruption laws, electoral reform and a new fiscal bargain with euro-zone partners that replaces austerity with growth. All or most of that will now have to wait until new elections, probably later this year, can produce more definitive results.

headline: The Crushing of the Safari Ants
abstract: In Kenya, a rising middle class, educated but struggling, finds its hopes for reform repeatedly dashed.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya

headline: Partisan Politics and Gun Violence
abstract: Three important weapons bills reach the Senate floor over strong Republican opposition. The need is urgent to give them an up-or-down vote.
lead_paragraph: Three months after the Newtown, Conn., school massacre, the Senate Judiciary Committee has finally produced three major bills that could each make a significant difference in lowering the number and firepower of guns on the street and keeping them out of the wrong hands. But they have a deeply uncertain future as they head to the Senate floor, underscored by the utterly partisan split in the committee votes.

headline: How Movements Recover
abstract: Augustine’s handling of a church in crisis provides a counterintuitive model for how to revive a troubled movement.
lead_paragraph: The Catholic Church in North Africa was in crisis at the beginning of the fourth century. The Roman emperor Diocletian had persecuted the Christians, and many bishops and priests had collaborated with the regime. Priests had turned over Christian believers to the pagan magistrates. Bishops had surrendered Holy Scriptures to be burned in the public square. An air of corruption and lewdness hung over the church.

headline: After the Flimflam
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: From the reaction to Paul Ryan’s latest cruel joke of a budget proposal, it seems as if Washington is finally getting serious about fiscal policy.
lead_paragraph: It has been a big week for budget documents. In fact, members of Congress have presented not one but two full-fledged, serious proposals for spending and taxes over the next decade.

headline: Chaos and Folly at the Finish
abstract: The first game of the Atlantic 10’s first tournament in Brooklyn ended with three technicals and an ejection in the final seconds as Charlotte pulled off an improbable victory over Richmond.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic 10 Conference introduced itself to Brooklyn on Thursday by producing one of the more ridiculous endings to a college basketball game in recent memory. The very first game of the conference’s very first tournament at Barclays Center ended with three technical fouls and an ejection in the final 4.7 seconds as Charlotte pulled off an improbable 68-63 victory over Richmond, which had led by 3 points with less than five seconds left.

headline: Even at 93, He Finds a Case Too Important to Pass Up
abstract: Robert M. Morgenthau, the former Manhattan district attorney, is still working — and has taken up a case left behind by his late son-in-law.
lead_paragraph: Grab a few minutes on Thursday morning with Robert M. Morgenthau. But don’t be late. There’s a little time open after his two morning meetings, and before one that begins at 12:30. He hoists a legal brief from atop the heap on his desk, which seems to have been transported intact from the one he vacated in 2009 after 35 years as the Manhattan district attorney.

headline: Not in Kansas Anymore: Following a Dream to Mexico
abstract: In “Mariachi Gringo” a confused blond and blue-eyed Kansan escapes to Mexico to play mariachi, puzzling out his life in a foreign land that feels vibrant and authentic.
lead_paragraph: “Mariachi Gringo” — great title, that — seems ready-made for an advertising pitch: A confused and handsome, blond and blue-eyed Kansan escapes to Mexico to play mariachi, discovering himself while an outsider in a foreign land. Standard fish-out-of-water tale, made for life lessons, a few high jinks and funny stuff, right?

headline: Losing 20 Games, Not Faith, on the Way to the N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: After starting 0-8, Liberty finished 15-20 by upsetting four straight Big South Conference rivals to earn an automatic berth.
lead_paragraph: In its opening game this season, the Liberty men’s basketball team had two starters sidelined with injuries and lost by 42 points.

headline: Divisions in G.O.P. Are Laid Bare on First Day of Conservative Conference
abstract: The Conservative Political Action Conference began with Senators Rand Paul and Marco Rubio offering their party starkly different paths back to prominence.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — The largest annual gathering of Republican activists began here Thursday with appearances by rival presidential hopefuls offering their party starkly different paths back to prominence — and diagnoses of what ails it — after last fall’s demoralizing losses.

headline: Things That Go Bump in the Night, Still
abstract: “My Amityville Horror” focuses on Daniel Lutz, who was a child in the family at the center of the 1979 movie “The Amityville Horror.”
lead_paragraph: Anyone still even remotely interested in that house in Amityville, N.Y., or the people who lived in it for a few weeks 37 years ago needs an exorcism. That is way too long to be dwelling on a cheesy ghost story.

headline: Snub of Reformers’ Choice Seen Before Pope’s Anointing
abstract: Francis’ march to the papacy began with the meetings of cardinals that occurred before the conclave. His remarks struck a chord, but he held on to a low profile.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The choice of Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio as pope was so surprising, the Italian bishops sent out an e-mail congratulating the wrong man. His profile was so low that he was barely mentioned by the feverish handicappers and Vaticanologists who make their living scrutinizing the Holy See. But the Argentine emerged from the conclave a swiftly anointed Pope Francis on Wednesday evening, barely 28 hours after it began.

headline: Best Metros in the World:  Hong Kong, Bangalore, Tashkent …
abstract: When Rendezvous asked readers about their favorite metro, we received hundreds of impassioned responses. Public transport, and especially its failings, can spark quite a debate.
lead_paragraph: Rudybahias in Tehuacan finds the New York subway “dirty, old and not punctual,” while Onno Frowein in Yerevan doesn’t mind it being “fast, noisy and a reflection of the life in the city.” Its 24-hour schedule is particularly appealing to Tomrsemail in Kabul, who “would choose a twenty-four hour deafening roller coaster over a part-time beauty.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 15, 2013
abstract: The New York Times critics on “Ginger & Rosa,” “Spring Breakers” and “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on “Ginger & Rosa,” “Spring Breakers” and “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Mar. 15, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Mar. 15, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “In this country, the expectation is that every generation does better than the previous generation. This is no longer the case. This generation might have less.”

headline: He Roots for ‘the Saints,’ on the Soccer Field and Off
abstract: San Lorenzo de Almagro, an Argentine soccer team with holy beginnings, now has a supporter at the Vatican in Pope Francis I.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — San Lorenzo de Almagro, a top-division soccer club here, has holy beginnings. It was created in 1908 by Lorenzo Massa, a priest. One of the team’s nicknames is Los Santos (the Saints), and the team’s colors, blue and red, are said to correspond to the colors of the Virgin Mary’s robe.

headline: A Rapper in Search of a New Path
abstract: In “Reincarnated” the rapper Snoop Dogg, who now wants to be known as Snoop Lion, heads to Jamaica for a spiritual pilgrimage of sorts.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Court Removes Boston Judge From Trial of Crime Boss
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Organized Crime', 'United States Attorneys', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Judge Richard Stearns’s work as a federal prosecutor could feed the perception of bias in the case against James (Whitey) Bulger, the court said.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The judge assigned to preside over the trial of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger was removed from the case on Thursday after a federal appeals court found that his career as a federal prosecutor in Boston could feed the perception of bias.

headline: Jamaican Passions in a Time of Tumult
abstract: “Better Mus’ Come” is a love story set in the political turmoil and gang warfare in 1970s Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Cuomos Differ on New Pope
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Popes']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called Pope Francis “praiseworthy,” while his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, suggested there might have been a better choice.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called Pope Francis “praiseworthy” on Thursday, just hours after his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, was quoted suggesting the new pope was not the best possible choice.

headline: Muslim Brotherhood’s Statement on Women Stirs Liberals’ Fears
abstract: In a statement on a proposed United Nations declaration to condemn violence against women, the Brotherhood issued a list of objections, which formally laid out its views on women.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — During its decades as an underground Islamist movement, the Muslim Brotherhood has long preached that Islam required women to obey their husbands in all matters.

headline: Lost Generation: A Serbian Version
abstract: In “Clip,” a debut film from Maja Milos, a rebellious Serbian teenager experiments with sex and drugs and records every move on her cellphone.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Corrections: March 15, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 15, 2013.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Rounded-Up Numbers
abstract: A Friday with lots of white space, by Joe Krozel.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m torn by this one by Joe Krozel, but I’m going to give it the fairest shot that I can. Maybe I just don’t have a great appreciation for pushing the envelope, at least in the way Mr. Krozel does it. But as I’ve said before in this blog, there’s room for everyone and everyone’s styles.

headline: Underneath Pajamas, Naked Depression
abstract: Christopher Durang’s “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” a comedy starring David Hyde Pierce and Sigourney Weaver, opened Thursday on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Did you hear there’s been an outbreak of mugging in a certain bucolic neighborhood of Bucks County, Pa., where many a moneyed Manhattanite has a summer retreat? I guess you’re not safe anywhere these days.

headline: Coated With Algae
abstract: Lake Erie before and after an algae bloom in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Lake Erie before and after an algae bloom in 2011.

headline: No Structural Damage in Anthony’s Sore Knee
abstract: As the Knicks prepared to face the Trail Blazers in Portland, Carmelo Anthony was back in New York on Thursday, having fluid drained from his back of his right knee.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Carmelo Anthony was back in New York on Thursday, confronting a long needle and a cranky knee that has undermined a once-glorious Knicks season.

headline: Back Home a Pontiff Is Honored, if Not by All
abstract: Some residents of Buenos Aires described an archbishop who had worked hard to change the lives of the poor, but others said he had done too little to challenge the country’s former dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Pope Francis was celebrated here on Thursday by faithful congregants and priests in some of this capital city’s vast slums as he started his papacy on an austere note, shunning the throne reserved for him at the Vatican, but the praise was tempered by criticism of him for his hard-line conservative views on a range of issues, including gay rights and artistic expression.

headline: Stagnant Wealth for Younger Generations
abstract: In 2010, the average person of 56 to 64 had more than twice the wealth that someone the same age would have had 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the average person of 56 to 64 had more than twice the wealth that someone the same age would have had 30 years ago.

headline: Louisville Turns Up Pressure and Turns Away Villanova
abstract: Villanova, the Cardinals’ unfortunate opponent in the Big East quarterfinals, committed 10 turnovers in the first six minutes. By halftime, after 18 giveaways, the Wildcats looked dazed.
lead_paragraph: When Louisville arrives at Madison Square Garden to play in the Big East tournament — usually after preliminary rounds — it sometimes seems as if a switch is flipped, and the action on the court zips to fast-forward, with players and colors whirring by in hazy streaks.

headline: Iran Chases U.S. Drone Over Persian Gulf
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Military Aircraft', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The encounter, the second since November, illustrated the dangers that such pursuits could lead to hostilities between the United States and Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Iranian jet fighter pursued an American surveillance drone over the Persian Gulf this week but ended the chase after a radio warning from an American escort plane, Pentagon officials said Thursday.

headline: Judge Rules Against SUNY Trustees in Their Vote to Shutter Long Island College Hospital
abstract: The ruling vacates decision by SUNY trustees and requires public deliberations before they vote again on closing the financially ailing hospital in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Trustees of the State University of New York violated the state’s Open Meetings Law in voting to close Long Island College Hospital, a State Supreme Court justice ruled on Thursday. The ruling vacates their decision and requires public deliberations before they vote again on closing the financially ailing hospital, which is in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: March 14, 2013

headline: Outsiders Faulted for Unrest in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Leaders in East Flatbush are pleading for calm a day after a vigil for Kimani Gray turned chaotic, the most sustained turmoil in three consecutive days of protests.
lead_paragraph: The anger in East Flatbush is local. But the unrest that has gripped the Brooklyn neighborhood, including clashes with the police after officers fatally shot a 16-year-old, has been encouraged and incited by people coming from outside, community leaders said on Thursday.

headline: As Drug Routes Shift, a Meth Trail Leads to Chinatown
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Methamphetamines']
abstract: An unsealed indictment offered new details about an investigation involving nearly $200,000 worth of crystal methamphetamine and low-level dealers’ easy access to Mexican suppliers.
lead_paragraph: In the past, his work as an undercover drug investigator had often led through New York City’s Chinese enclaves as he pursued heroin shipments from Asia.

headline: TV Roundtable: Changes at NBC
abstract: After the NBC News Group’s upfronts, Bill Carter and Brian Stelter join David Gillen to discuss the challenges and changes in the network’s future.
lead_paragraph: After the NBC News Group’s upfronts, Bill Carter and Brian Stelter join David Gillen to discuss the challenges and changes in the network’s future.

headline: Report Says Bronx Rent Disputes Favor Landlords
abstract: Tenant advocates charge that the heavy caseload in the borough, which handles more than 85,000 housing court cases a year, limits tenants’ access to resources and legal guidance.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx handles more than 85,000 housing court cases annually, more than any other borough, making it New York City’s epicenter for disputes between landlords and tenants.

headline: U.S. Says Greek Executive Evaded Sanctions on Iran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A business executive and 14 of his companies are accused of conspiring with Iran to sell that country’s oil in defiance of international restrictions.
lead_paragraph: The United States blacklisted a Greek business executive and 14 of his companies on Thursday, accusing them of conspiring with Iran to acquire eight large petroleum tankers used to transport Iranian oil to unwitting foreign customers in defiance of Western economic sanctions.

headline: Spring Rain, Then Foul Algae in Ailing Lake Erie
abstract: Lake Erie was once considered an environmental success story after it was pulled from the brink of death. Now it is sick again.
lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio — For those who live and play on the shores of Lake Erie, the spring rains that will begin falling here soon are less a blessing than a portent. They could threaten the very future of the lake itself.

headline: Sexist Taunt From North Korea Raises Gender Issue for the South’s New Leader
abstract: South Korea’s first female president, Park Geun-hye, daughter of a dictator and admirer of Margaret Thatcher, is considered tough on security, but North Korea is testing her.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When North Korea blamed President Park Geun-hye’s “venomous swish of skirt” this week for tensions on the Korean Peninsula, it brought up an issue that had been mainly unremarked upon in South Korea: Would their leader’s gender color the latest confrontation between the Koreas?

abstract: As part of an oral history project on storm survivors in Long Beach, N.Y., Mary Anne Trasciatti interviewed James Hodge.
lead_paragraph: As part of an oral history project on storm survivors in Long Beach, N.Y., Mary Anne Trasciatti interviewed James Hodge.

headline: Bahrain: Dozens Hurt During Protests
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Attacks on Police', 'United States International Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: Dozens of people were injured as protesters clashed with the riot police on Thursday on the second anniversary of a Saudi-led military intervention in Bahrain.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were injured as protesters clashed with the riot police on Thursday on the second anniversary of a Saudi-led military intervention in Bahrain, said antigovernment activists and government officials. The government said several officers were injured, and opposition groups said at least three protesters were critically wounded. The violence threatened to undermine talks aimed at ending the crisis that began two years ago after the authorities, with help from a Saudi-led regional force, suppressed an uprising. The Shiite-led opposition has demanded greater political rights from the Sunni monarchy, a United States ally.

headline: China: Coca-Cola Asked About GPS Use
abstract: Coca-Cola has said it is cooperating with Chinese authorities who are investigating whether its employees engaged in illegal mapping using GPS devices in Yunnan Province.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola has said it is cooperating with Chinese authorities who are investigating whether its employees engaged in illegal mapping using GPS devices in Yunnan Province. The investigation was reported by a provincial Web site on Feb. 28, and a reporter at China Radio International asked an official with a national mapping agency about that case and others involving illegal mapping on Tuesday at a legislative session in Beijing. The official, Li Pengde, did not mention Coca-Cola but expressed concern that some information could have been given to “foreign intelligence agencies.” The report on the Yunnan Web site said the Coca-Cola case was one of 21 in which a provincial agency was investigating the “illegal use of hand-held GPS equipment to collect classified information.” A Coca-Cola spokeswoman said some bottling plants had adopted electronic mapping and equipment that was “commercially available in China through authorized local suppliers.”

headline: Israel: Tensions Mount in West Bank
abstract: An Israeli mother and three children were seriously injured in a car crash in the West Bank on Thursday after stones thrown by Palestinians apparently hit their vehicle, the police said.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli mother and three children were seriously injured in a car crash in the West Bank on Thursday after stones thrown by Palestinians apparently hit their vehicle, the police said. Several other vehicles were also hit. Tensions have increased in the West Bank recently, with Palestinians protesting against hardship and Israeli actions in Gaza, and in support of Palestinian prisoners. Israeli forces killed a Palestinian man in the Hebron area on Tuesday. Israeli authorities said the soldiers were chasing Palestinians who had thrown a firebomb when they were attacked by and opened fire.

headline: Ryan and Getty Moss
abstract: As part of an oral history project on storm survivors in Long Beach, N.Y., Mary Anne Trasciatti interviewed Ryder and Getty Moss.
lead_paragraph: As part of an oral history project on storm survivors in Long Beach, N.Y., Mary Anne Trasciatti interviewed Ryder and Getty Moss.

headline: Capturing the Stories of a Hurricane’s Survivors
abstract: Mary Anne Trasciatti, a professor of rhetoric at Hofstra University who has lived in Long Beach since 2000, is collecting oral histories of Hurricane Sandy’s impact on the area.
lead_paragraph: For survivors of Hurricane Sandy in Long Beach, N.Y., the stories have become familiar by now, riveting in spite of — or perhaps because of — their similarities. Deciding not to evacuate, because Tropical Storm Irene was not so bad. Watching the water rise and rise and rise. Losing cars, basements, then more. Spending weeks at a relative’s home.

headline: Iran Nuclear Weapon to Take Year or More, Obama Says
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama made the comments to an Israeli television station less than a week before his first visit as president to that country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama told an Israeli television station on Thursday that his administration believed it would take Iran “over a year or so” to develop a nuclear weapon, and he vowed that the United States would do whatever was necessary to prevent that from happening.

headline: With Wright Scratched, U.S. Falls Short but Still Has a Shot
abstract: The Dominican Republic took advantage of David Wright’s absence because of a sore back to clinch a spot in the World Baseball Classic semifinals.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — David Wright had his cleats tied, his uniform on and tucked in, and three big letters, USA, across his chest. He was ready to go, to play his figurative Captain America role at the World Baseball Classic and continue some of what he had called the best times of his baseball life.

headline: Ask Well: Relief for Shinsplints
abstract: Shinsplints are painfully familiar to many of us who run, dance or play team sports, but wearing the right shoes and targeted exercises can provide relief, explains the Phys Ed columnist Gretchen Reynolds.

headline: Nadal Makes Quick Work of Ailing Federer
abstract: Playing in his first hardcourt tournament in nearly a year, Rafael Nadal defeated Roger Federer in the quarterfinals of the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — With Roger Federer clearly struggling with a back injury, Rafael Nadal rolled to a 6-4, 6-2 victory in the quarterfinals of the BNP Paribas Open here on Thursday night. The comprehensive win was Nadal’s 19th over Federer in 29 matches, and it came in Nadal’s first hardcourt tournament in more than 11 months. He missed more than six months with knee pain and returned to action on his preferred clay courts in February, winning two titles in smaller tournaments in Brazil and Mexico.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Disney) THE WIZARDS RETURN: ALEX VS. ALEX (2013) Selena Gomez reprises her “Wizards of Waverly Place” role as the sorcerer Alex Russo, who, while vacationing with her family in Italy, inadvertently conjures a spell that creates a good version of herself and a bad one (above) — and that leads to a monumental battle between them atop the Tower of Pisa. Ms. Gomez, whose racy feature, “Spring Breakers,” is being released in New York and Los Angeles on Friday, also serves as an executive producer of this movie.

headline: Boeing Pitches Its Solution for Dreamliner Problems
abstract: In Japan, company executives on Friday said that they were confident that engineers had eliminated all risk of fire or smoke from the troubled plane’s batteries.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Boeing executives said on Friday that they expected commercial flights of the company’s troubled new 787 Dreamliner jet to resume within weeks and that the company was fully confident that it had eliminated all risk of fire or smoke from its batteries, defending its use of the volatile lithium-ion technology.

headline: News Quiz | March 15, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: G.O.P.’s Portman, Saying Son Is Gay, Now Backs Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A leading Republican Senator switches his views on same-sex marriage after his son informs him of his sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, has switched his stand on same-sex marriage, saying he now supports it after his son told him he is gay.

headline: Trail Blazers Send Knicks to Third Straight Loss
abstract: Without the injured Carmelo Anthony and Tyson Chandler, the Knicks were blown out again on their Western road trip.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The $19.5 million knee was back in Manhattan, with a small needle hole in it. The $19.9 million knee was recovering from surgery. The $13.6 million knee was wrapped in ice in the visitors locker room at the Rose Garden.

headline: When Is Activism Worth Getting Arrested?
abstract: While no one knows how many environmental activists around the world have run afoul of the law during their protests, the numbers are growing.
lead_paragraph: EDF Energy announced this week that the company has decided to drop a £5-million lawsuit (roughly $7.5 million) against 21 British climate activists.

headline: Mumbai’s ‘Focus’ Festival Showcases Women Photographers
abstract: Work by Indian and international female photographers deals with free speech and emancipation.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI— A family picture set against an idyllic countryside with the figure of the father cut out, replaced by a studio backdrop. A panoramic view of a city in flux, taken at different times of the day. An ethereal image of a translucent plastic bag caught on a tree, fluttering in the wind. A family portrait dominated by the figure of a woman standing straight and tall, front and center.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 15
abstract: The papal election; Syria’s bitterly personal war; pig carcasses and the food supply in China; European leaders insist on austerity; and a new show from an all-male dance company.
lead_paragraph: NEWS While the workings of the conclave are secret, Pope Francis is said to have won the papacy in part because the Vatican-based cardinals protective of their bureaucracy snubbed the presumptive front-runner, and a favored candidate of reformers, Cardinal Angelo Scola. Daniel J. Wakin reports from Vatican City.

headline: Do You Think Life Exists — or Has Ever Existed — Somewhere Besides Earth?
abstract: What do you imagine extraterrestrial life to look like? Does it have humanoid features, like heads, torsos and limbs, like we typically see in popular movies? Or do you imagine something completely different?
lead_paragraph: With potentially hundreds of billions of galaxies in the universe, and with each of those galaxies housing billions of stars, do you think life exists — or has ever existed — somewhere besides Earth?

headline: Faithful to Fidel
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Why is Mexico so cool to Cuba’s most famous dissident?
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a country with barely any Internet access, the activist Yoani Sánchez has managed, with a blog and a Twitter account as her only tools, to tell the outside world about repression in Cuba. This has brought her a couple of arrests and a dozen international awards, including a special mention from the Maria Moors Cabot Prize committee and the Ortega y Gasset prize for online journalism.

headline: Wooed by a Campus Visit, an Applicant Awaits Word From a ‘Scholastic Suitor’
abstract: “I haven’t received my admissions decisions yet,” writes Candice Childress, a student in Las Vegas, “but it’s looking sunny here in the heart of cactus country.”
lead_paragraph: If my college adventure was the “Wheel of Fortune,” the National Merit board would be Pat, the University of Arizona, Arizona State University and the University of New Mexico would be the buzzer-clutching contestants, and the Fafsa folks would be Vanna, clad in a horrific $100-patterned empire waist gown with blinding orange accents.

headline: North Korea Sees South and U.S. Behind Cyberstrikes

abstract: North Korea said on Friday that it has found new foreign invaders: hackers from the United States and its allies shutting down its Web sites, its main tool of spreading propaganda abroad.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea, a country paranoid about perceived threats from the outside world, said on Friday that it had found new foreign invaders: hackers from the United States and its allies shutting down the North’s Web sites, the country’s main tool of spreading propaganda abroad.

headline: No End to Trauma for Some Older Veterans
abstract: Older veterans often are slow to recognize post-traumatic stress syndrome, even as it haunts many of them.
lead_paragraph: Who knew much about post-traumatic stress syndrome in 1945? The term didn’t enter the official manual of psychiatric diagnoses until 1980; effective treatments didn’t become widely available until the late 1990s.

lead_paragraph: ARGONNE, Ill. — Warning that the United States risks falling behind in the international race to develop alternative energy, President Obama on Friday proposed diverting $2 billion in revenue from federal oil and gas royalties over the next decade to pay for research on advanced vehicles.

headline: Kacey Musgraves’s Rebel Twang
abstract: The 24-year-old singer is hardly the first to push the buttons of the country-music establishment, but she might be the best at it.
lead_paragraph: Standing with guitar in hand on the stage of the Ryman Auditorium, the former home of the Grand Ole Opry, Kacey Musgraves faced an audience of gatekeepers and kingmakers. It was Feb. 27, and her major-label debut album, “Same Trailer, Different Park,” would be coming out on March 19. Her label, Mercury Nashville, and others owned by Universal Music Group were showcasing their artists in a private concert as part of the annual Country Radio Seminar. The curved wooden pews of the Ryman, a former tabernacle known as the Mother Church of Country Music, were lined with insiders representing radio stations, syndicators and other players in the proc­ess of deciding what airs on country radio — which still determines mainstream success in country music.

headline: Argentinian Pastoral
abstract: Bergoglio’s tense relations with the Argentine government suggest the new pope may be unafraid to ruffle a few feathers in the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — When the French cardinal Jean-Louis Tauran uttered the name “Bergoglio” in the middle of his Latin habemus papam announcement, I thought I had misheard. I wasn’t the only one in Argentina to think that. News anchors on the local cable channel went silent. The disbelief cleared only when Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, the archbishop of Buenos Aires, appeared on the balcony of St. Peter’s: An Argentine had just become pope.

headline: JPMorgan Faulted Over Trading Loss
abstract: Congressional investigators on Thursday released a harsh portrait of the events surrounding JPMorgan Chase’s huge trading loss. | The Fed said Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase were not strong enough to go ahead with plans to pay out billions of dollars to shareholders. | Bill Clinton may have spilled the beans about a new job for Marc Lasry of Avenue Capital. | Timothy F. Geithner is preparing to tell his side of what happened during the financial crisis and the recession.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN FAULTED OVER TRADING LOSS  |  Congressional investigators on Thursday released a harsh portrait of the events surrounding JPMorgan Chase’s huge trading loss last year, saying the bank ignored internal risk controls while its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, briefly withheld some information from regulators. The 300-page report is sure to escalate the debate over policing Wall Street, and it may foreshadow a criminal case against employees at the center of the trading disaster, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. Current and former JPMorgan executives, including Ina Drew, who led the office that oversaw the trades, are scheduled to testify at a hearing starting at 9:30 a.m., which DealBook will be live-blogging.

lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Reacting with unusual swiftness, the Vatican on Friday rejected any suggestion that Pope Francis of Argentina was implicated in his country’s so-called Dirty War during the 1970s, tackling the issue just two days after the pontiff’s election.

lead_paragraph: The online video Web site Hulu, in a state of flux as its owners decide what to do with it, said Thursday that the person in charge of content for the site, Andy Forssell, would become its acting chief executive.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Editor Charged With Hacking and Reform Talks in Britain Break Down
abstract: A social media editor at Thomson Reuters has been charged with helping Anonymous hack into The Los Angeles Times Web site, British talks on a new method to regulate the press have fallen through, and NBCUniversal News Group put a positive face forward at its upfront.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Keys, a 26-year-old deputy social media editor for Thomson Reuters, has been charged with helping the hacker collective Anonymous attack the Web site of The Los Angeles Times, Amy Chozick reports. Mr. Keys once worked as a Web producer at KTXL Fox 40, which, like The Los Angeles Times, is owned by Tribune Media. A federal indictment of Mr. Keys said that he provided Anonymous with login information for Tribune Company computers, encouraged the hackers to log on to the company’s server and damage it, and helped the group in an attack that allowed them to alter a feature on the newspaper’s Web site. Mr. Keys could face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000 for each substantive count.

headline: Everyday Externalities
abstract: Traffic is a big issue.
lead_paragraph: Via Mark Thoma, a new paper in Vox on the effects of increased rail service, making clever use of natural experiments created by changes in German ownership and regulation. The results aren’t that surprising — more frequent rail service sharply reduces pollution and other costs associated with driving — but it’s good to have this kind of solid work to back our intuition.

headline: History Evergreen
abstract: An Irish historian planned to spend six weeks organizing Jackie Clarke’s collection of more than 100,000 items documenting Ireland’s struggle to free itself of English rule, but eight years later, she’s still at it.
lead_paragraph: BALLINA, Ireland — In this removed County Mayo town at the mouth of the River Moy, the widow of a local fish merchant decided one day to share her husband’s collection of Irish miscellany with the public. Better to have it on display here in his beloved Ballina, as he had always wished, than to lose it, God forbid, in a fire in the family home above the family shop, Clarke’s Salmon Smokery.

headline: A Ballerina Makes Her Own Moves
abstract: The ballet dancer Gemma Bond will unveil her work “Silent Titles,” which she choreographed, at Florence Gould Hall.
lead_paragraph: When Gemma Bond was 14 and training at the Royal Ballet School in London she entered a choreographic competition. “It seems really silly now,” she said with the sort of half-embarrassed laughter that frequently trickles into her speech. “But I thought: ‘Well, I should have a go. Everyone else is trying.’ ” Her ballet, she added, wasn’t experimental in the least. “I just wanted it to be pretty.”

headline: What’s Not to Love About Graffiti?
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Adam Leon explains how he came to make “Gimme the Loot,” a movie about two graffiti writers from the Bronx who want to tag the Mets’ home-run apple.
lead_paragraph: Over the past five years Adam Leon has gone from working for film festivals to being honored by them. After a stint on the payroll of the New York Film Festival he eventually took his love for film behind the camera, writing and directing a feature debut that got festival audiences buzzing and distributors calling. That movie is “Gimme the Loot,” about two young graffiti writers from the Bronx whose quest to tag the New York Mets home-run apple takes them on a lively adventure throughout New York City. It includes encounters with drug dealers, a little petty theft and walking shoeless through the city streets.

headline: Grocery Stories
abstract: The sunny retail report is buoyed by inequality. The purchasing power of the few can overshadow the cutbacks of the many.
lead_paragraph: Many economists are reportedly encouraged by the stronger-than-expected gain in retail sales in February. In particular, they seem to think that the relatively upbeat numbers are evidence that that this year’s payroll tax increase is not having much of an impact on spending.

headline: San Francisco: The City by the Bars
abstract: Twenty pubs in four days.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco is one of this country’s great bar cities, a place where you can hit a graceful classic, a shady dive and a bitters-besotted new-school lounge in the same evening. During a trip last month, I set out on an extraordinary pub crawl — 20 bars in four days.

headline: Elisabeth Moss on What Peggy Won’t Do This Season on ‘Mad Men’
abstract: The actress reveals her hopes for the Don-Peggy relationship and her plans for what comes next.
lead_paragraph: You play a cop in “Top of the Lake,” a mini-series created by Jane Campion that makes its debut on the Sundance Channel on March 18. It includes an all-female commune led by Holly Hunter — a stark contrast to “Mad Men,” which is produced by Matthew Weiner and is so much about a man’s world.  I would definitely say “Top of the Lake” is more female-driven. But Matt is so in touch with his feminine side that “Mad Men” doesn’t really feel as if it’s run by a man. There are lots of boys and sexism, but you’ve got these three female leads who are really complex.

headline: My Cheating Friend
abstract: Thou shalt not commit judgment on her adultery.
lead_paragraph: I am a single woman in my mid-20s. I recently learned from my dear friend that she has developed a longtime pattern of cheating on her husband of five years. I understand cheating happens for various reasons — but if I remain friends with her, am I condoning her ongoing behavior? If I am “anti-compulsive-cheating,” do I therefore have to be anti-her? I value many aspects of our friendship but don’t see her (or my) views on philandering ever changing. EVE, HOUSTON

headline: Who Made That Cellphone?
abstract: The two-pound device that allowed us to be “fundamentally and inherently mobile.”
lead_paragraph: “We wanted to do a dazzling demonstration,” Martin Cooper says of the day in 1973 when he stood outside the Manhattan Hilton and fiddled with an object that was nearly the size of a child’s boot. “I had this thing with push-buttons on it, and I was talking into it,” he remembers. A crowd gathered around him on Sixth Avenue, gawking as he demonstrated how to make a call from the sidewalk — with no phone booth and no wires.
