abstract: Coaches of men’s college basketball go crazy on the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: Coaches of men’s college basketball go crazy on the sidelines.

headline: March Madmen
abstract: Coaches of men’s college basketball go crazy on the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: If the basketball court is a stage, one of its star performers is often the head coach, arms waving, face red, mouth open wide as he shouts over the din of the crowd. Some of that emotion is directed at officials, who say the antics from the coach’s box have become worse: in a memo last year, John W. Adams, the national coordinator of men’s basketball officiating for the N.C.A.A., encouraged officials to crack down on offenders. But the coaches are usually trying to get the attention of their players. Jay Bilas, a college basketball analyst for ESPN who played at Duke under Mike Krzyzewski, says that while Coach K might have been withering, he was constructive: “He’d say, ‘That was a bad bleeping shot,’ and, ‘Let’s do it right the next time!’ ” And did Bilas ever shout back? “Never,” he says. “What would I possibly yell back?”

headline: Is This Where the Third Intifada Will Start?
abstract: One village in the West Bank tests the limits of unarmed resistance.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Feb. 10, the living room of Bassem Tamimi’s house in the West Bank village of Nabi Saleh was filled with friends and relatives smoking and sipping coffee, waiting for Bassem to return from prison. His oldest son, Waed, 16, was curled on the couch with his 6-year-old brother, Salam, playing video games on the iPhone that the prime minister of Turkey had given their sister, Ahed. She had been flown to Istanbul to receive an award after photos of her shaking her fist at an armed Israeli soldier won her, at 11, a brief but startling international celebrity. Their brother Abu Yazan, who is 9, was on a tear in the yard, wrestling with an Israeli activist friend of Bassem’s. Nariman, the children’s mother, crouched in a side room, making the final preparations for her husband’s homecoming meal, laughing at the two photographers competing for shots from the narrow doorway as she spread onions onto oiled flatbreads.

headline: A Dozen Slawless Cabbage Recipes
abstract: This St. Patrick’s Day, cabbage deserves better than to be boiled within a clover’s width of its life.
lead_paragraph: BRAISED

headline: Sri Lanka, as It Heals From War
abstract: A return to the Jaffna Peninsula, where the spiritual life and a welcome to visitors are being renewed.
lead_paragraph: As soon as I arrived at the temple, an old man caught my eye and directed me to the inner sanctum. It was hot outside, and the sun was strong. But it was even hotter in the temple, where hundreds of festivalgoers had gathered.

headline: Popcast: Is Justin Timberlake Still a Pop Star?
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Justin Timberlake’s new album, “The 20/20 Experience,” only his third in eleven years.
lead_paragraph: This week: Justin Timberlake’s “The 20/20 Experience.” Jon Caramanica joins host Ben Ratliff to talk about the new album by the actor/television producer/golfer/former boy-band light-tenor, only his third in eleven years.

headline: Protecting Wealth in Volatile Fields Like Real Estate and Technology
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Real estate and high technology may have little in common, but executives in both fields earn their wealth from volatile assets in a cyclical industry.
lead_paragraph: PEOPLE who made their money by owning real estate and those who earned it in high technology would seem to have little in common. Real estate is, literally, a bricks and mortar business, and technology ventures like social media companies are pretty much the opposite.

headline: Baseball Grabs Some March Gladness
abstract: Basketball celebrations are a March tradition. But the World Baseball Classic had a memorable one of its own on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: This is the time of year for emotional victories, of teammates mobbing one another in unbridled joy. The scene never gets old, the heart-thumping excitement of the game spilling into the tearful postgame celebration, the youthful exuberance providing us that booster shot of pure happiness that reminds us why sports keeps winning us over.

headline: The Californication of Biarritz
abstract: Lately, an indie surf-meets-art-meets-fashion scene has sprung up, as cool young Parisians settle into this grand old town overlooking the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Biarritz has long been known as the surfing capital of France — ever since the American screenwriter Peter Viertel arrived on its beach during the filming of “The Sun Also Rises” in 1956. Nowadays, major surf brands like Quiksilver and O’Neill have offices, shops and competitions in the area. But lately, a more indie surf-meets-art-meets-fashion scene has sprung up, as cool young Parisians settle into this grand old town overlooking the Atlantic. Their presence — not just in summer but increasingly year-round — has transformed Biarritz and its surrounding beach towns from what was once a resort for bourgeois retirees into a breezy bohemian outpost that has come to be called “the French California.” It’s sunnier, friendlier and more rough-hewn than much of France, tied by its hardy Basque roots to its Spanish neighbors just over the border.

headline: Mossy Mitch McConnell
abstract: At CPAC, the senator insisted that everyone’s wrong about the character of the two parties.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — At last year’s Conservative Political Action Convention, Senator Mitch McConnell called Democrats “liberal thugs.” It was a rousing speech, if you go in for that sort of thing: Totally unapologetic. On Friday, addressing the same meeting of minds, and coming off his party’s 2012 election loss, he was just as unapologetic, clinging to the possibility that if Republicans keep doing the same thing over and over again they’ll eventually get different results, like the old definition of insanity.

headline: Shanghai on a Dime? Pretty Close
abstract: Even with a budget of only $50 a day, Shanghai is more than manageable.
lead_paragraph: Street signs in English, not-so-spicy cuisine, locals who don’t stare, contemporary art galleries, modern youth hostels and even interpreter hot lines for cabdrivers who don’t speak English. For independent travelers about to start an expedition into the huge, mysterious nation of China, I have some advice: stop in Shanghai and take a deep breath.

headline: Up the Yangtze River With a $50 Paddle
abstract: A few rookie mistakes and some grand discoveries while traveling in China on a budget.
lead_paragraph: As the Hai Nei Guan Guang 2 blasted its deafening foghorn and pulled into the Yangtze River port of Fengjie, I brimmed with confidence. Two days earlier, I had nervously boarded a similar workaday passenger boat along another leg of the Yangtze, no idea what was in store. But now, I knew the routine. I’d say san-deng (third-class), hand over some cash, receive a handwritten slip with my cabin number, step over sunflower-seed-spitting passengers camped on the floor and settle into whatever rock-hard bunk remained in a room of instant-noodle-slurping Chinese passengers.

headline: The Gun Report: March 15, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Chris from Baltimore posted the following comment to yesterday’s Gun Report: “More children are ‘slaughtered’ during circumcision in the U.S. than with assault rifles.” Chris, could you please provide the supporting data? We’re a tad skeptical.

headline: Striking All the Right Notes
abstract: A romance that began with cymbals — well, one, anyway.
lead_paragraph: Even before he was old enough to shave, which wasn’t all that long ago, Jake Goldbas had ruled out ever dating a singer.

headline: One Sinkhole Killed, and Many Others Opened, but Experts Counsel Not to Panic
abstract: After a man was swallowed by a sinkhole in Tampa, Fla., there seemed to be new ones opening up all over the place, but experts say that’s just what sinkholes do.
lead_paragraph: The recent bizarre death of a man who vanished into a huge sinkhole that opened beneath his home in suburban Tampa, Fla., unleashed a wave of sympathy, and not a little fear, among fellow Floridians. This is the “sinkhole season” in Florida, a time when homes, cars and — rarely — people can drop into the abyss without warning.

headline: Portman’s Progress
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A prominent Republican’s turnaround on gay marriage prompts questions.
lead_paragraph: I suppose it’s a measure of how far the fight for gay equality has come that within minutes of Senator Rob Portman’s announcement that he now supports same-sex marriage, because he learned that his own son is gay, my inbox began filling with messages not of celebration, but of complaint. Readers, colleagues and friends wrote that they were pleased with his destination, but offended by the route there.

headline: Kacey Musgraves Sings Not-for-Grandma Country Music
abstract: A musical primer on the next big star from Nashville in the Taylor Swift mold.
lead_paragraph: Kacey Musgraves, whom I profiled in this week’s magazine, looks like the next big thing from Nashville. Part of her promise lies in her potential to address both a traditional mainstream country audience and also younger, more eclectic listeners. Her first major-label album, “Same Trailer, Different Park,” comes out next Tuesday. If you’re not familiar with her music, these three videos offer a quick introduction.

headline: Is Justin Timberlake Still a Pop Star?
abstract: Jon Caramanica joins host Ben Ratliff to lean on Justin Timberlake’s “The 20/20 Experience,” the new album by the actor/television producer/golfer/former boy-band light-tenor, only his third in eleven years.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica joins host Ben Ratliff to lean on Justin Timberlake’s “The 20/20 Experience,” the new album by the actor/television producer/golfer/former boy-band light-tenor, only his third in eleven years.

headline: Nissan Recalling Some 2013 Vehicles for Problem With Air Bags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The vehicles are the 2013 Nissan Altima, Leaf, Pathfinder, Sentra and Infiniti JX35.
lead_paragraph: Nissan is recalling some of its newest models for an air-bag problem but the automaker cannot say how many vehicles are affected, according to a report the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: No Decision on Bee-Harming Pesticides in Europe
abstract: Representatives from Britain and Germany, two of the largest members of the European Union, abstained from the voting, which left the proposal in limbo.
lead_paragraph: A proposed measure to restrict the use of pesticides that have been implicated in bee die-offs around the world was left in limbo on Friday, after representatives from Britain and Germany, two of the largest members of the European Union, abstained from the voting in Brussels. The move left the committee without the needed qualified majority, which gives larger countries greater weight than smaller ones.

headline: Delusions at the European Commission
abstract: They have made a desert and called it a “delicate balance”.
lead_paragraph: I see that Vox has posted a self-justifying piece on fiscal austerity from the European Commission, declaring that the Commission is pursuing a “delicate balance”. Actually, that’s kind of awesome: how does that “delicate balance” feel in countries with 15, 20, 25 percent unemployment?

headline: Romney’s Warm Reunion, and Other CPAC Updates
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mitt Romney defied predictions that he might get a cold shoulder from a grass-roots conservative crowd, some of whom had their doubts about him as the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. – Mitt Romney received an overwhelmingly warm welcome here at the Conservative Political Action Conference, known as CPAC, defying predictions that he might get the cold shoulder from a grass-roots crowd, some of whom had their doubts about him as the Republican nominee.

headline: The Distracted American Driver
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: Nearly 70 percent of Americans ages 18 to 64 said they had chatted on their phones while driving in the past 30 days, and about 30 percent said they had sent text messages while behind the wheel, far more than drivers in seven European countries.
lead_paragraph: Despite increasing media attention and laws forbidding the practice, more Americans than ever are using their cellphones to talk and send text messages while driving, a new study shows.

headline: Pen Pals
abstract: A collection of letters between Paul Auster and J. M. Coetzee, in which the writers attempt to “strike sparks off each other.”
lead_paragraph: It’s an odd moment for literary letters as a genre. The proliferation of letter volumes published over the past few years (Beckett, Bellow, Wodehouse, Gaddis, with Calvino and Wallace on the way) might be considered post-mortem in more ways than one, putting to bed a form that is already effectively dead, along with its authors. For while the ­e-­revolution means changes in how we read any sort of book, the move from epistles to ­e-­pistles is, for better or worse, a fundamental redefinition of the genre itself. And while there are probably plenty of contemporary writers saving up their best e-mails on external hard drives for later publication, it’s difficult to imagine those looking or acting like a volume of letters. Since you will read these collected e-mails on your electronic device, there’s a fairly good chance they will look like, well, your in-box.

headline: True Lies
abstract: Forget fictionalized memoirs. More troubling are the countless novels tainted by elements of truth.
lead_paragraph: In January, two California men, a political consultant and a professional chef, filed suit against Lance Armstrong and his publishers after his interview with Oprah Winfrey, in which he confessed to blood doping and using other performance-enhancing drugs during his Tour de France championship spree. In their complaint, the litigants claimed they would not have purchased Armstrong’s autobiographies “It’s Not About the Bike” (2000) and “Every Second Counts” (2003) had they known that the books were built on a foundation of lies. Any inspirational messages contained within, they alleged, were communicated with a flagrant disregard for truth. Armstrong’s stories of training vigilantly and succeeding as a result grossly misrepresented actual circumstance. Moreover, the lawsuit suggested, the two books were categorically dishonest: they were marketed as nonfiction when they were, it turns out, fictitious.

headline: Requiem
abstract: In this memoir, Emily Rapp describes the months after learning of her young son’s fatal genetic disorder.
lead_paragraph: The “grief memoir” is by now a well-established subgenre of autobiography, the array of recent books about dead loved ones a veritable graveyard. The best of these — Jamaica Kincaid’s “My Brother” and Peter Handke’s “Sorrow Beyond Dreams” — aren’t just sad stories; they’re attempts to write one’s way out of the crisis. So it is with Emily Rapp’s “Still Point of the Turning World,” a memoir in which a mother’s grief occasions a brilliant study of the wages of mortal love.

headline: El N.B.A.: Insulting Latino Names or Smart Marketing?
abstract: Quirks of the game: The N.B.A. courts Latino fans with its Noche Latina promotions, but does calling its teams El Heat or Los Bulls appeal to Spanish speakers, or insult them?
lead_paragraph: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times sports blogs.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Sarah Manguso’s tastes have always run to memoirs that test and topple the boundaries of the form.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Manguso, who reviews a new memoir by Emily Rapp this week, is a poet and the author of two lacerating personal accounts: “The Two Kinds of Decay” (2009), her story of suffering from a rare neurological disease in her 20s, and “The Guardians” (2012), in which she reckoned with the suicide of a close friend.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Pat Summitt, the renowned women’s basketball coach who won eight national championships at the University of Tennessee, is now a No. 1 best-selling author, with the memoir “Sum It Up.”
lead_paragraph: A FISH CALLED GENO: Pat Summitt, the renowned women’s basketball coach from the University of Tennessee, is used to being No. 1: with 1,098 career victories, eight national championships and a win-loss ratio of .840, she is by some measures the most successful coach in N.C.A.A. history. So it makes a poetic kind of sense that her memoir — the wincingly titled “Sum It Up,” written with Sally Jenkins — would shoot straight to the top in its first week on the hardcover nonfiction list. The book is tumultuous and engaging (“one long roar of acceleration,” as Summitt describes her undefeated 1997-98 season), and unafraid to throw a good-natured elbow or two.

headline: How Sweet It Is
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Sugar', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Salt']
abstract: Michael Moss reveals how food companies use science to maximize our cravings for their products.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain enlightened segment of America that relishes a good gastro-scolding, whether delivered gently by a Michael Pollan (“Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants”) or more vituperatively by a Mark Bittman (“In the time it takes to go into a McDonald’s, stand in line, order, wait, pay and leave, you could make oatmeal for four while taking your vitamins, brushing your teeth and half-unloading the dishwasher”). But there is a much larger segment of America whose members heedlessly eat processed foods that make them overweight and unwell. Michael Moss, a dogged investigative reporter who neither scolds nor proselytizes, is here for them.

headline: Sea of Tranquillity
abstract: A 10-year-old with a hallucinatory consciousness is reclaimed from a monastery by his mother.
lead_paragraph: Thomas O’Malley’s second novel begins with a typewritten memo, a reproduction of the never-­delivered statement William Safire prepared for President Nixon in case the Apollo 11 moon landing went disastrously wrong and astronauts were stranded on the lunar surface, left to be “mourned by a Mother Earth that dared send two of her sons into the unknown.”

headline: Full House
abstract: A summer home both shelters and isolates the family in Elizabeth Graver’s multigenerational novel.
lead_paragraph: Late in Elizabeth Graver’s eloquent new novel, a therapist warns a very troubled young man against what he calls the “geographic” cure: “You can’t fix yourself by going somewhere else. . . . You’ll always take yourself along.” The young man, convinced that his family’s summer home on the coast of Massachusetts is the only place he has ever been happy, instantly bristles. “Ashaunt,” Charlie insists, isn’t “somewhere else.” By now, having occupied this windswept spit of land along with the Porters from World War II through Vietnam, Graver’s readers will be inclined to agree. It is indeed special, sometimes almost magical. But we also realize, having come to know the other lives entangled with Charlie’s, that Ashaunt’s spell can involve something much more complex than a dearly held childhood attachment, that a house like this, where “everyone could be together and so tight,” can also feel “vise tight, tight enough to blow a fuse.” The therapist may be right. Wherever they go, Graver’s characters will carry Ashaunt along, but its look and feel will be different for each of them, colored by the emotions they inhabit just as intimately as they do its drafty rooms and sandy footpaths.

headline: Jump-Cuts
abstract: In Renata Adler’s reissued novels, vignette follows vignette.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when her name would provoke admiration, anger and, not infrequently, fear. Renata Adler was a purveyor of definitive judgments, of arguments that seemed to march inexorably from a firmly held point of view. In the late ’60s, during a 14-month stint as a film critic for The New York Times, she eviscerated a good deal of what Hollywood had to offer. (Her loathing for John Wayne’s hyper-­patriotic “Green Berets” — “so unspeakable, so stupid, so rotten and false in every detail” — was entered into the Congressional Record by Strom Thurmond, who cited it as definitive proof “that this must be one of the most admirable movies of our generation.”) In 1980, she wrote an 8,000-word essay in The New York Review of Books that denounced the work of Pauline Kael as “piece by piece, line by line, and without interruption, worthless.” Throughout it all, she was a writer for The New Yorker, and her memoir of nearly 30 years there was similarly unsparing, showing that her category of “old friend” wasn’t necessarily distinct from that of “fair game.” She seemed dissatisfied with merely cutting something down to size; whatever offended her had to be put out of its miserable existence, and she wielded her hatchet with methodical and merciless strokes.

headline: International Aid
abstract: Alex Berenson’s superspy tries to rescue four relief workers kidnapped by a Somali warlord.
lead_paragraph: This is the seventh outing for Alex Berenson’s central character, John Wells, and the mileage is starting to show. Although “The Night Ranger” is skillfully engineered, its action hero feels distinctly weary.

headline: Arista Cat
abstract: Clive Davis reviews his career as a hit-maker.
lead_paragraph: No mere vulgar showbiz reminiscence — and that’s kind of a pity — Clive Davis’s autobiography has the ceremonious heft we associate with presidential memoirs. At 586 dense pages, “The Soundtrack of My Life” is dwarfed by Bill Clinton’s herculean “My Life.” But it leaves the shrimpy 497 pages of George W. Bush’s “Decision Points” looking like an amuse-bouche.

headline: Five Easy Pieces
abstract: Two novellas, three stories, shared memories.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Faulks’s “novel in five parts” isn’t really a novel — any more than Gertrude Stein’s “Three Lives” is a novel or, indeed, the book that inspired Stein’s, Flaubert’s splendid “Three Tales.” “A Possible Life” consists of three short stories, bookended by two novellas, each set, like Flaubert’s, in a different place and historical period. Indeed, Faulks’s story “Jeanne” is a retelling of the Flaubert tale “A Simple Heart,” but without the parrot.

headline: Carnal Knowledge
abstract: Lucy Ellmann’s novel follows the romantic escapades of a New York plastic surgeon who discovers his inner feminist.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Ellmann’s sixth novel, “Mimi,” starts off promisingly, and there are passages that mark her as a talented and erudite writer. But that Ellmann appears to share a word processor with another Lucy Ellmann, who insists on aggressively cloying tics: exclamation marks, Capital Letters and italics. She deploys these mannerisms with such remorseless, in-your-face frequency that the reader is left wondering whether Ellmann is attempting some elusive gestalt. Elusive, that is, unless gestalt also means “self-indulgent” in German.

headline: A Woman of Importance
abstract: Constance Wilde was more than just a long-suffering wife.
lead_paragraph: No one was ever more suitably named, at birth and by marriage, than Constance Wilde. Her first name conveys her near-endless loyalty to her irresponsible, genius husband, Oscar. Even after the worst of the humiliations — after he had taken up with the pretty young Lord Alfred Douglas and been sent to prison for the affair, after her household goods had been auctioned to pay the high-living Oscar’s debts, after she had fled to the Continent and changed the family name to protect their two small sons — she could still refer to him as a “poor, poor fellow” and write in a letter, “What a tragedy for him who is so gifted!”

headline: Lost Letters
abstract: Philip Hensher on the fading art of writing longhand.
lead_paragraph: In an era when the comment “You’re all thumbs” can be taken as high praise of texting prowess, the notion of hand writing a note, a business letter or even a grocery list seems quaint — like studying elocution or fastening shoes with mother-of-pearl buttons. Bemoaning the decline of the written hand smacks of fogyism, but the British novelist Philip Hensher, who is also a columnist for The Independent and an arts critic for The Spectator, enlivens his musings about penmanship’s demise with sharp insights and wry wit. In “The Missing Ink,” he argues that handwriting fills a human need: “It involves us in a relationship with the written word which is sensuous, immediate and individual. It opens our personality out to the world, and gives us a means of reading other people.”

headline: In China, Lessons Learned on the Yangtze (and in Shanghai)
abstract: The Frugal Traveler leads the way up the Yangtze River — after a stop in Shanghai — on budget of $50 a day, and finds plenty of lessons to pass on to readers.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s special Asia issue, the Frugal Traveler leads the way up the Yangtze River, on a budget of $50 a day, and finds plenty of lessons to pass on to readers. But first, he finds a soft landing in Shanghai, a surprisingly budget-friendly destination.

headline: Weighing Metaphysics, Mortality and, Yes, Infatuation
abstract: This week offers new releases by Veronica Falls, Suuns, Alice Smith, Youth Lagoon, How to Destroy Angels and Draco Rosa.
lead_paragraph: Veronica Falls

headline: Before an Actor Became an ‘Actor’
abstract: The BBC this week is releasing samples of Daniel Day-Lewis’s 1980s television work, a chance to see an Oscar-winning performer in his days of apprenticeship.
lead_paragraph: As Daniel Day-Lewis cracked jokes on the Oscars stage last month two related thoughts came to mind. First, why wasn’t any of this wit evident in his disconnected, oddly timid performance in “Lincoln,” for which he had just won the best actor award?

headline: In Time for St. Patrick’s Day, a Visit From Obama’s Irish Cousin
abstract: Henry Healy is just one of many Irish visitors in town for St. Patrick’s festivities, but he is the only Irishman or woman who can say his cousin is the president of the United States.
lead_paragraph: With St. Patrick’s Day looming on Sunday and the big parade set to march down Fifth Avenue on Saturday, Henry Healy is just one of many Irish visitors in town for the festivities.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BEAUTIFUL SOULS: The Courage and Conscience of Ordinary People in Extraordinary Times,  by Eyal Press. (Picador, $15.) What impels people to defy authority and convention? Sharing insights from sociology, political theory, neuroscience and philosophy, Press traces the paths of four dissenters: a Swiss police commander who broke the law to help Jewish refugees in 1938; a Serb who saved Croats by lying about their ethnic identity; an Israeli soldier who refused to serve in the occupied territories; and a financial industry whistle-blower.

headline: I.M.F. Says Euro Zone Remains Vulnerable
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The International Monetary Fund urged European leaders to create a mechanism for winding down failed banks and a system to guarantee customer deposits in order to prevent runs on banks.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The euro zone remains vulnerable to shocks because of weak banks and incomplete regulatory safeguards, the International Monetary Fund said Friday, in a warning to European leaders not to slacken their efforts to build a more resilient financial system.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LEAN IN: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead,  by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf, $24.95.) The lesson conveyed loud and clear by the Facebook executive is that women should step forward and not doubt their ability to combine work and family.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A nicely renovated Upper West Side two-bedroom, an Upper East Side prewar with a fireplace and a Cobble Hill floor-through with parking.
lead_paragraph: A nicely renovated Upper West Side two-bedroom, an Upper East Side prewar with a fireplace and a Cobble Hill floor-through with parking.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A five-bedroom contemporary in Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and a Westchester, N.Y., home with a high-end kitchen renovation.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom contemporary in Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and a Westchester, N.Y., home with a high-end kitchen renovation.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Michael Moss talks about “Salt Sugar Fat”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Jennifer Szalai discusses the fiction of Renata Adler; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Michael Moss talks about “Salt Sugar Fat”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Jennifer Szalai discusses the fiction of Renata Adler; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: TimesCast: Regulating Big Banks
abstract: The New York Times’s David Gillen on new findings against JPMorgan Chase, and Louise Story talks to Thomas Hoenig of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who says banks are too big to manage.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s David Gillen on new findings against JPMorgan Chase, and Louise Story talks to Thomas Hoenig of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who says banks are too big to manage.

headline: Book Review Podcast: America’s Food Cravings
abstract: Michael Moss discusses his new book, “Salt Sugar Fat.”
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, David Kamp reviews Michael Moss’s “Salt Sugar Fat,” an investigation of America’s relationship with processed foods. Mr. Kamp writes:

headline: Israelis Form Government Days Before Obama Visit
abstract: The new government is made up of five factions with somewhat contradictory positions on critical questions including the Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Political leaders on Friday signed agreements to form a new Israeli government that would almost certainly complicate the prospect of jump-starting a moribund peace process, focus attention on the economy and widen the rift between the ultra-Orthodox and more secular communities.

headline: Maxim Magazine Exploring a Sale
abstract: The magazine’s owner, Alpha Media Group, said it was exploring a sale now after transitioning from a magazine to a ”multichannel brand.”
lead_paragraph: Maxim, the lad mag that doles out advice and ribald humor that is especially appreciated in military circles, is on the market.

headline: A Border Transformed
abstract: Arizona’s boundary with Mexico was once considered the busiest border battlefront, and officials have declared that they will make a “last stand” there.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s boundary with Mexico was once considered the busiest border battlefront, and officials have declared that they will make a “last stand” there.

headline: Securing the Border
abstract: United States Border Patrol agents in Arizona’s Tucson sector say the border is safer and more secure than ever, but can it withstand a potential new wave of illegal immigration?
lead_paragraph: United States Border Patrol agents in Arizona’s Tucson sector say the border is safer and more secure than ever, but can it withstand a potential new wave of illegal immigration?

headline: Readers Capture the Complexity of the U.S.-Mexican Border
abstract: Readers submitted their photographs showing just how diverse and inconsistent the barrier along the 2,000-mile divide can be.
lead_paragraph: Readers submitted their photographs showing just how diverse and inconsistent the barrier along the 2,000-mile divide can be.

headline: TimesTalks | Marina Abramovic: Preview
abstract: The celebrated performance artist discusses her long career and talks about her new and upcoming projects.
lead_paragraph: The celebrated performance artist discusses her long career and talks about her new and upcoming projects.

headline: Marina Abramovic: Collaborations
abstract: Part 3: The artist talks about working with the theater director Robert Wilson, the musician Antony Hegarty and the actor Willem Dafoe.
lead_paragraph: Part 3: The artist talks about working with the theater director Robert Wilson, the musician Antony Hegarty and the actor Willem Dafoe.

headline: Marina Abramovic: My Nose
abstract: Part 15: The artist talks about how her life has been changed by her work.
lead_paragraph: Part 15: The artist talks about how her life has been changed by her work.

headline: Marina Abramovic: My Mother
abstract: Part 5: The artist reflects on her childhood and discusses her legacy..
lead_paragraph: Part 5: The artist reflects on her childhood and discusses her legacy..

headline: Marina Abramovic: Absolute Bottom
abstract: Part 11: The artist discusses the diverse audience interpretations of her work.
lead_paragraph: Part 11: The artist discusses the diverse audience interpretations of her work.

headline: Marina Abramovic: Science
abstract: Part 7: The artist discusses the differences in American and European sensibilities, and reflects on the possibility of collaboration between art and technology.
lead_paragraph: Part 7: The artist discusses the differences in American and European sensibilities, and reflects on the possibility of collaboration between art and technology.

headline: Marina Abramovic: Onstage Trauma
abstract: Part 4: The artist explains the most difficult part of creating her stage show, “The Life And Death Of Marina Abramovic.”
lead_paragraph: Part 4: The artist explains the most difficult part of creating her stage show, “The Life And Death Of Marina Abramovic.”

headline: Marina Abramovic: The Institute
abstract: Part 6: The artist talks about her plans for the Marina Abramovic Institute, and explains how she thinks people should experience art.
lead_paragraph: Part 6: The artist talks about her plans for the Marina Abramovic Institute, and explains how she thinks people should experience art.

headline: Marina Abramovic: What Art Demands
abstract: Part 9: The artist talks about her process and shares her thoughts on what it takes to make a career in art.

headline: Arizona Border Quiets After Gains in Security
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Mexican-Americans', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Series']
abstract: As Congress debates an overhaul of immigration laws, border officials in Arizona say that they have already made many enforcement advances that lawmakers seek.
lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — Flying low along the Mexican line in a Black Hawk helicopter, the United States Border Patrol officer saw surveillance towers rising above the cactus. He saw his agents’ white and green trucks moving among the mesquite, scouting for illegal crossers.

headline: Japan Moves to Enter Talks on Pacific Trade
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe portrayed the Trans-Pacific Partnership as Japan’s “last chance” to remain an economic power in Asia.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan will seek to join negotiations for a free-trade pact with the United States and other Pacific nations, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Friday, giving heft to talks that could encompass two-fifths of the world economy but also adding a country with demands and reservations that some participants fear will delay an agreement.

headline: FedEx to Pay City $2.4 Million in Cigarette-Tax Settlement
abstract: From 2006 to 2009, the city said, FedEx Ground delivered about 160,000 cartons of untaxed cigarettes that New Yorkers had ordered from CigarettesDirect2U.com.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:31 p.m. | FedEx’s ground-carrier division will pay New York City $2.4 million to settle a claim that the shipping giant delivered untaxed cigarettes to consumers in New York, the city announced Friday.

headline: How to Watch the NYC Half
abstract: There are a number of prime viewing spots along the route of the NYC Half, scheduled for Sunday.
lead_paragraph: People yearning to see the world’s fastest runners glide through city streets will have their chance Sunday morning in the NYC Half.

headline: Reading, Writing and Video Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Learning']
abstract: The concepts of work and play have become farcically reversed: schoolwork is meant to be superfun and play, like homework, is meant to teach.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a child, I liked to play video games. On my brother’s Atari, I played Night Driver. On his Apple II, I played Microwave, Aztec and Taipan! When I got to go to the arcade, I played Asteroids and Space Invaders.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Counter Culture Coffee, a roaster based in Durham, N.C., is hosting its 2013 Cup Tasters Challenge on Friday at its regional training centers across the country. At each, competitors will taste three coffees and identify their differences. At the New York center, at 37 West 26th Street in Chelsea, it’s $5 per person to attend and $10 to compete.

headline: Here, There and Everywhere: Assistant Coaches
abstract: Each team is allowed three assistant coaches, but when support staffers are added in, there seem to be more. Way more.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In college basketball, they are blurred backdrops to the back and forth of the game and the tight close-ups of the leading man. Like movie extras, they get screen time but barely any credit.

headline: After Five Years
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: When the Great Recession began five years ago, there were fears it could turn into a new Great Depression. That did not happen — except in Greece. This week Greece reported that its real gross domestic product fell for the fifth consecutive year, leaving the 2012 Greek economy 20 percent smaller than it was in 2007. The charts contrast the past five years in Greece with the same period after 1929 in the United States. All figures are adjusted for inflation. The economic numbers show the total change for each year compared with the base year.
lead_paragraph: When the Great Recession began five years ago, there were fears it could turn into a new Great Depression. That did not happen — except in Greece. This week Greece reported that its real gross domestic product fell for the fifth consecutive year, leaving the 2012 Greek economy 20 percent smaller than it was in 2007. The charts contrast the past five years in Greece with the same period after 1929 in the United States. All figures are adjusted for inflation. The economic numbers show the total change for each year compared with the base year.

headline: Looking for a Lesson in Google’s Perks
abstract: Whatever might be said of Yahoo’s workplace, it’s a long way from Google’s, whose various offices reflect the company’s overarching philosophy to create a happy and productive environment.
lead_paragraph: After Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, ordered employees working from home to show up at the office for work, there was speculation that she was emulating Google, her previous employer.

headline: Now Showing | Keith Edmier
abstract: For his show in the Netherlands, American sculptor Keith Edmier chose to focus on an apt subject: tulip mania.
lead_paragraph: The American sculptor Keith Edmier got his start in Hollywood, so it’s not entirely surprising that his work is influenced by pop culture. Over the years he’s worked with at least a couple of recognizable actresses, using an adolescent, prefame Lena Dunham as the model for a cast of his childhood crush in 1997 and collaborating with the actress and artist Farrah Fawcett. The result is a body of autobiographical work that is relatable to different generations.

headline: ‘Django’ Composer Takes Aim at Tarantino
abstract: Ennio Morricone, who has worked on four Quentin Tarantino films, told film students in Rome that he would never collaborate with the director again, saying he “places music in his films without coherence.”
lead_paragraph: Quentin Tarantino may have won an Oscar for “Django Unchained” (for best original screenplay), but he’s getting less than favorable reviews from the composer who supplied some whistle-heavy spaghetti western tracks for the movie’s soundtrack.

headline: Keller Agrees to Deal With Dolphins
abstract: Tight end Dustin Keller agreed to a one-year deal with Miami, a move that seems to weaken the Jets and strengthen one of their A.F.C. East rivals.
lead_paragraph: In a move that weakens the Jets and strengthens one of their A.F.C. East rivals, tight end Dustin Keller agreed to a one-year deal with the Miami Dolphins on Friday. Keller’s departure is the latest in a string of defections to strike the Jets, who have already lost three starters on defense and two on offense as free agents, with more likely to leave.

headline: Kosher Wines for the Seder Table
abstract: With wines easily found in stores, plan a Seder with one sparkling, one white, one red and one fortified without straying from the kosher path.
lead_paragraph: TO THE FOUR QUESTIONS that form the basis of the Seder, wine lovers habitually add a fifth: where is it written that kosher wine must be sweet, thick and unpalatable? Though some Jews retain a sentimental attachment to the jamlike pleasures of Concord grape wines, many desire something better. Much better.

headline: A Live Discussion of ‘Lean In:’ Sheryl Sandberg’s Chicken-and-Egg Problem
abstract: A live discussion of Sheryl Sandberg’s “Lean In” with KJ Dell’Antonia, Leslie Bennetts, Jessica Bennet, and Jennifer Romaniuk.
lead_paragraph: This conversation has ended, but you can read it in its entirety below. Have an opinion about how it worked or how it shaped? Please, share in the comments.

headline: SAC Capital to Pay $616 Million in Insider Trading Cases
abstract: Two affiliates of the giant hedge fund have settled insider trading cases with the S.E.C., for $616 million, in what the agency said was the biggest ever settlement for such cases.
lead_paragraph: 10:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: Assemblyman Is Charged With Marijuana Possession
abstract: Stephen M. Katz, a Republican from Mohegan Lake, was found with a “small bag” of  the drug after he was stopped for speeding, the State Police said.
lead_paragraph: A New York State assemblyman from the Hudson Valley was charged with marijuana possession after he was stopped for speeding, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: London Journal: From the Engine Room to the Dacha
abstract: James Graham’s “This House” finds suspense in the wheelings and dealings of Britain’s Parliament; Heather Headley shines as a pop goddess in “The Bodyguard”; and William Boyd tries his hand at an adaptation for the stage, with “Longing.”
lead_paragraph: It was with a leaden sense of duty that I dragged myself – through a stinging snowfall, no less – to the National Theater the other night to see “This House” by James Graham. What lay before me was nearly three hours of re-enactments of life in the House of Commons four decades ago. What did I know from parliamentary politics, especially from the 1970s?

headline: An About-Face on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: It’s becoming fashionable for Republicans like Senator Rob Portman to drop their opposition to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming positively fashionable for Republicans who no longer think they have a shot at national office to drop their opposition to gay marriage.

headline: Seen From Greece, Great Depression Looks Good
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Charts compare changes in gross domestic product and unemployment in the United States during the five years after 1929 with the changes in Greece during the five years after 2007.
lead_paragraph: FIVE years into the Great Depression, one out of five workers in the United States was unemployed. The economy was nearly 20 percent smaller in 1934 than it had been at the peak, in 1929.

headline: Tunic Time
abstract: The singer and songwriter Fergie says: “Being four months pregnant, I need to be comfortable, but I don’t want to be frumpy.”
lead_paragraph: The Grammy-winning singer and songwriter Stacy Ann Ferguson (better known as Fergie), 37, grew up in Hacienda Heights, Calif. Aside from music, she also runs her own Fergie Footwear line; the wine label Ferguson Crest with her father, Pat Ferguson; and a makeup collection with Wet N Wild, which started this year. She lives in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles with her husband, the actor Josh Duhamel, with whom she is expecting her first child.

headline: Full Statement From Jesuit Kidnapped by Argentine Junta on New Pope
abstract: An English translation of the statement released on Friday by Fr. Franz Jalics, a Jesuit priest who was kidnapped by the Argentine military in 1976, when he served under the man who was appointed pope this week.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 5:03 p.m. BERLIN — The Vatican rejected accusations on Friday that the newly appointed Pope Francis had failed to stand up for two Jesuit priests who served under him when they were kidnapped by the military in 1976, during the so-called Dirty War in his home country of Argentina.

headline: Learning the Hard Way About a Banned Ingredient
abstract: The stimulant DMAA is banned by numerous sports groups, but is still found in supplements sold at stores including GNC, as a tennis player discovered too late.
lead_paragraph: THE stimulant DMAA has been banned by the World Anti-Doping Agency, the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Major League Baseball. But it is still found in Jack3d and other supplements sold at stores like GNC and the Vitamin Shoppe.

headline: Concern Over Violence Grows in Karachi as a Social Worker Is Mourned
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Politicians and newspapers paid tribute to the victim, Parween Rahman, who was shot dead by unidentified assassins on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Concern over deteriorating law and order in Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city, continued to grow Friday as politicians and newspapers paid tribute to a celebrated social worker who was shot dead by unidentified assassins.

headline: Is the Seller to Blame?
keywords: ['Dimethylamylamine (DMMA)', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Consumer Protection', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Liability for Products']
abstract: After a soldier died, his parents took aim at a dietary supplement — and the retail chain GNC, where he bought it.
lead_paragraph: EVERY morning as she gets dressed for her accounting job, Leanne Sparling hangs her son’s military dog tags and a photograph of him in uniform around her neck. She wears the tags on the outside of her clothes, hoping to prompt strangers to ask about him. “When I do tell them what happened,” she says, “they are in total disbelief.”

headline: For Spurs, Belief in Popovich Trumps Strategy
abstract: The details of San Antonio Coach Gregg Popovich coaching strategies are secondary to how much his players believe in them.
lead_paragraph: In the closing moments of Thursday night’s game against Dallas and with the Spurs holding a one-point lead, San Antonio Coach Gregg Popovich pulled Tim Duncan in favor of Boris Diaw. From a pure basketball perspective, it wasn’t shocking. When the opposing team has the ball and a shot to win with 5.6 seconds left, most coaches want their most mobile, effective defenders on the floor.

headline: As Gun Measures Advance, Spotlight Falls on Reid
abstract: How four bills are presented to the full Senate — and which ones Senator Harry Reid chooses to promote — will probably reshape the debate over what to do about gun violence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – For months, as gun control advocates and gun rights groups have held competing rallies, senators have debated and President Obama has implored Congress to act, one key player, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, has remained largely on the sidelines of the national debate over guns.

lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week is about two groups of people — in very different occupations — who are similar in the potential for ups and downs in their income. They are real estate investors and people who work for social media companies.

headline: Sleek Storm Style
abstract: Unfazed by the mix of sleet and winds in winter, the Swedes keep their cool, often in a functional but sleek coat.
lead_paragraph: On a recent trip to Stockholm, I learned that the Swedes never stop looking cool. Unfazed by the mix of face-piercing sleet and blustery winds in winter, the guys maintain that enviable minimal style, often in a functional but sleek coat, like the one pictured here by Stutterheim. Based on the founder Alexander Stutterheim’s grandfather’s old fishing coat, the Arholma style is cut from rubberized cotton and hand-sewn (and signed) by a seamstress in the small town of Boras. Available in black, forest green, yellow and dusty white, $735; barneys.com. Jil Sander shirt; jilsander.com. Hermès pants; hermes.com.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Thailand, India, Singapore
abstract: Global festivals worth traveling for.
lead_paragraph: Songkran Water Festival, ThailandA nation takes to the streets with squirt guns, super-soakers, buckets and hoses in a no-holds-barred water fight. It sounds like a child’s fantasy, but it’s a description of Songkran, the Thai New Year celebration, from April 13 to April 15. The tradition takes place because Buddhists consider this time of year a period of cleansing and renewal, symbolized by water. But the country-wide water festival is also a way to get soaked and cool off during peak hot season. One way to stay dry: Centara Hotels & Resorts is offering a package that includes a Songkran survival kit (two water shooters and plastic waterproof covers for valuables) and one-night stay from 2,907 baht, $101, for two people.

headline: TiVo Explains Extra Charge for the Mini

lead_paragraph: In my column in The Times on Thursday, I reviewed the TiVo Mini. It’s a small plastic box that lets you gain access to your TiVo from another television in the house without having to buy a second entire TiVo.

headline: U.S. Is Bolstering Missile Defense to Deter North Korea
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Pentagon will deploy more missile interceptors on the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon will spend $1 billion to deploy additional ballistic missile interceptors along the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence and indications that Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, is resisting China’s efforts to restrain him.

abstract: Comedies like “Admission,” starring Tina Fey, examine women and childbirth: when they seek motherhood, when they don’t and when they give up children for adoption.

headline: Judge Allows Suit Over Aluminum Corrosion in Fords to Move Forward
abstract: The class action suit claims Ford used aluminum hoods but failed to properly insulate them from “old iron-based connecting and supporting parts,” despite knowing that “would give rise to galvanic coupling” and corrosion.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge says that a class action suit claiming corrosion on aluminum body panels has reduced the value of millions of cars and trucks made by Ford should proceed with depositions being taken this year.

Miller will be part of the broadcast team covering the tournament for Turner Sports.

headline: Home Buyers Seek Manhattan Wrecks
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Real estate brokers and analysts report a significant uptick in the number of people seeking fixer-uppers.
lead_paragraph: For people scrambling to make their way in the real estate market, there are many routes, and one of the most adventurous involves buying what brokers often describe as wrecks (fixer-upper is the more diplomatic term). An anemic inventory combined with increasing reluctance to shell out huge sums of money for other people’s taste is sending a growing number of buyers to places they can redo to their own liking, right down to the shape of the kitchen island and the color of the bathroom tile.

headline: Romney’s Late Stump Speech
abstract: The 2012 candidate said conservatives would win, in the end.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — Because he could no longer threaten dire consequences if Barack Obama won reelection, Mitt Romney condemned pessimism at CPAC on Friday. “It’s fashionable in some circles to be pessimistic,” he said, but “I utterly reject pessimism.” The campaign did not diminish his “optimism about America,” but increased it.

headline: A Carole King Musical Is Broadway Bound
abstract: “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical,” featuring Ms. King’s music and the story of her life, is scheduled to open on Broadway in spring 2014, with a book by Douglas McGrath.
lead_paragraph: In 1960, the Shirelles recorded “Will You Love Me Tomorrow,” which turned out to be the first No. 1 hit by a young, married songwriting team, Carole King and Gerry Goffin. Their marriage ended in 1968, but the pop music world continued to love their work, and the songs Ms. King continued to write, for decades.
