headline: The New Rules for Reporting Stock Sales
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Bucks readers discuss their experience with a new rule that requires their brokerage firms to report to the I.R.S. the price they paid for certain taxable investments.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column discusses the ins and outs of a new law that requires your investment brokerage firm to report to the Internal Revenue Service the price you paid for certain taxable investments.

headline: Other Europeans Balk at Bid by Britain and France to Arm Syria’s Rebels
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Gen. Salim Idriss, the leader of the Free Syrian Army, sought to rebut key arguments against arming the rebels, including fears of sectarian conflict and Islamist influence.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As the Syrian crisis entered its third year on Friday, the top rebel military leader declared that the opposition would “never give up” and asked for more support, even as a push by France and Britain to arm the outgunned rebels drew heavy resistance from other European countries.

headline: U.N. Calls Lag in Syria Aid Worst Funding Crisis in Recent Memory
abstract: Relief agencies are expressing alarm at the slow arrival and modest levels of financial support they are receiving to help the tens of thousands of civilians who have been fleeing Syria’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As Syria’s crisis moves into its third year, international relief agencies are expressing alarm at the slow arrival and modest levels of financial support they are receiving to help the tens of thousands of civilians who have been fleeing the conflict and the millions trapped inside the country whose plight becomes more desperate.

headline: Wines of The Times: Pinot Gris From Oregon
abstract: A wine with significant character for its price range, and one that is made in a wide variety of styles, Oregon pinot gris fascinates some panel members and frustrates others.
lead_paragraph: A wine with significant character for its price range, and one that is made in a wide variety of styles, Oregon pinot gris fascinates some panel members and frustrates others.

headline: Britain’s Plans for New Nuclear Plant Approach a Decisive Point, 4 Years Late
abstract: The British energy minister is expected to approve the country’s first new nuclear power plant in two decades, though it is already four years behind schedule.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If all goes according to plan, the British energy minister on Tuesday will formally approve construction of the country’s first new nuclear power plant in nearly two decades.

headline: Another Carnival Gets Stuck, This Time in Port
abstract: A month after Carnival Cruise Line had to tug the Triumph to port because it was disabled by a fire, there’s a problem with another one of its ships — the Dream.
lead_paragraph: A month after Carnival Cruise Line had to tug the Triumph to port because it was disabled by a fire, there’s a problem with another one of its ships — the Dream.

headline: Off-Track Intrigue as Season Opens
abstract: The first of 19 races in the 2013 Formula One world drivers and constructors championships was held last weekend in Australia, but much of the drama was taking place off the track.
lead_paragraph: By the time New Yorkers have gulped their first cup of Starbucks on Sunday morning, the first of 19 races in the 2013 Formula One world drivers and constructors championships will have finished in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: Bill Would Bar Youth From Buying Ice Picks
abstract: Legislation introduced in the City Council would prohibit the sale of ice picks and awls to anyone under 21, extending rules that already apply to box cutters.
lead_paragraph: If you’re buying beer, you need to show some ID. Planning to pick ice? You’ll need to do the same if legislation introduced Thursday in the City Council is enacted to bar those under 21 from buying an ice pick.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Romania, West Bank and Zimbabwe.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Romania, West Bank and Zimbabwe.

headline: Among G.O.P. Voters, Little Support for Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: An increasing number of high-profile Republicans, like Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, have recently announced support for same-sex marriage. But polling of rank-and-file Republicans shows they are still largely opposed.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Senator Rob Portman, a Republican from Ohio, to announce his support for same-sex marriage may come to be seen as a watershed moment for gay rights advocates. Mr. Portman’s announcement, which he said he made in part because his son is gay, has so far yielded relatively little pushback from Republicans on blogs and social media, or from other Republican office-holders. Instead, gay rights advocates are increasingly finding support from influential Republicans.

headline: After Negotiations, Cyprus Agrees to a Euro Zone Bailout Package
abstract: The agreement reached early Saturday puts some of the burden for shoring up the island’s beleaguered economy on its bank depositors.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Cyprus reached a long-awaited bailout agreement early Saturday that puts some of the burden for shoring up the island’s beleaguered economy on its bank depositors.

headline: Haroseth Truffles
keywords: ['Passover', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Recipes', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Food']
abstract: Tired of making the same old haroseth for Passover? Melissa Clark adds a new twist with a recipe for Sephardic haroseth truffles.
lead_paragraph: Tired of making the same old haroseth for Passover? Melissa Clark adds a new twist with a recipe for Sephardic haroseth truffles.

headline: Jets’ Cheap Seats Get a Little Cheaper
abstract: About 3,000 seats in the upper bowl will be lowered to $50 per game, bringing the total to 9,000 seats, or about one-third of the upper bowl, that will be priced at this level.
lead_paragraph: After winning just six games last season, their worst showing since 2007, the Jets said Friday that they were trimming the price of some of their cheapest tickets and not increasing the price of the other 80,000 seats in MetLife Stadium.

headline: The Secret at the Back of the Liquor Cabinet
abstract: A salad inspired by the Seder staple haroseth, and infused with Manischewitz Concord grape wine.
lead_paragraph: OTHER THAN HAROSETH and Caribbean black cake, there are not a lot of recipes calling for Manischewitz Concord grape wine. I know this because I’ve had the same bottle for what might be decades. I unearth the dusty thing during Passover to anoint my haroseth, then return the bottle to the depths of the liquor cabinet. It’s been a challenge to use up.

headline: Giambi Reinvents Himself, and Baseball Is Intrigued
abstract: Jason Giambi, who said his leaked testimony about using steroids was freeing, was a managerial candidate over the winter and is now a respected veteran in Indians camp.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz.

headline: Other People’s Children
abstract: You’re supposed to think about them, too.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Yglesias beats me to a point I was planning to make. Sen. Rob Portman has made headlines by declaring his support for gay marriage after learning that his own son is gay, and apparently we’re supposed to praise him for his new enlightenment. But while enlightenment is good, wouldn’t it have been a lot more praiseworthy if he had shown some flexibility on the issue before he knew that his own family would benefit?

headline: Should We Force Children into Sleep-Aways?
abstract: A fifth-grade class has a sleep-away field trip. What do do with a child who doesn’t want to go?
lead_paragraph: A reader’s child has a mandatory school sleep-away activity coming up. The fifth-grade class at her child’s (public) school traditionally spends a night away on a particular field trip, and the reader’s child doesn’t want to go.

headline: A Little Manischewitz Goes a Long Way
abstract: What to do with that bottle of holiday liquor in your cabinet.
lead_paragraph: This week’s column is all about trying to find new ways to use up that bottle of Manischewitz in my liquor cabinet. I decided to use the wine to candy walnuts, then tossed them into a haroseth-inspired apple salad.

headline: Pushing the Boundaries of the Workplace
abstract: Google’s East Coast headquarters is an unorthodox workplace with lavish perks that is meant to encourage creativity.
lead_paragraph: Google’s East Coast headquarters is an unorthodox workplace with lavish perks that is meant to encourage creativity.

headline: Scenes From Day 3 of South by Southwest Music
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: A slide show of images including performances by Follakzoid and The Generationals.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of images including performances by Follakzoid and The Generationals.

headline: Scenes From Day 3 of South by Southwest Music
abstract: A slide show of images of the festival.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of images from the festival.

headline: The Stories That Bind Us
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Parenting', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Studies indicate that children learn resilience when they hear what their relatives before them have faced.
lead_paragraph: I hit the breaking point as a parent a few years ago. It was the week of my extended family’s annual gathering in August, and we were struggling with assorted crises. My parents were aging; my wife and I were straining under the chaos of young children; my sister was bracing to prepare her preteens for bullying, sex and cyberstalking.

headline: A Chase Car to Lure Private Eyes Out of Retirement
abstract: The engineers of the SRT division have created a tuner edition of the 300, adding a raging bull of a Hemi engine that Rockford and Mannix would have loved.
lead_paragraph: When I think of people who’d fall hard for the Chrysler 300 SRT8, names come to mind: Kojak, Mannix, Rockford, Starsky and Hutch.

headline: The Second Coming of ‘Heaven’s Gate’
abstract: “Heaven’s Gate,” the 1980 film that torpedoed both a legendary studio and the New Hollywood era, has been restored and gets a new lease on life.
lead_paragraph: What was Michael Cimino thinking the day he pulled up to the Polo Lounge in Beverly Hills in his Rolls-Royce Corniche, three months before the release of his second, much-anticipated film, “The Deer Hunter” and seven months before he began shooting his third — possibly the costliest film ever made about class war?

headline: Hollywood’s New Role Model (Beard Optional)
abstract: Showbiz’s leading man of the moment is Ben Affleck. It’s a big turnaround from tabloid punch line to cinematic artist, showing that, in today’s industry, being serious is serious business.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It would be hard to imagine Frank Sinatra or Jack Nicholson or even Warren Beatty — easily the most politically active of his generation of actors — following up an Oscar win by making a beeline to the TED talks.

headline: In Sly Tweets, a Rich Lode for Comedy
abstract: Was that tongue-in-cheek? By flirting creatively with ambiguity, comedians branch out into fresh forms of humor.
lead_paragraph: The first time I noticed that Colin Quinn was doing something different on Twitter, he was attacking his former employer.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $14.25 Million, Luxury Combined
abstract: A 10-room residence with centerline vistas of Central Park and a Versailles-like entrance gallery was created by combining several units.
lead_paragraph: An alphabet’s worth of combined and adjacent apartments on the 21st floor of the opulent Trump Parc at 106 Central Park South, with commanding centerline vistas of Central Park and a Versailles-like 70-foot entrance gallery, sold for $14,250,000. The deal was the most expensive of the week, according to city records.

headline: Adieu to a Beloved VW
abstract: Thousands of cars were flooded with saltwater in Hurricane Sandy, including the VW Cabrio owned by Michael Winerip of The Times. He sadly follows this family treasure on its trip to the crusher.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of cars were flooded with saltwater in Hurricane Sandy, including the VW Cabrio owned by Michael Winerip of The Times. He sadly follows this family treasure on its trip to the crusher.

headline: Not Just a Car. A Storm Victim, Too.
abstract: My dear 2002 VW Cabrio  was pronounced dead on Feb. 21 at a Queens salvage yard, a victim of Hurricane Sandy. So I decided to follow the car each step of the way on its journey to the crusher.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — My dear, fun 2002 Volkswagen Cabrio — my black convertible summer car, the car that carried the family’s surfboards and bikes, that on warm nights with the top down, I’d take for moonlight drives along Jones Beach — was pronounced dead on Feb. 21 at the Alliance Auto Parts salvage yard at 50-16 72nd Street in Woodside, Queens, one more victim of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Building a Movie Language in Layers
abstract: Shane Carruth, whose first feature, “Primer,” won a prize at Sundance in 2004, returns with “Upstream Color.”
lead_paragraph: “I won’t always give satisfying answers,” the filmmaker Shane Carruth said, by way of warning, in an interview in early January. The premiere of his long-awaited second feature, “Upstream Color,” at the Sundance Film Festival was weeks away at the time. He was finishing the sound mix and working out the details of a self-distribution plan. But the greatest source of anxiety was the prospect of having to talk about his movie.

headline: The Long Goodbye
abstract: A victim of storm damage, the Volkswagen is survived by its owner, who was there with his beloved Cabrio to the very end.
lead_paragraph: A victim of storm damage, the Volkswagen is survived by its owner, who was there with his beloved Cabrio to the very end.

headline: Now Showing | Sverre Bjertnes
abstract: Bjarne Melgaard, often referred to as “the most famous Norwegian artist since Munch,” curates a retrospective for his friend, countryman and new Brooklyn studio-mate.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Girl Power
abstract: “Kick-Ass 2 Prelude: Hit-Girl” is No. 4 on the hardcover list this week.
lead_paragraph: Coming in at No. 4 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is “Kick-Ass 2 Prelude: Hit-Girl,” written by Mark Millar and illustrated by John Romita Jr. The book, published by Icon, an imprint of Marvel, involves the further adventures of Dave Lizewski, a young man who decides to fight crime as Kick-Ass, and Mindy Macready, who was trained by her father to be the lethal force for justice known as Hit-Girl. The premise of “Kick-Ass” is based in reality (what would it be like if heroes existed?), but the violence is amped up a thousandfold. It is somehow more absurd than some regular superhero comics, but infinitely more entertaining than most of them.

headline: Not Just Shakespeare
abstract: Photos of stage performances by Patrick Stewart.
lead_paragraph: Photos of stage performances by Patrick Stewart.

headline: Her Father’s Daughter: The Turbulent Life of Lisa de Kooning
abstract: Her death late last year at the age of 56 was one more puzzling turn in a life that had more than its share of drama.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 15, 2012, a mild early-winter day, some 250 guests filed into St. Luke’s Episcopal, a Gothic-style stone church in East Hampton, N.Y., for the memorial service of Lisa de Kooning, the only child and sole heir of Willem de Kooning, the Dutch-born Abstract Expressionist. She had died three weeks earlier, on Nov. 23, at her vacation home on St. John in the United States Virgin Islands. She was 56.

headline: Cleveland Does a Little Dance
abstract: Nick Swisher leads the Indians in a dance called the Tito–“just a little swivel in the hips.”
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — Terry Francona did not do much dancing at the end of his tenure as manager of the Boston Red Sox. His new team, the Cleveland Indians, is a livelier group. At least, it seems that way, judging by the new “Harlem Shake” video cooked up by the irrepressible Nick Swisher:

headline: Photo Replay: March 15
abstract: A view of the day in sports, from the slopes of Switzerland to basketball courts across the United States.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, from the slopes of Switzerland to basketball courts across the United States.

headline: Gulping Comic Bonbons
abstract: The French screenwriter Michel Audiard is honored with two comedies released on DVD by Olive Films.
lead_paragraph: France may be fabled as the country where the notion of the director as auteur first and most firmly took root, but Paris is certainly among the few cities where a public square is named after a screenwriter. La Place Michel-Audiard is in the Petit-Montrouge quarter of the 14th Arrondissement, a formerly working-class neighborhood where Audiard, the most celebrated “dialoguiste” of the French cinema, was born in 1920.

headline: Ram Dashboards Cracking
abstract: Hundreds of owners of older Ram trucks have complained that their dashboards are cracking, with some disintegrating.
lead_paragraph: When Joe Longo bought a new 2003 Dodge Ram 2500 he figured, even with a heavy-duty pickup, normal wear and tear would cause some parts to fail. But something happened that he had never imagined.

headline: Muscle Strain Could Put Wright’s Opening Day in Doubt
abstract: The Mets said third baseman David Wright, who was removed from the World Baseball Classic, would be re-evaluated after resting for up to five days.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The injuries for the Mets were already piling up, but to an extent they were palatable. The latest one may be harder to digest.

headline: After Guard’s Long Trip, Fordham Is Near a Berth
abstract: Stephanie Gaitley recruited Erin Rooney, who is from New Zealand, to Monmouth in 2009, and now they’re both at Fordham and possibly headed to the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: Erin Rooney could not help herself.

headline: Bill in North Dakota Bans Abortion After Heartbeat Is Found
abstract: Shortly after Arkansas adopted the country’s most stringent abortion limits, North Dakota’s Legislature approved a bill blocking the procedure as early as six weeks into pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Little more than a week after Arkansas adopted the country’s most stringent abortion limits, banning the procedure at 12 weeks of pregnancy, the North Dakota Legislature on Friday passed a more restrictive bill that would ban most abortions as early as 6 weeks into pregnancy.

headline: Knicks Sign Martin for Remainder of Season
abstract: Kenyon Martin will play for the Knicks, whose frontcourt has been beset by knee injuries, for the rest of the season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Kenyon Martin’s plan when he joined the Knicks three weeks ago was simple. After his first day of practice with the team, Martin explained what he wanted when he humbly became the first No. 1 overall N.B.A. pick in league history to sign a 10-day contract.

headline: A Playful Dining Room, and Pretzel Rolls, Too
abstract: Just Restaurant offers a blend of New American and Asian fusion in a playful atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: The ye olde typography of the sign at Just Restaurant in Old Bridge suggested a Renaissance Faire behind the heavy glass doors.

headline: Jim Barrett Dies; Helped Win Respect for California Wines
abstract: The proprietor of Chateau Montelena, Jim Barrett shocked the wine world by winning the 1976 Judgment of Paris competition.
lead_paragraph: Jim Barrett, the proprietor of Chateau Montelena in Napa Valley, whose chardonnay shocked the world with a first-place showing at the Judgment of Paris competition in 1976, died on Thursday in San Francisco. He was 86.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 15
abstract: Here is a slide show from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a surfer in Queens, mourners in Brooklyn and the faithful at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a surfer in Queens, mourners in Brooklyn and the faithful at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan.

headline: Taylor Swift Gets Some Mud on Her Boots
abstract: At the age of 23, the singer is experiencing a tumble in popularity that is also affecting her marketability.
lead_paragraph: Until very recently, it seemed as if Taylor Swift could do no wrong. Since 2006, when she arrived on the Nashville scene with the release of her eponymous album, as a gawky teenager in sundresses and cowboy boots, Ms. Swift has earned accolades (including seven Grammy Awards), upgraded to designer gowns (notably the Elie Saab black dress with sheer thigh panels that she wore to the Brit Awards in February) and perhaps more important, sold records and concert tickets as if they were frosted cupcakes — which, if you paid attention to Instagram, you’d know she bakes with pal Selena Gomez in her Nashville penthouse.

headline: Recognize This Regular Guy With Sticky Fingers?
abstract: The police just released a picture taken by a security camera 15 months ago, when a man pocketed what a diamond district store owner said was $108,000 in jewelry.
lead_paragraph: Is this your husband? Your father? Your funny uncle Mo? Did he bring you some new jewelry in the last, say, year and a half?

headline: Leading and Losing by Example
abstract: Just who is Tanya Zuckerbrot, and why are so many people willing to pay her so much to give them a nutritional makeover?
lead_paragraph: There were plenty of things Suzanne Schecter, a freelance TV producer in New York, could have done with $10,000. But instead of purchasing, say, a trip around the world, or just a Louis Vuitton steamer trunk, Ms. Schecter hired Tanya Zuckerbrot to help her lose weight.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Mixers
abstract: Global fashion took on new dimensions during the recent Paris showings.
lead_paragraph: Global fashion took on new dimensions during the recent Paris showings.

headline: Live From Beijing, a British Reporter’s Arrest
abstract: Viewers of Britain’s Sky News were treated to the unusual spectacle of a correspondent reporting live on his own detention from the back of a Chinese police van.
lead_paragraph: Mark Stone, a Beijing correspondent for Britain’s Sky News who is facile with new technology, urged his Twitter followers to tune in Friday for a live report from Tiananmen Square.

headline: Lots of Anger, All in Fun
abstract: Naomi O’Connell presented “Witches, Bitches & Women in Britches,” a program of songs in English, French and German, at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: There were no gentle, swooning maidens on the program presented by the Irish mezzo-soprano Naomi O’Connell at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday, with neurotics, sirens and kleptomaniacs the stars of the evening.

headline: Going Fishing Without the Pole
abstract: Fragrant Turkish halibut kebabs with a bright herb-laden yogurt sauce are just the thing to convince yourself that spring is finally here.
lead_paragraph: WHEN PEOPLE SPEAK of Turkey, I don’t think of Turkish taffy or Turkish delight. I think of swordfish kebabs.

headline: Ford Chief Benefits From Auto Comeback
abstract: The pay levels at Ford and General Motors far exceed what the companies were paying their executives a few years ago, when the automakers were losing billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: The turnaround of the American auto industry is paying off for senior management, particularly at the Ford Motor Company, even with a 29 percent reduction in compensation for its chief executive.

headline: Busy Bees Need Death Notices, Too, to Move on to the Next Keeper
abstract: Keely Garfield’s “Telling the Bees,” at the Chocolate Factory, is based on a beekeeping tradition from Northern Europe.
lead_paragraph: In her new dance the choreographer Keely Garfield melds her continuing spiritual quest with an earnest return to movement. “Telling the Bees,” which opened at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday night, takes its inspiration from the lapsed Northern European tradition of telling bees when their beekeeper died.

headline: A Pleasing Debut for 2012 Whites
abstract: The first batch of 2012 releases offered aromatic, flavorful whites that delivered charm and balance and will accompany a variety of dishes.
lead_paragraph: After tasting six food-friendly whites recently, I wished that more than half of them had been bottled with screw caps. It is easy to store such bottles on their sides in the refrigerator, making it more likely that they will be consumed promptly, capturing their freshness.

headline: Harsh Words for HBO’s Phil Spector Biopic
abstract: The movie has already been panned by Mr. Spector’s wife and the family of Lana Clarkson, an actress for whose 2003 murder he is currently serving 19 years to life in prison.
lead_paragraph: The new HBO biopic “Phil Spector” doesn’t make it debut until March 24, but it has already been panned both by Mr. Spector’s wife and the family of Lana Clarkson, an actress for whose 2003 murder he is currently serving 19 years to life in prison.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Culture
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including Gilbert Gottfried and a Broadway musical written by Amanda Green and Trey Anastasio of Phish.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including Gilbert Gottfried and a Broadway musical written by Amanda Green and Trey Anastasio of Phish.

headline: Props and Pop-Culture References to Tell the Story of an American Indian Princess
abstract: “Pocahontas, and/or America,” at the Bushwick Starr, repurposes historical material in a nearly two-hour production.
lead_paragraph: So, you know, blah blah and something something.

headline: Timeline: Philippe de Montebello
abstract: Defining moments for the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Defining moments for the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Old Dog Teaches New Tricks
abstract: In “Tom, Dick & Harriet,” Steven Weber plays an adman who finds a creative way to save his job after he is fired because he’s too old.
lead_paragraph: Seems as if it weren’t long ago that Steven Weber was playing the dashing, reckless younger brother on the sitcom “Wings.” In “Tom, Dick & Harriet,” a made-for-television movie Saturday night on the Hallmark Channel, he’s playing an adman who is fired because he’s too old. Time, apparently, rushes on.

headline: Boston Wins Race to Bottom
abstract: “Wicked Single” on VH1 follows a half-dozen young people around Boston.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations, Boston. You’re the new New Jersey.

headline: New Arrangements by a Singing Chef
abstract: At Om Bistro, nearly everything, including breads, sauces and desserts, is deftly prepared in-house, and nothing on the menu tops $19.
lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, I have been a fan of Richard Desmond. When he was cooking at Bliss in East Setauket from 2004 to 2006, I was there. When he went to Public House 49 in Patchogue in 2009, I followed him. In January he became the chef at Om Bistro in Great Neck, a new restaurant where he is also an owner. His partners there are Harjinder Singh, who is also a co-owner of Raga in East Setauket, and Sandeet Mehen.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Amazon Publishing and Surface Sales
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include a satirical dinner with a smartphone, changes to Amazon’s publishing business and a report of slow sales for Microsoft’s tablet.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: On the Road With Young Performers
abstract: “Mindless Behavior,” a documentary, follows the group of the same name on its “#1 Girl Tour” and in countless public appearances across the country.
lead_paragraph: Watching the quasi-documentary marketing tool “Mindless Behavior: All Around the World,” you would think that the boy band Mindless Behavior existed as a charity, so abundant are the platitudes about the members’ living for the fans, being positive, inspiring others and the self-actualization of the “mindless” state. Despite its title, the film, a record of the group’s “#1 Girl Tour,” follows this teenage R&B-lite foursome around the United States, interspersing concert footage with biographical tidbits, public appearances and countless images of screaming, swooning female tweens and adolescents.

headline: Making Movie Magic More Efficient
abstract: DreamWorks Animation’s next movie may sell popcorn in theaters, but it took lots of hard-nosed computer processing to get there. DreamWorks has been thinking hard about technology and digital costs for the last several years, In the process it has become a marquee client for Intel and Hewlett-Packard, speaking to the oil industry and Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: “The Croods” is a caveman movie from DreamWorks Animation that comes out March 22. The subject may be paleolithic, but the technology approach may well be cutting edge.

headline: Legal Brief Filed on Behalf of William Ernest Kuenzel
abstract: Robert M. Morgenthau, 93, and two other prominent former prosecutors are asking the United States Supreme Court to take up the case of William Ernest Kuenzel, who has been on death row in Alabama for 24 years.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Morgenthau, 93, and two other prominent former prosecutors are asking the United States Supreme Court to take up the case of William Ernest Kuenzel, who has been on death row in Alabama for 24 years.

headline: Ethanol Surplus May Lift Gas Prices
keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency']
abstract: To meet federal mandates, refiners trade ethanol credits, whose prices have jumped nearly tenfold since January, adding to costs at the pump, experts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A glut of ethanol in the gasoline supply is threatening to push up prices at the pump and may have exacerbated the growing cost gap between regular gasoline and premium, some oil experts say.

headline: Fuel Economy: Small Decline in 2011 and a Probable Climb in 2012, E.P.A. Says
abstract: The E.P.A. fuel economy and emissions numbers for 2012 are preliminary, and based on sales estimates provided to the agency by automakers.
lead_paragraph: An Environmental Protection Agency report issued on Friday offers a mixed picture of fleetwide fuel economy in the United States. It documents a minor decline in the 2011 model year to 22.4 miles per gallon, but projects “significant gains” to 23.8 m.p.g. for 2012, a 1.4 m.p.g. improvement over one year. The report said that the 2012 numbers, if confirmed, “would be all-time records and amongst the largest annual improvements since 1975.”

headline: Boeing Discloses Fixes for Lithium-Ion Batteries
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Lithium (Metal)', 'Batteries', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: To prevent fire and smoke episodes, Boeing said, the lithium-ion batteries on the 787 will be sealed in a steel box as a fail-safe.
lead_paragraph: Boeing officials have detailed for the first time their proposed fixes for the lithium-ion batteries aboard its 787 planes, and the changes include better insulation between the eight cells in the battery, gentler charging to minimize stress and a new titanium venting system.

headline: Shoes and Racism, for Sport
abstract: “Honky,” a brash comedy by Greg Kalleres presented at Urban Stages, looks at race relations through the perspective of basketball shoe company executives.
lead_paragraph: Just because you’re late to the party doesn’t mean you can’t be the life of the party. “Honky,” a hilarious play by Greg Kalleres receiving its premiere at Urban Stages, would probably have felt more cutting-edge about 25 years ago, but it’s still a daffy treat, irreverently tackling a subject that appears destined to be forever uncomfortable: race.

headline: Prado Museum
abstract: For many years, Madrid's Prado was almost a secret in plain sight, but now an extension moves the museum, stuck so long in the 19th century, into the 21st.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Madrid's Prado was almost a secret in plain sight, but now an extension moves the museum, stuck so long in the 19th century, into the 21st.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: Mary Jo White drew closer to taking over the Securities and Exchange Commission; European leaders recommitted to austerity measures; and Anna Wintour, longtime editor of Vogue, took on a new role at Condé Nast.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White drew closer to taking over the Securities and Exchange Commission; European leaders recommitted to austerity measures; and Anna Wintour, longtime editor of Vogue, took on a new role at Condé Nast.

headline: A Favored Look for Making Connections on the Street
abstract: The city announced the winner of a contest on Facebook intended to get residents thinking about what kind of changes they might like to see in public phones.
lead_paragraph: Concerning the future of New York City’s pay phones, the voters have spoken — the Facebook voters, anyway — and they have chosen a design that looks kind of like a very tall smartphone.

headline: In Bed With Matthias Schoenaerts
abstract: Our colleagues at T Magazine spent time with Matthias Schoenaerts, the Belgian-born star of the movie “Rust and Bone.” And we all get to benefit.
lead_paragraph: Our colleagues at T Magazine spent time with Matthias Schoenaerts, the Belgian-born star of the movie “Rust and Bone.” And we all get to benefit.

headline: Bolshoi Director Is Upbeat About His Recovery
abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, Sergei Filin, said at a news conference that he was on the way to a “full recovery” almost two months after he was severely burned in an acid attack in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: AACHEN, Germany — Wrapped in a thick, knitted black scarf and hat, his eyes hidden behind dark glasses, Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director, said he was on the way to a “full recovery” almost two months after he was severely burned during an acid attack in Moscow.

headline: The Prospects for Peace in the Mideast
abstract: Readers react to two Op-Ed essays that brought differing perspectives to the Israeli-Palestinian issue.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Thirty Years’ Work, Rescued From the Storm
abstract: Works by Ray Smith, most of them rescued from his studio after Hurricane Sandy, are on view at Mana Contemporary in Jersey City through May 5.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — In the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, Ray Smith’s cavernous Brooklyn studio in a warehouse near the Gowanus Canal was a gigantic indoor swimming pool six feet deep, as the artist described it. There, his huge figurative canvases and totemic wooden sculptures floated in the water as he and his assistants tried desperately to pump it out, salvaging what they could of 30 years’ worth of his artwork.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.
