keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Two readers, including Representative Candice Miller, Republican of Michigan, respond to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Shift on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: A reader reacts to Senator Rob Portman’s reversal on same-sex marriage after learning that his son is gay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Conservatives and Sewers
abstract: They’re socialism.
lead_paragraph: I see that some commenters on my traffic externalities post are speculating what Republicans would say about sewers if they didn’t already exist. Well, we don’t know about Republicans, but we do know what The Economist said, in 1848, about proposals for a London sewer system:

headline: Blanche Meets Stanley Anew, Reintroduced as Opera
abstract: Renée Fleming starred on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall in an operatic adaptation of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” written for her by André Previn.
lead_paragraph: Even with her star power, the soprano Renée Fleming has never been able to entice the Metropolitan Opera into mounting the work that André Previn wrote especially for her, “A Streetcar Named Desire,” adapted from the Tennessee Williams play, with a libretto by Philip Littell. The San Francisco Opera presented the premiere in 1998, and though audiences over all were excited, the critical reaction was decidedly mixed. There have been subsequent productions at international companies. But nothing in New York.

headline: Getting Legal Experience
abstract: Two law professors suggest incorporating more practical experience in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Saving the Sage Grouse
abstract: The Independent Petroleum Association says that putting the bird on the endangered list would hinder energy projects.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On the Prowl for New Acts at Southwest
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Music', 'Rock Music']
abstract: An agent from Brooklyn is on a mission to find new acts at South by Southwest.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — When the South by Southwest music festival started here 26 years ago, it was known as a place to discover new bands, a fertile hunting ground for booking agents and scouts for labels. These days indie labels and booking agents generally use the festival to promote the artists they have already signed, like vendors at a trade show. The major labels do too, often booking several shows for musicians they have just signed to contracts in hopes of generating excitement for debut albums. Every year a few major stars who have new releases out also make appearances.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 15
abstract: Subjects include a surfer in Astoria, mourners in East Flatbush and the faithful at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a surfer in Astoria, mourners in East Flatbush and the faithful at St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius
abstract: Different and gorgeous.
lead_paragraph: I keep finding NPR’s Tiny Desk Concerts a great place to find new music. I didn’t really expect to like this group — didn’t sound at all like my kind of thing — but they’re something special, and their songs keep rattling around in my head:

headline: Shame Is Not a Four-Letter Word
keywords: ['Teenage Pregnancy', 'Emotions', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Shame is an essential ingredient of a healthy society, particularly a liberal one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Remembering the Start of Syria’s Uprising
abstract: In an address marking the second anniversary of the uprising in Syria, the rebel commander reminded viewers that “the Syrian revolution started peacefully.”
lead_paragraph: Gen. Salim Idriss, the leader of the Syrian opposition’s military wing, marked the second anniversary of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad on Friday with a brief address posted on YouTube in Arabic and English.

headline: An Old-Style Boy Band, With Modern Wooing
abstract: The boy band Mindless Behavior is an African-American answer to British groups like the Wanted and One Direction. But its lack of success reflects how thoroughly black styles have been absorbed into pop.
lead_paragraph: Judging by the old rules and metrics, the boy band has been severely debased in the last couple of years. Gone are the song-and-dance extravaganza groups of decades past. What we have now are the Wanted and One Direction, British imports whose nonchalance can feel like an undermining commentary on the traditional model.

headline: I Was a Teenage Mother
abstract: I don’t need an ad campaign to tell me about the challenges of parenthood. I need support, not stereotypes and shame.
lead_paragraph: “EVERYTHING’S going to be O.K., mamita,” my mother said, before walking into her bedroom and crying her eyes out.

headline: Beijing’s Retirees Keep Eye Out for Trouble During Party Congress
abstract: As the National People’s Congress continued in Beijing, thousands of residents stood guard in the streets as the front lines in the government’s war against potential unrest.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Dressed in a new crimson windbreaker, a red cap and an armband emblazoned with “Capital Public Security Patrol,” Gao Fengping sat in a child-sized pink chair and vigilantly watched the midday bustle of a narrow back street. If a protest or disturbance erupted, Ms. Gao, 58, a retired factory worker, was ready.

headline: Fish Populations in the United States Rebound
abstract: Newly released data show that many commercial stocks depleted by overfishing are returning in abundance since a 1996 law that effectively ordered limits on catches.
lead_paragraph: Many commercial fishing stocks off the United States coast that were depleted by decades of overfishing are returning to abundance, thanks largely to a 1996 law that effectively ordered limits on catches until the fish populations had rebounded, a newly released analysis of federal data on fish populations states.

headline: Following Two Loves: Food and Family
abstract: With a name that conveys enthusiastic ambition, Carpe Diem is a newcomer to Locust Avenue in New Canaan.
lead_paragraph: With a name that conveys enthusiastic ambition, Carpe Diem (“Seize the day!”) is a newcomer to Locust Avenue in New Canaan. It’s a handsome, romantically lighted place, with charcoal-gray banquettes, and cream-colored walls decorated with photographs and racks of wine bottles. The cuisine is high-end Northern Italian.

headline: The Winter of the Monarch
abstract: Butterfly colonies are shrinking in the forests of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: IN the village of Contepec, in Michoacán, a few hours northwest of Mexico City, every winter day, rivers of orange and black butterflies would stream through the streets in search of water, swooping down from the Oyamel fir forest on Altamirano Hill. One of us, Homero, grew up with the monarch butterflies. The other, Lincoln, saw them for the first time in 1977, also in Michoacán, on a mountain called Sierra Chincua, where the branches of hundreds of fir trees were covered with butterflies that exploded into glorious flight when warmed by the sun.

headline: California: Judge Strikes Down Law on National Security Letters
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Search and Seizure', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A judge struck down a law that allows the F.B.I. to secretly seize subscriber information from Internet companies and other communications service providers without a warrant.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday struck down a law that allows the Federal Bureau of Investigation to secretly seize subscriber information from Internet companies and other communications service providers without a court warrant. The ruling, by Judge Susan Illston of Federal District Court in San Francisco, struck down the law because it forbids companies from disclosing that they had received such an order, called a National Security Letter, making the statute “impermissibly overbroad” under the First Amendment, she wrote. She also struck down a statute on legal challenges by recipients of the security letters, but stayed her ruling to allow the government to appeal.

headline: Players Club Stages a Real-Life Drama Over Whether to Oust Its Director
abstract: A leaked tape of a closed meeting of the private club for actors shows a membership unhappy with day-to-day operations and with the club’s executive director, John Martello.
lead_paragraph: One thing to be said for theater people: they know drama. On Thursday night, more than 100 members of the Players, a private club founded for actors, crowded into the main dining room of its 1847 Greek Revival town house on Gramercy Park for a vote on whether to oust their longstanding executive director.

headline: Honoring Italian-American Classics
abstract: Fiamma Trattoria in Mamaroneck is old-fashioned, but not retro, with fresh, hand-cranked pasta, a robust tagliatelle Bolognese and delicate lobster manicotti.
lead_paragraph: On our first visit to Fiamma Trattoria, which hugs a corner in a modest neighborhood near the Metro-North tracks in Mamaroneck, we were greeted with an enthusiasm that all but raised suspicion. No indifferent hostess sized us up us at a lectern; instead, our waiter, Anthony, pulled out a couple of chairs and said, “Sit down, I’ll be with you in a minute.” And he was, returning in a jiffy to fill us in on details, as if we were his new best friends.

headline: Criminal Lawyer Is Barred From Working in U.S. Court
abstract: A court grievance panel blocked Ivan S. Fisher from practicing in the Southern District of New York, saying he stole from a client.
lead_paragraph: Ivan S. Fisher, a prominent criminal defense lawyer, has been barred from practicing law in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the site of many of his celebrated trials, including representing a New York mafia boss in the well-known pizza connection narcotics case in the 1980s.

headline: At United, Comebacks Are Only for the Hosts
abstract: When Reading and Manchester United meet Saturday, history is on the side of United, which in English league play has not lost at home when leading at the half in almost 30 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twice in January, relegation-threatened Reading managed to reverse halftime deficits and win Premier League games. But if the team is to win at Manchester United this Saturday, history suggests that being behind after 45 minutes will not be part of the script.

headline: Turmoil at Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
abstract: More than a year after the death of their director, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco endure staff departures and complaints about the board president.
lead_paragraph: Since January, each morning visitors to the venerable Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco line up to catch the newest star attraction, Vermeer’s enigmatic painting “Girl With the Pearl Earring,” on the first stop in its American tour.

headline: Massachusetts: New Judge for Bulger
abstract: A new judge was named on Friday to preside over the trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, who faces 19 counts of murder, after another judge was removed over a possible perception of bias.
lead_paragraph: A judge who is relatively new to the federal bench was named on Friday to preside over the trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, Boston’s notorious crime boss who faces 19 counts of murder. The appointment of the judge, Denise J. Casper, comes a day after Judge Richard G. Stearns was removed because of a possible perception of bias. Ms. Casper, 45, a Harvard Law School graduate and former federal prosecutor, was appointed to the bench by President Obama in 2010. The court has not announced whether the trial, set to begin June 6, will be delayed to allow Ms. Casper to familiarize herself with the voluminous case material.

headline: Offspring Training
abstract: A former player is finally able to sit down and watch baseball with his children.
lead_paragraph: I do not claim to know what my playing career meant in the grand scheme of baseball. All I know for sure is that I found a passion I could express on a diamond. For this I am eternally grateful. Yet after my career was over, I found myself adrift from the game. A post-retirement stasis of sorts. In a way, it also kept my new family from embracing baseball.

headline: The Storm Took Their Cars, Then Thieves Disabled the New Ones
abstract: After Hurricane Sandy wiped out nearly all the cars in Howard Beach, Queens, residents bought new ones and provided tire thieves inviting targets.
lead_paragraph: First came the floodwater. Then the insurance checks. Then, just when things were looking up, more trouble, in the form of a sophisticated crew of thieves who work with precision, tools and, in a throwback to rougher times, heavy cinder blocks.

headline: Maryland: Repeal of Death Penalty Awaits Governor’s Signature
abstract: Maryland is likely to become the 18th state to outlaw executions after lawmakers approved a measure abolishing the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: Maryland is likely to become the 18th state to outlaw executions after lawmakers approved a measure abolishing the death penalty. Gov. Martin O’Malley, a Democrat who has long pushed for the change, is expected to sign the bill when the legislative session ends in April. The House of Delegates passed the bill 82 to 56 on Friday, 10 days after the Senate approved it. The legislation would replace death sentences with life terms without the possibility of parole. It would not apply to the five inmates on death row in the state. Mr. O’Malley will decide whether to convert their sentences.

headline: As Hong Kong Presses for More Democracy, Friction With Beijing Rises
abstract: Factional struggles in Beijing have spilled into Hong Kong, where tens of thousands of people have joined large street demonstrations against the Beijing-backed government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Looming over a modest Chinese medicine shop here that sells dried deer penises for virility and bat feces for vision is a 40-story monolith of dark glass and gray steel: the Hong Kong offices of the Chinese Communist Party.

headline: Baldwin North American Open Pairs
abstract: The winners of the Baldwin North American Open Pairs were Kevin Dwyer of Tampa, Fla., and Gavin Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Here on Thursday night, the winners of the Baldwin North American Open Pairs were Kevin Dwyer of Tampa, Fla., and Gavin Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla. They finished one and a half boards ahead of Jim Munday of Southaven, Miss., and Richard Oshlag of Memphis. Third were Robert Lebi of Toronto and John Rayner of Mississauga, Ontario.

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Image of the Day: March 15
abstract: Schoolchildren in Mumbai playing near a statue of former pope, John Paul II.

headline: On Western Lands, a Free-Market Path
keywords: ['Federal Lands', 'Land Use Policies', 'Ranches', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Environmental advocates have begun banding together with ranchers, hunters and rich landowners in a novel tactic to preserve the landscapes of the West: buy out their opponents.
lead_paragraph: REDSTONE, Colo. — Deep in the jagged heart of central Colorado lies one of the world’s most beautiful backyards: a rugged and wild quilt of national forest where elk roam and bobcats hunt. It is public land, and as the song says, made for you and me. But the rights to drill it for oil and gas belong to private companies.

headline: Making a Sometimes Invisible Minority Visible
abstract: The photographs of Corky Lee, a renowned chronicler of Asian-American life, are being displayed at Stony Brook University.
lead_paragraph: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — On Sept. 15, 2001, Corky Lee, a freelance photographer, showed up at a candlelight vigil held in Central Park by Sikh-Americans, who had become a target of violence after the 9/11 attacks.

headline: Mississippi Tells Public Schools to Develop Policies Allowing Prayers
keywords: ['Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Education (K-12)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: A new law, which takes effect in July, will allow students to pray over school intercoms, at assemblies and sporting events.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Phil Bryant of Mississippi has long wanted children to pray at public schools. This week, with his grandmother’s worn Bible on his desk, he signed a bill that gets him closer to that goal.

headline: University of Tennessee Wins Approval for Hydraulic Fracturing Plan
abstract: The university says leasing land to a gas company to conduct hydraulic fracturing would allow researchers to study the impact in a closed environment.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The University of Tennessee faced protests here on Friday over its proposal to let a private company drill for natural gas across a forest controlled by the university.

headline: Maryland Transplant Patient Dies of Rabies
abstract: Health officials say the patient, whose identity was not revealed, and three others received organ transplants from the same donor.
lead_paragraph: A patient in Maryland has died of rabies contracted from a kidney transplant, and three other people who received organs from the same donor were being treated to prevent the disease, health officials said Friday.

headline: Withering Questions at Senate Hearing on JPMorgan Loss
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Lawmakers took aim at JPMorgan Chase for misleading investors and regulators about a disastrous bet, building off a scathing 300-page Congressional report released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top JPMorgan Chase executive struggled to defend his actions on Friday as lawmakers scrutinized the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.

headline: Private Watkins’s War
abstract: The amazing, overlooked memoir of a Confederate soldier.
lead_paragraph: Although the battle of Perryville, Ky., was fought on Oct. 8, 1862, initial troop deployments occupied the preceding day while local residents pondered whether they should stay or leave. Much of the opposing lines were in plain view of one another. Upon drawing picket duty on the eve of the battle, a Confederate private named Sam Watkins of the First Tennessee was surprised to discover a Union guard, also on duty, just across the road. As Sam explains, that night they were not enemies.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company
abstract: Paul Taylor’s offerings at Lincoln Center plumb notions of Americanness.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor’s offerings at Lincoln Center plumb notions of Americanness.

headline: Worldly at 35, and Shaping Obama’s Voice
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Benjamin J. Rhodes is a 35-year-old deputy national security adviser with a soft voice, strong opinions and a reputation as the man who channels President Obama on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama prepares to visit Israel next week, he is turning, as he often does, to Benjamin J. Rhodes, a 35-year-old deputy national security adviser with a soft voice, strong opinions and a reputation around the White House as the man who channels Mr. Obama on foreign policy.

headline: Dreamscape of America, Rollicking or Sublime
abstract: From the poet-renegade to the passing of generations, Paul Taylor’s offerings at Lincoln Center plumb notions of Americanness.
lead_paragraph: Many American artists have adapted the myths, themes and art of Europe to American settings. Shakespeare’s “Othello” has been told to Motown music (last year in “Mo(or)town Redux,” by the choreographer Doug Elkins); Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro” has been set in an apartment in the Trump Tower (in Peter Sellars’s 1988 production).

headline: Senate Democrats Finally Take a Stand
abstract: Their 2014 budget is a strong counterweight to the reckless House proposals from Paul Ryan.
lead_paragraph: It’s been four years since the Democrats who control the Senate produced a budget. That has meant four missed opportunities to demonstrate what they stand for, in hard numbers and clear spending priorities. On Wednesday, the chamber’s leaders stiffened their spines and issued a 2014 budget. If the result isn’t quite a courageous resistance to political winds, it at least makes most of the right choices and is a solid rebuttal to the heartless collection of obsolete dogmas that is the House budget.

headline: Road Runners Facing More Difficulty 4 Months After Marathon Uproar
abstract: New York Road Runners, which was criticized over its handling of the canceled New York City Marathon, has had fewer finishers at its races this year.
lead_paragraph: The furor over New York Road Runners’ handling of its marathon last year has died down, but questions about the group’s future persist, including whether its dominance has started to erode because of rival race organizers and disaffected runners.

headline: The Opulent Edwardian Era, in Art and Artifacts
abstract: With “Edwardian Opulence,” in New Haven, the curators Angus Trumble and Andrea Wolk Rager ask us to look anew at an era we feel we know well, thanks to plays, novels, film and television dramas.
lead_paragraph: The three sumptuous objects, studded with gemstones and embellished with gold, are too large to be worn as jewelry; they’re too small to serve as display pieces. If they were boxes, they might hold stamps or face powder; but they don’t open. Their exquisite workmanship implies instead that they exist only to be beautiful.

headline: A Day With John C. Liu
abstract: Thirty-one packed hours in the life of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and a mayoral hopeful.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-one packed hours in the life of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and a mayoral hopeful.

headline: New York Mayoral Hopeful Forges Ahead, Undeterred
abstract: On Sunday, John C. Liu plans to announce his candidacy for mayor — a seemingly quixotic bid, given fraud charges against two associates, but one that he insists is still winnable.
lead_paragraph: John C. Liu is the most ubiquitous of New York City officeholders, with a voracious appetite for retail politics, ever smiling, hugging everyone he meets and sampling all the food along the way. He has been the brightest political hope of the city’s fast-growing Asian-American community, which propelled him first onto the City Council, and then to citywide office as comptroller.

headline: University of Virginia’s Crisis Reflects Wider Conflict
abstract: Conflict over governing the University of Virginia has become a proxy war in a much larger struggle over control of the nation’s public universities.
lead_paragraph: Nine months after the University of Virginia removed its president, prompting a storm of protest, and then reinstated her, the university still cannot go more than a few days or weeks without some new reminder of that spectacle, or persisting tensions between the president and the trustee who ousted her.

headline: Over the Line
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Afghanistan’s president has shown his truly sinister side in demonizing the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has been America’s faithless partner throughout the war. Despite corruption in his government and his own family, Washington has worked with him to hold the country together because it has had to.

headline: Gouging the Poor in New York
abstract: Bills that would allow check-cashing stores to enter the lending business and be exempt from the usury law are a bad idea.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has warned debt collectors that they could face legal sanctions if they try to collect predatory loans that violate the state’s usury law, which prohibits loans with interest rates above 25 percent. The governor needs to take an equally forceful stand against pending bills that would encourage predatory lending by allowing check-cashing stores to enter the lending business and exempting them from the usury law.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Boom Over, St. Patrick’s Isle Is Slithering Again
abstract: During the Celtic Tiger boom, snakes became a popular pet among the Irish nouveau riche. But after the bubble burst, many owners abandoned the pets they could no longer afford.
lead_paragraph: BALLIVOR, Ireland — Legend has it that St. Patrick drove all the snakes out of Ireland. The economic crisis has brought some of them back.

headline: One Last Chick
abstract: Wandering albatrosses have a highly improbably — and wondrous — approach to reproduction.
lead_paragraph: Reproduction is the evolutionary bottleneck, and nature seems to have tried almost every approach imaginable. A highly improbable one is that of the wandering albatross, Diomedea exulans.

headline: Quilts: From Classic to Crazy and Beyond
abstract: “Beyond the Bed: The American Quilt Evolution,” at the Katonah Museum, includes traditional and innovative patterns and amazing stitch work.
lead_paragraph: An intriguing question threads its way through the innumerable stitches that bind the countless scraps of fabric that make up the quilts in “Beyond the Bed: The American Quilt Evolution,” in the Beitzel and Righter Galleries at the Katonah Museum of Art. Guest curated by Jean M. Burks of the Shelburne Museum in Vermont, the exhibition traces developments in the art of quiltmaking from 1800 to the present. Ms. Burks said that she wanted “to get people asking, ‘Just what is a quilt?’ ”

headline: NBC Executive and Leno Said to Have Clashed Over Jokes
abstract: Three executives close to the situation said that NBC’s entertainment chief had taken offense to jokes that Jay Leno made last month about NBC’s ratings struggles
lead_paragraph: NBC has aggressively denied recent reports that it plans to replace Jay Leno soon as host of “The Tonight Show,” but the network’s top entertainment executive, Robert Greenblatt, recently stirred up a bit of a feud with the late-night star over jokes about the network.

headline: A Strong Voice Against Big Banks
abstract: The Times’s Louise Story talks to Thomas Hoenig, the vice chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who says he is not alone in calling for a breakup of banks too large to regulate.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Louise Story talks to Thomas Hoenig, the vice chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who says he is not alone in calling for a breakup of banks too large to regulate.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 16, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Mar. 16, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Most Americans don’t realize that you can have your home taken away, your children taken away and you can be a victim of domestic violence but you have no constitutional right to a lawyer to protect you.”

headline: Parking Help, Pocket-Size
abstract: Several mobile apps offer ways to better manage the hassles of parking your car, whether in a garage or on the street.
lead_paragraph: On the Upper East Side, an Israeli start-up is showing off what it thinks will be the future for local drivers, a process it gives the oxymoronic name “mobile parking.”

headline: A Religious Ritual Attracts Even Nonbelievers
abstract: An embrace of Lent is seen by some who call themselves atheists as cultural nostalgia and as claiming a sense of community.
lead_paragraph: “I grew up a fairly typical Italian-American New York Catholic,” says John Corvino, 43, the chairman of the philosophy department at Wayne State University in Detroit. “I was an altar boy, and later a lector. By the time I was in high school” — at Chaminade, the Catholic boys’ school on Long Island — “I decided I wanted to become a priest.”

headline: The Dread That Is Ted
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: After Senator Ted Cruz gave an extensive lecture to Senator Dianne Feinstein this week, I think we have a candidate for the senator who could patronize a doorknob.
lead_paragraph: It is possible that the high point of this week in Washington came when Senator Dianne Feinstein told Senator Ted Cruz to stop treating her as if she were in middle school.

headline: U.S. Embassy Criticizes Pardons in Nigerian Corruption Cases
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'United States International Relations', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: The United States Embassy said it was “deeply disappointed” after a former governor, who was convicted in 2007, was pardoned this week.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — Convictions for corruption by top officials in Nigeria are so rare that they are treated as national milestones. So when the government rolled back one of the most prominent of them this week, the shock was commensurate.

headline: Every Hair in Its Place
abstract: Atsuko Tanaka’s high standards have made her the stylist of choice for some well-off ultra-Orthodox Jewish women, who often invest thousands in a wig.
lead_paragraph: “If life was fair, I’d be 5 foot 5,” Atsuko Tanaka said as she fondled a thick strand of hair and worked it over with a comb and blow dryer. Even with the stylist chair set to its lowest level, and standing on tiptoes, Ms. Tanaka had trouble styling the higher regions of the client’s head.

headline: Corrections: March 16, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 16, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: French Study Indicates Some Patients Can Control H.I.V. After Stopping Treatment
abstract: A crucial element, as with a Mississippi case involving the apparent cure of a baby born with H.I.V., appears to be initiating drug treatment shortly after the infection occurs.
lead_paragraph: French researchers have identified 14 adults who have been able to control their H.I.V. infection for years after stopping treatment with antiviral drugs, a finding that suggests that some patients might be able to achieve a so-called functional cure.

headline: Totally Plugged-In
abstract: In which Julian Lim beats me mentally, yet I still have fun.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This was an interesting puzzle. Maybe it’s the kind of grid that should be held up as the Platonic ideal of Saturday puzzles.

headline: Pitcher Is Said to Be Suspended for Ties to Anti-Aging Clinic
abstract: Major League Baseball barred the minor leaguer Cesar Carrillo for 100 games amid its investigation of Biogenesis, a South Florida clinic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Major League Baseball suspended the journeyman minor league pitcher Cesar Carrillo on Friday, in the first instance of discipline linked to a South Florida anti-aging clinic. The clinic is under investigation for reportedly providing players with performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Ricky Gervais, Back in ‘The Office’ Spotlight
abstract: Ricky Gervais revisits “The Office” in a new video.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, when we last saw David Brent in his natural element — the British edition of “The Office” — he was selling cleaning products, trying to get into the music business, enjoying a minor dating success and exhibiting a tiny spark of self-awareness.

headline: Poetry or Striptease? What Night Is It?
abstract: Four women chose burlesque for their evening out at Duane Park on the Bowery, which also has two evenings a week reserved for poets.
lead_paragraph: Sunday and Monday nights, the restaurant’s stage belongs to poets. Wednesday through Saturday, it is for dancers in pasties and G-strings. Is New York a city of polymorphous perversity or what? I mean, poetry?

headline: A Transgender Elected Official Reflects an Evolving Cuba
abstract: Adela Hernández instantly became a national symbol for Cuban rights activists when she was elected last fall to the municipal council in Caibarién.
lead_paragraph: CAIBARIÉN, Cuba — JOSÉ AGUSTÍN HERNÁNDEZ may not be precisely the kind of New Man whom Che Guevara pictured shaping Cuban socialism.

headline: Listening to Jazz on 133rd
abstract: A question about the real Swing Street, on West 133rd in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Q. My father once mentioned that when he was a young man, he and friends would listen to jazz in speakeasies on 133rd Street in Harlem. Can you tell me about that stretch?

headline: Right to Lawyer Can Be Empty Promise for Poor
keywords: ['Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'States (US)', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Fifty years after the Supreme Court ruled in Gideon v. Wainwright, the promise of legal representation for all is not fully realized.
lead_paragraph: ADEL, Ga. — Billy Jerome Presley spent 17 months in a Georgia jail because he did not have $2,700 for a child support payment. He had no prior jail record but also no lawyer. In Baltimore last fall, Carl Hymes, 21, was arrested on charges of shining a laser into the eyes of a police officer. Bail was set at $75,000. He had no arrest record but also no lawyer. In West Orange, N.J., last summer, Walter Bloss, 89, was served with an eviction notice from the rent-controlled apartment he had lived in for 43 years after a dispute with his landlord. He had gone to court without a lawyer.

headline: The Times’s 1963 Article on the Gideon v. Wainwright Decision
abstract: In the Gideon v. Wainwright decision, which held that states must provide legal representation for the poor in serious criminal cases, the Supreme Court unanimously overturned its own 1942 decision in the landmark case of Betts v. Brady.
lead_paragraph: In the Gideon v. Wainwright decision, which held that states must provide legal representation for the poor in serious criminal cases, the Supreme Court unanimously overturned its own 1942 decision in the landmark case of Betts v. Brady.

headline: A Real Carbon Solution
keywords: ['Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming']
abstract: A lot is riding on the Texas Clean Energy Project. Its technology could be a climate-saver.
lead_paragraph: Sometime this summer, in Odessa, Tex., the Summit Power Group plans to break ground on a $2.5 billion coal gasification power plant. Summit has named this the Texas Clean Energy Project. With good reason.

headline: Knicks and Nets Won’t Meet Again, but the Race Is On
abstract: The Knicks’ slump has given the Nets new hope in their pursuit of the Atlantic Division title, and the ensuing playoff advantages.
lead_paragraph: When the Knicks and the Nets last met, the lasting image was of Joe Johnson, rising over J. R. Smith to sink the jump shot that clinched the game, tied the season series and silenced Madison Square Garden. That was Jan. 21.

headline: China: Uighur Detained in Attack
abstract: An ethnic Uighur farmer has been detained and accused of killing five people and wounding seven in a knife attack on March 7 in Korla, according to a report on Friday.
lead_paragraph: An ethnic Uighur farmer has been detained and accused of killing five people and wounding seven in a knife attack on March 7 in Korla, a center of oil production in the western region of Xinjiang, according to a report on Friday on the Xinjiang government Web site that cited an article in the newspaper Xinjiang Daily. The farmer, Aizitiali Mamuti, 27, had been punished by the authorities for three previous knife attacks, the report said. Right before the attack, he had argued with relatives and had decided to take “revenge on society.” The attack raised questions about ethnic tensions in Korla; in Xinjiang, ethnic Uighurs often speak of discrimination by ethnic Han, who rule China. Four of the victims were Han and one was Hui; the attack also injured six Han and one Uighur.

headline: Mexico: 7 Die in Cancún Shooting
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Seven people, some of them members of a taxi union, were fatally shot in a bar in Cancún, several miles from the city’s popular beachfront resorts, the authorities said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Seven people, some of them members of a taxi union, were fatally shot in a bar in Cancún, several miles from the city’s popular beachfront resorts, the authorities said Thursday. The state prosecutor, Armando García Torres, told a local radio station that the motive was under investigation, and that the possibility of the involvement of organized crime gangs, which have targeted taxi workers in other states, had not been ruled out. The shooting took place in a working-class neighborhood not on the tourist circuit, but Mexico’s efforts to increase tourism have not been helped by recent episodes of crime near or in tourist spots, including the arrest last month of local police officers in the rape of an Italian woman in Playa del Carmen, near Cancún, and the sexual assault of six women from Spain last month at a beach house in Acapulco, on the Pacific coast.

headline: A Last, Long Goodbye at the Garden
abstract: The final conference tournament meeting between fierce rivals Syracuse and Georgetown took place in a dream matchup that lived up to the hype.
lead_paragraph: Moments like these made the Big East tournament, made it less of a basketball culmination and more of a touchstone, complete with a distinct New York flavor. Take Friday. Here was Syracuse, and here was Georgetown, with every seat filled in Madison Square Garden, in a game that went into overtime, undecided until the final shot.

headline: Music Upstairs and Downstairs
abstract: On Sundays, the classical pianist Simone Dinnerstein and her 11-year-old son sometimes practice their instruments; her husband plays the radio.
lead_paragraph: The classical pianist Simone Dinnerstein, 40, has a hectic international performance schedule, but in Park Slope her husband, Jeremy Greensmith, 46, and their son, Adrian Greensmith, 11, keep her grounded. While she plays her nine-foot Hamburg Steinway concert grand on the second floor, Adrian practices downstairs on an electric guitar for his band, the Animation, and Mr. Greensmith cooks dinner or plans lessons for his fifth-grade classes at Public School 321. Ms. Dinnerstein (her first name is pronounced “Simona”) has a new album, “Night,” with the singer-songwriter Tift Merritt, being released on Tuesday in the United States; she and Ms. Merritt are scheduled to perform at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday.

headline: Still Together, 30 Years and 6 Deployments Later
abstract: An Army general and his wife, an Army colonel, talk about their 30 years of marriage, through two children and six deployments.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. Kenneth Dahl is a deputy commanding general for United States forces in Afghanistan, stationed in Kabul. His current assignment is to oversee the withdrawal of troops from the country, as well as to prepare for the removal of all military equipment and weaponry. From 2010 to 2011, he was stationed in Kandahar, and before that, from 2005 to 2006, he served in Iraq.

headline: Character and Fixture Known as Hersh
abstract: Arnie Hershkowitz, a Brooklyn high school teacher, treated the Big East tournament as his personal convention and was a fixture in college basketball before his death in 2004.
lead_paragraph: Writers who covered the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 15, 2013

headline: ‘No Confidence’ Vote for Head of N.Y.U.
abstract: The faculty of New York University’s largest college this week handed an embarrassing setback to John Sexton, the university’s president.
lead_paragraph: The faculty of New York University’s largest college this week approved a vote of “no confidence” in John Sexton, the university’s president, handing him an embarrassing setback at a time when he is aggressively selling the university’s expansion plans at home and abroad.

headline: Bloomberg Welcomes Big Container of a Different Variety
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Solar Energy', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans to install in Times Square 30 trash and recycling stations that can compact waste using solar energy and then alert workers when the bins are full.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg did not notice the Coca-Cola supersign at his back, shimmering in Times Square’s late morning cold on Friday.

headline: Yanks Look for Help in Others’ Castoffs
abstract: The Yankees signed outfielder Brennan Boesch, who was cut by the Tigers, less than a week after they added Ben Francisco, who was released by the Indians.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — With injuries threatening to derail their season before it has started, the Yankees have acted aggressively during training camp by pouncing on players released by other teams.

headline: Quinn Leads Democrats in Fund-Raising for 2013 Campaign
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, leads her Democratic mayoral rivals with a war chest of almost $5.6 million, according to financial-disclosure reports released on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Even though she has already raised more than she needs for her mayoral primary campaign, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, continued to distance herself financially from her main Democratic rivals, according to financial-disclosure reports released on Friday.

headline: By Strategy and Luck, a Penguin Finds the Net
abstract: The Penguins’ Pascal Dupuis, playing alongside Sidney Crosby and Chris Kunitz, has shown that he is no afterthought. Dupuis has scored 13 goals this season.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Pascal Dupuis was in the right place at the right time again.

headline: Ex-Detective Gets 3 to 9 Years in Prison for D.W.I. Crash That Killed a Woman
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Kevin C. Spellman, a retired New York detective, apologized to the relatives of Drane Nikac, whom he killed in 2009, but they said his sentence was too light.
lead_paragraph: A retired New York police detective who once tracked down dangerous fugitives was himself sent to prison on Friday for killing a 66-year-old woman in 2009 while driving drunk in the Bronx.

headline: Donovan’s Pub, a Fixture in Queens, Gets New Owners
abstract: A longtime bartender and his brother-in-law bought the pub, on Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens. Donovan’s, the new owners say, is going to be, more or less, Donovan’s.
lead_paragraph: A week after Jimmy Jacobson started as a busboy at Donovan’s Pub on Roosevelt Avenue, he heard a rumor that his brand-new job was in jeopardy. In the checkout line at Key Food, a neighbor gave him the dirt: Joe Donovan was selling. The bar, a fixture of Woodside, Queens, since 1966, was going on the market.

headline: Q&A: Keeping Files in Sync on Microsoft SkyDrive
abstract: If you find your files on Microsoft’s SkyDrive service are not quite in sync, a workaround or some troubleshooting may help.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Cartha D. DeLoach, No. 3 in the F.B.I., Is Dead at 92
abstract: Mr. DeLoach, who spent more than 25 years in the F.B.I., served as a powerful intermediary between J. Edgar Hoover and President Lyndon B. Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Cartha D. DeLoach, who as a top aide and confidant to J. Edgar Hoover was the F.B.I.’s liaison to the White House and a powerful intermediary between Hoover and President Lyndon B. Johnson during an especially tense political era, died on Wednesday on Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 92.

headline: Rafael Puyana, Famed Harpsichordist, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Puyana was one of the last disciples of Wanda Landowska, the great 20th-century emissary of the harpsichord.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Puyana, an internationally acclaimed Colombian harpsichordist who was among the last disciples of Wanda Landowska, died on March 1 in Paris. He was 81.

headline: Weakened Offense Adds Up to Another Early Exit for the U.S.
abstract: The United States, which managed only four runs in its last two games, both without David Wright, failed to make the finals of the World Baseball Classic for the third time.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The chants were sporadic and muffled, nearly drowned out by horns, bells and cheers from the Puerto Rican faithful. It started: “U-S-A! U-S-A!” A few moments, after a weak effort, it died.

headline: An Excerpt From ‘Fever’ by Mary Beth Keane
abstract: Read an excerpt of the book.
lead_paragraph: Prologue1899

headline: In Obesity Epidemic, Poverty Is an Ignored Contagion
abstract: In New York City, where the poverty rate has remained steady for a decade, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s efforts to limit the size of sugary drinks ignore a much larger problem.
lead_paragraph: Under the category “Summer Rentals That Have Gone Terribly Wrong,” there are perhaps few parallels to the experience of Charles Henry Warren, a Manhattan banker who, in 1906, took a house in Oyster Bay on Long Island’s North Shore. By the end of the season, Mr. Warren’s young daughter had developed typhoid. She was soon followed in illness by Mr. Warren’s wife, a second daughter, two maids and a gardener. At the time, typhoid, a bacterial illness spread through contaminated food and water, was largely a disease of the urban poor. The property’s owner, George Thompson, concerned that the house, on which he relied for rental income, would become associated with tenement filth in the minds of wealthy New Yorkers, invited a sanitary engineer to determine the source of the outbreak.

headline: Flamenco’s Foreign Saviors
abstract: While flamenco remains a quintessential component of Spanish culture, its economic sustainability relies increasingly on foreigners, who flock to Andalusia to learn the dance and its music.
lead_paragraph: SEVILLE, Spain — Alicia Márquez raises her arms high above her head to get her students to look up while they stamp their feet. She claps her hands hard to keep them in rhythm. To teach flamenco these days here in the epicenter of the dance, she finds she must rely more on showing than telling: Though the 10 women in her class this morning are all accomplished dancers in their 20s and 30s, only one is Spanish.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 15
abstract: Pope Francis’s past; snakes as Irish economic barometer; treason accusation in Russia; and Bolshoi director recovers.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Reacting with unusual swiftness, the Vatican on Friday rejected any suggestion that Pope Francis of Argentina was implicated in his country’s so-called Dirty War during the 1970s, tackling the issue just two days after the pontiff’s election. On a day when Francis delivered a warm address to his cardinals and continued to project humility, the Vatican seemed intent on quickly putting to rest questions about the pope’s past, dismissing them as opportunistic defamations from anticlerical leftists. Dan Wakin reports from Rome.

headline: Inside Small Schools
abstract: Adlai E. Stevenson High School used to be one of the most dangerous in New York City. Today, it is home to nine small high schools that teach the same people, and each school has different results.
lead_paragraph: Adlai E. Stevenson High School used to be one of the most dangerous in New York City. Today, it is home to nine small high schools that teach the same people, and each school has different results.

headline: Global Flamenco
abstract: The thousands of foreigners who train in southern Spain’s flamenco schools are exporting its culture and passion to different countries.
lead_paragraph: The thousands of foreigners who train in southern Spain’s flamenco schools are exporting its culture and passion to different countries.

headline: With Siva’s Help, Louisville Advances to Another Title Game
abstract: For the third straight year, Louisville knocked off Notre Dame in the Big East tournament semifinals. The Cardinals will meet Syracuse in the title game.
lead_paragraph: Few players look as at ease under the lights of the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden as Louisville’s Peyton Siva. He smiles and winks and banters with referees and cameramen. At times, he carries himself like an on-court diplomat.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL (2012) Seven financially distressed British retirees (Judi Dench, Bill Nighy, Penelope Wilton, Celia Imrie, Ronald Pickup, Tom Wilkinson and Maggie Smith) are lured by invitation to “outsource” themselves for a stay at what is billed as a luxurious retreat “for the elderly and beautiful” in Jaipur, India, in this film directed by John Madden. But upon arrival, they discover that the place is far from what was advertised by their host (Dev Patel, above right with Tena Desae), a wildly disorganized but enthusiastic young man who neglected to mention the lack of working telephones and doors on the rooms. “This leisurely paced two-hour movie is a reasonably tasty banquet for the same Anglophiles who embrace ‘Downton Abbey,’ ” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “Although it’s not as tidy or comfy as that self-congratulating fantasy of British noblesse oblige or as elevated as the Merchant-Ivory films set in India, it’ll do nicely.” He added, “Besides its sterling cast, its ace in the hole is its pungent depiction of Jaipur’s teeming streets, which give an otherwise well-mannered movie a blinding splash of color.”

headline: Nine High Schools, One Roof
abstract: Seeking better results, the city divided Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx into nine theme-based institutions; today the Stevenson Campus has the most schools under one roof anywhere in the city.
lead_paragraph: When teachers heard footsteps thundering in the hallways at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx, they threw down iron gates to stop student gangs from rioting, even as other students tried to deconstruct literature behind locked classroom doors. A decade ago, Stevenson, in the borough’s Castle Hill section, was one of the city’s most dangerous, overcrowded schools, barely containing its 3,054 students — when they showed up for class.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Himachal Pradesh: While the plains are gearing up for summer, there was fresh snowfall Thursday in the high-altitude regions of the northern state, according to an IANS report on the NDTV Web site.

headline: At Indian Wells, Crowds Prove Must-See Match Is Doubles
abstract: Bob and Mike Bryan have played in the BNP Paribas Open 15 times but have yet to win the tournament, which has a doubles field stacked with top singles players.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — For many of the world’s top players, the desert beauty of the BNP Paribas Open is better enjoyed with a buddy nearby. And the fans seem to prefer the pairs play, too.

headline: After Negotiations, Cyprus Agrees to a Euro Zone Bailout Package
abstract: The agreement worth $13 billion, or 10 billion euros, puts some of the burden for shoring up the island’s beleaguered economy on its bank depositors.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Cyprus reached a long-awaited bailout agreement early Saturday worth $13 billion, or 10 billion euros, that puts some of the burden for shoring up the island’s beleaguered economy on its bank depositors.

headline: The Weekend Word: Backlash
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and the weekly party addresses, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Ousted by the City, Tenants Seek a Home
abstract: On the crowded fourth floor of a Manhattan building, residents’ lives were upended when officials ordered occupants to leave because of safety violations.
lead_paragraph: The accommodations on the fourth floor of 81 Bowery were meager and tight: dozens of people, mostly new Chinese immigrants ranging in age from 19 to 88, crammed into small cubicles, sharing a bathroom. But for people with little money and nowhere to stay, like Zhu Benjin, 52, a construction worker, the closet-size cubicles were home.

headline: From One Failing School, Nine Experiments
abstract: How one New York City high school was split into nine in the same building.
lead_paragraph: How one New York City high school was split into nine in the same building.

headline: Five Arrested in Gang Rape of Swiss Tourist in Central India
abstract: The woman, 39, was on a cycling tour with her husband when they were attacked.
lead_paragraph: 7:43 p.m. IST | Updated

headline: The Very Confident Jean-Claude Trichet
abstract: Evidence? What evidence?
lead_paragraph: I’m somewhat belatedly getting to Jean-Claude Trichet’s op-ed in the Times; now that I have, I find myself puzzled. What, exactly, was his purpose in writing this? For that matter, what, exactly, did it say? I live and breathe this stuff, and I can’t get much of a message here except “trust us, we know what we’re doing”.

headline: Dropped Apostrophes Spark Grammar War in Britain
abstract: Some write tomatoes and some write tomato’s. In the face of confusion over correct usage of the wayward apostrophe, one English local council has decided to scrap it, at least in street names.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A local council in southern England has sparked a grammar war with proposals to ban the apostrophe from its street signs to avoid what it calls “adverse consequences in times of emergency.”

headline: With Marc Staal Injured, Brothers’ Reunion on Ice Will Have to Wait
abstract: Marc Staal, who is recovering from being hit in the eye with a puck, will not play when the Rangers host the Hurricanes and his brothers Eric and Jordan on Monday.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Eric Staal noticed the date as soon as the N.H.L. schedule was released in January. On March 18, the Carolina Hurricanes were set to play the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

headline: For G.M.’s, a Shortened Meeting Schedule but Lots to Discuss
abstract: Changes to the salary cap and player contracts under the new collective bargaining agreement will probably dominate the agenda, but player safety and other issues will also be discussed.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. general managers will gather on Wednesday in Toronto for their only in-season meeting of this lockout-shortened campaign. They usually get together twice a season for two-day sessions, but this year, it is just the one day, for six hours.

headline: 2 Tire Factories With Different Trajectories Reveal Social Schisms in France
abstract: One company is closing and the other has a promising future after workers agreed to concessions that many consider to be onerous.
lead_paragraph: AMIENS, France — This is a tale of two factories, across the road from each other in north Amiens, both owned by the same company, Goodyear Dunlop Tires France. But one, Goodyear, is scheduled to close after the union workers there refused to agree to new working conditions, which they argued were too harsh and benefited only the company. The other, Dunlop, has a promising future, and the company treats it very differently.

headline: Variety: Do Your Diagramless
abstract: A diagramless puzzle to do, by Fred Piscop.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I have a love-hate relationship with diagramless puzzles. On the one hand, they are a breath of fresh air after a week’s worth of crosswords, and on the other hand, they take up a lot more of my time than your standard crossword does. As someone who doesn’t have a whole lot of spare time and who apparently needs a refresher course in counting, the diagramless puzzles don’t give me the satisfaction I look for in solving.

headline: 2 Years Late, Zimbabwe Votes on New Constitution
abstract: The new charter is meant to resolve some of the problems that have kept Zimbabwe mired in crisis, but critics say it leaves the president’s powers undiluted.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Batsi Munyaka, 27, an unemployed mechanic, had not read the document that could govern his nation for decades to come. But he said he was tired of trying to cobble together a living with little ventures that did not add up to much, and he hoped that a new Constitution, whatever its provisions, could help get Zimbabwe’s economy on track.

headline: Assad Issues a Worldwide Plea as a Top Syrian General Defects
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Defectors (Political)']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Mohammed Nour Ezzedeen Khallouf, who was in charge of army supplies and logistics, has joined the rebels against President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Syrian general who was in charge of army supplies and logistics has defected from the army, he said Saturday, a day after the rebels’ top military commander again called for members of the armed forces to join the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, now entering its third year.

headline: Objections to U.S. Troops Intensify in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The continued presence of troops in Wardak, against the wishes of the Afghan government, brought demonstrators to Kabul on Saturday and provoked a  denunciation from Muslim clerics.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The continued presence of American Special Operations troops in Wardak Province, against the wishes of the Afghan government, brought demonstrators to the capital on Saturday and provoked a strongly worded denunciation from Muslim clerics.

headline: With Blessing, Pope Shows an Openness to Other Faiths
abstract: Pope Francis acknowledged that not all in his audience of news media workers were Catholic or believers, a sign of openness toward other faiths.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis on Saturday offered a silent blessing to an audience of journalists and other news media workers, acknowledging that not all of them were Catholic or believers — a rare gesture for a pontiff and a sign of openness toward other faiths and engagement with the secular world.

headline: Pakistan’s Government Steps Down, a Milestone
keywords: ['Elections', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The action represented a first in a country where the powerful military has regularly ousted civilian governments, either through coups or constitutional maneuvers.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s fragile democracy reached a milestone on Saturday when the government stepped down at the end of its five-year term, setting the stage for elections due to take place by mid-May.

headline: SXSW Music: For 3 Teenage Brothers, It’s Only Rock ’n’ Roll
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Radkey made an appearance at South By Southwest after sending MP3s of their songs to the festival’s bookers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Radkey’s tour bus is the family minivan, a venerable 2000 Plymouth Voyager with the nickname Harvey Dent because of a deep dent in one side that was never repaired.

headline: For Syracuse, Leaving Big East Means Leaving a Home
abstract: The basketball team’s coaches, players and fans say they will be back at Madison Square Garden, but it won’t be the same.
lead_paragraph: As soon as the final buzzer sounded for Syracuse 58, Georgetown 55, in overtime Friday night, the fan held up a sign that read, “The Rivalry Is Officially Closed.” He wore a T-shirt with “I Bleed Orange” across the front and pulled off a mask with the likeness of the Syracuse coach, Jim Boeheim.

headline: Days of Promise Fade for Ethanol
keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Rural Areas', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Five years ago, rural America was giddy for ethanol. But nearly 10 percent of the nation’s ethanol plants have stopped production over the past year.
lead_paragraph: MACON, Mo. — Five years ago, rural America was giddy for ethanol.

headline: Facing Bailout Tax, Cypriots Try to Get Cash Out of Banks
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Taxation']
abstract: The move revived fears of bank runs elsewhere in the euro zone, especially after a top European official declined to rule out similar measures on depositors in countries beyond Cyprus.
