headline: Red Bulls Banish Miller
abstract: Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke dropped defender Roy Miller from his 18-man roster for Saturday’s home opener against D.C. United and let him travel to Costa Rica to prepare for a World Cup qualifier.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Red Bulls Coach Mike Petke not only benched defender Roy Miller for Saturday’s match against D.C. United, but dropped him from the club’s 18-man game-day roster so he could return to Costa Rica to prepare for Friday’s World Cup qualifier against the United States in Commerce City, Colo.

headline: Men’s Tennis Tour Loves L.A. No Longer
abstract: The departure of the lone stop in Los Angeles to South America reflects the sport’s changing demographics.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Frank Sinatra sang at the Hollywood Bowl, Mikhail Baryshnikov danced at Shrine Auditorium, George Carlin told jokes at the Improv Comedy Club on Melrose Avenue. In Los Angeles over the decades, more stars have been visible on the night stage than in the night sky.

headline: An Aging American Legion Fights for Relevancy
abstract: In American Legion halls across the country, old age, apathy and budget deficits have become the enemies of an organization seeking to overhaul its image and increase membership.
lead_paragraph: ELGIN, Ill. — At first glance, the humble American Legion Post 57 just off Liberty Street in this tired river town near Chicago seems like a perfect slice of Americana — careworn, cozy and forever preserved in the amber of its ale and old-timey, wood-paneled charm.

headline: Zimbabweans Place High Hopes on New Constitution
abstract: Few have read the new draft or know of its provisions, but many hope that it will help set a course of democracy and economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Few have read the new draft or know of its provisions, but many hope that it will help set a course of democracy and economic growth.

headline: As Big East Changes, So Will Many Spring Rituals
abstract: For some fans who made attending the event a yearly pilgrimage, big changes to the tournament have been roughly tantamount to not celebrating a holiday.
lead_paragraph: As a law student living in New York City less than 10 years ago, Dan Guisbond had to watch his spending. Every March, he would ask for one birthday gift: a book of tickets to the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden.

headline: End of the World as the Yankees Knew It
abstract: The greatest decline-and-fall stories involve the mightiest empires. In the mid-1960s, it was the Yankees’ turn to collapse while the rest of baseball delighted in their misfortune.
lead_paragraph: The greatest decline-and-fall stories involve the mightiest empires. Ancient Greece. Rome. The borscht belt.

headline: Kenyan Court Asked to Order New Election For President
abstract: Raila Odinga, the second-place finisher in Kenya’s presidential race this month, filed a sweeping petition before Kenya’s Supreme Court on Saturday contending “glaring anomalies” in the vote and calling for a new election.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Raila Odinga, the second-place finisher in Kenya’s presidential race this month, filed a sweeping petition before Kenya’s Supreme Court on Saturday contending “glaring anomalies” in the vote and calling for the court to nullify the results and order a new election.

headline: Dodgers Catcher A.J. Ellis’s Long Climb to Success
abstract: Ellis, 31, developed plate discipline patience because he couldn’t hit, and in 2012 he led the National League in pitches per at-bat and had a gaudy on-base percentage.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What the Church Needs Now
abstract: Renewal from below depends on moral credibility at the top.
lead_paragraph: THE man who was transformed last week from Jorge Mario Bergoglio into the first Pope Francis faces a long list of challenges, each seemingly more daunting than the last. There’s the immediate need to reform a Vatican bureaucracy whose dysfunction helped sabotage his predecessor’s reign. There’s the larger challenge of lifting the shadow of the sex abuse crisis from the Western church. And then comes the task of making Catholic Christianity seem vital and appealing in cultures where the new pope’s church is widely regarded as archaic, irrelevant, or malign.

headline: When I Hire You, I’m Hiring Your Mentors’ Judgment
abstract: Ilene Gordon, the C.E.O. of Ingredion, says “I don’t think there’s anybody who’s successful in their role today who hasn’t been mentored by somebody.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Ilene Gordon, C.E.O. of Ingredion, a company that turns raw materials into ingredients for the food, beverage and other industries, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Gender Gap in Pain
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Gender', 'Pain', 'Medicine and Health', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: There is a gender gap in the diagnosis and treatment of painful disorders.
lead_paragraph: TO the list of differences between men and women, we can add one more: the drug-dose gender gap. Doctors and researchers increasingly understand that there can be striking variations in the way men and women respond to drugs, many of which are tested almost exclusively on males. Early this year, for instance, the Food and Drug Administration announced that it was cutting in half the prescribed dose of Ambien for women, who remained drowsy for longer than men after taking the drug.

headline: As Ethanol’s Luster Fades, Communities Struggle
keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Rural Areas', 'United States Economy', 'Drought', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The drought that has ravaged much of the nation’s crops has pushed commodity prices so high that ethanol has become too expensive to produce.
lead_paragraph: The drought that has ravaged much of the nation’s crops has pushed commodity prices so high that ethanol has become too expensive to produce.

headline: Unfair Punishments
keywords: ['Welfare (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Prostitution', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Editorials']
abstract: Denying food stamps and welfare to former drug offenders encourages dangerous behavior like prostitution.
lead_paragraph: Congress embraced a destructive policy when it decreed in 1996 that people convicted of drug felonies would henceforth be banned for life from receiving food stamps or cash assistance unless they lived in a state that expressly opted out of the ban.

headline: It’s Lose-Lose vs. Win-Win-Win-Win-Win
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Global Warming']
abstract: A carbon tax would be a better budget solution than the foolish sequester.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my favorite quotes about the state of U.S. politics was offered a couple years ago by Gerald Seib, a Wall Street Journal columnist, when he observed that “America and its political leaders, after two decades of failing to come together to solve big problems, seem to have lost faith in their ability to do so. A political system that expects failure doesn’t try very hard to produce anything else.” That’s us today — our entire political system is guilty of the “soft bigotry of low expectations” for ourselves.

headline: Googling You
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Electronic Communications Privacy Act', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: A 1986 federal law does not address new forms of privacy invasion, like Google’s mapping project, which also collected personal data.
lead_paragraph: The settlement last week between a group of state attorneys general and Google over the company’s improper data collection from home wireless networks shows the need to overhaul a 27-year-old federal law that is not up to the task of addressing new forms of privacy invasion.

headline: Elephants in Danger
abstract: Tens of thousands of African elephants are killed annually, the continent’s worst wildlife crisis in decades.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of African elephants are killed annually, the continent’s worst wildlife crisis in decades.

headline: Slaughter of the African Elephants
abstract: Poachers in central Africa are pushing elephants to extinction.
lead_paragraph: THERE is nothing a mother elephant will not do for her infant, but even she cannot protect it from bullets. About a year ago, poachers attacked a family of forest elephants in central Africa. The biologist who witnessed the attack told us that wildlife guards were completely outgunned. In the end, an elephant mother, riddled with bullets and trumpeting with pain and fear, was left to use her enormous body to shield her baby. Her sacrifice was for naught; the baby was also killed.

headline: To Catch a Tarpon, Be Ready for a Fight
abstract: The fish, distinguishable by their significant size and jumping ability, are a favorite of anglers, in part for the challenge they present.
lead_paragraph: JUCARO, Cuba — I stood on the bow of a Dolphin skiff anchored at the edge of a large channel in Jardines de la Reina. The incoming tide flooded through the strait with the Caribbean, a patchwork of shifting blues and greens, stretching to the south.

headline: A Contemporary Circus
abstract: After decades of decline, the circus is booming. Here are a sample of contemporary acts from around the world.
lead_paragraph: After decades of decline, the circus is booming. Here are a sample of contemporary acts from around the world.

headline: Wozniacki Survives Battle of Moonballs
abstract: Caroline Wozniacki and Angelique Kerber had several lengthy rallies with high, looping shots Friday in a BNP Paribas Open semifinal. Wozniacki will play Maria Sharapova in Sunday’s final.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — A thin crescent moon rose over Indian Wells about 4 p.m. Friday. But the moonballs began to take flight a few hours later.

headline: Moving Beyond the Big Tent
abstract: Circus has evolved into an exciting and vibrant art that needs support in the United States.
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL years ago, in Paris, I attended a performance of “nouveau cirque,” or “new circus.” This was far from your usual lion tamers and elephants: the show took place in a sleek white tent, its lobby filled with fashionable people lounging on red velvet couches. The performers, who wore tattered suit coats and scuffed leather shoes, were actors as much as acrobats, dancers as much as daredevils. They chanted Proust into crackling microphones and shouted Simon and Garfunkel lyrics.

headline: Open and Closed
keywords: ['Open-Source Software', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Beware the promises of false online transparency.
lead_paragraph: “CAN 3D printing be subversive?” asks a voice in the creepiest Internet video you’ll be likely to watch this month. It’s a trailer for Defcad.com, a search engine for 3D-printable designs for things “institutions and industries have an interest in keeping from us,” including “medical devices, drugs, goods, guns.”

headline: Israeli Areas Near the Old City
abstract: Israeli houses and settlements in East Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Israeli houses and settlements in East Jerusalem.

headline: Bishop Daniel Flores
abstract: The bishop of the most heavily Catholic town in the United States on heroes, responsibility and crayons.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Flores is the bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brownsville, Tex., a border town where 85 percent of the population is Catholic, the highest concentration in the United States. Known for his accessibility, empathy and advocacy of immigration reform, he has a devoted following among Catholics and non-Catholics alike.

headline: Lean In, Buddy Boy
abstract: Men, step aside and let the ladies do more of the work.
lead_paragraph: “Lean Back (and Relax!)”

headline: Smart Drones
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Artificial Intelligence']
abstract: Coming soon: weapons that have minds of their own.
lead_paragraph: IF you find the use of remotely piloted warrior drones troubling, imagine that the decision to kill a suspected enemy is not made by an operator in a distant control room, but by the machine itself. Imagine that an aerial robot studies the landscape below, recognizes hostile activity, calculates that there is minimal risk of collateral damage, and then, with no human in the loop, pulls the trigger.

headline: A High Line in Queens: Just Imagine the Food
abstract: Old railways have been turned into parks across the country. Will Queens be next?
lead_paragraph: For almost a century, American railroads of all sizes have been shedding branch and feeder lines, leaving more than 100,000 miles of abandoned railways across the country. And for the last 50 years, conservationists have been working to re-engineer these railways into long, narrow strips of parkland.

headline: Beyond the Bedroom
abstract: The Catholic Church is more persuasive on economic justice than on sexual morality. The new pope should put his focus there.
lead_paragraph: IT was too much to hope that after the white smoke rose and the TV anchors began nervously filling time and the cameras lingered for what seemed an eternity on that balcony over St. Peter’s Square, the man who stepped onto it would be someone open to revisiting the most archaic, obsolete matters of Roman Catholic doctrine. The group electing him was assembled by the last two popes, both conservatives. Its choice was bound to be more carbon copy than new page.

headline: Healing the Hospital Hierarchy
abstract: When doctors and nurses don’t get along, it’s the patient who suffers.
lead_paragraph: A hospital is, by its nature, the scene of constant life-or-death situations. It’s the work we nurses, doctors and other health professionals do; we chose it. The threat of harm can jazz you up or bring you down, but what it should demand, always, is the highest possible level of professionalism. Who’s at risk when that doesn’t occur?

headline: Sunday Dialogue: As the U.S. Reacts to North Korea’s Threats
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Readers discuss whether military defense and deterrence or diplomacy is most effective.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss whether military defense and deterrence or diplomacy is most effective.

headline:
Even on Reserves, Scant Protection for Elephants:
Three Stories From One Region
abstract: Like so many of Africa’s wilderness areas, the Buffalo Springs and Samburu reserves in Kenya are too cramped — smaller than the city of Detroit — for the majestic elephants they are supposed to protect.
lead_paragraph: Like so many of Africa’s wilderness areas, the Buffalo Springs and Samburu reserves in Kenya are too cramped — smaller than the city of Detroit — for the majestic elephants they are supposed to protect.

headline: The Real Spending Problem
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Tax Shelters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Tax giveaways are the costliest benefits the government provides.
lead_paragraph: The budget fight in Washington, which entered a new round last week as Senate Democrats and House Republicans introduced dueling plans, is usually cast as a contest between raising taxes and cutting spending. In fact, the taxes-versus-spending distinction is largely meaningless.

headline: Palin Bolsters Insurgents at Conservative Retreat
abstract: Sarah Palin’s reception at the Conservative Political Action Conference underscored her enduring popularity with the right.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin’s appearances no longer inspire speculation about her presidential aspirations, but her reception at a large gathering of conservatives on Saturday underscored her enduring popularity with the right. In a speech here, she offered zingers for the Republican base but also a strenuous defense of her Tea Party friends who are challenging the Republican establishment.

headline: How Much the N.Y.C. Mayoral Candidates Have Raised and Spent
abstract: A table and maps show who is ahead in the fund-raising race.
lead_paragraph: A table and maps show who is ahead in the fund-raising race.

headline: JPMorgan’s Follies, for All to See
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)']
abstract: The nation supposedly has new safeguards against another financial crisis. But a Senate report on JPMorgan Chase’s $6.2 billion trading loss offers cause for worry.
lead_paragraph: BE afraid.

headline: ‘It’s One Mistake for Another Here’
abstract: A Senate committee report on the $6.2 billion trading loss at JPMorgan Chase describes the anxious moments of phone conversations between traders.
lead_paragraph: THE Senate committee report on the $6.2 billion loss at JPMorgan Chase offers a peephole into the minds of the traders as they realized their big complex bets were melting down.

headline: Embrace New Skills, and Open New Doors
abstract: A classically trained professional dancer has this advice for anyone learning a new skill: Don’t be afraid to ask for help.
lead_paragraph: I’M a classically trained professional dancer, and I have three different jobs. My main one is performing with a group named Evidence, A Dance Company, which is based in Brooklyn. I’m also a co-choreographer and dancer in a three-person musical comedy group, Adira Amram and the Experience. On Saturdays, if not on the road with one of those groups, I teach dance at the Ailey School.

headline: SXSW Music: After a Hiatus, Green Day Returns
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong said little about his recent stint in rehab during a two-hour concert at Austin City Limits Live on Friday night, but he made it clear he was in a celebratory mood, whipping the crowded theater into a frenzy.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong said little about his recent stint in rehab during a two-hour concert at Austin City Limits Live on Friday night, but he made it clear that he was in a celebratory mood, whipping the crowded theater into a frenzy with exhortations to “get crazy.”

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 1
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Ten years after “shock and awe,” Iraq War veterans reflect on the first and last days of the war and what it meant to them.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago this week, on March 20, 2003, the United States invaded Iraq.

headline: Does Affirmative Action Do What It Should?
abstract: Some minority students who get into a top school with the help of affirmative action might be better served by attending a less elite institution.
lead_paragraph: WHAT’S more important to how your life turns out: the prestige of the school you attend or how much you learn while you’re there? Does the answer to this question change if you are the recipient of affirmative action?

headline: How to Force Ethics on the Food Industry
keywords: ['Food', 'Obesity', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Ethics (Institutional)']
abstract: Making people overweight is profitable. If we want change, we have to require it.
lead_paragraph: A COURT has struck down, at least for now, New York City’s attempt to slow the growth of obesity by limiting the portion size of sweetened beverages.

headline: SXSW Music: The 1960s, Getting Better With Age
keywords: ['Rock Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: You might expect that as the 1960s recede, so do its traditions, but young bands keep doing the psychedelia of the late-1960s better.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Ever since I’ve been coming to the South by Southwest Music Festival (and the CMJ Music Marathons, too), I’ve been running across young bands aiming to recreate the psychedelia of the late 1960s — which is, as the years go by, a time before many of them were born. You might expect that as the era recedes, so do its traditions, not to mention the inevitable breakdown and disappearance of authentic equipment. And beyond the indie-rock circuit, it’s pretty unlikely that that totally 1960s-style psychedelia would become a commercial force. But against those odds, young bands keep doing the 1960s better.

headline: Road Runners Facing Difficulty Months After Marathon Uproar
abstract: The furor over New York Road Runners’ handling of its marathon last year has died down, but questions about the group’s future persist, including whether its dominance has started to erode because of rival race organizers and disaffected runners.
lead_paragraph: The furor over New York Road Runners’ handling of its marathon last year has died down, but questions about the group’s future persist, including whether its dominance has started to erode because of rival race organizers and disaffected runners. Read full story here.

headline: No Trading Nuclear Arms for Aid, North Korea Says
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: The statement was the latest in a series in which North Korea has appeared to harden its position on its nuclear weapons program.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Saturday that its nuclear weapons were not a bargaining chip to trade for economic concessions, warning that it would never negotiate with the United States as long as Washington maintained its hostile policy toward the North.

headline: Coffee’s Economics, Rewritten by Farmers
abstract: Some coffee farmers are taking control of more of the supply chain, roasting and marketing their own beans for greater profit.
lead_paragraph: IN 2005, Kenneth Lander, a lawyer in Monroe, Ga., moved with his wife, stepdaughter and the youngest three of his seven children to a coffee farm in San Rafael de Abangares, Costa Rica. He always “had a heart,” he said, for Latin America, and after a vacation to the lush cloud forests near Monteverde in 2004, he was determined to return on a more permanent basis.

headline: Taking Over the Supply Chain
abstract: Thrive Farmers Coffee is built on a system that pays coffee farmers after their coffee has been exported, packaged and sold to retailers.
lead_paragraph: Thrive Farmers Coffee is built on a system that pays coffee farmers after their coffee has been exported, packaged and sold to retailers.

headline: Questions of Vulnerability as Heat Stay Hot
abstract: With the Heat having joined the 2007-8 Rockets and the 1971-72 Lakers as the only teams to record 21 or more wins in a row, the questions now become how long the team can keep the streak going.
lead_paragraph: For the Miami Heat to win their 21st consecutive game, they had to get through one of the few teams to win 20 in a row, the Milwaukee Bucks. Of course, the Bucks of this season are a far cry from the 1970-71 team that was led by a big three that rivals Miami’s: Lew Alcindor, Oscar Robertson and Bob Dandridge.

headline: Celebrating St. Patrick’s Day
abstract: People around the country celebrated the holiday with parades and green attire.
lead_paragraph: People around the country celebrated the holiday with parades and green attire.

headline: Ian M. Ross, a President at Bell Labs, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Ross was president of Bell Labs when its mission changed radically in 1984, after the breakup of its corporate parent, AT&T.
lead_paragraph: Ian M. Ross, who helped perfect the transistor and calculate whether the moon’s surface could support a spaceship’s weight, and then went on to lead Bell Laboratories, the legendary fount of technological marvels and Nobel Prize winners, died on March 10 at his home in New Smyrna Beach, Fla. He was 85.

headline: 36 Hours in Bangkok
abstract: How to spend 36 hours in Bangkok, a modern city with no shortage of tradition and graceful beauty.
lead_paragraph: How to spend 36 hours in Bangkok, a modern city with no shortage of tradition and graceful beauty.

headline: A Profession With an Egalitarian Core
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Though accused of defending selfishness, economics has a long tradition of treating individuals equally. That could have surprising implications in the debate over immigration.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMICS is sometimes associated with the study and defense of selfishness and material inequality, but it has an egalitarian and civil libertarian core that should be celebrated. And that core may guide us in some surprising directions.

headline: Challenging Management (but Not the Market)
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The investing style of Dimensional Fund Advisors, run by David Booth, is sometimes called passive, but the firm is often an extremely active shareholder in companies in its portfolio.
lead_paragraph: SOME investors make bold bets on the market, wagering on the financial effects of budget battles in Washington or the latest leadership shuffle in Beijing, Tokyo or Rome. David Booth, whose name is on the door of the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, made his fortune another way.

headline: Never Turning Away
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Ears and Hearing', 'Deafness', 'Disabilities']
abstract: The executive director of the Hearing Health Foundation says she saw early in life how some people could be condescending to those with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: GROWING up, I spent a lot of time in hospitals. My sister died of complications from birth defects when she was a year old, and in later years my mother developed multiple sclerosis. Both she and my grandmother died from the disease. I faced several difficult situations and learned to remain calm in a crisis.

headline: Jewish and Muslim, Bonding Over Dieting
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Weight', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Palestinians', 'Muslim-Americans']

lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Your mother-in-law fixes you a plate of food. Does she determine what you eat, and how much?

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Over the Line?
abstract: Did it or didn’t it? That was the question after D.C. United goalkeeper Bill Hamid swatted a ball off his line to preserve a 0-0 tie against the Red Bulls.

headline: Wright’s Backup Justin Turner Rolls His Ankle

headline: Ten Years Later
abstract: Iraq: down the memory hole?
lead_paragraph: Anniversaries of important events generally lead to a spate of articles and news reports looking back at those events. It’s not exactly irrational: the date can serve as a kind of focal point, in which articles that could have been written at any time can be published in the expectation that other pieces on the same subject will be published at the same time, raising the story to prominence.

headline: Any Pun for Tennis?
abstract: J.R.Leopold makes his debut and serves this puzzle to us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — First of all, how did I get to this point in my life and not know that Barbie a) had a last name, and 2) that that last name was ROBERTS? Granted, I wasn’t big on Barbie dolls, but it seems like the kind of pop culture factoid I should have known.

headline: How Top Students of Different Incomes Apply for College

lead_paragraph: A new study found that a majority of high-achieving high school seniors from low-income families did not apply to any selective colleges.

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Income Inequality', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Financial Aid (Education)']
abstract: Most low-income students who have top test scores and grades do not even apply to the nation’s best colleges, which contributes to widening economic inequality, economists say.
lead_paragraph: Most low-income students who have top test scores and grades do not even apply to the nation’s best colleges, according to a new analysis of every high school student who took the SAT in a recent year.

headline: Jeter Starts Second Straight Game at Shortstop
abstract: For the first time since his ankle was injured last October, the Yankees’ captain started consecutive games in the field.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — For the second consecutive game, Derek Jeter started at shortstop, which normally would not be too significant. Jeter has been the team’s starting shortstop since 1996.

headline: Walter Pierce, Modernist Architect, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Pierce, who was born in Brooklyn, lived his last 55 years in a house he built in Peacock Farm, Mass., a 45-acre subdivision of stylish, affordable homes that he designed.

abstract: Texas legislators tell voters they are collecting taxes for specific programs like trauma care, but then use some of the money to balance the budget.
lead_paragraph: Some people will do anything to stay away from tax bills and budget cuts.

headline: Water Rate in Small Town Has Residents Fuming
abstract: Like other small towns, Blue Mound says the rates charged by a private water company are much higher than those of neighboring big cities.
lead_paragraph: BLUE MOUND, Tex. — Minnie Wengert does not have a washing machine or a dishwasher. The 94-year-old conserves water by hand-washing dishes, using her shower sparingly and not watering the lawn.

headline: A Tough Road for Charter Proposal
abstract: Dan Patrick, the Texas Senate education chairman, has plans to expand the state’s charter school system, but they will have to pass a Legislature that defeated more modest proposals just two years ago.
lead_paragraph: When Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, told Texas lawmakers recently to “go big or go home” on education reform, the Senate education chairman, Dan Patrick, had already embraced that advice.

headline: So Much for Hoop Dreams, at Least for This Year
abstract: For the first time since 1977, the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament may not include a single team from Texas, and people have various explanations.
lead_paragraph: On Friday the University of Texas at Austin will play host to the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament for the first time in eight years. But what you may not see on the court at the Frank Erwin Center is a single team from Texas.

headline: Ukraine Wins Women’s Event Skipped by Many Big Names
abstract: The notable absence of some of chess’s elite players may have helped Ukraine grab the title at this year’s Women’s World Team Championship.
lead_paragraph: It is not easy to round up national squads for international competitions, judging by the notable absences at the Women’s World Team Championship in Astana, Kazakhstan.

headline: Guatemala’s Long March Toward Justice

lead_paragraph: Few believed the trial of the former dictator Efraín Ríos Montt for genocide and crimes against humanity committed during his rule would ever take place. But Guatemala’s justice system has begun a transformation.

headline: U.S. Cancels Part of Missile Defense That Russia Opposed
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

headline: Worker Is Crushed by Garbage Truck Compactor in Brooklyn
abstract: Luis Camarillo, 18, was standing at the rear of a truck that had been loaded with recycled paper when he was struck by the compactor and killed, the police said.
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old man was killed in Brooklyn on Saturday morning after being struck by the compactor of a privately owned garbage truck, the police said.

headline: Trying to Make the Majors, a Met Copes With the Death of a Child
abstract: As he works to make the Mets’ major league roster, catcher Landon Powell has been forthcoming about how the death of his 5-month-old daughter has affected his life.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Spring training is full of players who say that they are in the best shape of their lives, that they are raring to grab the game by its scruff and bend it to their will.

headline: The Cossacks Are Back. May the Hills Tremble.
abstract: Revered as fierce horsemen who once secured an empire’s frontier, Cossacks are gaining an increasing role in law enforcement in a newly conservative, nationalist Russia.
lead_paragraph: STAVROPOL, Russia — Outside this city’s police headquarters on a recent night, a priest in a purple velvet hat and gold stole moved from one man to the next, offering a cross to be kissed and drenching their faces with holy water from a long brush.

headline: Russia’s Cossack Revival
abstract: As the Russian government aims to promote a more conservative tone, Cossacks are playing a growing role, but threatening a gentle ethnic balance.
lead_paragraph: As the Russian government aims to promote a more conservative tone, Cossacks are playing a growing role, but threatening a gentle ethnic balance.

headline: In Final, Nadal Will Meet Del Potro, Who Upset Djokovic
abstract: The hardcourts at the California tournament must feel like clay to Rafael Nadal, who advanced to the title match of the BNP Paribas Open for the fourth time.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Although his nearly uninterrupted clay-court dominance has justifiably gotten most of the attention, Rafael Nadal has also been difficult to stop on the slow, gritty hardcourts in this desert community.

headline: Cossacks Expand Their Role in Russian Life
abstract: Cossacks are revered here for their bravery and pre-modern code of honor, like cowboys in America or samurai in Japan, and men in Cossack uniforms are all over Russia these days, attacking exhibits and theaters as standard-bearers for a resurgent church.
lead_paragraph: Cossacks are revered here for their bravery and pre-modern code of honor, like cowboys in America or samurai in Japan, and men in Cossack uniforms are all over Russia these days, attacking exhibits and theaters as standard-bearers for a resurgent church.

keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Performances on the fourth day of the festival included ones by Usher, Half Moon Run and Outer Minds.
lead_paragraph: Performances on the fourth day of the festival included ones by Usher, Half Moon Run and Outer Minds.

headline: Yankees Unveil a New Outfielder
abstract: Brennan Boesch, who seems destined for a platoon role, played his first spring training game for the Yankees
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Outfielder Brennan Boesch played his first game for the Yankees in Saturday afternoon’s 7-0 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies at Steinbrenner Field.

headline: Evolution of the New York Driver’s License
abstract: New York State first began issuing paper licenses to chauffeurs in 1910, and the shape, form and style have changed over the past century, adapting to new laws and technologies.
lead_paragraph: New York State first began issuing paper licenses to chauffeurs in 1910, and the shape, form and style have changed over the past century, adapting to new laws and technologies.

headline: Black and White and Wallet-Size, Unfit for Faking
abstract: New York State will introduce a new driver’s license in July that is made of polycarbonate and has other features that officials say will make it virtually impossible to forge.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Over the years, the authorities across the nation have tried all manner of tactics to combat fake drivers’ licenses. Holograms. Water marks. Even blunt red letters reading “UNDER 21.”

headline: New Apartments Will Complicate Jerusalem Issue
abstract: Israeli residences are being sandwiched into the fabric of Arab East Jerusalem, a construction many say undermines the idea that the area could serve as the capital of a Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Muslim call to prayer resounds through the traffic circle in the Palestinian enclave of Ras al-Amud, through the taxi stand where waiting drivers sip sweet coffee and the vegetable market where boys help their fathers after school. It can also be heard down the street in Maalot David, where a few Jewish families have quietly taken up residence in newly renovated apartments with prime views of Jerusalem’s Old City.

headline: New Pope Puts Spotlight on Jesuits, an Influential Yet Self-Effacing Order
abstract: Observers see both irony and opportunity in the election of a pope from the ranks of the Jesuits, an order that specifically rejects worldly ambition.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Men who join the Jesuits, the Roman Catholic Church’s largest religious order, take vows of poverty, chastity and obedience, and promise never to take any high office in the church.

headline: Wisconsin Forward Gets a History Lesson
abstract: Ryan Evans learned all about Hal Greer when he adopted a new style for his free throws.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Ah, youth. Wisconsin forward Ryan Evans never heard of Hal Greer, the Philadelphia 76ers star guard from the 1960s, until Badgers Coach Bo Ryan suggested a radical solution to Evans’s free-throw-shooting problems.

headline: China Names New Team to Secure Its Place in Asia and Face U.S. Competition
abstract: A new foreign policy team was named to manage Beijing’s side of the escalating competition in Asia between China and the United States.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s new foreign policy team, announced at a news conference on Saturday, includes officials whose records suggest the government will concentrate on consolidating what it considers the country’s rightful place at the center of Asia, even as the Obama administration says it will deploy more military power in the region.

headline: Anthony and Chandler Are Likely to Rest Again
abstract: Carmelo Anthony rejoined the Knicks, but Coach Mike Woodson was preparing to face the Clippers on Sunday without him and Tyson Chandler because of injuries.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Carmelo Anthony rejoined his teammates Saturday, two days after having fluid drained from his right knee in New York. But he did not join them on a practice court at U.C.L.A., instead taking a few jump shots off to the side.

headline: One Final Home Win for B.U.’s Coach
keywords: ['Coaches and Managers', 'College Athletics', 'Colleges and Universities', 'NCAA Ice Hockey Championships']
abstract: Jack Parker, Boston University’s hockey coach for 40 years, is calling it a career after this season.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Boston University gave Jack Parker, its soon-to-be-retiring head coach, one final victory Saturday night on the rink that bears his name. The Terriers defeated Merrimack College, 5-3, to sweep their Hockey East quarterfinal series, 2-0.

headline: Accuser Testifies in Ohio Rape Case; Verdict Expected
abstract: The trial abruptly ended Saturday night after the girl’s testimony, and the juvenile court judge who is hearing the case said he would issue a verdict at 10 a.m. on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — A 16-year-old girl who prosecutors say was raped by two high school football stars here last August after a night of drinking took the witness stand on Saturday and told a judge that she had no memory of a six-hour period during which each of the teenagers is said to have assaulted her.

headline: Louisville Takes Trophy on Its Way Out
abstract: The Cardinals rallied from a double-digit halftime deficit to beat the Orange in the last Big East final before they leave for the A.C.C.
lead_paragraph: After a week of nostalgia and remembrance, in this valedictory Big East tournament that threw open and widened memory lane, the championship game boiled down to basketball, plain and simple. That captured perfectly all that the tournament came to mean over the years.

headline: Civil Rights Cold Cases: ‘We Are Writing to Inform You ...’
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Examine forty-six letters from the F.B.I. to family members of the deceased regarding homicide cases from the civil rights era.
lead_paragraph: Examine forty-six letters from the F.B.I. to family members of the deceased regarding homicide cases from the civil rights era.

headline: When Cold Cases Stay Cold
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A few years ago, the F.B.I. began reopening dozens of cold cases involving blacks killed in the South decades ago, but resolution has been elusive.
lead_paragraph: FERRIDAY, La. — In the spring of 1965, the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington received a letter from Concordia Parish in northeastern Louisiana. Addressed to the bureau’s director, J. Edgar Hoover, the letter pleaded for justice in the killing of a well-respected black merchant.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 17
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 17.
lead_paragraph: “They respect strength here.”

headline: Brooklyn: The Brand
abstract: How the borough — with its local, back-to-the-basics lifestyle — morphed from landmass to global phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: How the borough — with its local, back-to-the-basics lifestyle — morphed from landmass to global phenomenon.

lead_paragraph: Images from Syracuse’s game against Louisville in the final Big East tournament championship game before the league’s core members go their separate ways.

headline: Kimberly Holton, Garrett van Ryzin
abstract: The bride is an associate professor at Rutgers; the groom is a professor at Columbia.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Alexis DaCosta Holton and Garrett John van Ryzin were married Saturday at St. Paul’s Chapel on the Columbia University campus in New York. The Rev. David W. Havens, a Disciples of Christ minister and the groom’s stepfather, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rachel Snyder and Drew Katz
abstract: The bride is a pro bono lawyer for an organization that helps impoverished young people; the groom is the chief executive of an outdoor advertising company and the founder of a foundation that supports charitable groups.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Lauren Snyder, the daughter of April J. Snyder and Dr. Robert A. Snyder of Golden Beach, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Drew Alexander Katz, the son of Marjorie J. Katz and Lewis Katz of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Aaron Krupnick officiated at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla., with Rabbi Edwin Farber taking part.

headline: Anna Richardson and Davis White
abstract: Both relocated to California from the East Coast, started working for Google and were connected by friends.
lead_paragraph: Anna Gabriella Richardson and Davis Cochrane White were married Saturday at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco. The Rev. Scott E. Richardson, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Right Rev. Marc Handley Andrus, the bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California.

headline: Leslie Griffith, David Graham
abstract: The bride is in law school and the groom is an editor at The Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Ann Griffith and David Andrew Graham were married Saturday in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Bruce B. Lawrence, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Sarah P. Duke Gardens on the campus of Duke University, where Father Lawrence is a professor emeritus of Islamic studies.

headline: Cristina Ros and Alexander Blankfein
abstract: The bride is on the board of a group that promotes women’s education; the groom will become a consultant.
lead_paragraph: Cristina Mercedes Ros, the daughter of Dr. Ana M. Viamonte Ros of Coral Gables, Fla., and Dr. Pablo Riera Ros of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married Saturday in Miami to Alexander David Blankfein, a son of Laura Jacobs Blankfein and Lloyd C. Blankfein of Manhattan. Rabbi Judy Kempler officiated at the Vizcaya Museum and Gardens.

headline: Jamie Alter, Gary Litt
abstract: The couple met at Penn.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Lauren Alter and Gary Daniel Litt were married Saturday evening at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. Rabbi Irwin Zeplowitz officiated.

headline: Katherine Graziano, Matthew Smith
abstract: The bride works for a consulting firm; the groom, an investment firm.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Graziano and Matthew Jared Smith were married Saturday at St. Bernard Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Brian Noel, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennifer Polin, Jonathan Grossman
abstract: The bride is a pediatric intern; the groom is a law clerk.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jennifer Ariella Polin, a daughter of Debra Aaronson Polin and Dr. Kenneth S. Polin of Skokie, Ill., is to be married Sunday to Jonathan David Grossman, a son of Debora G. Nobel and Dr. Elliot A. Grossman of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Milton H. Polin, the paternal grandfather of the bride, is to officiate at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: Alexandra Manzella, Timothy Kistner
abstract: The bride is a research associate at the American Institutes for Research; the groom is a law student at Boston University.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Lynn Manzella and Timothy Hale Kistner were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Kimi Riegel, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Colony Club, an event space in Detroit.

lead_paragraph: Erin Elizabeth Mumford and Andrew Martin Glenn were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Peter Schweitzer at the Tribeca Rooftop in Manhattan.

abstract: The bride and groom work at the Institute for Humane Studies at George Mason University, where they met.
lead_paragraph: Jeanne Marie Hoffman and William Davis Glod Jr. were married Saturday in New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Maureen Burwell Pollinger, a minister ordained by the New Seminary for Interfaith Studies in New York, officiated at the Greentree Country Club.

headline: Malancha Gupta, John Hennessy
abstract: The bride is an assistant professor at the University of Southern California; the groom is a postdoctoral scholar at the California Institute of Technology.
lead_paragraph: Malancha Gupta and John Joseph Hennessy were married Saturday evening at the Eventi Hotel in Manhattan. Pandit Nikhil Trivedi, a Hindu priest, officiated.

abstract: The bride is a reporter for ABC News; the groom is a software engineer, and was an extra in a pirate movie.
lead_paragraph: Susanna Gyu-jin Kim and Charles Soo Han were married Saturday at the Boston Harbor Hotel in Boston. The Rev. Eugene K. Lee, a minister ordained by the Evangelical Covenant Church of North America, officiated.

headline: Leah Sullivan and Joshua Pollack
abstract: The bride is a senior associate in a management consultancy firm; the groom works in the White House.
lead_paragraph: Leah McCord Sullivan and Joshua David Pollack were married Saturday at Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. George R. Fitzgerald, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

abstract: The couple met in July 2009, at a family reunion of sorts in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The Dolphins Get a New Fan

headline: Virginia VanZanten, Matthew Perlman
abstract: The couple were married Saturday at the Dumbo Loft, an event space in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Kyle VanZanten and Matthew Blake Perlman were married Saturday at the Dumbo Loft, an event space in Brooklyn. Megan R. Brown, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Christina Poulsen, Maxwell Brunner
abstract: The couple are graduates of Dartmouth, where they met.
lead_paragraph: Christina Lee Poulsen, a daughter of Joyce Lee Poulsen and Poul Skoedt Poulsen of San Rafael, Calif., was married Saturday to Maxwell Roy Brunner, a son of Sally Taylor Brunner and Timothy Allan Brunner of Ridgefield, Conn. Canon Mark Stanger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco.

headline: Nancy Quay and Sherry Marcy
abstract: Ms. Quay is a clinical social worker and the director of the comprehensive gender services program of the University of Michigan Health System, and Ms. Marcy retired from Pfizer.
lead_paragraph: A Partner and the Key to Her Survival

headline: Italian Lawmakers Elect Speakers, but Stable Government Remains Elusive
abstract: With three sizable blocs in Parliament, talks on a new government are expected to be difficult.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Italian Parliament elected speakers for the two houses of Parliament on Saturday, but failed to find broad agreement among lawmakers in what is shaping up to be an uphill effort to form a stable government after inconclusive elections last month.

headline: Dominicans Show Culture in Emotional Style of Play
abstract: With routine shows of emotion, the unbeaten Dominican Republic has led the World Baseball Classic in boisterous play, and had some American players grumbling.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Dominican Republic has celebrated every hit as if it were its last, every putout as if it had decided the game. Its players have clenched their fists, pounded their chests and screamed — sometimes in the fourth inning. And if the Dominicans took a late lead, the whole dugout would explode, players bursting onto the field, like confetti out of a party popper.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 16, 2013

headline: Red Bulls Do Everything but Win, Again
abstract: Despite dominating play for long stretches, the Red Bulls were held scoreless by D.C. United at Red Bull Arena.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — When they last met, the Red Bulls and D.C. United sat through a one-day postponement of their playoff game because of a snowstorm. The next day, D.C. ended the Red Bulls’ 2012 season.

headline: Dieng Powers Cardinals’ Defense, and Their Big Comeback
abstract: Louisville center Gorgui Dieng was an intimidating force in the middle of the defense, and he facilitated the offense in the Cardinals’ victory over Syracuse in the Big East tournament final.
lead_paragraph: Standing in the center circle for the opening tipoff of the last tournament of the old Big East, Louisville’s Gorgui Dieng knew the moment was weighty, but he may not have recognized just how much so.

headline: U.S. Soccer: Klinsmann’s Choices, Summer Friendlies, Women’s Injuries
abstract: Jurgen Klinsmann will name his roster for the United States national team’s next two qualifiers on Monday morning. But who will be going?
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann will name his roster Monday for the United States’ next two World Cup qualifiers. The games — against Costa Rica on Friday in Commerce City, Colo., and against Mexico next Tuesday in Mexico City — won’t decide whether the Americans play in the 2014 World Cup, but they could make getting there a lot easier, or infinitely more difficult.

headline: New Prime Minister Seeks to Reassure World on China’s Rise
abstract: As China grows, its image is suffering among some because of territorial disputes, alleged large-scale cyberattacks and severe environmental problems. Its new prime minister, Li Keqiang, sought to soothe those concerns Sunday.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Does China have a growing image problem in the world?

headline: The U.S. and Afghanistan
abstract: The long troubled U.S. — Afghan relationship winds down.
lead_paragraph: The long troubled U.S. - Afghan relationship winds down.

headline: A Crowded Venue for Justin Timberlake
abstract: If you want to know how far the South by Southwest Music Festival has strayed from its anti-corporate, indie rock roots, look no further than a show by Justin Timberlake.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know how far the South by Southwest Music Festival has strayed from its anti-corporate, indie rock roots, you need only consider this: One of the most popular shows on the final night of the festival was Justin Timberlake, playing a concert sponsored by Chevrolet to promote the newly revamped Myspace Web site.

headline:
Turmoil in Cyprus
Over a Bailout
Rattles Europe
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A decision to impose across-the-board losses on Cypriot depositors as part of a $13 billion bailout has fueled fears that bank runs there could spread to countries like Spain and Italy.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Europe’s surprising decision early Saturday to force bank depositors in Cyprus to share in the cost of the latest euro zone bailout set off increasing outrage and turmoil in Cyprus on Sunday and fueled fears that the trouble will spread to countries like Spain and Italy.

headline: In China, New Premier Says He Seeks a Just Society
abstract: In his first comments as prime minister, Li Keqiang offered a tantalizing palette of economic and social reforms that promised to transform the lives of the rural poor, migrants flooding into the cities and retirees.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Li Keqiang, in his first comments as China’s prime minister, laid out a vision on Sunday of a more equitable society in which environmental protection trumps unbridled growth and government officials put the people’s welfare before their own financial interests.

headline: The Psychologist as (Wary) Parent
abstract: When I was a psychologist pregnant with my first child, a colleague asked, “Do you want to hear how psychologists screw up their kids?”
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, I was eight and a half months pregnant with my first child and sitting with Debby, a treasured senior colleague and gifted psychotherapist. She departed from our regular business to venture:

headline: Kenyans Win in City’s First Major Race Since Marathon Cancellation
abstract: With a time of 1:01:02, Wilson Kipsang won the first major road race in the city since Hurricane Sandy forced the cancellation of the marathon in November.
lead_paragraph: Freezing temperatures and a dusting of snow Sunday did little to slow Wilson Kipsang, who ran away from a pack of elite runners to win the 13.1-mile New York City Half, the first major road race in the city since Hurricane Sandy led to the cancellation of the marathon in November.

headline: U.N. Revives Effort on Pact to Regulate Arms Trade
abstract: Negotiators will reconvene this week, over the objections of the National Rifle Association and other gun-rights advocates, to try to reach a deal on a global treaty to regulate sales of conventional weapons.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of the re-energized gun-control debate in the United States, negotiators at the United Nations will reconvene this week to try to reach a final agreement on a treaty to regulate the global trade in conventional weapons, a lucrative business that rights groups call the main source of illicit arms fueling deadly conflicts around the world.

headline: Ohio Teenagers Guilty in Rape That Social Media Brought to Light
abstract: The case of two high school football stars drew wide attention for the way social media spurred the initial prosecution and later helped galvanize national outrage over the episode.
lead_paragraph: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — Two high school football stars were found guilty on Sunday of raping a 16-year-old girl last summer in a case that drew national attention for the way social media spurred the initial prosecution and later helped galvanize national outrage.

headline: Wright Returns to Mets And Says Pain Is Easing
abstract: Mets third baseman David Wright, recovering from a strained muscle, said he hoped to be healthy by April 1, opening day.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Boldface names swept through the Mets’ spring training complex Sunday, including Regis Philbin, whose ceremonial first pitch sent cellphone cameras aloft around Tradition Field, and third baseman David Wright, whose presence in the clubhouse after his return from the World Baseball Classic also caused a stir.

headline: Disruptions: Stuck With a Provider Over the Long Haul
abstract: Owning a cellphone on one of the biggest providers can sometimes feel like an unhappy relationship, with companies frequently taking advantage of customers.
lead_paragraph: If dating were like the cellphone industry, you would have to sign a contract when you entered a relationship stating that you would remain monogamous for two years, even if you wanted to break up. That’s what cellular carriers have pulled off by successfully lobbying for a recent government ruling that you cannot take the phone you paid for and switch to another provider.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (E!) PLAYING WITH FIRE The former “Top Chef” competitor Candice Kumai; the night-life impresarios turned food entrepreneurs Derek and Daniel Koch; the brand ambassador Anna Boiardi; the pastry chef Julie Elkind; the restaurateur Todd English; and the actress and bakery owner Jennifer Esposito turn their lives into open cookbooks as they storm the New York culinary scene in this new reality series. In this premiere episode, the Koch twins prepare for the grand opening of Toy, a restaurant inside the Gansevoort Hotel. Ms. Boiardi, meanwhile, finds that her mother disapproves of her Bolognese-cooking technique. And Mr. English celebrates his birthday and the 10th anniversary of his restaurant Olives. Above, a scene from the show.

headline: Disney’s ‘Oz’ Keeps Lead at Box Office
abstract: “Oz the Great and Powerful” took in an estimated $42.2 million at North American theaters over the weekend for first place at the box office.
lead_paragraph: “Oz the Great and Powerful” continued to cast a spell on moviegoers over the weekend, while another magician — “The Incredible Burt Wonderstone” — essentially arrived to a chorus of boos. “Oz” (Disney) took in an estimated $42.2 million at theaters in the United States and Canada, for a strong two-week total of $145 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Mound Builders'
abstract: A scene from the Signature Theater’s revival of Lanford Wilson’s 1975 play.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the Signature Theater’s revival of Lanford Wilson’s 1975 play.

headline: Original Review: ‘The Mound Builders’
abstract: Mel Gussow’s 1975 review of the Lanford Wilson play.
lead_paragraph: Mel Gussow’s 1975 review of the Lanford Wilson play.

headline: Turkish Authorities Detain Man in Death of Tourist From Staten Island
abstract: A homeless man linked by DNA to the killing of Sarai Sierra was captured near the Turkish-Syrian border, officials said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A 46-year-old homeless man suspected in the killing of a Staten Island woman was taken into custody on Sunday, the Turkish authorities said.

headline: A Low-Carb, Low-Budget Cooking Show, Fiercely Seasoned
abstract: Meet a trim, sassy television personality, Soraya Sobreidad, who preaches the gospel of healthy Puerto Rican cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Television cooking shows, with their globe-trotting superstar chefs, are no longer humble small-studio affairs. But there is one program, glamorous in its own way, that gleefully bucks the trend. It is taped in a cramped apartment kitchen in Jackson Heights, Queens, and appears on public access. Its star is a trim, sassy drag queen named Soraya Sobreidad who preaches the gospel of healthful Puerto Rican cuisine.

headline: Funny or Die Makes a Steve Jobs Movie
abstract: The comedy Web site intends to unveil “iSteve,” starring Justin Long, on April 15.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Techies have been keeping a hot eye on dueling Steve Jobs biopics, one an indie starring Ashton Kutcher and the other, written by Aaron Sorkin, in the works at Sony, which made “The Social Network.”

headline: A Senate Plan Alters Waiting Periods for Immigration
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Visas', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The bipartisan group’s overhaul of an immigration law would decrease the amount of time it takes to become a naturalized citizen, but increase the wait for a green card.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s 11 million illegal immigrants would have to wait a full decade for a green card but could earn citizenship just three years after that, under a provision being finalized by a bipartisan group of eight senators working to devise an overhaul of immigration law, several people with knowledge of the negotiations said.

headline: The Cypriot Haircut
abstract: Uh oh.
lead_paragraph: OK, I didn’t see that one coming. With all the problems in Greece, Italy, Spain, and Portugal I wasn’t watching Cyprus. But that’s where the big euro news is this weekend; in return for a bailout, Cyprus is supposed to impose a large haircut — that is, loss — on all depositors in its banks.

headline: Appealing to Hearts and Gullets, Francis Delights Crowd on First Sunday as Pope
abstract: The pontiff reflected on God’s mercy in front of an estimated 200,000 people in St. Peter’s Square, then wished them all a good lunch.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In his first Sunday appearance from the papal apartment overlooking St. Peter’s Square, Pope Francis charmed a huge crowd by infusing the message of the Gospel with personal recollections and a smattering of humor.

headline: Architectural Iconoclast Wins the Pritzker Prize
abstract: Toyo Ito, who designed a library that survived Japan’s disastrous 2011 earthquake, has won his field’s top honor.
lead_paragraph: Toyo Ito, a Japanese architect who broke from Modernism and designed a library that survived his country’s catastrophic 2011 earthquake, was awarded his profession’s top honor, the Pritzker Architecture Prize, on Sunday.

headline: G.O.P. Leaders Unswayed by Obama’s ‘Charm Offensive’
abstract: In television appearances, Republican leaders who hold the most sway over fiscal negotiations were holding firm in opposing President Obama’s proposal to raise new tax revenue.
lead_paragraph: President Obama appeared on Sunday to still be enjoying a bit of good karma from his extended outreach to Congress last week, but Republican leaders who hold the most sway over fiscal negotiations were holding firm in opposition to the president.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Selection Sunday
abstract: Empty brackets become a thing of the past today as the field of 68 is chosen for the 2013 men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: Empty brackets become a thing of the past today as the field of 68 is chosen for the 2013 men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Mike Huguenin is providing live updates and analysis.

headline: You Really Can’t Eat Just One, and Here’s the Reason
abstract: Michael Moss’s “Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us” looks at food manufacturers’ distortion of the American diet in favor of calorie-dense products that maximize “bliss.”
lead_paragraph: Americans eat 33 pounds of cheese and cheese products per year, per person, which is triple the consumption rate of the 1970s. Fans of Humboldt Fog and Cabot Clothbound Cheddar may hope this signals the return of the artisan producer, but Michael Moss gives all credit to mighty Kraft and the other food giants.

headline: Onstage Patter, Before the Feet Move
abstract: Alvin Ailey’s junior company, Ailey II, gamely performed its program “All New” in its first New York season under its new artistic director, Troy Powell.
lead_paragraph: At the Ailey Citigroup Theater last April, Troy Powell talked about having to fill a small woman’s big shoes. He was referring to his succeeding Sylvia Waters, who was stepping down after 38 years as the artistic director of Ailey II, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s junior company. On Wednesday, when Ailey II opened its first New York season under Mr. Powell’s direction, he said that for himself and seven new dancers “everything is new, including my shoes.”

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: As Kuroda Enters What Could Be His Final Season, Wells Is an Unlikely Guide
abstract: Hiroki Kuroda, 38, recently sought advice about career longevity from the Yankees spring training instructor David Wells, who pitched until he was 44.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — An unlikely friendship was forged in front of Hiroki Kuroda’s locker Thursday morning when the quiet and clean-cut Kuroda invited the gregarious and tattooed David Wells to pull up a chair.

headline: Teixeira Expected to Be Out Longer With Partly Torn Tendon Sheath
abstract: First baseman Mark Teixeira said his wrist injury was not a sprain but rather a partially torn tendon sheath, which might keep him out until June, and maybe longer.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — First baseman Mark Teixeira returned to the Yankees’ spring training complex Sunday morning, wearing a brace on his right wrist and delivering grim news. His injury was originally thought to be a sprain, but is a partly torn tendon sheath. He will most likely be out until June, and maybe longer, if he and the Yankees do not employ an abundance of caution.

headline: Drones: A Booming Business?
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles, also known as drones, may soon become commercialized. In Grand Forks, N.D., people are preparing for a coming boom in drones-related business.
lead_paragraph: Unmanned aerial vehicles, also known as drones, may soon become commercialized. In Grand Forks, N.D., people are preparing for a coming boom in drones-related business.

headline: Domestic Drones Stir Imaginations, and Concerns
abstract: Companies, universities and lawmakers in the United States are preparing for a world in which remote-controlled planes will be ubiquitous in civilian air space.
lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — On the pilot’s computer screen, planted at ground level a few yards from the airport runway here, the data streaming across the display tracked an airplane at 1,300 feet above a small city on the coast, making perfect circles at 150 miles per hour.

headline: Republicans Act With Air, if Not a Vote, of Confidence
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In Congress, the party is pushing an agenda that is almost identical to the one it lost with in November, with no regrets and few efforts to reframe it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year ago this month, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin stood on the floor of the House and declared that the ideals of small government, privatized health care and rigorous spending discipline captured in the budget plan about to pass the House would and should be central to the 2012 election campaign.

headline: Painting’s Removal Stirs Outcry
abstract: The Seward House Historic Museum’s decision to sell Thomas Cole’s “Portage Falls on the Genesee” disturbs the descendants of Gov. William H. Seward and museum professionals.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 years it hung in the Seward family home in Auburn, in central New York State: a large oil painting by Thomas Cole, the founder of the Hudson River School, that was given to Gov. William H. Seward to thank him for his work expanding the Erie Canal.

headline: Summoning Jazz Spirits to the Temple
abstract: Charles Lloyd, the saxophonist, performed at the Temple of Dendur in the Metropolitan Museum on his 75th birthday.
lead_paragraph: On a small stage facing the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art the WNYC radio host Terrance McKnight put on his most serious voice and requested a divine secret of the saxophonist Charles Lloyd. “Who does one talk to,” he asked, “to have one’s 75th birthday fall on a Friday night?”

headline: Mother, as She Lives and Breathes
abstract: “Bates Motel,” a series beginning Monday on A&E, is a prequel of sorts to the movie “Psycho,” with Norman Bates as a teenager and his mother running the motel.
lead_paragraph: A series called “Bates Motel” can’t open with a shower scene. But since this new drama, starting Monday on A&E, is, after all, a prequel of sorts to the movie “Psycho,” homage had to be paid to Alfred Hitchcock upfront. The creators went with that director’s sly sense of humor.

headline: Pregnant Girl Vanishes, and Story Lines Fork
abstract: Elisabeth Moss stars in “Top of the Lake,” a seven-part Sundance Channel mini-series about a missing girl.
lead_paragraph: There are times during “Top of the Lake” when you can convince yourself that you’re watching a mystery story about a girl who goes missing. But that sensation never lasts.

headline: Start With Adolescent Spirit, Then Grow Into a Role
abstract: The soprano Diana Damrau gave her first performance as Violetta in Verdi’s “Traviata” as it returned to the Met on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A singer trying out a role for the first time anywhere at the barnlike, high-exposure Metropolitan Opera is like a runner taking a chance on a new distance at the Olympics. And that race is the marathon when the role is a touchstone like Violetta in Verdi’s “Traviata,” which returned to the Met on Thursday starring Diana Damrau, Plácido Domingo and Saimir Pirgu and conducted by Yannick Nézet-Séguin.

headline: I’ll Be There for You
abstract: A measure of a Monday puzzle by Daniel Landman.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a smooth solve until I got to the payoff. I solved this puzzle by Daniel Landman (who appears to be making a debut) from the outside in, noting the theme entries of two-word phrases that started with S and I. It’s an enjoyable solve, perfectly pleasant for a Monday, with a payoff that seems a bit Wednesdayish to me.

headline: A Death in Paraguay Leads a Niece to Brutal Truths
abstract: In “108 (Cuchillo de Palo)” Renate Costa investigates the secret life of her gay uncle, who had mysteriously amassed a fortune in Paraguay.
lead_paragraph: The style is simple but the emotions highly sophisticated in “108 (Cuchillo de Palo),” Renate Costa’s insistently prodding documentary about the secret life of her gay uncle, Rodolfo Costa, under the oppressive government of the Paraguayan dictator Alfredo Stroessner.

headline: Lebhar IMP Pairs in St. Louis
abstract: The winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs on Saturday evening here were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs on Saturday evening here were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York. They finished 5.36 international match points ahead of Lewis Gamerman of Westwood, Mass., and Robert McCaw of Sudbury, Mass. Third were Robert Cappelli of Bloomfield, Mich., and Robert Katz of Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Selling Stars, Brands and Baby Bands
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Rock Music']
abstract: Big names and big productions with corporate tie-ins were one thread at the South by Southwest festival, but lesser known acts still make up its core.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Two images linger from this year’s South by Southwest Music festival, which ended Sunday after five nights and days with hundreds of performances. One has been the major part of SXSW for all of its 27 years: sharing the crowded sidewalks with sleep-deprived but bright-eyed musicians toting their own equipment to the next gig. The other is more recent: a 62-foot-high outdoor stage built to resemble a snack-chip vending machine that turned into a six-story video billboard when it wasn’t showing live performances.

headline: Footnote
abstract: The New York theater company Clubbed Thumb has announced its lineup for the 18th annual Summerworks festival.
lead_paragraph: The New York theater company Clubbed Thumb has announced its lineup for the 18th annual Summerworks festival, which is set for May 24 to June 29 at the Wild Project in the East Village. The festival, which highlights original works by American playwrights, is to feature the three new plays; “Phoebe in Winter,” by Jen Silverman (“Crane Story”), “La Brea,” by Gregory S. Moss (“Billy Witch”) and Clare Barron’s “Baby Screams Miracle.”

headline: Waiting for the Run on the Banks
abstract: After months and months of something passing for blessed calm in the euro zone, the bailout of Cypriot banks rekindles fears of instability in Italy and Spain.
lead_paragraph: The economics Nobel laureate Paul Krugman could not have been clearer about the dangers of forcing depositors in Cypriot banks to take a loss on their accounts.

headline: To Reassure Investors, Fed Stresses It Will Not End Stimulus
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Concerns about the effects of the Federal Reserve’s stimulus policy can dilute the policy’s impact by causing investors to doubt that rates will remain low.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each time in recent years that the Federal Reserve has paused in its efforts to stimulate the economy, it has come to regret the decision as premature. Its leading officials say the recovery has been slower as a consequence of those pauses. It is a mistake they do not want to repeat.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The arrests come just one day after a referendum on a draft Constitution and follow months of harsh crackdowns on opposition politicians and civic groups ahead of a presidential election.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Security officials arrested three senior officials of the Movement for Democratic Change, Zimbabwe’s main opposition political party, and a renowned human rights lawyer on Sunday, one day after a largely peaceful referendum on a draft constitution.

keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']

lead_paragraph: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual Transformation conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A’s, held last week in New Orleans.

lead_paragraph: Now that we know who will be playing, it’s time to think about which lower-seeded teams will pull off upsets in this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Spreading Disruption, Shaking Up Cable TV
abstract: Aereo, a start-up backed by Barry Diller that captures broadcast signals to be streamed online, is sowing chaos in the cable television business.
lead_paragraph: The table in the conference room on the sixth floor of the IAC headquarters in Manhattan was a portrait of organization. In front of each of the 10 chairs was a leather case holding a fresh tablet of paper, with a sharpened pencil placed above it, just so. Everything in “the Helm,” as they call the room, was precise, orderly, logical. Just the way Barry Diller likes it.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'States (US)']

lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Clippers Overpower Knicks, Whose Skid Reaches 4 Games
abstract: The Knicks, without the injured Carmelo Anthony and Tyson Chandler, were dunked on eight times as the Clippers sent the team to its fourth straight loss.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The easiest way to get embarrassed in the N.B.A. is to be dunked on, to challenge the opposing player as he rises up and tries to put you on his highlight reel. The Los Angeles Clippers are the best team in the league at making opponents look silly, to the point that their video clips go viral seemingly within minutes.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When President Obama lands here on Wednesday, he may encounter some Israelis staging a hunger strike in support of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel.

lead_paragraph: How about this for a promotional thriller: Beginning Monday, on the 10th anniversary of the release of the mega-bestseller “The Da Vinci Code,” its publisher, Doubleday, will allow anyone to download the entire book free for a week.

lead_paragraph: The cable news channel HLN, which had some of its highest ratings during the trial of Casey Anthony two years ago, has become fixated on another: the trial of Jodi Arias, a woman accused of killing her ex-boyfriend, Travis Alexander, in Arizona in 2008.

lead_paragraph: Publishing a 36-page cover article called “Bitter Pill: Why Medical Bills Are Killing Us” certainly didn’t seem like a shameless attempt to bolster newsstand sales for Time magazine.

lead_paragraph: Richard D. Lyons, who covered science, Congress and the United Nations during almost 30 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died on Wednesday at his home in Charleston, S.C. He was 84.
