lead_paragraph: FOUNTAIN, Colo. — Coy Mathis was born a boy. But after just a few years, biology succumbed to a more powerful force.

headline: Divided Views of SAC Capital Settlement
abstract: The S.E.C. celebrated Friday’s settlement with SAC Capital Advisors, but both the fund and its rivals saw the $616 million fine as a good price for peace in the insider trading case.
lead_paragraph: Not many Wall Street executives, let alone hedge funds, could write a $616 million check and remain solvent.

headline: San Francisco Symphony’s East Coast Tour Is Canceled as Labor Talks Break Down
abstract: Talks with the musicians, who went on strike on Wednesday, mainly over wage issues, broke down on Sunday evening.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Symphony has announced that negotiations over a new contract with its musicians have broken down with the players’ rejection of a federal mediator’s proposal for a cooling-off period. As a result, the orchestra’s East Coast tour, which was to have included concerts at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Thursday as well as concerts in Newark on Friday and Washington on Saturday, has been canceled.

headline: Tax Credits or Spending? Labels, but in Congress, Fighting Words
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: As lawmakers struggle to narrow the government’s deficit, every dollar taken from a grant program counts as a budget cut, while every dollar taken from a tax credit is instead a tax increase.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a low-income neighborhood in Bozeman, Mont., taxpayers helped pay for the construction of a grocery store, Town and Country Foods. They are doing the same in New Orleans, with federal dollars helping to build new groceries, including a Whole Foods, in an area still suffering after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Louisville’s Pressure Defense Creates Victories
abstract: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino routinely reinforces one message: knock the ball away. The Cardinals’ trapping defense helped them earn the overall No. 1 seed.
lead_paragraph: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino has his assistants chart deflections whenever his team takes the court, whether for practice or for games. The totals are collected and posted, and Pitino reinforces the message every day, every hour, practically every minute through the season: stay active on defense, keep your hands busy, knock the ball away. At Louisville, deflections form the foundation for the team’s swarming defense.

headline: Terror Haven in Mali Feared After French Leave
abstract: Western and African officials are increasingly concerned that the soldiers expected to continue the campaign against militants lack proper training and equipment.
lead_paragraph: NEMA, Mauritania — With France planning to start withdrawing its troops from Mali next month, Western and African officials are increasingly concerned that the African soldiers who will be relied on to continue the campaign against militants linked to Al Qaeda there do not have the training or equipment for the job.

headline: Criticizing Bloomberg, Liu Enters Race to Succeed Him
abstract: John C. Liu, the city comptroller, announced his mayoral campaign on the steps of City Hall with a populist pitch and taking aim at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: Brushing off his legal troubles as the price of taking on powerful interests, an exuberant John C. Liu, the city comptroller, officially began his campaign for mayor on Sunday with a vow to represent the “100 percent,” not “the 1 percent.”

headline: Drones, Ethics and the Armchair Soldier
abstract: Does the advent of drone warfare, which keeps active soldiers out of harm’s way, require a new brand of moral responsibility?
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, I watched the Iraq invasion unfold on TV. It was for me, like most Americans, a remote-control event, the type that you tuned into occasionally to see how it was going before changing the channel, like the Olympics. And, as often happens in the Olympics, we crushed the opposition. But we Americans at home were not the only ones with remote controls. Many of our soldiers also had them, and used them to direct one of the most devastating military assaults in the history of modern warfare. The technological superiority of the United States — its ability to strike with precision from a distance — produced something like the “shock and awe” the media had relentlessly advertised. And it inspired a similar reaction in moral and legal theorists who were concerned about the relationship between advanced military technologies and the legitimation of warfare.

headline: Riffs by Cab Riders, Secretly Recorded for the Sake of Art
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Art', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Privacy']
abstract: A documentary filmmaker and licensed cabby secretly recorded the conversations of his passengers, assembled the highlights into an audio collage and installed the final product in his taxi.
lead_paragraph: His career as a New York City taxi driver began with a graveyard shift, a creative itch, and a brazen interpretation of privacy laws.

headline: Cruelty to Women Overseas
abstract: Even with the Helms amendment, foreign aid money could be used to provide abortions to victims of rape.
lead_paragraph: Each year some 47,000 women around the world die as a result of unsafe abortions. Efforts to reduce that toll are severely hampered by the Helms amendment, which was originally enacted in 1973 and restricts the use of United States foreign aid money to finance abortions overseas, even in places where abortion is legal.

headline: A Worsening Haitian Tragedy
abstract: Thousands of people are needlessly dying of cholera while groups that promised to help, particularly the U.N., abdicate responsibility.
lead_paragraph: The aid group Doctors Without Borders said last Tuesday that the cholera crisis in Haiti was getting worse, for the most unnecessary and appalling of reasons: a lack of money and basic medical supplies.

headline: No Nukes on the Korean Peninsula
abstract: South Korea’s security would not be improved by developing its own nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: It’s little wonder that South Koreans are thinking about ways to defend themselves, given North Korea’s bizarre and dangerous behavior. The North has recently launched a long-range rocket and conducted its third nuclear test. It has also unleashed a barrage of apocalyptic threats, including potentially launching “pre-emptive nuclear strikes” on Seoul and the United States and declaring the 1953 Korean War armistice nullified.

headline: Marches of Folly
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'News and News Media', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Did we learn anything from Iraq?
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, America invaded Iraq; somehow, our political class decided that we should respond to a terrorist attack by making war on a regime that, however vile, had nothing to do with that attack.

headline: U.S. Looked at Wall Street Journal Over Claims of Bribery
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: The investigation of The Wall Street Journal coincides with a broader search the government is conducting of News Corporation over a phone-hacking scandal in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The United States government’s inquiry into News Corporation broadened last year when the Justice Department investigated claims that employees in the China news bureau of The Wall Street Journal bribed local officials with gifts in exchange for information.

headline: Drugs for Early-Stage Alzheimer’s
abstract: A proposal to ease testing requirements is seductive but raises concerns about safety.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed lowering the bar for approving drugs to treat people at the earliest stages of Alzheimer’s disease, before they have developed any serious impairment or overt dementia. The goal is commendable — to find ways to prevent or slow the progression of this terrible disease before it can rob people of their mental capacities. But the proposal raises troubling questions as to whether the agency would end up approving drugs that provide little or no clinical benefit yet cause harmful side effects in people who take the medications for extended periods.

headline: Saving Schools and Libraries by Giving Up the Land They Sit On

headline: Fire in Bronx Apartment Building Kills 7-Year-Old Girl
abstract: Sixty firefighters responded to a fatal blaze on Grant Avenue that also critically injured a 3-year-old and sent dozens of residents into the pre-dawn cold.
lead_paragraph: A fire started in a Bronx apartment building just after 3 a.m. on Sunday, announcing itself with thick clouds of black smoke billowing through the hallways. It burned through a fourth-floor apartment, killing a 7-year-old girl and critically injuring a 3-year-old girl, the authorities said.

headline: Bubbling Up: The Downside of Being No. 1
abstract: A No. 1 ranking this season was more of a curse than an honor.  Parity, what makes the N.C.A.A. tournament electric in the first place, has become even more prevalent.
lead_paragraph: Of all the numbers in college basketball, No. 1 may be the most ubiquitous. You can find it on jerseys and foam hands and after victories when index fingers are shot skyward. You can hear it — “We’re No. 1” — chanted on most nights.

headline: Trial to Start in Class Suit on Stop-and-Frisk Tactic

headline: Starting a Papacy, Amid Echoes of a ‘Dirty War’

Another priest was accused of taking a newborn from his mother, one of the many baby thefts from female prisoners who were “disappeared” into a system of clandestine prisons.

headline: Excavating Lost Artifacts of the 1970s
abstract: “The Mound Builders,” by Lanford Wilson, being revived by the Signature Theater, offers an archaeological dig through the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: “The Mound Builders,” a 1975 play by Lanford Wilson, offers a sort of archaeological dig through the atmosphere and the attitudes that pervaded the decade in which it was written. Watching the new Signature Theater Company production, which opened on Sunday night, is like cracking open a time capsule that’s been buried for years. Unfortunately, in the director Jo Bonney’s slackly acted production, the contents don’t prove as fascinating to us today as we had reason to hope.

headline: City’s Sheltering of Out-of-Town Homeless, and Mayor’s Remark, Stir Debate
abstract: More people who gave their last address as outside the city are entering its shelter system, but advocates say the estimate of those people’s numbers is unverified and distorting.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has a penchant for hyperbole, was at it again this month when he fumed that New York State’s guarantee to shelter the homeless means “you can arrive in your private jet at Kennedy Airport, take a private limousine and go straight to the shelter system, and walk in the door and we’ve got to give you shelter.”

lead_paragraph: The New York Times examined gun-related crimes committed by people subject to domestic violence protection orders. These documents highlight three such cases across the country.

headline: In Clutch Situations, Michigan Turns to Burke
abstract: The sophomore point guard Trey Burke, the Big Ten Conference’s player of the year, is the unquestioned choice when Michigan needs a basket.
lead_paragraph: In a lineup loaded with talent, point guard Trey Burke stands out as the unquestioned choice when Michigan needs a basket. Everyone knows it, too.

headline: Trade Revis? Worth Considering if It Improves Jets, Johnson Says
abstract: The owner Woody Johnson said for the first time that if making his team better meant trading any player — including cornerback Darrelle Revis — he would listen to an offer.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, said for the first time Sunday night that if making his team better meant trading any player — including cornerback Darrelle Revis — he would listen to an offer.

headline: Tisch Uneasy About Prospect of Losing Cruz
abstract: The co-owner Steve Tisch said he worried that the Giants might have to match another team’s offer sheet for Victor Cruz or lose him and receive a first-round draft pick as compensation.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Steve Tisch, who owns the Giants with John Mara, said Sunday that he was anxious about the idea that receiver Victor Cruz might draw an offer sheet from another team, which would force the Giants to decide whether to match the offer to retain Cruz or lose him and receive a first-round draft pick as compensation.

headline: An Unusual Route for a Rising Gonzaga Star
abstract: An unusually timed redshirt year helped the 7-foot Kelly Olynyk grow into a national player of the year candidate for the nation’s top-ranked team.
lead_paragraph: Gonzaga has a long men’s basketball tradition, more than a decade of consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament appearances, but this season the Bulldogs became one of the most unlikely teams to reach No. 1. And that was in large part because of their unlikely star.

headline: Guard Is Steady Force for Miami
abstract: Point guard Shane Larkin has led the Hurricanes to their first A.C.C. regular-season and tournament titles.
lead_paragraph: There are more charismatic stars in the N.C.A.A. tournament, more compelling characters, louder and flashier. There are players who jump on scorers’ tables, and players who preen after dunks. Shane Larkin of Miami does none of that. He treats basketball like a chemistry exam, and he gets consistently high grades.

headline: In Some States, Gun Rights Trump Orders of Protection
abstract: Lobbyists and their allies are challenging states’ efforts to take guns from domestic violence offenders who have been served with civil protection orders.
lead_paragraph: Early last year, after a series of frightening encounters with her former husband, Stephanie Holten went to court in Spokane, Wash., to obtain a temporary order for protection.

headline: Obama Nominates Justice Aide for Labor Post
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama announced Monday that he would nominate Thomas E. Perez, who heads the Civil Rights Division at the Justice Department, to be the next secretary of labor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that he would nominate Thomas E. Perez, who heads the Civil Rights Division at the Justice Department, to be the next secretary of labor, a choice that promised to provoke a debate with Republicans about voting rights, immigration and discrimination.

headline: Soft Landing for Nadal in Triumphant Return
abstract: Rafael Nadal won his first hardcourt tournament in more than 11 months, beating Juan Martín del Potro, and Maria Sharapova beat Caroline Wozniacki.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Rafael Nadal’s collapses on a court after winning championship points should not be surprising, given all his successes in past years and recent months. But after injuries had kept him off hardcourts for more than 11 months, his fall to the hardcourt surface at the BNP Paribas Open as a champion on Sunday did seem remarkable.

headline: He Hasn’t Had It All Either
abstract: A father who has worked from home concludes that the difficulty of making jobs parent friendly isn’t the workplace, it’s work.
lead_paragraph: I have not had it all.

headline: With Chance to Firm Up Standing, Nets Stumble Against the Hawks
abstract: Not even the return of Joe Johnson could rejuvenate the Nets, whose four days off seemed to sap them of their moxie against the Hawks.
lead_paragraph: It will be April when the Nets next play on the sleek herringbone court of Barclays Center, and by then their game Sunday night against the Atlanta Hawks will linger as either a distant memory or a haunting omen. The Nets are good enough to have secured a solid footing in the Eastern Conference playoff race but too inconsistent to emerge as a credible threat.

headline: Lewis Rallies for Title and No. 1 Ranking
abstract: Stacy Lewis shot a final-round 64 to beat Ai Miyazato by three shots in the L.PG.A. Founders Cup.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — With three holes to play, Stacy Lewis’s chances of passing Ai Miyazato at the L.P.G.A. Founders Cup and the world No. 1 Yani Tseng in the rankings looked slimmer than a 3-iron.

headline: The World in a Grain of Sand
abstract: The sculptor Teresita Fernández ventures outside her usual medium to create a drawing inspired by new verse from Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Or a coin, or a keyhole. The sculptor Teresita Fernández ventures outside her usual medium to create a drawing inspired by new verse from Matthew Zapruder.

headline: WPP to Invest in SFX Entertainment
abstract: The $20 billion advertising giant, with major agencies like JWT, Grey and Young & Rubicam under its umbrella, will invest an estimated $10 million in Robert F.X.Sillerman’s company, SFX Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: When the media mogul Robert F.X. Sillerman returned to the music business last year after more than a decade, he said he wanted to use online media to unite the huge but disconnected audience for electronic dance music. One aspect of his plan involves the role of marketing and advertising, as evidenced by a new investment from the ad giant, WPP.

headline: Planning for the Next Flu Season
abstract: It’s not too soon to think about the coming flu season, and what must be done to avoid a repeat of this season’s epidemic.
lead_paragraph: The flu season may be winding down, but it’s not too soon to start thinking about the next one — and what all of us must do differently if we are to avoid a repeat of the epidemic of the past few months.

headline: Local TV News Is Following Print’s Path, Study Says
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Television', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Despite a robust public appetite for news, local television newscasts are cutting back, according to the Pew Research Center.
lead_paragraph: With shorter stories and scarce coverage of politics and government, local television newscasts in the United States, like local newspapers before them, are suffering from “shrinking pains,” according to the Pew Research Center.

headline: Word of the Day | coercion
abstract: This word has appeared in 423 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: coercion •\ ko-ˈər-zhən, -shən\• noun

headline: Corrections: March 18, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 18, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 18
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 18.
lead_paragraph: “I remember thinking, ‘Cops, I need the cops. He’s going to kill me in my own house. I’m going to die!’”

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TMC) MY LEFT FOOT (1989) Daniel Day-Lewis, in his first Oscar-winning role, portrays Christy Brown (1932-81), who was born in Dublin with cerebral palsy and learned to write and paint using the only limb he could control, his left foot. Brenda Fricker, who also won an Oscar, and Ray McAnally play Christy’s parents; Ruth McCabe (above, with Mr. Day-Lewis) is the young woman he falls in love with and eventually marries; and Fiona Shaw is the doctor who largely facilitates his education in what Vincent Canby, writing in The New York Times, called “an intelligent, beautifully acted adaptation” of Mr. Brown’s first book, directed by Jim Sheridan. But “though ‘My Left Foot’ is blunt and tough in its presentation of Christy’s handicaps, it avoids any direct criticism of the handicapped world into which he is born, one in which his mother spends most of her time being pregnant, in which poverty is as likely to make the spirit ugly as beautiful, and in which the church always has the last word.”

headline: While Sliding Rangers Look Up in Standings, the Surging Penguins Look Down
abstract: The slumping Rangers trail their metropolitan rivals, the Devils and the Islanders, while the Pittsburgh Penguins lead the Eastern Conference after beating Boston.
lead_paragraph: After a trip that ended with three straight losses, the Rangers occupy 10th place in the Eastern Conference with only 21 games to play. They face two games in the next two nights from a perspective they have not seen in more than five years.

headline: Kingdom of the Netherlands, the Epitome of the Classic
abstract: The Dutch team’s pitchers are largely from the Netherlands, and its star position players come from Curaçao and Aruba.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The goal of the World Baseball Classic has never been to prove which nation is best at baseball. This is not that kind of sport. Small samples can yield misleading conclusions. The validity of World Series results comes largely from the six-month grind just to get there.

headline: N.F.L. Is Pressured on Issues of Gay Rights
keywords: ['Football', 'Homosexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A series of controversial episodes have made one of the highest-profile leagues in professional sports a focus of a larger public debate about equal rights.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The N.F.L.’s investigation into why a team employee asked a college player if he liked girls during last month’s scouting combine has found that the comment was part of casual banter — “chatter that was inappropriate” — but not part of a formal interview process, said Robert Gulliver, the league’s top human resources executive.

headline: Boston University’s Coach Closes In on Retirement
abstract: Jack Parker, who is retiring after 40 seasons as coach of Boston University’s men’s hockey team, got his 895th victory at B.U. in his final home game.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The man at the wake for the father of the future Boston University hockey coach Jack Parker quietly approached Parker’s mother to offer his condolences. He also offered something more: cash.

headline: The Nets’ Long and Winding Road Trip
abstract: Making way for the circus, the Nets are leaving for 17 days to 8 cities. That’s life for N.B.A. teams that share their arenas with events like the Grammys and Disney on Ice.
lead_paragraph: When the N.B.A. completed the Nets’ schedule in August, forward Reggie Evans scanned the dates, and one doozy of a trip immediately caught his eye. The block of road games in late March, the one that involves 17 days, 8 cities, 10 chartered plane rides. Plans had to be made early.

headline: Greek Soccer Player Banned for Nazi Salute
abstract: Giorgos Katidis, a 20-year-old Greek soccer player who celebrated a game-winning goal by giving a Nazi salute, has been banned for life from representing his country in international tournaments.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 11:12 a.m. Giorgos Katidis, a 20-year-old Greek soccer player who celebrated a game-winning goal on Saturday by giving a Nazi salute to fans in Athens, has been banned for life from representing his country in international tournaments.

headline: News Quiz | March 18, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck.

headline: Puerto Rico Ousts Champion and Nears a Title of Its Own
abstract: Alex Rios’s two-run homer helped Puerto Rico eliminate Japan, the two-time winner of the World Baseball Classic, and advance to the final.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alex Rios had not played here since the 2007 All-Star Game, when the American League manager, Jim Leyland, inserted him in right field in the bottom of the ninth inning. With the bases loaded in a one-run game, a fly ball settled into Rios’s glove for the final out.

headline: A Conversation With: Pakistani Author Mohsin Hamid
abstract: The author of “The Reluctant Fundamentalist” on his latest book and settling down in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: One of the most anticipated book releases this year is “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia” by the Lahore-born writer Mohsin Hamid. The tome, which debuted March 5, is written in a cheeky self-help format and tells the rags-to-riches story of a man in modern Asia.

headline: The Vatican and the Other China
abstract: With the Vatican among the dwindling number of states that recognize Taiwan, President Ma Ying-jeou’s attendance at Pope Francis’s inaugural Mass is significant.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — There are approximately as many Catholics in the world as Chinese — over 1 billion each, with 1.3 billion Chinese just surpassing the world’s 1.2 billion Catholics.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March  18
abstract: Bank turmoil in Cyprus; worries about the French withdrawal from Mali; new colors for KLM; and an Austrian wins skiing’s World Cup for the second year in a row.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Europe’s surprising decision early Saturday to force bank depositors in Cyprus to share in the cost of the latest euro zone bailout set off increasing outrage and turmoil in Cyprus on Sunday and fueled fears that the trouble will spread to countries like Spain and Italy. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus, and Landon Thomas Jr. from London.

headline: Lawmaker Says Britons Agree to New Press Rules After Hacking Scandal
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Privacy', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Lawmakers on Monday were said to have struck a deal on new regulations for newspapers, potentially one of the strongest peacetime press curbs in three centuries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After months of wrangling and dispute, and centuries of rambunctious freedom, lawmakers agreed to ground rules on Monday for a new press code, the most significant step toward stricter curbs on this country’s scoop-driven newspapers since the phone hacking scandal convulsed Rupert Murdoch’s media empire and much of British public life.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 18, 2013
abstract: Can you calculate the amount of money students who complete an online course would pay if all of them had to pay a $60 exam fee?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Keeping an Eye on Online Test-Takers.”

headline: How Much Do You Know About Your Family’s History?
abstract: How do stories of previous generations shape and strengthen families today?
lead_paragraph: Many families have stories–of triumph, of struggle, of events almost too funny or too unlikely to be real, but somehow are. Does your family have stories like these? What family narratives did you grow up hearing? How do you think they’ve helped define who you are and how you see yourself?

headline: In the Bronx, Nine High Schools Share One Building
abstract: What changes occurred when Adlai E. Stevenson High School became Stevenson Campus?
lead_paragraph: In “Nine High Schools, One Roof,” Liz Robbins and Theodoric Meyer write about the Stevenson Campus in the Bronx.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are
abstract: Despite the march of time and civilization, small groups of Europeans still practice ancient pagan rites to mark the passing of seasons.
lead_paragraph: Charles Fréger was fascinated by what the human race lost over the millenniums when it evolved from hunter-gather to farmer and, eventually, urban dweller. After learning that there were Europeans who continued ancient pagan rites of celebrating the winter solstice and the beginning of spring, he set out to examine what traditions faded as people became more civilized.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Extends Restrictions on Italian Ambassador
abstract: The Italian ambassador has been barred from traveling outside India for another week.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI— ­ A diplomatic tiff between India and Italy showed no signs of easing Monday after India’s Supreme Court extended its travel restrictions against the Italian ambassador for another week.

headline: After Frosty Past, Pope Meets Argentine Leader
abstract: The pope, who was a cardinal in Buenos Aires, and President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner have clashed over social issues like legalizing gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A day before his formal installation, Pope Francis met privately on Monday with Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the president of his native Argentina, with whom he had clashed over social issues like Argentina’s legalization of same-sex marriage.

headline: Russia’s New Normal
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Bombarded with homophobia in Russia, my children now struggle to recognize things as they should be.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It’s the sort of thing one hates hearing from one’s child. “You know, mom,” my 11-year-old daughter said, “It makes me particularly nervous when people make fun of gays.”

headline: Part 1: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
abstract: Laura Perna, a researcher in college finance and affordability, answers select reader questions about paying for college. Part 1.
lead_paragraph: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blog’s Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: Sexual Offenses Bill to Be Altered to Pass Parliament
abstract: Definition of voyeurism and stalking expected to be watered down.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI— A bill aimed at toughening India’s laws on rape and sexual violence will be altered, India’s law minister said Monday, a move expected to garner wider political support in a divided Parliament.

headline: The Unregulated Work of Mechanical Turk
abstract: A brave new world of computer piecework will not automatically provide opportunities for human development or dignity, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.“

headline: The Early Word: Rise and Fall
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Daily Report: Domestic Drones on Patrol
abstract: Companies, universities and lawmakers in the United States are preparing for a world in which remote-controlled planes will be ubiquitous in civilian air space.
lead_paragraph: On the pilot’s computer screen, planted at ground level a few yards from the airport runway in Grand Forks, N.D., the data streaming across the display tracked an airplane at 1,300 feet above a small city on the coast, making perfect circles at 150 miles per hour.

headline: Zimbabwe Police Defy Order to Free Lawyer, Group Says
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights criticized the police for continuing to detain Beatrice Mtetwa, who was arrested the day after a largely peaceful referendum on a draft constitution.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The Zimbabwean police defied a high court ruling issued at midnight on Sunday ordering the release of a renowned human rights lawyer, Beatrice Mtetwa, and continued to hold her on charges of obstructing justice, a rights group said Monday.

headline: Indonesian Carrier Orders $24 Billion in Jets From Airbus
abstract: The order by the Indonesian airline Lion Air is a significant inroad for Airbus into one of Asia’s fastest-growing travel markets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Airbus said Monday that it had received a record order for $24 billion worth of new single-aisle jets from the Indonesian low-cost airline Lion Air, marking a significant inroad for the European plane maker into one of the fastest-growing air travel markets in Asia that until now has been dominated by its American rival, Boeing.

headline: Pakistani Militants Kill 4 in Attack on Court Complex
abstract: The attack at the court complex in Peshawar in northwest Pakistan on Monday also wounded at least 30 people, including a judge.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  —  Militants stormed a court complex in northwestern Pakistan on Monday, killing 4 people and wounding at least 30 people, including a judge, in the latest assault on government authority in the region.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 18, 2013
abstract: Every Monday we publish a New York Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 19

headline: This Week In Small Business: Surviving Shark Tank
abstract: Competing budgets, competitive vigor, and nap time. Plus, do you have time to button your shirt?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Up Here on This Island
abstract: Lessons from a 12-year-old boy who took in the world by his own measure.
lead_paragraph: The boy banged his thigh into the corner of the table, stopped mid-stride, grimaced, and the way you’d say godDAMmit, he said: johnHANcock! Then, because he knew that in the special school there was an expectation of a show of normality, he said: You’re probably wondering why I said that, but you wouldn’t understand.

headline: How the Other Half Thinks
abstract: Kenya needs to end a political culture that treats state resources as a winner’s preserve rather than national assets benefitting all citizens equally.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI — For a ringside seat on the spectacle of Kenyan democracy’s turbulent workings, I’d recommend Dormans on Mama Ngina Street. I had just ordered an espresso at the café, around the corner from the Supreme Court, on Saturday when the mood on this normally bustling street suddenly turned.

headline: Blunt Report Says G.O.P. Needs to Regroup for ’16
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A review of the Republican Party’s 2012 election efforts called for improving the way the party talks about its ideas, turns out potential voters and raises money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders on Monday offered a sweeping self-critique of a party they said was in an “ideological cul-de-sac” and needed better outreach and a new brand of conservatism to appeal to younger voters, ethnic minorities and women.

headline: SAC Looks on the Bright Side
abstract: SAC Capital sees the positive in a $616 million settlement of two insider trading suits. | A Senate hearing on JPMorgan Chase’s huge trading loss shines a spotlight on Jamie Dimon. | Shares of big banks fell on news that a bailout for Cyprus would require depositors to share the cost. | Lloyd C. Blankfein has gained a daughter-in-law.
lead_paragraph: SAC LOOKS ON THE BRIGHT SIDE  |  The $616 million fine against SAC Capital Advisors that was announced on Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission would be enough to cripple some hedge funds. But SAC saw the positive in the penalty, which settles two insider trading lawsuits brought by the government, DealBook’s Peter Lattman writes. The $15 billion hedge fund said in a statement that the settlements were “a substantial step toward resolving all outstanding regulatory matters.”

headline: Opinion Report: Treating Alzheimer’s
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: Environmental Woes Could Reverse Global Development
abstract: By 2030, 80 percent of the world’s middle class could live in what is currently termed the developing world. But environmental disasters could halt or even reverse gains.
lead_paragraph: Climate change and other environmental disasters could put 3.1 billion people into extreme poverty by 2050, if no significant steps are taken, says an annual United Nations report on the state of global development.

headline: March Madness for Book Geeks Rolls On
abstract: The online contest, first held in 2005, pits 16 novels published the previous year against each other in a series of critical cage matches decided by a panel of judges.
lead_paragraph: College basketball fans may have to wait until Tuesday for their yearly N.C.A.A. tournament fix, but March Madness for lit geeks is already well under way thanks to The Morning News’s Tournament of Books.

headline: Monday Reading: Frugal Travel Along the Yangtze River
abstract: Frugal travel along the Yangtze River, a dad can’t have it all either, answers to questions about paying for college and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Gender Bias Seen in Visas for Skilled Workers
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee heard testimony Monday arguing that a visa program that allows workers in high-tech fields to enter the United States discriminates against women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee heard testimony Monday afternoon arguing that the H-1B visa program, which covers highly skilled temporary foreign workers, often in high-tech fields, discriminates against women.

headline: Tournament Bracket and Forecast
abstract: Need help with your N.C.A.A. bracket? Nate Silver is estimating each team’s chance of advancing to any given stage of the N.C.A.A. bracket. View his estimates as a table and read his pre-tournament analysis.
lead_paragraph: Need help with your N.C.A.A. bracket? Nate Silver is estimating each team’s chance of advancing to any given stage of the N.C.A.A. bracket. View his estimates as a table and read his pre-tournament analysis.

headline: Advertising Research Foundation Gets Its First Female Leader
abstract: Gayle Fuguitt, a longtime research executive at General Mills, is to be introduced to the Advertising Research Foundation’s members on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Advertising Research Foundation is naming a longtime research executive at General Mills as its next president and chief executive, making her the first woman to lead the organization.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Ben Ehrenreich on Witnessing the Friday Protests in a West Bank Village
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article answers questions about what goes on in Nabi Saleh, a West Bank village where protests occur every week against the Israeli occupation.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ehrenreich is the author of this week’s cover article about the weekly Friday protests against Israeli occupation of Nabi Saleh in the West Bank. Ehrenreich has published two novels, “Ether” and “The Suitors,” and contributed to Harper’s Magazine, Los Angeles Magazine and other publications.

headline: The View of New York Under an Umbrella
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: When it began to rain one Sunday, a woman watched the crowds from the shelter of her umbrella.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: An Oracle Veteran’s Comeback Plan
abstract: Charles Philips was pushed aside from a top position at Oracle, but he hopes to win the last round. His new company, he says, will provide an easy way for smaller-sized industries to move to modern enterprise computing. From there, he plans to grow big enough to vanquish his old employer.
lead_paragraph: This has the makings of a decent revenge story, or at least a tech giant face-off.

headline: Thai Modern
abstract: A secluded new beach resort on the western coast of Phuket, Thailand, offers privacy like no other.
lead_paragraph: Rather than rooms, the Naka hotel is made up of 94 minimalist glass-and-stone pods, elevated and scattered pell-mell among tropical almond trees in this secluded new beach resort on the western coast of Phuket, Thailand. Each unit comes with a private pool and a cantilevered bedroom that juts out 20 feet toward the Andaman Sea. Rates from about $1,000; designhotels.com.

headline: A New Focus on Poverty Raises a Question About Times Coverage
abstract: The Times has done some great work on the issue of poverty. But is it enough, given the depth of the problem?
lead_paragraph: Poverty was in the news last week, with the coverage of Pope Francis’ attention to poor people worldwide, particularly those in his home country of Argentina.

headline: Cyprus Bailout Puts New Pressure on Europe’s Banks
abstract: Just as pressure was easing on Europe’s financial sector, the situation in Cyprus has created chaos, sending bank shares tumbling and raising concerns that other institutions could face similar problems.
lead_paragraph: 12:14 p.m. | Updated

headline: Ericsson and ST Microelectronics to Dissolve Venture
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computer Chips', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The decision to unwind ST-Ericsson brings a measure of finality to an attempt to build a European semiconductor business to compete with American and Asian market leaders.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Ericsson and STMicroelectronics announced plans on Monday to dissolve their unprofitable four-year-old Swiss venture, ST-Ericsson, a move that may eliminate 1,600 jobs worldwide.

headline: Senate Report on JPMorgan Loss May Provide Fresh Evidence
abstract: The Senate report and hearing on JPMorgan Chase’s $6 billion trading loss provides a portrait of a bank that went right to the edge of acceptable practices, and may have even stepped over the line.
lead_paragraph: The Senate report and hearing on JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar trading loss provides a portrait of a bank that went right to the edge of acceptable practices, and may have even stepped over the line. The questions now are what type of enforcement action the bank could face, and whether any individuals will be ensnared by the case.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Bribery Inquiry at The Journal, and Taking Aim at Cable TV
abstract: The Justice Department investigates claims of bribery at The Wall Street Journal, Barry Diller’s Aereo could change the game in television, and the case of Matthew Keys highlights problems with hacking laws.
lead_paragraph: A United States government inquiry into News Corporation broadened last year after the Justice Department investigated claims that Wall Street Journal employees in China bribed local officials with gifts in exchange for information, Christine Haughney writes. The Journal broke the news of the investigation on Sunday. Paula Keve, a spokeswoman for The Journal, said that the company was conducting its own investigation and had found no evidence of impropriety. The bribery accusations came out of a broader investigation into News Corporation’s practices, and Ms. Keve suggested that the claims had been made to discredit The Journal’s reporting.

headline: Island Nightmares
abstract: What is it about bankers and island nations?
lead_paragraph: What is it about islands around Europe’s periphery? Is there some peculiar psychological thing about proximity plus the illusion of isolation that makes them turn themselves into havens for runaway banks? Inquiring minds want to know.

headline: Leading Off: Selection Science or a Dartboard?
abstract: Hopeful signs coming out of the Big Ten? A North Carolina-Kansas matchup? One thing is certain: Kentucky will not be around to defend its title.
lead_paragraph: Normally, one of the best things about N.C.A.A. tournament week is its  democracy. No, not every one of the tournament’s 68 teams has an equal chance to win the title, but every single person in your circle of acquaintances has a roughly equal chance to win your N.C.A.A. pool. Because no matter how much the rabid basketball fans think they know about R.P.I. and strength of schedule and just how well Coach A does against Coach K, once the tournament starts, all that knowledge has as much to do with picking winners as it does forecasting an election in Burma. The bloke who picks against Notre Dame because it wore those horrific lime green jerseys in the Big East tournament? Our money’s on him.

headline: Resistance to HPV Vaccines Needs New Solutions
abstract: Parents cite safety concerns in their decisions not to seek out the HPV vaccine, but unspoken factors like convenience may also get in the way.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend three vaccinations for preteens and teenagers: a booster for tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap) given at 11-12 years; quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MCV4), with a first dose at 11-12 and a follow-up at 16-18; and human papillomavirus vaccine (HPV), given in three doses over a six-month period to boys and girls 11-12.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Hires Co-Heads of U.S. Technology Banking
abstract: The Royal Bank of Canada has hired Michal Katz and Michael Carter as co-heads of its United States technology investment banking group, and Erik-Jaap Molenaar as a technology deal maker.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Canada said on Monday that it had hired Michal Katz and Michael Carter as co-heads of its United States technology investment banking group. The bank also hired Erik-Jaap Molenaar as a managing director in technology mergers and acquisitions. All three come from Barclays, and had previously worked at Lehman Brothers.

headline: Queens Central Library Opens Wider
abstract: Building Blocks: In a $9.8 million renovation project, the 47-year-old Queens Central Library in Jamaica is being transformed into a more appealing space.
lead_paragraph: It’s a mystery at first. The youngsters on the computers in the children’s center adjoining the Queens Central Library appear to be squatting on floor cushions, but their legs are nowhere to be seen. In a moment, it grows clear. They’re seated at shallow wells scooped into the floor so there’s no danger of falling off their chairs.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: New York: As a chilly March drags on at the greenmarket, even a ramp would look good right now. Or how about a batch of rutabaga fries? — Patrick Farrell

headline: A Blankfein Wedding
abstract: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, has gained a daughter-in-law.
lead_paragraph: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, has gained a daughter-in-law.

headline: Ectopic Pregnancy Treatments Preserve Fertility
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: For women with ectopic pregnancies, surgery to remove a fallopian tube did not affect the ability to become pregnant later any more than more conservative treatments for the condition.
lead_paragraph: Each of the three main treatments for ectopic pregnancy — a condition in which a fetus develops outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tube — appears to be equally effective in preserving a women’s ability to become pregnant in the future, a new study found.

headline: Parity in N.C.A.A. Means No Commanding Favorite
abstract: Louisville is the nominal favorite to win the tournament despite its tough draw, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast. Still, it has only a 23 percent chance of doing so, just ahead of Indiana at 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: Even before the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket was announced on Sunday, there was plenty of discussion about how much parity there was in this year’s field. The chatter only increased after Louisville, the No. 1 overall seed, was placed in a brutally tough Midwest region that also includes Duke and Michigan State.

headline: The Unobstructed Home
abstract: A new book reminds us that accessible homes can also be beautiful.
lead_paragraph: The houses photographed for Deborah Pierce’s book, “The Accessible Home: Designing for All Ages & Abilities,” look so inviting that I want to move in.

headline: Beans and Greens: A Power Couple
abstract: This hearty, high-protein combination shows up in countless cuisines – including Persian cooking, which inspired several of this week’s dishes.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been a longtime follower of Recipes for Health, you know how much I like combining beans and greens. They make a good, nourishing couple and every peasant cuisine in the world seems to know this. It’s so easy to put together a hearty, high-protein one-dish meal rich in vitamins and minerals with these two foods as the focus.

headline: A Small-Business Office Is Accused of Advocating for Big Business
abstract: Why is the Small Business Administration asking General Electric to participate in small-business discussions?
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Office of Advocacy, a bureau within the Small Business Administration, has worked behind the scenes to soften the impact of federal regulations on small companies. It is charged with, among other responsibilities, representing “the views and interests of small businesses before other federal agencies.” To learn how regulatory policies might affect small businesses, the office regularly convenes round-table discussions with its constituents.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Karen Elson and Buzz Aldrin
abstract: A dual review of what’s new, by smoky-voiced chanteuse Karen Elson and legendary moonwalker Buzz Aldrin.
lead_paragraph: A dual review of what’s new, by model mom and smoky-voiced chanteuse Karen Elson and legendary moonwalker Buzz Aldrin.

headline: Maria Shriver Appears on ‘Today’ for Papal Coverage
abstract: Ms. Shriver, a former NBC correspondent, took a first step toward resuming that role when she contributed a report to NBC’s “Today” show.
lead_paragraph: Maria Shriver, a former NBC correspondent, took a first step toward resuming that role on Monday when she contributed a report to NBC's “Today” show.

headline: Singapore’s Lessons for an Unequal America
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The American elite loves to rationalize soaring levels of inequality. But the task of achieving a fairer society with more equality of opportunity is, though difficult, within reach.

lead_paragraph: Back from North Africa, The Times’s Eric Schmitt reports on mounting concerns surrounding French plans to draw down troops.

headline: Chrysler Warns Dodge Challenger Owners of Fire Risk
abstract: Chrysler is telling owners of about 2,500 of its 2013 Dodge Challengers with the 3.6-liter Pentastar V-6 to stop driving the vehicles and not park them near any structure.
lead_paragraph: Concerned about a fire hazard, Chrysler is telling owners of about 2,500 of its 2013 Dodge Challengers with the 3.6-liter Pentastar V-6 to stop driving the cars and not park them near any structure.

headline: With New Chinese Leaders in Place, Waiting for an Agenda to Emerge
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Premier Li Keqiang pledged in his first news conference to fight graft and pollution, but no one expects quick solutions.
lead_paragraph: China’s leadership succession that began last autumn is now complete. Xi Jinping holds the three top positions as general secretary of the Communist Party, chairman of the Central Military Commission and president. Li Keqiang is the new premier.

headline: Colleges Hope 8 Seconds on TV Provide Lasting Image
abstract: For teams like Florida Gulf Coast, a live shot on TV after a team is chosen for the N.C.A.A. tournament is the equivalent of a free commercial, a way to introduce the program.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The prime-time national television spotlight landed on the Florida Gulf Coast men’s basketball team at 6:14 p.m. Sunday and lasted for about eight seconds, as the Eagles whooped and danced and waved towels in delirium.

headline: The Яussians Are Coming! The Яussians Are Coming!
abstract: And other problems of capital mobility.
lead_paragraph: How big a deal is the Russian factor in Cyprus’s crisis? Pretty big, it seems. Over at FT Alphaville, Izabella Kaminska reports on estimates of 19 billion euros in Russian nationals’ deposits in Cyprus banks, which is more than the country’s GDP. Without being an expert here, I wonder whether this is an understatement; given what we think we know about the nature of much of this Russian money, is all of it really being declared as Russian?

headline: A Triumphant Show by the Artist Yadier Molina
abstract: Tony La Russa says Yadier Molina, who has helped Puerto Rico reached the World Baseball Classic final, is “as great a catcher as anybody that’s ever played the game.”
lead_paragraph: San Francisco

headline: Discovery Wins Bid to Televise Canyon Crossing

lead_paragraph: Nik Wallenda, the daredevil who crossed Niagara Falls on a tightrope last year, will try a similar stunt at the Grand Canyon in June, he announced on Monday.

headline: Image of the Day: March 18
abstract: Farmers protest outside the Parliament in New Delhi.

headline: Grand Bargaining
abstract: It’s always Obama’s fault.
lead_paragraph: Like others, Greg Sargent has been pleading with “centrist” pundits to acknowledge an obvious truth: Barack Obama has actually proposed the mix of spending cuts and revenue increases they want, while Republicans are unwilling to make so much as a dime of compromise. Greg looks at yesterday’s talk shows and finds this confirmed openly by GOP leaders: there is no ratio of spending cuts to revenues that will reconcile them to any tax hike whatsoever.

headline: Hillary Clinton Endorses Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former secretary of state and potential 2016 presidential candidate, said in a video posted on the Internet Monday that “gay rights are human rights.’’
lead_paragraph: Saying that “gay rights are human rights,’’ Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former secretary of state and potential 2016 presidential candidate, has endorsed same-sex marriage.

headline: China Cites Risk of New Tension as U.S. Bolsters Missile Defenses
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The statements underscored China’s caution on taking further action against North Korea despite its third nuclear test.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China said Monday that the United States’ decision to strengthen antimissile defenses in response to threats from North Korea risked deepening regional tensions, underscoring Beijing’s caution on further pressuring the North despite its third nuclear test.

headline: The Coupon Collector Puzzle
abstract: Collect all six and win a prize! How many purchases do you have to make?
lead_paragraph: Your favorite breakfast cereal has decided to run a tasty promotion. Each box of cereal will contain one of six different coupons. Collect all six coupons and win a prize! How many boxes of cereal can you expect to buy before you have at least one of each coupon?

headline: Race and Republican Politics

lead_paragraph: The Republican Party released a report today that attempts to explain why the G.O.P. keeps alienating large chunks of the American electorate. We’ll have lots to say about the report on our editorial page, but I wanted to separately address the issue of race.

headline: Really? Diabetics Should Avoid Eating Fruit
abstract: In the first randomized trial to address whether people with diabetes benefit from restricting fruit, researchers found that avoiding fruit may not have benefits for those with Type 2 diabetes.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Annie Baker Wins Blackburn Prize and Horton Foote Honor
abstract: The Susan Smith Blackburn Prize honors women who have written works of outstanding quality.
lead_paragraph: Annie Baker has been awarded the prestigious Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, an international award given annually since 1978 to women who have written works of outstanding quality. The prize, which Ms. Baker won for “The Flick,” her three-hour incisively nuanced exploration of love and friendship, includes a cash award of $25,000 and a signed, numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

headline: Bloomberg’s Plan Would Make Stores Conceal Cigarettes
abstract: Under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal, New York would become the first city in the nation to require stores to keep tobacco products out of sight.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, fresh off a defeat in his campaign to limit large servings of sugary drinks, is returning to a front where he has enjoyed far more success: making it more difficult to smoke, by proposing legislation on Monday requiring stores to put cigarettes out of sight.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund firm in the world, is imposing its own bonus cap for top executives.

keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Our financial situations can be easier to handle with a positive outlook, as long as we don’t get carried away with our optimism.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: We have an unusually long list of violent incidents in which guns were involved this weekend. It couldn’t be because Sunday was St. Patrick’s Day, could it? Here is our weekend report.

headline: China Arrests Man After Wife’s Self-Immolation Protest
abstract: The husband of a Tibetan woman who died after setting herself alight was detained by the police after he refused to blame domestic problems for her act, an overseas group said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese police arrested the husband of a Tibetan woman who died last week after setting herself alight in protest, an overseas group said on Monday, following a separate fatal self-immolation at a Tibetan Buddhist monastery over the weekend.

headline: Heart Puts Some Led in Its Summer Tour
abstract: Jason Bonham’s Led Zeppelin Experience will tour with Heart this summer.
lead_paragraph: It is hardly unheard of for rock stars to pay tribute to their colleagues and forbears, but Heart is taking professional hat-tipping to a new level.

headline: A Risk for Films That Move at a Zombie’s Pace
abstract: “World War Z,” a zombie film to be released in June, is an example of the genre movie that is often delayed for years — with no real ill effect — before coming to the screen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was the middle of 2006, and hardly anyone was particularly worried about the zombie apocalypse.

headline: What Comes Next for SAC
abstract: The criminal prosecution of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC employee, continues, and it raises the intriguing question about whether prosecutors will call anyone from the hedge fund as a witness against him.
lead_paragraph: The two settlements reached between SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund controlled by Steven A. Cohen, and the Securities and Exchange Commission raise the question of what comes next for the firm.

headline: White or Pink Beans With Beet Greens and Parmesan
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Recipes', 'Beans', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: A great way to use up your Parmesan rinds.
lead_paragraph: If you use white beans for this savory dish, the beet greens will infuse them with a lovely pink hue. Even more standout is the savory/umami flavor that the Parmesan rinds impart. Parmesan rinds will keep for months. Wrap them in foil and keep in the freezer. They add great depth of flavor to vegetarian soups and stews.

headline: New Jersey to Allow Casinos to Offer Daily Fantasy Sports
abstract: New Jersey’s Division of Gaming Enforcement said on Monday that its casinos could create their own fantasy sports games or partner with online companies, starting April 22.
lead_paragraph: With its plan to legalize sports gambling held up in the courts, New Jersey is allowing casinos to offer daily fantasy sports games as an alternative.

The production will star the vocalist and actress Dee Dee Bridgewater, who performed the role in Paris and London to acclaim in the 1980s.

headline: Fire Commissioner’s Son Resigns as Offensive Twitter Posts Surface
abstract: Joseph Cassano, an emergency medical technician, resigned after it was discovered that he posted messages suggesting hatred for Jews, blacks and poor people.
lead_paragraph: The son of the Fire Department commissioner, Salvatore J. Cassano, resigned on Monday from his job with the department after a series of offensive Twitter posts, many of them racially inflammatory, surfaced.

headline: From Lehman to Cyprus
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deposit Insurance', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Avoiding moral hazard proved to be disastrous when Lehman Brothers failed. Will Cyprus be similar?
lead_paragraph: The European decision not to honor deposit insurance in Cyprus, by making all depositors contribute to the cost of a bailout, reminds me of the decision to let Lehman Brothers go under. Moral hazard is being avoided. The question is what that will cost.

headline: Injuries Affect U.S. Roster for Costa Rica and Mexico Games
abstract: United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann announced his roster for the Americans’ next two World Cup qualifiers, against Costa Rica and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Injuries and illness have left United States national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann with a patchwork roster heading into two important World Cup qualifiers in the next nine days.

headline: Slaves’ Forgotten Burial Sites, Marked Online
abstract: A history student at Fordham University is working on a user-generated database to identify the whereabouts and residents of slave cemeteries across the country.
lead_paragraph: They have been bulldozed over by shopping centers, crept over by weeds and forgotten by time. Across the country, from Lower Manhattan to the Deep South, are unmarked slave burial sites, often discovered only by chance or by ignominious circumstance as when construction crews accidentally exhume bodies when building a shopping mall.

headline: Philip Crangi for JewelMint
abstract: A new series by the web site JewelMint brings high-end designers to a lower price point.
lead_paragraph: For its inaugural Studio Series, JewelMint tapped the CFDA designer Philip Crangi to create a limited-edition collection, which makes its debut online today. Though Crangi says that all of the pieces are original and exclusive to JewelMint, G&B x JM looks like it was plucked right from his classic collection of Giles & Brother. “I work from this group of references that I think keeps the continuum going with Giles & Brother,” he says about the tribal and equestrian influences on his etched brass and rose gold designs.

headline: Tamil Nadu Students Protest Alleged Human Rights Abuses in Sri Lanka
abstract: Hundreds of arrests planned in Indian police crackdown.
lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, Tamil Nadu—The police sought to arrest more than 200 university students in Tamil Nadu’s capital, Chennai as protests raged on college campuses over allegations of the Sri Lankan army’s brutal treatment of Tamil rebels.

headline: Surveying Emancipation
abstract: The American Freedman Inquiry Commission and the roots of Reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: President Lincoln’s issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation on Jan. 1, 1863 lent new urgency to the question of “what shall we do with the Negroes.” What had been only a possibility a few months before — the freeing of more than 3 million slaves still behind Confederate lines — had now become a likelihood dependent only on the success of Union armies.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Raikkonen’s Lotus Wins Formula One Opener

lead_paragraph: Kimi Raikkonen seemed to outsmart the competition in the season-opening Formula One race on Sunday, scoring a victory for Lotus in the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne.

lead_paragraph: More than a month has passed since Dell announced its planned $24.4 billion sale to its founder, Michael S. Dell. Since then, a number of shareholders have loudly complained that the price Mr. Dell has offered for the computer company is far too low.

abstract: A little clapboard house in Brooklyn got an offer after two weeks on the market, despite its being across the street from a huge, new arena.
lead_paragraph: On a noisy street in Brooklyn is a little clapboard house that looks as if it dropped out of a charming suburban sky. It has friendly yellow siding and a pitched roof, a chimney and a backyard. It all looks quaint and adorable. Except for the view from its front door: 12,000 panels of arched, rusted steel.

headline: With Your Goat’s Eye Martini, a Taste of Muskrat
abstract: Muskrat, alligator and maggots were all served at a cocktail party held in Manhattan by the Explorers Club.
lead_paragraph: James Cameron, the filmmaker (“Avatar” and “Titanic”) and explorer who last year dived to the bottom of the Pacific Ocean in his submersible, was about to enter a cocktail party given by the Explorers Club on Saturday evening at the Waldorf Astoria in Midtown, where the menu included a martini with a goat’s eye, pickled bull penises and strawberries dipped in white chocolate with black sprinkles of maggots. Later that night, Mr. Cameron would be awarded the club’s Explorers Medal. But first, a reporter asked him to name the strangest thing he had ever eaten.

headline: Sun Storm Forecast: Tiny Chance of Havoc
abstract: Huge solar flares that send out plumes of charged particles rarely directly hit Earth, but if one did, the resulting geomagnetic storm could be crippling.
lead_paragraph: In 1859 the sun erupted, and on Earth wires shot off sparks that shocked telegraph operators and set their paper on fire.

headline: A Burst of Solar Power
abstract: A NASA physicist explains why scientists are increasingly concerned about the effect of solar flares on our wired world.
lead_paragraph: A NASA physicist explains why scientists are increasingly concerned about the effect of solar flares on our wired world.

headline: Boys’ Club: Spring’s New Haircut
abstract: While “the Chop,” a pretty safe, layered bob plus some bang action, is making its rounds across beauty salons, I’ve noticed a more daring look on the red carpet in recent months that has a fresh, springlike appeal.
lead_paragraph: While “the Chop,” a pretty safe, layered bob plus some bang action, is making its rounds across beauty salons, I’ve noticed a more daring look on the red carpet in recent months that has a fresh, springlike appeal. At the Oscars, it was Charlize Theron’s blond Caesar cut that turned heads as much as her Dior gown. And Anne Hathaway’s grown-out “Les Misérables” pixie also stirred the pot with its poufy volume. A few weeks before that, at New York Fashion Week, it was Miley Cyrus’s transformative short crop in a shocking blond that seemed to announce: “I no goodie-goodie Disney star.”

headline: No Time to Lament as Nets Face 8-Game Trip
abstract: The Nets could have pulled into a virtual tie with the Knicks for the division lead with a win on Sunday night. They now have to try to gain ground on the road.
lead_paragraph: There is no shame in dropping a game to the Atlanta Hawks, even at home, but the Nets projected disappointment in the way they competed Sunday night in a puzzling 105-93 loss that bore a number of implications for playoff seeding.

headline: How Recent Popes Differ on Key Issues
abstract: Try to figure out which pope said what in seven critical areas.
lead_paragraph: Try to figure out which pope said what in seven critical areas.

headline:
Syrian Rebels Pick
U.S. Citizen to Lead
Interim Government
abstract: Coalition representatives meeting in Istanbul chose Ghassan Hitto, 50, who emigrated from Syria and until recently lived in Texas, to head a planned interim government.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s main exile opposition coalition elected a naturalized Syrian-born American citizen early Tuesday to be the first prime minister of an interim Syrian government, charged with funneling aid to rebels inside Syria and offering an alternative to the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Firing Carmody, Northwestern Aims Higher
abstract: After 13 years, and no appearance in the N.C.A.A. tournament, Northwestern begins a search for a new coach after the firing of Bill Carmody.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. – It made sense that on a gloomy, gray morning, Northwestern announced the firing of men’s basketball coach Bill Carmody. Despite leading the program to unprecedented levels of success — including four National Invitation Tournament bids — Carmody never brought the Wildcats to an N.C.A.A tournament.

headline: Madonna, Dressed for Camping, Weighs In on Boy Scouts’ Gay Ban
abstract: In a speech at the GLAAD Media Awards she says the organization should “change their stupid rules.”
lead_paragraph: Wearing a Cub Scout summer uniform, a Scoutmaster’s brimmed hat and hiking boots, Madonna took the occasion of an appearance at the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation’s 24th annual Media Awards ceremony to advise the Boy Scouts of America that the organization should “change their stupid rules,” specifically its ban on gay members.

headline: Walkabout – 3/18: Second Life for Hong Kong Airport; Street View at 22,000 Feet
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Air to Sea A one-time airport in Hong Kong has taken on a new life as a cruise terminal. Though it will not fully open until later this year, The Kai Tak Cruise Terminal welcomed its first 2,000 passengers during a trial run this weekend. (CNN)

headline: The Spirit of Adventure
abstract: Sometimes all it takes to feel transported is a new accessory in an exotic material.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes all it takes to feel transported is a new accessory in an exotic material. See the interactive slide show

headline: How One Soldier Learned the Iraq War Was On
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Don Gomez had imagined being informed through some official authority, not a random soldier.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Times will feature reflections on the 10th anniversary of the invasion. We invite anyone who was directly affected by the invasion to submit their essays via atwar@nytimes.com. Please keep pieces to 500 words.

headline: I Want More Children; He Doesn’t
abstract: After eight years of marriage and two kids, my husband and I are fighting over whether or not to have more children — and our battles are revealing bigger divisions.
lead_paragraph: When we were first married, my husband and I talked about “the big stuff.” We discussed religion and politics; we respected the differences in our opinions. We both wanted to raise children in New York City and remain united against the suburbs. With no red flags in sight, we began our union with confidence.

headline: A New Approach to Hip Surgery
abstract: Some surgeons say anterior hip replacements, in which the incision is made at the front of the hip instead of through the buttocks or the side, result in decreased pain and faster recovery.
lead_paragraph: Larry Kufel had always been an active man, tall and rangy, who worked out regularly and picked up basketball games at the gym. But age was taking a toll on his joints, and it had become clear that he needed a hip replacement.

headline: ‘The Bible’ Producers Deny Suggested Obama Link
abstract: The producers of the hit History Channel mini-series scoffed Monday at suggestions that an actor who plays Satan resembles President Obama.
lead_paragraph: The producers of the hit mini-series “The Bible” on the History Channel scoffed Monday at online suggestions that an actor who plays Satan on the series was intentionally made up to resemble President Obama.

headline: Landmark Status Sought for Public Library’s Rose Reading Room
abstract: The local community board in Manhattan has asked New York’s Landmarks Preservation Commission to give landmark status to the Rose Reading Room inside the New York Public Library’s flagship branch on Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Community Board 5, which represents Manhattan’s central business district, has requested that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designate as an interior landmark the main Rose Reading Room at the New York Public Library’s flagship branch.

headline: Vitamin D May Lower Blood Pressure in Blacks
abstract: A randomized trial suggests that vitamin D supplements may help lower blood pressure in African-Americans, a group with high rates of hypertension.
lead_paragraph: African-Americans have significantly higher rates of hypertension, and lower blood levels of vitamin D, than the rest of the population. Now a randomized trial suggests that vitamin D supplements may help lower blood pressure.

headline: The Risks of Transferring a Car Loan to a Credit Card
abstract: Transferring loan balances to a zero percent interest credit card may seem to be a good idea, but it may come at a cost.
lead_paragraph: The credit card site CardHub.com recently reviewed current zero-balance credit card transfer offers and found that many cards let consumers transfer all sorts of debt — not just credit card debt — onto the new cards.

headline: Bancroft Prize Awarded to Two Historians
abstract: The winners are John Fabian Witt for “Lincoln’s Code: The Laws of War in American History” and W. Jeffrey Bolster for “The Mortal Sea: Fishing the Atlantic in the Age of Sail.”
lead_paragraph: The Bancroft Prize, one of the most prestigious annual honors for historians, has been awarded to two scholars for books published last year.

headline: The Lesson From Cyprus
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deposit Insurance', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The crisis in Cyprus highlights the need for common European regimes on deposit insurance and on winding down failing banks, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: The Cyprus fiasco sets a high bar for the euro zone’s new banking union. The new superregulator might not have been able to stop the blowup, or to avoid losses for insured depositors. The clear lesson from the mess is the need for a procedure to wind down failing banks.

headline: What to Make of New Mexico
abstract: New Mexico won both the regular season and conference tournaments in the Mountain West, so why does no one know what to expect in the N.C.A.A. tournament?
lead_paragraph: We know what you are thinking. You do not know what to make of New Mexico. Overrated? Underrated? Final Four sleeper? Disappointing early exiter?

headline: A New Effort in Boston to Catch 1990 Art Thieves
abstract: The bureau said it believed it had figured out who pulled off a famous theft of 13 works of art, valued at up to $500 million, from Boston’s Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the most brazen art thefts in history. Two thieves, posing as police officers, prevailed on the night watchman at Boston’s Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum to let them in. After tying him up, and a leisurely 81 minutes, they walked out with 13 works of art and into the annals of one of the world’s most infamous unsolved crimes.

headline: For Civilian Drones, the Sky is the Limit
abstract: Potential uses of civilian unmanned aerial vehicles include monitoring railroad cars, scanning agricultural fields and scoping out the extent of a forest fire.
lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — As I wrote in Monday’s paper, crossing the hobbyist’s remote-controlled airplane with cheap electronics from the cellphone industry seems likely to yield highly capable, very inexpensive drones.

headline: Ina Drew Takes Risk, Goes on the Defensive
abstract: Finally getting a glimpse of Ina Drew, the subject of my October article who I had previously never met or caught on video or heard on tape.
lead_paragraph: Writing a profile about someone who is not cooperating with your story starts to feel a little bit like an exercise in stalking. I did not actually stalk Ina Drew, the chief investment officer who resigned from JPMorgan Chase following the bank’s $6 billion loss, as I reported on her for the magazine last October. But I did think about her for many of my waking moments throughout the summer of 2012, as I reported the story. I also showed up at her home once. I rang the doorbell, and met her husband, a tall, genial-looking man who told me that she was not available and would not talk to me, not that day and not anytime soon.

headline: In Performance: Judy Kuhn
abstract: Judy Kuhn, accompanied by Mairi Dorman-Phaneuf on cello, sings “Loving You” from Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s musical “Passion,” now in revival at the Classic Stage Company.
lead_paragraph: Judy Kuhn, accompanied by Mairi Dorman-Phaneuf on cello, sings “Loving You” from Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s musical “Passion,” now in revival at the Classic Stage Company.

headline: With a Big If, Science Panel Finds Deep Cuts Possible in Auto Emissions and Oil Use
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Automobiles', 'Biofuels', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Ethanol', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydrogen', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A panel finds that a blend of intensified research and strong policy could take a big bite out of oil use and CO2 emissions.
lead_paragraph: A panel convened by the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that deep cuts in oil use and emissions of greenhouse gases from cars and light trucks are possible in the United States by 2050, but only with a mix of diverse and intensified research and policies far stronger than those pursued so far by the Obama administration.

headline: The Labor Agenda
abstract: Thomas Perez has what it takes to be an outstanding labor secretary. But will Mr. Obama let him do his job?
lead_paragraph: Unemployment is persistently high. Wages are low. Inequality is rising. Employee bargaining power is decreasing. The lack of good jobs and the dearth of opportunities cast doubt on any and all indications of economic recovery.

headline: The Small Picture: When the Dogs Come Running In
abstract: Megan Coryat says she loves every day now that she’s her own boss.
lead_paragraph: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.
