headline: Second Thoughts in Europe as Anxiety Rises in Cyprus
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: A plan to tax deposits in exchange for a 10 billion euro financial lifeline for Cyprus frayed nerves, and quickly set off tremors far from the country’s shores.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The lights were dimmed and the doors were locked. But inside a branch of Laiki Bank, one of Cyprus’s two dominant banks, a few silhouettes glided about Monday, filling cash machines to calm a wave of anxiety that has washed over this tiny island since European leaders took the unprecedented step Saturday of trying to force depositors to pay for part of an international bailout.

headline: Best N.B.A. Games of the Week
abstract: Notable N.B.A. games this week include Miami at Boston, Denver at Oklahoma City, and Utah at Houston.
lead_paragraph: Off the Dribble will highlight three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

headline: People’s Theater
abstract: A look at some of the shows produced at the Public Theater under its artistic director, Oskar Eustis.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the shows produced at the Public Theater under its artistic director, Oskar Eustis.

headline: For 10th Anniversary of Iraq War, a Low-Key Approach From The Times
abstract: In its news pages, The Times will offer no major project or section but several articles.
lead_paragraph: Anniversary journalism, as I’ve noted before, is a tricky proposition. At its best, it’s an opportunity to look back on an important event and provide the rich perspective that can only come with time. At its worst, it’s empty – a mere regurgitation of what happened with little that is new or fresh added.

headline: Photo Replay: March 18
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including the dusty beginning to mountain-bike racing in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including the dusty beginning to mountain-bike racing in South Africa.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
abstract: What we’re reading now from Anna Wintour’s “listening tour” to the Milliners Guild’s new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The Business of Fashion explains how the SXSW festival explored technological innovations like 3-D printing that will affect the fashion industry.

headline: Detecting Heat Stress in Cows
abstract: Cows who are feeling too hot avoid lying down, leading to exhaustion, according to researchers who used temperature and motion sensors to study the animals.
lead_paragraph: Heat stress among dairy cows is a growing problem in the United States as the climate warms and farmers look to increase production from their herds. Now, researchers say farmers can predict which cows are in danger of overheating: the ones that stand for long periods without lying down.

headline: A Challenge to Dollo’s Law
abstract: A study of dust mites, which are free-living, suggest they evolved from parasites that in turn had evolved from free-living organisms, contradicting an axiom that species cannot regain lost characteristics.
lead_paragraph: Dollo’s law, named for the 19th-century paleontologist Louis Dollo, states that evolution always moves forward — that an organism cannot redevelop an organ or attribute discarded by its ancestors. But new research on humble dust mites, the tiny arachnids that live in cushions and carpets everywhere, is challenging the law.

headline: Columbia Picks New Journalism Dean
abstract: Steve Coll, who will succeed Nicholas Lemann, is a former reporter and managing editor at The Washington Post and a former writer for The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: Steve Coll, a veteran of The Washington Post and The New Yorker whose investigations won him two Pulitzer Prizes, will be the next dean of the Columbia Journalism School, the president of Columbia University announced on Monday.

headline: Fantasy Baseball: Outfield Preview
abstract: When it comes to outfielders, strike early and often, as there is five-tool ability throughout the top 20, but a drop-off in talent soon after.
lead_paragraph: Justin Sablich is one half of the Sablich brothers, who provide fantasy sports advice on nytimes.com and on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Julie Hochfelder, Aaron Webman
abstract: The couple were married Saturday evening at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.
lead_paragraph: Julie Anne Hochfelder and Aaron Louis Webman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Steven Bayar at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

headline: On the Trail of Cancer
abstract: Dan Fagin’s new book, “Toms River,” is an edge-of-your-seat account of industry and illness in a New Jersey town, with plenty of side trips.
lead_paragraph: IT’S HIGH TIME a book did for epidemiology what Jon Krakauer’s best-selling “Into Thin Air” did for mountain climbing: transform a long sequence of painfully plodding steps and missteps into a narrative of such irresistible momentum that the reader not only understands what propels enthusiasts forward, but begins to strain forward as well, racing through the pages to get to the heady views at the end.

headline: A Parisian Passover
abstract: Putting on a Seder every year can be a bit of a challenge in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Putting on a Seder every year can be a bit of a challenge in Paris.

headline: Solving the Passover Puzzle
keywords: ['Passover', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: The French are apt to keep religious beliefs private, so you won’t find recipes for chopped liver or advertisements for kosher wine in the mainstream media.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Seder in Paris should never be boring. So when Roger Yvon, an upscale butcher, proposed his signature deboned duck decorated with pitted green olives for the Passover dinner, I ordered two.

headline: For Timberwolves Forward, a New Decisiveness
abstract: Derrick Williams of the Timberwolves has become a genuine offensive threat.
lead_paragraph: Although Minnesota Timberwolves forward Derrick Williams had a career-high 28 points Sunday night in a 97-95 win over the New Orleans Hornets, his reaction was typically low-key. “Feels good,” he said, brushing aside his individual achievement to talk about the team. “We got a close win. That’s even better.”

headline: Former Romanian Premier Ordered Released From Prison
abstract: The former Romanian prime minister, Adrian Nastase, will be released early from prison after serving nine months of a two-year term for corruption.
lead_paragraph: The Romanian former prime minister Adrian Nastase will be released early from prison after serving nine months of a two-year term for corruption, a Bucharest court ruled on Monday.

headline: A Newborn, but No Wobbly Legs
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Luxury Goods']
abstract: The Chloé boutique in SoHo features the French house’s top-of-the-line runway items.
lead_paragraph: DISSING JULIA ROBERTS’S streetwalker on Rodeo Drive in “Pretty Woman”; sneering at Elaine Benes’s tussles with “skinny mirrors” at Barneys on “Seinfeld”: the intimidating salesclerk used to be the ultimate signifier of upscale retail. Of late, though, she (for it is often a young, beautiful she) has taken a curious turn toward overweening niceness.

headline: Good News Beats Bad on Social Networks
abstract: While old-fashioned outlets focus on tragedy and drama, on social media, people tend to share more positive news, especially about themselves.
lead_paragraph: BAD NEWS SELLS. If it bleeds, it leads. No news is good news, and good news is no news.

headline: Justices Appear Divided on Arizona Voting Law
abstract: The Supreme Court appeared divided along liberal and conservative lines over whether Arizona can require proof of citizenship from people seeking to register to vote in federal elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared divided along familiar lines on Monday as it heard arguments  over whether Arizona can require proof of citizenship from people seeking to register to vote in federal elections.

headline: Lifting the Shadow of Scandal
abstract: Roger Mahony, Angelo Sodano, and the unfinished business awaiting Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: There has been so much enthusiasm around the public style of Pope Francis — who has been populist, self-effacing and unscripted in his first few days as pontiff — and so much eagerness from so many quarters to see him as the reformer that the Catholic Church needs, that I felt like a bit of a downer accentuating the negative in my Sunday column, and emphasizing all the moral credibility that still needs to be rebuilt. But if personal holiness and seriousness of faith were sufficient qualities in a Roman pontiff, the last ten years would not have been a period of crisis in Catholicism, and the shadow of the sex abuse crisis would be fully lifted from the church. And it’s especially important, at the outset of a new pontificate, to understand the precise nature of that shadow, because at this point it’s no longer really about priestly sex abuse itself. Rather, it’s about a church that has cleaned house effectively and set up impressive structures of accountability everywhere except at the most prominent levels of the hierarchy.

headline: A Gray Jobs Market for All Ages
abstract: Here are some tips on how to get the education you need to obtain a job that benefits the aging population.
lead_paragraph: INSIDE the lower-level studio of the McBurney Y in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, Abba’s 1970s hit “Dancing Queen” is thumping out: “See that girl, watch that scene, diggin’ the dancing queen.” Right in step to the bouncing beat is a senior squad of 40 slightly sweaty women and men, ages 60 to 85.

headline: The Great Aid Gap
abstract: Job certificate programs are prized by employers for equipping workers with in-demand skills, but they are often not eligible for federal financial aid.
lead_paragraph: IT was an unusually enthusiastic shout-out for the job certificate programs offered by many community colleges. A report found that men with nondegree certificates in computer/information services earned $72,498 a year on average — more money than 72 percent of men with associate’s degrees and more than 54 percent of men with bachelor’s degrees.

headline: Aquatic Academy Isn’t Kid Stuff
abstract: Not the typical program for older students, the academy includes required reading and homework and aims to transform the Aquarium of the Pacific into a serious adult-learning environment.
lead_paragraph: “ATTENTION,” reads a sign at the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, Calif., “Sharks Ahead.”

headline: In Tourism, Classes Can Open Doors
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: The travel business has job openings — it added more jobs in 2012 than many other industries — and offers training through colleges and professional organizations.
lead_paragraph: JOHN LINDER had a career as a senior human resources manager, but he wanted something more. “It was a good job, but I didn’t want to be in an office anymore or in a corporate environment,” he said. He also did not want extensive schooling, since he already had a master’s degree.  He loved to travel, and knew his strong people skills would translate well. His answer: a two-week immersion course at the International Tour Management Institute.

headline: Back on Campus to Experience Road Not Taken
abstract: Professional schools are not traditionally thought of as places to go for the mere joy of it, but some are returning later in life to study business and law for a love of learning.
lead_paragraph: ADITI ROY wasn’t looking to become an entrepreneur or head to Wall Street or move up the corporate totem pole like most of her compatriots in the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School executive M.B.A. program. She was the morning news anchor for WCAU-TV, the NBC affiliate in Philadelphia, and already had a stint as West Coast correspondent for the network.

headline: Online Certificate Programs at Colleges and Universities Gain Popularity
abstract: As employers demand more skills, many people are turning to online certificate programs to acquire a specific expertise that can lead them to a job or a promotion.
lead_paragraph: AS employers demand skills and more skills, many people are turning to online certificate programs to acquire a specific expertise that can lead them to a job or a promotion — or, sometimes, simply to ensure that they hang on to their current position.

headline: Those Returning to School Can Find Help in the Tax Code
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADULT EDUCATION', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Credits and deductions can help a taxpayer meet the costs of continuing education. Eligibility depends on income, how tuition is paid and the type of student.
lead_paragraph: ROCCO ABBATEMARCO, 42, a middle school teacher from New York City, recently moved to Portland, Me., where he landed a teaching spot at a youth correctional facility. His new job required that he become certified in special education. To do so, Mr. Abbatemarco is taking accredited online courses, studying in the evening and on weekends.

headline: Colleges Assess Cost of Free Online-Only Courses
abstract: Elite universities are joining in, but the massive online open courses, known as MOOCs, threaten to poach paying students from other institutions.
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA M. ROMETTY, the chief executive of I.B.M., recently urged her employees to take 40 hours of continuing education this year. The company would not reimburse tuition, but would pay for expenses, like textbooks.

headline: Budding Entrepreneurs Can Choose an M.B.A. Lite
abstract: More colleges are offering entrepreneurship programs as a way to help people get their businesses off the ground.
lead_paragraph: THEY’RE called entrepreneurship or small-business certificates, and they don’t carry the cachet or the credit of an M.B.A. But they take far less time to obtain, and they cost less, too. More colleges are offering them as a way to help people get their businesses off the ground.

headline: Former Pentagon Lawyer Offers Pros and Cons of Drone Court
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The speech by Jeh C. Johnson, the Defense Department’s former general counsel, offered a window into the thinking of someone who participated in the inner circles of Obama administration national security decision-making until recently.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The former top lawyer at the Pentagon during President Obama’s first term warned on Monday that the secrecy surrounding the government’s use of “targeted killings” by drone strikes and other means is breeding mistrust, but he voiced skepticism about proposals for court review of decisions about which terrorism suspects the executive branch decides to assassinate.

headline: Bringing a Virtual Brain to Life

headline: Elegant Headphones, Crammed With Features

lead_paragraph: The French technology company Parrot is known primarily for its hands-free systems for cars, but it has added to its lineup a pair of wireless headphones that blend design and comfort with some very clever features.

lead_paragraph: Hotels are changing the way guests check in to their rooms, eliminating the traditional stop at the front desk to speed up, simplify and, in some cases, personalize the process.

headline: Medieval Remains, Dwindling Butterflies and Chatterboxes
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Breast Cancer', 'Lions', 'Meat', 'Butterflies and Moths', '3-D Printers', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news and a glance at what’s ahead.
lead_paragraph: This week’s opening category is “interesting stuff buried in the British Isles.”

headline: Evangelical Groups Call for Path to Citizenship in Immigration Overhaul
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A coalition including some of the nation’s largest evangelical Christian organizations said on Monday that Congress should include “clear steps to citizenship” for illegal immigrants in any bill to overhaul the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: A coalition including some of the nation’s largest evangelical Christian organizations said on Monday that Congress should include “clear steps to citizenship” for illegal immigrants in any bill to overhaul the immigration system.

headline: Reggie Miller Twitter Q. & A.
abstract: Reggie Miller, former star shooting guard for U.C.L.A. and the Indiana Pacers, answered questions via Twitter about the 2013 men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Miller will be part of the broadcast team covering the tournament for Turner Sports.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Miller, former star shooting guard for U.C.L.A. and the Indiana Pacers and member of the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame, answered questions via Twitter about the 2013 men’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Miller will be part of the broadcast team covering the tournament for Turner Sports.

headline: A Soft-Focus Look at Fox’s Tough-Talking Tough Guy
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Roger Ailes: Off Camera,” by Zev Chafets, offers little new insight into the life and mind of Mr. Ailes, the Fox News chairman and Republican political strategist.
lead_paragraph: He’s been called “one of the few visionaries in the television business” and the “most successful executive” in TV; a Republican kingmaker who would become “the sharpest thorn in the side of Barack Obama” and a pit-bull political strategist with only “two speeds: attack and destroy.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Kickstarting ‘Veronica Mars,’  and Microsoft Connections
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include a Kickstarter project for a ‘Veronica Mars’ movie that has already surpassed its goal, a video of a penguin showing great enthusiasm, or agitation, over an iPad and musicians accused of buying virtual fans.

headline: Congolese Warlord Wanted for War Crimes Surrenders to U.S. Diplomats in Rwanda
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A Congolese warlord whose troops were routed over the weekend walked into the United States Embassy in Rwanda and asked to be sent to The Hague to stand trial for war crimes.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 10:06 a.m. A Congolese warlord whose troops were routed over the weekend walked into the United States Embassy in Rwanda on Monday and asked to be sent to The Hague to stand trial for war crimes.

headline: Lost Sleep Can Lead to Weight Gain
abstract: A study showed that participants consumed more calories and were an average of two pounds heavier after one week of sleeping only about five hours a day.
lead_paragraph: The best path to a healthy weight may be a good night’s sleep.

headline: Moments of Lyricism in a Purely Russian Story
abstract: The Jerusalem Quartet played its first of four performances of the complete Shostakovich cycle at Lincoln Center on Sunday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: In Shostakovich’s career, pockmarked with forced commissions, attempts to placate Soviet officials and humiliating bouts of censorship, his string quartets occupy a special place. Many critics have likened them to a confessional into which the composer confided the fears and hopes he had to suppress in public. But most of all, the 15 quartets represent the music Shostakovich wanted to write at a given moment.

headline: ‘Giselle’ Meets Kabuki in a Tale of Love, Madness and Toxic Breath
abstract: “Bell” by Yasuko Yokoshi recasts a Kabuki play into a dance mixing Eastern and Western elements.
lead_paragraph: A Rudyard Kipling ballad starts with the refrain “Oh, East is East, and West is West, and never the twain shall meet.” In the choreographer Yasuko Yokoshi’s “Bell,” which had its world premiere on Saturday at New York Live Arts, East and West indeed don’t meet. But they share the stage; they overlap; they coincide. The result, unlike any production I have seen, runs a gamut: It’s peculiar, admirable, a bit long-winded and sometimes perplexing.

headline: ‘Bodyguard’ and Its Diva, Now Onstage
abstract: Playing a pop goddess in “The Bodyguard,” the new musical based on the 1992 movie that starred Whitney Houston and Kevin Costner, Heather Headley gives great diva.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Playing a pop goddess in “The Bodyguard,” the new musical based on the 1992 movie that starred Whitney Houston and Kevin Costner, Heather Headley gives great diva. Ms. Headley, who won (and deserved) a Tony as the title character in Disney’s “Aida,” scores another personal triumph and once again transcends her material as the celebrity in jeopardy in Alexander Dinelaris’s lumpy adaptation of Lawrence Kasdan’s original screenplay.

headline: Off the Streets, Out of the Mines
abstract: The 70-minute presentation is a shambles, though one with much to recommend it.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The South African dance company Via Katlehong began in 1992 as an effort to siphon young men off the tough streets of Katlehong, a township near Johannesburg. About 10 years later French presenters took an interest in the troupe’s blend of dances from the street and the mines, and it began to tour internationally — a chain that often ends with local idioms being transformed into slick global products.

headline: Freedom Is Brief for Canadians Who Fled Prison by Helicopter
abstract: Two Canadian convicts shimmied up a rope at a provincial detention center north of Montreal to a helicopter hijacked by two accomplices, but they were back in custody a day later.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — In a bold prison break, two Canadian convicts shinnied up a rope at a provincial detention center north of Montreal to a hijacked helicopter hovering overhead and, briefly, experienced freedom.

headline: Museums Go Shopping at Maastricht
abstract: More museums have returned to the European Fine Art Fair. Some say American institutions are feeling more flush; some museums are reopening and want new works.
lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — Every March museum directors and curators from around the world flock to the European Fine Art Fair, held in a soulless convention center here. They come to look at the art, gauge the market and network with colleagues, collectors and trustees. But this year, barely 24 hours after the preview on Thursday, there were reports that more museums than usual were among the serious shoppers.

headline: How Fast We Slow Down Running Longer Distances
abstract: When running double the distance, it doesn’t merely take double the time — a study of world record times over various distances shows an increase by a factor of 2.15.
lead_paragraph: How fast do we slow down?

headline: On the Origins of Gadgets
abstract: “How We Invented the World” is a four-part Discovery Channel series on the innovations behind everyday technologies.
lead_paragraph: Once, maybe, everyone more or less understood everything and how it worked. But society pushed past that point long ago, into a realm where we are dependent on devices and structures we couldn’t possibly make ourselves and whose origins we don’t even know. As you realize if you’re reading this on a cellphone.

headline: Love Goddess? Never Saw That Coming
abstract: In the season finale of “Girls” on HBO, Lena Dunham offered a romance-novel surprise.
lead_paragraph: One of the more notable things about the season finale of “Girls” on Sunday is that Hannah, the heroine played by Lena Dunham, kept her clothes on.

headline: As Crop Prices Surge, Investment Firms and Farmers Vie for Land
abstract: Farmers are receiving record prices for their land — but economists and banking regulators warn this boom, like so many before it, could end badly.
lead_paragraph: From the potato fields of Michigan to the high prairies of Kansas, farmers are receiving record prices for their land — but economists and banking regulators warn that this boom, like so many before it, could end badly.

headline: Albums by Low and Phosphorescent
abstract: Low releases its 10th full-length album, “The Invisible Way”; and “Muchacho” is Phosphorescent’s new record.
lead_paragraph: LOW“The Invisible Way”(Sub Pop)

headline: Bloomberg Doubles Its Tech Television
abstract: Bloomberg Television is adding a morning technology program to its lineup. Executives there say it reflects a growing interest in the topic.
lead_paragraph: 5:53 p.m. | Updated In a world of shrinking newsrooms, real expansion is an increasingly rare story. But next Monday, Bloomberg West, Bloomberg Television’s show on technology, will double its daily programming to two hours. Along with the existing afternoon program, Bloomberg West will present another hour of tech news at 10 a.m. Pacific time.

headline: Jordan’s King Finds Fault With Everyone Concerned
abstract: In a magazine interview, King Abdullah criticized other Arab leaders, officials in Jordan and even his sons while insisting that only he can lead the country’s transition to democracy.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — King Abdullah II of Jordan leads one of the smallest, poorest and most vulnerable Arab nations. But that does not stop him from looking down on many of those around him, including the leaders of Egypt, Turkey and Syria, as well as members of his own royal family, his secret police, his traditional tribal political base, his Islamist opponents and even United States diplomats.

headline: St. Louis Watches Selection Show in Electronics Store
abstract: Fearing they would miss it, the St. Louis men’s basketball players stopped at a New Jersey store to watch the N.C.A.A. tournament selection on their way to the airport.
lead_paragraph: St. Louis navigated Virginia Commonwealth’s full-court press well enough to win the Atlantic 10 Conference tournament title game Sunday afternoon at Barclays Center. It was after the game when the Billikens were slowed by what some might consider a more stressful situation — fighting New York City traffic on the way to the airport.

headline: What the Cyprus Bailout Could Mean for Europe’s Debt
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Some economists say that they are optimistic about reducing Europe’s debt levels after leaders took controversial steps in the Cyprus bailout.
lead_paragraph: The Cyprus bailout is perhaps an even bigger deal than it first seemed, and not for bad reasons.

headline: U.N. Rights Council to Vote on Resolution on Sri Lanka
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The resolution urges Sri Lanka to investigate allegations of mass civilian slaughter in the army campaign that crushed a rebel group in May 2009.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council is preparing to vote this week on a resolution that urges Sri Lanka to deliver on its promises to investigate allegations of mass civilian slaughter in the army campaign that crushed a rebel group in May 2009, and expresses growing international concern over a lengthy catalog of continuing atrocities.

headline: Stolen Works
abstract: Two men disguised as police officers stole 13 works of art in 1990, including rare paintings by Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer, all of which have been valued at approximately $500 million.
lead_paragraph: Two men disguised as police officers stole 13 works of art in 1990, including rare paintings by Rembrandt, Degas and Vermeer, all of which have been valued at approximately $500 million.

headline: 10 Years Later, an Anniversary Many Iraqis Would Prefer to Ignore
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As historians, pundits and officials elsewhere mark 10 years since the invasion of Iraq, Iraqis are more attuned to the bombings, protests and political strife of the present.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The war that arrived a decade ago is still too painful and too controversial to be taught to schoolchildren or subjected to serious academic study at universities, and the local news media are too busy reporting on the latest bombings, protests and political disagreements to care much about an anniversary.

headline: Small Knives, Small Risk? Not Everyone Thinks So
abstract: Flight attendants and pilots criticized the agency’s easing of rules governing carry-on items.
lead_paragraph: HOW do flight attendants feel about allowing passengers to carry little knives on board? Well, I can always depend on Rene Foss, a flight attendant for over 25 years, to get right to the point.

headline: Wanted Congolese Rebel Leader Turns Himself In to U.S. Embassy
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Child Soldiers']
abstract: Bosco Ntaganda, accused of massacring civilians, said he wanted to be sent to the International Criminal Court, where has been wanted on war crimes charges for six years.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Bosco Ntaganda, a Congolese rebel general accused of massacring civilians and building an army of child soldiers — considered one of Africa’s most wanted men — surprisingly turned himself in to the American Embassy in Rwanda on Monday, saying he wanted to be sent to the International Criminal Court.

headline: Mets’ Harvey Delivers Another Strong Outing
abstract: The 23-year-old starter looked sharp over five and a third innings, allowing two runs, six hits and a walk while striking out six.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The Mets’ future hinges on the performances on a group of young arms in which the club has invested its resources and rested its hopes.

headline: Style at SXSW
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: There was no shortage of perfectly worn in Converse, cut-off shorts and sundresses at SXSW this year.
lead_paragraph: There was no shortage of perfectly worn in Converse, cut-off shorts and sundresses at SXSW this year.

headline: Local Russian Hijab Ban Puts Muslims in a Squeeze
abstract: Torn between education and their faith, Muslims in the Stavropol region find themselves at the center of an emerging debate over religion in Russia.
lead_paragraph: LEVOPADINSKY, Russia — The girls of the Salikhov family live in frontier country. Their road is dirt, punctuated by puddles and sheep, and their house does not have plumbing or running water. They had been hoping this would be the year the local authorities got around to hooking up natural gas.

headline: American Honda Divides Its Biggest Ad Assignments
abstract: One of the largest recent reviews for an advertising account has ended with the incumbent agency keeping a significant part of the assignment, but relinquishing two large pieces to other agencies.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest recent reviews for an advertising account has ended with the incumbent agency keeping a significant part of the assignment, but relinquishing two large pieces to two other agencies.

headline: Pennsylvania: Appoint Judges, Ex-Governors Say
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Four former Pennsylvania governors called for eliminating elections for senior judges in favor of appointing them.
lead_paragraph: Four former Pennsylvania governors called for eliminating elections for senior judges in favor of appointing them. Judges seeking campaign donations are open to corruption, the governors argued. “The influence of money on judicial elections is pernicious,” said Edward G. Rendell, a former Democratic governor, who joined with a fellow Democrat, George Leader, and two Republicans, Tom Ridge and Dick Thornburgh, in the unusual bipartisan appeal. Last month, a Pennsylvania Supreme Court justice, Joan Orie Melvin, was convicted on campaign corruption charges. Only six states select all judges in partisan elections, according to Pennsylvanians for Modern Courts, which wants the governor to fill the state’s three appellate benches. The change requires a constitutional amendment. Critics say it would introduce secretive back-room deals.

headline: Man Says He Killed Tourist in Turkey After She Rebuffed Kiss
abstract: Ziya Tasali, who was formally charged with killing Sarai Sierra, a tourist from Staten Island, said in a statement to prosecutors that a struggle broke out after she rejected his advances.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — The fatal encounter between a Staten Island woman and a homeless man in Istanbul earlier this year began when she resisted his attempt to kiss her, according to a two-page statement he gave to prosecutors.

headline: Oh, California
abstract: The land out here is a series of characters to me, as mysterious and alluring as any people I might invent on the page.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things I’ve been called in my time, the one that surprises me the most is “California Writer.” When I hear that, I look over my shoulder, certain that the phrase must apply to the writer behind me or to my left. It’s the way I feel when I am addressed by my husband’s last name. It takes me a moment to realize his mother is not in the room.

headline: U.S. Drug Costs Dropped in 2012, but Rises Loom
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The 1 percent drop in drug spending was partly a sign of the rising use of generics, but experts warn that the high cost of specialty medicines could reverse the downturn.
lead_paragraph: Spending on prescription drugs nationwide has been slowing for years because of the increasingly widespread use of low-cost generics. But in 2012, something unheard-of happened: money spent on prescription drugs actually dropped.

headline: Hughes Is Hit by Grounder in Return, but Says He’s Fine
abstract: Phil Hughes pitched in a simulated game, throwing off a mound for the first time since being shut down Feb. 18 because of a bulging disk.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Tucked away in the corner of the Yankees’ minor league facility, on a day off for the team, three players who are key to the Yankees’ hopes this season toiled in relative obscurity Monday.

headline: A New First Couple in Sports: Woods and Vonn
abstract: Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn confirmed that they are dating, uniting one of the world’s best golfers with one of the world’s best ski racers.
lead_paragraph: With eerily similar announcements to a combined Facebook and Twitter audience of nearly 6.5 million, Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn confirmed Monday that they are dating, then asked for privacy because they want to live, in Woods’s words, “as an ordinary couple.”

headline: Negotiators for Arms Trade Treaty Discuss Regulation of Ammunition
abstract: Negotiators at the United Nations began a final round of talks on Monday aimed at completing a treaty to regulate the international trade in conventional weapons.
lead_paragraph: Negotiators at the United Nations began a final round of talks on Monday aimed at completing a treaty to regulate the international trade in conventional weapons. Objections by the United States and other major weapons exporters prevented an agreement. The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, lamented what he called the lack of regulatory controls for the import and export of conventional weapons, asking why “there are common standards for the global trade in armchairs but not the global trade in arms.” One of the most contentious issues was whether ammunition should be included in the scope of the treaty. Anna McDonald, a representative of Oxfam, which is pushing for strong treaty, said her group wanted strict and specific language that would regulate ammunition. Thomas Mason, a representative of the World Forum on Shooting Activities, a group that represents firearms makers and users, said the sheer volume of ammunition produced made such monitoring impractical.

headline: China: More Pigs Found in River
abstract: The number of dead pigs found in the river near Shanghai rose to more than 13,000 over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The number of dead pigs found in a river near Shanghai rose to more than 13,000 over the weekend. Last Friday, the figure stood at about 7,500. The authorities, who are in the middle of a weeklong effort to collect the carcasses, are still trying to determine how the pigs died and why they ended up in the Huangpu River, which winds through Shanghai. The government has insisted that there is no evidence of an epidemic and that the food supply is safe. City officials also say the river meets national water quality standards. The authorities say they believe that many of the pigs came from the nearby city of Jiaxing, in Zhejiang Province, where there are major pig farms.

headline: Former Calpers Chief Indicted Over Fraud
abstract: Federico R. Buenrostro and an associate are charged with defrauding Apollo Global Management.
lead_paragraph: As head of the country’s largest pension fund, Federico R. Buenrostro wielded vast influence in the money management world.

headline: Seeking Profit for Taxpayers in Potential of New Drug
abstract: Congress wants a second look at how private firms profit from public research after Pfizer and the National Institutes of Health developed a potentially lucrative new drug.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With automatic spending cuts cascading through the government, lawmakers are calling for a review of federal policies they say have allowed businesses to profit on government research with limited return for taxpayers or consumers.

headline: Bombs Strike Bus Station in Nigeria
abstract: At least 20 people were killed in the attack, and possibly many more, as the fire from the explosions spread to nearby buses.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — Suicide bombers crashed an explosives-laden Volkswagen into a crowded bus on Monday as it was parked at a depot in Kano, northern Nigeria’s largest city, and officials said at least 20 people were killed, possibly many more, as the conflagration spread to four nearby buses.

headline: Electronic Arts Chief Resigns
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: John Riccitiello, who became chief executive in 2007, fell victim to internal errors and falling sales of traditional video games as consumer tastes changed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The chief executive of Electronic Arts resigned on Monday, a victim of a troubled environment for the big video game companies as well as of internal missteps.

headline: New Jersey Lawyer Guilty of Murder
abstract: A jury in federal court in Newark convicted Paul W. Bergrin, known for his defense of drug lords and rap stars, on all 23 counts.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — For years Paul W. Bergrin eluded charges from his former colleagues in the United States attorney’s office that he had become “house counsel” for gangs, using his criminal defense practice here as an elaborate front for prostitution, drug running and even the killing of witnesses.

headline: ABC Works on an App for Live Streaming Shows to Mobile Devices
abstract: The app, which would stream programming to the phones and tablets of cable and satellite subscribers, could become available to some subscribers this year.
lead_paragraph: THE WALT DISNEY Company, while sorting out the future of the online video Web site Hulu, has an app in the works that may render Hulu passé for some people.

headline: A Bank Levy in Cyprus, and Why Not to Worry
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Analysts were breathless waiting for impending disaster from the bailout in Cyprus. But nothing bad happened.
lead_paragraph: Never mind.

headline: It’s Move It or Lose It in Path of a Nor’easter
abstract: Some officials in Plum Island, Mass., say it’s time to face the reality of increasingly violent storms and rising seas and consider relocating coastal homes.
lead_paragraph: PLUM ISLAND, Mass. — Barbara Murray walked her dog past a ribbon of the police tape that wound its way around sections of this scenic barrier island, about an hour north of Boston, where she has lived for 50 years.

headline: Strategy in Scandal Makes Spanish Duke’s Ex-Partner a Prisoner in Home
abstract: Diego Torres’s $2 million house has become a luxury bunker since he challenged the Spanish royal family by revealing their private e-mails in a corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Diego Torres, a onetime marketing guru, built a $2 million dream home outside Barcelona, but it has become a luxury bunker since he challenged the Spanish royal family by revealing its private e-mails as part of his legal defense in a corruption investigation.

headline: A Young Man With Down Syndrome, a Fatal Encounter and a Cry for Understanding
abstract: After the death of Ethan Saylor, a Maryland man with Down syndrome, in the custody of mall security officers, advocates want more than raised awareness.
lead_paragraph: You may not have heard of Robert Ethan Saylor, but his death in January should inspire something more lasting than a small-town police investigation.

headline: A Cure, in Essence, for H.I.V. in Some Adults
abstract: French researchers have identified 14 adults who were treated with antiviral drugs but then stopped treatment and are considered “functionally” cured.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, American doctors reported that they had “functionally” cured a baby infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, with an aggressive treatment of drugs starting some 30 hours after the baby was born. Experts hailed the feat but cautioned that the findings might have little relevance to adults.

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 3
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ten years after “shock and awe,” Iraq War veterans reflect on the first and last days of the war and what it meant to them.
lead_paragraph: This is the third part of a six-part series.

headline: Should Depositors Save Cyprus's Banks?
abstract: Is penalizing depositors to prop up Cypriot banks just? Or will it undermine confidence in banks elsewhere in Europe, causing an economic meltdown?

headline: Taxing Savers in Cyprus
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Editorials']
abstract: Europe’s bailout plan for the island is needlessly harsh and could do lasting damage to confidence in banks in other euro-zone countries.
lead_paragraph: A European plan could force Cyprus to tax bank depositors as a condition of a bailout in a way that would unfairly punish savers and could do lasting damage to confidence in banks in other euro-zone countries in financial crisis. The country’s leaders have a chance to change the agreement and should do so.

headline: A Conversation With: Former Tihar Inmate Niranjan Kumar Mandal
abstract: Mr. Mandal recounts the horrors of living inside Delhi’s Tihar jail after being wrongly implicated in a rape case.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The death of Ram Singh, one of the six defendants in the Delhi gang rape case who was found hanged in his cell, has raised speculation about its cause and questions about the management of Tihar Jail. While the post-mortem report suggested suicide, Mr. Singh’s parents contend that the police murdered him, in part because both his arms were damaged from previous accidents.

headline: The Andes Chronicles: A Ban on Hydraulic Fracturing
abstract: A town’s new law reads like an imitation of the physical act it is trying to prevent.
lead_paragraph: Once or twice a year I bring news from the small Catskills town of Andes, and usually the news concerns the ongoing battle to preserve the town’s rural character in the face of incursions from entrepreneurial energy companies. A few years back Andes passed an ordinance banning wind turbines. Late last month the town board passed a law prohibiting heavy industry. The intended target of the law was hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, the technique by which natural gas is extracted from underground rock formations that have been subjected to the high velocity impact of chemically laced water.

headline: Ranked No. 1, Lewis Keeps Expectations in Check
abstract: Stacy Lewis became the seventh woman to ascend to No. 1 in the world rankings and the second American. Pressures aside, Lewis said she planned to continue to have fun.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — As a teenager, Stacy Lewis spent 18 hours a day wearing a back brace to cope with scoliosis. That was hard.

headline: A Pattern of Problems at a Hospital for Veterans
abstract: A special counsel’s letter to the White House detailed complaints on missed diagnoses, poor sterilization and understaffing at a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an unusually strong letter sent to the White House on Monday, the office that handles complaints from federal whistle-blowers says it has found a pattern of problems at a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss., that raises serious questions about the hospital’s management practices.

headline: Vatican’s Bureaucracy Tests Even the Infallible
abstract: For Pope Francis to change the Vatican, he must tame a hierarchy whose branches are run like medieval fiefs and whose supplicants vie for access and influence.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — An Italian industrialist tried to curry favor by donating $100,000 worth of truffles. A Mercedes-Benz executive hoped for an audience to suggest improvements to the Popemobile. But in the final years of the papacy of Benedict XVI, others sent very different messages, too, desperate for the pope’s ear.

headline: Arizona’s Barrier to the Right to Vote
abstract: Arizona’s Proposition 200 conflicts with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 and should be struck down by the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s Proposition 200, passed in 2004, prohibits local officials from registering any would-be voter who does not provide “satisfactory evidence of United States citizenship.” That requirement conflicts with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, also known as the Motor Voter Act, which set up a national registration system for federal elections.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Ax Isn’t Sharp Enough
abstract: His plan takes 10 years to balance the budget. You call that radical?
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: The Progressive Shift
keywords: ['Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Liberalism in the United States seems to have moved to believing that government is the first and final engine of all progress.
lead_paragraph: There is a statue outside the Federal Trade Commission of a powerful, rambunctious horse being reined in by an extremely muscular man. This used to be a metaphor for liberalism. The horse was capitalism. The man was government, which was needed sometimes to restrain capitalism’s excesses.

headline: Does China Have a Foreign Policy?
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Chinese leaders use strong rhetoric and fan nationalist flames to compensate for the absence of a clear, well-developed strategy for participating in the international order.
lead_paragraph: Shanghai

headline: Falling Out of Love With China
abstract: Why Beijing’s declining global prestige matters, and how to get it back.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: Pre-K Provider Stole Millions, State Audit Says
abstract: Auditors said the provider of services to preschoolers diverted $5.8 million over six years.
lead_paragraph: One of New York City’s largest providers of special education services to preschoolers with disabilities illegally diverted millions in taxpayer financing to a girls’ religious school, summer camps and a kosher supermarket owned by the group’s officers and board members, state auditors said on Monday.

headline: Cyprus Bailout Incites Turmoil as Blame Flies
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: An 11th-hour deal produced a package that has outraged almost everyone involved and prompted a blame game across the Continent, offering a vivid illustration of why Europe has so much trouble making decisions.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A plan to rescue the tiny European country of Cyprus, assembled overnight in Brussels, has left financial regulators, German politicians, panicked Cypriot leaders and a disgruntled Kremlin with a bailout package that has outraged virtually all the parties.

headline: Lawyers for Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)']
abstract: The president of the American Bar Association writes that reform “must instill due process as the bedrock principle.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
