abstract: A reader responds to a Sunday Review article, “Keep Calm and Carry On ... Buying.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Treating Early Alzheimer’s
abstract: The chairman of USAgainstAlzheimer’s responds to an editorial about the drug-approval process.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Budget Cuts and the Poor
abstract: Jim Wallis, the president of Sojourners, a Christian faith group for social justice, responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Too Busy for Dad?
abstract: A reader responds to a column about a new digital “etiquette.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
lead_paragraph: March 18, 2013

headline: Knowing What’s in the Food We Eat
abstract: Responses to an editorial that opposed mandatory labels for genetically modified foods.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Mar. 19, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, Mar. 19, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "In a sense, we’re playing Russian roulette with the Sun.”

headline: For Colorado Governor, a Long Path to Gun Limits
abstract: Eight months after the Aurora, Colo., shooting rampage, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper is poised to sign some of the toughest new gun control laws in the nation.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The wounds and rage from a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater were still raw one morning last July when Gov. John W. Hickenlooper went on national television to discuss grief and guns. Shaken and groping for answers, he nevertheless cast doubt on one idea: that tighter gun laws could have prevented the carnage.

headline: More Charges Against Brooklyn Legislator
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Politics and Government', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr., already embroiled in a bribery case, is now facing charges that he falsely secured tens of thousands of dollars in travel reimbursements.
lead_paragraph: A New York lawmaker already facing bribery charges is now facing additional charges of falsely securing tens of thousands of dollars in travel reimbursements from the Assembly by submitting travel vouchers when he was not working on legislative business.

headline: A Goal for Obama in Israel: Finding Some Overlap on Iran
abstract: As President Obama tries to connect with the Israeli people,  he will work to convince Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he can rely on the United States to take care of Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If President Obama’s most obvious goal on his trip to Israel this week is to forge a connection with the Israeli people, his challenge behind closed doors is to persuade Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he can rely on the United States to take care of Iran.

headline: State Leaders Reach Deal to Raise Minimum Wage
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders were working on a plan that would increase the base pay to $9 in exchange for new tax breaks.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached a tentative agreement on Monday to increase the state’s minimum wage to $9 over the next three years.

headline: In Women’s Bracket, Top Seeds Are the Same but Baylor Leads the Way
abstract: Unlike the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament, one powerhouse stands out in the women’s field: Baylor. The Lady Bears, led by Brittney Griner, have won 30 straight games.
lead_paragraph: If the only remarkable element of the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament bracket was its parity, the opposite is true for the women’s bracket, revealed Monday, with all roads leading again to Baylor, the Goliath out of the Big 12 that has lost once in two seasons.

headline: Just You Wait
abstract: Mike Buckley holds a gathering of sorts for us.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to another episode of True Stories, in which I regale you with a long-buried and potentially embarrassing story from my life that is unceremoniously dislodged from my brain by an entry in the puzzle.

headline: Tennis Association Seeks Parkland, and Gets a Fight
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Tennis', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: The operator of the United States Open needs less than an acre in Corona, Queens, to execute a plan to replace two of its aging courts, but it faces an unusually well-organized opposition.
lead_paragraph: It was two years ago that a match at the United States Open was interrupted because an 18-inch hairline crack developed along the service line in the middle of a game. “Of course, it was all captured on TV,” recalled Daniel Zausner, the chief operating officer of the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens. “It was an embarrassment.”

headline: How Blogger Helped the Steubenville Rape Case Unfold Online
abstract: The blogger who helped bring national attention to the Steubenville rape case speaks out.
lead_paragraph: On the day after two high school football players from Steubenville, Ohio, were found guilty of rape, Alexandria Goddard, a crime blogger whose early and dogged research helped bring national attention to the case, is still fending off criticism that she helped create “an Internet lynch mob.”

headline: A Glut of Electronic Waste
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Computer Monitors', 'Television Sets']
abstract: As recently as a few years ago, broken monitors and televisions were being recycled profitably. But flat-screen technology has lowered demand, creating stockpiles of useless material across the country.
lead_paragraph: As recently as a few years ago, broken monitors and televisions were being recycled profitably. But flat-screen technology has lowered demand, creating stockpiles of useless material across the country.

headline: Nets Still Trying to Find Themselves
abstract: Having missed a chance to move into a tie for first in the Atlantic Division, the Nets began a grueling eight-game trip Monday.
lead_paragraph: There is no shame in dropping a game to the Atlanta Hawks, even at home, but the Nets projected disappointment in the way they competed Sunday night in a puzzling 105-93 loss that bore a number of implications for playoff seeding.

headline: Corrections: March 19, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 19, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Murder Conviction Tossed Out in Queens
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'District Attorneys', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: A judge said the Queens district attorney’s office had failed to turn helpful information over to the defense team of Pedros Bedi, as required by law.
lead_paragraph: A judge has thrown out the murder conviction of a man who already served more than 13 years in prison and granted him a new trial, saying that the Queens district attorney’s office had failed to give the defense information that would have shown a crucial witness lied on the stand.

headline: Unwanted Electronic Gear Rising in Toxic Piles
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Computer Monitors', 'Television Sets', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Advances in flat-screen technology have made older monitors and televisions obsolete, decimating demand for tube glass used in them and creating vast stockpiles of useless material.
lead_paragraph: Last year, two inspectors from California’s hazardous waste agency were visiting an electronics recycling company near Fresno for a routine review of paperwork when they came across a warehouse the size of a football field, packed with tens of thousands of old computer monitors and televisions.

headline: A Focus on 3 Encounters in a Stop-and-Frisk Trial
abstract: The judge deciding the case will consider the significance of the soaring number of street stops by the police over the last decade.
lead_paragraph: The first time the police stopped and then frisked him on his block in the Bronx, David Floyd remembered wanting only “to get home” and “be in my own space.” The second time it happened, Mr. Floyd testified, he was left with the impression that “I needed to stay in my place, and my place was in my home.”

headline: The Senate’s Muckraker
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Senator Carl Levin of Michigan has done more than anyone to expose the financial industry the past few years.
lead_paragraph: I’ll miss Carl Levin when he leaves the Senate after the next election — and you will, too.

headline: Traffic Fatalities in City Increased in 2012, but Officials Point to Larger Picture
abstract: More people died in New York City traffic last year than the year before, but officials said there is a long-term trend of reduced fatalities.
lead_paragraph: More than 270 people died in New York City traffic in 2012, the most traffic-related fatalities since 2008, officials said on Monday.

headline: Court Is Asked to Drop Charges Against Kenya’s President-Elect
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The president-elect of Kenya, Uhuru Kenyatta, is facing charges of crimes against humanity in the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lawyers for Kenya’s president-elect, Uhuru Kenyatta, said Monday that the charges of crimes against humanity that he faces should be dropped because they were based on hearsay and were fundamentally flawed.

headline: For Some, Spending Less on Drugs
abstract: As lower-cost generic drugs have become more widely prescribed, the dollar amount spent on drugs fell last year for the first time.
lead_paragraph: As lower-cost generic drugs have become more widely prescribed, the dollar amount spent on drugs fell last year for the first time.

headline: Abortion Doctor’s Murder Trial Opens
abstract: Dr. Kermit Gosnell, who operated a women’s health clinic in West Philadelphia, is accused of performing illegal late-term abortions and killing seven viable fetuses.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In opening statements in court on Monday, prosecutors charged that a doctor who operated a women’s health clinic here killed seven viable fetuses by plunging scissors into their necks and “snipping” their spinal cords and was also responsible for the death of a pregnant woman in his care.

headline: Injuries Leave Knicks With Odd Lineup
abstract: With the injured Carmelo Anthony and Tyson Chandler sidelined, the Knicks patched together a starting lineup of players who had never played together to face the Jazz.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Through 64 games this season, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson never had to construct his starting lineup out of pure desperation. Woodson did for Monday’s nationally televised game against the Utah Jazz.

headline: Erwin Harris, Ad Executive Who Seized Cuban Assets, Dies at 91
abstract: Armed with a court order, Mr. Harris took planes, a Navy boat, cigars and a trainload of lard to cover an advertising contract the Castro government stopped paying.
lead_paragraph: Erwin Harris left behind a respectable record of achievement as an advertising executive, an estimable collection of Chinese antiquities (his lifelong hobby), a loving family and a remarkable if little-remembered role in the tortured history of diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba in the early 1960s.

headline: Nets Look Impressive in First Stop of Their Trip
abstract: The Nets began their longest trip by doing something they have routinely done: win against a mediocre team.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, MICH. — The Nets began their longest trip of the season — 13 days away from home, which will most likely fall between a fascinating footnote and a season-defining stretch — by doing something they have routinely done all season: win against a mediocre team.

headline: Olen Burrage Dies at 82; Linked to Killings in 1964
abstract: Mr. Burrage was a Ku Klux Klan member who owned the Mississippi farm where the bodies of three civil rights workers were found, and he was later acquitted in a federal trial.
lead_paragraph: Olen Burrage, a Ku Klux Klan member who owned the Mississippi farm where the bodies of three slain civil rights workers were found in 1964, died on Friday in Meridian, Miss. He was 82.

headline: A Justice Dept. Official Is Named to Lead Labor
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama tapped Thomas E. Perez, who heads the Civil Rights Division at the Justice Department, to be his next labor secretary. Some Senate Republicans called him a divisive choice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a few confirmation victories in his pocket, President Obama decided Monday to press ahead with another cabinet nominee in defiance of Republican opposition as he tapped an assertive civil rights regulator to be his next labor secretary.

headline: Booth Gardner Dies at 76; Ex-Washington Governor
abstract: Mr. Gardner served two terms and then led a campaign to allow physician-assisted suicide after becoming a Parkinson’s disease patient.
lead_paragraph: Booth Gardner, a two-term governor of Washington whose diagnosis with Parkinson’s disease after he left office helped motivate him to lead a successful voter initiative to allow physician-assisted suicide, died on Friday at his home in Tacoma. He was 76.

headline: A Guide to Watching Syria’s War
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Amateur video has been pivotal to the way the conflict in Syria is understood.
lead_paragraph: Amateur video has been pivotal to the way the conflict in Syria is understood.

headline: Ban on Gay Marriage Led Lawyers to Shift Role
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: A challenge by San Francisco to a ban on gay marriage was the start of a kind of civil disobedience movement, and it led to a Supreme Court case to be argued next week.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nine years ago, city officials here sued to strike down a state ban on same-sex marriage. It was the first government challenge to such a law, and it set in motion a legal chain reaction that gave rise to a momentous Supreme Court case to be argued next Tuesday.

headline: In Rare Move, Patriots’ Owner Gives Details of Welker Talks
abstract: Team owner Robert K. Kraft said the Patriots wanted to keep receiver Wes Welker, offering him a deal worth more than the one he took with the Denver Broncos.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In a news conference that offered an unusual amount of detail from one of the N.F.L.’s most tight-lipped organizations, the Patriots owner Robert K. Kraft said Monday that everyone in the organization wanted receiver Wes Welker to return. Welker signed a two-year contract with the Broncos last week for $6 million per year, and the Patriots signed Danny Amendola to replace him for about the same amount.

headline: One Person One Vote (or Was That One Voter One Vote?)
abstract: Voting districts may hold the same number of people, but they don’t hold the same number of voters. The Supreme Court will decide next week whether to hear a Texas case on the issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the exception of the Senate, where voters from states with small populations have vastly more power than those from, say, California or Texas, the rest of the American political system is committed to the bedrock principle of “one person one vote.”

headline: In the Song of Egypt,  a Chord for Both Secular and Religious Jews
abstract: A boomer who baby-sits for a 5-year-old finds that playing “Egypt” is fun, but that it is also common ground for secular and religious Jews.
lead_paragraph: Hanina, the 5-year-old I baby-sit, loves to play “pretend.” When we come up with a story he enjoys, we play it over and over. Small children love repetition — if it’s fun the first time, it’ll be fun the second! (And the 22nd!) Hanina’s favorite books inspire many of our games. I can’t count the number of times we’ve ridden the Magic School Bus as it made its interminable, fact-filled way through the local water works or blasted into outer space. Other games, like a recent one featuring a marauding army of killer cannibal princesses, Hanina dreams up on his own.

headline: Q&A: Logging Out of Gmail From Another Computer
abstract: Even if you forget to log out of Gmail from one computer, you can log out of your account on that machine from another computer.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Celtics Give Heat All They Can Handle, but They Handle It
abstract: LeBron James knocked down an 18-foot jumper with 10.5 seconds left to lift the Heat over the Celtics and extend Miami’s winning streak, which is 10 shy of the N.B.A. record.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — They trailed by 17 in the first half. They trailed by 13 with eight-plus minutes to play. They were hit by an offensive explosion like none they had seen all season, not from Kevin Durant, Kobe Bryant or Carmelo Anthony.

headline: So You’re Extinct? Scientists Have Gleam in Eye
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Cloning', 'Genetic Engineering', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Woolly Mammoths']
abstract: It could be years before scientists succeed in bringing species back from extinction, but they are thinking of ways to give new life to creatures like woolly mammoths and weird frogs.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, the arrow of natural selection seemed to go only one way. A species could form, then it could flourish, then it could go extinct. And once it was extinct, it could not come back.

headline: Word of the Day | guileless
abstract: This word has appeared in 105 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: guileless •\ˈgi(-ə)l-ləs\• adjective

headline: Small Infrastructure Gains Are Observed in Engineering Report
abstract: A report released Tuesday gave America’s infrastructure a rating of D+, the first time in the 15 years of the study that the grade has improved.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s infrastructure is crumbling a little bit less.

headline: Bryant’s Roles Evolve From Peacemaker to Assistant Coach
abstract: Sidelined with an ankle injury, Kobe Bryant tried his hand at coaching the Lakers to a win. Earlier in the season he played peacemaker with his teammate Dwight Howard.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Having been many things to many people and everything to the Lakers over the last 17 years, Kobe Bryant emerged last week in a role no one expected: assistant coach.

headline: L.I.R.R. Train Derails in Queens
abstract: No passengers were aboard when the incident occurred, but the authorities said there was a potential for delays during the morning commute.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island Rail Road train derailed Monday night west of Jamaica Station in the vicinity of Forest Hills, Queens, causing potential delays for the morning commute, but no injuries, the authorities said.

headline: Fukushima Blackout Hints at Plant’s Vulnerability
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Power Outages and Blackouts', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: Vital cooling systems at the stricken nuclear plant were restored more than 24 hours after a partial power failure cut cooling water to four spent fuel pools, the company that operates the plant said.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant this week experienced its worst power failure since the disaster there in 2011, and though the plant’s operator said all electricity was restored by early Wednesday, the problem underlined its continuing vulnerability.

headline: Rangers Manage to Break Losing Streak, if Not Their Scoring Struggles
abstract: To motivate the Rangers, Coach John Tortorella showed a reel of offensive highlights from the season. The tactic woke up the Rangers, who ended their skid with a win over the Devils.
lead_paragraph: Marc Staal watched from a Madison Square Garden luxury box, attending his first game since taking a puck near the right eye in a frightening accident March 5. Staal did not speak to reporters, but obviously liked what he saw — a 2-1 shootout victory for the Rangers over the Carolina Hurricanes and his brothers Eric and Jordan on Monday night.

headline: United States Facing Two Qualifying Games With Thin Roster
abstract: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann has had to piece together a roster light on experience for two World Cup qualifiers after his team was hit hard by injuries.
lead_paragraph: When United States national team Coach Jurgen Klinsmann called in attacking threats like Jozy Altidore, Herculez Gomez and Clint Dempsey for his latest roster, it was surely done with the hope that the United States would be able to score often in its two coming World Cup qualifying matches. Given the injuries and illness that have racked Klinsmann’s group of defenders, he could hardly be blamed for thinking he will need as many goals as possible.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC) SPLASH The Olympic gold medalist Greg Louganis, above, will tutor 10 celebrities — among them, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Louie Anderson, Drake Bell, Keshia Knight Pulliam and Kendra Wilkinson — in the art of diving before they try to flip, twist and spin off a regulation platform and springboard in this new competition series. The diver David Boudia and the director of the United States team, Steve Foley, will critique each dive. Chuy Bravo, Rory Bushfield, Nicole Eggert, Ndamukong Suh and Katherine Webb round out the roster of competitors; Joey Lawrence and Charissa Thompson host.

headline: Dominican Republic Reaches World Classic Final
abstract: The Dominicans defeated the Netherlands, setting up a matchup with Puerto Rico in the World Baseball Classic final.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — No team has gone undefeated in a World Baseball Classic. The Japanese won it in 2006 and 2009 while losing three games the first time and two the second. Now, the Dominican Republic will take an unblemished record into the final game on Tuesday at AT&T Park.

headline: News Quiz | March 19, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: The Rebels’ Loose Cannon
abstract: Guard Marshall Henderson has led Ole Miss into the N.C.A.A. tournament with his scoring and antics on and off the court.
lead_paragraph: Steve Green had seen it all before. The hand gestures. The histrionics. The nonstop conversation Marshall Henderson was having with himself.

headline: Thomas Helps Short-Handed Knicks Hold Off Jazz
abstract: Kurt Thomas played through a right foot injury, helping the Knicks end a brutal four-game losing streak as they wrapped up a five-game western swing.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Kurt Thomas sat at his locker, his right foot in a bucket of ice, in the visitors’ locker room at EnergySolutions Arena. He had a smile on his face, appearing content to quietly reflect on his night.

headline: Jets Sign a Pass Rusher
abstract: The Jets bolstered their pass rush by signing outside linebacker Antwan Barnes to a three-year contract.
lead_paragraph: The Jets bolstered their pass rush Monday by signing outside linebacker Antwan Barnes to a three-year contract.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 19
abstract: More anxiety over the Cyprus bailout; an American will lead the Syrian opposition; a giant order for Airbus; and David Bowie live, sort of, in London.
lead_paragraph: NEWS President Nicos Anastasiades delayed a vote on a $13 billion deal that set off outrage for calling on Cypriot bank depositors to bear part of the cost, while stock markets faltered on concerns over the plan. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus, and Landon Thomas Jr. from London.

headline: Francis Vows to Serve ‘Poorest, Weakest’ and Urges Leaders to Offer Hope
abstract: At the installation Mass to mark the formal start of his papacy, Pope Francis struck tones of humility and laid out a vision of his own role in the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Striking a tone of radical humility that has already become his trademark, Pope Francis offered a passionate pledge in his installation Mass on Tuesday to serve “the poorest, the weakest, the least important,” urging world leaders to protect human life and the environment and use tenderness to inspire hope.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 19, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the best antonym for “unambiguous” as it is used in the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Sun Storm Forecast: Tiny Chance of Havoc.”

headline: British Newspapers Challenge New Press Rules
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'News and News Media']
abstract: An array of newspapers protested on Tuesday against the attempt to impose stricter curbs on this country’s scoop-driven dailies, calling potential fines a “crippling burden.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A day after British lawmakers agreed to ground rules for a new press code, an array of newspapers protested on Tuesday against the attempt to impose stricter curbs on this country’s scoop-driven dailies following the phone hacking scandal that convulsed Rupert Murdoch’s media empire and much of British public life.

headline: A Verdict in the Steubenville High School Rape Case
abstract: Why, according to the judge, was the case a “cautionary lesson”?
lead_paragraph: In “Ohio Teenagers Guilty in Rape That Social Media Brought to Light,” Richard A. Oppel Jr. writes about a case that drew wide attention for the way social media spurred the initial prosecution and later helped galvanize national outrage over the episode.

headline: False Historical Consciousness
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Gentrification', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Beijing is destroying its architectural heritage to make way for replicas, favoring shiny fakery over shabby authenticity.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — My courtyard home in the heart of old Beijing has a view of the Drum Tower, which for centuries helped citizens keep track of the time.

headline: Should Computer Games Be Used for Classroom Instruction?
abstract: What have video games taught you?
lead_paragraph: Some say the future of classroom learning should be digitized and “gamified,” so that students barely notice they are learning. Do students learn important skills and concepts playing computer games? What do you think?

headline: Who Lives Longest?
abstract: What Swedish babies and the Stone Age can teach us about life expectancy and income inequality.
lead_paragraph: A Swedish baby born in 1800 had a life expectancy of just 32 years. We know this because Sweden was one of the first countries to keep extensive records of births and deaths and, by 1800, had a reliable national system that allowed this morbid statistic to be calculated. That baby’s life may sound nasty, brutish and short, especially for a nation advanced enough to keep such detailed records, but before you imagine 19th-century Swedish teenagers suffering the regret and ennui of midlife crises, consider this: that same year, a 20-year-old Swede could reasonably expect to live another 37 years.

headline: Where Home Is an Elusive Fantasy
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Foreclosures', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Nadia Shira Cohen and Paulo Siqueira moved into a Florida motel to document the lives of families uprooted by poverty, illness and misfortune.
lead_paragraph: A young man stands in a swimming pool, eyes covered, shoulders hunched, his head slightly bowed. A child bounces from bed to bed. A dainty green cupcake with confetti sprinkles occupies a place of honor on a paper plate.

headline: Rejection of Deposit Tax Scuttles Deal on Bailout for Cyprus
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Cyprus’s president, Nicos Anastasiades, was set to return to negotiations with lenders after lawmakers rejected a package that would tax depositors to help fund a financial rescue.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Lawmakers rejected a 10 billion euro bailout package on Tuesday, sending the president back to the drawing board to devise a new plan that might still enable the country to receive a financial lifeline while avoiding a default that could reignite the euro crisis.

headline: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
abstract: Laura Perna, a researcher in college finance and affordability, answers select reader questions about paying for college. Part 2.
lead_paragraph: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blog’s Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: The Early Word: Goals and Challenges
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Daily Report: Electronic Arts Chief Resigns
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: John Riccitiello, who became chief executive in 2007, fell victim to internal errors and falling sales of traditional video games as consumer tastes changed.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Electronic Arts resigned on Monday, a victim of a troubled environment for the big video game companies as well as of internal missteps, David Streitfeld reports in The New York Times on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Buyer for BBC’s Book Unit on Travel
abstract: The sale of the Lonely Planet guidebooks, for $77.8 million, is a significant loss on the broadcaster’s purchase price of about $196 million.
lead_paragraph: SERRAVAL, France — In 2007, when the British Broadcasting Corporation bought the Lonely Planet travel guidebooks, it drew criticism from rival media organizations in the private sector, which argued that a public television company had no business expanding into areas like book publishing.

headline: Questioning the TOMS Shoes Model for Social Enterprise
abstract: Is the buy-one, give-one model philanthropy or is it social enterprise?
lead_paragraph: After visiting Argentina and seeing the impact of poverty on some of its children, Blake Mycoskie was inspired to create a philanthropic “for-profit business that was sustainable and not reliant on donations.” The result was Toms Shoes, which promised that for every pair of shoes it sold, it would give away another pair to a child in need.

headline: Pakistan Arrests Militant Suspected in Daniel Pearl Killing
abstract: The suspect is a senior figure in the Islamist group Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, accused in the mass killing of Shiites.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials have arrested a senior militant accused of involvement in the murder of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002.

headline: Creating Canada’s ‘Quantum Valley’
abstract: Two co-founders of BlackBerry have started a $100 million fund to invest in companies using quantum physics. They plan to help create ultrapowerful sensors and motors, building on esoteric discoveries at research labs they’ve financed in Ontario.
lead_paragraph: Showing how quickly an esoteric technology can become mainstream, Mike Lazaridis and Doug Fregin, who together founded BlackBerry, are establishing a $100 million venture fund for technologies that employ practical applications of quantum physics.

headline: Many Israelis Unsure of Obama, but Are Ready to Listen During Visit
abstract: During a visit to Israel, President Obama will confront a public still smarting from perceived slights in years past.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Obama administration officials have made it clear that the top agenda item for the president’s visit here this week is to win the hearts of the Israeli people. He has a lot of work to do.

headline: The Politics of the 14th Amendment and the Debt Limit
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The reasoning behind the 14th Amendment provision that addressed Civil War debt should be applied today, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Finance Bill, Nearing Senate Passage, Would Protect Some Favored Programs
abstract: While the bill would protect funding for programs like infant nutrition, lawmakers warned of painful cuts for others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The worst of the federal cuts to a major infant nutrition program would be reversed. Embassy security and construction could be spared in the wake of the consulate attack in Benghazi, Libya. And child care subsidies, once seen as critical to the success of welfare reform, would take a haircut, not the hammer blow that President Obama once loudly warned was coming.

headline: Assessing the Cyprus Bailout
abstract: The plan for a bailout of Cyprus has a lot to do with the particulars of that country, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes. | A richer offer for Dell may not readily materialize. | The penalty SAC Capital is paying does not end its possible legal troubles. | The Senate Banking Committee meets to consider the nomination of Mary Jo White to head the S.E.C.
lead_paragraph: The European plan to take money from bank depositors to help pay for a bailout of Cyprus has set off alarm bells among some analysts and politicians. But the move, far from setting a precedent for other countries, has a lot to do with the particulars of Cyprus, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: Allegations of War Crimes in Sri Lanka Shake Indian Government
keywords: ['Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Tamil Nadu’s D.M.K. party wants the government to push Sri Lanka to investigate.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI– The Congress Party faced a new crisis on Tuesday after a southern political party threatened to withdraw from the governing coalition if India did not join an international push to investigate alleged war crimes in Sri Lanka.

headline: In Performance: Judy Kuhn of ‘Passion’
abstract: Ms. Kuhn sings “Loving You” from the Classic Stage Company revival of this Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s musical “Passion,” set in 19th-century Italy, tells an unlikely love story: Giorgio, a young army captain with a beautiful mistress, is changed by the obsessive love that Fosca, an invalid he meets while serving at a mountain outpost, has for him. In this number from the Classic Stage Company revival, Fosca, played by Judy Kuhn, sings “Loving You,” in which she tells Giorgio that her love for him “is not a choice, and not much reason to rejoice.” Ms. Kuhn is accompanied on cello by Mairi Dorman-Phaneuf; the arrangement is by Rob Berman, the show’s musical director. “Passion” continues through April 19.

headline: Subjunctivitis
abstract: Granted, the subjunctive mood is a bit more arcane than some of our other common grammar problems, like subject-verb agreement. Still, it’s a sign of polish and precision to get this right. The subjunctive is most often used in contrary-to-fact conditions and for wishes and other hypothetical expressions.
lead_paragraph: The subjunctive mood is a bit more arcane than other entries on our list of favorite grammar gaffes, like subject-verb agreement. Still, it’s a sign of polish and precision to get this right. The subjunctive is most often used in contrary-to-fact conditions and for wishes and other hypothetical expressions.

headline: Taxing Deposits in Cyprus
abstract: A plan to tax bank depositors in Cyprus sets off alarms.
lead_paragraph: A plan to tax bank depositors in Cyprus sets off alarms.

headline: Opinion Report: Cypriot Bank Deposits
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: The Dunning-Kruger-Madoff Effect
abstract: Nothing will shake the right-wing faith.
lead_paragraph: Via Mark Thoma, Hale Stewart is bemused by John Hinderaker of PowerLine. As Stewart notes, Hinderaker begins by asserting that everyone knows that an economic crisis is coming — which apparently means everyone he talks to — then rolls out just about every one of the myths that have been proved wrong again and again by events, from the looming debt crisis to the imminent takeoff of inflation.

headline: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: Music and Dance
abstract: Musicians and artists often transcend their nations, borrowing from others’ cultures and making new hybrids
lead_paragraph: The grand cities of Mumbai and New York differ from each other in a million ways, but are brought together by a few common strands – their entrepreneurial spirit, their dynamic “always on-the-go” nature, their lively sidewalks, their gorgeous coastlines, the diversity of their residents who bring unique culture and religion and their vibrant music scene.

headline: Boeing and Ryanair Agree to a Deal for 175 New Jets
abstract: The contract for 737s, most likely at a discount from the $15.6 billion list price, will allow the European low-cost airline to increase its fleet to 400 planes.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Tuesday that it had signed an order for 175 single-aisle 737s, its biggest deal so far this year, from the European low-cost carrier Ryanair.

headline: Committed, Sort Of
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman in Chelsea hears a trendy word for a person who has a significant other and then some.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Tuesday Reading: Lost Sleep Can Lead to Weight Gain
abstract: Lost sleep can lead to weight gain, a new approach to hip surgery, hotel guests check in without a front desk and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Cogan, Taylor, and the Confidence Fairy
abstract: Still at it.
lead_paragraph: Ugh. And I say that advisedly. John Cogan and John Taylor have a piece in the WSJ (where else) arguing that the latest Ryan budget would actually be expansionary, because confidence! It’s as if all the experience of recent years, in which the confidence fairy has yet to make an appearance, hasn’t happened.

headline: Expat Fury at Cyprus ‘Bank Raid’
abstract: Thousands chose Cyprus for a quiet retirement. Now, the euro crisis threatens to dent their peace of mind, and their savings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Thousands of expatriates living in Cyprus may be having second thoughts about picking the Mediterranean island as their retirement home.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ABC Works on a Streaming App and British Newspapers Protest Regulations
abstract: The Walt Disney Company is developing an app that will live stream ABC programming on digital devices, British newspapers protest a new regulatory agency, and the pace of Hollywood’s biggest films often remains glacial, even as other media speed up.
lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company is working on an app that would stream ABC programming to the tablets and phones of cable and satellite subscribers, Brian Stelter reports. ABC would be the first of the American broadcaster to provide such an app, and it is likely to result in a mixture of awe and fear from other networks. Disney already has streaming apps for content from ESPN and the Disney Channel, but special complexities exist for networks like ABC because of older contracts with companies that produce its shows and local stations, which might feel threatened by the app. It is not yet clear what the app would mean for online streaming services like Hulu, which does not require viewers to subscribe and has grown increasingly marginalized as its parent companies (including Disney) seek more lucrative revenue streams.

headline: Malone Takes a Step Back Into Cable With Charter Stake
abstract: Liberty Media agreed on Tuesday to buy a 27.3 percent stake in the cable services provider Charter Communications for $2.6 billion, in the latest deal by the billionaire John C. Malone.
lead_paragraph: 10:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: U.S. Says Laos Is Blocking an Inquiry Into 3 Missing Men
abstract: An American team was prevented from gathering information about the disappearance of two citizens and a resident of the United States, Ambassador Karen B. Stewart said.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The American ambassador to Laos said on Tuesday that the Laotian authorities had blocked a United States investigation into the disappearance of two citizens and a resident of the United States.

headline: Southwest Broadens Approach in New Campaign
abstract: In an initiative to begin on Tuesday, Southwest Airlines is replacing its longtime humorous advertising approach with a smoother, more polished tack.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines, for the first time in many years, is making major changes in how it presents itself to current and potential customers.

headline: A Modest Proposal
abstract: Right now, covering up seems way sexier and far more modern than baring it all.
lead_paragraph: Right now, covering up seems way sexier and far more modern than baring it all.

headline: Paul Spells Out His Plan for Immigration Overhaul
abstract: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, would first require assurances regarding border security, according to excerpts of remarks prepared for the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce.
lead_paragraph: Read an updated version of this post.

headline: U.S. Treasury Secretary and Chinese President Meet
abstract: A meeting between Secretary Jacob J. Lew and Xi Jinping was the first high-level encounter between U.S. and Chinese officials in Mr. Xi’s presidency.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Jacob J. Lew, the American Treasury secretary, met with President Xi Jinping of China on Tuesday in the first high-level encounter between American and Chinese officials since Mr. Xi assumed the presidency, and one that recognized sticking points in a relationship that has drifted in the last few months.

headline: Condoleezza Rice to Write Book for Henry Holt
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: The former secretary of state in the George W. Bush administration will examine the creation of democracy, drawing upon her career and personal life.
lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is writing a book that will examine the creation of democracy at home and abroad, drawing upon stories from her career and personal life, the publisher Henry Holt & Company said Tuesday.

headline: Times Names Berlin Chief and Editor for Europe
abstract: Richard W. Stevenson will move from the newspaper’s Washington bureau to take over supervision of European news from Paris. Alison Smale will become Berlin bureau chief.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times on Tuesday announced changes to its European operations, saying that Alison Smale would become Berlin bureau chief and Richard W. Stevenson would become Europe editor.

headline: Philippine Court Delays Law on Free Contraceptives for Poor
abstract: Supporters and opponents of the legislation for the poor, which was to take effect March 31, will argue their cases on June 18.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine Supreme Court on Tuesday temporarily halted a landmark law that would provide free contraception to poor women.

headline: Syria and Activists Trade Charges on Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Syrian government said rebels fired chemical weapons in Aleppo; activists accused the government of the same attack. Neither account was confirmed.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government and Syrian rebels traded accusations about a lethal attack in the northern province of Aleppo on Tuesday, in which each side in the country’s two-year-old conflict said the other had used chemical weapons.

headline: A San Francisco Classic: Vesuvio’s Bohemian Coffee
abstract: I visited 20 bars in four days in San Francisco. Here, a recipe for Vesuvio Cafe’s signature drink, the Bohemian Coffee.
lead_paragraph: I had to tell people to stop. After I put out an informal call for San Francisco bar recommendations for this month’s Drink column, I simply couldn’t visit the dozens of bars that people suggested. I’m sure I had to omit some of your favorites — chime in and let me know what those are — but 20 bars in four days was all I could manage. This time.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and Political Savvy
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: It was once essential for politicians to support “traditional” marriage. Now the opposite is the case.
lead_paragraph: Anyone wondering why Republicans such as Jon Huntsman and Rob Portman are suddenly announcing their support for gay marriage (and why the anti-gay marriage forum at the Conservative Political Action Convention last week was empty while the pro-marriage forum was packed) should take a look at this poll from ABC News and the Washington Post.

headline: 7 Marines Killed in Nevada Training Exercise
abstract: A mortar round explosion at a weapons depot used to train troops for Afghanistan left at least seven Marines dead and several injured.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seven Marines were killed and several others were injured when a mortar round unexpectedly exploded during a live-fire training exercise at a weapons depot in western Nevada, the military said Tuesday.

headline: A 1930s Beauty Contest With Shapely Horns and Fine Beards
abstract: After Prohibition ended, Central Park served as the stage for the Brewers Board of Trade to pick Mr. Manhattan, a billy goat that would go on to vie to be the mascot in a bock beer advertising poster.
lead_paragraph: You probably knew this already, but there was a time when there were regular goat beauty pageants in Central Park.

headline: You Don’t Dance With Your Face, or Do You?
abstract: Rashaun Mitchell’s “Interface” makes liberal use of facial expressions, but that’s not all that’s going on in this dance.
lead_paragraph: In contemporary dance, the face is largely unexplored territory. A neutral expression is the default, so as not to distract from what’s happening elsewhere.

headline: Civil Disobedience
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: San Francisco’s city attorney discusses why he challenged his state’s ban on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco’s city attorney discusses why he challenged his state’s ban on same-sex marriage.

headline: Q&A: Keeping Adobe Flash Player Secure
abstract: Although they can be annoying, Adobe’s frequent updates to its Flash player and other software can help keep your computer safer.
lead_paragraph: Q.

abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Jewish Daily Forward: What is kosher salt, exactly? And why do chefs like it so much? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Hitchcock’s Earliest Films to Tour U.S.
abstract: Newly restored Hitchcock silent films from the 1920 will go on tour in the United States.
lead_paragraph: With a film and TV movie about Alfred Hitchcock and even a new TV series based on his work, fans of the director have had a lot to check out recently. Now add nine more films, black-and-white silents that constitute his earliest-surviving work, which will be shown together on an American tour later this year.

headline: Away From the Bronx, Cano Takes On a More Vocal Role
abstract: Robinson Cano says he is still learning from his Yankees teammates, but his Dominican Republic manager at the World Baseball Classic says he has grown as a leader.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco

headline: Another New Album Coming From Justin Timberlake
abstract: The singer said he will release a companion volume to his new album, “The 20/20 Experience.”
lead_paragraph: Justin Timberlake says he plans to release new music in the near future: a second volume to his just-released album, “The 20/20 Experience.”

headline: A Gay Man at Midlife Ponders Being Lonely and ‘Invisible’
abstract: Advice on how to confront ageism in the gay community despite earlier losses and how to avoid being alone.
lead_paragraph: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners,” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Around the World in 60 Days
abstract: Our intrepid blogger is back with her Swedish club team after playing for the U.S. in friendly matches at home and competing in the Algarve Cup in Portugal.
lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Since the beginning of February, I’ve played in four states in the United States, three countries (soon to be four), and have reshuffled my suitcases almost as often as a casino worker shuffles cards. The sport might be called something different each place I travel, but the last two months of excitement have come together as fitting parts of my ascension to become a more complete player.

headline: Dismissing Concerns, Panel Backs White’s S.E.C. Nomination
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mary Jo White cleared an important hurdle to becoming head of the S.E.C., as all but one lawmaker on the Senate Banking Committee backed her nomination.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White cleared an important hurdle on her path to becoming a top Wall Street regulator when a panel of lawmakers overwhelmingly backed her nomination on Tuesday.

headline: The Gun Report: March 19, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Many readers have wondered when the gun violence death toll, post-Newtown, would surpass the death toll from the Sept. 11 attacks. It didn’t take long. According to Slate’s gun-death tracker, which we link to each day, an estimated 2,793 people have died as a result of gun violence since December 14, 2012. The recorded death toll of the Sept. 11 attacks stands at 2,752.

headline: Wanderlust in Repose
abstract: Part of the beauty of travel, stylistically speaking, is letting go of the restraints of the everyday for a more carefree look.
lead_paragraph: Part of the beauty of travel, stylistically speaking, is letting go of the restraints of the everyday for a more carefree look.

headline: Posters for Chefs, the New Rock Stars
abstract: An artist in Southern California who runs his own branding and design consulting company happens to have a thing for restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Whether we’re talking about San Francisco in the 1960s, during the early years of the Grateful Dead and Jefferson Airplane, or the alternative-rock scene that produced bands like Superchunk, Soundgarden and Pavement in the 1980s and ’90s, rock music has long been a fertile breeding ground for visual art.

headline: A Streak That Doesn’t Take the Spotlight
abstract: The Miami Heat have won 23 games in a row, an accomplishment that is overshadowed by the N.C.A.A. tournaments — and Tiger and Lindsey.
lead_paragraph: About the only thing you can fault the Miami Heat on these days is their lousy timing. Yes, the Heat’s 23-game winning streak is one to behold, no matter the time of year and yes, it certainly is a reason to tune in to games when the regular season usually turns to unwatchable mush. But there is so much out there clamoring for fans’ attention these days, the Heat are struggling to get the hype machine pointed squarely in their direction.

headline: Bringing Back the Dead
keywords: ['Biology and Biochemistry', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Genetic Engineering', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: A Stanford professor discusses the science and ethics of resurrecting extinct species.
lead_paragraph: A Stanford professor discusses the science and ethics of resurrecting extinct species.

headline: The States With the Highest Car Insurance Rates
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: An analysis from Insure.com finds Louisiana has the costliest car insurance premiums, on average, while Maine has the least expensive.
lead_paragraph: If you want cheap car insurance rates, it’s best not to live in Louisiana. Or Michigan.

headline: Queens Museum of Art to Be Renamed Amid Expansion
abstract: The cultural institution in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park is changing its name to the Queens Museum as it undergoes a $65-million, 50,000-square-foot expansion.
lead_paragraph: The 9,335-square-foot Panorama of New York City will still be there, but the familiar logo for the Queens Museum of Art will not. The cultural institution in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park is changing its name to the Queens Museum. The renaming accompanies a planned $65-million, 50,000-square-foot expansion that is scheduled to be finished in October.

headline: Shorter Cyprus
abstract: Laundering, not just of money.
lead_paragraph: So, a quick summary: The Germans don’t want a Cyprus collapse / exit from the euro, but they also don’t want the spectacle of German taxpayers bailing out Russian money-launderers. So what they did instead was blackmail Cyprus into having Cypriot depositors bail out Russian money-launderers. That way Germany’s hands are clean.

headline: In Charter, Malone Returns to His Roots
abstract: As The New York Times wrote in 1997, “a day without a deal is like a day without sunshine,” to Mr. Malone. Here is a look at some of his memorable moves.
lead_paragraph: John C. Malone is returning to his roots.

headline: Image of the Day: March 19
abstract: More than 35 people were killed in a bus accident in Maharashtra.

headline: M.L.S. Plays On, Minus 38
abstract: Thirty-eight players on clubs in Major League Soccer are off on national team duty this week.
lead_paragraph: Squeezed on all sides by scheduling conflicts and an unforgiving worldwide soccer calendar, Major League Soccer will play on with  eight games this weekend as leagues around the world take a break on two official FIFA dates for international matches.

headline: A Witness to 4 Iraqi Wars, but No More
keywords: ['Awakening Movement (Iraq)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mohammed Hussein, a former head of the newsroom in The New York Times’s Baghdad bureau, recalls living through four wars in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Hussein is a former head of the newsroom in The New York Times’s Baghdad bureau. He fled to Syria in 2007 at the height of the sectarian fighting, returned in 2008 when the situation improved, then moved to the United States with his family in 2010 under a program in which Iraqi interpreters working with Americans could receive special immigrant visas. His previous blog posts can be read here.

headline: Judge Approves Sale of Rights to Hostess Brands, Including Twinkies
abstract: A bankruptcy judge has approved the sales of several major Hostess Brands product lines, including Twinkies, fetching about $800 million for the bankrupt baker.
lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge on Tuesday approved the sales of several major Hostess Brands product lines, including Twinkies, fetching about $800 million for the various pieces of the bankrupt baking company and clearing the way for it to be eventually wound down.

headline: It’s Mr. Hell on the Line
abstract: In his autobiography, the writer, rocker and provocateur Richard Hell chronicles his coming of age as a luminary of the first wave of punk.
lead_paragraph: The two men who founded the seminal proto-punk band Television in 1973 had almost everything young rockers need: ambition, attitude, brooding good looks and a modicum of talent. Here’s what they lacked: names that evoked their malcontented essences.

headline: Doctors Urge F.D.A. to Restrict Caffeine in Energy Drinks
abstract: Caffeine levels in the drinks “pose serious potential health risks,” specifically to children and young adults, according to a letter from 18 doctors and public health experts.
lead_paragraph: A group of 18 doctors, researchers and public health experts jointly urged the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday to take action on energy drinks to protect adolescents and children from the possible risks of consuming high amounts of caffeine.

headline: Hal Steinbrenner Plots New Course for Yankees
abstract: The Yankees’ managing general partner talks about working for his father, how he flew planes to escape his father, his plan to spend less on payroll than his father and the weather.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — On Oct. 17, in the hours before Game 4 of the American League Championship Series was scheduled to begin, a steady, gloomy rain fell on Detroit. Sitting in his hotel room, Hal Steinbrenner watched the downpour and frowned. And then his phone rang.

headline: Garbled Texting as a Sign of Stroke
abstract: Doctors in Detroit encountered the unusual case of a 40-year-old patient who had no trouble reading, writing or understanding language. His only consistent problem was that he had lost the ability to type coherent text messages on his phone.
lead_paragraph: Slurred and incoherent speech is one of the classic signs of a stroke. But new research finds that another symptom may be garbled and disjointed text messages, which could provide early clues to the onset of a stroke.

headline: Marie Ponsot Wins Lucrative Poetry Prize
abstract: The Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize for lifetime achievement will go to Ms. Ponsot, 91.
lead_paragraph: Marie Ponsot, a poet known for her bold reimaginings of traditional forms, has been awarded the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, one of the most prestigious (and richest) in poetry, which comes with a $100,000 award.

headline: Demystifying Taylor’s Confidence Fairy (Wonkish)
abstract: The (dubious) assumptions behind the results.
lead_paragraph: I was wondering, but Noah Smith does the work.

headline: Iraqis’ Pain Never Abates as Attacks Kill Dozens
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Nineteen bombs and an assassination on Tuesday served as a reminder of the violence that regularly afflicts Iraq a decade after the American-led invasion.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq closed a painful decade just as it began: with explosions reverberating around the capital.

headline: Debevoise & Plimpton’s Trusts and Estates Group Finds a New Home
abstract: Loeb & Loeb has hired the group of trusts and estates lawyers from Debevoise & Plimpton, which had decided last year to eliminate the practice.
lead_paragraph: In December, the trusts and estates lawyers at Debevoise & Plimpton received shocking news. The law firm’s leadership said it had decided to eliminate its trusts and estates practice, and instructed the group’s lawyers to look for a new home.

headline: Settlement of Class Action Against Audi Gets Preliminary Approval
abstract: The settlement covers anyone in the United States who leased or bought from Audi a 2002-6 A4 or A6 model with a continuously variable automatic transmission.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has given preliminary approval to settling a class-action suit over transmission problems on about 64,000 of Audi’s most popular models.

headline: Rand Paul to Speak at Iowa Republican Dinner
abstract: As his profile grows, Senator Rand Paul’s speech at Iowa Republicans’ Lincoln Day Dinner offers him an early chance to introduce himself to potential 2016 caucus-goers.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul will speak at the Iowa Republicans’ Lincoln Day Dinner in Cedar Rapids on May 10. The fund-raiser for the state party offers Mr. Paul an early chance to introduce himself to potential caucusgoers as he considers a bid in 2016.

headline: Port Authority, With Eye on Income, Will Pick Firm for Trade Center Observatory
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to approve a 15-year deal with Legends Hospitality Management that it says could yield the agency $875 million over the contract’s life.
lead_paragraph: New York’s newest and tallest observation deck will offer an interactive immersion in all things New York as it shuttles visitors 102 floors into the sky and provides panoramic views of the city and beyond, from the harbor to Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

headline: The Right Wine for Halibut
abstract: A good sauvignon blanc can show a spectrum of herbal and citrus flavors that complement the neutrality of halibut.
lead_paragraph: Halibut is the chardonnay of the fish family, essentially neutral in flavor but brilliant in transmitting external influences. In David Tanis’s recipe for halibut skewers with yogurt sauce, the dominant flavors will be the Turkish spices, along with the lemon, onion and cooling herbs.

headline: Samsung Speaks Up First About a Smart Watch
abstract: Samsung Electronics has made it clear that it is making a wristwatch, even as Apple is rumored to be working on a smart watch itself. It is a rare for a big tech company to voluntarily reveal a future product.
lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics has made it clear that it is making a wristwatch, even as Apple is rumored to be working on a smart watch itself. It is rare for a big tech company to voluntarily reveal a future product.

headline: ‘Anna Nicole,’ as in Smith, Is Part of City Opera’s Coming Season
abstract: The company will also offer the American premiere of a work by Johann Christian Bach.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera announced on Tuesday that its 2013-2014 season would feature the American premiere of two operas, “Anna Nicole,” by Mark-Anthony Turnage, based on the paparazzi-filled life and death of Anna Nicole Smith, and  “Endimione,” a little-known and rarely staged work composed by Johann Christian Bach in 1772.

headline: Swirls of Stain, the Art of N.C.A.A. Branding
abstract: Universities and college conferences, and even the N.C.A.A. itself, increasingly see the basketball court as one of the last, untapped frontiers for image making.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The basketball court at the Mountain West Conference tournament was like no other, impossible to ignore, which is exactly the point. Stained in at least four hues of brown, it featured deep contrasts of arcs and boxes and jags, including a range of snow-capped peaks stretching the length of the floor.

headline: Judge Proposes a National Lawyers Corps to Help Immigrants
abstract: Robert A. Katzmann, a federal appellate judge in New York, has warned that if immigration reform is enacted, millions of people will need legal assistance. Now he has an idea for providing it.
lead_paragraph: As Congress takes up immigration reform, Robert A. Katzmann, a federal appellate judge in New York, has been looking beyond the debates and envisioning a crisis.

headline: Transocean Chief Admits Crew Shortcomings in Oil Spill
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The admission from the chief of the company that owned the Deepwater Horizon rig goes to the heart of the trial to assign responsibility for the 2010 gulf disaster.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The chief executive of the company that owned the Deepwater Horizon oil rig acknowledged in court on Tuesday that his crew should have done more to avert the 2010 oil well blowout that left 11 dead and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches along the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Rand Paul on Immigration
abstract: The Times’s Michael D. Shear talks about Senator Rand Paul’s proposals on immigration.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Michael D. Shear talks about Senator Rand Paul’s proposals on immigration.

headline: It’s a Bag, It’s a Desk, It’s Got Geek Appeal
abstract: Considering what it is – a bag that converts into a standing desk for the iPad – shouldn’t the $170 Strotter Platforma look much more clumsyr?
lead_paragraph: Considering its purpose – a bag that coverts to a standing desk for the iPad – shouldn’t the Strotter Platforma look much, much nerdier?

headline: Lesson Learned After Financial Crisis: Nothing Much Has Changed
keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The investigation into JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar trading loss shows that bankers are not acting cautious and regulators remain docile.
lead_paragraph: People have learned their lesson.

headline: The Truth About Working From Home
abstract: A group of owners offer support to Marissa Mayer. Said one owner: “There’s a generation of people who are like, ‘I want to go kayaking. Can I kayak today, instead?”
lead_paragraph: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about the pros and cons of allowing workers to do their jobs from home.

headline: What If You Hate Mountains?
abstract: In a recent report from the World Economic Forum analyzing 140 countries’ competitiveness in travel and tourism, Switzerland ranked first.
lead_paragraph: In a recent report from the World Economic Forum analyzing 140 countries’ competitiveness in travel and tourism, Switzerland (above) ranked first, and the United States was sixth. The factors that determined a country’s ranking include its tourism infrastructure, appeal to business travelers and friendliness (in that last category, Iceland scored high marks and Bolivia finished last).

headline: Creamy Banana Pudding With Pistachio Crumble
abstract: The banana pudding at Fedora in the West Village is irresistible: sweet, creamy, salty, crunchy and all too easy to lap up.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: New ‘Guy,’ New ‘Girl’ Joining ‘Once’
abstract: Ben Hope and Laura Dreyfuss will succeed Steve Kazee and Cristin Milioti in the musical’s lead roles.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award-winning Broadway musical “Once” is having a cast makeover. Sunday will mark the last scheduled appearance of the show’s Tony-winning star, Steve Kazee, and his colleagues Cristin Milioti, Elizabeth A. Davis and Will Connolly.

headline: These Chicks Are Not of the Easter Basket Variety
abstract: At the Bronx Zoo, three hatchlings of the maleo, a rare chickenlike bird indigenous to Indonesia, emerged from their shells after about 70 days of careful incubation.
lead_paragraph: After about 70 days of carefully controlled incubation beneath deep river sand, heated electrically from below, three rare maleo chicks have hatched at the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Jeter, His Ankle Still Stiff, Is Scratched From Lineup
abstract: Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter, still recovering from surgery on his left ankle, said he has been told that the stiffness and the soreness were to be expected.
lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Derek Jeter described his mood as more frustrated than concerned, although the Yankees may feel otherwise. He complained Tuesday about more than the normal stiffness in his surgically repaired left ankle and was scratched from the starting lineup against the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Broadway ‘Cat’ Revival Cools at Box Office
abstract: The revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” starring Scarlett Johansson, may still recoup its capitalization on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: This is the season of star vehicles on Broadway – Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson, Tom Hanks, Alec Baldwin, Bette Midler – but not all of them are burning rubber at the box office.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Psychiatric Diagnoses
abstract: A psychiatrist addresses critics who say diagnoses are often stigmatizing and subjective. Readers are invited to reply.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What the Stats Say About This Year’s Tournament
abstract: Key statistical categories identify Duke and St. Louis as potential early upset victims in the N.C.A.A. tournament, but Gonzaga is looking good.
lead_paragraph: Last season, The Quad published a study that showed field goal percentage defense, assist-to-turnover ratio and rebounding margin are the three statistics most correlated to college basketball success.  Using that information, we identified Duke, Missouri and Michigan as vulnerable teams entering the 2012 N.C.A.A. tournament.  All three lost their first game.

headline: Misunderstanding IS-LM (Wonkish and Unimportant)
abstract: No, I didn’t make an elementary logical error.
lead_paragraph: Some readers have asked me to reply to this Steve Keen piece claiming that I don’t understand the IS-LM model. Sigh. I really don’t want to spend time fighting against people with whom I don’t really have a current policy disagreement — and this is so silly, besides. But to satisfy those who are for some reason nervous, here’s a brief explanation of why somebody doesn’t understand IS-LM.

headline: To Many Yogurt Fans, It’s All Greek
abstract: Greek yogurt, now produced under a number of name brands, is catching on in restaurants as an ingredient that’s sumptuous and easy to use.
lead_paragraph: You know Greek yogurt is having its moment when an artisan in Brooklyn is making it from an old family recipe, downtown mixologists are using it in a cocktail and chefs are pairing it with fried brussels sprouts and green cauliflower.

headline: Blair Says Iraq Would Be ‘Worse Than Syria’ Now, if Antiwar Critics Had Prevailed
abstract: Defending Britain’s participation in the American-led invasion of Iraq, former Prime Minister Tony Blair told the BBC that Iraq “would look a lot more like Syria, and probably a lot worse than Syria,” today if the war had not taken place.
lead_paragraph: Defending Britain’s participation in the American-led invasion of Iraq, former Prime Minister Tony Blair told the BBC that Iraq “would look a lot more like Syria, and probably a lot worse than Syria,” today if the war had not taken place.

headline: Spam Texts Vex Me and Make Me Feel Old
abstract: Spam texts can be both annoying and misdirected.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t lived in Atlanta for several years. But my cellphone, which still has an Atlanta phone number, apparently maintains a very active social life there. Every weekend it gets invitations to wild parties throughout the city, including a hip place called “The Mansion Elan.”

headline: Raising Children Who Will Speak Up to Prevent Rape, Not Defend It
abstract: Though there is a verdict in the Steubenville case, we’re a long way from the end of the culture that allowed it to happen.
lead_paragraph: I spent Sunday morning at a birthday party for one of my son’s classmates. As the kids gathered around a paper-covered table to begin an art project, I stood off to the side, furiously typing away on my phone as I scoured my Twitter feed for news of the verdict in the Steubenville rape case.

headline: Mariinsky Theater Plans Star-Studded Opening of New Opera House
abstract: A gala on May 2 will include Plácido Domingo and Anna Netrebko, among others.
lead_paragraph: The Mariinsky Theater in Russia announced on Tuesday plans for a three-day celebration to mark the opening of the new Mariinsky II opera house in St. Petersburg in May.  An opening-night gala conducted by the theater’s artistic and general director, Valery Gergiev, on May 2 will feature performances by an array of stars that include Plácido Domingo, Olga Borodina, Ekaterina Gubanova, Anna Netrebko, René Pape and Yekaterina Kondaurova.

headline: For the G.O.P., It’s Not Just the Message
abstract: If Republican leaders want a broader appeal, they should re-examine their divisive policies.
lead_paragraph: The battering that Republican candidates suffered in 2012 — particularly among women and minorities — seems finally to have worked its way into the party’s cerebral cortex. For weeks, party leaders like Eric Cantor have talked about broadening the party’s appeal, and on Monday, Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, unveiled a lengthy report that took the party to task for alienating large segments of the public.

headline: House Ethics Panel Finds Cause to Investigate 2 Lawmakers
abstract: The committee found credible evidence that a Republican from Alaska and a Democrat from New Jersey improperly used campaign money for personal expenses, among other abuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Ethics Committee has found credible evidence that two lawmakers — a Republican from Alaska and a Democrat from New Jersey — improperly used campaign money for personal expenses, among other abuses.

headline: Solid as a Rock
abstract: In the rarefied world of haute couture jewelry, Taffin’s designer James de Givenchy offers a unique combination of elegance and edginess.
lead_paragraph: In the rarefied world of haute couture jewelry, Taffin’s designer James de Givenchy offers a unique combination of elegance and edginess. It’s a mix he loves, and lives by.

headline: The Revolt of the (Republican) Elites
abstract: On the Republican National Committee’s vision for G.O.P. reform.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee’s extended autopsy on the G.O.P.’s 2012 defeat, which officially abjures policy recommendations but then goes on to nudge the party toward supporting comprehensive immigration reform and gay marriage, is the highest-profile distillation of what I described last week as the “donorist” view of how the Republican Party needs to change. As Ramesh Ponnuru suggests, this the party elite’s vision of domestic policy reform, reflecting the views of people who are already “more likely to favor same-sex marriage and comprehensive immigration reform on principle,” and who don’t “tend to have any major problems with the Republican economic agenda and do not believe it needs to be rethought in any serious way.” Or to put it another way: If you believe that Mitt Romney’s economic platform and “you built that” rhetoric would be the basis for a durable majority if they weren’t associated with the religious right and anti-immigration sentiment, then this is the vision of Republican reform for you.

headline: MSNBC Announces Replacement for Chris Hayes
abstract: Steve Kornacki, a Salon editor and co-host of “The Cycle” will take over “Up” on weekends.
lead_paragraph: MSNBC on Tuesday named Steve Kornacki the new host of “Up,” a weekend morning panel discussion program that is about to be vacated by its original host, Chris Hayes.

headline: A Closer Look at Obama’s Plan to Pay for Energy Research With Drilling Fees
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Natural Gas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Research', 'Royalties', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Two energy analysts assess President Obama’s energy research trust fund.
lead_paragraph: As was discussed here last Friday, President Obama has proposed using a tiny portion of federal revenues from offshore oil and gas production to build an “Energy Security Trust” to pay for the kinds of tough or longer-term energy research projects that the private sector tends to neglect. (A White House explanatory graphic is here.)

headline: Former Governor Advances in South Carolina Race
abstract: Mark Sanford won enough primary votes to qualify for a runoff between Republicans for a Congressional seat, while Democrats overwhelmingly picked Elizabeth Colbert Busch.
lead_paragraph: The first chapter in a wild race to fill a Congressional seat in South Carolina was written Tuesday when former Gov. Mark Sanford staged something of a comeback in a Republican field crowded with 16 candidates, and Democrats overwhelmingly picked Elizabeth Colbert Busch, a businesswoman on leave from Clemson University.

headline: Little Resistance on the Heat’s Path
abstract: Going from 23 consecutive wins to the N.B.A. record of 33 sounds daunting for the Miami Heat, until one considers the weak Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — LeBron James could not be slowed by the personal demons that once haunted him in the most hostile of N.B.A. arenas, or by the ghosts of famous Celtics past, or by a 43-point scorer suitably named Green.

headline: College Groups Connect to Fight Sexual Assault
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Campaigns against sexual assault on campuses have connected people who, while sometimes seeking advice elsewhere, have largely learned from one another.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated and angry over the handling of sexual assault cases at Occidental College in Los Angeles, a group of students and faculty members recently decided to take the matter to the federal government as a civil rights case. Few people had explored this legal terrain, so the Occidental group reached out to women at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who had filed a similar complaint — which this month prompted a federal investigation — for insights on how to press their case.

headline: European Art Fair May Join With Sotheby’s for Chinese Sales
abstract: The organizers of the European Fine Art Fair are in talks with Sotheby’s about holding a high-end art and antiques fair in China.
lead_paragraph: In what might seem like a pairing of competitive bedfellows, the organizers of the European Fine Art Fair – that 10-day event going on through Sunday in Maastricht, the Netherlands – announced on Tuesday that they were in talks with Sotheby’s about holding a high-end art and antiques fair in China. The new event, which would be called Tefaf Beijing 2014, would be “planned as a collaboration between Maastricht, the Netherlands-based event, and Sotheby’s recently forged joined venture with China’s state-owned Beijing Ge-Hua Cultural Development Group,’’ the European Fine Art Fair said in an e-mail.

headline: Charges Upgraded in Hit-Run Crash That Killed Couple
abstract: Brooklyn prosecutors cited reckless behavior in bringing second-degree manslaughter charges against Julio Acevedo.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury has indicted the driver accused in a fatal hit-and-run crash this month on new charges of second-degree manslaughter, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Tuesday.

headline: A SWAT Team for Waterlogged Artwork
abstract: When floods, fires or earthquakes threaten art and artifacts, the American Institute for Conservation’s emergency response team swoops in.
lead_paragraph: THE patient was in rough shape.

headline: Inviting Tropical Fruits to Stick Around
abstract: With the season for mangoes and pineapples finally arriving, preserve them while they are at their best.
