lead_paragraph: The exotic tastes of tropical fruit evoke an endless summer of ocean breezes, sandy beaches and drinks with umbrellas. But just like their colder-climate cousins (say, blueberries and peaches), these fruits have their season.

headline: Justices Permit Resale of Copyrighted Imports
keywords: ['Textbooks', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The court ruled that owners of goods from overseas can do what they like with them, just as they can with those bought in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a pair of decisions issued on Tuesday, the Supreme Court made it easier to import textbooks and other copyrighted products from abroad and made it harder for plaintiffs in class-action suits to stay out of federal court.

headline: An Interior Design Showroom Featuring Lalique Maison
abstract: The Art Deco-inspired collection took two-and-a-half years to develop and includes furniture, lighting, bedding, tabletop items and even a backgammon set.
lead_paragraph: Lalique has unveiled an interior design showroom in New York featuring Lalique Maison, a collection of furniture and accessories by Tina Green and Pietro Mingarelli. Lady Green is the wife of the British billionaire Sir Philip Green and the creative director of Argent, an interior design firm with offices in London and Monaco. She took on Lalique Maison after Silvio Denz, the chairman of Lalique, toured a yacht she had outfitted with a generous number of his products.

headline: Living in the Columbia Street Waterfront District
abstract: The lively Brooklyn neighborhood lies west of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway, bound by it and a working harbor.
lead_paragraph: The lively Brooklyn neighborhood lies west of the Brooklyn Queens Expressway, bound by it and a working harbor.

headline: Between the Drink and the B.Q.E.
abstract: New condos are popping up, joining hundred-year-old row houses, converted industrial buildings, and multifamily urban-renewal town houses built in the ’80s and later.
lead_paragraph: A cynic might call this Mosesville. Ever since the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel were built in the 1940s, courtesy of the powerful city planner Robert Moses, the semi-industrial strip of South Brooklyn now called the Columbia Street Waterfront District has been a skinny, scruffy island of a neighborhood cut off from adjacent areas.

headline: Ducks Re-Sign Perry
abstract: Anaheim signed forward Corey Perry to a long-term extension, giving the Ducks little cap room to keep a supporting cast together.
lead_paragraph: Scratch Corey Perry’s name off the list of trade rumors as the N.H.L.’s April 3 deadline approaches. Anaheim signed Perry to an eight-year, $69 million contract extension late Monday night.

headline: No Silver Bullet for Reaching Fuel and Emissions Goals, Study Says
abstract: Tougher fuel economy standards and surcharges for inefficient vehicles are among options cited for reducing fuel consumption.
lead_paragraph: The United States could possibly achieve the goal of an 80 percent reduction in oil use and greenhouse gas emissions from cars and small trucks by 2050, but it will not be easy, a National Research Council report said.

headline: Say Goodbye to the Assault Weapons Ban
abstract: It was always a longshot, but now it’s done.
lead_paragraph: Fans of military-style assault weapons can stop worrying — their gun lobby has done its work, and all but assured that Congress will not pass a ban on their dangerous toys.

headline: Decision Point: Understanding the U.S.’s Dilemma Over North Korea
abstract: In this lesson, students will play the role of White House advisers, exploring policy options and recommending the best strategy for preventing war in East Asia.

headline: In Mayor’s Race, Sources of Contributions Shift
abstract: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn has raised the most money in the race for New York City mayor. But compared with 2001, the last time there was no incumbent running, contributions from wealthy Manhattan districts are way down.
lead_paragraph: #nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1{position:relative;width:480px;height:495px;}.nytg-aiAbs{position:absolute;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 p{font-family:arial,helvetica,sans-serif;font-size:13px;line-height:18px;margin:0;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle0 {font-size:12px;line-height:16px;padding-bottom:3px;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle1 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;text-transform:uppercase;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle2 {font-size:11px;line-height:8px;text-transform:uppercase;text-align:center;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle3 {font-size:11px;line-height:8px;text-transform:uppercase;text-align:right;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle4 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;color:#231f20;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle5 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;font-weight:bold;text-transform:uppercase;color:#000000;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle6 {font-size:11px;line-height:13px;text-align:center;color:#231f20;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle7 {font-size:10px;line-height:8px;text-align:right;color:#020200;}#nytg-nycmayorforweb-artboard_1 .nytg-aiPstyle8 {font-size:10px;line-height:8px;color:#020200;}

headline: Malone’s Minority Report
abstract: The cable pioneer John C. Malone has a history of parlaying minority stakes in companies into advantageous deals for himself.
lead_paragraph: John C. Malone has slipped through the door again. The American cable magnate is buying 27 percent of Charter Communications from three buyout firms for $2.6 billion. He’s no garden-variety minority owner, though. Even heavyweights like Rupert Murdoch and Barry Diller can attest to Mr. Malone’s cunning use of smaller stakes. Charter investors should keep their guards up.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: Desnuda, a larger edition of the inventive East Village cevicheria, opens in the East Village; Melibea arrives in Greenwich Village with a creative take on Mediterranean food.
lead_paragraph: Opening

headline: More Injuries for Knicks, but the News Isn’t All Bad
abstract: Forward Kurt Thomas may need two to four weeks to recover from his right foot injury, but center Tyson Chandler will need only about a week to recover from a bulging disk in his neck.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks issued two more injury updates Tuesday, involving a bulging disk, a stress reaction and a stress fracture. In the context of this freakishly painful Knicks season, it practically qualified as a good-news report.

headline: Off Broadway Theater To Be Named After Lynn Redgrave
abstract: The Culture Project’s main stage theater will be named after the British actress, who performed there several times.
lead_paragraph: The Culture Project’s main stage theater at 45 Bleecker Street is being renamed the Lynn Redgrave Theater to honor the British actress, who died in 2010.

headline: Senator Is Angry Over Bill’s Exclusion of Assault Gun Ban
abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein of California deplored the loss of a measure she had fought desperately to keep in a gun control bill the Senate is to consider next month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who 35 years ago discovered the bullet-riddled body of the gay activist Harvey Milk, reacted with anger on Tuesday that gun control legislation the Senate is to consider next month will not include the reinstatement of an assault weapons ban, a measure she had fought desperately to keep.

headline: By The Numbers
abstract: We chart the success of the architect Peter Marino, who has been riding high since his work for Barneys New York twenty years ago.
lead_paragraph: We chart the success of the architect Peter Marino, who has been riding high since his work for Barneys New York twenty years ago.

headline: Lizard Olympics
abstract: When comparing two lizard species that seem to share traits but that may have evolved independently, sometimes you have to go to the video replay.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
abstract: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Times’s Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the men’s basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Times’s Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the men’s basketball tournament.

headline: U.S. Said to Look Into Microsoft Bribery Allegations
abstract: The S.E.C. and Justice Department are investigating accusations involving the company in China, Italy and Romania, a person briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Federal authorities are examining Microsoft’s involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry.

headline: Michelle Shocked Draws Fire for Anti-Gay Remarks
abstract: Some venues have canceled upcoming shows after the folk singer’s remarks about homosexuality at a performance in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Shocked, the punk folk-singer, liberal activist and born-again Christian, has drawn fire for an anti-gay tirade in San Francisco over the weekend, during which she said God hates homosexuals.

headline: Turning Down a Deposit Tax
abstract: The Times’s Liz Alderman discusses next steps after Cyprus rejects a proposed bailout for its troubled banks.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Liz Alderman discusses next steps after Cyprus rejects a proposed bailout for its troubled banks.

headline: This Week’s Links
abstract: NYT developers pass along their recommendations from around the web.
lead_paragraph: This is a weekly series in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Photo Replay: March 19
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including wrestling in Tbilisi, Georgia, and curling in Riga, Latvia.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including wrestling in Tbilisi, Georgia, and curling in Riga, Latvia.

headline: Baked Beans With Pomegranate Molasses, Walnuts and Chard
abstract: Sweet baked beans with Persian flavors.
lead_paragraph: This Iranian-inspired rendition of baked beans is sweetened with pomegranate molasses, which you can find in Middle Eastern markets.

headline: Leader of the Pack
abstract: We chart the success of the architect Peter Marino, who has been riding high since his work for Barneys New York twenty years ago.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, the architect Peter Marino vaulted onto the style world’s A-list with his limestone-clad design for the Barneys New York flagship, helping ignite a mania for luxurious retail environments that endures to this day. Hundreds of boutiques later, for clients like Louis Vuitton and Dior, Marino has nearly doubled his business in the last two years and is riding higher than ever — more often than not on a Harley-Davidson.

headline: Black-Eyed Pea Soup or Stew With Pomegranate and Chard
abstract: A hearty Persian-inspired dish that can be a soup or a stew.
lead_paragraph: This is another dish inspired by a recipe in Louisa Shafia’s book “The New Persian Kitchen.” You can use more or less water, depending on whether you want the dish to have the consistency of a soup or a thick stew. It’s hearty, and the most beautiful pink hue.

headline: Statue of Liberty to Reopen by July 4
abstract: The statue has been closed since Hurricane Sandy damaged several structures on Liberty Island, including the ferry dock.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:52 p.m. | The Statue of Liberty, which has been closed to visitors since Hurricane Sandy struck and open for only one day since the fall of 2011, will reopen by the Fourth of July holiday, federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: Snedeker Plans a Return at the Arnold Palmer
abstract: After sustaining an injury at Pebble Beach, Brandt Snedeker will compete this week at the Arnold Palmer Invitational in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The fastest starter out of the gate in 2013 returns to action at the Arnold Palmer Invitational this week after spending the past five weeks on his couch in Nashville.

headline: Rebutting the Contention That Small Is Better for Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deposit Insurance', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In relation to the economy it supports, the United States banking system is relatively small compared with those of other developed countries, so breaking up banks doesn’t seem justified, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm Paul Hastings and is writing “The Crisis Not Wasted – The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.’s First Five Hundred Days,” a book on the creation of modern financial regulation during President Franklin Roosevelt’s first term of office.

headline: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
abstract: A discussion about the men’s basketball tournament and strategies to win your tournament pool.
lead_paragraph: FiveThirtyEight’s Nate Silver spoke with Megan Liberman on Tuesday about our forecast for the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, strategies to win your tournament pool and the end of the overwhelming favorite in college hoops.

headline: Record Ticket Sales for Bowie Exhibition in London
abstract: An exhibition devoted to the career of David Bowie at the Victoria and Albert Museum has sold over 42,000 advance tickets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “David Bowie Is,” a major retrospective of the British singer’s career and cultural influence, which opens at the Victoria and Albert Museum on Saturday, has sold over 42,000 advance tickets, more than double the amount generated by any previous exhibition at the museum.

headline: Large White Bean, Tuna and Spinach Salad
abstract: A substantial salad that’s good at any time of year.
lead_paragraph: You could use canned cannellini beans for this, but I love the size and texture of large white limas. I don’t soak limas because the skins tend to detach and the beans fall apart when you cook them. You want them intact for this, but you also need to make sure to cook them all the way through.

headline: The Retro-Lean-Back Snow Day
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The life of a parent is ever-evolving, and we should resist defining ourselves by phrases like “Retro Wife,” “Opt-Out” or “Lean In.”
lead_paragraph: It’s a snow day here.

headline: Judge Sets Court Date in ‘Spider-Man’ Trial
abstract: Despite agreeing in principle on a settlement, the producers and former director of the show have not been able to hammer out final details in their dispute over copyright and profits.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has set a May 28 trial date for the director Julie Taymor, Bono and the Edge of U2, and the producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” to battle in court over a lawsuit stemming from the spectacular implosion of their years-long collaboration on the show.

headline: Wheelies: The Make-Some-Noise Edition
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: A proposed rule to establish minimum noise levels for electric vehicles would make them louder than some sports cars, lobbyists for automakers say.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Actress’s Suit Against IMDb for Publishing Her Actual Age Can Go to Trial
abstract: Junie Hoang, 41, argued that the database illegally used information to obtain her real age, exposing her to age discrimination in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Junie Hoang, the actress who sued Amazon and its Internet Movie Database unit for posting her age, can take her complaint — or at least some of it — to a jury.

headline: The House That Generosity Built: Staten Island Little League Plans Opener
abstract: Little League Fields on Staten Island were demolished by Hurricane Sandy. A group called Pitch In for Baseball did just that.
lead_paragraph: Opening Day arrives two weeks late for Staten Island Little League this season, but after Hurricane Sandy’s knockdown pitch, having any season is cause for celebration.

headline: Guggenheim Gets Grant to Commission Chinese Art
abstract: The Robert H. N. Ho Family Foundation has provided a $10 million grant to commission works from artists born in mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong or Macau.
lead_paragraph: For years now the Guggenheim Museum has been broadening its scope far beyond the Western world to places like South and Southeast Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and North Africa. Now it is extending its reach even further, embracing the art of China.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, chocolate at 2Beans, chef-made Peeps, the genuine black Périgord truffle and more.
lead_paragraph: To Shop: Chocolate for You, Coffee for Me

headline: If Those Dusty Common Rooms Could Talk ...
abstract: The Keen Company revives “The Old Boy,” A. R. Gurney’s 1991 tale of class-consciousness, money, loyalty and resistance to change.
lead_paragraph: Alison, in her 40s now, is having straight vodka with a former beau in a room that looks like the Harvard Club. “They say if you marry money, you earn every cent of it,” she observes.

headline: Hit Men and Hurt Lovers Meet Minnesota Nice
abstract: “The Norwegians,” C. Denby Swanson’s extremely odd and delightful comedy at the Drilling Company, is about two Scandinavian hit men in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: A pair of sweet Scandinavian hit men in Minnesota grill a young woman under bright lights while serving her elderberry wine. In flashback, the woman talks to a new friend at a bar — about the weather, horses and the men who recently did them wrong.

headline: Chez Sardine
abstract: Inside the restaurant where stoner Asian food meets fat-on-fat cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Inside the restaurant where stoner Asian food meets fat-on-fat cuisine.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Vatican City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the Vatican, Argentina, Afghanistan and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Vatican, Argentina, Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Journalism Professor Sues Columbia, Claiming Misuse of Endowment Funds
abstract: Sylvia Nasar, a professor and the author of “A Beautiful Mind,” said the university had mishandled money received from the Knight Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A tenured professor at Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism and co-director of that school’s business program filed a lawsuit on Tuesday accusing the university of misdirecting $4.5 million in funds over the last decade.

headline: 2 Cuisines, Both Full of Themselves
abstract: Asian stoner food and the fat-on-fat school come together in a West Village tavern.
lead_paragraph: ONE MAJOR THEME of modern restaurants is what we might call Asian stoner food. This is the cuisines of Japan, Korea and other places as seen through bloodshot eyes, the cravings of a hipster whose late-night munchies send him out in search of tacos stuffed with bulgogi, pigs’ tails cooked in root beer and the like.

headline: Panic in Cyprus
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Why did European leaders think it would be acceptable to tax insured deposits of less than 100,000 euros? And who came up with the plan?
lead_paragraph: It comes as no surprise that the Parliament of Cyprus on Tuesday voted down a terrible plan to tax insured bank deposits as part of a deal to rescue its failing financial system. The country’s leaders and policy makers in Europe will now have to go back to the drawing board.

headline: Mars Rover Is Repaired, NASA Says
abstract: Engineers have repaired computer problems that stalled the craft, which they say should resume its work later this week.
lead_paragraph: A NASA official said Tuesday that engineers had resolved the latest problem with the Curiosity rover on Mars and that the laboratory-on-wheels should resume science operations this week after a three-week delay.

headline: Revealing a Lot, Aromatic and Otherwise
abstract: Denyse Beaulieu’s memoir delves into her obsession, perfumers who hold rock-star status, their process and their creations.
lead_paragraph: “The scent, my God: it is so indecent," said the author and perfume blogger Denyse Beaulieu from Paris. She was speaking of Shocking, the 1937 Elsa Schiaparelli perfume dressed in hot pink: the original version, not a later reformulation.

headline: Wistful Reflections but Very Few Regrets
abstract: Bebe Neuwirth has brought her brand of storytelling to 54 Below with songs by the likes of Kurt Weill, Kander and Ebb, and Tom Waits.
lead_paragraph: “It was fantastic! It was fantastic! Beyond belief!”

headline: Pop-Up Hotels: Rooms With a Fleeting View
abstract: Want to spend the night in a recycled sea container? Or a boat balanced atop a London roof? Pop-up hotels are offering those options and more for travelers who act fast.
lead_paragraph: POP-UP STORES. Pop-up restaurants. Pop-up lounges. Shouldn’t this fascination with pop-ups — which are by definition ephemeral — have disappeared already?

headline: Hotel Review: Pousada de Cascais in Cascais, Portugal
abstract: This Renaissance-era citadel with a royal and military heritage has been reborn as a stylish hotel by the sea near Lisbon.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: The Doctor Is In (Well, Logged In)
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Doctors', 'E-Mail', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Jay Parkinson is a founder of Sherpaa, a Web site that operates like a virtual doctor’s office, examining patients by e-mail and text message.
lead_paragraph: Surfing the Web in his all-white Dumbo loft, Dr. Jay Parkinson, 37, looks like any other young tech visionary. He has a trim beard and thick-framed glasses. He wears slim-fitting black outfits and jaunty scarves. He speaks with a measured, “This American Life”-like cadence. And he’s a firm believer in the utopian promise of the Internet.

headline: City Approves 700-Unit Rental Complex on Gowanus Canal
abstract: The complex is to consist of two buildings of graduated heights, some as tall as 12 stories. Most apartments are to be sold at market prices, but 140, or 20 percent of them, are to be reserved for people of modest incomes.
lead_paragraph: Gritty and offbeat as its reputation is, the Gowanus Canal may, in a few years, start becoming more bourgeois.

headline: The Sound of Tango, the Story of Mary
abstract: Astor Piazzolla’s “María de Buenos Aires” is an intense cocktail of poetry, tango music and dance.
lead_paragraph: There was no piano in Astor Piazzolla’s vacation home in Parque del Plata, Uruguay, where he spent the summer of 1968 working with the poet Horacio Ferrer on an operita, a “little opera,” so he composed on the bandoneón. The resulting work, “María de Buenos Aires,” is an intense cocktail of poetry, tango music and dance that is performed by a folk contralto, an operatic baritone and one male actor. But it’s the fourth voice — the bandoneón, the soulful South American accordion — that calls the shots and, to borrow Ferrer’s words, “burns in the back of your throat.”

headline: Tongue-in-Cheek Commentary, With Arms and Legs
abstract: Leading the matinee program on Saturday during the company’s three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater, t “Scudorama” retained its odd fascination.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor made his dance “Scudorama” 50 years ago. After 10 years it fell out of his troupe’s repertory, not to be revived until 2007. Leading the matinee program on Saturday during the company’s three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater, the work retained its odd fascination.

headline: Building a Narrative That’s Explosive
abstract: For the new edition of Gears of War, the writers were in the room almost from the beginning.
lead_paragraph: In 2010 Tom Bissell — author of seven books, contributor to publications like The New Yorker and Harper’s Magazine, darling of book reviewers who compare him to writers like Wells Tower and John Jeremiah Sullivan — announced that he was going to “go game,” in the way that prominent writers “go Hollywood,” in search of bigger paychecks and the challenges of a new form.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Strike Darkens Halls
abstract: The cancellation of the symphony’s East Coast tour will leave some major concert halls empty this week, including Carnegie Hall and the Kennedy Center.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall will remain dark on this Wednesday and Thursday evenings. Ditto the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark on Friday and the Kennedy Center Concert Hall in Washington on Saturday.

headline: Crustacean Elation
abstract: The Red Hook Lobster Pound finally opened its doors in March after sustaining massive damage from flooding during Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: The Red Hook Lobster Pound finally opened its doors in March after sustaining massive damage from flooding during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: As ARM Chief Steps Down, Successor Talks About ‘Body Computing’
abstract: ARM’s chief executive stepped down with no drama on Tuesday. But what Warren East, the old chief, and Simon Segars, his successor, plan for the next decade is more disruptive than what the low-power chip company did by moving into most of the world’s smartphones. Body computing could be part of it.
lead_paragraph: ARM Holdings, the specialist in low-power semiconductors, is looking to put computers everywhere around us, and even inside us.

headline: Before Obama Trip, Polls Find Sympathy With Israel, and Doubts on Peace
abstract: Americans continue to sympathize more with Israel than with the Palestinians, but few want the United States to take a leading role in resolving the conflict there.
lead_paragraph: New polls released just ahead of President Obama’s trip to Israel this week find that Americans continue to sympathize more with Israel than with the Palestinians. But few want the United States to take a leading role in resolving the conflict there, and most do not anticipate that the trip will do much to ease regional tensions.

headline: Businesses Return to the Neighborhood, and the People Follow
abstract: In the more than four months since Hurricane Sandy struck, the reopening of the Fairway market has brought people back and even helped other businesses.
lead_paragraph: Crocuses are peeping out of tree pits in Red Hook, Brooklyn, once drowned by a briny soup of seawater and diesel fuel. At the newly reopened Fairway supermarket, bright piles of lemons, tomatoes and oranges pop almost luridly. Kevin’s, a beloved seafood restaurant, has a shiny new wood floor and a new bar built out of donated marble, and across the way in the back of the Red Hook Lobster Pound, gutted by Hurricane Sandy and since rebuilt, sits a shiny new deep fryer, a veritable symbol of marital compromise and rebirth.

headline: The Best Easter Hams
abstract: The Dining section tasting panel tried a variety of hams that were wet cured, smoked over wood and minimally processed. Here are the results.
lead_paragraph: The Dining section tasting panel tried a variety of hams that were wet cured, smoked over wood and minimally processed. Here are the results.

headline: How to Pick an Easter Ham
abstract: What says Easter more than the bunny? A roast ham, the traditional feast that’s not as easy to get right as it may seem.
lead_paragraph: I do not come from ham-eating people.

headline: Playing at New Directors/New Films
abstract: Images of select films screening in the festival.
lead_paragraph: Images of select films screening in the festival.

headline: Nate Silver on the N.C.A.A. Bracket
abstract: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Times’s Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the men’s basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: The FiveThirtyEight blogger talks to The Times’s Megan Liberman about his statistical analysis of the men’s basketball tournament.

headline: More From The Times, and Elsewhere, on the 10th Anniversary of the Iraq War
abstract: Room for Debate in The Times’s Opinion section is soliciting reader opinion on the results of the war.
lead_paragraph: I wrote Monday about The Times’s relatively low-key approach to covering the Iraq war’s 10th anniversary, contrasting it to more robust efforts in The Guardian and to its own efforts on the anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: Eisenhower Memorial in Criticism Barrage
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Simmering conflict over a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower designed by Frank Gehry for the National Mall came out into the open on Tuesday at a Congressional hearing on the project.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Simmering conflict over a $142 million memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower designed by the architect Frank Gehry for the National Mall here erupted into the open on Tuesday at a Congressional hearing on the future of the project.

headline: West 22nd Street, 4:51 P.M.
abstract: Photo: tableau with woman, firefighter and small dog.

headline: True Story Inspires Tale of Sex Trade; in a Twist, a U.S. Marshal Is the Bad Guy
abstract: “Eden,” directed by Megan Griffiths, is an examination of sex trafficking in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Enough films about human trafficking have been made in recent years that the outlines of “Eden” should be painfully familiar. But that familiarity doesn’t cushion this movie’s excruciating vision of under-age women conscripted into sexual slavery by a criminal enterprise from which there is seemingly no escape.

headline: Early Favorites in a Showcase for New Filmmakers
abstract: Film critics’ first picks for the first week of New Directors/New Films, the annual venture of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Killers and clowns, the quick and the dead roam through New Directors/New Films, the annual showcase of promising and confirmed cinematic talent that begins on Wednesday. Now in its 42nd year, the series was established to present work from emerging filmmakers from across the globe back when such festivals were rare. A joint venture of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, where all the screenings will be held, it remains a laudatory New York event.

headline: A Model for Reducing Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Natural Gas', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Coal', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Energy costs and market-driven technological advances have led to a major reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Who would have thought the United States would one day be a leader in cutting greenhouse gas emissions?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Smart Shoes and the Top Social Network Among Teens
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include building a smart light bulb, the rapid growth in business e-mail, and how switching to Google Glass from a smartphone could eliminate some important social cues.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Brazilian Billionaire Confirms Talks to Sell Stake in Energy Firm
abstract: Eike Batista confirmed on Tuesday that he was negotiating to sell part of his stake in MPX, his natural gas and electricity generation company, which has over $3 billion in debt.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista confirmed on Tuesday that he was negotiating to sell part of his stake in MPX, his natural gas and electricity generation company that has over $3 billion in debt and several generation projects running behind schedule.

headline: Israel’s Animated Diplomacy
abstract: On the eve of President Obama’s visit to the Middle East, Israel’s embassy in Washington posted an animated YouTube clip apparently designed to make light of reported tension between the countries’ leaders.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Wednesday, 8:02 p.m. On the eve of President Obama’s visit to the Middle East, Israel’s embassy in Washington rolled out the cartoon red carpet, in the form of an animated YouTube clip apparently designed to make light of reported tension between the two countries’ leaders.

headline: Real Fur, Masquerading as Faux
keywords: ['Fur', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Labeling and Labels', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: In a forehead-slapping development, Neiman Marcus and two other retailers settled federal claims that they had marketed rabbit, raccoon and other real fur as fake fur.
lead_paragraph: The Stuart Weitzman ballet flats from Neiman Marcus sported sweet faux fur pom-poms. The Alice and Olivia coat was trimmed with a dark faux fur collar.

headline: Online Comments in Ohio Rape Case Lead to Charges Against Two
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Sex Crimes', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Two teenage girls accused of posting threats against the victim in a Steubenville, Ohio, rape case have been charged with intimidation and ordered held in detention pending a hearing.
lead_paragraph: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio — The rape trial that concluded here on Sunday with the conviction of two high school football stars has spurred calls in many quarters for expanding — or more aggressively enforcing — the legal obligations of those who know about a sexual assault, or who could be in a position to prevent one.

headline: France: Court Says Head Scarf Is No Grounds for Firing
abstract: France’s highest court ruled Tuesday that a French Muslim woman was unjustly fired in 2008 for wearing a head scarf at work in a private child-care center in a Paris suburb.
lead_paragraph: France’s highest court ruled Tuesday that a French Muslim woman was unjustly fired in 2008 for wearing a head scarf at work in a private child-care center in a Paris suburb. The court ruled that the dismissal violated the woman’s religious freedom. Religious symbols of all kinds are banned from public schools and institutions under French law, but the child-care center is private. The ruling overturned an appeals court decision, which had said the center had the right to set its own rules about religious neutrality. Interior Minister Manuel Valls told Parliament that the court’s ruling was regrettable because it “calls into question the principle of secular education.”

headline: Michigan State’s Toughness Starts With Its Nonconference Schedule
abstract: Few coaches prepare their teams to win in March as consistently as Tom Izzo, through 16 consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament bids, 6 Final Fours and a national title (in 2000).
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mark Montgomery never noticed this about Tom Izzo. Not that he could. Between playing for Michigan State when Izzo was an assistant, then serving as an Izzo assistant for 10 seasons until 2011, Montgomery had too much else going on to scrutinize Izzo’s sideline mannerisms.

headline: Massachusetts: M.I.T. Will Release Documents in Hacking Case
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced on Tuesday it would release documents related to the case against Aaron Swartz, the Internet activist who committed suicide.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Tuesday announced that it would release documents related to the case against Aaron Swartz, the Internet activist who committed suicide in January, about a month before he was to go to trial on charges that he illegally downloaded academic articles from the university’s computer network. In a letter to the M.I.T. community, the university president, L. Rafael Reif, said lawyers for Mr. Swartz had requested in federal court that the institution make evidence related to the case public. Mr. Reif said M.I.T. planned to release those documents, with some information redacted, when it completed an investigation led by a computer science professor, Hal Abelson, into the university’s role in the case. Professor Abelson said in late January that he hoped to complete the investigation within a few weeks.

headline: Ohio: Teenage Killer Gets Life
abstract: A defiant 18-year-old was sentenced Tuesday to spend the rest of his life in prison for a 2012 shooting at a high school cafeteria in Chardon, where he killed three students and wounded three others.
lead_paragraph: A defiant 18-year-old was sentenced Tuesday to spend the rest of his life in prison for a 2012 shooting at a high school cafeteria in Chardon, where he killed three students and wounded three others. Wearing a T-shirt with the word “killer” printed on it, T. J. Lane directed an obscene statement and gesture toward family members of the shooting victims when asked for a statement. He pleaded guilty last month to three counts of aggravated murder, two counts of attempted aggravated murder and one count of assault.

headline: Britain: Girl Shot by Taliban Returns to the Classroom
abstract: Malala Yousafzai, the 15-year-old Pakistani campaigner for girls’ education who was gravely wounded by the Taliban in October, is back in school for the first time since the attack.
lead_paragraph: Malala Yousafzai, the 15-year-old Pakistani campaigner for girls’ education who was gravely wounded by the Taliban in October, is back in school for the first time since the attack, according to a statement by her family. Ms. Yousafzai, shown with her father, is now enrolled full time at Edgbaston, a private girls’ high school in Birmingham, England, where her family now lives and where she underwent extensive medical treatment in recent months. “I miss my classmates from Pakistan very much, but I am looking forward to meeting my teachers and making new friends here in Birmingham,” she was quoted as saying in the statement.

headline: Court Announces Early Release of Same-Sex Marriage Arguments
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Supreme Court announced on Tuesday that it would release same-day audio recordings of arguments in two same-sex marriage cases scheduled to be heard next week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Tuesday that it would release same-day audio recordings of oral arguments in two same-sex marriage cases scheduled to be heard next week.

headline: Ian McKellen to Lead Wedding for Patrick Stewart
abstract: When Sir Patrick Stewart and Sunny Ozell wed, Sir Ian McKellen will officiate at the ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Sir Ian McKellen has announced that he will be officiating at the wedding ceremony of Sir Patrick Stewart, 72, and Sunny Ozell, 35, a singer and songwriter whom Mr. Stewart met in 2008 when he was performing in a production of “Macbeth” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Jane Goodall Admits Borrowing Passages for New Book
abstract: Ms. Goodall, the primatologist known for her research on chimpanzees, said she was “distressed” that sources were not properly cited in an upcoming book on plants.
lead_paragraph: A forthcoming book by Jane Goodall, the primatologist known for her research on chimpanzees, contains passages taken from Web sites without attribution, according to a published report.

headline: Put Cigarettes Out of View? It’s Been Tried
abstract: Nearly a year ago, before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his latest salvo against smoking, Haverstraw, N.Y., passed a law that would have banned the display of tobacco products in stores.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg this week announced his latest salvo against smoking, his press office put out a news flash: “City Would Be First in Nation to Keep Tobacco Products Out of Sight.”

headline: For Some Palestinians, Wariness on Eve of Obama Visit
abstract: No American flags or banners to greet President Obama in the West Bank, but some protests have begun; on most posters, Mr. Obama’s face has been painted over or torn off.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — There are no American flags lining the streets here, no banners bearing the official “Unbreakable Alliance” logo of President Obama’s visit, as there are seven miles away in Jerusalem. Instead, dozens of posters warn the president not to bring his smartphone when he arrives in the West Bank because there is no 3G service, one of an untold number of complaints Palestinians have about their life under Israeli occupation.

headline: N.R.C. Votes for Upgrades to Some Reactor Vents
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Filters', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission stopped short of requiring filters on the vents, which resemble the ones that melted down in Japan two years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3 to 2 on Tuesday to require improvements to the emergency vents at 31 American reactors that share design similarities with the Japanese reactors that melted down two years ago. The agency stopped short, however, of requiring filters to scrub out radioactive particles coming through those vents.

headline: Praising Griner Proves Far Easier Than Stopping Her
abstract: Center Brittney Griner, who has improved her technique and composure, is the star attraction on a Baylor team that is confident it will return to the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. — Just in case anyone doubted Baylor’s confident intent to reach the women’s Final Four in New Orleans, Coach Kim Mulkey wore a fleur-de-lis on her T-shirt as she watched the tournament pairings, while some fans wore Mardi Gras beads and sang, “When the Saints Go Marching In.”

headline: Deal in Albany Would Extend Higher Taxes on Top Earners
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and New York lawmakers are finalizing a surprise deal to extend a high-tax bracket first approved in late 2011 as a temporary response to disappointing revenues.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Congress dodged the so-called fiscal cliff in part by raising taxes on high incomes. California voters addressed their state’s school budget troubles with a surcharge on big incomes. And now Albany has decided to raise revenue with a high income tax rate for people with seven-figure incomes.

headline: StubHub Barred Near Yankee Stadium, for Now
abstract: The Yankees argued that the store was within 1,500 feet of the stadium, violating a state law that bans tickets from being resold that close to a venue.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees won a court order Tuesday temporarily preventing StubHub from opening a store near Yankee Stadium that is designed to allow customers to pick up their tickets before games.

headline: Teenage Gunman in Ohio Mocks Victims’ Families
abstract: Thomas Lane, 18, was given three life sentences for a 2012 shooting in a school cafeteria that left three students dead and two others injured.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Lane wore a T-shirt with KILLER scrawled in black ink during his sentencing Tuesday in an Ohio courtroom for shooting and killing three students in a high school cafeteria and wounding two others last year.

headline: A Decade Later, Stability Eludes Iraq
abstract: The reverberations of the American-led invasion are still being felt in Iraq, which remains a deeply divided, violence-plagued country that some fear may be headed for a full-blown civil war.
lead_paragraph: The first American bombs and missiles to hit Baghdad were four 2,000-pound bunker-busters dropped by two F-117 Nighthawk fighter-bombers and 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles, a thunderous volley aimed at killing Saddam Hussein and his two sons in a secret underground redoubt beside the Tigris River known as Dora Farms. The impacts, some missing their targets, came soon after first light on March 19, 2003.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Is Reining In Payday Lenders
abstract: Bank customers will be allowed to stop withdrawals for high-interest payday loans and close their accounts sooner.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase will make changes to protect consumers who have borrowed money from a rising power on the Internet — payday lenders offering short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.

headline: Banning the Big Gulp Ban
abstract: What’s “capricious” about the Board of Health doing its job where it could?
lead_paragraph: Neither I nor anyone else I’ve read on last week’s judicial stay of New York City’s “Big Gulp Ban” is a lawyer. (We call it the Big Gulp Ban, though in fact it famously would not have banned 7-Eleven’s massive drinks.) But I doubt that our Board of Health was being “capricious” or “arbitrary” — those were the words of the ruling justice, Milton A. Tingling — when it decided last September, by a vote of 8 to 0 (you read that right), to forbid the sale, where it could, of super-size sugary drinks. (From this point on I’ll just call them “soda.”)

headline: 2nd Vote for Closing Long Island College Hospital
abstract: The State University of New York board will now resubmit its plan to shut down Long Island College Hospital to the State Health Department.
lead_paragraph: The board of the State University of New York voted on Tuesday, for the second time in several weeks, to close Long Island College Hospital, which was taken over by the university system two years ago, and which university officials say is losing $1 million a week.

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 4
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ten years after “shock and awe,” Iraq War veterans reflect on the first and last days of the war and what it meant to them.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth part of a six-part series.

headline: Iraq War’s 10th Anniversary Is Barely Noted in Washington
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Those on both sides of the debate over the war were largely silent about it a decade after the American invasion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A decade after the night that American bombs first rained down on Baghdad, the president joked about wearing a green tie for a belated St. Patrick’s Day celebration. Congress noisily focused on whether spending cuts would force the cancellation of the White House Easter egg roll. Cable news debated whether a show about young women has too much sex in it.

headline: Ryan Tiptoes Around a Revis Question
abstract: Jets Coach Rex Ryan, speaking at the A.F.C. coaches’ breakfast on Tuesday, perhaps played a game of semantics when he said that the Jets are not actively trying to trade cornerback Darrelle Revis.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Jets Coach Rex Ryan, speaking at the A.F.C. coaches’ breakfast on Tuesday, perhaps played a game of semantics when he said that the Jets are not actively trying to trade cornerback Darrelle Revis, even as he acknowledged that the team would listen to offers.

headline: Renovation Pays Off for a Chelsea Nonprofit
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Nonprofit Organizations']
abstract: New York Foundling will put more workers into smaller quarters, clearing three floors it can lease to other groups as a revenue source.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Foundling, one of the city’s largest and oldest child welfare agencies, completes a $5.5 million renovation of its Chelsea headquarters this summer, it will squeeze more workers into less space and lease its top three floors, bringing in substantial revenue.

headline: Developers Are Making Bets on a Rising East Harlem
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Gentrification', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: As developers build more housing in East Harlem, the 96th Street dividing line between the neighborhood and the Upper East Side is becoming murky.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Kahen and his partner Haim Levi are making a multimillion-dollar bet on East Harlem. The developers recently closed on a vacant parcel at 119th Street and Third Avenue where they plan to build a 60-unit market-rate rental building.

headline: Joel Breitkopf
abstract: Mr. Breitkopf is a principal of Alchemy Properties, which specializes in boutique residential developments.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Breitkopf, 48, is a principal of Alchemy Properties, which specializes in boutique residential developments.

headline: Britain’s Press Crackdown
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Editorials', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The kind of press regulations proposed by British politicians would do more harm than good because an unfettered press is essential to democracy.
lead_paragraph: In an attempt to rein in its reckless tabloid newspapers, Britain’s three main political parties this week agreed to impose unwieldy regulations on the news media that would chill free speech and threaten the survival of small publishers and Internet sites.

headline: In Shift, Lobbyists Look for Bipartisan Support to Repeal a Tax
abstract: In Washington, lobbyists who had long backed Republicans are also focusing on Democrats to build coalitions against a medical device tax.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When executives from Cook Medical gathered last month to offer Representative Cheri Bustos a tour of their central Illinois medical equipment plant, they had good reason to expect a frosty reception from Ms. Bustos, a new Democratic congresswoman.

headline: Was It Worth It?
abstract: Is America better off now than it was when Saddam Hussein was in power?

headline: A Decade of Despair
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Outside, the bombs went off. Inside, we toasted the queen.
lead_paragraph: Baghdad

headline: What America Learned in Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Some hope that the enormous price of the Iraq war was not paid entirely in vain.
lead_paragraph: Annapolis, Md.

headline: Iraq: Where Terrorists Go to School
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Qaeda-affiliated militants drawn to Iraq since 2003 have been battle-tested. They are taking the fight to neighboring countries, especially Syria.
lead_paragraph: IRAQ, President George W. Bush said in 2003, was a “central front” in the war on terrorism. He was wrong, but prescient. Iraq has become a front for militant extremism — a front the United States created.

headline: Sectarian Strains Pit Some Iraqis Against Their Own Leaders
abstract: Rafe al-Essawi, until recently Iraq’s finance minister and one of the highest-ranking Sunni politicians, is now on the run from the Shiite-led government.
lead_paragraph: RAMADI, Iraq — As Rafe al-Essawi, the embattled Sunni leader, sped south on a desert highway last week to attend the funeral of a political ally who was assassinated, his cellphone rang with a warning: Up ahead, Iraqi soldiers, backed by two helicopters hovering overhead, planned to arrest him.

headline: Francis Ruddle, Who Led Transgenic Research, Dies at 83
abstract: Dr. Ruddle, one of the first scientists to map genes’ locations on specific human chromosomes, helped lay the groundwork for the Human Genome Project.
lead_paragraph: Francis Ruddle, a Yale University geneticist who plumbed the DNA of mice and men, and from whose laboratory sprang the first transgenic mammal — a mouse with added foreign DNA — died on March 10 in New Haven. He was 83.

headline: In a New Aisle, Energy Drinks Sidestep Some Rules
keywords: ['Energy and Sports Drinks', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Caffeine', 'Beverages', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies']
abstract: The producer of Monster Energy will no longer be required to tell federal regulators about reports potentially linking its products to deaths and injuries.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Monster Energy, the popular high-caffeine energy drink, may not notice the change: its ingredients will be the same and its familiar label bearing a green, clawlike monogram will change only slightly. But the drink’s maker has decided after a decade of selling it as a dietary supplement to market it as a beverage, a switch that will bring significant changes in how it is regulated.

headline: Democrats, Dragons or Drones?
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Iraq might seem to have been the last place in the Middle East we should have tried to help establish a democracy, but it was the most important.
lead_paragraph: On this 10th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq, three things are clear. First, whatever happens in Iraq, we overpaid for it in lives and treasure and focus. Second, you can overpay for something decent and you can overpay for total junk. What exactly we overpaid for in Iraq is not yet clear and will be decided by Iraqis. Third, as much as we’d prefer to forget about Iraq, what happens there matters more than ever for the Middle East.

headline: Ten Years After
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Editorials']
abstract: An ill-conceived war continues to affect American policy.
lead_paragraph: Ten years after it began, the Iraq war still haunts the United States in the nearly 4,500 troops who died there; the more than 30,000 American wounded who have come home; the more than $2 trillion spent on combat operations and reconstruction, which inflated the deficit; and in the lessons learned about the limits of American leadership and power.

headline: Murrey Marder, Early McCarthy Skeptic, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Marder may not have gotten a lot of the glory for helping bring down a Red-baiting Senator Joe McCarthy, but he deserves much of the credit, colleagues said.
lead_paragraph: By certain journalistic lights, the reporter Murrey Marder was an editor’s nightmare. He wrote slowly and squeezed against deadlines. He debated with editors. His articles were long, often complicated and never laid claim to stylish writing.

headline: Damage From Derailment to Slow L.I.R.R. Trains for Days
abstract: About three-quarter mile of track was damaged, and crews will most likely be working until Friday to make repairs, officials said.
lead_paragraph: There will be minor delays and some cancellations of Long Island Rail Road trains until at least Friday, officials said, citing extensive damage that was caused by a train derailment.

abstract: The Center for Food Safety takes issue with a Sunday Review article, “Don’t Be Afraid of Genetic Modification.”

abstract: A reader calls on President Obama to release Jonathan Jay Pollard, convicted of spying for Israel.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Mar. 20, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, Mar. 20, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I came in here as a 30-something with kids, a mother who was alive. This case killed my whole life.”

headline: Justices Explore Fine Line on Generic Drug Injuries
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments Tuesday on whether a drug maker could be held responsible for severe injuries caused by its generic pain pill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2010, a New Hampshire jury awarded Karen Bartlett $21 million for the ordeal she endured from taking a generic pain pill for an aching shoulder. It caused two-thirds of her skin to slough off, damaged her lungs and esophagus and rendered her legally blind.

headline: On Gay Unions, a Pragmatist Before He Was a Pope
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: By suggesting in 2010 that the church in Argentina support civil unions for gay couples, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio revealed himself to be a deal maker willing to compromise.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The very idea was anathema to many of the bishops in the room.

headline: G.O.P. Opposition to Immigration Law Is Falling Away
abstract: A scramble by leading Republican lawmakers to halt a loss of support among Hispanic voters is providing strong momentum for an immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican opposition to legalizing the status of millions of illegal immigrants is crumbling in the nation’s capital as leading lawmakers in the party scramble to halt eroding support among Hispanic voters — a shift that is providing strong momentum for an overhaul of immigration laws.

headline: Used to Baghdad’s Battles, and Adjusting to New York’s Bustle
abstract: Since the invasion of Iraq, 10 years ago this month, 82,000 Iraqis have settled in the United States; Omar al-Mashhadani and his family are among them.
lead_paragraph: In his first 48 hours in the Bronx, Omar al-Mashhadani caught a few echoes of the life that he and his family had left behind in Baghdad. Thousands of people were swarming along 161st Street, toward the hulking stadium on the other side of the El on River Avenue.

headline: Protecting Their Own, Russians Offer an Alternative to the Cypriot Bank Tax
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Gazprom, a company in a tight embrace with the Kremlin, made its own bailout proposal to Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When the European Union said it would bail out Cypriot banks by seizing a percentage of deposits, Cypriots erupted. Russian government officials also raged, on behalf of Cyprus’s many Russian depositors.

headline: For Steinbrenner and Yankees, a Commitment to a New Order
abstract: Hal Steinbrenner talked about his conviction that the Yankees should be able to contend with a payroll under $200 million, placing an emphasis on retaining more prospects.
lead_paragraph: For Yankee fans hoping Brian Cashman will trade a prospect or two to get a player like Justin Morneau from the Minnesota Twins to play first base until Mark Teixeira returns — if he returns — this season from a wrist injury, it might be useful to hear some recent comments from Hal Steinbrenner.

headline: Iraq’s Fragile Future
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Iraq continues to face political strife, sectarian violence and corruption and mismanagement.

They continue to face political strife, sectarian violence and corruption and mismanagement. As a country in transition in the volatile Middle East, it still merits sustained American interest.

keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)']

headline: Both Needing a Win, the Rangers Top the Devils
abstract: Rick Nash’s second-period goal and Henrik Lundqvist’s stout netminding gave the Rangers a desperately needed victory and boosted them to eighth place in the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Last spring the Rangers and the Devils stood at the pinnacle of the East, battling in the conference finals for a chance at the Stanley Cup. On Tuesday night they stood at a far more modest place — along the playoff cut line — battling to salvage what has been a mediocre season for both teams.

headline: Bishops Challenge Cuomo on Stronger Abortion Rights
abstract: The Catholic delegation wants the governor to abandon efforts to rewrite state law to guarantee expansive abortion rights, even if Roe v. Wade is overturned at the federal level.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — As Roman Catholics worldwide celebrated the inauguration of Pope Francis, New York bishops traveled to Albany on Tuesday to meet with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, whose looming effort to strengthen abortion rights in the state has met with strong protests from Catholic and evangelical clergy.

lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail in New York, the path to City Hall leads past hundreds of social events, and thousands of restaurants. Candidates have their own ways of coping with the temptations of food.

headline: No Merger for Los Angeles Museum
abstract: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which has been facing financial problems and considering possible mergers, said it would stay independent.
lead_paragraph: After several weeks of exploring a merger to shore up its weak financial status, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles appears to have decided to try to go it alone, releasing a statement on Tuesday announcing its intention to stay independent.

headline: French Minister Steps Down in Swiss Bank Investigation
keywords: ['Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Tax Evasion', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Money Laundering', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just hours after an announcement that he would be investigated on charges of tax fraud and money laundering, Budget Minister Jérôme Cahuzac resigned from the French government on Tuesday evening, though he insisted he had done nothing wrong.

lead_paragraph: Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, was greeting voters at an Upper West Side political club recently when, midschmooze, he picked up a chocolate-frosted doughnut and prepared to help himself to a sizable, sprinkled bite.

headline: Administration Official Defends Release of Detainees
abstract: The director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement told a House subcommittee that the release of over 2,200 immigrants in February was solely a budgetary savings measure.
lead_paragraph: Under fierce questioning from Republicans at a hearing in the House of Representatives, the top Obama administration official in charge of immigration enforcement insisted Tuesday that the release of more than 2,200 immigrants from detention in February was solely a budgetary savings measure, and he disputed accusations that they had included many dangerous criminals.

headline: Subway Worker Freed After Hours Stuck in Mud
abstract: A construction worker on a New York City subway project who had been trapped in a 75-foot-deep tunnel was freed early Wednesday morning in a four-hour rescue.
lead_paragraph: A construction worker on the Second Avenue subway project who became stuck in mud up to his waist in a 75-foot-deep tunnel on Tuesday night was freed early Wednesday morning in a four-hour rescue involving more than 100 emergency workers, the authorities said.

lead_paragraph: Two central characters recurred in the Tuesday night mayoral debate over public safety and the future of the Police Department: one who is real and one who is, at least at this point, still notional.

lead_paragraph: DZILAM DE BRAVO, Mexico — Whispers of high-speed boat chases, harpoon battles on the open sea and divers who dived deep and never re-emerged come and go around here like an afternoon gale.

lead_paragraph: Heading a soccer ball can, on the plus side, score goals and impress fans. But it may also adversely affect a player’s ability to think, a new study of high school soccer players suggests.

headline: Zimbabwe: Constitution Passes by Wide Margin
abstract: Voters overwhelmingly approved Zimbabwe’s new Constitution, the Election Commission announced Tuesday, with more than three million people voting yes and fewer than 200,000 voting no.
lead_paragraph: Voters overwhelmingly approved Zimbabwe’s new Constitution, the Election Commission announced Tuesday, with more than three million people voting yes and fewer than 200,000 voting no. The new charter replaces the Constitution that has governed Zimbabwe since the end of white minority rule in 1980 and is a crucial step toward holding presidential elections this year to replace an uneasy power-sharing government installed after the violent 2008 election.

Many of these sites that feature fresh, organic produce and gourmet products were started by young entrepreneurs who didn’t want time constraints get in the way of a good home-cooked meal.

Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia, Cyprus.

headline: Parading on the Edges
abstract: Revelers gathered along Fifth Avenue on Saturday to view the St. Patrick’s Day parade, and Nicole Bengiveno was in their midst, on assignment, snapping away.
lead_paragraph: “I love surreal-ness,” said Nicole Bengiveno, staff photographer of The New York Times, who photographed the St. Patrick’s Day parade in New York on Saturday. “You have men in skirts, you have people with shamrocks on their faces — I kept snapping pictures of people with these funny hats and green hair. Because they’re just really in the spirit.” Followed by the freelance videographer Elaisha Stokes, Ms. Bengiveno demonstrates how, for the parade-going photographer, it is helpful to be drawn to strangeness. After all, if you have photographed as many parades as she has, an eye for the uncommon can be a gift. Likewise, a knack for sticking to the sidelines. “I like to stay around the edges,” Ms. Bengiveno said. “I like the idea of being invisible.”

headline: Seeking Lessons From the Iraq War. But Which Ones?
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: On the 10th anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, the lessons hang heavily over the United States as it confronts problems elsewhere in the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Stephen J. Hadley, who played a central role in the decision a decade ago to go to war in Iraq, recently described the cascade of misjudgments and inaccurate assumptions inside the Bush White House leading up to the war as a “failure of imagination.” His explanation of what went wrong is rife with lessons for two crises – one in Syria, another in Iran – that President Obama confronts as he lands in Israel on Wednesday morning.

headline: Too Big Not to Fail
abstract: The Portuguese government’s policy of merging public schools into large clusters has been a slow-moving disaster.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Education policy isn’t the Portuguese government’s strong suit. There have been 28 education ministers since 1974. Only half of the country’s 25-to-34 year-olds have successfully completed high school; dropout rates are among the highest in Western Europe.

headline: In Israel, Obama Seeks to Offer Reassurance of ‘Unbreakable Bonds’
abstract: As President Obama traveled to Israel for the first time in his presidency, he conveyed a message of solidarity and defense against threats.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It took four years and a second term, but President Obama traveled to Israel on Wednesday for a richly symbolic state visit, bearing a message of solidarity to a wary Israeli public, and a promise to defend Israel from threats near and far.

headline: Deal Makers Foresee a Feast of Activity, Survey Finds

lead_paragraph: As deal makers prepare to head down to New Orleans for one of the biggest merger conferences of the year, many will do so with a spring in their step.

headline: Business for Sale: A Long-Haul Trucking Company
abstract: Would you pay $2.2 million for this business?
lead_paragraph: Let’s take a look at another business for sale. And once again, we’ll consider the business from the point of view of a potential buyer, but we will also see what lessons this business might hold for owners of other businesses.

headline: Becoming the All-Terrain Human
abstract: For Kilian Jornet, running across the Pyrenees is like a jog in the park. What one elite endurance athlete can tell us about the human body’s potential.
lead_paragraph: Kilian Jornet Burgada is the most dominating endurance athlete of his generation. In just eight years, Jornet has won more than 80 races, claimed some 16 titles and set at least a dozen speed records, many of them in distances that would require the rest of us to purchase an airplane ticket. He has run across entire landmasses­ (Corsica) and mountain ranges (the Pyrenees), nearly without pause. He regularly runs all day eating only wild berries and drinking only from streams. On summer mornings he will set off from his apartment door at the foot of Mont Blanc and run nearly two and a half vertical miles up to Europe’s roof — over cracked glaciers, past Gore-Tex’d climbers, into the thin air at 15,781 feet — and back home again in less than seven hours, a trip that mountaineers can spend days to complete. A few years ago Jornet ran the 165-mile Tahoe Rim Trail and stopped just twice to sleep on the ground for a total of about 90 minutes. In the middle of the night he took a wrong turn, which added perhaps six miles to his run. He still finished in 38 hours 32 minutes, beating the record of Tim Twietmeyer, a legend in the world of ultrarunning, by more than seven hours. When he reached the finish line, he looked as if he’d just won the local turkey trot.

headline: Happy International Happiness Day
abstract: The United Nations is marking March 20 as a day on which to highlight the links between happiness and world development. Does that make you happy, or do you think the U.N. has better things to do?
lead_paragraph: LONDON – If you want to avoid the risk of being accosted by total strangers urging you to “be happy,” you should probably stay home on Wednesday.

headline: American Realty Capital Offers to Buy Cole Credit for $5.7 Billion

lead_paragraph: American Realty Capital Properties said on Wednesday that it had offered to buy Cole Credit Property Trust III for $5.7 billion, in a deal that would create one of the biggest publicly traded real estate investment trusts.

lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are examining Microsoft’s involvement with companies and individuals that are accused of paying bribes to overseas government officials in exchange for business, according to a person briefed on the inquiry, Nick Wingfield reports in The New York Times.

headline: JPMorgan’s New Policy on Payday Lenders
abstract: JPMorgan Chase is making changes to its policy on Internet-based payday lenders. | John C. Malone is moving to re-enter the cable business. | Federal authorities are scrutinizing Microsoft’s involvement with companies and officials accused of paying bribes overseas. | Bill Gross is auctioning off some rare stamps.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is moving to protect customers whose accounts are tapped by Internet-based payday lenders, planning to give those customers more power to stop withdrawals and close their accounts, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. Under the changes, to be announced on Wednesday, JPMorgan is also limiting the fees it charges customers when the withdrawals trigger penalties.

headline: Waiting for Catastrophes: Aleksandar Hemon Talks About ‘The Book of My Lives’
abstract: In his new collection of essays, Mr. Hemon writes about growing up in Sarajevo and his life in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, Aleksandar Hemon was visiting Chicago when war broke out in his home country, Bosnia. Chicago became his adopted home, and he soon became a highly praised writer of fiction. In 2004, he received a MacArthur “genius” grant. Mr. Hemon’s new book, “The Book of My Lives,” collects nonfiction pieces about his upbringing in Sarajevo and his life in America. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hemon discussed displacement, visiting Sarajevo now, the purpose of art and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Suntech Unit Declares Bankruptcy
abstract: Suntech Power, which rose to become the world’s largest producer of solar panels, suffered from quick expansion in manufacturing capacity followed by a drop in prices.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Suntech Power, a Chinese manufacturer that became the world’s largest producer of solar panels by 2011 only to be battered by plummeting prices, announced on Wednesday evening that its main operating subsidiary had been pushed into bankruptcy by eight Chinese banks.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Networks Embrace Content Marketing and Retailers Admit to Faking Faux Fur
abstract: Television networks are creating commercials for advertisers, three retailers settled claims that they marketed real fur as faux, and a professor at Columbia’s journalism school says the university misdirected endowment funds.
lead_paragraph: Television networks and channels are becoming increasingly involved in making commercials, hoping to prevent audiences from skipping ads, Stuart Elliott writes. New efforts at content marketing (also called content advertising and native advertising) have become the norm as networks try to convince marketers to pay more for airtime. Scripps Networks Interactive, the parent of cable channels like DIY, Food Network and Travel Channel, is one of the leaders in the field. Jonathan LaConti, vice president for ad sales at the company’s New York office, said that Scripps strives to make commercials that look “really natural,” particularly if they involve one of the network’s hosts.

headline: As Bailout Deadline Approaches, Cyprus Scrambles to Find Funds
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: One proposal would nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and hold an emergency bond sale in an effort to raise €5.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Scrambling to placate international lenders, Cyprus late Wednesday proposed to nationalize pension funds from state-run companies and conduct an emergency bond sale to help raise the €5.8 billion the indebted country needs to secure a bailout.

headline: Voters, Deficits, and Jobs
abstract: Same as they ever were.
lead_paragraph: Update: On the other hand, via Greg Sargent, a huge majority of Americans — three quarters! — supports federal spending programs to create jobs. But we know that this is out of the question, because, well, because.

headline: In One Simple Tool, Hope for H.I.V. Prevention
abstract: A device that makes male circumcision easier and less painful could help prevent millions of H.I.V. infections in the next decade.
lead_paragraph: Two plastic rings, a rubber band, and a thread.

headline: Two for the Road
abstract: With a clever bag and shoe combination, dressing for any destination can be shockingly simple.
lead_paragraph: With a clever bag and shoe combination, dressing for any destination can be shockingly simple.

headline: The Tale of a Transgender 6-Year-Old Child Raises Reader Concerns
abstract: Parental approval and the child’s own willingness should rule the day
lead_paragraph: In Monday’s New York Times, an article by the national reporter Dan Frosch examined a Colorado case involving a 6-year-old child, who is biologically male but identifies as a female. The article used the child’s name, Coy Mathis, and two color photographs that showed her face clearly.

headline: Psychiatric Patient Arrested in Beating Death at a Brooklyn Hospital
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Spence Andrews, 20, was charged with second-degree murder after Conrad Delimar, 47, was found dead in a shower room at Interfaith Medical Center.
lead_paragraph: A 47-year-old psychiatric patient was beaten to death in a locked shower room at Interfaith Medical Center in central Brooklyn late on Tuesday, officials said, and another patient, a 20-year-old, has been charged with second-degree murder in the killing.

headline: Joining the Toad Patrols of Britain
abstract: Toads are creatures of habit, heading back to their home bodies of water each spring to spawn. In Britain, that often means crossing busy roads. Groups of volunteers have sprung up to help them safely find their way home.
lead_paragraph: My latest Green column goes patrolling for toads in Britain. Toads are mostly terrestrial creatures but when they mature at the age of about three they return in early spring to the body of water in which they were born to spawn.

headline: Round Trips to Cyprus
abstract: Have money, will travel.
lead_paragraph: Still trying to wrap my head around the Cyprus situation; what makes it so interesting (as in “may you live in interesting times”) is the role of the island as a tax, regulation, and law enforcement haven.

headline: Chinese Solar Panel Giant Is Tainted by Bankruptcy
abstract: A solar panel maker, Wuxi Suntech, declared bankruptcy in a remarkable reversal for part of a huge Chinese government effort to dominate renewable energy industries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was the Icarus of the solar power industry. And, on Wednesday, it fell to earth.

headline: Australia Prime Minister Fights Own Party to Stay in Office
abstract: The premier, Julia Gillard, accepted a public demand for a vote on Thursday that could remove her from office in favor of the man she ousted in 2010.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The embattled prime minister of Australia, Julia Gillard, was fighting for her political life on Thursday after she accepted a public demand for a leadership ballot put forward by a senior lawmaker from her ruling Labor Party, who said that the party’s only hope of prevailing in upcoming elections was to return to office the man Ms. Gillard deposed in a 2010 party coup.

headline: Tip of the Week: Making an iTunes Wish List
abstract: The iTunes Store has a Wish List feature that lets you save links to songs, videos and other content for purchasing later.
lead_paragraph: The iTunes Store has millions of songs, videos and other digital goods that make it easy to run up the credit-card bill. If you find items you want to buy — but need to pace your spending — you can use the Wish List feature to set them aside for purchasing later. To use the Wish List when you are logged in and browsing the iTunes Store, click the triangle next to the price listed for a song, album, video, book or other content for sale, and choose “Add to Wish List” from the menu that appears.

headline: With JPMorgan Settlement, MF Global Clients Move Closer to Payout
abstract: MF Global customers moved one step closer to recouping their missing money late on Tuesday when JPMorgan Chase released its claim to more than $500 million belonging to the bankrupt brokerage firm.
lead_paragraph: MF Global customers moved one step closer to recouping their missing money late on Tuesday when JPMorgan Chase released its claim to more than $500 million belonging to the bankrupt brokerage firm.

headline: Colorado Reels After Killing of Top Official Over Prisons
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The killing of Tom Clements, executive director of the Department of Corrections, cast a shadow on the signing of stiffer state gun control measures.
