lead_paragraph: DENVER — As Colorado’s governor signed a hard-won package of gun control measures on Wednesday, officials across the state were reeling from the seemingly inexplicable shooting death of the state’s prisons chief, who was gunned down at the front door of his home.

headline: Study of Men’s Falling Income Cites Single Parents
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Men and Boys', 'Single Mothers', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Boys raised in single-parent households, particularly those headed by women, appeared to fare poorly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decline of two-parent households may be a significant reason for the divergent fortunes of male workers, whose earnings generally declined in recent decades, and female workers, whose earnings generally increased, a prominent labor economist argues in a new survey of existing research.

headline: India’s Weakened Government May Struggle For Reform
keywords: ['Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: After losing a key ally over the issue of alleged war crimes in Sri Lanka, key economic reforms may falter.
lead_paragraph: India’s government faced accusations Wednesday that it will be incapable of bringing about much-needed reforms after the withdrawal of its biggest ally Tuesday night, a southern political party that protested the government’s stance on Sri Lanka’s alleged war crimes.

headline: More Proof That Rules Alone Won’t Save Threatened Wildlife
abstract: Poachers killed at least 86 elephants in Chad, including 33 pregnant females and 15 calves showing just how hard it is to enforce strictures put in place by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – A major international conference on wildlife trade last week added 343 animal and plant species to the list of roughly 34,000 that are considered threatened. Trade in these creatures is either banned or strictly monitored, and the outcome was widely welcomed by conservationists as an important development.

headline: ‘Downton’ Season 3 Sets PBS Record
abstract: The season’s seven episodes averaged 11.5 million viewers a week, PBS said after it received updated Nielsen numbers that included digital video recorder playback.
lead_paragraph: The third season of “Downton Abbey” was even more popular than previously believed. The season’s seven episodes averaged 11.5 million viewers a week, PBS said Tuesday after it received updated Nielsen numbers that included digital video recorder playbacks. Earlier numbers suggested that seven million to eight million viewers had tuned in for each episode. The total audience — up about 65 percent from the second season — makes the third season of “Downton” the most popular drama ever televised by PBS. The show’s online viewership was counted separately. But there, too, a record was set: The public broadcaster said there were 900,000 video streams on the “Masterpiece” Web site the day after the Season 3 finale, the most for the site.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Southern Foodways Alliance: It must be spring: Hansen’s Sno-Bliz in New Orleans has started serving sno-balls again. — Julia Moskin

headline: Afghans Compromise Over Ban on Elite U.S. Troops
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: After weeks of acrimony, the Afghan government softened a deadline for American forces to leave Wardak Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai’s government has agreed to compromise on his demand that American Special Operations forces immediately leave Wardak Province, according to statements from American and Afghan officials on Wednesday, breaking an increasingly acrimonious impasse.

headline: Google Hosts Narendra Modi at Tech Summit
abstract: The Gujarat chief minister is expected to offer tips on using the Internet in politics.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI– Gujarat’s controversial chief minister, Narendra Modi, will address a Google summit in New Delhi on Thursday to speak about how the Internet is changing politics in India.

headline: Hugo Chávez’s Unlikely Soccer Legacy
abstract: Hugo Chávez, the leader of Venezuela who died recently, played a big role in elevating the quality of soccer in Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: In death, Hugo Chávez may conjure more debate and split more opinions than he ever did in life. Whether the former Venezuelan leader is remembered as a man of the people who brought millions out of extreme poverty or castigated as a deranged autocrat who drove his country in to debt and hyperinflation, the true measure of his time as a president will lie in the legacy and future he has left for Venezuela.

headline: ‘The Rite of Spring’
abstract: “When Stravinsky Met Nijinsky,” written and illustrated by Lauren Stringer, reveals the reasons why a ballet caused such a fuss.
lead_paragraph: It’s not surprising that Disney set a battle between a stegosaurus and a Tyrannosaurus rex to a soundtrack of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” in the 1940 film “Fantasia.” For most children, that’s what the music is about. But few are probably aware that when the ballet made its debut at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in 1913, a near riot broke out in the audience.

headline: The Gun Report: March 20, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: What if there were a technology that insured that only the person who owned a gun could shoot it? No child who stumbled across the gun could accidentally shoot his brother. No one could make use of a stolen gun. No one could buy a gun on someone else’s behalf because it wouldn’t work for anyone but the buyer. Such a technology would not eliminate gun violence, of course, but it certainly would decrease it. It would greatly diminish, and perhaps even eliminate, fatal accidents involving children finding guns in their homes, which I find the most wrenching stories to read in The Gun Report. Such a technology, it turns out, does exist. I plan to write about it soon.

headline: Van Cliburn, My Nemesis
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The pianist’s recent death prompted a boyhood recollection of parental admonishments: “Why can’t you be more like …?”
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Robert Forster to Play Reagan in a New Play
abstract: “The Lifeguard: Ronald Reagan and His Story,” by David Rambo, will have its world premiere at the Geva Theater Center in Rochester.
lead_paragraph: The actor Robert Forster, a Rochester native (and Max Cherry in Quentin Tarantino’s “Jackie Brown”), will portray Ronald Reagan at Rochester’s Geva Theater Center in June, the theater announced.

headline: Once So Mighty, Now Gone: China’s Ministry of Railways
abstract: This month, China’s once powerful Ministry of Railways was dissolved and in a historic change, is being replaced by a corporation.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With nearly 100,000 kilometers of track, China’s railway system is the second-largest in the world, according to Sheng Guangzu, the last minister of railways. Its nearly 9,400 kilometers of high-speed rail — rising fast as China invests heavily in the sector — is the largest.

headline: The Power Breakfast: Andrew Jenks
abstract: The filmmaker Andrew Jenks sits down with The Times’s Tanzina Vega at Delicatessen in New York City to discuss the latest season of his MTV show, “World of Jenks,” and the evolution of reality TV.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Andrew Jenks sits down with The Times’s Tanzina Vega at Delicatessen in New York City to discuss the latest season of his MTV show, “World of Jenks,” and the evolution of reality TV.

headline: A New Purpose for an Old Telephone Building, but Its Dull Face Remains
abstract: Plans to turn 375 Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan into a glass-skinned office tower collapsed in the five years since they were announced, and now the building is becoming a commercial data center, its limestone exterior intact.
lead_paragraph: When City Room last visited the bulky old telephone switching station at 375 Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan, it was poised to emerge — like a chrysalis — from its limestone shell and turn into a sleek glass-skinned office tower, putting at risk its standing as one of the uglier skyscrapers in New York.

headline: Wisdom From Flyers With Nut Allergies
abstract: In-flight allergy reactions to tree nuts and peanuts have been reported by only small numbers of passengers, and scientists are uncertain whether dust from the nuts poses serious airborne risks to travelers, but many allergy sufferers take a pro-active stance, a new study indicates.
lead_paragraph: When Roxanne Palin of Manhattan travels by plane with her family, some of whom are allergic to tree nuts or peanuts, she has a standing battle plan. She books flights in advance so that the three with allergies can sit together, and makes sure they bring their own food and beverages. She swabs their seats and table trays with alcohol pads or baby wipes. She packs eight doses of self-injectable epinephrine, including back-ups, in case any of them has an allergic reaction.

headline: Autonomy Questions for Hewlett-Packard
abstract: Mike Lynch, the founder of Autonomy, is back, posting an open letter to Hewlett-Packard shareholders on the day of the company’s annual meeting. In it, he again raises questions of how Hewlett came to take an $8 billion write down on the purchase of Autonomy.
lead_paragraph: You didn’t really think Mike Lynch would stay away from Hewlett-Packard, did you?

headline: U.K. Takes Steps to Spur Stuttering Economy
abstract: George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, stuck to his austerity plan, but added concessions for home buyers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government was forced on Wednesday to seek new ways to revive the sputtering economy after acknowledging for the second time in three months that it would take longer than expected to meet its debt-reduction target.

headline: Just 5 Banks Prohibit Use of Social Security Numbers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identity Fraud', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: Five top banks no longer use Social Security numbers to verify a customer’s identity, though the nation’s biggest banks still use them, a new report finds.
lead_paragraph: Despite the risk of fraud associated with the theft of Social Security numbers, just five of the nation’s largest 25 banks have stopped using the numbers to verify a customer’s identity after the initial account setup, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds.

headline: The Master Fish Butcher of Tokyo’s Union Square
abstract: “You have to be meticulous if you are taking a creature’s life,” says Yoshikazu Kondo. “With fish, you must always take great care.”
lead_paragraph: Back of House, an occasional column, celebrates the unsung characters who animate the restaurant universe.

headline: A Sophisticated Instagram Alternative
abstract: Maybe Instagram’s privacy blunder took the bloom off the rose, but that’s no reason to stop sharing photos through social media as Instagram alternatives like Tadaa continue to emerge.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Instagram’s privacy blunder took the bloom off the rose, but that’s no reason to stop sharing photos through social media as Instagram alternatives continue to emerge.

headline: Last Splash
abstract: A promenade outside of Mumbai adorned with a mural by Rouble Nagi. The prime season for tourism there is ending as temperatures rise ahead of monsoons.
lead_paragraph: A promenade outside of Mumbai adorned with a mural by Rouble Nagi. The prime season for tourism there is ending as temperatures rise ahead of monsoons.

headline: Back in the Tournament, Butler Has a Challenge in Bucknell
abstract: The view from Butler: Bucknell and the senior center Mike Muscala will be a tough match-up for the Bulldogs.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The Butler men’s basketball team is a No. 6 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s East Regional after a 67-56 loss in the semifinal round of the Atlantic 10 tournament to eventual champion St. Louis. The Bulldogs enter the N.C.A.A. tournament with a 26-8 record.

headline: ‘The Revisionist’ Eyes Broadway as It Extends Run
abstract: The play by Jesse Eisenberg, starrting Vanessa Redgrave, is one of the hottest Off Broadway tickets.
lead_paragraph: One of the hottest Off Broadway tickets, the Vanessa Redgrave-Jesse Eisenberg play, “The Revisionist,” is adding an extra week of performances before its new closing date of April 27, Rattlestick Playwrights Theater announced on Wednesday. The theater’s leaders have also begun exploring transferring the production to Broadway during the 2013-14 season.

headline: Rat Body Linked to Blackout at Atomic Site
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: The operator of the crippled Japanese nuclear plant found a rodent’s scorched body inside a switchboard and said the animal may have short-circuited it.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The operator of the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant said Wednesday that it had found what it believed was the cause of an extended blackout that disabled vital cooling systems this week: the charred body of a rat.

headline: An Insider’s Tour of Chongqing Yields Frugal Gems
abstract: With a local guide, seeking experiences “unsuitable for tourists” in the intimidatingly large Chinese city.
lead_paragraph: As we drove down the mountain from Lao Jun Dong, a Taoist temple perched above the smoggy mega-city of Chongqing, I tried to describe to YangYang, my host and a local magazine editor, the kind of restaurant where I wanted to eat that Sunday evening.

headline: Pope Francis, the Pragmatist
abstract: The Times’s Simon Romero explains how Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio navigated the politics of gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Simon Romero explains how Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio navigated the politics of gay marriage.

headline: Symbolic Visit
abstract: The Times’s Isabel Kershner on what Israelis expect from a visit by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Isabel Kershner on what Israelis expect from a visit by President Obama.

headline: For Kentucky, There’s Always Last Year
abstract: Sportswriters agreed that the end of Kentucky’s season, after winning the national title a year ago, couldn’t come soon enough.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina A&T won an N.C.A.A. tournament game for the first time on Tuesday, a 73-72 victory over 20-loss Liberty. (Make that 21-loss Liberty.) And in pro basketball, the Denver Nuggets won their 13th straight.

headline: 8 Filipinos Are Charged in Incursion on Borneo
abstract: The men were the first to be charged since an armed group from the southern Philippines claimed ancestral rights to land in the state of Sabah.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Eight Filipinos were charged on Wednesday in a Malaysian court with committing terrorism and waging war in connection with their recent incursion on the island of Borneo, according to the Malaysian state news agency Bernama.

headline: To Save a Man’s Life, a Muddy Tug of War With the Earth Itself
abstract: When a city construction worker became stuck in the mud deep underground, rescuers had to improvise a solution for a problem none of them had seen before.
lead_paragraph: Deep below Second Avenue, where workers blast into Manhattan’s bedrock to build the first new subway line in New York City in decades, mud and muck are a fact of life.

headline: Longing for the Test of War as a Young Man
abstract: Hugh Martin’s war began while he was watching television in a friend’s living room, showing off his military knowledge. In less than a year, he was in Iraq himself.
lead_paragraph: The war began for me while I was sitting on a couch in a living room. Like many people, I watched it all commence on television. At a friend’s house on campus, I sat with a few college friends and drank Bud Ice from bottles. We weren’t drinking beer because of the war; we were drinking simply because, being in college, it was something we often did. White smoke from an explosion would burst up from the cityscape of Baghdad as the sound echoed through the dark. Yellow tracers from antiaircraft fire sprayed randomly into the sky. The ticker on the bottom of the screen euphemistically summarized what was happening (while adding some alliteration and a subtle rhyme): “Large explosion rocks Iraq’s capital.”

headline: Safety Agency Upgrades Inquiry on Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedans
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has gathered about 350 complaints from owners about fuel leaking or a strong odor of gasoline, particularly after refueling.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says it is upgrading an investigation into fuel leaks on about 250,000 Mercedes-Benz sedans, according to a report posted on the agency Web site. The investigation covers 2003-8 E-Class models.

headline: Image of the Day: March 20
keywords: ['Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Students in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, protest alleged war crimes committed against the Tamil community in Sri Lanka.

headline: Matches as Memories
abstract: Matchbooks were once ephemera — written on, burned up in the space of a weekend — but they’re now a keepsake.
lead_paragraph: Everyone swipes the matches. They were once ephemera — written on, burned up in the space of a weekend — but they’re now a keepsake. Maybe they bring you back to the Hemingway Bar at the Ritz or remind you of the pink-and-white striped pool towels at the Beverly Hills Hotel. In a way, they are the perfect hotel souvenirs, and also the most anachronistic — having been left essentially unchanged since the bygone days of steamer trunks, Baedeker guides, swizzle sticks and, let’s not forget, smoking.

headline: Where NASA’s Voyager Is a Musical Instrument
abstract: The Bang on a Can People’s Commissioning Fund Concert showcased eclectic composers who were directed to use field recordings in their works.
lead_paragraph: Instead of the usual warning to silence all electronic gadgets, the WNYC host John Schaefer asked the audience at Merkin Concert Hall, gathered on Thursday evening for Bang on a Can’s 2013 People’s Commissioning Fund Concert, to keep their phones on.

headline: Questions Abound in Learning to Adjust to Health Care Overhaul
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Small Business']
abstract: The owners of a wholesale bakery near San Diego must decide whether to offer insurance to their employees or pay into a government fund.
lead_paragraph: Baked in the Sun is a wholesale baker and distributor of freshly baked pastries near San Diego.

headline: Mariam Farhat, Known as ‘Mother of Martyrs,’ Dies at 64
abstract: Ms. Farhat, a Palestinian lawmaker also known as Umm Nidal, had three sons who died in attacks against Israel.
lead_paragraph: Mariam Farhat, a Palestinian lawmaker known as the “mother of martyrs” after three of her sons died in attacks against Israel, one of which was a suicide mission that she encouraged in a homemade video, died on Sunday in Gaza City. She was 64.

headline: PEN/Faulkner Fiction Award Goes to Benjamin Alire Sáenz
abstract: Mr. Sáenz has won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for his short story collection “Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club.”
lead_paragraph: Joining a pantheon that includes Philip Roth, E.L. Doctorow and John Updike, Benjamin Alire Sáenz has won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for his short story collection, “Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club,” The Associated Press reported.

headline: Should a Bakery With More Than 50 Employees Offer Health Insurance?
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Outsourcing', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Baked in the Sun has three options under the new law: offer insurance, pay the penalty or reduce head count.
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about Baked in the Sun, a wholesale bakery and distributor trying to decide how best to comply with the Affordable Care Act, which requires businesses with 50 or more employees to offer health insurance or pay a penalty. The company, owned by Rachel Shein and Steve Pilarski, who are married, started out making scones 16 years ago and expanded with the growth of coffeehouses. Baked in the Sun now produces nearly 20,000 items per day — almost 200 different products, including brownies, coffee cakes, muffins and cookies — and employs nearly 100 people in San Marcos, Calif.

headline: A Challenge Grant From Weills to Spur Carnegie Hall Renovation
abstract: Sanford I. Weill, and his wife, Joan, and their Weill Family Foundation make a $10 million grant, with Carnegie Hall asked to raise $20 million.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall has received a $10 million challenge grant from its chairman, Sanford I. Weill, and his wife, Joan, and their Weill Family Foundation toward the completion of its $230 million renovation. The project, known as the Studio Towers Renovation, will create new spaces for music education on the landmark building’s upper floors and upgrade the concert hall’s backstage areas. It is scheduled to be completed in 2014.

headline: From Morgan Stanley, Investing in Women on Corporate Boards
abstract: A team within Morgan Stanley’s wealth management division is starting a new portfolio that seeks to invest in companies that have demonstrated a commitment to including women on their boards.
lead_paragraph: The lack of women on corporate boards has been a hot topic in financial circles recently, especially after a debate in Europe last year over imposing quotas.

headline: HBO Cancels ‘Enlightened’
abstract: The cult-favorite series “Enlightened” won’t return for a third season.
lead_paragraph: Despite some critical acclaim, a second-season ratings spike and a Golden Globe award for best actress, HBO’s “Enlightened” will be no more. After two seasons, the series, created by Mike White and Laura Dern, who also starred, has been canceled, The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: All the Plan B’s for Cyprus Look Dreadful
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Every day that the banks stay shut, the people of Cyprus may begin to appreciate the advantages of doing a deal with the euro zone.
lead_paragraph: The Cypriots have an expression, “eninboro allo.” It means: I cannot take any more of it.

headline: Minds at War
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: A comprehensive study of Civil War casualties shows that the conflict’s psychological impact was less extensive than we thought.
lead_paragraph: Any attempt to calculate the carnage of the Civil War, the number of sick, wounded, dismembered and dead, leaves one numb in the struggle to make sense of it all. The conditions and horrors faced by those who fought the war exacted a horrific toll.

headline: Outside the Citadel, Social Practice Art Is Intended to Nurture
abstract: Social practice artists blur the lines among object making, performance and activism, creating participatory work that often flourishes beyond galleries and museums.
lead_paragraph: In Detroit a contemporary-art museum is completing a monument to an influential artist that will not feature his work but will instead provide food, haircuts, education programs and other social services to the general public.

headline: Seder in Paris: Readers Want to Correct and Connect
abstract: Elaine Sciolino’s tales of making Seder meals as a gentile and an American in Paris drew requests for an invitation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mastering Passover hasn’t been easy. I’ve just written my Letter From Paris column on learning to do a proper Seder – as a Roman Catholic married to a Jew, and as an American living in Paris, where people tend to keep their religious beliefs and rituals to themselves.

headline: Trapped in the Muck
abstract: The Times’s Marc Santora on the successful effort to rescue a worker on the Second Avenue subway construction site.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Marc Santora on the successful effort to rescue a worker on the Second Avenue subway construction site.

headline: A Chef’s Guide to Eating in Jerusalem
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Chefs', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The London-based chef Yotam Ottolenghi offers advice for finding everything from memorable meze to his hometown’s best hummus.
lead_paragraph: When the London-based chef and restaurateur Yotam Ottolenghi, who grew up in the Jewish west side of Jerusalem, crisscrossed his hometown to research a cookbook he was writing with his company’s head chef, Sami Tamimi, from the Arab east, he became a specialist in the city’s subtle culinary distinctions. From the spices preferred by Jews from Libya to the technique Palestinians perfected for boiling chickpeas, “Jerusalem: A Cookbook” contains recipes inspired by the many flavors of the city’s shops and restaurants in tucked-away corners. Jerusalem should not be missed, Mr. Ottolenghi said. “Especially,” he added, “if you’re interested in those layers of the history, the people, the religions, the tensions.”

headline: Palmer Is Down on McIlroy’s Absence, Long Putters
abstract: Arnold Palmer is disappointed that Rory McIlroy is skipping the Arnold Palmer Invitational and he has no love for long putters, either.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. – Despite good-natured needling by the tournament host, Arnold Palmer, the world No. 1 Rory McIlroy chose love over a legend.

headline: How Viable Is Rand Paul for 2016?
abstract: Rand Paul has had a very good 2013, and he has been fairly explicit about his potential interest in running for president. Yet, oddsmakers continue to view him as a long shot.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no Republican has had a better 2013 than Rand Paul, the Kentucky senator who drew attention and praise for his talking filibuster against the C.I.A. director nominee John Brennan, then last week won the straw poll at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington. Then, on Tuesday, as my colleague Ashley Parker reports, Mr. Paul gave a speech to the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, outlining his plan for immigration reform.

headline: Havana, Art Deco Capital
abstract: Cuba is one of the world’s most significant but overlooked troves of Art Deco architecture, with many classic examples of the style in a state of disrepair.
lead_paragraph: Cuba is one of the world’s most significant but overlooked troves of Art Deco architecture, with many classic examples of the style in a state of disrepair.

headline: Indian Government Gets Support From Unlikely Corner
abstract: All India Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee supports government on Sri Lanka.
lead_paragraph: India’s beleaguered governing Indian National Congress received an unexpected boost Wednesday evening when a political party that had withdrawn its support in September offered its backing – on foreign policy, at least.

headline: And Snoring in 14E …
abstract: Finnair began a new check-in service this month that allows passengers to share their Facebook profiles with others on board. It’s a boon for fliers looking to socialize, not for those hoping to take a nap.
lead_paragraph: Finnair began a new check-in service this month that allows passengers to share their Facebook profiles with others on board and even see who’s seated next to them. It is the latest of a handful of carriers experimenting with social seating. The voluntary service is a boon for fliers looking to socialize, not for those hoping to take a nap.

headline: A ‘Sham Procedure’ Leads to Disappointing M.S. News
abstract: Today, the results of an early study on a controversial treatment for M.S. will be released.

headline: Who Has The Fastest LTE Service?
abstract: RootMetrics, a company that tests mobile network performance, did a survey in 77 cities and found that AT&T had the fastest LTE network and Verizon had the largest.
lead_paragraph: Which cellular carrier’s LTE data service is the fastest?

headline: Republicans Ask Themselves What Went Wrong
abstract: Brooks and Collins on the R.N.C.’s candid report, the philosophy of Ted Cruz and the emergence of Rand Paul.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, I recall that during the presidential primaries, you worried that the Republicans would nominate Mitt Romney, that Romney would lose and then the Tea Party would beat its chest and say that the only road to victory was through the far right. Last weekend, Senator Ted Cruz told a convention of conservatives: “We’re winning!” It made me think about what a good predictor you are.

headline: The Missing Piece
abstract: As the United States national soccer team prepares for two important World Cup qualifying matches, much focus is on Landon Donovan, who has taken a break from the sport.
lead_paragraph: Landon Donovan’s self-imposed exile from soccer has often been described as unprecedented or unusual, but this is hardly true. There is a rich and compelling history of surprising celebrity sabbaticals, with a wide variety of outcomes.

headline: Pope Meets Other Religious Leaders, Pledging Respect
abstract: Pope Francis described the spiritual bond between Catholics and Jews as “very special” and expressed gratitude to Muslim leaders.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis promised friendship, respect and continued dialogue with other religious leaders on Wednesday, pledging cooperation with Orthodox churches, describing the spiritual bond between Catholics and Jews as “very special” and expressing gratitude to Muslim leaders.

headline: Baby Steps on Gun Control
abstract: Congress can’t surmount pressure from the gun lobbies.
lead_paragraph: As gun-control opponents often argue, no single law will prevent any single act of gun violence. But hardly a day goes by without a reminder of how out-of-control our gun culture is, how much violence is committed with guns—and how tragic it is that the gun lobbies want to prevent the government from even trying to rein things in.

headline: Keeping the World Safe for Art
abstract: The job of a museum guard demands long hours, constant vigilance and a reservoir of patience to put up with illicit picture takers, soda smugglers and pontificating amateur art critics, among other annoyances.
lead_paragraph: The job of a museum guard demands long hours, constant vigilance and a reservoir of patience to put up with illicit picture takers, soda smugglers and pontificating amateur art critics, among other annoyances.

headline: The Era of Deep Archiving Begins
abstract: Soon everyone may be digitally archiving their lives. The architect William McDonough offers a glimpse of where we’re going.
lead_paragraph: As a Dartmouth student in the early 1970s, William McDonough went, somewhat casually, to hear a lecture by a visiting celebrity. Mr. McDonough had little idea beforehand who Buckminster Fuller was, but listening to the designer and futurist had a long-term effect.

headline: Sudden Rise in Home Demand Takes Builders by Surprise
abstract: As welcome as a long-awaited improvement in the American housing market may be, the unusually low level of homes for sale is creating problems for buyers and sellers alike.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — After six years of waiting on the sidelines, newly eager home buyers across the country are discovering that there are not enough houses for sale to accommodate the recent flush of demand.

headline: Young Opponents of Gay Marriage Undaunted by Battle Ahead
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Foreseeing a long battle like the one over abortion, conservatives in their 20s and 30s said there was time to shift the debate away from gay rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They hear that their cause is lost, that demographics and the march of history have doomed their campaign to keep marriage only between a man and a woman. But the young conservatives who oppose same-sex marriage — unlike most of their generation — remain undaunted.

headline: Police Search I.M.F. Chief’s Home in French Financial Investigation
abstract: A panel is looking into whether Christine Lagarde was complicit in the embezzlement of public money when she was the French finance minister.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French police on Wednesday searched the Paris apartment of Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, in connection with an investigation into her handling of a financial scandal when she was the French finance minister.

headline: A ‘Big Data’ Freeway for Scientists
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A “Big Data freeway system” for future science projects in fields including genomic sequencing, climate science and physics is to be announced by the University of California at San Diego this week. The new network is part of a move toward an era when networks will move trillions of bits per second.
lead_paragraph: The University of California, San Diego, this week plans to announce that it has installed an advanced optical computer network that is intended to serve as a “Big Data freeway system” for next-generation science projects in fields including genomic sequencing, climate science, electron microscopy, oceanography and physics.

headline: Excerpt: 'Breakfast at Tiffany's'
abstract: Emilia Clarke and Cory Michael Smith in a scene from the new Broadway play at the Cort Theater.
lead_paragraph: Emilia Clarke and Cory Michael Smith in a scene from the new Broadway play at the Cort Theater.

headline: Number of Hunger Strikers Surges at Guantánamo
abstract: Twenty-five prisoners are refusing food, the Defense Department said, and lawyers for the detainees said an underlying cause was searches of Korans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A hunger strike by detainees who have been held for years without trial at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has grown to involve at least 25 prisoners, the Defense Department disclosed Wednesday.

headline: Moscow Court Rejects Punk Band’s Appeal
abstract: A judge rejected an appeal by three members of the rock group Pussy Riot who were jailed for hooliganism after a protest in a church last year.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Moscow appellate court on Wednesday rejected an appeal by three members of the punk group Pussy Riot who were jailed for hooliganism after they called for the Virgin Mary to rid Russia of President Vladimir V. Putin in a protest in a church last year.

headline: Student Crossword | The Human Body
abstract: Play our crossword online or in print to see what you know, then discover more through our list of related links.
lead_paragraph: Play our crossword (PDF) to see what you know about the human body. And you can find the answers here.

headline: Spring Training
abstract: How athletic pieces, when paired with crisp shirts and neat trousers, can add graphic interest to the most basic wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: Though men have been wearing their suits with running shoes and incorporating sweatshirts into work gear for a while now, the athletic look continues this spring. Miuccia Prada presented a collection of what seemed to be team uniforms for the future. Valentino, Bottega Veneta and Raf Simons showed the majority (if not all) of their looks with sneakers instead of proper oxfords. Some designers were even more specific with their sporty adaptions — as in the case of the young British designer Lou Dalton, who created this high-fashion take on a baseball shirt ($399; openingceremony.us).

headline: What Argentine Priests Knew About the ‘Dirty War’
abstract: During Argentina’s “Dirty War,” people thought to be enemies of the state were bundled into Ford Falcons without license plates and disappeared. Would the “war” have been less dirty if the Roman Catholic church had stood up to its perpetrators?
lead_paragraph: In 1975, I watched churches in Buenos Aires fill with distraught mothers praying futilely for news of missing sons and daughters. Troubled police officers frequented the confessionals. Most Argentines suspected that President Isabel Perón and her Rasputin, José López Rega, were behind official death squads that made so many people disappear. Priests knew the details.

headline: Dreams of Saving Art Deco Havana
abstract: A world congress of Art Deco experts is uncovering gems in Havana ripe for restoration.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Kathleen Murphy Skolnik gasped one recent morning as she gazed up into the stairwell of a 1939 downtown apartment building here and pointed at the chevron pattern in the ironwork, at the unpolished rust-pink marble and a simple alcove on the stairway crowned by a stepped arch.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa: Longer, and Shaping Up for a Big Year
abstract: Pictures of Azzedine Alaïa’s latest collection don’t adequately capture the three-dimensional quality of the knitting.
lead_paragraph: Pictures of Azzedine Alaïa’s latest collection don’t adequately capture the three-dimensional quality of the knitting. Polka dots on a baby-doll dress, shown with matched leggings, are actually raised, like embroidery, and a series of vertically striped dresses are in fact ribbons of lacework backed by a shimmery knit. Other sophisticated techniques include honeycomb pleating, and most of the garments have a minimum number of seams. It’s remarkable what Mr. Alaïa is able to express through one form.

headline: Chemicals Would Be ‘Game Changer’ in Syria, Obama Says
abstract: President Obama’s remarks represented both an effort to warn Syria’s government of the consequences of using its chemical arsenal and to signal support for Israel, the main point of his trip there.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Showing solidarity with Israel’s growing concern about chemical weapons in neighboring Syria, President Obama stated bluntly on Wednesday that if an investigation he had ordered found proof that the Syrian military had used such weapons it would be a “game changer” in American involvement in the civil war there.

headline: Barclays Bankers Cash In on Past Bonuses
abstract: The British bank disclosed on Wednesday that its investment banking head, Rich Ricci, had cashed in $26 million of deferred shares.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It pays to be a Barclays banker.

headline: Knicks’ Anthony Says He Is Ready to Return
abstract: If all continues to go well, Carmelo Anthony will return from his knee injury on Wednesday night against Orlando at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks slept in their own beds Tuesday night after being on the road for 10 days, the longest such stretch of the season. A brutal five-game western road trip, during which they were 1-4 and lost Carmelo Anthony, Tyson Chandler and Kurt Thomas to injury, is finally in the past.

headline: At Hanjan, It’s No Secret When the Chicken Died
abstract: At a new Korean tavern, the owner and chef says that the best way to serve poultry is on the same day that it met its maker.
lead_paragraph: For the most part, American restaurants are not keen on reminding their customers that the meat they’re about to eat comes from an animal that has, at some point along the way, been killed.

headline: CBS Renews ‘C.S.I.’
abstract: CBS has renewed, C.S.I is the biggest television hit of the past decade, for a 14th season.
lead_paragraph: CBS announced Wednesday that it has renewed the biggest television hit of the past decade, “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation,” for a 14th season.

headline: Justices Back Loggers in Water Runoff Case
abstract: In its ruling, the Supreme Court deferred to the Environmental Protection Agency’s reading of its own rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that logging companies and forestry officials in Oregon were not required to obtain permits from the Environmental Protection Agency for storm-water runoff from logging roads.

headline: Cell Therapy Shows Promise for Acute Type of Leukemia
abstract: Genetically altering a patient’s immune cells has, for the first time, produced remissions in adults with a virulent blood cancer. In one patient, the disease vanished in eight days.
lead_paragraph: A treatment that genetically alters a patient’s own immune cells to fight cancer has, for the first time, produced remissions in adults with an acute leukemia that is usually lethal, researchers are reporting.

headline: Exhibitions on View
abstract: A sampler of offerings at art museums across the country this spring and summer.
lead_paragraph: A sampler of offerings at art museums across the country this spring and summer.

headline: With Freddie Mac Suit, Banks Face Billions More in Libor Claims
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Mortgages', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Unlike other plaintiffs, Freddie Mac looks to have a strong case because it dealt directly with many of the banks accused of manipulating the London interbank offered rate.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, has already cost banks $2.5 billion in penalties, not to mention loss of reputation.

headline: Team on the Way to Collect Congo War Crimes Suspect
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Bosco Ntaganda, who has been accused of massacring villagers and recruiting child soldiers in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, showed up unexpectedly at the American Embassy in Rwanda.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — American officials on Wednesday said that a team from the International Criminal Court was on its way to Rwanda to collect a war crimes suspect who had turned himself in to the American Embassy and that they were hoping Rwanda would cooperate.

headline: Fed to Maintain Stimulus Efforts Despite Jobs Growth
abstract: “We need to see sustained improvement,” the Fed’s chairman, Ben Bernanke, said on Wednesday. “One or two months doesn’t cut it.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Employment has been increasing at a healthy clip for the last few months, but the Federal Reserve is not ready to relax just yet.

headline: Backup Cat Out of ‘Breakfast’
abstract: Montie, the main cat understudy for “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” will be replaced by Moo.
lead_paragraph: Even as “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” prepared to open on Broadway Wednesday night, one cat was out of the bag — or at least, out of a job. The main cat understudy, Montie, a black-and-white male, has been fired for being, well, difficult. He didn’t follow stage directions.

headline: Single Parents: Unsupported, and Feeling the Blame
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Income Inequality', 'Parenting', 'Research', 'Single Mothers', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Men and boys appear caught in a vicious cycle of single-parent families and poverty, but the effects are felt by both sexes.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes research results are politically incorrect, or even offensive for some of us, and still worth talking about.

headline: Ronald Dworkin’s ‘Religious Atheism’
abstract: In this week’s briefs: religious atheists, the peculiar career of Hilary Putnam, and more.
lead_paragraph: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Many Strands Make Up One Woman
abstract: “Shaheed: The Dream and Death of Benazir Bhutto,” a one-woman show written and performed by Anna Khaja at the Culture Project, explores the assassinated prime minister of Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: A modernizing democrat or a “kleptocrat in a Hermès scarf”? Pakistan’s “daughter of destiny” (the title of her autobiography) or puppet of the West? That Benazir Bhutto, a two-time prime minister of Pakistan educated at Harvard and Oxford, contained not merely multitudes but multitudes of contradictions, would seem to be the premise of the uneven one-woman show “Shaheed: The Dream and Death of Benazir Bhutto,” written and performed by Anna Khaja at the Culture Project.

headline: Yankees Say Jeter May Not Be Ready for Opener
abstract: Derek Jeter received a cortisone shot after complaining of ankle stiffness, and General Manager Brian Cashman acknowledged he could begin the season on the disabled list.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — It’s Derek Jeter, so people automatically assume he will exceed normal standards. But it is possible that not even Jeter will be able to make the Yankees’ opening day lineup less than sixth months after fracturing his left ankle and needing surgery to repair it.

headline: Chip Kelly Could Have Been a Giant
abstract: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin once tried to hire Chip Kelly, the new coach of the Eagles, but was turned down.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Keep this in mind when the Giants and Eagles play: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin tried to hire new Eagles Coach Chip Kelly as a quality control coach not that long ago and was turned down. Kelly was the offensive coordinator at the University of New Hampshire, early in his meteoric rise, when the Giants came calling in 2006.

headline: NIMBY Deficit Hawks
abstract: Lawmakers love to talk about cutting spending. They just don’t like to do it.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Moran often repeated the Republican party’s magical incantation when he was running for senator from Kansas in 2010: “We don’t have a revenue problem – we have a spending problem.” After he was elected, he continued the drumbeat, and supported using the debt ceiling as a threat to enact more budget cuts. He opposed the 2011 budget deal that led to the sequester, not because he was against the sequester but because it didn’t cut spending enough.

headline: Iran’s Support Emboldens Assad, Envoy Says
abstract: Iran is stepping up its military assistance to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, strengthening his belief that he can prevail over the opposition, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran is stepping up its military assistance to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, and the supplies have strengthened his belief that he can prevail in his struggle with the opposition, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.

headline: Bon Jovi Bests Bowie on Album Chart
abstract: Bon Jovi’s “What About Now” topped Billboard’s album chart, outselling “The Next Day,” David Bowie’s first new album in a decade.
lead_paragraph: With the top of the Billboard album chart this week looking like a bit of a flashback to 1986, Bon Jovi is No. 1 and David Bowie has landed at No. 2 with his first new album in a decade.

headline: Hands, Disfigured in Fire, Are Now Essential to Livelihood
abstract: Sandy Yu’s fingers were fused together when she was a child. Still, she operates a portable watch-repair shop.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, Sandy Yu, protected by a red parka, was one of the few sidewalk vendors who showed up along a normally jammed Fifth Avenue commercial strip in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Stimulus Derangement Syndrome
abstract: An economists’ affliction.
lead_paragraph: Miles Kimball goes after John Taylor’s latest, and in the process reminds us of an earlier Taylor episode, in which JT argued that low interest rates are actually contractionary — a conclusion he reached by confusing the Fed’s setting of an interest rate target, which is achieved by buying bonds, with a rent-control-type price ceiling enforced by simply banning above-target transactions. It was an amazing thing for a highly credentialed macroeconomist to say. But it wasn’t unique; just offhand I can think of multiple comparable flubs ever since we began monetary and fiscal stimulus to fight the Great Recession.

headline: Test Run: Rdio vs. Spotify for Streaming Music
abstract: Spotify and Rdio, two popular streaming music apps, are duking it out for the loyalty of streaming music listeners. But Rdio’s beautiful design, recently improved in its mobile app, gives it an edge.
lead_paragraph: Talking about Spotify versus Rdio, two competing music streaming services, can be like arguing with someone in a bar over two baseball teams: People passionately love one or the other and will happily share their disdain for the rival. But Spotify often wins with its might and size, touting millions more users than Rdio.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Amazon-C.I.A. Deal, and Googling for GIFs
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include Amazon setting up the Kindle as a place to store online articles for reading later, how the explosion of cellphones has put drone technology into the public domain and within the budgets of hobbyists, and Apple’s great “I’m a Mac and I’m a PC’ ads collected on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Diverging Fortunes for Men and Women
abstract: In recent decades, men have lost ground to women in educational attainment, cutting into the real income of most males as prospects for those without a college education have worsened.
lead_paragraph: In recent decades, men have lost ground to women in educational attainment, cutting into the real income of most males as prospects for those without a college education have worsened.

headline: ‘Tonight,’ With New Host, Set to Reclaim Its New York Roots
abstract: An always-fractious changing of the guard on the late-night show will this time be accompanied by a change of scenery.
lead_paragraph: NBC has settled on two new stars for “The Tonight Show”: Jimmy Fallon and New York City.

headline: Iraq: 10 Years and Counting
abstract: Americans try to understand the war as Iraqis live with its consequences.
lead_paragraph: Americans try to understand the war as Iraqis live with its consequences.

headline: A Simpler Way to Complain About Student Loan Collections
abstract: The Department of Education has improved its online system for complaints about federal student loan collections.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers who run into trouble with their federal student loans should have an easier time filing complaints about private collection agencies that work under contract to the government, a new report says.

headline: The Nuggets Have a Streak of Their Own
abstract: Thanks to a balanced scoring attack, the Denver Nuggets have won 13 consecutive games, a club record, even without a high-scoring star.
lead_paragraph: With all eyes cast squarely upon the Miami Heat’s 23-game win streak, the Denver Nuggets have quietly put together a timely blitz of their own.

headline: Blending Art and Technology
abstract: Though other museums have experimented with interactive technology, the extent of a program at the Cleveland Museum of Art is unprecedented.
lead_paragraph: Though other museums have experimented with interactive technology, the extent of a program at the Cleveland Museum of Art is unprecedented.

headline: Key Democrat Chides President and Senators on Pace of Immigration Bill
abstract: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, frustrated that political calculations have delayed the release of an immigration proposal, issued a plea for more speed.
lead_paragraph: 6:46 p.m. | Updated As the Senate Judiciary Committee held its second hearing this week on overhauling the nation’s immigration laws, the committee’s chairman issued a frustrated plea for speeding up the overall pace of producing actual legislation.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Rationalizing Iraq
abstract: John Yoo says that if you think the Iraq war was a mistake, you must also support returning Saddam Hussein to power.
lead_paragraph: Via Conor Friedersdorf at The Atlantic

headline: Appeal Denied, Ex-Consultant Is Off to Jail
abstract: John F. Haggerty Jr., who was convicted in 2011 of stealing campaign funds from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, had been free on bail pending the outcome of an appeal.
lead_paragraph: For 17 months, John F. Haggerty Jr., a former Republican political consultant, fought his conviction on charges of stealing campaign money from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Michelle Shocked Says Comments on Gay Marriage Were Misunderstood
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The singer issued a statement after at least ten venues canceled scheduled performances.
lead_paragraph: At least ten clubs and music halls have canceled concerts by Michelle Shocked since she went on an anti-gay tirade during a show in San Francisco on Sunday night.

headline: Cyprus Shows How Not to Do a Bailout
abstract: The Cyprus crisis shows that, for all the faults with the financial crisis rescues in the United States, the European Union still finds ways to show us how poorly a bailout could be handled.
lead_paragraph: Cyprus can’t really be about Cyprus, can it? After all, the banking sector in that country pales in comparison to things like the London Whale trade and the amount of capital the big banks have to raise to meet Basel III.

headline: Best-Selling Russian Writer Turns From Crime to History
abstract: Grigory Chkhartishvili, better known by the pen name Boris Akunin, says he will write a multivolume history of Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Grigory Chkhartishvili, the best-selling Russian writer known for his detective novels set in imperial Russia (written under the name Boris Akunin), and for his foray into opposition politics directed against Vladimir V. Putin announced that from now on he would devote himself to writing a multivolume history of Russia.

headline: Hawk Cam Returns for Third Season
abstract: The live reality raptor drama, chronicling the lives of two Washington Square Park red-tailed hawks, Rosie and Bobby, will return for a third season.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:58 p.m.,Thursday | The Hawk Cam, which has chronicled the lives of red-tailed hawks in Washington Square Park since 2011, has returned for a third season. The stars of the reality raptor drama, believed to be last year’s couple, Rosie and Bobby, are currently warming three eggs on a nest situated on the 12th-floor window ledge of New York University’s president, John Sexton.

headline: A Litany of Betrayals, Petty Yet Terrifying
abstract: In “It’s No Good,” Kirill Medvedev turns a pitiless lens on intellectual corruption in Russia in the Putin era.
lead_paragraph: The feminist Russian punk band Pussy Riot, some of its members recently imprisoned, stands for many things, notably opposition to the policies of Vladimir Putin. One of its best-known songs contains the line “Virgin birth-giver of God, drive away Putin!” Another is titled, depending on the translation, “Putin Is Wetting Himself.”

headline: Devils Enjoying Surge in Attendance
abstract: The Devils may not be doing so well on the ice recently, but their ticket sales are on the upswing.
lead_paragraph: The Devils have won only three of their last 10 games, but they are on a more successful run at the box office. Including Wednesday night’s game against the Rangers at the Prudential Center in Newark, the Devils have sold out 14 of their last 16 home games this season and 25 of the last 27 games stretching back to last season’s playoffs.

headline: She Can’t Be Caged
abstract: Twitter followers were quick to judge the actress after she agreed to spend 90 days in rehab instead of jail.
lead_paragraph: Talk about revolving-door justice. On Monday, Lindsay Lohan struck a deal to spend 90 days in rehab instead of jail, after pleading no contest to reckless driving in a car crash last year along the Pacific Coast Highway. Twitter users were quick to judge.

headline: Indian Motorcycles Revs Up a New App
abstract: Polaris Industries is using an iPhone app to lead its introduction of the new Indian Motorcycles
lead_paragraph: Can you sell a nostalgic brand using a high-tech phone?

headline: New Reasons to Change Light Bulbs
abstract: LED bulbs last longer and use less power than older ones, and with prices falling, a change makes even more sense.
lead_paragraph: People sometimes have trouble making small sacrifices now that will reward them handsomely later. How often do we ignore the advice to make a few diet and exercise changes to live a longer, healthier life? Or to put some money aside to grow into a nest egg? Intellectually, we get it — but instant gratification is a powerful force.

headline: If You Like Billie Holiday, Try Madeleine Peyroux
abstract: The music of Billie Holiday and Madeleine Peyroux can provide the perfect backdrop for dinner parties.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Intertrust Sues Apple, Charging Patent Violations
abstract: Intertrust, which received a huge patent infringement settlement from Microsoft nearly a decade ago, has turned its focus to Apple with a lawsuit filed on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Intertrust, a company that nabbed a huge settlement over patents in a lawsuit with Microsoft nearly a decade ago, has turned its focus to Apple, suing the technology giant on Wednesday and charging infringements of its security and content protection patents.

headline: Site Where Man Was Pulled From the Mud
abstract: A diagram of the site in New York City where a worker was trapped in mud for four hours.
lead_paragraph: A diagram of the site in New York City where a worker was trapped in mud for four hours.

headline: Monetary Policy Statement From the Federal Reserve
abstract: The Fed’s statement announcing it was holding its base federal funds target rate at a record low between zero and 0.25 percent:
lead_paragraph: Following is the text of the Federal Reserve’s statement on Wednesday announcing it was holding its base federal funds target rate at a record low between zero and 0.25 percent:

headline: 71 Years in New York City Is Enough for Elaine Stritch
abstract: Elaine Stritch, 88, who has a Tony Award and three Emmys, said her last show at Café Carlyle would be in the first week of April.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Stritch is leaving the building.

headline: Obama and Netanyahu Meet in Israel
abstract: President Barack Obama held a joint press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday in Israel.
lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama held a joint press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday in Israel.

headline: The Prolific Willy Rizzo
abstract: Willy Rizzo, who died on Feb. 25, was known for his photography, his work as a furniture designer and his appearance as an actor in the film “Hoffa,” among his many pursuits.
lead_paragraph: FASHION WAS A CHALLENGING SUBJECT for a photojournalist like Willy Rizzo. He was already well established and living in Paris in the 1950s, his subjects having included politicians, playboys and a pontiff, when Alexander Liberman, then the art director of Vogue, asked him to shoot for the magazine.

headline: Peru, Chile and the War of the Pacific
abstract: Chile faces Peru in Lima on Friday in a critical World Cup qualifying match for the two South American rivals.
lead_paragraph: In many parts of the world, soccer equals history. Not a fan? Simply listening to the 40,000 fans at Estadio Nacional in Lima amplify the Peruvian national anthem blaring through the speakers before Friday night’s South American World Cup qualifier with Chile might change things.

headline: The Salary Bracket: This Is One Harvard Wins
abstract: Breaking down the N.C.A.A. tournament by alumni salaries, Harvard is the top seed.

headline: Profit Down 31%, FedEx Cuts Outlook
abstract: In an effort to reduce costs, FedEx said it would retire some older and less efficient airplanes.
lead_paragraph: Express shipping seems much less urgent these days.

headline: Emphasizing Safety, N.F.L. Passes Rule on Helmet Hits
abstract: N.F.L. owners passed a much-debated rule that penalizes players for lowering their helmet and using it as a battering ram to ward off opponents.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Tom Coughlin has pulled players aside during games to remind them not to lower their heads when they strike a blow.

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: Opening Ceremony’s ‘Spring Breakers’ collection; DKNY offers DJ lessons and other shopping related news.
lead_paragraph: Collaboration

headline: Flexibility and Moxie Can Save West Side
abstract: Should the permit for Madison Square Garden be extended in perpetuity, fixing Penn Station in place for the future?
lead_paragraph: New York is at a crossroads. After half a century a fleeting opportunity has finally arrived to address the disaster of Penn Station, the nation’s busiest and most appalling transit hub, and to reimagine a new West Side for Midtown Manhattan that could be a center for development and innovation.

headline: Photo Replay: March 20
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including the women’s European wrestling championships.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including the women’s European wrestling championships.

headline: Mad for Museums in China
abstract: In China, museums — big, small, government-backed, privately bankrolled — are opening like mad. In 2011 alone, some 390 new ones appeared. And the numbers are holding.
lead_paragraph: In China, museums — big, small, government-backed, privately bankrolled — are opening like mad. In 2011 alone, some 390 new ones appeared. And the numbers are holding.

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Finance Government and Soften Spending Cuts
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate on Wednesday passed legislation to keep the government financed through the end of the fiscal year — and to take some of the sting out of across-the-board spending cuts coursing through the government.
lead_paragraph: Read an updated version of this post.

headline: Travel Essentials | Brussels
abstract: The short list on where to eat, sleep and view art in Belgium’s capital.
lead_paragraph: The short list on where to eat, sleep and view art in Belgium’s capital.

headline: Art Market | Big in Belgium
abstract: With cheap spaces, a friendly scene and a thoughtful audience, the once sleepy Brussels arts scene is making some noise.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Kreider Gets Another Chance at Sticking with Rangers
abstract: The Rangers have recalled rookie forward Chris Kreider for a third time this season to help bolster the team’s anemic attack.
lead_paragraph: Chris Kreider, the Rangers’ rookie forward, will get a third try at sticking with the team this season after being recalled from the American Hockey League Wednesday. Kreider scored six goals in eight games for Connecticut, the Rangers’ A.H.L. affiliate, since his latest demotion on Feb. 28.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: March 21
abstract: Fashion trend: transparent bags; Frame Denim’s skinny jeans; a wardrobe staple acquires some fresh looks; and Candela Turco’s Pasionae Murano glass rings.
lead_paragraph: Fashion trend: transparent bags; Frame Denim’s skinny jeans; a wardrobe staple acquires some fresh looks; and Candela Turco’s Pasionae Murano glass rings.

headline: In City Hall, a One-Man Show That Ran for Three Terms
abstract: In “The Little Flower” Tony Lo Bianco sets out to demonstrate what made Fiorello La Guardia, who ran New York City from 1934 through 1945, so beloved.
lead_paragraph: The man hated lawyers. He wiped out political corruption (Tammany Hall, anyway). He was a Republican who bonded with Franklin D. Roosevelt. On his first day at City Hall he cut his own salary in half. During a newspaper strike he read the comics on WNYC Radio.

headline: Better Asteroid Detection Is Needed, Experts Say
abstract: A former astronaut told a Senate panel that there would have been far more casualties if New York had been hit by a meteor instead of Siberia.
lead_paragraph: Making a case for the need to detect asteroids before they hit Earth, a former astronaut said Wednesday that the number of casualties would have been enormous had the space rock that exploded in Russia last month blown apart directly over New York City instead.

headline: Where’s Voyager 1? That Depends.
abstract: For about three hours on Wednesday, Voyager 1 had left the solar system — before a rewritten news release headline pulled it back in.
lead_paragraph: For about three hours on Wednesday, Voyager 1 had left the solar system — before a rewritten news release headline pulled it back in.

headline: Stepping Back Into a Jazzy Tap-Dance Cabaret
abstract: The American Tap Dance Foundation presented a nostalgic cabaret-style show as part of its “Rhythm Is Our Business” program at the 14th Street Y.
lead_paragraph: This week the American Tap Dance Foundation is presenting two productions, one recreating tap’s past, one exhibiting tap’s present. “Rhythm Is Our Business,” the backward-looking show, opened at the Theater at the 14th Street Y on Tuesday with a video montage of great moments in tap from the 1930s through the 1950s that was oddly silent and so dimly projected you could barely see it. The live performances that followed were much more vivid, though a little faint too.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Israel, Syria, North Korea and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Syria, North Korea and Greece.

headline: Camouflage on the Fall 2013 Runways
abstract: How camo can you go?
lead_paragraph: How camo can you go?

headline: Canyons, Inspiring to the Eye, Capture the Ear, Too
abstract: Robert Spano conducted Ensemble ACJW in a performance of Messiaen’s “Des Canyons aux Étoiles” at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: The visionary French composer Olivier Messiaen and the citizens of Utah had a mutual appreciation. Messiaen, inspired to write his glittering “Des Canyons aux Étoiles” (“From the Canyons to the Stars”) after visiting the state’s parks in 1972, declared southern Utah the most mystical landscape he had ever seen. In gratitude, a mountain was renamed in his honor.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: LED Light Bulbs
abstract: LED bulbs are a gigantic improvement over incandescent bulbs and compact fluorescents. David Pogue tries out LED bulbs and kits from six manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: LED bulbs are a gigantic improvement over incandescent bulbs and compact fluorescents. David Pogue tries out LED bulbs and kits from six manufacturers.

headline: A Disguise for When You Want to Be Seen
abstract: How camo can you go? Dries Van Noten’s spring show was just the tip of a brown and dark green mottled iceberg.
lead_paragraph: No one saw it coming. The men’s fashion collection that Dries Van Noten showed for spring was a cavalcade of camouflage.

headline: Palestinian Protesters Set Up Camp in West Bank
abstract: As President Obama began his visit to Israel, scores of Palestinian activists pitched tents in the hotly contested area known as E1.
lead_paragraph: AL-AZARIYA, West Bank — It was hardly the most visible place to stage an anti-Obama protest, on a stony hillside on the edge of this West Bank town just east of Jerusalem. But for the Palestinians, it was highly symbolic.

headline: Sensuously Rippling Bodies, All There to Serve the Rhythm
abstract: DanceBrazil’s program at the Joyce Theater features a cast that is deeply sensuous but has only a hint of eroticism.
lead_paragraph: The performers of DanceBrazil, as seen this week at the Joyce Theater, exist in a ravishing, hard-working paradise. They’re barefoot; their attire (T-shirts, loose trousers, light dresses or skirts) has no hint of luxury. What matters here above all is the gorgeously full physicality of movement, allied to music. While spines continually plunge beneath the level of the waist, legs kick explosively above it or maintain powerful extensions like searchlights.

headline: The Man of the Hour, or Four
abstract: Anderson Cooper is honored and Madonna is the star at the (lengthy) Glaad Media Awards.
lead_paragraph: After an enervating evening that was about to hit the four-hour mark and was driving some members of the audience to the exits, Madonna came on stage Saturday at the 24th Glaad Media Awards and reminded people exactly why she’s a superstar.

headline: Republican Council Members Endorse Lhota
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota gained support as he faces a better-financed rival, John A. Catsimatidis, in the party’s primary for mayor.
lead_paragraph: All four Republican members of the City Council made an endorsement in the New York mayoral race on Wednesday, pledging their support to Joseph J. Lhota, a former deputy in the Giuliani administration and Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman.

headline: Celebrating Philip Roth at 80
abstract: Mr. Roth’s native Newark celebrated his birthday with a daylong academic conference, a new photo exhibition, a bus tour and a party at the Newark Museum.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Roth’s native Newark celebrated his birthday with a daylong academic conference, a new photo exhibition, a bus tour and a party at the Newark Museum.

headline: Country’s Straight-Talk Feminists
abstract: Ashley Monroe’s “Like a Rose” and Kacey Musgraves’s “Same Trailer Different Park” are a pair of acidic and beautiful new country albums.
lead_paragraph: Country music fearmongers in the mid-2000s had their choice of invading bêtes noires. From one direction Taylor Swift arrived, a pop-friendly ingénue with sparkling songs and a killer instinct. From another, Miranda Lambert was stomping in, full of vitriol and skepticism, an alpha answering to no beta.

headline: Goodbye, Newark, the Place Roth Never Left
abstract: Philip Roth’s native Newark celebrated his 80th birthday with a daylong academic conference, a new photo exhibition, a bus tour and a party at the Newark Museum.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Since he announced his retirement from writing, Philip Roth has been in an unusually good mood. On Tuesday he celebrated his 80th birthday here — a city where he no longer lives but never entirely left — by juking into a reception space at the Newark Museum behind marching-band drummers from Weequahic High School, his alma mater. There Mr. Roth, normally the most private of authors, was greeted with applause from 250 friends, relatives and invited guests, including members of the Philip Roth Society, scholars who specialize in his work.

headline: Spring North American Championships
abstract: The Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was won on Sunday evening by Martin Fleisher of New York City and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — At the Spring North American Championships here the Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was won on Sunday evening by Martin Fleisher of New York City and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J. They finished just over one board ahead of JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif., and Jeff Meckstroth of Clearwater Beach, Fla. Third were John Kranyak of Las Vegas and Vincent Demuy of Laval, Quebec.

headline: Thorny Questions for Justices in Raisin Case
abstract: The Supreme Court tried to sort out a tangled argument involving a raisin farmer who cited the Fifth Amendment in challenging a Depression-era program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The current Supreme Court sometimes seems to relish a procedural puzzle.

headline: A Feminist Illustrator Gets Her Due
abstract: Barbara Nessim is honored with a London retrospective.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Nessim is honored with a London retrospective.

headline: At the Table, a Touch of Couture
abstract: A 50-piece collection from Christian Lacroix Home with four wildly different patterns to mix and match.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, the fashion label Christian Lacroix suspended its couture and women’s ready-to-wear activities and lost 90 percent of its staff, including Mr. Lacroix. But under Sacha Walckhoff, Lacroix’s longtime creative director, the company continues to design vibrant, pattern-clashing items. Next month in the United States, it will introduce a 50-piece collection of china in four motifs. The tableware, made by Vista Alegre in Portugal, features polychromatic butterflies, roughly painted black stripes, a floral mosaic and a 19th-century engraving of the ancient Roman arena in Arles. The bold consumer is encouraged to combine any or all of these patterns.

headline: Photography’s New Prominence
abstract: Large numbers of exhibitions are being organized by museum photography departments across the country at a time when a new crop of photography curators have taken the helm at major museums.
lead_paragraph: Large numbers of exhibitions are being organized by museum photography departments across the country at a time when a new crop of photography curators have taken the helm at major museums.

headline: Pushing the Boundaries of Scandinavian Design
abstract: Antik, which sold antiques in TriBeCa, reopens as Hostler Burrows in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Antik, which sold Scandinavian antiques in TriBeCa until May, has re-emerged in Greenwich Village as Hostler Burrows. When the shop opened in the late ’90s, “people knew Hans Wegner, Georg Jensen, Jens Risom — three Danish designers,” said Kim Hostler, an owner with Juliet Burrows. The women have since introduced other 20th-century Scandinavians. Shown at top, the work of five Swedish designers: 1940s blue-gray chairs by Otto Schulz ($14,000 a pair), 1950s ivory chairs by Kerstin Horlin-Holmqvist ($12,500 a pair) and a table by Axel Einar Hjorth ($16,000). Above, 1950s porcelain vases by Berndt Friberg (from $2,200 each) and a 1939 rug by Sigvard Bernadotte ($28,000): (212) 343-0471, hostlerburrows.com.

headline: Sculpture From the Storm
abstract: Gregg Klewicki, a woodworker on Long Island, carves bears, gulls and other objects from stumps, many of them from trees brought down by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Most of the thousands of tree limbs and stumps left by Hurricane Sandy were sent to composting facilities and trash heaps. But some homeowners have embraced the wreckage by turning their downed trees into sculpture. Gregg Klewicki, a 45-year-old woodcarver in Huntington, N.Y., began his craft when he was 20. His first project, he said, was a giant nose that he placed on his front lawn. Within a few weeks, someone knocked on his door willing to pay $300 for it, so he started carving on the weekends. A few years later, Mr. Klewicki had enough commissions to quit his day job driving a beer truck. Last week, he laid down his chain saw long enough to talk to a reporter.

headline: Sales at Ann Gish, Tom Dixon and Others
abstract: Discounts on bed linens, furniture, lighting and more.
lead_paragraph: Bed and tabletop linens are up to 80 percent off at Ann Gish Thursday to Sunday (a queen-size Jack Stripe silk duvet cover by Ann Gish, shown, originally $1,165, is $350); 4 West 20th Street, (212) 727-2122, anngish.com.

headline: Some Plants Deserve a Toast
abstract: In “The Drunken Botanist,” Amy Stewart explores the connection between plants and alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Amy Stewart has a way of making gardening seem exciting, even a little dangerous, as she did with “Wicked Plants,” her best-selling book about poisonous and invasive vegetation. In “The Drunken Botanist” (Algonquin, $19.95), her latest, Ms. Stewart is once again out to show the sexier side of the garden, this time linking plants to alcoholic spirits.

headline: Bavarian Castle, Moat Included
abstract: A 12th-century castle in Kipfenberg, Germany, is on the market for $7.4 million.
lead_paragraph: A 12th-century castle in Kipfenberg, Germany, is on the market for $7.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
keywords: ['Palaces and Castles', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The conservative lending practices of German banks have bolstered home prices, which have continued to climb despite the global economic downturn.
lead_paragraph: A 12th-CENTURY BAVARIAN CASTLE SURROUNDED BY A MOAT AND 27 ACRES

headline: Cubes and Spheres at Work
abstract: A new collection from the British furniture designer Faye Toogood is now available in New York.
lead_paragraph: The British designer Faye Toogood makes one-of-a kind, expressively minimal furniture. But Ms. Toogood, a former editor at The World of Interiors magazine, wanted to reach a broader audience and turned to batch production, making 10 to 100 pieces of a design at a time. Her Batch line was introduced in London last year and is now available in the United States at Matter, in SoHo. The collection includes the Element table, right, which has a tinted glass top that rests on a cube, sphere and cylinder, all made of solid ash. “I have fabricated the table in many different materials before,” she said. “By simply changing the materials and the volume and void of the piece, it has seen many incarnations.” This one is 39 inches square, 8 inches tall and $5,360. Information: (212) 343-2600 or mattermatters.com.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
abstract: A co-op in Washington, D.C., a Gothic Revival in Omaha and a condo in Savannah.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C.

headline: Properties for $800,000
abstract: A four-bedroom co-op in Washington, D.C., a Gothic revival in Omaha, Neb., and a parlor floor condo in an 1894 townhouse in Savannah, Ga.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom co-op in Washington, D.C., a Gothic revival in Omaha, Neb., and a parlor floor condo in an 1894 townhouse in Savannah, Ga.

headline: Market Ready
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Paint', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: I want my home to stand out from the crowd. Which paint colors will make it look unique, but still clean and crisp?
lead_paragraph: Q. I want my home to stand out from the crowd. Which paint colors will make it look unique, but still clean and crisp?

headline: Shopping for Paperweights
abstract: Andrew Zobler, the founder and chief executive of the Sydell Group, has amassed 100 or so paperweights since he was a boy.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Zobler, the founder and chief executive of the Sydell Group, has amassed 100 or so paperweights since he was a boy.

headline: Paperweights
abstract: In an increasingly digital world, paperweights still have a place on the desk, from paper organizer to objet d’art.
lead_paragraph: SOME 8-YEAR-OLD BOYS collect Legos or baseball cards, but when Andrew Zobler was that age, he collected paperweights. It wasn’t exactly his decision.

headline: The Particular Puzzles of Being a Small Museum
abstract: Riding the slipstream of a tourist boom can help, but most modest museums have to be very inventive to bring in visitors — and cultivate a loyal core.
