lead_paragraph: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, 13 people gathered outside the Merchant’s House Museum on East Fourth Street in Manhattan. Each had paid $15 for a guided tour of the surrounding NoHo neighborhood, once a tony section of the city. Their guide: an expert from the museum.

headline: Technology That Serves to Enhance, Not Distract
abstract: The Cleveland Museum of Art’s iPad app and its touch-screen gallery are intended to let the rest of the galleries display art without a lot of bells and whistles.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND

headline: Progress Stalls in California on Earthquake Warnings
abstract: While other quake-prone places like Mexico and Japan have surged ahead with effective alert systems, California’s network, which would be the nation’s first, has been delayed by a lack of money.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Scientists at the Caltech Seismology Laboratory were at their computers last week when a warning popped up on the screen: “Earthquake, earthquake!” The initial magnitude of the quake, 100 miles away, was 5.2, the alert said, and a countdown clock warned that mild shaking would reach here in 40 seconds.

headline: Leader Unafraid to Venture Outside of the Lines
abstract: Since taking over in 2007 as director of the Society of Illustrators, Anelle Miller has focused on attracting innovative artists and younger visitors.
lead_paragraph: THINK of the Society of Illustrators and the image likely to spring to mind is that of a quaint, august institution whose heyday coincided with that of The Saturday Evening Post. But this wasn’t the picture the society presented one recent winter evening, when every floor of its building on East 63rd Street fairly blazed with activity.

headline: Enshrining Art With a Permanent, and Personal, Home
abstract: Museums founded by moguls represent a departure from recent philanthropy directed at solving social problems, and the trend coincides with a modest rise in arts philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: RIVALING earlier American moguls who built elaborate edifices to house their art collections, magnates of the 21st century are pouring their fortunes into founding their own ambitious museums.

headline: Examining Sargent’s Shift From Oil to Watercolors
abstract: Experimental works by John Singer Sargent are grouped together in a collaborative effort by the Brooklyn Museum and Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts.
lead_paragraph: BY the time John Singer Sargent reached his mid-40s at the beginning of the 20th century, he had long been saluted as the best society portrait painter of the Gilded Age. But he was having a midlife career crisis.

headline: Renovation, Italian Style
abstract: A man, his partner, her old flame and his wife fixed up a Tuscan parish house that once sheltered priests, pilgrims, knights and farmers.
lead_paragraph: Elisabetta Bruscolini and Giancarlo Astrologo are passionate collectors of friends, objects and, yes, homes.

headline: Rothko’s Journey to His Fields of Color, in Full View
abstract: “The Decisive Decade,” a touring exhibit of 37 works in different media, shows the transformation over time of the artist Mark Rothko.
lead_paragraph: FOR many art lovers, Mark Rothko’s layered bands of misty color represent the apex of 20th-century abstraction. Here was an artist who painstakingly distilled the achievements of the painters who came before him and forever changed how we see the horizon line.

headline: A Tribute for Turning Light Into Art
abstract: Three museums are planning coordinated, successive exhibitions dedicated to the work of James Turrell.
lead_paragraph: “LIGHT is this thing we usually use to illuminate other things,” said the artist James Turrell, who first considered the presence of a beam of light cast from a slide projector during art history class at Pomona College in the early 1960s. “I’m interested that light has thingness itself, so it’s not something that reveals something about other things you’re looking at, but it becomes a revelation in itself.”

headline: Seeing the Art in Plastic Straws and Other Castoffs
abstract: A contest for New York City students, sponsored by Ripley’s Believe or Not Odditorium, challenges them to turn recycled materials into art.
lead_paragraph: THE contest challenge was to create outrageous art from unconventional materials. The students in Eileen Farrelly-Moyotl’s 11th-grade fashion design class at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan were up to it: one of them made a dress from plastic bags filled with floating fish.

headline: Modern Wrapped in Tuscan Stone
abstract: An ancient Tuscan parish house, fitted with a sleek interior.
lead_paragraph: An ancient Tuscan parish house, fitted with a sleek interior.

headline: Art and History Among the Dead
abstract: Cemeteries are taking on the characteristics of museums to raise their public profiles and to increase fund-raising efforts.
lead_paragraph: ONE of New York City’s most unusual museums is not on Fifth Avenue or Madison Avenue, but on 400 acres of beautifully landscaped land at Webster Avenue and East 233rd Street in the Bronx.

headline: In Rome Exhibition, a Poem to New York
abstract: “Empire State,” featuring 25 well- and lesser-known New York artists, opens in Rome’s Palazzo delle Esposizioni on April 22.
lead_paragraph: NEW York’s role as the ruling city of the art world has held steady since at least the middle of the 20th century. Next month, a new exhibition about the city’s ever-growing and constantly shifting art scene is opening in the capital of a much older empire: Rome.

headline: The Rijksmuseum, Reborn
abstract: The renovation of the Rijksmuseum is the latest cultural project to be completed in Amsterdam in recent years.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM

headline: The Stories of the Holocaust
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Museums', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: A Web site created by the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Manhattan is intended to teach young people about the Holocaust through stories from survivors.
lead_paragraph: INGE OPPENHEIMER is accustomed to telling her story. How she watched her synagogue burn on Kristallnacht, survived the Nazi labor camps and immigrated to the United States, where she became a school librarian.

headline: Grasping at Straw
abstract: Even if your yard is asphalt, there’s an easy way to grow vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Do you have bad dirt? No dirt? Is the earth in your garden actually a sidewalk?

headline: Justin Timberlake Takes the Style Spotlight
abstract: Long gone and perhaps best forgotten is the boy-band alumnus with frosted curls and cornrows.
lead_paragraph: Long gone and perhaps best forgotten is the boy-band alumnus with frosted curls and cornrows.

headline: In Denver, Exhibits Interweave Genres
abstract: To encourage visitors to see the breadth of its holdings and all parts of its campus, the Denver Art Museum devised “Spun: Adventures in Textiles,” an exhibition that crosses various departments.
lead_paragraph: THIS summer, the Denver Art Museum is staging a blockbuster exhibition — make that exhibitions. Called “Spun: Adventures in Textiles,” it presents about a dozen exhibits, all variations on the theme, and is designed to address a chronic problem at museums: getting visitors to look at their permanent collections.

headline: Justin Timberlake, He’s All Dressed Up
abstract: Justin Timberlake, no stranger to sartorial makeover, has transformed himself into a new Cary Grant.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever seen the body?” Tom Ford, the designer, said by telephone from London, referring to a broad-shouldered, narrow-hipped physique that might represent the universal standard for male models. He was talking about Justin Timberlake.

headline: A Boston Palace Where Greenery Ties Old to New
abstract: The rooms of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston are virtually unchanged since 1924 — but the courtyards link the past to the future.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON

headline: Looking for Ways to Groom Repeat Visitors
abstract: As attendance at art museums flags, membership programs are being tailored for a new kind of loyalty.
lead_paragraph: ART museums, seeking the repeat and committed visitor, are experimenting with new ways to cultivate a closer relationship with the public — and, in essence, to become a welcoming extension of the living room, rather than a stiff, Sunday-best excursion.

headline: Country Music Temple Stays in Financial Tune
abstract: Unlike most museums, which rely on donations, the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum depends on income from admissions, retail sales and events.
lead_paragraph: VINCE GILL was there, singing about his wife’s smile. Emmylou Harris started off with “Love Hurts.” Jason Aldean sang “Big Green Tractor,” and laughed about hitting the big time with a tune about a farm vehicle. Late last month, they and a handful of other country music stars were gathered in a Times Square theater for a “guitar pull,” an improvised concert at which anything might happen.

headline: The Science of Moving Science Across Town
abstract: While many Exploratorium employees were eagerly anticipating the improvements at their new home, a $220 million space nearly tripling the exhibition area, there was room for reminiscing.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Shrines for Locals Who Made Good
abstract: Small museums tucked away on America’s back roads keep alive the memories of once-popular movie stars and singers.
lead_paragraph: THE round birthday cake was small and simple — “Happy Birthday Mario,” it read. A little more than a dozen people showed up for the cold-cut spread and the operatic music piped into the little party room.

headline: The Man Who Would Be Done
abstract: The editor of This Old House has worked on his own home for 14 years, with no end in sight.

headline: What Did You Do in the Civil War, California?
abstract: A museum is a monument to an often-overlooked theater of the Civil War, the Far West.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

headline: Brodeur Ready to Return to Struggling Devils
abstract: Goalie Martin Brodeur, whose monthlong absence led to a 3-8-2 slide by the Devils, is expected to rejoin the lineup for Thursday night’s game against the Hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK – Goalie Martin Brodeur, whose monthlong absence triggered a tumble in the standings that has the Devils in danger of missing the playoffs, is expected to rejoin the lineup for Thursday night’s game at the Carolina Hurricanes.

headline: A Curmudgeon’s Home Remade
abstract: The results of a painful and ongoing renovation of the Hoboken, N.J., home owned by the editor of This Old House magazine.
lead_paragraph: The results of a painful and ongoing renovation of the Hoboken, N.J., home owned by the editor of This Old House magazine.

headline: Israeli Group Protests Detention of Palestinian Children Suspected of Throwing Rocks
abstract: The Israeli rights group B’Tselem protested the detention of 27 Palestinian children suspected of throwing rocks at settlers and soldiers in the West Bank city of Hebron.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli rights group B’Tselem protested the detention on Wednesday of 27 Palestinian children suspected of throwing rocks at settlers and soldiers in the West Bank city of Hebron.

headline: Celebrating Fellini and Venice
abstract: At a benefit for the Venetian Heritage Foundation, the spirit of the film director Federico Fellini was very much present.
lead_paragraph: The architect Peter Marino had an aversion to toga-and-sandal epics until he saw “Satyricon,” Federico Fellini’s bawdy, episodic narration of Roman life in the age of Nero.

headline: A Building Boom as Chinese Art Rises in Stature
abstract: China is opening museums on a surreal scale, but the country is still sorting out what exactly it wants from them.
lead_paragraph: After years of fevered activity, museum building and expansion in the United States have slowed to a crawl under a low-lying economic cloud. In Europe, where the climate is even stormier, venerable state-financed institutions go begging for cash.

headline: The Lens Rises in Stature
abstract: Museums — many of them with new photography department heads — are organizing exhibitions that in some cases incorporate other art media.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent wintry afternoon, Jeff Rosenheim, the newly appointed head of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s photography department, stopped in at its special exhibition galleries. He was checking on the installation of a new acquisition: a 61-minute video called “Street,” by the British-born artist James Nares.

headline: Varied Duties, and Many Facets, in a Guard’s Life
abstract: Consider the army grunts of the art world. They stand on the front lines of a battle to keep our cultural heritage accessible and safe.
lead_paragraph: IN the 1990s, a technology company, Cybermotion, tried to sell museums on the concept of robot security guards.

headline: On Exhibit, From Ancient Arts to Sound and Video
abstract: A collection of events planned at museums nationwide this spring and summer.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of the rich variety of art on view this spring and summer.

headline: Anti-Fracking Group Criticizes Energy Nominee for Not Disclosing Industry Ties
abstract: The group says the president’s choice to be the energy secretary, Ernest J. Moniz, had close ties to the natural gas industry that he did not disclose before he authored a report on the subject.
lead_paragraph: A watchdog group that opposes fracking for natural gas released a report on Wednesday that criticizes the president’s choice to be energy secretary, Ernest J. Moniz, for failing to disclose in an energy study that he led his ties to the natural gas industry.

headline: An Epic Gathering of Leviathans From the Deep
abstract: The remarkable story of the evolution of whales will be displayed at the American Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: JOHN J. FLYNN invited me to slip my hand under the jaw of an ancient carnivore, a prize of the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Beauty Spots
abstract: The transition to spring, with its ups and downs, can irritate skin.
lead_paragraph: With its up-and-down temperatures, the transition from winter to spring can be tough on skin. Herein, a few products that will soothe confused complexions.

headline: U.S. Open Increases Payout to Players
abstract: Payout to players will nearly double by 2017, reaching $50 million, and starting in 2015, men’s players will compete in a Sunday final with a day of rest after the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: In response to players’ complaints about prize money and the tournament schedule, United States Open officials announced a huge increase in the overall payout to players and will permanently give the men’s players a Sunday final and a day of rest after the semifinals, starting in 2015.

headline: Parental Study Shows Rise in Autism Spectrum Cases
abstract: The chances of a school-aged child receiving a diagnosis rose 72 percent in 2011-12 from 2007, but most of the increase was because of previously undiagnosed cases, a report said.
lead_paragraph: The likelihood of a school-aged American child receiving a diagnosis of autism, Asperger syndrome or a related developmental disorder increased 72 percent in 2011-12 from 2007, according to an analysis of a phone survey of parents released Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Health Resources and Services Administration.

headline: Inside the Metropolitan’s Stage
abstract: Ahead of renovations, a look at the interior workings of the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of renovations, a look at the interior workings of the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Zimbabwe Rights Lawyer Denied Bail
abstract: A magistrate judge ordered Beatrice Mtetwa held on a charge of obstruction of justice until April 3.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe – A magistrate judge denied bail to the human rights lawyer Beatrice Mtetwa on Wednesday, ordering her held on a charge of obstruction of justice until April 3.

headline: Woods Is Smiling Now, and He Has Reasons
abstract: Tiger Woods, who in the fall of 2011 had tumbled to No. 58 in the rankings, would regain No. 1 with a victory this week in the Arnold Palmer Invitational, an event he has won seven times.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — In the fall of 2011, golf’s peak cast a Mount Kilimanjaro-like shadow over Tiger Woods, who found himself in the deepest valley of his career. Roughly a year after losing his No. 1 world ranking to Lee Westwood, Woods had tumbled to No. 58, his downward momentum snowballing under the weight of injuries, a swing change and upheaval in his personal life.

headline: Housing Is Finally on the Mend
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Housing Starts', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: More than six years after the housing bubble burst, the industry is beginning to recover. With the available supply of homes down to levels not seen since 1999, prices have begun to rise and home builders are responding by planning to construct more homes than at any time in the last eight years. The trend is particularly pronounced in places like Sacramento, which was hit especially hard during the downturn.
lead_paragraph: More than six years after the housing bubble burst, the industry is beginning to recover. With the available supply of homes down to levels not seen since 1999, prices have begun to rise and home builders are responding by planning to construct more homes than at any time in the last eight years. The trend is particularly pronounced in places like Sacramento, which was hit especially hard during the downturn.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,171 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,171 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Quickly Zeroing In on New Places to Call Home
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Apps allow prospective home buyers to find available properties, and compare features and prices quickly, most without leaving home.
lead_paragraph: Finding a new place to live used to be all about hunting through the real estate pages of local newspapers or endless hours working through an agent’s files. If you were lucky, you would find a house or apartment to buy or rent that matched your needs and your wallet. But it could be a thankless and time-consuming task.

headline: Search Tool on Facebook Puts Network to Work
abstract: Facebook’s new search tool uses friends and their “likes” to find people, places and things.
lead_paragraph: Most Internet users have become accustomed to using Facebook to keep up with friends — or at least, Facebook “friends” — while using more specialized sites and apps to search for restaurants, books and people. But if you have built up a network of friends on Facebook, those connections can now help you find people, places and things in the real world, in ways that more specialized sites like Google, Yelp and Amazon cannot.

headline: Mayor Vows to Veto Inspector for Police
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said a bill, endorsed by the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, to create an overseer for the Police Department would “make our city less safe.”
lead_paragraph: Less than a day after the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, endorsed a bill to create an inspector general to oversee the Police Department, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday vowed to veto the proposal, assailing it as “disastrous for public safety.”

headline: Appreciation of the Horse, Well-Cooked
abstract: Despite outrage across Europe over horse meat in food, restaurants in Moscow freely use it in sausage and stews, and even as tartare.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Uryuk, a chain of Uzbek teahouse restaurants with a dozen locations here, offers two types of horse sausage on its appetizer menu.

headline: Now a Coach, Drew Aims to Take Valparaiso on Another N.C.A.A. Run
abstract: Bryce Drew, who hit a game-winning 3-pointer as Valparaiso made it to the Round of 16 in the 1998 N.C.A.A. tournament, leads the Crusaders against Michigan State on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — About 400 students and fans gathered Sunday at the Valparaiso student union to see which giant the Crusaders would play this March. Projection screens were set up in ballrooms. The N.C.A.A. tournament selection show was on.

headline: Arizona: Tucson Schools Chief Resigns
abstract: John Pedicone, the superintendent of the Tucson Unified School District, which has been shaken by a dispute over its Mexican-American studies program, announced his resignation on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The superintendent of the Tucson Unified School District, which has been shaken by a dispute over its Mexican-American studies program, announced his resignation on Wednesday. The superintendent, John Pedicone, is leaving on June 30, a year before his contract ends. Mr. Pedicone, the district’s fifth superintendent in 10 years, said the departure would allow the district’s governing board to choose a replacement in a nonelection year. Internal disagreements over the way the district handled the state’s targeting of its Mexican-American studies program, banned by legislation that said it fostered hatred against white people, pushed other educational efforts off course, he said. The district eliminated the program last year under financial threat from the state, but it must now create “culturally relevant” courses as part of an agreement to lift a federal desegregation order.

headline: Wright Still Has Sights Set on Opening Day
abstract: The Mets’ David Wright was prescribed five days of rest and treatment Friday because of a strained intercostal muscle in his left rib cage. He still cannot do much more than rest.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — David Wright of the Mets was prescribed five days of rest and treatment Friday when he was diagnosed with a strained intercostal muscle in his left rib cage. Five days have passed, and Wright still cannot do much more than rest and receive treatment.

headline: California: 5 Ex-Officials Guilty of Inflating Pay
abstract: Five former officials from Bell, one of the poorest cities in Los Angeles County, were convicted Tuesday of misappropriating public money in a scheme to pay themselves inflated salaries.
lead_paragraph: Five former officials from Bell, one of the poorest cities in Los Angeles County, were convicted Tuesday of multiple counts of misappropriating public money in a scheme to pay themselves inflated salaries of up to $100,000. The former mayor of the working-class city of 36,000, Oscar Hernandez, and four former City Council members — Teresa Jacobo, George Mirabal, George Cole and Victor Bello — were acquitted on other counts. The five appointed themselves to an oversight board, which met only once but increased their pay by more than $10,000. Another former council member, Luis Artiga, was acquitted on all counts. Mr. Artiga joined the council later than his co-defendants, after members’ salaries had already been raised. The defendants accused the former city manager, Robert Rizzo, who made nearly $800,000 a year, of masterminding the scheme. He will be tried separately.

headline: Berlin Won’t Join Effort to Ban Far-Right Party
abstract: The Merkel government said a separate filing by the upper house of Parliament would be enough to bring the case against the National Democratic Party to the Constitutional Court.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s center-right government said Wednesday that it would not try to ban a far-right political party deemed “racist, anti-Semitic and revisionist” by domestic intelligence, choosing instead to focus on combating neo-Nazi extremism through other channels.

headline: Bittersweet Exits From Conferences, This Time in Rinks
abstract: A major shift will follow this week’s tournaments for the Central Collegiate Hockey Association and the Western Collegiate Hockey Association.
lead_paragraph: As reporters and fans rhapsodized and lamented last week about the end of an era for the Big East men’s basketball tournament, two of the oldest conferences in men’s college hockey were going through similarly bittersweet celebrations of rivalries and relationships.

headline: Marcum Dealing With Shoulder Issue
abstract: Health concerns continued to pile up for the Mets, as they announced that right-hander Shaun Marcum had flown to New York on Tuesday to receive a cortisone shot for a shoulder impingement.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — The spring training health concerns continued to pile up Wednesday for the Mets, as the team announced the right-hander Shaun Marcum had flown to New York to receive a cortisone shot Tuesday for a shoulder impingement.

headline: New York Governor Favors Easing Newly Passed Gun Law
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said a ban on the sale of gun magazines holding more than seven rounds had proved unworkable even before it took effect.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In the wake of the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn., Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York pushed through the State Legislature gun control measures that included not only a tougher assault weapons ban but also a tighter restriction on the maximum legal capacity of gun magazines.

headline: Afghan Villagers Take On Taliban in Their Heartland
abstract: An uprising in Panjwai has spread through dozens of other villages in southern Afghanistan, in the most significant popular turning against the Islamist insurgents in recent years.
lead_paragraph: PISHIN GAN SAYEDAN, Afghanistan — An uprising against the Taliban that began last month in this southern Afghan village has now spread through dozens of others, according to residents and Afghan and American officials, in the most significant popular turning against the Islamist insurgents in recent years.

headline: Biden and Mayor to Meet on Gun Policy
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will gather at City Hall to “press the case for a common sense federal gun law,” a spokesman for the mayor said.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will meet on Thursday with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and families of some of the shooting victims from the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Hiding the Smokes
abstract: Keeping cigarettes out of sight could help prevent young people from developing a deadly habit.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose antismoking policies have cut smoking rates substantially in New York City, now wants to ban open displays of cigarettes or tobacco in stores. It is hard to know whether hiding the products would really work to discourage smoking. But the hope is that keeping cigarettes out of sight could help prevent young people from developing this deadly habit.

headline: Deterring Predatory Lending
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Payday Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Credit and Debt', 'Editorials']
abstract: New policies intended to shield customers from predatory lenders are a good first step, but banks should be doing more.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has instituted new policies intended to shield customers from predatory lenders who can charge 500 percent interest or more and who drain the borrower’s bank account through automatic withdrawals.

headline: Firearms and Domestic Violence
abstract: Stronger state laws are needed to require abusers to surrender their guns.
lead_paragraph: A man abuses and threatens his ex-wife. She tells a judge that she is frightened and that he is armed. The court orders him to stay away from her. Should it also order him to give up his guns?

abstract: At home, Pope Francis showed compassion to clerical families.
lead_paragraph: Annapolis, Md.

abstract: The problem is not with God, but with an all-male clerical culture that views women as lesser than men.
lead_paragraph: Columbus, Ga.

abstract: After 44 years the Exploratorium, San Francisco’s interactive science museum, left its home at the Palace of Fine Arts for a new location along the city’s eastern waterfront.
lead_paragraph: After 44 years the Exploratorium, San Francisco’s interactive science museum, left its home at the Palace of Fine Arts for a new location along the city’s eastern waterfront.

headline: New Contract for New Mexico’s Alford
abstract: Before New Mexico began its N.C.A.A. tournament practice Wednesday, in preparation for its West Region game against Harvard, Coach Steve Alford got a raise and some job security.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Before New Mexico began its N.C.A.A. tournament practice Wednesday, in preparation for its West Region game against Harvard, Coach Steve Alford got a raise. Some job security as well.

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 5
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Ten years after “shock and awe,” Iraq War veterans reflect on the first and last days of the war and what it meant to them.
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth part of a six-part series.

headline: Wedding Bells
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Homosexuality', 'Referendums', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: As the Supreme Court prepares to take up the question of same-sex marriage, it seems worth remembering how much has changed without the Supreme Court’s ever addressing the issue directly.
lead_paragraph: I was at the Library of Congress the other day, doing some research in Justice Harry A. Blackmun’s collected papers there (an amazing gift that keeps on giving to anyone interested in the history of the Supreme Court in the last three decades of the 20th century). Thinking about the same-sex marriage cases that the court will hear next week, it occurred to me to see whether Justice Blackmun, who annotated nearly every piece of paper that came across his desk, had recorded any thoughts about a case that arrived at the court in 1971, Baker v. Nelson.

headline: The Sequester Hits the Reservation
abstract: The budget cuts known as the sequester now threaten basic health care for two million American Indians.
lead_paragraph: The Congressional Republicans who brought us the mindless budget cuts known as the sequester have shown remarkable indifference to life-sustaining government services, American jobs and other programs. So what do they make of the country’s commitments to American Indians, its longstanding obligations to tribal governments under the Constitution and treaties dating back centuries?

headline: The War in Washington Square
abstract: How did Dr. Sexton lose the confidence of so many faculty members? By ignoring us.
lead_paragraph: LAST week the faculty of arts and science of New York University approved a no-confidence resolution against the university’s president, John Sexton. I had introduced the resolution in December, and in the ensuing months it generated one of the largest campus debates in recent memory. The final no-confidence vote, the first in N.Y.U. history, was decisive: 298 to 224.

headline: Companies: Show Us the Money
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising', 'Corporations']
abstract: The financial regulator can — and should — force corporations to disclose their political donations.
lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, the Senate Banking Committee gave Mary Jo White, President Obama’s choice to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, a rousing show of support, voting 21 to 1 to send her nomination to the full Senate for a vote. Ms. White, who is likely to be confirmed as the S.E.C. chairwoman, will need that bipartisan backing as she takes on a host of challenges at the nation’s top financial regulator.

headline: Reaching Those on the Wrong Side of the Digital Divide
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Many jobs today require technology skills, and job seekers who don’t go online miss opportunities.
lead_paragraph: THE Advertising Council and Connect2Compete, a nonprofit group whose goal is to eliminate the digital divide in the United States, are introducing a public service campaign to help those who are not digitally literate find free training to obtain these skills.

headline: Yankees’ Aces Under Watchful Eyes
abstract: The Yankees are considering signing former pitcher Chien-Ming Wang, while their current pitcher, C. C. Sabathia, pitched in a minor league game.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Away from the spotlight that is always there when the Yankees play the Red Sox, even if it is a spring training game, the team’s former and current pitching aces toiled under watchful eyes at the Yankees’ minor league training center Wednesday.

headline: Manning Open to Redoing His Deal to Keep Cruz
abstract: Quarterback Eli Manning is willing to help the Giants reach a new contract with Victor Cruz, who had 10 touchdown catches last season.
lead_paragraph: Eli Manning compiled roughly a quarter of his 3,948 passing yards last season on completions to Victor Cruz. Manning tossed 10 of his 26 touchdown passes to the salsa-dancing Cruz, too. Now, as Cruz’s status with the Giants remains at a contractual impasse, Manning has said he would be willing to sacrifice to keep Cruz as one of his top targets.

headline: Man Charged With Plotting Against U.S. Abroad
abstract: A foreigner accused of conspiring to attack American facilities in Nigeria is the latest example of defendants apprehended overseas and being extradited to federal courts in New York.
lead_paragraph: A man who prosecutors said was an overseas operative of Al Qaeda during the years following the Sept. 11 attacks was charged in Brooklyn with a host of terrorism charges, in the latest example of a foreigner accused of acts of terrorism abroad being extradited to American courts.

lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim played down the latest reports about investigations into his basketball program, suggesting that there was nothing new to revelations on Wednesday, the day before the Orange’s N.C.A.A. tournament opener against Montana.

abstract: The parks department shut down Cedar Lane Stables in Howard Beach, saying that it can resume operations in six months only if the operators can make certain assurances.
lead_paragraph: One horse died after becoming tangled in its head collar. Two horses in the barn died from old age, while another died shortly after it was born. Two more died of causes that could not be determined.

headline: Known for 3-Point Prowess, Underdog Expands Its Attack
abstract: Belmont, a No. 11 seed that will face Arizona in its N.C.A.A. tournament opener, has evolved into more than just a long-range threat.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Rick Byrd became the basketball coach at Belmont in 1986, the same year the N.C.A.A. universally put in the 3-point line. Byrd considered himself a basketball purist, and still does. Initially, he did not care for the new rule or the strange arc.

headline: Harry Reems, Star of ‘Deep Throat’ Film, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Reems became America’s first bona fide male porn star by appearing in the 1972 movie “Deep Throat.”
lead_paragraph: Harry Reems, whose starring role in “Deep Throat” in 1972 made him America’s first bona fide male porn star — and whose life, more than most, embodied the time-honored American narrative of fame, failure and redemption — died on Tuesday in Salt Lake City, Utah. He was 65.

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Dr. Benjamin Carson was a political unknown just weeks ago.

headline: Henry Bromell, Writer of TV Dramas, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Bromell found rich sources of inspiration in the secretive past of his father, a C.I.A. agent.
lead_paragraph: Henry Bromell, who wrote short stories for The New Yorker 40 years ago and later stumbled into a career writing, directing and producing television shows, including “Northern Exposure,” “Homicide: Life on the Street” and the more recent hit “Homeland,” died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 65.

headline: Dempsey Named U.S. Captain
abstract: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann on Wednesday named Clint Dempsey the captain of the U.S. team that will play Costa Rica on Friday in a World Cup qualifying match.
lead_paragraph: COMMERCE CITY, Colo. — Clint Dempsey will wear the captain’s armband on Friday night when the United States faces Costa Rica in a World Cup qualifying match.

headline: Bobbie Smith, Voice of the Spinners, Dies at 76
abstract: The faces of the Spinners may have changed over the years, but Mr. Smith was there from the start.
lead_paragraph: Bobbie Smith, whose mellifluous vocals helped make the Spinners one of the leading soul acts of the 1970s, died on Saturday in Orlando, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Cyberspace Space
abstract: Try not to get mixed up in this puzzle by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Puzzle blogging makes me hungry. Or maybe I’m just too susceptible to subliminal suggestion. It’s just that there are so many references to food in the puzzles, and when you sit all day and solve puzzles with food references in them, it starts to get to you.

headline: More Waifish Than Wild, the Ingénue Returns
abstract: The new “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” on Broadway at the Cort Theater, is more faithful to Truman Capote’s novella than the 1961 film was, yet far more melancholy.
lead_paragraph: Holly Golightly does not. Go lightly, that is. The new stage adaptation of “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” Truman Capote’s beloved portrait of a glamorous waif in 1940s New York, moves with a distinctly leaden step, as if it dreaded what might be waiting around every dark corner of the sinister city it portrays.

headline: Fab Five, All Family
abstract: The Tinkles may be the most talented basketball family in the country, with two generations of playing and coaching in the family set to collide this weekend in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — If the N.C.A.A. held a coed basketball tournament of families — your five against their five, all the way through the bracket — the Tinkles of Missoula, Mont., would be the runaway favorite, seeded first over all.

headline: Canada: Possible Drug Use by Pilot Helped Cause Crash, Report Suggests
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The impairment of a pilot and marginal weather led to the crash of a commercial flight of a small turboprop plane in Canada’s far north that killed two people and injured two others, a report released on Wednesday said.
lead_paragraph: The impairment of a pilot and marginal weather led to the crash of a commercial flight of a small turboprop plane in Canada’s far north that killed two people and injured two others, a report released on Wednesday said. The Transportation Safety Board said that urine, blood and lung fluid tests of the pilot, who died after the Air Tindi flight crashed in October 2011, showed levels of the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana that were well above those known to cause impairment.

headline: Man Convicted in Rabbi’s Killing Faces Freedom With Apprehension
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: David Ranta, 58, has spent two decades in prison for the 1991 shooting of a Hasidic rabbi, Chaskel Werzberger, a crime that he almost certainly did not commit.
lead_paragraph: David Ranta once worked as a printer, though he is not certain that such jobs exist anymore.

headline: Mandatory Use of Visors a Hot Topic
abstract: Making the use of visors mandatory was among the leading subjects at the N.H.L. general managers meetings.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Mandatory visors, goalie equipment and a coach’s review were the subjects that dominated nearly seven hours of the N.H.L. general managers meetings Wednesday and several recommendations will be made during the competition committee meetings at the Stanley Cup final.

headline: The Face of Future Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Although Kaiser Permanente is considered an example of the future of health care, its chief acknowledges that it has not been able to deliver that care at a low enough cost.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When people talk about the future of health care, Kaiser Permanente is often the model they have in mind.

headline: Northern Ireland: Judge Holds 2 Liable in Bombing by I.R.A. Splinter Group
abstract: A Belfast judge ruled on Wednesday that two alleged leaders of the Real Irish Republican Army were liable for damages in the 1998 Omagh car bombing that killed 29 civilians and wounded 200 others.
lead_paragraph: A Belfast judge ruled on Wednesday that two alleged leaders of the Real Irish Republican Army were liable for damages in the 1998 Omagh car bombing that killed 29 civilians and wounded 200 others. Justice John Gillen told a Belfast court the case against Colm Murphy and Seamus Daly was “overwhelming.” The police have failed to win any criminal convictions in the bombing, the most deadly single attack during the years of violence known as the “Troubles.”

headline: H.P.’s Board Wins Re-election, but Change May Be Coming Anyway
abstract: A few board members of the technology giant who had come under fire from shareholders were re-elected anyway at H.P.’s annual meeting on Wednesday. But another prominent board member, the activist investor Ralph Whitworth, indicated there would be changes ahead.
lead_paragraph: Members of Hewlett-Packard’s board dodged a bullet Wednesday.

keywords: ['NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)', 'Basketball (College)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: A. J. Davis scored 20 points as the Dukes beat L.I.U. Brooklyn in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Jim Boeheim played down the latest reports about investigations into his program, suggesting that there was nothing new to the revelations on Wednesday, the day before the Orange open the tournament against Montana.

headline: Current Laws May Offer Little Shield Against Drones, Senators Are Told
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: There is little in privacy law that would limit the use of drones for surveillance in the United States because the laws were not written with the aircraft in mind, witnesses said at a hearing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Targeted killings have made drones controversial, but a new class of tiny aircraft in the United States — cheap, able and ubiquitous — could engage in targeted snooping that existing laws are inadequate to address, witnesses and members of the Senate Judiciary Committee said in a hearing on Wednesday.

headline: China: Leader Says He Wants to Ease Tensions Between Two Koreas
abstract: China’s newly appointed president, Xi Jinping, spoke to his South Korean counterpart, Park Geun-hye, by telephone on Wednesday, and told her that his government wanted to help ease tensions between the two Koreas.
lead_paragraph: China’s newly appointed president, Xi Jinping, left, spoke to his South Korean counterpart, Park Geun-hye, by telephone on Wednesday, and told her that his government wanted to help ease tensions between the two Koreas. China has long served as the North’s political and economic mainstay, but it also seeks to keep close ties with the South, which is a much larger trade partner. “The South and North are compatriots, and relations between them are of vital importance for the peninsula,” Mr. Xi told Ms. Park, according to a statement by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. “China is willing to provide the necessary assistance to encourage bilateral reconciliation and cooperation between the South and North.” Relations between the Koreas have been especially tense since North Korea staged a nuclear test last month and the United Nations responded with sanctions, infuriating the North.

headline: Stop-and-Frisk Trial Turns to Claim of Arrest Quotas
abstract: An officer testified that superiors demanded specified numbers of arrests and stop-and-frisk encounters.
lead_paragraph: For the first two days, the trial focused on sidewalks and street corners from Harlem to Flatbush, as African-American men testified about how they were stopped by the police.

headline: Four Share a History: Nobody Believed in Us
abstract: All four teams involved in Thursday’s day session in Lexington, Ky. — Butler, Bucknell, Marquette and Davidson — rose from relative obscurity to captivate the tournament in Marches past.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The wily bracket-crafters on the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee missed a chance to create a blissful sort of havoc at Rupp Arena on Thursday afternoon. If only they had also slotted the tournament sweethearts Gonzaga and Virginia Commonwealth and Valparaiso and, why not, Northwestern State in a pod already teeming with upstarts.

headline: Sacrifice Pays Off for Guard, and Iona
abstract: Lamont Jones, a senior averaging 23 points per game, has led the Gaels to two N.C.A.A. tournament berths since he transferred from Arizona.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — Lamont Jones’s willingness to put family above all else has helped Iona reach the N.C.A.A. tournament in consecutive seasons for the first time since 2000 and 2001.

headline: Late-Night Shuffle
abstract: A look at more than two decades of shifting schedules and fortunes in late-night talk shows.
lead_paragraph: A look at more than two decades of shifting schedules and fortunes in late-night talk shows.

headline: Runner Who Died During Half Marathon Is Identified
abstract: The runner who collapsed and died in Sunday’s New York City Half, a 13.1-mile run around Manhattan, has been identified as John Tanner, 46, of Marlborough, Mass.
lead_paragraph: The runner who collapsed and died in Sunday’s New York City Half, a 13.1-mile run around Manhattan, has been identified as John Tanner, 46, of Marlborough, Mass. He had a heart attack about 9:10 a.m. just past the race’s 12-mile marker, the police said.

headline: As Senate Passes Spending Measure, Stark Budget Views Are on Display in House
abstract: House members held an animated debate over the budget for the 2014 fiscal year that begins when the spending measure expires Sept. 30.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate passed a spending measure on Wednesday to keep the government financed through the end of September, resolving one contentious budget fight as Congress moved quickly to the next.

headline: Sex Charges in Connecticut Are Dissected on Internet
abstract: Two Torrington High School athletes were charged with sexually assaulting 13-year-old girls.
lead_paragraph: It took nearly two weeks for the authorities in Connecticut to make the first arrests involving claims that athletes at Torrington High School had sexually assaulted 13-year-old girls.

headline: Document Suggests Abbas’s Desire to Resume Israeli Talks
abstract: The shift in the stance by the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, was laid out in a draft set of talking points  in advance of his private meeting on Thursday with President Obama.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority is so eager to return to peace talks with the Israelis that he may soften his demand that Israel’s president publicly pledge to halt construction of new settlements on Palestinian land before such negotiations can resume.

headline: The Knicks’ World Looks Brighter After Anthony Returns
abstract: After missing some action because of knee problems, Carmelo Anthony looked sharp as he scored 21 points in the Knicks’ victory over the woeful Magic.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in three weeks, Carmelo Anthony left a basketball court with his head up, his right knee nimble, his smile bright and his team victorious. That was all the Knicks could have asked for Wednesday night, after a frightful month of diagnostic tests and doctor visits that ravaged the roster.

headline: Ailing Knicks Content With Players They Have
abstract: No matter how Knicks fans feel about their team’s roster being affected by a rash of injuries, Coach Mike Woodson made it clear before Wednesday’s game against the Orlando Magic that he and General Manager Glen Grunwald are not looking to sign free agents.
lead_paragraph: You could call Knicks Coach Mike Woodson stubborn about the status of his roster as more and more of his players — especially the older ones — become injured. Or you could say Woodson is faithful to his players, especially the veterans he brought to New York.

headline: Q. and A. on Obama’s Trip to Israel
abstract: Readers pose questions on the first day of Mr. Obama’s trip to Israel as president.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 12:11 p.m. Jodi Rudoren, Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times, answered questions from readers, including on Facebook and Twitter, on the first day of President Obama’s trip to Israel as president. We distilled questions asked by several readers and included a few specific examples posed on the social networks.

headline: Angles of Attack for Israel’s Iron Dome Missile System
abstract: Skeptics say the Israelis have exaggerated the success rate of the Iron Dome missile system and that the odds of destruction depend critically on how the interceptor approaches the rocket.
lead_paragraph: Skeptics say the Israelis have exaggerated the success rate of the Iron Dome missile system and that the odds of destruction depend critically on how the interceptor approaches the rocket.

headline: Weapons Experts Raise Doubts About Israel’s Antimissile System
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Iron Dome, the newest of Israel’s antimissile systems, was built with American help and hailed as a great success in the Gaza conflict in November, but it is unclear how effective it really was.
lead_paragraph: After President Obama arrived in Israel, his first stop on Wednesday was to inspect an installation of Iron Dome, the antimissile system hailed as a resounding success in the Gaza conflict in November. The photo op, celebrating a technological wonder built with the help of American dollars, came with considerable symbolism as Mr. Obama sought to showcase support for Israel after years of tensions over Jewish settlements and how to curb Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: Physical Wichita State Team Looks to Exceed Expectations
abstract: The Shockers are similar to Pittsburgh, their first opponent in the N.C.A.A. tournament: both teams play a brand of basketball that more closely resembles football.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — There are some unlikely N.C.A.A. tournament teams here. Southern qualifies. So does Harvard.

headline: Resistance and Scant Support Sealed Fate of Push for Assault Weapons Ban
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Despite a high-profile push by President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the assault weapons ban promoted by Senator Dianne Feinstein never had a chance of passage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As she stood surrounded by gunshot victims and displays of firearms in January to announce her intention to renew the push for an assault weapons ban after the massacre in Newtown, Conn., Senator Dianne Feinstein all but conceded defeat.

headline: Friend or Foe? For a Game, at Least, There May Be Confusion
abstract: In Thursday’s N.C.A.A. tournament games, two best friends will face off as V.C.U. takes on Akron, and two contrasting personalities will meet in Michigan’s game against South Dakota State.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Shaka Smart considers Keith Dambrot to be among his best friends. Dambrot joked this week that he and Smart knew each other so well, they could probably trade sidelines and coach each other’s teams.

headline: Now in Pinstripes, Youkilis Greets His Former Team
abstract: Kevin Youkilis, playing against the Red Sox for the first time as a Yankee, went 0 for 4 and striking out twice, while playing third base on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Kevin Youkilis knows what it is like to passionately root for a sports team. A native of Cincinnati, he has been a lifelong Bengals fan.

headline: The Republican Autopsy Report
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Reince Priebus, Karl Rove and the religious right battle for the soul of their party.
lead_paragraph: On Monday a Republican task force released a remarkably hard-headed diagnosis of the party’s many liabilities: its ideological rigidity, its preference for the rich over workers, its alienation of minorities, its reactionary social policies and its institutionalized repression of dissent and innovation.

headline: Rising Stars in Republican Party Compete for the Spotlight
abstract: Two years before the next presidential campaign even begins, Senators Rand Paul and Marco Rubio are flying in each other’s airspace, not quite rivals but obvious competitors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They are supposed to be natural allies: two relatively young conservatives from the Tea Party wing of the Republican Party who ascended to the Senate in the Republican sweep of 2010 and already figure prominently in the early chatter for 2016.

headline: Rebooted Big East Makes a Splash in Manhattan
abstract: The 10 colleges that will make up the re-formed Big East will be partners, in a big way, with News Corporation’s new sports network.
lead_paragraph: The new Big East could not have chosen a more appropriate site for its launch party: the Manhattan headquarters of News Corporation. The conference’s seed money — and more — is coming from Fox Sports 1, News Corporation’s new sports network.

headline: Louisville Starting Its Run in the Home of Its Rival
abstract: Louisville will play at Rupp Arena, but it will not face Kentucky, which lost on Tuesday night in the first round of the N.I.T.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The question about Kentucky was posed thus to Peyton Siva, the superlative senior point guard for Louisville: “Is there part of you that kind of takes a little satisfaction — not only are you guys the No. 1 seed, but you are playing here, and they’re not even in the N.I.T. anymore?”

headline: Nets Win, With Points and Scowls to Spare
abstract: Brook Lopez scored a season-high 38 points as the Nets beat the Mavericks and showed an attitude that they were poised for a serious playoff run.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Brook Lopez, the Nets’ often overlooked 7-foot center, stroked a shot in the third quarter, holding his pose an extra second, as if he knew Wednesday night would be special.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Mar. 21, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, Mar. 21, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “If you can separate two Siamese twins, maybe you can separate Democrats and Republicans in Washington.”

headline: The Art of the Dealer
abstract: Part shrewd salesman, part cultivated European, the gallery owner David Zwirner is expanding into territory formerly occupied by Larry Gagosian, the most powerful dealer in the business.
lead_paragraph: Part shrewd salesman, part cultivated European, the gallery owner David Zwirner has built a blue-chip empire with a sharp eye and a steady hand.

headline: Costly Bank Payday Loans Criticized in Report
abstract: In a new report, the Center for Responsible Lending is condemning payday loans issued by big banks.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s largest banks continue to offer payday loans, pitched as advances on direct-deposit paychecks, despite growing regulatory scrutiny and mounting criticism about the short-term, high-cost loans.

headline: Windfalls for Wall Street Executives Taking Jobs in Government
abstract: Big banks accelerated the vesting of stock so top executives could cash in before leaving, creating a debate on Wall Street over whether that is a conflict of interest.
lead_paragraph: People usually say they go into government to perform public service. If they came from Wall Street, however, their former employers often provide another service.

headline: From Sleep Study, Clues to Happiness
abstract: A brain chemical called hypocretin may help explain why we “fall down” with laughter, and why people with narcolepsy, who lack the substance, get depressed. But hypocretin’s effect on mood also raises concerns about new sleeping pills designed to block the substance.
lead_paragraph: A little over a decade ago, scientists discovered that narcolepsy, the neurological disorder that leads to episodes of irresistible sleepiness, is caused by the loss of brain cells that produce hypocretin, a neurotransmitter that promotes wakefulness.

headline: SFX Entertainment Buys Major Stake in Dutch Festival Promoter
abstract: The deal with ID&T, perhaps the biggest in the market so far, will give SFX a major foothold on the global festival circuit as it tries to build a $1 billion media empire centered on dance.
lead_paragraph: As corporations hear the siren call of electronic dance music, the deals keep getting bigger.

headline: Pediatrics Group Backs Gay Marriage, Saying It Helps Children
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics said gay and lesbian parents should be allowed to marry because it helps guarantee rights, benefits and long-term security for children.
lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Pediatrics declared its support for same-sex marriage for the first time on Thursday, saying that allowing gay and lesbian parents to marry if they so choose is in the best interests of their children.

headline: Word of the Day |  jaunt
abstract: This word has appeared in 215 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: jaunt •\ˈjȯnt, ˈjänt\• noun and verb

headline: Soccer Apps We Like
abstract: A selection of five soccer apps we like. Are there more? Of course.
lead_paragraph: If you cannot get to the game, what could be better than having the game come to you on your smartphone or tablet or both. Most of the apps below also provide access to news, video and other content.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) THE TEMPEST The British composer Thomas Adès conducts the Metropolitan Opera premiere of his English-language opera based on the Shakespeare play, in a production staged by Robert Lepage. Simon Keenlyside leads the cast as the exiled magician Prospero, who in this setting imagines himself an impresario of 18th-century opera and has recreated on his island the opera house La Scala, from his hometown, Milan. Isabel Leonard plays his daughter, Miranda; Alek Shrader is the shipwrecked prince, Ferdinand; Alan Oke (above), is the monstrous island native Caliban; and Audrey Luna is the spirit Ariel. Writing in The New York Times, Anthony Tommasini called the production, presented here by “Great Performances at the Met,” “one of the most inspired, audacious and personal operas to have come along in years.” Mr. Adès, he added, “drew a textured, glittering and suspenseful account of his opera from the great Met orchestra.”

headline: News Quiz | March 21, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Farming a Beach
abstract: Nothing but sand and pebbles where there once were fertile fields on a Brahmaputra River tributary.
lead_paragraph: BORALAPAR, Assam — Jagot Chekanidhara, a 50-year-old local schoolteacher, mounds up a wall of sand. Nearby, his sister Lakhimi digs a row of holes. It looks like seaside fun-in-the-sun, but this is no beach and no child’s play.

headline: As Hacking Continues, Concerns Grow That Chinese-Americans May Suffer
abstract: As tension grows between China and the United States over cyberhacking, I talked to a prominent Chinese-American about whether he worries it will lead to problems for the Chinese-American community.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As tensions build between Washington and Beijing over cyberattacks, with a growing body of evidence that much of the hacking is coming from China and that the United States is a major target, as The New York Times has reported, are Chinese-Americans feeling the pressure? Are they concerned that growing suspicions about China’s intentions toward the United States may cause them to suffer greater discrimination?

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 21
abstract: Popular uprisings against the Taliban in Afghanistan; South Korean computers hit by hacking; a new treatment for acute leukemia; I.M.F. chief’s home is searched; a plan for more women at the European Central Bank; and sports in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: NEWS An uprising against the Taliban that began last month in a southern Afghan village has now spread through dozens of others, according to residents and Afghan and American officials, in the most significant popular turning against the Islamist insurgents in recent years. Carlotta Gall reports from Pishin Gan Sayedan, Afghanistan.

headline: Australian Prime Minister Survives Ouster Attempt
abstract: The premier, Julia Gillard, was re-elected unopposed on the same day that she issued the national government’s first public apology for a decades-long policy of forced adoptions.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Julia Gillard on Thursday survived an effort by a senior lawmaker within her own party to oust her from her job, after her predecessor Kevin Rudd, whom she deposed in a 2010 party coup, unexpectedly declined to run against her.

headline: Library of Congress Makes Room for Simon & Garfunkel, Van Cliburn and the Ramones
abstract: Works by Simon & Garfunkel, Van Cliburn, Pink Floyd and the Ramones are among those whose musical creations will be added to the National Recording Registry.
lead_paragraph: Whatever Simon & Garfunkel meant by “Sounds of Silence,” those sounds will now reverberate in perpetuity — whether silently or otherwise — along with works by Van Cliburn, Pink Floyd, the Ramones and many other artists whose musical creations will be added to the National Recording Registry of the Library of Congress.

headline: AstraZeneca Makes a Bet on an Untested Technique
abstract: The troubled drug giant will pay a record initial payment of $240 million for access to Moderna Therapeutics’ new RNA technology.
lead_paragraph: The troubled drug giant AstraZeneca, which is overhauling its research operations, is betting at least $240 million that a novel but untested technology from a small biotechnology company can provide it with a huge array of new drugs.

headline: The Legacies of Iraq: An Ailing Press and an ‘Invade or Nothing’ Foreign Policy
abstract: A decade after Iraq, the American foreign policy debate has devolved into an “invade or not invade” dichotomy and the news media is one-third the size of the public-relations industry.
lead_paragraph: American households will be blanketed this week by a torrent of coverage, commentary and regret about the 10th anniversary of the Iraq war. Liberals claim that Twitter — if it had existed — could have stopped the invasion. Conservatives argue that the links between Saddam Hussein and terrorism have, in fact, been underplayed.

headline: Obama Urges Young Israelis to Lead the Push for Peace
abstract: President Obama moved closer to Israel’s position on resuming stalled peace talks with the Palestinians, even as he passionately implored a young audience to get ahead of its own leaders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Obama, appealing to very disparate audiences to solve one of the world’s thorniest problems, moved closer on Thursday to the Israeli government’s position on resuming long-stalled peace talks with the Palestinians, even as he passionately implored young Israelis to get ahead of their own leaders in the push for peace.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 21, 2013
abstract: Can you choose the word that correctly completes the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Subway Worker Freed After Hours Stuck in Mud.”

headline: A Strategy for Opposing Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: What percent of Republicans between 18 and 44 years old said in a recent survey that they thought same-sex couples should be able to marry?
lead_paragraph: In “Young Opponents of Same-Sex Marriage Undaunted,” Ashley Parker writes about young people who want to reverse a seeming shift of public opinion in favor of gay marriage.

headline: Toppling Saddam and a War’s Coverage
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'News and News Media', 'Photography', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: The gripping footage of a Baghdad throng toppling Saddam Hussein’s statue was hardly the turning point of the war. If anything, it symbolized the problems covering the conflict.
lead_paragraph: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: The London Whale, Richard Fisher and Cyprus
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Standing on the sidelines or having theoretical discussions while the potential grows for big-bank damage to the economy is unacceptable, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: What Makes You Happy?
abstract: In honor of International Happiness Day, list five specific things that make you happy, tell how you make others happy, and judge how happy you think your nation is as a whole.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations declared March 20 the first International Day of Happiness, declaring that “the pursuit of happiness is a fundamental human goal.”

headline: What India’s New ‘Anti-Rape’ Bill Actually Says
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Stalking (Crime)', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A breakdown of new charges, punishments and rules for handling sexual assault cases.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI–After clearing the Lok Sabha or lower house of Parliament earlier this week, a bill to toughen India’s laws on sexual offenses is being debated in the upper house on Thursday.

headline: North Korea Threatens U.S. Military Bases in Pacific
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The country threatened to attack American bases in retaliation for training missions over the Korean Peninsula, while state radio blared air-raid warnings to the North Korean people.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Thursday threatened to attack American military bases in Japan and on the Pacific island of Guam in retaliation for recent training missions by American B-52 bombers over South Korea.

headline: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions About Paying for College
abstract: Laura Perna, a researcher in college finance and affordability, answers select reader questions about paying for college. Part 4.
lead_paragraph: The Choice has invited Laura Perna, an author, professor at the University of Pennsylvania and researcher in college finance and affordability, to answer your questions about paying for college in the blog’s Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: The Early Word: Elbows
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:In Israel for the first time since he took office in 2009, President Obama intends to convey a message that he cares about Israel and will do whatever is necessary to protect its people from enemies, Mark Landler and Jodi Rudoren write. On Thursday, Mr. Obama is scheduled to meet with the president of the Palestinian Authority before giving a speech in Jerusalem that will address the need for a renewed peace effort.

headline: The Doctor’s New Prescription: A Lawyer
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Legal Profession', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: Elderly people often need legal help, and law students need experience. Some health care institutions are making the match.
lead_paragraph: Consider the geriatricians working at the Lakeside Senior Medical Center, an outpatient clinic at the University of California, San Francisco. Many of their patients, despite multiple chronic diseases and advanced age, have never filled out power-of-attorney documents or appointed someone to make health care decisions if they are unable to.

headline: The (G)loved Ones
abstract: The United States has a long history of producing world-class goalkeepers.
lead_paragraph: It has been a rough couple of weeks for a top American goalkeeper and national team stalwart.

headline: Mood Darkens in Cyprus as Deadline Is Set for Bailout
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Cypriots flocked to cash machines as the European Central Bank said it would shut off low-cost bank financing if an accord is not reached by Monday.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — As the European Central Bank threatened to shut off crucial financing for banks in Cyprus without a rapid accord on an international bailout, members of Parliament put off a vote on Thursday on yet another revamped formula. The vote was rescheduled for Friday.

headline: Daily Report: New Reasons to Change Light Bulbs
abstract: LED bulbs last longer and use less power than older ones, and with prices falling, a change makes even more sense, David Pogue writes in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: For use in the lamps and light sockets of your home, LED bulbs have been slow to arrive, mainly because of their high price.

headline: When You Hire the Right Person for the Wrong Position
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Online Advertising', 'Small Business']
abstract: What do you do if it turns out that the job itself is not a good fit for the company?
lead_paragraph: The interview process had been exhaustive, and my co-founder and I were pleased. We had put an expert in pay-per-click-advertising through a series of tests, and he emerged on the other side of the process having demonstrated his deep proficiency in this customer-acquisition channel. After checking multiple references and having an additional meeting to ensure that he fit our culture, we hired our new expert in direct marketing.

headline: The King of Cliftonia
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: News of General Pervez Musharraf’s return to Pakistan is sparking little fear of a military takeover. The country has come a long way in his absence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — General Pervez Musharraf has announced his intention to return to Pakistan this Sunday. The country’s former president and army chief is coming home as a civilian politician to contest an ordinary parliamentary seat in elections scheduled for May.

headline: Bollywood’s Sanjay Dutt Will Go to Prison
abstract: India’s highest court upheld the conviction of the Bollywood star Sanjay Dutt on charges of illegal possession of guns supplied by the masterminds of the 1993 Mumbai bombings, but it reduced his prison sentence by a year to five years.
lead_paragraph: India’s highest court upheld the conviction of the Bollywood star Sanjay Dutt on charges of illegal possession of guns supplied by the masterminds of the 1993 Mumbai bombings, but it reduced his prison sentence by a year to five years.

lead_paragraph: President Obama spruces up U.S.-Israeli ties.

headline: Sectarian Clashes Are Reported in Central Myanmar
abstract: At least five people have been reported killed in fighting between Buddhists and Muslims in central Myanmar, a resurgence of communal violence that is testing a fledgling democracy.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — At least five people have been killed in fighting between Buddhists and Muslims in central Myanmar, residents and a hospital official said Thursday, in another sign of a resurgence of communal violence that is testing the country’s fledgling democracy.

headline: Deals Like Lew’s Aren’t Uncommon
abstract: Jacob J. Lew’s arrangement with his former employer, Citigroup, is not so unusual on Wall Street, a study finds. | Cyprus is scrambling to find ways to finance its bailout. | C.D.O.’S, an investment class at the heart of the credit crisis, appear to be making a comeback. | Some start-ups are caught in purgatory.
lead_paragraph: Jacob J. Lew, the new Treasury secretary, was asked pointed questions during his confirmation hearing about a deal with his former employer, Citigroup, that guaranteed him preferential financial treatment if he left for government service. But according to a new study, such arrangements are not so unusual on Wall Street, DealBook’s Susanne Craig reports.

headline: Standard Chartered Chairman Retracts Comments on Sanctions Settlement With U.S.
abstract: John W. Peace, chairman of the British bank Standard Chartered, on Thursday retracted statements about the bank’s recent settlement with American authorities over violations of sanctions laws, saying his earlier comments were “wrong.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – John W. Peace, chairman of the British bank Standard Chartered, on Thursday retracted statements about the bank’s recent settlement with American authorities over violations of sanctions laws.

headline: Ken Levine Talks About His New Video Game
abstract: With the release coming of among the most anticipated new titles of 2013, Mr. Levine spoke from the offices of his development studio in Quincy, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Through a combination of obsessive hard work, an affable personality and marketing savvy, Ken Levine has become one of the most beloved creators of narratively fulfilling, big-budget video games. Not only do his BioShock games sell well (the first sold more than five million copies), but they are also taught in colleges and parsed in the same way as, say, David Lynch’s film “Mulholland Drive” was analyzed by critics.

headline: The Nerd as Auteur in BioShock Infinite
abstract: The third installment of the video game series BioShock is packed with cultural references high and low, going back in time to the 1893 Chicago World’s Fair.
lead_paragraph: QUINCY, MASS. — The office here that houses Irrational Games isn’t listed on a building directory. The company door is unmarked and locked. And the maze of rooms that many people would want to see behind that door — the studio where one of the year’s most anticipated video games is being readied for release on Tuesday — is harder to find.

headline: Cyprus: The Sum of All FUBAR
abstract: Everything wrong, in one island package.
lead_paragraph: At this point the Cyprus situation is pretty clear — and clarity does not bring reassurance. In fact, it looks as if Cyprus has managed to combine in one place everything that has gone wrong elsewhere.

headline: Hezbollah Courier Found Guilty in Plot to Attack Israeli Tourists in Cyprus
abstract: The ruling, in a Cyprus court, could provide impetus to efforts to have Hezbollah designated a terrorist organization by the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In a decision that could have significant repercussions for Hezbollah’s operations in Europe, a court in Cyprus on Thursday found a man guilty of participating in a plot to attack Israeli tourists there, part of a conspiracy similar to a deadly bombing last July in Bulgaria.

abstract: Finding frugal gems in Chongqing, why you should buy LED light bulbs, camouflage goes trendy and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
