abstract: Federal prosecutors announce criminal charges against Rajarengan Rajaratnam nearly two years after his brother, the Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam, was convicted and sentenced to 11 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: 6:41 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Kurdish Spring on Many Fronts
abstract: An anticipated truce between Turkey and Kurdish rebels could mark the latest advance for the largest nation in the world without a state of its own.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Abdullah Ocalan, the jailed leader of the rebel Kurdish Workers Party, or P.K.K., called for a ceasefire Thursday in the three-decade war between Kurdish rebels and the Turkish state, giving a new impetus to New Year celebrations by Kurds.

headline: The End of War Stories
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Brandon Friedman served in Iraq and Afghanistan as an infantry officer with the 101st Airborne Division. But when people ask him about the war in Iraq now, he feels like he’s going through the motions, reciting lines long memorized–almost as if he’s telling someone else’s tale instead of his own.
lead_paragraph: I can’t remember the last time I told a real war story — the kind you recount with waving arms and an animated voice, impersonating friends you haven’t talked to in years. The kind you really get into.

headline: Setting Themes of Humility, a New Archbishop of Canterbury Is Installed
keywords: ['ANGLICAN CHURCHES', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, the new archbishop, spoke in sympathetic terms of same-sex relationships, but reaffirmed his commitment to opposing gay weddings in church.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At his installation as archbishop of Canterbury on Thursday, Justin Welby, a former oil executive who made an unusually rapid rise to the leadership of the Anglican Church, used the ceremony in Canterbury’s nine-century-old cathedral to set themes of simplicity, modesty and innovation that echoed the tone Pope Francis has set for his week-old papacy.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Fallon to Become Host of ‘Tonight’ and Ads Aim to Close Digital Divide
abstract: NBC is planning for Jimmy Fallon to take over the “Tonight” show from Jay Leno, a new campaign seeks to diminish the digital divide in the United States, and the new Big East conference kicked off at News Corporation’s headquarters.
lead_paragraph: NBC has made a commitment to make Jimmy Fallon, the 38-year-old host of its “Late Night” show, the host of the “Tonight” show and to move the show from Burbank, Calif., back to New York, Bill Carter reports. Mr. Fallon would succeed Jay Leno, who will turn 63 next month and whose show still regularly leads the late-night ratings. The change would by fall 2014 at the latest. NBC has been desperate to avoid acrimony that often surrounds one of the biggest changes in late-night television; their attempt to replace Mr. Leno with Conan O’Brien three years ago ended with recriminations and a reversal, as Mr. Leno was reinstated and NBC endured weeks of negative coverage.

headline: Microsoft Releases Report on Law Enforcement Requests
abstract: Publication of the report on government data requests places Microsoft alongside Google, Twitter and other Web businesses in releasing regular transparency reports.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft disclosed for the first time on Thursday the number of requests it had received from government law enforcement agencies for data on its hundreds of millions of customers around the world, joining the ranks of Google, Twitter and other Web businesses that publish so-called transparency reports.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Recap, Episode 8: You Can Go Home Again, It Just Might Get Complicated
abstract: “House of Cards”, this time with no Zoe Barnes, no Slugline, no journalism. Ashley Parker loved the episode and David Carr gave to to thumbs “meh.”
lead_paragraph: Deep into “House of Cards” and wondering what it all means? You are not the only one. Ashley Parker and David Carr read between the lines of episode eight in search of a deeper message.

headline: Scientists Propose a New Architecture for Sustainable Development
abstract: Analysts of global environmental trends seek to topple the three pillars of sustainable development.
lead_paragraph: As a United Nations working group negotiates a set of “sustainable development goals,” 10 scientists and development analysts, in a commentary published today in Nature, have proposed a fundamentally different way to frame this concept. (Click here for relevant Dot Earth posts.)

headline: India Passes Sweeping Bill on Crimes Against Women
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Stalking (Crime)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: India’s normally slow-moving Parliament passed the bill just three months after the Delhi gang rape that sparked widespread protests.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Less than three months after a New Delhi woman who was gang raped on a moving bus died from her injuries, India’s Parliament passed a comprehensive bill that imposes stronger penalties on men who attack women and criminalizes offenses like stalking and voyeurism.

headline: Timeline on Iran’s Nuclear Program
abstract: Whether Iran is racing toward nuclear weapon capabilities is one of the most contentious foreign-policy issues challenging the West.
lead_paragraph: Whether Iran is racing toward nuclear weapon capabilities is one of the most contentious foreign-policy issues challenging the West.

headline: Parents of the ‘Touch-Screen Generation,’ Don’t Free Your iPad Yet
abstract: Hanna Rosin boldly allowed her 2-year-old unfettered access to an iPad for six weeks. It’s not an experiment I’ll duplicate.
lead_paragraph: Every weekend morning, one or the other of my younger children appears early. He or she creeps to the side of my bed, and for a brief moment, I can feel the child’s thoughtful, assessing gaze, but I don’t move. There is usually a pause. Waking Mommy can be a dangerous proposition. But it’s worth it for the prize. “Mommy,” the child whispers, “can I have your iPad?”

headline: Changing the Culture of College Application
abstract: Changing the application and enrollments patterns of high-achieving, low-income students will probably take an enormous amount of initial work. Over time, though, the work will get easier.
lead_paragraph: When Central Magnet High School opened in Bridgeport, Conn., almost 30 years ago, few of its students thought about applying to selective colleges.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: NPR: Parents worried about their children’s weight often give them low-fat milk. But studies show that preschoolers who drank it were heavier than those who consumed whole milk. – Patrick Farrell

headline: Linking Past and Present in Nuremberg
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: This Bavarian city, known to many for its World War II significance, has much more to offer than dark history.
lead_paragraph: “This will be easy to see,” said Annelise, our guide, flipping off the lights in the chilly sandstone beer cellar that had been converted to an air-raid shelter during World War II. A small plaque on the wall glowed with electric-lime phosphorescence. It was, she told us, an emergency exit sign for the 50,000 civilians who had fled — two to a square meter — to these cellars-cum-bunkers during Allied firebombings.

headline: Charleston’s Cousin Gets in the Picture
abstract: An award from This Old House Magazine is just part of a new story being told in North Charleston, S.C.
lead_paragraph: An award from This Old House Magazine is just part of a new story being told in North Charleston, S.C.

headline: Restaurant Report: Orquideas in Vieques, P.R.
abstract: At this recently rebooted spot near the water, diners can sample local greens and dig into meat fired on an unusual, but effective, grill.
lead_paragraph: With Caribbean Sea views and a soundtrack of lapping waves, it’s hard to deny the appeal of the Malecón, the esplanade in the village of Esperanza that traces Puerto Real, a bay on the southern shore of Vieques, P.R. So it’s no surprise that the Malecón is home to the island’s highest concentration of restaurants. With such attractive real estate, they have to be only passable to be packed; for the same reason, those even a block from the water must be twice as good to garner equal attention.

headline: Okay Expectations
abstract: The outlook is for a slow economy for a long time to come.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has trimmed its forecast for growth in 2013, but not by much and not by as much as might have been expected given that Washington is forging ahead with ill-advised budget cuts. In these days of diminished expectations, that passes for good news.

headline: A Tale of Two Frozen Lakes
abstract: Inclement weather foiled attempts to dive in a second Antarctic lake, but we managed to get a quick glimpse under its ice.
lead_paragraph: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee in Antarctica.

headline: Mexican New Yorkers Are More Likely to Live in Poor Households
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Education (K-12)', 'Income', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mexican-Americans', 'Minorities', 'Poverty', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Nearly two-thirds of the city’s Mexican residents, including immigrants and the native-born, are living in low-income households, said a report by the Community Service Society.
lead_paragraph: People of Mexican descent in New York City are far more likely to be living in poor or near-poor households than other Latinos, blacks, whites or Asians, according to a study to be released on Thursday.

headline: Executives Press European Antitrust Chief on Google
abstract: In a letter, the heads of 11 Web businesses in Europe asked Joaquin Almunia to compel Google to change its business practices so that smaller rivals are not unfairly harmed.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With the European antitrust inquiry into Google’s search engine practices entering a third year, a group of 11 Web companies sent a joint letter to the top antitrust official in Europe on Thursday, asking him to compel Google to change its business practices to ensure that smaller rivals are not unfairly harmed.

headline: Fran Warren, Singer in Big-Band Era, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Warren, best known for her hit “A Sunday Kind of Love,” sang professionally for more than half a century.
lead_paragraph: Fran Warren, one of the last surviving singing stars of the big-band era, died at her home in Brookfield, Conn., on March 4, her 87th birthday.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: Should a bride send a wedding invitation to someone she already knows cannot attend? What are some alternatives to the traditional shower?
lead_paragraph: Inviting Confusion

headline: Marvel’s ‘Age of Ultron’  Features Controversial Angel
abstract: The appearance of Angela in a Marvel comic was kept under wraps for a remarkably long time.
lead_paragraph: In “Age of Ultron,” a story currently being published by Marvel Comics, the Avengers and their allies are on the ropes against their archenemy Ultron, an artificial intelligence who has taken over the world. The story concludes in June and will feature a special guest star: the angel Angela, a character created by the writer Neil Gaiman and the artist Todd McFarlane for “Spawn,” published by Image Comics.

headline: Court Says South Korean Dictator, Father of Current President, Violated Constitution
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Three emergency decrees issued in the 1970s by Park Chung-hee outlawing criticism of his government and protest rallies were rejected by the nation’s Constitutional Court.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Three emergency decrees issued in the 1970s by South Korea’s dictator at the time, Park Chung-hee, were unconstitutional, the nation’s Constitutional Court ruled on Thursday, in a landmark verdict on the legacy of the current president’s father.

headline: NBC’s Late-Night Dream
abstract: The Times’s Brian Stelter on NBC’s hopes to win younger viewers by replacing the host of “The Tonight Show,” Jay Leno, with Jimmy Fallon.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Brian Stelter on NBC’s hopes to win younger viewers by replacing the host of “The Tonight Show,” Jay Leno, with Jimmy Fallon.

headline: The Gun Report: March 21, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: I was in Detroit on Wednesday, and as I passed the airport newsstand, I did a double-take when I saw the headline in the Detroit Free Press. “Grandma Guilty of Murder,” it read: “Teen’s 911 cry for help sways jury.” The article reported on the end of a murder trial in which Sandra Layne,  a 75-year-old West Bloomfield woman, shot to death her 17-year-old grandson. Jonathan Hoffman’s parents had moved to Arizona, where their daughter was undergoing multiple surgeries for a brain tumor. Their son had stayed behind in Michigan to finish high school, moving in with his grandparents.

headline: Caroline Kennedy: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “Poems to Learn by Heart” loves books about the Inquisition and the crusades, but feels “guilty reading bad things about the Catholic Church.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “Poems to Learn by Heart” loves books about the Inquisition and the crusades, but feels “guilty reading bad things about the Catholic Church.”

headline: Girls in the Band
abstract: Mariachi Flor de Toloache, a New York band, may be the first all-female mariachi ensemble in the city.
lead_paragraph: Mariachi Flor de Toloache, a New York band, may be the first all-female mariachi ensemble in the city.

headline: Highlights and Analysis of N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: Times editors and reporters cover the opening round of the men’s college basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin, Times editors and reporters break down the first full day of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Paul Rose, Quebec Separatist Involved in a Kidnapping and Murder, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Rose was a member of the FLQ extremist group that kidnapped Canadian political leaders and committed dozens of terrorist bombings. He was later convicted of murder.
lead_paragraph: Paul Rose, a strident Quebec separatist leader who in October 1970 helped kidnap and, he claimed, strangle a provincial official, inflaming a crisis that pitted terrorists against the Canadian prime minister, Pierre Trudeau, died March 14 in Montreal. He was 69.

headline: She’s Not Impressed? Then You’re Not In
abstract: Tina Fey stars as an admissions officer at Princeton in “Admission,” a comedy directed by Paul Weitz.
lead_paragraph: The timing of “Admission,” Paul Weitz’s new comedy, is either clever or cruel — perhaps both. In the next few weeks, word will go forth from colleges across the land about who is in and who is out, as the American higher-education-industrial complex enacts its own Darwinian version of “Project Runway.” As the father of a high school junior, paying my tithe to the test prep gods while preparing to sacrifice most of my worldly goods on the altar of the liberal arts, I can’t tell if I’m part of the intended audience, or if the ratings board should issue a special warning for sensitive parents like me. How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?

headline: Ai Weiwei to Let 1,000 Tents Bloom in Germany
abstract: The artist will create an installation along a river consisting of 1,000 tents.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei plans to create a major installation at a festival in Germany this summer consisting of 1,000 tents set up along the Emscher River, the BBC reported.

headline: Citigroup Banker Says It’s Too Early to Toast a Revival in M.&A.
abstract: In kicking off a conference at Tulane University, Mark Shafir, co-head of global mergers and acquisitions at Citigroup, says that while the factors for a recovery in deal-making are in place, there are enough potential problems that the market is lagging behind where it should be.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS – While many of the lawyers gathered here may be ready to toast an upswing in deals, one prominent mergers banker thinks it is too early to plan a party.

headline: The Liberation of Paris
abstract: A vibrant group of young, adventurous and international chefs are breaking down barriers and revolutionizing the city’s age-old Michelin-guarded culinary scene.
lead_paragraph: A vibrant group of young, adventurous and international chefs are breaking down barriers and revolutionizing the city’s age-old Michelin-guarded culinary scene.

headline: Scenes From Two Days at the Met
abstract: Behind the curtain at the Metropolitan Opera. In order of appearance: setup for “La Rondine,” set assembly for “L’Elisir d’Amore,” stage rehearsal of “Rigoletto” and setup for “Le Comte Ory.”
lead_paragraph: Behind the curtain at the Metropolitan Opera. In order of appearance: setup for “La Rondine,” set assembly for “L’Elisir d’Amore,” stage rehearsal of “Rigoletto” and setup for “Le Comte Ory.”

headline: The Epic Ups and Downs of Peter Gelb
abstract: What it takes to run the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Most mornings Peter Gelb, the 59-year-old general manager of the world’s most prominent opera company, rises between 4 a.m. and 5 a.m. The elegant Upper West Side duplex he shares with his wife is four blocks from Lincoln Center. He puts on a bathrobe and pads downstairs to the kitchen, where he turns on his La Pavoni espresso machine with the hand-levered piston that allows him to feel, amid all he can’t control at the Metropolitan Opera, that he can at least control the quality of his coffee. He fixes a skim-milk cappuccino with two shots of espresso, eats a banana and then sits down in his home office, where the walls are decorated with autographed scores by Verdi, Puccini and Shostakovich and the shelves are filled with hundreds of CDs, including some by his great-uncle, the renowned violinist Jascha Heifetz. Gelb himself has no particular musical gift, but his ability to remain alert while attending 280 or so opera performances and rehearsals a year on apparently very little sleep qualifies him as a virtuoso of some sort.

headline: 3 Tibetans Sentenced in Immolation Cases
abstract: The men were said to use others’ self-immolation deaths for publicity purposes.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Three Tibetans from Qinghai Province have been given prison sentences for “inciting state secession,” according to a statement on an official provincial Web site. On Monday, a court in Haidong Prefecture sentenced the Tibetans — Kalsang Dhondup, Jigme Thabkey and Lobsang — to terms of six, five and four years, respectively. The online announcement said that the men used self-immolations by Tibetans for publicity purposes and circulated texts and photographs related to Tibetan independence, spreading “bad influence locally and internationally.” Since 2009, at least 109 Tibetans have set fire to themselves to protest Chinese rule, and most have died. To deter the act, Chinese officials are trying to prosecute people associated with those who commit self-immolation. Tibetans opposed to Chinese rule say those who self-immolated did it out of frustration with Chinese policies.

headline: You Won’t Win, but the Heat Probably Will
abstract: Underdogs will, as usual, wreck a lot of N.C.A.A. tournament brackets. But no one, not even a fan on the court, seems able to stop the Miami Heat.
lead_paragraph: It is officially underdog day (Part 1), when America is united in rooting for a bunch of guys we have never heard of toiling for a university we cannot find on a map, the only acceptable exception being when that bunch of guys can totally ruin your bracket. (And even then, expect office ridicule if you start rooting loudly for Duke.) Because we are all about the underdog, the Round of 64 in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament tapping into that vein in our national character. Hey, back in 1776, England was the big-money team with the overpaid coach and look what we did then. That was our first 3-pointer at the buzzer.

headline: Spend Sunday Online With Pink Floyd
abstract: To celebrate the 40th anniversary of the album “The Dark Side of the Moon,” the band will stream it online.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1970s, fans of Pink Floyd were known to gather in small groups around their stereos, often in darkened living rooms, imbibe their drug of choice and listen to “The Dark Side of the Moon” in its entirety.

headline: Workers Still Uneasy About Retirement Finances
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Personal Finances', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Savings']
abstract: Many workers essentially guess about how much money they’ll need in retirement, a survey finds.
lead_paragraph: Americans remain uneasy about their retirement finances despite a brightening economic outlook — perhaps because it is dawning on them just how much they have to save, a long-running survey finds.

headline: Robert Parker vs. Antonio Galloni
abstract: Antonio Galloni left Robert M. Parker Jr.’s Wine Advocate to start his own Web publication, but now The Advocate is suing him for breach of contract and fraud.
lead_paragraph: Just five weeks after the wine critic Antonio Galloni left Robert M. Parker Jr.’s Wine Advocate to start his own Web venture, The Advocate is suing him in federal court on charges that include breach of contract and fraud, according to Courthouse News Service.

headline: An All-Female Band, Making Its Way in the World of Mariachi
abstract: Mariachi has always been male-dominated, but all nine members of Mariachi Flor de Toloache are women, the pioneers of what they believe is New York’s first all-female mariachi ensemble.
lead_paragraph: One is German, another a New Yorker of Egyptian descent. Others are Cuban-American, Colombian, Dominican and Argentine.

headline: President May Be Quarterback, but Today Congress Plays a Different Game
abstract: Once House and Senate leaders deferred to the seniority and expertise of committees, but today’s leaders follow the battle plans of warring political armies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like quarterbacks in football, presidents are central to most Washington stories. So discussion of budget gridlock often revolves around whetherPresident Obama plays as effectively as his predecessors.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Some keep the Sabbath going to Church’
abstract: To mark the coming of Passover and Holy Week, our Poetry Pairing this week features “Some keep the Sabbath going to Church,” a poem by Emily Dickinson, with “A Religious Ritual Attracts Even Nonbelievers” by Mark Oppenheimer.
lead_paragraph: To mark the coming of Passover and Holy Week, our Poetry Pairing this week matches “Some keep the Sabbath going to Church,” by Emily Dickinson, with “A Religious Ritual Attracts Even Nonbelievers” by Mark Oppenheimer.

headline: Image of the Day: March 21
abstract: A dancer participating in an awareness campaign to save tigers, in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Doctors and Their Online Reputation
abstract: The Internet is quickly becoming patients’ resource of choice to learn more about their doctors. But doctors have been slow to embrace it for one reason: they aren’t sure how to be a doctor online.
lead_paragraph: When a doctor I know recently signed up for a Twitter account, his colleagues began teasing him. “Are you going to tweet what you eat?” one joked.

headline: Door Shut on South Korea-Syria Match
abstract: The planned closed-door exhibition match between Syria and South Korea will not go off as planned in Seoul on Friday.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine in the midst of the bloody Syrian conflict anything happening other than the daily task of survival. Yet despite the descent into chaos, the Syrian national team has remained intact, escaping the implosion of its country.

headline: Path to Citizenship for Immigrants Draws Support Across Party Lines, Survey Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Nearly two-thirds of Americans favor giving illegal immigrants an opportunity for legal status, according to a poll by the Public Religion Research Institute and the Brookings Institution.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two-thirds of Americans favor giving illegal immigrants in the country an opportunity for legal status with a path to citizenship, according to a poll published Thursday by the Public Religion Research Institute and the Brookings Institution. Support for an earned path to citizenship for those immigrants came from 71 percent of Democrats and also a majority, 53 percent, of Republicans, the poll found.

headline: ‘Lean In’
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Sheryl Sandberg’s “Lean In.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: My New Office: A Parking Space
abstract: There is a downside to working from home: chores.
lead_paragraph: Before my fiancé, James, and I bought our first car, we discussed money, fantasy vacation homes, insurance, pleather, climate control, climate change and unborn children. But perhaps more important was what we didn’t discuss. And that was parking. We spent about 30 seconds on it.

headline: House Passes Money Bill and Budget Blueprint
abstract: As it approved legislation to pay for federal spending through September, the Republican-led House also passed a blueprint for a smaller government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House gave final approval on Thursday to legislation to keep government financed through September, and it also passed a Republican blueprint that enshrined the party’s vision of a balanced budget that would substantially shrink spending, privatize Medicare and rewrite the tax code to make it simpler.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Obama’s Choice for Interior Dept.
abstract: Sally Jewell, the chief executive of Recreational Equipment Inc., won approval of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee by a large bipartisan margin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – President Obama’s nominee to lead the Interior Department, Sally Jewell, cleared her first hurdle on the way to confirmation on Thursday, winning approval of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee by a large bipartisan margin.

headline: Redemption’s Advocate
abstract: Tom Clements, the slain head of the Colorado prison system, reminded me how and why prisons matter.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans don’t think or talk much about the way prisons in this country are funded or run. We want a vague, blanket assurance that our politicians and their appointees are being tough on crime. We pay attention to verdicts and to sentences but not to what happens afterward, to the experience that a convicted criminal has over the years before he or she most likely reenters society. We forget—or we simply don’t bother to recognize—that the nature of this experience has an effect on whether the criminal breaks the law again. We want to feel safe, and yet we’re utterly uneducated about, and inattentive to, a part of our criminal justice system that in fact has enormous bearing on our safety.

headline: Transcript of Obama’s Speech in Israel
abstract: Following is a complete transcript of President Obama’s remarks in Jerusalem on March 21, 2013
lead_paragraph: Following is a complete transcript of President Obama’s remarks in Jerusalem on March 21, 2013. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service).

headline: ‘Matilda’ Comes to Broadway
abstract: Patrick Healy interviewed the composer Tim Minchin about the challenges of bringing Roald Dahl’s work to Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy interviewed the composer Tim Minchin about the challenges of bringing Roald Dahl’s work to Broadway.

headline: U.N. to Investigate Chemical Weapons Accusations in Syria
abstract: An inquiry will begin “as soon as practically possible” over allegations that the weapons were used in Aleppo Province, said the Secretary General Ban Ki-moon.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations will investigate accusations that chemical weapons were used earlier this week in Aleppo Province in northern Syria, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced on Thursday.

headline: It’s Mountain West vs. Pac-12
abstract: The N.C.A.A. tournament will have a say in whether the Pac-12 or Mountain West is the better basketball conference.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. – In the Mountain and Pacific time zones, the rise of the Mountain West Conference has turned it into the chief rival of the Pac-12 Conference

headline: Dream Big, Girl
abstract: “Matilda,” a hit in London, arrives on Broadway as the theater’s latest shot at the dream of a global blockbuster.
lead_paragraph: “Matilda” isn’t just one of the most anticipated shows of the Broadway season. This new musical is the theater’s latest shot at the dream of a global blockbuster, a rare glory that producers and audiences crave to offset all the duds that cross the stage each year.

headline: The Rise of the ‘Infernal Machines’
abstract: How mines and torpedoes shaped the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 12, 1862, the Union ironclad gunboat Cairo and a small group of support vessels moved cautiously through a bend in Mississippi’s sluggish Yazoo River. They sought torpedoes, what we now know as mines. Suddenly, Walter E.H. Fentress, an ensign sitting in a small boat some distance from the Cairo, heard an explosion and “saw her anchor thrown up into the air.” Onboard the Cairo, George Yost, a 14-year-old ship’s boy, wrote that the torpedoes “crushed in the bottom of the boat so that the water rushed in like the roar of Niagara.” The Cairo went down in 15 minutes. Fortunately, no lives were lost; most of the crew simply stepped into small boats as the ship sank – the first warship sunk by an underwater explosive.

headline: Face-to-Face Talks
abstract: The Times’s Jodi Rudoren discusses President Obama’s visits with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jodi Rudoren discusses President Obama’s visits with Israeli and Palestinian leaders.

headline: Risë Stevens, 99, Stalwart at the Met for Decades in Carmen Role, Is Dead
abstract: Ms. Stevens, a mezzo-soprano, practically owned the role of Carmen during the 1940s and ’50, and gained popularity through her appearances on radio, television and in movies.
lead_paragraph: Risë Stevens, the internationally renowned mezzo-soprano who had a 23-year career with the Metropolitan Opera, where she practically owned the role of Carmen during the 1940s and ’50s, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.

headline: Illustrating Her Own Narrative
abstract: A retrospective of work from Barbara Nessim at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London recognizes her talents as an illustrator.
lead_paragraph: Women who built careers as illustrators in “Mad Men”-era New York were few and far between, and one is Barbara Nessim. In the early 1960s she became known for brightly colored pop portraits of women, made with fluid, expressive lines, which appeared in Esquire, Harper’s Bazaar and girlie magazines. During feminism’s rise in the early ’70s her focus on women and gender roles drew the interest of publications covering women’s issues, like Ms. (Gloria Steinem was once her roommate), New York and Time. In the ’80s Ms. Nessim became one of the first illustrators to work with computers, which may be how she is best known today.

headline: Obama Lays Out Case for Israel to Revive Peace Talks
abstract: In a carefully crafted speech that was enthusiastically welcomed by a youthful audience of Israelis, President Obama advocated a vision of a future Israel at peace with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: Laying out his case for a future Israel at peace with the Palestinians, President Obama delivered an enthusiastically welcomed speech on Thursday before an audience of youthful Israelis in Jerusalem, assuring them of America’s strong support but asking them to empathize with their Israeli-occupied neighbors and “look at the world through their eyes.”

headline: Keeping Score: The Clippers’ Game Changer
abstract: Chris Paul of the Los Angeles Clippers is the rarest of stars: he makes a massive contribution to his team while being one of the N.B.A.’s most efficient players.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James and Kevin Durant have received a lot of attention this season, and deservedly so. James and Durant are the two best players in the N.B.A., but there should be room in the spotlight for a player who is not too far behind: Chris Paul of the Los Angeles Clippers.

headline: As New Drone Policy Is Weighed, Few Practical Effects Are Seen
abstract: For months, the Obama administration has promised to create a more lasting legal framework for its drone program, but the only proposal to surface so far may have little short-term effect.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Under growing pressure to bring greater transparency and accountability to its use of targeted killing, the Obama administration is struggling to transform a program that was conceived under pressure, has operated in a secretive and often haphazard manner and has left the United States increasingly isolated even from its allies.

headline: The Risks of Expanding Into Australia, Part 2
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Small Business']
abstract: The role of a general manager evolves dramatically in the first few years; unfortunately, only about half of our G.M.’s survive the transition.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, I wrote about our plans to open our 22nd foreign office in Australia. We have checked the very important first few boxes in our process to conduct a successful foreign-office opening with limited risk and investment — including finding a general manager, Anna Minns, who will start drawing a salary as soon as we start invoicing. Most important, we have a few partnership deals that are close to closing.

headline: The Red One, Next to the Fiat
abstract: The Hertz Corporation recently expanded its Supercar rental offerings in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Hertz Corporation recently expanded its Supercar rental offerings in Europe, increasing the number of cars and models available in Britain and Spain, and adding Italy, France and (beginning in April) the Netherlands, to the countries where the premium cars can be rented. Renters can now choose brands including McLaren, Lamborghini (shown) and Aston Martin. What European financial crisis?

headline: Playwrights Horizons Season To Range From Simpsons to Kama Sutra
abstract: Plays written and directed by women make up a significant share of the Off Broadway company’s 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: Playwrights Horizons is once again putting women front and center in the company’s 2013-2014 season, staging four plays by women, including two world premieres. Three of the first five plays the Off Broadway company announced on Thursday will also be directed by women.

headline: The Renaissance Followed Him North
abstract: The National Gallery’s new exhibition of works by Albrecht Dürer covers his career from beginning to end.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Albrecht Dürer had it all: the eye of a Raphael, the brains of a Leonardo, the looks of a cleaned-up Kurt Cobain. He produced the earliest known self-portrait drawing in European art when he was 13, and some of the first stand-alone landscapes. He brought the pliant warmth of Italian Classical painting to the shivery Gothic north, and transformed the woodcut medium from semi-folk art to fine art, and very fine art indeed.

headline: Wheelies: The ‘Top 10’ List Edition
abstract: Graham Rahal of the Rahal Letterman Lanigan racing team takes a turn presenting the Top 10 List on “The Late Show.”
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: U.S. to Play Mexico in Ohio
abstract: The United States announced the venues for four home World Cup qualifying matches and also said it would play Germany in Washington in June.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Soccer on Thursday announced the venues for four home World Cup qualifying matches and confirmed that it will play a centennial match against Germany in Washington on June 2. Kickoff is scheduled for 2:30 p.m. Eastern. (Also as part of the federation’s 100th anniversary, the U.S. women’s national team will play Canada at BMO Field in Toronto later that day, with the match scheduled to start at 4:30 p.m.)

headline: The Envelope Please: Leobardo Espinoza
abstract: As college admission decisions begin to roll in, Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a senior at Topeka High School in Kansas, wonders whether now is the best time to take a break and travel abroad.
lead_paragraph: As college admission decisions begin to roll in, Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a senior at Topeka High School in Kansas, wonders whether now is the best time to take a break and travel abroad.

headline: To Boaz Weinstein, Betting Against JPMorgan’s Trade Was ‘Easy’
abstract: Boaz Weinstein, the founder of Saba Capital, reflected on Thursday about the ramifications of JPMorgan Chase’s infamous “London Whale” trade that cost the bank billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has been in an uncomfortable spotlight over the last week, after the release of a scathing Senate report related to its multibillion-dollar trading loss last year.

headline: Recipe Lab | Nigella Lawson

lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of eight senators is considering a plan that would double the number of visas available to highly skilled foreign workers, as well as sharply increase the number of green cards available to foreign students who graduate from an American university with a degree in science, technology, engineering or math, two people familiar with the negotiations said.

headline: Gap Year Now or Study Abroad Later?
abstract: As college admission decisions begin to roll in, Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a senior at Topeka High School in Kansas, wonders whether now is the best time to take a break and travel abroad.
lead_paragraph: Last summer I had the opportunity to travel abroad. As a youth ambassador with the State Department, I was selected to travel to the small Central American country of Belize to learn more about American and Belizean diplomacy, civic engagement and volunteerism.

lead_paragraph: Four Latin American nations have objected to an auction this weekend in Paris by Sotheby’s because they say some of the 300 items of pre-Columbian art to be sold were illegally exported.

headline: Emerging From the Deep
abstract: Crave Fishbar, with its becalmed nautical décor and shipwreck theme, evokes the surprising pleasures of being marooned in Midtown.
lead_paragraph: THE MENU AT Crave Fishbar reads like a come-on. First there is nori powder, a nutty dust with a fizz of brine; then vinegar made from fermented plantains; black garlic, syrupy and sour-sweet; burned lemon peel, a bartender’s trick, applying flame to make the oils caramelize; and schmaltz, rendered chicken fat, at once motherly and wanton.

headline: On Cooking With Fresh Chicken
abstract: More details about how fresh chicken can get from the market to the tables at Hanjan so quickly.
lead_paragraph: We received a few questions from readers regarding Wednesday’s Diner’s Journal item about the “Fresh Killed Chicken” offerings on the menu at Hanjan, the bustling new Korean tavern that the chef Hooni Kim has opened in the Flatiron district.

headline: The Men in Late Night Dreams
abstract: A reporter remembers a man who came to town with the circus.
lead_paragraph: I have noticed these days that reporters never talk to each other about sleeping with their subjects.

headline: Jailed Leader of the Kurds Offers a Truce With Turkey

lead_paragraph: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — The jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on Thursday called for a cease-fire and ordered all his fighters off Turkish soil, in a landmark moment for a newly energized effort to end three decades of armed conflict with the Turkish government.

headline: Sweetening the Deal
abstract: M.&A. bankers and lawyers telling a public relations firm that specializes in deals that they expect to see more merger activity makes for sweet echo-chamber music
lead_paragraph: M.&A. bankers and lawyers telling a public relations firm that specializes in deals that they expect to see more merger activity makes for sweet echo-chamber music. The survey released by the Brunswick Group to coincide with an annual American deal maker convention found three of four practitioners expecting more mergers and acquisitions globally this year than last. They’re more bullish than ever about North America, with 97 percent anticipating growth in the region. A discount needs to be applied to all the optimism.

headline: As Congress Votes to Avert One Fiscal Crisis, Boehner Moves On to Another
abstract: Just as Congress passed legislation to finance the government through the end of the fiscal year, Speaker John A. Boehner made a statement suggesting the House would not increase the debt limit without further spending cuts.
lead_paragraph: Just when it looked as if both political parties were ready to step off the bloody budget battlefield, the troops on Thursday began mustering for a new skirmish on an old issue: the debt ceiling.

headline: Masked by Gibberish, the Risks Run Amok
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)']

lead_paragraph: Can anyone manage a big bank these days? Should anyone try?

headline: Universe as an Infant: Fatter Than Expected and Kind of Lumpy
abstract: A Planck satellite image shows the cosmos as it appeared only 370,000 years after the Big Bang.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers released the latest and most exquisite baby picture yet of the universe on Thursday, one that showed it to be 80 million to 100 million years older and a little fatter than previously thought, with more matter in it and perhaps ever so slightly lopsided.

headline: Norovirus Is Common in Children
abstract: Norovirus infection has become the leading cause of gastroenteritis in children under 5 in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Norovirus infection has become the leading cause of acute gastroenteritis in children under 5 in the United States.

headline: Marcum Says Shoulder Issue Is Not New
abstract: Mets pitcher Shaun Marcum says he has dealt with shoulder inflammation for the past three years.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Shaun Marcum described his shoulder inflammation, which drove him to receive a cortisone injection Tuesday and forced him to miss his last Grapefruit League start, as part of his spring training routine.

headline: Consumer Agency Warns Lenders on Bias in Auto Loans
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau takes on auto dealers and lenders who are engaging in discriminatory lending practices.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau laid out its authority over auto lenders on Thursday and warned them to comply with fair lending requirements. The agency said that it was issuing the new instructions in response to discriminatory practices that resulted in Hispanic and black borrowers’ illegally being charged higher rates than whites for auto loans.

headline: Caffeine May Boost Driver Safety
keywords: ['Caffeine', 'Coffee', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: Long-haul truck drivers who drink coffee or other caffeinated drinks are significantly less likely to have an accident than their uncaffeinated peers, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Long-haul truck drivers who drink coffee or other caffeinated drinks are significantly less likely to have an accident than their uncaffeinated peers.

headline: Gun Control and Speed Legislating
abstract: After rushing through a gun bill, the governor of New York realized he’d made a mistake.
lead_paragraph: When Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York responded to the Newtown massacre by quickly pushing through the toughest gun control laws in the country, we congratulated him on our editorial page, but worried about the speed and secrecy with which he accomplished this feat.

headline: Seeking Bracket Perfection? Fat Chance
abstract: It is far more likely that your home will be hit by a meteorite than that you will fill out a perfect N.C.A.A. tournament bracket.
lead_paragraph: As the bulk of the N.C.A.A. tournament action proceeds with the Round of 64 on Thursday and Friday, most people quickly abandon any thoughts of perfection. No, by the end of the first day, most amateur bracketeers are hoping their brackets aren’t dripping with corrective red ink and their Final Four picks survived unscathed.

headline: Mapping the Big Bang
abstract: The Times’s Dennis Overbye discusses a portrait of the universe as a young cosmos.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Dennis Overbye discusses a portrait of the universe as a young cosmos.

headline: Endnotes | The Dover Bookshop
abstract: The London store, a trove of ready-made inspiration for art directors, fashion designers and boldfaced bibliophiles alike, is closing at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: Since opening in 1986, the Dover Bookshop in London has catered to a discerning clientele that includes art directors, fashion designers and boldfaced bibliophiles like Helena Bonham-Carter, Terry Gilliam and Jimmy Page. In addition to supplying great books, the store became a go-to destination for royalty-free images pulled from Victorian-era women’s magazines or 19th-century garden manuals that artists could incorporate into their work. For those who considered the shop a trove of ready-made inspiration, the news that it will close at the end of the month comes as a huge shock. “The Charing Cross Road area of London has changed from a haven for small shops to an area for mainstream brands and fashion,” the store’s manager Tim Matthews wrote in an e-mail. “Beyond that, though, image resources are increasingly found online and Dover Publications are moving steadily into that world.” Among the brilliant, obscure volumes that made up the shop’s stock in trade were Gustave Doré’s illustrations of London; Jan Vredeman De Vries’s book of 16th-century architectural engravings, “Studies in Perspective”; and Jim Harner’s collection of 1,000 black-and-white animal drawings.

headline: Israeli Beauty Queen Next in Line to Press Obama to Release Spy
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Israeli politicians have tried and failed to convince President Obama to release Jonathan Pollard, a former United States Navy intelligence analyst serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel. Now it is Miss Israel’s turn.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Friday, 9:19 a.m. As my colleague Isabel Kershner explained, Israeli politicians have taken turns this week pressing President Obama to release Jonathan Pollard, a former United States Navy intelligence analyst serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel.

headline: A Jazz Pairing That Plays Outside the Lines
abstract: Cooper-Moore and Lonnie Holley will perform in conjunction with the “Blues for Smoke” exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: The Miser moved to New York in the mid-1990s mostly for love, it’s true, but also because of a growing interest in avant-garde jazz. And at the time, it was still possible to catch a pioneer like Cecil Taylor, Anthony Braxton or even Ornette Coleman in an intimate setting somewhere in downtown Manhattan.

headline: Addressing Fears About LED Light Bulbs
abstract: A column about LED light bulbs generated a lot of reader e-mail, probably because LED represents change. And change is always scary. David Pogue addresses some reader concerns.
lead_paragraph: In my Times column Thursday, I reviewed a new generation of LED light bulbs. They last 25 times as long as regular bulbs, use maybe one-eighth the electricity, work with dimmers, turn on instantly to full brightness and remain cool to the touch. A big drawback has always been cost, but now, I noted, the prices have fallen.

headline: Pro-Assad Cleric Killed in Blast in Damascus
abstract: The cleric, Mohammad Said Ramada al-Bouti, was the most important religious figure to be killed so far in the Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A large explosion killed at least 42 people inside a central Damascus mosque on Thursday, including the top Sunni cleric in Syria, one of the major remaining Sunni supporters of President Bashar al-Assad’s embattled government in the civil war.

headline: Iona Is Happy to Be Back, but No Rerun, Please
abstract: The view from Iona: After a heartbreaking loss to Brigham Young last year, the Iona Gaels will play Ohio State on Friday.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — A year ago, Iona suffered one of the most heartbreaking defeats in N.C.A.A. tournament history.

headline: Rosneft Completes Acquisition of TNK-BP
abstract: With the sale to the Russian oil giant, BP aimed to resolve one of two problems that have clouded its future and depressed its stock price.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BP, the British oil company, said on Thursday that it had completed the sale of its 50 percent stake in the Russian affiliate TNK-BP. In a series of transactions, BP will receive about $12.5 billion in cash and will own 19.75 percent of Rosneft, the largest Russian oil company.

headline: For Euro Zone, a Cyprus Exit Would Have Little Impact
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Europe’s losses from a Cypriot banking collapse would be minimal compared with the havoc that a Greek exit would have created.
lead_paragraph: A Cyprus exit from the euro union, if it comes to that, would have a devastating effect on the country’s citizens, who are among the most indebted in the euro zone. And for European unity and diplomacy, the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short-term disaster.

lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until I got to know Anjali better that I realized how much it took for her to approach me in the waiting room at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center last summer.

On Tuesday, lawyers will argue a challenge to California’s gay marriage ban, Proposition 8, and the next day, the justices will hear a challenge to the federal law known as the Defense of Marriage Act.

headline: Sixers Can Measure Young’s Success by the Numbers

lead_paragraph: In his six years in the N.B.A., the Philadelphia 76ers’ Thaddeus Young has evolved into the kind of small-ball power forward who is supposed to be in the vanguard of the positional revolution.

lead_paragraph: Apple on Thursday rolled out a tool that strengthens password security for Apple accounts: two-step verification, a feature widely available for many Web services.

lead_paragraph: David Ranta walked out of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Thursday a free man, after spending more than two decades in a maximum-security prison for a crime he almost certainly did not commit.

headline: His Lawyer Is Writing a Book About Johnny Carson
abstract: The lawyer, Henry Bushkin, describes himself as Carson’s learpiece, mouthpiece and running buddy, among other things.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Carson and “The Tonight Show” have been extensively chronicled, including in books over the years from Carson himself and from his longtime co-host, Ed McMahon.

headline: Ex-Horace Mann Students in Talks on Sex-Abuse Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The negotiations are said to involve 32 former students who say they were abused by teachers and staff members at the Bronx preparatory school.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-two former students of the Horace Mann School have said they were sexually abused by teachers and staff members, and they have been meeting with school officials in the past two weeks to negotiate compensation, according to a person knowledgeable about the talks.

headline: Virginia Overton
abstract: Virginia Overton has a solo show at the Mitchell-Innes & Nash Gallery in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

headline: Mom and Dad, Midwest and Milan
abstract: In “The Force of Things: A Marriage in War and Peace,” the journalist Alexander Stille tells the story of his parents’ passionate, tempestuous marriage.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth and Misha, Alexander Stille’s mother and father, met in May 1948 at a party for Truman Capote. She came to the party with her husband at the time, Bob, and left with Misha. Within a week, she’d moved out of the apartment she’d shared with Bob, and begun an intense romance with Misha. The pair would get married and stay married for more than four decades, but the marriage would be a fiercely tempestuous one, fueled by epic fights and threats of divorce — a marriage that their son describes as a toxic clash of civilizations. When he was a teenager, he says, it reminded him of Sartre’s line “Hell is other people.”

headline: Global Ticket Sales for Movies Rise 6%
abstract: China, with $2.7 billion in ticket sales last year, passed Japan to become the second-biggest market for films, according to industry statistics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Movie ticket sales around the world rose 6 percent last year, to $34.7 billion from $32.6 billion in 2011, as China became the world’s second-biggest market for theatrical films after the United States, according to statistics released by the Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday.

headline: The Hard Math on Fossil Fuels
abstract: Even the recent reduction in carbon-dioxide emissions in the United States is not nearly sharp enough to avoid reaching what climate scientists consider the prudent limit in global warming within decades.
lead_paragraph: How close is the world to devastating climate upheaval? My column on Wednesday argued that the natural gas boom is helping the United States reduce its emissions of heat-trapping carbon into the air, encouraging power generators to switch to gas from the much dirtier coal. American CO2 emissions last year totaled about 5.25 billion tons — almost 13 percent less than in 2007.

headline: Pollock and André Derain at Auction; Met Expands Hours
abstract: An early Pollock and an André Derain portrait are among the most notable works coming to auction. The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open on Mondays starting July 1.
lead_paragraph: With deadlines for the spring auctions fast approaching, experts at Sotheby’s and Christie’s are scrambling to get top material for their sales. It’s been a tough couple of months. No major estates are up for grabs, and most collectors are reluctant to sell a work unless they need cash. Slowly, however, a few significant works are beginning to come on the market for the sales, among them “The Blue Unconscious,” an early abstract canvas that Jackson Pollock painted in 1946.

headline: Sather Has Surgery to Treat Prostate Cancer
abstract: Jeff Gorton, the Rangers’ assistant general manager, will fill in for Glen Sather as the April 3 N.H.L. trade deadline approaches.
lead_paragraph: Glen Sather, the Rangers’ president and general manager, had surgery to treat prostate cancer on Thursday at Weill-Cornell Medical Center in New York and was expected to be off the job for a few days.

headline: Now Booking | Hotel de Nell in Paris
abstract: A forgotten corner of Paris’s Ninth Arrondissement is now home to one of the best big-city boutique hotels on the Continent.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, the interior designer Jean-Michel Wilmotte and the hotelier Lisa Konckier-Abrat have created an elegant and supremely handsome 33-room hotel that’s one of the best examples of big-city boutique lodgings on the Continent. Think luxe, calme et volupté.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Season of the Sputtering Starlet
abstract: Emilia Clarke in “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” is the latest example of a screen actress struggling to adapt to the stage.
lead_paragraph: The geese who fly east from Hollywood on an annual basis, looking for a little Broadway luster to boost their showbiz stock, aren’t laying as many golden eggs as they normally do this season. As Patrick Healy noted recently, the box office at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where Scarlett Johansson is starring in a revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” has not exactly been inundated since the show opened to middling reviews in January. Nor did Katie Holmes’s ballyhooed return to Broadway after a tumultuous few years as constant tabloid fodder do much for “Dead Accounts,” the Theresa Rebeck play that closed quickly in the fall after opening to sour reviews and sluggish ticket sales.

headline: She Makes Objects Speak, and They Won’t Stop Arguing
abstract: “As it were ... So to speak: A Museum Collection in Dialogue With Barbara Bloom,” at the Jewish Museum, uses objects and texts to create a spirited back and forth.
lead_paragraph: Entering Barbara Bloom’s show at the Jewish Museum you must pass between pairs of painted eyes that peer out from masklike apertures in the wall. As you stand before these veiled portraits you will also hear argumentative voices: recordings from “Annie Hall,” “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and other television and movie sources.

headline: States Vie to Conduct Commercial Drone Tests
abstract: Federal aviation officials plan to choose six sites where the commercial use of drone aircraft will be tested.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The state of Nevada recently joined the crowded bidding to be named a federal test site for the commercial use of pilotless aircraft under a program that will allow as many as six states to test the controversial but potentially lucrative technology for a five-year period.

headline: Bill on Crime Against Women Passes in India
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', "Women's Rights", 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Stalking (Crime)', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: The new law is intended to deter and punish sexual offenders, including men who stalk and harass women, and to make the police and prosecutors more responsive.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s Parliament passed a comprehensive bill on Thursday to impose stronger penalties on men who attack women and to criminalize offenses like stalking and voyeurism.

headline: Uplift From a Gloomy Gus
abstract: A cheerful Strindberg play? It’s true; his “Easter” is anything but depressing.
lead_paragraph: Abandon hope, all ye who enter a Strindberg play. That Swedish writer steeped his characters in desperation and contempt, and he wasn’t affable to his audience, either. “If my tragedy depresses many people, it is their own fault,” he wrote of his masterpiece, “Miss Julie.”

headline: Draped in Red, White and Blue
abstract: Some seem light and agile, somewhat restrained. Others are dominated by zingy American hop flavors.
lead_paragraph: SPRING CRIES OUT for a mellow brew, something to lift the spirit and reawaken the senses, buried so long under layers of winter protection.

headline: He’s the Man of Steel, as Well as a Man of Song
keywords: ['Theater', 'Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert (Series)', 'Superman (Fictional Character)']
abstract: The Encores! concert production of “It’s a Bird ... It’s a Plane ... It’s Superman” is given a pitch-perfect staging by John Rando at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Two-dimensional isn’t usually an adjective that any self-respecting musical would want attached to its name. But the show that opened at City Center on Wednesday night seems perfectly contented — no, make that downright delighted — to exist entirely on a flat surface. And therein lies the not-to-be-dismissed charms of the winning Encores! concert production of “It’s a Bird ... It’s a Plane ... It’s Superman,” which runs through Sunday.

headline: Biden Joins Mayor and Newtown Families to Push for Gun Limits
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in New York City, urged lawmakers to think about the Connecticut school shootings as they consider stricter firearm regulations.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. joined Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and some families of the victims in the Connecticut school shootings on Thursday to push for new federal gun laws, just days after Senate Democrats dropped an assault weapons ban from a gun-regulation package they plan to consider next month.

headline: Highlights From Obama’s Speech in Israel
abstract: President Obama outlined his case for a future Israel at peace with the Palestinians in Jerusalem on March 21, 2013.
lead_paragraph: To view the complete video of President Obama’s speech in Jerusalem on Thursday, click the play button. To jump to key passages, click on the time markers below.

headline: Looks Like ‘The Steven Tyler Act’ Is Sunk
abstract: A Hawaii bill to protect stars from paparazzi won’t become law.
lead_paragraph: We ran an editorial last month about a bill in the Hawaii Legislature to punish paparazzi for photographing celebrities like the rock god Steve Tyler, for whom the bill was named. (No joke: the sponsor, Senator Kalani English, is apparently a big Aerosmith fan who wanted to honor  “Steven Tyler’s contribution to the arts in Hawai‘i and throughout the world.”)

headline: Excerpt: 'Hands on a Hardbody'
abstract: A scene from the number "Joy" from the new Broadway musical at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the number "Joy" from the new Broadway musical at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

headline: David Murdock of Dole Food Opens California Estate for a Concours
abstract: The Ventura Farms Concours, held on the estate of the billionaire David Murdock, is envisioned as an annual fund-raiser.
lead_paragraph: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — David Murdock, 89, chairman of the Dole Food Company, opened his 2,200-acre estate here for the first Ventura Farms Concours last Sunday, inaugurating an annual event that will tie in with St. Patrick’s Day and jubilantly asserting California’s need for yet another fancy car show.

headline: A Morning and a Night and a Morning and a Night at the Opera
abstract: A video of what two days look like at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Mallon

headline: Fun Down Under in Brisbane
abstract: See culture, grab a cocktail and get a little crazy in this trip around Australia’s third-largest city.
lead_paragraph: See culture, grab a cocktail and get a little crazy in this trip around Australia’s third-largest city.

headline: 36 Hours in Brisbane, Australia
abstract: The warm and welcoming capital of Queensland, Australia’s Sunshine State, has lively bars, fine art and ... koalas.
lead_paragraph: With the Sunshine Coast to the north and the Gold Coast to the south, Brisbane has long been a natural waypoint for visitors seeking a slice of South Pacific paradise on Australia’s eastern shores. But the country’s third-largest city deserves to be a destination in its own right. Fans of fine art and live music will revel in the diversity of the city’s offerings, and nature lovers will delight in discovering the local wildlife sanctuary filled with arguably the cutest creatures on the planet — koalas. Some new bars and restaurants have recently introduced big-city sophistication to this subtropical metropolis, but you needn’t trade your flip-flops for formal footwear just yet. The warm and welcoming capital of Queensland, Australia’s Sunshine State, is still as casual and easygoing as ever.

headline: A Strange Bank Holiday
abstract: In Cyprus, the banks are closed. And the withdrawals are continuing. Who says logic is needed?
lead_paragraph: The bank holiday continues in Cyprus. Banks are closed.

headline: Pressured, Investment Firm Is Said to Skip Fees
abstract: Faced with weaker returns, some big investors have been pushing private equity firms to lower fees or make other concessions.
lead_paragraph: Score one for private equity investors.

headline: March Madness, the Other
abstract: The ESPN family of networks will be all over the other March Madness, World Cup qualifying soccer games on Friday, Saturday and Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: No, it is not the road to the Final Four. Will the final 32 (31 plus host Brazil) do instead?

headline: Show Puts Count Guglielmo Libri in an Unflattering Light
abstract: A new exhibition reveals negative aspects about Count Guglielmo Libri, a 19th-century aristocrat and art collector.
lead_paragraph: A COUNT WITH TASTE

headline: Why Am I Out of Shape?
abstract: If baby boomers are so fit, how come they’re so unfit?
lead_paragraph: “The first generation to grow up exercising.”

headline: A Monster With a Sweet Spot for Jazz
abstract: The Miles Davis Trumpet in-ear headphones by Monster may not give you the most sound quality for the dollar, but they have lovely aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: The Miles Davis Trumpet in-ear headphones by Monster may not give you the most sound quality for the dollar, but they are high on aesthetic value.

headline: ‘Painted on 21st Street’
abstract: A look at the new Helen Frankenthaler exhibition at Gagosian.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new Helen Frankenthaler exhibition at Gagosian.

headline: Yankees-StubHub Hearing Delayed Until April
abstract: A hearing in the dispute between the Yankees and StubHub over a store near Yankee Stadium will be held on April 16.
lead_paragraph: The battle between the Yankees and StubHub got a reprieve, sort of.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bezos Raises Moon Rockets, and False Face of the Drone
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include cybersecurity as a booming business for lobbyists, a woman says a man made sexist comments and they are both fired, and young wealth in the San Francisco Bay area.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Grapefruit League for Jeter Ends on Technicality
abstract: The Yankees will hold Derek Jeter out of any more major league spring training games, to keep their disabled list options open.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter’s availability for the Yankees’ season opener on April 1 is still a question mark. But General Manager Brian Cashman said with an exclamation point Thursday that Jeter would not see any more action in major league spring training games.

headline: In Space You Can Still Hear the Drones
abstract: “Oktophonie,” a composition by Karlheinz Stockhausen, is given the otherworldly treatment he had sought at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Karlheinz Stockhausen, the avant-garde German composer who died in 2007, is on a roll at, of all places, the Park Avenue Armory, a building dedicated in 1880 as the headquarters of New York’s Seventh Regiment, a volunteer outfit that catered to the city’s silk-stocking set.

headline: Ready in Case the Other Shoe Should Drop
abstract: In 30 years of serial monogamy, dodging in and out of serious relationships, I have always planned for the end from the beginning.
lead_paragraph: I pay $189 a month ($2,268 a year) for my Single Girl’s Starter Kit. My Single Girl’s Starter Kit is a storage facility I keep in Brooklyn. I recently moved in with my boyfriend of seven years. Giving up my low-rent apartment in Park Slope is as serious a commitment as I’ve ever made to any human being.

headline: The Corpse in the Bedroom
abstract: Many of the stories in this collection pursue the theme of infidelity.
lead_paragraph: First story collections, even good ones, tend to fall into two broad categories. On the one hand, there is the energetic but diffuse hodgepodge, the result, perhaps, of an eager mind fussing with the newly discovered tools of literary culture. Such books often contain a few terrific stories interspersed with failed experiments. On the other hand is the imitative, overly mannered matched set, wherein the author behaves like a traveler in a new country, trying to do as the natives do. Such a book may be skillfully made, but can feel staid or too careful.

headline: Treading Gingerly
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Parties (Social)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Addressing concerns about Easter egg hunts, the neighbors’ housekeeping skills, names of affection and pay raises.
lead_paragraph: My sister and I are Jewish, but our family never went to temple or celebrated religious holidays. Now we have children of our own (though we’re no more religious). Last year, my young son went to an Easter egg hunt and had an absolute blast. So, next weekend, I’m making one for him. When my sister found out, she excoriated me and told me I am “a bad Jew.” How should I proceed?

headline: Staking a Claim in South America
abstract: Developers and real estate investors are working to build residential housing and commercial spaces in Brazil, Uruguay and Colombia.
lead_paragraph: THE BUZZ IS LOUD these days about South Americans buying Miami and New York condos at a furious pace, helping to stoke high-end residential boomlets in those cities. But back home, their own real estate markets have started to lure investment from big-name American real estate companies.

headline: His Work Is the Cat’s Meow
abstract: Gregory Popovich, a lifelong circus performer, mainly finds his co-stars in his Popovich Comedy Pet Theater at animal shelters.
lead_paragraph: NOT up for the big top? Coinciding with Ringling’s run at Barclays Center in Brooklyn is something of a little top: the Popovich Comedy Pet Theater, which is playing two shows at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center in Manhattan March 30 (tribecapac.org).

headline: Justin Timberlake Keeps it Retro
abstract: Timberlake’s latest album delivers its artistry through its familiarity.
lead_paragraph: In pop music, hindsight is the key to relevance. There is the Warholian logic to the iTunes chart: the artist who appropriates a particular time period with the most cunning and skill feels the freshest. The Los Angeles-based musical duo Rhye have received critical acclaim recently for evoking the early-‘80s-era “quiet storm” of Sade. Azealia Banks channels the 1990s with her best Crystal Waters imitation with about the same success as Lady Gaga’s echoing of Blond Ambition-era Madonna. (Remember that?) The moody atmosphere of Drake’s oeuvre picks up the pieces that Aaliyah left behind in 2001. And the dance-pop white noise that inhabits the radio today is, of course, a rehash of the Euro-pop and rave culture of yesteryear that Daft Punk helped foster. The French D.J. duo, who recently signed to Columbia and have a new album coming out in time for summer, are said to be working with the funk legend Niles Rodgers for their anticipated new release, situating themselves comfortably in the 1970s disco revival moment that has become a staple of underground night-life culture in Paris, London and New York.

headline: Tribute to a Drummer Who Moved Jazz On
abstract: A concert at Symphony Space on Friday organized by the saxophonist Joe Lovano and the guitarist Bill Frisell will celebrate the influence of their former band mate, the drummer Paul Motian.
lead_paragraph: “We are going to play one more song,” Reid Anderson, the bassist in the Bad Plus, told an overflow crowd in a large tent at the most recent Newport Jazz Festival. “It’s another Paul Motian song, because we love Paul so much, and his music means so much to us.” This statement met with a rumble of approval — a lot of “yeahs” punctuated the applause — as the band, joined for the occasion by the guitarist Bill Frisell, ventured on.

headline: Larceny for the Sake of Art
abstract: Two Bronx graffiti artists go on a daylong quest to finance an ambitious project: the tagging of a big plastic apple at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: “Gimme the Loot,” Adam Leon’s loose and rambunctious debut feature, tells the tale of two young artists scrambling to kick-start an ambitious project. Or, if you prefer, it follows a pair of vandals through a day of improvised criminality. Really, though, it’s both: a celebration of outlaw creativity and entrepreneurial gumption.

headline: A Rendezvous With 1,000 Rooms
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Grand Central Terminal (NYC)']
abstract: The long-gone Biltmore Hotel was the linchpin of Terminal City, now the focus of redevelopment.
lead_paragraph: Whether you think of them as quotidian, or “soaring masonry facades enlivened by decorative details,” as does the New York Landmarks Conservancy, the network of 1910s and 1920s buildings erected over Grand Central’s sunken railroad yards was a remarkable development, unlike anything ever done in New York.

headline: Pipes of Size and Salty Sentiments
abstract: Bridget Everett, whose original songs often concern lust and body parts, is a spirited provocateur with a powerful voice.
lead_paragraph: Multiply the mouthy, flesh-jiggling early Bette Midler by one hundred, give her the super-plus-size figure and fashion sense of Divine, the John Waters diva, and the manners of a Flintstone, and you’ve got a rough approximation of Bridget Everett, the alt-cabaret star who roared around the stage of Joe’s Pub on Wednesday evening.

headline: For Luck, Iona Coaches Decide to Sweat It
abstract: Since Iona’s coaches started wearing sweatsuits for games on March 1, the Gaels have not lost. They will be wearing them again Friday for the game against Ohio State.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — Three weeks ago, before what was then Iona’s biggest game of the season, Coach Tim Cluess asked his staff what they thought about dressing down a little on the sidelines. The idea was to raise awareness for the efforts of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, seeking a cure for the chronic lung disease that afflicts the nephew of two prominent Iona alums.

headline: Loans for a Niche Market
abstract: A staple of the jumbo market, interest-only loans are used mainly by affluent borrowers to help manage irregular cash flow or free up cash for other investments.
lead_paragraph: If interest-only loans were issued too freely before the foreclosure crisis, their availability now is restricted to a privileged few.

headline: He’s Weary, but Psyched to Save Democracy
abstract: In the “Die Hard” tradition, the lead character in “Olympus Has Fallen” is a world-weary professional battling evil amid pyrotechnics.
lead_paragraph: The most recent “Die Hard” movie — which the record shows I reviewed a little more than a month ago, although I have no recollection of it — was terrible, but it turns out not to have been the worst “Die Hard” movie this year. That honor, for the moment at least (it’s only March!), belongs to “Olympus Has Fallen,” which is not, strictly speaking, part of the franchise at all. It is more a “school of Die Hard” production, in which a weary and battered law enforcement professional, severely constrained by time and space, fights off a ridiculous number of bad guys.

abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and other comedic performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Comedy

headline: U.N. Panel to Investigate Human Rights Abuses in North Korea
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The 47-member Human Rights Council was unanimous in adopting a resolution to create a commission to investigate reports of food deprivation, labor camps and torture.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The United Nations Human Rights Council voted on Thursday in Geneva to create a three-person commission to look into allegations of human rights violations in North Korea, including food deprivation, labor camps for political prisoners and torture.

abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Movies

headline: Jumbo Homecoming
abstract: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has begun a 23-show run in Brooklyn, returning to a borough that was once a regular stop for its clowns and elephants.
lead_paragraph: FOR decades the ritual blooming of circus cotton candy each March has been a sure sign of spring for winter-weary New Yorkers.

headline: Gone Gone Gone (Woah Oh Oh)
abstract: Al Pacino and Helen Mirren star in the HBO movie “Phil Spector,” about the pop-music impresario and the defense lawyer representing him in the murder of an actress.
lead_paragraph: Lana Clarkson is not a familiar figure anymore, but when she was found dead — shot through the mouth — in the California mansion of the pop-music impresario Phil Spector in 2003 that actress turned nightclub hostess finally won the moment of fame that had eluded her for so long.
