headline: Designing ‘The Croods’
abstract: A look at some of the designs from “The Croods,” with commentary by its production designer Christophe Lautrette.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the designs from “The Croods,” with commentary by its production designer Christophe Lautrette.

headline: There’s Something About That Boy
abstract: “The Croods” is an animated comedy about a Stone Age family, starring the voice of Emma Stone.
lead_paragraph: “The Croods” makes a better study of Stone Age sociology than it does a children’s movie. But it’s colorful and has an appealing central character and — who knows? — might even give the little ones something more challenging to think about than its tired main plot.

headline: Music for a Season of Solemnity and Joy
abstract: A selection of seasonal musical performances at churches and museums in New York, featuring composers of many eras.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted otherwise, church choirs are featured in church concerts.) An expanded listing is available at nytimes.com.

headline: A Young Colorist, Antennas Aquiver
abstract: “Painted on 21st Street: Helen Frankenthaler From 1950 to 1959,”at the Gagosian Gallery, offers a revelatory look at a period in which the artist achieved a fusion of color and canvas.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 26, 1952, a 23-year-old artist named Helen Frankenthaler made a painting on unstretched, unprimed canvas laid on the floor, using a freehand stain technique that owed a great deal to Jackson Pollock but was less systematic. She called it “Mountains and Sea,” and it became her best-known, most influential work. Its bounding scale, skirmish of pastel colors and charcoal lines, and mixture of landscape, still life and abstraction were distinctive. But most important was the way it fused color and canvas into a new, streamlined unity. Frankenthaler’s stain painting method, as it was sometimes called, was considered a breakthrough in many circles, the gateway to what would become Color Field abstraction.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for March 22-28
abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in New York.
lead_paragraph: Classical

headline: As Pollution Worsens in China, Solutions Succumb to Infighting
abstract: Even as top officials admit the severity of China’s environmental woes, conflict within the government is one of the biggest obstacles to enacting stronger policies.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop. More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai. A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital, causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City.

abstract: LPL Financial has grown in recent years to become one of the largest retail brokerage companies in the country, but the firm has run afoul of regulators unusually often.
lead_paragraph: LPL Financial has grown in recent years to become one of the largest retail brokerage companies in the country, but the firm has run afoul of regulators unusually often.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Myanmar, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Myanmar, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Israel.

headline: Money Requested for New Prison at Guantánamo
abstract: The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million to build a new prison building for “special” detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on top of other renovations it says are necessary since Congress has decided to keep it open indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million to build a new prison building at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for “special” detainees on top of other renovations it says are necessary since Congress has decided to keep it open indefinitely. That brings the potential taxpayer bill for upgrading the deteriorating facilities to an estimated $195.7 million, the military said on Thursday.

headline: The Circus Comes to Brooklyn
abstract: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has a new show at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has a new show at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Colorado Approves Same-Sex Unions
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Although the new law fell short of providing full marriage rights, it nonetheless signified a changing attitude in the state that outlawed gay marriage in 2006.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — With a stroke of the governor’s pen, Colorado on Thursday legalized civil unions for same-sex couples, a major shift for a Western state where voters outlawed same-sex marriages in 2006.

abstract: A guide to cultural events in New York for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘SHADOW PLAY’

headline: Gun Bill Will Be Taken Up After Senate Recess
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Procedural motions began on a bill that seeks to enhance background checks for gun buyers, and to curb gun trafficking and increase money for school safety.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The Senate plans to begin debating a package of gun regulations next month when it returns from its Easter recess, said Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader. Mr. Reid began procedural motions late Thursday on a bill that seeks to enhance background checks for those who purchase guns, and to curb gun trafficking and increase money for school safety.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Mud, Sweat and Tears Pottery
abstract: The studio’s longtime home is a place you could spend a few hours, or while away the decades and watch Hell’s Kitchen become Clinton.
lead_paragraph: The studio’s longtime home is a place you could spend a few hours, or while away the decades and watch Hell’s Kitchen become Clinton.

headline: Spare Times Listings for March 22-28
abstract: A listing of walking tours, cultural events and more in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: The Dark Side of the Expat Life
abstract: An American reader living overseas writes: “I’ve watched as peers back home have married, had children, bought houses, advanced in their careers.” He, meanwhile, finds himself living a Peter Pan-like existence, neither here nor there. Have you left your native country, for work or study? Do you plan to return? What have you valued about being abroad? What do you miss?
lead_paragraph: If you are a member of Rendezvous’s  global tribe, “home” might be where your apartment, your work or your belongings — or even your family and friends — are. But it might also be a place where language and culture are confounding. And deep down, despite the thrills and invigorating challenges of an experience abroad, more often than not, we know it’s not a place we’ll stay forever.

headline: Seeing the World From Different Angles
abstract: Books of abstract art by Jay DeFeo, Per Kirkeby, Hassel Smith and Nico Luoma and from the “Destroy the Picture” exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Books of abstract art by Jay DeFeo, Per Kirkeby, Hassel Smith and Nico Luoma and from the “Destroy the Picture” exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago.

headline: I.B.M. Research Points to Circuits That Mimic the Brain’s Design
abstract: Researchers at the computer giant said Thursday that they had developed a fluidic electronic system that mimics the way the brain works.
lead_paragraph: I.B.M. scientists said Thursday that they had developed a fluidic electronic system that mimics the circuits in the human brain and potentially offers a new direction for ultra-low-power microelectronics and artificial intelligence.

headline: Finding Beauty in Decay and Math
abstract: Books of abstract art by Jay DeFeo, Per Kirkeby, Hassel Smith and Nico Luoma and from the “Destroy the Picture” exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago.
lead_paragraph: As I studied these five books of abstract art they made me think about a factory where I once worked that cleaned 55-gallon steel drums of oils, paints, solvents and more. One of the things I remember from those days in the 1970s is how beautiful some of the drum covers became on their industrial journey.

headline: Pacino’s Portrayals
abstract: Al Pacino is playing the eccentric title character in the HBO film “Phil Spector,” one of several in which the actor has embodied a real-life figure.
lead_paragraph: Al Pacino is playing the eccentric title character in the HBO film “Phil Spector,” one of several in which the actor has embodied a real-life figure.

headline: Defiant Souls and Hopeful Sounds of the ’60s
abstract: “The Sapphires” chronicles a female quartet of Aboriginal singers on the way to stardom in the 1960s and the obstacles they face.
lead_paragraph: “The Sapphires” tells the story of an all-female singing quartet on the way to stardom in the 1960s. As is usual in such tales, the group, known as the Cummeragunja Songbirds before their gemological rechristening, faces its share of obstacles, but in spite of internal disharmony and tough circumstances, the singers’ voices rarely falter.

headline: Andy Cohen’s West Village Home
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Pop culture artifacts fill the apartment of Andy Cohen, host of “Watch What Happens Live.”
lead_paragraph: Pop culture artifacts fill the apartment of Andy Cohen, host of “Watch What Happens Live.”

headline: Here’s What Happens
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Andy Cohen, the host of Bravo’s “Watch What Happens Live,” is at home in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: Five nights a week on Bravo, Andy Cohen hosts the highly rated late-night talk show “Watch What Happens Live” in a studio filled with knickknacks and tokens of pop trivia. He sits in one of a set of Danish modern chairs that swivel and lean back; he sips from a highly toxic blend of Fresca and tequila, and shoots the breeze with celebrities ranging from LaToya Jackson to Meryl Streep.

headline: O.K., Class, Let’s Rock to Shakespeare
abstract: In “Hunky Dory,” a drama teacher persuades her pupils to stage a rock opera based on “The Tempest.”
lead_paragraph: The British punk-rock explosion was only months from detonation in the early summer of 1976, the time of Marc Evans’s high school musical, “Hunky Dory.” This sun-bleached, candy-colored movie is set in southern Wales, where Vivienne Mae (Minnie Driver), a passionate, feisty drama teacher, mobilizes her apathetic students to stage a rock opera based on Shakespeare’s “Tempest” in the final weeks of the school year. The score will consist of existing rock songs.

headline: Progress Is Reported in Arms Talks With Russia
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Renewed cooperation may be under way just days after the United States canceled part of a Europe-based missile defense program that had infuriated the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian and American officials on Thursday reported progress in discussions about nuclear weapons reductions, in a sign that renewed cooperation may be under way just days after the United States canceled part of a Europe-based missile defense program that had infuriated the Kremlin.

headline: Police Wound Armed Suspect in Brooklyn
abstract: The police said that the man did not appear likely to die, and that they had recovered his firearm.
lead_paragraph: Two plainclothes officers shot and wounded an armed suspect on Thursday on a Brooklyn street after he pulled a gun and fired at them, the police said.

headline: Cheaper by the Gross
abstract: A sperm donor, played by Patrick Huard, gets in touch with his paternal side years later in “Starbuck,” directed by Ken Scott.
lead_paragraph: “I’m just a meat delivery guy and a terrible one at that,” declares David Wozniak (Patrick Huard), a lovable oaf in “Starbuck,” Ken Scott’s sloppy, feel-good French Canadian comedy. David, who is 42 and works in his father’s butcher shop, has one claim to fame, should he ever decide to shed his anonymity.

headline: Drone Cameras May Be High Worry, but They’re Not High Tech
abstract: A hearing Wednesday focused on privacy concerns related to drones, which create new issues because they are small and unobtrusive, and the technology they carry can be quite basic.
lead_paragraph: The contrast between fast-moving technology and slow-moving laws was on full display on Wednesday at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on domestic use of drones. The issue was not arming them, because the Federal Aviation Administration bans weaponizing civil aircraft. (Several senators asked about drones outfitted with weapons, though, including nonlethal options like tear gas or stun grenades.)

headline: A Strange Computer Promises Great Speed
abstract: Lockheed Martin will make commercial use of quantum computing, which could solve some business and science problems millions of times faster than can be done today.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Our digital age is all about bits, those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code.

headline: France: Sarkozy Faces Investigation
abstract: At issue is whether Former President Nicolas Sarkozy abused the frailty of Liliane Bettencourt, 90, the heiress to the L’Oréal fortune and France’s richest woman, to raise funds for his 2007 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was informed Thursday that he would face a formal investigation into whether he abused the frailty of Liliane Bettencourt, 90, the heiress to the L’Oréal fortune and France’s richest woman, to get funds for his 2007 presidential campaign. Mr. Sarkozy has denied accepting illegal campaign funds from Ms. Bettencourt, either personally or through his party treasurer at the time, Éric Woerth, as alleged by her former butler. Mr. Sarkozy’s lawyer, Thierry Herzog, called the judge’s decision, which indicates that the judge believes that Mr. Sarkozy probably committed a crime, “incoherent” and “unjust.” The lawyer said he would appeal. The ruling does not necessarily mean that Mr. Sarkozy, who lost his re-election bid last May and with it his presidential immunity from prosecution, will stand trial.

headline: Notre Dame Sits and Waits
abstract: Notre Dame will play the last game in the tournament’s second round. Until then, there’s nothing to do but wait.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — Notre Dame arrived here Wednesday night and practiced early Thursday evening, just as the action in the N.C.A.A. tournament was getting good. During team stretches in their locker room, they had the television set tuned to the final moments of the St. Mary’s-Memphis game, and they stole more than a few glances at it.

headline: Where Dirty Hands Act as Therapy
abstract: Many of the potters at the Mud, Sweat and Tears Pottery studio in Clinton work in demanding professions, and the pottery seems to play a therapeutic role.
lead_paragraph: A corner storefront glows warmly on a winter night. Inside, a stool and a friendly proprietor beckon. This is a place where you could spend a few hours, or wile away the decades, watch Hell’s Kitchen become Clinton.

headline: Egyptian Activists Defend ‘Riots’ Against an Unreformed Police Force
abstract: In their latest video, the activists of Cairo’s Mosireen film collective argue that violent resistance to an unreformed police force is not only justified, but also necessary.
lead_paragraph: In their latest video, “Why Riot?,” the activists of Cairo’s Mosireen film collective argue that violent resistance to an unreformed police force is not only justified, but also necessary. They write, by way of introduction to the film: “Two years after the start of the January 25 revolution we still riot because the ruling elite still exploit us, because the police still torture, maim and kill us and none of them are brought to justice.”

headline: Rainbow Becomes a Prism to View Gay Rights
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Art', 'Vandalism', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A 30-foot-tall rainbow sculpture in downtown Warsaw has been set on fire four times since June, with opponents outraged at what they say is its pro-gay-rights message.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The 30-foot-tall rainbow sculpture in downtown Savior Square here is looking somewhat the worse for wear these days, half covered in patches of artificial flowers and half bare from being set on fire. What was intended as a work of public art without an overt political message beyond the need for inclusiveness, according to the artist behind it, has instead become part of a culture war over homosexuality that has been brewing in one of Europe’s most Catholic countries.

headline: Marketing Deal Gives a Small Town an Identity Crisis
abstract: Dish, Tex., got its name as part of a deal with the Dish Network satellite TV service. But the town is not exactly TV land, and the arrangement did not turn the place into a household name.
lead_paragraph: DISH, Tex. — In this rural North Texas town, it is no coincidence that residents of Dish watch Dish.

headline: Mets Make It Official: Wright Is Their Captain
abstract: David Wright is the franchise’s fourth captain, and its first since reliever John Franco.
lead_paragraph: David Wright has long been seen as the de facto leader of the Mets. He began his professional career as a member the organization, rose to stardom playing third base for the club and is the longest-tenured player on the current roster.

headline: Maurice Barbash, Who Saved Fire Island’s Terrain, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Barbash maintained the character of the landscape in his designs and took on a nuclear power company and Robert Moses to block projects that would have altered Long Island’s environment.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Barbash, a homebuilder and environmental activist who was instrumental in blocking two giant projects that threatened to radically alter Long Island’s environment — a $6 billion nuclear power plant near completion on the North Shore, and a four-lane highway that Robert Moses proposed building along the spine of Fire Island — died on March 13 in Bay Shore, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Niese Will Pitch the Mets’ Opener
abstract: Jon Niese will fill in for Johan Santana, whose shoulder fatigue has kept him from pitching in spring training.
lead_paragraph: Jon Niese will start the Mets’ season opener against the San Diego Padres on April 1. The role was handed to Johan Santana at the start of camp, but Santana has not pitched a single game during spring training because of shoulder fatigue.

headline: A Free Spirit and the Sculptor She Raised
abstract: “Leonie,” a biopic, stars Emily Mortimer in the story of Isamu Noguchi’s mother.
lead_paragraph: Who is Leonie Gilmour and why does she rank her own biopic? For the writers of “Leonie,” Hisako Matsui (who also directed) and David Wiener, the short answer is that she’s the mother of the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. And the long answer is this plodding film.Leonie (Emily Mortimer, who against all odds creates a credible character) meets and falls in love with a Japanese poet, Yone Noguchi, who is living in New York. She becomes his editor, lover and the mother of his child. For some reason — motivations in “Leonie” are either murky or too neatly explained — he dumps her when she’s pregnant and moves back to Japan. She joins him there, but their relationship is over, and she strikes out on her own.

headline: Jerry West Roots for the Heat, but Not Too Hard
abstract: Jerry West, a member of the Lakers team that holds the N.B.A. record for consecutive victories, said the Heat’s 24-game winning streak is good for the league.
lead_paragraph: Jerry West watched the Miami Heat’s incredible comeback Wednesday night, watched them obliterate a 27-point deficit, watched them take another step toward history — West’s history — and marveled at the sight.

headline: Europe Weighs iPhone Sale Deals With Carriers for Antitrust Abuse
abstract: Some wireless carriers contend Apple’s strict contracts are putting other cellphone makers at a disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators are examining the contracts Apple strikes with cellphone carriers that sell its iPhone for possible antitrust violations after several carriers complained that the deals throttled competition.

headline: Learning From the Gardner Art Theft
abstract: Twenty-three years may seem like an inordinate amount of time to solve a burglary, but museums and the investigation have come a long way since the 1990 theft.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, the F.B.I. announced that it had identified the two men who robbed the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston in March 1990, in the biggest art theft in American history. The F.B.I. said the criminals, whom it did not identify, had most likely moved their loot to Connecticut or the Philadelphia area.

headline: For Sri Lanka, More Empty Words
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: For too long, the Sri Lankan government has turned a blind eye to its human rights abuses. United Nations resolutions — without tough action — won’t get it to change.
lead_paragraph: New Delhi

headline: Obama’s Nixonian Precedent
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Vietnam War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Targeted Killings']
abstract: The bombing of Cambodia in the Vietnam War era can’t be used to justify today’s drone attacks.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta

headline: Blackstone Studying Dell, but Decision Is Uncertain
abstract: The private equity firm Blackstone has only hours left to decide if it will make a bid for Dell.
lead_paragraph: The private equity giant Blackstone Group is weighing whether to make an offer for all or part of Dell as a Friday deadline looms, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

headline: Recall Is Expensive Setback for Maker of Yoga Pants
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Yoga']
abstract: As Lululemon counted its expected losses from a recall of pants that turned out to be too sheer, rivals hoped to capitalize on the mistake.
lead_paragraph: Even novice shoppers know to wiggle around in a pair of pants before you buy them. But that was a lesson that Lululemon Athletica overlooked when it stocked too-sheer yoga pants, leading to a product recall, an expected hit of around $60 million in lost sales, and the risk that Lululemon — a widely envied retailer — has at last given competitors an opening.

headline: From Scaling Windmills to Literary Editor
abstract: Excerpts from “The Selected Letters of Willa Cather,” edited by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout.
lead_paragraph: Excerpted from “The Selected Letters of Willa Cather” edited by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout. Copyright 2013 by Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout. Excerpted by permission of Knopf, a division of Random House. All rights reserved.

headline: Experimental Marketing
abstract: In 2005, the rural town Clark, Tex., agreed to change its name to Dish as part of a deal with the Dish Network satellite TV service.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, the rural town Clark, Tex., agreed to change its name to Dish as part of a deal with the Dish Network satellite TV service.

headline: The Dark and Light of East London
abstract: “My Brother the Devil” is the first feature directed by Sally El Hosaini, a Welsh-Egyptian filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Death is always hovering just out of sight in “My Brother the Devil,” but there’s nothing deadening about this engaging first feature from the Welsh-Egyptian filmmaker Sally El Hosaini.

headline: To Live and Decorate in L.A.
abstract: “Dorfman in Love,” directed by Bradley Leong, features Sara Rue in the title role.
lead_paragraph: Deb Dorfman (Sara Rue of the sitcom “Malibu Country”), 27 and single in Los Angeles, has had it with serving people. Among those placing demands are her widowed, irascible father, Burt (Elliott Gould), with whom she lives in the San Fernando Valley; her unhappily married brother, Daniel (Jonathan Chase), who employs her; and her hunky Web journalist friend Jay (Johann Urb), whom she secretly pines for and whose loft she has volunteered to house-sit and decorate while he’s away for a week. But no one is taking care of her.

headline: Amid Criticism, U.S. Coach Focuses on World Cup Qualifying Match
abstract: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann has remained focused on the United States playing Costa Rica on Friday despite questions about team chemistry.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The schedule leading up to an in-season international soccer match almost always feels quick.

headline: A War, Before and After, Part 6
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: The last installment of the series by Iraq veterans, 10 years after the start of the war.
lead_paragraph: This is the final installment of the six-part series.

headline: Burgers, Fries and Lies
keywords: ['Fast Food Industry', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: There’s nothing wrong with asking businesses to pay for a small part of the problem they helped create.
lead_paragraph: The old adage — what will not kill you makes you only stronger — certainly doesn’t apply to a bacon cheeseburger from Five Guys Burgers and Fries. This tasty gut bomb delivers two days’ worth of saturated fat and nearly 1,000 calories, a la carte. I hacked my way through one of these heart-stoppers the other day, and though I still have a pulse, it stayed with me in ways that would not please any doctor.

headline: When Friends Collide
abstract: Oklahoma’s Lon Kruger and San Diego State’s Steve Fisher are good friends, but one of them is going to lose on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma’s Lon Kruger and San Diego State’s Steve Fisher consider themselves good friends, so both men said it would difficult to coach against each other Friday at Wells Fargo Center.

headline: His Arms Raise Up Him and His Audience
abstract: “You Don’t Need Feet to Dance” is a documentary that looks at Sidiki Conde, a Guinean-born drummer and dancer disabled by polio.
lead_paragraph: Unlike some nonfiction tales of grace under adversity, “You Don’t Need Feet to Dance” leaves in the mundane obstacles rather than skipping to reassuring triumph. Low-key to a fault, Alan Govenar’s vérité documentary joins the Guinean-born drummer and dancer Sidiki Conde on his daily rounds and observes the added labor and gumption required of a working artist who cannot walk or stand.

headline: Attempt to Win Hearts Is Tempered by a Challenge to Wary Israelis
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'United States International Relations', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians']
abstract: President Obama has captured the hearts of many Israelis over the past two days, but he warned on Thursday that Israel’s future as a Jewish and democratic state was at risk.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With Hebrew phrases, testaments to Israel’s ancient roots, expressions of deep admiration and displays of empathy, President Obama has captured the hearts of many here over the past two days, appearing to erase years of skepticism and wariness overnight.

headline: Recording Points to Race Factor in Stops by New York Police
abstract: A recording played in a lawsuit over millions of stop-and-frisk encounters suggested that, in at least one Bronx precinct, skin color can be a deciding factor in who is stopped.
lead_paragraph: For years, the debate over the New York Police Department’s use of stop-and-frisk tactics has centered on whether officers engage in racial profiling. Now, a recording suggests that, in at least one precinct, a person’s skin color can be a deciding factor in who is stopped.

headline: In South Korea, Gangsters in Good Suits
abstract: “New World,” directed by Park Hoon-jung, is a gangster story set in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Any film that opens with a snitch being force-fed a cement smoothie deserves some latitude to make its case, and the South Korean crime drama “New World” is no exception. Set in the scheming heart of a powerful crime syndicate, this stylish saga from Park Hoon-jung conjures a world where hardly anyone is who he seems.

headline: ‘I Speak to You as a Friend ...’
abstract: President Obama’s speech in Israel was a rhetorical success. But now what?
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, President Obama used his Middle East trip to reach out to the Arab world and try to build a new basis for regional understanding to replace the Bush administration’s post-Sept. 11 policies of fear and vengeance. Mr. Obama failed; skipping Israel and pursuing a poorly conceived peace initiative backfired.

headline: Change of Heart for Vietnam War Buddies
abstract: In “Love and Honor,” a drama set in the Vietnam War era, two soldiers go AWOL to win the hearts of teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: Danny Mooney’s “Love and Honor” is for anyone who thought “Taking Woodstock” was too hard-core. Set during the Vietnam War, this trifle about two soldiers who sneak away to America while on leave unfolds in a world about as realistic as a flashback on a sitcom. The film dresses up pretty young things in fatigues and retro T-shirts for a story so clichéd and brainless that it’s almost more disturbing than laughable.

headline: Apocalypse Fed
abstract: “Silver Circle,” directed by Pasha Roberts, is set in a post-apocalyptic world brought on by the Federal Reserve’s monetary policies.
lead_paragraph: The animated “Silver Circle” is set in a dystopian Washington in 2019, when the Federal Reserve Police, in riot gear, are forcibly seizing houses from homeowners when they refuse to sell them to the government. At the same time, inflation runs amok, and working-class people turn to an underground economy, using silver for money. Society’s ills, you see, stem from all that paper money circulating.

headline: North Carolina Overreaches
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Supreme Court correctly slapped down a law that could squeeze far more money from beneficiaries than they actually owe.
lead_paragraph: Under the federal Medicaid statute, states must seek reimbursement for medical expenses if the beneficiary also receives money from an insurance company or another third party. This week, the Supreme Court correctly slapped down a North Carolina law that could squeeze far more from beneficiaries than they actually owe.

headline: The Farm From Afar
abstract: Is it spring if you’re not there to feel it?
lead_paragraph: Last week I got an e-mail from one of the two young farmers living at my small farm in upstate New York while I’m teaching in Southern California for the semester. She mentioned “green spears” shooting out of the ground. The thought threw me into a vernal prolepsis, a mental flash-forward to spring, for which there must be a German word or a Chinese poem.

headline: Alone in an Island of Creepy Kids
abstract: “Come Out and Play” is the Belarussian director Makinov’s debut feature about feral children on an island.
lead_paragraph: “We have to run now!” are five words no heavily pregnant woman ever wants to hear, though when the alternative is being beaten to a bloody pulp by a gang of feral children, a cumbersome belly seems the least of your problems.

headline: Treasure Island Trauma
keywords: ['Tax Shelters', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: From the way things are going with Cyprus, you’d think the financial crisis didn’t teach our leaders anything.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, the journalist Nicholas Shaxson published a fascinating, chilling book titled “Treasure Islands,” which explained how international tax havens — which are also, as the author pointed out, “secrecy jurisdictions” where many rules don’t apply — undermine economies around the world. Not only do they bleed revenues from cash-strapped governments and enable corruption; they distort the flow of capital, helping to feed ever-bigger financial crises.

headline: Pac-12, a Dismissed Conference, Does Some Dismissing of Its Own
abstract: Handed No. 12 seeds, but sent to the same site to open the N.C.A.A. tournament, Oregon and California provided back-to-back upsets of fifth-seeded opponents to lift the Pacific-12 Conference’s reputation.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — First Oregon, then California. Just like that, men’s basketball in the Pacific-12 Conference does not seem so measly after all.

headline: Fast-Growing Brokerage Firm Often Tangles With Regulators
abstract: The low-cost model that has aided LPL Financial’s explosive growth has brought with it a host of shortcomings, authorities and analysts say.
lead_paragraph: The firm sounds like an upstart Merrill Lynch, the investment house that brought Wall Street to Main Street.

headline: After the ‘London Whale’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: We will soon find out whether JPMorgan’s trading fiasco will change anything.
lead_paragraph: For all the questions that were answered by the Senate inquiry into JPMorgan Chase’s $6.2 billion “London Whale” trading loss, one big question remains: What happens now?

headline: The Man Behind the Doctor’s Mask
abstract: Viggo Mortensen plays a pediatrician in Buenos Aires who decides to start a new life by assuming the identity of his twin.
lead_paragraph: The title of Ana Piterbarg’s moody not-quite-a-thriller “Everybody Has a Plan” doesn’t apply to its protagonist, Agustín (Viggo Mortensen). He has an acute, unmooring malaise that has left him almost blank. A pediatrician in Buenos Aires, he drops out of his life and holes up in his study, growing a beard and growing strange.

headline: Posthumous Salute to a SEAL Team Leader
abstract: “Murph: The Protector” is a documentary about Lt. Michael P. Murphy, the SEAL team leader awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously in 2007.
lead_paragraph: For the American military June 28, 2005, was a very bad day. A four-man Navy SEAL reconnaissance team in the Hindu Kush region of Afghanistan had been caught in a mountainside firefight with overwhelming Taliban forces, and the Special Operations helicopter sent to extract them was shot down. The 16 men aboard died, as did 3 of the 4 team members on the ground. (The one who lived, Marcus Luttrell, wrote a best-selling account, “Lone Survivor”; the major-motion-picture version, starring Mark Wahlberg, is scheduled for release next fall.)

headline: Hallmark Joins Cable Networks’ Rush to Original Series
abstract: Two channels owned by Crown Media Family Networks will accelerate a push to add original programming for the 2013-14 season.
lead_paragraph: EFFORTS to significantly increase the amount of original programming on the Crown Media Family Networks’ two cable channels are already paying off with advertisers and viewers, senior executives of Crown Media said on Thursday.

headline: Forecasting Fox
abstract: One man unveils a strategy for better forecasting.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, Philip E. Tetlock published a landmark book called “Expert Political Judgment.” While his findings obviously don’t apply to me, Tetlock demonstrated that pundits and experts are terrible at making predictions.

headline: The Power of the Prenup
abstract: Should everyone have a prenuptial agreement? Do they really mean anything?

headline: Taxing the Rich
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks about a budget proposed by progressives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Does Shame Have a Place in Society?
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article about a New York City advertising campaign to combat teenage pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For-Profit Online College
abstract: The University of Phoenix responds to an article in the Continuing Education special section.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Influence of Small States
abstract: A history professor responds to a front-page article, “Smaller States Find Outsize Clout Growing in Senate.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Church and the Poor
abstract: A Johns Hopkins professor of population studies responds to two news articles.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Baseball Said to Be Suing People Linked to Florida Clinic
abstract: A suit says people tied to an anti-aging clinic hurt the sport by supplying drugs. It could also provide a way for Major League Baseball to pursue suspected dopers who haven’t tested positive.
lead_paragraph: Limited by their inability to compel people to cooperate with their investigators, Major League Baseball officials will open a new front in their battle against doping. They plan to file a lawsuit on Friday against a number of people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic, alleging that the individuals damaged the sport by providing some of the game’s biggest stars with performance-enhancing drugs, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Out of One Gram of Marijuana, a ‘Manufactured Misdemeanor’
abstract: Arrests based on the open display of marijuana are a tumorous outgrowth of the stop-and-frisk practices and are now broadly recognized as scandalous. Yet they remain out of control.
lead_paragraph: For marijuana smokers in the right neighborhoods, there is no need to go out for supplies. A dealer-businessman will come right to the door, sit at the dining room table and open a box that looks as if it could be used to display herbal tea choices in restaurants. This particular case, however, is used to show varieties of cannabis — weed — and the businessman will annotate the flavor and potency of his offerings. Bought and smoked behind closed doors, the pot in such transactions has almost no risk of attracting attention from law enforcement.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 21, 2013

headline: Suspect in Colorado Killing Is Shot in Texas
abstract: An unidentified man who was suspected of being connected to the killing of Colorado’s prison director was wounded after trying to elude law enforcement officials near Dallas.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A paroled Colorado inmate grievously wounded after a gun battle and high-speed chase with Texas law-enforcement officers on Thursday is suspected of being tied to the killing of the head of Colorado’s prison system.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Mar. 22, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Mar. 22, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “We reached the point where weapons should go silent and ideas speak.”

headline: The Cactus Commute
abstract: Cars on the New York City subway have been painted with saloon doors, wagon wheels and cactus plants as part of an advertising campaign to tempt sun-deprived New Yorkers into visiting Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Cars on the New York City subway have been painted with saloon doors, wagon wheels and cactus plants as part of an advertising campaign to tempt sun-deprived New Yorkers into visiting Arizona.

headline: Hockey Gear Is the Focus of a Tariff Cut in Canada
abstract: The cut was meant to match the prices of American online retailers, but has highlighted a source of embarrassment: that most hockey gear is made in China.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Take a walk down an aisle at Pro Hockey Life, an emporium of the Canadian national sport here on the capital’s southern fringe, and a customer comes away with a decidedly non-Canadian feel. Almost every pad, mask, stick and skate is made elsewhere — mostly in Asia, often by foreign-owned manufacturers.

headline: Officials Concede Failures on Gauging Border Security
abstract: Lawmakers warned that failure by the Obama administration to devise a reliable way to evaluate overall border security could imperil passage of immigration legislation.
lead_paragraph: More than two years after Homeland Security officials told Congress that they would produce new, more accurate standards to assess security at the nation’s borders, senior officials from the department acknowledged this week that they had not completed the new measurements and were not likely to in coming months, as the debate proceeds about overhauling the immigration system.

headline: Welcome to Scottsdale. Now, Watch the Doors.
abstract: For weeks, Manhattan riders have witnessed the fruits of the Arizona city’s daring gamble: that an advertising campaign will lure a very skeptical audience.
lead_paragraph: We now interrupt this subway ride with a brief message from Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: O Revelations! Letters, Once Banned, Flesh Out Willa Cather
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Letters', 'Archives and Records', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: An anthology of letters sheds light on the very private Willa Cather, now that her ban on publication of her correspondence has been lifted decades after her death.
lead_paragraph: For decades Willa Cather has been a peculiar enigma in 20th-century American literature: beloved by ordinary readers for vivid evocations of frontier life in novels like “O Pioneers!” and “My Antonia,” but walled off from closer personal scrutiny by some of the tightest archival restrictions this side of J. D. Salinger.

headline: Israelis Meet Obama Anew
abstract: President Obama’s speech elicited appreciation and hope from Israelis at a viewing party in Tel Aviv, organized by a group called Peace Now.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s speech elicited appreciation and hope from Israelis at a viewing party in Tel Aviv, organized by a group called Peace Now.

headline: Renewed Tax Credit Buoys Wind-Power Projects
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Numerous wind-energy projects stalled at the end of 2012, but Congressional action on a critical incentive has spurred developers to resume efforts.
lead_paragraph: After a deep slump at the end of last year, the wind industry is picking up.

headline: Corrections: March 22, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 22, 2013.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: A Home-Court Feeling for 2 Kansas Teams
abstract: Kansas and Kansas State are playing in the Sprint Center pod, making it easy for their fans to turn out.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The selection committee didn’t only do Kansas and Kansas State a travel favor by placing them in this Sprint Center pod. It may have ensured they both advance to the Round of 16.

headline: Not in Eine Million Jahre
abstract: Friday fun with Tim Croce.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This is the first time in my own solving history that I can honestly say that I was stumped by the entire top third of a puzzle. It’s O.K.; I eventually finished, but I had to work my way back up, and even then, there were quite a few things I didn’t know (I’m looking at you, OTOMIS) or were fooled by in the cluing. If anyone else had a similar experience, this must be Friday, and this must be a Tim Croce puzzle.

headline: Hope Is a Thing With Tires
abstract: “Hands on a Hardbody,” on Broadway at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, is a musical with a handmade feel and a bluesy-country-rock vibe about Texans vying to win a truck.
lead_paragraph: You can hear the sound of America singing in “Hands on a Hardbody,” the daring new musical that opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Thursday night. With a bravado to match the gumption of its characters, a hard-pressed bunch of Texans hoping to beat the odds and win a truck in a grueling contest, this new show drives onto the Broadway lot without the high-gloss blandishments that adorn most big musicals: glittering sets and costumes, high-kicking chorines, megawatt star turns. Instead it concentrates its energies on giving voice to a story of average people fighting to hold onto hope in the face of fierce economic headwinds and bad breaks, not to mention buckling knees.

headline: Lots of Food, Little Sleep, and Hope for Southern
abstract: Twenty-four hours with the Jaguars included meetings, film review, a walk-through with an apple as a basketball and much more. It also almost included an upset over Gonzaga. Almost.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Twenty-four hours with the Southern University Jaguars, a full day in the life of a No. 16 seed at the N.C.A.A. tournament, included meetings, film review, a walk-through with an apple in place of a basketball, speeches, music, chess, backward cuff links, forgotten spandex, “Law & Order” and platters of meat. Nearly $1,200 worth of meat.

headline: ‘Dirty War’ Victim Rejects Pope’s Connection to Kidnapping
abstract: A priest captured by the Argentine junta in the 1970s disputes accusations made by a fellow victim that the new pope played a role in his detention.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A Jesuit priest whose kidnapping by the Argentine military raised questions about the actions of Jorge Mario Bergoglio, now Pope Francis, during that country’s so-called Dirty War said in a statement this week that Father Bergoglio did not initiate the detention by reporting him and another priest to the authorities.

headline: Chicago Says It Will Close 54 Public Schools
abstract: After weeks of uncertainty, principals were officially notified of the closings, which represent the largest group of campuses to be shut down at one time by a city in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — After weeks of uncertainty, principals at 54 public schools here officially learned from city officials on Thursday that their schools would close, with 11 more to share space with other schools. The closings represent the largest group of campuses to be shut down at one time by a city in recent memory.

headline: Deal Will Give Cuomo Administration 12-Seat Suite at the Bills’ Stadium
abstract: The box, part of the state’s $130 million deal to renovate Ralph Wilson Stadium, has been seen by critics as a perk, but officials say it will be used to promote the state.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The Buffalo Bills’ renovated stadium will feature a new entrance plaza and an 8,000-square-foot team store, as well as more restrooms and large video screens.

headline: A Zigzag Offers a More Direct Route to a Park
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The long-awaited Squibb Bridge provides a new, faster way to gain access to Brooklyn Bridge Park from Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: It looks like something out of “Tarzan,” a wooden catwalk that snakes 450 feet through the air and moves gently up and down with each footfall. It is the long-awaited Squibb Bridge, which opened on Thursday and provides a new, faster way to access Brooklyn Bridge Park from Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Aimed at Ecology, Park Group’s Letter Offends Some Jews
abstract: The Prospect Park Alliance defended its message, which implied that some Jews were improperly throwing bread to the waterfowl at Prospect Park Lake before Passover.
lead_paragraph: It initially seemed like just an eco-friendly news release — a reminder to “the public” not to throw bread into Prospect Park Lake because it is not healthy for geese and other waterfowl.

headline: Post Office Rebuffed Again on 5-Day Service
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: The Government Accountability Office said there was no legal basis for the post office to reduce mail deliveries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Thursday received another setback in its attempts to stop delivering mail on Saturdays.

headline: Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell
abstract: From “Old Yellow Moon”
lead_paragraph: From “Old Yellow Moon”

headline: Davidson Grants Marquette Last-Second Reprieve
abstract: Third-seeded Marquette came back from 5 points down with 28 seconds remaining to beat Davidson. Earlier in the day, Butler held off a late rally by Bucknell.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — When it was over Thursday night, after 39 bracket-busting minutes and one of pure mayhem, the Davidson Wildcats sat on their chairs, as if unwilling — or, perhaps, unable — to move. It was still all too fresh for them, how defeat was snatched from the jaws of victory, another monumental upset in the N.C.A.A. tournament filched with a second to spare.

headline: City Health Officials Warn Some Men on Lethal Strain of Meningitis
abstract: Over the last two years, it has appeared only in men, believed to be contracted through anonymous sexual encounters with other men. But health officials fear an outbreak.
lead_paragraph: It is a variant of a disease that can go from a fever and headache to a galloping rash and then to death within hours — so quickly that some victims have been found dead in bed before they could even get to a doctor. Over the last two years, it has appeared only among men, and they often got it, health officials say, through anonymous sexual encounters with other men found through Internet chat rooms or digital apps or at parties, making it all but impossible to trace the path of infection.

headline: Commuter Cycling Stays Flat in ’12
abstract: Unlike in previous years, there was no growth in the number of commuting cyclists in the typical riding season in 2012 in New York, but officials highlighted an increase in off-season ridership.
lead_paragraph: After years of growth in bike ridership, commuter cycling in New York remained flat in 2012 during the typical riding season, according to counts conducted by the city at six commuter locations last year.

headline: In Budget, a Tax Break for ‘Tonight’ to Relocate
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Television', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Cuomo administration officials denied that the tax break was written with “The Tonight Show” in mind.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The new state budget has a gift for NBC. A tax credit aimed at variety and talk shows, included in the new budget plan, will be an added incentive for NBC as it plots to relocate “The Tonight Show” to New York City. On Wednesday, The New York Times reported that the network plans to have Jimmy Fallon take over for Jay Leno next year.

headline: Spending Cuts Put Damper on Trips by Lawmakers
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner told members he would not authorize military aircraft for official overseas travel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Official travel abroad by members of Congress — trips known universally on Capitol Hill by the shorthand term “codels” — has always been something of a sensitive topic.

headline: Cano, the Classic’s M.V.P., Is Back in Camp
abstract: The Yankees welcome one of their few healthy stars, who is in the final year of his contract.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Flashing one of his first-to-third smiles, Robinson Cano arrived at the Yankees’ spring training camp Thursday and said he wanted to “keep the same momentum going” from his successful stint in the World Baseball Classic.

headline: Once Few, Women Hold More Power in Senate
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Female senators remain an anomaly, but with 20 now in office, they have become a new force on important committees and legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress, Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home. As Ms. Ayotte, a freshman Republican from New Hampshire, sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes, a doorman marched toward her with purpose.

headline: For Albany, an Australian Pipeline to the Tournament
abstract: The Great Danes experience against No. 2 Duke will be one to savor, particularly for the team’s three Australians and their families.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Shortly after the N.C.A.A tournament brackets were announced Sunday, Sam Rowley learned that his parents and his 19-year-old brother were working the phones to book flights so they could watch Albany’s opening game here Friday afternoon.

headline: Obamas Host State Dinner
abstract: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, hosted their first state dinner for their guests of honor, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India and his wife, Gursharan Kaur.

headline: Funds Sought for New Guantánamo Jail
abstract: The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million for a new prison building at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for “special” detainees.
lead_paragraph: The United States Southern Command has requested $49 million for a new prison building at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for “special” detainees, in addition to other renovations it says are necessary because Congress has decided to keep the prison open indefinitely. That brings the potential taxpayer bill for upgrading the deteriorating complex to $195.7 million, a spokesman for the command said Thursday. That is notably higher than an estimate of $150 million to $170 million provided by Gen. John F. Kelly, the command’s leader, in Congressional testimony on Wednesday. The special facility was not included in a list of projects released by the Southern Command on Wednesday. The military has not given specifics about the facility, but it appears to be a replacement for Camp 7, which houses so-called high-value detainees like Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Frenetic Northwestern State Has Designs on an Upset

headline: Seeking 90 Minutes of Peace for Two Teams and Their Fans
abstract: A World Cup qualifying match between host Croatia and Serbia has been feared as a potential flash point for nationalist fervor and memories of the ethnic clashes that brought war to the region in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: ZAGREB, Croatia — The visiting team’s fans have been barred from attending the World Cup qualifying match Friday between host Croatia and Serbia, a security measure the sport’s officials deemed necessary for the first soccer game between the countries since the violent dissolution of Yugoslavia. The match at Maksimir Stadium has long been feared as a potential flash point for fans with nationalist fervor and vivid memories of the ethnic clashes that brought war to the region in the 1990s.

headline: With Obama as Broker, Israelis and Turkey End Dispute
abstract: Israel’s apology for errors in a 2010 raid on a ship bound for Gaza thawed relations with Turkey and gave President Obama a solid achievement as he closed out his Middle East visit.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under persistent prodding from President Obama, Israel and Turkey resolved a bitter three-year dispute on Friday with a diplomatic thaw that will help a fragile region confront Syria’s civil war, while handing the president a solid accomplishment as he closed out his visit to the Middle East.

headline: Preserving a Famous American Racecar
abstract: The Ford Mark IV that Dan Gurney and A.J. Foyt drove to a historic victory at the 1967 24 Hours of Le Mans will be undergoing “conservation.”
lead_paragraph: The Ford Mark IV GT40 that Dan Gurney and A.J. Foyt drove to a historic victory at the 1967 24 Hours of Le Mans is going to be making a maintenance pit stop at Mr. Gurney’s All American Racers shop in California. The swoopy red sports car belongs to the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., but made several appearances in Europe last year to commemorate the 45th anniversary of its Le Mans triumph. That tour of the continent proved somewhat taxing, and the car was slightly damaged, so the museum has asked the Gurney shop to perform a conservation — a process that will ensure the car’s condition is the same as it was at the end of the race.

headline: Blackstone Circles Dell
abstract: The Blackstone Group faces a midnight deadline to submit a rival bid for Dell. | Rengan Rajaratnam, a younger brother of the fallen hedge fund titan Raj Rajaratnam, was indicted on insider trading charges. | The firm run by the billionaire Ronald W. Burkle is said to have cut fees for investors after suffering losses. | LPL Financial, a rapidly growing brokerage, has a growing list of regulatory problems.
lead_paragraph: BLACKSTONE CIRCLES DELL  |  The Blackstone Group may yet emerge as a challenger to the proposed $24 billion buyout of Dell. With a deadline approaching at midnight Friday, the private equity firm is weighing whether to make an offer for all or part of the computer maker, though “some people close to Blackstone are skeptical that any offer will materialize,” DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. Still, among the parties that have looked at Dell’s books under a “go-shop” period run by a special committee of the company’s board, Blackstone is considered the likeliest to make an offer, people briefed on the matter said.
