lead_paragraph: LONDON – Reports that the Russian bear was about to take tiny Cyprus into its crushing embrace, exploiting a banking crisis to strengthen the Kremlin’s foothold in the Mediterranean, may have been premature.

headline: Off the Charts: The Invisible Boom
abstract: Housing starts are rising at the fastest rate in more than a quarter- century, but the level is so low that the gains are having only a minor impact on the economy.
lead_paragraph: Housing starts are rising at the fastest rate in more than a quarter- century, but the level is so low that the gains are having only a minor impact on the economy.

headline: Housing, Ailing for Years, Starts to Recuperate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'Building (Construction)', 'Housing Starts']
abstract: After six years of declines, residential construction spending rose 12 percent last year.
lead_paragraph: THE first couple of years of economic recovery after the Great Recession were notable for one no-show.

headline: F.D.A. Seeks to Toughen Defibrillator Regulations
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said the new rules are intended to improve the use of the devices, which have failed thousands of times in cardiac arrest cases since 2005.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that it was moving to toughen regulation of the industry that produces heart defibrillators — devices used to jolt a failing heart back into its regular rhythm — after tens of thousands of malfunctions and hundreds of deaths in recent years.

headline: Late Marriage and Its Consequences
abstract: Winners, losers, and complexities in a world of steadily-later marriage.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday I had the privilege of joining a Brookings Institution event organized around the new report “Knot Yet: The Benefits and Costs of Delayed Marriage,” which tries to tease out the social implications of the steadily rising age of first marriage — now at 27 for women and 29 for men, both historic highs. Not surprisingly, a lot of the discussion focused on the impact of this trend on children, because the story of late marriage is entangled with the story of rising out-of-wedlock births, thanks to what the authors call “the great crossover” — the fact that the age of first marriage, which was once about a year earlier than the average age at which the first child was born, now lags the average age of first birth by about a year. Hence the report’s most attention-grabbing statistic: That 48 percent of overall first births, and 58 percent of first births to what the report calls “Middle Americans” — women with a high school diploma and maybe some college, but no 4-year degree — now take place outside of marriage, a trend whose negative consequences for children probably don’t need to be rehearsed here.

headline: Site Brings New Way to Connect With Vergara and Other Latino Stars
abstract: The Web site, called NuevoWorld, was created by Luis Balaguer, Ms. Vergara’s business partner and the co-founder of Latin World Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Vergara’s 4.2 million Twitter followers have seen the actress post a consistent stream of photos of her family, her friends and her Modern Family co-stars. Soon, many of those photos and posts will take her Twitter fans to a new Web site called NuevoWorld, which will make its debut on Friday.

headline: Time Stands Still When a Player Rolls the Ball in
abstract: A clock management strategy in basketball called “walking the dog” has become a quirk of the game.
lead_paragraph: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on the Times’s sports blogs.

headline: Ireland Recovers, and Recovers, and Recovers
abstract: Always good news.
lead_paragraph: March 2010: “Greece has a role model, and that model is Ireland” — Jean-Claude Trichet

headline: Shoeshine Notes
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A shoeshine man in Midtown draws customers with snappy patter and appeals to their fashion guilt.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Hallmark Channels Add Original Content and Sales of Movie Tickets Rise
abstract: Hallmark’s channels are introducing more original programming to attract viewers and advertisers; movie ticket sales rose 6 percent around the world; and Scottsdale, Ariz., has brought a taste of the Southwest to the New York subway.
lead_paragraph: Crown Media Family Networks’ executives said Thursday that efforts to increase the amount of original programming on their two Hallmark cable channels are already attracting advertisers, Stuart Elliott reports. Hallmark Channel plans to introduce five original prime-time series in July, and Hallmark Movie Channel will present original movies with Christmas themes this fall. Crown Media joins a lengthy list of media companies pursuing original programming rather than rerunning shows from broadcast networks. William J. Abbott, president and chief executive at Crown Media Holdings, said advertising gains will be “strong, strong, strong.”

headline: Cyprus Update
abstract: Icelandization, it seems.
lead_paragraph: Well, it looks as if the Icelandization of Cyprus — at least in the sense of making offshore depositors take a big hit — is happening faster and more decisively than I feared. Great summary by Paul Murphy at FT Alphaville, ending thusly:

headline: Court Opens Delhi Gang Rape Trial to Press
abstract: The Delhi High Court ruled on Friday that reporters can now start attending the trial of the Dec. 16 fatal gang rape case that has sparked widespread outrage in India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI— The Delhi High Court ruled on Friday that reporters can now start attending the trial of a gang rape case in the national capital.

headline: Chinua Achebe, African Literary Titan, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Achebe, the celebrated author of “Things Fall Apart,” wrote stirring essays and poignant poems rooted in his native Nigeria’s cities and countryside.
lead_paragraph: Chinua Achebe, the Nigerian author and towering man of letters whose internationally acclaimed fiction helped to revive African literature and to rewrite the story of a continent that had long been told by Western voices, died on Thursday in Boston. He was 82.

headline: When Should a Middle Schooler Change Schools?
abstract: How does a parent know when an unhappy seventh grader needs a change, and when she should stay put and learn to endure?
lead_paragraph: “How do you know when a middle schooler’s unhappiness at school is for real, or is simply early adolescent angst and moodiness?”

headline: 3 Marines Dead at Base in Shooting and Suicide
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The three were all enlisted personnel who worked at the officer training school in Quantico, Va., officials said.
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va. — Three staff members of the Marines’ officer training school are dead after a gunman killed himself and two colleagues, a man and a woman, officials said on Friday.

headline: The Apotheosis of the Tiger Man
abstract: It is time to look at how men are portrayed in Bollywood.
lead_paragraph: In the trailer for “Himmatwala” (The Brave), a remake of a 1983 revenge drama that releases next Friday, Ajay Devgn’s title character stands outside a temple and swings, by long golden chains, massive temple bells in each hand as a crowd of 50 men armed with sickles and scythes charges toward him.

headline: A Bridge for Two Bicentenary Rivals
abstract: As the music world observes the bicentenaries of Wagner and Verdi’s births, it may be instructive to chart the influence of Beethoven’s music over both.
lead_paragraph: WAGNER AND VERDI are destined to be linked forever, however awkwardly, since they were both born in 1813: Wagner in Leipzig, Germany, on May 22; Verdi in little Roncole, Italy, in the Duchy of Parma, on Oct. 9 or 10. (The records are not clear.)

headline: Highlights and Analysis: N.C.A.A. Tournament, Round of 64, Day 2
abstract: Times editors and reporters supply updates from every game on the second full day of the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: O.K., O.K. So you probably didn’t pick Harvard on Thursday night. Or Wichita State. But you had Oregon’s upset, right? And Cal? … Well, fine, but a lot of people disrespect the Pac-12, so your bracket is probably still alive in the office pool and you need to keep up with Friday’s action. Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters will supply updates from around the country.

headline: New Chief of Royal Opera Is a Manager, Not an Artist
abstract: The new chief executive of the Royal Opera House is Alex Beard, the deputy director of the four Tate museums.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—When it was announced in November that Tony Hall, the chief executive of the Royal Opera House, would leave in April to run the BBC, speculation about who would replace him was immediately rife. Mr. Hall is a hard act to follow. In the 12 years that he has run the opera house, he has transformed it from an institution beset by a succession of artistic directors, funding problems and a reputation for elitest money-wasting, to a model of balanced budgets, expanded access and artistic stability.

headline: Backer of an Open Internet Steps Down as F.C.C. Chief
keywords: ['Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality']
abstract: Julius Genachowski’s resignation raises a thorny issue for President Obama: whether it will be possible to keep the Internet free and open to businesses and users.
lead_paragraph: The resignation on Friday of Julius Genachowskiafter four years as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission again raises a thorny issue forPresident Obama: whether it will be possible to get the F.C.C. or Congress to help him fulfill a campaign promise to guarantee that the Internet remains free and open to businesses and users.

headline: Galloping Through Grand Central
abstract: To celebrate the centennial of the famous train station, students from the Ailey School of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will (literally) be horsing around in Nick Cave’s Soundsuits next week.
lead_paragraph: The sight of 30 multicolored horses galloping through Grand Central Terminal would give pause to even the most jaded New Yorker. But don’t worry; you won’t be imagining things. From March 25 to March 31, at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. each day, a group of students from the Ailey School of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will put on horse costumes — which are actually the artist Nick Cave’s famous mixed-media Soundsuits — and move through the space, either as a herd or in smaller groups. The project, “HEARD NY,” which Cave has done in collaboration with the Chicago choreographer William Gill, is presented by Creative Time and MTA Arts for Transit to celebrate Grand Central’s centennial. Between performances, the Soundsuits will be on display in the terminal’s Vanderbilt Hall for closer inspection. The video above offers a glimpse of the dancers rehearsing on-site, as well as the reactions of passers-by.

headline: In Mindfulness, a Method to Sharpen Focus and Open Minds
abstract: Misconceptions surround the practice of mindfulness, which is part meditation and part a greater awareness of the things around you.
lead_paragraph: LIKE most people, I have my share of tension and anxiety. And I’m happy to find ways to cope that don’t involve illegal drugs. So when the term mindfulness began cropping up everywhere, I became intrigued.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Smithsonian: No, it’s not Captain Nemo and his crew, it’s a team of researchers investigating the giant squid, and here’s everything you ever wanted to know about the mysteries of this exceedingly rare tentacled creature. Tastes like chicken? — Glenn Collins

headline: When ‘Tonight’ Was a ‘Lifeline to New York City’
abstract: Long before “The Tonight Show” made the move to California, it made its debut on West 44th Street, “just off the crossroads of the world, Times Square.”
lead_paragraph: So we called Dick Cavett to ask what “The Tonight Show” had meant to New York when it originated from Midtown Manhattan. Our idea was to follow up on reports that NBC planned to bring “Tonight” back to New York after a 41-year exile in California and name Jimmy Fallon the host, replacing Jay Leno.

headline: Ask Well: Fresh vs. Dried Blueberries
abstract: Do dried blueberries provide the same antioxidant benefits as fresh berries? Anahad O’Connor responds to a reader’s question.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Global Study of Monsoons Finds Ocean Variations Have Driven Recent Shifts
keywords: ['El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Floods', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Monsoons', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: The recent behavior of monsoons in the Northern Hemisphere clashes what was predicted under a push from global warming.
lead_paragraph: [March 24, 11:10 p.m.: Apologies for the blog silence and slow comment moderation. I’m camped on a beach with Pace University students making a film about efforts to balance fishing with marine conservation. ]

headline: Senate Republicans Push to Slow Financial Rule-Writing
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In nonbinding amendments tucked into the budget plan, Senate Republicans hope to erect potential new obstacles to financial rule-writing at agencies like the Securities and Exchange Commission and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
lead_paragraph: Congress cut a deal to keep the lights on in Washington. But new measures in the Senate may cut the power of financial regulators to curb Wall Street risk-taking.

headline: Leading Off: The First Full Day, From Agony to Ecstasy
abstract: Get into the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament and almost anything can happen. And then, almost everything does.
lead_paragraph: For so long, the two games were remarkably similar. No. 14 Davidson wasn’t playing the plucky underdog trying to surprise No. 3 Marquette, it was dismantling the Golden Eagles, just as its bookend, No. 14 seed Harvard, would discombobulate No. 3 New Mexico. This was true parity on display, teams much more evenly matched than their seeds would ever suggest. Our country may be separated into the 1 percent and the 99 percent, but college basketball is one big mosh pit of nearly equal opportunity. Get into the N.C.A.A. tournament and almost anything can happen.

headline: Ratings Fall for ‘Anger Management,’ With 80 Episodes to Go
abstract: Ratings for Charlie Sheen’s FX comedy “Anger Management” have fallen sharply, but the network is committed to producing 80 more episodes.
lead_paragraph: The cable channel FX raised a few eyebrows last August when it agreed to order 90 more episodes of Charlie Sheen’s comedy “Anger Management,” after only 10 episodes had been shown. It was an unusually large commitment to a new show, not often seen in television.

headline: The Things She Carried
abstract: Mary Beth Keane’s novel imagines the harried life of the woman known as Typhoid Mary.
lead_paragraph: Mary Beth Keane’s first novel, “The Walking People,” could stand as a historical sequel to her new novel, “Fever.” The earlier book is the story of two Irish sisters who immigrate to New York in the early 1960s, accompanied by a young man who belongs to the “walking people,” also known as the “traveling people” or tinkers. That novel is less about the anomalous position these itinerant peddlers occupy in Irish society than it is about the consequences of concealing from a child the circumstances of her birth. At the same time it’s a long, fond portrait of a family.

headline: I’ve Been Meaning to Tell You
abstract: Sexual transgression is only one means to an end for the characters in Amber Dermont’s stories.
lead_paragraph: The other day a headline, “Female Prison Guard Pregnant by Cop Killer Inmate,” came pulsing across the electronic ticker of a morning news show. Paging T. Coraghessan Boyle! I thought. The outsize combination of tragedy and brinkmanship, of hope and human folly, was straight out of a Boyle story. Several books in, we know exactly what we mean by a T. C. Boyle story — or a William Trevor story or an Antonya Nelson story. Indeed our pleasure is heightened by knowing the lay of the land because we can read for the new: how this particular Alice Munro story differs from what we’ve come to expect from an Alice Munro story.

headline: Straight Through the Heart
abstract: How to teach literature? With more attention to visceral reactions, and a lot less to theory and historical background.
lead_paragraph: As each semester begins at Grinnell College, a small liberal arts school nestled in the Iowa prairie, I get numerous e-mails from students pleading for a spot in my fiction workshop. The wait list is long, and as much as I’d love to take credit for the course’s popularity, I’m learning it’s less about the teacher and more about the way fiction writers approach the teaching of literature.

headline: Up Front
abstract: No single issue of the Book Review could contain every one of this season’s significant newcomers.
lead_paragraph: This winter, as we made our way through the usual stacks of upcoming titles on our shelves, we noticed an interesting trend: Many of the books that held our attention were written by first- or second-time authors who were relatively or entirely new to the scene. Apart from the unfamiliarity of the names on the title pages, not much united these works. There were novels, story collections, memoirs of food and art and unimaginable suffering. Their authors represented a range of backgrounds and sensibilities. And “new” didn’t necessarily mean “young” — youth (or age, for that matter) being no indicator of talent. But all the voices were fresh, and all made us sit up a bit straighter before settling in for the journey. Call it an accident of timing, but publishing’s spring crop offers a tangible rebuke to the lament that books are endangered, and suggests that literature’s future is in good hands.

headline: Japan Leader Backs Move of U.S. Base on Okinawa
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he would ask Okinawan officials for a key permit to begin construction to relocate an unpopular American air base.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Seeking to remove a longstanding irritant in Japan’s ties with the United States, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Friday that his government would ask local officials on the island of Okinawa for a key permit to begin construction to relocate an unpopular American air base to another part of the island.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Sheryl Sandberg’s “Lean In,” No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has renewed longstanding debates about the paucity of female executives and the best way to remedy it.
lead_paragraph: A BOARDROOM OF ONE’S OWN: “Lean In,” Sheryl Sandberg’s polarizing manifesto about the role of women in the workplace, roars onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 1. Sandberg is the chief operating officer of Facebook, and her book has renewed longstanding debates about the paucity of female executives and the best way to remedy it. (Sandberg’s answer, boiled down, is: “Work harder, girls!”) One sign that the book has touched a nerve is that, along with a steady stream of praise, it is also fielding criticism from across the ideological spectrum. On the one hand, in the “biology is destiny” camp, Christina Hoff Sommers recently charged in The Atlantic that Sandberg was “mired in 1970s-style feminism” with her earnest calls for “consciousness-raising groups” and her desire to “liberate her fellow Americans from the stereotypes of gender.” What if those stereotypes are innate, Sommers wondered, and women just aren’t interested in high-powered careers? “In the pursuit of happiness,” she wrote, “men and women often take different paths.”

headline: Varieties of Disturbance
abstract: Zombies, unicorns, shrink rays — an ordinary world is beset by unusual phenomena in Manuel Gonzales’s story collection.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of Manuel Gonzales’s lucid and confident first collection of stories, “The Miniature Wife,” he tells a tale from the point of view of a half-­human, half-zombie with conflicting ­urges. It’s one of the strongest (and funniest) in the collection, no small feat in our zombie-saturated cultural landscape. It also, in its way, sums up the central struggle of many of Gonzales’s characters: When does one just sit by, and when do darker impulses bubble up and take over? When do we stand aside, and when do we act? These stories vary widely — an elegiac description of a plane circling Dallas for decades, a futuristic wake mourning the loss of Africa into the ocean, social science “reportage” about false anthropological claims — but they work best when the characters, for whatever reasons, succumb to a buried darkness. Inner zombie rises up.

headline: Washed Away
abstract: Sonali Deraniyagala says of her family members killed in the 2004 tsunami: “They were my world. How do I make them dead?”
lead_paragraph: Sonali Deraniyagala’s extraordinary memoir, “Wave,” opens on the morning of Dec. 26, 2004, as the author putters around a Sri Lankan beach-side hotel with her family. By chapter’s end she’s pantless, half-drowned, bleeding, bruised and numbly resistant to what she’ll soon be forced to know: The five people she loves most in the world are dead. Her two young sons. Her husband. Her parents. All of them killed by a force she can’t yet comprehend, though she was caught up in it and nearly killed by it too. She only knows that “something came for us.” It was, as she and the world will soon learn, a tsunami of epic scale that took an estimated 230,000 lives across a dozen countries.

headline: Swinging Back to the Heyday of the Rat Pack
abstract: “Swing This,” Debby Boone’s show at Café Carlyle, featured songs from the Rat Pack era.
lead_paragraph: She was a just toddler when her father, Pat Boone, was a Las Vegas headliner who hobnobbed with the Rat Pack. But the singer Debby Boone had her eyes and ears wide open, and she remembers things like the look of Sammy Davis Jr.’s house and Dean Martin’s jokes about her father’s teetotaling. And on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle Ms. Boone, glamorized to the max, was the very picture of a tastefully attired Las Vegas babe as she devoted an entire program to songs of the Rat Pack era in a show titled “Swing This.” The swing was provided by an excellent nine-member band under the direction of John Oddo, the longtime musical director of Ms. Boone’s mother-in-law, Rosemary Clooney.

headline: 186-Year-Old Vampire Haunts Carnegie Hall
abstract: Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra, which specializes in obscure repertory, brought Marschner’s seldom-performed “Vampire” to Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Witches are an operatic staple, but vampire protagonists rarely appear in productions today. Heinrich Marschner’s “Vampire” is one of the several early-19th-century vampire-theme works that are now seldom performed.

headline: “House of Cards” Recap, Episode 9: Alliances Crumbling on All Sides
abstract: “House of Cards”: Recapping episode 9. Revolt is in the air: Frank Underwood’s carefully crafted bill to prop up Peter Russo’s candidacy comes undone and it’s an inside job. The alliance of convenience between Frankand Zoe Barnes becomes an intimate battle for power.
lead_paragraph: If you have loyally stayed with us to this point, you know the drill. Ashley Parker and David Carr put the old gimlet eye on “House of Cards” with an emphasis on the optics and verisimilitude of the show’s media and political angles. And if you are just arriving, you can catch up with recaps of episodes one, two,three, four, five, six,seven or eight. Lots of spoilers, so proceed with caution.

headline: Vying for a Shot of the Wedding
abstract: It has become easier than ever to take and share snapshots, for better or for worse.
lead_paragraph: To promote photo sharing at their wedding in Manchester, N.H., last month, Laura Bishop and Walter Carroll placed postcards on the tables with instructions for their guests on how to download an application called WedPics. After the reception, the couple immediately signed onto WedPics and found some 200 photographs.

headline: For Photographers, Competition Gets Fierce
abstract: New technology brings more entrants to the field, often at much lower prices.
lead_paragraph: For professional photographers, advancements in technology pose an interesting predicament. Camera innovations have enabled them to take better photos, but it’s lowered the barrier to entry by competitors.

headline: Q & A
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Plumbing', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: Plumber’s Permit Required; Questionable Co-op Voting; Resolving Disputes With a Mediator.
lead_paragraph: Plumber’s Permit Required

headline: Mommy Highest
abstract: A writer’s relationship with her mother, both a drug addict and a life force, is at the heart of this memoir.
lead_paragraph: Nikki, the childhood incarnation of Domenica Ruta and the daughter of a sometimes charismatic, other times irascible Italian-American single mom, makes the following precocious observation early on in “With or Without You.” “Even nature programs revealed to us the brutal world as we recognized it: sharks leaving flesh wounds as part of the courtship ritual, procreation by gang rape and, for the finale, intrauterine cannibalism! Shakespeare couldn’t have done a finer job.”

headline: ‘To Talk to You in Letters’
abstract: This epistolary novel about two writers is based on the correspondence of Flannery O’Connor and Robert Lowell.
lead_paragraph: With enough distance, it’s possible to be nostalgic about pretty much anything, even the gray-flannel decade the poet Robert Lowell, who spent part of it on Thorazine, called the “tranquilized ’50s.” Ah, for the days of “duck and cover,” “The Pajama Game” and “I Like Ike.” Now Carlene Bauer, author of a precocious memoir, “Not That Kind of Girl,” about growing up evangelical in a secular age, has dug into the dawn of the “Mad Men” era for her first novel, about two young writers on the rise who meet at an artists’ colony modeled on Yaddo during the summer of 1957.

headline: Saucy Dishes
abstract: In his memoir, the chef Eddie Huang writes about his family, his love of hip-hop and his efforts to perfect red cooked skirt steak.
lead_paragraph: Hold the presses! Not all Asian-Americans are studying math and practicing the piano. Some, like the young Eddie Huang, are busy shoplifting CDs, taking Ecstasy and getting thrown in the clink. Huang’s rambunctious memoir boasts many classic adolescent moments — the employment of a SPAM launcher, for example, and the inevitable arrival of a Miss Lacey on the scene. There are tussles with his parents, tussles with his peers. There are cops and drugs. And of course, channeling his inner Holden Caulfield involves, well, language:

headline: Everything in Its Path
abstract: In this novel, a couple escape the devastation wrought by a tornado — for which their community destroys them.
lead_paragraph: Just before 1 o’clock on the afternoon of March 18, 1925, over the farmland of southeastern Missouri, a column of air, spinning like a skater with her arms folded, came down from the clouds and touched ground. To prevent public panic, the word “tornado” had been officially banned from United States weather forecasts since 1887, so the regional forecast called only for rain and shifting winds. It was possibly the greatest understatement in the history of meteorology.

headline: A Feast for the Senses
abstract: Tamara Shopsin — graphic designer, illustrator, short-order cook — chronicles a year of travel, work and misfortune.
lead_paragraph: I’ve managed to eat at Kenny Shopsin’s legendary restaurant and ­customer-hazing clinic only once, thanks to a regular who had passed muster and brought me along to breakfast. This was when Shopsin’s was still in Greenwich Village and felt like a crazed version of the general store it had once been; over the stack of plain pancakes that I ordered without knowing any better, I tried not to be too alarmed by the abusive banter in the kitchen between Shopsin and one of his sons — which sounded, to the uninitiated, like a job for 911. Could I call social services, I wondered, and still come back for more pancakes?

headline: Beautiful Losers
abstract: The characters in Jim Gavin’s stories live in run-down Los Angeles neighborhoods and are the sons of journeymen and salesmen.
lead_paragraph: A generous humanity and a fond wit animate Jim Gavin’s wonderful first collection, “Middle Men.” Gavin’s stories revolve around a familiar theme — men searching for identity and meaning — but they’re distinguished by his more specific concerns: how work shapes lives, and the differences in the way the young and the old confront the humbling problem of ambition and success. Gavin’s characters, most of whom live in down-at-the-heels neighborhoods of Los Angeles or in modest industrial towns south of the city, are sons of journeymen, low-paid assistants and traveling salesmen. These men know, or are beginning to suspect, that the mark they will make on the world is small. But “Middle Men” doesn’t wallow in pessimism; with deft portraiture, nimble prose and an intimacy with the lives of his amiable characters, Gavin shows us that the real work of a life takes place not when the sale is made but when the salesman goes back home, looks in a half-empty refrigerator and considers his options.

headline: Buffalo Noir
abstract: Stephan Talty makes the city of Buffalo both the locale and a major character in his first thriller, “Black Irish.”
lead_paragraph: When it comes to great settings for a crime novel, there’s no place like home. For Stephan Talty, that’s Buffalo, which he has made both the locale and a major character in his first thriller, BLACK IRISH (Ballantine, $26). As viewed by Detective Absalom (Abbie) Kearney, lately returned to care for a father whose mind is going, Buffalo is a decaying place, sunk in despair, haunted by its illustrious past. “The whole city was entombed by the artifacts of its glory days,” she observes of the disintegrating waterfront, the bankrupt mills and “silent” smokestacks, the highways built for a population long gone. And nowhere is this sense of loss more keenly felt than in the section where Abbie grew up, “a patch of Ireland in the wilds of America” known as the County.

headline: Women in the Upper Chamber
abstract: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota discusses the record number of women in the United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota discusses the record number of women in the United States Senate.

headline: The Gun Report: March 22, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Joe wrote about Jewelry For a Cause, which designs bracelets that were initially made from melted-down guns confiscated in long-forgotten Newark, N.J. criminal cases. The company has since donated $40,000 to the city of Newark to help pay for gun buybacks, with the idea that it would use the gun’s metal to make more bracelets. A virtuous cycle if ever there was one.

headline: For the Caring Generation, a New Name in Luxury
abstract: The French luxury group PPR will henceforth be known as Kering.
lead_paragraph: The French luxury group PPR will henceforth be known as Kering. In a statement today, the group said its new moniker (pronounced “caring”) reflects “the distinctive way in which we look after our brands, our staff, our customers and our stakeholders.”

headline: Stress of Cancer Scare May Last Years
abstract: Even after three years, some women with a false positive mammogram test result displayed higher levels of distress than those with normal findings.
lead_paragraph: The psychological fallout from a false positive mammogram test result can last up to three years, a new study has found.

headline: Weekends Worse for Surgery
abstract: Emergency surgeries performed on a weekend may have poorer results than the same operation performed on a weekday, a new study concludes.
lead_paragraph: Emergency surgeries performed on a weekend may have poorer results than the same operation performed on a weekday, a new study concludes.

headline: Ancient Art for a Modern World
abstract: The Rev. John Walsted of New Brighton on Staten Island creates Orthodox-style icons for churches and private collections.
lead_paragraph: Inside a rambling Victorian house in New Brighton, a part of Old Russia lives on. Most days, the Rev. John Walsted crouches over a worktable in his second-floor studio, dipping a slender brush into glistening pools of egg yolk and powdered pigment as he painstakingly creates Orthodox-style icons for churches and private collections.

headline: Antidoping Lawsuit Cites Six People With Links to Florida Clinic
abstract: The suit is one of the more aggressive moves Major League Baseball has taken in to try to thwart doping, and it could lead to other officials in sports suing suspected suppliers of banned drugs.
lead_paragraph: In its continuing fight to thwart the use of performance-enhancing drugs, Major League Baseball took the unusual step Friday of filing a lawsuit in Florida state court, accusing six people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic of damaging the sport by providing various players with prohibited substances.

headline: Honda Recalling 76,000 Acura TSX Models for Stalling Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The recall covers only vehicles sold or registered in salt-belt states.
lead_paragraph: 3:14 p.m. | Updated Citing a problem first detected in Iceland in 2011, Honda is recalling about 76,000 of its 2004–8 Acura TSX models in the United States because of a stalling problem, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a report posted on the agency’s Web site.

headline: The Drink With No Name
abstract: An experimental cocktail from Big, a minuscule lounge in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: During my San Francisco bar crawl, I was charmed by Big, a minuscule lounge. It has the finest virtues of great cocktail bars (foremost among them: thoughtful, unusual drinks prepared with great finesse) minus the stuffiness that sometimes suffuses such places.

headline: How My Sister Cured My Writer’s Block
abstract: I asked her to send me a single sentence. In 12 words, she revealed just how much she really knew.
lead_paragraph: So I call her on Sunday morning. I ask the usual questions about her week, and then I say, I’m stuck. Send me just one sentence. Can be about anything. It doesn’t matter.

headline: Oy Vey, Christian Soldiers
abstract: What could be wrong with Bible-believing evangelicals giving their son a bar mitzvah?
lead_paragraph: Of all the surprises promised by the recent TLC reality show “The Sisterhood,” which followed the lives of five Atlanta preachers’ wives, the only one that truly amazed me was the Christian bar mitzvah, an event organized by Pastor Tara Lewis and her husband, Pastor Brian, for their son, Trevor. Brian was born to Jewish parents; Tara was not. Both are born-again Christians, and they’re of one mind about their son’s bar mitzvah as a Christ-centered take on the traditional Jewish coming-of-age ceremony.

headline: A Tax Lawyer’s Quandary
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: Is it ethical to advise wealthy companies on how to take advantage of legal loopholes to save money?
lead_paragraph: I am a tax lawyer. Is advising wealthy companies of ways to reduce their tax bills through sophisticated legal structures ethically permissible? The structures take advantage of legal loopholes in the tax legislation. NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: Mary Robinson Doesn’t Need to Be Popular
abstract: Ireland’s first female president on sharp elbows, Margaret Thatcher and struggles at the U.N.
lead_paragraph: In your memoir, “Everybody Matters,” you write that you were the third child amid four boys. Do you think having so many brothers affected your political path?  I do joke that this is the start of my belief in human rights and using my elbows. But more seriously, I had a stronger sense of myself as a young Irishwoman than many of my contemporaries. When I was elected president of Ireland in 1990, I was very conscious that I could use symbols in a way that would be harder, maybe, for a man. In my inauguration, I emphasized the word “love,” which is somehow easier for a woman to use.

headline: Who Made Spring Break?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: How Easter turned into sun, sand and beer.
lead_paragraph: In 1958, Glendon Swarthout, an English professor at Michigan State University, overheard his students buzzing about their Easter-break trip to Fort Lauderdale. In that more-ecumenical era, students typically shuttled home to attend church services with their parents, but now word was spreading of another kind of spring break. Swarthout decided to tag along so that he could observe the rituals (pool-hopping, pith helmets, beatnik jazz) and capture the lingo (“beaucoup beers,” “schizoid,” “babyroo”). Upon his return, he dashed off a novel about coeds who cruise the beach and “play house” with boys from other colleges — a 1950s version of “Girls Gone Wild.” In a nod to the Easter season, he called his book “Unholy Spring,” but Hollywood executives persuaded him to change the title to “Where the Boys Are.” The result was a blockbuster book that was spun off into a movie — marketed with the phrase “spring vacation” — as well as a Connie Francis song.

headline: The 3.10.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE ALLERGY BUSTER

headline: Kate Atkinson’s ‘Groundhog Day’ Fiction
abstract: The British novelist hasn’t met a plot too complicated — even if it means telling a story backward or starting over in every chapter.
lead_paragraph: Imagine having the gift (or the curse) of continually dying and being reborn, so that you relive segments of your life again and again, differently each time, going down various paths and smoothing out rough areas until you get it right and can move on. Imagine, too, that you are not conscious that this is happening, but experience it as intermittent déjà vu, a sometimes-inchoate dread, an inexplicable compulsion at sudden moments to do one thing rather than another.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE RIGHTEOUS MIND: Why Good People Are Divided by Politics and Religion,  by Jonathan Haidt. (Vintage, $16.) Why doesn’t the other side listen to reason? Haidt, a social psychologist, charts the “mental mechanisms that make us adept at promoting our group’s interests, in competition with other groups,” and explains why liberals and conservatives have such different intuitions about right and wrong. In Our Divided Political Heart: The Battle for the American Idea in an Age of Discontent (Bloomsbury, $18), the Washington Post columnist E. J. Dionne Jr. situates our current political dysfunction in the full sweep of American history. “Americans disagree about who we are,” he writes, “because we can’t agree about who we’ve been.”

headline: Pope Appeals for More Interreligious Dialogue
abstract: Pope Francis called for intense discourse with Islam and urged church leaders to renew dialogue with countries that do not have official ties with the Holy See.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis appealed for more intense dialogue with Islam on Friday, while calling on church leaders to renew diplomatic discourse with countries that do not have official ties with the Holy See, like China.

He was eventually convicted and imprisoned, but only recently did Ms. Rivera find out that her cooperation with investigators had qualified her for a special benefit: a visa for victims of serious crimes.

headline: Officials Release Details of Plan to Build Near Housing Projects
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: New York City Housing Authority officials have faced criticism that they had not disclosed enough information about a proposal to lease lands for private development at eight Manhattan projects.
lead_paragraph: One public housing project, Frederick Douglass Houses on the Upper West Side, could eventually add as many as three apartment buildings — with a total of 794 units — on what are now parking spaces on its grounds. Another project, Alfred E. Smith Houses, could see as many as 1,151 apartments rise on a single parcel of land by the East River.

headline: A Full Circle for Emmylou Harris
abstract: With a new duets album out, Emmylou Harris talks about four decades of singing and the reinventions and tradeoffs along the way.
lead_paragraph: In her four-decade career, Emmylou Harris has earned a dozen Grammy Awards and a spot in the Country Music Hall of Fame. Her long list of collaborators includes Gram Parsons, Bob Dylan, Roy Orbison, George Jones, Willie Nelson, Neil Young, Dolly Parton, Linda Ronstadt and Rodney Crowell, an old friend and former band mate with whom she has just released a duets album, “Old Yellow Moon.”

headline: Style Coaches
abstract: In a new video series, Coach features its spring collection of handbags and accessories in a series of videos that brings together young and old fashion icons to discuss what style means today.
lead_paragraph: In a new digital project called “Generations of Style,” Coach features its spring collection of handbags and accessories in a series of videos that brings together young and old fashion icons to discuss what style means today. Ari Seth Cohen, the 31-year-old behind Advanced Style, orchestrated the one-on-one conversations between fashion bloggers in their 20s and women ranging in age from 65 to 92. “I love these intergenerational projects that bring younger people into the same environment as older people to discuss things that they can both relate to and really show that there is a lot that they can learn from each other,” he says. In one of the flicks, Cohen captures Leandra Medine (“Man Repeller”) playing dress up with the Off Broadway Boutique owner Lynn Dell and saying, “I can’t wait to turn 80!”

headline: In Guyana, Wildlife Makes a Slow Return
abstract: In Guyana, a place that was once denuded regains some of its former wildness — with the help of some who used to strip it.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lesley de Souza, a research biologist at John G. Shedd Aquarium, writes from Guyana, where she studies the region’s rich aquatic wildlife, including the arapaima, one of the largest freshwater fishes in the world.

headline: Funding Site to Designers: Leave the Business End to Us
abstract: Byco, a new microfinancing site, combines old-fashioned capitalism with crowd-funding principles.
lead_paragraph: The other day you may have read about Patrick Robinson, the former Gap creative director, who is producing a new line, Paskho, with money he hopes to raise on Kickstarter. Among crowd-funding sites, Kickstarter is the largest, with more 30,000 projects financed and $300 million in pledges. A virtue of these sites is that for a small sum an investor can feel included in the creative process, whether it’s a film or an amazing sweatshirt. If the project is successful, investors receive a reward or privilege.

headline: Walt Whitman’s Boss

lead_paragraph: On the morning of March 20, 1863, Walt Whitman sat at his desk in a bustling office building in Washington and penned a letter to friends. At one point, he gazed out of his fifth-floor window at the wartime capital. After a long pause he resumed writing and described the vista.

lead_paragraph: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill. — On a raw and windswept day in this forsaken place, as the rest of the world’s eyes turned to the cardinals assembling amid Vatican grandeur to select a new pope, Brother Norbert Karpfinger sat down to write a letter. It was late February, two weeks into Lent, a busy time for the correspondence that is his mission.

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — One day after the Yankees said they were shutting down shortstop Derek Jeter from playing in any more major league spring training games, he announced Friday that nobody should rule out anything.

headline: What Are You Doing for World Water Day?
abstract: World Water Day is dedicated to promoting access to clean water, a challenge that is only growing as population and pollution increase.
lead_paragraph: When you open your tap today and, as if by miracle (and thanks to a good deal of engineering), a stream of clean and drinkable water starts flowing, think of the millions of people for whom such basic access is not so simple.

headline: “Bluebird Wine”
abstract: From “Old Yellow Moon”
lead_paragraph: From “Old Yellow Moon”

headline: Among the Vines in Chile, Villas and Views
abstract: In the Colchagua and Millahue Valleys, about two hours from Santiago, wineries are hoping to lure sophisticated visitors.
lead_paragraph: From my horse-top perch, I could view seemingly endless rows of green vines, stretching out across a wide valley floor. To the west, sharp mountains rose behind a glassy emerald lake reflecting slow-moving clouds; a family of herons roosted by the water. Other than the winemaker who rode next to me, a few workers, hundreds of cattle, those herons and millions of precious grapes, I was alone on this 11,000-acre Chilean estate.

headline: Winter Is Prime in Puglia
abstract: Head to the heel of Italy’s boot in the colder months and you’ll find smaller crowds, lower prices and tastier food.
lead_paragraph: Disappointment swept across the table. Daniela, our waitress, with tight jeans and dyed pink hair, hovered over our table, shaking her head. “I trying to warn you,” she scolded. There were dozens of bowls of antipasto unfinished, many of them untouched. She just shook her head some more. “I leaving and you eating. Now.” With a nod that smacked of finality, she turned and sashayed back to the kitchen.

headline: Miami, My Way
abstract: Forget Art Basel. My Miami is a place of fruit stands, fritters, airboat rides and a serene hotel on Ocean Drive.
lead_paragraph: We stood on the Everglades boardwalk, an hour south of Miami Beach, squinting in the sun, looking like fools. He was as white as milk and as gangly as Napoleon Dynamite, with a gaudy beach towel we’d bought at a Woolworth’s tied around his neck. I was dressed head-to-toe in discount specials: a bright orange cover-up and plastic sandals three sizes too big. As we stood in our absurd get-ups, marring the blue-skied Florida backdrop, he told me I looked like a Dreamsicle.

headline: Ready to Fight Gay Marriage at Court Door
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Brian S. Brown has become the nation’s leading opponent of gay marriage. Now, his views are set for the ultimate American test: a Supreme Court hearing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As gay couples fight for the right to wed, a little-known but determined force is working to stop them: Brian S. Brown, a 39-year-old father of eight who has raised millions of dollars from religious conservatives — especially his fellow Roman Catholics — to become the nation’s leading opponent of same-sex marriage.

headline: Judges’ Spat Strikes a Chord Among Deal Makers
abstract: Delaware judges have used the bully pulpit to right wrongs and guide the behavior of lawyers and their clients. Going too far, however,can create confusion.
lead_paragraph: Deal makers delivered a verdict on snarky judges at the annual M.&A. jamboree in New Orleans this week. The spectacle of Delaware jurists bashing the clever bromides and superfluous legal rulings of colleagues elicited hoots of delight from the assembled lawyers and bankers. The criticism is on target. To avoid any confusion, courts should stick to the facts and the law.

headline: Hofstra Fires Basketball Coach
abstract: Coach Mo Cassara had three years left on his contract, but the Pride were 7-25 this season and several of his players had run-ins with the law.
lead_paragraph: After a 7-25 season and a litany of player arrests, Hofstra fired its men’s basketball coach, Mo Cassara, on Friday morning after three seasons.

headline: In Defense of Palestinians
abstract: In Israel, President Obama made a strong case for recognizing the Palestinian peoples’ right to self-determination and justice.
lead_paragraph: Back when Republicans senators and conservative commentators were consumed with trying to bury Chuck Hagel’s nomination as defense secretary, one of their patently false lines of attack was that he was anti-Israel.

headline: New Leader Taps Mexican Discontent to Press Agenda of Change

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Few topics get Mexicans more worked up than their country’s cellphone service, especially that provided by the dominant carrier, Telcel.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Summer (Season)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']

lead_paragraph: The emerald hedgerows that are a natural euphemism for Hamptons exclusivity (out here, good hedges, not good fences, make for felicitous neighbors) are hanging tight.

headline: Immigration Talks Hit Snag Over Business and Labor Concerns
abstract: Negotiations over a comprehensive immigration bill hit a snag on Friday as business and labor communities failed to reach an agreement on the future flow of legal immigrants into a low-skilled, year-round, temporary worker visa program.
lead_paragraph: 9:01 p.m. | Updated On Friday evening, the group of eight senators who are working to produce bipartisan immigration legislation and racing to work out a final dispute between the business and labor communities before Congress left for a two-week recess hit yet another obstacle, when the four Republican senators in the group spurned what a major union described as a another attempt at compromise.

headline: Shalom, Mr. President: Obama Tries to Charm Israelis With Hebrew
abstract: President Obama sprinkled Hebrew throughout his public remarks during his trip to Israel, an element of his effort to connect with the Israeli public.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As one Israeli columnist put it, he had them at “Shalom.”

headline: John Mayer to Tour This Summer
abstract: After a long hiatus to recover from vocal cord surgery, the singer will play across the United States this summer.
lead_paragraph: John Mayer announced on Friday he will mount a major concert tour this summer, his first in three years. The tour comes after a lengthy period of surgery and resting his voice to repair damage to his vocal cords.

headline: Wanted: Hot- and Cold-Running Quiet
abstract: Crystal Wei was in the market for a condo in Brooklyn that was spacious enough to hold her musical instruments and art supplies.
lead_paragraph: It was the street noise that made Crystal Wei want to leave her shared apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where she paid a rent of around $1,100 a month. A bus stop was nearby, as was a rowdy bar. Ms. Wei made an uneasy truce with the racket, but her mother, when she visited, couldn’t sleep.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Strange and Thrilling Stories
abstract: Jamie Quatro discusses her collection of stories, “I Want to Show You More.”
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, J. Robert Lennon admires Jamie Quatro’s collection of stories, “I Want to Show You More,” calling it “an obsessive first collection that feels like a fifth or sixth.” Mr. Lennon writes:

headline: However Justices Rule, Issues Remain
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: A victory for gay rights in either of two monumental cases before the Supreme Court this week will not settle the financial and legal issues that same-sex couples face.
lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court strikes down the law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman, same-sex couples across the country will undoubtedly gain access to a broad range of federal benefits.

headline: Another Day of Madness
abstract: The second day of the Round of 64 featured 16 more games on Friday, with many more upsets.
lead_paragraph: The second day of the Round of 64 featured 16 more games on Friday, with many more upsets.

headline: Does a No. 1 Seed’s Margin of Victory Mean Anything for Its N.C.A.A. Title Hopes?
abstract: Gonzaga fans can take heart: Close victories by No. 1 seeds over No. 16s are not a good sign for a team’s chances to win the N.C.A.A. tournament, but there isn’t enough data to make it truly predictive.
lead_paragraph: Southern almost pulled off the one upset that hasn’t happened at the N.C.A.A. tournament. And although No. 1-seeded Gonzaga escaped the first loss to a No. 16 when it pulled away from the Jaguars at the end of its 64-58 win on Thursday, it is easy to question whether its close call could have implications in the long term.

headline: Cruz, Patriots and Seahawks: Answers to Readers’ Questions
abstract: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: Digitally Aided Education, Using the Students’ Own Electronic Gear
abstract: In a growing trend, school districts pressed for money are allowing students to bring their phones, laptop computers or tablets to be used in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Educators and policy makers continue to debate whether computers are a good teaching tool. But a growing number of schools are adopting a new, even more controversial approach: asking students to bring their own smartphones, tablets, laptops and even their video game players to class.

headline: Is Your Kitchen a Health Hazard?
abstract: Our kitchens, like our girths, have grown substantially, in terms of size and of function.
lead_paragraph: OUR kitchens may be killing us — slowly. Not so much with radon or gas leaks, but with kindness and proximity.

headline: The Financial Effects of a Court Ruling Recognizing Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Bucks readers talk about the financial and legal implications for them if the Supreme Court overturns a ban on gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column tries to envision how life may change for same-sex couples if the federal law that bans gay marriage is struck down.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 22
abstract: Subjects include a St. Patrick’s Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include a St. Patrick’s Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.

headline: PPR to Show Breton Roots With Rebranding as Kering
abstract: The Paris luxury house, whose brands include Gucci, Balenciaga and Puma, said it was changing its name to Kering, a word based on the Breton for “home.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — PPR is on the way out. The Paris luxury group, whose stable of brands includes Gucci, Balenciaga and Puma, said on Friday that it was changing its name to Kering.

headline: Rebel Leader in Congo Is Flown to The Hague
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Bosco Ntaganda, a rebel commander accused of massacring Congolese civilians, was flown out of Rwanda bound for the International Criminal Court at The Hague.
lead_paragraph: NAIVASHA, Kenya — Bosco Ntaganda, a rebel commander accused of massacring civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was flown out of Rwanda on Friday bound for the International Criminal Court at The Hague, where he faces 10 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

headline: Paris Auction Goes Forward Despite Heritage Claims
abstract: Sotheby’s held an auction of antiquities in Paris on Friday despite complaints from four Latin American countries that some of the items for sale had been illegally exported.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s in Paris went forward today with a two-day sale of pre-Columbian artifacts despite claims by four Latin American nations that many of the 313 items had been illegally exported.

headline: Upscale, Downsized
abstract: With prices of roughly $30,000 to $50,000, a smaller class of luxury cars offers a less-is-more display of status.
lead_paragraph: With prices of roughly $30,000 to $50,000, a smaller class of luxury cars offers a less-is-more display of status.

headline: Taking It to the Limit
abstract: A new documentary, “People’s Park,” continues a tradition of directors experimenting with continuous takes, from Hitchcock to Robert Frank to Alexander Sokurov.
lead_paragraph: The new documentary “People’s Park“ surveys the range of human activity in a bustling urban park in Chengdu, China. People stroll, snack, socialize, practice calligraphy and engage in a wide variety of song and dance, from Chinese opera to pulsing disco. Some ignore the camera; others play to it. The filmmakers, Libbie Dina Cohn and J. P. Sniadecki, are never seen, but their presence is felt, not least because of how they chose to portray the park’s myriad denizens and activities: as a literal panorama of leisure and revelry, filmed in one long tracking shot.

headline: Nets Clinch, and Owner Wants You to Know
abstract: In an unusual move, Mikhail D. Prokhorov issued a news release on Friday to commemorate the Nets’ first postseason berth since he bought the team.
lead_paragraph: Upon seeing his team clinch its first playoff berth in six years, Mikhail D. Prokhorov celebrated with the verbal equivalent of a Champagne shower.

headline: Inside ‘The Place Beyond the Pines’
abstract: In this Anatomy of a Scene, the director Derek Cianfrance narrates his film’s opening sequence.
lead_paragraph: In this Anatomy of a Scene, the director Derek Cianfrance narrates his film’s opening sequence.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Brian K. Vaughan Talks About ‘The Private Eye’
abstract: “The Private Eye” is available on Panel Syndicate, a new online hub for original comics.
lead_paragraph: New at No. 3 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is “Season One: Avengers,” a look back at the earliest days of Marvel’s premiere superhero team. The “Season One” books are conceived as a way of introducing new readers to Marvel’s biggest heroes without being weighed down by the decades of sometimes-convoluted history can sometimes be amassed.

headline: Myth Making on Motorcycles
abstract: Ryan Gosling collaborates with his “Blue Valentine” director, Derek Cianfrance, on the three-part drama “The Place Beyond the Pines.”
lead_paragraph: “I never felt more like Janet Leigh in my life,” Ryan Gosling said with his best straight face.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures for March 22
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including the return of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including the return of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey to Brooklyn.

headline: A ‘Mary Tyler Moore Show’ Reunion, Via Cleveland
abstract: The TV Land sitcom “Hot in Cleveland” will reunite all of the major female stars from one of television’s most beloved comedies, “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”
lead_paragraph: The cable channel TV Land lives on nostalgia for classic television and that will certainly reach a peak this summer in an episode of the sitcom, “Hot in Cleveland.” The show will reunite all of the major female stars from one of television’s most beloved comedies, “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”

headline: Waiting for War, and Working to Fit In
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A general assignment reporter from Manhattan, Michael Wilson worked hard to fit in among the Marine officers in Kuwait and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: And here we had all been getting on so well.

headline: When ‘What Do You Do?’ Is Taboo
abstract: When a friend or acquaintance has lost a job, the art of conversation becomes a lot trickier.
lead_paragraph: TALKING TO UNEMPLOYED friends and colleagues requires a certain delicacy. The question “How was your day?,” when leveled with what is perceived as an undue amount of concern, can cause steam to emerge from ears. Robert Reich, the secretary of labor under President Clinton, said, “I don’t ask ‘What are you doing with yourself these days?’ or ‘How’s the job search coming?’ unless it’s a good friend. I wait for him to bring it up. Being jobless is distressing enough without people asking about it.”

headline: How About a Little Luxury?
abstract: Luxury vehicles have long pushed the limits of size, but automakers are now whipping up fancy bite-size models, confident that Americans are seeing the upside of small, yet artful, portions.
lead_paragraph: From tailfinned Cadillacs of the 1950s to three-ton S.U.V.’s at the turn of the century, luxury vehicles have always pushed the limits of size and mass.

headline: Buick Stakes a Claim in Munchkinland
abstract: Buick, long known for its big cars, is bravely venturing into the small end of the S.U.V. market with the new Encore, a mini-Buick that is blazing an upscale trail that other brands will soon follow.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, N.H. — Buick’s image is so ingrained in the national consciousness that the name has become shorthand for an American road barge with ample proportions. That moose, someone may say, “is as big as a Buick.”

headline: From the Andrews Sisters to Hip-Hop
abstract: A throwback artist who uses hip-hop beats, Willy Moon discusses his first album and how the Andrews Sisters, of all people, helped shape his style.
lead_paragraph: AT 23 WILLY MOON is a throwback artist in the most contemporary mode, with an ear for melding early rock sounds with synthy production and hip-hop beats. Signed to a major label before he ever played a gig, Mr. Moon was noticed by Jack White, who released his single “Railroad Track” and took him on tour in England last year. His debut album, “Here’s Willy Moon,” 12 propulsive songs that total less than 29 minutes, will be out April 2 on Cherrytree/Island; thanks to its use in an iPod commercial his single “Yeah Yeah,” which borrowed a Wu-Tang Clan sample, has already made the charts.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: “The Tonight Show” is expected to move back to New York City, and surging demand for homes has left some areas of the country with a shortage of inventory.
lead_paragraph: “The Tonight Show” is expected to move back to New York City, and surging demand for homes has left some areas of the country with a shortage of inventory.

headline: Short Season for a Rare Fish
abstract: The tiny sardines are available only for 45 days along the French Riviera.
lead_paragraph: Fishermen in Cagnes-Sur-Mer, in southeastern France, collect young fish in their nets on Thursday during the short poutine fishing season. Poutine, a type of baby sardines, are found between Antibes and Menton on the French Riviera for only about 45 days each year at the end of winter. Their price at market reflects their rarity: They will fetch about 30 euros, or $40, per kilogram.

headline: JPMorgan Board Confirms Dual Role for Dimon
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Boards of Directors', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: Rebuffing some investors, the 11-member board said that Mr. Dimon should continue to serve as both chief executive and chairman, as he has since 2006.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s board said on Friday that it was standing behind Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chairman and chief executive, in the face of calls from some investors that the two jobs be split.

headline: A Voice That Leaps Between Genres
abstract: On “Twain” and other albums the singer Rebecca Martin blurs the lines between jazz and other vocal styles.
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, N.Y. — Rebecca Martin and Larry Grenadier live in a house on a hill in this weathered Hudson Valley city, some 90 miles upriver from Manhattan. At a glance, their sturdy Victorian doesn’t seem like the obvious hub of a small-batch initiative to redraw contemporary jazz singing. During one recent visit, there was snow on the ground and soup on the stove, and their 7-year-old son, Charlie, was home from school.

headline: Shuffleboard? Oh, Maybe Let’s Get High Instead
abstract: Today’s retirees are more accepting of marijuana use, and not just for medical reasons.
lead_paragraph: For Cher Neufer, a 65-year-old retired teacher, socializing with friends (all in their 60s) means using marijuana. Once a week they get together to play Texas Hold ’Em poker “and pass around a doobie,” Ms. Neufer said.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 22, 2013
abstract: The New York Times critics on "Admission," "Olympus Has Fallen" and "Gimme the Loot."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on "Admission," "Olympus Has Fallen" and "Gimme the Loot."

headline: The Extreme (Existential) Makeover
abstract: What if you could do your life over again? Many late stage adults are trying to find out.
lead_paragraph: AMONG the many unexpected downsides of increased longevity (running through one’s retirement money; more years in an assisted-living facility; entertaining the possibility that we ourselves may suffer the consequences of global warming, even though we thought we were just “passing the problem on to our children”), one can now include the prospect of more time to sit on a park bench brooding about how we could have done it differently — been better than ourselves.

headline: The Vehicular Side of the Vatican
abstract: The original popemobile was a plush sedan chair carried by 12 footmen in red uniforms. Once the Vatican went to four wheels, the cars have included Fiats, Peugeots and Fords.
lead_paragraph: As the newly installed pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis will often be seen greeting the world from the back of a rather peculiar vehicle. It’s taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one we’ve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.

headline: At 102, Margaret Dunning Looks Ahead to Next Concours
abstract: In May, Margaret Dunning will take part in the Keels and Wheels concours in Seabrook, Tex. She hopes to attend the coming Indy 500 race and will speak this summer at the national Packard Club’s annual meeting, to be held in Pontiac, Mich.
lead_paragraph: At 102, Margaret Dunning could be living a genteel, quiet life. Instead, Ms. Dunning, who owns a 1930 Packard 740, has become a doyenne of the show-car circuit and is often away from home.

headline: Vatican City 1
abstract: It’s taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one we’ve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.
lead_paragraph: It’s taken many shapes over the last three decades, but the classification is one we’ve become pretty accustomed to: the popemobile.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 22
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: The Best Thing I Learned At SXSW Was From the Unabomber
keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Unabomb Case']
abstract: The best thing I learned at this year’s South by Southwest came from the unlikeliest of sources — a techno-skeptic and professor of philosophy who says he believes that technology is ruining modern society.
lead_paragraph: Now that I’m back and mostly recovered from South by Southwest, my friends, editors and fellow reporters keep asking me about the most interesting thing I saw in Austin.

headline: Kyle Dake Is Going for Four
abstract: The Cornell wrestler Kyle Dake is attempting to be the first collegiate wrestler to win four titles in four different weight classes. He is competing this weekend at the N.C.A.A. championship in Des Moines, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: The Cornell senior Kyle Dake is looking to make wrestling history this weekend. If he wins the 165-pound weight class at the N.C.A.A tournament in Des Moines, Iowa, he will be the only collegiate wrestler to have won four titles in four different weight classes.

headline: Big Ticket | Baronial Show House Sold for $22.85 Million
abstract: A 17-room limestone mansion, 25 feet wide with over 10,000 square feet, was once the site for a fund-raising decorator show house event.
lead_paragraph: A magisterial limestone town house on one of the Upper East Side’s most moneyed blocks sold for $22.85 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Finding Their Next Facebook
abstract: The Winklevoss brothers have moved on from their battle with Mark Zuckerberg and are more active than ever.
lead_paragraph: As you sit across from Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, it is easy to lose track of whom exactly you’re talking to. Tall, blue-eyed and each built as broad-shouldered as a fridge, the twins are identical right down to their entrees: a pair of lobster rolls, with potato chips. Each has an espresso; neither eats the biscotti it comes with. And while the restaurant around them is spinning with chatter on this February night, the twins are each laser focused on getting their message across.

headline: Obama Withdraws Judicial Nomination After Second G.O.P. Filibuster
abstract: President Obama has withdrawn the nomination of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to serve on an important federal appeals court in Washington, blaming Republicans for blocking her confirmation twice.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has withdrawn the nomination of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to serve on an important federal appeals court in Washington, blaming Republicans for blocking her confirmation twice.

headline: Scheduling Conflict Forces Ravens to Open on Road
abstract: The N.F.L. usually stages its season opener at the home of the Super Bowl champion, but a Ravens-Orioles scheduling conflict will keep that from happening.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Ravens, the defending Super Bowl champions, will open the season on the road because the N.F.L. and Major League Baseball could not work out a scheduling conflict with the Baltimore Orioles.

headline: Heartbreaking News, Heavenly Exhortations and Lonely Sentiments
abstract: New music this week comes from the band Chvrches; the roots-rock group Water Liars; and the singers Kat Dahlia, Tasha Cobbs and Brotha Lynch Hung.
lead_paragraph: Chvrches

headline: A Sitcom That Some Find, Well, Alien
abstract: Despite a critical roasting, “The Neighbors,” a science fiction comedy series that takes place in a gated suburban community, has managed to stay in ABC’s lineup.
lead_paragraph: In her 30-year acting career Jami Gertz has never heard a negative peep from her parents about her projects. “It could go straight to video,” she said, “and my father will be like, ‘You were the best thing in it.’ ”

headline: Movie Review | 'Admission'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Admission."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Admission."

headline: A Family’s Secrets Bared, on Camera
abstract: In “Kind Hearted Woman,” his latest portrait from the margins of rural America, the filmmaker David Sutherland focuses on an American Indian family enduring two generations of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: It took a powerful, disturbing dream from which she awoke sobbing to convince Robin Charboneau, an Oglala Sioux and member of North Dakota’s Spirit Lake tribe, that “I needed to open my mouth, and I needed to speak.” So she let the documentary filmmaker David Sutherland follow her for more than three years as she struggled to raise her family as a single mother while confronting her alcoholism and the scars of being sexually abused as a child.

headline: Another Look at Natural Gas
abstract: Whether the natural gas boom could reduce the threat of climate change by fostering a switch from coal depends in part on how much gas leaks out in the course of hydraulic fracturing.
lead_paragraph: After my column on Wednesday about how the nation’s natural gas boom is helping reduce emissions of heat-trapping carbon, I received a bunch of e-mail arguing that gas obtained by hydraulic fracturing could, on the contrary, worsen climate change.

headline: Visors Should Be Mandatory, Says Player Who Lost an Eye
abstract: Greg Neeld lost his left eye to a high stick as an 18-year-old junior defenseman in 1973 and later developed the first helmet visor.
lead_paragraph: For a true advocate for mandatory visor use in the N.H.L., talk to a hockey player who lost an eye playing the game.

headline: Movie Review | 'Olympus Has Fallen'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Olympus Has Fallen.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Olympus Has Fallen.”

headline: BlackBerry Z10 Goes on Sale in U.S.
abstract: The new smartphone, which is critical to the company’s financial future, went on sale on Friday for AT&T customers, and will be available later in the month for Verizon Wireless and T-Mobile.
lead_paragraph: An after-midnight sale at a 24-hour Best Buy store in New York’s Union Square was the site of the American debut of the BlackBerry Z10 smartphone on Friday.

headline: Big as a Buick? Not This One
abstract: The Encore is a bold move from a brand once known for cautious conservatism.
lead_paragraph: The Encore is a bold move from a brand once known for cautious conservatism.

headline: Suddenly, They’re All Gone
abstract: The caregiving is over, but instead of being relieved, I feel worse.
lead_paragraph: Caring for the old is just like parenting an infant, only on really bad acid. It’s all there: the head-spinning exhaustion, the fractured brain, the demands and smells. Only this time with the knowledge that it won’t get better.

headline: Dressing Up for a Special Occasion
abstract: Use a colorful combination of currants, golden raisins, dried apricots and dried cranberries to make this year’s holiday Easter bread something special.
lead_paragraph: THESE DAYS WE ARE constantly surrounded by sweet baked goods, but once upon a time they were really considered quite special. Daily bread was usually brown and meant for sustenance; only for holidays, Easter in particular, was it rich and extravagant, made with fancy white flour, milk, butter and eggs, and studded with candied fruit.

headline: At The New Republic, Even Firings Enter the Digital Age
abstract: Timothy Noah, an editor at the magazine, tweeted out that he’d been fired.
lead_paragraph: Just one year after the Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes bought The New Republic, the magazine confirmed it had fired one of its top editors.

headline: Gay Conversion Therapy
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Chris Christie is deciding whether or not to sign a bill that would outlaw the unscientific practice.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s Governor Chris Christie is apparently agonizing over whether he should sign a bill that would outlaw so-called “reparative therapy.”

headline: A Forger’s Impressions of Impressionism
abstract: In Gilles Bourdos’s “Renoir,” about the Impressionist painter Pierre-Auguste Renoir and his son Jean, paintings by the forger Guy Ribes play a significant role.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny weekday morning in a cafe in Brooklyn the French director Gilles Bourdos is flipping through his laptop’s gallery of international art. There’s a charcoal study of Cézanne card players; Picasso’s inkblot Don Quixote, tilting his lance at the Spanish sun; and a blue-hued, Old World fantasy, bearing the kaleidoscopic hallmarks of Marc Chagall.

headline: A Secret-Agent Premiere for a New Range Rover
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Bond, James (Fictional Character)', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: On the eve of the New York show, the Range Rover Sport is having its debut in Manhattan with the help of the actor who plays James Bond.
lead_paragraph: A conventional news conference would hardly suffice for the debut of the 2014 Range Rover Sport, Land Rover executives thought, so on March 26, the night before the New York auto show opens for two days of press previews, the new S.U.V. is to be revealed in a Hollywood-caliber video.

headline: Plug and Play for Internet Connections
abstract: The Audiovox Car Connection kit, which went on sale at the end of last year, tracks the car and monitors the driver.
lead_paragraph: Far too often, drivers of older vehicles try to add the services available in new Internet-connected cars by balancing smartphones in their laps. But smartphones — aside from the obvious distraction they present — cannot do things like monitor the car’s location when someone else is using it or send a maintenance reminder based on miles traveled.

headline: Arab Student Explains Why He Heckled Obama in Jerusalem
abstract: The 24-year-old student from Israel’s Arab minority who interrupted President Obama’s speech in Jerusalem on Thursday explained his comments and why he said them in an interview on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The 24-year-old student from Israel’s Arab minority who interrupted President Obama’s speech in Jerusalem on Thursday explained his comments and why he made them in an interview with The Lede on Friday.

headline: Little Support for Idea of Medicare Payments That Vary
abstract: A push to reimburse more for low-cost, high-quality care gets scant support from an interim Institute of Medicine report.
lead_paragraph: Medicare should not adjust payments on a broad regional basis to reward hospitals and doctors that spend less to achieve high-quality care, an interim report issued Friday by the Institute of Medicine concluded.

headline: Cuban Dissident Calls to End Embargo
abstract: Blogger and activist Yoani Sánchez regularly condemns the Cuban regime from her home in Havana. On her first trip abroad in nearly a decade, she also called for an end to the American embargo.
lead_paragraph: Blogger and activist Yoani Sánchez regularly condemns the Cuban regime from her home in Havana. On her first trip abroad in nearly a decade, she also called for an end to the American embargo.

headline: Cultural Capital
abstract: Travel is about seeing new things, and also familiar things in a new way.
lead_paragraph: This issue starts off in America, or at least an idea of America. Brooklyn, N.Y., has, as we all know, become a bastion of handcrafted, locally sourced, small-scale-production everything, from bikes to beer.
