The irony is that this passion for authenticity, diversity and a longing for realness have now turned what was once just a borough into a global brand, one that is vigorously being exported around the world: France, Russia, the United Arab Emirates. The local has gone global, or in other words, anti-homogenization is itself now being homogenized: In Paris you find food trucks, in Gorky Park a snack kiosk called Williamsburg, there is a Brooklyn Diner in Dubai, and even the native beer, Brooklyn Brewery, is planning an outpost in Stockholm — how local is that? When a value system based on unscalability starts to scale, it may be time to turn to other locales for a sense of uniqueness and locally grown culture.

headline: Ribaldry Before the Code
abstract: New on DVD: the comedies of Bert Wheeler and Robert Woolsey.
lead_paragraph: BERT WHEELER and Robert Woolsey made 21 feature films together (and a couple separately) between 1929 and 1937. They were one of the most popular comedy teams of a decade that knew several great ones, and yet today they are almost unknown, except to cinephiles who make a habit of exploring the uncharted overnight territory of the Turner Classic Movies channel.

headline: Bausch & Lomb Plans I.P.O.
abstract: Bausch & Lomb, the eye-care company, said in an I.P.O. registration filing that Warburg Pincus would continue to own a majority of the stock after the offering.
lead_paragraph: Bausch & Lomb, the eye-care company primarily owned by Warburg Pincus, filed documents on Friday to go public again.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Israel, Myanmar and Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Israel, Myanmar and Cyprus.

headline: This Week’s Movies: March 22
abstract: Times critics on “Admission,” “Olympus Has Fallen” and “Gimme the Loot.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “Admission,” “Olympus Has Fallen” and “Gimme the Loot.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Nigerians React to News of Achebe’s Death
abstract: Cultural and political figures weigh in on the legacy of Chinua Achebe, author of “Things Fall Apart.”
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria— The news of the death of Chinua Achebe, the influential Nigerian author renowned for his novel “Things Fall Apart,” reverberated across the country’s cultural and political circles on Friday. “I must say it’s a most painful death for me,” said Odia Ofeimun, a poet and the former president of Association of Nigerian Authors. “Just when we were learning to argue with him, he died.”

headline: Ch-Ch-Ch Changes of David Bowie
abstract: The exhibition “David Bowie Is,” at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, looks to show the many guises Mr. Bowie has created over a nearly 50-year career.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A photograph hangs inconspicuously near the entrance of “David Bowie Is,” a Victoria and Albert Museum exhibition opening on Saturday that has already sold a record number of tickets. It shows the young man who began life as David Jones, seated, in a dark suit and tie, with a leg propped up on his chair, beneath which sits a drum bearing the name of his band, the Kon-rads. One hand grips a saxophone, the other rests delicately against his face, and he looks out at the world with a mesmerizing blend of reserve and come-hither allure.

headline: Israeli Students Reflect on Obama’s Speech
abstract: President Obama gave a fervent address to students from universities in Israel on Thursday during his first presidential trip to the country. Some of the students shared their views of the speech with The Times.
lead_paragraph: President Obama gave a fervent address to students from universities in Israel on Thursday during his first presidential trip to the country. Some of the students shared their views of the speech with The Times.

headline: Yoko Ono Details Why She Posted Lennon’s Bloodied Glasses on Twitter
abstract: Yoko Ono explains her antigun message on Twitter and why she shared a photo of the blood-spattered spectacles her husband was wearing when he was killed in 1980.
lead_paragraph: On what would have been her 44th wedding anniversary Wednesday, Yoko Ono said, she walked through a park, remembering how much she and her husband, John Lennon, had laughed and smiled on their wedding day. “Then I felt the emptiness more acutely because of the beautiful memory,” she said.

headline: Bowie on Display
abstract: A look back at a David Bowie career retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London in 2013.
lead_paragraph: A look back at a David Bowie career retrospective at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London in 2013.

headline: The Hall, a Player as Important as the Strings
abstract: Bernard Labadie was one of four conductors to apply his approach to the New York Philharmonic’s Bach Variations festival at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Bach Variations festival, which the New York Philharmonic is presenting through April 6, is built on a question: Should large symphony orchestras still play Bach, now that there are so many ensembles specializing in the historically informed performance of Baroque music? With four conductors from different backgrounds — Alan Gilbert, Andras Schiff, Masaaki Suzuki and Bernard Labadie — the Philharmonic also looks at the question of how. What they failed to address is the where.

headline: Obama in the Mideast: Sampling the Reviews
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article and an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Comeuppance of a Reprobate, With Hints of Gluck’s Glory to Come
abstract: The Little Opera Theater presents a rare and stylish production of Gluck’s “Ivrogne Corrigé” (“Reformed Drunkard”), translated into English by Philip Shneidman and Ivana Mestrovic.
lead_paragraph: Among the 50-odd operas written by Gluck, to say nothing of myriad variants and other hybrid entertainments, only a handful tend to show up on the modern stage. Almost invariably these are the so-called “reform” works of Gluck’s later years, like “Orfeo ed Euridice,” “Alceste” and the two Iphigénie operas, all composed between 1762 and 1779.

headline: Low-Income Students and Elite Schools
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Guidance Counselors', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Readers react to an article about high-performing students who choose to stay close to home for college.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fastidious Percussion With Plenty of Electronics
abstract: Tyondai Braxton’s “Hive,” billed as a concert and an installation, filled the Guggenheim Museum’s atrium on Thursday with zips, swoops and ever faster beats.
lead_paragraph: Five pedestals stood in the atrium of the Guggenheim Museum on Thursday night: perforated, metallic-looking bases, lighted from within, supporting oval platforms, each large enough to hold one musician surrounded by equipment. It was the architect Uffe Surland Van Tams’s setup for Tyondai Braxton’s “Hive,” billed as “part installation/part band” by the Guggenheim’s Works & Process series and Wordless Music, which presented it.

headline: Coyote Hunting in Utah
abstract: A $50 bounty to control the coyote population in Utah has hunters excited, environmentalists crying foul and state wildlife administrators stuck somewhere in the middle.
lead_paragraph: A $50 bounty to control the coyote population in Utah has hunters excited, environmentalists crying foul and state wildlife administrators stuck somewhere in the middle.

headline: Amid ‘Kill’ Chants, Croatia and Serbia Set Peaceful Example
abstract: For 90 minutes at least, and despite ugly chants in a tension-filled stadium, peace prevailed on the soccer field in a World Cup qualifying match between the two national teams.
lead_paragraph: ZAGREB, Croatia — For all the talk of conciliation, for all the pleas for tolerance before the game and for all the statements from players and coaches that the war should take a back seat to the soccer, the crowd at the Maksimir Stadium in Zagreb found it harder to forget and forgive on Friday.

headline: Interview With Cuban Blogger Yoani Sánchez
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Cuban-Americans', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations']
abstract: Yoani Sánchez, a Cuban dissident, is on an 80-day international tour after the Cuban government allowed her to leave the country for the first time in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Saturday, 9:10 p.m. Yoani Sánchez stepped out of a coffee shop in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York and quickly pulled a winter hat over her head, covering about three inches of her waist-length brown hair. “This is my disguise,” she said, “It’s not working.”

headline: A Plan to Demolish Libraries to Save Them
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers express concern about a New York City proposal to rebuild public institutions by making deals with developers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Sameness of Their Differences
abstract: Marjani Forté’s “being Here...” takes a brave look at the ravages of mental illness and addiction.
lead_paragraph: In the darkness the sound might be crying or laughter. Brightening lights reveal a woman sitting in a pile of feathers. She laughs hysterically. She hyperventilates. One fit subsides, only to be followed by another. Pain seems to rack her body, as if she were giving birth. She screams.

headline: The Sly Coyote Becomes a Bounty Hunters’ Target in Utah
abstract: An incentive program in Utah to curb the coyote population has provoked enthusiasm from hunters and concern from environmentalists.
lead_paragraph: OGDEN, Utah — Spencer Glauser, who started hunting as a boy perched on his father’s shoulders, is an unabashed coyote hater. “One’s too many” to have roaming the mountains and encroaching on towns, he said.

headline: No Disciplinary Hearing for Nash; Rangers Waive Halpern
abstract: Rick Nash, the Rangers’ top scorer, will not face suspension for the leaping elbow he delivered to the back of Tomas Kopecky’s head in a loss to Florida on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Rick Nash, the Rangers’ top scorer, will not face suspension for the leaping elbow he delivered to the back of Tomas Kopecky’s head in a 3-1 loss to the Florida Panthers on Thursday night.

headline: Movie Review | 'Gimme The Loot'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Gimme The Loot."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Gimme The Loot."

headline: T Spring Travel 2013
abstract: “America and Beyond” is the theme of the spring travel issue of T.
lead_paragraph: “America and Beyond” is the theme of the spring travel issue of T. Start off locally with “Modernism Is the Message,” a look at fashion’s new minimalism, as seen through the eyes of the photographer Mario Sorrenti. Then read Simon Romero’s piece on how São Paulo, Brazil’s largest city, is being redefined. There’s also a report on Seoul, the South Korean capital that is becoming the fashionable intrigue of the Far East, and an essay on the exportation of Brooklyn, which has transformed the borough from landmass into global phenomenon. As you hopscotch around the globe, don’t forget to read Alexandra Marshall’s dispatch on the young chefs revolutionizing Paris, Christian Louboutin’s travel diary of his visit to the Marrakesh film festival or “Matches as Memories,” which rounds up the perfect hotel souvenirs that may also be the most anachronistic: matchbooks.See more from the issue >>

headline: Creating ‘Cosmos’
abstract: Neil deGrasse Tyson, the director of the Hayden Planetarium, credits Ann Druyan, widow of Carl Sagan, as the main creative force behind a new version of the show.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Breaking It Down: Nieminen vs. Nalbandian
abstract: In a shocking contrast of form, Jarkko Nieminen’s previously wayward shots all started landing in a bizarre comeback victory against David Nalbandian at the Sony Open.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–The match was over.

headline: Tower at O’Hare May Be a Victim of Federal Cuts
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said it would close 149 control towers at smaller airports, but even an O’Hare International Airport tower in Chicago could be affected.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Up 14 stories by elevator and two more by stairs, Adonna Prior, an air traffic controller, watched for airplanes emerging as specks in the sky from her perch at the top of O’Hare International Airport’s sleek $40 million north tower.

headline: There’s a Word for a Movie Like This
abstract: “InAPPropriate Comedy,” with Adrien Brody, Rob Schneider and Michelle Rodriguez, tries to be a parody of bigoted offensiveness, but succeeds only in being deeply unfunny.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a movie is so awful that the word awful is not up to the task of conveying its awfulness. The awful “InAPPropriate Comedy” is such a movie. It is memorably awful. It is stunningly awful. It is so awful that we are fortunate that “awful” has an adverbial use that means “very” or “extremely.” This movie is awfully awful.

headline: Cholera in Haiti
abstract: The aid group AmeriCares responds to an editorial, “A Worsening Haitian Tragedy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Goes Well With Swagger
abstract: Vito Schnabel, an independent curator, fell hard for a cowboy shirt.
lead_paragraph: DURING THIS BRIEF LULL between New York’s two dueling monster art fairs, the recent Armory Show and the forthcoming Frieze, one wonders about the accuracy of the genteel, old-fashioned term, “the art world.”

headline: Major League Baseball v. Biogenesis of America
abstract: Major League Baseball ton Friday of filed a lawsuit in Florida state court that accuses six people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic of damaging the sport when they provided various players with performance-enhancing substances.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball ton Friday of filed a lawsuit in Florida state court that accuses six people connected to a South Florida anti-aging clinic of damaging the sport when they provided various players with performance-enhancing substances.

headline: Obsessed? You’re Not Alone
abstract: When and why did this verb, which once connoted a serious psychological disorder, become hijacked by the fashionable young of America?
lead_paragraph: Sharing an Amtrak car recently with four chatty debutantes on their way to a cotillion in Boston, powerless not to eavesdrop, I started cataloging all the vernacular expressions they emphatically overused, transcribing the choicest dialogue to Facebook. (“They’re just jealous of her.” “They’re jealous.” “Because she’s pretty. And has a nice personality.” “She’s pretty.” “So jealous.”) But the short phrase that so got my attention was “I’m obsessed.”

headline: Week in Pictures for March 22
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a St. Patrick’s Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a St. Patrick’s Day parade on Staten Island; the closing of a Queens stable; and the city comptroller, John C. Liu, on the campaign trail.

headline: A Weekend in the Country: Britain’s Power Elite at Play
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Chipping Norton, a Tory stronghold in rural Oxfordshire, is London’s amped-up version of the Hamptons, but one whose social fabric has been frayed by recent media scandals.
lead_paragraph: Chipping Norton, England — The power centers of British politics and media may reside in London, but their tentacles extend to a tiny working-class market town with rows of glistening stone buildings, 17th-century pubs and a medieval church.

headline: Wealthy Russians Ensnared as Cyprus Crisis Deepens
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: About 25 percent of Russian foreign direct investment moves through Cyprus, according to an estimate, often in a way meant to lubricate Russia’s economy.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two decades ago, Dmitry E. Rybolovlev was a small-town hustler hoping to strike it rich amid the collapse of the Soviet Union. Today, he is one of the wealthiest men in the world, with a penthouse in Monaco, a yacht named “My Anna” worth more than $100 million, and two of the most expensive private residences in the United States.

headline: Words and War: Toni Morrison at West Point
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Students at West Point attended a reading by Toni Morrison on Friday, where she read from her novel “Home,” which centers on a Korean War veteran.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — As thousands of hungry West Point cadets streamed into the mess hall for their 20-minute lunch break here on Friday, they paused from the rush to the tables to give a rousing group cheer to a guest who has received hundreds of accolades, but perhaps none this thunderous.

headline: Some Sour Music for Horwitz
abstract: In a post on his new Twitter account, the Mets’ public relations director seemed to forget about R.A. Dickey.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jay Horwitz, the Mets’ public relations director got into some hot water with fans this week because of something he posted on his new Twitter account.

headline: Sheepsquatch, Pulling the Wool Over Your Eyes
abstract: According to “Monsters and Mysteries in America,” there are more than sasquatches and aliens to beware of: there are sheepsquatches and the mothman.
lead_paragraph: Television’s baser purveyors can’t get enough of the endlessly futile search for bigfoots, extraterrestrials and ghosts, but credit the newest show in the genre, “Monsters and Mysteries in America,” with at least recognizing that those Big Three have received a disproportionate amount of attention. It seems to realize that we haven’t heard nearly enough about the sheepsquatch infestation.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Netflix TV, and Bitcoins for Drugs
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include making Web sites accessible to people with disabilities, why Eric Schmidt uses a BlackBerry instead of an Android device, and posts about the firing of a man for questionable remarks and of the woman who reported him.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Doctors and a Prescription for Trouble
abstract: Another Atlanta reality show, “Married to Medicine,” on Bravo, follows doctors and spouses of doctors.
lead_paragraph: Will the last woman in Atlanta who is not being followed by a camera crew please raise her hand?

headline: Relics of the Bygone (and the Illegal)
abstract: The numbers game is dwindling, even in Harlem, once its stronghold, but it’s not obsolete.
lead_paragraph: Someone knocked on the door of the basement apartment on East 115th Street on March 13. A man let him in. A detective watched, and arrested the man who had opened the door.

headline: After Withdrawing, Harvard Star Roots From Afar
abstract: Harvard’s co-captains withdrew last fall in order to preserve their eligibility during an investigation into a cheating scandal. They say they’re happy for the team, which won on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of college basketball fans across the country were rooting for Harvard on Thursday night when it upset third-seeded New Mexico, 68-62, in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 64. There was no bigger supporter than Brandyn Curry, who was watching the game with his family in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Quarterfinals
abstract: The Rockwell Mixed Pairs in St. Louis on Wednesday evening were won by a married couple, Paul and Linda Lewis of Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The Rockwell Mixed Pairs here on Wednesday evening were won by a married couple, Paul and Linda Lewis of Las Vegas. They finished one-third of a board ahead of Barbara Lehman of Glenview, Ill., and Craig Jacobson of Skokie, Ill. Third were Jenni Carmichael of Kennesaw, Ga., and Greg Humphreys of Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops
abstract: Cheer up!
lead_paragraph: I was going to post something substantive, but first I had tech problems (an hour on the phone with NY Times support), then internet access problems, so enough for today. Here’s some cheerful stuff from a group people have been telling me to give a listen.

headline: Where Citizenship Went to Die
abstract: A new Constitution resolves who gets to be a Zimbabwean.
lead_paragraph: Harare, Zimbabwe

headline: Orders Cut, as Publisher and Retailer Quarrel
abstract: Barnes & Noble has reduced its orders of Simon & Schuster titles, authors and agents say, because of a dispute between the two over the price of books and display space in retail stores.
lead_paragraph: A standoff over financial terms has prompted the bookstore chain Barnes & Noble to cut back substantially on the number of titles it orders from the publishing house Simon & Schuster, raising fears among other publishers, agents and authors that the conflict may harm the publishing industry as a whole.

headline: Pennsylvania: Environment Secretary Resigns
abstract: Michael Krancer, the state environment secretary, will step down next month to return to private law practice, Gov. Tom Corbett said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Michael Krancer, the state environment secretary, will step down next month to return to private law practice, Gov. Tom Corbett said Friday. Since taking office in January 2011, Mr. Krancer, 55, has been accused by environmentalists of lax regulation of Pennsylvania’s booming oil and gas industry, and of reporting incomplete results of water tests from private wells near gas sites. Mr. Corbett, a Republican, praised Mr. Krancer’s efforts to stop gas companies from sending wastewater to treatment plants that were not equipped to process it, as well as his role in keeping open three refineries that were in danger of being closed.

headline: Ex-President of Pakistan to End Exile in Bid to Regain Influence
abstract: In an effort to aid his fledgling political party, Pervez Musharraf said he would return on Sunday to Pakistan, where he faces stiff opposition and criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani military lore is obsessed with the romance of the daredevil commando, parachuting into hostile territory and taking the fight to the enemy despite daunting odds.

headline: Pope Cancels Newspaper Delivery Back Home in Argentina
abstract: “Seriously, it’s Jorge Bergoglio, I’m calling you from Rome,” the new pope insisted in a call to Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, apparently working down his to-do list since taking his new position, made a call to his local newspaper kiosk in Buenos Aires this week to cancel his daily delivery and send his greetings, according to a report from the Catholic News Agency.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wild Ones
abstract: At the Paris fashion shows earlier this month, the biker’s jacket was prominent on many in the audience.
lead_paragraph: At the Paris fashion shows earlier this month, the biker’s jacket was prominent on many in the audience.

headline: Boeheim Still Defiant, Whether or Not End Is Near
abstract: Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim has led a charmed life on the court, but if the N.C.A.A. puts the university on probation, now seems as good a time as any for him to retire.
lead_paragraph: San Jose, Calif.

headline: Italy’s President Asks Center-Left Party to Form Government
keywords: ['Elections', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy has asked the center-left Democratic Party to try to form a government, but political analysts predict that will be difficult.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A month after national elections failed to yield a clear result, President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy on Friday asked the leader of the Democratic Party to try to form a government, but only if he meets the challenge of mustering a strong enough majority to govern.

headline: Girls Excel in the Classroom but Lag in Entry to 8 Elite Schools in the City
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Gender', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: More girls than boys have been going to college for years now, but at one set of prestigious public schools in New York City, it’s the girls who are lagging.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, girls have outshined boys in high school for years, amassing more A’s, earning more diplomas and gliding more readily into college, where they rack up more degrees — whether at the bachelor’s, master’s or doctoral levels.

headline: Waking Up to the Enduring Memory of Rape
abstract: I was raped at 16, but I didn’t tell my parents until I was 27. The case in Steubenville, Ohio, and stories like mine, are common in part because we keep quiet about them.
lead_paragraph: Memphis

headline: A Look at Pablo Berger’s ‘Blancanieves’
abstract: The black-and-white silent film “Blancanieves” sets the story of Snow White amid a bullfighting milieu in Seville, Spain, in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: The black-and-white silent film “Blancanieves” sets the story of Snow White amid a bullfighting milieu in Seville, Spain, in the 1920s.

headline: For Musicians, the Most Prized Violins Are for Borrowing, Not Buying
abstract: The market for instruments by the old masters of Cremona is now dominated not by soloists, but by foundations and hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: The din inside the Metropolitan Pavilion in Chelsea recently was that of any crowded trade fair, except for the snippets of music that wove in and out of the roar of voices.

headline: ‘Tonight Show’ to New York? Local Comics Applaud
abstract: Comedians based in New York see a boon if reports that “The Tonight Show” will return to the city prove true.
lead_paragraph: Even though the influence, buzz and relevance of network talk shows has waned, make no mistake, “The Tonight Show” still matters, particularly to comedy.

headline: The Bullpen Bloomberg Built: Candidates Debate Its Future
abstract: In ways that betrayed much about their own personalities, mayoral candidates criticized Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s preference for working surrounded by staff members.
lead_paragraph: It is the ultimate symbol of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s management style, borrowed from Wall Street, plunked incongruously into the middle of City Hall and studied by everyone from M.B.A. students to visiting heads of state.

headline: Bud Palmer, Jump Shot Pioneer, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Palmer gained fame as a sports telecaster, but his most consequential role was in helping to change basketball in a fundamental way by being the first to shoot a jump shot.
lead_paragraph: Bud Palmer gained fame as a sports telecaster, covering everything from the Olympics to dog shows. He was Mayor John V. Lindsay’s official greeter, welcoming dignitaries to the city. He was the first writer of Glamour magazine’s “Ask Jake” column, offering women advice from a man’s viewpoint. (“Don’t show up drunk for a dinner date.”) And he was the first captain of the New York Knicks.

headline: The Rat Pack, Fondly Recalled
abstract: “Swing This,” Debby Boone’s show at Café Carlyle, featured songs from the Rat Pack era.
lead_paragraph: She was a just toddler when her father, Pat Boone, was a Las Vegas headliner who hobnobbed with the Rat Pack. But the singer Debby Boone had her eyes and ears wide open, and she remembers things like the look of Sammy Davis Jr.’s house and Dean Martin’s jokes about her father’s teetotaling. And on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle Ms. Boone, glamorized to the max, was the very picture of a tastefully attired Las Vegas babe as she devoted an entire program to songs of the Rat Pack era in a show titled “Swing This.” The swing was provided by an excellent nine-member band under the direction of John Oddo, the longtime musical director of Ms. Boone’s mother-in-law, Rosemary Clooney.

headline: Tight Deadlines and Lagging Funds Bedevil Obama Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)']
abstract: Supporters of the law say President Obama has done little to trumpet its benefits, educate the public or answer the critics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was another turbulent week for President Obama’s health care law. Congress rejected a White House request for nearly $1 billion to carry out the law, even as federal responsibilities increased to include the supervision of insurance markets in more than half the states. Then, on Friday, Republican attacks on the law continued in the Senate, where Democrats beat back Republican proposals to repeal the law and many of its tax increases.

headline: Artistic Touches in Mexican Food
abstract: A takeout stand that was transformed into a lively full-scale restaurant is buoyed by its chef, who balances the traditional and the inventive.
lead_paragraph: The last great Mexican meal I ate was in 2004, at La Super-Rica Taqueria in Santa Barbara, Calif., whose most famous patron was Julia Child. The lines were endless.

headline: Police Storm Squatters at Rio Stadium Site
keywords: ['World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Olympic Games (2016)', 'Indigenous People', 'Land Use Policies', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: At the home of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics, the clash highlighted tension over evictions in areas scheduled for development.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian police on Friday stormed the work site of Maracanã, the venerable soccer stadium under renovation ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics, in an attempt to end a standoff with more than 20 indigenous protesters who had squatted for years in an adjacent building that once housed Brazil’s first Indian Museum.

headline: Opening With a Clang, a Rebel Recovers
abstract: Marshall Henderson missed 12 of his first 13 field-goal attempts but kept shooting, helping Mississippi upset Wisconsin in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 64.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The 3-point attempt clanged high off the rim, again, and the standout Mississippi shooting guard Marshall Henderson ran downcourt shaking his head. Great, he thought. I’m finally playing in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and now I stink.

headline: Egypt: Dozens Injured in Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Dozens of people were injured Friday when thousands of supporters and opponents of the ruling Muslim Brotherhood clashed outside the group’s Cairo headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were injured Friday when thousands of supporters and opponents of the ruling Muslim Brotherhood clashed outside the group’s Cairo headquarters, many of them armed with weapons like meat cleavers, cattle prods and pistols. The police fired tear gas as protesters tried to approach the headquarters. Anti-Brotherhood protesters also attacked the offices of the Freedom and Justice Party, the Brotherhood’s political wing, in Alexandria and Mahalla, according to local reports. The confrontations in Cairo were among the most violent between Brotherhood supporters and opponents since deadly clashes outside the presidential palace in December. For months, opposition groups and protesters have called on President Mohamed Morsi, above, a former Brotherhood leader, to make political concessions, including replacing his cabinet with a national unity government. Mr. Morsi has resisted those calls, deepening Egypt’s political stalemate.

headline: Bearing Witness, With Words
abstract: Chinua Achebe examined colonialism and masculinity with a sensitive understanding about how culture functions and what it means.
lead_paragraph: “If you don’t like someone’s story,” Chinua Achebe told The Paris Review in 1994, “write your own.”

headline: Sectarian Violence Spreads in Myanmar
abstract: Clashes between Buddhists and Muslims spread to villages outside a city in central Myanmar on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Clashes between Buddhists and Muslims spread to villages outside a city in central Myanmar on Friday.

headline: Williams’s Star Shined in Knicks Guard Tandem
abstract: Ray Williams, a former Knicks and Nets player who died Friday, partnered with Micheal Ray Richardson in a backcourt that reached the playoffs but dissolved because of excessive partying.
lead_paragraph: Ray Williams and Micheal Ray Richardson parted ways years ago, not by choice, and in Richardson’s mind, much too soon.

headline: Left Behind: Johan Santana
abstract: The Mets’ left-hander, who has not pitched in a spring training game, will continue to condition his arm at the Mets’ facility in Florida.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla — Johan Santana will continue conditioning his arm at the Mets’ spring training facility here when the rest of his teammates depart for New York at the end of the month, Manager Terry Collins said Friday.

headline: At Virginia Commonwealth, a Defense That Is Called Havoc
abstract: Virginia Commonwealth runs its own brand of smothering defense, frustrating opponents and setting up easy baskets.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — To end practice Wednesday, Shaka Smart stood at midcourt and had his Virginia Commonwealth team — players, assistant coaches, trainers, everyone else — line up in the paint.

headline: Man Killed in Brooklyn Shooting; Three Are Wounded
abstract: The shooting occurred just before 4 p.m. at the Gravesend Houses, a public-housing project. The suspect remained at large on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Four people were shot — one fatally — in an apartment at a Coney Island housing project on Friday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Eager Rebounder From Iran Powers Oregon With Double-Doubles
abstract: Arsalan Kazemi, a 6-foot-7 senior forward, piles up double-doubles for the Ducks, who meet the St. Louis Billikens on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Arsalan Kazemi’s father owns a candy factory, churning out gaz, a nougat-and-pistachio concoction that visitors to Esfahan, Iran, buy as a souvenir. When Kazemi comes home in the summer, for just a week or so, his father gives him some to bring back to the United States.

headline: World Cup Qualifying: U.S. vs. Costa Rica
abstract: His choices limited by injuries, Coach Jurgen Klinsmann announced a remade lineup for Friday night’s World Cup qualifier against Costa Rica at Commerce City, Colo.
lead_paragraph: It was wild, and it was wintry, but it was a win. The United States national team righted its teetering World Cup qualifying campaign with a 1-0 win over Costa Rica on Friday night in Commerce City, Colo., in a game that nearly descended into farce as inch after inch of snow piled up.

headline: Los Angeles Mayor Is Leaving Without Car, Job or Regrets
abstract: Antonio R. Villaraigosa faces life as a private citizen in Los Angeles after eight years in office, but he is not ruling out more public service.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Antonio R. Villaraigosa has been a mayor whom this city loves to love and loves to hate. The red carpets. The late-night parties. The lofty promises, many met and some not. The disintegration of a marriage and a relationship with a television reporter while in office, all covered with the flashbulb ferocity befitting a Hollywood personality.

headline: Lebanese Premier Resigns as Syrian War Fuels Sectarian Split
keywords: ['Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Najib Mikati resigned on Friday and called for a unity government to rescue Lebanon from deepening divisions over the war in Syria, which threatens to spill over the border.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s prime minister resigned on Friday and called for a national unity government to rescue the country from deepening sectarian divisions over the war in neighboring Syria, which threatens to spill over the border. Lebanon’s most powerful political factions back opposite sides in the Syrian conflict.

headline: A Menu in Harmony With the Cocktails
abstract: 116 Crown was always trendy, but with the help of a new chef, Will Talamelli, it has quietly transformed itself into a first-class restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Since it opened in 2007, 116 Crown, a hip, urban place in Ninth Square in New Haven, has been known for its striking onyx bar and inventive cocktails. Now, with the help of a new chef, it is quietly reinventing itself as a first-class restaurant. John Ginnetti, who owns 116 Crown with his wife, Danielle, said he knew it would be a challenge: “When you walk in, there’s this giant glowing bar. We knew that would work against us as a dinner place.”

headline: Prestigious High Schools, Testing and Gender
abstract: New York City high schools that rely entirely on the eighth-grade Specialized High School Admissions Test tend to have fewer female students.
lead_paragraph: New York City high schools that rely entirely on the eighth-grade Specialized High School Admissions Test tend to have fewer female students.

headline: A Rare Dive Into His Own Songbook
abstract: At the Iridium on Wednesday, the pianist George Cables seemed intent on reinvigorating some lesser-known tunes in his repertory.
lead_paragraph: The pianist George Cables ended his first set at the Iridium on Wednesday night with “My Muse,” a compact tune with the kind of crisp, sunny melody that might have made it a staple in the age of jukeboxes and roller rinks. Over a percolating rock beat, he played the theme jauntily, saving all his flash for a cascading solo that started fast and never flagged. If the song carried a burden of sentiment, he wasn’t about to let it show.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 22, 2013

headline: Senate Democrats Offer a Budget, Then the Amendments Fly
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Senators on both sides of the aisle offered hundreds of changes, most of them largely meaningless, in a marathon session known as the “vote-orama.”
lead_paragraph: An updated version of this article can be found here.

headline: Darlings of Yore Hear the Cheers, but Not for Them
abstract: While Harvard captured its first-ever N.C.A.A. tournament victory, over New Mexico, top-seeded Gonzaga barely scraped by with a six-point win over No. 16 Southern University.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — The N.C.A.A. tournament unfolded here as if in some sort of parallel universe: the conversation dominated by Gonzaga, the spotlight stolen by Harvard.

headline: Beyond the Cheese, a Quirky World of Flavors
abstract: The pleasures at Mint, which began life as a gourmet food shop, reside in its ambience as much as its food.
lead_paragraph: Mint Premium Foods began life as a gourmet food shop, and when entering the Tarrytown restaurant one is met by a display case containing huge chunks of delicious cheese, bowls of salty, fragrant olives and shelves of imported sauces, pastas and crackers. If you’re lucky, the elegant proprietor, Hassan Jarane, will offer you a slice of Pickwick Cheddar with caramelized onion, a pesto basil Gouda or a subtle truffle cheese from Tuscany.

headline: Walking While Black in New York
abstract: Testimony in a stop-and-frisk trial has pointed to disturbing conduct by the police command.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Police Department has a long history of violating constitutional rights by stopping, questioning or frisking people on the streets without legal justification. The city has steadfastly denied that the detentions — made under its increasingly unpopular stop-and-frisk program — have been based on race.

headline: Watchman at the Water’s Edge
abstract: Bird life continues at Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge after Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Two bird-watchers moved camera-ready through the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge last week, grateful that the first ospreys had arrived at their familiar nests after flying 2,600 miles from winter roosts in South America. The fish hawks hungrily plied the bay’s resources as jetliners traversed the horizon across the way at Kennedy Airport. But the birders were more intent on investigating worrisome breaches in the refuge’s earthen walls caused by Hurricane Sandy. Would that affect the comings and goings this year of the multitudes of aquatic and meadow birds that favor the 13,000-acre preserve?

headline: Keep Guns Out of Criminal Hands
abstract: A vote is scheduled for one of the most important measures to reduce gun violence.
lead_paragraph: The Senate, at long last, will take up a package of gun-control measures when it returns from recess next month. On Thursday, the majority leader, Harry Reid, announced that one of those measures will require almost all gun buyers to undergo a background check. This is a vital step that would help keep guns out of the wrong hands, and it deserves far more bipartisan support than it has received.

headline: Overdue Reconciliation
abstract: At President Obama’s urging, Israel and Turkey have chosen a wiser course and restored diplomatic relations.
lead_paragraph: President Obama concluded a successful visit to Israel on Friday by helping broker an end to the self-defeating standoff between two American allies, Israel and Turkey. The breakthrough is a credit to both prime ministers, Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, but it is also a sign that Mr. Obama, criticized as “leading from behind” on foreign policy, is prepared to engage more directly in international affairs.

headline: A Favorite Is One of the First to Go
abstract: In its first trip to the N.C.A.A. tournament, 15th-seeded Florida Gulf Coast defeated Georgetown, a perennial power and No. 2 seed.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The final two and a half minutes were, in Andy Enfield’s estimation, the longest two and a half minutes of his life. The game could not end soon enough, not with the way Georgetown was making 3-pointers and chipping away at Florida Gulf Coast’s lead.

headline: Among 200 Wines, Local Reds Shine
abstract: Eight Long Island producers joined 32 vintners from other regions in at New York Drinks New York, a public tasting in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: LONG ISLAND REDS shone when eight of the Island’s producers joined 32 vintners from other wine regions on Monday in New York Drinks New York, a public tasting of more than 200 wines.

headline: Corrections: March 23, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Spiral-Horned Antelope
abstract: A Saturday brain-strainer by David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This one was a brain-breaker for me, but it was ultimately doable.

headline: Mary and the Zombies: Consciousness Revisited
abstract: The author responds to readers’ theories on whether consciousness can be explained by science.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the nearly 800 readers who submitted comments on last week’s column, “Mary and the Zombies: Can Science Explain Consciousness?”  Together they produced over 100,000 words (a good sized book).  The column summarized two widely discussed arguments against understanding consciousness as entirely physical: the Mary Argument and the Zombie Argument.

headline: North Dakota to Put End to Abortions on the Ballot
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Constitutional Amendments']
abstract: A measure allowing the public to decide whether the State Constitution should assert that life begins at conception will appear on next year’s ballot.
lead_paragraph: North Dakota lawmakers passed a resolution on Friday to allow the public to decide whether the State Constitution should assert that life begins at conception, a move that would essentially ban all abortions in the state.

headline: Iceland: Prosecutor Issues Charges Over Collapse of 2 Banks in 2008
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A special prosecutor in Iceland issued indictments this week against the chief executives and 14 other employees of two banks whose spectacular collapse in 2008 sent the Icelandic economy into a tailspin.
lead_paragraph: A special prosecutor in Iceland issued indictments this week against the chief executives and 14 other employees of two banks whose spectacular collapse during the financial crisis of 2008 sent the Icelandic economy into a tailspin. In one of the world’s most ambitious prosecutions stemming from the crisis, the 16 people are being charged with manipulating the financial markets and with putting their institutions in jeopardy by flouting internal rules. Among other things, the indictment says they issued loans to friendly companies that in turn used the loans to buy shares in the banks, elevating their stock prices. The people charged could face up to six years in prison if convicted.

headline: A Lifelong Colorado State Fan, From Horns to Tail
abstract: An allegiance to the Colorado State Rams has transformed Justin Stank, 16, into the university’s most recognizable fan and unofficial mascot.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — At the Stank family home in Greeley, Colo., there is a picture of a 6-month-old Justin lodged in the mouth of a bulldog.

headline: Saving Children From Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Biometrics', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: If we can insist that aspirin bottles be childproof, why not guns?
lead_paragraph: For nearly two months, my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I have been publishing a daily blog in which we aggregate articles about shootings from the previous day. Of all the stories we link to, the ones I find hardest to read are those about young children who accidentally shoot themselves or another child. They just break my heart. Yet Jennifer and I find new examples almost every day.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Bachmann Problem
abstract: The Republican Party is experiencing an existential crisis, born of its own misguided incongruity with modern American culture.
lead_paragraph: The current intramural squabbling on the right is just too delicious for words. At least for nice words.

headline: Database Is Shut Down by NASA for a Review
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security']
abstract: As part of a security investigation, the agency shut down a large public database used by professionals and students, and it restricted foreign nationals’ access to its facilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — NASA has shut down a large public database and is limiting access to agency facilities by foreign citizens as part of a broader investigation into efforts by China and other countries to get information about important technology.

headline: Teeing Off at Edge of the Arctic? A Chinese Plan Baffles Iceland
abstract: An Icelandic frontier village, eyed by a Chinese billionaire for a golf resort, is the setting for a drama involving intrigue, millions of dollars and a swarm of conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: GRIMSSTADIR, Iceland — Struggling to stand upright against a howling wind, Bragi Benediktsson looked out over his family’s land — a barren expanse of snow and ice that a Chinese billionaire wants to turn into a golf course — and laughed. “Golf here is difficult,” said Mr. Benediktsson, a 75-year-old sheep farmer.

headline: Looking Beyond a Restaurant’s Charm
abstract: BlonDee’s Bistro and Bar opened in August under the name Two Blondes and a Stove. The restaurant now serves dinner.
lead_paragraph: A breakfast and lunch spot called Two Blondes and a Stove, which opened in August in Huntington Village, N.Y., changed its name and its ambitions within six months or so of its opening. Now called BlonDee’s Bistro and Bar, it is also serving dinner.

headline: New Jersey Wins Fight Against a Tiny Invader
abstract: After 11 years, during which 20,000 trees were removed, the state has eradicated the Asian long-horned beetle.
lead_paragraph: LINDEN, N.J. — The enemy forces were numerous, numbering in the thousands. They were particularly adept at hidden warfare. The fight, which endured for more than a decade, was complicated by the difficulty of detection, with the invader measuring an inch and a half, tops.

headline: Kansas Survives Against 16th Seed; La Salle Upsets Kansas State
abstract: Jeff Withey’s shot-blocking and inside scoring in the second half Friday enabled Kansas to hold off Western Kentucky becoming the first No. 1 seed to lose to a No. 16 in the men’s tournament.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The 7-footer Jeff Withey’s shot-blocking and inside scoring in the second half Friday enabled Kansas to hold off Western Kentucky, 64-57, and avoid the upset of upsets as the first No. 1 seed to lose to a No. 16 in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: A lawsuit over allowing immigrants to obtain a driver’s license in Arizona is part of a broader clash with an Obama administration program offering reprieves from deportation.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — At a hearing on Friday on a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of an order that would keep some young immigrants from getting driver’s licenses, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona again found herself trying to prove that her policies are not discriminatory.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty in Theft at Masa
abstract: Rafael Thomas, a former bookkeeper at the restaurant, one of the city’s most expensive, pleaded guilty to taking nearly $100,000 from the establishment.
lead_paragraph: A former bookkeeper for Masa, one of the most expensive and well-reviewed restaurants in New York, pleaded guilty on Friday to stealing almost $100,000 from the business over the course of a year.

headline: Mets’ Latest Weapon, So They Hope
abstract: The Mets are one of the major league teams using a Doppler radar unit to track the movement of a baseball out of a pitcher’s hand and off a hitter’s bat.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The mysterious apparatus sits high above the home plate seats at Tradition Field, the spring training home of the Mets. Dark, glossy and rectangular, it resembles an expensive flat-screen television.

headline: Comic Book Fundamentals
abstract: More than 100 vendors and 30 guest writers and artists will be at the event, meant to get back to the roots of comic conventions.
lead_paragraph: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — “Back to basics” could be the theme of the third installment of Asbury Park Comic Con, to be held at Convention Hall on the Boardwalk here on March 30.

headline: Rivals Fault Quinn’s Block of a Vote on Sick Time
abstract: Two Democratic candidates for mayor on Friday criticized Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, for blocking a vote over paid sick-leave legislation.
lead_paragraph: Two Democratic candidates for mayor challenged Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on her home turf on Friday, for blocking a vote over paid sick-leave legislation.

headline: Horace Mann Reaches Settlement With Former Students
abstract: The school has reached financial settlements with most of the former students who said they had been sexually abused, a person familiar with negotiations said Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Horace Mann School has reached a settlement worth hundreds of thousands of dollars with most of the former students who have said they were sexually abused by staff members there, a person familiar with negotiations said Friday.

headline: To Wealthy Plain Jane With Poor Boyfriend: Be Careful
abstract: “Rich Girl” asks a timely question for fans of Henry James’s “Washington Square”: What if suspicious Victorian parents could have Googled their daughters’ suitors?
lead_paragraph: THE APARTMENT, WITH its marble floors, gratuitously high ceilings and unaffordable modern art, is what you would expect as the Manhattan home of a wealthy author and television financial expert. The expert’s daughter is less glamorous. But that seemingly plain, dull and easily pushed-around daughter finally lashes out.

headline: With New Pope, Spotlight Returns to a Mild but Rebellious Priest
abstract: The Rev. Helmut Schüller is one of the organizers behind a group of more than 400 priests and deacons who in 2011 issued an “Appeal to Disobedience.”
lead_paragraph: VIENNA

headline: Anthony’s 37 Points Help Knicks Secure a Playoff Berth
abstract: Carmelo Anthony, in just his second game back from knee troubles, played 43 minutes to help defeat the Raptors and secure the Knicks’ third consecutive season in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It was little more than a week ago that a doctor stuck a needle in the back of Carmelo Anthony’s stiff right knee and drained the fluid that had dampened his game. It was only days ago that Anthony returned, gingerly, to the Knicks’ lineup, his knee still a source of curiosity and concern.

headline: A Broader Field of Abstract Expressionists
abstract: A show at the Nassau County Museum of Art includes over 80 works by nearly 50 artists, many of whom might be unfamiliar to viewers.
lead_paragraph: ART HISTORY HAS OFTEN been accused of being overly concerned with the canon, the significant artists and masterpieces within the field, and that concern becomes even more complicated where living artists and recent history are involved.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Suspect in Knifing
abstract: The authorities said the man, 29, had stabbed a roommate in the shoulder and then threatened officers with a knife in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Police officers shot and killed a man Friday night who they said had stabbed his roommate in Brooklyn and then threatened the officers with a knife, a spokesman for the New York Police Department said.

abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: An Artist’s Eye at Work
abstract: “Avant-Garde Persuasion: the Photographs of Harold Haliday Costain,” at the Bruce Museum, straddles the line between fine art and commercial photography.
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, CONN. — In the photograph “Crystal Fantasy,” in the Bruce Museum’s “Avant-Garde Persuasion: The Photographs of Harold Haliday Costain,” drinking glasses and decanters of all shapes and sizes rise from a fishbowl filled with water. Shimmering with points of light, they float diagonally against a rippling background as if lured by a mysterious force.

headline: Stars of a Violent Rap Video Are Found Guilty of Violent Crimes in Real Life
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Music']
abstract: Some of the performers in a rap video depicting armed robbery were found guilty of committing similar crimes in the Bronx and Westchester County.
lead_paragraph: The slick rap video had all the trappings of a hit: guns, gritty urban setting, armed robbery and a flashy getaway car. But, as it turned out, the video found its true potential not on YouTube, but in federal court.

headline: First Visor Wearer Remains Advocate
abstract: After losing an eye to a high stick in 1973, Greg Neeld developed and wore the first helmet visor. It’s about time they were mandatory, he says.
lead_paragraph: For a true advocate of mandatory visor use in the N.H.L., talk to a hockey player who lost an eye playing the game.

headline: A Different School Bus
abstract: A coalition of public school supporters is using a blue bus to carry their message to New York City’s mayoral candidates, taking the bus on a weeklong tour across the boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a beat-up school bus from Wassaic, N.Y., rolled into Queens Village, and a team of public school students, parents and members of advocacy groups descended upon it. They covered its sun-washed green paint with sky blue, ripped out its seats and any traces of its former life — which at one point included transporting a 30-piece marching band and dance ensemble to play at demonstrations and other social- justice activities.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: A question about flower baskets on lampposts in the Grand Central Business Improvement District.
lead_paragraph: Q. Along Madison and Fifth Avenues at 44th and 45th Streets, the lampposts have basketlike structures encircling the posts above head height, with some kind of soft-looking material inside. What are they used for? Nests?

headline: This Mayor’s Decree: Smile
abstract: Bobby Fibel, 69, has been a fixture of a busy stretch of Broadway near Columbia University for years, serving as the neighborhood’s memory keeper.
lead_paragraph: EVERY NEIGHBORHOOD in New York City has its unofficial mayor, and Morningside Heights has Bobby Fibel.

headline: Song of the Sanitation Worker
abstract: Books on the city’s sanitation department, the founder of Cooper Union and urban planning.
lead_paragraph: GARBAGE IN, GARBAGE OUT, the saying goes. Robin Nagle defies that maxim in “Picking Up: On the Streets and Behind the Trucks With the Sanitation Workers of New York City” (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, $28), an entertaining tribute to the unheralded municipal employees who remove your trash.

headline: Peace Prevails on the Pitch
abstract: Croatia defeated Serbia to enhance its prospects of qualifying for the World Cup, but Friday’s match was about much more than soccer.
lead_paragraph: Croatia defeated Serbia to enhance its prospects of qualifying for the World Cup, but Friday’s match was about much more than soccer.

headline: In Search of the Perfect Espresso Bean
abstract: Curt Ellis, 33, executive director of FoodCorps, likes to visit a farmers market in the East Village and to cook.
lead_paragraph: Curt Ellis, 33, is executive director and a founder of FoodCorps, a nonprofit organization started in 2010 to improve schoolchildren’s diets by placing volunteers in their communities for a year of service. He also was a maker of the documentary “King Corn,” which won a Peabody Award. Mr. Ellis lives with his wife, Caitlin Boyle, 31, the founder and president of film.sprout, a distributor of documentaries; and their 8-week-old son, Oliver, in a 390-square-foot fifth-floor walk-up in the East Village. Mr. Ellis, an Oregon native, likes to run on Sundays, visit a farmers’ market and cook.

headline: Building High Anxiety
keywords: ['MetLife Building (Manhattan, NY)', 'Grand Central Terminal (NYC)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The 50th anniversary of the Pan Am Building shows us that while erecting an office tower changes the visual impact of a city, its embedded ethos can also affect our quality of life.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 23, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Mar. 23, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody knows what the devil they are up to.”

headline: Local Stop: Elmhurst, Queens
abstract: The rows of identical single-family homes belie the broader cultural and architectural mix of the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The rows of identical single-family homes belie the broader cultural and architectural mix of the neighborhood.

headline: Gauchos, Kung Fu and a Paraboloid
abstract: Despite the rows of seemingly uniform single-family houses, signs of the area’s diversity are everywhere, particularly in the streets crowded with Asian and Latin American shops.
lead_paragraph: A bright yellow banner advertising a “Kung Fu Training School” hangs in front of Elmhurst’s oldest church, a simple clapboard structure built in 1734, when the Queens neighborhood was still the independent town of Newtown. Despite rows of seemingly uniform single-family houses, signs of the area’s diversity are everywhere, particularly in the streets crowded with Asian and Latin American shops.

headline: Creighton Aces the Drill, Defeating Cincinnati
abstract: Creighton, the No. 7 seed in the Midwest, hit 11 of 12 free throws in the final 1 minutes 42 seconds to fend off No. 10 Cincinnati and secure a spot against Duke in the Round of 32.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Coach Greg McDermott has punctuated nearly every one of his team’s practices this season with a free-throw drill. His players must make 10 in row, sometimes more, before they can head home. If it looks as if he might have to turn out the lights on them, he puts a couple of minutes on the clock. Once time runs out, the loners who are left behind line up and run.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Costa Rica (0)
abstract: Rating the performance of U.S. players in Friday’s World Cup qualifying match against Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: No frills. Lots of snow. Three points. Is there anything else we need to know?

headline: Wintry Weather and U.S. Team Throw Blanket Over Costa Rica
abstract: In a game dubbed as a “must-win” for the United States, the American players responded, delivering a victory over Costa Rica in a snowy World Cup qualifier on Friday.
lead_paragraph: COMMERCE CITY, Colo. — The temperatures were freezing. The winds were battering. The snow was coming down sideways.

headline: The Mayor’s Geek Squad
abstract: New York City’s Office of Policy and Strategic Planning is a group of tech-savvy and civic-minded number crunchers analyzing city statistics for solutions to some pressing and convoluted problems.
lead_paragraph: It was a case for a digital Sherlock Holmes. Last fall, the city’s Department of Environmental Protection wanted, finally, to crack down on restaurants that were illegally dumping cooking oil into sewers in their neighborhoods — congealed yellow grease is responsible, the department says, for more than half of New York’s clogged drains. The question, of course, was how to find the culprits?

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) SPARKLE (2012) Whitney Houston, above, who died before this film was released, portrays Emma, a performer turned prim church lady in late-1960s Detroit in this remake of the 1976 movie starring Irene Cara and Lonette McKee, with a score by Curtis Mayfield. The “American Idol” winner Jordin Sparks plays Sparkle, Emma’s youngest daughter, who breaks free from the ranks of the girl group she has formed with her sisters (Carmen Ejogo and Tika Sumpter) and ascends to stardom against her mother’s wishes. “Houston dominates the new ‘Sparkle’ and gives its most compelling vocal performance in her rendition of ‘His Eye Is on the Sparrow,’ ” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “Her vocal stamina was considerably diminished by the time she filmed the movie, but her disciplined, slightly hoarse rendition of that gospel standard gives ‘Sparkle’ much of its heart.” He added: “If the new songs on the soundtrack are effective Motown pastiches, most of them pale beside their prototypes. But diluted Motown is better than none.”

headline: Marriage and the Supremes
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The context for the high court’s hearings on gay marriage is a profound social and political revolution.
lead_paragraph: I’M not sure I’ve ever seen advocates of gay rights — of equal rights, I should say — as revved up as they are right now, with the Supreme Court poised, on Tuesday and Wednesday, to consider same-sex marriage in two separate cases.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 23
abstract: Cyprus partly approves a formula to obtain a bailout; Israel apologizes to Turkey; the writer Chinua Achebe dies; cargo ships in trouble; and the Malaysian Grand Prix.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Lawmakers in Cyprus took steps late Friday to revise a formula for obtaining a bailout of the country’s banks but faced strong signals that the plan would not pass muster with international lenders. The Parliament put off until later this weekend a vote on a crucial new proposal that would confiscate 22 to 25 percent of uninsured deposits above €100,000 through a new tax on account holders in one of the nation’s most troubled banks. Liz Alderman reports from Nicosia.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: Assailants suspected of being terrorists killed an 18-year-old boy in the Sopore district on Tuesday night, IBNLive reported. Initial investigations have pointed to the involvement of the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba. The attack came on the heels of a suicide attack on a Central Reserve Police Force camp in Bemina last week. The police have arrested four people, including a Lashkar-e-Taiba operative, in connection with that attack, according to NDTV.

headline: Senate Passes $3.7 Trillion Budget, Setting Up Contentious Negotiations
abstract: The 50-to-49 vote early Saturday sets up contentious — and potentially fruitless — negotiations with the Republican-dominated House to reconcile two vastly different visions for dealing with America’s economic and budgetary problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After an all-night debate that ended just before 5 a.m., the Senate on Saturday adopted its first budget in four years, a $3.7 trillion blueprint for 2014 that would provide a fast track for passage of tax increases, trim spending modestly and leave the government still deeply in the red a decade from now.

abstract: Warren Richard Rodwell, who was abducted by members of an Islamic militant organization in 2011, was released early Saturday in the coastal town of Pagadian.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — An emaciated 54-year-old Australian man held for 15 months by a kidnap-for-ransom group in the southern Philippines was released Saturday, officials said.

headline: Poverty Blamed for Bulgaria’s Suicide Wave
abstract: The economic plight of Bulgaria, one of the European Union’s most impoverished nations, has prompted a wave of public self-immolations and suicides amid protests against corruption and mismanagement.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Bulgaria’s caretaker government will introduce a plan on Monday to try to tackle an epidemic of suicides that is afflicting the impoverished East European nation.

headline: (Not a) Model-Morphosis
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of real women, with professional makeup by Tina Turnbow.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of real women, with professional makeup by Tina Turnbow. Here, the fashion and beauty blogger Kristin Booker in a look Turnbow created just for her.

headline: U.S. Tweets Come In From the Snow
abstract: Some tweets from U.S. players after Friday night’s victory over Costa Rica in the snow.
lead_paragraph: Some reactions, via Twitter, from U.S. players after Friday night’s 1-0 Snow Bowl victory over Costa Rica in a World Cup qualifying match in Commerce City, Colo.:

headline: The Attachment That Still Makes Noise
abstract: The stapler remains the one office tool that gives the satisfying click of a job that’s done.
lead_paragraph: DO you have a stapler?

headline: Obama Has Lost Advantage Over G.O.P. on Economy
abstract: During the debate over the so-called fiscal cliff in December, public opinion surveys showed that more Americans trusted President Obama than trusted Congressional Republicans when it came to handling the economy. Not anymore.
lead_paragraph: During the debate over the so-called fiscal cliff in December, public opinion surveys showed more Americans trusted President Obama than trusted Republicans in Congress when it came to handling the nation’s economy. The New Year’s Day deal to avoid going over the cliff, which included higher marginal tax rates on high earners — something Mr. Obama had campaigned on and lobbied for — was largely seen as a victory for the president.

headline: Costa Rica Considering Protest to FIFA
abstract: Costa Rica was considering lodging a protest with FIFA on Saturday after Friday night’s match in the snow against the United States.
lead_paragraph: Costa Rican soccer officials said they planned to file a protest with FIFA on Saturday after Friday night’s 1-0 loss to the United States in a World Cup qualifying match played in a blizzard.

headline: Updates and Analysis: N.C.A.A. Tournament, Round of 32, Day 1
abstract: Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters will supply updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Top seeded Gonzaga is out of the N.C.A.A. tournament thanks to No. 9 Wichita State and No. 3 Marquette ends the run of No. 6 Butler. Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters detail Saturday’s action from the N.C.A.A. Tournament.

headline: The Gun Report: March 23, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Today, Joe is devoting his column to smart gun technology, which includes biometric gun locks that ensure only a gun’s owner can fire it. States including New Jersey and California would like to make “gun personalization” technology, as it is called, required for all legally owned firearms. Many Second Amendment absolutists believe that any refinement to current gun laws is an infringement on their rights. “Why should legal gun owners suffer background checks when such a small percentage of people use guns to kill?” they ask.

headline: Security Cameras on East Coast Capture Meteor
abstract: Security cameras on the East Coast captured a flash in the sky Friday night that appears to have been a small meteor.
lead_paragraph: Security cameras on the East Coast captured a flash in the sky Friday night that appears to have been a small meteor.

headline: Behind Image of Seamless Transition, Vatican Navigates Uncharted Waters
abstract: Virtually every day highlights the strangeness of the Vatican’s circumstances and brings new debate about what the relationship between the two pontiffs will be.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Sharing lunch is rarely historic, except perhaps when the two people eating are a pope and his predecessor.

headline: A Once-Vibrant City Struggles as Panama Races Ahead on a Wave of Prosperity
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: While Panama rides a 9 percent growth rate, joblessness and squalor in Colón, whose black residents say they face racism, appear to only increase.
lead_paragraph: COLÓN, Panama — On one end of the Panama Canal, the nation’s capital gleams with new skyscrapers; a subway, the first in Central America, is under construction; and new malls and restaurants fill with patrons. The city fancies itself a mini-Dubai on the Pacific.

headline: Blackstone and Icahn Are Said to Make Preliminary Bids for Dell
abstract: The Blackstone Group and the billionaire Carl C. Icahn have sent preliminary deal proposals to Dell Inc., people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, signaling that a potential three-way race for control of the computer company is underway.
lead_paragraph: 9:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: France Confirms the Death of a Qaeda Leader in Mali
abstract: President François Hollande says it has been “definitively confirmed” that the regional Al Qaeda leader Abu Zeid, who was reported killed in February in fighting in northern Mali, is dead.
lead_paragraph: France on Saturday officially confirmed the death of the regional Qaeda leader Abdelhamid Abu Zeid, weeks after he was reported to have been killed in fighting in northern Mali at the end of February.

headline: Variety: A Collectible Acrostic
abstract: A collectible acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s quote comes from essayist ANNE FADIMAN, who writes of Vladimir NABOKOV’s tendency to “hoard” rare words that seem otherworldly to us now. And man, this was a hard one! I tend to solve Acrostics by “toggling” back and forth between guessing the clues and filling in the words as they take shape. But how do you do that when some of the words are IRIDULE or LEMNISCATE? It’s like Eugene Maleska came back to life and wrote an acrostic.

headline: As His Recovery Lags, Santana Stays Positive
abstract: There appears to remain a long road ahead for the left-hander Johan Santana, who has not pitched in a spring training game and will not join his teammates for the start of the regular season next month.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — There appears to remain a long road ahead for the left-hander Johan Santana, who has not pitched in a spring training game and will not join his teammates for the start of the regular season next month.

headline: Just Freed, Cleared Man Has a Heart Attack
abstract: David Ranta, who was wrongly convicted in 1991 of killing a Hasidic rabbi, was taken to a New York hospital where doctors put in a stent, and he is expected to undergo another procedure.
lead_paragraph: On his second day of freedom after serving 23 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, David Ranta suffered a serious heart attack Friday night, his lawyer said.

headline: China’s Leader Argues for Cooperation With Russia
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China suggested that the two countries could find common ground as they each seek to claim a place as a respected great power.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Xi Jinping of China made a case on Saturday for closer economic and foreign policy cooperation with Russia, using a speech at a university here to argue that the countries have converging goals, including an expansion of the oil and gas trade, as they pursue dreams of “national revival” and seek to offset the influence of the developed West.

headline: Cyprus Makes Plan to Seize Portion of High-Level Deposits
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Facing a Monday deadline to avoid a banking collapse, Cyprus and its negotiators devised a plan Saturday to take a percentage of savers’ deposits above 100,000 euros to raise money for a bailout.
lead_paragraph: An updated version of this story is here.

headline: McIlroy and Wozniacki Striving, With Some Success, for Ordinary
abstract: The normal dating relationship that Rory McIlroy and Caroline Wozniacki have seemingly achieved is what Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn apparently aspire to.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — The day after Tiger Woods and Lindsey Vonn posted formal, studio-quality photographs on their Facebook and Twitter accounts to show that they were dating, the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki posted her own sports power-couple shot on Twitter.

headline: In Snowstorm, U.S. Finds Remedy for a Cold Spell
abstract: Friday’s match between the United States and Costa Rica will be remembered for the snow, but it belonged to DaMarcus Beasley — and the coach who put him out there.
lead_paragraph: They continued the soccer match during a snowstorm Friday night near Denver for a very good reason.

headline: A Tireless Connoisseur of Texas Barbecue Gets Ready for the Main Course
abstract: Daniel Vaughn, a tireless barbecue aficionado, has been hired by Texas Monthly as its first barbecue editor, a position that exists at no other magazine in America.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Daniel Vaughn stood at the counter at Lockhart Smokehouse here, ordering dinner. Lockhart serves smoked meat the way butchers serve raw meat — wrapped in a large rectangle of butcher paper — and its customers are encouraged to eat it the way cowboys used to, or maybe Neanderthals, without sauce, forks or even plates.

headline: How Much Electricity Comes From Renewable Sources
abstract: Circles are sized according to the electricity use per capita for a selection of countries.
lead_paragraph: Circles are sized according to the electricity use per capita for a selection of countries.

headline: Bands Go Beyond the Music
abstract: The Virginia Commonwealth University band and others provide the soundtrack for the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — What you do not always see during the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament on television is this: a bass trombone player who hops around on stilts before the game, a band director who rips off his dress shirt and conducts in a tank top, and a tuba player who shimmies out of his pants at halftime, revealing American-flag boxers and tights.

headline: Mohsin Hamid
abstract: The Pakistani writer on how Lahore is blues country.
lead_paragraph: Mohsin Hamid, a Pakistani writer, is the author, most recently, of “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia.” The film adaptation of his best-selling book, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” will be in theaters April 26.

lead_paragraph: For over 20 years, photographer Alex Webb has been documenting street life in Cuba.
