abstract: As the Castro era ends, a four-century legacy of racism lives on.
lead_paragraph: Havana

headline: The Obama Era, Brought to You by the Iraq War
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: The current Democratic majority was forged in the backlash against George W. Bush’s Middle East policies.
lead_paragraph: WHEN prominent people in Washington spend an anniversary apologizing for being catastrophically, unforgivably wrong about a decade-old decision, you might expect that the decision in question had delivered their party to disaster or defeat. But last week’s many Iraq war mea culpas were rich in irony: one by one, prominent liberals lined up to apologize for supporting a war that’s responsible for liberalism’s current political and cultural ascendance.

headline: Where Battier Goes, Winning Streaks Follow
abstract: Shane Battier, one of the Miami Heat’s stalwarts during their current 25-game win streak, also contributed significantly to lengthy victory stretches with the Duke Blue Devils and the Houston Rockets.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether it is better to be loved or hated may never be answered satisfactorily, but when it comes to Shane Battier, there is no need to choose. He is loved and hated with equal passion, based almost entirely on how one feels about Duke basketball.

headline: In India, Women’s Issues Are Finally Out Front
abstract: The rape and murder of a young woman in New Delhi last year may have been a tipping point in a long struggle.
lead_paragraph: Having recently returned to the United States from a four-year assignment in India, I’m often asked about events in that country. And so it was with the brutal rape and murder of a 23-year-old student in New Delhi in December that set off big protests across India and was covered widely around the world. Why has this particular rape inspired so much outrage, people ask, when sexual violence is, sadly, so pervasive and commonplace there?

headline: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, the Sequel
abstract: After its contributions to science, the HeLa cells may help create laws to protect the privacy of the family of Henrietta Lacks — and yours.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, scientists sequenced the genome of cells taken without consent from a woman named Henrietta Lacks. She was a black tobacco farmer and mother of five, and though she died in 1951, her cells, code-named HeLa, live on. They were used to help develop our most important vaccines and cancer medications, in vitro fertilization, gene mapping, cloning. Now they may finally help create laws to protect her family’s privacy — and yours.

headline: Israel: Bits, Bytes and Bombs
abstract: President Obama paid a visit. Now what will the Israelis and Palestinians do?
lead_paragraph: READING the news from the wider Middle East and then watching President Obama visiting Israel triggered this thought: The president looked as if he were visiting an atoll in the Pacific, or maybe New Zealand — but definitely some kind of island state surrounded by roiling seas.

headline: Imprisoned by Innovation
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Science and Technology', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Technology can redeem even the most dreadful situations and environments — but this doesn’t obviate the need to fight them.
lead_paragraph: PRISONS — those bastions of routine and tradition — are finally ripe for disruption. Such is the rosy conclusion of “Beyond the Bars,” a provocative report from management consultants at Deloitte published earlier this month.

headline: St. John’s Weathered a Season of Changes
abstract: The Red Storm host Dayton on Sunday in a first-round game of the N.C.A.A. Division I women’s basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: St. John’s will host Dayton on Sunday at Carnesecca Arena in making its fourth consecutive appearance in the N.C.A.A. Division I women’s basketball tournament, an accomplishment that does not begin to suggest the turbulence the Red Storm encountered.

headline: The Times’s Work in Progress
keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'News and News Media', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Challenges in the newspaper’s journalism and its business bring an evolution in policy and practice.
lead_paragraph: SINCE I started as The Times’s fifth public editor last September, I’ve taken up topics from “false balance” in news articles to negative arts criticism to government secrecy. After six months, 16 Sunday columns and close to 100 blog posts to the Public Editor’s Journal, I thought it would be worthwhile to see where some of the issues I have written about stand now.

headline: Report Card on Health Care Reform
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Medicare', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Political attacks ignore the considerable benefits delivered to millions of people since the law’s enactment three years ago.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders in Congress regularly denounce the 2010 Affordable Care Act and vow to block money to carry it out or even to repeal it. Those political attacks ignore the considerable benefits delivered to millions of people since the law’s enactment three years ago Saturday. The main elements of the law do not kick in until Jan. 1, 2014, when many millions of uninsured people will gain coverage. Yet it has already thrown a lifeline to people at high risk of losing insurance or being uninsured, including young adults and people with chronic health problems, and it has made a start toward reforming the costly, dysfunctional American health care system.

headline: Shrinking Prisons, Saving Billions
abstract: Imprisonment rates continue to decrease, but more states need reforms to keep the population and cost down.
lead_paragraph: The mandatory sentencing craze that gripped the country four decades ago drove up the state prison population sevenfold — from under 200,000 in the early 1970s to about 1.4 million today — and pushed costs beyond $50 billion a year. Until recently, it seemed that the numbers would keep growing. But thanks to reforms in more than half the states, the prison census has edged down slightly — by just under 2 percent — since 2009. A new analysis by the Pew Charitable Trusts shows that the decline would have been considerably larger had the other states not been pulling in the opposite direction.

headline: Heightened Scrutiny
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Discrimination', 'Editorials']
abstract: The justices should be as dubious about distinctions based on sexual orientation as on gender.
lead_paragraph: One of the central questions in the two gay marriage cases to be argued before the Supreme Court this week is whether gays and lesbians are a protected class under the Constitution. Under longstanding principles, government actions that fall heavily on “discrete and insular minorities” historically subject to prejudice and stigma are to be given particular scrutiny.

lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Catcher John Buck meant no offense, but his sense of plain-spoken realism had developed over nearly a decade as a major leaguer.

headline: A Plan To Fix Cancer Care
keywords: ['Cancer', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: Five major changes need to occur in the delivery of care for cancer.
lead_paragraph: This year, more than 1.6 million Americans — 0.5 percent of the population — will receive a diagnosis of cancer. Their treatment will consume at least 5 percent of the country’s health care spending, at a cost that is growing faster than all other areas of medicine. Doctors and patients recognize that this is unsustainable and that we need to change the way we deliver care.

headline: Colón Struggles as Rest of Panama Races Ahead
abstract: Wedged between a busy port and a handsome cruise ship terminal, Colón is a crowded, cacophonous city of 220,000, with street after street of faded colonial facades.
lead_paragraph: Wedged between a busy port and a handsome cruise ship terminal, Colón is a crowded, cacophonous city of 220,000, with street after street of faded colonial facades.

headline: A Baseball Education Under the Sun
abstract: A daughter accompanied her father to spring training, and followed in his footsteps.
lead_paragraph: We are in the family car, sometime in the 1950s, somewhere south of the Mason-Dixon line. Burma Shave signs still marked the two-lane highways between New York and Florida, and the South of the Border motel had beds that vibrated for 25 cents and were the highlight of the drive to spring training for a bored child on this annual three-day trip.

headline: Acceptance by Example, on the Field and at Home
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Football', 'Homosexuality', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Linebacker Scott Fujita views his platform as a way to highlight causes like marriage equality and hopes to pass compassion on to his children.
lead_paragraph: My three young daughters, like most kids, are curious and ask a lot of questions. My wife and I are as open and honest with them as possible. But there’s one question I’m not prepared to answer: “Why aren’t Clare and Lesa married?”

headline: Tipped Off
keywords: ['Biographical Information', 'Reading and Writing Skills', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: What happens when a biographer learns about potentially explosive information after the book is finished?
lead_paragraph: The first time it happened was at a Fourth of July picnic in New Hampshire. I’d just turned in my book manuscript to the copy editor and was in a celebratory mood until a friend tugged at my elbow. She’d found a thick stack of letters written by my subjects, three New England sisters of the 19th century, in a trunk in her attic. Did I want to read them?

headline: Life After Oil and Gas
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Solar Energy', 'Natural Gas', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Wind, water and sun could power the United States. But will they?
lead_paragraph: WE will need fossil fuels like oil and gas for the foreseeable future. So there’s really little choice (sigh). We have to press ahead with fracking for natural gas. We must approve the Keystone XL pipeline to get Canadian oil.

headline: Mortgages’ Future Looks Too Much Like the Past
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An alternative under discussion to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the big mortgage guarantors, sounds an awful lot like the status quo, with taxpayers as the backstop.
lead_paragraph: IN a perfect world, policy makers, legislators and concerned Americans would have spent the last few years conducting an honest dialogue about two important issues: how to resolve Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-owned mortgage finance giants, and how to create a housing finance system that would serve borrowers without imperiling taxpayers.

headline: A Boss’s Challenge: Have Everyone Join the ‘In’ Group
abstract: David Rock, the director of the NeuroLeadership Institute, says that by creating shared goals, managers can make everyone sense that they’re part of the team.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  David Rock, director of the NeuroLeadership Institute, was conducted and edited by  Adam Bryant.

headline: No Krstic or Jefferson, but the Nets Can Play On
abstract: After a first-round victory over the Raptors, New Jersey lost to LeBron James and the Cavaliers in a hard-fought series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The last time the Nets made the playoffs, the idea of moving to Brooklyn had been hatched, but the team was nowhere near ready to leave New Jersey. Led by Jason Kidd, Vince Carter and Richard Jefferson, the Nets won 10 of their final 13 games in the regular season and entered the 2007 postseason as a .500 team, one of three Eastern Conference playoff teams that season to win either 41 or 40 games.

headline: Russian Oligarch and Critic of Putin Dies in Britain
abstract: Once a close ally of Boris N. Yeltsin who helped install Vladimir V. Putin as president, Boris A. Berezovsky later exiled himself to Britain after a bitter falling-out with the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Boris A. Berezovsky, once the richest and most powerful of the so-called oligarchs who dominated post-Soviet Russia, and a close ally of Boris N. Yeltsin who helped install Vladimir V. Putin as president but later exiled himself to London after a bitter falling out with the Kremlin, died Saturday.

headline: A Gamble With No Regrets, So Far
abstract: The A’s had scouting reports on Yoenis Cespedes from international tournaments, but Billy Beane, the team’s general manager, also had numbers that forecast success.
lead_paragraph: Phoenix

headline: ‘Another Name for Death’
abstract: WIlliam Clarke Quantrill, the most feared bushwhacker of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1862-3, William Clarke Quantrill traveled from Missouri to Richmond, Va., to request a colonelcy from Confederate Secretary of War James A. Seddon. Normally, men fighting for the Confederacy wouldn’t have had to make such a trip, or had the temerity to do so. But Quantrill was no ordinary soldier. He made his request under the provisions of the Partisan Ranger Act, passed by the Confederate Congress in 1862 to organize and promote unconventional warfare along the western border. When Seddon asked Quantrill’s opinions about the war, Quantrill replied, in the florid rendering of the Confederate sympathizer John N. Edwards, one of his biographers, “I would wage such a war … as to make surrender forever impossible. I would cover the armies of the Confederacy all over with blood. … I would exterminate.”

headline: Big Data Is Opening Doors, but Maybe Too Many
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection', 'Software']
abstract: The dawn of mainframe computers offered huge technological benefits, but also challenged notions of privacy. Now Big Data is bringing similar expectations and concerns.
lead_paragraph: IN the 1960s, mainframe computers posed a significant technological challenge to common notions of privacy. That’s when the federal government started putting tax returns into those giant machines, and consumer credit bureaus began building databases containing the personal financial information of millions of Americans. Many people feared that the new computerized databanks would be put in the service of an intrusive corporate or government Big Brother.

headline: In Havana, Remembering a Minor League Championship
abstract: For more than six seasons in prerevolutionary Cuba, the Sugar Kings were the Reds’ Class AAA affiliate in Havana.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — When the Havana Sugar Kings were mentioned to Asdrubal Baró, a smile crept across his wrinkled face, revealing missing teeth. Seated in a wheelchair on the balcony of his Havana apartment surrounded by cactus plants, he said, “I must show you something.”

headline: There’s a Reason for Deposit Insurance
keywords: ['Deposit Insurance', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Savings and Loan Associations', "Great Depression (1930's)"]
abstract: The bank turmoil in Cyprus, and previous financial crises elsewhere, are reminders that depositors are also bank creditors, and remain vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: FOR all the criticism of bailouts since the financial crisis struck, virtually no one has suggested that depositors in banks be made to suffer along with their investors, employees and customers. Until this week, when the euro zone proposed that, in return for a bailout of the failing banking system in Cyprus, depositors pay a “tax” of 6.75 percent of their deposits — 9.9 percent for deposits above 100,000 euros.

headline: Obama Shows Talent for Arm-Twisting, and Raises Hopes on Peace Effort
abstract: After helping heal a rift between Israel and Turkey, analysts wonder whether President Obama will bring the same doggedness and personal involvement to pursuing peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — There is little doubt that President Obama can deliver a memorable speech, as he did in Jerusalem last week about the need for peace. The big surprise on his trip to Israel and Jordan, which ended here on Saturday, is that he can also twist arms.

headline: Michigan Beats Press in a Rout of V.C.U.
abstract: The fourth-seeded Wolverines defeated the No. 5 Rams to advance to the Round of 16 in the N.C.A.A.’s South Region.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — The first half was winding down, and Trey Burke, again, swerved past his defender, into the paint, into the heart of Virginia Commonwealth’s defense. It was helpless with Burke there. He lofted the ball toward the rim.

headline: Witnesses Deny Rebel Gains in Central African Republic
abstract: There were conflicting reports about a rebel advance on the capital as some said the rebels had entered but witnesses and the president’s spokesman denied it.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — There were conflicting reports on Saturday about a rebel advance on the capital of the Central African Republic, with some saying the rebels had entered the city, but with witnesses in the capital and the president’s spokesman denying it.

abstract: The Eagles’ upset of Georgetown has seemed to energize the 12,000-plus students at Florida Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: Florida Gulf Coast University has its own beach. And it may come in handy this weekend.

headline: A Winding Road to Benefits From Long-Term Care Insurance
keywords: ['Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: After months of exchanges of information, a woman who had a stroke is denied benefits under a long-term care policy. Her son-in-law asks the Haggler to intervene.
lead_paragraph: OUR episode about Whirlpool’s grudging approach to customer service, as illuminated by the tale of a faulty microwave, prompted more than a dozen e-mails of the oh-you-think-that’s-bad? variety. Most were mundane variations on a theme of Whirlpool indifference, incompetence or both. But one stood out. It came from Shira London, a librarian in Baltimore, and the owner of a Whirlpool refrigerator that makes a very loud buzzing noise.

headline: Demoted Last Season, Cervelli Emerges as Yankees’ Starting Catcher
abstract: Francisco Cervelli, 27, is expected to replace the departed Russell Martin behind the plate after beating out Chris Stewart, who took Cervelli’s backup job last season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Francisco Cervelli’s blue eyes peer with a perpetual state of wonder, open and expressive, as if he is seeing the world for the first time. Perhaps it was not surprising, then, that the thought of being the Yankees’ opening-day catcher seemed to startle him.

headline: In IndyCar, Racing in the Streets
abstract: The drivers Dario Franchitti and Charlie Kimball talked recently to Times reporters and editors about their hobbies, IndyCar’s movie moment and the perfect street course.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 IndyCar Series season begins Sunday in Florida with the Honda Grand Prix of St. Petersburg, one of six street courses on the 19-race schedule. Target Chip Ganassi Racing will be trying to reclaim the series title after Ryan Hunter-Reay, 32, of Andretti Autosport ended Ganassi’s five-year run of championships. The Ganassi teammates Dario Franchitti, 39, a four-time series champion and three-time Indianapolis 500 winner, and Charlie Kimball, 28, the winner of the Tony Renna Rising Star Award last year and the first IndyCar driver with diabetes, talked recently to New York Times reporters and editors about their hobbies, IndyCar’s movie moment and the perfect street course.

headline: Apple Plugs Password Security Hole
abstract: Apple has fixed a security hole that made it easy for someone to seize another person’s Apple account, which controls access to iCloud, iTunes and other Apple services. The company made the password reset page for Apple ID accounts available again, not long after the discovery of the security hole forced it to take the site down.
lead_paragraph: Apple has fixed a security hole that made it easy for someone to seize another person’s Apple account, which controls access to iCloud, iTunes and other Apple services.

headline: Answering Calls to Serve
abstract: The leader of Mansa Equity Partners recalls two career moves to public service — first in Florida and then on a national stage.
lead_paragraph: MY father, who was born and raised in Panama, became an American citizen by joining the Army when the United States operated the Panama Canal. He moved to the United States in the early 1950s, attended Howard University, met my mother and became a successful architect.

headline: Not Even a Squabble Between Teammates Can Slow the Spartans
abstract: Michigan State bullied the No. 6 seed Memphis, winning at the Palace of Auburn Hills on Saturday, in front of a mostly green and white crowd.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Michigan State was trying to fend off Memphis, trying to do what it does almost every March and advance to the Round of 16, when two of its best players, who are also best friends, got into a spat during a second-half timeout.

headline: Mixing Freedoms in a 32-Ounce Soda
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Taxation', 'Children and Childhood', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Proposed curbs on sugary sodas reflect a clash of ideals. Which is more important: the freedom to consume the drinks we want or the freedom of parents to raise healthy children?
lead_paragraph: ON narrow technical grounds, a New York State court recently rejected Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposed curbs on large sodas and other sugary drinks. The ruling is being appealed, but many people who viewed the proposal as a step down a slippery slope to a nanny state were quick to celebrate the court’s move.

headline: How to Unlock That Stashed Foreign Cash
abstract: Various American companies have parked huge sums of money abroad.  One money manager says they should repatriate that wealth, pay taxes on it and then watch their stock prices rise.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S a novel way to drive up a company’s share price: Pay billions of dollars in additional taxes.

headline: JPMorgan’s Trading Loss
abstract: A reader responds to “JPMorgan’s Follies, for All to See” (Fair Game, March 17).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Supplements and Sellers
abstract: Readers respond to “Is the Seller to Blame?” (March 17).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ruth Ann Steinhagen Is Dead at 83; Shot a Ballplayer
abstract: Ms. Steinhagen’s 1949 shooting of the Phillies’ Eddie Waitkus made its way into the novel “The Natural” and its film adaptation.
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 14, 1949, a young woman gave an enormous tip — $5 — to a bellhop at the Edgewater Beach Hotel in Chicago to deliver a note to another guest, Eddie Waitkus, the first baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, who were in town to play the Cubs. The two had never met, but she needed to see him, she explained in the note, in which she called herself Ruth Anne Burns. Could he come to her room?

headline: Excitement of Deadline Day Has Potential to End With a Thud
abstract: Some believe that this year’s N.H.L. trade deadline, April 3, might not be as active as in years past.
lead_paragraph: As with all things in this shrunken N.H.L. season, which began slightly more than two months ago, the April 3 trade deadline is coming fast. Canada’s all-sports television networks like TSN began showing specials on it 30 days before the deadline, have dedicated Web pages to it and will, as always, devote at least nine hours of live programming on deadline day for an audience that includes viewers of the NHL Network in the United States.

headline: New York in His Blood, Winning on His Mind, Obstacles in His Way
abstract: John Davidson, Columbus’s president for hockey operations, is trying to bring new life to a franchise that has been around since 2000 but has yet to find its niche.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — John Davidson was reminiscing about his three decades in New York as a Rangers goaltender and a television announcer.

headline: You’ll Know It When You See It
abstract: A question definitively answered, by Dan Schoenholz and some other people you might have heard about.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, if we didn’t know what art was before, we definitely know it now.

headline: Mayors Against Illegal Guns Ad: Father
abstract: The $12 million national advertising campaign that focuses on trying to persuade senators to support a pending package of federal regulations to curb gun violence.
lead_paragraph: The $12 million national advertising campaign that focuses on trying to persuade senators to support a pending package of federal regulations to curb gun violence.

headline: Bloomberg’s TV Blitz on Guns Puts Swing Senators on the Spot
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Political Advertising', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent $12 million on a national campaign that names senators he believes might be persuaded to support federal gun regulations.
lead_paragraph: The commercial is an unambiguous appeal to gun owners: a middle-aged hunter, shotgun in hand, vows that he will fight to protect the Second Amendment. But in a sensible, father-of-the-house tone, he also urges voters to support comprehensive background checks, “so criminals and the dangerously mentally ill can’t buy guns.”

headline: Mayors Against Illegal Guns Ad
abstract: The ads, in a dozen states, will blanket those senators’ districts during an Easter Congressional recess that is to be followed by debate over gun legislation.
lead_paragraph: The ads, in a dozen states, will blanket those senators’ districts during an Easter Congressional recess that is to be followed by debate over gun legislation.

headline: Tackling Concerns of Independent Workers
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Organized Labor', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Series']
abstract: The Freelancers Union, one of the nation’s fastest-growing labor organizations, seeks to make health insurance and other benefits more affordable for independent workers.
lead_paragraph: SOON after landing a job at a Manhattan law firm nearly 20 years ago, Sara Horowitz was shocked to discover that it planned to treat her not as an employee, but as an independent contractor.

headline: In Dealing With Injuries, Collins Takes the Long View
abstract: The Mets’ manager said that he will not rush David Wright and Daniel Murphy back into action.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets could begin the season without two key infielders, but Manager Terry Collins would prefer to be safe for the short term rather than risk any long-term absences.

headline: U.S. and Afghans Reach Deal on Bagram Prison Transfer
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The agreement to transfer control of Bagram Prison to the Afghan government ends a particularly acrimonious chapter of America’s relationship with President Hamid Karzai.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of delays and recriminations by American and Afghan officials, the Pentagon announced Saturday that a deal had been reached to transfer control of Bagram Prison to the Afghan government.

headline: What Drought? Just Don’t Tread on Our Green Grass
abstract: At some point, the realities of the drought will force Texas’ lush green lawns to enter the water shortage debate.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Critics of State Bill Say It Would Restrict Abortions
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'State Legislatures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Supporters of the bill awaiting a vote in the Texas Senate say it would improve women’s safety, but opponents call it an effort to close most abortion clinics.
lead_paragraph: A bill advancing through the Texas Legislature could drastically decrease the number of legal abortion facilities in the state.

headline: With Political Savvy, A&M Chancellor Charts a Smooth Course for Big Changes
abstract: After 18 months as chancellor of the Texas A&M University System, John Sharp is on a smooth course, showing off both political and creative skills.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION — When the Texas A&M University System was looking for a new chancellor in 2011, alumni groups told Richard Box, the chairman of the Board of Regents, that the board should conduct a nationwide search of academics.

headline: A Restaurateur Builds Up His Austin Enterprise
abstract: With several restaurants under his belt, Larry McGuire will update an Austin classic, Jeffrey’s, as part of the opening of his latest endeavor.
lead_paragraph: Larry McGuire, Austin’s prolific restaurateur, sits down to lunch at his newest restaurant, Josephine House, in the central Clarksville neighborhood. With impeccably clean hands, he straightens his Rag & Bone shawl-collar cardigan and unfolds a crisp napkin, which he places over his lap.

headline: Venus Williams Withdraws From Sony Open
abstract: Venus Williams withdrew from the Sony Open with a lower back injury; she had been set to play the up-and-coming Sloane Stephens.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Just minutes before she was supposed to take the court Saturday against Sloane Stephens, Venus Williams withdrew from the Sony Open with a lower back injury.

headline: Russian Ties Put Cyprus Banking Crisis on East-West Fault Line
keywords: ['Taxation', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: With Cyprus’s role as a provider of financial services for Russians, what began as another episode in a familiar narrative has escalated into a drama with geopolitical implications.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — Andreas Marangos, a Porsche-driving lawyer here, had just woken up when he heard the news that threatened to destroy his and Cyprus’s most lucrative business: setting up shell companies and providing financial services for wealthy Russians.

headline: After 3 Days of Violence, City in Myanmar Counts the Dead
abstract: Army units have restored order to Meiktila, Myanmar, where 32 people have been reported killed and the death toll is expected to rise.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Army units restored order on Saturday to a city in central Myanmar devastated by three days of religious rioting and arson attacks.

headline: Jeter Plays, but Not in the Field
abstract: Derek Jeter returned to action Saturday, as a designed hitter in a minor league game.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — Derek Jeter made it back into a game Saturday, his first since he was scratched from Tuesday’s game due to soreness in his surgically repaired left ankle.

headline: So Much for That Week of Rest
abstract: Chris Stroud was planning to take a few days off to dote on his two young daughters. But then he got a call from Arnold Palmer’s tournament.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — This was going to be the week Chris Stroud recharged his batteries and doted on his two young daughters. Instead, a single phone call set into motion one of the more exhausting weeks of Stroud’s seven-year PGA Tour career.

headline: Dr. Jacquelin Perry, Surgeon Who Aided Polio Victims, Dies at 94
abstract: Dr. Perry earned attention for her work in analyzing the human gait, which she broke down into eight motion patterns governed by 28 major muscles in each leg.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jacquelin Perry, a physician and researcher who shed light on the complexities of walking, and was a leader in treating polio victims in the 1950s and again in the ’80s when the symptoms of some returned, died on March 11 at her home in Downey, Calif. She was 94.

headline: Long Shots and Long Road Converge at Site of Long-Ago Title
abstract: The 13th-seeded Explorers will face 12th-seeded Mississippi in Kansas City, the site of their 1954 national title.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Municipal Auditorium, the most historic place in La Salle University men’s basketball, still stands at the corner of West 13th and Wyandotte Streets here. A breathtaking mix of art deco and curving forms, it remains home to the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (N.A.I.A.) Division I national championship and other events. On Saturday, it hosted a cheerleading competition.

headline: In Syria’s Civil War, Doctors Find Themselves in Cross Hairs
abstract: More than 100 physicians have been killed and hundreds more have disappeared into Syrian jails in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — Six months after Syrian secret police officers led Dr. M. Nour Maktabi away from his Aleppo clinic, the morgue at the university hospital summoned his family to collect his corpse.

headline: Pakistani Cricket Star Tries Again to Turn Adulation Into Political Support
abstract: The star, Imran Khan, kicked off his populist campaign for national elections with a huge rally, hoping to help his political party, which has not won more than a single Parliament seat.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Imran Khan, a Pakistani cricket star turned politician, kicked off his populist campaign for national elections with a huge rally here on Saturday, a national holiday, in a symbolic move timed to tap into surging nationalist sentiment and bolster his political party, which has never won more than a single seat in Parliament and is flagging in the polls.

headline: From LeBron James to Buckeyes, a Coach Brings His Shooting Touch
abstract: Ohio State assistant Chris Jent has an impressive résumé that includes a four-year stint as LeBron James’s personal shooting coach.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — When second-seeded Ohio State bulldozed Iona in its West Region opener Friday, shooting 48 percent from the floor, one Buckeyes assistant took no small amount of personal satisfaction.

headline: Helen Kutsher, Pampering Matriarch of a Grand Borscht Belt Resort, Dies at 89
abstract: Mrs. Kutsher would circulate around the dining room, send food baskets up to rooms, and, until a few years ago, handle reservations to ensure that regulars got the lakeside views.
lead_paragraph: Helen Kutsher, the matriarch of the last of the grand Catskill resorts, who greeted guests with a “Welcome home,” made sure the regulars got rooms facing the lake, entertained them with comedians and filled them with blintzes and stuffed cabbage, died on Tuesday in Philadelphia. She was 89 and lived most of her life in Monticello, N.Y., in a house on the grounds of the hotel.

headline: A Blur of Steals and Scoring for Louisville
abstract: No. 1-seeded Louisville forced turnovers, thwarted inbounds passes, crowded passing lanes and turned its game against Colorado State into a rout.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — There was red, so much red at Rupp Arena on Saturday night. There was noise, so much noise. And there was pressure, so much pressure. Louisville welcomed it, thrived in it, inflicted it. Until Thursday morning, Larry Eustachy, the Colorado State coach, did not know a single player on Louisville’s team, let alone Russ Smith or Peyton Siva, whose names he is as familiar with now as his wedding anniversary.

headline: Change in Title Format Forces Switch in Strategies
abstract: The World Chess Federation is using a tournament this year to choose a challenger to the world champion, Viswanathan Anand, and the players vying for that chance have had to adapt.
lead_paragraph: The Candidates Tournament to select a challenger to face Viswanathan Anand for the world chess championship began on March 15 in London, and it has proved one thing: A single event beats the elimination matches that have most often been used since 1965.

headline: Expectations Elevated, But Harvard Is Humbled
abstract: The Wildcats dominated the Crimson, a favorite bracket buster, with their swift guards and towering post players to advance to a West Region semifinal.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Brawn battered brains on Saturday. Hope was swallowed by Arizona’s size. There went Harvard, among the darlings of this N.C.A.A. tournament, a life powerhouse turned basketball underdog whose charmed appearance here ended on the wrong end of a blowout.

headline: Joe Weider, Creator of Bodybuilding Empire, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Weider, who was a mentor to Arnold Schwarzenegger, created a world of muscle magazines, fitness equipment and dietary supplements, helping popularize the sport.
lead_paragraph: Joe Weider, a scrawny youngster who sculptured himself with bodybuilding during the Great Depression and created an empire of muscle magazines, fitness equipment, doubtful dietary supplements and Olympic-style contests featuring Arnold Schwarzenegger, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Yankees Bring Back an Old Hand
abstract: The Yankees are bringing back Chien-Ming Wang, who had success for them until he was injured in 2008.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — The Yankees announced they signed Chien-Ming Wang, their own former pitcher, to a minor league contract to provide pitching depth. He is scheduled to work out on Monday.

headline: For Shelter-Seeking Syrians, Home Is a Cave
abstract: As President Bashar al-Assad’s military continues to pound neighborhoods aligned with the rebels, uncountable Syrian families are waiting out the violence in the caves of bygone times.
lead_paragraph: As President Bashar al-Assad’s military continues to pound neighborhoods aligned with the rebels, uncountable Syrian families are waiting out the violence in the caves of bygone times.

headline: Jammed in Roman Caves, Ducking Syria’s War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Squatters', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: In Syria, the caves of bygone times have become essential once more, restored to modern use because their thick walls offer a chance of survival to a population under fire.
lead_paragraph: SARJAH, Syria — Abdulkader Darwish did not go far after a Syrian military aircraft dropped a bomb near his house last year, prompting him to gather his family and flee. He ventured with a shovel into the local olive groves. There he dug through the sealed entrance to an abandoned Roman cave.

headline: Detroit Waits, Apprehensive, for Manager to Take Over
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'City Councils', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: A city whose finances are in a dire state loses the power to run itself, and everyone waits to see what will happen next.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The City Council is both anxious and defiant. Public employees’ unions are bracing for a showdown. Protests and lawsuits are promised. Meanwhile, the mayor has simply stopped talking about what is on nearly everyone’s mind in this troubled city.

headline: No, Miami Isn’t Surprised
abstract: The Miami Hurricanes suffered what was widely considered a bad loss during the regular season when they were beaten by Florida Gulf Coast. It doesn’t look so bad now.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — It was a perfectly lobbed question. “Shane, were you surprised Florida Gulf Coast … ”

headline: Woods Takes Usual Place at Bay Hill
abstract: Tiger Woods overtook Justin Rose in the third round of the Arnold Palmer Invitational. Woods, the defending champion, is trying to win his eighth title as a professional at Bay Hill.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The electricity in the air made the hairs stand on people’s necks, but it was not because of the thunderstorms in the area. The force of nature bearing down on Bay Hill Club and Lodge on Saturday was Tiger Woods. Trailing Justin Rose, the 36-hole co-leader, by five when he made the turn, Woods carded two birdies and an eagle on the back nine on his way to a six-under-par 66 that vaulted him into the lead at the Arnold Palmer Invitational.

headline: Coach Keeps Heart in Mind at Iowa State
abstract: A heart condition nearly killed Iowa State Coach Fred Hoiberg seven years ago and prematurely ended his N.B.A playing career. Another possible health scare is never too far from his thoughts.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — It was well past midnight by the time Iowa State Coach Fred Hoiberg had finished his news media obligations and walked back out to the court, where his team was still celebrating Friday’s victory over Notre Dame.

headline: Man Detained in Fatal Coney Island Shooting
abstract: The authorities said Joseph Brown, who had not been charged, killed one man and wounded three other people at a housing project on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The police on Saturday detained a man suspected of shooting four people — one fatally — in an apartment at a Coney Island housing project on Friday.

headline: Martin Puts Spring in Knicks’ Step
abstract: Kenyon Martin scored 18 points in one of the more energetic performances of his New York revival, and the Knicks beat the Raptors to extend their winning streak to four games.
lead_paragraph: From the beginning, it seemed this Knicks season would be defined by age — its benefits, its limitations and its consequences, with the precise weight of each effect to be determined by the 82-game schedule.

headline: How the Court Could Rule on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: The Supreme Court is set to release decisions in two cases about same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is set to release decisions in two cases about same-sex marriage.

headline: Shadow of Roe v. Wade Looms Over Ruling on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Even supporters of abortion rights believe the 1973 Supreme Court ruling went too far, too fast, a lesson opponents of same-sex marriage hope the court, hearing two cases, will take to heart.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court hears a pair of cases on same-sex marriage on Tuesday and Wednesday, the justices will be working in the shadow of a 40-year-old decision on another subject entirely: Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling that established a constitutional right to abortion.

headline: Immigrants Held in Solitary Cells, Often for Weeks
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: New federal data shows that on any given day, about 300 immigrants are held in solitary confinement at Immigration and Customs Enforcement centers, a practice psychiatrists worry is overly punitive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On any given day, about 300 immigrants are held in solitary confinement at the 50 largest detention facilities that make up the sprawling patchwork of holding centers nationwide overseen by Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials, according to new federal data.

headline: Oregon Ends Emotional Run by St. Louis
abstract: A first-half run by the Ducks left the Billikens too far behind to extend their emotional season. St. Louis wore patches that read “coach” to honor Coach Rick Majerus, who died in December.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The end for St. Louis started simply, with one 3-pointer, then another, bombs to break apart a game clogged by tight defense. And when Oregon made another to bookend a 20-4 run to end the first half, the highly regarded Billikens, wearing patches on their uniforms to commemorate the December death of their coach, finally found themselves in a situation they could not overcome.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 13
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 13.
lead_paragraph: “Animals, like wolves, refuse to live in such places. But we have to accept this.”

headline: For Surprise No. 1, It’s Two Games and Out
abstract: Gonzaga, which had secured the first No. 1 seed in university history, fell to No. 9 Wichita State, exiting the N.C.A.A. tournament before the second week for the fourth straight year.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — They shuffled down the corridor at EnergySolutions Arena, first the Gonzaga cheerleaders, then Coach Mark Few and three of his players, then the band. No one said a word. It resembled a funeral procession.

headline: Pettitte Still Likes the Yankees’ Chances
abstract: Despite the pessimism around Major League Baseball about the Yankees’ prospects, Andy Pettitte pointed out that the team is still the defending A.L. East champion.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — The growing sentiment around baseball takes a dim view of the Yankees’ chances in 2013, what with the losses of key players like Nick Swisher, Russell Martin and Rafael Soriano, plus injuries to Mark Teixeira, Curtis Granderson, Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter.

headline: Corrections: March 24, 2013.
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 24, 2013.
lead_paragraph: EDITOR’S NOTE

headline: A Birthday Kidd Won’t Forget
abstract: Jason Kidd celebrated his 40th birthday at Madison Square Garden with thousands of his closest friends, a song by a teammate, and a victory.
lead_paragraph: Jason Kidd was with his teammates when one of them, Chris Copeland, started walking to midcourt just before tipoff of the Knicks’ game against the Toronto Raptors on Saturday at Madison Square Garden. Kidd did not know what Copeland was doing, why he was alone or why he was holding a microphone.

headline: Marquette Rallies Again to Survive Butler
abstract: Back and forth went Butler and Marquette, their game coming down to the final play, the final second, before the Golden Eagles escaped with a win.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Back and forth they went, Butler and Marquette, their game — less a basketball matchup, more a war of attrition — coming down to the final possession, the final moment, because it had to. Every made shot, every rebound, every defensive stop was met in kind.

headline: Shannon Nees and Reid Ravin
abstract: The bride is a medical intern in pediatrics; the groom is a medical intern in vascular surgery.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Shannon Nichole Nees, a daughter of Donna and Kevin Nees of Hatfield, Pa., was married Saturday in Bensalem, Pa., to Dr. Reid Armstrong Ravin, a son of Claudia and Dr. Neil Ravin of Hampton, N.H. The Rev. Christopher M. Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Pen Ryn Mansion.

headline: Katherine Lamper, Alex Radetsky
abstract: The bride is a vice president at Doral Bank; the groom is a vice president at the Clearing House.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Sophia Lamper and Alex Radetsky were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated.

headline: Jennifer Barron and Meadow Braun
abstract: A campus outreach intern for a Somali rape crisis clinic and a personal chef marry in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Nicole Barron and Meadow Sylvia Braun were married Saturday at the Galapagos Art Space, an event space in Brooklyn. Alice L. Soloway, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated.

headline: Sally King and Adam McBride
abstract: The bride is a manager at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the groom is a financial analyst.
lead_paragraph: Sally Hoagland King and Adam Gregory McBride were married Saturday by the Rev. James B. Lemler at Christ Church Greenwich in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: JiWon Kim and Francis Kim
abstract: The bride is a pediatric resident in New York; the groom is an internal medicine resident in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Dr. JiWon Kim and Dr. Francis Young-Gyu Kim were married Saturday afternoon at the Broadway Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Danny Han, a senior pastor with Joy Christian Fellowship Church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jessica Meisels, Matt Halliday
abstract: The bride owns a public relations and marketing firm; the groom is a racecar driver.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Kotlen Meisels and Matt Brendt Halliday were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Resort in Wailea, Hawaii. Robert Gilman, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Paula Miller, Eric Weil
abstract: The bride, a lawyer, and groom, a video producer, are Penn graduates.
lead_paragraph: Paula Lynn Miller and Eric Victor Weil were married Saturday evening at BallenIsles Country Club in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Joel L. Levine officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Epstein, Benjamin Mundel
abstract: The bride and groom met at Penn, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Robin Epstein, a daughter of Bonnie Newman Epstein and Dr. Mark A. Epstein of Coral Springs, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Milton Mundel, a son of Elinor Stoff Mundel and Randolph S. Mundel of Uniontown, Pa. Rabbi Noah Fabricant officiated at the Fairfax at Embassy Row, a hotel in Washington.

headline: Hilary Shpeen, Joshua Brownstein
abstract: The bride is a high school teacher; the groom is a manager with a security services company.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Rachel Shpeen and Joshua Nachum Brownstein were married Saturday evening at Congregation Beth Emeth in Albany. Rabbi Randi Musnitsky officiated, and her husband, Rabbi Ronald W. Kaplan, participated.

headline: Shannon Carey, Christopher Fazzolari
abstract: The bride is a registered dietitian at the NYU Langone Weight Management Program in New York; the groom is a royalty-compliance manager in the New York office of Gelfand, Rennert & Feldman.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Marie Carey and Christopher Fazzolari were married Saturday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Mara Raphael, John Mendell Jr.
abstract: The bride is a producer of “Showbiz Tonight”; the groom is a marketing director for a hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: At a Farewell, Romance Begins

headline: Justin Figari, Jason Garcia
abstract: The couple wed in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Justin David Figari and Jason Scott Garcia were married Saturday evening at the Glasshouses, an event space in the Chelsea Arts Tower in New York. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Alexa von Tobel and Michael Ryan Jr.
abstract: The couple met at Harvard, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Alexa Leigh Marie von Tobel and Michael Clifford Ryan Jr. were married Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton in Amelia Island, Fla. Dr. Brandon Z. von Tobel, a brother of the bride and a notary public, officiated.

headline: Mindy Borisoff, Steven Balet
abstract: The bride is an account executive at an insurance company; the groom is an independent financial consultant.
lead_paragraph: Mindy Jacqueline Borisoff and Steven Craig Balet were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Edward Schecter at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in White Plains.

headline: Emily Whitfield, Robert Fader
abstract: The bride is a communications consultant; the groom is an executive and the buyer for Posman Books.
lead_paragraph: Emily Anne Whitfield and Robert Innes Fader are to be married Sunday at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Harold Zernike, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

headline: Sharon Otterman, Rajiv Agashiwala
abstract: The bride is a reporter; the groom is a family physician.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Otterman and Dr. Rajiv Mahesh Agashiwala were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: CeCe Barfield, William Thompson III
abstract: The bride is an interior designer; the groom works for a hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Claire Barfield and William McIlwaine Thompson III were married Saturday by the Rev. Patrick Gahan III, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Episcopal Church in San Antonio.

headline: Julia Fefferman and Matthew Jacobs
abstract: The bride is a director of strategic partnerships at WebMD; the groom is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Social Media Aids Modern Romance

headline: With Its Shots Awry, Syracuse Uses an On-Target Defense to Advance
abstract: Each team shot 39 percent from the field, but the Orange’s 2-3 zone defense lulled California into taking long jump shots and enveloped the Bears’ swingman Allen Crabbe.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — There might not be another team in the N.C.A.A. tournament that can go more than 12 minutes without a field goal in the second half of a game and extend its lead.

headline: Where Parity Rules, a Florida Gulf Coast Can Rise
abstract: In this year’s Round of 64, eight double-digit seeds advanced — none more surprising than No. 15 Florida Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Before his team faced Mercer in the Atlantic Sun Conference tournament final March 9, Andy Enfield, the coach at Florida Gulf Coast, regaled his players with another story. Enfield has lots of stories. One for every occasion, some for no occasion at all.

headline: Nets Can’t Slow Paul, Falling to Clippers Late
abstract: Chris Paul scored 17 of his 29 points in the final quarter in a 101-95 victory that allowed the Clippers to avoid a season sweep by the Nets
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Nets will extend their longest trip of the season to Phoenix on Sunday with the knowledge of how close they came to victory Saturday night.

headline: Women’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 23
abstract: In the first full day of the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament, 12th-seeded Kansas upset fifth-seeded Colorado and 10th-seeded Creighton held off No. 7 Syracuse.
lead_paragraph: In the first full day of the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament, 12th-seeded Kansas upset fifth-seeded Colorado and 10th-seeded Creighton held off No. 7 Syracuse.

headline: Larkin and Scott Spark Miami From the Backcourt
abstract: Whether in games or in 3-point contests at practice, Hurricanes guards Shane Larkin and Durand Scott lift one another with their intensity.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The drill immediately stokes their competitive fire. When Miami Coach Jim Larranaga calls out “five minutes of 3s” at practice, his players respond with an energy and alacrity reflected in Larranaga’s tone.

headline: U.S. and China Relations
abstract: A new surprise for Uncle Sam.
lead_paragraph: A new surprise for Uncle Sam.

headline: ‘World Dream,’ Business on Chinese President’s First Overseas Trip
abstract: As Xi Jinping, China’s new leader, headed to Africa after Russia, on his first overseas trip, there was talk back home of a “China dream” to be shared by the world. And of business.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Even as President Barack Obama was wrapping up a Mideast trip – his first to Israel as president – during which he discussed war and peace, a new world leader, Xi Jinping, had begun his first overseas trip as the Chinese president, amid talk of dreams, business and even “a new type of inter-power relations.”

headline: Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 23
abstract: Wichita State upset No. 1 Gonzaga and fourth-seeded Michigan defeated fifth-seeded V.C.U. in Saturday’s tournament action.
lead_paragraph: Wichita State upset No. 1 Gonzaga and fourth-seeded Michigan defeated fifth-seeded V.C.U. in Saturday’s tournament action.

headline: In ‘Spirited’ Talks, Kerry Tells Iraq to Help Stop Arms Shipments to Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry told Iraqi officials that helping to stop the flow of weapons from Iran is a condition for Baghdad’s participating in discussions about Syria’s future.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Secretary of State John Kerry told Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, the prime minister of Iraq, on Sunday that Iraq must take steps to stop Iran from shipping arms to Syria through Iraqi airspace. But an hour and 40 minutes of discussions here, which Mr. Kerry said were sometimes “spirited,” failed to yield a breakthrough on the issue.

headline: When Hope Tramples Truth
keywords: ['Evolution', 'Pessimism', 'Philosophy', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: It is easy to trace disasters like the Euro and the Arab Spring to the bursts of unfounded optimism that gave rise to them. So why is pessimism so often ignored?
lead_paragraph: Apollo granted to his Trojan priestess Cassandra the gift of prophecy. But because she resisted his advances he punished her by ensuring that nobody would ever believe what she said. Such has been the fate of pessimists down the ages. Those who interrupt the good cheer of their fellows with the thought that the things about which they are all agreed might go badly wrong are either dismissed as madmen or condemned as fools.

headline: Musharraf Greeted in Pakistan by Threats and Small Crowds
abstract: Former President Pervez Musharraf ended more than four years in self-exile on Sunday, seeking a possible political comeback in defiance of judicial investigations and death threats.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s onetime military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, ended four years of self-imposed exile on Sunday in hopes of carving out a political future, but he received an unremarkable welcome as he landed at the airport in Karachi.

headline: As Deadline Nears, Cyprus Scrambles to Devise a Bailout
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: European finance ministers and Cyprus officials face a Monday deadline, when the European Central Bank has threatened to cut off the financing that is keeping the country’s banks from collapsing.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders convened emergency meetings here Sunday night hoping to devise a bank bailout package that would enable Cyprus to stay in the euro zone and rebuild its devastated economy.

headline: At West Point, Morrison Gets at Truths of War in Fiction
abstract: Students at West Point attended a reading by Toni Morrison on Friday, where she read from her novel “Home,” which centers on a Korean War veteran.
lead_paragraph: Our colleague Abigail Meisel writes that the author Toni Morrison received a hero’s welcome at West Point, where cadets greeted her Friday with a “rousing group cheer” during their 20-minute lunch break in the dining hall.

headline: When Family Stories Are Hard to Tell
abstract: Not all family stories are happy ones. We should tell them anyway.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been thinking hard about family stories.

headline: Myanmar’s Ethnic Minorities Grow Pessimistic About Peace
abstract: Deadly rioting between Buddhists and Muslims has further underlined how ethnic and religious fissures in Myanmar pose serious impediments to democratic change.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Ethnic conflicts have been described as Myanmar’s original sin, a legacy of hatred and mistrust that fueled more than six decades of intermittent civil war.

headline: Syrian Opposition Leader Quits His Post
abstract: Moaz al-Khatib, the president of the main Syrian exile opposition group, resigned just days after the coalition elected an interim prime minister who rejects talks with the Syrian government.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Moaz al-Khatib, the president of the main coalition of the Syrian opposition in exile, declared Sunday that he was resigning, and he complained bitterly about foreign powers that he said were withholding aid from the Syrian rebels while trying to control their every move.

headline: Once the King of Harlem Hairdressers, Now Nearly Forgotten
abstract: Rogers Simon was once known as the king of Harlem hairdressers and his main client was the boxing legend, “Sugar” Ray Robinson.
lead_paragraph: In 1983, Glenn Caldwell, a music teacher from Maryland, was playing saxophone in a South Carolina bar and began talking with a singer whose dapper outfit and slick hair seemed from a bygone era.

headline: Disruptions: F.A.A. May Loosen Curbs on Fliers’ Use of Electronics
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Electronics']
abstract: Under mounting pressure, the Federal Aviation Administration hopes to announce by the end of this year that it will relax the rules for reading devices during takeoff and landing.
lead_paragraph: If you’re sitting on a plane at the gate and reading this column on an electronic gadget, you’re about to hear eight dreaded words: “Please power down your electronic devices for takeoff.” But this time next year, you might hear something very different: “Please put your devices on ‘airplane mode’ for takeoff.”

headline: In Seattle, Public Art With an Interactive Twist
abstract: The artist Doug Aitken has installed a permanent exhibition that will be displayed on the facade of the Seattle Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: A finished piece of architecture is typically thought to be immutable, and the same is true of an artwork, an object fixed to its particular moment of creation; or, in the case of video, repeating itself.

headline: President Is Said to Flee as Rebels Seize Capital of the Central African Republic
abstract: The rebels met little opposition and the whereabouts of President François Bozizé were not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — Rebels entered Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, on Sunday morning, seizing control of the city in the culmination of a lengthy uprising in one of the world’s weakest and most impoverished states. The country’s president was reported to have fled.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Analysis, Round of 32, Day 2
abstract: Times editors and reporters covered Sunday’s action from the N.C.A.A. tournament as the field was cut to 16 teams.
lead_paragraph: The field of the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament is whittled down to the final 16. Can the upset parade continue? Zach Hillesland, Mike Huguenin and Times editors and reporters covered Sunday’s action.

headline: Foreign Businesses in Cyprus Grind to a Standstill
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: Hundreds of foreign companies have been drawn to Cyprus because of its low taxes and business-friendly banks. Suddenly, all bets are off.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, CYPRUS — It is not just about rich Russians and Cypriot retirees.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) PHIL SPECTOR (2013) A wigged-out Al Pacino reunites with the writer and director David Mamet (“Glengarry Glen Ross”) to portray the music producer and songwriter charged with the 2003 shooting death of Lana Clarkson inside his home in Alhambra, Calif. Helen Mirren, right with Mr. Pacino, plays the lawyer Linda Kenney Baden, who represented Mr. Spector alongside Bruce Cutler (Jeffrey Tambor) at his first trial, in 2007, which resulted in a hung jury. (He was convicted in 2009 and is serving 19 years to life.) The movie has already set off controversy: Mr. Spector’s wife, Rachelle, has complained about the film’s depiction of her husband as “a foul-mouthed megalomaniac.” Edward Lozzi, a former publicist for Ms. Clarkson, has taken exception to the film’s focus on the defense’s argument that she killed herself. The film is a work of fiction, Mr. Mamet said in an HBO interview, spun from his fascination with Mr. Spector’s character “and the mythological possibilities.” “The focus on the tender and respectful bond between lawyer and client looks a lot like a revisionist re-enactment and maybe even absolution,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “Everyone has a right to the best available defense, but not everyone deserves to be played by the best available actor.”

headline: A Line at the Supreme Court, and Some Are Paid to Be There
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Several dozen people formed a line in front of the Supreme Court over the weekend, hoping for one of the roughly 50 seats reserved for the public to witness arguments in the same-sex marriage case, which begins on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 people formed a line in front of the Supreme Court over the weekend, hoping for one of the roughly 50 seats reserved for the public to witness arguments in the landmark same-sex marriage case that begins on Tuesday. With thousands of tourists streaming into Washington for the Easter break and the National Cherry Blossom Festival, gawkers and passers-by alike paused to ask what the line was about or to offer their opinions on the case.

headline: After Other States’ Moves, Connecticut Is Still Working on Stricter Gun Law
abstract: Democrats have enough power in Hartford to impose their legislative will, yet they and Republicans seek consensus and say they don’t want to make a mistake through haste.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — The original goal of producing legislation before the end of February has long passed. So has the next target, a bill within three months of the massacre of 20 children and 6 educators at the Sandy Hook Elementary School on Dec. 14.

headline: Moviegoers Welcoming Animation And Thriller
abstract: “The Croods” and “Olympus Has Fallen” led the weekend’s movies, rare commercial triumphs in a slow season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood finally lured moviegoers out of their caves.

headline: N.R.A. Chief Says He Will Counter Bloomberg’s Gun Control Campaign
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The head of the National Rifle Association said his organization would lead a national campaign against efforts by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to persuade Congress to adopt stricter gun controls.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of the National Rifle Association said Sunday that his organization would lead a national campaign against efforts by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to persuade Congress to adopt stricter gun controls.

headline: Breaking It Down: Murray Vs. Tomic
abstract: Playing against Andy Murray at the Sony Open, Bernard Tomic appeared to give up.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–Bernard Tomic will not be leaving Miami with a new trophy but he did reinforce his nickname – Tomic the Tank Engine.

headline: Ohio State Survives on a Buzzer-Beater Out of a Child’s Daydream
abstract: Aaron Craft hit the go-ahead 3-pointer with five-tenths of a second remaining to lift Ohio State over Iowa State — giving an already wild N.C.A.A. tournament another memorable moment.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — The West Region is in shambles. The one, three, four, five, seven and eight seeds will not be going to Los Angeles for the regional semifinals this week.

headline: Jeter, Still Sore, Appears Headed for the D.L.
abstract: Derek Jeter reported more soreness in his surgically repaired left ankle, prompting General Manager Brian Cashman to say that Jeter will almost certainly start the season on the 15-day D.L.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Brian Cashman explained that additional soreness in Derek Jeter’s surgically repaired ankle would most likely force Jeter onto the disabled list, which would ensure that he would miss opening day. Moments later, Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, was asked if everything else was all right.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: Thompson Names 2 Aides for Mayoral Bid
abstract: William C. Thompson Jr. hopes that an outside perspective can provide an edge in a wide-open Democratic primary for mayor of New York City.
lead_paragraph: When William C. Thompson Jr. ran unsuccessfully against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2009, he relied chiefly on longtime local loyalists to guide his campaign.

headline: Tennessee Race for Medicaid: Dial Fast and Try, Try Again
abstract: The state opens a health care hot line for a few hours each year for patients who do not qualify for Medicaid. Thousands try, but not many qualify for the limited funds.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Two nights a year, Tennessee holds a health care lottery of sorts, giving the medically desperate a chance to get help.

headline: He’d Probably Help With Your Science Project, Too
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s current production of Gounod’s “Faust” is updated to the atomic era.
lead_paragraph: You can almost hear the conversation that must have transpired at some point between the conception of the Metropolitan Opera’s current production of Gounod’s “Faust” and the debut of that staging, offered last season. The kernel is elementary: The physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, widely credited as the father (or at least a father) of the atomic bombs dropped on Japan near the end of World War II, has been said to have made a Faustian bargain to secure wartime victory for America.

headline: A Metric for News Apps
abstract: OpenNews fellow Brian Abelson recently pondered some deep questions on his blog: How do you define “success” for a news app? And how can you measure reader engagement?
lead_paragraph: OpenNews fellow Brian Abelson recently pondered some deep questions on his blog: How do you define “success” for a news app? And how can you measure reader engagement? The Times’s Red Carpet Project serves as a case study. (Bonus: math and graphs!)

headline: Pushing and Pulling Between Opposites to Zones in Between
abstract: A three-week visit by the Paul Taylor Dance Company, encompassing works spanning the choreographer’s career, concluded Sunday at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: Who in the world is Paul Taylor? Every year this impossible question comes around with the New York season of his dance company; this year’s, a three-week affair at the David H. Koch Theater, ended on Sunday.

headline: A Spectacle With Something for Everyone, Even Poor Neglected Pluto
abstract: “Planetarium” combined a string quartet and a chaotic, multimedia spectacle at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of the first half of Friday evening’s performance of “Planetarium” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, during a string quartet arrangement of a song called “Year of the Boar” by the singer-songwriter Sufjan Stevens, the violinist Ben Russell let loose with a wild riff. His finger slithered up and down the fingerboard producing electric guitarlike squeals while the other members of the quartet — Nadia Sirota (viola), Clarice Jensen (cello) and Rob Moose (violin) — provided an accompaniment of crunchy rhythmic chords that were subtly amplified and altered through giant speakers on each side of the stage.

headline: Art Adds a Dimension to Biblically Inspired Melody
abstract: “Seven Words” mingles art by Ofri Cnaani, music by the Salzburg Chamber Soloists, and the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: In the first full season she has planned as the general manager of concerts and lectures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Limor Tomer has tried to link music programs to the museum’s exhibitions and collections. A concert on Friday night put that goal into practice. The Salzburg Chamber Soloists performed Haydn’s ruminative masterpiece “The Seven Last Words of Christ on the Cross,” an hourlong work in nine movements, including seven slow movements called sonatas that reflect the final phrases Jesus spoke during the Crucifixion.

headline: North American Championships in St. Louis
abstract: Three major titles were won Friday at the North American Bridge Championships.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Three major titles were won Friday at the North American Bridge Championships here.

headline: Irregular Trial Venue
abstract: Adam Prince is feeling entitled.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I was going to start today’s post with an old joke about a famous ship’s CAPTAIN and his propensity for wearing a red shirt and brown pants, but decided that it was far too juvenile and inappropriate for this blog. As I’ve said many a time, far be it from me to contribute anything that might not be sophisticated in concept, and …

headline: Something in the Air? It Must Be the Headliner
abstract: Pink’s aerial acrobatics punctuated her hit-filled concert at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: “The Truth About Love Tour,” which stopped at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, is built on a suspension of disbelief, but maybe not the one you’re bracing for. It isn’t about the way that Pink, the tour’s vocal dynamo and principal object in motion, defies logic and the laws of gravity during her unstoppable two-hour show. The aerial acrobatics, the taut cables and spinning cages, the whole business of soaring around an arena like a pop-punk Peter Pan: by now she has trained her audiences to expect this species of amazement in concert. It’s a condition of her current reality.

headline: Economy Is Woeful, and the Sex Even Worse
abstract: “For Love,” at the Irish Repertory Theater, is a riotously tart and fiercely energetic dramedy about women in their mid-30s struggling in contemporary, recession-ravaged Dublin.
lead_paragraph: After recent excursions into Americana with the radio play of “It’s a Wonderful Life,” rural nostalgia with “Donnybrook!” and 20th-century institutional repression with “Airswimming,” the Irish Repertory Theater switches into high contemporary gear with “For Love,” a riotously tart and fiercely energetic production that opened on Tuesday. Billed as a “dark blue romantic comedy,” the play — a dramedy, really, only fleetingly romantic — plunges straight into Ireland’s fraught urban present.

headline: Still an Ecstatic Rebel Spirit, but Easing Up on Shock
abstract: Lil Wayne’s new album, “I Am Not a Human Being II,” is consistent with music from his sober period: slapdash, a mix of blustering boasts, spiteful sex, warm sex and flashes of self-realization.
lead_paragraph: Lil Wayne has long been one of hip-hop’s loosest cannons, but his narrative changed dramatically in 2010 after his release from Rikers Island jail, where he spent eight months on a weapons charge. For three years at least, sobriety was to be his sidekick. As part of a plea agreement in a separate drug possession case, he consented to regular drug tests.

headline: A Man of Many Realms, Most Recently Daytime TV
abstract: A successful new daytime syndicated TV talk show, “Steve Harvey,” has helped cement Mr. Harvey’s status as one of the foremost entertainers in America.
lead_paragraph: Steve Harvey and Ted Harbert go way back — all the way to 1994, when Mr. Harbert, then president for entertainment at ABC, ordered a Harvey-led sitcom called “Me and the Boys.” The sitcom failed, as most do. But in 2011, “when my name came across his desk, he remembered me,” Mr. Harvey said this month, sounding appreciative still.

headline: Aggressive Play Catches Up to Mets’ Prospect
abstract: Outfielder Matt den Dekker landed on his glove hand and broke his wrist as he tried to make an awkward, acrobatic catch Sunday.
lead_paragraph: 6:48 p.m. | Updated PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Matt den Dekker’s audacious outfield play has earned him many plaudits during this spring training, and his spectacular catches have kept many wondering whether the Mets would start him at the major leagues solely for his glove.

headline: Master’s Blueprint, Born of Revolution
abstract: Vladimir Nabokov’s first major work, the play “The Tragedy of Mister Morn,” pits a mysterious king, who has brought peace to a fairy-tale land, against a group of revolutionaries.
lead_paragraph: The Russian Revolution upended the lives of Vladimir Nabokov and his family. Leaving behind an aristocratic world of colossal wealth and privilege (a world about which he could speak of “the smallest and oldest of our gardeners”), Nabokov would become an exile in Berlin, where he supported himself as a tutor, teaching French, English and tennis. On March 28, 1922, his father, a liberal politician, was shot and killed at a Berlin lecture while trying to protect another man from an assassin — a loss that would reverberate throughout Nabokov’s life and fiction.

headline: A Late 3-Pointer Falls, Ensuring That No. 1 Indiana Does Not
abstract: Victor Oladipo’s 3-pointer with 14 seconds remaining sealed top-seeded Indiana’s victory against No. 9 Temple.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — Indiana’s Christian Watford, Remy Abell and Yogi Ferrell watched Gonzaga lose to Wichita State from their hotel room Saturday night, enjoying the way the Shockers hit shots and felled a top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s opening weekend.

headline: Watch Out for the Horses on Your Way to the Train
abstract: An arts project is bringing life-size horses, each made colorful raffia and fitting two dancers, to the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: Commuters in Grand Central Terminal will encounter a new obstacle to making the train on time this week: 30 dancing horses.

headline: Escaping the Cross for a Spiritual Quest
abstract: The life of the man spared from crucifixion when Jesus died is presented in a two-part production with an international cast.
lead_paragraph: Barabbas, the man the crowd spared from crucifixion instead of Jesus, makes only a brief appearance in the Bible, but in more recent times his bit part has been expanded into a full-fledged “Easter event.”

headline: With Shovels and Science, a Grim Story Is Told
abstract: Excavation of a mass grave of Irish railroad workers in Pennsylvania, who died during a cholera epidemic in 1832, answers some questions and raises many more.
lead_paragraph: MALVERN, Pa. — They laid his bones in a bed of Bubble Wrap, with a care beyond what is normally given to fragile things. They double-boxed those bones and carried them last month to the United Parcel Service office on Spruce Street in Philadelphia. Then they printed out the address and paid the fee.

headline: American Dance Festival Unveils Summer Season
abstract: The American Dance Festival has announced the 80th edition of its summer season, from June 13 to July 27 in Durham, N.C., and New York City.
lead_paragraph: The American Dance Festival has announced the 80th edition of its summer season, from June 13 to July 27 in Durham, N.C., and New York City. The festival is to feature nine world premieres, including two by the dance troupe Pilobolus. The first is a collaboration with the choreographer Trish Sie set to original music by the Nortec Collective Presents Bostich + Fussible, a Latin fusion group. The second will highlight the illusionists Penn and Teller.
