Another world premiere is to be Twyla Tharp’s 130th work, which she has created for American Dance Festival students and set to a score by the music producer David Kahne. The festival is to include 47 performances by 25 companies, including Shen Wei Dance Arts, Paul Taylor Dance Company, Trisha Brown Dance Company, the Brenda Angiel Aerial Dance Company from Argentina, Mark Haim, Kyle Abraham/Abraham.In.Motion and Faye Driscoll. Among those presenting for the first time at the festival are Camille A. Brown & Dancers, the 605 Collective from Canada and Ponydance from Ireland. The festival plans to start a social-media campaign in honor of its anniversary, called “80 Years — 80 Stories,” in early May.

headline: With Woods Leading, Rain and Wind Push Final Round to Monday
abstract: A victory would be Tiger Woods’s record-tying eighth at the Arnold Palmer Invitational, but weather problems have forced him to wait.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — After Tiger Woods birdied the second hole to increase his lead at the Arnold Palmer Invitational to three strokes, it seemed that only an act of nature could prevent him from winning his 77th PGA Tour title, and his record-tying eighth in a single tournament.

headline: The Difficult Choices Ahead for the Dell Board
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The bids, for now, are placeholders. And even if all of the hoops are jumped through and the Dell board finds a Blackstone bid or Icahn final bid to be superior, the Silver Lake group has matching rights under the merger agreement.
lead_paragraph: Reports that both the Blackstone Group and Carl C. Icahn have submitted preliminary bids for Dell now set off a highly choreographed dance of next steps. And the developments highlight the difficult choices that the Dell board now faces.

headline: Yankees Working on a Deal to Acquire Vernon Wells from Angels
abstract: The outfielder, who has struggled in his two years in Los Angeles, is owed $42 million over the next two seasons. The Angels are expected to pick up much of that, receiving a marginal player in return.
lead_paragraph: 10:03 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees were working to sort out the final details Sunday of a trade that would bring them outfielder Vernon Wells from the Los Angeles Angels.

headline: Trimming the Field to 16
abstract: Florida Gulf Coast became the first No. 15 seed to reach the Round of 16, while higher seeds fended off upset challenges.
lead_paragraph: Florida Gulf Coast became the first No. 15 seed to reach the Round of 16, while higher seeds fended off upset challenges.

headline: Catcher d’Arnaud Among Six Trimmed From Mets Roster
abstract: Travis d’Arnaud will start at Class AAA, but the Mets said that if they needed a replacement for starter John Buck they would turn to d’Arnaud.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets demoted six players from their major league camp on Sunday.

headline: French Protest as Gay Marriage Bill Nears Passage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Many opponents have focused on a provision of the bill, which has already passed the lower house of Parliament and is expected to be approved by the Senate next month, that would allow same-sex couples to adopt children.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hundreds of thousands of protesters marched in the French capital on Sunday in opposition to a gay marriage bill sponsored by President François Hollande.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'States (US)']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Why I am on Hunger Strike in Bahrain
abstract: Zainab al-Khawaja, a human rights activist in Bahrain, writes a letter from prison about why she is on a hunger strike and how Martin Luther King Jr. guides her acts of civil disobedience.
lead_paragraph: This is a letter that Zainab al-Khawaja, a human rights activist and political prisoner in Bahrain, wrote from jail. I wrote about her in a column examining the regime’s repression of protesters. The United States is a leading backer of the Bahrain government and sells it weapons. Zainab went on a hunger strike recently, after being denied family visits in jail. – Nicholas D. Kristof

headline: China’s First Lady Strikes Glamorous Note
abstract: A well-known singer and a striking contrast to her predecessors, Peng Liyuan is adding star power to her husband’s first trip abroad as president, and might even outshine him.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Peng Liyuan, China’s new first lady, is glamorous, fashionable and one of her nation’s best-known singers, a startling contrast to her dour-looking predecessors. As she accompanies her husband, President Xi Jinping, on his first trip abroad as China’s leader, Ms. Peng appears ready to carve out a new role for herself.

headline: Libya Transferring $2 Billion to Egypt’s Bank
abstract: The timing of what amounts to a loan came after at least three Qaddafi loyalists in Cairo were rounded up for possible extradition.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libya’s transitional government is completing an agreement with Egypt to deposit $2 billion in the Egyptian central bank, an official briefed on the talks said Sunday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'Durable Goods (Economic Indicator)']
abstract: Economic data to be released Tuesday include durable goods for February, new-home sales for February and consumer confidence for March.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Economic data to be released include durable goods for February, the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller housing price index for January, new home sales for February and consumer confidence for March (Tuesday); pending home sales for February, weekly jobless claims, fourth-quarter gross domestic product (revised) and the Chicago P.M.I. for March (Thursday); personal income and spending for February and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March (Friday).

headline: Permit Allowing a Few Pints Tests a Tolerance for Drunken Driving
keywords: ['Rural Areas', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: An Irish town drew attention this winter after a county council passed a motion calling for people living in country areas to be allowed a few beers before driving home.
lead_paragraph: KILGARVAN, Ireland — Nestled in the shadow of the picturesque southern mountain range Macgillycuddy’s Reeks, home to Ireland’s three highest peaks, Kilgarvan is little more than a blink-and-you-miss-it blip on the busy road between the tourist towns of Killarney and Kenmare: a single street, a straggle of houses, a shop, two bars, a church and a graveyard. But it became the center of an international media frenzy this winter when the local council voted to legalize drunken driving.

headline: Ex-Ranger Kovalev Wants to Keep Playing
abstract: Alexei Kovalev, the last player still active from the Rangers’ 1994 Stanley Cup championship team before his retirement last week, said Sunday that he intends to play in Europe next season.
lead_paragraph: Alexei Kovalev, the last player still active from the Rangers’ 1994 Stanley Cup championship team before his retirement last week, said Sunday that he intends to play in Europe next season.

headline: In Leak Case, State Secrecy in Plain Sight
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Courts-Martial', 'News and News Media', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The government is withholding details about Pfc. Bradley Manning’s ostensibly public trial over state secrets.
lead_paragraph: Reporters covering the government’s prosecution of Pfc. Bradley Manning, who is being court-martialed for conveying secret information to WikiLeaks, have spent a year trying to pierce the veil of secrecy in what is supposed to be a public proceeding.

headline: Pension Funds Wary as Bankrupt City Goes to Trial
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Bankruptcies', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Local Government', 'Government Employees']
abstract: In Stockton, Calif., bondholders and insurers want the pain of the city’s bankruptcy to be evenly distributed. Calpers, the country’s largest pension system, prefers to protect its retirees.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is taking America’s biggest pension fund to court this week, for a long-awaited battle over who takes the losses when a city goes bust — workers and retirees, municipal bondholders, or both.

headline: Violence Brings an Identity Crisis in a Free-Spirited California Beach Town
keywords: ['Crime Rates', 'Homeless Persons', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Dueling slogans — “Keep Santa Cruz Weird” versus “Keep Santa Cruz Safe and Clean” — reflect heated debates on the city’s policies toward drug abuse and homelessness.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — Keep it weird? Or keep it safe and clean?

headline: Successful Four-Year Run Ends in Double-Overtime Loss for St. John’s
abstract: The Red Storm women came back from a 10-point deficit to force an overtime, but fell short against the Flyers in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: The most accomplished senior class in the history of women’s basketball at St. John’s suffered an agonizing end by falling to Dayton, 96-90 in double overtime, in a first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game at Carnesecca Arena.

headline: Ads That Speak the Language of Social Media
abstract: The new starring role of social media in ads signals that agencies and advertisers believe they are prevalent enough to refer to without the risk of being misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: MADISON AVENUE is offering consumers a status update on just how pervasive social media have become.

headline: A Last Smile and a Wave for Bay Area Commuters
abstract: Human toll collectors on the Golden Gate Bridge will be replaced this week by a fully automated system, and some are lamenting the loss of familiar faces in the booths.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To hear Jackie Dean tell it, it all started more than 18 years ago with her cousin Peaches’s beat-up Lincoln, a tip from her friend Gayle and possible betrayal by her own mother. But, really, it may have actually started back in the second grade, in Mr. John’s class, when Jackie and her classmates read the most books in their school in Oakland and won a choice of a field trip.

headline: Bringing In Help, Mayor Bows Out in Style at Annual Revue
abstract: The formerly low-key Inner Circle parody of city politics has been transformed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s wealth, this year featuring Broadway cast members.
lead_paragraph: He has descended to the stage as Spider-Man, pretended to smoke a joint as a hippie from “Hair,” and offered up satirical lessons in “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.”

headline: Pennsylvania Study Finds Halfway Houses Don’t Reduce Recidivism
abstract: A groundbreaking study concluded that inmates in halfway houses were more likely to return to crime than inmates released directly to the street, a finding that led the state to overhaul its contracts with providers.
lead_paragraph: The federal government and states across the country have spent billions of dollars in recent years on sprawling, privately run halfway houses, which are supposed to save money and rehabilitate inmates more effectively than prisons do.

headline: Thrills, and Hope, on Opening Day
abstract: Five months after Hurricane Sandy devastated the coast, the familiar traditions on opening day at Luna Park on Coney Island hinted at a return to normal.
lead_paragraph: Arriving at 8:30 the night before the ride was supposed to reopen for the season, Mr. Cyclone — otherwise known as Eric Knapp, 47 — had claimed the first spot in line to ride the Cyclone, Coney Island’s famed wooden roller coaster, and more than 15 hours later, he was still excited. Very excited.

headline: As SpinMedia, Web Firm Aims to Lift Smaller Sites
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: SpinMedia, formerly Buzzmedia, will introduce technological improvements to encourage readers to linger and to track them as they move from one device to another.
lead_paragraph: In the race for Internet advertising, could a few dozen runner-up blogs win in the end?

headline: Hot Money Blues
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Dealing with love-’em-and-leave-’em investors.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the final outcome in the Cyprus crisis — we know it’s going to be ugly; we just don’t know exactly what form the ugliness will take — one thing seems certain: for the time being, and probably for years to come, the island nation will have to maintain fairly draconian controls on the movement of capital in and out of the country. In fact, controls may well be in place by the time you read this. And that’s not all: Depending on exactly how this plays out, Cypriot capital controls may well have the blessing of the International Monetary Fund, which has already supported such controls in Iceland.

headline: Tragedies of Past Offer a Guide as Newtown Aid Goes Unspent
abstract: Organizations have raised millions to help Newtown, Conn., but some who have experienced mass tragedies in the past said charities had failed to distribute aid to those most in need.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — Almost as soon as the shooting stopped, the aid began. It came from groups large and small, established and impromptu.

headline: Three Cheers for the Nanny State
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Give me a 32-ounce soda or give me death! Seriously?
lead_paragraph: Brunswick, Me.

headline: Kansas Surges Past North Carolina and Williams
abstract: The top-seeded Jayhawks overcame a halftime deficit against their former coach Roy Williams and advanced to the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — North Carolina Coach Roy Williams walked out of the tunnel last, well after his players and assistants, a police officer beside him until he reached the hardwood floor. Slowly, politely, Kansas fans at Sprint Center stood and cheered for Williams, a former Jayhawks coach.

headline: ABC Creates Commercial to Save Its ‘Happy Endings’
abstract: Taking a cue from fans of endangered shows, the network made a commercial to keep a low-rated sitcom on the air.
lead_paragraph: The impulse among television superfans to create “save our show” campaigns for every imperiled sitcom and drama has been co-opted by one of the very networks that shows have to be saved from.

headline: States Gone Wild
abstract: Is our indivisible nation coming apart at the seams?
lead_paragraph: NO sooner had Arkansas adopted the country’s most regressive abortion law earlier this month — a ban after about 12 weeks of pregnancy — than North Dakota lowered its limit to as early as six weeks. Both measures are expected to be ruled unconstitutional, but here’s my question: Is North Dakota that much more conservative than, say, South Dakota, where abortions are permitted up to 24 weeks?

headline: No Longer Will News Lap at Miami Herald’s Door
abstract: In June, The Herald will leave its longtime home on Biscayne Bay for Doral, a small city best known for its traffic, warehouses and airport access.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — One Herald Plaza rises like a boxy behemoth on Biscayne Bay, an industrial-looking rectangle that is not so easy to like but hard to ignore. A fitting trait, it turns out, for a daily newspaper.

headline: Kerry Appeals to Laos in Case of a Missing Man
keywords: ['Missing Persons', 'United States International Relations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry urged the government to make public the results of an investigation of what happened to Sombath Somphone, an American-educated agricultural specialist.
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos — On the 100th day since the disappearance of a prominent American-educated Laotian agriculture specialist, Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday urged the government here to make public the results of an investigation into what had happened to him, and to return him to his family.

headline: A Magazine Article on Race Sets Off an Outcry
abstract: Philadelphia Magazine’s article “Being White in Philly” provoked a rebuke from the mayor, angry comments and the threat of a boycott, as well as a sales bump.
lead_paragraph: Few subjects appear to provoke from readers as much debate, and anger, as race does. Since Philadelphia Magazine published its article “Being White in Philly: Whites, race, class, and the things that never get said” in late February, it has drawn a public rebuke by the city’s mayor, the threat of a boycott by the local African-American Chamber of Commerce and at least two forums where the magazine’s editor and the article’s writer answered angry questions.

headline: Willful Ignorance
abstract: Cuts to the Census Bureau’s budget will create a big information gap.
lead_paragraph: Automatic spending cuts are a mindless way to budget, and they will leave the nation in the dark. Here’s how: Under the cuts, the Census Bureau budget will be $845 million, well below the Obama administration’s $970 million request. That will force the bureau to delay completion of the Economic Census, an immense survey done every five years that provides the benchmark measurements for economic growth and other vital indicators, including inflation and productivity. Without such data, policy makers, business leaders, investors, economists and social researchers will be at a disadvantage.

headline: The Credit-History Pariah Class
abstract: People whose credit history was damaged in the recession should not be shut out of the job market.
lead_paragraph: Research has shown that someone with a poor credit history is not automatically a poor job prospect. Nevertheless, millions of Americans who have emerged from the recession with medical debts or a record of late payments are at risk of being denied jobs by companies that use credit histories to screen applicants. Several states have placed limits on this practice. But until the federal government engages the issue more aggressively, employers will consign otherwise qualified applicants to a kind of pariah class that gets shut out of the job market.

headline: Is the Estate Tax Doomed?
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Taxation', 'United States Economy', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: As inequality has risen in the developed world, many governments have been dismantling — not increasing — estate taxes. In the United States, it took national wartime mobilization to create the political conditions that made progressive estate taxation possible.
lead_paragraph: Under the deal struck by President Obama and Congress to avert the “fiscal cliff,” the estate tax — long targeted for elimination by Republicans — survived, but in a substantially diminished form.

headline: For Homesick Russian Tycoon, Instant of Ruin Came in Court
abstract: It is still unclear how Boris A. Berezovsky died, but what is certain is that a humiliating court ruling last August helped to drive the exiled oligarch into despair.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The moment of ruin for Boris A. Berezovsky, the exiled Russian oligarch who was found dead on Saturday outside London, came not when he fell out with the Kremlin, or when his latest long-term relationship broke up, or even when Russia sentenced him to prison in absentia.

headline: Justices to Look at Deals by Generic and Branded Drug Makers
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: The Supreme Court is to decide whether the maker of a brand-name drug can pay a generic-drug company to keep its version off the market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just about anyone who has gone to a pharmacy and paid for a prescription knows that a generic copy costs much less than the brand-name drug. The makers of those two versions of a drug, therefore, usually compete fiercely for market share and profits.

headline: Time to Strengthen Family Immigration
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Reuniting loved ones will bolster communities and the economy, as it always has.
lead_paragraph: The momentum in Washington for immigration reform has been growing with amazing speed in recent weeks, and it seems that the question now is not whether Congress will try to fix the immigration system this year, but how big and effective the repairs will be. We hope that whatever bill emerges will continue to protect and unite families, preserving and strengthening a bedrock value of America’s immigration system.

headline: Wichita State Put Attitude on Display Against Gonzaga
abstract: Lost among the attention given to Gonzaga after falling to the Shockers was how Wichita State played down the stretch. They inflicted pain and owned the game at times.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY

headline: Europe Caps Bank Bonuses
abstract: The restrictions just passed are unlikely to make bankers more accountable or the financial system more sound.
lead_paragraph: European policy makers are imposing new restrictions on bonuses paid to bankers in an attempt to reduce incentives that encourage them to take imprudent risks. Unfortunately, the rule is unlikely to make bank executives and financial traders more accountable or the financial system more sound.

headline: Academic Filmmaking for Profit
abstract: The film school at Chapman University in California is experimenting with moviemaking for a profit, with films directed by Chapman alumni.
lead_paragraph: Venture philanthropy? Social entrepreneurship? Robert L. Bassett, dean of the Dodge College of Film and Media Arts at Chapman University in Orange County, Calif., said he still wasn’t sure how to label it.

headline: At the Hospital: The Role of the Team
abstract: Doctors and a dentist respond to a Sunday Review article, “Healing the Hospital Hierarchy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: E.U. Officials Agree to a Deal Rescuing Cyprus
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The deal, struck after hours of meetings in Brussels, would drastically reduce the size of the country’s banking sector and scrap the controversial tax on bank deposits.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Struggling into the early-morning hours to avoid a collapse of Cyprus’s banking system, European Union leaders on Monday agreed on a bailout package intended to keep Cyprus in the euro zone and rebuild its devastated economy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery Numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 24, 2013

headline: 2 Rivals Complicate Deal for Dell
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The private equity giant Blackstone Group and the investor Carl C. Icahn have each separately submitted preliminary takeover proposal for Dell, the embattled computer maker.
lead_paragraph: Two rival bids for Dell Inc. have emerged, threatening to complicate or change — or upend — an effort to take the embattled computer maker private in a $24 billion deal under the leadership of Michael S. Dell.

headline: F.C.C. Shift May Thwart a Murdoch Media Deal
abstract: News Corporation wants the F.C.C. to waive a rule that would prevent it from acquiring The Los Angeles Times, but a regulator’s exit may delay further action.
lead_paragraph: In weighing a bid for The Los Angeles Times, Rupert Murdoch finds himself in a familiar role: waiting for rule changes from the government. With the resignation last week of Julius Genachowski, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, he may have to wait a little longer.

headline: New Efforts to Make a Scenic California Highway Less Perilous
abstract: A tunnel, part of a $439 million project, is one of several recent efforts to improve Highway 1, which is perched on rocky cliffs along the earthquake-prone coast.
lead_paragraph: PACIFICA, Calif. — After a half-century of debate, motorists early Tuesday will be able to drive onto a bridge suspended 300 feet above land and through a tunnel dug into a verdant mountain 20 miles south of San Francisco. The federally financed $439 million project skirts the treacherous Devil’s Slide slice of California Highway 1 in one of the most scenic stretches of highway in the world.

headline: An Ex-Gambler Weighs the Cost of Addiction
abstract: Stephen M. Block, a counselor to problem gamblers, discusses the latest attempts by New York State to expand opportunities and thus dip deeper into the pockets of those who can least afford to lose.
lead_paragraph: Sure he knows when he made his last wager, Stephen M. Block said. It was on May 10, 1975, “a lifetime ago.”

headline: Gators Lose Big Lead but Finally Pull Away
abstract: The third-seeded Gators, who have struggled in close games all season, took a 48-27 lead at halftime, then withstood a comeback by No. 11 Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Florida has proved equal parts fragile and unflinching this season, frittering away tight games that a program of its stature is expected to dominate or handing opponents demoralizing defeats.

headline: Naughty in Name Only
abstract: Sophia Amoruso turned an eBay store selling vintage finds into Nasty Gal, an online fashion retailer with nearly $100 million in annual sales.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If ever there were a Cinderella of tech, Sophia Amoruso might be it.

headline: Candidate Ends Effort to Sidestep a City Cap
abstract: Testing campaign finance rules has proved more difficult than George T. McDonald predicted, and the mayoral hopeful is now preparing to participate in the very system he wishes to undermine.
lead_paragraph: George T. McDonald, a first-time candidate for mayor, has pursued an unorthodox electoral strategy thus far: deliberately violating the city’s campaign finance rules, in order to change them.

headline: For the College-Bound, Are There Any Safe Bets?
abstract: Which majors and careers have a reliable “return on investment”?

headline: Guns and Abusers
abstract: Legal Momentum, a legal defense and education fund for the rights of women and girls, responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Callous Spending Cuts
abstract: A reader criticizes budget cuts proposed by Representative Paul C. Broun Jr.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Love and Disability
abstract: The mother of a son with Down syndrome responds to an Editorial Observer essay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Algae in Lake Erie
abstract: The Agriculture Department and the Environmental Protection Agency describe their actions to help farmers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Aid to Victims of Rape
abstract: The Center for Health and Gender Equity responds to an editorial, “Cruelty to Women Overseas.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This Time, Paul Is Winner in Point Guard Battle
abstract: The Clippers’ victory over the Nets was a rare victory for Chris Paul over the Nets’ Deron Williams, who holds a 14-5 advantage in the career series against Paul.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Whether the Nets are beating bad teams and losing to better opponents, feasting on the Eastern Conference while struggling against teams in the West, matchups have often dictated results in the team’s inaugural season in Brooklyn. In the Nets’ 101-95 loss to the Los Angeles Clippers, the matchup theme unfolded in a variety of interesting battles on the court, like a series of skits in a Saturday night showcase.

headline: NBC Risks Its Late-Night Dominance With a ‘Tonight’ Gamble
abstract: Jay Leno is still the ratings king of late-night television, but his expected replacement, Jimmy Fallon, has Internet skills and cross-generational appeal.
lead_paragraph: The Green Bay Packers had a long, successful run with Brett Favre until they decided in 2008 that it was time to give the quarterback job to a rising talent — Aaron Rodgers — even though the future Hall of Famer was still winning games. Now NBC is following the same script in another hugely competitive arena: late-night television.

headline: Arms Airlift to Syria Rebels Expands, With Aid From C.I.A.
keywords: ['AIRLIFTS', 'Arms Trade', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Military help for Syria’s opposition from Arab states and Turkey has grown in recent months, and the C.I.A.’s role has indicated an American willingness to help support lethal aid.
lead_paragraph: With help from the C.I.A., Arab governments and Turkey have sharply increased their military aid to Syria’s opposition fighters in recent months, expanding a secret airlift of arms and equipment for the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, according to air traffic data, interviews with officials in several countries and the accounts of rebel commanders.

headline: Women’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 24
abstract: In the second full day of women’s games, No. 14 Albany gave No. 3 North Carolina a scare and No. 10 St. John’s fell to No. 7 Dayton in double overtime.
lead_paragraph: In the second full day of women’s games, No. 14 Albany gave No. 3 North Carolina a scare and No. 10 St. John’s fell to No. 7 Dayton in double overtime.

headline: Luring Young Web Warriors Is Priority. It’s Also a Game.
abstract: Taking a page from China, the United States is scouring high schools for hackers, finding recruits with contests that aim to get them excited about cyberdefense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the eighth grade, Arlan Jaska figured out how to write a simple script that could switch his keyboard’s Caps Lock key on and off 6,000 times a minute. When friends weren’t looking, he slipped his program onto their computers. It was all fun and games until the program spread to his middle school.

headline: As Chicago’s Wait for Rose Continues, Weight Grows Heavier
abstract: The return of Derrick Rose, who has been medically cleared to play, remains a mystery for the Bulls. Each day, cameras follow him and fans keep asking “when?”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Derrick Rose sustained a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in the first round of last year’s N.B.A. playoffs, Chicago Bulls fans immediately began counting the days until his return. Eleven months later, they are still counting, but are also fully engaged in hand-wringing, anxious uncertainty and perhaps even prayer as the waiting continues and Rose’s return this season is no longer a question of when, but if.

headline: An Arms Pipeline to the Syrian Rebels
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: More than 160 military cargo flights for Syria’s rebels, mostly from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, have landed in Turkey and Jordan since January 2012.
lead_paragraph: More than 160 military cargo flights for Syria’s rebels, mostly from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, have landed in Turkey and Jordan since January 2012.

headline: Bebo Valdés, a Force in World of Cuban Music, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Valdés, a pianist, arranger and composer, was at the center of Havana’s musical life in the pre-Castro era.
lead_paragraph: Bebo Valdés, a pianist, arranger and composer who was a musical lightning rod in Havana during the evolution of the mambo and, after a long fallow period, a million-selling success in his last two decades, died on Friday in Stockholm, his primary residence since 1963. He was 94.

headline: A Human Touch
abstract: On Wednesday, Jackie Dean, who began working on the Golden Gate Bridge 18 years ago, will be one of more than two dozen toll collectors who will be replaced by a completely automated system.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Jackie Dean, who began working on the Golden Gate Bridge 18 years ago, will be one of more than two dozen toll collectors who will be replaced by a completely automated system.

headline: 15th Seed Makes Round of 16 for First Time
abstract: In only its second season eligible for the N.C.A.A. tournament, Florida Gulf Coast has gone from an unknown team to perhaps the most celebrated. The Eagles beat No. 7 San Diego State on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — After pregame player introductions, Florida Gulf Coast’s Sherwood Brown began to dance as his teammates, their arms interlocked, spun in a circle around him, their speed building and building until they broke apart and scattered.

headline: Ray Williams Dies at 58; Itinerant in Pros and Life
abstract: Mr. Williams played 10 well-traveled seasons with the National Basketball Association, but he became homeless and declared bankruptcy after his career until landing a job in his hometown.
lead_paragraph: Ray Williams could seemingly do it all on a basketball court. He had an outstanding shooting touch, he possessed superb body control, and he could make a timely pass. He teamed with Micheal Ray Richardson in the Knicks’ backcourt to dazzle the crowds at Madison Square Garden in the late 1970s and early ’80s.

headline: Malachi Throne, Actor on TV, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Throne, of the ’60s television shows “It Takes a Thief” and “Batman,” was in both Gene Roddenberry’s original “Star Trek” and “Star Trek: The Next Generation.”
lead_paragraph: Malachi Throne, a character actor best known for playing Robert Wagner’s boss on the ABC spy series “It Takes a Thief” and a villain on “Batman,” died on March 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Gaining Point Eases the Sting of a Loss
abstract: The Rangers bounced back from another slow start, but Henrik Lundqvist, who excels in shootouts, could not steal another point.
lead_paragraph: Going into Sunday’s game against the Washington Capitals, Henrik Lundqvist had won 44 shootouts, more than any other N.H.L. goalie, and his .765 save percentage was better than that of any goalie who had been in 20 or more shootouts.

headline: James Herbert, British Horror Novelist, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Herbert wrote supernatural thrillers and horror stories, like “The Rats,” that made fans like Stephen King squirm.
lead_paragraph: James Herbert, a British novelist who wrote supernatural thrillers and horror stories and whose menagerie of marauding rats, serial killers, evil spirits, ghosts and ghost hunters filled books that sold millions of copies and frightened readers around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Sussex, England. He was 69.

headline: Cal Whipple, 94, Dies; Won 1943 Fight to Print Photo of War Dead
abstract: When censors refused Life magazine permission to publish a photo showing the bodies of three American soldiers, Mr. Whipple got President Franklin D. Roosevelt to reverse the decision.
lead_paragraph: A. B. C. Whipple held high posts in the Time-Life publishing empire and wrote extensively about the sea. But he counted among his proudest achievements the role of tenacious young intermediary in a fight by Life magazine against the military censorship of a single photograph during World War II — a fight that went all the way to the White House.

headline: Eddie Bond, Elvis Contemporary, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Bond was known, among other things, for telling a young Elvis Presley that he wouldn’t make it big as a singer.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Bond, a rockabilly singer and radio host who once told a teenage Elvis Presley that he would be better off driving a truck than trying to make it in music, died on Wednesday at his home in Bolivar, Tenn. He was 79.

headline: Pushed to the End, Miami Finds Its Rhythm and Holds Off Illinois
abstract: No. 2 seed Miami needed everything it had to turn back seventh-seeded Illinois and advance to the Round of 16 for only the second time in university history.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Miami Hurricanes start four seniors, and their lone underclassman, the sophomore guard Shane Larkin, happens to be the Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year.

headline: What Causes Hearing Loss
abstract: Tens of millions of Americans, including 12 percent to 15 percent of schoolchildren, have permanent hearing damage caused by everyday noise.
lead_paragraph: Noise, not age is the leading cause of hearing loss. Unless you take steps now to protect to your ears, sooner or later many of you — and your children — will have difficulty understanding even ordinary speech.

headline: Infants Are Fed Solid Food Too Soon, C.D.C. Finds
abstract: Doctors now recommend waiting until a baby is at least 6 months old, but a national survey found that many mothers were unaware of the guidelines and that many struggled to buy formula.
lead_paragraph: Despite growing warnings from pediatricians about feeding newborns anything other than breast milk or formula, many mothers appear to be introducing solid food well before their babies’ bodies can handle it, says a study published Monday in the journal Pediatrics.

headline: Pro-Obama Group Enters Immigration Fray
abstract: Starting this week, Organizing for Action will promote online personal stories from supporters of a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Organizing for Action, the political group that grew out of President Obama’s successful re-election campaign machinery, will jump into the immigration debate this week with an aggressive online effort to highlight the personal stories of immigrants.

headline: Sounders Have Found Something in Yedlin
abstract: DeAndre Yedlin, 19, has been a revelation since signing with the Seattle Sounders as a homegrown player in January. A berth on the United States under-20 team could be next.
lead_paragraph: When Major League Soccer created the homegrown player rule in 2008, it was an attempt to offer an incentive for teams to invest in youth development by allowing clubs to directly sign their academy players instead of having them go potentially to other teams through the SuperDraft.

headline: Word of the Day | optician
abstract: This word has appeared in five New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: optician •\äp-ˈti-shən\• noun

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) 180 DAYS: A YEAR INSIDE AN AMERICAN HIGH SCHOOL This two-part report follows a year in the life of the first graduating class of Washington Metropolitan High School in the District of Columbia, a public school where only 7 percent of students are deemed proficient in math and 19 percent in reading. Still, its outspoken young principal, Tanishia Williams Minor, remains optimistic that her charges will succeed despite low test scores and numerous personal and academic obstacles. Among the students are Raven Coston, 17, above, who was displaced from New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina and is raising a baby and working part time; Raven Quattlebaum, 18, who grew up in foster care and spent her days robbing and assaulting people before becoming determined to go to college; Rufus McDowney, 16, who has been in and out of the juvenile justice system for three years; Tiara Parker, 18, an aspirational senior who maybe not be able to afford college; and Delaunte Bennett, 18, a sophomore who was kicked out of several schools because of fighting and now lags two years behind his peers.

headline: Driving the Lane, La Salle Finds It Leads Straight to the Round of 16
abstract: No. 13 La Salle squeezed by No. 12 Ole Miss in the final seconds to advance to the Round of 16, where they will face Wichita State.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — So what, exactly, is a Southwest Philly floater?

headline: Ex-Ranger Kovalev Still Wants to Play
abstract: Alexei Kovalev, the last player still active from the Rangers’ 1994 Stanley Cup championship team before his retirement last week, said Sunday that he intends to play in Europe next season.
lead_paragraph: Alexei Kovalev, the last player still active from the Rangers’ 1994 Stanley Cup championship team before his retirement last week, said Sunday that he intends to play in Europe next season.

headline: Corrections: March 25, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 25, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Mother of 4 Is Said to Be 110th Tibetan to Self-Immolate
abstract: A Tibetan mother of four was reported to have set herself afire Sunday in protest over Chinese rule, as an article by a respected writer calling on his fellow Tibetans to stop the self-immolations remained available on the domestic Internet; unusually, since any mention of the suicides is normally quickly removed.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A mother of four, Kal Kyi, set fire to herself on Sunday afternoon in Aba, a Tibetan area of Sichuan Province in China, becoming the 110th Tibetan to self-immolate in protest over Chinese rule since 2009, according to a report on an India-based Tibetan Web site, Phayul.com.

headline: Nets Regain Their Road Momentum
abstract: Behind 21 points from Brook Lopez and 20 from Deron Williams, the Nets beat the Suns for their third win in the first four games of an eight-game trip.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — One team was missing its sweet-shooting guard. The other got an unexpected explosion from an erratic shooting guard of the same surname. headline: What Are You Doing to Fix India’s Broken Education System?
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Education (K-12)', 'English Language', 'Poverty', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: A teacher in a Mumbai slum says all Indians, and in fact the entire world, have a moral responsibility to address crippling inequalities.
lead_paragraph: It is now almost four years since I first walked through a series of winding by-lanes in a Mumbai slum toward my new job as a teacher at a low-income school. I was forced to confront India’s educational inequities squarely in the eye. Students filed into a dilapidated old school building, and my own musty classroom, crammed with cupboards, barely left any room to move.

headline: The Man Behind Putin
abstract: Until his death on Saturday, the oligarch Boris Berezovsky thought it was a brilliant idea for him to have backed the president who is ruining Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The oligarch Boris Berezovsky, who died near London on Saturday, would have enjoyed watching Russians react to his death. He reportedly suffered from depression in the last few months of his life, and I know he was plagued by the nagging sense that he could no longer make himself relevant to Russian politics. Not only has his death dominated every media outlet and every conversation in Moscow, but President Vladimir Putin’s press secretary, Dmitri Peskov, stated that Berezovsky wrote to Putin a couple of months ago asking forgiveness and “requesting permission to return to the motherland.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Murdoch Weighs a Newspaper Deal and Steve Harvey Surprises Daytime TV
abstract: Rupert Murdoch will have to wrangle with regulators once again if he tries to buy The Los Angeles Times, Steve Harvey has become a daytime TV standout and NBC is risking one of its rare high points in the ratings by replacing Jay Leno on “Tonight” with Jimmy Fallon.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch finds himself in a familiar predicament as he considers a bid for The Los Angeles Times: awaiting rule changes from the government, Amy Chozick reports. Mr. Murdoch has increased his lobbying efforts to revise a media ownership rule that prevents companies from owning both television stations and newspapers in the same local market (News Corporation owns KTTV and KCOP in the Los Angeles area). Mr. Murdoch has given mixed signals about his interest in The Los Angeles Times, which the Tribune Company plans to sell. The resignation last week of the Federal Communications Commission chairman, Julius Genachowski, could further slow the process. Mr. Genachowski had proposed allowing a rule change to allow a single company to own both a TV station and newspaper in a top-20 market provided the station was not in the top four in audience size.

headline: Leading Off: An Injection of Joy

lead_paragraph: They have sprung to life like bright flowers in a desert, their sheer exuberance breaking the bleak landscape around them. The Florida Gulf Coast players laugh. They do the chicken dance. They throw preposterous passes for alley-oop dunks in the tense moments of games. They celebrate like this moment is all that matters, the only one guaranteed them, or any of us. And we laugh along with them. Because we can. And we should. It’s as if they were dialed up by the sporting gods for this N.C.A.A. tournament to remind us this is supposed to be fun. This is what joy looks like.

headline: Now Showing | The Abraham Archives
abstract: In Antwerp, a closer look at the intricately printed textiles from the firm Abraham, which supplied the couture houses Dior, Givenchy and Balenciaga.
lead_paragraph: Though Paris was undisputedly the world capital of fashion in the immediate postwar period, one of its more important, if lesser-known, suburbs was Zurich, the home of the exclusive textile firm Abraham, which kept the couture houses of Christian Dior, Hubert de Givenchy, Cristóbal Balenciaga et al supplied with intricately printed, ultraluxurious Lyon silk. Abraham and its creative director, Gustave Zemsteg, who called on artist friends like Joan Miro and Marc Chagall to design prints, are the subjects of a new exhibition at Antwerp’s Mode Museum. Zemsteg’s most fruitful partnership was with his close friend Yves Saint Laurent, whom he met at the funeral of another client, Christian Dior. “I wouldn’t call their correspondence love letters, but they are certainly affectionate,” says the show’s curator, Karen Van Godtsenhoven. “It was a friendship as well as a business relationship.” Saint Laurent, then the newly appointed Dior heir, went on to use Abraham silk throughout his career; his last couture collection, in 2002, was the firm’s death knell. Faced with a dwindling market for its ultra-upscale fabrics, it closed its doors and donated its meticulous archive to the Swiss National Museum. “The bold flower prints, the fabrics with gold — what they did was incredibly opulent,” Van Godtsenhoven says.

headline: Tracking Your Finances, One Number at a Time
abstract: Tracking a single number — whether it’s how much you save each month or how much your investments are worth — may be a subtle nudge to improving your finances.

As Thomas Monson, an author and president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, said: “When performance is measured, performance improves. When performance is measured and reported back, the rate of improvement accelerates.”

headline: What You Need to Know About Credit Card Processing
abstract: Every merchant services application I have seen has required a Social Security number and demanded that all card transactions be backstopped by my own assets. My house, my car and my savings are all up for grabs if things go wrong.

It was not an easy search, but I learned a lot — much of which I never wanted to know but some of which I think may be helpful to other business owners.

headline: Building a Better Sandwich
abstract: Sandwiches can provide a great way to get more vegetables into your diet.

They are working together to address the problem, which is at the heart of the health and obesity crisis facing our country. A couple of weeks ago I brought you burgers that were made with a mix of meat and vegetables. What I didn’t talk about was how you could build on that burger, with layers of different lettuces, tomatoes, peppers, onions, pickles and even cooked greens.

headline: Know When to Hold ’Em: Making Family Time Work for Teens
abstract: When did I lose the power to declare “family time”?
lead_paragraph: When my children were little, it was easy to create connected family time. I called it incubation, when we’d shut out the rest of the world and go off on our own, just the kids and my husband and me. We’d make a plan, pack up some snacks, load everyone in the car or strollers, and head out to some near or far-off state park or nature area, where we could run, play, climb and be as loud as a family of six people is sometimes wont to be.

headline: Anna Quindlen and Andrew Solomon Join Discussion About Media and Transgender Children
abstract: News organizations should evaluate the motivations of parents who want to take their child’s story public.
lead_paragraph: My blog post last week – about Coy Mathis, the 6-year-old transgender Colorado child – drew some strong responses from readers. On Twitter, I immediately heard from those who sharply questioned my suggestion that “the willingness of the child” be considered, along with parental approval, in deciding to name her and use photographs of her. As many of these critics (some of whom were parents) noted, young children are willing to do many things they might regret later; they don’t have the maturity to know how their actions will play out.
