headline: The Gun Report: March 25, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The new meme among gun absolutists appears to be hammers. “Why did you elect to report on guns as a choice of weapon, when according to current F.B.I. stats, bear claw hammers and baseball bats are the number 1 and number 2 choice of weapon?” wrote a pro-gun reader: “Guns are 3rd.” When I was interviewing Second Amendment absolutists for Saturday’s column, I heard the same thing. So of course, Jennifer Mascia and I looked into it. Guess what? It doesn’t appear to be true, as Slate reported in February. According to F.B.I. data, if you add up all the non-gun methods used to kill people in 2011 (fire, drowning, poison, strangling, hammers, etc.), you get 4,081 non-gun homicides. That’s fewer than half of the F.B.I.’s reported 8,583 gun homicides in 2011. Guns killed more than 17 times more people than hammers and are responsible for nearly 70 percent of total murders. Indeed, Slate reported, “only 496 people were killed by blunt objects, a category that includes not just hammers and baseball bats but crowbars, rocks, paving stones, statuettes, and electric guitars.”

headline: Attorney General Picks Ex-Bloomberg Aide to Be Chief of Staff
abstract: Micah C. Lasher, who served as the mayor’s chief lobbyist in Albany, will join the office of Eric T. Schneiderman as he gears up for re-election next year.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The state attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has hired a former aide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to serve as his chief of staff.

headline: Companies Get Strict on Health of Workers
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Motivation and Incentive Programs', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Medicine and Health', 'Corporations', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A survey found that employers are using both rewards and penalties in an effort to lower their health costs.
lead_paragraph: Employers are increasingly trying to lower health care costs by using incentives to persuade workers to make better lifestyle choices, a new survey shows, but what remains less clear is whether a reward is better than a punishment — or whether the programs work at all.

headline: Zimbabwe: Human Rights Lawyer Released From Jail
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Beatrice Mtetwa had been held on a charge of obstruction of justice after demanding a search warrant at a client’s home.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — After more than a week in jail, the human rights lawyer Beatrice Mtetwa was released Monday after a high court judge overruled a lower court’s decision that she be held without bail on a charge of obstruction of justice.

headline: Hong Kong Court Denies Residency to Domestics
abstract: A landmark case, involving a Filipino woman who had worked in Hong Kong for 27 years as a domestic helper, highlighted questions of judicial independence.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s highest court ruled unanimously on Monday that a woman from the Philippines who had lived and worked here for nearly 27 years as a domestic helper was not entitled to permanent residency, ending an acrimonious legal fight over the immigration rights of migrant workers.

headline: A Breakup Letter From My Chemical Romance
abstract: Gerard Way, the singer of My Chemical Romance, tried to explain the band’s split in a 2,200-word letter posted online.
lead_paragraph: My Chemical Romance — a band known for its dense, intensely strained instrumental textures, darkly poetic if often mysterious lyrics and elaborately theatrical performance style — announced its breakup on Friday evening after a 12-year career that produced four highly regarded studio albums (most notably “The Black Parade”) as well as two live discs and a handful of EPs.

headline: Breaking It Down: Isner Vs. Dodig
abstract: John Isner and Ivan Dodig are polar opposites in how they approach the game. But as a match at the Sony Open demonstrated, their strategies are effective.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–The beauty of tennis is that there are so many different ways to win a match.

headline: The Improbable Life of Paul Erdős
abstract: Paul Erdös was one of the most extraordinary mathematicians of the last century. Celebrate the 100th anniversary of his birth with two puzzles, including a challenge from a longtime collaborator, Ronald Graham.
lead_paragraph: This week we celebrate the life of the most published mathematician in history, Paul Erdos (AIR-dosh), who was born 100 years ago on March 26. Dr. Erdos, who has been called the world’s greatest problem poser and solver, collaborated with over 500 mathematicians before his death in 1996.

headline: Sending a Message for Backpedaling on Settlements
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Standard Chartered learned the hard way that prosecutors take deferred prosecution agreements quite seriously, when the government forced the chairman to retract his statements on the settlement.
lead_paragraph: When a company accepts a deferred prosecution agreement to resolve a criminal investigation, one requirement is that it cannot backtrack on an admission of guilt. Standard Chartered learned the hard way that prosecutors take these agreements quite seriously when an executive tries to soft-pedal any corporate wrongdoing.

headline: BioShock’s Latest: Civil War in a City in the Sky
abstract: The new BioShock Infinite, from the Irrational video game studio, takes place in a 1912 dystopian environment loaded with period detail.
lead_paragraph: During the long development of BioShock Infinite — the first release by the Massachusetts studio Irrational Games since the original BioShock transfixed players more than five years ago — there were open fears on blogs, in discussion forums and in conversations among video game journalists that the new BioShock game just wouldn’t be any good.

headline: Single-Serving Wine for Sipping Small
abstract: Pinot grigio, California merlot, cabernet sauvignon and chardonnay are now sold in sealed single-serve plastic goblets.
lead_paragraph: Buy me some pinot and Cracker Jack! Pinot grigio, California merlot, cabernet sauvignon and chardonnay are now sold in sealed single-serve plastic goblets. Next month, Zipz, the company behind this new format, will introduce them at baseball stadiums, including Citi Field (hear that, Mets fans?), and at wine shops.

headline: Street Style: Boyfriend Jeans
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of March 18.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of March 18.

headline: Spotify, New to Advertising, Says ‘I’ve Got the Music in Me’
abstract: The major competitors in digital music services are spending large sums on advertising campaigns that are meant to generate awareness, consideration and trial. The newest entrant in the ad club is Spotify, which plans on Monday to start its first campaign aimed at American music lovers.
lead_paragraph: The field of digital music services is getting as crowded as CBGB was when the Ramones played. So major competitors are spending large sums on advertising campaigns that are meant to generate awareness, consideration and trial.

headline: The Hotel del Coronado’s Past Lives
abstract: This year, the San Diego hotel celebrates its 125th anniversary with a series of events and a new commemorative book.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who’s walked the grounds of the famed Hotel del Coronado knows all too well, the past has a way of catching up with you. There’s the ghost of Kate Morgan, whose dead body was found on Nov. 29, 1892, five days after she’d checked in under the alias Lottie A. Bernard. The San Diego coroner ultimately determined that the gunshot wound to her head was self-inflicted. Today, those who stay in her room (3327, previously No. 302) — the most requested one in the hotel — continue to report paranormal activity, including a television set that randomly turns on. Ms. Morgan is not the only famous name on the hotel’s guest register. Previous guests have included Frank Sinatra, Lucille Ball, Desi Arnaz, Charlie Chaplin, Charles Lindbergh and Marilyn Monroe, whose film “Some Like It Hot,” was shot here. This year, the hotel celebrates its 125th anniversary with a series of events and a new commemorative book, “Hotel del Coronado History.”

headline: Drone Disdain
abstract: Fifty-two percent of Americans oppose the use of drones to target American citizens living abroad.
lead_paragraph: Each time a reporter or an elected official questions the Obama administration about its theory that the president may order the killing of an American citizen that he considers an actual or even potential terrorist threat, the same thing happens. The administration reacts with ill-concealed disdain.

headline: Paul Rose, Quebec Separatist Involved in Kidnapping, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Rose was a member of the FLQ extremist group that kidnapped Canadian political leaders and committed dozens of terrorist bombings. He was later convicted of murder.
lead_paragraph: Paul Rose, a strident Quebec separatist leader who in October 1970 helped kidnap and, he claimed, strangle a provincial official, inflaming a crisis that pitted terrorists against the Canadian prime minister, Pierre Trudeau, died on March 14 in Montreal. He was 69.

headline: Cornell Wrestler Savors 4th Title in 4th Weight Class
abstract: Kyle Dake of Cornell became the first wrestler to win four N.C.A.A. titles in four weight classes.
lead_paragraph: By winning the 165-pound weight class at the N.C.A.A. wrestling championships in Des Moines over the weekend, Kyle Dake became the first collegiate wrestler to win four national titles in four weight classes and the third to win four titles over all.

headline: Q. and A.: A Decisive Moment on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Referendums']
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Tuesday on whether Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage, violates the federal Constitution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear an hourlong argument on Tuesday morning over the constitutionality of Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage. Here is a look at the background of the case, Hollingsworth v. Perry, No. 12-144; the issues it raises; the lawyers who will argue it; and the possible outcomes.

headline: Obama Presides Over Swearing In New Americans
abstract: The ceremony came as momentum builds for a plan to legalize millions of other foreigners now in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: President Obama presided over a ceremony swearing in new American citizens at the White House on Monday as part of his pitch for legislation that would overhaul the nation’s immigration laws.

headline: Indian Car Ad Goes Viral, Not in a Good Way
abstract: Ford Motor Company was forced to apologize Monday for an ad posted online last week promoting its Indian hatchback with a cartoon showing three bound and gagged women in the rear of a vehicle driven by Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps putting the maxim that there is no such thing as bad publicity to a new test, Ford Motor Company was forced to apologize Monday for an ad posted online last week promoting its Indian hatchback with a cartoon showing three bound and gagged women in the rear of a vehicle driven by Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister.

headline: Worries Over Violence Prompt Shutdown in Myanmar
abstract: A major commercial area of Yangon, the country’s largest city, closed Monday after rumors spread of attacks on Muslims, reflecting the nervous mood after deadly rioting last week.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A major commercial area of Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city, shut down on Monday after rumors spread there of sectarian attacks on Muslims. The shutdown reflected the nervous mood in the country after deadly rioting last week by Buddhist mobs.

headline: Cyprus Rescue Deal Addresses Important Principles
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: The bailout deal that Cyprus reached with its euro zone partners makes the best of an extremely bad situation, but there are lingering doubts on capital controls and the effect the debt will have on the economy, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Cyprus’s economy is going to suffer terribly in the next few years. Some of that is inevitable given how bloated its banking system has become. But the disastrous handling of the crisis, especially in the last week, will make things much worse.

headline: Advice to Researchers and Reanimating Dead Mice
abstract: A look at coming events at the intersection of science and culture.
lead_paragraph: BOOK

headline: Supreme Court Preview
abstract: The Times’s Adam Liptak lays out the key issues in the same-sex marriage cases this week.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Adam Liptak lays out the key issues in the same-sex marriage cases this week.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: If you’ve wondering whether that woman really climbed that tall, rocky mountain in the Citibank commercial, here’s the answer.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: New Suitors for Dell Raise Specter of Founder’s Loss
abstract: Michael S. Dell considers the Blackstone Group’s preliminary proposal for his company to be potentially friendly to management and may reach out to talk later this week, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: 8:43 p.m. | Updated

headline: Best N.B.A.Games of the Week
abstract: The best N.B.A. games this week include two challenges to the Heat’s winning streak, Knicks at Celtics and the Nuggets at Spurs.
lead_paragraph: Off the Dribble highlights three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)

headline: In an Area Plagued by Violence, a ‘God Squad’ Hits the Streets
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police']
abstract: The Rev. Gilford Monrose says the role of the 67th Precinct Clergy Council “is to diffuse a potential disaster in Brooklyn.” The death of Kimani Gray, 16, tested the council like never before.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Gilford Monrose was asleep in his Brooklyn apartment on March 9, when a text message from another pastor knocked him from his slumber: BROOKLYN: *POLICE SHOOTING* E52 ST X SNYDER AVE, LEVEL 1 MOBILIZATION CALLED. It was 11:39 p.m., and Mr. Monrose was about to begin the most trying week of his life.

headline: “House of Cards” Episode 10, the Recap: Frank Forgets How to Count and Peter Tumbles
abstract: Episode 10 recap, “House of Card”: After Frank Underwood is clobbered by the president for getting the vote count wrong, he realizes that Congress is not the house he needs to get in order. Ashley Parker and David Carr tease apart the episode.
lead_paragraph: We are now officially headed toward end-of-season recess on “House of Cards” and Ashley Parker and David Carr take a look at episode 10. If you like reading their take on the political and media dimensions of the rest of the season, you can find episode one, two,three, four, five, six,seven , eight or nine here. Spoilers are thicker than plots on “House of Cards,” so consider yourself warned.

headline: China’s Leader Tries to Calm African Fears of His Country’s Economic Power
abstract: President Xi Jinping defended China’s economic stake in many African countries during a speech in Tanzania, and promised aid in an effort to counter fears over competitive Chinese companies.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s new president, Xi Jinping, sought to assure African countries on Monday that his government would heed complaints that relentlessly competitive Chinese companies were suffocating African efforts to nurture industry and jobs, and he promised aid, scholarships and technology transfers in an effort to counter those fears.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Paul Caine joined Dial Global, New York, as chief executive. Mr. Caine had been executive vice president and president for advertising at Time Inc., New York.
lead_paragraph: Paul Caine joined Dial Global, New York, a radio syndication company, as chief executive. He succeeds Spencer Brown, who is leaving, the company said. Mr. Caine had been executive vice president and president for advertising, as well as chief revenue officer, at Time Inc., New York, part of Time Warner.

headline: ‘The Flick’ Prompts an Explanation From Playwrights Horizons
abstract: The artistic director of Playwrights Horizons sent an e-mail to subscribers explaining the company’s decision to produce Annie Baker’s play “The Flick,” which has been embraced by critics but has prompted threats of subscriber cancellations.
lead_paragraph: The artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, a leading Off Broadway company that produces new American plays, took the unusual step on Saturday of e-mailing 3,000 of the theater’s subscribers to explain his decision to produce Annie Baker’s new play “The Flick,” whose three-hour length and periods of long silence have infuriated some audience members.

headline: MTV Video Music Awards Show Coming to Brooklyn
abstract: No host was announced yet for the show, scheduled for Sunday, Aug. 25, at the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Some things just get better when they move to Brooklyn — Walt Whitman; Arthur Miller; the former New Jersey Nets — and MTV is hoping that one of its signature institutions will benefit from the aura exuded by the borough of Spike Lee, Chris Rock, Coney Island and artisanal pickles. On Monday the network said that its 2013 MTV Video Music Awards will be held on Aug. 25 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, marking the 30th year of that program, which in recent years has been held either in Manhattan or Los Angeles.

headline: New Roku Box Makes Streaming TV Even Easier
abstract: Roku introduces its third-generation streaming media player, with a new interface that offers smoother navigation.
lead_paragraph: Roku’s new streaming media player, the Roku 3, looks remarkably like its predecessors: a hockey puck. Instead of upgrading the appearance, the company has improved the way the device works, while keeping the price at $100.

headline: Temp Tee Urges Shoppers to ‘Whip’ Up Passover Dishes
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Passover']
abstract: A campaign for Temp Tee, a dairy product, offers some humorous solutions to the dreaded “matzah fatigue” of Passover.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, ads pitched Geritol tonic as the cure for “tired blood.” Now, a dairy product is being proposed as the antidote to “matzah fatigue.” Matzah fatigue could be classified as among “Passover problems,” the puzzles that perplex Jews who celebrate the eight-day holiday, which begins at sunset on Monday. It is a fanciful expression, to be sure, but it does address what is, for many, an issue each year: Around the third day, the palate often begins to rebel against a steady diet of foods that are kosher for Passover like matzah, the unleavened bread also known as matzo or matzoh.

headline: First Hint of Spring Links
abstract: Some links while waiting for spring to kick in.
lead_paragraph: Diet News: The Mediterranean diet is not just good for your health, but also improves food security. Is there nothing this way of eating can’t do? Less encouraging is that Mississippi, the most obese state in the nation, is banning Bloomberg-style portion control. No, really — the bill is called the “The Anti-Bloomberg Bill.”

headline: To Whom It May Concern
abstract: Pioneer 10 and 11 carry plaques intended to show where they came from and who made them, and other spacecraft contain information about Earth and humankind.
lead_paragraph: Q. Do the spacecraft we have sent to investigate the universe carry any identification of their human and earthly origin?

headline: Swinton Under Glass: New Offering From MoMA
abstract: The actress Tilda Swinton is periodically appearing at the museum, lying on a mattress in a glass box.
lead_paragraph: Among the second-floor contemporary-art galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, visitors on Monday were happening upon an unexpected sight: the actress Tilda Swinton lying on a mattress in a glass box, apparently asleep. Ms. Swinton, an Oscar winner for the 2007 film “Michael Clayton,” has brought her performance piece “The Maybe” to MoMA, 18 years after she first performed it for a week in the Serpentine Gallery in London.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: A selection of events for this week.
lead_paragraph: At Brushstroke, 30 Hudson Street in TriBeCa, Isao Yamada, the chef, and Eric Hastings, the sommelier, are putting together an eight-course tasting menu for dinner on Wednesday that includes old-world wines and artisanal sake. The meal is $250 per person, and reservations can be made online.

headline: Free Checking Still Widespread at Credit Unions
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Unions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Free checking accounts remain the rule at credit unions, a Bankrate.com analysis finds.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three-quarters of the country’s largest credit unions still offer no-strings-attached free checking accounts, a new report from Bankrate.com finds.

headline: A Sea Change in Less Than 50 Years as Gay Rights Gained Momentum
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: This week, as the Supreme Court hears two landmark cases on same-sex marriage, the speed and scope of the gay rights movement are astonishing supporters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The struggle for African-Americans’ rights, symbolized by the bloody 1965 Selma march, is as old as the nation. The effort for American women’s rights began at Seneca Falls, N.Y., more than 150 years ago.

headline: Scalia’s Gay Marriage Problem
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Will the conservative justice manage to control himself at oral arguments tomorrow and Wednesday?
lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court set to hear oral arguments tomorrow and Wednesday in a pair of same-sex marriage cases, there are two questions preoccupying legal writers: How will Justice Anthony Kennedy, the court’s wild card, vote, and how will Justice Antonin Scalia behave?

headline: Chandler Practices, a Little, and Eyes Knicks Return
abstract: The Knicks’ Tyson Chandler tested his sore neck in practice on Monday and said he is closer to returning.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – Tyson Chandler spent a few minutes on the court Monday morning, practicing post defense and testing his sore neck. But it was for only a few minutes.

headline: An Old Prescription for Sour Faces
abstract: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus revived a local tradition by staging a special show at the Brooklyn Hospital Center.
lead_paragraph: When the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus made its first appearance at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last week, it marked a return to the borough where it was born in the 19th century. The circus revived another tradition on Monday, when it staged a performance for young patients, staff members and other guests at the Brooklyn Hospital Center.

headline: Leader of Central African Republic Fled to Cameroon, Official Says
abstract: A day after being ousted by rebel forces, President François Bozizé turned up in Cameroon, where he will remain temporarily.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A day after being ousted by rebel forces, President François Bozizé of the Central African Republic surfaced in Cameroon on Monday, according to a statement read on state radio by a senior Cameroonian official. He will remain there until he finds a more permanent refuge, said the official, Ferdinand Ngoh Ngoh.

headline: Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis Knocks at Australia’s Door
abstract: A visitor from Papua New Guinea was Australia’s first death from the disease, a fact that has alarmed health officials and added heat to a debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s first death from XDR-TB — extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, which is nearly incurable — has alarmed health officials and added new heat to a debate over how to treat immigrants with dangerous diseases. That debate echoes one on the United States’ southern border.

headline: The Secret May Be in the Coffee
abstract: Residents of the Greek island of Ikaria have remarkably long life expectancies, and researchers say one factor could be the coffee they drink.
lead_paragraph: People who live on the Greek island of Ikaria are known to have remarkably high life expectancies, and researchers have been studying them carefully to learn why. Now a new report suggests that one reason may be the coffee they drink.

headline: Malaysia to Relocate Residents of Contested Areas
abstract: The plan is in response to an incursion into the Malaysian state of Sabah by gunmen seeking to re-establish an ancient claim on the land.
lead_paragraph: MANILA  — The Malaysian authorities will resettle residents of remote coastal areas near the southern Philippines amid fighting that has killed more than 70 people, officials said Monday.

headline: Made in L.A. | Modernism at Sunset
abstract: The interior designer and writer David Netto takes a tour of the VDL Research House, the former home and studio of the architect Richard Neutra.
lead_paragraph: A residence made mostly of glass and wood, surrounded by trees, tucked neatly behind a modernist building. The interior designer and writer David Netto leads a tour of the VDL Research House, the former home and studio of Richard Neutra located on Silver Lake boulevard in Los Angeles. Netto describes Neutra, the architect originally from Austria, as “the shaper of the future of California,” and demonstrates how the house reflects the architect’s point of view.

headline: Portman’s Son Describes Personal Side of Senator’s Shift on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Will Portman writes that his father, Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, delayed announcing support for same-sex marriage to protect his privacy.
lead_paragraph: 4:58 p.m. | Updated When Senator Rob Portman, the Ohio Republican, announced his support for same-sex marriage, he said his son’s admission that he was gay prompted the change of heart. But the timeline left some puzzled: If the son, Will, came out two years ago, why did the senator’s announcement come 10 days ago?

headline: Is It Ever O.K. for Christian Kids to Have a Bar Mitzvah?
abstract: Plus: a video tutorial for a Christian Passover seder!
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Riff essay, Maud Newton writes about the popularity of traditional Jewish rituals among American evangelical Christians — specifically, but not limited to, holding bar mitzvahs for their kids. Here, in a bonus to Riff, Newton explains a bit of her own back story and provides further explanation of this curious, and controversial, phenomenon. Newton has previously written Riff essays on the lingering linguistic influence of David Foster Wallace and the best-selling book “Heaven Is Real.”

headline: A Clearer View of the Space Bullet That Grazed Russia
abstract: Scientists have gotten a much more accurate picture of the small asteroid that exploded near the Russian city of Chelyabinsk last month.
lead_paragraph: Using an eclectic mix of crowd-sourced video, information from Google Earth and data from nuclear test-ban sensors, scientists have gotten a much more accurate picture of the small asteroid that exploded near the Russian city of Chelyabinsk last month.

headline: Prisoner X of Israel Is Said to Have Exposed Top Spies
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Two news organizations have reported that the man, Ben Zygier, unintentionally revealed the identities of two top spies for Israel in Lebanon to a man known to be close to Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel has revealed very little about the man known as Prisoner X, an Australian-Israeli who was jailed here in 2010 after apparently getting caught in a web of espionage and intrigue, other than how he died: alone, by asphyxiation, after hanging himself in the shower of his cell.

headline: Photo Replay: March 25
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including a car rally in Saudi Arabia and Tiger Woods at Bay Hill.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including a car rally in Saudi Arabia and Tiger Woods at Bay Hill.

headline: Decoded: Steve Harvey’s Daytime Success
abstract: The Times’s Brian Stelter decodes Steve Harvey’s talk show success.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Brian Stelter decodes Steve Harvey’s talk show success.

headline: Tibetan Mother of 4 Self-Immolates to Protest Chinese Rule
abstract: The woman, Kalkyi, set fire to herself near a monastery in the county of Dzamthang in Ngaba Prefecture, according to a report by Radio Free Asia.
lead_paragraph: A Tibetan mother of four killed herself by self-immolation on Sunday to protest Chinese rule, according to a report on Monday by Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government. The report said Kalkyi, 30, set fire to herself near a monastery in the county of Dzamthang in Ngaba Prefecture, which has been a focal point of the wave of Tibetan self-immolations that began in 2009. At least 110 people in Tibetan regions of China have set fire to themselves, and the vast majority have died. Ms. Kalkyi’s self-immolation took place around 3:30 p.m. Sunday, and her body was taken by locals to the Jonang monastery, according to Radio Free Asia, which cited sources inside Tibet. Ms. Kalkyi had three sons and one daughter, all under the age of 15. Radio Free Asia said that Ms. Kalkyi was the 16th woman to self-immolate since 2009. On March 13, a woman, Konchog Wangmo, 31, killed herself by self-immolation in Ngaba Prefecture, and her husband, Drolma Kyab, was later detained by the authorities, the news service reported.

headline: Bankia Stock Value Is Nearly Wiped Out Under Recapitalization Plan
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Shares in Bankia, the giant Spanish mortgage lender whose collapse last year led to a banking crisis in Spain, slumped 41 percent on Monday after regulators wiped out most of the stock’s value.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Shares in Bankia, the giant Spanish mortgage lender whose collapse last year led to a banking crisis in Spain, slumped Monday in the first day of trading after regulators wiped out most of the stock’s value.

headline: Rice Pudding
abstract: Melissa Clark shows how to make rice pudding that is simple, luscious and creamy.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows how to make rice pudding that is simple, luscious and creamy.

headline: Back at No. 1, Woods Shifts Gaze to Augusta
abstract: Tiger Woods, who last held the No. 1 ranking in October 2010, fell as low as No. 58 as he coped with a personal crisis and injuries to his left leg.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — A few miles from Bay Hill Club and Lodge, Tiger Woods ran into a fire hydrant, and out gushed sordid details of his private life. Two years later, in November 2011, he reached rock bottom in his professional life, dropping to No. 58 in the world rankings.

headline: How Many Vietnam Veterans Are Still Alive?
abstract: Some online estimates suggest that only a third of Vietnam veterans are still alive, but those are a result of using incompatible numbers from different sources. The real share of Vietnam-era veterans still among us: about 75 percent.
lead_paragraph: The approximate percentage of Vietnam-era veterans who are still alive in 2013 is 75.

headline: Hachette Delaying Goodall Book With Borrowed Passages
abstract: The famed primatologist has apologized for borrowing passages from Web sites for her new book, “Seeds of Hope,’' and vows to correct any unintentional errors.
lead_paragraph: After revelations that Jane Goodall’s forthcoming book “Seeds of Hope” contains passages copied from various Web sites, the Hachette Book Group has decided to delay its publication. The book was set to be published April 2. No new date has been set.

headline: Fold Up Your Handkerchiefs: Books Have Gotten Less ‘Emotional,’ Study Says
abstract: Using Google’s enormous Ngram database, researchers at three British universities tracked the use of “mood” words over the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: If you find you’re crying less while reading and throwing fewer books across the room, there may be a good reason. English-language books became steadily less “emotional” over the 20th century, according to a new study crunching billions of words via Google’s Ngram database.

headline: Qatalyst Hires Morgan Stanley Banker
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Qatalyst Group, the West Coast boutique advisory firm led by Frank Quattrone, has hired Marcie Vu, formerly of Morgan Stanley, as a partner.
lead_paragraph: Qatalyst Group, the West Coast boutique advisory firm led by Frank Quattrone, has hired Marcie Vu as a partner.

headline: The Tournament’s Biggest Surprise? La Salle
abstract: Florida Gulf Coast is the popular underdog in the N.C.A.A. tournament but La Salle is an even unlikelier team to have reached the round of 16.
lead_paragraph: Right now, Florida Gulf Coast is everybody’s darling.

headline: Sale of Pre-Columbian Art Falls Short of Expectations
abstract: Sales fell short of expectations at an auction in Paris of pre-Columbian artifacts that several Latin American nations had objected to.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s weekend sale in Paris of pre-Columbian artifacts earned about $13.3 million, well below the pre-sale estimate of $19 million to $23 million, according to the auction house.

headline: France Seeks Slower Pace of Negotiations for a U.S.-Europe Trade Pact
abstract: The French trade minister said any agreement would have to overcome thorny issues, including France’s insistence on special treatment to protect its homegrown music and movies.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If anyone thought working out a free-trade agreement between the United States and the European Union was going to be easy, France has a message: Slow down.

headline: The Iraq War and Domestic Politics
abstract: More on the Iraq invasion’s impact on the Obama era.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of pushback, much of it from liberals, to my column yesterday arguing that the Obama era as we know it has been made possible by George W. Bush’s decision ten years ago to launch an invasion of Iraq. Some of this pushback, on Twitter and elsewhere, reflects a slight misreading of my point, so let me clarify: I was not arguing that absent the Iraq War, the Democratic Party would necessarily still be in the minority today, or that the Democratic presidential nominee would necessarily have lost the elections of 2008 and 2012. As I said at the top of the piece, it’s entirely plausible that in a world with no Iraq invasion we would be presently entering Hillary Clinton’s second term, and I agree (and have acknowledged many times before) that the current Democratic advantage is founded on deep demographic and social trends as well as the accidents of politics.

headline: In Praise of Pale Food
abstract: Before the last grasp of winter’s cold has slipped away, or the colorful spring produce arrives, let’s pay tribute to all that is carb-heavy, creamy and unchallenging.
lead_paragraph: IT’S ONE OF THE FIRST THINGS people mention when they learn I have a 4-year-old daughter.

headline: Looking for Evidence That Therapy Works
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Studies suggest surprisingly few patients receive evidence-based treatments like cognitive behavioral therapy, which have been shown to be effective.
lead_paragraph: Mental-health care has come a long way since the remedy of choice was trepanation — drilling holes into the skull to release “evil spirits.” Over the last 30 years, treatments like cognitive-behavioral therapy, dialectical behavior therapy and family-based treatment have been shown effective for ailments ranging from anxiety and depression to post-traumatic stress disorder and eating disorders.

headline: Look of the Moment | Charlotte Casiraghi
abstract: The Monaco royal is pretty in a pink dress by Chanel.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The Monaco royal at the Bal de la Rose du Rocher in Monte-Carlo, Monaco.

headline: A Rice Pudding for Anyone
abstract: If an elaborate pudding doesn’t ‘t feel right, here’s something simple that can be stirred together with a minimum of fuss.
lead_paragraph: As an ardent fan of rice pudding, I’ve made many versions over the years, most involving an egg custard and many baked in a water bath. While none are difficult, they are all more elaborate than the simple pudding I wanted for this week’s column about white food.

headline: Suit Offers a Peek at the Practice of Inflating a Legal Bill
abstract: Legal scholars say a legal fight over fees is likely to reinforce a perception that law firms inflate bills by performing superfluous tasks.
lead_paragraph: 8:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kyle Busch Wins as Hamlin and Logano Wreck
abstract: Feuding former teammates Denny Hamlin and Joey Logano crashed into each other while battling for the lead on the final turn.
lead_paragraph: Feuding former teammates Denny Hamlin and Joey Logano crashed into each other while battling for the lead on the final turn, and Kyle Busch squeezed past them to take the victory in Sunday’s 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Auto Club Speedway in California.

lead_paragraph: As a recurring bonus to the Riff essay, we sporadically present Five-Ku: five haiku poems about a current celebrity or cultural phenomenon. (Past examples include haikus about Susan Sarandon, Russell Crowe and classic horror films.)

headline: Following Your Bliss, Right Off the Cliff
abstract: Pursuing a passion into a career change may bring the success you dream of. But disaster is also a possibility.
lead_paragraph: SO you want to be a writer. Or an artist. Or to open a cupcake shop. What you’ll hear, often, is that you should pursue your dream. Follow your passion. Quit your job and live the life you want.

lead_paragraph: The interior designer and writer David Netto takes a tour of VDL Research House on Silver Lake boulevard in Los Angeles.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra to Collaborate With Opera on ‘Salome’
abstract: The Philadelphia Orchestra will work with Opera Philadelphia to create a semistaged version of Strauss’s “Salome” in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Orchestra has programmed a concert performance of the Strauss opera “Salome” for next season. Now, they are calling in the experts. The orchestra said on Monday it would be collaborating with Opera Philadelphia to create a semistaged version of the work, to be performed in May 2014. Kevin Newbury is to direct and Vita Tzykun will design the production, to be performed in the orchestra’s home, Verizon Hall at the Kimmel Center, which has no proscenium. “It’s a bit of a feat to try to imagine a theatrical mash-up, if you will,” said Allison Vulgamore, the orchestra’s chief executive and president.

headline: Minnesota Women’s Hockey Wins 49 in a Row to Win Title
keywords: ['Basketball', 'College Athletics', 'Hockey, Ice', 'NCAA Baseball Championships', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Women)', 'NCAA Ice Hockey Championships', 'NCAA Lacrosse Championships', 'NCAA Soccer Championships', 'NCAA Volleyball Championships', 'Volleyball']
abstract: The Minnesota women’s hockey team completed their season undefeated in winning the N.C.A.A. title on Sunday, and have won 49 straight games stretching back to last season.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Penguins have won 12 games in a row. The Miami Heat have won 26 in a row. The Baylor women’s basketball team has won 31 in a row. But they have a ways to go to catch the University of Minnesota women’s hockey team. The Gophers completed a 41-0 season Sunday by winning their second straight national championship with a 6-3 victory over Boston University.

headline: Nick Cave: HEARD NY
abstract: For a week at Grand Central station, students from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will move through the station wearing Nick Cave's Soundsuits as part of the station's centennial celebration.
lead_paragraph: For a week at Grand Central station, students from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will move through the station wearing Nick Cave's Soundsuits as part of the station's centennial celebration.

headline: ‘A Renaissance Globemaker’s Toolbox’
abstract: An excerpt from a new book about “Johannes Schöner and the Revolution of Modern Science 1475-1550.”
lead_paragraph: Introduction

headline: Why America Is Called America
abstract: John W. Hessler’s book “A Renaissance Globemaker’s Toolbox” saves from obscurity Johannes Schöner, a 16th-century globe maker who rescued the nation’s 1507 “birth certificate.”
lead_paragraph: A DECADE AGO, the Library of Congress paid $10 million to acquire the only known original copy of a 1507 world map that has been called “the birth certificate of America.” The large map, a masterpiece of woodblock printing, has been a star attraction at the library ever since and the object of revived scholarly fascination about the earliest cartography of the New World. The research has also rescued from obscurity a little-known Renaissance man, the 16th-century globe maker Johannes Schöner, who was responsible for saving the map for posterity.

headline: With Acquisition, Apple Looks Indoors for Future of Maps
abstract: Apple has acquired WiFiSlam, a start-up company that helps improve the accuracy of indoor maps and other services. Indoor maps look poised to become a new battleground between big tech companies.
lead_paragraph: It appears Apple is thinking seriously about what the mobile maps of tomorrow will look like, not just fixing the maps service it has today.

headline: When Fig Wasps Can’t Take the Heat
abstract: New research indicates that hot weather shortens the life span of some wasps in the tropics — ominous news for the wild fig plants.
lead_paragraph: There are more than 700 species of wild fig in the tropics. Remarkably, most can be pollinated only by a unique species of fig wasp. In turn, the wasps rely on fig plants as hosts for their eggs. Neither species can survive without the other, a relationship known as obligate mutualism.

headline: Cold, Wet Wait for Tickets to Supreme Court’s Same-Sex Marriage Cases
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A spring snowstorm did not deter a few dozen people from waiting outside the Supreme Court for one of the few coveted tickets for two same-sex marriage cases to be heard this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Being a witness to history can be messy business. And for those waiting outside the Supreme Court on Monday for one of the few coveted tickets to hear oral arguments in a pair of same-sex marriage cases this week, it was also cold, wet and tedious.

headline: Go Find Your Flippers
abstract: Hurricane Sandy hasn’t canceled summer on Fire Island.
lead_paragraph: The real estate, and dunes, on Fire Island qualified for a post-mortem in the wake of Hurricane Sandy. Besides the dozen or so homes swept into the sea, nearly 1,600 sustained significant damage — by wind or saltwater or a combination. The Army Corps of Engineers, which so far has five demolition permits for homes too ravaged to repair, is handling the removal of tons of debris.

headline: More Join Hunger Strike at Guantánamo Prison
abstract: An official military count said that 28 detainees were refusing food, up from 26 on Friday, but prisoners and their lawyers said that tally was short.
lead_paragraph: A  hunger strike among detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who have been imprisoned by the United States military without trial — some for more than a decade — is continuing to grow, although there is sharp disagreement between the military and lawyers for the detainees about how many are participating.

headline: With or Without Bailout, Cypriots Lose Trust in Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Account holders, business customers and many experts worry that Europe’s solution to the banking crisis in Cyprus is only a temporary bandage.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — With her wedding day three months away, Despina Charalambous is desperate to gain access to her savings, which have been frozen at the Bank of Cyprus for more than a week. She plans to take out all her money once the banks reopen, even though the new bailout plan for her country supposedly guarantees the safety of her deposits.

headline: A Russian Supper Club for ‘Natasha’ Musical
abstract: Dave Malloy’s acclaimed electropop show, which originated at Ars Nova, is to be restaged in a 6,000-square-foot space in the meatpacking district.
lead_paragraph: A vacant lot in Manhattan’s meatpacking district is being transformed into New York’s latest theater spectacle, a sexy Russian supper club that will be the new home of “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,” Dave Malloy’s acclaimed electropop opera that ran at Ars Nova last fall.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Myanmar and Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Syria, Myanmar and Yemen.

headline: In the Shadow of LaFerrari, the Pininfarina Sergio
abstract: The car is built around the basics of the Ferrari 458. But because it is lighter and sleeker than the production car, the Sergio can go from 0 to 100 kilometers per hour in 3.4 seconds, Pininfarina calculates.
lead_paragraph: Almost overlooked at the Geneva auto show earlier this month was the Pininfarina Sergio concept. Normally, the product of the world’s most famous Italian coach builder would be a headliner. But this year was different. The show was dominated by the impact of the LaFerrari, the powerful supercar from Ferrari.

headline: Walkabout – 3/25: No Carry-on? Go to Front of the Line, Says American
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Flying Light American Airlines is testing new boarding procedures that award passengers who don’t bring any carry-ons by allowing them to board before others in economy class. (Today)

headline: A Push for HPV Vaccinations
keywords: ['Cervical Cancer', 'Human Papilloma Virus (HPV)', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Health professionals hope to make the shots more accessible, and to make the vaccine sound less scary to parents and daughters.
lead_paragraph: The government recommended years ago that all adolescent girls get a vaccine to protect against cervical cancer. But nearly seven years after it first came to market, an overwhelming majority of girls have yet to be inoculated.

headline: Female Business Travelers Make a Case for Pen Knives
keywords: ['Airport Security', 'Business Travel', 'Knives', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In more than 300 e-mail replies on whether to allow pen knives on planes, many of the strongest supporters of the rule change were women who travel for business.
lead_paragraph: HERE is what the Transportation Security Administration said its screeners discovered in passengers’ carry-on bags at airport security in the seven days that ended last Thursday: 32 guns, 23 of them loaded and seven with rounds in the firing chamber; eight stun guns; a four-inch knife concealed in a suitcase lining; and an eight-inch tactical spike hidden in a sock.

headline: Clearing the Jungle (Barely) on a Wing and a Pilot’s Prayer
abstract: Ahmed Rahim is a co-founder and chief executive of Numi Organic Teas. He knew it was time to worry when he heard the pilot of the six-seater praying for liftoff in the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: SINCE I’m in charge of international sales and product development at Numi Organic Tea, my business travel can be crazy. I may not have to leave California, our headquarters, for a few weeks, and then I may be gone for four or five weeks visiting farms overseas, or looking for new business opportunities or potential partners. Much of my travel can be dictated by growing seasons.

headline: Avicii Turns to Nashville for Ultra Music Festival Show
abstract: His set included performances by Mac Davis, Audra Mae and Dan Tyminski.
lead_paragraph: 1:31 p.m. | Updated  MIAMI — Avicii, the Swedish music producer and D.J., is known for catchy house music like the hits “Levels” and “Silhouettes.” But on Friday, at the Ultra Music Festival here, his one-hour set more resembled a Nashville concert than a performance by one of the stars of electronic dance music.

headline: The Mouth’s Guard
abstract: Every day, humans generate two to three pints of saliva, which comes in two varieties, with heroic attributes.
lead_paragraph: Humans secrete two kinds of saliva, stimulated and unstimulated, no more alike than most siblings. The prettier child is stimulated saliva. It comes from the parotid glands, between cheek and ear. When a plate of spaghetti carbonara makes your mouth water, that’s stimulated saliva. It makes up 70 to 90 percent of the two to three pints of saliva each of us generates daily. Stimulated saliva looks, tastes and flows like water — it is, in fact, 99 percent water with some proteins and minerals. Each person’s saliva contains minerals in unique proportions.

headline: The Marvels in Your Mouth
abstract: Before you swallow a bite, a devilishly complex sequence of events and reflexes has already begun.
lead_paragraph: WAGENINGEN, THE NETHERLANDS — When I told people I was traveling to Food Valley, I described it as the Silicon Valley of eating. At this cluster of universities and research facilities, nearly 15,000 scientists are dedicated to improving — or, depending on your sentiments about processed food, compromising — the quality of our meals.

headline: Gulp! The Quiz
abstract: Chew, swallow, digest, repeat. Take this quiz to learn some of the amazing things that go on in your gut.
lead_paragraph: Chew, swallow, digest, repeat. You probably don’t think much about your digestive tract, but there are some amazing things going on in your gut. Take this quiz, based on the new book “Gulp!” by Mary Roach, excerpted in this week’s Science Times, to find out how intimately you know your innards.

headline: Vain Glorious | Kiehl’s Stress Relief
abstract: To combat and correct stressed-out skin, Kiehl’s launched an exclusive service and a line of products.
lead_paragraph: Stress. Our bodies are engineered to cope with a certain amount comfortably, but sustained, intense stress is an entirely different matter. It can negatively impact our minds, our hearts, and our body’s largest organ, skin. “Its effects are particularly harsh, causing premature aging and advancing the symptoms of every common skin condition from sensitive skin to eczema and psoriasis,” says Dr. Cynthia Ackrill, a fellow at the American Institute of Stress.

headline: A Meteor’s Data Trail, Journey on the Alimentary Canal and Using the Body to Fight Cancer
keywords: ['Meteors and Meteorites', 'Digestive Tract', 'Leukemia', 'Cancer', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Henry Fountain on how science is tracking the meteor that exploded over Russia back to its source; Mary Roach on our fascinating guts; Denise Grady on a novel treatment for some cancers of the blood.
lead_paragraph: Henry Fountain on how science is tracking the meteor that exploded over Russia back to its source; Mary Roach on our fascinating guts; Denise Grady on a novel treatment for some cancers of the blood.

headline: The Multipurpose Airport
abstract: Airports, particularly those in Europe and Asia, are responding to travelers’ needs by offering an increasing array of services, like hair salons, medical clinics and dry cleaners.
lead_paragraph: Jim Rosenberg, the head of online and social media for the World Bank, can vouch that some airports offer a lot more than places to eat and newsstands filled with gossipy magazines.

headline: Beware of the High Cost of ‘Free’ Online Courses
abstract: Michael Cusumano, a professor at M.I.T., raises doubts about the ultimate cost to the education field of massive open online courses, or MOOCs.
lead_paragraph: That the acronym MOOCs rhymes with “nukes” seems apt. Massive open online courses, or MOOCs — led by two profit-making start-ups, Coursera and Udacity, founded by entrepreneurial Stanford professors — are a new disruptive force in education. Leading universities have scrambled to join or offer alternatives like edX, a collaboration of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Harvard University and others.

headline: Different Versions of a Life, All Lived
abstract: “Life After Life,” the latest novel by Kate Atkinson, depicts a woman who appears in contradictory versions of similar events.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of a secret love affair, Ursula Todd discovers that she is an excellent liar. The same can be said admiringly of Kate Atkinson, whose latest novel, “Life After Life,” is her very best. Ms. Atkinson’s wide-ranging body of work includes several novels that resemble mysteries, but she has never had the narrowly deductive mind to suit that genre. “Life After Life” is a big book that defies logic, chronology and even history in ways that underscore its author’s fully untethered imagination.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  After Google Reader, and Steve Jobs Manga
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Monday, selections include the effects of Google reader on the spread of news on the Web, Digg trying to rebuild itself in Google Reader’s image and a report of a Silicon Valley PAC that is said to have a very odd assortment of priorities.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Solid Sales for ‘Pippin’ and ‘The Nance’ on Broadway
abstract: Two of the highest-profile new shows had healthy starts in their first weekend of performances, while “The Book of Mormon” broke a record for combined sales in London and New York.
lead_paragraph: Two of the highest-profile Broadway shows this spring, the revival of the musical “Pippin” and the new Nathan Lane play “The Nance,” had solid ticket sales during their first weekend of performances, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: A Highly Public Trip for China’s President, and Its First Lady
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: China’s leadership has been promoting a concept called the “Chinese Dream” that depends on continued economic growth and stable relations with the United States. Apple, meanwhile, finds itself the target of attacks in the official media.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping of China is on his inaugural overseas trip. Mr. Xi stopped first in Russia, went to Tanzania, and will then  visit the Republic of Congo and South Africa, where he will also attend a summit meeting of emerging BRICS economies — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.

headline: YouTube Videos Unlock Meteor’s Secrets
abstract: Scientists around the world have been using videos made by Russian citizens and uploaded to YouTube to figure out exactly where the meteor that exploded over Russia on Feb. 15 came from.
lead_paragraph: Scientists around the world have been using videos made by Russian citizens and uploaded to YouTube to figure out exactly where the meteor that exploded over Russia on Feb. 15 came from.

headline: Exploring the Language That Speaks the Inexpressible
abstract: In his concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, Jeremy Denk conveyed a sense of how music connects to life’s broader concerns.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the pianist Jeremy Denk play, you never doubt that he is someone who thinks about music deeply and rather a lot. It’s not that you sense that he fusses overmuch about tempos and dynamics, or that he’s out to demonstrate his awesome cleverness through programming juxtapositions. Rather, what Mr. Denk’s playing conveys most is an inclusive consideration of where each piece came from, what it reflects about its composer and how music connects to a life’s broader concerns.

headline: Where Bowls and Bodies Fly Though the Air
abstract: What’s the next level after impressed? Whatever it is, that emotion arrives often in “Totem,” the newest show from Cirque du Soleil.
lead_paragraph: What’s the next level after impressed? Amazed? Awe-struck? Whatever it is, that emotion arrives often in “Totem,” the newest show from Cirque du Soleil.

headline: A Beige Wine for a Beige Meal
abstract: The crispness and acidity of good chardonnay pairs beautifully with chicken potpie and other rich, creamy foods.
lead_paragraph: For a meal of relentlessly beige food, may I suggest the beigest of wines? That would be chardonnay, which will go beautifully with Melissa Clark’s chicken potpie. I call it beige in the most insulting way, as chardonnay long ago became kind of a generic term for a glass of insipid white wine in any bar in the land. But of course chardonnay also makes some of the greatest, most distinctive white wines in the world. This potpie calls out for a crisp wine, with no oakiness and plenty of lively acidity and herbal-citrus zest to cut through the richness of the filling.

headline: Librarian Lets Down Hair and Downs Many Drinks
abstract: “Happy Birthday,” written by Anita Loos as a vehicle for Helen Hayes, has been revived at the Beckett Theater.
lead_paragraph: The history of romantic comedies would be considerably shorter without the presence of the shy girl. You know, the mousy one who’s overlooked until that magic moment when she. ... (Insert standard plot twist leading to capture of Prince Charming.)

headline: A Concerto for a First Among Equals
abstract: The pianist Richard Goode was soloist on Saturday with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra is celebrating its 40th anniversary this season with a roster of new collaborators, including the jazz greats Wayne Shorter and Brad Mehldau, and the contemporary composer-performers Timothy Andres and Gabriel Kahane. But on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall this conductorless orchestra teamed up with an old friend, the pianist Richard Goode, who joined the players in a lucid performance of Schumann’s Piano Concerto.

headline: What You Didn’t Post, Facebook May Still Know
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Facebook is no longer relying solely on what its users reveal. Instead, it is tapping outside data sources to learn even more about them, and to sell more finely targeted ads.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Debra Aho Williamson, an advertising industry analyst and devoted coffee drinker, was intrigued by a promotion that popped up on her Facebook page recently. Sign up for a Starbucks loyalty card, it said, and get $5 off.

headline: Salesmen in the Surgical Suite
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Medical Devices', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: A lawsuit raises questions about the marketing of robotic surgical equipment.
lead_paragraph: When Fred E. Taylor arrived at Harrison Medical Center in Silverdale, Wash., for a routine prostatectomy, he expected the best medical care new technology had to offer: robotic surgery, billed as safer, less painful and easier on the body than traditional surgery.

headline: The Grown-Up Behind a Tween Phenomenon
abstract: Rachel Renée Russell will soon release the sixth book since 2009 in her “Dork Diaries” series, which speaks the language of middle school girls.
lead_paragraph: CHANTILLY, Va. — If you are one of those people whose lives do not include a girl under the age of 12 — and in that case, OMG I am SO SORRY for you!!! — then the “Dork Diaries,” a series for tweens that has sold over 10 million copies in less than four years, may have escaped your notice.

headline: Hearts Suffer and Crumble When Mourning the Loss of Children
abstract: New York Theater Ballet performed “Dark Elegies” during an ambitious program at Florence Gould Hall.
lead_paragraph: We see Antony Tudor’s “Dark Elegies” (1937) too seldom. There are many who consider it one of the foremost dance masterpieces of the last century; for a few it’s the greatest. Though I’m not among its ardent admirers, I certainly think it’s an important, compelling and finely made piece — well worth seeing and arguing about.

headline: TimesTalks: David O. Russell
abstract: The film director David O. Russell speaks with The Times's Melena Ryzik about how his craft has evolved over the years.
lead_paragraph: The film director David O. Russell speaks with The Times's Melena Ryzik about how his craft has evolved over the years.

headline: Baseball Fan Clubhouse Gets an Art Gallery
abstract: Major League Baseball will display the work of contemporary artists in a new space at the M.L.B. Fan Cave in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: An art gallery in the middle of a building devoted to baseball may strike some as a culture clash, but Major League Baseball will try to change that view with the launch of the M.L.B. Fan Cave Art Gallery on April 4 in Manhattan.

headline: Caregiver for Disabled People Sues New York State
abstract: Jeffrey Monsour, a state worker who has questioned a number of practices, accused officials of retaliating against him for his whistle-blowing.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A New York State-employed caregiver for people with developmental disabilities sued the state on Monday, accusing it of retaliating against him for whistle-blowing.

headline: The Place That Makes a Riddle of Pitching
abstract: Colorado scrapped its experimental four-man rotation with a 75-pitch limit per start and will try a five-man rotation supplemented by three long relievers.
lead_paragraph: Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Festival Glimpses the Future of Film
abstract: Movies by Shane Carruth, Marcello Lordello, Sarah Polley and others in the New Directors/New Films festival, through March 31.
lead_paragraph: The post-Oscar scarcity of interesting movies in theaters is relieved, as always, by New Directors/New Films, the annual spring festival presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, which continues through Sunday. It is also a place to glimpse the future of movies, as fledgling careers take wing, and new hybrid forms (of science fiction and melodrama, of documentary and personal narrative) are explored. Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, chief film critics of The New York Times, discuss this week’s highlights below.

headline: Albums by Dido, OneRepublic, Thompson Square, Tomasz Stanko
abstract: “Girl Who Got Away” by Dido; “Native” by OneRepublic; “Just Feels Good” by Thompson Square, “All That for This” by Crystal Bowersox; and “Wislawa” by Tomasz Stanko.
lead_paragraph: Dido

headline: Watching the Choreographer’s Mind Churn
abstract: The choreographer Kate Weare presented a series of duets as part of the Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The format of this year’s Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y requires choreographers to discuss their work, lecture-demonstration style, before the dancers perform with lights and costumes. On Friday night the choreographer Kate Weare began her weekend at the Y by explaining how hard it was for her to explain. Her creative process, she said, contains mysteries she is resistant to analyzing.

headline: Emblem3 at Irving Plaza
abstract: The trio, which placed fourth on “The X Factor” last year, performed at Irving Plaza on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: The trio, which placed fourth on “The X Factor” last year, performed at Irving Plaza on Friday night.

headline: New Onstage, but Sounding Familiar
abstract: Emblem3, which placed fourth on the reality show “The X Factor” last year, performed a sold-out show at Irving Plaza.
lead_paragraph: The modern era of reality-TV singing competitions has been with us for just over a decade, and even though in that time they have minted a few stars — Kelly Clarkson, Carrie Underwood, Jennifer Hudson — it’s arguable that in terms of impact on the shape of pop music, they’ve served absolutely no purpose at all.

headline: Art Worth Millions, Yet No Cash for Burial
abstract: Merton Simpson’s fortune is locked up in his art and the intrigue that has arisen since his death.
lead_paragraph: Family and friends gathered in Charleston, S.C., on Friday for the funeral of the New York-based artist Merton D. Simpson, a painter and pioneering champion of African art who accumulated a collection said to be worth millions of dollars. Gathering in the city of his birth, eulogists celebrated Mr. Simpson’s expertise on the saxophone, his generosity and his visionary artistic taste.

headline: NASA Engines Found, News About Squid and More
abstract: Recent developments in health and science news and a glance at what’s ahead.
lead_paragraph: So few people do favors for NASA these days. So when Jeff Bezos, the Amazon.com founder, announced last week that an expedition he financed had hoisted two F-1 rocket engines from an Apollo mission off the ocean floor, the agency was understandably grateful.

headline: Hopes Outside the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Protesters and supporters explain why they are standing in freezing rain for a chance to witness hearings on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Protesters and supporters explain why they are standing in freezing rain for a chance to witness hearings on same-sex marriage.

headline: Taking Safety Agency’s App for a Test Drive
abstract: Car buyers can scan N.H.T..S.A.’s safety ratings, the same information available on the agency’s Web site SaferCar.gov.
lead_paragraph: Although it has concerns about consumers using smartphones behind the wheel, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration now has its own app.

headline: Wood Creek Adds to Music Holdings, Acquiring Concord
abstract: Concord’s niche was catering to adult tastes, with artists like Paul Simon and Creedence Clearwater Revival, and extensive jazz holdings.
lead_paragraph: The Concord Music Group, an independent music company with an artist roster that includes Paul McCartney, Paul Simon and Creedence Clearwater Revival, has been sold to Wood Creek Capital Management, a private equity firm that has been quietly building a collection of music assets.

headline: The Emotional Lure of Prepaid College
abstract: The Private College 529 Plan lets participants prepay tuition at private colleges and universities, at today’s rates.
lead_paragraph: MATTHEW ROGERS’S infant daughter was just weeks old when he learned that her grandfather already had plans for her.

headline: Among Young Inheritors, an Urge to Redistribute
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Philanthropy', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: Among those who receive inheritances, a small subset — call them trust-fund progressives — want to give all or most of the money away while they are young.
lead_paragraph: MOST people would probably be quite happy to receive an inheritance. They would pay off debt, maybe their mortgage; save for retirement; take a trip or two. It would be blissful, and it would make their lives easier.

headline: After You Read the Listings, Your Agent Reads You
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Customer Relations', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Real estate agents keep an eye on their clients for unspoken signals and use psychology to help guide them to decisions.
lead_paragraph: EVERY saleswoman will tell you that the customer is always transparent. Maybe not entirely, completely, but compared with the poker face a buyer thinks that he or she is wearing, there are always expressions and signals that are obvious to the practiced observer.

headline: Money Talk Before Marriage a Tip You Can’t Disparage
abstract: Research shows that money is the No. 1 reason couples fight and a main reason marriages end, but many couples don’t talk about money beforehand.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Joe, 64, a computer professional in Massachusetts, married for the first time, he was 31 and very in love.

headline: For Older Americans, a Deepening Debt Problem
abstract: The number of Americans aged 60 and over in debt is alarming, putting too many seniors at financial risk just at a time when debt should be done with.
lead_paragraph: OH, to be young and in debt.

headline: To Avoid the Biggest Investing Mistake, Stay Strong
abstract: Scary markets often cause us to do crazy things like ditching our well-designed investing plans to either buy high or sell low.
lead_paragraph: IF you have been awake for the last five years, your investing experience has probably been anything but smooth. Scary markets like the one that bottomed out in March 2009 often cause us to do crazy things. This craziness may be temporary, but it doesn’t take long to make what I call the big mistake: ditching your well-designed investing plan to either buy high or sell low.

headline: Growing Up With a Trust
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Wills and Estates']

lead_paragraph: STUART LUCAS learned about his trust fund the old-fashioned way: when he was 18 and went east to Dartmouth College.

headline: Expense and Emotions in Preparing for Long-Term Care
abstract: Long-term care insurance is becoming increasingly complex and expensive, and it can be difficult to separate emotions from the financial considerations.
lead_paragraph: ANDY SHAPIRO had never given much thought to whether he would need help with daily activities as he aged. After all, the 61-year-old software consultant figured, he kept himself in good shape.

headline: Emotion, Wild Card of Finances
abstract: In this special section, prepared with American Public Media’s “Marketplace Money” radio program, a series of stories illustrate where money and emotions collide.
lead_paragraph: Few topics are as emotionally charged as money.

headline: Saving for Retirement as an Act of Wild Optimism
abstract: A few months after Virginia McGuire was found to have ovarian cancer a second time, she and her husband received a big tax refund. But did it make sense to put it toward retirement?
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was 30, the ovarian cancer I’d had as a child returned after a 20-year hiatus. The new diagnosis arrived dramatically, when a trip to the emergency room revealed a tumor that was causing internal bleeding. During the week I spent in intensive care, my son, Leo, stopped speaking aloud and talked only in a whisper. He was almost 4.

headline: How to Set a Price on the Life of a Beloved Pet?
abstract: As veterinary medical technology advances, more options become available for animals in dire straits, but the expense involved can make decisions on care more difficult.
lead_paragraph: I COULDN’T begin to add up the number of times my husband and I have had the Talk. We know illness and death are two of life’s certainties. And we’ve taken care of the issue when it comes to ourselves. We’ve signed medical directives saying we want no extraordinary measures taken to extend our lives if we become incapacitated to the point that we’re a burden, emotionally and financially, to our families.

headline: A Family Manipulated by an Economic Crisis
abstract: The puppet drama “Saga,” about how Iceland’s economic crisis affected a family, appears to push puppetry into new mature territory.
lead_paragraph: There’s no need to condescend to puppets anymore.

headline: Still Bleeding, 10 Years Later
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In two combat tours in Iraq, Jason Davis learned that in war, there are no days off.
lead_paragraph: Chasing WarThe blades wore a darkened silver sheen, dulled at the edge. Bits of hair, dried salt-sweat and dung-powdered dirt clogged the head so that with each firm scrape, tiny beads of crimson and pus dried into little scab islands in the crease of my neck. There was no water, no cream, no electrical outlets — just a cracked Humvee mirror and the light from the rising sun. My Mach3 wouldn’t skive the glaze from a stick of butter, but still I bled.

headline: Stricter Rules but Signs of Disarray in Cyprus Deal
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: European powers used the crisis in Cyprus to establish more punitive rules for countries needing emergency aid, but some critics said the bailout showed chaotic decision making.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Cyprus deal announced Sunday, another late-night showdown in Brussels that looked like a shambles, laid down some important new markers for the future of the European Union and the countries that use the euro. The big European powers used the crisis to establish some new, more punitive rules for countries needing emergency aid.

headline: Jozy Altidore: One Down, One to Go
abstract: The conditions will be far different but the goals will be the same when the United States faces Mexico: a win and three points.

headline: Post-Mortem for Russian Finds No Sign of a Struggle
abstract: The death last week of the exiled Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky outside London was “consistent with hanging,” the British police said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A post-mortem examination on the exiled Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky found the cause of death was “consistent with hanging” with no sign of a violent struggle, the police said late Monday, after two days of intense speculation over the final hours of one of the Kremlin’s most vocal critics.

lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A man from Haifa recalled taking his children here in the 1970s, to buy products not yet available in Israel: Ovaltine, licorice, 7-Up, Wrigley’s gum. A woman who lives in a Jerusalem suburb said she used to come in the 1980s, for political demonstrations.

headline: Shaving Below a Man’s Neck, if That’s What She Wants

lead_paragraph: AS bare-chested photographs of the hirsute actors Sean Connery and Burt Reynolds from the 1960s and 1970s suggest there was a time when an abundance of body hair for men was widely considered attractive. But look at magazines like Men’s Health and Men’s Fitness in recent years, and the vast majority of the shirtless cover models have polished torsos, well-defined six-pack abs and pectoral muscles.

Bloomberg, a firm advocate of gun control, as well as the mayor himself, had tried to contact the family of a Brooklyn 16-year-old who was killed by plainclothes officers after the police said he had pointed an illegally obtained revolver at them.

But the deal, reached over the weekend, will still impose harsh austerity on the people of Cyprus and could further sap public confidence in the banks of other weak European economies, like Spain and Italy.

abstract: Constitutional principles bar defining marriage as a union between a man and a woman.
lead_paragraph: California’s Proposition 8 rewrote the state’s Constitution so that “only marriage between a man and a woman is valid or recognized in California.” The 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, for purposes of any federal law, defined the word marriage to mean “only a legal union between one man and one woman.”

headline: The Killing Chain
abstract: Our present debate around violence fixates on guns at the unhelpful expense of nonmaterial factors and more prudent policy considerations.

headline: Rand Paul’s Loopy Ascent
abstract: At risk to a party that must muffle its cuckoo’s nest, the junior senator from Kentucky spreads his wings.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve got loons the likes of Ted Cruz and Sarah Palin fluttering about, I suppose it’s easy not to seem like such a wacko bird yourself.

headline: Anthony Lewis, Champion of the Law
abstract: One by one, his columns informed an entire generation about the promise of the law.
lead_paragraph: My introduction to Anthony Lewis, who died on Monday at 85, came late one afternoon in 1963 in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, where I was a microscopically junior editor and he was one in a towering cast of journalistic stars assembled by James Reston, the bureau chief. It was decision day at the Supreme Court, and Tony handed me brief summaries of three or four articles he intended to write by the time his bus to suburban Virginia left at 6:30. And so, to my astonishment, he did — one big piece on the most important case; smaller ones on the others; each one crisp, learned and requiring almost nothing in the way of editorial improvement.

headline: Massachusetts Plan Starts Small for Big Upgrade to Rail System

headline: ‘Oh Boy! So Many Questions!’ About China in Africa
abstract: Amid talk of China as “new colonials” in Africa, Tanzanian President Jakaya Kikwete said China wasn’t different from any other power and questioned the intense interest surrounding the topic.
