headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) TAVIS SMILEY REPORTS: EDUCATION UNDER ARREST Mr. Smiley travels to Washington State, Louisiana, Missouri and California to examine the connection between the juvenile justice system and the dropout rate among American teenagers; as many as three-quarters of those incarcerated in detention centers withdraw from high school. Along the way he speaks with educational experts on the front lines of reform, including Jimmie Edwards, a juvenile court judge and the founder of the Innovative Concept Academy in St. Louis, who believes that the zero-tolerance policy applied by some schools — under which minor infractions, including disruptive behavior, foul language and truancy, can escalate into jail time — is not the best route; and the Loyola and Tulane University law students who work for Stand Up for Each Other!, an advocacy group for children who have been expelled from school. Part 2 of “180 Days: A Year Inside an American High School,” which chronicles one year in the life of the first graduating class of Washington Metropolitan High School — a public school where only 7 percent of students are deemed proficient in math, and only 19 percent in reading — follows at 9. (Mr. Smiley, above right, with Michael Triplett, principal of the Innovative Concept Academy.)

headline: Old Dog Needs $6,000 Surgery. What Do You Do?
abstract: The 21st-century dog has received an upgrade, from “pet” to “family,” and life-prolonging surgery is definitely an option.
lead_paragraph: The average bichon frisé will live to be 16 years old.

headline: Women’s Team Plays On at Kentucky
abstract: Kentucky, buoyed by a fierce defense referred to as “40 minutes of dread,” are competing for a team-record fourth consecutive season.
lead_paragraph: One week after defending national champion Kentucky made a swift exit from the National Invitation Tournament with an upset loss at Robert Morris, the Wildcats’ basketball banner is flying high.

headline: News Quiz | March 26, 2013
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: U.S.A.I.D. Administrator Rajiv Shah
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Foreign Aid', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The American agency has changed its approach to aid in India completely.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI— Each year, about 1.5 million children under 5 years old die in India, which has the largest number of such deaths worldwide. A majority of these deaths stem from pneumonia, diarrhea, malnutrition and complications at birth and can be prevented. In February, at the India Call to Action on Child Survival and Development Summit, India’s Ministry of Health and Family Welfare released a strategic road map to tackle preventable child deaths and introduced a National Child Survival Score Card and a dashboard to track progress on child survival and development.

headline: Bachmann Is Subject of Ethics Investigation
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Office of Congressional Ethics is examining allegations of wrongdoing that emerged in the aftermath of Mrs. Bachmann’s failed bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, is the subject of an ethics investigation examining allegations of wrongdoing that emerged in the aftermath of her failed bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012, a lawyer for the lawmaker confirmed Monday.

headline: Agent G.M.O.
abstract: Monsanto, the chemical company that brought Agent Orange to Vietnam during the war, is now offering to bring it genetically engineered crops. Be wary.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY — It’s 5 a.m. and the streets already are buzzing. People know that the best time to shop at open-air markets is before daybreak. And they know to ask for fresh, firm vegetables grown locally, rather than in China, where dangerous pesticides are routinely overused.

headline: As Scotland Turns the Page, a Lesson for Other Teams
abstract: Scotland is learning that, for a team facing a generational transition, there’s no time to waste in starting over.
lead_paragraph: When the Scottish Football Association drew up a short list of potential successors to the fired Scotland manager Craig Levein last year, the country’s news media and the team’s supporters did the same. Naturally, the lists differed, but there was one commonality: everyone linked with the vacant post was a Scot.

headline: Italy’s Highest Court Overturns Acquittal of Amanda Knox
abstract: The implications for Ms. Knox, an American who was an exchange student in 2007 when she was accused of murder, were unclear.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s highest court on Tuesday ordered a new trial in the sensational case of Amanda Knox, an American student accused of murdering her 21-year-old roommate, Meredith Kercher of Britain, in 2007.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 26, 2013
abstract: Can you use context clues to select the word that best completes the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Letter by Letter, Keeping a Catholic Outpost Alive.”

headline: Raising a Hindu Kid in New York
abstract: Getting a little help with religious instruction.
lead_paragraph: How do you teach your children about religion, particularly your own? Are the parents responsible for this vital task, or should they call in some outside help? It’s a question I faced when I became a parent almost five years ago.

headline: Do Millennials Stand a Chance in the Real World?
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Labor and Jobs', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: The members of Generation Y have developed an obsession with money — partly because they don’t have any.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, my grandmother used to spirit packets of oyster crackers from restaurants. She unwrapped gifts meticulously, peeling back the tape with her nails so that she could reuse the paper. She also stockpiled so many coupon-bought cans that she probably could have had her own show on TLC.

headline: Praying for Dry Land in Panama
abstract: Steadily rising waters are threatening the homes and traditions of the Kuna Indians, who inhabit a chain of islands off Panama’s Caribbean coast.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of years on the Kuna Yala islands, water and prayer were intertwined with daily rituals.

headline: Calling All High School Hackers
abstract: Why is Arlan Jaska “just the type the Department of Homeland Security is looking for”?
lead_paragraph: In “Luring Young Web Warriors Is a Priority. It’s Also a Game.,” Nicole Perlroth writes about how and why the U.S. government is now searching high schools for talented computer hackers.

headline: See the Play, Don’t Miss the Program
abstract: One of the pleasures and privileges of theatergoing in London — in addition to those little wooden spoonlets that come with the interval ice cream – is the beauty of the printed theater program. Granted, they’re not free.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the pleasures and privileges of theatergoing in London — in addition to those little wooden spoonlets that come with the interval ice cream — is the beauty of the printed theater program. Rather than the advertising-heavy publications of many cities, particularly New York, chock-full of fluffy profiles of the newest musical star and features on the favorite Thai restaurant of a chorus member of “Wicked,” a London theater program is often a quick study guide — a cheat sheet for the high-brow pop quiz of theater about to unfold.

headline: Justices Say Time May Be Wrong for Gay Marriage Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Six justices questioned whether the case was properly before the court and hinted they might vote to dismiss it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court on Tuesday weighed the momentous question of whether gay and lesbian couples have a constitutional right to marry, six justices questioned whether the case, arising from a California ban on same-sex marriages, was properly before the court and indicated that they might vote to dismiss it.

headline: College Decision Checklist: However It Arrives, Check Your Envelope at Home
abstract: College counselors remind students of what to do before, when and after their admission decisions arrive.
lead_paragraph: This week, as final college decisions are announced, The Choice blog is running a series of posts dedicated to the climax of the admissions season.

abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times

headline: Declining Wealth Brings a Rising Retirement Risk
abstract: With equity tied up in homes and facing the switch to defined-contribution pension plans, many Americans have been left short of funds needed for a comfortable retirement, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Mexico-U.S.: Tables Turned in 90 Minutes
abstract: Mexico, with only two draws in its first two games of the Hexagonal, is under pressure to defeat the U.S. in Tuesday’s World Cup qualifying match in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: What a difference 90 minutes makes.

headline: North Korea Calls Hawaii and U.S. Mainland Targets
abstract: In a show of anger over military exercises by the United States and South Korea, the North ordered missile and artillery units to be ready to hit targets in those counties.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s military said it put all its missile and artillery units on “the highest alert” on Tuesday, ordering them to be ready to hit South Korea, as well as the United States and its military installations in Hawaii and Guam.

headline: Daily Report: He Has Millions and a New Job at Yahoo. And Soon He’ll Be 18.
abstract: One of Yahoo’s newest employees is a 17-year-old high school student in Britain. As of Monday, he is one of its richest, too, Brian Stelter reports on Tuesday in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: One of Yahoo’s newest employees is a 17-year-old high school student in Britain. As of Monday, he is one of its richest, too, Brian Stelter reports on Tuesday in The New York Times.

headline: My Search for Reasonable and Understandable Credit Card Processing
abstract: It would take eight months and many hours of meetings and research for me to figure out how I was being charged and what I could do about it.
lead_paragraph: I have been accepting credit cards at my business for many years. My recollection is that I first signed up to take them in 1994. During most of that time, I have used my regular business bank, PNC, to process the transactions. When I signed up for PNC’s merchant-processing services, I knew that I would be paying fees for the services, but I was wrapped up in other business issues at the time and paid little attention to the details.

headline: T-Mobile Unveils New Pricing Plan, Kind Of
abstract: New pricing has appeared on the T-Mobile Web site. If this is the new “unplan,” what kind of deal is it?
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile has unveiled what is presumably its new pricing plan. I say presumably because the company will not confirm or deny that the plan appearing on its Web site is its new plan.

headline: The Record Keepers
abstract: Never mind the category: group kissing, public nakedness, mass cooking. Mexicans want to break — no, obliterate — all Guinness World Records out there.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO — Saturday, March 16, was a sad day for Mexican chefs. A group of 2,333 cooks, all dressed up in their whites, most wearing tall toques, formed a very long line along Paseo de la Reforma, in the heart of the city. But they were 511 short.

headline: In Dell, Shifting Attitude Toward Buyouts
abstract: The battle over Dell suggests that investors today may be slightly less short-term greedy than previous generations. | A collection of internal e-mails at the law firm DLA Piper could reinforce a perception that law firms inflate bills. | Puerto Rico is fashioning a new identity for itself as a tax haven. | A report says that the board of Hulu has approached potential buyers.
lead_paragraph: IN DELL OFFERS, SHIFTING ATTITUDE TOWARD BUYOUTS  |  The battle over Dell puts into focus the question of whether management-led buyouts are in shareholders’ best interests, and it reflects a shifting ethos on Wall Street, “one that might be slightly less short-term greedy than that of previous generations,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. “It appears that some shareholders of companies involved in buyouts would prefer to ride a wave of gains alongside the buyout kings rather than cash out immediately.”

headline: Bright Passages
abstract: Don’t worry: the nagging and fault-finding proceed as usual in the “In a Word” section below. But first, a small and subjective sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions. Nominations are always welcome.
lead_paragraph: Don’t worry: the fault-finding proceeds as usual in the “In a Word” section below. But first, a small and subjective sampling of sparkling prose from recent editions. Nominations are always welcome.

headline: In Performance: Tina Packer of ‘Women of Will’
abstract: The actress plays Queen Margaret in a scene from Shakespeare’s “Henry VI, Part III,” from her show “Women of Will.”
lead_paragraph: In “Women of Will” the actress Tina Packer, the founder and former artistic director of Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, Mass., explores Shakespeare’s heroines. In this excerpt from “Henry VI, Part III,” Ms. Packer plays Queen Margaret of Anjou, who has captured the Duke of York and is about to have him killed for usurping the English crown for his children, even though Margaret’s children are the rightful heirs. The show, which also stars Nigel Gore, continues through June 2 at the Gym at Judson Memorial Church.

headline: Opinion Report: Anthony Lewis
abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: Oral Arguments Echo in Gatherings Across Nation
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: As the Supreme Court weighed a challenge to California’s ban on same-sex marriage, the weight of the decision that the justices will make was felt in thousands of communities.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Most United States Supreme Court cases, however significant, pass largely unnoticed when they are argued. But the opening of hearings over the legal definition of marriage was a cultural moment that brought America to its front porch.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Yahoo’s Big Hire Is 17, and Anthony Lewis Dies at 85
abstract: Nick D’Aloisio is Yahoo’s newest hire and a millionaire at 17; Anthony Lewis, New York Times reporter and columnist who changed how the Supreme Court is covered, has died at 85; and the writer of the popular tween girl’s books “The Dork Diaries is actually a 53-year-old divorced former bankruptcy lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Nick D’Aloisio is living the technology entrepreneur’s dream: he sold his news-reading app, Summly, to Yahoo on Monday for tens of millions of dollars and became the resurgent Web giant’s newest employee, Brian Stelter writes. The only problem is that Mr. D’Aloisio still has to finish high school; the British programmer is only 17. Mr. D’Aloisio received venture capital from high-profile investors like Yoko Ono, Wendi Murdock and Li Ka-Shing, the Hong Kong billionaire, when he was just 15. Yahoo plans to incorporate Summly, which summarizes long-form stories for smart phones, into Yahoo’s suite of mobile apps.

headline: The Unnatural Rate Hypothesis
abstract: Was it the Fed wot did it?
lead_paragraph: When I read opinion pieces by insiders, I often find the ostensible argument less interesting than what is taken for granted. It’s the throwaway lines, the statements that obviously are meant to refer to what “everyone knows”, that can be truly revealing about the state of conventional wisdom.

headline: Tuesday Reading: A Push for HPV Vaccinations
abstract: A push for HPV vaccinations, setting a price on the life of a beloved pet, T-Mobile unveils new pricing plan (sort of) and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: When Money and Emotions Collide
abstract: Articles that illustrate where emotions affect financial decisions — from following a dream even when the dream is dashed to the people who give away their big inheritances — appear in a special section published by the Your Money team, in collaboration with American Public Media’s “Marketplace Money” radio program.
lead_paragraph: We all have some sort of history that has shaped the way we relate to money, and those feelings can influence many of the financial decisions we make, both both big and small. Human nature plays a big role, too.

headline: A Sidewalk Hit and Run, With a Suitcase
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: When a self-centered person rolls her suitcase over your foot and then blames you for being in her way, it helps to have sympathetic onlookers.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Controversial Media Deal in Taiwan Nears Collapse
abstract: The pro-Beijing businessmen seeking to buy two liberal publications in Taiwan were unlikely to meet a deadline on Wednesday to complete the sale, a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The $500 million sale of two of the most liberal publications in Taiwan to largely pro-Beijing investors appeared on the verge of collapse on Tuesday.

headline: We Don’t Want the Smoking Gun to be an Entitlement Mushroom Cloud
abstract: Someday we’ll be right, right?
lead_paragraph: Tom Tomorrow. Go read. Also, check out his blasts from the past.

headline: 5 Police Officers Killed in Bomb Attack in Afghanistan
abstract: Suicide bombers stormed the headquarters of a special unit of the Afghan police in Jalalabad, and the Taliban later claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Eight suicide bombers stormed the headquarters of a special unit of the Afghan police in the eastern city of Jalalabad on Tuesday morning, killing five officers and wounding four.

headline: Cyprus Deal Sparks Anti-German Mood — and Defenders
abstract: Critics of the bailout deal imposed on Cyprus have directed their ire at Germany and Chancellor Angela Merkel. But does Germany’s role in the crisis excuse the latest wave of Germanophobia in Europe?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the overheated atmosphere of the Cyprus bailout crisis, Germany has once more been portrayed as a bullying villain wielding its economic power to dominate a struggling Europe.

headline: Questions About Pet Health Care
abstract: Answers to some basic questions about medical care for pets.
lead_paragraph: Decisions about end-of-life care for pets are heart-wrenching for their owners. That’s even more so now than 10 or 20 years ago because new technology and advances in medical treatments have made their way down to pet care, meaning there are more ways to save or extend your pet’s life. But it also means more expense, if you choose to do so.

headline: What Next From North Korea?
abstract: North Korea searches for more bluster.
lead_paragraph: North Korea searches for more bluster.

headline: China’s New-Style First Lady and Old-Style Fears
abstract: Old patriarchal fears about mixing women and power underscore the significance of the cultural shift behind Peng Liyuan, President Xi Jinping’s wife, taking on a more prominent First Lady role.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Peng Liyuan, China’s glamorous, new first lady, stepped out of the Air China airplane in Moscow next to her husband on his inaugural trip abroad, an old fear stepped out too: as a woman close to power might she bring disaster on the country?

headline: The Mideast Peace Gap
abstract: The important question is not whether Israel does want peace but just how much it does.
lead_paragraph: Regarding “Bits, bytes and bombs” (Views, March 25): Thomas L. Friedman aptly criticizes Israel’s dream of permanent occupation of the West Bank — especially now with extreme annexationists in the cabinet. Of course not all Israelis have this dream, but many do, and many more wish for more continued settlement expansion beyond today’s 320,000 settlers. What is hard to square with either of these wishes is the other wish that Israel claims to have — for peace. Doubtless Israel does want peace. The important question is not whether Israel does want peace — for who doesn’t — but just how much it does.

headline: Europe Expands Investigation Into Derivatives Market
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The inquiry, which has already ensnared major international giants like Barclays, JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank, has been broadened to include the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, a trade organization for market participants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union antitrust regulators have expanded their investigation into whether a small network of big banks unfairly controls the derivatives market.

headline: Q&A: Erasing Saved Web Site Passwords
abstract: Most Web browsers let you save user names and passwords for frequently visited sites, but this information can be deleted.
lead_paragraph: March 29, 2013, 4:03 p.m. | Updated  Added alternate ways to reach the Settings screen on Chrome for the Macintosh in response to reader questions.

headline: Site to Be Seen | Victoria Beckham
abstract: Beckham’s Web site now offers e-commerce for her Victoria, Victoria Beckham label and a new collection created exclusively for online shoppers.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham, whose eponymous fashion line was heretofore available exclusively at specialty retailers including Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and FortyFiveTen and online powerhouses Net-A-Porter and MyTheresa, is now offering e-commerce for her Victoria, Victoria Beckham label and accessories like handbags, denim and eyewear. “It’s all about modern luxury, and the ability to shop online and have anything delivered to your door is very much a modern convenience,” says Beckham. Although her mainline collection is not currently available on the site, a new collection called ICON, which Beckham created exclusively for online shoppers, will feature a selection of her iconic dresses.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Mother Jones: As long as moms and dads are getting worked up over the yellow dyes in Kraft Macaroni and Cheese, they might want to look at the product’s other ingredients. The authors here found them not that different from the stuff in Cheez-Its – which use natural coloring. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Oscar Dates Set for Next Year and 2015
abstract: Circle your calendar: March 2, 2014, will be Oscar night.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Oscars will be held on March 2 next year, slightly later than this year’s Feb. 24 date, and on Feb. 22 in 2015, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said. The date for next year is the first Sunday after the end of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Woods’s Return to No. 1 Soothes Golf
abstract: Golf fans do not love the underdog the way college basketball fans do, and they really love it when Tiger Woods is winning.
lead_paragraph: For the traditionalists who had a tough weekend, the status quo fought back for you Monday. There were a lot of people rattled by the rise of Florida Gulf Coast and La Salle and Wichita State — you could spot them staring balefully at brackets dominated by colleges they had actually heard of — but their world grew a little brighter Monday. That is because Tiger Woods showed he could dominate golf again, returning to No. 1 after a long climb from his ignominious fall. This comforted people, unlikeable as he has become. If you cannot count on Woods scowling his way around postcard-pretty golf courses and collecting gobs of money, what can you count on in this world?

headline: Shape Up or Don’t Fly, Air India Tells Cabin Crew Over 40
abstract: Older crew members at state-run airline have until Friday to pass a battery of medical tests.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Air India is cracking down on its cabin crew over the age of 40, who could be grounded in coming weeks if they are found to be unfit or overweight.

headline: March 26 Updates on Supreme Court Same-Sex Marriage Hearing
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Lede is following the Supreme Court hearing on Tuesday, the first of two days of arguments related to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: That’s a wrap for today, but we’ll be back on Wednesday with live updates from the oral arguments as the high court weighs the Defense of Marriage Act. For now, The Times’s Adam Liptak and Scott Shane report that the justices might be nervous about acting too quickly on gay marriage, and Jeremy Peters writes about the people who waited for days to witness the discussion. Don’t want the argument to end? Room for Debate has a discussion about whether gay marriage is best left to the courts or to states.

headline: Feliciano Will Stay With Mets
abstract: Pitcher Pedro Feliciano, who will not begin the season with the Mets, said he would remain with the organization. Las Vegas is a likely destination.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — One day after it appeared he would seek a new employer, Pedro Feliciano, one of the last links to the Mets’ playoff run in 2006, said he would stay with the team somewhere in the organization.

headline: How Opinion on Same-Sex Marriage Is Changing, and What It Means
abstract: Support for same-sex marriage is increasing, but is it doing so at a faster rate than in the past? How much of the shift is because of generational turnover? And how many states would approve same-sex marriage today?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court will hear arguments this week on two cases related to same-sex marriage, the first involving a California referendum that barred gay marriage, the other involving a federal law that prevents the government from recognizing same-sex unions. A variety of outcomes are possible, but it seems prudent to take stock of public opinion on same-sex marriage before the decisions come down.

headline: $616 Million Poorer, Hedge Fund Owner Still Buys Art
abstract: A renowned art collector, Steven Cohen has bought Picasso’s “Le Rêve” from the casino owner Stephen A. Wynn for $155 million. It is at least the second $100 million-plus acquisition of art by Mr. Cohen in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund owned by the billionaire trader Steven A. Cohen, agreed to pay the government $616 million to settle accusations of insider trading, Mr. Cohen has decided to buy a little something for himself.

headline: The Gun Report: March 26, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Every day we cite gun death statistics culled by Slate, which has been publishing the number of gun deaths since the Newtown massacre last December. Slate’s initiative was prompted in part by the fact that the F.B.I. statistics on gun deaths are woefully outdated, and that there is a void that needs to be filled: no research organization is even trying to “create a real-time chronicle of the death attributable to guns in the United States,” as Slate puts it. How does Slate compile its information? It uses crowdsourcing techniques, relying especially on a Twitter feed, @GunDeaths, which is run by an anonymous researcher who has been tweeting every reported gun death he can find since the mass shooting in Aurora.

headline: Digging Through Mounds of Storm Debris, Seeking Recyclable Objects
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: At a cleanup site in the Rockaways, excavators sort through wreckage from Hurricane Sandy, looking for hazardous objects or metal that can be recycled.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks and months since Hurricane Sandy pummeled the New York City area, cleanup crews have hauled off thousands of tons of wreckage, much of it left on city streets by people trying to piece their lives back together.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Regrets
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Times’s Peter Baker on why the former president says signing the Defense of Marriage Act was a mistake.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Peter Baker on why the former president says signing the Defense of Marriage Act was a mistake.

headline: Cahill Scores … for Australia
abstract: Tim Cahill and Brett Holman scored goals in the second half as Australia salvaged a 2-2 tie Tuesday against Oman in an Asia World Cup qualifying match.
lead_paragraph: In his 15-game career (so far) in Major League Soccer, Tim Cahill has scored only one goal.

headline: Goldman Amends Warrants Deal With Buffett
abstract: The modified agreement essentially makes the billionaire one of the Wall Street firm’s biggest investors without having to pay additional money.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is about to join a rarefied club: the group of banks that count Warren E. Buffett as a big investor.

headline: Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles Says Its Endowment Will Reach Record Level
abstract: The museum says that is has been promised donations that will increase its endowment to more than $60 million.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, which has been beset by financial struggles and board defections, announced Tuesday that it had been promised donations that would raise its endowment to more than $60 million, the highest in the museum’s 34-year history.

headline: Petrobras, Once Symbol of Brazil’s Oil Hopes, Strives to Regain Lost Swagger
abstract: Once a symbol of Brazil’s rise as a global oil powerhouse, Petrobras, the national oil company, now embodies the sluggishness of the economy itself.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s oil production is falling, casting doubt on what was supposed to be an oil bonanza. Imports of gasoline are rising rapidly, exposing the country to the whims of global energy markets. Even the nation’s ethanol industry, once envied as a model of renewable energy, has had to import ethanol from the United States.

headline: In Egypt, Five Face Charges of Urging Violence in Postings
abstract: The five are accused of using social media to incite attacks against President Mohamed Morsi’s allies in the Muslim Brotherhood that took place last Friday.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Supporters of President Mohamed Morsi on Tuesday defended an arrest warrant for five activists on charges of using social media to incite attacks against Mr. Morsi’s allies in the Muslim Brotherhood that took place last Friday.

headline: Federal Reserve Faults Citigroup Over Money Laundering Controls
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Money Laundering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Federal Reserve took aim at Citigroup and the American branch of its Mexican subsidiary over failure to monitor cash transactions for potentially suspicious activity.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve hit Citigroup with an enforcement action on Tuesday over breakdowns in money laundering controls that threatened to allow tainted money to move through the United States.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Legalizing Aid in Dying
abstract: A writer for an elder care center discusses end-of-life care and options. Readers are invited to reply.

headline: Image of the Day: March 26
abstract: Festival of Panguni Uthiram being celebrated in Chennai, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Coming to New York, a Smorgasbord Auto Show
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (NYC)']
abstract: Carmakers will show an eclectic mix of vehicles that do not seem especially well suited for the daily driving needs of New Yorkers, but the show floor will still have plenty of  new mainstream models.
lead_paragraph: Arriving in Manhattan a week after the Ringling Brother and Barnum & Bailey Circus rode the rails to Brooklyn’s Barclays Center, the New York International Auto Show opens its doors just as the populace emerges from its winter isolation and spring teases an appearance — and as the car-shopping season starts to warm up. The show opens to the public on Friday and continues through April 7.

headline: Talking Talent | George C. Wolfe
abstract: George C. Wolfe, the director of the new Broadway show “Lucky Guy,” reminisces about its writer Nora Ephron and tells T what plays he’s dying to direct next.
lead_paragraph: The American playwright and director George C. Wolfe, who has won Tonys for “Angels in America: Millennium Approaches” and for “Bring in ‘da Noise/Bring in ‘da Funk,” is the director of “Lucky Guy,” opening at the Broadhurst Theater on April 1. It is the last play Nora Ephron wrote before her death last year, and stars Tom Hanks as Mike McAlary, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper journalist who covered the police beat in New York in the 1980s and ’90s. A resident of the city during those years, Wolfe was drawn to the pulse of Ephron’s script and the challenge of recreating such a dynamic time in New York’s history.

headline: The GoogaMooga Festival Will Return in May
abstract: The enormous festival of food, drink and music in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park will be held over three days this year, May 17 to 19.
lead_paragraph: The Great GoogaMooga festival of food, drink and music in Prospect Park, which drew thousands of people to its first outing last spring, will return. And there will be improvements to the festival, where general admission attendees complained last year of hourlong waits for food, drinks and bathrooms at the two-day event. Those who bought $250 tickets for Extra Mooga, the V.I.P. section of the festival, received refunds after organizers acknowledged that the experience was not commensurate with the price tag. (General admission tickets were, and will remain, free for Saturday and Sunday.)

headline: A Narrow Escape, and Lasting Guilt
abstract: When I hear about a tragedy caused by a moment of parental carelessness — a hot car, an unlocked pool gate — I don’t judge the parents. I was lucky.
lead_paragraph: I was a new mom at 36, and there was a lot about motherhood that terrified me. I had no experience with infants, nor did my husband,  Michael. As happy as we were to be expecting, I was filled with fear and trepidation. How on earth would I know what to do?

headline: Publishers Revel in Youthful Cruelty
abstract: Books about bullying, for youngsters and adults, are now so numerous they are a genre in themselves.
lead_paragraph: Nobody likes a bully — but these days the book industry loves having them to kick around.

headline: A Doll Helps Disabled Women Find Their Voices
abstract: Women with learning disabilities are especially vulnerable to sex abuse. The Josephine Project is helping educate such women and raising awareness of the issue.
lead_paragraph: NEWCASTLE, England — Josephine, a life-size doll, sat on a chair in the middle of a community center in this city in northeast England.

headline: Howard Can’t Play, So He’d Prefer Not to Watch
abstract: After breaking two bones in a game last month, goalkeeper Tim Howard will hope for a United States victory over Mexico from afar.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Tim Howard likely won’t be watching his United States teammates when they face Mexico in Tuesday’s World Cup qualifier.

headline: Edward Bland, ‘Cry of Jazz’ Filmmaker and Composer, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Bland’s documentary, released in 1959, explained jazz in the context of black history. He went on to work on commercial and avant-garde musical ventures.
lead_paragraph: Edward Bland made only one film before deciding to pursue a career as a musician, composer and arranger. And that film, “The Cry of Jazz,” a 34-minute documentary explaining jazz in the context of black history, was by his own account amateurish.

headline: D.H. Lawrence’s War Poems to Be Published, Dirty Words and All
abstract: The poems will be included in a two-volume critical edition of the author’s verse.
lead_paragraph: Various unprintable words kept the unexpurgated “Lady Chatterley’s Lover,” D.H. Lawrence’s classic 1928 novel of sexual congress across class lines, off bookshelves for more than three decades. But who knew that words like “Salonika” and “Mesopotamia” would keep some of Lawrence’s poetry out of print until 2013?

headline: To Save the King of the Jungle, a Call to Pen Him In
abstract: A new paper from nearly 60 top lion scientists and conservationists suggests that building more fences may be the best way to save African lions.
lead_paragraph: After 35 years of field research in the Serengeti plains, Craig Packer, director of the Lion Research Center at the University of Minnesota, has lost all patience with the romance of African wilderness. Fences, he says, are the only way to stop the precipitous and continuing decline in the number of African lions.

headline: After a Series of Setbacks, a Music Collective Reopens Its Doors
abstract: Issue Project Room, an experimental music collective that is now in its fourth location, is searching for stability in its current home in Downtown Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: To compare the challenges faced by the Issue Project Room, an experimental music collective in Brooklyn, to Homer’s Odyssey might be a stretch, but the challenges faced by the group certainly have all the trappings of an ancient tragedy. The recent performance of “November” — a five-hour piano performance written by Dennis Johnson — was yet another triumph for the organization, which has oscillated between progress and defeat for nearly a decade.

headline: As Supreme Court Deliberates, Jeb Bush Speaks
abstract: The former governor of Florida indicates that he has not yet evolved on the issue of gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: Quite a few Republicans have been announcing new stages in their “evolution” on same-sex marriage, which is being debated in the Supreme Court today and tomorrow. Senator Rob Portman of Ohio said earlier this month that he was prompted to reverse his position when he learned his son was gay – after a two-year period of reflection that included having his name floated as a potential running mate for Mitt Romney, a staunch opponent of gay marriage.

headline: If You Like ‘Horse With No Name,’  Try Band of Horses
abstract: Hearing the band America in the music of Band of Horses.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: For Cohen, a Big Art Deal
abstract: The billionaire hedge fund manager is paying $155 million for Picasso’s “Le Rêve,” according to The New York Post’s Page Six. The painting is the one that casino magnate Stephen A. Wynn accidentally — and famously — damaged with his elbow.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire hedge fund manager is paying $155 million for Picasso’s “Le Rêve,” according to The New York Post’s Page Six. The painting is the one that casino magnate Stephen A. Wynn accidentally — and famously — damaged with his elbow.

headline: Your Carriage, Ma’am
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II marking the 150th anniversary of the London Tube.
lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II marking the 150th anniversary of the London Tube. Those who ride regularly can view historic posters at the Transport Museum.

headline: New Laws Ban Most Abortions in North Dakota
abstract: Gov. Jack Dalrymple signed the nation’s toughest abortion restrictions into law on Tuesday, including a measure that bans the procedure as soon as six weeks into a pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — Gov. Jack Dalrymple of North Dakota approved the nation’s toughest abortion restrictions on Tuesday, signing into law a measure that would ban nearly all abortions and inviting a legal showdown over just how much states can limit access to the procedure.

headline: Pardon Me, Is That Rihanna in Your Purse?
abstract: The $300 Stellé Couture Audio Clutch appears to be a woman’s handbag, but springs open to reveal a speaker dock that pumps out surprisingly good sound.
lead_paragraph: Was I expecting too little of the Stellé Audio Couture Audio Clutch?

headline: Justices Hear Gay Marriage Arguments
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: After witnessing the same-sex marriage hearings, The Times’s Scott Shane assesses the questions posed by the Supreme Court justices.
lead_paragraph: After witnessing the same-sex marriage hearings, The Times’s Scott Shane assesses the questions posed by the Supreme Court justices.

headline: Locking Horns Where Others Might Sing ‘Kumbaya’
abstract: The new cast members for “The Real World” on MTV arrive in Portland, Ore., aware of the tribulations ahead: heavy drinking, meaningless squabbles and a chance at a new life.
lead_paragraph: The inevitable “Portlandia” sketch about “The Real World: Portland” will probably go something like this: Jocks and cheerleaders and assorted dunderheads converge on an organic farm on the outskirts of Portland, Ore., ready for what happens when people stop being polite and start getting real. One by one, as in most contagion films, the subjects flip. Soon they’re crocheting sweaters, singing indie-rock karaoke, digging in thrift-store bins, pickling vegetables.

headline: Cancer Diagnosis: Less Can Be More
abstract: Dr. Peter Scardino of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center says current prostate cancer screening is painful and imprecise but vastly improving.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Peter Scardino of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center says current prostate cancer screening is painful and imprecise but vastly improving.

headline: New Ways to Assess Prostate Cancer
abstract: New tests that supplement the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.
lead_paragraph: New tests that supplement the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.

headline: New Prostate Cancer Tests Could Reduce False Alarms
abstract: Sophisticated new tests might supplement unreliable readings of the protein P.S.A., which often detect cancers that are unlikely to cause harm.
lead_paragraph: Sophisticated new prostate cancer tests are coming to market that might supplement the unreliable P.S.A. test, potentially saving tens of thousands of men each year from unnecessary biopsies, operations and radiation treatments.

headline: Hotel Partners, Strange Bedfellows
abstract: The parent company of IKEA and Marriott International announced this month that they are teaming up to create Moxy, a chain of budget hotels across Europe.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of the design-driven furniture maker IKEA and the untrendy Marriott International announced this month that they are teaming up to create Moxy, a chain of budget hotels across Europe, news that strikes many travelers as an odd coupling. (And inspires questions, like, will you have to put together your nightside table with an Allen wrench?)

headline: Soros to Give $1 Million to NAACP Legal Fund
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: George Soros, the billionaire financier and philanthropist, has pledged $1 million to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund.
lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire financier and philanthropist, has pledged $1 million to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, the country’s leading civil rights legal advocacy group, officials there said Tuesday.

headline: Sampling Island Flavor With Amber Ales
abstract: What makes these squid fritters unusual is that they are sizzled like pancakes, rather than deep-fried.
lead_paragraph: Assuming the occasion does not demand fancy fare, there is very little you can’t enjoy with American amber ales. I proved that at a recent Sunday lunch. We had just spent a long weekend at the home of friends in the Grenadines, where Venita Alexander, an accomplished local cook who adds island flavor to some of her meals, made an impossible quantity of conch fritters for lunch one day. We ate them all with Hairoun, the local lager, but it could just as well have been an American amber ale. What made her fritters unusual was that she didn’t deep-fry them; rather, she used much less oil to sizzle them like pancakes. I stole her idea, replacing the conch with more easily obtained squid and adding beer (instead of milk) to my batter. FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: Detroit’s Contemporary Art Museum Finally Has a New Director
abstract: Elysia Borowy-Reeder will take over at the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit.
lead_paragraph: Detroit might not be doing so well – it was placed this month under the control of an emergency manager as it tries to stave off financial default. But its contemporary-art scene is thriving and on Tuesday the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit announced that it had selected a new director after more than a year and a half without a permanent leader. Elysia Borowy-Reeder, who was most recently the director of the Contemporary Art Museum in Raleigh, N.C., where she focused on strengthening that museum’s education programs, will take over in early April.

headline: Buyers of Long-Term Care Insurance Prefer Home Care
keywords: ['Elder Care', 'Elderly', 'Home Health Care', 'Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Nursing Homes']
abstract: Some consumers see long-term care insurance as a way to help them stay out of a nursing home and in their own homes longer.
lead_paragraph: Long-term care insurance, which can help cover the cost of extended care if you’re unable to care for yourself, is something no one really wants to think about. It’s a product you buy, after all, in the hope that you will never have to use it.

headline: Bakery Owner Talks About Coping With Health Insurance Changes
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Rachel Shein, owner of Baked in the Sun, responds to reader comments from last week’s case study.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about Baked in the Sun, a wholesale bakery and distributor that is trying to decide how best to comply with the Affordable Care Act. Starting in January, the new law requires businesses with 50 or more full-time employees to offer health insurance or pay a penalty. Owned by Rachel Shein and Steve Pilarski, husband and wife, the company employs nearly 100 workers to bake and deliver freshly made pastries to coffee shops, hospitals and hotels in Southern California.

headline: T-Mobile Shakes Up Its Service
abstract: The American mobile carrier, which has struggled against rivals like AT&T and Verizon, will offer the iPhone 5 and other top smartphones without locking in customers for two years.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA, long trailing its rivals in the cellphone industry, is trying to catch up by changing the conversation: it is selling the iPhone cheaper than the competition, and most important, customers would not have to sign a contract.

headline: Syrian Opposition Joins Meeting of Arab League
abstract: The Arab League’s decision to give Syria’s membership to the opposition coalition was considered a symbolic but important moment in the two-year-old Syrian conflict.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — To the outrage of Syria’s embattled government, the opposition coalition leader formally took its vacant seat at an Arab League summit meeting on Tuesday and immediately requested broader recognition, including from the United Nations, as part of an effort to further ostracize President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Shrimp and Broccoli Rabe, Done in a Flash
abstract: What’s for dinner? Spicy shrimp and broccoli rabe, roasted with a quick blast of high heat.
lead_paragraph: In What’s for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diner’s Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Rangers, Free to Spend, Don’t Spend Freely
abstract: As this off-season showed, the Rangers are a big-market club with a smaller-market mind-set, determined to avoid long, backbreaking deals.
lead_paragraph: Surprise, Ariz.

headline: Living in High Bridge, the Bronx
abstract: The neighborhood offers a mix of income-restricted and market rate properties at prices lower than in nearby Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood offers a mix of income-restricted and market rate properties at prices lower than in nearby Manhattan.

headline: Buffett and Goldman Scratch Each Other’s Backs
abstract: By not tying up cash in Goldman Sachs, Warren E. Buffett can keep it in reserve for another Heinz-like elephantine acquisition target.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and Warren E. Buffett have found a way to scratch each other’s backs — again.

headline: Name to Get Its Meaning Back
abstract: A housing-rich neighborhood close to Manhattan is poised to make the interborough connection walkable again.
lead_paragraph: Straddling a high point in the Bronx, High Bridge takes its name from a near-forgotten pedestrian crossing into Manhattan, closed off in the early 1970s. But in recent years, given plans to reopen the restored High Bridge next year, both it and the neighborhood have been rediscovered by growing numbers of would-be buyers and renters.

headline: Photo Replay: March 26
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including World Cup qualifying soccer matches in Sydney, Australia, and Amman, Jordan.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including World Cup qualifying soccer matches in Sydney, Australia, and Amman, Jordan.

headline: States Chipping Away at Roe v. Wade
abstract: A number of states in recent years have passed restrictions on abortion rules that give women the right to an abortion until the fetus is viable outside the womb, usually about 24 weeks into pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: A number of states in recent years have passed restrictions on abortion rules that give women the right to an abortion until the fetus is viable outside the womb, usually about 24 weeks into pregnancy.

headline: Qatar Proposes $1 Billion Jerusalem Heritage Fund
abstract: The emir of Qatar, Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, said he would contribute $250 million toward the fund, aimed at protecting Jerusalem’s Arab and Islamic legacy.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Qatar’s emir proposed on Tuesday that the Arab League create a $1 billion fund to protect the Arabic and Islamic heritage of Jerusalem, the disputed holy city that remains one of the most intractable issues in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: N.F.L. Free Agents Who Are Still Worth Signing
abstract: The players remaining in free agency have their flaws, but there are still a lot of good buys on the market.
lead_paragraph: It has been an unusually soft free-agent market this year. There could be multiple reasons for that: the salary cap’s lack of growth, a deep pool of draft prospects at the same positions that are deep in free agency (defensive end, for example), a subtle leaguewide shift in the way free agents are viewed, perhaps. Whatever the case, it’s left a lot of really good buys on the market. True, every unsigned veteran has a flaw or two. (After all, there’s a reason he’s still unsigned.) But a lot of these players still have valuable attributes that can fill an important niche for a team. These unsigned veterans should not be viewed in terms of what they once were; they should be viewed in terms of what they are now. Here are 10 who are worth signing:

headline: The Dining Room at the Modern
abstract: Inside Danny Meyer’s eight-year-old restaurant in the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Inside Danny Meyer’s eight-year-old restaurant in the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Florida Gulf Coast Point Guard Takes Turn in Spotlight
abstract: Overshadowed in high school by his teammate Austin Rivers, Brett Comer of Florida Gulf Coast has been a standout in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: Florida Gulf Coast point guard Brett Comer has enjoyed tournament success before, but even then he was used to being overshadowed.

headline: Art on the Walls and on the Plates
abstract: At Danny Meyer’s restaurant on the ground floor of the Museum of Modern Art, a view of the sculpture garden and a dining experience that goes from one delight to another.
lead_paragraph: WHEN MY GUEST in the Dining Room at the Modern realized he could order three courses of foie gras, he looked like somebody who had just found a $50 bill on the street. He would have extended his streak to four courses, I think, had the menu offered a foie gras dessert.

headline: Copyright Ruling Rings With Echo of Betamax
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A 1984 Supreme Court decision to permit home videotaping shaped the evolution of digital media. A ruling last week might have a similar effect.
lead_paragraph: Before Napster and LimeWire, before Megauploads and the Pirate Bay, media companies’ epic struggle against copying, piracy and generally losing control over their creations can be traced to a legal fight more than 30 years ago over a device that has long since passed on to the great trash heap in the sky: the Sony Betamax.

headline: Does Victoria’s Secret Care That Parents Hate Pink?
abstract: Victoria’s Secret may have quietly pulled its “Feeling Lucky?” thong, but it’s still on a mission to sell its cheap-lace definition of youth.
lead_paragraph: Victoria’s Secret manufactures, markets and sells clothes and lingerie intended to make women look and feel sexy. That’s its mission (if not its formal mission statement): to sell more stuff to more people.

headline: Orchestra Turns 50, Its Youthful Fire Coming Through
abstract: The New York Youth Symphony, celebrating its 50th anniversary, played a program at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: It can be inspiring to hear standard repertory works played by young musicians discovering them for the first time. Whatever such performances may lack in assurance is usually compensated for by the involvement and freshness that comes through.

headline: In a Chinese Alley, an $8 Tasting Menu
abstract: In the southern Chinese city of Wuhan, creating a cheap tasting menu from an array of street food just takes some creative thinking and a willingness to follow the crowds.
lead_paragraph: Even the strictest of budget should allow for occasional splurges: a modest hotel room after a string of hostel bunks; a just-this-once late-night cab; a beer upgrade from P.B.R. to I.P.A. But some luxuries never enter the frugal equation. Take, for example, the restaurant tasting menu — those drawn-out dinners of 8 or 10 or 25 courses, exquisitely designed (and sometimes served) by the chef. Or so I’ve heard.

headline: In a Faded Wall St. Scandal, Lessons for a Current One
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Extradition', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The backdating scandal pales in comparison to the recklessness of the financial crisis, but it does have implications for criminal cases.
lead_paragraph: Remember Jacob Alexander? Perhaps you should. For as financial crisis prosecutions seem to fizzle out, his tale is a lesson: not only do financial scandals fade quickly from memory, but sometimes corporate executives really do pay for bad choices.

headline: Reader Idea | Discussing Junk Food With English-Language Learners
abstract: A teacher in Prague takes a long-form Times Magazine article and breaks it up via excerpts, discussion questions, a vocabulary activity and an advertising analysis exercise to help his E.L.L. students think about junk food and how it is marketed.
lead_paragraph: This week, in lieu of our own lesson plans, we’ll be publishing new entries in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: An Interview With Ken Mehlman
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Ken Mehlman, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, discusses the arguments before the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Ken Mehlman, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, discusses the arguments before the Supreme Court.

headline: Yahoo’s ‘Acqui-Hiring’ and Its Tax Implications
abstract: Yahoo’s acquisition of Summly could have certain tax benefits for its founder.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Yahoo announced that it was buying the mobile news reader app Summly for about $30 million. Summly has a staff of five and no revenue. It was also reported Monday that Apple was buying the indoor-GPS company WifiSLAM for $20 million. That start-up, only two years old, has a handful of employees.

headline: Olivier Awards Nominations Announced
abstract: Helen Mirren, Rupert Everett and Kristen Scott Thomas were among those nominated for Britain’s top theater honor.
lead_paragraph: The Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys, announced its 2013 nominations on Tuesday, a list brimming with big names: Helen Mirren in “The Audience”; Rupert Everett in “The Judas Kiss”; Kristen Scott Thomas in “Old Times”; and Mark Rylance, a two-time Olivier winner, in an all-male production of “Twelfth Night.”

headline: Tax-Abatement Changes Affect Many Unit Owners
keywords: ['Cooperatives', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Property Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Tax abatements for co-ops and condos will no longer be available to those who own their residences through trusts and LLCs.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of co-op and condominium owners across New York City are facing a tax increase this year after the recent tweak of tax-abatement regulations.

headline: One on One: Nolan Bushnell, Video Game Legend and Steve Jobs’s Boss
abstract: Nolan Bushnell, one of Steve Jobs’s first and only bosses, blended memories of his former employee with advice about hiring and nurturing creative talent in a new book called “Finding the Next Steve Jobs.”
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of highlights to Nolan Bushnell’s career – he was a founder of Atari, the pioneering video game company, as well as of the Chuck E. Cheese’s Pizza Time Theater chain – but one of the more glorious footnotes is that he was one of Steven P. Jobs’s first and only bosses.

headline: The Dell Deal Scorecard
abstract: Need help remembering who’s offering what for Dell? Here’s a guide to the proposed takeovers that Michael S. Dell and Silver Lake, Blackstone and Carl C. Icahn have each outlined for the computer company.
lead_paragraph: With three suitors now in the mix for Dell Inc., it can be a little tough remembering who’s offering what and who’s working with whom. We’re here to help.

headline: FIFA Dismisses Costa Rica Appeal
abstract: FIFA on Tuesday dismissed Costa Rica’s protest of last Friday’s match against the United States, which was played in a snowstorm.
lead_paragraph: Quicker than it takes snow to melt, FIFA on Tuesday dismissed Costa Rica’s protest of last Friday’s match against the United States that was played in a snowstorm in Commerce City, Colo. The U.S. won, 1-0.

headline: First Woman Is Chosen to Lead Secret Service
abstract: Julia Pierson, a longtime agent who joined the service after three years as a police officer, is taking over at a time when the agency is still recovering from a scandal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday appointed Julia A. Pierson, a longtime Secret Service agent, as the first woman to head the agency best known for protecting the president, vice president and their families.

headline: To Join This Club, Be a Star
abstract: For Chefs Club, visiting chefs from around the country and the world will contribute dishes and occasionally cook for diners.
lead_paragraph: Chefs Club, a showcase for culinary stars, is having its initial run in Aspen, Colo. But like many a big production, it’s headed for a New York opening.

headline: Son and Lawyer Lose Appeal in Looting of Astor Estate
abstract: A decision by a midlevel appellate court upheld the top charge in the 2009 convictions of Anthony D. Marshall and a lawyer for Brooke Astor’s estate, making prison time more likely.
lead_paragraph: More than three years after they were convicted of looting the estate of Brooke Astor, her son and a lawyer for the estate lost a significant appeal on Tuesday, moving them much closer to being forced to serve their prison sentences.

headline: Congolese Rebel Commander Tells War Crimes Court He Was Just ‘a Soldier’
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Bosco Ntaganda, the Congolese rebel commander, appeared timid and anxious in his first appearance before the International Criminal Court on war crimes charges.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bosco Ntaganda, the rebel commander in the Democratic Republic of Congo with a reputation for extreme brutality, did not live up to his nickname “The Terminator” on Tuesday when he appeared for the first time at the International Criminal Court on charges of rape, murder, sexual slavery and using children as soldiers.

headline: War on the Heels of a Wedding
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Newspapers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Rebekah Sanderlin, an Army wife, recounts the start of the war in Iraq as a new bride.
lead_paragraph: I remember exactly where I was when American troops invaded Iraq. I was in a newsroom in Fayetteville, N.C., which was closer to war than I ever imagined I would be.

headline: In Cyprus, Big Losses Expected on Deposits
abstract: International lenders have assumed the country’s economy would shrink 3 percent, but with the chaos of recent weeks it may shrink 5 to 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — With time running out until Cyprus’s devastated banks must reopen their doors to the public, Cypriot and European officials are scrambling to put in place a set of measures that would allow jittery depositors access to their savings while preventing many billions of euros from fleeing the country.

headline: Crystal Bowersox to Play Patsy Cline on Broadway
abstract: “Always … Patsy Cline” is scheduled to start previews in July.
lead_paragraph: Crystal Bowersox, the runner-up on the 2010 edition of “American Idol,” will play Patsy Cline on Broadway this summer in a new production of the musical “Always … Patsy Cline,” a tribute show featuring classic songs performed by the country singer like “Crazy,” “Walkin’ After Midnight” and “I Fall to Pieces,” the producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: Wylie Dufresne opens Alder; bistros sprout like daffodils; more steak for Mets fans.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Polls Show Consistent Gains in Support for Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A number of recent polls show a majority of Americans support legalizing marriage between gay and lesbian couples.
lead_paragraph: With the Supreme Court hearing arguments on Tuesday about the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the 2008 California ban on same-sex marriage, a number of recent polls show that a majority of Americans support legalizing it.

headline: Light as a Feather, Hard as a Brick: Harsh Realities at Warp Speed
abstract: The Belgian choreographer Wim Vandekeybus brought back his first work, “What the Body Does Not Remember,” to the Schimmel Center for the Arts.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-six years ago the Belgian choreographer Wim Vandekeybus founded a company called Ultima Vez and staged his first work, “What the Body Does Not Remember.” The piece made a splash, earning acclaim for its aggressive physicality and brutal confrontations. Now it’s on an anniversary tour, and at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts this past weekend, as part of Pace Presents, it still made waves.

headline: Steinway to Sell Its Famed Showroom Building
abstract: The main showroom will stay for up to 18 months, and then be relocated, and the operation for concert pianists will be moved to a site Steinway says will still be near Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Steinway Hall, the 88-year-old building down the block and across the street from Carnegie Hall where generations of famous and not-so-famous pianists have tried out pianos, is being sold, the piano company and the buyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: High-Tech Bike Helmets and Great Swedish Words
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include a 25-year-old University of Texas law student working to build semiautomatic weapons using 3-D printers, ways to opt out of targeted Facebook ads and an innovative bicycle helmet.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Marriages']
abstract: The court considered Hollingsworth v. Perry, a case challenging California’s ban of same-sex marriage, on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The court considered Hollingsworth v. Perry, a case challenging California’s ban of same-sex marriage, on Tuesday.

headline: Key Moments From the Hearing on Proposition 8
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Times reporters offered analysis of the hearing, with audio excerpts, over the constitutionality of California’s law banning same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Times reporters offered analysis of the hearing, with audio excerpts, over the constitutionality of California’s law banning same-sex marriage.

headline: Cyprus, Seriously
abstract: Desperate times call for desperate measures.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent whom I respect has (gently) challenged me to say plainly what I think Cyprus should do — leaving aside all questions about political realism. And he’s right: while I think it’s OK to spend most of my time on this blog working within the limits of the politically possible, and relying on a combination of reason and ridicule to push out those limits over time, once in a while I should just flatly state what I would do if given a chance.

headline: A Poet in Hiking Boots (Not the Happy Wanderer)
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: The English poet Simon Armitage hikes the Pennine Way, giving readings en route, and chronicles his experience in the book “Walking Home.”
lead_paragraph: One of the surprise best sellers of 1998 was “A Walk in the Woods,” Bill Bryson’s account of five months slogging it along the Appalachian Trail. His book made many readers want to hike that route themselves, which bewildered me.

headline: Rabbi Herschel Schacter Is Dead at 95; Cried to the Jews of Buchenwald: ‘You Are Free’
keywords: ['Concentration Camps', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Rabbis', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: As an American Army chaplain, Rabbi Schacter entered the concentration camp an hour after its liberation in 1945 and told frightened inmates, “Peace be upon you, Jews, you are free!”
lead_paragraph: The smoke was still rising as Rabbi Herschel Schacter rode through the gates of Buchenwald.

headline: Pushback on Nike Ad Celebrating Woods
abstract: Nike’s new Tiger Woods ad with the quotation “Winning Takes Care of Everything” sounds too much like hero worship without context.
lead_paragraph: On one hand, Nike’s exuberance over Tiger Woods rising again to No. 1 in the world is understandable. The company stood by Woods through his infidelity-fueled fall from grace — unlike dumping the likes of the cyclist Lance Armstrong and the runner Oscar Pistorius for far more serious offenses — and quietly waited for their superstar to start winning again.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Central African Republic, South Korea and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Central African Republic, South Korea and Afghanistan.

headline: Entrances and Exits, Now Erased
abstract: The Icelandic band Sigur Ros played its first concert in the main space at Madison Square Garden on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: When you say “Band X played at Madison Square Garden,” the second half of the sentence is at least as important as the first. A concert there is a moment for Band X to make a statement that is philosophically incontestable, full of territory marking and implied significance: I am here now.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, a weekend of Asian-themed vendors; bratwurst adopts the word “Brooklyn”; bibimbap bars and more.
lead_paragraph: To Graze: Evenings Meant for Snacking

headline: Plans for Ground Zero Arts Hub Shift Again
abstract: Instead of having one anchor, a performing arts center in Lower Manhattan is to be a multidisciplinary space.
lead_paragraph: And then there were none.

headline: Middle-Aged, Yet a Prince, Slouching but Haunted
abstract: A middle-aged Hamlet, played by Paul Giamatti, takes the stage in the new production at Yale Repertory Theater.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — “To be or not to be,” Shakespeare’s immortal head-scratcher, obviously does not vaporize into irrelevance as you grow older. It may burn with raging persistence when you’re a college student philosophizing with your dorm mates late into the night, but the question settles more deeply in the soul as the years pass and life’s trials pile up. To hear it posed by Paul Giamatti, in the Yale Repertory Theater production of “Hamlet” here, is to be reminded that slings and arrows can find their mark no matter your age, and that pushing through them may only get tougher.

headline: Writer, and Bird Lover, at Center of a Dispute About Cats Is Reinstated
abstract: The National Audubon Society on Tuesday reinstated Ted Williams, a longtime magazine columnist it had put on probation over an online piece in another publication.
lead_paragraph: Nature can be harsh and unforgiving; so, too, can nature writing.

headline: This Week’s Links
abstract: NYT developers pass along their recommendations from around the web.
lead_paragraph: This is a weekly series in which NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Off the Eaten Path
abstract: Pete Wells explores the tastes of Red Hook, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Pete Wells explores the tastes of Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Composers Explain Whys and Wherefores
abstract: American Modern Ensemble presented works by Robert Paterson, Alejandro Rutty, David Ludwig, Sean McClowry and Steven Mackey.
lead_paragraph: What compels a composer to write a piece? Presumably there are as many answers to that question as there are composers to ask. On Monday evening at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music four of the five composers whose works were being played in a concert by the American Modern Ensemble took turns answering during an onstage interview midway through the show.

headline: DLA Piper Calls E-Mails Cited in Lawsuit an ‘Offensive’ Attempt at Humor
abstract: In the wake of a lawsuit of involving the billing practices of DLA Piper, the law firm issued a memo to its lawyers on Tuesday, calling language in e-mails written by its lawyers “unprofessional” and explaining its position in a case.
lead_paragraph: After a lawsuit involving the billing practices of DLA Piper, the law firm on Tuesday issued a memo to its lawyers, calling language in e-mails written by its lawyers “unprofessional.”

headline: Instagram and the New Era of Paparazzi
abstract: A photo of Beyoncé, the popular singer, and her baby daughter that has made its way around the Web was captured by an enthusiastic fan on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, a rare and new photo of the pop star Beyoncé and her daughter, Blue Ivy, quickly spread around the Internet, on various celebrity and gossip sites.

headline: A Sleek Office Building Rises Over Gritty Astor Place
abstract: Edward J. Minskoff Equities in May will open 51 Astor Place, which takes up an entire block between Third and Fourth Avenues in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the jobs associated with Astor Place in the East Village usually involved selling Beat Generation paperbacks on a blanket on a sidewalk or, maybe, inking tattoos.

headline: An Investor Adjusts His Ambitions
abstract: Instead of going after trophy buildings in big cities, Scott Lawlor is buying up garden apartment complexes in much smaller towns, earning steady income.
lead_paragraph: For many observers of the arcane world of commercial real estate investment, Scott Lawlor became a tarnished emblem for the aggressive investors who poured other people’s money into major office buildings at the height of the market, driving values into the stratosphere until the bubble burst.

headline: Smooth Operators Slink Into the Desolate Night
abstract: In “Welcome to the Punch” a group of thieves is joined in the uninhabited night by a cop, who, from the looks it, is angry, determined and terminally alone.
lead_paragraph: Watching “Welcome to the Punch” I kept hoping for clowns, the inflatable kind that you sock in the head and that bounce back again and again — or maybe a couple of pugilists with tragic faces and Michelangelo musculature. While this curiously titled, intently self-serious British cops-and-robbers showdown doesn’t feature any clowns, it does include plenty of mano-a-mano action and a clutch of presumably unintended laughs. This isn’t a warning. It’s a recommendation.

headline: Treasures on Every Block
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Wines', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Sidewalk Cafes', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Food']
abstract: For variety, charm, oddity and rugged urban beauty, there is nothing in New York like eating and drinking your way across Red Hook.
lead_paragraph: RED HOOK IS A STRANGE PLACE to choose for a day trip. The nearest subway stop isn’t near at all, and it’s closed for repairs until next month at least. Driving to Van Brunt Street, the main drag, means a turbulent ride on 19th-century Belgian-block roads that are apt to end with no warning. None of the restaurants are on a fast track to the World’s 50 Best, and none of the food businesses, except perhaps Fairway Market, can be called a destination.

headline: Debate Over Music Piracy Writ Large, on Billboard
abstract: The Brooklyn band Ghost Beach addresses the debate over music piracy in a big way: on an LED billboard above the American Eagle Outfitters store in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of unknown musicians start arguments over online piracy. Few get the chance to do so on a 15,000-square-foot video billboard overlooking Times Square.

headline: NBC Lures Back Viewers With ‘The Voice’ and ‘Revolution’
abstract: “The Voice” returned on Monday and soared back to the top of the ratings with a 4.7 rating among the target audience of viewers between the age of 18 and 49, and 13.4 million viewers. “Revolution” was also a winner at 10 p.m., averaging a 2.7 rating in the 18-49 group with about 7.2 million viewers.
lead_paragraph: NBC had a lot riding on the comeback of its twin hits from the fall — “The Voice” and “Revolution” — with “The Voice,” in particular, taking a big chance by coming back for a second arc in the same season (no singing competition had done that before) and with a new lineup of judges.

headline: Ross Adam Cole
abstract: Mr. Cole is a founder and a principal of BAM Architecture Studio, a New York design firm focusing on the entertainment and health care industries.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cole, 50, is a founder and a principal of BAM Architecture Studio, a design firm based in New York whose focus has been in the entertainment and health care industries. Mr. Cole started the firm in 2000 with his wife, Pamela J. Cole, and Brian Spence.

headline: Yankees Sign Overbay to Minor League Deal
abstract: First baseman Lyle Overbay, released by the Red Sox, has been signed by the Yankees and has only a few days to make an impression.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees’ seemingly unending pursuit of castoffs continued Tuesday when Vernon Wells showed up in camp and just an hour later they signed first baseman Lyle Overbay to a minor league deal.

headline: Pro-Obama Group Details Fund-Raising and Policy Goals
abstract: Organizing for Action, the group that emerged from the president’s campaign, outlined its push for big donations and plans to jump into the climate debate.
lead_paragraph: New details are emerging about the ambitious financial goals of Organizing for Action, the tax-exempt group created by former Obama campaign operatives to advance the president’s agenda.

headline: A Plan of Attack for the Urban Antique Hunter
abstract: Steven Sclaroff, a designer who has decorated Jack Spade stores, on finding treasure among “stuff you can’t believe has a price tag.”
lead_paragraph: Stepping into a Jack Spade store, you might wonder who the fabulous, well-traveled gent was who lived there. The clothing store pulls off a deft, eclectic, lived-in look: classic midcentury armchairs, salvaged-wood tables, a quirky collection of salt figurines amid the clothing.

headline: CBS Acquires 50% Stake in Former TV Guide Network
abstract: The company said Tuesday that it had completed a deal to buy a half interest in TVGN, formerly the TV Guide Network.
lead_paragraph: CBS announced on Tuesday that it had completed a deal to buy a half-interest in TVGN, formerly the TV Guide Network, fulfilling a longstanding goal of adding a general entertainment basic cable network to the company’s media portfolio.

headline: Reproductive Restrictions Accelerated
abstract: Cecile Richards, president of Planned Parenthood, reacts to new laws that nearly eradicate abortion rights in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Cecile Richards, president of Planned Parenthood, reacts to new laws that nearly eradicate abortion rights in North Dakota.

headline: Admiral at Center of Inquiry Is Censured by Navy
keywords: ['Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Discrimination']
