abstract: Rear Adm. Charles M. Gaouette, who had commanded a carrier strike group, was accused of using profanity in public  and making racially insensitive comments.
lead_paragraph: The Navy on Monday officially disciplined the admiral who had commanded a carrier strike group until being abruptly removed from the position last fall while the vessels patrolled the North Arabian Sea.

headline: A Marriage Born Where Tables for 2 Women Were Common
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Restaurants', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Edith S. Windsor, whose challenge to the federal Defense of Marriage Act will be heard by the Supreme Court, met her spouse in 1963 at Portofino, in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Among many Italian restaurants around Greenwich Village in the early 1960s, Portofino was known for celebrity-spotting, a relaxed atmosphere and dinners that were abundant but affordable.

headline: Shopping Shapshots: March 28
abstract: Atlanta de Cadenet Taylor, daughter of the photographer Amanda de Cadenet and John Taylor of Duran Duran, has fashion and music in her DNA; Cargo pants are even more relaxed this time around; and more shopping snapshots.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta de Cadenet Taylor, daughter of the photographer Amanda de Cadenet and John Taylor of Duran Duran, has fashion and music in her DNA; Cargo pants are even more relaxed this time around; and more shopping snapshots.

headline: A Top Agency Expands Its Social Footprint
abstract: A division of McCann Erickson New York that specializes in social media will grow to 30 employees, and will stress interactions with consumers.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the largest agencies on Madison Avenue, McCann Erickson New York, is ramping up its efforts in social media to reflect the rapidly growing interest among marketers in reaching consumers through platforms like Facebook, Pinterest, Tumblr, Twitter and blogs.

headline: A Mortgage Practice Gets a Closer Look by Regulators
abstract: A widespread practice by lenders of buying often-costly insurance for mortgaged property and billing the owner is under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Among the conditions imposed on most people who borrow money to buy a house, maintaining property insurance is one of the most common. If a borrower lets such a policy lapse, the lender will often protect its investment by purchasing a policy and billing the homeowner for it.

headline: McIlroy Has a Change of Scenery and of Mind-Set
abstract: Rory McIlroy, who just lost his No. 1 ranking to Tiger Woods, decided after his abrupt withdrawal from the Honda Classic earlier this month to return to the roots of why he plays.
lead_paragraph: During his week off in Key Biscayne, Fla., Rory McIlroy practiced at a public course. It was not quite like the tennis star Novak Djokovic’s hitting on a neighborhood court surrounded by a chain-link fence, with grass growing out of the cracks in the concrete. Crandon Park Golf Course, where McIlroy made himself at home, has been ranked one of the top public courses by various golf publications.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Founder of Yoga Empire of Misconduct
abstract: The suit, filed in Los Angeles by a former student, accuses Bikram Choudhury of sexual harassment, discrimination and defamation.
lead_paragraph: A former student has sued Bikram Choudhury, the millionaire founder of a wildly popular yoga franchise, accusing him of sexual harassment, discrimination and defamation.

headline: Kerry Hears Afghan Fears From Women in Business
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', "Women's Rights", 'United States International Relations', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: An encounter that was intended to demonstrate progress also highlighted apprehensions about the course Afghanistan will follow after 2014.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After meeting again with the leader who is at the top of the Afghan pyramid, Secretary of State John Kerry paid a visit on Tuesday to a group of women who have managed to make their way in male-dominated Afghan society.

headline: The Fine Print on T-Mobile’s New No-Contract Cellphone Plans
abstract: The new pricing structure that T-Mobile announced on Tuesday has some important asterisks.
lead_paragraph: Now that T-Mobile’s new “Simple Choice” price plan is official (a bit anticlimactic considering it was available on the Web on Monday), there are still a few questions that may nag current T-Mobile customers and potential new customers.

headline: Transactions
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: Recent Sale

headline: Officials to Review Immigrants’ Solitary Confinement
abstract: Janet Napolitano, the homeland security secretary, said she would examine policies on solitary confinement after new data showed that some people were held for lengthy periods.
lead_paragraph: Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said Tuesday that she had asked federal immigration officials to provide her with more information about immigrants being held in solitary confinement at federal facilities.

headline: Europeans Planted Seeds of Crisis in Cyprus
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The path that led to Cyprus’s crisis leads back to a decision in late October 2011 to help rescue Greece at its hour of financial need.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — When European finance chiefs explained their harsh terms for rescuing Cyprus this week, many blamed the tiny Mediterranean nation’s wayward banking practices for bringing ruin on itself.

headline: Monsanto and DuPont Settle Fight Over Patent Licensing
abstract: DuPont will pay Monsanto at least $1.75 billion over 10 years for the rights to technology for herbicide-resistant soybeans.
lead_paragraph: Monsanto and DuPont, which have bitterly battled for dominance in the seed business, have settled their major disputes with a broad patent-licensing deal.

headline: A Rookie Unheralded, Undrafted and Unfazed
abstract: Cory Conacher, listed at 5-foot-8, tried out for three minor league teams before earning a pro contract. Now he leads all N.H.L. rookies in points.
lead_paragraph: Cory Conacher is a 5-foot-8 center in a league that still looks askance at small players. He played four years at Canisius College, which had never sent a player to the N.H.L. Undrafted, he tried out with three minor league teams before signing a pro contract. He has Type 1 diabetes. Yet there he is, racing all over the ice for the Tampa Bay Lightning and becoming the N.H.L.’s top rookie scorer this season.

headline: South Dakota Senator Won’t Run Again
abstract: The decision by Tim Johnson, a Democrat, not to seek re-election opens up a potential new opportunity for Republicans in a state that President Obama lost by a large margin last year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Tim Johnson, the South Dakota Democrat who suffered a major brain hemorrhage a month after his party retook the Senate in 2006 and recovered enough to run again two years later, announced Tuesday that he would not seek re-election in 2014.

headline: Slow Food Quickens the Pace
abstract: A gastronomic movement’s founder reflects and finds reasons for optimism.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — It may be that Slow Food’s original focus on taste and the quality of food — on gastronomy — simply seemed too narrow, and therefore elitist. But at least since its “Puebla Declaration” [1]in 2007, Slow Food has become a force to be reckoned with, probably the only international organization that integrates concerns about the environment, tradition, labor, health, animal welfare … along with real cooking, taste and pleasure.

headline: Quinn Is Said to Be in Talks Over Sick Time
abstract: After three years of resistance, New York City Council speaker Christine C. Quinn is changing course on mandating compensated sick days for many employees.
lead_paragraph: Her stance on the issue has been loudly booed at public forums, picked over in newspaper editorials and derided at weekly news conferences by a leading rival in the race for mayor.

headline: Clothes Make the Coach, Whatever He Says
abstract: The custom suits. The lucky ties. The hair product. For college basketball coaches, it is all about the suits. And the mousse.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For college basketball coaches, N.C.A.A. tournament preparation extends beyond white boards and practices and game strategy. This advance work is less about their preferred style of play and more about their preferred style of dress.

headline: New Mexico Farmers Seek ‘Priority Call’ as Drought Persists
abstract: With the Pecos River desiccated, some in southeastern New Mexico are trying to force the state to distribute water in a way that would allow most farmers to benefit over big industries.
lead_paragraph: CARLSBAD, N.M. — Just after the local water board announced this month that its farmers would get only one-tenth of their normal water allotment this year, Ronnie Walterscheid, 53, stood up and called on his elected representatives to declare a water war on their upstream neighbors.

headline: Group of Emerging Nations Plans to Form Development Bank
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A big goal is set by the so-called BRICS countries — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa — which seem to have little in common.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A group of five emerging world economic powers met in Africa for the first time Tuesday, gathering in South Africa for a summit meeting at which they plan to announce the creation of a new development bank, a direct challenge to the dominance of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Bloomberg Seeks End to Cheap Cigarettes
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s bill establishes a minimum price for cigarettes and cigarillos, or little cigars, of $10.50 a pack, the first time such a strategy has been used to combat smoking.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened a new front in his antismoking campaign last week when he proposed new legislation that would require stores to keep tobacco products out of sight, making New York the first city in the nation to do so.

headline: Parts of Low Country Are Now Quake Country
abstract: In Loppersum, the Netherlands, residents fear an increase in earthquakes from drilling for natural gas.
lead_paragraph: LOPPERSUM, the Netherlands — Jannes Kadyk’s modest brick home suffered more than $5,000 in damage. Bert de Jong’s more stately home will need about $500,000 to get back into shape.

headline: H.G.H. Case Could Affect N.F.L. Talks
abstract: N.F.L. negotiations to establish a human growth hormone testing program may encounter more complications after a ruling that overturned the suspension of a two-time Olympic gold medalist.
lead_paragraph: The Court of Arbitration for Sport on Tuesday questioned the reliability of limits set for positive tests for human growth hormone, which could complicate N.F.L. negotiations to establish an H.G.H. testing program for players.

headline: Italy’s Foreign Minister Resigns Over Marine Case
keywords: ['Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'International Relations']
abstract: Giulio Terzi quit over the government’s decision to return two Italian marines to India to stand trial for killing two local fishermen.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Foreign Minister Giulio Terzi resigned Tuesday over the government’s decision to return two Italian marines to India to stand trial for killing two local fishermen in a case that has soured diplomatic ties between the countries.

headline: Justice Flunks Math
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Forensic Science', 'Mathematics', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Statistics']
abstract: In the Amanda Knox case, ignorance of math may be a detriment in the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England

headline: The Talmud and Other Diet Books
abstract: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s anti-obesity programs fail, look to God and the ancient Greeks.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta

headline: Timberlake’s Album, Aided by Extensive Campaign,  Has Blockbuster Start
abstract: “The 20/20 Experience,” Justin Timberlake’s first new album in almost seven years, sold nearly a million copies in its first week.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate Justin Timberlake.

headline: Firm Is Accused of Sending Spam, and Fight Jams Internet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Spam (Electronic)', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: A squabble between a group battling spam and a Web hosting company said to be sending it has escalated into an attack clogging up infrastructure worldwide.
lead_paragraph: A squabble between a group fighting spam and a Dutch company that hosts Web sites said to be sending spam has escalated into one of the largest computer attacks on the Internet, causing widespread congestion and jamming crucial infrastructure around the world.

headline: Rebel Chief Suspends Constitution for 3 Years
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Looting', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The leader of the rebel group that seized power in the Central African Republic also said Monday that he was dissolving Parliament and initiating a three-year “consensual transition.”
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The leader of the rebel group that seized power in the Central African Republic, Michel Djotodia, announced Monday that he was suspending his country’s Constitution, dissolving its Parliament and initiating a three-year “consensual transition.”

headline: Querrey’s Loss Completes a U.S. Shutout
abstract: Sam Querrey’s loss to Tomas Berdych meant it would be the first time since the Sony Open began in 1985 that no American man would reach the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Sam Querrey helped create a first on Tuesday at the Sony Open, but not the way he would have liked.

headline: Good Friends, Same Party but Legal Opponents
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Two conservative Republican lawyers, Theodore B. Olson and Charles J. Cooper, argued opposite sides of a historic Supreme Court case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the conference room at the Justice Department’s august Office of Legal Counsel, portraits of Theodore B. Olson and Charles J. Cooper hang side by side. Both men headed the office under President Ronald Reagan in the 1980s, with Mr. Cooper succeeding Mr. Olson. Both went on to stellar legal careers on the conservative side of Washington’s divided political universe.

headline: In Japan, a Portrait of Mistrust
abstract: Two years after a tsunami and nuclear meltdown in Fukushima, Japan, the filmmaker Itai Keshet presents a documentary portrait of public fear, mistrust and suspicion about the safety of food.
lead_paragraph: Two years after a tsunami and nuclear meltdown in Fukushima, Japan, the filmmaker Itai Keshet presents a documentary portrait of public fear, mistrust and suspicion about the safety of food.

headline: ‘In Japan, a Portrait of Mistrust’
keywords: ['Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Radiation']
abstract: A documentary explores the public fear and suspicion about the safety of food in Japan.
lead_paragraph: Two years after a huge earthquake, giant tsunami and nuclear meltdown ravaged parts of Japan, life has only seemingly returned to normal. Authorities say that outside the evacuation zone in Fukushima, there is at most a very low amount of radioactive contamination — that everything is safe. But after the tragedy, many citizens ask themselves if they can believe the government.

headline: 3 Officers, Prolific at Stops, Will Get Their Say at Trial
abstract: Pretrial testimony from three Brooklyn officers who recorded among the highest number of stop-question-and-frisk encounters in 2009 sheds light on their decisions.
lead_paragraph: One officer described how car thieves might pretend to be beggars, sifting through curbside trash. “If someone is in the middle of a dark street, staring into the car and then when we drive by, they start ripping up garbage bags,” the police officer, Michael Noboa, said, “that would give me reasonable suspicion to conduct a stop, question” and possibly frisk.

headline: Berezovsky’s Death Is Unlikely to Be Mourned in Russia
abstract: If Boris A. Berezovsky, the exiled oligarch who died in London over the weekend, is remembered at all, it will be for the role he played in the post-Communist 1990s — an era that many Russians would just as soon forget.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At the end of his extravagant, intrigue-filled and ultimately solitary life, Boris A. Berezovsky, the post-Soviet robber baron who was the consummate Kremlin insider before he became a detested outcast, wondered if he would have been better off had he never fled Russia for England, if he had been thrown in jail like his fellow oligarch-turned-inmate, the oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, another antagonist of President Vladimir V. Putin who remains in a northern Russia prison camp.

headline: Jeter Confirms Stint on Disabled List
abstract: Derek Jeter said he was disappointed to open the season on the disabled list but that he intends to start for the bulk of the season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter finally acknowledged the sobering reality Tuesday that he will start the season on the disabled list, forcing him to miss his first opening day game since 2001.

headline: Caution, Curves Ahead
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: There is a strong argument for everyone doing more to end the Syrian civil war, but satisfactory answers are needed first to some crucial questions.
lead_paragraph: There are mounting reports that the U.S. is getting more deeply involved in supporting the Syrian rebels trying to topple President Bashar al-Assad. There is a strong argument for everyone doing more to end the Syrian civil war before the Syrian state totally collapses and before its sectarian venom and refugees further destabilize Lebanon, Iraq and Jordan. But I hope that before President Obama gets more deeply involved in Syria, he gets satisfactory answers to the following questions:

headline: China: Vietnam Alleges Attack
abstract: Tensions between China and Vietnam sharpened Tuesday after Vietnam said that a Chinese vessel fired flares and damaged a Vietnamese fishing vessel last Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Tensions between China and Vietnam sharpened Tuesday after Vietnam said that a Chinese vessel fired flares and damaged a Vietnamese fishing vessel last Wednesday in a disputed area of the South China Sea. Vietnam said it had lodged a formal complaint with China and asked for an investigation and compensation for the damaged vessel, which was fishing in a region claimed by both countries. The episode was the latest in a series of disputes between China and some of its neighbors in the South China Sea. In Beijing on Tuesday, a Chinese government spokesman did not say whether a government ship had fired flares but said that any action taken was “necessary and justified.” China said that the territory near the Paracel Islands is clearly Chinese and that the Vietnamese boat was fishing illegally. China also denied the vessel suffered damage.

headline: Sales Tax Fairness
abstract: Congress may finally pass a bill allowing states to require sales taxes from online retailers. Now is the time to be fair to both Internet and bricks-and-mortar businesses.
lead_paragraph: At long last, Congress may finally be ready to pass a bill allowing states to require online retailers to collect sales taxes. Under federal law, which largely predates the Internet, online retailers are required to collect sales tax only if they have a physical presence in the customer’s state. That lets many online retailers off the hook for sales-tax collection, giving them an unfair advantage over bricks-and-mortar stores and depriving states of an estimated $11 billion in annual sales-tax revenue.

headline: Picking New York’s State Soil? Not So Fast
abstract: A quiet, seemingly straightforward bill to name a state soil hit a snag. New York already has one.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — If ever there was a process that should have been as dull as dirt, it was the naming of New York’s state soil.

headline: Gen. Musharraf Returns
abstract: General Musharraf, who has shown his preference for autocracy over democracy, is not the man to “save” his country.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Pervez Musharraf has returned to Pakistan, proclaiming an intention to “save” his country. If there is anyone capable of saving Pakistan, he is not it.

headline: State Tells Investors That Climate Change May Hurt Its Finances
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: The warning, to appear in New York State’s bond offerings, comes as the governor urges officials to deal with the frequency of extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has started to caution investors that climate change poses a long-term risk to the state’s finances.

headline: Down to the Wire
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Editorials']
abstract: It is past time for the United Nations to approve a tough international treaty intended to keep conventional weapons out of the wrong hands.
lead_paragraph: We are now approaching the 11th hour for an international treaty intended to keep conventional weapons out of the hands of unscrupulous regimes, militants and criminals. Negotiators at the United Nations are supposed to complete the document by Thursday, but they are still battling over what many governments and arms-control activists consider serious flaws.

headline: Justices, Citing Ban on Unreasonable Searches, Limit Use of Drug-Sniffing Dogs
abstract: The Supreme Court case concerned a Labrador retriever that had detected the smell of marijuana outside a Florida house. The police found a marijuana-growing operation inside.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday limited the ability of the police to use drug-sniffing dogs outside homes.

headline: The California Marriage Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Editorials']
abstract: On the merits, the Supreme Court should endorse basic rights for same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: Before the Supreme Court justices turned to the merits of the case on Proposition 8, California’s ban on same-sex marriage, they seemed perplexed by a procedural issue: whether the petitioners had legal standing to appeal a lower-court ruling that struck down the ballot measure. Having taken the appeal, they cannot easily decide to avoid the substantive question of whether same-sex couples have a constitutionally protected right to marry in California and elsewhere in the country.

headline: Knicks Poised to Take Celtics’ Crown
abstract: With one more victory, the Knicks can claim the season series against the Celtics for the first time in nine years, and that chance will come Sunday at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It will be at least another month, perhaps in a first-round playoff series, before declarations can be made, or conclusions drawn, or torches passed — or wrested away. After five years of pre-eminence, the Boston Celtics have at least earned a withholding of judgment until the games really matter.

headline: Massachusetts: Bulger Trial Will Proceed on Schedule
keywords: ['Racketeering and Racketeers', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: The new judge in the trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, the Boston gangster, said that the trial would begin on June 10.
lead_paragraph: The new judge in the trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, the Boston gangster, held her first hearing with lawyers for Mr. Bulger and government prosecutors on Tuesday, and said that the trial would begin on June 10, as scheduled by her predecessor. The new judge, Denise J. Casper of Federal District Court, was assigned the case this month after an appeals court removed Judge Richard G. Stearns because his previous career as a federal prosecutor was found by a federal appeals court to feed the perception of bias in his handling of the case. Mr. Bulger faces a sweeping racketeering indictment that charges him with involvement in 19 murders. Lawyers on both sides of the case said Tuesday that they expect the trial to last through the summer.

headline: Indiana: Voucher Program Ruled Constitutional
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Vouchers', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The state Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that a two-year-old school voucher program allowing low- and middle-income families to use public funds to attend private schools was constitutional.
lead_paragraph: The Indiana Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the state’s two-year-old school voucher program allowing low- and middle-income families to use public funds to attend private schools was constitutional. In a 5-to-0 decision, the court said that the voucher program did not violate the state’s prohibition against using state funds to benefit religious institutions because the primary beneficiaries of the vouchers were the families who used them. Since the state legislature enacted the voucher program, about 9,000 families have taken advantage, and the vast majority are sending their children to parochial schools. Glenda Ritz, Indiana superintendent of public instruction, said she was disappointed in the court’s decision. “I personally believe that public dollars should go to public schools,” she said in a statement.

headline: The Fight for Water in New Mexico
abstract: The drought-fueled anger of southeastern New Mexico’s farmers and ranchers is boiling, and there is nowhere near enough water in the desiccated Pecos River to cool it down.

Coach Doc Rivers drew up his 17th starting lineup Tuesday night — and then watched his injury-ravaged team drop a 100-85 decision to the Knicks, the Celtics’ 11th — and worst — home defeat of the season.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2:15 P.M. (Comedy Central) POOTIE TANG (2001) Lance Crouther is Pootie Tang, a modern-day renaissance man whose talent, we’re told, in the fields of music, film, martial arts and pottery are exceeded only by his skills in crime fighting, in this comedy written and directed by Louis C. K. Pootie Tang uses these powers for good, battling drug dealers and corporations with the support of his friends, J. B. (Chris Rock), Trucky (J B Smoove) and Biggie Shorty (Wanda Sykes). “ ‘Pootie Tang’ may be raw and slovenly — hey, it often is raw and slovenly — but it succeeds as a laugh getter because of the spot on satirical notes,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “You might say that the movie walks it like it talks it; I’m not sure what Pootie would say.” (Above, from left, Mr. Rock, Mr. Smoove, Mr. Crouther and Mario Joyner.)

lead_paragraph: Ahn Sehong had to go to China to recover a vanishing — and painful — part of Korea’s wartime history. Visiting small villages and overcoming barriers of language and distrust, he documented the tales of women — some barely teenagers — who had been forced into sexual slavery during World War II by the Japanese Army.

headline: A Privacy Law Often Misinterpreted

lead_paragraph: Roberta Greene was suffering such severe abdominal pain that she headed for the emergency room at a big Manhattan teaching hospital. Her sister, Carol Levine, joined her there. After a considerable wait — it is surprising how long it sometimes takes to see a physician for a supposed emergency — a nurse appeared and walked Ms. Greene to an examining room.

headline: My Search for a Credit Card Processor, Part 2
abstract: National Processing was willing to go forward with the deal but on one condition — it wanted to establish a reserve account to guarantee that it wouldn’t be left holding the bag in case of an unresolved chargeback. I had never heard of this before, and frankly, I was a little insulted.
lead_paragraph: At the conclusion of Tuesday’s post, I had just applied for cheaper credit card processing from Emerald World, and I had received an unsettling phone call about the status of my application. The events I am about to describe took place in June 2012, at a time when my business was experiencing a sales slump. We were about to come out of it, but I didn’t know that at that time. Cash was tight, and the prospect of saving money on my credit card processing was very attractive.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

headline: Subways Pay
abstract: Even in LA.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an interesting new working paper: Subways, Strikes, and Slowdowns. Unfortunately, there doesn’t seem to be an ungated version. But here’s the summary: the author argues that mass transit has a significant impact in reducing traffic congestion, even when it carries only a small fraction of commuters. Why? Because commuters who take mass transit are, very disproportionately, people who would otherwise be driving on the most congested routes. So even the small number of people taken off the roads has a surprisingly large effect in reducing travel delays.

headline: Myanmar Jarred by Peace Laureate at Military Parade
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel peace laureate whose presence among generals would have been unthinkable years ago, watched Myanmar’s military assert its role in Burmese politics on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s military asserted its role in the country’s politics at a ceremony on Wednesday that featured a prominent guest, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate, whose presence among the generals would have been unthinkable a few years ago.

headline: British Regulator Fines Prudential Over Lack of Deal Disclosure
abstract: As Prudential of Britain was planning a $35.5 billion bid for one of Asia’s biggest life insurers three years ago, the company was worried about details of its deal leaking. That hyper-cautiousness, it seems, cost about $45 million.
lead_paragraph: As Prudential of Britain was planning an ambitious $35.5 billion bid for one of Asia’s biggest life insurers three years ago, the company was worried about details of its deal leaking to the outside world.

headline: A Look at the Issues in the Defense of Marriage Act Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear almost two hours of arguments on Wednesday morning about the constitutionality of a part of the 1996 law.

Here is a look at the background of the case, United States v. Windsor, No. 12-307; the issues it raises; the lawyers who will argue it; and the possible outcomes.

headline: Soaring Like Dragons
abstract: Before the show’s third season, HBO brought “Game of Thrones” stars and producers to Los Angeles, San Francisco and Seattle for a promotional tour.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the time that Peter Dinklage has portrayed the cunning nobleman Tyrion Lannister on the HBO fantasy series “Game of Thrones,” he has calculated his way out of life-or-death situations, led victorious armies on battlefields and won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his work. But he had never been to a gala premiere for “Game of Thrones,” because HBO had never held one.

headline: Kurdish New Year’s Resolutions
abstract: Turkey’s prime minister is making good progress negotiating with Kurdish militants. Now he needs to convince his own constituents that compromising means peace, not defeat.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Last Thursday was the start of the Kurdish New Year and, if all goes according to plan, the advent of a new era in Turkey’s relationship with its own Kurdish population. In Diyarbakir, the largest city in southeastern Turkey, a few hundred thousand people converged to listen to a proclamation, read — first in Turkish, then in Kurdish — on behalf of Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned founder of the Kurdistan Workers Party, also known as P.K.K.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Publishers Tackle Bullies, and Columnist Sparks Cat vs. Bird Dispute
abstract: Book publishers join the antibulling effort in a big way, the National Audubon Society reinstates a writer after a cat-poisoning dispute, and a Supreme Court decision about textbook copyrights may have widespread ramifications.
lead_paragraph: The publishing industry has taken a real shine to bullies of late, Leslie Kaufman writes. According to World Cat, a catalog of library collections worldwide, the number of English-language books tagged with the key word “bullying” in 2012 was 1,891, an increase of 500 in a decade. Several publishing houses, including Random House, Simon & Schuster and Harlequin, have even started antibullying campaigns pegged around the books. The surge reflects the broader cultural recognition of the problem, spurred in part by several high-profile cases of cyberbullying that resulted in suicide.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — Most Americans have never heard of Mary Bonauto. But inside the tightknit world of gay legal advocacy, Ms. Bonauto is a quiet celebrity — a lawyer and mother of twins who some say is almost single-handedly responsible for the same-sex marriage cases now pending before the Supreme Court.

headline: The Destructive Influence of Imaginary Peers
abstract: How conveying that good behavior is the social norm can change how people drink, recycle and even pay their taxes.
lead_paragraph: We humans irrationally think we’re rational. We think that we decide how to behave by weighing the pros and cons. In reality, the strongest influence on our decisions is the example of the people around us — even, oddly enough, when they are imaginary.

headline: Designing Big Data That Works
abstract: Cloud computing and mobility have brought to the fore an unexpected strategic asset from the humanities: design. A start-up called Tidemark, which sells cloud-based business analytics software, has introduced a series of planning features designed to speed forecasting and decision making.
lead_paragraph: Whether the move is from mainframes to minicomputers, or from there to personal computers and servers, and now to mobile devices and cloud computing, we are witnessing one grand process of moving machine intelligence closer to the people on the front lines, even as the computing at the center gets more powerful.

lead_paragraph: The failed elevator pitch. Kevin Schmiegel, a retired Marine Corps lieutenant colonel, had heard dozens of them from young veterans trying to sell themselves to prospective employers. Acronyms. Jargon incomprehensible to civilians. Puzzling explanations of military jobs. An inability, or unwillingness, to take credit for awards, specialized training or even leadership positions.

lead_paragraph: Wanelo, the social shopping site that resembles a well-designed window display, is quickly gaining fans online,  despite being largely under the mainstream radar.

headline: The Gun Report: March 27, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Crowdfunding has become a popular way to raise money for music, art projects, and even small business start-ups. But gun research? Given the lack of federal funds available for such research, why not? (A quick reminder: In 1996, the National Rifle Association lobbied Congress to cut all funding to the Center for Disease Control for gun-related research.) That hasn’t stopped researchers at the University of Alabama at Birmingham, however. Last year, a U.A.B. study found that increased gun background checks correlate with fewer homicides and suicides. The study concluded that more comprehensive background checks at the state level may reduce firearm deaths, but “more research is needed.”

headline: Easter vs. Passover: In Interfaith Marriages, Mom’s Faith Wins Out
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Marriages', 'Parenting', 'Passover', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In interfaith marriages, children are more likely to adopt the religion of their mother.
lead_paragraph: I never thought of myself as part of an interfaith marriage — more of a faith/no-faith marriage. I am a Conservative Jew and my husband is a former Jehovah’s Witness, now an “aspiring atheist.” I told him on our first date that our children would be raised Jewish — indeed that they would go to Jewish day school. A little forward, perhaps, but I had friends who spent years arguing over faith until they finally decided their relationship just wasn’t going anywhere. And I had friends who wanted to expose kids to “a little bit of both” and then let them decide. Bringing up children as Unitarians or Jews for Jesus wasn’t in the cards for me.

headline: On Illegal Betting Slips, a Three-Digit Mystery
abstract: Two people were arrested in East Harlem this month and accused of running numbers. But what exactly do the numbers mean?
lead_paragraph: So what do all those numbers in a so-called numbers-running racket mean, anyway?

headline: Screening Checkpoint Delays
abstract: Charter flight passengers are more likely to slow down airport screening than scheduled passengers, suggests a study.
lead_paragraph: Charter flight passengers are more likely to slow down airport screening than scheduled passengers, suggests a study of a European regional airport by Kirschenbaum Consulting, an Israel-based security firm. Among the findings: a lower percentage of scheduled passengers among those interviewed carried prohibited items compared with charter passengers, and a lower percentage of scheduled passengers than charter passengers needed to be re-examined by security employees.

headline: Impressed in the South
abstract: The Confederacy was designed to maximize white freedom, but by 1863 its impressment policies had grown unbearable for many.
lead_paragraph: In August 1862, the popular journalist, planter and politician J. F.H. Claiborne voiced a concern shared by thousands throughout the Confederacy. “We are now proving our loyalty by starvation,” he wrote to Gov. John Pettus of Mississippi. Claiborne’s plaint exposed the very real fear that spiraling inflation would combine with the military’s growing demands for food and supplies, and the central government’s ill-defined policies of how to satisfy them, in creating drastic food shortages, particularly in the South’s cities.

headline: Mark Leyner on the Art of Being ‘Sufficiently Carnivalesque’

headline: Some Vintages of Soldera Wine Survive a Vandalism
abstract: The former employee who was responsible for the break-in was sentenced last week to four years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Case Basse di Soldera, the great Brunello di Montalcino estate where more than 60,000 liters of wine were destroyed last year by a disgruntled former employee, apparently did not lose all the wine from six vintages from 2007 through 2012. The proprietor, Gianfranco Soldera, announced recently that the estate had been able to salvage small parts of each of those vintages, at least preserving the opportunity to see how those wines will age and evolve.

headline: Cash-Hungry States Eye Sports Betting, to Leagues’ Dismay
abstract: More than $200 million will be wagered in Nevada sports books on the N.C.A.A. men’s college basketball tournament, a sum double that bet on the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — It is a lucrative time of year for Nevada, where more than $200 million will be wagered in sports books on the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, a pot of money that has budget-crunched states across the country pushing for a piece of the action despite strong opposition from the N.C.A.A. and professional sports leagues.

headline: Before Attack, Parents of  Gunman Tried to Address Son’s Strange Behavior
abstract: A release of records shed light on the behavior of Jared L. Loughner, who killed 6 people and wounded 13 in Tucson, including former Representative Gabrielle Giffords.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — The parents of Jared L. Loughner, the man who killed six people and wounded 13 others during a meet-and-greet event hosted by former Representative Gabrielle Giffords in 2011, told the authorities after the mass shooting that they had become so concerned about their son’s strange behavior in the previous months that they had taken away his shotgun, insisted he get psychological counseling and had even begun to disable his car so that he could not go out at night, according to thousands of pages of documents related to the case released Wednesday.

headline: Call to a CNN Host Hints at a Shifting ‘Today’
abstract: An NBC executive is said to have asked Anderson Cooper if he would consider taking Matt Lauer’s job as co-host on the “Today” show, which has slumped in the ratings.
lead_paragraph: Last week, it was Jay Leno who learned what NBC imagined his future to be. This week, it is Matt Lauer’s turn in the spotlight.

headline: Brother (and Rival) of British Party Leader Quits Politics

lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Miliband, the former British foreign secretary who lost a party leadership contest to his younger brother, said Wednesday that he was quitting front-line politics, drawing to an end a fraught sibling rivalry that had divided both a family and a political party.

headline: Obama’s Public Lands Record
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: The president designated five new national monuments, but overall he’s been more than generous to oil interests.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s decision to designate five new national monuments is a warm farewell present to the outgoing Interior secretary, Ken Salazar, who has been trying without great success to get Mr. Obama to protect more public lands from development. It also makes a nice welcoming gift for Sally Jewell, the presumed incoming secretary, whose life will be much happier if the President continues along this path. But environmentalists are not dancing in the streets, at least not yet. Conservation issues still do not loom large in this White House, and the lands Mr. Obama has protected over the course of his administration are small change compared to the efforts of his recent predecessors.

headline: ABC Family Plans Spinoff of ‘Pretty Little Liars’
abstract: The new show, “Ravenswood,” will start in October.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a way to make fans of your television series very happy: Announce another season of the show and a new spinoff series at the same time. That’s what the ABC Family channel did on Tuesday when it renewed “Pretty Little Liars” for a fifth season (before the fourth one even starts), and revealed plans for a spinoff called “Ravenswood.”

lead_paragraph: One of the first things we did when our children were born was contribute to a state-sponsored 529 college savings plan for each of them. Saving for their education is, for us, as much of an emotional investment as a financial one.

lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The Cypriot government on Wednesday announced severe restrictions on access to funds held in the country’s banks, hoping to control a rush to withdraw money when the banks open Thursday for the first time in nearly two weeks.

headline: Montenegro’s Rapid Ascent Stuns England
abstract: Tiny Montenegro, all of 7 years old, has developed its national soccer team quickly. Just ask England, the team it played to a draw in World Cup qualifying on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: In England’s World Cup qualifying match against the tiny nation of Montenegro on Tuesday night in the Montenegrin capital of Podgorica, there were no bullying tactics by the Montenegro team, as the English press claimed there had been when the teams played to a draw on the same pitch two years ago. There weren’t any chairs thrown at the visiting team’s goalkeeper as there had been in Montenegro’s match against Poland last fall.

lead_paragraph: Rachel Rhine’s apartment in Borough Park, Brooklyn, has a strange view: two small trees standing sentinel at the entrance of her building are covered in used pacifiers.

lead_paragraph: Shia LaBeouf, who was fired from the Broadway play “Orphans” last month after clashing with the director, Daniel Sullivan, and his co-star Alec Baldwin, attended the first preview performance of the play on Tuesday night at the Schoenfeld Theater – sitting in the first row on the aisle and leaping to his feet before any other audience member to give a standing ovation at the end.

headline: Flags’ Waving Doesn’t Come Cheap
abstract: If you wonder how the city’s budget tops $66 billion, it’s not just because of the big-ticket items. The parks department spends about $160,000 a year in flagpole maintenance.

headline: Balance Restored, Shard by Shard
abstract: At the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia conservators are piecing together a Greek antiquity that was a centerpiece of one of Albert C. Barnes’s meticulously arranged galleries.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The art collector Albert C. Barnes had no compunction about letting people know precisely how much he wanted things his way. In a 1939 letter to the auto scion Walter P. Chrysler Jr. he gleefully torpedoed a request — as he did frequently, especially from the rich and powerful — to visit his personal foundation near Philadelphia, where he housed his world-class works.

headline: Digging for Feasts Across the Florida Panhandle
abstract: Can you eat well in a region sometimes known as the “Redneck Riviera”? You can, if you know where to look, and you’re willing to drive.
lead_paragraph: I should’ve known this would happen: oyster withdrawal. More than 24 hours had passed since my last dozen. My stomach was making fearsome noises, and my mind was starting to slip. Was that a giant bottle of cocktail sauce in the distance? No, merely a water tower. Perhaps these car seat cushions were edible?

headline: Is Abortion Heading Back to the Supreme Court?
abstract: Arkansas and North Dakota are testing the boundaries of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Forty years after the Roe v. Wade decision made abortion legal and recognized a woman’s right to control her body and her life, the issue may well be headed back to the Supreme Court.

headline: A New Variation of a Costly Tax-Time Offer
abstract: It’s harder to find refund anticipation loans these days, but refund anticipation checks are becoming more widespread.
lead_paragraph: Tax refund anticipation loans, which are short-term advances made at tax time at high interest rates, are far less prevalent now partly because of a federal crackdown on banks that had been making the loans, according to a new report.

headline: Assad Sends Letter to Emerging Powers Seeking Help to End Syrian War
abstract: The country’s embattled president reached out to the BRICS group after the Arab League gave Syria’s membership to the opposition.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria beseeched a five-nation group of emerging powers on Wednesday to help halt the Syrian conflict, one day after the Arab League moved to further isolate Mr. Assad by ceremoniously filling his government’s vacant seat with the opposition coalition that has sworn to topple him.

headline: Stepping Outside Manhattan
abstract: New York City this month introduced a Web guide called Neighborhood x Neighborhood, which highlights areas outside of Manhattan on the city’s tourism site.
lead_paragraph: New York City this month introduced a Web guide called Neighborhood x Neighborhood, which highlights areas outside of Manhattan on the city’s tourism site. The first featured guide was for Brooklyn, focusing on haunts in Bushwick, Fort Greene and Williamsburg (above) that are not on the well-worn tourist path. Fans of Fette Sau, prepare for an even longer wait.

headline: A Start-Up Tries to Give Wine Spritzers a New Image and a Second Wind
abstract: A year from now, Jayla Siciliano hopes Bon Affair’s bottles will be lining the shelves of all the Whole Foods stores in California and offered on Virgin America flights.
lead_paragraph: During the seven years she did product development and design for both Diesel in Santa Barbara, Calif., and Burton Snowboards in Burlington, Vt., Jayla Siciliano attended a lot of work-related parties and dinners and did plenty of social drinking. The problem was that she also had to get up the next morning and work, so during social events she started pouring sparkling water into her wine. “It was perfect,” she said. “I could sip that all night and I would wake up feeling fine.”

headline: It’s Personal
abstract: A personal defense of abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: To the editor: In Mr. Keller’s article [States Gone Wild, Monday, March 25] he repeatedly mentions his strong aversion to restrictive abortion rules…Has Mr. Keller previously shared his rationale for this strong opinion? For example, is it based on his interpretation of the Constitution or perhaps a personal understanding of when life commences. I ask if he might consider replying to this inquiry with a succinct summary of his position. Thank you.

headline: In the Wee Hours in Albany, the Talk Turns to Kumquats
abstract: In one of the stranger rhetorical runs in recent Albany memory, more than a half-dozen senators referred to kumquats in their musings about the state’s spending plan, which they approved at 4:15 a.m. Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The great kumquat debate began around 1 a.m. on Wednesday, when State Senator George S. Latimer, a Westchester County Democrat, likened a voluminous budget bill to a Christmas gift basket that contained some items that were desirable, and others that were not.

headline: (Not a) Model-Morphosis | Caitlin Monahan
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of real women, with professional makeup by Tina Turnbow.
