headline: At Mercedes, B Is for Battery
abstract: The all-electric Mercedes-Benz B-Class hatchback will arrive in the United States early in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27: 2014 Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive compact.

headline: Food Bloggers Unite to Fight Hunger
abstract: Doing good with food blog posts.
lead_paragraph: The Power of the Post

headline: Investors vs. Occupants in the Housing Recovery
abstract: One big question about the sustainability of the housing recovery is whether it’s being driven by owner-occupants — the people who live in the houses they buy — or speculators.
lead_paragraph: One of the big questions about the sustainability of the housing recovery is whether it’s being driven by owner-occupants — the people who live in the houses they buy — or speculators.

headline: A Lighter, Faster Volkswagen GTI for 2015
abstract: VW says the new GTI, which the company says is 220 pounds lighter than the previous model, will get up to 23 percent better fuel economy.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27, 2013: 2015 Volkswagen Golf GTI

headline: Jetsons in Their Comfort Zone
abstract: Owen, in the Meatpacking District, is where silhouettes are more brazen, the fabrics less expected and the sense of experimentation heightened.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES THE BEST SHOPPING is watching — seeing how other people move through a space, whether their fingers lightly flit over fabric or linger on the details, if they stop for the obvious blaring-siren pieces or dig out the ones that hang at a low hum. We all have our rhythms and rituals. I’m often far more comfortable in a crowded store, where my quirks might pass unnoticed, than stalking a store alone, the only thing moving.

headline: Bacteria in the Intestines May Help Tip the Bathroom Scale, Studies Show
abstract: Two studies have found that the bacterial makeup of the intestines may help determine whether people gain or lose weight.
lead_paragraph: The bacterial makeup of the intestines may help determine whether people gain weight or lose it, according to two new studies, one in humans and one in mice.

headline: Few Know How to Enter; Fewer Finish
abstract: Only 12 ultrarunners have completed the 100-mile Barkley Marathons, and those connected to this ultrasecret race hope a coming documentary does not alter its counterculture charm.
lead_paragraph: WARTBURG, Tenn. — On Friday night, in the Cumberland Mountains of eastern Tennessee, 28 men and 7 women will lie in tents half asleep in anticipation of hearing a conch shell being blown at Big Cove Campground in Frozen Head State Park. When they hear the call, which will arrive sometime between 11 p.m. that night and 11 a.m. Saturday, they will know they are 60 minutes from the start of an ordeal once referred to as a “satanic running adventure.”

headline: Hair on the Street
abstract: One of the biggest growth areas on Wall Street? It may just be on the faces of some executives. Carl Icahn has now joined Lloyd Blankfein as one of the bearded elite of finance.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest growth areas on Wall Street? It may just be on the faces of some executives. Carl Icahn has now joined Lloyd Blankfein as one of the bearded elite of finance.

headline: Sit! Staaayyyy. Play Music! Good Dog!
abstract: The TechPet from Bandai cradles your iPhone or iPod Touch and turns it into a playful, interactive puppy.
lead_paragraph: Riding on the popularity of other interactive pets, like Hasbro’s Furby and Mattel’s Figit, comes the TechPet from Bandai.

headline: A Senior Dancer Is Leaving Paul Taylor Company
abstract: Amy Young, who made her debut with the Paul Taylor Dance Company in 2000, will give her final performance in May.
lead_paragraph: Amy Young, the senior female dancer of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, is leaving the troupe. She made her New York farewell at the end of Sunday’s performance, the last in the company’s New York season in March at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

headline: A Potential Potemkin Fight Over Dell
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Blackstone, or even Carl C. Icahn, may succeed with their bids, but it’s just as likely that all the maneuvering won’t bring a better deal for Dell investors, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Even losers could emerge as winners from the Dell takeover battle. Blackstone Group, Silver Lake Partners, the Dell board and founder Michael S. Dell could stand to benefit from the impression of a hard-fought auction. A Potemkin fight, if that’s what it turns out to be, just may not help shareholders quite so much.

headline: A Comeback Story for BMW’s Diesel Sedans
abstract: The BMW 3 Series sedan is powered by a 4-cylinder diesel that emphasizes fuel economy.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27: 2014 BMW 328d

headline: Musical by Gorillaz Duo To Get Substantial Run in Lincoln Center Festival
abstract: “Monkey: Journey to the West” will open the annual summer event, which this year runs July 6 to 28.
lead_paragraph: “Monkey: Journey to the West,” a music and theater mash-up that also includes cartoon segments, martial arts and acrobatics, will open the Lincoln Center Festival this summer and play more performances than any show in the event’s history.

headline: It’s Back. But What Does It Mean?
abstract: Stanley Kubrick’s longtime assistant, Leon Vitali, says various theories about hidden meanings in “The Shining,” proposed in the documentary “Room 237,” are just “balderdash.”
lead_paragraph: Did you watch the classic 1980 horror film “The Shining” and think it was about a man driven to insane and murderous rage by a haunted hotel? If so, you blew it. Or rather, you missed profound messages subtly embedded in the film by its enigmatic director, Stanley Kubrick.

headline: Full Transcript From Hearing on Defense of Marriage Act
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments about whether married gay couples are entitled to federal benefits.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard arguments about whether married gay couples are entitled to federal benefits.

headline: Kenya Opens Hearing on Vote Results
abstract: With lawyers claiming there were several instances of blatant voter fraud, the Supreme Court began hearing evidence on the March 7 election.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — With millions of Kenyans staring raptly at television sets and glued to radios, Kenya’s Supreme Court began hearing evidence on Wednesday to resolve the nation’s disputed presidential election as lawyers claimed there had been instances of blatant voter fraud.

headline: Sweet Suits
abstract: Sustainable doesn’t need to be boring. Popupshop has created swimsuits with tropical themes for children aged 2 to 10.
lead_paragraph: The motivation behind the sustainable clothing line Popupshop is clear: create simple, chic, wearable and environmentally defensible garments for women and children. The usual pieces are mostly neutral and work well as basics for everyday mixing and matching. It may be easy to outfit children aged 2 to 10 in a uniform of mostly beige and navy blue, but Popupshop is changing things this season with little swimsuits covered in colorful, tropical birds, nuzzling zebras and dancing flamingos (in the same organic and sustainably sourced cotton it has used in the past). Cotton tees, leggings, jumpers and rompers are also available in bright animal prints, and range from $38 to $78 at Sweet William LTD, the children’s clothing store in downtown Manhattan and Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Popupshop fits right in with the store’s stock of other ethically responsible, and mostly independent, brands.

headline: Big Changes for ‘Today’ Show?
abstract: The Times’s David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the possibility of CNN’s Anderson Cooper replacing NBC’s Matt Lauer.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the possibility of CNN’s Anderson Cooper replacing NBC’s Matt Lauer.

headline: McCarver to Retire From Broadcasting After Season
abstract: Tim McCarver, 71, Fox’s No. 1 analyst since 1996, said on Wednesday that this baseball season, his 34th, would be his last.
lead_paragraph: Tim McCarver has been as close as it is possible to being a ubiquitous baseball announcer.

headline: Photo Replay: March 27
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including snowboarding in Spain and Manny Ramirez’s baseball debut for the EDA Rhinos in Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including snowboarding in Spain and Manny Ramirez’s baseball debut for the EDA Rhinos in Taiwan.

headline: Shadows and Textures Make a Pie
abstract: When the subject is bland, a photographer relies on light and contrast to make a picture pop.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: Jailed Bahraini Activists on Hunger Strike
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Abdulhadi al-Khawaja and his daughter Zainab started their hunger strike last week after being denied family visitation rights.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 10 a.m. Two jailed Bahraini human rights activists — a father and daughter — have gone on a hunger strike and their medical conditions are worsening, according to a family member and a rights group.

headline: Acura Looks to the Front With the MDX
abstract: The Acura MDX broadens its market with the addition of front-wheel drive.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday March 27, 2013: 2014 Acura MDX

headline: Fetal Heartbeat Laws Gain Momentum
abstract: Kansas state lawmakers debate their own tough measure to curb abortions on the same day a similar bill is signed into law in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: Kansas state lawmakers debate their own tough measure to curb abortions on the same day a similar bill is signed into law in North Dakota.

headline: I.R.S. Videos Come Under Fire
abstract: Videos based on “Gilligan’s Island” and “Star Trek” have emerged on YouTube and have drawn criticism from a senator.
lead_paragraph: An Internal Revenue Service training and leadership video based on “Gilligan’s Island,” the campy 1960s television show, has emerged.

headline: Fleeting Thoughts, Captured by Pixels
abstract: Introducing the note pad Google Keep, a combination Web site and app for Android phones. Wait, that sounds like Evernote.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of personal computers, people talked about how great they’d be for managing recipes. Remember?

headline: Packing the Family for a Solar Eclipse
abstract: Sometimes traveling 37 hours and 12,000 miles to witness an event that lasts mere minutes makes perfect sense.
lead_paragraph: A television commercial break during the Super Bowl. The world record for a woman to run a mile. The time it took to board my flight.

headline: Wal-Mart Introduces Lockers as It Battles Amazon in E-Commerce
abstract: In its competition with Amazon, Walmart is stepping up its offerings in e-commerce and mobile shopping, including the introduction of lockers for picking up items ordered online and a new Web site and mobile app.
lead_paragraph: Following Amazon.com, Walmart will soon allow shoppers to order items online and pick them up from lockers in local stores.

headline: Italy’s Talks on New Government Stumble
abstract: Negotiations between the center-left leader, Pier Luigi Bersani, and the Five Star Movement failed to yield a majority.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s political gridlock deepened on Wednesday as talks to form a government broke down between the center-left leader, Pier Luigi Bersani, and the upstart Five Star Movement, a month after national elections failed to yield a majority.

headline: Before They Were Legendary
abstract: Photos made by Lloyd Ziff in the 1960s of Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe are on view at the Danzinger Gallery in Chelsea; and a book of insiders’ beauty tips by Carole Sabas, a Paris Vogue correspondent.
lead_paragraph: WERE THEY INNOCENT, IRREDEEMABLY wicked or perhaps a little of both? Lloyd Ziff’s haunting portraits of Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe, shot in the late 1960s, captured those alternating currents in his subjects’ personalities, which in those days had yet to take definitive form.

headline: Living the B&B Dream, a Couple Plans to Update an Inn’s Web Site
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Bed-and-Breakfast Lodgings', 'E-Commerce', 'Search Engines', 'Small Business', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Can the Wedgwood Inn attract more visitors to a Web site and, ultimately, to a very remote part of Canada where the nearest traffic light is an hour away?
lead_paragraph: Nancy Galloway and Andre Laporte are living what is, for many, the ultimate retirement dream: owning and operating a bed & breakfast. Their current challenge is figuring out the best ways to attract visitors to their Web site and, ultimately, to a very remote part of Canada where the nearest traffic light is an hour away.

headline: Quinn, on CNN, Denies Being Vindictive
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, said she did not use the power of her office to avenge grievances with other elected officials, but two council members later said that was not so.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, denied on Wednesday that she had used the power of her office to avenge grievances with elected officials who disagreed with her.

headline: $17 Million Gift to Bolster Old Master Collection at Dallas Museum of Art
abstract: Marguerite Steed Hoffman, a former chairwoman of the museum, offered the gift to expand its holdings of European art of the Renaissance and Baroque eras.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell L. Anderson, the suave former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, swung through New York on Wednesday to update folks in the media about goings-on at his latest gig — the Dallas Museum of Art, where he became director 15 months ago.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: New books by Nancy Kricorian, Benjamin Lytal, Ryan McIlvain, Leigh Newman, Kate Southwood and Steven Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: Paris often becomes the main character in novels, but this month Tulsa, Okla.; Anchorage; and the fictional Illinois town of Marah make an appearance as well, likewise serving as far more than backdrop.

headline: Rewriting His Own Meal Ticket
abstract: Ben Pundole, the man behind Ruschmeyer’s and the Surf Lodge, has created his own travel Web site.
lead_paragraph: When Ben Pundole announced last summer that he had left King & Grove, the boutique hotel chain he helped found, a lot of people wondered what the man behind Ruschmeyer’s and the Surf Lodge, two hot spots in Montauk, N.Y., was going to do next.

headline: In the CLA45, Mercedes Unleashes a Beginner’s AMG
abstract: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG sedan is a vehicle with a $17,550 premium over the standard CLA250’s base price, but it is the least expensive AMG version available.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27: 2014 Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG sedan

headline: Banks Seek to Overturn Judge’s Ruling in Critical Mortgage Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The nation’s largest banks, facing a torrent of lawsuits over shoddy mortgage securities, are pushing to overturn a series of tough rulings in a high-stakes case filed by the Federal Housing Finance Agency in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest banks, facing a torrent of lawsuits over shoddy mortgage securities, are pushing to overturn a series of tough rulings in an important case.

headline: Indomitable Yet Prone to Grieving
abstract: Opening a 30th-anniversary program at the Joyce Theater, the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company invoked the deaths of two dancers in a signature watery work.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company began a two-week 30th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater. After the performance the audience members applauded enthusiastically, but Mr. Jones quieted them with the pall of death. He spoke of Mr. Zane, his former partner, who died of AIDS in 1988, and of Demian Acquavella, a company member who died of AIDS in 1990. “There are ghosts in this piece,” he said, twice.

headline: Mr. T Does Hockey
abstract: The Blackhawks invited Mr. T to compete in an intermission contest where he scored on a shot from center ice.
lead_paragraph: In their current era, you can’t fault the Chicago Blackhawks for not making their games entertaining. From the raucous national anthem to the infectious goal song to the fast-paced playing style they employ on the ice, games at United Center are certainly feasts for the eyes.

headline: Connecting With the Classical
abstract: Sugar Vendil, the pianist, brings together designers and pieces usually performed on august stages.
lead_paragraph: The setting was generic Midtown office building, and possibly even less exciting was a yawning space there filled with rows of straight-back chairs. The audience’s long wait for seats was the only glimmer one evening this winter that an experience unrelated to everyday business might occur.

headline: Table Talk | The Clove Club
abstract: The Clove Club, London’s newest restaurant in the Shoreditch neighborhood, is now serving a five-course tasting menu and small plates for sharing.
lead_paragraph: With arguably one of the most anticipated London restaurant openings this year, the Clove Club — on Old Street in the vibrant and edgy neighborhood of Shoreditch — is the creative and culinary collaboration of Daniel Willis, Johnny Smith and the chef Isaac McHale. After receiving much critical acclaim for their first restaurant, Upstairs at the Ten Bells, they felt it was time to make a bigger, bolder move. And to the historic Shoreditch Town Hall they decamped. It’s impossible not to be impressed by the restaurant’s ground-floor space, with its soaring high ceilings; original period features; bare, white walls; and dark, reclaimed wood. In the dinner-only room, McHale serves a constantly rotating five-course tasting menu; in the more casual bar area, an assortment of small, shared plates is available.

headline: Google Street View Captures Ghost Town in Fukushima’s Evacuation Zone
abstract: Google Street view provides a glimpse of the the eerily empty streets of Namie, a town deep in the evacuation zone around the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant.
lead_paragraph: The eerily empty streets of Namie, a town deep in the evacuation zone around the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, are featured in the latest images captured by Google for its Street View mapping project.

headline: Lorne Michaels and ‘Louie’ Are Among Peabody Award Winners
abstract: A range of HBO shows — including “Girls,” “Game Change” and “Real Sports” — were among the 39 recipients of the honors, which the University of Georgia awards for excellence in electronic media.
lead_paragraph: Lorne Michaels, the creator of “Saturday Night Live,” as well as Scotusblog, the widely followed Supreme Court news source, and the FX series “Louie,” created by the comic Louis C.K., were among the recipients of the 2012 George Foster Peabody Awards, announced on Wednesday.

headline: New Director Selected for Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
abstract: The Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco have announced the selection of a new director, Colin B. Bailey, who is now deputy director of the Frick Collection in New York.
lead_paragraph: After 15 months without a director, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco announced Wednesday that the board has chosen Colin B. Bailey, a deputy director at the Frick Collection in New York, as the new chief. Mr. Bailey said in an interview that he is excited about his new position and unfazed about the turmoil among the staff that the museums have been experiencing.

headline: Kia Adds Some Upscale Touches to the Soul
abstract: A new crop of urban utilities, including the Nissan Juke and Mini Countryman, are vying for the Soul’s target audience, but the Soul sharply undercuts most of them on price.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27, 2013: 2014 Kia Soul

headline: Padres Know the Fragility of Pitching
abstract: Andrew Cashner, whose fastball averaged 97.7 miles an hour in 2012, has a chance to emerge as the star of San Diego’s pitching staff, which has been vexed by injuries.
lead_paragraph: Peoria, Ariz.

headline: How 3-D Printers Are Now Making Weapons
abstract: Cody Wilson, a 24-year-old law student at the University of Texas, has successfully printed parts for a 3-D printed gun that he used to shoot off nearly 30 bullets.
lead_paragraph: In October, I wrote a column about 3-D printed guns, and profiled Cody Wilson, a 24-year-old law student at the University of Texas, who was building a completely functional printed weapon.

headline: Stretching From Opera to Saloons
abstract: Listening to Patricia Racette’s renditions of classic torch songs makes it easy to feel the connection between Puccini and the world of Sinatra and Piaf.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Patricia Racette, celebrated for her portrayals of Puccini heroines, is the latest in a lengthening list of classical singers to venture into cabaret, with her show “Diva on Detour” at 54 Below. That is also the title of her new album recorded with Craig Terry, her accompanist at Tuesday evening’s opening-night performance.

headline: Electric Blue Is the Spring Look for Men
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Lately a kind of analog has emerged: shocking blue, a bright electric blue that is a far cry from the navy suits and light-blue business shirts of traditional men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: Lately a kind of analog has emerged: shocking blue, a bright electric blue that is a far cry from the navy suits and light-blue business shirts of traditional men’s wear.

headline: Shock Value
abstract: This shade of blue isn’t a big jolt, but just enough to awaken a spring wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, shocking pink has become so popular that it has lost virtually all of its power to do just that. Once distressingly linked with racy lingerie, Barbie dolls and bad taste, the color has amped, ramped and vamped up those associations and become a tongue-in-cheek beacon of femme feminism.

headline: CBS Renews 18 Prime-Time Shows
abstract: All of the network’s top shows all were renewed, including the dramas, “NCIS,” ‘NCIS LA,” “Elementary,” “Person of Interest,” “Hawaii Five-0” and “Blue Bloods.”
lead_paragraph: Flaunting the stability that has made it the top-rated network, CBS on Wednesday announced the renewal of 18 of its prime-time shows in one swoop, assuring that most of the network’s lineup will return next season.

headline: Jared Loughner Files From Pima County Sheriff
abstract: A selection of crucial documents released from authorities in Tucson about the arrest and investigation of the gunman who killed six people and left Representative Gabrielle Giffords wounded.
lead_paragraph: A selection of crucial documents released from authorities in Tucson about the arrest and investigation of the gunman who killed six people and left Representative Gabrielle Giffords wounded.

headline: Fake Ads in India Showing Bound and Gagged Women Lead to Firings
abstract: The fake celebrity poster ads were created by employees of JWT India, for a real agency client, Ford Motor, without Ford’s approval or authorization. The agency said its disciplinary action included “the exit of employees.”
lead_paragraph: The Indian operation of a worldwide advertising agency has fired employees and apologized after an uproar over fake celebrity poster ads that were created for a real agency client, Ford Motor, without Ford’s approval or authorization.

headline: Key Moments From the Hearing on the Defense of Marriage Act
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments over a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard arguments over a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman.

headline: A Nifty 50th for the Porsche 911
abstract: In conjunction with the New York auto show, Porsche celebrated half a century of its 911 sports car at a beer garden in the meatpacking district of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Not many car companies are associated with a single automobile. Fewer still continue to produce the very car that made the marque. So the 50th birthday of the Porsche 911 is definitely noteworthy.

headline: Clip: 'Evil Dead'
abstract: A scene from "Evil Dead," directed by Fede Alvarez.
lead_paragraph: A scene from "Evil Dead," directed by Fede Alvarez.

headline: On Mundell-Fleming (Very Wonkish)
abstract: Got that covered.
lead_paragraph: Aha. I see that Simon Wren-Lewis is on a campaign against the use of the Mundell-Fleming model, a simple international macroeconomic extension of IS-LM analysis, because of the way it handles the relationship between interest rates and exchange rates. And it’s true that the simplest version of Mundell-Fleming assumes that interest rates are equalized by capital flows, taking no account of expectations of future exchange rate changes.

headline: Court Hears Arguments on Defense of Marriage Act
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Marriages', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: The Supreme Court appeared ready on Wednesday to strike down a central part of a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman. It was the second day of intense arguments over the volatile issue of same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court appeared ready on Wednesday to strike down a central part of a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman. It was the second day of intense arguments over the volatile issue of same-sex marriage.

headline: Faulkner’s Past Isn’t Dead; You Can Buy It at Auction
abstract: A cache of writings by William Faulkner, some previously unknown works, were found last year and will be auctioned in June.
lead_paragraph: William Faulkner typed the story on the back of University of Mississippi letterhead, an early exercise in fiction writing about a fur trapper’s trip to a big city. Its 13 browned pages, stashed in an old, mismarked box in a barn on the Faulkner family farm in Charlottesville, Va., were discovered just last year. Now they, along with a stack of hand-corrected manuscripts, letters, a hand-bound poetry book and Faulkner’s Nobel medal, are headed to Sotheby’s for auction in June.

headline: Pig’s Head Is Just One Plot Point of Many
abstract: “The Burgess Boys,” Elizabeth Strout’s follow-up to her Pulitzer-winning “Olive Kitteridge,” has three siblings, a legal case and many detours along the way.
lead_paragraph: “The Burgess Boys” has the ring of a story about outlaws in the old West. But it’s about lawyers from small-town Maine instead. This new novel by Elizabeth Strout, the 2009 Pulitzer Prize winner for “Olive Kitteridge,” features two Burgess brothers, as well as a Burgess girl. Ms. Strout, whose first books were “Amy and Isabelle” and “Abide With Me,” writes most comfortably about women, but this book is mostly about the midlife crises of men.

headline: For Cyprus, a Sudden Need to Play Nice With Turkey
abstract: The country’s sudden reversal of fortunes implies that self-reliant Cyprus may need to brush up on its own relations with Turkey to make its gas wealth a reality.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With its economy in tatters, Cyprus urgently needs to tap its natural gas deposits. But opening the spigot will force the easternmost member of the European Union to make the tough choices it has long been loath to confront.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: New Directions in Start-Ups, and  iCloud Trouble
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Wednesday, selections include a looming trade-off of speed versus battery life for smartphones, LinkedIn’s and Facebook’s hopes that internal search tools will keep people engaged on their sites, and an expense report company endorsing the virtual currency Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Didn’t Like Our Play? You’re Right. Very Sorry.
abstract: At Playwrights Horizons, a theater dedicated to new work, some audience members have walked out of “The Flick,” by Annie Baker, and the artistic director has sent an explanation by e-mail.
lead_paragraph: Never apologize, never explain: the familiar aphorism is usually invoked after the fact, when the apologizing or explaining has been done, to deleterious effect. It sprang to mind again as I read the letter that Tim Sanford, the artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, sent to some subscribers of that Off Broadway theater, offering a long and eloquent explanation (with a spoonful or two of apology) of the theater’s decision to mount “The Flick,” the new play by Annie Baker.

headline: New Ugliness in a Little Cabin of Horrors
abstract: A reimagining of the 1981 horror classic “The Evil Dead” stirs mixed reactions from the original’s fans.
lead_paragraph: Zack Carlson is a huge fan of the 1981 horror film “The Evil Dead.” That’s why he won’t be seeing the new “Evil Dead” when it opens on Friday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Washington, Syria, Virginia and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Washington, Syria, Spain and the Vatican.

headline: A Garden of Delights, Mapped Out in Your Hand
abstract: A handy arsenal of apps to help any type of gardener, whether a novice or an old hand.
lead_paragraph: The sun and the earth have revolved to the relevant positions in space and spring, ladies and gentlemen, has definitely sprung. While I have the opposite of green thumbs, I now have a handy arsenal of gardening apps to help me in my springtime garden.

headline: Are You a Giver or a Taker?
abstract: The Times’s Susan Dominus talks to the organizational psychologist Adam Grant about givers, takers and succeeding in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Susan Dominus talks to the organizational psychologist Adam Grant about givers, takers and succeeding in the workplace.

headline: Tap’s Present and Future, in a Meeting of Minds, Hearts and Feet
abstract: The American Tap Dance Foundation’s “Rhythm in Motion” explored the many moods of tap at the 14th Street Y.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, near the start of “Rhythm in Motion,” the second of two shows that the American Tap Dance Foundation presented at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, the event’s director, Tony Waag, made an announcement and gave a warning. The announcement: All nine of the works on the program had been created within the last year at his American Tap Dance Center. The warning: The show would be “a bit moody.”

headline: Scene City: Dinner and Dance for Hermès
abstract: Socialites fete a new Hermès watch collection.
lead_paragraph: Socialites fete a new Hermès watch collection.

headline: Hermès Introduces a Watch With a Dance Performance
abstract: Hermès commissions a dance for its new watch, and the choreography gets some folks thinking about heavy issues.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, Hermès hosted a dinner party celebrating its latest watch, the Dressage Chrono. And everything about it was serious. Very serious.

headline: The N.C.A.A.'s Thankless Task
abstract: Sure, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its flaws, but, The Times’s William C. Rhoden says, the organization is a product of its environment.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its flaws, but, The Times’s William C. Rhoden says, the organization is a product of its environment.

headline: Trying to Testify Before the Court
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Celebrities lent their support for #MarriageEquality. But none of the justices, it should be noted, seem to be active on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: For much of Tuesday, the trending topic on Twitter wasn’t Kimye baby names, LiLo’s prehab or Shakira on “The Voice.” Rather, it was the Supreme Court’s hearing of arguments in a same-sex marriage case. Celebrities lent their support for #MarriageEquality. But none of the justices, it should be noted, seem to be active on Twitter.

headline: Jaguar High Performance Comes in Threes
abstract: With only 30 examples headed to the United States market, the XKR-S GT coupe will remain only a dream for many people.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27, 2013: 2014 Range Rover Sport, Jaguar XJR and XKR-S GT

headline: Video: The N.C.A.A.’s Thankless Task
abstract: Sure, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its flaws, but, William C. Rhoden says, the organization is a product of its environment.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its flaws, but, William C. Rhoden says, the organization is a product of its environment.

headline: The Timberlake Brand, Carried Along on a Media Storm
abstract: Justin Timberlake’s new album, “The 20/20 Experience,” posted huge sales after a carefully orchestrated marketing strategy.
lead_paragraph: What does it really mean for an entertainer to be a “brand”?

headline: Controlling the ‘Smart Home’ With Tablets and Smartphones
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Tablet Computers', 'Thermostats', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Newer home automation technologies let mobile devices control functions like heating, lighting and home security.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I bought a $25 wall switch that could automatically turn my porch light on at dusk and off at sunrise, hoping to make my 1920s-era home a bit smarter.

headline: The War in Syria Through a Child’s Eyes
abstract: A devastating video report by the German photojournalist Marcel Mettelsiefen chronicles the impact of the war in Syria on the children of Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: This week, Britain’s Channel 4 News broadcast a devastating video report by the German photojournalist Marcel Mettelsiefen on the impact of the war in Syria on the children of Aleppo, the country’s ruined commercial capital. The film, which contains some disturbing images, focuses on the life of a 12-year-old boy named Mohamed Asaf, who spends long days and nights working in a medical clinic that treats residents and rebel fighters.

headline: He Speaks Country in a Dialect of His Own
abstract: Blake Shelton has developed an ability to appear to be adhering to country’s core values while also subverting them.
lead_paragraph: There is no parental advisory warning label on the new Blake Shelton album, “Based on a True Story,” no special Walmart clean edition.

headline: In New Jersey, a Resignation, Then a Search for Redemption
abstract: “Fall to Grace,” a documentary about the life of James E. McGreevey after he resigned the New Jersey governorship, is a strangely smooth redemption story.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s the shallow, overly friendly filmmaking, or maybe it’s some kind of former politician’s curse, but “Fall to Grace,” a documentary about what James E. McGreevey has been doing since resigning the New Jersey governorship in 2004, never feels as if it got to the core of the man.

headline: New York as a Work in Progress
abstract: James Gulliver Hancock set out to draw every building in New York; a new book chronicles the task so far.
lead_paragraph: James Gulliver Hancock is one of those people who set impossible tasks for themselves that evolve into blogs and then into books. For Mr. Hancock, a 35-year-old Australian artist and illustrator, the task has been to draw every building in New York. He started in April 2010, while living in Brooklyn. Now back home in Sydney with his wife and year-old son, he returns to the scene of his ambition from time to time and otherwise works from photographs and Google Maps. The drawings are posted on his Web site, allthebuildingsinnewyork.com, where they often inspire commissions, leading Mr. Hancock’s pen on an erratic course from Staten Island to the Bronx and from squat warehouses to soaring landmarks. Next week, Universe Publishing will release “All the Buildings in New York: That I’ve Drawn So Far” ($19.95), a sampler of the more than 500 drawings he has executed. Mr. Hancock spoke of his starry-eyed project on the phone from Sydney.

headline: The JCP Monogram
abstract: J. C. Penney is introducing home furnishing boutiques through partnerships with well-known designers.
lead_paragraph: Seeking the cachet of specialty stores, J. C. Penney (recently rebranded as JCP) is installing home-furnishings boutiques in almost half of its 1,100 stores. These shops will offer dedicated collections by well-known designers. “We wanted good partners who could appeal to a wide variety of people,” said Paul Rutenis, general merchandise manager for JCP Home.

headline: Island Fever in Italy
abstract: Werner Aisslinger’s “Bikini” furniture for Moroso disrupts convention.
lead_paragraph: The word “bikini” became popular referring to minimalist beachwear and to the South Pacific atoll where nuclear tests were conducted. It is also the name of two new furniture projects by Werner Aisslinger for the Italian company Moroso. This work, which is to be introduced next month at the Milan Furniture Fair, is neither lethal nor scandalous, but it does disrupt convention.

headline: Within a Sconce, Reflections of Infinity
abstract: The Stella sconce was designed by Rosie Li for Roll & Hill.
lead_paragraph: To look into Stella, a sconce from the Brooklyn lighting company Roll & Hill, is to peer at infinity. The fixture has a prismatic lens formed by three one-way mirrors that reflect and multiply the appearance of LED strips within an ebonized ash wood frame. “The idea was to maximize volume with very minimal space,” said the designer, Rosie Li, a 2011 graduate of the furniture-design program at the Rhode Island School of Design. “I was really interested in playing with perspective.”

headline: A Different Time Stamp
abstract: A D.I.Y. kit for carving your own rubber stamps.
lead_paragraph: You have to root a little for Yellow Owl Workshop, a San Francisco company that makes beautiful paper products in this paperless age. Their newest offering is the Carve-A-Stamp-Kit, a D.I.Y. set for creating ink stamps to adorn thank-you cards or envelopes. The $28 kit includes a rubber stamp block, a carving tool, an ink pad, tracing paper and 25 designs (or create your own).

headline: Traditions Honored, Then Sidestepped, at Salzburg Easter Festival
abstract: At the Salzburg Easter Festival, where success is measured by conformity to tradition, the Dresden Staatskapelle had big, beloved shoes to fill.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — This year’s Salzburg Easter Festival began on Saturday with a production of Wagner’s “Parsifal” that imagined the sorcerer Klingsor’s castle of false pleasures as a museum.

headline: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Sferra and Others
abstract: Discounts on knives, bed linens and tabletop, glassware and accessories.
lead_paragraph: During Broadway Panhandler’s knife sale, through Sunday, knives are up to 80 percent off (a Wusthof Grand Prix II 7-inch hollow-edge Santoku, shown, regularly $125, is about $50; a Global 8-inch cook’s knife, with MinoSharp sharpener, regularly $206, is $118); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: The Art of Unjumbling
abstract: Leave it to a comedian like Ursus Wehrli — no neatnik, he — to find the humor in making things tidy.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — It may come as a bit of a disappointment to certain design blog fans to learn that Ursus Wehrli is not exactly a neatnik, or in any way obsessive or compulsive. While Mr. Wehrli, 44, is famous in his country for being half of the anarchic comic duo Ursus & Nadeschkin (think Groucho and Harpo, but in German and with circus skills), he has lately accrued another sort of fame as an author with a particularly fastidious worldview.

headline: Market Ready
abstract: The wood on my dining table is scratched, and it makes the room look kind of scruffy. Should I have it repaired before trying to sell my home?
lead_paragraph: Q. The wood on my dining table is scratched, and it makes the room look kind of scruffy. Although I plan to take the table with me when I move, should I have it repaired before trying to sell my home?

headline: The Art of Heavy-Metal Blunders
abstract: A look at some of the ineffective album cover art from “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists.”
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the ineffective album cover art from “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists.”

headline: Sleeper Sofas
abstract: Ron Marvin, an expert on small apartments, takes a look at these versatile space savers.
lead_paragraph: Ron Marvin didn’t set out to become an authority on small spaces. But then his handsome 300-square-foot Chelsea apartment was featured in Metropolitan Home and on Apartment Therapy. And before long, Mr. Marvin, a New York interior designer, found he had a string of clients with space-challenged homes, and was making regular appearances as an expert on the HGTV show “Small Space, Big Style.”

headline: Shopping for Sleeper Sofas
abstract: The sleeper-sofa, your extra bedroom for that occasional overnight guest.
lead_paragraph: The sleeper-sofa, your extra bedroom for that occasional overnight guest.

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: Gilt Groupe, the flash-sales site, is opening a weeklong series of virtual sales around various themes.
lead_paragraph: Dress for Less

headline: Cleaning Up
abstract: The comedian Ursus Wehrli has been accruing another sort of fame as a best-selling author of picture books based on a simple but satisfying sight gag. His latest is “The Art of Clean Up: Life Made Neat and Tidy.”
lead_paragraph: The comedian Ursus Wehrli has been accruing another sort of fame as a best-selling author of picture books based on a simple but satisfying sight gag. His latest is “The Art of Clean Up: Life Made Neat and Tidy.”

headline: Design in the Round
abstract: A selection of bowls from “Object Focus: The Bowl” at the Museum of Contemporary Craft in Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: A selection of bowls from “Object Focus: The Bowl” at the Museum of Contemporary Craft in Portland, Ore.

headline: Enter the Lighting Expert
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: How a house near Venice Beach kindled romance.
lead_paragraph: David and Dorothy Measer’s house in Los Angeles is neither a cottage nor a bachelor pad, but when the couple met nine years ago, it was both.

headline: Finally, the Bowl Gets Its Due
abstract: The most commonplace of household objects stars in a new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a media frenzy erupted when a small white ceramic bowl carved with a pattern of lotus blossoms sold for more than $2.2 million at auction in New York. That price, which included the buyer’s premium, was 10 times what the auction house, Sotheby’s, expected the bowl to fetch, and more than 700,000 times what the sellers had paid for it.

headline: A Driving Force Behind Wikipedia Will Step Down
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: Sue Gardner will leave the Wikimedia Foundation to spend more time directly advocating for an open Internet.
lead_paragraph: Sue Gardner, who oversaw a period of rapid growth and evolution of Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia, said she would step down as executive director of the nonprofit foundation that runs it.

headline: Better Than a Bachelor Pad
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Turning a Venice Beach cottage into a house fit for a growing family.
lead_paragraph: Turning a Venice Beach cottage into a house fit for a growing family.

headline: Where in the World Are Windows Phones Outselling iPhones?
abstract: On Wednesday, Microsoft said that Windows Phone was out-shipping Apple’s iPhone in seven countries. Where? Microsoft didn’t say, so Bits asked IDC.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, Frank Shaw, the head of public relations at Microsoft, published a blog post tallying Microsoft’s progress across several different product areas, including Windows Phone, its operating system for smartphones.

headline: Elite in China Face Austerity Under Xi’s Rule
abstract: President Xi Jinping has imposed a form of austerity on China’s free-spending elite officials, warning that graft and gluttony threaten to bring down the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Life for the almighty Chinese government official has come to this: car pools, domestically made wristwatches and self-serve lunch buffets.

headline: A Palm Beach Society Writer’s Own Boldface Name
abstract: Shannon Donnelly, a society editor in Palm Beach, Fla., has become a boldface name herself, and not in a flattering way.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Donnelly, the society editor of the Palm Beach Daily News — the small, must-read chronicle of the outlandishly rich — can’t get to every party during the high season.

headline: Ready to Talk Amps and Ohms?
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Power Outages and Blackouts']
abstract: The best time to think about buying a generator is when there are no storms in sight.
lead_paragraph: When the February blizzard unplugged my Connecticut home from the power grid for the fourth time in recent years, the whining started immediately: here we go again with the spoiled food, the lack of running water, the dormant oil burner.

headline: North American Championships
abstract: On Sunday evening, the last day of the American Contract Bridge League’s North American Championships in St. Louis, three national titles were decided.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — On Sunday evening, the last day of the American Contract Bridge League’s North American Championships here, with some 10 inches of snow falling outside, three national titles were decided.

headline: Tucker Carlson Takes Over ‘Fox & Friends’ Weekend Edition
abstract: Mr. Carlson, a longtime political voice and founder of The Daily Caller, becomes the permanent host and instant competitor to the new weekend host on MSNBC.
lead_paragraph: Tucker Carlson is the new co-host of the weekend editions of “Fox & Friends,” the Fox News Channel’s popular morning talk show.

headline: A New Cherokee for Jeep’s Next Generation
abstract: Built on the same platform as the Alfa Romeo Giulietta and Dodge Dart, the new Cherokee may be more pasta than apple pie.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Wednesday, March 27: 2014 Jeep Cherokee

headline: Ashley Judd Passes on Senate Run in Kentucky
abstract: After a high-profile flirtation with a Senate race, the actress Ashley Judd said she would not seek the 2014 Democratic nomination to run against Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader.
lead_paragraph: After a high-profile flirtation with a Senate race, the actress Ashley Judd announced Wednesday that she would not seek the Democratic nomination in 2014 from Kentucky.

headline: James McGreevey, This Side of Redemption
abstract: After his very public fall from grace, Mr. McGreevey, the former New Jersey governor, does a 180 with his life, career and love.
lead_paragraph: Cloaked in ivy, the Wedgwood-blue Georgian Revival in Plainfield, N.J., has the air of an upper-crust fortress. Surrounded by 1.7 leafy acres landscaped by the firm of Frederick Law Olmsted, the 17-room house offers few clues about its owners. On a recent afternoon, a black Prius is parked in the drive and Easter-bunny cutouts romp across a lawn that slopes down to the quiet street.

headline: The Third Man
abstract: With soft lights and dark shadows, this bar mimics its namesake.
lead_paragraph: ON A BLOCK ALREADY filled with a Bavarian biergarten (Zum Schneider), a Serbian restaurant (Kafana) and an Austrian gastro pub (Edi and the Wolf) comes another Eastern European-inspired import: the Third Man, a Viennese-style bar that channels Marshall Plan scruffiness (the mirrors are distressed, the bricks, exposed) with elegant cocktails and Austrian hors d’oeuvres.

headline: Hedge Fund Titan Buys Hamptons Property for $60 Million
abstract: Steven A. Cohen is known for his rapid-fire trading style, moving in and out of stocks with dizzying speed at his hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors. He seems to be taking a similar approach to his real estate.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen is known for his rapid-fire trading style, moving in and out of stocks with dizzying speed at his hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Obama to Visit Mexico and Costa Rica in May
abstract: President Obama will meet with the leaders of Mexico, Costa Rica and other Central American countries with the aim of increasing cooperation within the Americas.
lead_paragraph: In a trip aimed at reinforcing cultural, familial and economic ties with Mexico and Central America, President Obama will visit Mexico and Costa Rica in May, the White House announced Wednesday.

headline: Favorite Brands at Whole Body
keywords: ['Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Health Foods', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries']
abstract: Creams from a self-proclaimed pharaoh; for Canadian soap, look for the goats; hair colors named after spices.
lead_paragraph: Whole Body, the beauty department of Whole Foods Market, has provided several niche brands with a national stage. Below, four favorites.

headline: Beauty Products in a Health-Food Store
abstract: Whole Body has been a department in Whole Foods stores since the company started in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Whole Body has been a department in Whole Foods stores since the company started in 1980.

headline: Hughes Is Set for D.L.
abstract: Yankees pitcher Phil Hughes will begin the season on the 15-day disabled list, Manager Joe Girardi said, and may not start until April 11, or even later.
lead_paragraph: Yankees pitcher Phil Hughes will begin the season on the 15-day disabled list, Manager Joe Girardi said, and may not start until April 11, or even later. Hughes pitched in a minor league game Wednesday and threw 81 pitches, but it was only his second spring game. He had to take two weeks off earlier in spring training because of a back problem that slowed his progress and arm conditioning. Until Hughes comes back, the Yankee rotation will consist of C. C. Sabathia, Andy Pettitte, Hiroki Kuroda, Ivan Nova and David Phelps.

headline: For a Holistic Lifestyle, Go to Aisle 2
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Beauty', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Just as the Whole Foods Markets have helped make over Americans’ diets, the chain’s Whole Body shops are laying claim to their complexions.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after New York Fashion Week, I stood with my umbrella dripping on the concrete floor of Whole Body, the health and beauty department of the Whole Foods Market in Chelsea. After days of Champagne and late nights, the thought of rejuvenating with natural beauty products had conjured visions of “Sound of Music” bliss, but the aisles were jammed with more labels and products than I could easily navigate.

headline: Chief Who Led Expansion at Hearst Will Step Down
abstract: Frank A. Bennack Jr., Hearst’s chief executive, plans to retire. He will be succeeded by Steven R. Swartz, the company’s chief operating officer.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 30 years of running the Hearst Corporation, the privately held media company, Frank A. Bennack Jr. has announced that he is stepping down.

headline: With Trial Suddenly Looming, Russian Activist Expects the Worst
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny said he expected to be convicted in an embezzlement case that was dismissed last spring but then revived after he led streets protests in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Since his earliest days as an opposition blogger, Aleksei A. Navalny has known that a prison sentence loomed as a possibility.

headline: Job Prospects Are Dimming for Radiology Trainees
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Doctors', 'Medical Schools', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Recent radiology graduates with huge medical school debts are having trouble finding work, let alone the $400,000 jobs that beckoned as they signed on for years of low-paid labor as trainees.
lead_paragraph: For years, medical students who chose a residency in radiology were said to be on the ROAD to happiness. The acronym highlighted the specialties — radiology, ophthalmology, anesthesiology and dermatology — said to promise the best lifestyle for doctors, including the most money for the least grueling work.

headline: Hjalmar Andersen, Norwegian Speedskater, Dies at 90
abstract: Hjalmar Andersen broke world records in the early 1950s and won three gold medals at the 1952 Winter Olympics in Oslo.
lead_paragraph: Hjalmar Andersen, a Norwegian speedskater who broke world records in the early 1950s and won three gold medals at the 1952 Winter Olympics in Oslo, died on Wednesday in Oslo. He was 90.

headline: U.S. Road Opens on Way to Brazil
abstract: With the surprising pair of Matt Besler and Omar Gonzalez in central defense Tuesday night against Mexico, the United States men’s team enhanced its chances of qualifying for the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY

headline: After Plan for Speed Cameras Fails in Albany, a Tirade From Bloomberg
keywords: ['Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Cameras', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The next time a child is killed by a speeding car, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, “call your state senator and ask why they allowed that child to be killed.”
lead_paragraph: As it became clear that a proposal to place speed-tracking cameras on New York City’s streets would fail in Albany, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg let fly a charged and unusually personal attack against state lawmakers on Wednesday, blaming state senators, by name, for the future deaths of children killed by speeding cars.

headline: Plaintiff, 83, Is Calm Center in a Legal and Political Storm
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: Edith Windsor, the central figure in the case challenging the Defense of Marriage Act, finds herself an unlikely standard-bearer in the quest for marriage equality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Edith Windsor and her girlfriend got engaged in 1967, she was too nervous about how to answer the inevitable “Who is he?” queries to wear an engagement ring. So they compromised on a ring-shaped diamond brooch instead.

headline: Riddle Posed by Orange Doesn’t Change, or Get Easier
abstract: Every season, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim unveils another iteration of his 2-3 zone defense and dares opponents to concoct solutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is one of college basketball’s great riddles. Every season, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim unveils another iteration of his 2-3 zone defense and dares opponents to concoct solutions.

headline: Dolan Goes Behind Bars to Commune With Inmates
abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan joked to the inmates at Shawangunk Correctional Facility that he had been locked in recently — of course, it was in the Sistine Chapel.
lead_paragraph: WALLKILL, N.Y. — Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan gazed at a group of well-behaved and truly captivated worshipers, flashed a big smile, and launched into a story about his recent participation in the papal conclave in Rome, where he helped elect Pope Francis.

headline: Ex-Prisoners Bring Taste of West Bank to Gaza
abstract: Nader Abu Turki and another former prisoner found a market for their dessert in the scores of Palestinians who longed for a treat they used to eat at home.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Nader Abu Turki first gained a reputation as a confectioner while serving time as a prisoner in Israel.

headline: 3rd Oral Drug to Treat MS Is Approved by the F.D.A.
abstract: Wall Street analysts, doctors and patients expect Tecfidera to become a blockbuster because of its efficacy, relative safety and convenience.
lead_paragraph: A chemical once used to treat sofas — until it was found to cause rashes and blisters in people who sat on them — is now poised to become a major therapy for multiple sclerosis.

headline: Officer Tied to Tapes’ Destruction Moves Up C.I.A. Ladder
abstract: The officer, who in 2005 advocated destroying tapes depicting the interrogation of two detainees belonging to Al Qaeda, was promoted to the top position in the C.I.A.’s clandestine service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A C.I.A. officer directly involved in the 2005 decision to destroy interrogation videotapes and who once ran one of the agency’s secret prisons has ascended to the top position within the C.I.A.’s clandestine service, according to current and former intelligence officials.

headline: Attacks Used the Internet Against Itself to Clog Traffic
abstract: A huge denial-of-service attack that eventually slowed traffic across much of the Internet relied on vulnerabilities in the network’s own hardware to amplify its effects.
lead_paragraph: An escalating cyberattack involving an antispam group and a shadowy group of attackers has now affected millions of people across the Internet, raising the question: How can such attacks be stopped?

headline: Dairy Finds a Way to Let Cows Power Trucks
keywords: ['Cattle', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Methane', 'Natural Gas', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Biofuels']
abstract: An Indiana farm is turning the manure from its cows into fuel  for its fleet of 42 delivery trucks, an endeavor that is being called a pacesetter for the dairy industry.
lead_paragraph: FAIR OAKS, Ind. — Here at one of the largest dairy farms in the country, electricity generated using an endless supply of manure runs the equipment to milk around 30,000 cows three times a day.

headline: Dribbling Prodigy Now a Coach
abstract: Long before Sean Miller guided Arizona to the Round of 16, he was shown dribbling three balls at once in the film “The Fish That Saved Pittsburgh.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It seemed inevitable that Sean Miller would end up here, with a permanent home underneath Hollywood’s bright lights, where his prodigious childhood talent for dribbling and handling a basketball drew the attention of film and movie types.

headline: Getting to Know Wichita State’s Mascot WuShock
abstract: For the uninitiated, a Wichita State primer from a reader who shared his thoughts on the team’s nickname and mascot.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Wichita State will play an N.C.A.A. tournament game here Thursday. For the uninitiated, the team’s nickname is the Shockers, shortened from Wheat Shockers.

headline: Court Rejects Antitrust Suit in Victory for Comcast
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The Supreme Court majority said that the group that brought the lawsuit was not cohesive enough to have suffered measurable, common damages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday threw out a proposed class-action antitrust lawsuit against Comcast, the nation’s largest cable television company, in which a group of more than two million current and former Comcast subscribers sought to prove that the company had unfairly eliminated competition and overcharged customers.

headline: U.N. Close to Curbing Arms Trade With Treaty
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The treaty would set international standards for conventional weapons sales, tying them to respect for human rights, the prevention of war crimes and the protection of civilians.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The effort over many years to forge an international treaty regulating the booming $70 billion annual trade in conventional weapons headed toward fruition on Wednesday with a final draft sent to the governments of all United Nations member states for approval.

headline: New Problem for Boeing 787 Battery Maker
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Lithium (Metal)', 'Batteries', 'Defective Products', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Automobiles']
abstract: GS Yuasa, the maker of the battery for the Boeing 787 that overheated and led to the grounding of the fleet, has discovered overheating in its lithium-ion battery for cars.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Two lithium-ion car batteries produced by GS Yuasa, the same Japanese company that supplies batteries for the grounded Boeing 787 jetliner fleet, have overheated in recent days.

headline: James M. Nabrit, a Fighter for Civil Rights, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Nabrit was a longtime lawyer for the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund who argued for school integration at the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: James M. Nabrit III, a civil rights lawyer who fought school segregation before the Supreme Court and helped ensure that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s 1965 march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., was allowed to go forward, died on Friday in Bethesda, Md. He was 80.

headline: Beleaguered? Not Teachers, a Poll on ‘Well-Being’ Finds
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Gallup Poll', 'Careers and Professions', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Contrary to public perceptions that teachers are unhappy and demoralized, a Gallup survey measuring job satisfaction found that the instructors ranked second only to physicians.
lead_paragraph: Recent battles over school funding, performance evaluations and tenure have given rise to public perceptions of a beleaguered teaching corps across the United States.

headline: N.F.L. Doctor Says Disease Is Overstated
abstract: A doctor asked that a mention of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., be removed from an advisory for players because it’s “not fully understood” and lacks “epidemiological validity.”
lead_paragraph: When a government agency prepared a workplace safety fact sheet based on a study of degenerative brain disease in retired N.F.L. players, the organization invited several people to comment on a draft.

headline: On the Brink of Justice in Guatemala
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Mayans', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A decade and a half after peace accords ended 36 years of civil war, Guatemala is being given a chance to show the world how much progress it has made in building democracy.
lead_paragraph: Haverford, Pa.

headline: Twitter Posts Lead Weight Watchers Online to a New Spokeswoman
abstract: After Weight Watchers’ social media team discovered the comedian Ana Gasteyer’s Twitter messages about the program, the company asked her to appear in a campaign.
lead_paragraph: WEIGHT WATCHERS is closely associated with celebrity endorsers like Jennifer Hudson, Jessica Simpson and Charles Barkley, but some celebrities end up joining the program on their own.

headline: A Republican Left Turn?
abstract: Grover Norquist doesn’t think so, but other party strategists want to try it — no matter how it makes evangelicals feel.
lead_paragraph: If the Republican Party concedes defeat in the culture war, as a number of commentators on the right and the left argue it should, what what will happen to the conservative coalition? Can hard-line stands on social issues be set aside?

headline: Antibiotics and the Meat We Eat
abstract: While the F.D.A. can see what kinds of antibiotic-resistant bacteria are coming out of livestock facilities, the agency knows little about the antibiotics that are being fed to the animals.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco

headline: A No-Fly Zone for Knives
abstract: The men and women who work in airports and aircraft every day oppose the T.S.A.’s decision to let small blades back on planes.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: Immigration in Spotlight as Senators Tour Arizona
abstract: John McCain and Charles E. Schumer were among four senators who went to a city on the border with Mexico looking for ways to improve security and control migration.
lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — Four United States senators came to this bustling city on the Mexican border on Wednesday searching for answers to the question that has ensnarled the debate over immigration reform: How secure is that border?

headline: Cypriots’ Criticism of Bailout Rattles Nerves and Raises Ire in Germany
abstract: Intense negative reactions to the bailout program for Cyprus appear to be jangling nerves in Berlin, where Germans are bridling at comparisons with the country’s dark past.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is bothered by images of her wearing a mustache like Hitler’s, which are being waved in streets from Cyprus to Spain, she has yet to show it, choosing instead to stress the importance of the protesters’ freedom of expression.

headline: A Vote on Scottish Independence
abstract: After more than three centuries, breaking up with the United Kingdom will be complicated.
lead_paragraph: Scottish voters will decide on Sept. 18, 2014, whether Scotland should remain part of the United Kingdom or become an independent nation. After more than three centuries of political union, breaking up would be complicated.

headline: Monitoring New York City’s Police
abstract: New York City should create the position of inspector general to strengthen supervision and accountability of its police department.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York and Commissioner Raymond Kelly are apoplectic about a bill pending in the City Council that would create the position of inspector general, an official with broad powers to review the policies of the nation’s largest police department. Given the department’s long history of episodic misconduct, the idea is one whose time has clearly come. The City Council should press ahead with the bill and be prepared to override a veto by the mayor.

headline: Down Syndrome and a Death
abstract: Why did an encounter between a man with Down syndrome and three off-duty county sheriff’s deputies at a movie theater have to turn deadly?
lead_paragraph: A grand jury in Frederick County, Md., decided last week not to bring criminal charges in the death of Robert Ethan Saylor, a 26-year-old man with Down syndrome who was killed in a struggle with three off-duty county sheriff’s deputies at a movie theater in January. Advocates for people with intellectual disabilities are bewildered and furious, and it is easy to see why.

headline: The Indefensible Marriage Act
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A majority of justices seem doubtful that this antigay law has any legitimate purpose.
lead_paragraph: The discrimination embedded in the Defense of Marriage Act is precise yet sweeping. The 1996 statute defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman, and applies that definition to about 1,100 federal laws and programs. One of its many discriminatory results is that same-sex couples are prohibited from collecting many federal benefits available to other couples.

headline: Defense in Colorado Killings Seeks Plea Deal
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: Lawyers for James E. Holmes, charged in the Aurora theater massacre, signaled in court filings Wednesday they would let their client plead guilty if he was spared the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Defense lawyers for James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people and wounding dozens more at an Aurora, Colo., movie theater last summer, signaled in court filings on Wednesday that they were willing to have Mr. Holmes plead guilty if he was spared the death penalty.

lead_paragraph: Is spring actually here? We are definitely getting tired of snow stories. It’s time for some sun. And then the drought stories!

headline: Miami Coach Left a Mark With a Run in 2006
abstract: Jim Larranaga and Miami will face Marquette at Verizon Center, the same arena where his George Mason team upset Connecticut seven years ago and gained unexpected national exposure.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va. — The basketball commemorating George Mason’s run to the Final Four in 2006 is perched inside a modest trophy case near an obscure back entrance of the university’s basketball arena. Embossed with the score of the East Region final — George Mason 86, Connecticut 84 — the basketball is not all that easy to find in this sprawling suburban campus 20 miles from Washington, and hundreds of students pass it without notice each day.

headline: Hague: 2 Serb Police Chiefs Convicted
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The Yugoslav war crimes tribunal convicted two Bosnian Serb police chiefs, Mico Stanisic and Stojan Zuplanin, for participating in a violent ethnic cleansing campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Yugoslav war crimes tribunal on Wednesday convicted two Bosnian Serb police chiefs for participating in a violent ethnic cleansing campaign that aimed to drive non-Serbs from their homes in 20 municipalities of Bosnia during the war of early 1990s. The two, Mico Stanisic and Stojan Zuplanin, were each handed a 22-year prison sentence. The verdicts underscored the crucial roles played by the police and armed militia in the notorious persecution of Croats and Muslims, many of whom were beaten, tortured, raped or otherwise abused in as many as 50 wartime detention centers run by Bosnian Serbs. The judges said that many civilians were killed or died from hunger, illness and mistreatment during the campaign to create zones for Serbs only in Bosnia.

headline: With Vouchers, States Shift Aid for Schools to Families
abstract: Critics say funneling money to families to choose their preferred schools could further weaken public education.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A growing number of lawmakers across the country are taking steps to redefine public education, shifting the debate from the classroom to the pocketbook. Instead of simply financing a traditional system of neighborhood schools, legislators and some governors are headed toward funneling public money directly to families, who would be free to choose the kind of schooling they believe is best for their children, be it public, charter, private, religious, online or at home.

headline: Close Wins Set Penguins Apart
abstract: The Pittsburgh Penguins go into Thursday’s game against the Winnipeg Jets with 13 straight victories, tied for the fifth-longest winning streak in N.H.L. history.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Penguins go into Thursday’s game against the Winnipeg Jets with 13 straight victories, tied for the fifth-longest winning streak in N.H.L. history. The Penguins, who lead the Eastern Conference with 52 points, have not lost in March, their last defeat coming Feb. 28 at Carolina. Pittsburgh has outscored opponents by 47-26 during the streak, but nine of the victories have been by a single goal, including two wins in overtime and one in a shootout. Below, a look at the longest N.H.L. winning streaks, including one-goal games. (The N.H.L. introduced an overtime period for regular-season games in the 1983-84 season and started the shootout in the 2005-6 season.)

headline: Study Shows Bacteria Moves From Animals to Humans
abstract: A new study established that a strain of antibiotic-resistant bacteria has been transmitted from farm animals to people, a connection that the food industry had long disputed.
lead_paragraph: A new study used genetic sequencing to establish that a strain of antibiotic-resistant bacteria has been transmitted from farm animals to people, a connection that the food industry has long disputed. Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, said the study by researchers in Britain and Denmark, which drew on data from two small farms in Denmark, “ends any debate” about whether giving antibiotics to livestock is a risk to humans. Scientists had shown a connection between animals and people before, but never in as much detail, said Keeve Nachman, a scientist at the Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future.

headline: Link Is Found Between Stressful Events and Stillbirths
abstract: Pregnant women who have stressful experiences in the year before giving birth are more likely to deliver stillborn babies, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who have stressful experiences in the year before giving birth are more likely to deliver stillborn babies, a new study reports. The study, by the National Institutes of Health, asked 2,000 women in five states about specific events, like losing a job, moving or losing a close friend or relative. Stillbirth risk increased with each event. Non-Hispanic black women were most affected. Experiences most correlated with stillbirth included being in a fight, going to jail and hearing a partner express opposition to the pregnancy.

headline: Miami Absorbs Hard Hits and, for Once, a Loss
abstract: Luol Deng led the Bulls with 28 points and Carlos Boozer added 21 as Chicago fended off a furious rally by the Heat to hand them their first loss in 53 days.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Before Wednesday’s tip-off at United Center, LeBron James lay on a towel in the Miami locker room as a team assistant helped him stretch. James rapped along to a song on his iPod as his thighs were kneaded and his long limbs were pushed and pulled. Nearly 20 reporters and cameramen watched his every movement.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: MIDNIGHT (BBC America) GATTACA (1997) In the not-too-distant future, when people’s social standing is determined by the strands of their DNA, Vincent Freeman (Ethan Hawke, above) tries to become an astronaut by assuming the identity of Eugene (Jude Law). “Imagine an Orwellian story presented with a cool, eerie precision like Peter Greenaway’s and you have some sense of ‘Gattaca,’ a handsome and fully imagined work of cautionary futuristic fiction,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this film written and directed by Andrew Niccol. She also appreciated the decision to set a space agency’s headquarters in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Marin County Civic Center in San Rafael, Calif. “The building becomes a perfect reflection of the film’s spare, controlled state of mind,” she said.

headline: Evans Guides Nets to Another Road Victory
abstract: Reggie Evans grabbed a career-high 26 rebounds and scored 22 points as the Nets beat the Trail Blazers for their 20th road win of the season, matching a franchise best.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Nursing an eye problem, Reggie Evans looked ahead, large black-and-gold-rimmed designer sunglasses blocking out the light of the Rose Garden’s visitors locker room. Evans had tied his career high with 22 points and snared a career-high 26 rebounds, and the Nets had pushed their circus road trip record to 4-1 with a blowout victory over the Trail Blazers on Thursday night.

headline: BRIC, BRICS or BRICSI? The Growing Challenge
abstract: Does BRICS increasingly challenge the world financial order as it forges more definite goals and measures, and is it a place to be for a strong Asian economy like Indonesia?
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — First it was called BRIC, a group of emerging economies thought up in 2001 by a Goldman Sachs economist, Jim O’Neill, made up of Brazil, Russia, India and China. Then it acquired an “s” for South Africa and become BRICS. Now there’s talk of Indonesia, which has a strongly growing economy, maybe wanting in: BRICSI, anyone?

headline: The Debate on Bank Size Is Over
abstract: Mounting evidence shows that the battle to control the biggest banks is being won, although tactics remain to be worked out, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Photo That Was Hard to Get Published, but Even Harder to Get
abstract: An iconic World War II image nearly went unseen because the Pentagon wouldn’t allow photos to be published of American war dead. The image also was nearly never taken, because of the danger the photographer put himself in.
lead_paragraph: One of the most significant war photographs in American history is routinely taken for granted.

headline: U.S. Runs Practice Sortie in South Korea
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The rare announcement that the United States military ran a practice bombing sortie over South Korea underscores Washington’s commitment to defend its ally amid rising tensions with North Korea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American military on Thursday carried out a rare long-range mission over the Korean Peninsula, sending two nuclear-capable B-2 stealth bombers on a practice sortie over South Korea, underscoring Washington’s commitment to defend its ally amid rising tensions with North Korea.

headline: Edgy Calm as Banks in Cyprus Reopen
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Relief that bank doors were open again mixed with anxiety over new rules that allow customers to make deposits but tightly ration out the money already in accounts.
lead_paragraph: AKAKI, Cyprus — As Cyprus cautiously cracked open the doors of its crisis-ridden banks on Thursday, Stelios Sofroniou, a pig farmer, fumed at being able to withdraw only 300 euros, about $385. That would buy one ton of feed, not the 30 he needed for his 15,000 increasingly hungry pigs.

headline: What’s in Your Envelope?
abstract: The colleges and universities of the Ivy League and other selective institutions will announce their highly anticipated admission decisions at 5 p.m. Eastern time on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: If you are a college applicant, you may have imagined that this week will be an Oscar-like experience, in which worthy candidates clutch the arms of their chairs, hoping and praying that the envelope bears good news.

headline: Orlando Wants to Add M.L.S. to Attractions
abstract: The partnership of a Brazilian businessman and an English soccer executive is behind efforts to land an M.L.S. team for Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Although Orlando is a healthy market for third-division soccer, the Florida city was in the back of the pack for an M.L.S. team until an unlikely partnership put the Orlando City Lions on the radar of Major League Soccer.
