abstract: Counseled borrowers were deemed nearly a third less likely to fall behind in payments 90 days or more in the first two years after closing.
lead_paragraph: Is prepurchase counseling an effective way to prevent buyers from taking on more house than they can afford?

headline: Ancient Tragedy, Echoed by a Chorus of Veterans
abstract: The Aquila Theater’s “Herakles” uses video clips of interviews with combat veterans in place of a classical chorus.
lead_paragraph: In modern productions of Greek tragedy, the chorus is often the Achilles’ heel.

headline: Fighting the Peacenik Alien Within Her
abstract: In “The Host” Saoirse Ronan seeks refuge from an alien race that has transformed most of the human population into smiling peaceniks.
lead_paragraph: Around 2006, the year her second “Twilight” book hit, Stephenie Meyer cooked up a little science-fiction something called “The Host” that has, inevitably, been turned into a movie. Ms. Meyer of course unleashed both a new era of vampire romanticism and a female audience that has ravenously fed on that romanticism’s innocent passions.

headline: Q & A
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Moving From a Sublet; Cracks in a New Condo Unit; An Absent Co-op Director.
lead_paragraph: Must a Subtenant Move?

headline: Separate Country Roads Meet on the Upper West Side
abstract: Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell brought their style of Americana to the Beacon Theater in a concert backing their album, “Old Yellow Moon.”
lead_paragraph: Between songs at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night Emmylou Harris brought up fondly remembered things: cassette tapes, percolator coffee, hotel windows that opened. There was a bigger one too. “Remember country music?” she asked.

headline: The Flesh and the Asphalt, Both Weak
abstract: The photographer LaToya Ruby Frazier’s “Haunted Capital” exhibition, at the Brooklyn Museum, explores her city and her family.
lead_paragraph: Braddock, Pa., is about nine miles southeast of Pittsburgh, hugging the eastern bank of the Monongahela River. But in the photographs of LaToya Ruby Frazier, who grew up in this steel town, its coordinates are not so precise. Braddock is in the bodies of Ms. Frazier’s elder family members, who used to work at the local mills; it’s in the empty foundation of the hospital that used to serve them, before it was closed and demolished. It’s there in every picture Ms. Frazier has taken, and it’s here in her outstanding first New York solo show.

headline: In the Round: Honda Urban S.U.V. Concept
abstract: A 360-degree view of the Honda Urban SUV Concept at the New York auto show.
lead_paragraph: The Honda Urban S.U.V. Concept at the New York auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

headline: Good Intentions, Paving the Usual
abstract: “The Place Beyond the Pines,” set in and around Schenectady, N.Y., is a tripartite tale in which the sins of the fathers are visited upon the sons.
lead_paragraph: “The Place Beyond the Pines,” Derek Cianfrance’s new movie, reveals the scale of its ambitions by slow and patient accretion. The film starts out as the modest tale of a small-time carnival performer — a motorcycle stunt rider — who turns to crime for misguided but nonetheless semi-admirable reasons, and in the early scenes you might mistake it for an earnest, locavore indie melodrama.

headline: Unlikely to Succeed at Successions
abstract: The discussion about the future of Matt Lauer of “Today” demonstrates how little NBC has learned about placing and displacing anchors.
lead_paragraph: This can’t be happening again.

headline: A Career Bringing Natural History to Life
abstract: Stephen Christopher Quinn has spent nearly 40 years creating and repairing dioramas at the American Museum of Natural History, but on Friday he will officially retire.
lead_paragraph: “I’m in my work clothes,” Stephen Christopher Quinn said as he smoothed a dark blue apron splotched with paint. “I’ve got to finish two murals by Friday.”

headline: Sticky Fingers Make the Show
abstract: Adam Parker Smith’s exhibition “Thanks” is made up entirely of works he stole from 77 artists: paintings, sculptures, sketchbooks, video, architectural objects, artmaking devices and more.
lead_paragraph: THE art heist began, as art heists should, with a planning session in a nearby bar. Though he had already committed more than 60 such thefts, the perpetrator, Adam Parker Smith, a 34-year-old Brooklyn artist, was nervous. “Everyone whose work I like and who I respect, I’ve been lying to and stealing from,” he said, sipping a beer.

headline: Comedy Listings for March 29-April 4
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and more in New York.
lead_paragraph: Comedy

headline: Bringing France to Life With Pencil and Chalk
abstract: Nearly 60 works by 19th-century French artists are included in “The Impressionist Line From Degas to Toulouse-Lautrec: Drawings and Prints From the Clark,” at the Frick Collection.
lead_paragraph: A remarkably ugly lithograph by Pierre-Auguste Renoir welcomes visitors to “The Impressionist Line From Degas to Toulouse-Lautrec: Drawings and Prints From the Clark,” at the Frick Collection. Called “Pinning the Hat” (around 1898), it shows a woman applying flowers to a doll-faced young girl’s headgear — Renoir at his treacly worst. It is an inauspicious start to a confusing exhibition of drawings and prints from the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass.

headline: The High-Wire Act Called Conversion
abstract: Successful real estate developers have a healthy appetite for risk and a sixth sense for what will ultimately sell.
lead_paragraph: Real estate developers — the successful ones, at least — have a healthy appetite for risk and a sixth sense for what will ultimately sell.

abstract: A selected guide to rock, electronic dance music, soul, pop, indie rock and more.

headline: Cyberattacks Seem Meant to Destroy, Not Just Disrupt
abstract: Corporate leaders have long feared hacking in service of fraud or spying, but now a new threat has taken hold: attackers, possibly with state support, who seem bent on destruction.
lead_paragraph: American Express customers trying to gain access to their online accounts Thursday were met with blank screens or an ominous ancient type face. The company confirmed that its Web site had come under attack.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Art

headline: The Nanny Arrives; Eccentricity Is Squared
abstract: In “Mental” a hitchhiker helps a man raise his troubled daughters after their mother is committed.
lead_paragraph: Who is crazy, and who is sane? That question nags at almost all the characters in “Mental,” a hectic, hyperkinetic farce that reunites the Australian director P.J. Hogan with Toni Collette, the star of his hit 1995 comedy, “Muriel’s Wedding.” In “Mental” Ms. Collette plays Shaz, an unkempt, bong-smoking, knife-carrying nanny hired off the street by Barry Moochmore (Anthony LaPaglia), the mayor of Dolphin Heads, a coastal town in Queensland.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Chosen for Glass, and Serious Facebook Games
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include protests and resignations after lightly clad female dancers perform at a gamer meeting, the corporate culture at Samsung Electronics and real-life versions of tracking cookies in retail stores.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

abstract: A critical guide to plays running in New York, with special note of productions in previews or opening.
lead_paragraph: Theater

abstract: A guide to cultural events in New York for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Samsung Galaxy S 4 Will Cost More Than iPhone on AT&T
abstract: Samsung’s new Galaxy smartphone is expected to pose a serious challenge to Apple’s iPhone. But shoppers may be put off by its higher price tag.
lead_paragraph: Samsung’s new Galaxy smartphone is expected to pose a serious challenge to Apple’s iPhone. But shoppers may be turned off by the Galaxy’s higher price tag.

headline: Lost: Man’s Best Friend
abstract: The tale of a man, played by Jack Plotnick, in search of his missing dog, Paul, from the maker of the killer-tire classic, “Rubber.”
lead_paragraph: Explaining why something is funny is about as fruitful and friend-winning an endeavor as explaining why it’s not. “Wrong,” from the director of the ready-made cult film “Rubber,” demonstrates exactly that, with its sluggish chain of absurd situations: an office in which it is perpetually raining; a pizza delivery girl who quits her marriage after falling in love during a failed phone order; a backyard palm tree mysteriously replaced by a pine.

headline: 7 of 8 Ivy League Schools Report Lower Acceptance Rates
abstract: Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell, Columbia, Brown and Penn were more selective when admitting the freshman class of 2013. Dartmouth is the only Ivy League institution that did not decrease its acceptance rate this year.
lead_paragraph: 9:12 a.m. | Updated  This post has been updated to include admission statistics from Dartmouth College.

headline: Spare Times for March 29-April 4
abstract: A listing of cultural events, author discussions, walking tours and more.
lead_paragraph: Around Town

headline: Pre-Raphaelite Technicolor
abstract: Images from a new exhibition at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new exhibition at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Weak Job Market Leaves City’s Unemployment Rate Flat
abstract: A school bus strike and Wall Street layoffs contributed to the weak market last month and kept New York City’s unemployment rate well above the nation’s, the State Labor Department reported.
lead_paragraph: A strike by school bus drivers and layoffs on Wall Street contributed to a weak job market in New York City last month and kept the city’s unemployment rate well above the nation’s, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Capital Overload
abstract: Capital flowed into Cyprus from overseas in 2008 and 2009, helping to set up the crisis.
lead_paragraph: Capital flowed into Cyprus from overseas in 2008 and 2009, helping to set up the crisis.

headline: Failed Burglary Immortalized on Video
abstract: The police department of Redding, Calif., has asked the public for help in identifying a suspect whose failed attempt to rob a market was caught on tape.
lead_paragraph: When police officers in the California town of Redding arrived at the scene of an attempted burglary one night earlier this month, they had little to go on, save for a blaring alarm and a broken window. Then they looked at the security-camera video. The tape revealed, as Anthony DeRosa of Reuters observed, an 18-second master class in “How Not to Rob a Convenience Store.”

headline: A Newcomer Makes a Splash in Museum Attendance Standings
abstract: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, opened in late 2011 in Bentonville, Ark., by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice Walton, brought in 565,488 visitors in its first full year, more than double the number the museum expected.
lead_paragraph: The Art Newspaper’s annual roundup of international museum attendance numbers for 2012 found a lineup of heavyweights whose positions haven’t changed much – the Louvre is still the world’s most popular, with 9.7 million visitors, topping the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in second place with 6.1 million. But the survey found a surprising bump in an out-of-the-way place: the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, opened in late 2011 in Bentonville, Ark., by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice Walton, brought in 565,488 visitors in its first full year, more than double the number the museum expected.

headline: On Speed-Dial Before Speed-Dial
abstract: William Bunker Tubby was the go-to architect of the Pratt family of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: An architect can claim exceptional good fortune to find a client loyal through two decades. Such was William Bunker Tubby, who enjoyed the patronage of the oil-rich family of Charles Pratt, and speckled Brooklyn with picturesque, usually Richardsonian-Romanesque-style houses, schools and factories from the 1880s through the early 20th century. And thanks to one very unusual commission, Tubby took care of the Pratts even in the afterlife.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Worldtone Dance
abstract: Worldtone Dance in Manhattan is a popular spot to buy shoes for the dancesport community, a mix of social and competitive styles, like ballroom and salsa, as opposed to jazz, tap and ballet.
lead_paragraph: Worldtone Dance in Manhattan is a popular spot to buy shoes for the dancesport community, a mix of social and competitive styles, like ballroom and salsa, as opposed to jazz, tap and ballet.

headline: Is Domestic Bliss Too Much to Ask?
abstract: Olesya Rulin stars in “Family Weekend,” a comedy about a high school athlete who tries to make her family “normal.”
lead_paragraph: In the domestic, ostensibly dark farce “Family Weekend,” 16-year-old Emily (Olesya Rulin), a driven high school athlete, snaps when her affluent, eccentric family fails to show for her jump-rope competition. Conscripting her siblings — her movie-obsessed younger sister (Joey King); her younger brother (Robbie Tucker), a savant with perfect memory; and her dimmish older brother (Eddie Hassell) — for the crime, she ropes her type-A working mother (Kristin Chenoweth) and burned-out painter father (Matthew Modine) to chairs and teaches them lessons in parenting. She wants them to be “normal,” which among other things apparently means a nonvegetarian diet and trying to talk her brother out of his suspicions that he might be gay.

headline: As Fracking Proliferates, So Do Wastewater Wells
abstract: Texas regulators may soon tighten the rules for the construction of wastewater disposal wells amid concerns about the possibility of accidents and groundwater contamination.
lead_paragraph: GONZALES, Tex. — In a dusty lot off the main highway in this South Texas town, Vern Sartin pointed to a collection of hose hookups and large storage tanks used for collecting wastewater from hydraulic fracturing jobs.

headline: 2014 Subaru XV Crosstrek Hybrid: Mild Gains
abstract: This is Subaru’s first production hybrid, based on the XV Crosstrek crossover introduced last year.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: 2014 Subaru XV Crosstrek Hybrid

headline: New York Court Upholds Sales Tax for Online Retailers
abstract: The court rejected arguments from Amazon and Overstock that they should be exempt from a state law requiring online retailers to collect sales taxes on purchases made by New York residents.
lead_paragraph: New York’s highest court rejected arguments Thursday by two Internet retailers that they should be exempt from collecting state sales tax.

headline: Guns, Sex, Drug Cartels, Narco Cinema!
abstract: Narco cinema, hastily made Mexican films about the country’s violent drug cartels, is a popular video-rental genre in Texas.
lead_paragraph: After the arrest in 2010 of Edgar Valdez Villarreal, who the authorities said was the head of a violent Mexican drug cartel, customers at Video Mexico in Austin told Eduardo Betancourt, the owner, something he should have known: the man’s life was already the subject of a low-budget movie.

headline: Deal Reached to Force Paid Sick Leave in New York City
abstract: A legislative compromise came after a raw display of political muscle by unions and activists who ran into fierce objections from the business-minded mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, and his corporate allies.
lead_paragraph: New York City is poised to mandate that thousands of companies provide paid time off for sick employees, bolstering a national movement that has been resisted by wary business leaders.

headline: The Joes Fight the Power
abstract: Noise and heavy weaponry are major players in this follow-up to “G.I. Joe: Rise of the Cobra.”
lead_paragraph: A couple of surprises await fans of “G.I. Joe: Retaliation,” a follow-up to the 2009 moneymaker “G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra.”

headline: Doctor and Assistant Accused in Drug Case
abstract: There was one big difference, the authorities said, between the prescriptions Dr. Hector Castro and Patricia Valera handed out: she charged a lot more.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Hector Castro had a secret.

headline: Santana’s Year Appears Over Before It Begins
abstract: Johan Santana of the Mets is likely to spend the season rehabilitating a new tear in his pitching shoulder.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Johan Santana will be making $25.5 million in the sixth and final year of his enormous contract with the Mets. But it is highly unlikely that he will throw a pitch for the club this season and it is unclear if he will pitch again in the major leagues.

headline: A Fighting Mood Over Marijuana in Montana
abstract: The 2010 campaign to repeal Montana’s legalization of medical marijuana is the subject of the documentary “Code of the West.”
lead_paragraph: It’s all about protecting the young people, of course. “We stand to lose a whole generation of kids,” Cherrie Brady, a community advocate, says in “Code of the West.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 28, 2013
abstract: The New York Times critics on “The Place Beyond the Pines,” “The Host” and “Renoir.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on “The Place Beyond the Pines,” “The Host” and “Renoir.”

headline: 7 of 8 Ivy League Schools Report Lower Acceptance Rates
abstract: Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell, Columbia, Brown and Penn were more selective when admitting the freshman class of 2013. If Dartmouth follows suit, all eight Ivy League institutions will have reported lower acceptance rates this year.
lead_paragraph: It was a little more difficult this year to get admitted to an Ivy League school, as tens of thousands of college applicants learned Thursday evening.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: If the Dancing Shoe Fits
abstract: With more than 500 styles, Worldtone Dance has been a destination for theatrical and competitive dancing shoes for more than 40 years.
lead_paragraph: When Broadway princesses need new glass slippers, they turn to Worldtone Dance, the city’s go-to place for theatrical and dancesport shoes.

headline: Donovan, Sabbatical Over, Is Eager to Return to the U.S. Team
abstract: The career leader in goal scoring for the United States is hoping to earn his way back onto the national team.
lead_paragraph: Lest anyone think that Landon Donovan’s recent sabbatical from soccer diminished his desire to play for the United States, Donovan said Thursday that he would even be willing to change positions if it meant being called in by Coach Jurgen Klinsmann.

headline: Subaru WRX Concept: A Pocket Rocket That Looks the Part
abstract: The WRX Concept is right out of the “Fast and Furious” movies, which have probably sold a lot of Japanese pocket rockets.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: Subaru WRX Concept

headline: Pentagon Reduces Furlough Days for Civilian Staff
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Government Employees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A compromise spending bill signed this week helped the military reduce the number of unpaid days off for hundreds of thousands of Defense Department employees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of thousands of Defense Department civilian employees will get a partial reprieve from the work furloughs imposed by the automatic across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester, with their number of unpaid days off reduced to 14 from 22 between now and October.

headline: Amazon to Buy Social Site Dedicated to Sharing Books
abstract: Amazon’s purchase of Goodreads, a social media site built around sharing books, would give the online bookseller more power in determining which authors get exposure.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, the dominant online bookseller, said late Thursday that it would buy Goodreads, the most visited social media site built around sharing books. The companies did not disclose a purchase price or other conditions of the sale, which will close in the next quarter.

headline: For a Musician, Life Was a Song
abstract: Francisca Gavilán plays the lead in “Violeta Went to Heaven,” about the Chilean musician and artist Violeta Parra.
lead_paragraph: Depicting the unconventional life of the Chilean musician and folk artist Violeta Parra, “Violeta Went to Heaven” unfolds as a poetic sine wave of celebration and defeat.

headline: Most Children’s Meals at Large Restaurant Chains Are Still Unhealthy, a Study Finds
abstract: A study of the nutritional quality of children’s meals at the nation’s largest chain restaurants showed little improvement in the last four years.
lead_paragraph: A new study of the nutritional quality of meals for children on the menus of the nation’s largest chain restaurants has found that 91 percent do not even meet the standards set by the National Restaurant Association’s Kids LiveWell program.

headline: The Setting Is Juvenile, the Problems Are Not
abstract: “Dog Pound” is an update of a 1970s film about teenage inmates adjusting to prison life.
lead_paragraph: Few things can be more embarrassing than being arrested while performing cunnilingus, as the 16-year-old Davis (Shane Kippel) can attest. Nabbed in his bedroom for drug possession while enthusiastically pleasuring his girlfriend, Davis is soon joining fellow teenage offenders Angel (Mateo Morales) and Butch (Adam Butcher) as the newest inmates of a juvenile prison in Montana.

headline: Dealing With a Lot, and Nothing at All
abstract: In “Somebody Up There Likes Me” a young man with little ambition has two constants in his life.
lead_paragraph: “Somebody Up There Likes Me” is a 24-hour film. That is, 24 hours after you see it, it’s still lingering in your mind. But 48 hours after? Gone.

headline: His Truck Is Stuck. Really Stuck.
abstract: In “Detour,” Neil Hopkins tries to keep his sanity as he deals with being stuck in his vehicle after a mudslide.
lead_paragraph: Without knowing how much the actor Neil Hopkins was paid to perform in “Detour,” I’m guessing it wasn’t enough. Like Ryan Reynolds in “Buried,” Mr. Hopkins must convey hunger, thirst, physical injury and slow asphyxiation in a confined space; unlike Mr. Reynolds, he must do so within the constraints of a barrel-scraping budget. As his character, Jackson Alder, says at one point, “That can’t be good.”

headline: Mystery Malady Kills More Bees, Heightening Worry on Farms
abstract: A mysterious ailment appears to have expanded drastically in the past year, wiping out as many as half of the hives needed to pollinate much of America’s produce.
lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — A mysterious malady that has been killing honeybees en masse for several years appears to have expanded drastically in the last year, commercial beekeepers say, wiping out 40 percent or even 50 percent of the hives needed to pollinate many of the nation’s fruits and vegetables.

headline: A Disastrous Year for Bees
abstract: For America’s beekeepers, who have struggled for nearly a decade with a mysterious malady called colony collapse disorder that kills honeybees en masse, the last year was particularly bad.
lead_paragraph: For America’s beekeepers, who have struggled for nearly a decade with a mysterious malady called colony collapse disorder that kills honeybees en masse, the last year was particularly bad.

headline: E.P.A. Plans Stricter Limit for Sulfur in Gasoline
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Air Pollution', 'Sulfur and Sulfur Compounds', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency’s proposal to cut sulfur levels, to match standards used by California, could raise the cost of gasoline by up to 8 cents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency will propose a rule on Friday that will cut the amount of sulfur allowed in gasoline by two-thirds to improve the performance of the catalytic converters in engines that fight smog, the agency has told refiners and clean-air advocates.

headline: Holocaust Heroism in the Philippines
abstract: “Rescue in the Philippines: Refuge From the Holocaust” recounts an effort that saved hundreds of lives.
lead_paragraph: The fascinating documentary “Rescue in the Philippines: Refuge From the Holocaust,” with narration by Liev Schreiber, recounts a little-known chapter of World War II heroism that is as heartbreaking as it is courageous. While much of the world was reluctant to help early victims of Nazi Germany, an effort devised in Manila during late-night poker games eventually delivered more than 1,200 European Jews to safety in the tropics.

headline: Old Enough to See the Glass as Half-Full
abstract: Children in India campaign for a proper water-delivery system in “Revolutionary Optimists.”
lead_paragraph: The title of Maren Grainger-Monsen and Nicole Newnham’s film happens to evoke the function of many documentaries: enlighten audiences about world problems and make them feel a bit more hopeful now that someone with initiative is taking care of things. Centered on a neighborhood in Kolkata lacking potable water, “The Revolutionary Optimists” puts a spin on this tendency because these caretakers of the future are youngsters with a surprising knack for talking points.

headline: Stoudemire Happy After Surgery, but Playoffs Are Uncertain
abstract: Amar’e Stoudemire of the Knicks spoke about his rehabilitation from the surgery he had on his right knee three weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: Amar’e Stoudemire of the Knicks spoke Thursday about his rehabilitation from the surgery he had on his right knee three weeks ago. Stoudemire said the procedure, called a debridement, which he also had on his left knee before the season began, was successful.

headline: California Beaming
abstract: You can laugh at the sunbaked barbarians, but their renaissance is another chapter in the American experiment.
lead_paragraph: SAN SIMEON, Calif. — To take in the gardens of Italian cypress and perfumed citrus, to sit at poolside under a Roman temple front, to stare at the infinity of the Pacific from 1,600 feet above the water is to realize that Hearst Castle was much more than the Xanadu that entombed a tragic giant in “Citizen Kane.”

headline: Bob Teague, WNBC Reporter Who Helped Integrate TV News, Is Dead at 84
abstract: When he joined WNBC-TV, there were few black reporters. But Mr. Teague was eventually disillusioned with TV newscasts.
lead_paragraph: Bob Teague, who joined WNBC-TV in New York in 1963 as one of the city’s first black television journalists and went on to work as a reporter, anchorman and producer for more than three decades, died on Thursday in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 84.

headline: Russia: Opposition Activist’s Trial to Begin in April
abstract: The trial of the opposition activist Aleksei A. Navalny, who is accused of embezzling $500,000 from a timber company, will begin between April 15 and 19, court officials in Kirov now say.
lead_paragraph: The trial of the opposition activist Aleksei A. Navalny, who is accused of embezzling $500,000 from a timber company, will begin between April 15 and 19, and may be lengthy, court officials in Kirov now say. An aide to Mr. Navalny, Anna Veduta, said he had not been officially notified of the date. Mr. Navalny, the most recognizable face of the antigovernment protests that began in 2011, faces several criminal cases opened over the past year. In the embezzlement case, he is accused of organizing a conspiracy to steal timber from KirovLes, a state-owned company, while he served as an adviser to Kirov’s governor four years ago. Mr. Navalny has said he expects to be sent to prison.

headline: A Brief Stop That Altered Everything
abstract: Oregon Coach Dana Altman’s one-day stint with Arkansas — after what he deemed a late change of heart — ultimately altered the direction of three programs.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The video of Dana Altman’s most embarrassing professional moment is on YouTube, shot by a hand-held camera directed at a computer screen, viewed nearly 18,000 times. It was 55 seconds that forever changed Altman’s career.

headline: A New High
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: The S. & P. 500 overtook its previous 2007 high on Thursday, to close at 1,569.15
lead_paragraph: The S. & P. 500 overtook its previous 2007 high on Thursday, to close at 1,569.15

headline: Volvo V60 R-Design Wagon: Sportiness Balanced With Comfort
abstract: This vehicle is not at all like your eclectic uncle’s boxy Volvo 240 station wagon of yore.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: Volvo V60 R-Design Wagon

headline: Mayor Says ’13 Hopefuls Haven’t Won Him Over
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called the field of politicians jockeying to replace him “really depressing” after hearing them lay out their platforms to improve public safety in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is looking at the field of politicians jockeying to replace him, and he says he does not like what he sees.

headline: The Ivy League Was Another Planet
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Rural Areas', 'Poverty']
abstract: If elite universities are looking for a more comprehensive tutorial in recruiting the talented rural poor, they might take a cue from one institution doing a truly stellar job: the military.
lead_paragraph: LEWISBURG, Pa.

headline: The Tyranny of the Billable Hour
abstract: The billable hour system is the way most lawyers in big firms charge clients — but it serves no one. Well, almost no one.
lead_paragraph: WILMETTE, Ill.

headline: Izzo’s Son Sides With Krzyzewski
abstract: A son of Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo picked Duke to beat the Spartans in the Midwest Region semifinals.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Luckily, Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo thinks this is funny. So he tells the story himself.

headline: Riding Wave of Popularity, Craft Brewers Ask Congress for a Tax Cut
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Beer', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hundreds of brewers went to Washington this week to seek aid that they said would help them brew more beer and hire more workers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They came to an opening night beer blast at the National Air and Space Museum, 4,000 strong in baseball caps and T-shirts, to look at the Wright Brothers’ airplane and drink Citizen by DC Brau, which also makes a wryly named hometown brew, Corruption.

headline: Ex-Soldier Is Charged With Aiding Terrorist Group
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Eric Harroun, 30, of Phoenix, was charged on Thursday with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former American soldier was charged Thursday with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad, whose ouster the United States has sought for nearly two years.

abstract: The Detention Watch Network decries the treatment of jailed immigrants.

headline: What Is the Purpose of Lent?
abstract: This week, many Christians are ending their 40 days of sacrifice. For believers or others, is there a point to giving something up?

abstract: Jeffrey W. Rubin, a history professor at Boston University, responds to an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Sophie in ’t Veld, a member of the European Parliament, responds to an editorial, “Cruelty to Women Overseas.”

headline: Drug-Sniffing Dogs and the Fourth Amendment
keywords: ['Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Search and Seizure', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Supreme Court ruling on the use of police dogs wasn’t all that surprising, but how the vote went down sure was.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court correctly ruled this week that using a drug-sniffing police dog on a suspect’s property without a warrant violates the Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable searches. The ruling was not surprising; the split among the justices was.

headline: Wealth That Comes of Tragedy
abstract: In Newtown, officials are listening to the veterans of past tragedies before disbursing the donations that poured in.
lead_paragraph: No one should envy the civic leaders of Newtown, Conn., as they attempt to bring order and transparency to distributing most of the $15 million in donations that has poured into town since the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre of 20 children and six adults last December. The money was given through 40 ad hoc groups, many of them pursuing separate causes from helping families to building a local memorial, even an angel atop the town flagpole.

headline: Terror in Tahrir Square
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: The increase in sexual assaults against women dehumanizes and demeans all Egyptians.
lead_paragraph: Cairo’s Tahrir Square once symbolized the hope Egyptians felt when they overthrew Hosni Mubarak and began building a democracy. But this iconic rallying point for protesters has today also come to symbolize the terror and contempt women increasingly face since the Muslim Brotherhood came to power and the country descended into turmoil.

headline: Jayhawks Seeking Better Guard Play
abstract: Lackluster play by the Jayhawks’ guards is a concern heading into the Round of 16. Ben McLemore is in a slump, a reason the No. 4 seed Wolverines are suddenly considered a favorite.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — On the floor of Cowboys Stadium, Kansas guard Ben McLemore could not wait to take shots. McLemore let the ball fly from 15 feet, then 20, and immediately called for another ball. He flicked his wrist over and over, keeping his elbow up to provide the necessary arc.

headline: Cheating Our Children
abstract: The deficit scolds who insist on reducing government borrowing have done far more damage to future generations than the federal debt ever did.
lead_paragraph: So, about that fiscal crisis — the one that would, any day now, turn us into Greece. Greece, I tell you: Never mind.

headline: Victim and Prosecutor Back Death Row Inmate’s Bid for Resentencing
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Duane E. Buck’s guilt has never been disputed, but the testimony of a psychologist has raised questions about the role that race played in the decision to sentence him to die.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — One morning in July 1995, Phyllis Taylor stood inside her best friend’s house here, face to face with her stepbrother. He was holding a .22-caliber rifle, his eyes bloodshot red. Then he pulled the trigger.

headline: The Empirical Kids
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Youth', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A Yale senior takes a stab at defining her generation, one emerging into adulthood on the heels of the 2000s.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, I wrote a piece for The Atlantic, called “The Organization Kid,” about the smart, hard-working, pleasant-but-cautious achievatrons who thrive in elite universities. Occasionally, somebody asks me how students have changed since then. I haven’t been perceptive enough to give a good answer.

headline: A Scene Stealer Isn’t Ready to Give Up the Spotlight
abstract: Florida Gulf Coast is still embracing the underdog role, but the Eagles looked as if they had shaken off the stardust as they prepared for a game against third-seeded Florida.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The team from so-called Dunk City had yet to rattle a rim or shake a backboard, and about 2,000 fans at Cowboys Stadium appeared bored as they watched a practice filled with drills of floating jumpers, entry passes and — gasp! — free throws.

headline: Palestinians Fight Prison Sentences for Mocking Their President on Facebook
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Palestinians', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: For the second time in a month, a Palestinian court issued a one-year jail sentence to a West Bank resident convicted of insulting President Mahmoud Abbas on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian court on Thursday upheld a one-year jail sentence for a journalist convicted of insulting President Mahmoud Abbas with a pastiche image posted on Facebook. Another Palestinian was given the same sentence last month for posting a humorous caption beneath an image of Mr. Abbas kicking a soccer ball on the social network.

headline: Sprint Nears a U.S. Deal to Restrict China Gear
abstract: Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to accept restrictions from American law enforcement officials on the companies’ ability to pick telecommunications suppliers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to address national security concerns, Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to enter an agreement with American law enforcement officials that will restrict the combined company’s ability to pick suppliers for its telecommunications equipment and systems, government officials said on Thursday.

headline: Malicious Obstruction in the Senate
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: President Obama’s nominees for his cabinet and the courts face an unprecedented level of ridiculous Republican hurdles.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, during one of his new across-the-aisle good-will tours, President Obama pleaded with Senate Republicans to ease up on their record number of filibusters of his nominees. He might as well have been talking to one of the statues in the Capitol. Republicans have made it clear that erecting hurdles for Mr. Obama is, if anything, their overriding legislative goal.

headline: A Safety-First Message Aimed at Getting More Youths Behind the Wheel
abstract: Madison Avenue and automakers are trying to lure young Americans who are more interested in the newest smartphone than in the newest sedan.
lead_paragraph: MADISON AVENUE and the automotive industry are fretting over a growing trend involving the important demographic group of young Americans known as millennials or Generation Y: more of them are just not that into driving, car culture or the lure of the open road.

headline: The Lanzas’ Ammunition Inventory at a Glance
abstract: A look at the assortment of ammunition and other items listed in the search warrants from Adam Lanza’s home.
lead_paragraph: A look at the assortment of ammunition and other items listed in the search warrants from Adam Lanza’s home.

headline: A Dying Art Gets a Rare Exhibition
abstract: Duke’s Mason Plumlee stands out in the N.C.A.A. tournament simply because he is among a few practitioners of a shot that is difficult to guard: the hook shot.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Let’s get this straight: that hook shot Duke’s Mason Plumlee used against Albany in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament was not a Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sky hook. Close, but not quite.

headline: Manslaughter Charges for Doctor Who Gave Liposuction to Transplant Recipient
abstract: Prosecutors said Dr. Oleg Davie recklessly performed liposuction on Isel Pineda, a woman with a transplanted heart, leading to her death.
lead_paragraph: A doctor who prosecutors said recklessly performed liposuction on a woman with a transplanted heart, leading to her death, was arraigned Thursday on charges including manslaughter and falsification of records.

keywords: ['Fuel Efficiency', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: The 74-horespower 1.2-liter 3-cylinder engine found in the Mirage could stir up memories of driving economy cars from decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013 2014 Mitsubishi Mirage

headline: Beloved but Ill, Boston Mayor Won’t Run Again
abstract: Thomas M. Menino, the city’s longest-serving mayor, personally met more than half of Boston’s 625,000 residents.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Some of the most enduring myths of this city are starting to crumble. Whitey Bulger, the notorious gangster who was on the lam for 16 years, is behind bars. The thieves who snatched priceless art from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in 1990 were identified this month.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Mar. 29, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, Mar. 29, 2013.
lead_paragraph: "I know Syria needs us right now. But — enough. I give up.”

headline: Isel Pineda’s Original and Altered Medical Forms
abstract: The medical history forms that Dr. Oleg Davie filled out for Isel Pineda have the same date, but differ considerably in other ways.
lead_paragraph: The medical history forms that Dr. Oleg Davie filled out for Isel Pineda have the same date, but differ considerably in other ways.

headline: For Obama, Tricky Balancing Act in Enforcing Defense of Marriage Act
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. accused President Obama of not having “the courage of his convictions” for enforcing the law even after he concluded it was unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama decided that his administration would no longer defend the Defense of Marriage Act in court, he was presented with an obvious question with a less obvious answer: Would he keep enforcing a law he now deemed unconstitutional?

headline: Divided Parliament Stymies Efforts to Form New Government in Italy
abstract: An inconclusive election last month effectively split Parliament into three hostile fronts, making coalition-building an uphill struggle.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The leader of Italy’s center-left coalition acknowledged on Thursday that he had been unable to cobble together a governing majority in nearly a week of “dramatic” and difficult talks with representatives of the political parties in Parliament.

headline: Shelby Raptor: A Ford With Extra Spice — Lots of It
abstract: Production is supposed to be limited to 100 per model year.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Thursday, March 28, 2013: Shelby Raptor 4×4 pickup truck

headline: Pro-Cuomo Group Repeats as Top Spender on Lobbying
abstract: The coalition of business leaders who are supportive of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spent more money on lobbying in New York State last year than any other group, but its future is unclear.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — For the second consecutive year, a coalition of business leaders supportive of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spent more money on lobbying in New York State last year than any other group, according to a report the state ethics commission released on Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 28, 2013

headline: Sabathia Sets Sights on Opener, and the Red Sox
abstract: C. C. Sabathia made his last spring training start Tuesday and has since shifted to his regular-season work mode as he prepares to start Monday against Boston.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As the Yankees finish up their final two spring training games in two locales — Washington and West Point, N.Y. — they inch tantalizingly closer to opening day. But for one player, the regular season has already begun.

headline: Cackling Loon
abstract: Josh Knapp treats us to a spiffy Friday with a little something extra.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Hey, we got us a Friday with a theme, sort of. Not only that, but it’s a super clean, fun solve. Nicely done, Josh Knapp and Will Shortz. This puzzle was a very pleasant end-of-week surprise.

headline: Corrections: March 29, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 29, 2013.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fay Kanin, Writer for Film and Stage, Dies at 95
abstract: Ms. Kanin wrote comedies and dramas about relationships for film, stage and television as well as movies about death in the Vietnam War and prostitution.
lead_paragraph: Fay Kanin, half of the husband-and-wife team that wrote the Clark Gable-Doris Day comedy “Teacher’s Pet” and the writer of television movies including Emmy-winning vehicles for Maureen Stapleton and Carol Burnett, died on Wednesday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 95.

headline: Long Prison Term Is Less So Thanks to Judge’s Regrets
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: The reversal of a woman’s lengthy prison sentence for selling a few ounces of crack cocaine, and the judge’s apology for imposing it, is a case study on the effects of mandatory sentencing guidelines.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — When Denise Dallaire was arrested at age 26 on charges of selling a few ounces of crack cocaine here a decade ago, she was sentenced to prison for more than 15 years. Last month, shackled inside the same court and facing the same judge, she received an apology and was set free.

headline: Study Links 2011 Quake to Technique at Oil Wells
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Geology', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing']
abstract: Findings published by the journal Geology are the latest to tie quakes to underground disposal of wastewater from oil and gas production.
lead_paragraph: A damaging earthquake in central Oklahoma two years ago most likely resulted from the pumping of wastewater from oil production into deep wells, scientists say.

headline: Damascus University: A Snapshot
abstract: Damascus University is the largest and oldest institution of higher education in Syria, but the aura of normalcy around the university was shattered after an attack Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The state-financed Damascus University is the largest and oldest institution of higher education in Syria. The university has persevered in offering classes despite the encroaching war, and many students continued to attend in an effort to go on with their lives. On Thursday, the sense of normalcy  was shattered when mortar shells hit an outdoor student cafe. Here are some facts about the university, which at one time was considered Syria’s most prestigious.

headline: Heat Distinguished, and Distanced, Themselves
abstract: Miami not only put together a 27-game winning streak but also gave itself an insurmountable lead over the Eastern Conference competition.
lead_paragraph: Most coverage of the Miami Heat’s 27-game winning streak focused on LeBron James and his ability to take over games.

headline: Health Care Law Will Raise Some Premiums, Study Says
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The report, commissioned by the State of California, says that the law will drive up individual insurance premiums, but that subsidies will offset most of the increase for low-income people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A study commissioned by the State of California says that the new federal health care law will drive up individual insurance premiums, but that subsidies will offset most of the increase for low-income people.

headline: Taliban Spread Terror in Karachi as the New Gang in Town
abstract: The grab for influence and power in the city shows that the Taliban have been able to extend their reach across Pakistan, not just in the country’s frontier regions.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — This seaside metropolis is no stranger to gangland violence, driven for years by a motley collection of armed groups who battle over money, turf and votes.

headline: In Politics, Never Say Never to an Aggie
abstract: One of Gov. Rick Perry’s newest appointees to the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents is the lawyer Anthony Buzbee, a Democrat and fellow Aggie.
lead_paragraph: Familiar with the “never-always” problem? That’s when you lay down a hard and fast rule, and then eat your words when an exception comes along.

headline: Memphis Drops Confederate Names From Parks, Sowing New Battles
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'City Councils', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Names, Geographical']
abstract: The City Council’s decision to remove Confederate names from three parks has sparked controversy in the face of a state bill that would make such renamings more difficult.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Two bright metal signs long welcomed visitors here to the grassy bluffs overlooking the Mississippi River, near a cluster of Civil War cannons and historical plaques.

headline: Another 3-Pointer Falls, and Ohio State Escapes Again
abstract: Ohio State, the last remaining top seed in the West Region, prevailed again, but barely. With a late 3-pointer, the No. 2 Buckeyes squeezed by No. 6 Arizona.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For Ohio State, the end felt so four days ago. Here came the Buckeyes, in another tied game in the N.C.A.A. tournament, with the ball in the final seconds.

headline: Tom Boerwinkle, Who Had Night to Remember as a Rebounder, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Boerwinkle, a stalwart center for the Chicago Bulls in the 1970s, set a franchise record with 37 rebounds.
lead_paragraph: Tom Boerwinkle, a stalwart center for the Chicago Bulls in the 1970s who once used his 7-foot frame to grab 37 rebounds in a game known both for that feat — a team record that still stands — and for the frigid conditions in which it was played, died on Tuesday at his home near Chicago. He was 67.

headline: Cases of Fever Caused by Fungus Rise
abstract: Cases of valley fever in the American Southwest have risen sharply in the past decade for unknown reasons, federal health officials said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Cases of valley fever in the American Southwest have risen sharply in the last decade for unknown reasons, federal health officials said Thursday. The fever is caused by inhaling a fungus that thrives in desert soil. The disease resembles flu or pneumonia. Though the illness is rarely fatal, more than 40 percent of known patients are hospitalized. From 1998 to 2011, cases went from 5 per 100,000 population in the region — Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico and Utah — to 43 per 100,000, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The increase may be due to changing weather patterns or to excavation for new housing. Those who are often outside appear slightly more likely to get it, said Dr. Benjamin J. Park, the C.D.C.’s chief epidemiologist for fungal diseases, “but people who work in office buildings have gotten it, and there’s one case of someone who just passed through the Phoenix airport.”

headline: Often Overlooked, Marquette Overwhelms No. 2 Seed Miami
abstract: With its 10-deep rotation, Marquette smothered second-seeded Miami, whose only lead in the game came in the first three minutes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is no mistaking Marquette Coach Buzz Williams’s disgust for how others have assessed his team during the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: In Doubles, Lisa Raymond and Laura Robson Cover the Age Spectrum

headline: Donovan Speaks About a National Team Return, and More
abstract: Landon Donovan, speaking with reporters Thursday for the first time since ending his self-imposed sabbatical from soccer, talked about a return to the game, to the national team and about the reactions of others to his difficult “mental place.”
lead_paragraph: Landon Donovan spoke with reporters on Thursday for the first time since announcing he would return to Major League Soccer’s Los Angeles Galaxy this week. Sam Borden’s article for The Times dealt mostly with the one question on the mind of most fans when he walked away from the game after winning last year’s M.L.S. title: is he planning to return to the United States national team?

headline: From Today’s Paper: Water Line Break and Flood Homes in Hoboken
abstract: Water lines break in Hoboken.
lead_paragraph: Workers at Willow Avenue and 8th Street in Hoboken, N.J., the site of one of two water line breaks just a few blocks apart. The other was at Willow and 14th. Many in the city lost water pressure, and an advisory was issued warning residents to boil water.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:30 A.M. (AMC) HACKERS (1995) Two New York high school students (played by Angelina Jolie and Jonny Lee Miller) use their hacking skills for mischiefmaking until they stumble upon a corporate extortion scheme and are charged for computer crimes they did not commit. Only through copious in-line skating, frenzied typing and obsolete tech lingo can their names be cleared. Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times about this ’90s time capsule directed by Iain Softley, said, “A lot of attention has gone into the film’s video games, computer imagery and costumes, to the point where simply watching these artifacts is half the fun.”

headline: A Time as  Fleeting as Waxwings
abstract: A mother recalls a long-ago morning in a family where an autistic child pushes against the world, and everyone must cope.
lead_paragraph: I wrote this piece about six years ago, thinking back on a particular morning and piecing together the events of that day through old e-mails. I am 55 now and divorced, and think wistfully about the brief constellation that was our family. Studies of divorce rates among parents of autistic children contradict one another, citing rates as low as 24 percent and as high as 80 percent.

headline: Syracuse Smothers No. 1 Seed Indiana
abstract: Syracuse, a No. 4 seed, leaned on its usual brand of swarming defense to topple the Hoosiers, who shot 33.3 percent from the field and committed 19 turnovers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Indiana could not have looked more lost. The Hoosiers missed layups, dribbled into defenders and threw passes that sailed into the Syracuse bench, as if a gust of wind had suddenly swept through Verizon Center. And that was just the first few possessions.

headline: London’s Dynamic Duo of Theatrical Dames

headline: Wichita State Muscles Past La Salle Into the Round of 8

First, the Explorers shadowed one another and boxed out. Then, one by one, as Coach John Giannini tossed basketballs at the rim, they maneuvered around one person, grabbed the rebound and shot the ball, over another, taller person, in the paint.

headline: From College to N.B.A., Coaching Approaches Differ

headline: Freed of a Secret’s Burden, a Soccer Player Looks Ahead
abstract: If Robbie Rogers returns to professional soccer, he would become the first openly gay male athlete to compete in a major American team sport.
lead_paragraph: The computer document was named LetterOfLife. Robbie Rogers, a former member of the United States national team and a professional soccer player in England, wrote it one night last December, pounding on his keyboard while sitting in bed. When he finished, he saved it on the main screen of his laptop and it stayed there, for more than two months, while Rogers alternately pondered it, ignored it and agonized over whether he could make it public.

lead_paragraph: Margalit Fox writes the obituary of Rabbi Herschel Schacter, the man who “Cried to the Jews of Buchenwald: ‘You Are Free’.”

lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — After a second night in a hospital being treated for a recurrent lung infection, former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa was in good spirits on Friday, enjoying breakfast and making steady progress, according to the office of President Jacob Zuma, who had earlier urged his compatriots not to panic.

abstract: Russia and China watched with concern on Friday as the Pentagon rebuked North Korea over its rising threats toward the United States and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korean state media said Friday that the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, had ordered his missile units to be ready to strike the United States and South Korea, which South Korean officials said could signal either preparations for missile tests or just more blustering.

headline: The Stalemate in Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: When I got to Aleppo, I expected to find raging battles. Instead, I saw a war progressing in slow motion.
lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — Syria’s largest city sits in a valley down from a hill with an old citadel. Over the centuries, the massive stone fortress has hosted Romans, Mongols and Ottomans; these days, it’s home to the soldiers of President Bashar al-Assad. The rebels occupy the eastern portion of the old city, a maze of alleyways and courtyards down below. It’s an ideal terrain for urban guerrilla: Tanks cannot enter the narrow passages, and the thick stone walls act as shields against artillery and air strikes.

headline: Daily Report:  ‘The Attacks Have Changed From Espionage to Destruction’
abstract: American Express is the latest victim in a wave of attacks on the online operations of American banks, David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth on Friday in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: American Express customers trying to gain access to their online accounts on Thursday were met with blank screens or an ominous ancient type face. The company confirmed that its Web site had come under attack, David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth report on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: Choosing a Credit Card Processor (and Drawing Some Conclusions)
abstract: After months of research into how credit card transactions are processed, I make a decision. Part 4 of a series.
lead_paragraph: My search for a credit card processor started last April and dragged on through the end of January. Like many small-business owners, I have plenty of things to keep me busy, so my search was an on again/off again thing. As it progressed, I found that the more carefully I looked at the terms I was agreeing to, the less I liked them.

lead_paragraph: This week, App Smart was all about gardening because spring has sprung, or is about to. There are many apps that can help you in the garden, like plant reference guides or advice about garden bugs, and even apps that can help you manage your garden and its plants over time.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Awkwardness at NBC, and Barbara Walters’ Retirement
abstract: NBC has yet to learn how to handle successions gracefully, Barbara Walters will retire in 2014, and Christopher Cuomo and Kate Bolduan will host a new CNN morning show.
lead_paragraph: Networks never seem to absorb lessons of lineup changes gone bad, NBC most of all, Alessandra Stanley writes. Matt Lauer, the host of NBC’s “Today” show, who may be on the way out, was admirably suave onscreen despite reports that NBC may be seeking a new host. Mr. Lauer’s problems began with his succession last year, when many viewers blamed him when his co-anchor Ann Curry was clumsily cast aside. The drama is not new.  More than 20 years ago, NBC replaced Jane Pauley with the younger Deborah Norville; that “Today” show shakeup became a founding fiasco of morning television, and Ms. Norville’s career never recovered.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — NPR is ending the 21-year-old call-in radio show “Talk of the Nation” and will encourage local stations to replace it with an expanded version of “Here and Now,” an afternoon news broadcast that is produced here, the organization announced on Friday.

headline: Raids in Russia Target ‘Foreign Agents’
abstract: Russia has dismissed Western concerns about a wave of raids targeting civil society groups in Russia. Could President Vladimir V. Putin’s latest hard-line tactic to marginalize his opponents backfire on the Kremlin leader?
lead_paragraph: LONDON – It has been a nerve-jangling week for civil society groups in Russia as they awaited a knock on the door by state officials on the hunt for “foreign agents.”

abstract: In a new version of Tomb Raider, the creators have tried to turn Lara Croft into something new: a realistic, relatable person.
lead_paragraph: Lara Croft, perhaps the most famous heroine in video games, started out as a man, according to reports about her creation some 17 years ago. She was too much of an Indiana Jones clone, the men making the original Tomb Raider thought, so they turned her into a woman.

headline: Europe’s Second Depression
abstract: Not doing too well.
lead_paragraph: Correction: It turns out that I messed up slightly on the historical data — in a way that weakened my point! The truth is worse: Europe’s recovery is already behind where it was in 1935.

headline: Kristallnacht in Myanmar
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: President Thein Sein claims security forces refrained from intervening to stop recent violence against Muslims to protect Myanmar’s democratic transition. Not so.
lead_paragraph: MEIKTILA, Myanmar — Not one bullet was fired, not one smoke bomb was dropped as scores of Muslims were attacked and some were burnt alive in Myanmar last week. The security forces just looked on. In a country where they routinely use brute force against political dissidents, villagers who protest land grabs and even monks, their passivity was sadly revealing.

headline: The Gun Report: March 29, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of gun news yesterday. An inventory of Adam Lanza’a possessions was released by police. According to the Times, they included “several firearms, more than 1,600 rounds of ammunition, 11 knives, a starter pistol, a bayonet, 3 samurai swords,” as well as “photographs of what appeared to be a corpse smeared in blood and covered in plastic, as well as a newspaper clipping that chronicled a vicious shooting at Northern Illinois University.”

headline: We Do Not Want to Go Home Again
abstract: When John Swan and Sarah Masel searched for a rental apartment to share, a usable living room was a priority.
lead_paragraph: John Swan was acutely aware of what his apartment on the Upper East Side lacked — a living room.

headline: A Man of His Time
abstract: A new biography of Karl Marx emphasizes his responses to events, not his body of ideas.
lead_paragraph: The Karl Marx depicted in Jonathan Sperber’s absorbing, meticulously researched biography will be unnervingly familiar to anyone who has had even the most fleeting acquaintance with radical politics. Here is a man never more passionate than when attacking his own side, saddled with perennial money problems and still reliant on his parents for cash, constantly plotting new, world-changing ventures yet having trouble with both deadlines and personal hygiene, living in rooms that some might call bohemian, others plain “slummy,” and who can be maddeningly inconsistent when not lapsing into elaborate flights of theory and unintelligible abstraction.

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘The Host,’ ‘Renoir’ and ‘The Place Beyond the Pines’
abstract: Times critics review three of this week’s new films.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics review “The Place Beyond the Pines,” “The Host” and “Renoir.”
