abstract: Junior rodeos in the Texas Panhandle.
lead_paragraph: Junior rodeos in the Texas Panhandle.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WAVE,  by Sonali Deraniyagala. (Knopf, $24.) Deraniyagala’s unforgettable account of her struggle to carry on living after her husband, sons and parents were killed in the 2004 tsunami isn’t only as unsparing as they come, but also defiantly imbued with light.

headline: It’s a Natural Gas, Gas, Gas
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Books and Literature', 'Royalties', 'Food', 'Drilling and Boring', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Weight loss; the Abbie Hoffman rule.
lead_paragraph: I’m a biologist with a federal agency. My family owns land in northeast Pennsylvania. A portion is owned outright by my mother, who has entered into a contract with a natural-gas company to allow drilling on the property. Royalties from the gas extraction allow her to live comfortably in retirement. My mother made the arrangements for the gas drilling without my support. I’m not in favor of increasing fossil-fuel dependence. In light of the anticipated royalties, my mother was advised by her lawyer to establish a corporate partnership with my brother and me, for liability protection. This would mean a portion of the royalties will be mine. If I intend to work on any future climate-change projects professionally, should I decline the partnership with my mother? If I do not support natural-gas drilling, is that another reason to decline the partnership? And is this decision different from eventually inheriting money related to drilling? RICHARD, WASHINGTON

headline: A Modest Proposal for More Back-Stabbing in Preschool
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Income Inequality', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Sure, I want my kid to learn how to share. I also want her to learn how to thrive.
lead_paragraph: Late last week, I was driving my daughter to her play-based, shoe-optional, sugar-free preschool — a magical Arcadia where an actual chicken is free to roam and grow fat off Pirate’s Booty, and where the major areas of academic focus revolve around turn-taking, problem-solving and the life story of Rosa Parks — when I experienced a moment of self-doubt so paralyzing I almost had to pull over. The radio in my car was tuned to an NPR show, on which callers were debating the decision by the C.E.O. of Yahoo, Marissa Mayer, to ban employees from working from home. I’d been thinking about Mayer since early that morning, having fallen down an Internet rabbit hole that plunged me deep into her art collection, her exclusive wardrobe and her estimated $300 million net worth. Specifically, I was thinking about the rather highhanded, Marie Antoinette-ish way in which she dismissed the need for extended maternity leave, as if it hadn’t occurred to her that building an en suite nursery for her newborn next to her office basically elided the need for it, since the baby could remain within a few feet of her all day long.

headline: A Brief Resurrection
abstract: I thought I’d left the habit behind — until I ran into my ex-husband.
lead_paragraph: I was sitting next to my husband in our neighborhood pub on a spring afternoon, munching on fish and chips. I reached for my beer and looked out the window, and there he was: a 30-something fellow in a scruffy beard. My ex-husband.

headline: Tony Visconti Will Lie for David Bowie
abstract: The producer talks about keeping “The Next Day” under wraps and doing drugs with John Lennon.
lead_paragraph: You produced David Bowie’s new album, “The Next Day,” which was recorded in total secrecy. How did you keep it under wraps?  It wasn’t difficult. Most of us had been with him for decades, myself the longest, 45 years. Maybe one or two people said, “Is David Bowie making a new album?” and then I’d have to lie.

headline: The 3.17.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: IS THIS WHERE THE THIRD INTIFADA WILL START?

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: OUR LADY OF ALICE BHATTI,  by Mohammed Hanif. (Vintage, $15.) Alice Bhatti, a Karachi nurse with mysterious healing powers, is at the center of Hanif’s blistering comedy, which delivers a broadside on the socially sanctioned butchery of women and girls in Pakistan. Working miracles at Sacred Heart Hospital for All Ailments, a cesspit of incompetence, Alice is beloved, but not even her supernatural skill set can stem the tide of dead women.

headline: Get Yer Yeah Yeah Yeahs Out
abstract: Karen O and her bandmates have never seemed comfortable as rock stars. Which has only made them that much more compelling.
lead_paragraph: The fall of 2000 felt like end times for rock ’n’ roll in New York City. On the radio it was all boy bands and Britney Spears, and there hadn’t been a vital rock scene since punk in the 1970s. But on a Sunday night at a tiny club in Lower Manhattan, something was happening. There were four acts on the bill at the Mercury Lounge; the Yeah Yeah Yeahs were the openers, and it was still light out when they took the stage. The band was elemental: guitar and drums, no bass. But the singer, who called herself Karen O, was otherworldly. She was dressed in a kind of “Clockwork Orange” burlesque, with cutout hearts as pasties. Before the show, she doused herself in olive oil. Onstage, she danced around like a lunatic, manically grinning and flinging droplets of oil from her hair into the crowd. The guitar player, Nick Zinner, had seen this side of her. But the drummer, Brian Chase, had practiced with the band only once, and this was their first gig. “The only thing to do,” Chase remembers thinking, “is just be like, ‘Whoa.’ ”

headline: Who Made That Learjet?
abstract: Designing a hot rod for the sky.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1960s, William Lear invited potential buyers to tour the jet that he designed as a hot rod for the sky. The plane was sleek and narrow, with a cabin ceiling so low that you had to take care not to bang your head. When one man complained that he couldn’t stand up inside this so-called luxury plane, Lear groused, “You’re absolutely right — and you can’t stand up in your [expletive] Rolls-Royce, either.”

headline: Bobby Cannavale, Broadway’s Hottest Outsider
abstract: He has starred with Chris Rock, Al Pacino and Alec Baldwin. And now he’s getting the best parts.
lead_paragraph: It was a miserable morning, rainy, cold and Wednesday, so Barney Greengrass was mostly empty. Bobby Cannavale was there having breakfast with the actor Richard Kind. Cannavale buttered a bialy as Kind endured a vegetable omelet. “I’ve been dieting for 45 years,” he said mournfully. Cannavale took his arm. “You look great, man,” he said. The two friends share a trainer.

headline: Summary Judgment
abstract: Sandra Day O’Connor offers an overview of the Supreme Court’s history.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Day O’Connor retired from the Supreme Court in 2006, but she still turns up for the occasional argument, sitting off to the side in one of the seats reserved for important guests. She can look a little grim, and with reason. The court has been busy disassembling her work.

headline: Yes Man
abstract: Disguised as a self-help book, Mohsin Hamid’s novel traces a nameless hero’s journey from impoverished boy to corporate tycoon.
lead_paragraph: “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia” begins under a bed. With you — yes, you — under a bed. Once you quit cowering, you’ll be the hero of this novel written in the second person, although there’s nothing remotely heroic about you at the moment; you’re so sick you can scarcely speak. The only remedy at hand is a large white radish, which your mother cooks up in a foul brew.

headline: Masters and Slaves
abstract: Andrea Stuart pursues the history of both sides of her Caribbean family.
lead_paragraph: On a trip to Paris, I recently had the same shocked realization that Andrea Stuart describes in her astounding new book, “Sugar in the Blood.”

headline: Peculiar Institutions
abstract: A Revolutionary War veteran and his slave are locked in an intimate battle of wills in Margaret Wrinkle’s first novel.
lead_paragraph: One of the challenges white writers face in creating black characters is the avoidance of caricature and stereotype. If cultural appropriation must take place, the thinking goes, then authors should treat black narratives — often the products of American history, and thus as sacred as the Constitution itself — with kid gloves. If they fail even in the slightest, readers are sure to voice criticism and, maybe justifiably, rain down judgment and reckoning.

headline: Asylum Seekers
abstract: Two Kurdish brothers are forced to flee the ayatollah’s revolution in Laleh Khadivi’s novel.
lead_paragraph: What does a political refugee notice when arriving in, say, Los Angeles? Is he shocked by the quotidian displays of flesh? Troubled by the angry jumble of a city he has known only in its varnished Saturday matinee form? Unbalanced by discordant echoes of home, like the Venice Beach busker whose turban appears native to the old country?

headline: Prince of Punk
abstract: The rocker and frontman for the Voidoids ruminates on his life, loves and his rift with a collaborator.
lead_paragraph: Richard Hell was partly responsible for the phenomenon of punk, a visionary whose style Malcolm McLaren imported to England and impressed upon his pet project, the Sex Pistols, who popularized and cashed in on Hell’s spiky hair, torn clothes and audacious attitude — embodied in his seminal record of 1977, “Blank Generation.” In his new autobiography, “I Dreamed I Was a Very Clean Tramp,” Hell admits to resenting the Sex Pistols for failing to acknowledge how much they lifted from him. But in a moment that speaks to this punk-icon-turned-accomplished-writer’s commitment to an objective distance from himself, he rhetorically asks, “How many kids were going to get excited about calling themselves ‘blank’? The concept of ‘anarchy’ was just as disgusted and contrary but a lot more fun.”

headline: Mother of the Movement
abstract: This biography reveals a fiercely determined activist behind the mild-mannered lady in a hat.
lead_paragraph: Beautiful Rosa Parks sits alone in the Montgomery, Ala., city bus she desegregated, an image endlessly replicated, most recently on an American postage stamp issued in February to commemorate Black History Month and what would have been Parks’s 100th birthday. By the time she died in 2005, Parks had become an American saint. President Bill Clinton gave her a Medal of Freedom in 1996; Congress awarded her a Gold Medal in 1999 (passed nearly unanimously — only Representative Ron Paul of Texas dissented); and after her death, her body lay in the Capitol Rotunda. She was the first woman to be so honored, and the first black woman to have a statue in her likeness placed in the National Statuary Hall of the Capitol. It was unveiled this year and positioned, House Speaker John Boehner pointed out, “right in the gaze” of Jefferson Davis, president of the ­Confederacy.

headline: What Now for Gun Control?
abstract: Some Democrats aren’t giving up.
lead_paragraph: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and other Democratic leaders in Congress folded their tents on comprehensive gun control fast — dropping a ban on assault weapons and limits on the size of magazines as they watered down the “official” bill that will hit the Senate floor.

headline: When Worlds Collide
abstract: Alexander Stille looks at the discordant strains of his parents’ marriage.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to invest the remnants of the past — the letters, the heirlooms, the junk — with tremendous explanatory power, especially when the stuff is your family’s. The cliché about the dustbin of history is almost too apt when Alexander Stille walks into his aunt Lally’s apartment. Buried in the stacks of clothes, receipts, lottery tickets and old balls of yarn, there are fantastic photographs, a letter from the proto-Fascist poet Gabriele d’Annunzio and all the living room furniture Lally’s parents had taken with them when the family fled Russia for Italy and then Italy for the United States.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
abstract: New books by Petra Reski, Sam Roberts, Walter Stahr and Jessica Grogan.
lead_paragraph: THE HONORED SOCIETY  A Portrait of Italy’s Most Powerful Mafia.  By Petra Reski. Translated by Shaun Whiteside.Nation Books, paper, $16.99.

headline: Undue Process
abstract: An investigative journalist examines a juvenile justice scandal, and a maverick defense lawyer recounts his most fraught case.
lead_paragraph: As we commemorate the 50th anniversary of Gideon v. Wainwright, the landmark Supreme Court decision that gave poor defendants the right to counsel, it would be nice to celebrate. That case, taken together with the 1967 decision In re Gault, which gave juveniles the same rights in court as adults, stands for the principle that process matters in our system of justice; when faced with the awesome power of the state, the accused — rich or poor, old or young — must be properly armed.

headline: Irish Legacy of Leniency on Mortgages Nears an End
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Foreclosures', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: More than 143,000 home mortgages are in arrears in Ireland, but forced repossessions have been politically and legally difficult. That is about to change.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ben Gilroy, one of tens of thousands who over-borrowed in the giddy property boom that preceded Ireland’s economic collapse, has made no mortgage payments for two years. But he says he does not worry that he will lose his home any time soon.

headline: By Night in Chile
abstract: Alejandro Zambra’s novel considers the legacy of Pinochet.
lead_paragraph: In a summary, most literary careers nowadays — in New York or Zagreb — can look eerily similar. Take, for instance, the case of Alejandro Zambra. Zambra is a Chilean who has so far written three novels. He was born in 1975, and teaches literature at the Diego Portales University in Santiago. He has figured on Granta’s list of best young Spanish-­language novelists, and the Bogotá39 project. His career, in other words, has the usual global vibe. But if you held his novels in your hand, then something much stranger would be immediately apparent. “Bonsai,” his first, takes up only 86 miniature pages. His second, “The Private Lives of Trees,” requires 98. His third, “Ways of Going Home,” which has just been published in a translation by Megan McDowell, uses a comparatively gargantuan 139. All of them are marked by a uniquely manic brevity.

headline: A Crack in the Darkness
abstract: Novelists can peer into places like North Korea, with help from Google Earth.
lead_paragraph: That old dictum, write what you know? I’ve always thought that was terrible advice. Most of us don’t know much. And what we do know can feel shopworn in the retelling. Shopworn or just divested of emotional content. Sometimes, the things we’re closest to — our lives, for instance — are the very things we least want to examine with rigor.

headline: Attacca Quartet Plays John Adams on ‘Fellow Traveler’
abstract: “Fellow Traveler: The Complete String Quartet Works of John Adams,” recorded by the Attacca Quartet, finds the musicians rearranging the movements to their liking.
lead_paragraph: ‘Fellow Traveler: The Complete String Quartet Works of John Adams’

headline: Screening History
abstract: In A. B. Yehoshua’s novel, an Israeli film director travels to Santiago de Compostela for a tribute to his work.
lead_paragraph: Narrative imagination is its own thing: the muscular yet uncanny gift of the storyteller. It is distinct from useful, more rational elements like the psychology of characters, rich details of settings, pungent dialogue, clever plots, memorable images — all remain mechanical unless animated by the pure mastery of “and then,” the mysterious, proliferating other-life of narrative conviction. In the kind of narrative I mean, incidents themselves are prolific. That teeming germ-culture thrives notably in the writing of the Israeli novelist A. B. Yehoshua.

headline: Mozart Piano Concertos Performed by Jan Lisiecki
abstract: Jan Lisiecki, a Canadian piano prodigy, recorded two Mozart piano concertos.
lead_paragraph: Mozart: Piano Concertos Nos. 20 in D minor, 21 in C

headline: Rachmaninoff’s ‘All-Night Vigil’
abstract: Rachmaninoff’s “All-Night Vigil” was recorded by the Latvian Radio Choir under the direction of Sigvards Klava.
lead_paragraph: Rachmaninoff:

headline: Glass Lewis Urges MetroPCS Investors to Reject T-Mobile Deal
abstract: The firm joined its larger rival, Institutional Shareholder Services, in casting aspersions on the transaction, raising pressure on MetroPCS and T-Mobile to sweeten the terms of the merger or risk defeat.
lead_paragraph: MetroPCS, at least you have Egan-Jones.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Jonathan Sperber talks about his new biography of Karl Marx; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Parul Sehgal discusses Mohsin Hamid’s new novel, “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Sam Tanenhaus.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jonathan Sperber talks about his new biography of Karl Marx; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Parul Sehgal discusses Mohsin Hamid’s new novel, “How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Sam Tanenhaus.

headline: Male Roles? Yes, but Ready for Divadom
abstract: Alice Coote, known for her range and agility in male parts, will sing the role of Sesto in David McVicar’s production of Handel’s “Giulio Cesare” at the Met.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t want to see me after a rehearsal,” said the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote, looking stylish during a recent prerehearsal interview at the Metropolitan Opera. “I’m sweating and disgusting. I have to sing while being physically active and rolling around the floor and leaping around with guns.”

headline: ‘Spring’ Festival as Rite of Refreshment
abstract: Still reeling from an acid attack on its artistic director, the Bolshoi Ballet is preparing to look back on a drama of a different sort: a daring, and shocking, 1913 performance of “The Rite of Spring.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The scandal surrounding the 1913 Paris premiere of “The Rite of Spring,” by Serge Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes, is legendary. The performance of Vaslav Nijinksy’s modernist choreography, based on pagan ritual and set to Stravinsky’s dissonant score, shocked audiences and changed the course of dance.

headline: Lil Wayne, Sobriety and the Damage Done
abstract: Jon Caramanica and host Ben Ratliff talk about Lil Wayne’s “I Am Not A Human Being II,” the third in his theoretically drug-free era — he has consented to regular, court-ordered drug tests since 2010 — and talk about Wayne (again, theoretically) pre- and post-sobriety.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and host Ben Ratliff talk about Lil Wayne’s “I Am Not A Human Being II,” the third in his theoretically drug-free era — he has consented to regular, court-ordered drug tests since 2010 — and talk about Wayne (again, theoretically) pre- and post-sobriety.

headline: What Pet Owners Must Do to Get New York Apartments
abstract: New Yorkers will jump through all kinds of hoops, and even play a few tricks, in order to share a home with a beloved pet.
lead_paragraph: In a seemingly endless game of cat-and-mouse, pet owners do many things to ease their way into the apartment of their dreams — legitimate and not so.

headline: Leading Off: The Joyless Round
abstract: Where did the fun go? Syracuse and Marquette won in Big East style, but the games weren’t easy to watch.
lead_paragraph: For everyone who giggled through last weekend’s N.C.A.A. tournament games, Thursday’s Round of 8 games hit like a bucket of ice water. Fun? Apparently it was outlawed since Sunday. In its place came the Big East’s antijoy squad, Jim Boeheim and Buzz Williams, who preach defense in their sleep and wring the life out of games as if their last breaths depended on it.

headline: Can Line’s Messaging App Crack the American Market?
abstract: Line, a popular South Korean mobile messaging application, is setting up shop in San Francisco in the hopes of making inroads in the crowded American market. But the competition is stiff.
lead_paragraph: Line, the mobile messaging application that has built up more than 110 million customers around the world, particularly in Asia, is hoping to make similar inroads in the United States.

headline: A Triplex at the Pierre Hotel
abstract: A look inside what is considered one of the most important and historic luxury apartments in the country.
lead_paragraph: A look inside what is considered one of the most important and historic luxury apartments in the country.

headline: Women’s Tennis Serves Up No. 1 vs. No. 2
abstract: The meeting between Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova will be the ninth between a women’s No. 1 and No. 2 since 2005; in that time, the top two men have met 33 times.

headline: Opulent, at a Price to Match
abstract: A triplex at the distinctive apex of the Pierre Hotel, with cathedral windows replicating a Versailles chapel, has a record asking price of $125 million.
lead_paragraph: The penthouse at the distinctive apex of the Pierre Hotel, a triplex confection graced by a grand black-marble staircase, arched cathedral windows that replicate a Versailles chapel, 23-foot ceilings, and fireplaces embraced by mantels designed in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries is poised for a return to the market at a price that reflects its irreplaceable heritage; if met, it would set another record for trophy residences in New York City.

headline: Safety Agency Opens Inquiry on Hyundai Sonata Suspension Failures
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The new investigation was prompted by six reports from owners that a rear control arm failed, apparently because of corrosion.
lead_paragraph: Almost four years after Hyundai had to recall about 600,000 vehicles for corrosion problems, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has started investigating possible corrosion-related rear suspension failures on an estimated 393,000 2006-8 Hyundai Sonatas, according to a report posted on Friday on the agency Web site.

headline: Popcast: Lil Wayne, Sobriety and the Damage Done
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff talk about Lil Wayne’s “I Am Not a Human Being II” and assess the artist before and after the start of his (theoretical) enforced sobriety.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jon Caramanica and the host, Ben Ratliff, talk about Lil Wayne’s “I Am Not a Human Being II,” his third album since he  theoretically stopped using drugs — he has consented to regular, court-ordered drug tests since 2010 — and about Wayne (again, theoretically) before and during his enforced sobriety.

headline: More Choices for Healthy Fish Dishes
abstract: Serving more than the four favorite species of fish is wise advice for the home cook trying to eat more seafood.
lead_paragraph: Trying to include more fish and seafood in your diet can be confusing. Fish is healthy and nourishing, and I love to cook and eat it. But whenever I think about the environmental impacts of both farming and overfishing I feel torn. I am not the only one with these concerns, as was made clear by the recent Too Few Fish in the Sea Room For Debate feature.

headline: One on One: Jerry Weissman, Silicon Valley’s Storyteller
abstract: Jerry Weissman has been helping companies go public for nearly a quarter century. He’s not an engineer or a venture capitalist, though; he’s a former theater director, who schools top executives in how to talk to Wall Street. Getting a story into a clear logical flow can mean millions. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Weissman may produce more revenue than almost any director in history. His big successes haven’t been plays or movies, though. For more than two decades, Mr. Weissman, a former television and stage director, has coached the executives of technology companies on the theater of the initial public offering.

headline: New Phone by Facebook to Showcase Its Network
abstract: Facebook will introduce a version of Google’s Android software system next week that is modified to put the social network front and center on a smartphone. The software will make its debut on a handset made by HTC, said a Facebook employee who had been briefed on the product.
lead_paragraph: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tests Start for Patients of Dentist in Inquiry
abstract: Patients of Dr. W. Scott Harrington are being urged to get tested for H.I.V. and hepatitis B and C, and he is accused of being a “menace to the public health.”
lead_paragraph: The unsanitary practices of a dentist in Tulsa, Okla., may have exposed thousands of patients to H.I.V. and hepatitis, forcing him to close his offices while health officials investigate and test about 7,000 people who had visited him since 2007.

headline: In the Round: Mitsubishi Mirage
abstract: A 360-degree view of the Mitsubishi Mirage at the New York auto show.
lead_paragraph: The Mitsubishi Mirage at the New York auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

headline: Bad Directors and Why They Aren’t Thrown Out
abstract: The track record of the board of Hewlett-Packard is calamitous, and yet they have retained their jobs, because efforts to remove such directors are not always made and rarely succeed.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of shareholder democracy, it’s hard to imagine a more compelling case against a company’s directors than those who presided over the serial management calamities that have plagued the computer giant Hewlett-Packard in recent years.

headline: On the Market in the Region
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A restored home from 1712, the oldest in Newark, N.J., and a four-bedroom clapboard colonial in Nassau County, Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A restored home from 1712, the oldest in Newark, N.J., and a four-bedroom clapboard colonial in Nassau County, Long Island.

headline: Cost of Environmental Damage in China Growing Rapidly Amid Industrialization
abstract: A report from the Ministry of Environmental Protection put the figure at $230 billion in 2010, based on costs rising from pollution and damage to the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The cost of environmental degradation in China was about $230 billion in 2010, or 3.5 percent of the nation’s gross domestic product — three times that in 2004, in local currency terms, an official Chinese news report said this week.

headline: Abbas Pardons Journalist Sentenced for Insulting Him
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority pardoned Mamdouh Hamamreh, who officers said portrayed Mr. Abbas as a traitor on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, has pardoned a Palestinian journalist whose one-year prison sentence for insulting him on Facebook was upheld by a West Bank appeals court on Thursday, the president’s legal adviser said in a statement. The journalist, Mamdouh Hamamreh, was arrested in 2009 after Palestinian intelligence officers said they saw a photograph portraying Mr. Abbas as a traitor on Mr. Hamamreh’s Facebook page. The Palestinian Center for Development and Media Freedoms, a nongovernmental organization based in the West Bank, said that Mr. Hamamreh was not the person who had posted the photograph, nor did he share or “like” it. The president’s legal adviser said that Mr. Abbas respected freedom of opinion and expression and that he had not personally filed a complaint against the journalist.

headline: Money Advice for Doctors and Lawyers and the Rest of Us
abstract: Doctors and lawyers are big earners and smart people, but that does not necessarily mean they’re the best financial decision-makers.
lead_paragraph: IN most places in America, doctors and lawyers are at the top of the career pyramid. They’re often the top earners in town. And they usually live in the nicest neighborhoods and drive expensive cars.

headline: Your ‘Game of Thrones’ Questions, Answered
abstract: David Benioff and D. B. Weiss, the creators of “Game of Thrones,” answered selected questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: Previously we heard from the creators of “Modern Family,” “Homeland,” “Justified” and “New Girl.”

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A condo in Hell’s Kitchen with private outdoor spaces, a Greenwich Village loft in a prewar cast iron building and a Boerum Hill row house with an upper-floor rental.
lead_paragraph: A condo in Hell’s Kitchen with private outdoor spaces, a Greenwich Village loft in a prewar cast iron building and a Boerum Hill row house with an upper-floor rental.

headline: What the Yeah Yeah Yeahs Listened to When They Were Kids
abstract: A playlist of the music that inspired Karen O, Nick Zinner and Brian Chase.
lead_paragraph: Back in the early 2000s, Karen O had a crush on a lame dude. “For whatever reason at that point in my life I was like yeah. I was totally into it,” she told me when I was reporting this weekend’s article about her and her band, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. Out one night at the Cooler, a now-defunct venue in the Meatpacking district in New York, the guy was ignoring her, and she was drowning her sorrows when she saw Debbie Harry at the bar. “I go up to her and I’m like, ‘Yeah, um, I’m in a band and sometimes I just feel like a girl in a boys world.’ She says, ‘Honey, just enjoy it while it lasts.’” At the time, Karen O, whose last name is Orzolek, was horrified. “It felt condescending.” But she has a different take on it now. “She’s right as rain . . . I am a girl in a boys world but . . . it doesn’t really matter, just enjoy it!”

headline: An Aromatic Advantage From Olive Oil?
abstract: The Times’s Anahad O’Connor explains why scientists suggest you don’t have to eat olive oil to benefit from it.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Anahad O’Connor explains why scientists suggest you don’t have to eat olive oil to benefit from it.

headline: What’s the Value of Media?
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download, and what entertainment is worth.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download, and what entertainment is worth.

headline: The Bundesliga’s Soft Underbelly
abstract: Does the lack of a German club in the Europa League quarterfinals, despite the presence of two in the Champions League, say something about the strength or weakness of the rest of the Bundesliga?
lead_paragraph: There are a number of ways to measure the strength of a domestic league in European soccer: the number of challengers for the title; the ability of the league to promote and produce quality young players; or the likelihood of the sides within that league to compete for continental honors. Each statistic tells its own story, and grants a small insight in to the overall health of the league in question.

headline: Mar. 31 — April 6
abstract: A selection of cultural events.
lead_paragraph: That Filipina Diva Kicks Up Her Heels

headline: After the Diagnosis, the Get-Togethers
abstract: This spring, the Alzheimer’s Association plans to launch ‘social engagement’ groups nationwide for people with early-stage dementia.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Kennard Lehmann walked out of a neurologist’s office in Sacramento, Calif., newly diagnosed with early-stage Alzheimer’s disease, a prescription in hand and absolutely no idea where to turn for help.

headline: A Simple Way to Send Poor Kids to Top Colleges
abstract: Basic information can substantially increase the number of low-income students who apply to, attend and graduate from top colleges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Look of the Moment | Ryan Gosling
abstract: Gosling demonstrates how to wear a velvet suit.
lead_paragraph: The Guy: The actor at the premiere of “The Place Beyond the Pines” in New York.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Harlan Coben, whose thriller “Six Years” is at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, has read every book by a fellow native of Newark: Philip Roth.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY BOYS: In all the recent hoopla over Philip Roth’s 80th birthday, nobody much remarked on the existence of another follicle-challenged Jewish novelist born in Newark, 29 years after Roth. But Harlan Coben — whose latest thriller, “Six Years,” goes straight to No. 1 in its first week on the hardcover fiction list — was in a forgiving mood when I reached him on the phone recently. “I’ve read every book Philip Roth has ever written,” he said. “He’s my favorite writer. In fact, when I was growing up in Livingston, N.J., a woman who lived down the street from us was rumored to have been the girl from ‘Goodbye, Columbus.’ I think my mother was the one who told us that. It seemed very exciting and scandalous.”

headline: Suit Claims Ford Failed to Protect Vehicles From Unintended Acceleration
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The suit asks to represent those who leased or bought Ford vehicles manufactured from 2002 to 2010.
lead_paragraph: A class-action suit filed against the Ford Motor Company on Thursday asserted that the automaker knew its vehicles were “vulnerable to sudden unintended acceleration events,” but failed to equip them with a system so that the brake pedal would always overrule the gas pedal.

headline: Florida Gulf Coast, From Plucky Underdog to Chic Pick
abstract: Suddenly, Florida Gulf Coast has become a popular pick to keep its N.C.A.A. tournament upset streak going, this time against Florida.
lead_paragraph: ESPN analysts Digger Phelps and Bruce Pearl have picked Florida Gulf Coast to beat Florida. They did so matter-of-factly, too, like a 15th seed knocking off a No. 3 in the round of 16 is as common as pouring milk on cereal.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Paris, Scotland and New York City
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Paris Haute Couture, Paris There’s vintage, and then there’s historic couture. This show of 100 dresses is the latter. The selection from the Musée Galliera collection — from late-19th-century Worth evening gowns (a 1925 Jean Patou dress is shown right) to an intricately embroidered outfit by John Galliano for Christian Dior — is on view at Paris’s City Hall through July 6.

headline: Voting Irregularities in Kenya Election Are Confirmed, Adding Fuel to Dispute
abstract: Kenya’s Supreme Court released results from a recount in the presidential election that Uhuru Kenyatta won, narrowly avoiding a runoff and clinching the presidency by a few thousand ballots.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The landmark legal challenge to Kenya’s presidential election wrapped up on Friday, and the last bits of evidence confirmed what many had suspected from the beginning: there were definitely voting irregularities, but were they big enough to change the outcome?

headline: A Romance Guided by Stars, Planets and Telescopes
abstract: Sara Schechner and Kenneth Launie bonded over a shared love of science and history.
lead_paragraph: When the call came in April 2004, it was hard for Kenneth Launie to contain his enthusiasm. An amateur collector and restorer of telescopes, he had seen the instrument before, but only behind the glare of a glass case at Harvard. Then, out of nowhere, came the offer: Bring your white gloves and your screwdriver, and take apart the telescope that had been used by John Winthrop, a Harvard professor and descendant of the Massachusetts Bay Colony founder, to observe the transit of Venus in 1769.

headline: U.S. May Sell Airwaves That Help Broadway Sing
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is considering plans to force the users of cordless microphones to move to a less desirable spot on the nation’s airwaves.
lead_paragraph: An hour before curtain at “Mamma Mia!” at the Winter Garden Theater on Broadway, Craig Cassidy, the head sound man, starts his nightly ritual of testing the wireless microphones that the performers wear hidden in their white spandex bell bottoms.

headline: In Ratings Race, ‘The Voice’ Gains on ‘Idol’
abstract: In its first week this season sharing the singing stage with NBC’s “The Voice,” “American Idol,” Fox’s perennial ratings giant, fell to its lowest-rated performances two nights in a row.
lead_paragraph: 3:51 p.m. | Updated Time, and maybe the presence of “The Voice,” seem to be catching up with the great TV ratings titan of the last decade, “American Idol.”

headline: Federal Complaint Against Harroun
abstract: Eric Harroun, a former American soldier, was charged with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syria’s government.
lead_paragraph: Eric Harroun, a former American soldier, was charged with fighting alongside a terrorist group that is battling the Syria’s government.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Pay to Play
keywords: ['Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: David Carr and A.O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download and what entertainment is worth.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about paywalls, what we download and what entertainment is worth.

headline: Landslide Near Seattle Followed Years of Shift
abstract: The earth on Whidbey Island had been moving slowly for years, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: The violent energy of the earth can sometimes feel predictable. An earthquake striking a steep slope of gravel or boulders creates an outcome that even a nongeologist could foresee. Volcanoes can literally move mountains.

headline: You Are Feeling Very ... Uncertain
abstract: Danny Boyle’s “Trance” centers on a triangle made up of an auction house employee (James McAvoy), a criminal (Vincent Cassel) and a beleaguered hypnotherapist (Rosario Dawson).
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, TEX. — Danny Boyle has always been something of a cinematic hypnotist. He has a knack for guiding moviegoers across disparate cinematic terrain using colorful, kinetic visuals and throbbing electronic soundtracks, conjuring immersive worlds that viewers easily fall into.

headline: Good News: U.S. Traffic Is Getting Worse
abstract: American traffic delays are rising for the first time in years. That’s an indication that the economy is getting healthier, according to an analysis by Inrix, a data firm.
lead_paragraph: American traffic delays are rising for the first time in years. That’s an indication that the economy is getting healthier, according to an analysis by Inrix, a data firm.

headline: Infections Tied to Cognitive Decline
abstract: Lower scores on tests of mental function were tied to exposure to common viruses and bacteria like herpes, cytomegalovirus, chlamydia and Helicobacter pylori.
lead_paragraph: A new study adds to the evidence that chronic infection, known to be associated with vascular disease, is also associated with poorer performance on tests of mental ability.

headline: As Economy Heats Up, Traffic Backs Up
abstract: The Inrix Gridlock Index monitors driving time by tracking GPS devices and cellphones; a rising index means economic movement.
lead_paragraph: TRAFFIC is getting worse in the United States, according to a company that monitors driving time by tracking cellphones and GPS devices in cars and trucks.

headline: Not Buying (or Bankrolling) the Easter Bunny
keywords: ['Easter and Holy Week', 'Families and Family Life', 'Gifts', 'Lunar New Year', 'Parenting']
abstract: My friends tell me that the Easter Bunny is all about wonder and magic that I’m too much of a killjoy to appreciate.
lead_paragraph: When a friend of mine who knows that I’m a Santa Claus denier, a Valentine’s Day objector and a St. Paddy’s Day agnostic asked me what I thought about the Easter Bunny, I launched into a rant about traditions where we celebrate joy and wonderment by deceiving our children.

headline: Bentley Showcases Its Craftsmanship at an Atelier
abstract: A leather master and a wooden veneer expert demonstrate what goes into the Flying Spur’s interior details.
lead_paragraph: With an almost Dickensian air of Bob Cratchit sitting at his tall desk, two craftsmen from Bentley’s bespoke studio in Crewe, England, occupied a space on Greenwich Street in Manhattan on Tuesday. They had been transported to Lower Manhattan to showcase the American introduction of the company’s new car, the Flying Spur sedan.

headline: Breaking It Down: Haas vs. Djokovic
abstract: Tommy Haas used an excellent game plan and executed it superbly to upset No. 1 Novak Djokovic Tuesday at the Sony Open in Key Biscayne, Fla.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Tommy Haas had a game plan.

headline: Letter to Patients and Complaint Against Dr. W. Scott Harrington
abstract: The Oklahoma Board of Dentistry accused Dr. Harrington of being “a menace to the public health” by using unsafe and unsanitary practices.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Board of Dentistry accused Dr. Harrington of being “a menace to the public health” by using unsafe and unsanitary practices.

headline: Ayanbadejo, Kluwe to Be Honored for Equality Efforts
keywords: ['Football', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Brendon Ayanbadejo and Chris Kluwe will receive a Straight for Equality in Sports Award from former N.F.L. commissioner Paul Tagliabue.
lead_paragraph: The former N.F.L. commissioner Paul Tagliabue will present an award to players Brendon Ayanbadejo and Chris Kluwe next week, honoring their support of equality for the gay and lesbian community.

headline: Hit or Flop? Expert on Broadway Musicals to Write History Explaining Why
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert (Series)', 'Theater']
abstract: Jack Viertel, the artistic director of Encores!, will explore the architecture of classic shows in “The Secret Life of the Broadway Musical.”
lead_paragraph: Jack Viertel, the artistic director of New York City Center Encores!, has signed a deal with Farrar, Straus & Giroux to write a book about the structure and inner workings of Broadway musicals and why some shows succeed and others falter, the publisher and Mr. Viertel said this week. The book, tentatively titled: “The Secret Life of the Broadway Musical: How Broadway Shows are Built,” is scheduled for publication in winter 2016.

headline: Syria, Iran and the N.R.A. Versus Everybody
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: The treaty to regulate global trade in conventional weapons is essential. But a few pariah states, plus a few interest groups, don’t like it.
lead_paragraph: It was always wishful thinking to expect that all of the United Nations’ 193 member states would approve the treaty regulating global trade in conventional weapons that was negotiated in New York this week. But the conclusion reached on Thursday was stark: On one side, opposing the new pact, were three of the world’s pariah states – Syria, Iran and North Korea. On the other side, favoring the new pact, was … everybody else.

headline: Many Film Languages
abstract: Images of Hollywood actors in non-English films.
lead_paragraph: Images of Hollywood actors in non-English films.

headline: Bilingualism Steps Into a Leading Role
abstract: Actors like Viggo Mortensen, who is fluent in Spanish, are joining Kristin Scott Thomas in working in films performed in a foreign language.
lead_paragraph: In his latest movie, a noir thriller called “Everybody Has a Plan,” Viggo Mortensen plays twin brothers, one a doctor in a midlife crisis, the other a ne’er-do-well mixed up in all kinds of shady business. In her newest offering, “In the House,” Kristin Scott Thomas is cast as an art gallery director whose marriage starts to teeter when her husband, a high school literature teacher, takes an undue interest in a pupil.

headline: Some Veteran Rockers Help to Pass the Torch
abstract: Alice Cooper, Robbie Krieger and others perform at a benefit concert for a rock ‘n’ roll academy.
lead_paragraph: With Alice Cooper approximating Jim Morrison’s trademark alternation of growling intensity and meditative sultriness, and Robby Krieger reprising his vintage guitar solos, a starry band dominated by glam-metal veterans worked their way through the Doors classics “Back Door Man” and “Break On Through (To the Other Side)” on Thursday evening in Sioux Falls, S.D., as part of a concert to benefit the city’s new Brennan Rock & Roll Academy.

headline: Fresh Kicks
abstract: In its latest collaboration with Vans, Kenzo takes leopard and floral cues from Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Vans, a favorite of surfers and skaters, goes for an Asian punk brightly colored look this season. The Kenzo designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim emblazoned the canvas kicks with motifs culled from their spring 2013 collection, which was inspired by a trip to Thailand. While the collection’s colorful leopard spots and bursts of floral prints may be a challenge to pull off on a head-to-toe look, the exuberant pops of pattern on these Vans feel just right. $125; openingceremony.us (beginning Monday).

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: While many Easter workshops may be for children, Neuhaus, the luxury Belgian chocolatier at 500 Madison Avenue in Midtown, is offering one for adults, from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday and 9 to 11 a.m. Saturday. Guests will decorate their own chocolate Easter egg shells and choose pralines to take home in a houndstooth-wrapped package. The class is $75 a person and includes all materials and beverages. Call (212) 644-4490 to make a reservation.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Earth 2’ at No. 1
abstract: “Earth 2″ chronicles a parallel world in which Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman have died.
lead_paragraph: There is an embarrassment of riches on our hardcover and paperback graphic books best-seller lists this week.

headline: Who Wanted to Take the Case on Gay Marriage? Ask Scalia
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: It appears the conservative members of the Supreme Court, calculating that their chances of winning would not get better, were behind the decision to take up the volatile subject.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Why did the Supreme Court agree in December to hear a major same-sex marriage case and then seem to think it had made a terrible mistake on Tuesday when it came time for arguments?

headline: Why Are Boomers Getting S.T.D.s?
abstract: Many baby boomers who start dating again later in life find that sex is readily available. But so are some diseases.
lead_paragraph: Some time back, researchers writing in The New England Journal of Medicine decided to ask older Americans about their sex life and discovered something interesting: very often, they have one.

headline: Strikeouts on the Rise
abstract: Last season, teams struck out at a rate never before seen. Theories as to why hitters are striking out in ever-increasing numbers reflect changes in both pitching and hitting.
lead_paragraph: Last season, teams struck out at a rate never before seen. Theories as to why hitters are striking out in ever-increasing numbers reflect changes in both pitching and hitting.

headline: In Paris, Mixing the Contemporary With the Classics
abstract: Amid the city’s countless historic treasures, several modern-day architectural projects are worth seeking out.
lead_paragraph: While many world capitals feed off the energy of modernity, Paris is loved because it represents an escape from it. So when most people visit the city, their agenda involves visiting monuments like the Louvre, the Hôtel de Ville and Notre Dame. The baby of the group is the Eiffel Tower, built in 1887.

headline: Hiking Beyond Borders in the Balkans
abstract: In the once-tense border region separating Albania, Kosovo and Montenegro, a new trail offers a path for travelers to explore the area’s dramatic beauty.
lead_paragraph: The seasons were changing fast, and the warmth I’d taken for granted had vanished as night mustered in the hills. I gathered the blanket around my neck and listened to the dogs barking below. It was now long past midnight, with only a few hours until the morning call to prayer.

headline: A Book Doctor in Dallas Patches Up Well-Loved Bibles
abstract: The Bibles that Candice McKay repairs can be the marked-up ones of regular churchgoers or ones old enough to have palm leaves stuck in them from when Grover Cleveland was president.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — “We’ll find hair clippings,” Candice McKay, owner of the Book Doctor in Dallas, said last week. “And palm leaves from Palm Sunday. It’s not uncommon.”

headline: Into the Albanian Alps
abstract: Towering peaks, rustic inns and views that span countries on a trek through the Balkans.
lead_paragraph: Towering peaks, rustic inns and views that span countries on a trek through the Balkans.

headline: Guest Workers Are at Crux of Groups’ Deal on Immigration
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Visas', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Progress in talks between top business and labor groups, which had stalled, bolstered hope among a group of senators that they would be able to introduce overhaul legislation soon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top business and labor groups were near agreement Friday on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants, closing in on a deal that would eliminate one of the last significant obstacles to a new proposal for a broad overhaul of immigration laws, officials involved in the talks said.

headline: Why Strikeout Rates Are Soaring
abstract: Strikeout rates have been trending upward for most of the past century, but what has happened in recent years seems to indicate something more. What is the cause?
lead_paragraph: As their strikeout totals piled up last summer, the pitchers for the Milwaukee Brewers hardly noticed. The team was struggling to reach .500, and the rotation had been in flux all year. It did not feel as if the pitching staff was closing in on the record for strikeouts in a season.

headline: Vegetables Make the Sandwich
abstract: The Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers recipes for vegetable-based sandwich fillings to have on hand, and ideas for delicious sandwiches you can build with them.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiches are often about the meat or the cheese between two slices of bread, but with a simple shift of focus, a sandwich can be a healthful showcase for vegetables, as Martha Rose Shulman writes in this week’s Recipes for Health:

headline: In the Round: Kia Sorento SXL V-6
abstract: A 360-degree view of the Kia Sorento SXL V6 at the New York auto show.
lead_paragraph: The Kia Sorento SXL V-6 at the New York auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

headline: Relative of Jailed Chinese Laureate Faces Fraud Charges
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The brother-in-law of Liu Xiaobo, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, is accused in a case that supporters said appeared to be an effort to intimidate the family.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The brother-in-law of Liu Xiaobo, China’s jailed Nobel Peace Prize winner, is likely to face trial soon on fraud charges that a lawyer for the family said on Friday lacked sufficient evidence and that supporters said appeared to be an effort to deter Mr. Liu’s wife from defying house arrest.

headline: Making Big Money, Finally, for Not Striking Out
abstract: The Chicago White Sox value the hitting approach of Jeff Keppinger, whose career average of 15.64 plate appearances per strikeout is the best among active American Leaguers.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Jeff Keppinger is playing for his seventh major league team in 10 years. He has never reached double figures in home runs or stolen bases, has never played in the postseason and has never, until now, played on more than a one-year contract.

headline: On a Cold Night in Brooklyn … a Daredevil Bike Race
abstract: If you were about to compete in a fixed-gear bike race, in the dark, in the cold, your nerves would show, right? The photographer Benedict Evans decided to find out.
lead_paragraph: If you were just about to compete in a fixed-gear bike race, in the dark, in the cold, on a course with some very sharp turns and 30 or so other competitors, your nerves would show, right? At the Red Hook Criterium last year, the photographer Benedict Evans decided to find out. “The idea,” Evans, an avid cyclist himself, told me, “was to set up a kind of portable studio outdoors near the track, but it rained on the day, so I ended up renting the biggest U-Haul truck I could afford, covering the inside of it with black paper, driving it up next to the finish line and coaxing people inside it to be photographed. I figured that anyone willing to ride brakeless bikes around an intricate course in the dark of night would make for an interesting subject.” You can see some of his portraits here, among them that of Dan Chabanov, a bike messenger who has won three of the five races held so far.

headline: Investing as an Art Form, Not a Science
abstract: Bucks readers tell of their own experiences in spending and saving after they got their first jobs.
lead_paragraph: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at the investing prowess of doctors and lawyers — the people who often live in the fanciest houses in town and drive the most expensive cars.

headline: Mets Leave Camp Upbeat Despite Santana’s Injury
abstract: The Mets’ enthusiasm overshadowed the news on Thursday that their ace pitcher, Johan Santana, had retorn a capsule in his pitching shoulder.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A day after Johan Santana learned that he had retorn a capsule in his pitching shoulder, all but ending his career with the Mets, his agent insisted that Santana was not done pitching.

headline: Savage Versus Sumptuous in a Season of Viennese Opera
abstract: With “Parsifal” and “Wozzeck,” the Staatsoper in Vienna exhibits its prowess at performing challenging Wagner operas with little rehearsal time.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Performances of Wagner’s “Parsifal,” with its Christian themes and Good Friday finale, start to swell toward the beginning of the year and crest in the Easter season.

headline: Big Ticket | Terraced Duplex, Sold for $17.75 Million
abstract: A home of the convicted financier Hassan Nemazee that had been seized to repay debts has 15 rooms and 2 terraces.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling duplex co-op on prim Park Avenue that had been owned by Hassan Nemazee, who apparently lived a tad too large before being sentenced in 2010 to 12 years in prison for $292 million in bank fraud, was sold by the federal government for $17.75 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Cutting Up Fennel
abstract: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to cut up fennel to use both the bulb and the fronds.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to cut up fennel to use both the bulb and the fronds.

headline: A Childhood Favorite Grows Up
abstract: Tomato soup with grilled cheese is unbeatable, but grown-up additions like fennel and chile powder take the dish to a higher level.
lead_paragraph: The childhood pleasure of tomato soup with a side of grilled cheese had been enshrined in my mind since I’d last had it, decades ago. A tart, bright tomato soup and a crispy sandwich with an oozing interior: no wonder they are an iconic match.

headline: Judge Says Cambodian Statue Case Can Go Forward
abstract: A federal judge has ruled that the U.S. government can proceed with a case in which it seeks to seize an ancient Cambodian statue that Sotheby’s had sought to sell at auction.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled Friday that the United States government has enough evidence to move forward in court with its effort to seize a 10th century Cambodian statue that Sotheby’s had hoped to sell for $3 million.

headline: For N.C.A.A., AT&T Calls on Pro Basketball Stars
abstract: To take advantage of its sponsorship of the 2013 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, AT&T and its advertising agency are creating commercials with basketball themes that are inspired by the series of well-received commercials for AT&T that carry the theme “It’s not complicated.”
lead_paragraph: A popular series of television commercials is getting stretched out, literally and figuratively.

headline: The Original Digital Pet Returns for a New Generation
abstract: Tamagotchi, which was introduced 16 years ago, is making a comeback as an app, which released on Thursday for iOS devices.
lead_paragraph: Making the most of a recent nostalgia trend in technology that has brought back brands like Furby and Pac-Man, Bandai is reintroducing Tamagotchi, the digital pet from the 1990s, as a lifestyle brand called Tamagotchi L.I.F.E. (for Love Is Fun Everywhere).

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ and the Fantasy Author’s Challenge
abstract: Why George R.R. Martin broke out, and other fantasists don’t.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for this weekend’s premiere of season 3 of “Game of Thrones,” John Lanchester has a fine London Review of Books essay on the show, the George R.R. Martin books, and fantasy fiction’s place in literary culture today. I recommend reading the whole piece (so long as you don’t mind significant spoilers), but I was struck by this meditation on fantasy’s longstanding segregation from more respectable forms of fiction:

headline: Grandfathers’ Age Linked to Autism
abstract: Researchers have found that the older a man is when his child is born, the greater the risk for autism in his grandchild.
lead_paragraph: Older paternal age has been linked to autism in a man’s offspring, but now researchers have found that the older a man is when his child is born, the greater the risk for autism in his grandchild.

headline: Designer Fashion, but Only So Much
abstract: Bobbi Brown says she doesn’t feel comfortable in high-end clothing and slips back into T-shirts and jeans whenever possible.
lead_paragraph: Bobbi Brown, 55, is the founder and chief creative officer of the makeup line that bears her name. A Chicago native and mother of three sons, Ms. Brown lives in Montclair, N.J., with her husband, Steven Plofker, a real estate developer.

headline: After Photo Goes Viral, ‘Dufnering’ Becomes a Thing
abstract: The golf world has had a good laugh over a photograph of Jason Dufner that Keegan Bradley posted on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: HUMBLE, Tex. – Everywhere you looked at the Houston Open, golfers were holding their poses Friday. Not their follow-throughs after textbook swings but their imitations of their fellow touring professional Jason Dufner.

lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s former military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, narrowly escaped being struck in the head by a shoe hurled at him outside a courtroom in Karachi on Friday, video of the incident showed.

headline: ‘Prince of Broadway’ Is Becoming King of Delays
abstract: The show, already postponed once, is put off again.
lead_paragraph: 5:37 p.m. | Updated

headline: Fennel Frond Pesto and More
abstract: Don’t throw out those fennel fronds.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video I demonstrate how to dismember a fennel bulb. Then I use both the bulb and some of the fronds in a tomato soup recipe in this week’s column.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Withdraws I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Toys']
abstract: Nearly three years after filing to go public, the retailer, which is backed by private equity, has decided to pull back from a market debut.
lead_paragraph: The stock market may be on a roll, but Toys “R” Us will not be joining the fun.

headline: A Last Chance for ‘Happy Endings’
abstract: The ABC comedy “Happy Endings” returns on Friday night after a two-month hiatus with back-to-back episodes that may be the show’s last chance for salvation.
lead_paragraph: The ABC comedy “Happy Endings” returns on Friday night after a two-month hiatus, with back-to-back episodes that may be the show’s last chance for salvation.

headline: The Emily Posts of the Digital Age
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: Young people “sick of the irony, rudeness and snark that is so prevalent in their online lives” are making a return to the world of manners.
lead_paragraph: Are manners dead? Cellphones, Twitter and Facebook may be killing off the old civilities and good graces, but a new generation of etiquette gurus, good-manner bloggers and self-appointed YouTube arbiters is rising to make old-fashioned protocols relevant to a new generation.

headline: Obama Pushes Plan to Build Roads and Bridges
abstract: Declaring, “Let’s get started rebuilding America,” President Obama promoted a merger of tax breaks, loans and private investment to generate money for projects.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — President Obama came to the congested ocean port here on Friday to promote his plans to rebuild the nation’s “raggedy” roads, bridges, schools and other infrastructure with a marriage of public and private investment.

headline: Her Gig Canceled After Tirade, Michelle Shocked Plays Outside in Protest
abstract: The punk-folk singer showed up outside a club in Santa Cruz, Calif., which had canceled her scheduled performance after she made anti-gay remarks at a San Francisco concert.
lead_paragraph: After the punk-folk singer-songwriter Michelle Shocked made remarks critical of homosexuality and same-sex marriage while performing in San Francisco two weekends ago, clubs around the country responded by canceling bookings they had made with her. But that hasn’t stopped her: Thursday night she turned up outside one such club with her face covered and her mouth taped shut to protest the way she is being treated.

lead_paragraph: Flipping through a recent issue of The New Yorker, I noticed an ad for a handsome-looking bag in brown tooled leather. What caught my eye was the low-key design and dark hue but also the brand: the King Ranch of Texas.

lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. – One more world No. 1 has been toppled at the Sony Open, this time on the women’s doubles side.

headline: Filing Shows Twisting Path to Three-Way Race for Dell
abstract: Dell’s long-awaited proxy filing shines a light on the 45-day “go shop” period that led to the Blackstone Group and Carl C. Icahn challenging the company’s founder, Michael S. Dell, for control of the embattled computer company.
lead_paragraph: Though the race for Dell Inc. has narrowed to three contestants, many more arose over a month ago.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Place Beyond the Pines."

abstract: Bucks readers share their experiences investing in real estate rental properties.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column looks at the pros and cons of investing in rental properties.

headline: Rental Investment May Seem Safer Than It Really Is
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Becoming a landlord can be troublesome, especially if your property needs emergency repairs or if the housing market crashes again.
lead_paragraph: Investing in a tangible asset like real estate may seem to offer a greater sense of control. You can walk through a house, after all, which somehow feels safer than subjecting your savings to the whims of the stock market.
