abstract: Unleash the dragons! Just in time for HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” T’s got a clutch worthy of a Khaleesi.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate this Sunday’s premiere of the third season of HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” unleash the dragons with a clutch worthy of a Khaleesi.

headline: The Coast Along Whidbey, Before and After the Earth Moved
abstract: A landslide that struck an island 50 miles north of Seattle sent the equivalent of 40,000 dump-truck loads of earth heaving toward Puget Sound.
lead_paragraph: A landslide that struck an island 50 miles north of Seattle sent the equivalent of 40,000 dump-truck loads of earth heaving toward Puget Sound.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 29
abstract: Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration “bullpen” at City Hall.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration “bullpen” at City Hall.

headline: Blood, Guts and Hair Spray
abstract: The authors of “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists,” Howie Abrams and Sacha Jenkins, preview their choices for the most embarrassing pieces of art for heavy-metal album covers.
lead_paragraph: IT PROBABLY SEEMED LIKE a good idea at the time for the members of the British glam-metal band Wrathchild to be so peacockishly come-hither on the cover of their 1984 album “Stakk Attakk.” With songs like “Trash Queen” and “Too Wild to Tame,” no doubt they took pride in their toweringly teased locks, baby-doll lips and strappy S-and-M gear. But nearly 30 years later the image doesn’t quite scream Beasts of Metal. It more whispers, Lady Clown.

headline: Timeline: How Michael Dell’s Takeover Bid Got Hatched
abstract: DealBook has compiled a chronology of Silver Lake’s bidding history for Dell, stretching well back to the early days of the computer company’s deliberations about whether to go private.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders may still be irate over the $13.65 a share that Michael S. Dell has bid for the company that bears his name.

headline: Who Are the Best Voices in the History of Metal?
abstract: In a genre in which singers growl, howl, scream and otherwise create vocal mischief, defining a good metal singer can be a challenge. Who do you think has the best metal voice of all time?
lead_paragraph: “Raining Blood” may not be “Harlem Shake,” but to Howie Abrams and Sacha Jenkins it might as well be. Slayer’s popular 1986 song is No. 4 on the list “Our Favorite Songs by the Best Metal Bands,” one of several indexes the authors compiled for “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists,” set for release this month by Abrams Image. The book features scores of compilations of bests (songs, drummers, bass tones), worsts (“10 Heavy Metal Fashion Faux Pas”) and the only-in-metal (“10 Illegible Black Metal Logos”).

headline: Students Nod to Forefathers of Styles
abstract: Students from the Royal Ballet School and American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company shared a program at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: For a few decades now, some of the top ballet schools and companies of various nations have brought their foremost students and apprentices together in exchanges and public sharings. The results in performance can be enchanting, fascinating, perplexing, frustrating — sometimes all at once. On Tuesday, when the Royal Ballet School and American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company shared a program at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, all the young dancers were very appealing; some rose to their challenges with particular skill.

headline: Southern Town in Syria Is Seized by Rebel Fighters
abstract: If confirmed, the takeover of the town, Dael, would represent a new setback to Syrian forces, who have already ceded territory in the north and east.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Syrian antigovernment activists reported the rebel seizure of a strategically important town in southern Syria on Friday only a few miles from the Jordanian border, which if confirmed would represent a new setback for government forces, who have already ceded territory to the insurgency in the north and east.

headline: Reimagining a Brawny Jeep for a Less Rugged Landscape
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'New York International Auto Show']
abstract: Jeep says the look of the new Cherokee reflects two sides of the brand’s personality. The upper half is sleek and streamlined, the lower tough and rugged.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Jeep came to New York, of all places, to take the wraps off a new S.U.V. with an old name: the Cherokee.

headline: Jeep Opts for Sleek
abstract: Boxy, rough-riding S.U.V.’s have faded in favor of car-based crossovers aimed at younger, more suburban customers. To keep up with that trend, Jeep gave its 2014 Cherokee a softer look.
lead_paragraph: Boxy, rough-riding S.U.V.’s have faded in favor of car-based crossovers aimed at younger, more suburban customers. To keep up with that trend, Jeep gave its 2014 Cherokee a softer look.

headline: Another Sport Franchise for Ford
abstract: The 2013 Ford Explorer Sport is a seven-seat S.U.V. that  lives up to its name, with more power and better handling than the base Explorer.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2013 Ford Explorer Sport

headline: Fast-Food Union Organizers Get Some Historical Perspective
abstract: Two sanitation workers from the successful 1968 strike in Memphis that drew the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered a series of pep talks to fast-food servers in New York facing an uphill campaign to unionize.
lead_paragraph: When Alvin Turner and Baxter Leach joined a strike in Memphis in 1968, they were two sanitation workers protesting the abuse of black employees and demanding higher wages and the recognition of their union. They recalled being beaten and assaulted with tear gas by the police during marches. But after more than 60 days, the strike ended with the city granting many of their demands.

headline: Something Borrowed From the Past
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Dresses', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: The silhouette of these vintage gowns and the variety of options for accessories are the attraction.
lead_paragraph: The latest wedding fashions are inspired by a couple who didn’t work out so well and by a television series that has been a resounding success.

headline: A Swagger Retooled for 1908
abstract: Jeremy Piven, who plays the lead role in the eight-part PBS series “Mr. Selfridge,” says he relates to the pathbreaking department store founder.
lead_paragraph: JEREMY PIVEN IS BEST KNOWN as the venal, tantrum-throwing superagent Ari Gold on HBO’s hit comedy “Entourage”; as an alumnus of the Piven Theater Workshop in Chicago, founded by his parents, Joyce and Byrne Piven; and as the center of a highly publicized 2009 breach-of-contract dispute after he left a Broadway production of “Speed-the-Plow” two months early, citing exhaustion and mercury poisoning. (Mr. Piven won in arbitration.)

headline: Drive by Wire, an Aerospace Solution
abstract: A new application of so-called drive-by-wire technology, to be available on the 2014 Infiniti Q50 sedan, may attract some attention. Except during emergencies, that car’s steering wheel will have no mechanical connection to the front wheels.
lead_paragraph: So long as their car moves when the pedal is pressed, there is little reason for drivers of newer cars to care whether electronics have replaced the physical connection between the accelerator and the engine.

headline: Beyond All-Wheel Drive, All-Wheel Steering
abstract: The 2014 Acura RLX, on display at the New York auto show, has a feature that Acura calls Precision All-Wheel Steer, which is intended to improve handling by adding steering capability to the rear wheels.
lead_paragraph: The notion of making vehicles turn better by steering all four of their wheels has inspired engineers for decades. The United States Army experimented with all-wheel-steering jeeps during World War II, and the benefits to maneuverability of rear-steering have long been known to firefighters assigned to hook-and-ladder trucks.

headline: Celebrating With Beer, Not Bubbly
abstract: While New Yorkers will see the usual Lotto-winner fantasies at the auto show, which opened to the public on Friday. the most important debuts run to entry-price luxury cars and mainstream models.
lead_paragraph: Shrinking unemployment, healthy sales, shoppers flexing their tire-kicking legs: carmakers selling in the revived North American market have much to celebrate at the New York International Auto Show, which opened on Friday.

headline: A Big Gulp in the Czech Republic
abstract: The biggest wine bottle in the Czech Republic, according to the Guiness Book of Records.
lead_paragraph: A representative of the Guinness World Records measures a giant bottle of wine in Cejkovice, in southern Czech Republic. At more than two meters in height, and containing 200 liters of wine, it has been declared the largest wine bottle in the Czech Republic.

headline: A Few Thoughts on Her Shoes
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: There are many styles that differ from the traditional white shoe for the bride.
lead_paragraph: It’s not only about the dress. For some brides these days, the shoes are commanding as much attention as the gown. Brides are kicking aside the classic white or ivory pumps in favor of bright pops of color, floral patterns, those bedazzled with bling, accentuated with feathers and lace, and even their own customized pair.

headline: Your Favorite Bowls
abstract: Consider the bowl, the most common of household objects. We asked readers to send images of their favorite bowls and tell us what makes them special.
lead_paragraph: Consider the bowl, the most common of household objects. We asked readers to send images of their favorite bowls and tell us what makes them special.

headline: Vows: Vintage-Inspired Style
abstract: The wedding style guru Mark Ingram and the Styles reporter Bee-Shyuan Chang discuss the 1920s style wedding trend and offer ways to incorporate a little Daisy Buchanan into your wedding-day look.
lead_paragraph: The wedding style guru Mark Ingram and the Styles reporter Bee-Shyuan Chang discuss the 1920s style wedding trend and offer ways to incorporate a little Daisy Buchanan into your wedding-day look.

headline: Wedding Gowns That Evoke A Bygone Era
abstract: Bridal gowns that recall the look of “The Great Gatsby” are growing increasingly popular this wedding season.
lead_paragraph: Bridal gowns that recall the look of “The Great Gatsby” are growing increasingly popular this wedding season.

headline: The Pictures from the Week in Culture, March 29
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including performances by Taylor Swift and Sigur Ros.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week including performances by Taylor Swift and Sigur Ros.

headline: Bipartisan Rebuke for Republican Congressman Who Used Slur
abstract: Representative Don Young of Alaska apologized for using the slur to describe Hispanic farm workers who picked tomatoes on his father’s ranch.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from Congressional leaders and advocacy groups, Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, has apologized for describing Hispanic farm workers who picked tomatoes on his father’s ranch as “wetbacks” in an interview.

headline: Listening to the Leukocytes and Moving Beyond James Brown
abstract: Music from Steve Coleman and Five Elements and Charles Bradley are among new releases.
lead_paragraph: Steve Coleman and Five Elements

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, March 29
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: 'Game of Thrones' Fans Flourish
abstract: The Times's Dave Itzkoff on why a fantasy television show set in medieval times is catching fire with a broad audience.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Dave Itzkoff on why a fantasy television show set in medieval times is catching fire with a broad audience.

headline: Ex-Schools Chief in Atlanta Is Indicted in Testing Scandal
abstract: A third-grade teacher’s 2010 choice to aid a state investigator helped lead to the indictment Friday of a former superintendent and 34 others in a vast alleged cheating scheme.
lead_paragraph: During his 35 years as a Georgia state investigator, Richard Hyde has persuaded all sorts of criminals — corrupt judges, drug dealers, money launderers, racketeers — to turn state’s evidence, but until Jackie Parks, he had never tried to flip an elementary school teacher.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Ugly Photos, and Delivery by Google
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include an easy and free way to file tax returns that has been fought for years by Intuit, a chart showing many of Amazon’s acquisitions and a museum-quality exhibit of Apple material that will appear at the Vintage Computer Festival Southeast in April.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: In Relocating, a Bar Will Lose No Claim to Celluloid Fame
abstract: The Emerald Inn, the Upper West Side bar that was the setting for a scene in the movie “The Apartment,” is moving to the site of a bar that figured in another, much darker, movie, “Looking for Mr. Goodbar.”
lead_paragraph: The Emerald Inn, the Upper West Side bar that was the setting for a scene in the movie “The Apartment,” is moving to the site of a bar that figured in another, much darker, movie, “Looking for Mr. Goodbar.”

headline: Fogging Up the Windows of a Big Store
abstract: Edwardian England is revisited with “Mr. Selfridge,” a mini-series about the founder of the London department store Selfridges in 1909.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Selfridge” is an eight-part, roughly eight-hour mini-series about the American businessman who opened the revolutionary London department store Selfridges in 1909. It’s also a soldier in the current bloody war for period-drama domination between the British television networks ITV and BBC, whose combatants include “Downton Abbey” and “Mr. Selfridge,” on ITV, and “Call the Midwife” and “The Paradise,” on BBC. (Already dead: BBC’s flat-footed “Upstairs Downstairs” sequel.)

headline: The Rewards of Being Very Serious
abstract: Think about the revolving door.
lead_paragraph: A while back, before moving to Slate, Matthew Yglesias had what I considered a brilliant insight into the incentives facing small-country political leaders:

headline: One Woman, Multiplying Identities
abstract: In “Orphan Black,” a young woman juggles two identities, and all the nightmares that come with them.
lead_paragraph: It may not be entirely clear to you from the first episode why BBC America is billing “Orphan Black,” its new suspense series, as part of its “Supernatural Saturday” programming block, alongside “Doctor Who.” But by the end of the second episode, this tasty show starts to reveal that it is not just another identity-swapping story. Something creepily sci-fi is definitely going on.

headline: A Robot for Part of the Pit Crew
abstract: The Pentagon, in an effort to develop low-cost artificial hands, has built a robot that can take a tire off a car. Putting it back on is another problem altogether.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon, in an effort to develop low-cost artificial hands, has built a robot that can take a tire off a car. Putting it back on is another problem altogether.

headline: Justin Bieber and Youth’s New Wilderness
abstract: Hard-working under-age performers disrupt our sense of childhood as a period of all play and no work.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber has had it rough of late. Even before this week’s news that his neighbor was accusing him of battery, the 19-year-old Canadian superstar endured a public breakup with his girlfriend, Selena Gomez; was photographed supposedly reveling with codeine-spiked cough syrup and marijuana, and was snubbed by the Grammys. He retaliated with a live-stream Internet performance that hit technical snags.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Modern Man
abstract: The people behind me, they don’t understand.
lead_paragraph: My late-in-life odyssey through current music began when Arcade Fire’s The Suburbs won the Grammy for best album, and I decided for some reason to give them a listen — and was shocked to discover that good music didn’t end in the 1970s. Since then I’ve found many bands I love, but I do keep coming back to AF — and I keep finding new depths in that album. Here’s a quiet one:

headline: Still Dancing Freely at 50, in 50 Birthday Duets
abstract: Lance Gries’s 50th-birthday project, with 50 dancers, at La MaMa La Galleria.
lead_paragraph: The number 50 figures prominently in the choreographer and teacher Lance Gries’s new video installation, which he created in honor of his 50th birthday. For it he asked 50 dancers to each join him for a 50-minute improvisatory duet.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a New Diabetes Drug From J.&J.
abstract: Clinical trials for the drug, Invokana, showed that it improved patients’ blood-sugar levels and also led to weight loss and reductions in blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first of a new class of medicines to treat diabetes.

headline: The Dark Stuff, Distilled
abstract: As head writer for “The Americans,” Joseph Weisberg makes good use of his time in the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph Weisberg was training to be a case officer for the C.I.A. in the early 1990s, he soon learned that deception was a crucial skill, one that involved lying to his family on a regular basis.

headline: AIDS Memorial Loses Plants and Gains Supporters
abstract: The structure planned in Greenwich Village got through city review by shedding its garden trellis look and introducing a dip in its roof that opened up the view.

headline: An Unlikely Jihadist, Denouncing Assad in Mandarin
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A video that seems to show a Han Chinese man working for the overthrow of the Assad government is raising eyebrows in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The man in camouflage fatigues raised his Kalashnikov rifle and fired three shots into the air while trudging through a field of purple and yellow flowers.

headline: Europe’s Second Depression: A Correction
abstract: It’s worse than I thought.
lead_paragraph: Aha — in my post on Europe’s policy failure, I somehow failed to notice that the new Maddison dataset provides per capita real GDP, which means that I should use per capita GDP in looking at the current crisis. And my point about dismal performance gets even stronger:

headline: What Dell Thought of Alternatives to the Silver Lake Proposal
abstract: Buried in Dell’s proxy filings is a presentation that JPMorgan Chase bankers delivered to a special committee of Dell’s board on Jan. 18, explaining the downsides of alternatives to a full leveraged buyout.
lead_paragraph: Dell Inc. directors have repeatedly emphasized that they considered all potential ways to improve value for shareholders before accepting a $24.4 billion takeover bid by Michael S. Dell and the investment firm Silver Lake.

headline: Taking Flight to a Land of Noodles
abstract: Sun Noodle, with its gleaming 6,000-square-foot Teterboro factory and “ramen lab,” makes and sells 100,000 servings a week of more than 30 varieties of noodles.
lead_paragraph: TETERBORO, N.J. — Before Sun Noodle held its first “ramen flight” here earlier this month, George Kao, the company’s sales manager and host of the event, was up until 1 a.m. studying his notes. The five participants in the combination culinary class and tasting probably would have shown up, though, even without the educational part of the program.

headline: Feeling Less Guilt and Doing Some Good
abstract: Spending money to aid charity, with a purchase as a bonus.
lead_paragraph: The first summer I ever earned any money, I started reading the utilitarian philosopher Peter Singer, who had a few ideas about how I should spend it. To Mr. Singer, since it is cheap to save lives in the third world, we are culpable if we have the cash and don’t help save them. “If you would save a child from drowning in a pond, even if it meant ruining your expensive shoes,” he wrote, “then shouldn’t you also save a child from drowning in poverty, for the cost of your expensive shoes?”

headline: Ex-Soldier Accused of Joining Terrorist Group in Syria Left Trail of Videos
abstract: Eric Harroun was arrested on Wednesday after arriving at an airport outside Washington and charged in Alexandria, Va., on Thursday with “conspiring to use a destructive device outside the United States.”
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Scott Shane reports, a former American soldier was charged on Thursday with fighting alongside a rebel group linked to Al Qaeda on the battlefields of the Syrian civil war.

headline: Where the Recipes Call for Sharing
abstract: At Saigonese, traditional Vietnamese dishes are offered in large portions for the health and taste conscious, with seasoning that is unlikely to offend.
lead_paragraph: Traditional Vietnamese cuisine has the reputation of being one of the healthiest in the world. Considering in the growing popularity of foods that are not only tasty, but also healthful, Saigonese could not have arrived in Hartsdale at a better time. Cooking in this restaurant’s kitchen is about quick preparations of fresh ingredients with masses of dewy herbs (parsley, mint, sweet basil and cilantro). Few items are deep fried.

headline: Applause in Unlikely Places: A Conductor Who Rewrites the Rules
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel led the Los Angeles Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall for two programs this week.
lead_paragraph: During the “Infernal Dance” of Stravinsky’s “Firebird,” which depicts the subjects of the ogre Kastchei spinning with such savagery that they drop in exhaustion, the music builds to vehement, searing chords. In his performance of the complete “Firebird” on Thursday night with the Los Angeles Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, the second of two programs, Gustavo Dudamel drew such blazing colors, slashing attacks and sheer terror from the orchestra that at the climax of the dance some people in the hall broke into applause and shouted “Bravo.” This temporarily drowned out the transition that immediately follows: the powerful chords disperse to reveal mysterious, hushed sonorities.

headline: Emcee
abstract: An emcee at a Jamaican dancehall party.
lead_paragraph: An emcee at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: A Colorful Palette for a Multicultural Cuisine
abstract: At Cora Cora, Hector Ludena and Luisa Jimenez take guests on a tour of Peru’s vivid and robust cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Rooted in street food, chicken shacks and back-alley cebicherias, Peruvian food has won praise in recent years from such cosmopolitan chefs as Ferran Adrià and Dan Barber. And the king of Peruvian restaurants in central Connecticut is Cora Cora, where Hector Ludena and Luisa Jimenez take guests on a tour of their country’s vivid and robust cuisine.

headline: New Police Chief Confident He Can Handle Job
abstract: Philip Banks III, the newly minted head of the Police Department, said he would strive to empower people in the community and work with them to further reduce crime.
lead_paragraph: The first question was simple: What made you want to become a police officer?

headline: To Replace Old Cobblestones, Old-Looking Cobblestones
abstract: To make the streets of Dumbo and Vinegar Hill more accessible and bike-friendly, the city is offering to install new stones that are aged artificially, like a pair of stonewashed jeans.
lead_paragraph: They have survived in Brooklyn’s northwestern corner for over a century — handmade and rounded, their shades weathered to a medley of noble grays — rattling the frames of carriages and Chryslers, buses and bicycles beside the waterfront.

headline: Making Robots Mimic the Human Hand
abstract: The Pentagon has invented a two-armed robot that can remove a tire from a car, and released the video.
lead_paragraph: As part of a national research project to develop low-cost artificial hands, the Pentagon has released a video of a robot that can change a tire — almost.

headline: Reducing Gun Violence: What Works?
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Readers react to a column by David Brooks questioning the effectiveness of gun control.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Charisma, Wealth, Flattery. How Can She Resist?
abstract: In “Temptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor,” a moralizing film directed by Tyler Perry, a bored wife succumbs easily to the blandishments of a wealthy man.
lead_paragraph: The actor, director and playwright Tyler Perry has long embraced religion in his films, but perhaps never more so than in his slack fable “Temptation: Confessions of a Marriage Counselor.” Adapted from his 2008 play, “The Marriage Counselor,” the movie inveighs against deviation from the church, monogamy and the righteous path of cooking meals for a husband.

headline: Questions for an Expert on North Korean Propaganda
abstract: Since it is easy to focus on the accidental comedy in North Korean propaganda, The Lede asked B. R. Myers, an expert on the subject, what he makes of the isolated nation’s current saber rattling.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Saturday, 12:35 p.m. As my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reports, North Korea’s state news agency released the latest in a series of saber-rattling images on Friday, this time showing the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, studying what the agency called “plans to strike the mainland U.S.”

headline: Indictments in Atlanta Public Schools Cheating Scandal
abstract: A grand jury indicted Beverly L. Hall, the former superintendent of the Atlanta Public Schools, and 34 others on charges connected to one of the largest test-score cheating scandals in the country.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury indicted Beverly L. Hall, the former superintendent of the Atlanta Public Schools, and 34 others on charges connected to one of the largest test-score cheating scandals in the country.

headline: Developing New Drugs
abstract: Pfizer writes about its use of publicly funded research.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Subversion, Cool and Collected
abstract: Two late masterpieces from Luis Buñuel — “Tristana” (1970) and “That Obscure Object of Desire” (1977) — come to Blu-ray in restored versions.
lead_paragraph: Luis Buñuel began his career as a filmmaker with a Dadaist determination to shock and outrage. He cast himself as the square-jawed dandy who, at the beginning of his first film, “Un Chien Andalou” (1929), impassively draws a straight razor across the eyeball of a compliant young woman without troubling to remove the cigarette from his mouth.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: The bailout in Cyprus was completed, and banks there reopened, albeit under tight capital controls; T-Mobile, now selling the iPhone, introduced a new billing plan; and a top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was arrested.
lead_paragraph: The bailout in Cyprus was completed, and banks there reopened, albeit under tight capital controls; T-Mobile, now selling the iPhone, introduced a new billing plan; and a top portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was arrested.

headline: Poor Baby: Daddy’s Got a Text Message
abstract: Readers react to an essay calling for more personal interaction and less texting.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Italian Classics, Served With Fun
abstract: Toro Pazzo in Wantagh offers more than good food: it provides an atmosphere in which patrons can enjoy themselves.
lead_paragraph: Chris Santoro has a sense of humor. The owner of Toro Pazzo, a year-and-a-half-old restaurant in Wantagh, Mr. Santoro said playfully that his name could be translated as “holy bull” in Italian, so he chose as the restaurant’s logo a snorting bull with a halo.

headline: Hollande Draws Bad Reviews as He Answers Critics on TV
abstract: Already low in opinion polls, President François Hollande was seen as less than inspiring as he answered questions about France’s ailing economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande, low in the opinion polls less than a year into the job, went on national television for over an hour on Thursday night in what French commentators likened to an “oral exam” on his job performance.

headline: Nature’s Case for Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Reproduction (Biological)']
abstract: The biological evidence right outside the Supreme Court’s chambers makes a natural case for gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: BIOLOGY has returned to the nation’s highest court. It’s not Darwin’s theory of evolution on the docket this time, but the nature of sex. Defenders of Proposition 8, California’s ban on gay marriage, base their case on what they call the “objective biological fact” that procreation is an exclusively heterosexual process. Citing the 18th-century English jurist William Blackstone, they argue that marriage should be “founded in nature.”

headline: Roster Moves Leave Mets With Two Spots to Fill
abstract: Landon Powell, sent down to Las Vegas, was grappling with the death in the off-season of his 5-month old daughter Izzy, who had an autoimmune disease.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets made several roster moves Friday after they played their final home spring training game. Outfielder Marlon Byrd and pitchers Scott Atchison, LaTroy Hawkins and Scott Rice made the team, while Robert Carson and Omar Quintanilla were sent to Las Vegas, where the Mets have their Class AAA franchise.

headline: Celebrating a Writer Who Put Poetry in Pop
abstract: Marissa Mulder takes on the challenging songs of Tom Waits in a cabaret setting at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: Among the countless songs written from a soldier’s point of view, none is more wrenching than Tom Waits and Kathleen Brennan’s “Day After Tomorrow,” a 21-year-old serviceman’s letter to his Illinois family on the eve of his homecoming. He reflects in a song that is beyond bitter:

headline: Silodor Open Pairs
abstract: Billy Cohen of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and David Bakhshi from England won the Silodor Open Pairs in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: At 12:30 p.m. on Thursday, March 21, Billy Cohen of Sherman Oaks, Calif., was getting ready to watch college basketball on his hotel room’s wide-screen television in St. Louis, the site of the Spring North American Championships.

headline: Names of the Dead
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,174 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,174 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: A New Dance Move
abstract: An evolving dance move is performed in a Jamaican dance hall.
lead_paragraph: An evolving dance move is performed in a Jamaican dance hall.

headline: Just Folk, Inspired by Hungary and Romania
abstract: On the eve of a European tour, the members of a Hawk and a Hacksaw discuss their Eastern European influences and their new album, inspired by a 1960s Soviet film.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, the duo known as a Hawk and a Hacksaw have been exploring the traditional music of Eastern Europe from a distinctly American folk-pop perspective. Though the accordion player Jeremy Barnes was formerly the drummer in Neutral Milk Hotel, and the violinist and pianist Heather Trost played on Beirut’s first two records, their inspiration now comes mostly from places like Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Macedonia.

headline: Jamaican Dancehall Dancing
abstract: Dancing at a Jamaican dancehall party.
lead_paragraph: Dancing at a Jamaican dancehall party.

abstract: Some new fashion at a Jamaican dancehall party.
lead_paragraph: Some new fashion at a Jamaican dancehall party.

lead_paragraph: A woman performs a dance move at a party in Jamaica.
