headline: Nominee for Energy Secretary Lists Assets and Posts
abstract: Ernest J. Moniz, President Obama’s nominee for energy secretary, agreed to resign his positions and sell shares if confirmed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee for energy secretary, Ernest J. Moniz, is a consultant to the energy giant BP and a member of the advisory council and board of trustees of King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center, of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, among other positions, according to disclosure statements filed with the government and released on Friday.

headline: Dancing at a Jamaican Dancehall Party
abstract: Partygoers dance at a Jamaican dancehall party.
lead_paragraph: Partygoers dance at a Jamaican dancehall party.

headline: Oscars Group Asks for Advice
abstract: In an unusual move, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has summoned its members for a discussion about the future of the group.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is inviting its roughly 6,000 members to join what promises to be an unusual group discussion of something that has set off much private debate here recently: the Academy’s future.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Change of Tune in Caramoor’s Music Room
abstract: An experimental series at Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts will present roots music, filtered through a modern sensibility.
lead_paragraph: KATONAH, N.Y. — Nestled amid the stucco buildings on the sprawling campus of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, the Rosen House Music Room, known for the Renaissance artifacts collected by Caramoor’s onetime owners, Walter and Lucie Rosen, is a stately space where decorous string quartets and the like usually play. So when Caramoor hired the raucous roots group Spuyten Duyvil to entertain at a media event in the room this month, traditionalists found the choice less than wholly palatable.

headline: At Twain’s Home, an Era He Skewered
abstract: “The Gilded Age of Hartford” includes plenty of Mark Twain’s wit, but it also depicts cruelty and prejudice beneath Hartford’s late-Victorian prosperity.
lead_paragraph: You would expect to be amused at an exhibition generously peppered with the wit and wisdom of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, the writer better known as Mark Twain. And the new show at the Mark Twain House and Museum, “The Gilded Age of Hartford,” does indeed deliver entertainment as it documents the rising fortunes and changing social framework of Hartford in the 1870s, ’80s and ’90s.

headline: Turin Shroud Going on TV, With Video From Pope
abstract: The linen cloth revered by many Christians as the burial cloth of Jesus is also getting its own app.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Shroud of Turin, which since medieval times has been revered by many Christians as the burial cloth of Jesus, is about to make its debut on modern media platforms.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The New Man
abstract: The men’s fashion revolution is in full swing, with looks ranging from ’30s styles to a revival of grunge and mouth grilles.
lead_paragraph: The men’s fashion revolution is in full swing, with looks ranging from ’30s styles to a revival of grunge and mouth grilles.

headline: Ohio Fangirls Embark on a Perilous Quest
abstract: In “Geek!,” a Vampire Cowboys production written by Crystal Stillman, a day at an anime convention in Ohio requires battles and frequent costume changes.
lead_paragraph: With “Geek!” the playwright Crystal Skillman and the troupe Vampire Cowboys fly high the freak flag of fantasy. An ode to fangirls and fanboys, the show, in Cowboys tradition, celebrates the universe of anime, comics, science fiction, manga and Hollywood effects spectaculars. It’s a milieu Ms. Skillman clearly knows well and depicts with affection.

headline: Week in Pictures for March 29
abstract: Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration “bullpen” at City Hall.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the opening of amusement parks in Coney Island, a dodgeball marathon and the Bloomberg administration “bullpen” at City Hall.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Falling to Earth, Only to Witness a Pole Dance
abstract: The National Asian-American Theater Company’s “Dream Play” adapts the Strindberg drama about the daughter of a goddess who sets out to understand what makes human beings tick.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to be fascinated by our own dreams. Yet when the dreams of others are recounted to us, so much gets lost in translation. Or, to put it more plainly: suffering through someone else’s jump cuts and surreal metaphors can be tedious  as all get-out.

headline: Earnestly, Internationally in Search of Love
abstract: Composed in nearly 40 fleeting scenes set across the globe, “Roundelay” presents characters who speak longingly about achieving meaningful relationships.
lead_paragraph: A romance that whirls halfway around the world, “Roundelay: A Comedy” skips back and forth from America to India, Kenya and the Caribbean as its multicultural characters either pursue love or run away from it. The Passage Theater Company’s production of R. N. Sandberg’s new play at the Mill Hill Playhouse in Trenton offers a pleasant, if somewhat hectic, sojourn with 10 individuals of varying ethnicities who all yearn for love.

headline: Focus on Healing Arts After Kidnapping Conviction
abstract: Tomás Cassella, a former Uruguayan Army colonel who was extradited to Chile in 2006, has become a reiki master, but is living in legal limbo as he appeals his case.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile

headline: Events on Long Island
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: The Young Germans Who Stood Up to the Nazis
abstract: Jud Newborn, a Holocaust scholar, will present a multimedia lecture on the White Rose resistance movement, a small, student-based group that wrote and printed anonymous anti-Nazi leaflets.
lead_paragraph: Jud Newborn, a Holocaust scholar who lives in Plainview, was doing research in Munich as a graduate student in the early 1980s when he became intrigued with the story of the White Rose resistance movement. The small, student-based group wrote and printed anonymous anti-Nazi leaflets in Munich and distributed them in that city and beyond before its key members were captured and executed in 1943.

headline: Hospitals Question Medicare Rules on Readmissions
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: In response to new federal regulations, institutions are spending millions to help patients avoid returning to the hospital, but some say that the penalties they seek to avoid are unjust.
lead_paragraph: It is no longer enough for hospitals to make patients healthy enough to leave. Now, as part of the Obama administration’s health care overhaul, they are spending millions of dollars to keep those patients from coming back, often acting like personal assistants to help them manage their post-hospital lives.

headline: From the Swinging ’60s, a Recipe for Farce
abstract: In “Boeing-Boeing,” now onstage at the Engeman Theater at Northport, one bachelor has a trio of lovers, each one thinking she is his one and only.
lead_paragraph: The eight sturdy doors that surround the living room of a Paris apartment in Marc Camoletti’s “Boeing-Boeing” are a good tip-off that a farce is about to ensue. So is the setup — one bachelor, three fiancées — which is outlined early on by the bachelor, an American architect named Bernard.

headline: The Harsh and Haunting Winds of Sept. 11
abstract: The University of Kansas Wind Ensemble came to Carnegie Hall to introduce Mohammed Fairouz’s Symphony No. 4, based on a graphic-novel memoir by Art Spiegelman.
lead_paragraph: For many casual observers, the term “wind ensemble” will conjure up notions of earnest students huffing and thumping through Sousa marches and college fight songs. But aficionados, and those who have played in a university wind ensemble during the last 30 years or so, know that such groups now constitute a bona fide hotbed of opportunity for contemporary composers. Neo-Romantics, avant-gardists and postclassical eclectics have heeded the call, lured by generous commissions, multiple performances, and rehearsal time measured in weeks instead of hours.

headline: Blossoming Colt Stirs Up Dreams Set in Kentucky
abstract: Eddie Plesa Jr., a little-known trainer, has a leading Kentucky Derby contender in Itsmyluckyday, a slight 2-1 favorite to win the Florida Derby.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Itsmyluckyday stops while walking the shed row in Barn 74 at Calder Race Course to gaze at his reflection in the glass door that leads into the office of Eddie Plesa Jr., his trainer. He leans his head to the right and peers intently as if to say, “Is that really me?”

headline: Libya Arrests 2 Men in Attack on 5 British Aid Activists
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Sex Crimes', 'Kidnapping', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: At least two of the activists, who were abducted at a checkpoint near Benghazi, Libya, were women and were sexually assaulted.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libyan security officials said Friday that they had arrested two men in the kidnapping this week in eastern Libya of five British humanitarian activists, at least two of them women who had been sexually assaulted.

headline: Women (and Men) Face Big Hurdles in Training for Marine Infantry Units
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A training course in Quantico, Va., was the most recent test of the goal of placing women in the toughest combat roles.
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va. — A group of Marine second lieutenants, all men, stood before the ropes on an obstacle course. They looked exhausted, though the day was far from done. One by one, they took their shots at scaling the line. One by one, most of them dropped short of the top. They were already three hours behind the front-runners in their class.

headline: The Point Man of Syracuse’s Tournament Run
abstract: Syracuse guard Michael Carter-Williams has managed to deliver his finest performance of the season during the N.C.A.A. tournament in the wake of personal adversity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gerry McNamara still participates in an occasional practice at Syracuse. Not far removed from his playing career, McNamara is the youngest assistant on Coach Jim Boeheim’s staff, so the onus often falls on him to get out there and compete.

headline: With Policy Moves, Quinn Defuses de Blasio’s Attacks in Race for Mayor
abstract: Christine C. Quinn has been embracing more liberal positions, creating a problem for Bill de Blasio, whose mayoral campaign has been geared toward shaming her into such a shift.
lead_paragraph: He has hammered her over the surging level of fines against small businesses, chided her for not demanding greater oversight of New York’s police and denounced her for failing to support a bill providing paid time off for sick workers.

headline: Suspect’s Death Puts Reward in Question
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Police', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The dwindling bounty in the case of a former police officer who killed himself while the subject of a frenzied manhunt looms as a potential embarrassment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the midst of a frenzied weeklong manhunt, Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa put together one of the largest rewards in Southern California history: $1 million for information leading to the arrest and conviction of Christopher J. Dorner, the former Los Angeles police officer who was wanted in multiple killings last month.

headline: Ohio State’s Best Shooter, or Maybe Its Worst
abstract: Buckeyes Coach Thad Matta described junior forward Deshaun Thomas as a “bad-shot taker” and a “bad-shot maker.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — According to ESPN’s statistics, Deshaun Thomas took 564 field-goal attempts this season. Not all of them were bad. It only sometimes seemed that way.

headline: Tonight, Tonight, Its World Is Full of Blight
abstract: A certain revered late-night talk show has had a rollercoaster history.
lead_paragraph: Once again, “The Tonight Show” rears its hoary head in the headlines. (Unintentional word-play.)

headline: Quinn Accepts Sick Leave Deal
abstract: After blocking legislation for three years, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, agreed to a compromise that will eventually make thousands of companies give paid time off to sick workers.
lead_paragraph: After blocking legislation for three years, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, agreed to a compromise that will eventually make thousands of companies give paid time off to sick workers.

headline: Two Ohio State Players Join Buzzer-Beater Club
abstract: Winning shots by Ohio State’s Aaron Croft and LaQuinton Ross in the final seconds of back-to-back games have put both players on the list of N.C.A.A. magic makers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The club, among the most exclusive in N.C.A.A. tournament history, includes stars and unknowns, guards and post players, from universities with tradition and without. From Christian Laettner to Bryce Drew, James Forrest to Scottie Reynolds, they are linked by clocks dwindled and buzzers beaten and heartbeats elevated.

headline: Pyongyang Blusters, and U.S. Worries About Quieter Risks
abstract: Actions that are difficult to trace to North Korea, like an online assault on South Korea’s banks and a 2010 attack on a submarine, concern the United States more than its brash threats.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — This week, North Korea’s young leader, Kim Jong-un, ordered his underlings to prepare for a missile attack on the United States. He appeared at a command center in front of a wall map with the bold, unlikely title, “Plans to Attack the Mainland U.S.” Earlier in the month, his generals boasted of developing a “Korean-style” nuclear warhead that could be fitted atop a long-range missile.

headline: Nevada Legislator Expelled, Then Arrested, as His Life Unravels for the Public to See
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: After weeks of erratic behavior by Steven Brooks, a two-thirds vote removed him from office Thursday, and then a high-speed chase led to his arrest in California.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Nevada’s State Legislature this week voted for the first time to expel one of its own members, and the man was arrested later the same day.

headline: Sick-Pay Plan Called Blessing and Burden
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Small Business', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A sick-leave law for workers in New York City drew cheers from employees, but some employers said it would unfairly load yet another expense onto their shoulders.
lead_paragraph: The compromise reached on a sick-leave law for workers in New York City drew cheers on Friday from employees who have feared that catching a cold could cost them their jobs. But some employers complained that it would unfairly load yet another expense onto their shoulders.

headline: Marquette Reaping Benefits From Preseason Bootcamp
abstract: The team-building benefits of Coach Buzz Williams’s intense preseason boot camp help explain Marquette’s game-long, defensive pressure and rebounding.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marquette Coach Buzz Williams called himself cantankerous on Friday. He also conceded he had no compassion on the basketball court. One day earlier, he tried to convince reporters that he was not a good person to be around on game days.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Mar. 30, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, Mar. 30, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “The cheating had been going on so long. We considered it part of our jobs.”

headline: Devices Like Cable Boxes Figured in Internet Attack
abstract: This week’s Internet attack was enabled by the operators of more than 27 million Internet servers who left their equipment wide open to a motivated attacker.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the aftermath this week of one of the most powerful attacks on the Internet, finger-pointing quickly ensued.

headline: A Cross-Cultural Passover
abstract: Toloache, a Mexican restaurant, has welcomed the arrival of Passover by fusing Jewish and Mexican cuisines into a kind of south of the border Seder menu.
lead_paragraph: For the last five years, Toloache, a Mexican restaurant on 50th Street near Eighth Avenue, has welcomed the arrival of Passover by fusing Jewish and Mexican cuisines into a kind of south of the border Seder menu. Toloache’s chef, Julian Medina, grew up Catholic in Mexico City and converted to Judaism several years ago after marrying a Jewish woman. One way to honor his new tradition was to dream up Mexican riffs on classic Jewish soul food dishes (can you say, tacos de brisket)? The Passover menu, which will continue until April 2, filled the house one evening last week with curious cross-cultural diners and Jewish families — like the Katzes, from North Bellmore, on Long Island.

headline: The Attack of the Killer Surplus
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: Can a state be too rich for its own good? Well, things are definitely in flux in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often we stop to ask ourselves: “What’s going on with North Dakota?” But I believe this is the moment.

headline: Lawmakers and Relatives Want More Details Released About Newtown Gunman
abstract: The lack of information from investigators about Adam Lanza has frustrated lawmakers and some relatives of the victims.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after the Virginia Tech massacre in 2007, Tim Kaine, then governor of Virginia, closed a loophole in the state’s gun laws that had allowed a mentally disturbed student to buy the guns used in the rampage, which left 33 dead.

headline: On Space Coast, Signs of Comeback After End of an Era
abstract: After a harsh economic downturn and the loss of 8,000 jobs at NASA when a shuttle program ended, Brevard County, Fla., is recovering by diversifying beyond aerospace.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Fla. — The day after the shuttle Atlantis landed for the last time at the Kennedy Space Center on July 21, 2011, Angel Telles, a man with three master’s degrees, scooped up his white Mission 101 coffee mug and drove away from NASA after 24 years on the job there. The shuttle era had ended, and with it the jobs of 8,000 NASA and civilian workers who found themselves unemployed in the midst of a harsh economic downturn and a crush of home foreclosures.

headline: The Coach Who Fought Back
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: After a decade of litigation, can one man change the N.C.A.A.?
lead_paragraph: In 1966, Beryl Shipley, the basketball coach at the University of Southwestern Louisiana, recruited three African-Americans to play for the Ragin’ Cajuns. Although the school, now known as the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, had accepted black students since the mid-1950s, its teams remained segregated — as did every college athletic team in the state.

headline: Estimated Range of North Korean Missiles
abstract: Missiles currently in North Korean arsenal.
lead_paragraph: Missiles currently in North Korean arsenal.

headline: Waterfront Plans Threaten Dream to Honor a Warship in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Museums', 'Eminent Domain', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: A parcel of land in Greenpoint has pitted a couple’s dream of building a museum dedicated to U.S.S. Monitor against a neighborhood push to turn the waterfront into a park.
lead_paragraph: On the coast of gentrifying Brooklyn, the famous Civil War ironclad the U.S.S. Monitor is now caught up in another fierce battle.

headline: Zumba Instructor Admits to Running a Prostitution Ring
abstract: The instructor in Kennebunk, Me., pleaded guilty to using her studio as a front for a ring involving scores of men, including a former mayor, a high school hockey coach and a minister.
lead_paragraph: A Zumba instructor in Kennebunk, Me., pleaded guilty on Friday to using her dance studio as a front for a prostitution ring that involved scores of men in New England. The plea means that the instructor, Alexis Wright, will avoid a trial, as will the numerous clients who might have been called as witnesses.

headline: Wichita State Loose as Ohio State Looms
abstract: Wichita State was looser than one might expect before its matchup with No. 2 Ohio State. But the Shockers’ game plan is simple: step up rebounding and stop the Buckeyes’ Deshaun Thomas.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Wichita State was watching highlights of Ohio State on Friday morning, when the whole team shared a big, hearty laugh.

headline: The Campaign to Outlaw Abortion
abstract: Extreme new restrictions in North Dakota and elsewhere are clearly unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: Anti-abortion groups have been trying to re-impose restrictions on abortion rights for 40 years, but the Legislature and governor of North Dakota have taken this attack on women’s reproductive health and freedom to a shocking new low by passing a bill that they must know perfectly well is unconstitutional by any reading of the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision and others since.

headline: Corrections: March 30, 2013
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 30, 2013.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Went in Tandem
abstract: A Saturday stumper by Gareth Bain.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It has been a long, cold March with a lot of activity, and my brain is worn to a nub atop my brain stem. Maybe that’s why I found this one by Gareth Bain so tough. Or maybe it’s the diabolical cluing. Either way, it’s definitely Saturday, and in my opinion, Dr. Bain and Will Shortz are out for blood.

headline: Toyotas and Torch Songs
abstract: Al Lambert, who has been called Mr. Staten Island, is a car salesman who also entertains at weddings and other events.
lead_paragraph: Al Lambert, Staten Island’s man of cars and song, can sell you a used Toyota by day and give you “Summer Wind” with his big band that evening.

headline: Strengthening the I.M.F.
abstract: It is in America’s interest that Congress ratify proposed changes to the fund.
lead_paragraph: Let’s face it: the International Monetary Fund is not widely loved. It has forced countries in financial distress to adopt counterproductive austerity policies, and it failed to anticipate the financial crisis. But in recent years the I.M.F. has helped stabilize the global economy, most recently by providing loans to troubled European countries like Greece and Ireland. That is why Congress needs to strengthen its governance and bolster its resources by ratifying reforms to the organization that were agreed to in 2010 by its 188 member countries.

headline: Provocateur Comes Into View After Cyberattack
abstract: Although Sven Olaf Kamphuis says he did not orchestrate a large-scale cyberattack this week and has not been charged, he is at the heart of an international investigation.
lead_paragraph: Sven Olaf Kamphuis calls himself the “minister of telecommunications and foreign affairs for the Republic of CyberBunker.” Others see him as the Prince of Spam.

headline: Some Yankees Fans Have Gnawing Feeling That All Is Not Well
abstract: Alarmed by injuries and an aging roster, some Yankees fans believe they are already in the same boat as Mets fans, dreading the season to come.
lead_paragraph: There is little that screams the words “damage” and “control” like a typically news-media-shy baseball owner suddenly making the rounds of sports talk radio and opening his door to quotation-hungry reporters. In a spate of recent interviews, Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ managing general partner, has given his personal assurance that his franchise remains committed to “fielding a championship-caliber team every year.”

headline: Relying on Hotel Rooms for Thousands Uprooted by Hurricane Sandy
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: City officials said those in hotels were mostly poor, with no home to return to or not enough income to qualify for available apartments.
lead_paragraph: Five months after Hurricane Sandy, more than 2,000 people who were displaced by the storm remain in hotels in New York City, leading some officials to acknowledge that the city had not been prepared for the challenges in finding them housing.

headline: New Cabs Could Avoid Hybrid Ban
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The Bloomberg administration wanted all cabs to be Nissan NV200s, but relented and said some large hybrids could be allowed.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a lawsuit aimed at blocking New York’s so-called Taxi of Tomorrow because it is not a hybrid, the Bloomberg administration has proposed a compromise: Some owners can buy hybrids, as long as they are big enough.

headline: China: Landslide Buries Workers at Mine in Tibet
abstract: A huge landslide buried 83 workers at a gold mining site in western China on Friday, setting off a frantic rescue effort, China’s state-run Xinhua news agency reported.
lead_paragraph: A huge landslide buried 83 workers at a gold mining site in western China on Friday, setting off a frantic rescue effort, China’s state-run Xinhua news agency reported. The government said more than 1,000 rescue workers had been called in to stabilize the area and search for the victims, who had been working at a subsidiary of the China Gold Group Corporation. The authorities said the landslide occurred in Maizhokunggar County, about 45 miles east of Lhasa, the capital of Tibet. There were no details about casualties.

headline: A Ride Home That’s Not a Taxi, Maybe
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: SideCar, a new ride-share app, offers an alternative to cabs, but may run afoul of New York City regulators.
lead_paragraph: As I was finishing dinner in Park Slope last Friday, I opened an app on my phone and arranged for a car to pick me up.

headline: Japan: Nuclear Plant’s Operator Cites Poor Preparation
keywords: ['Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: The operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant acknowledged Friday that it had been ill prepared for the tsunami that swept over the site two years ago.
lead_paragraph: The operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant acknowledged Friday that it had been ill prepared for the tsunami that swept over the site two years ago. “Though it was difficult to anticipate a giant tsunami, we should not simply blame nature for this accident,” said a report prepared by an internal task force of the plant’s operator, the Tokyo Electric Power Company. “We must sincerely accept that we were unable to draw on human wisdom to prevent it.” The acknowledgment was a reversal from the company’s earlier assertion that the waves were bigger than it could have predicted.

headline: Some Savers in Cyprus May Lose 60 Percent
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Cyprus is struggling to comply with the conditions that Europe is demanding of it before it gets a desperately needed 10 billion euro loan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Big-ticket savers at the Bank of Cyprus may be forced to accept losses on their deposits that exceed 60 percent in order to keep the stricken bank afloat, bankers briefed on the negotiations said on Friday.

headline: Judge Rebukes 2 Lawyers Profiting From U.S. Disability Law
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Disabilities', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: A Brooklyn federal court judge has ruled against two lawyers who brought forth lawsuits claiming that businesses had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act.
lead_paragraph: The lawyers drafted the lawsuits by the dozens, claiming that local businesses had violated federal law by not providing access to people with disabilities — and generating thousands of dollars per case in legal fees for themselves.

headline: Central African Republic: Bodies Found in the Capital
abstract: Volunteers have collected 78 bodies from the streets of Bangui, Central African Republic’s capital, since rebels seized control of the city last week, the Central African Red Cross reported.
lead_paragraph: Volunteers have collected 78 bodies from the streets of Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, since rebel fighters seized control of the city last week, the Central African Red Cross reported Friday. Many of the bodies lacked identification documents, a Red Cross official told Agence France-Presse, and other medical officials said it was not immediately clear whether the dead were rebels, government soldiers, foreign soldiers or civilians. Hospitals in the capital are overflowing with rebels and others wounded in the fighting, above, officials said. A loose coalition of armed groups from the country’s northeast ousted President François Bozizé on Sunday; the rebels, who are reported to have child soldiers among their ranks, accused Mr. Bozizé of breaching the terms of a January peace deal. He first fled to Cameroon but has since requested refuge in Benin, news reports said Friday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 29, 2013

headline: A Prescription for Sick Workers
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Editorials', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Finally, a bill that will help more employees enjoy a basic benefit moves to the City Council.
lead_paragraph: New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn has finally agreed to require businesses to provide paid sick leave for as many as one million workers. This is good news, although it will take at least a year for most employees to enjoy a basic benefit widely available elsewhere.

headline: Platitudes Loom After the Newtown School Carnage
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'School Shootings', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Editorials']
abstract: From the size of the crowds at more than 100 rallies this week, it’s going to take a stronger push from the public to demand that Congress not duck gun control.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD

headline: Fighting to Join the Ranks
abstract: The latest chapter in the effort to incorporate women into Marine Corps ground combat units closed Thursday, after two women (and 12 men) were eliminated from a challenging course.
lead_paragraph: The latest chapter in the effort to incorporate women into Marine Corps ground combat units closed Thursday, after two women (and 12 men) were eliminated from a challenging course.

headline: France: Most Cities Postpone Plan for New School Hours
abstract: Most French cities have elected to postpone until 2014 a new government plan for an extra half-day of elementary school, the Education Ministry confirmed Friday.
lead_paragraph: Most French cities are in no hurry to introduce a new government plan for an extra half-day of elementary school on Wednesdays and have elected to postpone the change until 2014, when it becomes mandatory, the Education Ministry confirmed Friday. The ministry estimated that the plan would affect fewer than 25 percent of France’s nearly six million public school children ages 3 to 11 in the coming school year. But several large cities, including Paris, will begin the half-day in September. For more than a century, the French school schedule has been punctuated by a midweek break, originally created for catechism studies. The new plan, which has drawn opposition from teachers and parents, calls for three hours of class time on Wednesdays while reducing the regular school day — which typically runs from 8:30 a.m. to at least 4 p.m. — by 45 minutes.

headline: Savoring the Mellower Music of Home
abstract: Vernon Reid, guitarist in the band Living Colour, usually rises before the rest of his family and tries to catch up with his favorite podcasts; he calls them a kind of rebirth of radio.
lead_paragraph: When Vernon Reid, guitarist in the band Living Colour, became a rock star, he bought a Victorian house in the St. George neighborhood on Staten Island. Now, as the band celebrates the 25th anniversary of its breakthrough album, “Vivid” — which the group will play at Irving Plaza on April 6 — Mr. Reid, 54, still enjoys the neighborhood’s mix of Fort Greene-style diversity with a maritime vibe. A composer as well as a musician, he lives with his wife, Gabri Christa Reid, 49, a choreographer and filmmaker, and their daughter, Idea Viola Reid, 9. They have three cats.

headline: With a Sniffle Here and a Steal There, Louisville Pulls Away From Oregon
abstract: No. 12 Oregon could not get by Louisville’s full-court press, so the Ducks just stopped trying. The top-seeded Cardinals held the Ducks to 45 percent shooting.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Oregon was the newcomer to the Midwest Region semifinals, joining three of college basketball’s blue-blood programs — Louisville, Duke and Michigan State — and, in somewhat self-deprecating fashion, the Ducks brought their lone N.C.A.A. championship trophy on the team plane here.

headline: Anyone Can Get a Table, Eventually
abstract: The NoMad’s general manager reveals some tricks of the high-end restaurant trade.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Tascarella, 33, is the general manager of the year-old restaurant the NoMad, at Broadway and 28th Street. He can be found on the restaurant’s floor from 10 a.m. to after 11 p.m. daily, solving problems and chatting with the regulars among the 250 nightly guests. He credits his first job in New York City, waiting on tables at Fiamma, a defunct SoHo restaurant, for his love of wine, fine dining and long hours.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Diversity Deserts
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Too many House Republican districts are isolated in naturally homogeneous areas or gerrymandered ghettos.
lead_paragraph: Well, that didn’t take long.

headline: Coming Soon
abstract: Natan Dvir photographs giant signs in Midtown that advertise the imminent arrival of brand-name stores and transform the streetscape.
lead_paragraph: Natan Dvir photographs giant signs in Midtown that advertise the imminent arrival of brand-name stores and transform the streetscape.

headline: Michigan Stuns No. 1 Seed Kansas
abstract: Trey Burke hit a tying 3-pointer with three seconds left in regulation to give Michigan early momentum in overtime. The Wolverines shut down Ben McLemore to edge Kansas.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The shot was not a pedestrian 3-pointer, a casual 3 from 20 feet 9 inches. This was a heave. When Trey Burke stepped back, he was at least nine feet beyond the regulation 3-point line. He was drifting and Kansas’ 6-foot-8 Kevin Young was jumping toward him. The chances of the ball going in were about the same odds many gave Burke and Michigan when they trailed by 14 with less than seven minutes remaining.

headline: Avenue of Dreams, and Hot Dogs
abstract: Natan Dvir’s streetscapes depict titanic images of sleek models, heralding the imminent arrival of name-brand clothing stores, and the diminutive mere mortals below.
lead_paragraph: It was like “Attack of the 50 Foot Woman” everywhere, except the women weren’t exactly attacking.

headline: Richard Griffiths, Falstaffian English Actor, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Griffiths, who played Uncle Vernon in the Harry Potter movies, reached a career peak as a schoolteacher in “The History Boys” on Broadway and the West End.
lead_paragraph: Richard Griffiths, the rotund British actor whose stage career reached a pinnacle with his Tony-winning performance as an idealistic but tormented pedagogue in Alan Bennett’s play “The History Boys” and who achieved popular fame in the movies as Harry Potter’s mean-spirited Uncle Vernon Dursley, died on Thursday in Coventry, England. He was 65.

headline: Knicks’ Streak Hits 7 As Smith Stays on Roll
abstract: The Knicks started strong and then coasted to a 111-102 victory against the Charlotte Bobcats, as J.R. Smith scored 37 points.
lead_paragraph: The chants were faint but audible.

headline: Teacher’s Vision, but Done New York City’s Way
abstract: Michael Zamansky, a teacher at Stuyvesant in Manhattan, is credited with the idea behind the Academy for Software Engineering, but it hasn’t turned out exactly as he had hoped.
lead_paragraph: At last year’s State of the City speech, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the creation of a public high school called the Academy for Software Engineering. The school would be part of an ambitious expansion of computer science education in the city, and Mr. Bloomberg called it the “brainchild” of a local teacher named Michael Zamansky.

headline: Finally Beaten in Florida, Haas, 34, Isn’t Stopping
abstract: Tommy Haas’s unexpected surge in the Sony Open ended with a semifinal loss to David Ferrer, who will face Andy Murray in the final. Haas made clear it wasn’t the end for him.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — One set into his Sony Open semifinal match against David Ferrer on Friday, Tommy Haas could almost taste his first Masters final since 2001. Haas was looking to end a memorable week in the Miami area in style.

headline: Dreams of a Harlem Jazz Rebirth
abstract: Although the storied Lenox Lounge has closed, three lovers of jazz music see opportunities ripe for reviving the scene that helped put the neighborhood on the map.
lead_paragraph: As another evening falls, the Lenox Lounge sits dim and lonely. Commuters pour out of the 125th Street subway station and onto Lenox Avenue, past its padlocked door. At Ginny’s Supper Club across the street, a mostly black crowd of men in suits and women in heels sips and sways as a band turns out a haunting rendition of John Coltrane’s “My Favorite Things.”

headline: As Home Opener Nears, the Battered Yankees Are Still Looking for Help
abstract: As teams get ready to trim their rosters for opening day, the Yankees will continue monitoring which players become available before rosters are due Sunday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For almost a century, the Yankees have been a team accustomed to snatching the best players from other organizations, whether it was Babe Ruth, Catfish Hunter or Alex Rodriguez. But that is not the case this spring.

headline: Lessons Found in the Mud
abstract: There are inklings around the city of a movement toward a learning philosophy that promotes creative play; in Brooklyn, one program takes toddlers into Prospect Park and teaches them to dig in the mud.
lead_paragraph: If you know anything about New York City, you know that there is an insufficient number of preschool spaces for all the children needing to attend preschool, and that this is experienced by the parents who live here with varying degrees of garment-rending.

headline: Murray Shrugs Off Slow Start to Advance to Sony Open Final
abstract: Andy Murray topped Richard Gasquet in a second semifinal Friday night, 6-7 (3), 6-1, 6-2, to set up a title match with David Ferrer.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Andy Murray ensured that two of world’s top players would meet in the men’s final of the Sony Open by coming back to defeat Richard Gasquet on Friday night in the second semifinal, 6-7 (3), 6-1, 6-2.

headline: Men’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: March 29
abstract: Michigan shocks No. 1 Kansas in overtime, Florida spoils Florida Gulf Coast’s Run, Louisville smothers Oregon and Duke drops Michigan State.
lead_paragraph: Michigan shocks No. 1 Kansas in overtime, Florida spoils Florida Gulf Coast’s Run, Louisville smothers Oregon and Duke drops Michigan State.

headline: IHT Quick Read: March 30
abstract: Scrutiny for a hacker; mortgage leniency ends in Ireland; hedge fund executive is arrested, and cyberattacks target companies.
lead_paragraph: NEWS Sven Olaf Kamphuis calls himself the “minister of telecommunications and foreign affairs for the Republic of CyberBunker.” Others see him as the Prince of Spam. Mr. Kamphuis, who is actually Dutch, is at the heart of an international investigation into one of the biggest cyberattacks identified by the authorities. Because of his outspoken position in a loose federation of hackers, the authorities in the Netherlands and several other countries are examining what role he or the Internet companies he runs played in snarling traffic on the Web this week. Eric Pfanner and Kevin J. O’Brien report.

headline: Injuries May Affect Ticket Sales of Openers
abstract: The Yankees and the Mets both have their problems and that is something that is reflected in the market for ticket.
lead_paragraph: The local forecast on Monday calls for a high near 60 degrees with a mix of sun and clouds. Not bad for fans heading to Yankee Stadium and Citi Field as the Yankees and the Mets open their seasons simultaneously in New York for the first time.

headline: Duke Pushes Out Michigan State
abstract: The second-seeded Blue Devils used stout defense, Seth Curry’s 3-point touch and a second-half run to top No. 3 Michigan State.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Steven Izzo called it right. Two weeks ago, Steven, the 13-year-old son of Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo, sidestepped family loyalty and picked Duke to defeat the Spartans in his N.C.A.A. tournament bracket. The Blue Devils validated his nerve Friday night by sending the Izzos home.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) SNOW WHITE AND THE HUNTSMAN (2012) Kristen Stewart, above, is Snow White, who seeks to usurp the evil queen Ravenna (Charlize Theron) with the help of the Huntsman (Chris Hemsworth) and a specific number of dwarfs (played by Ian McShane, Ray Winstone and Bob Hoskins, among others) in this darkened adaptation of the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, directed by Rupert Sanders. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said: “There is nothing cute about this movie. And that feels right. There is something exciting about how seriously ‘Snow White and the Huntsman’ takes its themes.” He added that Ms. Stewart’s Snow White was “part of an interesting new breed of warrior princesses — Katniss Everdeen is their current leader — whose ascendance reflects the convergence of commercial calculations and cultural longings. Long may they reign.”

headline: Nets Fade and Fall in Denver
abstract: The Nuggets scored the game’s first 21 fast-break points en route to their 18th straight victory at the Pepsi Center, where Denver is 33-3, the best home record in the league.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The Nets’ bid to ensure a winning road record for the first time since entering the N.B.A. in 1976 came up well short against the Denver Nuggets’ home dominance on Friday night.

headline: How the Cyberattack on Spamhaus Unfolded
abstract: A look at the attack and the defense in one of the largest known distributed denial of service attacks.
lead_paragraph: A look at the attack and the defense in one of the largest known distributed denial of service attacks.

headline: Florida Ends Florida Gulf Coast’s Run
abstract: The Eagles, the first 15 seed to advance to the Round of 16, could not keep up with the resourceful and unwavering Gators, a No. 3 seed.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Florida’s Mike Rosario seemed thwarted as he looked to make an inbounds pass with two minutes to play. The Gators were safely ahead, so a turnover at this juncture would have been meaningless.

headline: Fifty-One Years Across Town, but United in Misery for Six
abstract: In their 51 years together, the Mets and the Yankees have both been losing teams on only six occasions. Could it happen again? A look at the six seasons when it happened.
lead_paragraph: In their 51 years together, the Mets and the Yankees have both been losing teams on only six occasions, and the last time it happened was way back in 1992. Since then, the Yankees have won five World Series and the Mets ... well, they’re the Mets, so they haven’t won any.

headline: North Korea Threatens to Close Factories It Runs With South
abstract: Some leading government-run Web sites stopped operating in what may be another case of cyberwarfare on the Korean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea, reiterating that it considered the Korean Peninsula back in “a state of war,” threatened Saturday to shut down a factory complex it jointly operates with South Korea and that stands as the last significant symbol of cooperation.

headline: The Weekend Word: Checkpoint
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the president’s weekly address.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Dogs, Nets and Poverty – a Tough Combination
abstract: An effort to rescue two puppies determined to be ensnared in fish nets has a surprising end.
lead_paragraph: Dogs and developing countries are a rough mix — with the lack of neutering resulting in puppy population explosions and all manner of bad outcomes, from millions of dog bites a year in India to rabies outbreaks in Indonesia to fatal maulings in Mexico City. Learn more from Veterinarians Without Borders and the “Street Dog Welfare” page of Humane Society International.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: The state government Thursday tabled a bill that seeks to regulate the functioning of private security agencies in the state, the Business Standard reported. Under the new proposal all such agencies will have to seek a mandatory license before they are allowed to operate in the state.

headline: Italian President Enlists Special Help on Political Deadlock
abstract: President Giorgio Napolitano was reportedly weighing whether to resign to give a new team a chance at breaking an impasse over forming a government.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s president said Saturday that he would turn to a group of outside advisers to help him end the country’s political deadlock, after weeks of inconclusive consultations with political leaders failed to overcome ingrained divisions.

headline: After Cyprus, Euro Concerns Over Slovenia, a Former Euro Star
abstract: Since the Cyprus bailout crisis, analysts have been on the lookout for the next vulnerable euro zone economy likely to need help. The small Alpine state of Slovenia is high on their lists.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Will Slovenia be the next Cyprus?

headline: Islanders Give Visnovsky Contract Extension
abstract: Lubomir Visnovsky, who was concluding a five-year, $28 million contract and would have become an unrestricted free agent this summer, had been a source of trade rumors.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders have signed defenseman Lubomir Visnovsky to a two-year contract extension.

headline: The Price Is Wrong
abstract: But which price? That makes all the difference.
lead_paragraph: But which price — that is the question.

headline: No Trickle
abstract: Lots for profits, little for workers.
lead_paragraph: I should give a shout-out to Larry Mishel’s note showing that the share of corporate-sector income going to profits has soared to levels not seen in more than 40 years. Here’s another way to see the same thing, with total workers’ compensation in blue and profits in red, both shown as indexes with the quarter before the recession at 100:

headline: Kenyan Court Upholds Election of Candidate Facing Charges in The Hague
abstract: The decision eliminated the last hurdle for Uhuru Kenyatta, who has been charged with crimes against humanity, to take office. Protests erupted soon after.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya’s Supreme Court on Saturday unanimously upheld the election victory of Uhuru Kenyatta as the country’s president, dismissing allegations that the vote had been rigged.

headline: Marriage Looks Different Now
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We’re seeing a revolution with wider ripples than its supporters admit.
lead_paragraph: IN 1997, two prominent conservative writers, David Frum and Andrew Sullivan, debated same-sex marriage for the online magazine Slate.

headline: Egypt Orders Arrest of Satirist Over Skits on Islam and Morsi
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In the nine months since Mohamed Morsi became president, his government has been accused of employing the same harsh measures against dissent as did the previous leaders.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s public prosecutor on Saturday ordered the arrest of a popular television satirist on charges that included insulting President Mohamed Morsi and denigrating Islam, the state news agency reported, a move that amplified criticisms that the Islamist government is moving aggressively to stifle freedom of expression.

headline: High-Tech Means of Production Belies Nostalgic Image of Maple Syrup
abstract: Maple syrup conjures images of old-fashioned rural New England, but the reality is changing with the help of technology.
lead_paragraph: EAST MONTPELIER, Vt. — The rich, sweet tang of sap being boiled into maple syrup greeted tourists at Burr Morse’s sugar shack here this month — along with Mr. Morse, every inch the rural maple farmer in worn baseball cap and syrup-stained jacket, stirring the steaming evaporator with an old-fashioned dipper.

headline: Maple Syrup Takes Turn Toward Technology
abstract: Over the past decade technology has allowed maple farmers to offset the effects of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade technology has allowed maple farmers to offset the effects of climate change.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Mixing it up cryptically with Rich Silvestri.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I must be getting better at these, because I’m definitely enjoying cryptics more. The variety of ways to clue an entry in a cryptic crossword gives your brain such a refreshing flossing that there is no way not to enjoy solving.

headline: Social Security, Present and Future
keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: There are sensible ways to reform Social Security, but it is not driving the deficit.
lead_paragraph: In the fight over the federal budget deficit, Social Security has so far been untouched. That may soon change.

headline: Boston College Faces Tough Road in Title Defense
abstract: To reach the Frozen Four, the Eagles will have to clear the East regional, which includes No. 1 Quinnipiac, Canisus and Union.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. – Besides Boston College, the East regional of the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament is not filled with historic powers. With the other three universities coming from lesser-known conferences, it could be easy to overlook the bracket.

headline: Who Can Bring the E.U. To Its Senses?
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Editorials']
abstract: Until there are leaders who will push for the interests of Europe as a whole, expect more near-disasters like Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: Cyprus finally got a revised bailout plan last week. It taxes big, uninsured bank depositors to pay part of the cost of restructuring the country’s two biggest banks while leaving the savings of smaller, insured depositors untouched. But just days before, Cyprus, with the blessings of the smartest bankers and smartest finance ministers in Europe, came within a whisker of adopting a truly reckless plan that would have taxed small savers, undermined deposit insurance and risked sparking disastrous bank runs elsewhere, notably Italy and Spain, the euro zone’s third- and fourth-largest economies.

headline: Resurrecting California’s Public Universities
abstract: More robust budgets, not online courses, are the best answer.
lead_paragraph: Even before the recession hit, the public colleges and universities that educate more than 70 percent of the nation’s students were suffering from dwindling state revenue. Their response, not surprisingly, was to raise tuition, slash course offerings and, in some cases, freeze or even reduce student enrollment. The damage was acute in California, whose once-glorious system of higher education effectively cannibalized itself, shutting out a growing number of well-qualified students.

headline: Immigrant Detainees and the Right to Counsel
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration Detention', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)']
abstract: Is a lawyer a necessity or a financial drain on the immigration system?
lead_paragraph: DO immigrants who are incarcerated while their legal status is resolved deserve a lawyer?

headline: Heat’s Streak May Be Over, but Show Rolls On
abstract: LeBron James and the Heat appear to have shaken off the loss that ended their 27-game win streak. They dominated the Hornets, with James’s grabbing 36 points.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — If LeBron James seemed bothered by the lapse of Miami’s 27-game winning streak or the hard fouls — physical and verbal — he had absorbed in recent days, it was not apparent Friday morning. His hunger for victory or reprisal seemed outweighed at the moment by his hunger for lunch.

headline: Our Inconsistent Ethical Instincts
abstract: We like to believe that our principles are rooted in conviction. But much research shows that they often prove to be finicky, inconsistent intuitions.
lead_paragraph: MORAL quandaries often pit concerns about principles against concerns about practical consequences. Should we ban assault rifles and large sodas, restricting people’s liberties for the sake of physical health and safety? Should we allow drone killings or torture, if violating one person’s rights could save a thousand lives?

headline: Decision on Coyotes Seems Near
abstract: If the Coyotes move from the Phoenix area to Quebec, the N.H.L.’s realignment plan would be thwarted. The league said it did not have a Plan B.
lead_paragraph: The Phoenix Coyotes’ ownership situation, which has been unsettled for nearly four years, could finally be resolved soon. According to published reports and to officials familiar with the situation, the N.H.L. either will sell the Coyotes to the last in a long line of prospective buyers who pledged to keep them in Glendale, Ariz., or will decide as soon as next month to allow the team to relocate.

headline: Shawn Askinosie
abstract: For Easter, an artisanal chocolate maker thinks about monks, a Buddhist nun and “Real Housewives.”
lead_paragraph: Shawn Askinosie is a criminal defense lawyer turned confectioner. His company, Askinosie Chocolate in Springfield, Mo., makes highly regarded bean-to-bar artisanal chocolate with 10 percent of the profits shared with the company’s cocoa farmers in Ecuador, Honduras, the Philippines and Tanzania.

headline: Short of Money, Egypt Sees Crisis on Fuel and Food
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Shortages', 'Food', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The cash shortage is raising questions about Egypt’s ability to keep importing wheat that is essential to the food supply, stirring fears of an economic catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: QALYUBEYA, Egypt — A fuel shortage has helped send food prices soaring. Electricity is blacking out even before the summer. And gas-line gunfights have killed at least five people and wounded dozens over the past two weeks.

headline: In Brazil, Streets of Dancing Cars and Swagger
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Mexican-Americans', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Mexican-American lowrider culture, with its dazzling wheels, hydraulic-pump systems and muscle shirts, has spread from East Los Angeles to Brazil and beyond.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — José Américo Crippa’s 1974 Chevrolet Monte Carlo boasts just about every feature that a lowrider should have, including dazzling chrome wheels, a sliding ragtop roof, a candy-apple red paint job and hydraulic pumps that enable the vehicle to bounce several feet in the air at the press of a button.

headline: Why I Count Glass Eels
abstract: “Citizen science” offers new ways for ordinary people to engage with the natural world.
lead_paragraph: “WHO looks upon a river in a meditative hour and is not reminded of the flux of all things?”

headline: Truth in Rebounding for Tough Nets Forward
abstract: Reggie Evans is on pace to be only the second player with a rebounding rate above 24.1 percent.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Anyone who deals regularly with Reggie Evans or follows him on social media is familiar with his frequent use of the expression “I ain’t lyin’.” It started in his hometown, Pensacola, Fla., and his N.B.A. teammates picked it up.

headline: America the Innovative?
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Creativity', 'United States Economy', 'Research', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: As China becomes richer, is it destined to pass the United States as the world’s most inventive nation?
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN

headline: In College Hockey Tournament, Quinnipiac and Canisius Have Doubters
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Hockey, Ice', 'NCAA Ice Hockey Championships', 'NCAA Soccer Championships']
abstract: Quinnipiac has been consistently ranked in the top five this season while Canisius snuck into the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — One team was consistently ranked in the top five all season. The other is one game above .500 and barely snuck into the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament.

headline: An Arena’s Stunning Moments, From Floor to Ceiling
abstract: This year’s Final Four in Atlanta will probably be the last at the Georgia Dome, the site of exciting regional clashes, a memorable Kentucky-Arkansas title game and even a roof-piercing tornado.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Georgia Dome, the host of the men’s Final Four this year, is 21 years old and adequate as a site for major sporting events. But because more money can be made with a new stadium, a path is being cleared for the dome’s extinction. So this is probably the last time a college basketball champion will be crowned at its climate-controlled environs.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Remembering an Easter Miracle in Northern Ireland
abstract: The Irish peace process reaffirms the possibility that — despite the weight of evidence against human nature — we are all still capable of small moments of resurrection.
lead_paragraph: PEACE, said W. B. Yeats, comes dropping slow.

headline: Hope Is All Around in New, Open A.L. East
abstract: Gone are the days when the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox could count on their perennial exclusive battle for division supremacy.
lead_paragraph: In 10 of 12 seasons, from 1998 through 2009, the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox finished in the top two spots in the American League East. When they open the season this week at Yankee Stadium, there will be no undercurrent of divisional superiority.

headline: Need a Job? Invent It
keywords: ['Education', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Education (K-12)', 'Books and Literature', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Finding a job is so 20th century. That is why young people today need to be more “innovation ready” than “college ready.”
lead_paragraph: WHEN Tony Wagner, the Harvard education specialist, describes his job today, he says he’s “a translator between two hostile tribes” — the education world and the business world, the people who teach our kids and the people who give them jobs. Wagner’s argument in his book “Creating Innovators: The Making of Young People Who Will Change the World” is that our K-12 and college tracks are not consistently “adding the value and teaching the skills that matter most in the marketplace.”

headline: For the Sultan of Small Sample Size, a 1.000 Career Average
abstract: John Paciorek, who went 3 for 3 for a 1.000 career average, could be considered baseball’s greatest hitter — if you’re having a little fun with statistics.
lead_paragraph: Last season, the intensifying debate over baseball statistics grew a little louder.

headline: A Childless Bystander’s Baffled Hymn
abstract: We’re obsessed with every nuance of child-rearing. Here’s the view from the bleachers.
lead_paragraph: MODERN parenting confuses me. The vocabulary, for starters.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Choosing How We Die
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Law and Legislation', 'Doctors']
abstract: Should it be legal for doctors to help end dying patients’ lives?
lead_paragraph: Should it be legal for doctors to help end dying patients’ lives?

headline: N.L. Pennant Within the Nationals’ Grasp
abstract: With all due respect to the other powers, the team formerly known as the Montreal Expos has what it takes to reach the World Series at last.
lead_paragraph: For the last 13 years, more often than not, the path to the National League pennant has run through St. Louis. The Cardinals have appeared in seven league championship series since 2000, including the last two without the benefit of winning their division.

headline: Will Gays Be Punished for Success?
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Once more, the Supremes are singing: You can’t hurry love.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: King Cotton’s Long Shadow
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Slavery', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Slavery was crucial to the development of global capitalism.
lead_paragraph: Last month, researchers at University College London made public a database that describes in illuminating detail one of the largest government bailouts in modern history. In 1833, Britain paid 20 million pounds to compensate 3,000 Caribbean slaveholders for the emancipation of their slaves. The payments constituted about 40 percent of total governmental expenditures that year. Conversation about the database in Britain centered on the recipients of these reparations for slaveholders, among them the ancestors of George Orwell, Graham Greene and David Cameron.

headline: Introducing a Repurposed President and a Revamped Star
abstract: The Mariners’ $10 million scoreboard and the Astros’ new look are among the new things to watch for this season.
lead_paragraph: We know this baseball season will have breakout stars we never expected, injuries we never saw coming and — based on last year — about 100 no-hitters and perfect games. That all involves players. Here are nine new things to watch on the periphery of the game.

headline: Machines of Laughter and Forgetting
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Home Appliances', 'Privacy', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The problem with attempts to “bury” technology is that they embody an amoral and unsustainable vision.
lead_paragraph: UNTIL very recently, technology had a clear, if boring, purpose: by taking care of the Little Things, it enabled us, its human masters, to focus on the Big Things. “Unless there are slaves to do the ugly, horrible, uninteresting work, culture and contemplation become almost impossible,” proclaimed that noted connoisseur of contemplation Oscar Wilde.

headline: Anger Over Plan to Sell Site of Wounded Knee Massacre
abstract: The location of an infamous massacre in 1890, and a violent standoff in 1973, has again become the subject of introspection and dispute.
lead_paragraph: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D. — Ever since American soldiers massacred men, women and children here more than a century ago in the last major bloodshed of the American Indian wars, this haunted patch of rolling hills and ponderosa pines has embodied the combustible relationship between Indians and the United States government.

headline: Wounded Knee Up for Sale
abstract: This haunted patch of rolling hills and ponderosa pines has embodied the combustible relationship between Indians and the United States government.
lead_paragraph: This haunted patch of rolling hills and ponderosa pines has embodied the combustible relationship between Indians and the United States government.

headline: Breaking It Down: Ferrer vs. Haas
abstract: The secret to David Ferrer’s success is a baseline strategy called the 2-1. He will need to execute it to defeat Andy Murray in Sunday’s Sony Open final.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.–The secret to David Ferrer’s success is a baseline strategy called the 2-1. It is a three-shot sequence that begins in the ad court by initially disarming the opponent with depth, then stretches him wider off the court with direction that opens a gaping hole in the deuce court for the player to finish the point.

headline: Yvonne Brill, a Pioneering Rocket Scientist, Dies at 88
abstract: In the early 1970s, Mrs. Brill invented a propulsion system to help keep communications satellites from slipping out of their orbits.
lead_paragraph: She was a brilliant rocket scientist who followed her husband from job to job and took eight years off from work to raise three children. “The world’s best mom,” her son Matthew said.

headline: Hitched to an Aging Star: Anatomy of a Deal, and Doubts
abstract: Alex Rodriguez’s contract — the largest ever in American sports — hangs over nearly every decision that the Yankees make, especially given the team’s financial straits.
lead_paragraph: Yankees pitcher Mariano Rivera was convinced that Alex Rodriguez had made a colossal blunder.

headline: Labor and Business Reach Deal on Immigration Issue
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Foreign Workers', 'Organized Labor', 'Visas']
abstract: The agreement between the nation’s top business and labor groups clears the path for broad immigration legislation to be introduced when Congress returns from its two-week recess in mid-April.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top business and labor groups have reached an agreement on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said on Saturday. The deal clears the path for broad immigration legislation to be introduced when Congress returns from its two-week recess in mid-April.

headline: Embracing a Mexican-American Subculture
abstract: A scene with roots in East Los Angeles has spread to places like Japan and New Zealand. Its devotees share a simple connection, beyond a few Spanish words: lowrider cars and bikes.
lead_paragraph: A scene with roots in East Los Angeles has spread to places like Japan and New Zealand. Its devotees share a simple connection, beyond a few Spanish words: lowrider cars and bikes.

headline: If a Fund Turns on a Dime, Watch Your Dollars
abstract: The demise of the Willow Fund, which was sponsored and sold by UBS, offers two lessons in investment risk.
lead_paragraph: LAST October, shareholders in the Willow Fund, a closed-end investment fund sponsored and sold by UBS, received some disturbing news: the fund, which had assets of almost $500 million in 2006, was being liquidated.

headline: An American Quilt of Privacy Laws, Incomplete
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Consumer Protection', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Europe and the United States are operating at far different speeds with respect to data privacy regulation. And that could be a stumbling block in future trade talks.
lead_paragraph: WE don’t need a new platform. We just need to rebrand.

headline: Want to Know Me? Just Read My User Manual
abstract: Ivar Kroghrud, the lead strategist at QuestBack, says he came up with a one-page “user manual” so “people can understand how to work with me.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Ivar Kroghrud, the lead strategist at QuestBack, which specializes in feedback management, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Mr. Kroghrud, a co-founder of the firm, was its C.E.O. for 13 years.

headline: A Sustainable Budget Should Endure Any Storm
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s goal for the federal budget is a “fiscally sustainable path.” But he may be applying too easy of a standard for achieving it.
lead_paragraph: IN the national debate over fiscal policy, an important question is what the long-run goal should be. Representative Paul D. Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, has a plan to balance the federal budget in 10 years. When asked if he would do the same, President Obama demurred.

headline: Thomas McEvilley, Critic and Defender of Non-Western Art, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. McEvilley’s evisceration of a Museum of Modern Art show on “primitivism” in 1984 put curators on the defensive and changed the debate about multiculturalism in art.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, when the Museum of Modern Art in New York opened its exhibition “ ‘Primitivism’ in 20th Century Art: Affinity of the Tribal and the Modern,” the reception was generally favorable. Then came Thomas McEvilley’s shattering review in Artforum magazine.

headline: On Being Catholic
abstract: Can reflective and honest intellectuals actually believe in the church’s teachings?
lead_paragraph: An old friend and mentor of mine, Ernan McMullin, was a philosopher of science widely respected in his discipline.  He was also a Catholic priest.  I don’t know how many times fellow philosophers at professional meetings drew me aside and asked, “Does Ernan really believe that stuff?”  (He did.) Amid all the serious and generally respectful coverage of the papal resignation and the election of a new pope, I often detect an undertone of this same puzzlement.  Can reflective and honest intellectuals actually believe that stuff?

headline: Those Irritating Verbs-as-Nouns
abstract: Why “that was an epic fail” sounds so good and also so annoying.
lead_paragraph: “Do you have a solve for this problem?” “Let’s all focus on the build.” “That’s the take-away from today’s seminar.” Or, to quote a song that was recently a No. 1 hit in Britain, “Would you let me see beneath your beautiful?”

headline: Phil Ramone, Producer for Music’s Biggest Stars, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Ramone defined the role of record producer as being roughly equivalent to that of a movie director.
lead_paragraph: Phil Ramone, a prolific record producer and engineer who worked with some of the biggest music stars of the last 50 years, including Ray Charles, Frank Sinatra, Paul Simon, Billy Joel and Barbra Streisand, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 79. (Though it was widely reported that he was 72, public records and his family confirm that he was born on Jan. 5, 1934.)

headline: Still at a Trot, This Bull May Have Farther to Go
abstract: Bull markets typically do not die of old age, but from the side effects of a lengthy rebound.
lead_paragraph: FOR the last four years, market watchers have bemoaned the muted economic recovery, with its sluggish growth, tepid job creation and continuing investor fears.

headline: Letting Down Our Guard With Web Privacy
abstract: Consumers insist that they treasure their online privacy. But their mouse clicks tell a far different tale, as the experiments of a behavioral economist show.
lead_paragraph: SAY you’ve come across a discount online retailer promising a steal on hand-stitched espadrilles for spring. You start setting up an account by offering your e-mail address — but before you can finish, there’s a ping on your phone. A text message. You read it and respond, then return to the Web site, enter your birth date, click “F” for female, agree to the company’s terms of service and carry on browsing.

headline: Alford Is Hired as the Coach at U.C.L.A.
abstract: Steve Alford was lured him from New Mexico days after he signed a 10-year deal to coach the Lobos.
lead_paragraph: Eleven days ago, New Mexico announced a 10-year contract extension for Coach Steve Alford, who agreed to coach the Lobos until 2023. But on Saturday, U.C.L.A. announced that Alford would be its next coach, the latest man charged with returning the Bruins to glory.

headline: State-Wrecked: The Corruption of Capitalism in America
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'National Debt (US)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Eight decades of bipartisan Keynesian spending and Federal Reserve money-printing have left us exhausted and bankrupt.
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, Conn.The Dow Jones and Standard & Poor’s 500 indexes reached record highs on Thursday, having completely erased the losses since the stock market’s last peak, in 2007. But instead of cheering, we should be very afraid.

headline: Victory Strengthens a Case for the Derby
abstract: Orb’s fourth straight win would make him a favorite at Churchill Downs, but his owners haven’t committed to the race.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Orb’s owners, the esteemed Phipps Stable and Stuart Janney III, declined to speak about the Kentucky Derby ahead of the Florida Derby on Saturday, insisting they had not yet caught Derby fever.

headline: Why Innovators Get Better With Age
abstract: The most common image of an innovator is of a kid developing a great idea in a garage. But that is the exception to the rule.
lead_paragraph: “WE need some gray hair” once referred to needing someone with more experience. But I haven’t heard that expression in a very long time.

headline: Freed From Its Cage, the Gentler Robot
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: New factory robots, designed to work and play well with others, no longer have to be fenced in to protect workers from accidents.
lead_paragraph: FACTORY robots are usually caged off from humans on the assembly line lest the machines’ powerful steel arms deliver an accidental, bone-crunching right hook.

headline: Setting Yourself Apart
abstract: “Sometimes you must do more than differentiate your product,” says the C.E.O. of Satellite Healthcare. “You must differentiate yourself.”
lead_paragraph: I’M a first-generation American. My father was born in Poland and changed his last name when he came to this country. My mother’s family was from Sweden. My family owned two bakeries, and my siblings and I were expected to work in them. I started out cleaning the bakeries and made deliveries for the catering part of the business when I got my driver’s license.

headline: Fatigue May Be a Foe for Duke
abstract: After a slugfest with Michigan State, the Blue Devils’ players shuffled into a news conference looking visibly worn down.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Before anyone could ask a question at the news conference after Duke’s win over Michigan State, Blue Devils Coach Mike Krzyzewski made a request.

headline: Before Facing Duke, Pitino Lets Sarcasm Flow
abstract: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino is several decades removed from his upbringing on Long Island, but he has not lost his biting New York sense of humor.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Louisville Coach Rick Pitino is several decades removed from his upbringing on Long Island, but he has not lost his biting New York sense of sarcasm.

headline: Dieng of Louisville Learns Fast
abstract: Gorgui Dieng, a Senegalese who has become a formidable center, missed the Cardinals’ loss to Duke last fall with an injury and eagerly awaited the rematch in the Round of 8.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Louisville guard Russ Smith used to room with Gorgui Dieng on the road, the oddest of odd couples, so he can neatly summarize how much the Senegal native has matured off the court.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 31
abstract: Senators Charles E. Schumer and Jeff Flake join NBC to talk about immigration, President Obama is on Univision and Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York is featured on ABC and CBS, discussing the new head of the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Two members of the bipartisan Senate group working on overhauling immigration policy — Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona — will be on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” Business and labor leaders reached a deal on a guest worker program for low-skilled immigrants on Friday.

headline: McIlroy Battles Mental Mistakes
abstract: Rory McIlroy postponed a humanitarian trip to Haiti to play in the Texas Open the week before the Masters.
lead_paragraph: HUMBLE, Texas — At Redstone Golf Club on Saturday, Rory McIlroy stood over a five-foot birdie putt, which would have gotten him to four under for the day and inside the top 10 for the Houston Open.

headline: Special Features
abstract: Find the hidden treasure in Caleb Madison’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this is what a Sunday puzzle is supposed to be like. Great, crunchy fill, with little to no junk. Multilayered, with more than one surprise to uncover. And that extra surprise is what keeps you going through the longer Sunday solve.

abstract: The country’s Supreme Court unanimously backed the election victory of Uhuru Kenyatta as president and dismissed charges of vote rigging.

headline: Orange Cut Down Nets That They Barely Used
