About 11 minutes remained in Syracuse’s East Region final against Marquette, but Triche kept looking at the clock, wishing hard that the minutes would tick away.

headline: Curious Grade for Teachers: Nearly All Pass
abstract: New teacher evaluation systems were intended to provide useful feedback and weed out weak performers, but the reluctance to set a high bar has led to scores that seem impossibly rosy.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, education reformers and their allies in both parties have revamped the way teachers are graded, abandoning methods under which nearly everyone was deemed satisfactory, even when students were falling behind.

headline: We’re One Big Team, So Run Those Stairs
abstract: CrossFit, the workout fitness program, is viewed by some companies as a way to improve worker production and morale.
lead_paragraph: AT 12:30 p.m. on a Tuesday, the chief executive of Datalogix was spider-crawling across a conference room floor. All around him, account managers and data analysts were thrusting 20-pound medicine balls overhead, while their Spandex-clad co-workers sprinted up and down the lobby’s carpeted staircase.

headline: Sweating It for the Company
abstract: Trainers at CrossFit Sanitas Boulder demonstrate how to perform various exercises. The heavy-duty fitness regimen is increasingly being offered at businesses to improve worker productivity and lower health insurance costs.
lead_paragraph: Trainers at CrossFit Sanitas Boulder demonstrate how to perform various exercises. The heavy-duty fitness regimen is increasingly being offered at businesses to improve worker productivity and lower health insurance costs.

headline: 9-Year-Old Breaks Record for Youngest U.S. Master
abstract: Awonder Liang broke the record set in 2010 by Samuel Sevian of California, who was 10 days older when he achieved the master rank.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old from Madison, Wis., became the youngest chess master in American history last weekend when his rating passed 2,200 after he won two games at the Midwest Open Team Chess Festival in Dayton, Ohio.

headline: New Ideological Battle in Pakistan: Traffic Circle’s Name
abstract: A plan to rename a traffic circle in Lahore, Pakistan, for a man who was not Muslim has become a showcase battle in an ideological war over nomenclature and identity.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — If ever a squabble over a street name could sum up a nation’s identity crisis, it is happening in Lahore, Pakistan’s cultural capital.

headline: Not Playing Her Best, Williams Is Still Good Enough vs. Sharapova
abstract: Serena Williams overcame a slow start to beat Maria Sharapova and win her sixth Sony Open title.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Serena Williams now stands alone as the woman with the most Sony Open championships after storming back to defeat Maria Sharapova, 4-6, 6-3, 6-0, in Saturday’s final. It was her sixth title in the event, one better than Steffi Graf. She solidified her world No. 1 ranking by winning the last 10 games after being broken in the fifth game of the second set.

headline: A Wary Easter Weekend for Christians in Syria
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The holiday is infused with uncertainty for Syria’s Christians, with many saying they fear not only the country’s general chaos, but also the rise of religious intolerance.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Torches flickered outside the church. Little girls wore their sparkly Easter best. Children bearing lanterns filed out through the heavy gilt doors, as worshipers carried an icon of Jesus and a cross covered with carnations.

headline: Santana to Have Shoulder Surgery Again, Almost Certainly Ending Mets Career
abstract: The left-hander will have a torn capsule in his shoulder repaired for the second time in 30 months, and the Mets will buy out his club option for 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Mets said Johan Santana would have surgery Tuesday on his left shoulder. Given the gravity of the injury — a tear of the capsule in the left-hander’s shoulder — there is no chance he will pitch this season.

headline: Shot Becomes a Youthful Vision Realized
abstract: The sophomore point guard became a part of Wolverines lore with his 30-foot 3-pointer that forced overtime against Kansas.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — His teammates have talked about framing a picture of the shot as a keepsake. For Michigan fans, it has already ascended into Wolverines lore, a thunderbolt fired from between the 3-point line and midcourt, one Trey Burke had always visualized growing up in Columbus, Ohio.

headline: College Rivalry, or Differences Over Policy?
abstract: Could it be that Rick Perry, an Aggie, is riled up over the University of Texas System because of a college rivalry?
lead_paragraph: Is this about Bill Powers or U.T.’s tower?

keywords: ['Easter and Holy Week', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Easter weekend is usually the year’s most festive for Syrian Christians, but this year, it is infused with grave uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Easter weekend is usually the year’s most festive for Syrian Christians, but this year, it is infused with grave uncertainty.

headline: A Texas Senate Bill Would Revise the State’s End-of-Life Procedure
abstract: Lawmakers are grappling over changes to state law that allows physicians to discontinue treatment they deem medically futile.
lead_paragraph: Texas lawmakers have grappled year after year over whether families or medical professionals should decide when to end a terminally ill patient’s life-sustaining care. This year, they seem closer to a compromise.

headline: Mets Make Final Preparations
abstract: Manager Terry Collins used a lineup in Saturday’s spring training finale that will most likely be the one the team uses in Monday’s regular-season opener.
lead_paragraph: Manager Terry Collins was in a jovial mood before the Mets played their spring training finale against the Baltimore Orioles. His roster was nearly set and despite a spate of injuries, two of his stars, David Wright and Daniel Murphy, appeared to be on the mend.

headline: Your State’s Gun Control Just Got Stricter? Come on Down!
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Firearms', 'Relocation of Business', 'States (US)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: As debates over gun control intensify nationwide, Gov. Rick Perry hopes to attract firearms and accessories manufacturers from other states to Texas.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Perry speaks wistfully — almost lovingly — about a rifle he recently fired while he was at a range in Leander owned by the manufacturer LaRue Tactical. “I’m incredibly passionate about a well-made piece of equipment,” Mr. Perry said in a phone interview last week, “whether it’s an automobile or a weapon.”

headline: Klan Protests in Memphis Over Renaming of Three Parks
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Names, Geographical', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: No violence was reported, and there were no arrests at the rally, which featured about 75 members.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — The Ku Klux Klan rallied in Memphis on Saturday to protest the City Council’s decision last month to rename three city parks that honored Confederate troops.

headline: Using More Than Skill, a Gator Grows Up
abstract: Florida’s Mike Rosario, a former high-scoring Rutgers player, once butted heads with Coach Billy Donovan. But now Rosario has become a leader under Donovan’s discipline.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The tattoos are the essence of Florida guard Mike Rosario, his testimonials. They cover his body, and he is not even sure how many there are — more than 60, he guesses. Rosario is the canvas for his story.

headline: ‘Cowboy Stuntman’ Was an Olympic Medalist, Too
keywords: ['Stunts and Stuntmen', 'Movies', 'Track and Field', 'Olympic Games', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The Texas-born stuntman Dean Smith has retired to Stephens County, but his new book, “Cowboy Stuntman: From Olympic Gold to the Silver Screen,” may bring him out of hiding.
lead_paragraph: The wood-paneled walls and shelves of Dean Smith’s modest home, about 20 miles south of Graham in rural Stephens County, are cluttered with photographs and memorabilia from a lifetime and then some. A visitor might think he had stumbled into the living room of a real-life Forrest Gump.

headline: A Game Forever Links Krzyzewski and Pitino
abstract: Duke’s Mike Krzyzewski and Louisville’s Rick Pitino will meet in the Midwest Region final, but it is the 1992 East Region title game for which they will be most remembered together.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — For Duke, the living history lessons convene all over the place.

headline: As OSHA Emphasizes Safety, Long-Term Health Risks Fester
keywords: ['n-Propyl Bromide (nPB)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foam', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the agency that many Americans love to hate and industry calls overzealous, has largely ignored the slow, silent killers that claim the most lives.
lead_paragraph: TAYLORSVILLE, N.C. — Sheri Farley walks with a limp. The only job she could hold would be one where she does not have to stand or sit longer than 20 minutes, otherwise pain screams down her spine and up her legs.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Jim Rutenberg on the rampant speculation about the former secretary of state’s presidential ambitions.

headline: A Clinton in ‘Transition’ Keeps Opponents and Donors Frozen
abstract: The early maneuvering for the 2016 presidential race on the Democratic side has been stalled by questions about Hillary Clinton’s intentions.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton left the State Department nearly two months ago, but she still needs a staff to keep up with the considerable business of being Hillary Clinton. A half-dozen people now work for the former secretary of state and Democratic presidential candidate in a tiny corporate space on Connecticut Avenue in Washington, in what is called her “transition office.”

headline: Fab Freshmen at Michigan, 2013 Version
abstract: Nobody is comparing them to Kentucky’s one-and-done national champion freshman class of last season, but three Wolverine newcomers are on a big roll.

headline: Wichita State Upsets Ohio State to Emerge From Topsy-Turvy West
abstract: Wichita State, seeded ninth, held off Ohio State’s second-half rally to advance to the Final Four. The No. 2 Buckeyes came within 3 points in the final minutes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gregg Marshall sat atop a stage, squinted at the bright lights that reflected off his glasses and tried to make sense of all that had occurred the past two weeks. He needed a few more hours, both to process and to explain.

abstract: Syracuse’s thumping of Marquette could be viewed as a time capsule moment for a disappearing genre: an old-fashioned Big East basketball game with Coach Jim Boeheim leading the way.

headline: Mother and Baby Critically Injured in Crash at Brooklyn Bus Stop
abstract: At least eight other people were also hurt when a car swerved to avoid another vehicle and drove through a bus pavilion near Utica and Church Avenues on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: At least 10 people were injured, including a mother and her baby, when a car ran up on a sidewalk and rammed through a bus stop in Brooklyn on Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Bob Turley, Pitcher With a Blazing Fastball, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Turley was a Cy Young-winning, right-handed pitcher who helped lift the Yankees to a come-from-behind victory over the Milwaukee Braves in the 1958 World Series.
lead_paragraph: Bob Turley, a Cy Young Award-winning right-handed pitcher whose blazing fastball bored in on baffled hitters like a dissolving aspirin and lifted the Yankees to a come-from-behind victory over the Milwaukee Braves in the 1958 World Series, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 82.

headline: Oil Pipeline Ruptures in Arkansas
abstract: An Exxon Mobil crude oil pipeline ruptured near Mayflower, Ark., spilling as many as 10,000 barrels of oil, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Emergency crews worked Saturday to contain several thousand gallons of crude oil that spilled from a ruptured Exxon Mobil pipeline in central Arkansas.

lead_paragraph: The Knicks could be the team with the longest winning streak in the league when they arrive in Miami to play the Heat on Tuesday. First, though, they will need to beat the Boston Celtics on Sunday.

Brandon II, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Green Pastures Victorian Estate, an event space in Austin, Tex.

headline: Nets’ Promising Western Swing Ends With a Thud
abstract: Randy Foye’s eight 3-pointers tied a Jazz record and helped Utah beat the Nets, who lost the final two games of their 13-day trip.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Randy Foye made five 3-pointers in the third quarter Saturday as the Utah Jazz went on a 22-11 run to take control of a close game and defeat the Nets, 116-107, at Energy Solutions Arena.

headline: With Mets and Yankees, It May Be Pick Your Poison
abstract: The Yankees and the Mets have finished below .500 in the same season six times in 51 years. Could this be the start of No. 7?
lead_paragraph: So here we are, at the start of the 2013 season, wondering whether it is possible that both the Yankees and Mets will finish below .500 this year.

headline: In Bitter Loss for Buckeyes, Something Was Missing: Them
abstract: Ohio State’s poor shooting in the first half dug a hole they couldn’t climb out of against Wichita State.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Aaron Craft caught the ball on the right wing, with Ohio State behind by 6 and less than a minute remaining, the crowd was tense, the game’s outcome was uncertain, and the first half seemed so far away.

headline: Slain Texas Lawman Had Pledged to Hunt Down ‘Scum’
abstract: After the assassination of his deputy, Mike McLelland, the district attorney in Kaufman County, responded with a flash of angered bravado. He and his wife were found dead on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: KAUFMAN, Tex. — After the daylight assassination of his deputy two months ago, Mike McLelland, the district attorney in largely rural Kaufman County, responded with a flash of angry bravado, denigrating the perpetrators as “scum” and vowing to hunt them down.

abstract: Easter weekend in Asia was marked with many baptisms expected in China and the Philippines seeing a continuation of a nearly six-decade-old tradition of real crucifixions.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — If past years are anything to go by, thousands of Chinese were to be baptized Catholic on Easter Sunday, in a reflection of an increasingly intense search for spirituality in an officially atheist nation.

headline: Hillary and the 2016 Presidential Election. Yes, 2016.
abstract: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, speaks with Jim Rutenberg, a Times political correspondent, on the rampant speculation over Hillary Clinton’s political ambitions — and the evidence that suggests “she is.”
lead_paragraph: Rendezvous’s editor, Marcus Mabry, speaks with Jim Rutenberg, a Times political correspondent, on the rampant speculation over Hillary Clinton’s political ambitions — and the evidence that suggests “she is.”

headline: The ECB and the Austerity Trap
abstract: In search of the origins of obtuseness.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis tries to show some sympathy for the devil: he tries to get into the mindset of European officials who defend austerity. And he gets at an important point in the process, although he may let the austerians off too lightly.

headline: A Word of Caution From Rubio on Immigration
abstract: As several of the senators taking part in a bipartisan effort to overhaul to the nation’s immigration laws appeared on the Sunday talk shows to sound an optimistic note, Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican member of the group, sounded a strongly worded note of caution.
lead_paragraph: Read an updated version of this post.12:45 p.m. | Updated As several of the senators taking part in a bipartisan effort to overhaul to the nation’s immigration laws appeared on the Sunday talk shows to sound an optimistic note, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and a member of the group, offered a strongly worded note of caution. In a statement released by his office  on Sunday, the headline — in all capital letters — read: “No Final Agreement on Immigration Legislation Yet.”

headline: Indebtedness Dwarfs the Economy
abstract: Chart shows the total credit market of the United States as a percent of G.D.P.
lead_paragraph: Chart shows the total credit market of the United States as a percent of G.D.P.

headline: A Fighter for Tenants Relaces Her Gloves
abstract: Doris Diether, an 86-year-old civic activist who lobbied for years on behalf of tenants against landlords, renovators and developers all over the city, is at it again.
lead_paragraph: It was 1959, and a painter and actress from Greenwich Village posted an “open letter to the people of New York” around Manhattan, warning that a plan by the formidable Robert Moses, then the city parks commissioner, jeopardized Shakespeare in the Park. Moses eventually dropped the plan. At the top of the letter, which Doris Diether still keeps, appear the handwritten words “start of my civic career.”

headline: Fresh Thoughts from Authors of a Paper on 11,300 Years of Global Temperature Changes
abstract: The authors of an important new study comparing recent warming with the last 11,300 years answer questions.
lead_paragraph: April 1, 12:17 a.m. | Update below |There’s been vigorous discussion here and elsewhere (e.g., Climate Audit and Skeptical Science) of the methods and findings in “A Reconstruction of Regional and Global Temperature for the Past 11,300 Years,” a recent Science paper by Shaun A. Marcott, Jeremy D. Shakun, Peter U. Clark and Alan C. Mix.

headline: The Child, the Tablet and the Developing Mind
abstract: Researchers still do not know what the future might hold for a generation raised with smartphones and tablets.
lead_paragraph: I recently watched my sister perform an act of magic.

headline: What's on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS (2009) Bill Hader, Anna Faris and Andy Samberg, among others, lend their voices to this animated comedy about an eccentric inventor, above, who creates a machine that can transform water into food. But the machine malfunctions and is accidentally launched into the atmosphere, where it begins to affect the weather, turning rain into cheeseburgers and a tornado into a swirling mass of spaghetti and meatballs. “Parents will enjoy tracking the endless stream of movie and television sendups,” Daniel M. Gold wrote in The New York Times, adding, “If the filmmakers opt to make only light statements about junk food, obesity and solid waste, they at least leave the audience sated on a single serving of inspired lunacy.”

headline: ‘G.I. Joe: Retaliation’ Has a Strong Start
abstract: The box-office performance validated an unusual decision by Paramount Pictures to delay the film’s release so that it could rework parts of the plot.
lead_paragraph: “G.I. Joe: Retaliation” was a burly No. 1 at North American theaters over the Easter weekend, validating an unusual decision by Paramount Pictures to delay its release so that it could rework parts of the plot. “Retaliation,” which cost at least $130 million to make, took in about $41.2 million over the weekend, for a total since opening on Thursday of $51.7 million. Overseas, the movie — originally planned for release last summer — generated an additional $80.3 million in ticket sales.

headline: Maestro’s Steady Hand Helps Resurrect Rome Opera
abstract: Riccardo Muti  has led to full houses, a much-improved orchestra and the first invitation for the Rome Opera to perform at the prestigious Salzburg Festival in Austria.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The work was by Verdi. Three fine young singers held the Rome Opera’s stage. But the spotlight, one night last month, was unmistakably on the maestro in the pit, Riccardo Muti.

headline: Cranky Old Men
abstract: David Stockman joins their ranks.
lead_paragraph: Shorter David Stockman:

headline: From a Tricycle to Many Vehicles
abstract: Joseph Keckler’s new work, “I Am an Opera,” mixes song, text and video.
lead_paragraph: TALL AND STRIKING (imagine a more debonair, calmly coifed Edward Scissorhands) Joseph Keckler stood in the middle of a stage, rehearsing his new work, “I am an Opera.” “Then there’s a Minotaur,” he explained to an observer. “He turns out to be a delightful companion.”

headline: As Banks in Cyprus Falter, Other Tax Havens Step In
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Tax Shelters', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Cyprus is hardly the only safe harbor for the tax-averse. Switzerland, Luxembourg, Malta and the Caymans are reminding those shaken by events in Cyprus that they remain open for business.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — Bloodied by a harsh bailout deal that drives a stake through the heart of this Mediterranean country’s oversize financial industry, Cyprus now faces a further blow to its role as an offshore tax haven: the vultures from competing territories are circling.

headline: Hagel Warns of Big Squeeze at the Pentagon
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: As President Obama negotiates a spending and revenue deal, the defense secretary and Pentagon officials warned that there could be larger budget reductions than expected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ending his first month as defense secretary, Chuck Hagel invited six young enlisted personnel for lunch in his private Pentagon office. Without military or civilian aides, Mr. Hagel himself took extensive notes as the sergeants and petty officers poured out their concerns about pay, benefits, training and sexual assault — issues that would decide whether they make the military a way of life or just a way station in life.

headline: Israel Taps an Offshore Natural Gas Field
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Natural gas started flowing from the Tamar reservoir, which is expected to supply 50 to 80 percent of Israel’s natural gas needs over the next 10 years.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel moved closer to its goal of energy independence on Sunday as natural gas from a large offshore field began flowing into the country, a harbinger of important change that will benefit the country strategically and economically, officials said.

headline: TV Taps the Foreign Idea Factory
abstract: American TV has a long tradition of imitating foreign shows, and the fall season may include several new forms of flattery, with “Friends and Family,” “Pulling,” “Rake,” “Second Sight” and “Spy.”
lead_paragraph: Ideas may not fall out of trees, but they do come in the mail from Sydney and Tel Aviv. Of the 100 or so pilot episodes being shot as candidates for the broadcast television networks’ fall lineups, at least a dozen are based on shows from Argentina, Australia, Britain or Israel.

headline: Inventive New Works Swoop In
abstract: The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company presented two premieres in celebration of its 30th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: All the works in the 30th anniversary season of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company at the Joyce Theater are set to classics of chamber music, played live. But where the first program is dominated by celebrated dances freighted with history, the second consists of two premieres created for and by the current company. In the older works the dancers look dutiful; in the new they look wonderfully like themselves.

headline: As Market Heats Up, Trading Slips Into Shadows
abstract: More stock trades, about 40 percent on some days, are being conducted outside public exchanges.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is embracing its dark side.

headline: Baby Giraffe Draws Attention to Sanctuary
abstract: Photos of a baby Rothschild giraffe at the LEO Zoological Conservation Center in Connecticut are lighting up television and computer screens around the world.
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, Conn. — In February, the LEO Zoological Conservation Center proclaimed to the world the birth of a male eastern mountain bongo, a large African antelope. That did not get much notice.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Company Reports', 'Unemployment', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The highlight of the week’s data releases will come on Friday, with the United States employment report for March.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the I.S.M. manufacturing index for March and construction spending for February (Monday); factory orders for February (Tuesday); A.D.P. employment and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing index for March (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for March and the trade deficit and consumer credit for February (Friday).

abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'States (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: PBS to Show Block of ‘Martha’ Programs
abstract: Reruns of “Martha Bakes” will follow new episodes of “Martha Stewart’s Cooking School.”
lead_paragraph: Fans of Martha Stewart who since last fall have been tuning into her “Cooking School” program on PBS for advice on how to braise, roast and sauté are about to get some sweeter wisdom on how to handle the often overlooked stars of menus: baked goods and desserts.

headline: Dolan Says the Catholic Church Should Be More Welcoming to Gay People
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York said that the Roman Catholic Church could be more open to gay men and lesbians, but that it would not change its teachings.
lead_paragraph: On Easter Sunday, weeks after he helped elect a new pope for a church struggling with declining numbers and controversy over social issues, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan said that the Roman Catholic Church could be more welcoming of gay men and lesbians despite opposing same-sex marriage.

headline: Social Marketing Drives a New York Renaissance
abstract: Marketers are being drawn to digital realms like social media, in which agencies in New York — home to Silicon Alley as well as Madison Avenue — are increasingly proficient.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK, New York, a wonderful town, according to the song — or, if you prefer the unexpurgated lyric from the Broadway version, a hell of a town. Either way, that was the sentiment back in the day when mad men ruled Madison Avenue.

headline: Murray’s Sony Open Title Is a Matter of Perseverance, and a Few Inches
abstract: Andy Murray fended off a match point and defeated David Ferrer in an exhausting final that lasted 2 hours 45 minutes in Key Biscayne, Fla.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Andy Murray needed every bit of energy he could muster Sunday to capture his second Sony Open championship, defeating David Ferrer, 2-6, 6-4, 7-6 (1).

headline: Papers Worldwide Embrace Web Subscriptions
abstract: Online advertising, once seen as the great hope for the future, has begun leveling off, which is accelerating the push for new Internet business models.
lead_paragraph: SERRAVAL, France — Newspapers, once reluctant to try to charge readers for access to their Web sites, have begun doing so in droves.

headline: Boeheim Maintains a Passion as Intense as His Defense
abstract: After earning his fourth trip to the Final Four, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said he was in no hurry to retire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Michigan Barrels Into the Final Four After a 20-Year Absence
abstract: The Wolverines took apart the Gators with equal parts patience and raw power, advancing to the Final Four for the first time since 1993.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The scissors seemed awkward in their hands, and rightfully so. It had been 20 years since a Michigan basketball team had climbed a ladder this high, and as these Wolverines celebrated and carefully snipped away at the nets, they had proved worthy of creating a new legacy.

headline: Then Life Got in the Way
abstract: The summer camp friends in “The Interestings” by Meg Wolitzer find their later years not unfolding quite as they imagined.
lead_paragraph: The principals in Meg Wolitzer’s heavily detailed new novel, “The Interestings,” are only in their midteens when they decide to give themselves the label of the title, hoping the nickname will stick for life. This is a bravely embarrassing move for Ms. Wolitzer. Surely she knows that self-dramatizing, narcissistic teenagers aren’t necessarily interesting, let alone Interesting with a capital I.

headline: Echoes of Languages No Longer Heard
abstract: The enigmatic sounds of two nearly dead languages came to life in performances of two works by the trombonist Kevin James that mixed recorded voices, ambient sounds and electronica with a live score.
lead_paragraph: The “Vanishing Languages” project by Kevin James, a New York-based trombonist and composer, is a rare hybrid of conservation effort and memorial, new music and ancient languages. Prodded by Unesco statistics that predict that by the end of the century half of the world’s 6,000 languages will be extinct, Mr. James spent months in the field tracking down and recording the last remaining speakers of four critically endangered tongues: Hokkaido Ainu, an aboriginal language from northern Japan, the American Indian Quileute from western Washington, and Dalabon and Jawoyn, aboriginal languages from Arnhem Land in Australia.

headline: Raging Against the Fates, With Intermittent Elegies
abstract: The Australian singer Nick Cave, backed by an ensemble including Sharon Van Etten at the Beacon Theater, offered a set spanning his 30-year career.
lead_paragraph: Visions of murder, catastrophe, transfiguration and desperate love issued from the Beacon Theater stage on Friday night, set to dirges, stomps and inexorable crescendos. Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds — along with a string ensemble, the backup singers Sharon Van Etten (who opened the concert) and Shilpa Ray, and a youth choir, the Harlem Voices — were midway through a sold-out three-night stand. Songs from their new album, “Push the Sky Away” (Bad Seed Ltd.), started and ended the set. In between they revisited material recorded over the last three decades.

headline: Discovery Expands Its Reach Overseas
abstract: With a proliferation of channels competing for a diminished number of total viewers, media companies have looked elsewhere for growth.
lead_paragraph: Alana Thompson, the 7-year-old beauty queen known as Honey Boo Boo, has had some mishaps in child pageants in the Deep South, where her reality show on Discovery Communications’ TLC channel is based. But the chubby and charming contestant and her overbearing parents are big in Brazil.

headline: Spring North American Championships
abstract: The winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York City.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — At the Spring North American Championships here last month the winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York City. They did well in the diagramed deal from the first session on the second and last day, when Wooldridge read the cards perfectly.

headline: Disco and Villains in 1983 Bollywood
abstract: “Himmatwala” is a remake of a Bollywood disco film from 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In its first scene, set at the Funkytown Disco in Bombay — year: 1983 — “Himmatwala” loads on the period markers, with quick nods to Michael Jackson, Madonna and, of course, the reign of disco in a song-and-dance number (called “Thank God It’s Friday,” no less) full of flashing lights and silver-clad hoofers.

headline: Archaeologists of Vinyl Rejoice in Return Home
abstract: The Moving Sidewalks reunited for their first gig in nearly 44 years on Saturday night at B. B. King Blues Club and Grill.
lead_paragraph: The Moving Sidewalks, in their first gig in nearly 44 years on Saturday night at B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, played some pretty nice gear for a band that never had a national hit. Tube amplifiers by Magnatone, the recently revived pre-’70s American brand, handsome in design, broad and deep in sound; custom-made Telecaster-like guitars with psychedelic blob patterns swirling on a small screen underneath the strings, as if iPads had been built into the instruments’ bodies.

headline: Nuzzling (or Is It Nudging?) Their Way Through a Duet
abstract: Ursula Eagly and Abby Block wore skin-tone outfits in Ms. Eagly’s duet “Self Made Man Man Made Land,” at the Chocolate Factory.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Ursula Eagly and her collaborator, Abby Block, struck crooked poses in the middle of a pristine white floor at the Chocolate Factory on Thursday. They might have been innocent girls pretending to be trees, except that the discomfort of the posing, combined with their dazed and wandering eyes, suggested something awry.

headline: Could the Killings Be Connected?
abstract: With the murder of a Texas prosecutor on Saturday, less than two months after one of his assistants was killed, investigators say they can’t rule out a connection to white supremacist groups, and another prominent murder. Here is a timeline of those events.
lead_paragraph: With the murder of a Texas prosecutor on Saturday, less than two months after one of his assistants was killed, investigators say they can’t rule out a connection to white supremacist groups, and another prominent murder. Here is a timeline of those events.

headline: Laughing at Rappers, Who Laugh Right Back
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: The Kid Mero and ItsTheReal satirize the hip-hop world, and real rappers are often in on the jokes.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost certainly too soon, and definitely futile, to be discussing what constitutes golden ages of any Internet pursuit, but in the area of hip-hop humor the peaks may have already been set.

headline: An Eyewear Company’s Simple Sell
abstract: The start-up Warby Parker is one of a number of new innovators that has decided to design, manufacture and sell its inexpensive products directly to its Web-savvy customers.
lead_paragraph: The start-up Warby Parker is one of a number of new innovators that has decided to design, manufacture and sell its inexpensive products directly to its Web-savvy customers.

headline: Anthony Can Learn From Pierce’s Career Arc
abstract: The Celtics’ Paul Pierce, 35, is considered one of the league’s stalwart and sage big-game veterans. His delayed rise might reflect the best-case career trajectory for the Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony.
lead_paragraph: Shaquille O’Neal is generally credited as the first to describe Paul Pierce as the truth, which eventually stuck as an uppercase nickname. But there were years before that when Pierce, upon consideration for membership in the fraternity of authentic N.B.A. elites, was dismissed as anything but.

headline: Islamist Fighters Slip Back Into Timbuktu and Are Repelled by French and Malians
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Tuareg (Ethnic Group)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: The attackers appeared to number perhaps 10 or 15, said the French military spokesman, Col. Thierry Burkhard. “A half-dozen” were confirmed killed, he said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A small band of radical Islamist fighters battled French and Malian soldiers for hours in a firefight in Timbuktu on Sunday after infiltrating the Malian city overnight, Malian officials and witnesses said.

headline: Indies Grab the Controls at a Game Conference
abstract: Led by Journey, the game of the year, independent studios outgunned majors for attention at the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Game Developers Conference is the kind of place where controllers for the PlayStation 4, Sony’s forthcoming console, sit under glass like the Hope Diamond, and where designers and other industry professionals line up for hours to try the Oculus Rift virtual-reality headset, which has begun shipping as prototypes to those who paid $300 for a development kit.

headline: Game Developers Conference
abstract: Scenes from the gathering in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the gathering in San Francisco.

headline: E-Commerce Companies Bypass the Middlemen
abstract: E-commerce companies that make everything from bedding to eyeglasses are trying to build premium brands at discount prices by cutting out middlemen and going directly to manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: When the founders of a start-up that sells eyeglasses online, Warby Parker, began investigating why designer glasses cost several hundred dollars, they discovered that everyone in the process was taking a cut: designers, manufacturers, brands, wholesalers and retailers.

headline: Smoky Voice Covers the Ground From Gloomy to Morbid
abstract: The baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky performed works by Rachmaninoff and Sviridov at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: If an enormous sculpture is placed in a small room, or a miniature is marooned on a vast museum wall, the art can lose its impact. Particular genres of music also need to be performed in an appropriate space to be best enjoyed.

headline: Art Collector Buried After Three-Week Delay
abstract: Merton D. Simpson, the painter and influential collector of African art, was buried on Saturday in his hometown, Charleston, S.C., three weeks after his death at 84.
lead_paragraph: Merton D. Simpson, the painter and influential collector of African art, was buried on Saturday in his hometown, Charleston, S.C., three weeks after his death at 84. The delay stemmed from bitter infighting among his family, friends and a court-appointed guardian.

headline: Calculating the Impact of Cyprus’s Bailout
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The rescue of Los Angeles-based IndyMac Bancorp may provide lessons for what the losses required by the Bank of Cyprus bailout will mean.
lead_paragraph: WHAT are the implications of the huge losses — 60 percent — that the Cypriot bailout is imposing on the biggest depositors of that country’s two largest banks?

headline: Fool
abstract: Gary J. Whitehead defines the day for us.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — No, I’m not calling you all FOOLs. And lest you think that Gary J. Whitehead is trying to insult us, please note today’s date. Yes, it’s April FOOL’s Day, and today’s puzzle is all about FOOLs and being FOOLed.

headline: Rates of A.D.H.D. Diagnosis in Children
abstract: Nearly one in five high school-aged boys has been given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one in five high school-aged boys has been given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

abstract: Oregon State Hospital features a museum that pays tribute to the movie “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” and explores mental health treatments of the past.

keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Television', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Bassem Youssef, a popular television host, is accused of insulting President Mohamed Morsi and denigrating Islam.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian television satirist who was summoned by prosecutors on charges that he had insulted President Mohamed Morsi was ordered to post bail on Sunday, indicating that the authorities were continuing to pursue their investigation of the popular host.

keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation']

headline: Scrub Away Your Worries
abstract: A reader writes that cleaning is a good way to distract oneself.

headline: More Stockman
abstract: Deficits are a monopartisan issue.
lead_paragraph: Not much more, I promise. As Mark Thoma points out, the verdict among everyone who knows anything is that Stockman’s piece, mysteriously given star treatment, was pathetic and embarrassing. It’s full of big numbers that are scary because they’re big numbers — we’ve run a current account deficit of $8 trillion. So? We have a $16 trillion a year economy; America’s net international investment position is a debt of about 30 percent of GDP, which isn’t that big; our balance of investment income is still positive. But it’s EIGHT TRILLION DOLLARS!

headline: Data Storage Player Prepares to Compete Overseas
abstract: Box, a business data storage and management company, is expanding as part of plans for an expected initial public offering in 2014.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Box, an online business data storage and management company, plans to expand its sales force and team of developers by opening offices in Germany and France in coming months, building on its first overseas foray last summer in Britain.

headline: N.Y.U. and the Village
abstract: A longtime resident of Greenwich Village writes that the neighborhood will be irreparably harmed by New York University’s expansion plan.

headline: Pope Calls for ‘Peace in All the World’ in First Easter Message
keywords: ['Easter and Holy Week', 'Palestinians', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Before an estimated 250,000 people jammed into St. Peter’s Square, Pope Francis also deplored a world “divided by greed looking for easy gain.”
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In his first Easter Sunday message, Pope Francis passionately called for “peace in all the world,” urging Israelis and Palestinians to “resume negotiations to end a conflict that has lasted all too long,” calling for an end to the civil war in Syria, and promoting a “renewed spirit of reconciliation” on the Korean Peninsula, where tensions have been rising.

headline: The Tar Sands Disaster
abstract: President Obama will be doing Canada a favor if he blocks the Keystone XL pipeline once and for all.
lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Ontario

headline: New Disney Characters Make It Big in TV’s Preschool Playground
abstract: After a year, Disney Junior, a channel aimed at preschoolers, already has the top three preschool cable programs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sorry, Dora. You’ve been dethroned.

headline: 2 Men in China Die of Lesser-Known Strain of Bird Flu
abstract: The authorities said the two Shanghai men, 27 and 87 years old, fell ill after contracting the H7N9 strain in February and died in March.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Two men have died here after contracting a strain of avian flu that had not been previously found in humans, Xinhua, China’s official news agency, reported Sunday.

headline: From Asylum to Museum
abstract: The hospital once known as the Oregon State Insane Asylum is one of only a few institutions around the world that house museums inside of still-functioning treatment facilitys.
lead_paragraph: The hospital once known as the Oregon State Insane Asylum is one of only a few institutions around the world that house museums inside of still-functioning treatment facilitys.

headline: Disney Junior Finds Ratings Success
abstract: As Disney Junior’s ratings catch up to Nick Jr.’s, Brooks Barnes of The New York Times sits down with the Disney executive Nancy Kanter to discuss the success of Disney’s children’s programming.
lead_paragraph: As Disney Junior’s ratings catch up to Nick Jr.’s, Brooks Barnes of The New York Times sits down with the Disney executive Nancy Kanter to discuss the success of Disney’s children’s programming.

headline: Rubio Says Immigration Bill Still Has a Way to Go
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As other senators working on a bipartisan overhaul expressed optimism, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, issued a strongly worded message of caution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As several of the eight senators taking part in a bipartisan effort to overhaul to the nation’s immigration laws appeared on television Sunday to voice optimism about the negotiations, Senator Marco Rubio, a member of the group, issued a strongly worded message of caution.

headline: Tracking Cicadas, With Helpers
abstract: “Radiolab” has scheduled Cicada Tracker Maker events to help people build sensors that will detect the temperatures that herald the emergence of cicadas.
lead_paragraph: The 17-year Magicicada Brood II cicadas are coming, and WNYC and its nationally distributed “Radiolab” program will be there to welcome them — after a mad sprint to persuade hundreds of listeners in the next two weeks to build temperature sensors and stick them in the ground, from Virginia to Connecticut.
